The Blade Breaker's Daughters

by IndiSmile, RK3996

Summary

Jeralt the Blade Breaker was a legendary hero, one who had faced countless challenges in his life, and yet, none of that prepared him for fatherhood.

Even more so when he ends up adopting a second kid.

An Accidental Hit

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

For many people, the mercenary lifestyle seemed like a fantasy. Being able to travel to and fro, paid riches from nobles, and perhaps even save a lover to be. In reality, it was not like that. Not at all.

 

Sure you would be traveling, but oftentimes it would mean not having a place to truly call home. Nobles may hire you, but they're just as likely to cut you loose if it'd profit them, and the chances of saving someone who'd fall for you wasn't exactly an everyday occurrence. 

 

Worst of all, sometimes you don't have enough food to go around. 

 

Hence why young Byleth Eisner was currently hunting, having volunteered to get some food as rations were running low. Normally her father wouldn't let her get so far away from the camp without him, but even he had to admit that his silent daughter would be able to track a prey without alerting it. 

 

With soft, even breaths, the young mercenary pulled her bowstring taut, keeping her eyes on the deer before her. The wild animal was completely unaware of who was stalking it as it grazed in the fields. As soon as it lifted its head, an arrow would fly through its neck– 

 

A loud rustling from the other side of the Deer caught its attention, making it run as Byleth let the arrow loose in hopes of hitting it–

 

"GAH!"

 

…That did not sound like a deer. 

 

Staying quiet, Byleth moved her way to the bush where the scream came from, and parted it to be greeted with the sight of a girl with purple hair. One who was currently lying on the ground and bleeding from the arrow pierced into her shoulder, having seemingly gone unconscious from the pain. 

 

Hm.

 

Shouldering her bow, Byleth reached down to pick up the girl, and trudge her way back to the camp. After all, her father told her if there was a problem, best bring it to him. 

 

Granted, he probably never expected a problem to be a bleeding unconscious girl that his own daughter had shot. 

 

Thankfully all his years as a mercenary…well, they didn't exactly prepare him for this moment, but they were enough to keep him cool as he took the young girl to get her patched up. And by that, he meant taking her to the group's medic, who saw to her without any problems, aside from some exasperation at being called up for something “so easy”. 

 

Even so, he made sure to stay nearby, keeping an eye on the girl as she rested in the infirmary tent after being patched up, especially as he noted some things about her. Age wise, she seemed about the same age as Byleth, and while it seemed she probably hadn't eaten recently, he could see the calluses on her hands telling him she was at least used to wielding a weapon. Add in the fact that she also had a knife meant that she was a hunter, or even a mercenary. 

 

Jeralt couldn't help but frown at the thought. Sure, Byleth might technically be one as well, but that was because he had trained her to protect herself, and he couldn't just leave her anywhere. This girl on the other hand…he didn't know what her circumstances were, but he was never fond of young fighters having to risk their lives. 

 

“What in the world has your life been like…” he muttered under his breath, watching the strange girl.

 

He considered leaving. 

 

At the end of the day, the girl wasn’t his. He already had one kid to take care of and whoever this kid was, she wasn’t any of his business. But it was his daughter who put an arrow through her shoulder. So he stayed until she stirred awake.

 

Her eyes fluttered open slowly, blearily, before shooting open when she seemed to realize she was somewhere unfamiliar.

 

“Easy there,” Jeralt soothed, raising a hand to her. Not touching, just close by…He probably shouldn’t be treating a scared kid like a startled horse, but in the absence of experience, he fell back on what was familiar. “How are you feeling?”

 

“...” The girl had purple eyes, similar in shade to her bright hair. It was a surprise Byleth hadn’t managed to spot her, even in the forest. Maybe he should get her eyes checked? “...where am I and who are you?”

 

That was more direct than he expected. There was suspicion in the girl’s gaze, but it looked like she was sizing him up. It occurred to him that he should’ve taken the knife from her belt.

 

“You’re in my camp. I’m Jeralt, the leader of Jeralt’s Mercenaries.” Not for the first time, he considered whether he should rename his band into something less self-referential, before discarding the thought. “What’s your name?”

 

“You’re a mercenary?” Weirdly, the girl brightened up. She suddenly sat up with a smile on her face, one that barely faltered from the leftover sting of her healed wound, even if he did hear her hiss through her teeth. “My name is Shez, sir! I’m best with using a sword, but I am capable of using any weapon and I can read and write! I can also cook and clean if you need it, and I am very cheap to hire! I only need three meals a day and somewhere to sleep, and I promise I will work for you very faithfully!”

 

“...What?”

 

Her smile almost faltered. “I-I can work for two meals a day! No lower!”

 

“That…kid, what are you talking about?”

 

She stared at him, then tried another smile. “You said you’re a mercenary, so I want to work for you! I’ve done it before, I know how it works!”

 

“You’ve done it before?”

 

“Yeah! Three times! I’m experienced!”

 

Jeralt didn’t know what to do with that information. “Alright, slow down. How old are you? Ten?”

 

The girl pouted. “I’m not ten, I’m…twelve? Twelve, probably…”

 

“You don’t know how old you are?” He tried not to sigh. “How does a kid work for three mercenary companies before she’s even fifteen?”

 

“Oh, easy. My parents died, then my mom died, and the village says I can’t have the house, so I gotta get money and I met a guy named Dieter and he said I could help his group because I can read and he can’t and then he got hanged so I joined the people that hanged him for crimes and then they all got eaten by a giant wolf so I wandered for a while–”

 

Jeralt let the girl ramble. It was easier than asking more questions. He was so used to his own quiet, unemotive daughter that he had no idea how to interact with more…energetic kids.

 

As if summoned by his thoughts, Byleth chose then to come into the tent.

 

She stared at the new girl, Shez, for a second, before directing her attention back to him. “Papa.”

 

“Hey kid,” he greeted, letting his daughter sit beside him.

 

“Who’s that?”

 

“That…” It took him a second to realize Shez was the one that asked. “...This is Byleth, my daughter. She’s the one that found you.”

 

He decided to be diplomatic and avoid mentioning just how Byleth found her.

 

“I shot you with an arrow.” Byleth, however, didn’t understand his plan at all.

 

“THAT WAS YOU!?” Kids could be loud, apparently. Had it really been that long since he interacted with a non-quiet child?

 

“Yeah. You were behind the deer.”

 

"I was hunting that deer!" 

 

"Oh…You should be quieter when hunting." 

 

"I was being quiet!" Jeralt quickly realized he should step in. 

 

"Look, Shez, if you need a place to stay for a bit, I don't mind letting you stick around till we get to town." Before she could argue, he raised a hand. "For now, why don't we get you something to eat?" 

 

Based on the loud growl her stomach let out, she agreed with the idea. 

 

"Th-Thank you Sir!" Well, she was polite at least. Even if she kept glaring at Byleth for an understandable reason. Hm, he just remembered that someone still needed to go hunting later since Byleth hadn't actually brought any food back… 

 

And, well, while the food at the camp wasn't bad by any means, the young kid acted like it was cooked by a royal chef with how eagerly she ate what he brought her.

 

"S-So, does this mean I'm hired?" Shez asked when she had finished eating, to which Jeralt sighed in response. 

 

"Is she joining?" Byleth asked, glancing up to her father. 

 

"Look, I'm not about to hire a child mercenary, but if you want to make yourself useful, I can give you some chores." 

 

"Th-Thank you sir!" 

 

"Don't mention it, but try to get some rest first okay? I'd hate for your injury to get worse." Especially since it was his kid who had caused it. 

 

"Sir, yes, Sir!" Jeralt wasn't sure if he should be glad she knew how to 'properly' respond, but he left it at that as he got up to leave with Byleth. 

 

"...how long is she staying?" his daughter asked after they had left the tent. 

 

"Just for a few days, if we're lucky enough we might find someone to take her in. As is, I'd rather not let someone who already joined three mercenary gangs at such a young age wander on her own." 

 

"Is it bad that I'm also a mercenary?" 

 

"Well, no. I mean, you're not really a mercenary, I'm just training you to defend yourself, is all." 

 

"Are you going to train her then?" 

 

"No. She's injured for one, and I don't plan on keeping her around for long." 

 

"But shouldn't she know how to defend herself?" 

 

Jeralt couldn't help but let out an exasperated sigh. He couldn't believe it. Here he was, Jeralt the Blade Breaker, the strongest mercenary in Fódlan, and he couldn't even win an argument with his kid. The fact that Byleth was even arguing was throwing him off. Kid usually just went with whatever he did.

 

"Fine, I'll teach her some things, but don't expect her to stick around." 

 

If only Jeralt knew how wrong he would be. 

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Man, it's been quite some time since we've wrote fanfiction, but well, three hopes really reignited our love for this series so I hope y'all enjoyed this!

Red: It really has. Funny to think how long it's been since we've posted on here, but, well, life and stuff. Anyways, thanks for reading the start of this nonsense!

The New Kid in Camp

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

"Hey…has anyone else noticed that the Captain has a kid around?" a mercenary asked one day after they had set up camp, whispering to one of his fellow sellswords while they relaxed after the day's march. 

 

"What? Of course he has a kid around, that’s his daughter. Are you that oblivious?" 

 

"I know about Byleth! I meant the other girl, the one with the purple hair. You know, the one he keeps making do chores?"

 

“...” The second mercenary tilted her head in thought. “...” It was a long thought. “...Oh yeah!”

 

“Seriously?”

 

“Yeah, that is weird. Has he always had two kids?”

 

“No, of course–Wait, is she his kid?”

 

“Probably, right? Why would he have a random kid around the camp?”

 

“I don’t know, maybe she’s the new chore girl or something.”

 

“Why would the captain hire a chore girl? He has a daughter, he can make her do chores.”

 

“Right, that’s what I’m saying.”

 

The second mercenary paused. “...What were you saying again?”

 

“I…no, hold on, what was I…I had a point, what was it?” The first mercenary furrowed his brow and crossed his arms over his chest. “...Right! What’s with the new girl! That’s what I was saying!”

 

“What new girl?” a third mercenary asked while walking by, leading to a further confused conversation.

 

Still, Shez’s presence had received some notice from the mercenaries in Jeralt’s camp. Not much, given most of the sellswords had better things to do than wonder about a random child in their midst, but still some notice.

 

For a mercenary in Fodlan, having a family wasn’t particularly unusual. Many soldiers-for-hire worked to support family members back in their hometowns, after all. It was slightly unusual to have a child present in a mercenary camp, given the inherent danger of the lifestyle, but the mercs under Jeralt’s command had gotten used to Byleth. It helped that the captain’s daughter was a very quiet, unobtrusive child who never really interacted with anyone aside from her father unless prompted. 

 

Shez was not like that.

 

Shez seemed to go out of her way to interact with the mercs, asking them if they needed any help cleaning their gear, helping carry supplies to and fro, even staring quite intensely at any sparring matches going on. So it came to no surprise that word kept spreading around about the new kid. 

 

"Do you think she's his kid?" a mercenary asked while he watched the young girl cleaning clothes. 

 

"Maybe?" 

 

"Neither of them look like him though. And they also don't look like each other." 

 

"Maybe they have different moms?" another suggested. 

 

"Well, they most definitely do, but what does that matter?" 

 

"Just thinking, Captain used to be from the Knights of Seiros, yeah?" At his fellow mercs’ nods, the first one continued. "And he also used to live at Garreg Mach, where the central church is, right? Both of which he doesn't want to go near?" 

 

"Just get on with your point." 

 

"I'm getting there! What I'm trying to say is…maybe he was married to someone over in the Central Church, but then he had an affair." 

 

“What? The captain’s from the Central Church?” a fourth mercenary walking by with a box in his arms asked, prompting immediate shushing from his fellows.

 

“Not too loud! Captain Jeralt doesn’t like people talking about his past.”

 

“Probably because of the affair,” the first mercenary said.

 

“What! There was an affair??”

 

“We don’t know there was an affair,” the second merc contradicted, though the third looked thoughtful.

 

“He is really weird about church stuff. But would he have an affair? He doesn’t seem like the type.”

 

“You never know,” the first pointed out, “There’s some reason why he doesn’t talk about his time at the church unless he’s ten cups in.”

 

“...can priests even get married?” the fourth asked. The trio of chatty mercs stared at him for a moment, before turning to each other again in a unanimous decision to ignore him.

Not that it dissuaded him as he stood nearby, piping in occasionally as they continued. 

 

"So, let's say that the Captain did have an affair, why is the other kid here now?" 

 

"Maybe something happened with the mom? If she wasn't that rich, maybe she couldn't afford to keep her around." 

 

"Do nuns get paid alot?" 

 

"Still, even if she couldn't keep her kid, wouldn't it be safer to give her to an orphanage?" 

 

"Well you know how the captain is with the first kid, could be he didn't want to give her up." 

 

"Does he actually care though? Girl has only been here for a few days, and he's been making her do chores the entire time." 

 

"Maybe the mom is dead, and that's why he had to take her in." 

 

“I don’t know, I don’t see the captain treating a kid of his as a chore girl. You know how protective he is of little Byleth.”

 

“Byleth isn’t that little anymore. He’s been having her help out more.”

 

“Fishing doesn’t count as helping.”

 

“Hunting does though–”

 

“Fishing completely counts! Fish is great!”

 

“Agreed with the new guy, fish is good–”

 

“What are you idiots doing?”

 

The quartet paused in their discussion, then looked to a new addition to their gabbing gaggle. “Oh hey Healer. Hey, you know the new kid?”

 

The medic raised her eyebrow. “Do you mean Shez?”

 

“Yeah her, purple hair girl, the tiny one.”

 

“She’s actually pretty tall for her age.”

 

“Sure, sure, whatever. Do you know anything about her?”

 

“I know the captain brought her in with an arrow in her shoulder. Aside from that though, she’s in good health, if a little underfed,” the medic explained, not noticing the looks the first and second mercenaries gave each other, “What are you all even chatting about anyway?”

 

“Just if the new girl is the captain’s kid or not.”

 

“...Huh. I don’t think so. Are you taking bets?”

 

“We weren’t, but we could be.”

 

“Five gold on not.”

 

“Alright, I’ll make a note of that,” the third mercenary concluded, before turning back to his fellows. Who were back to whispering again.

 

“I guarantee it, the mother was killed and that’s why Jeralt took Shez in.”

 

“But why? Was it some kind of assassination?”

 

“That doesn’t make sense, you can’t assassinate commoners. Nobles get assassinated, commoners get murdered.”

 

“What if she was noble? Oh! Or what if it was Jeralt’s church wife! She could have tracked them down, used church assassins!”

 

“The church doesn’t have assassins…Does it?”

 

“We could ask the captain. Hey Captain!”

 

The three mercenaries went stiff, all looking at the fourth member of their cohort, who was waving over towards Jeralt. The captain of their band glanced up from the log book he was writing in and raised an eyebrow. “What?”

 

“Does the church have assass–Mfh!”

 

Jeralt’s eyebrow remained raised as he watched one of the newer mercs get tackled by two of his seniors. “...Does the church have what?”

 

“Um, captain, sir!” He glanced down as Shez stood at attention. The kid saluted. “The clothes are clean and now drying, sir! Um, hanging up to dry! Near the–It’s at the pole–”

 

“You don’t need to give me a full report every time, Shez. But, ah, thanks. Why don’t you go play with Byleth for a while?” Jeralt knew Byleth didn’t go out of her way to interact with other kids, but she should hang around someone her age during her freetime. At least, he was pretty sure she should. If nothing else she needed a break from training. 

 

"Of course, Captain, Sir!" Shez saluted again, before heading over to where Byleth was swinging a wooden sword. 

 

"...Hm, maybe he just found her and decided to keep her around so his kid would have a friend?" the second mercenary suggested while still keeping the fourth one pinned to the ground.

 

"Would that count as kidnapping?" the third one asked.

 

"...Captain wouldn't do that, right?" And before that specific thread could be continued, a loud yelp could be heard. Looking over at the sound, they spotted Shez on the ground, clutching her head with a wooden sword at her side, with Byleth standing over her. The latter of whom had seemingly hit her possible-sister on the head. 

 

"Hey, no sparring if no one is keeping an eye on you two!" Jeralt said, taking the sword from Byleth. 

 

"Right, guess that means I'm up," the healer said, pushing herself up to check on Shez.

 

"Hm…kinda seems like she's not a fan of the new kid," the first merc noted. 

 

"Well, she doesn't really seem to like anyone really." 

 

"True, but also, maybe she doesn't like her cause she's an affair kid. That kinda stuff can ruin a family." 

 

“Wait, but we’ve never seen Byleth’s mother around. Doesn’t that mean the family’s already ruined?”

 

“That’s a rough way to think of things. I was raised by my dad on his own and I turned out fine.”

 

“You’re choking out the new guy.”

 

“Oh, crap, didn’t realize.” The second merc got off of the less-than-conscious fourth.

 

 "...I'm not helping you carry him," the first mercenary said. 

 

"Shit, ah, guess I'll need to make it up to him…hey do any of you know his name?" 

 

"Man, I don't don't know your name, why would I know his?" 

 

"Wait, really?" 

 

"Why would I?" the third merc asked with a quirked eyebrow, "I'm an archer, so unless you're helping me support everyone else, I don't especially know anyone."

 

"Huh…guess that makes sense, I tend to be near the front," the first mercenary responded. 

 

"Same, though I'm part of the mounted squad, the most you'll get out of me is me paying enough attention to not run you over,” the second merc joked as he lifted up the unconscious new guy. 

 

"Gee, thanks pal." Huffing, the first merc looked back over at the captain and his kids, where the Captain was currently telling Byleth not to whack the new girl if she didn't have any armor on. Both kids were listening along, with the purple-haired girl seeming weirdly invested in whatever the captain was saying.

 

Hm…maybe he could start a betting pool on if the cap did have an affair?

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Worst part of traveling with a band of mercenaries is the lack of privacy which leads to rumors getting spread.

Red: Turns out most mercs are total gossips. Who knew?

Indi: Jeralt certainly didn't. Also hope y'all enjoyed this! And if you wanted to see more shenanigans with Byleth, Shez, and Jeralt don't worry, we'll be uploading another chapter later today!

The Start of Friendship?

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Shez had to admit, while it wasn't exactly what she was expecting, she did find it nice to work for Jeralt's Mercenaries. Sure, some of the mercs were weird, but the food was nice, and having an actual tent to sleep under was even better. Though there was one big oddity; namely that of Captain Jeralt’s kid, Byleth. 

 

She wasn't sure what was up with the blue-haired girl, but she hardly ever talked and most of the time she did, it was to her dad. 

 

She was also very strong. Sure, she wasn't much of a match for any of the adults, but Shez couldn't even land a single hit on her! And, she wasn't sure why, but that really irked her! A part of Shez couldn't help but want to win against the strange girl.

 

Hm, was this like the destined rival thing her mom used to tell her about in those stories? Which, if that was the case, wow, she had a destined rival! 

 

“Hey Byleth!” Shez called out to attract the attention of her newly found foe, “You’re my destined rival!”

 

“...Okay,” Byleth replied. Then she turned back to continue setting up the training dummies some of the older mercenaries used.

 

Actually, now that Shez was thinking about it, shouldn’t she be helping with that too?

 

Heading on over, Shez held the training dummy as Byleth made sure it was properly secured. 

 

"You know, you could at least be a bit more excited about being rivals," Shez said as they moved onto the next dummy. 

 

"...What's a destined rival?" 

 

"Huh? You really don't know what that is?" Shez asked, getting a blank stare in return. "Doesn’t your dad read you stories?" 

 

"Should he?" 

 

"Uh…well, I guess he doesn't have to. Still, if you're going to be my rival, you should know your stuff!" At Byleth's stare, she continued, striking what she thought was a heroic pose. It involved a lot of pointing, first at the sky, then at Byleth. “And I shall teach you!”

 

“Okay.”

 

“Hm, we need to work on you being excited…Hey does your dad–I mean, does Captain Jeralt have any books to read from? That might make things easier.”

 

It was hard to tell if Byleth was thinking about the question or not, but Shez was patient! Well, mostly. She might’ve given Byleth a poke in the side when she took too long. “Mm. Don’t do that.”

 

"You could at least say you don't know instead of staying quiet." Byleth just stared silently at her in response. "Right, we can ask him later. All you need to know is that it means we're gonna be making each other stronger!" 

 

"But I'm already stronger than you." 

 

"Th-That's just for now! If I keep training, I'm sure I'll be able to beat you one day! Besides, I haven't even used magic in our fights yet." 

 

"You can use magic?" Oh? That seemed to have gotten her interested…at least, Shez thought so since Byleth's eyes opened a bit. 

 

"That I can, my mom taught me!" Well, she taught her a spell, but it was still something. 

 

"Can you show me?" 

 

“You bet I can!” Shez smiled brightly, then tried to think back on her mother’s lessons. She was pretty sure she said something about using tomes to safely channel magic but…eh, it would probably be safe. Grinning, she brought her hand up, aiming at the training dummy, and began to focus as a white sigil began to form in front of her hand.

 

Shez would soon come to learn the importance of using tomes when you weren't that used to magic as the sigil abruptly broke, sending Shez backwards as it did. 

 

"Ugh…that's never happened before." Shez said, slowly getting up. 

 

"Are you okay?" She heard Byleth ask her. 

 

"Yeah I'm good-..." Shez stopped talking the instant she saw a trail of blood leaking from Byleth’s forehead. "A-Are you okay?!”

 

She got up and rushed over to Byleth, who regarded her with her usual blank look. Which might be a bad thing, since Shez vaguely remembered head injuries being bad injuries."Hm?" 

 

"Y-You're bleeding!" Shez shouted and tried wiping the blood away, though it only seemed to annoy Byleth since she tried pushing her away. 

 

"I'm okay." 

 

"No you're not!" Shez responded, grabbing her hand and trying to pull her along. If she hadn't been panicking, she likely would have noticed the nearby mercs watching the scene play out, a few chuckling at Shez’s franticness. As it stood, she was far more focused on the fact that Byleth kept bleeding and that she needed to fix this–Oh no, if Jeralt found out, he'd kick her out of the group for sure!

 

Thankfully Shez was able to find the medic, who seemed a bit confused to see her dragging Byleth over. 

 

"P-Please stop the bleeding!"

 

The healer sighed, her shoulders slumping. “Great, what did you two do this time?”

 

"I-it was just an accident, no need to tell the captain!" Shez said, as Byleth finally pulled her hand free, seeming more annoyed at getting dragged around than the blood leaking down her face. Sighing again, the medic kneeled down, wiping away the blood to try and look at the wound. 

 

"Well, the good news is that it's not a bad cut, it just looks like it is because wounds above the eye bleed easily," the medic said, sitting Byleth down as she went to grab her supplies. 

 

“B-But it’s a lot of blood! And head injuries are bad, right?!”

 

“I just said they bleed a lot. And sure, they can be, but this is just a cut,” she explained. The healer brushed Byleth’s hair back and dabbed at the wound with a cloth. Despite everything, Byleth didn’t even make a noise of discomfort at the sensation, instead just watching as the medic worked. “I don’t even need to use a vulnerary for something this small, okay?”

 

“Mh–B-But–”

 

“I said it’s fine. I swear, you’re worse than Jeralt…”

 

Shez blinked. “I am? Wait, what’s so bad about the captain?”

 

“Not too much these days, aside from his drinking habits and his stubborn tendencies that make my work harder. I’ve heard some stories about just how protective he can be of this little weirdo though.”

 

“Hey!” The healer paused and glanced at Shez, who was glaring at her. “Don’t call Byleth a weirdo! She’s my destined rival!”

 

“...Sure, kid.” She looked back to Byleth and gave her a pat on the head. “The ‘weirdo’ comment was meant to be affectionate. You’re easily the least annoying patient I have to deal with, if just because you actually stay quiet during exams.”

 

“Okay,” Byleth replied, as monotone as ever. Shez was mollified, but only barely, as she still frowned at the healer to show her displeasure.

 

The medic made an amused noise, before placing a small bandage across Byleth’s cut. “Keep this on for the day. There might be a little scar, but nothing that won’t fade in time.”

 

“Okay.”

 

“Really? She’s okay?” Shez asked, pressing closer than the medic would’ve preferred in her attempt to check on her rival.

 

“She’s fine. What did you two do to get her hurt anyway? More sword fighting?”

 

In an instant, Shez went from checking on Byleth with some obvious concern to ducking her head and fidgeting with her hands. “Uh…um…an icicle hit her, it wasn’t my fault.”

 

“An icicle, huh? At this time of year? In this part of Fodlan? In the middle of our camp?”

 

“...Yes.”

 

“Hmm. Well that is concerning. You two should show me where the icicles are growing so we can clear them off. We don’t want anyone else to get accidentally hit, do we?”

 

“Okay,” Byleth agreed, before she hopped down from the stool and walked out of the tent, apparently intent on leading the way, much to Shez’s immediate alarm.

 

“Ah! B-Byleth! Don’t–U-Um, w-wait up!”

 

The healer smiled faintly as she watched the new girl scurry after Byleth. She didn’t particularly like kids, but seeing Jeralt’s near-silent daughter hanging around with a kid her age…well, it made her seem less creepy, at least.

 

“Ah, Miss Healer Lady!” Then Shez popped her head back into the tent again.

 

“What is it, kid? Do you want me to actually see these icicles of yours?”

 

“No! I mean…they’re kind of not real…a-anyway, thank you for your help! A-And please don’t tell Captain Jeralt!”

 

“I won’t.” She didn’t need to. Half the camp was bound to tell him the instant he got back.

 

Shez smiled brightly at her response though, so the healer decided not to mention that part. “Thank you! And, um…what’s your name?”

 

“Gertrude.”

 

“Okay! Thank you Miss Gertrude!” 

 

Gertrude the healer watched Shez scamper off again, probably to keep Byleth from showing off whatever mishap she caused. She had a feeling she’d see the two of them in her tent sooner rather than later. Hopefully later, if just because she didn’t particularly like seeing injured children, but she wasn’t going to get her hopes up.

Somehow, Shez didn’t consider the fact that Byleth’s new bandage was really obvious. Obvious to the point that Jeralt immediately noticed and asked about it while the two of them were busy sorting some of the equipment.

 

“An icicle hit me,” Byleth explained, and Shez felt a weird mix of relief and guilt when she heard the other girl lie for her.

 

“An icicle, huh? I did notice one of the practice dummies seemed frostier than usual,” Jeralt noted, and Shez felt the guilty part start to grow.

 

"An icicle hit it too." 

 

"Is that so?" 

 

"U-Uh, Captain Jeralt, sir," Shez spoke up, tentatively raising her hand as she prepared to admit her guilt. "I-It was my fault, I…wanted to show off my magic, but I wasn't able to control it." 

 

“Ahhh, now that makes more sense,” Jeralt said, nodding his head, “You cast a spell without a tome?”

 

"A-ah, yes, my mom told me it wasn't safe, but I wanted to show off…" Jeralt was only able to let out a sigh before Shez spoke up again. "P-please don't kick me out of the group. I swear I won't do it again!" 

 

That gave him some pause. He didn’t think Shez would be that attached to his group, but…as he thought about it, it did make some sense. A girl who lost her mother, was basically thrown out of her village, and joined three different mercenary bands would probably have attachment issues.

 

Crap, he definitely couldn’t leave her at the next village if that was the case. There was no way she would take it well. 

 

He sighed. “I’m not going to kick you out, Shez.”

 

She immediately lit up. “You mean it?!” 

 

"Yeah, but you better not practice magic again without a tome. Or someone to show you how to cast properly," Jeralt said, before muttering something about finding a mage to do so. 

 

"Thank you sir!" Shez couldn't believe her luck at being able to stick around. Out of all the groups she's worked with before, this one was by far the easiest and best gig! Heck, she might just be a chore girl again, but she got plenty of good meals! 

 

"Just make sure to finish sorting the equipment, okay?" 

 

"Sir, yes, sir! Oh, uh, captain, I did want to ask you something. You wouldn't happen to have any books that have a hero and a rival, do you?" 

 

"I can check, why do you ask?" 

 

"Because, Byleth is my destined rival and she doesn't know what that means, so I have to show her!" Blinking, Jeralt turned to look at Byleth, who met his gaze. 

 

"She's going to teach me." 

 

…Jeralt wasn't sure, but had the two of them become friends? 

 

"I'll see what I can find." It was always hard to tell, but for a second, Jeralt saw a glimmer of what could’ve been happiness in his daughter’s eyes. 

 

Yeah, maybe keeping Shez around was a good idea. 

 

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Very interesting to think about how a character would be in the past before they became fully developed.

Red: That it is. Their personalities aren't fully set yet, though they are on the way to it. Leads to some fun stuff.

Indi: yup yup, and as such, is interesting to think about what changes to said person would happen if they were to say, get a sibling.

Red: And thus, this story came to be. And we hope you're all enjoying it!

Indi: That we do, see you when we update again!

Smile!

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Shez let out a yelp as her wrist was smacked with a training sword, making her drop her own wooden blade, before Byleth placed her sword against her throat. Shez couldn't help but take a step back as her rival's eyes bore into her. 

 

"Alright, that's enough training," Jeralt said, getting both of the girls' attention. Byleth moved back the instant she registered his words, leaving Shez to relax without the wooden blade at her neck. "Good job Shez. You've been improving, but you still have to be careful about overextending yourself." 

 

Despite the slight praise, Shez couldn't help but pout a bit as she rubbed her wrist. Sure, it was only training, so it wasn't a big deal, but she still felt annoyed at losing. Especially since her rival didn't even seem pleased about winning! 

 

"Captain, it's time to meet the client," a mercenary said as he walked up, getting Jeralt’s attention. 

 

"It's that time already? Alright you two, make sure to put your gear away, and stick by the camp ‘til I get back, okay?" 

 

"Yes, sir!" 

 

"Okay, papa." Taking off their helmets, the two young girls made their way towards the storage tent. 

 

"You know, you could at least act happy that you won,” Shez muttered as they entered the tent. 

 

"...?" Tilting her head slightly, Byleth stared at Shez. "But I am happy?" 

 

"You sure don't act like you are." She gave Byleth a curious look. “In fact, I don’t think I’ve ever seen you smile? Huh.”

 

“...” Byleth didn’t seem to have a response to that. She just set her helmet down in its place and began unbuckling the training armor she wore.

 

“Hmm…hey, By.”

 

She paused and looked over at Shez. “By?”

 

“Yeah, it’s your name. Well, part of it. It’s a shortened version, it makes it easier to say, but that’s not important! I have a very serious question,” Shez stated. She pressed her hands together in a way she’d seen some adults do when they were thinking. Or praying? One or the other. “Do you know what emotions are?”

 

Somehow, Byleth’s usual flat look looked even flatter. “...I’m not stupid.”

 

“I didn’t say you are!” Shez frowned, then shook off her annoyance– “Hey! Don’t leave!”

 

Byleth turned around.

 

“Okay, so you know what emotions are, that’s good! That makes my new plans even easier!”

 

“...” Byleth turned–

 

Shez grabbed Byleth’s arm to keep her from leaving. “No! Listen! I’m going to help you express yourself!”

 

“...Let go of my arm.”

 

“Not until you agree to my lesson plan!”

 

“Papa says I’m allowed to hit people if they grab me.”

 

Shez frowned, but let go of Byleth’s arm. “Okay, fine, but first, I want to see you smile! Prove to me that you can do it!”

 

“...I don’t want to.”

 

“Why not? It’s really easy.” Shez smiled wide, showing her teeth in a bright grin. “See? Now you do it!”

 

“...” Byleth showed her teeth. It couldn’t reasonably be called a smile by any metric, but to call it a grimace would ascribe emotion that just wasn’t there. 

 

Shez tilted her head. “Huh. Okay, maybe not like that…try it again with your lips closed!”

 

“...” The second attempt was worse. Byleth clearly had enough of an idea of what a smile looked like, but her ability to actually make her lips curl upwards properly into one was so completely lacking even Shez felt faintly unnerved.

 

“Huh…okay, that was better, you actually had kind of a smile there.” Luckily, Shez wasn’t the type to let discomfort get to her. “But you need to sort of…move your eyes? And not stretch your lips that far. It kinda looked like someone cut your cheeks when you did that.”

 

“Hm.” She stopped “smiling”.

 

“But we can work on it! Actually, hm…do you know how to make any other expressions? What does it look like when you get mad?”

 

“Like this.”

 

“Really? Huh, okay…what about when you’re sad?”

 

For the first time in her life, Byleth felt like sighing.

Jeralt felt like sighing. His more annoying clients were usually nobles, but there was something about a village headman with an inflated ego that just felt uniquely irritating. At least the job wouldn’t be too difficult. Clearing a band of bandits could vary in difficulty, but from all indications, this gang was a small one. Not too much trouble.

 

At least he could let the girls stay in town while he was out handling things. It always felt better when he didn’t have to worry about Byleth…Hm.

 

Speaking of Byleth, he could hear someone in his tent again. It was noisier these days since Shez joined up, especially since she decided Byleth was her “rival”, and that was definitely her voice.

 

“–made a bunch of these, so you have to look at them!” That was a weird sentence.

 

He wasn’t completely sure why, but he moved carefully and slowly opened the tent flap, enough to peek inside instead of just announcing his presence. 

 

Byleth and Shez were sitting on his daughter’s cot, and Shez was showing his daughter…papers?

 

“See, this one’s a happy face. See how the eyes are curled like this? And the smile’s–Wait, I need to explain this like a teacher…See how the lips are curled like this? That’s a smile!”

 

“I know what a smile is.”

 

“Yeah, but it’s part of the explanation!”

 

…What in the world were they doing?

 

“Okay, just remember, this is a happy face!” Shez insisted as she waved the paper in her hand near his daughter’s face. She set it down and picked up another paper, and Jeralt felt an eyebrow raise when he saw the blue frowning face on it. “And this is a sad face! See how it’s drooping? The eyes are curled differently, and the lips are frowning, not smiling!”

 

“Okay.”

 

“And there’s usually tears and snot when someone’s crying, so it’s gross. I think the lips are kind of pouty too? But pouting’s different from frowning! You jut out your lip when you’re pouting or puff up your face, stuff like that.”

 

“Did you draw that?”

 

“I…didn’t think I needed to…um, that’s for next time! For the advanced class!”

 

Jeralt started to get an idea of what was going on here, and he wasn’t sure if he should be annoyed at Shez for trying to push Byleth to emote…or glad she cared enough about his kid to try “helping”.

 

“Anyway! This next one’s a mad face! It’s for when you’re angry! See how the eyes are glaring and the mouth is frowning? It’s a different frown from a sad frown though. It’s a…snarl, I think. Or maybe a scowl? It’s very ‘grrrrr’. Try making that noise! It’ll help!”

 

“Grrrrr,” Byleth growled in complete monotone.

 

“Okay, maybe not like that…It’s okay, we’ll work on it!”

 

“Mm. Hi papa.” Ah, guess he was noticed.

 

Byleth looked over at him and Shez followed her gaze a second later. The purple-haired girl squeaked, and Jeralt felt like he shouldn’t be amused by her obvious surprise. He was, of course, but still. “C-Captain Jeralt, sir!”

 

She tried to salute and smacked herself in the face with the paper. Since she couldn’t see it, he let himself smile for a brief second before putting his stern face back on. “Shez, what are you doing?”

 

“A-Ah, um…I was trying to teach Byleth about emotions?”

 

“She wants me to smile better so she knows when I’m happy,” Byleth explained.

 

“Yeah, that! Exactly! Wow, you’re a good student.”

 

Jeralt knew his daughter wasn’t the emotive type. It gave him no end of concern in her early years, but he got used to it, and he knew that while she didn’t show much emotion, she wasn’t completely emotionless. So he felt some amusement at seeing a flicker of annoyance cross Byleth’s face, followed by actual surprise when Shez gave her a pat on the head.

 

“...What are you doing?”

 

“Oh, this is what my mom did when I did well in her lessons. It feels nice, right?”

 

“...Yeah. Papa does that too sometimes.”

 

“Oh hey, that’s–” Shez seemed to remember Jeralt was still there and dropped her hand from Byleth’s head with a sheepish smile. And, while it went quick, for a moment, Jeralt thought he saw his daughter pout.

 

“Relax, I’m not mad,” Jeralt said. He was having a hard time keeping himself from smiling. “I don’t mind if you two do stuff like this. It’s better than any unsupervised magic or sparring.”

 

Shez ducked her head, embarrassed, and he took a moment to glance at the papers at her side. Which…

 

“How much paper did you use?” 

 

“Huh? Uh…” Shez glanced at the small pile. “...um…well, um, I tried making one for every emotion I could think of, so…”

 

“You know that stuff costs money, right?” Maybe he was having too much fun messing with the new kid, but the stricken look on her face was priceless. “Well, whatever. I’ll just take the cost out of your pay.”

 

“Wait, I’m getting paid?”

 

“You’re part of the group, so yeah, you’re getting paid. Ask me later and I’ll hand over what you’ve already racked up.”

 

“I should get paid too,” Byleth piped up.

 

“You already get an allowance.”

 

“Hm. I should get more. I work here too.”

 

“Sure, but you’re also my kid, which makes it an allowance instead of pay. And you’re too young to ask me for a raise, so don’t bother.”

 

“Don’t worry By, I’m sure when you’re a full blown mercenary like me, you’ll get a bigger allowance!” Shez reassured. Then she smiled brightly. “Ah, see! That’s an angry face! Good job!”

Chapter End Notes

Indi: It's very fun writing these cute moments with Byleth and Shez

Red: Shez is helping! Or at least trying her best to.

Indi: Eh it's the thought that counts. Even if Byleth is somewhat annoyed by it.

Red: The fact that she's even managing to annoy Byleth could be considered an accomplishment.

Indi: yup yup, wonder how Byleth will end up turning out thanks to Shez lol

Visiting a Village

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

"You're pouting." Byleth said as she stared at Shez. 

 

"Of course I am!" Shez responded while she continued sulking, "It's not fair the captain is making us wait here while they go on a mission."  

 

“We have a mission.”

 

“Buying supplies isn’t a mission! It’s a chore!”

 

“Papa said it’s an assignment,” Byleth contradicted, “He also said you need to buy more paper to replace the ones you used.”

 

Shez huffed in annoyance, before looking at the list Captain Jeralt gave her. The list written on paper, she might add, so it wasn’t just her wasting it! Not that the stuff she made was a waste! “Okay, the list says we need paper and ink, which some merchants should maybe have. Also smoked or salted meat from the butchery, leather if there’s a tanner, some extra bandages and vulneraries…eesh, there’s a lot here…How are we gonna carry all of this?”

 

“We’re not. Papa wants us to order the things on the list. We tell the seller we need it and then someone from the camp gets it later.”

 

“Ohhh, that makes so much more sense. Do you do this a lot?”

 

Byleth shrugged. “Not a lot. I usually go with papa.”

 

"Hmph, well in that case, I'll be taking charge!" 

 

"But I'm older." 

 

"And which one of us is the actual paid mercenary? Ah, hey you're getting good at the angry face!" Grinning, Shez grabbed her hand. "Besides, do you want to be the one talking to the villagers?" 

 

At the lack of response, Shez smiled again, before pulling Byleth along. 

 

"So, you thinking of buying anything else?"

 

"Hm…bread sounds nice." 

 

"Well, yeah, but anything else besides food?" 

 

"...?" Byleth tilted her head in faint confusion. 

 

"You know, like a book, or something else? Actually, do you have any hobbies?" 

 

"...Fishing is nice." 

 

"...I'm really starting to feel like I'm the older one." 

 

“You’re not.”

 

“I could be! When were you born?”

 

Byleth tilted her head in thought. “...Not sure. Papa says I was born in Horsebow though.”

 

“Okay! So that’s the…one, two, three–Sixth month! I think…Were you born in Fall?”

 

“I guess. When were you born?”

 

“I…” Shez paused. “...uh…I don’t know. Mom and I didn't really celebrate birthdays, and I don't remember anything from before she took me in." 

 

“Oh. When did she take you in?”

 

“No idea!” Shez confidently proclaimed, “So I’m probably older than you.”

 

“...How does that make sense?”

 

“It just does. Now come on!”

 

Forced to concede to Shez’s unassailable logic, or just not really interested in continuing this conversation, Byleth resigned herself to being pulled along by the definitely not older girl.

 

And so, while Shez and Byleth went around purchasing supplies, Byleth did her best to remember just how old she was. She remembered her papa saying Shez was maybe twelve and Byleth was sure she was older than that…maybe. She got her dagger as a present to celebrate her…tenth year? How many years ago was that… 

 

"Alrighty, that should be everything, and hey, we got some spare gold if we wanna get something for ourselves!" Shez announced, snapping Byleth out of her thoughts. 

 

"Use your own money." 

 

"Aw, come on, it's not like he's gonna know." 

 

"I thought you were a 'paid mercenary’." That definitely got Shez to shut her mouth, before she huffed. 

 

"Fine fine, I'll use my own money," Shez muttered as she looked around to see what exactly the village was selling. It wasn't exactly a sprawling place, so they didn't have much when it came to commodities. Even so, the merchant selling vulneraries also had a few odds and ends, so there was something at least. "Oh hey, By, look!" 

 

Grabbing a book titled 'Of Knights and Mages', Shez showed it off to Byleth. 

 

"This is a story my mom read to me before, it has the destined rivals!" Grinning, she handed it to Byleth. "Here, a present from me!" 

 

"...Really?" 

 

"Of course!" Handing over some gold for the book, Shez continued smiling. "It might be a few months late, but as the older one it's only right I get you a present." 

 

"...Hm." Glancing over at the wares, Byleth paused for a moment, before grabbing a hair clip and putting it on Shez, moving her hair out of her eye in the process. "Here." 

 

"Huh?" 

 

"Present for you, we can make today your birthday." For a brief moment, Shez could have sworn Byleth seemed smug. "And since it's after my birthday that means you're younger than me.”

 

“...Hey, wait, that’s cheating!”

 

“No it’s not.”

 

“Yeah, it is–H-Hey, don’t walk away!” Shez demanded. She felt her face redden, especially when she heard the merchant snicker from behind her, before she huffed and followed after Byleth. She quickly caught up to the shorter girl and bumped her shoulder against hers. “You’re lucky it’s my birthday so I’m feeling generous.”

 

Byleth didn’t dignify that with a response, leading Shez to pout again.

 

“Hmph…so, hey, do you know how to read? I just realized it would be a bad idea to get you a book if you can’t read it.”

 

“I can read. Papa taught me how.”

 

“Ohh, that makes sense. Captain Jeralt seems smart…hm. Hey, tell me more about yourself.”

 

“...Why?”

 

“Because I don’t know a lot about you and I should if you’re gonna be my destined rival! Here, I’ll go first. My name is Shez–”

 

“I know that part.”

 

“–I was born in…um, not sure, but I’m from…uh, wait, what was the village called…?”

 

“You don’t know a lot about yourself.”

 

“Hey! I know…important stuff! What about you? Where were you born?”

 

“I don’t know.”

 

Shez blinked. “Wait, you too? Wow, that’s funny. And more proof that we’re destined to be rivals!”

 

Byleth’s lips twitched for a moment. That hadn’t happened before, so she was a little surprised by her own reaction. It didn’t feel like too big of a deal though, so she kept leading the way towards the camp.

 

“Hmm…Well, I don’t really know much about my birth parents. Mom didn’t know much about them either, she said she found me when I was abandoned, but I think they’re probably dead. Maybe from war or something?” Shez shrugged. “Hmm…oh, my mom’s name was Periander! That’s important, right?”

 

“I guess. My papa’s name is Jeralt.”

 

“I knew that part already! Hm…do you know your mom’s name?”

 

Byleth paused. She didn’t. “I don’t. I never met her.”

 

“She probably died then,” Shez noted. She nodded to herself, confident in her guess, then noticed Byleth had stopped walking. “...Oh. Oh, um, sorry! I didn’t–”

 

“It’s okay. I didn’t really think about it before.”

 

“...Hey, come on.” Shez took Byleth’s hand and pulled her along, leading her over to one of the trees in between the edge of town and the edge of where their camp was set up. She sat down under it, and patted the ground beside herself. “Sit!”

 

“...” Byleth sat.

 

Shez smiled, then scooted closer to Byleth and pulled her new book open to the first page. “Here, let’s read together! You can learn about destined rivals!”

 

“...Okay.” Byleth settled in, letting her back rest against the trunk of the tree, and began to read.

“Ugh, do we really have to bring back the leader’s head? Can’t we just go with an ear? That’s so much easier to carry,” complained one of Jeralt’s mercenaries on the way back to camp. He was one of the longer lasting ones, though Jeralt wasn’t totally sure which one he was. Either Victor or Hector, something like that…or Harold? Or…No, it was probably Victor.

 

“The headman made his terms clear,” Jeralt said, glancing back at his complaining subordinate, “Besides, you’re the one who decided to bet on who had to carry it.”

 

“Yeah, but I didn’t think I’d lose.”

 

He tried not to sigh as he trudged back with the rest of his band, leading Argo by his reins for the moment. The woods had been too dense to really go in as proper cavalry so what would’ve been an easy rout turned into a bloody fight. Not on his side, at least. The blood currently dripping off his troops wasn't their own, though cleaning everything off was going to be a pain.

 

“Aw! Captain, look at that!”

 

He paused in his thoughts and glanced over to where another of his mercs was pointing. 

 

Sitting underneath a tree was Byleth and Shez, a book in both their laps as the two kids leaned on each other, obviously asleep.

 

“D’aw, that’s sweet,” Victor said, before casually hoisting the sack holding the bandit boss’s head over his shoulder, “Right, guess that means I’ll be handing this over. You see to your kids, captain, I’ll see if I can bring the money back.”

 

“Hm? Yeah, alright, go for it,” he agreed, waving his troops off. He looked over at his daughter again. She looked…relaxed. Just completely at peace.

 

“...Yeah, there’s no way she’s going to let Shez go,” he muttered under his breath, before heading over to the two. If Byleth was a few years younger, he might’ve picked her up and taken her to her bed, but even if age wasn’t about to catch up to him any time soon, she was definitely getting too heavy for that. That, and he wasn’t sure what to do with Shez in that situation, so he lightly shook his daughter’s shoulder. “Hey kid, wake up.”

 

With a slight fluttering of her eyes, Byleth woke up to stare up at her dad. 

 

"Papa?" 

 

"Hey there, sorry for waking you up, but you two should really sleep in a tent instead of under a tree," Jeralt said, speaking softly. 

 

"Hm…okay." Closing the book, Byleth held it close. "...Papa, what was mom's name?" 

 

“...” Jeralt needed a second. No, what he needed was to be deep in his cups so this question wouldn’t feel like a sucker punch straight to his gut. But he didn’t have that. What he had was a daughter asking about her mother for the first time. And he had no idea how to begin that conversation. So he just…answered her. “Sitri. Her name was Sitri.”

 

“Mm.” She looked up at him, her blue eyes completely unlike his own. He could so clearly see her mother in her that it hurt, like an old wound reopened. “...”

 

Byleth moved up and leaned her head against his chest, like she used to when she was little and tired. “...She died.”

 

“...Yeah, kid. She did.”

 

No more questions came after that. Byleth just stayed close, and before long, his daughter was asleep again. 

 

Jeralt let out a slow, soft sigh, and picked her up. It was easier than he expected.

 

He glanced down at Shez, sighed, and lightly shook her awake too.

 

“I’m up!” she snapped awake, blinking rapidly, then seemed to recognize his presence. “O-Oh, uh, hey captain! Um…oh! Mission accomplished! We put in orders and–”

 

“I don’t need a full report. Come on, if you two are this tired, you should get to bed.”

 

“I-I’m not tired–” Her immediate yawn proved she was lying, and Jeralt couldn’t help his slight grin at her embarrassed look. 

 

“Want me to carry you too?”

 

“N-No! I can walk!” she insisted, and did a good job of getting up too. Still, he kept an eye on her as they headed back to the tent. 

 

And while Jeralt would never admit it, at least while he was sober, he found it nice that she was there. His daughter needed a friend, and he was glad she found one.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Now we're really getting into the changes of Byleth having an outside influence like Shez!

Red: That we are! Turns out having someone around to ask her stuff raises questions of her own.

Indi: Yup yup, and we certainly have some big plans for future changes!

Red: As for what those are, you'll just have to wait for the next bits.

Indi: yup yup, and just so y'all know, we'll be updating the tags as we go along!

Red: So that should be interesting. Just note that the "graphic violence" tag is there for a reason. An ominous reason.

Indi: until then, hope y'all enjoyed!

New Tricks

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

"Shez's birthday was yesterday," Byleth told her dad when he awoke. 

 

"Huh?” Jeralt took a moment, blinking awake, then gave his daughter a confused look. “Since when did you know when her birthday is?" 

 

"Since last year," Byleth explained, before a slight pout appeared on her face. "I wanted to tell you, but you returned late on your mission." 

 

"Ah…yeah, sorry about that." It probably wasn't a fair excuse, but after the job of clearing out those giant wolves went on much longer than expected, he couldn't help getting maybe a bit too excited for the feast he was offered. Especially with the high quality booze they had. Turns out nobles were sometimes good for something… "Did you two have fun yesterday?" 

 

"Yes, the bakery had some nice bread rolls." 

 

"That's good," Jeralt said, feeling relieved that the town he left them in was nice.

 

"Shez also wants to show you something," Byleth said, gesturing for him to follow her. 

 

"Huh?" A bit confused, Jeralt felt her grab his hand and do her best to pull him out of the bed he was using. Which, well, Jeralt was curious to see what was going on, so he followed along. 

 

"Hey there, Captain, Sir! I hope you're ready to be blown away!" Shez greeted as she stood in the training field, her hands on a pair of training swords.

 

“...Alright, what am I looking at?”

 

“My new style!” she declared, before turning towards a training dummy and showing off some type of two sword style she developed. 

 

She wasn’t that bad, he had to admit as he watched how easily she swung each sword, delivering quick blow after blow to the dummy. It wasn’t his type of thing at all, admittedly, but he’d always been built for heavy hits instead of this quick and light stuff.

 

He did let out an impressed whistle when Shez took off the dummy’s head with her off hand. “Not bad. Not bad at all.”

 

“Oh, wow, I didn’t–O-Oh, thanks sir!” She smiled brightly, before turning and leveling her sword at his daughter. “Now, my fated rival, we shall–”

 

“You’re going to have to fix the Headless Dummy later though.”

 

It shouldn’t be so funny to take the wind out of the kid’s sails, but it, well, it was. “Nh…o-okay, but later! For now, Byleth–Wait, where’s Byleth?”

 

“Over here,” Byleth called out from the armory tent, where she’d just gotten a training sword and helmet for herself. “I’m ready.”

 

“...You could at least let me finish issuing the challenge.”

 

Byleth stared. “Are we going to fight now?”

 

“Yes! We are! And I’m going to win this time!”

 

“If you say so.”

 

Surprisingly enough, Shez actually put her coin where her mouth was for once. Jeralt kept a close eye on things the whole time, because training gear or not, he didn’t want the kids hurting each other, and he had to admit, Shez had definitely figured out something suitable for herself. Her fast movements were something Byleth had seen before, but adding the second sword into the mix threw her off enough that Jeralt already made a mental note to change up his daughter’s training.

 

She was fourteen already, so maybe he should see if the other mercs would be willing to spar? Either way, he clapped his hands together the instant he saw Shez catch Byleth’s sword and get a solid strike in across the head. He tried not to react too badly as he saw his daughter hit the dirt, instead offering Shez a smile. “Good work there, kid.”

 

“...huh? Wait, I did it? I did it! Byleth! I did it!” Shez practically squealed, her eyes bright and happy as she smiled down at her friend…before she frowned and nudged Byleth with her foot. “By? Are you okay? Hey, By!”

 

Jeralt, having seen his daughter give Shez an annoyed look and then deliberately close her eyes, sighed in some exasperation. “Byleth, don’t play dead.”

 

“...mh. She would have believed me,” Byleth complained as she sat up. 

 

Shez huffed, elation turning to frustration as she tapped Byleth on the head with her sword. “Don’t do that! You made me worried!”

 

“Sorry.” Byleth pushed herself up, then reached up and patted Shez on her helmet. “Good job.”

 

“...Hm, no, it doesn’t work as well. You’re shorter than me so it feels weird when you do it.”

 

“...” She poked Shez’s nose instead, making her squawk indignantly.

 

“Hey! Is that any way to treat someone older than you, huh?”

 

“Your birthday was yesterday.”

 

“The birthday you decided on! I won the privilege of being older by beating you! That was the agreement!”

 

Jeralt raised an eyebrow. He wasn’t sure what was going on, but he was also pretty sure, despite being taller than Byleth already and looking like she’d get even bigger as she grew into a lanky teen, Shez was probably a year younger than his daughter. Granted, he did guess that she was ten when he first met her, so his view might be skewed…

 

“I want a rematch.” And there was some unexpected stubbornness from Byleth.

 

“Hm…no.” And Shez completely refused, dropping her swords in favor of sprinting in the opposite direction.

 

Jeralt couldn’t help it. He laughed outright, especially when he saw the look of genuine offense on Byleth’s face before she chased after her friend.

 

“Hahahahaha! Ahh…hm…I guess I should do something for the kid’s birthday…the other kid.” Jeralt frowned at himself. “I should also come up with something to call Shez other than kid if I’m going to keep using that nickname for Byleth…”

"So captain, when are you letting us on a mission with you?" Shez asked while she repaired the headless dummy. Byleth had finally caught her and dragged her back to fix it up, so Jeralt was supervising.

 

"This again? How many times are you going to keep asking?" 

 

"Until you let us join! Come on, By and I are tough, so you're just wasting us by keeping us on the side!" Jeralt couldn't help but sigh at her response. 

 

"Even if I did take you two along, it wouldn't be on our next mission. I may not like nobles but I have to at least keep up appearances in front of a major noble." 

 

“Aw! But that’s more reason we should go! Byleth needs to know how to talk to nobles if she’s going to take jobs, right?”

 

“I’m not retiring anytime soon, kid.”

 

“Yeah, but…eventually! You’re old, right? So you gotta prepare!”

 

“I’m old, but I’m not gray. Besides, even if I was quitting, which I’m not, I wouldn’t take Byleth to meet a Count for her first noble negotiation. Nobles are prickly at the best of times, and the job we’re taking is coming from one of the Alliance’s leaders.” He frowned in thought. “At least I think he is. I’m not completely sure how that round table thing works.”

 

“That’s more reason why we should go then! Meeting a big noble is going to be great for our reputations!”

 

“Shez, no. I understand you want to go, but it’s just a bad idea right now.”

 

Shez grumbled under her breath and stepped away from the slightly more stable dummy with its head belted back on. They’d probably need a better fix if they actually wanted to keep its head on, but it would work for now. “Well…what about the mission, huh? We could come along for that!”

 

Goddess save him from stubborn children… “I’ll have to see what it is first.” He held up a hand to keep her from getting too excited. “I’m not saying yes. I’m just saying if it turns out to be something easy, I might let you two watch. From a distance. With someone keeping an eye on you so you don’t charge into the fray.”

 

“I wouldn’t do that!” At his flat look, she relented, scuffing her boot in the dirt. “...I’ll be good.”

 

“Alright. Now, let’s see if we have anything that will keep this poor guy’s head on…we should still have some nails around here.”

 

"Okay." Shez said, still pouting. Though that stopped as Jeralt gave her a pat on the head. 

 

"Come on now, you're a good kid, I just want to make sure you and Byleth are fully prepared before you join the battlefield." 

 

"I know, but you don't have to worry so much dad." 

 

"That's not going to-...what did you say?" And it seemed Shez realized just what exactly she said since she suddenly stiffened. "Shez, did you-" 

 

Jeralt raised his hand to catch the disembodied training dummy head that was thrown at him, taking a moment to stare at it, before he looked back up to see Shez running away from the training grounds. 

 

"...I'm not drunk enough for this." Jeralt said, before unceremoniously dropping the head on the ground. 

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Don't you just hate it when you call your mercenary captain dad.

Red: Could be worse. At least it took a year for Shez to slip up.

Indi: And hey, least no one was around to tease her.

Red: Yup yup, no witnesses she might have to bury. Well, aside from the dummy, but she already decapitated that one.

Indi: So she's safe. For now.

The First Mission

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

“How do you think it’s going?” Shez asked, glancing up at Byleth. The other girl was standing beside her, her hand on a short spear as she looked out into the distance.

 

“Probably good. Papa is good at his job.”

 

“That’s true, he is.” Shez shifted in place and squinted, trying to see if there were any poachers out on the fields or in the woods. “…Being a lookout is really boring.”

 

“Is it?”

 

“Yeah! It definitely is! We’re just waiting until we see something!”

 

“I guess. You’re supposed to blow a whistle if we see something. That sounds interesting.”

 

"But that's only if we see something, and like you said, with how good the captain is at his job, we probably won't see anything!" 

 

"Hm…is everything okay?" 

 

"Aside from how bored I am?" 

 

"Did something happen with you and papa?" 

 

"H-Huh? What do you mean?" Shez asked, making it obvious something was wrong. 

 

"You were being quiet back at the camp, even when Papa gave us the whistle and told us where to go." 

 

"W-Well, th-that's just cause I ate something weird earlier!" 

 

"Oh…Did you eat a bug?" 

 

"...why is that your first thought?" 

 

“I’ve eaten bugs before,” Byleth explained.

 

“...Were they any good?”

 

“Not really. Did you know ants are spicy?”

 

“They are?? That’s so weird–”

 

“EEEEYAAAAAH!”

 

Both girls paused, then looked at each other. 

 

“Was that a scream?” “That wasn’t you.” they said in unison, before Shez frowned.

 

“Why would that be me–Wait! That was a scream! From the village!”

 

“Yeah, it sounds like it. I didn’t notice any–Shez?”

 

Shez was already halfway down the hill in a full sprint, heading for the village as quickly as she could! The mission was to protect the villagers, so she was going to do exactly that! “Byleth, you handle the signal thing! I’ll save everybody!”

 

Byleth barely heard what her friend said. Running away from someone didn’t make it easy for them to hear what you’re saying, funny enough. And even if she did properly hear what Shez said, the purple-haired girl forgot one important fact: She was the one with the whistle.

Sauin Village was a fairly peaceful place most days. As a village of hunters, trappers, and traders, it wasn’t unusual for the smell of blood to linger in places with how much freshly caught game tended to be brought through the area. That didn’t mean things were violent though; catching food and trading furs were natural parts of life. 

 

A grown man holding a sword to the throat of a young girl most definitely was not the natural state of affairs around there.

 

“BACK OFF! STAY BACK ALL OF YOU OR THE BRAT BREATHES THROUGH A NEW HOLE IN HER NECK!” threatened the poacher, his eyes wide and desperate as he backed up closer and closer to the village’s stables.

 

“L-Let go of me–!”

 

“SHUT IT, BRAT!” the poacher screeched, “YOU’RE LUCKY I DON’T CUT YOU OPEN RIGHT HERE AS VENGEANCE FOR MY COMRADES!”

 

“Let her go!” shouted one of the nearby villagers. A few had gathered at the commotion, though no one was willing to risk getting too close to the wild-eyed thug. “Leonie didn’t do anything to you!”

 

“THIS LITTLE SHIT THREATENED ME!”

 

“She had a stick–!”

 

“I DON’T CARE!” He moved the sword from the young girl’s neck and leveled it at the closest villager. “NOW BACK OFF AND LET US GET SOME STEEDS OR I’LL CUT HER BLOODY NOSE OFF–GYAH!”

 

Whatever other threats he was going to make were cut off in a sharp scream as Shez rammed her hunting knife into the skinny man’s side. His vest was barely padded and she could feel the blade sink in as she shoved him to the ground.

 

The orange-haired girl fell away from the poacher, her eyes wide in shock and confusion as Shez pushed herself up, a bright grin on her face. “Don’t worry! I’ve got this!”

 

“W-Woah…woah, how did you do that!?”

 

“Speed, strength, and plenty of training–”

 

“FHAAAH, GODDESS, FUCK!” screamed the poacher, clutching at the knife in his side, “YOU LITTLE SHIT! YOU STABBED ME! AH, GODDESS, I’M DYING!”

 

“Eesh, he’s really loud,” Shez complained, before shaking it off, “Well, anyways, hi there! I’m Shez, of Jeralt’s Mercenaries, and I–”

 

“Ah, wait!” Leonie interrupted, remembering something very important, “There were two of–”

 

Some instinct prompted Shez to move, tackling Leonie out of the way just in time as an axe crashed down into the ground where she’d been sitting. 

 

“Damn it, Lloyd, you were supposed to keep them distracted,” growled the larger, bulkier, greasy-haired poacher, scowling over at his thinner, balding comrade as he ripped the axe out of the dirt. 

 

“Screw you Vincent! I have a knife in my guts!”

 

“That’s a really big guy,” Shez muttered under her breath. She glanced back at the orange-haired girl and gave her a light push. “Come on, get moving!”

 

“W-Wait! What about you!?”

 

“Don’t worry, I know exactly what I’m doing!” Shez lied. Leonie didn’t know that though, so she just nodded with some visible hesitation and concern, before running over to the villagers currently hanging back, none willing to get close to the axe-wielding brute.

 

Shez, meanwhile, did the logical thing for herself to do in this situation and drew the sword at her hip. Jeralt had given her a few lessons on handling live steel over the months, so she knew what she was doing. Well, she knew what she was doing in handling a sword. Facing off against a man twice her size…

 

Vincent seemed to notice her hesitation from the scoff he let out. “You’re joking. A pipsqueak like you thinks she can take me? You might’ve gotten my bud with that cheap shot, but you’re not getting one on me.”

 

“I don’t need a cheap shot to take down someone like you!”

 

He barked a laugh. “You’ve got a spine, kid! It’s almost a shame I gotta tear it out.”

 

“No it’s not!” Lloyd shouted, “Just kill her already!”

 

Despite his demands, Shez moved first, lunging for the big man with some quick stabs at his chest that he blocked with the blade of his axe. She dodged back as he swung in retaliation and tried to maneuver around him, using her smaller size and quicker speed to find a gap in his defense. 

 

Then he backhanded her and she remembered she shouldn’t keep her eyes on just his weapon.

 

His fist crashed into the side of her head with the force of a boulder, sending her down before his hand went around her throat and he slammed her up against the wall of the stable, driving the air from her lungs in a wheezing choke.

 

“Too bad, brat,” he taunted as she struggled, kicking at his chest and pulling at his thick fingers, “A few more years, and you might’ve been trouble. You won’t have to worry about that now though.”

 

His grip tightened and she wheezed again, trying to breathe under the crushing force squeezing down on her neck. Black spots were starting to fill her vision and she could feel her heart beating faster and faster, even as her struggles were starting to slow. She couldn’t die here, not like this, but it was getting so hard to keep going–No! No, she refused to think like that, there had to be a way out, there had to be something–

 

A strange feeling came over her for a moment, a weird feeling of strength and motion, like something inside her was trying to get out–Then she felt the grip around her neck loosen. 

 

Shez dropped to the ground, coughing and gasping as her lungs ached for air, then the headless body of Vincent the poacher collapsed to the ground a second later and Shez saw Byleth’s face in front of her own as the blue-haired girl looked her over.

 

“There’s bruising. I have a vulnerary, it’ll help. Can you drink it now?” Byleth asked. Her eyes were completely on Shez, checking what damages her friend had suffered, but Shez was more focused on the sword in Byleth’s grip. 

 

She dimly recognized it as the sword the other poacher, Lloyd, had been wielding, and there was blood dripping down the blade. Byleth had grabbed it and cleaved Vincent’s head off in one stroke. That was…wow. 

 

“Wow…” Shez mumbled, before noticing Byleth’s frown.

 

“Are you concussed? How many fingers am I holding up?”

 

“...By, that’s the hilt of a sword.”

 

“Incorrect, I had two fingers extended. We should get you checked out–”

 

“You little shits...if I’m going down, I’m taking you both with me!” the somehow still alive second poacher, Lloyd, snarled as he pushed himself to his feet and ripped the knife out of his side.

 

He made it two paces before the logical thing happened. No, he didn’t die of blood loss, though he likely would have in a few more seconds; no, instead a thrown spear essentially obliterated his head as Jeralt arrived on the scene.

 

"C-Captain-"

 

"Are you two okay?" Jeralt asked, worry evident in his voice as he looked down at them. 

 

"Y-Yes, sir." 

 

"I checked her, she's okay." At their responses, Jeralt nodded, seeming relieved before his features hardened.

 

"What do you think you're doing!? I told you to stay on lookout!" Jeralt shouted, making Shez stiffen. 

 

"S-Sorry, Sir-" 

 

"I don't want to hear an apology, I want an explanation," Jeralt stated, staring down at the two. 

 

"...U-Uh, w-well, sir-" 

 

"It's my fault, I heard someone screaming in the town and rushed ahead." Byleth said, trying to take the blame for Shez. 

 

"Don't lie, I know you're not the type to do that," Jeralt retorted, not believing her for a moment, "Look, we'll talk about this later. For now, both of you head back to camp, and I better see you two there when I head by later." 

 

Shez cringed at the captain’s obvious anger and frustration, but didn’t resist as Byleth helped her to her feet. “...s-sorry.”

 

He’d already moved away by that point, heading over to the poacher’s corpse to pull his lance free from the ruined skull, but Byleth gave her a pat on the back. “It will be okay.”

 

“Mnh…are you sure? I’ve never seen him mad like that…”

 

“Yeah, it’s fine. Papa just wants us to be safe.” Byleth gave Shez a slight smile. She still wasn’t that good at them, but the small smile was still reassuring. “Let’s go back to camp. We can get something to eat.”

 

Shez snorted, brushing at her eyes. “Is food the only thing you think about?”

 

“I think about lots of things. Food is important.”

 

"Including bugs?" 

 

"...Most food is important."

Jeralt was a man who had lived far longer than most people would. He had been in countless battles and faced immeasurable challenges. Even so, when he was stressed, he had one response: find the nearest mug of ale. 

 

And, despite the mess that had occurred, the villagers of Sauin were more than happy to offer him and his mercenaries a feast. The ale might not have been the best, but the villagers really knew their stuff when it came to food. Guess it must come with the territory of being a hunting village. 

 

Tearing into a chunk of boar meat, Jeralt savored the flavor, before washing it down with some ale. Truly, it was the simple rewards that made being a merc worth it. 

 

"C-Captain Jeralt!" Came a young voice, catching his attention. Glancing over, Jeralt saw a young girl, Leonie if he remembered correctly, standing behind him. 

 

"Did you need something?" 

 

"I wanted to say, thank you for saving us!" Leonie said, before bowing to him. 

 

"I was just doing my job,” Jeralt responded as he turned to face her. 

 

"S-Still, you're a hero! You haven't even been here for long and you took out the poachers no problem, and the way you threw that spear was super cool! You didn't even hesitate to save those two girls!" 

 

"They wouldn't have needed saving if they actually listened to my orders,” Jeralt muttered. 

 

"Th-They were just trying to save me! Well, Shez was anyway." Leonie muttered the last part. "S-Still, it was my fault for getting captured!" 

 

"...Not sure how you getting held hostage can be your fault." 

 

"I uh…might have tried to fend the poacher off when he arrived. I thought I could have been a hero like you." Leonie said, before trying to shake her unease and seem confident. "B-But I wanted to ask if you could make me your apprentice!" 

 

…Jeralt really needed to drink more. Grabbing his mug, Jeralt downed what remained before he answered.

 

"Sorry kid, I'm not looking for an apprentice." 

 

"Th-Then what about those two girls? They don't look any older than me." 

 

"They're not my apprentices, they're my kids." Jeralt responded, not really thinking about his response in his drunken state. 

 

"Wait, Captain, Shez is actually your kid?" one of his mercs asked, butting in. 

 

Upon being asked that, Jeralt paused, and began to think about Shez. Sure she might have been more than a handful, but…he couldn't help but think of how fond he was of the brat. And while Byleth might have learned a few bad lessons from her, Shez had been a good influence overall… 

 

"Yeah, she's my kid,” he decided. It wasn’t like he needed anything official to adopt her.

 

"Aw, dammit, I lost the bet!" the merc yelled, slamming his hands on the table. 

 

"What bet?" 

 

"C-Captain!" Leonie spoke up before Jeralt could get his answer. "Even if you aren't looking for an apprentice, are you sure I can't join your group? Anyone around here can tell you how good of a hunter I am!" 

 

Jeralt couldn't help but let out a sigh at her pleading eyes. 

 

"Look, I'm not going to take you along." He raised a hand before she could speak. "But…we were hired to take care of the poachers, and it would look bad on me if I left without making sure they were completely dealt with. So I might stick around for a few days if you want to learn a few things." 

 

Leonie immediately lit up, smiling bright and happy. “I won’t let you down, Captain!”

 

Jeralt tried not to groan. Something about this felt way too familiar and he was far too sober to deal with it.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Turns out having a sister to nudge things along mean you get to go on your first mission early!

Red: Mostly because Shez isn't the type to be happy sitting back and being patient when it comes to missions. Though hey, it does mean a certain someone shows up early too.

Indi: Yup yup! Wonder how things will change there. Especially since Leonie won't just have one captain's daughter to deal with!

Red: I suppose we'll have to see, huh? For now though, thanks for reading!

The Apprentice

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

“Hello! My name is Leonie Pinelli, and I’m going to be Captain Jeralt’s new apprentice!” greeted the new girl on the training field, her bright and eager expression completely at odds with Jeralt’s visible hangover and exhaustion.

 

"I thought I said I wasn't looking for an apprentice," Jeralt said, rubbing his head as he tried to soothe his headache. 

 

"Ah, right, sorry captain!" Leonie said, still sounding very eager as she stood before Shez and Byleth, both of whom seemed unsure of what was going on. Which, right, they still hadn't talked about what had happened at the village the day prior. 

 

"Papa, is everything okay?" Byleth asked, deciding to speak up as Shez shifted in place 

 

"Everything is okay, Leonie is just going to be joining us for training while we're here," Jeralt said, before glancing at Shez. "We can talk about what happened after training." 

 

"Okay."

 

"Now then, to start, Leonie, what weapons are you good with?" Jeralt asked, addressing the new girl. 

 

"I'm really good with the bow, Captain! Ah, but I would love to learn how to use the spear!" 

 

"Is that so? In that case, I can certainly help teach you a thing or two. You kids mind helping her out with the training gear?" Jeralt asked his two kids. 

 

After a moment, Byleth nodded, walking over with Shez to help Leonie get set up. They weren’t planning to spar, at least not immediately, so some basic gloves and padding would be fine for protection.

 

“So what’s it like fighting with Captain Jeralt?” Leonie asked, smiling brightly at Byleth.

 

“We usually stay at the camp,” Byleth answered in her usual monotone, and Jeralt fought back a wince at how obviously Leonie frowned.

 

“Really? Well, you have to do some interesting stuff around here.”

 

“Yeah, we do. Here, you’ll want one of these ones, they’re shorter and easier to use.” Byleth handed Leonie one of the training spears, but the new girl’s frown didn’t disappear. In fact, she looked more annoyed at Byleth’s flat, matter-of-fact replies.

 

“We mostly help out around,” Shez spoke up, some of her nerves fading as she talked, “It’s mostly chores, but every bit is important to keep the camp running!”

 

“Heh, I can imagine!” And Leonie’s mood immediately turned right around. Jeralt knew Byleth wasn’t the best with new people, but since things turned out well with Shez…well, maybe he was just getting in his own head here.
