“Alright, now that you’ve got your weapon, let’s work on your form,” he said, deciding to interrupt the socializing. 

 

“Yes captain!” Leonie replied. She snapped to attention in an instant, so she had that going for her at least.

 

It had been a while since Jeralt worked with someone who didn’t have a foundation to work off of. Shez picked things up quickly, especially with the training she got in her previous merc bands, and he helped Byleth train from the moment she could hold a sword steady. And that wasn’t even mentioning the recruits he’d had to deal with back in the day…

 

Leonie clearly had some training, but it was a hunter, not a lancer. “You want the tip to stay up, pointed towards their face like this. That keeps your head protected and lets you move it easier. Right hand here, left hand down here, you guide with your right and push with your left. Keep your right foot forward, we’ll work on footwork once we get the armwork down. The butt should be by your hip, the tip at eye level. Like I said, aim for the face, not the neck, it’s easier to maneuver and no one wants to get stabbed in the face.

 

He did still know what he was doing though. “Short thrust, you partially extend your arm but keep your elbow bent. Long thrust, you extend it all the way. Keep your footing firm. You don’t need to stay in place, but you do need to be steady. Low thrusts are an option, but remember, most people are going to armor their chest and you need to be prepared for how it feels to punch into that. The main point to lances is thrusting, you don’t want to swing it like it’s a blade for your first option, even if you're handling something like a halberd. If you get deflected, you can always bring it around for a slash, much easier than trying to thrust again.”

 

And Leonie was taking to the lesson quickly enough. The girl might be green, but she was willing to learn and didn’t even complain when he made it clear he expected at least twenty reps against a dummy to make sure she had the basic thrust down.

 

Shez and Byleth were hanging around nearby, and…right, he really should address things.

 

“Kid–Byleth, keep an eye on Leonie. I need to talk to Shez.”

 

"Okay." Nodding, Byleth took a position nearby to keep an eye on Leonie as Jeralt and Shez stepped away. 

 

"Did you need something, Sir?" Shez asked, nervousness evident in her voice. 

 

"..." Clearing his throat, Jeralt tried his best not to speak too roughly. "Can you tell me why you rushed in yesterday?" 

 

"U-Uh, w-well, it's just…" 

 

"I'm not mad, I just want to hear why." 

 

"...I didn't really think, I just heard someone screaming so I wanted to go help…and when I got there, I thought if I saved the day, it would prove to you that we don't need to be babied anymore," Shez explained, unable to look him in the eye. 

 

"And why didn't you use the whistle?" And that got Shez to stiffen. 

 

"I, uh, kinda…told Byleth to use it, but I forgot I was the one who had it." 

 

"...Right." 

 

"S-Sorry, Sir!" 

 

"You don't need to apologize," Jeralt said, trying to think about the right thing to say, "I'm not trying to baby you, but when you're a mercenary a single mistake can lead to your death. Hell, if you hadn't been pushing for it so hard, I probably wouldn't have let you and Byleth join a mission for another two years." 

 

"T-Two??" Shez asked incredulously. 

 

"Yes, two, likely three if this is how your first mission went." Jeralt probably shouldn't have been amused at Shez blanching. "But I just want to make sure you two are ready. I mean, you're both my kids." 

 

"...H-Huh?" Thankfully for Shez, the two of them got interrupted by Leonie letting out a yelp. Looking over, they saw the young hunter on the floor, having seemingly gotten knocked over by Byleth. 

 

"Hey, who said you two could spar?" Jeralt asked, approaching the two to help Leonie up. 

 

"She wanted to," Byleth answered, earning a glare from Leonie. 

 

"Yeah, I did, and she cheated! She kicked my legs out from under me!" 

 

"That's cheating?" Shez asked from behind Jeralt. Sighing, Jeralt shook his head. 

 

"Leonie, if there's one thing you learn from me, then it's this. There's no such thing as cheating when it comes to a fight. It's better to play dirty and win, then it is to play fair and lose." 

 

She blinked. "Really?" 

 

"Yeah, honor doesn't mean anything if you're dead. As far as we're concerned, a mercs honor is whether they can complete a job or not. Course, you still have to look out for yourself, if a noble is treating you poorly there's no reason to stay, and if a client dies you don't have an obligation to avenge them." 

 

"But…what about your reputation?" 

 

"Well that's up to you. What's more important, your life or your rep?" 

 

Leonie frowned. “...but you still try to help people, right?”

 

“Of course, there’s nothing wrong with that. Just make sure you’re getting paid for it,” he joked. Well, half-joked. “Now let’s try that again. Shez, you mind jumping in?”

 

“Huh–Oh! Y-Yeah, you got it, sir!” She saluted and picked up a training sword, moving to the field to face off against Leonie.

 

“Remember Leonie, a spear gives you more reach,” Jeralt called out, “You’ll always have an advantage against someone with a sword so long as you remember that.”

 

“Understood!”

 

Jeralt settled back, watching the two girls face off. After a moment, Byleth moved over to his side and he gave her a glance, waiting to see if she wanted to talk.

 

“...Is Shez my sister?”

 

Well, that wasn’t what he expected her to ask. “Do you want her to be?”

 

“Yeah. I’ve never had a sister. She’s nice. Kind of stupid though.”

 

Jeralt bit back a laugh at his kid’s blunt summary. “She’s not a bad kid. I never thought I’d wind up adopting another kid though. It’s a strange thought.”

 

“Hm. Hey, Shez is my sister now, right? She wasn’t my sister before?”

 

“...” Okay now he was just confused. “Could you explain that one to me?”

 

“Some of the mercenaries were betting on if Shez was your bastard.” He nearly choked on his own spit. “Is a bastard a secret daughter?”

 

“...Shez isn’t my…secret daughter, kid. You’re the one that found her, remember?”

 

“Huh. That’s true.” She looked thoughtful, then looked up at him again. “When was I born?”

 

“Uh…the twentieth of Horsebow?” Where was this going?

 

“What year?”

 

Jeralt raised an eyebrow at her sudden curiosity, then considered if he should answer the question truthfully or not. There…probably wasn’t any harm in it. It wasn’t like he’d be running into anyone from the church anytime soon. “Eleven fifty-nine.”

 

“Hm…” She seemed to be counting something from how she moved her fingers. “...I’m fourteen then. How old is Shez?”

 

“You’re asking a lot of questions today.”

 

“Please answer.”

 

“Uh…well, I don’t know. I was assuming she’s probably a year younger than you, at least.” Well, he thought she was three years younger at first, but that didn’t seem too likely now.

 

“Mm. So I’m older. Good.”

 

…He really had no idea what his kid was thinking sometimes.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: And so, the adoption finally happens! Took awhile, but we got here.

Red: And Byleth approves! So long as she's the older sister, of course.

Indi: Can't let Shez get to bit of a head after all. Well, bigger than it is already.

Red: Shez would never let it go if she ever got proof that she was older than Byleth. Similarly, she would never live it down if it was ever proven she was younger.

Indi: Best hope neither gets proven, so Shez can always deny being the younger one.

Time to Travel

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

They stuck around Sauin for a few more days. Jeralt and some slightly scuffed members of his band, the ones who needed to learn not to bet on his personal life and to watch their language around the kids, kept up on searching around for any remaining poachers while Byleth and Shez helped out with training their father’s “new apprentice”.

 

Jeralt still chipped in with Leonie’s training, of course, but his kids made for decent sparring partners for the young girl. Byleth also took to helping with some surprising, if muted, enthusiasm. She was the one most often directing the two younger girls and she was competent enough with a lance to show Leonie how best to use it when Jeralt wasn’t available, though the redhead wasn’t especially receptive to what she saw as Byleth’s criticism of her skills.

 

As for Shez, she was grounded. No going into the village unless it was with Jeralt and she was completely locked down to the camp otherwise. Not that she protested much. She messed up, so she was willing to take her punishment. Even if it was a really boring one.

 

Besides, Leonie was still fun for her to spar with, so it wasn’t like she was completely bored.

 

Eventually though, the time to move on came,

 

“Are you sure you can’t stay for a little longer?” Leonie asked, pouting as she looked up at Jeralt. 

 

“Sorry kid, a merc has to make a living, and we still have to go receive our payment from the count.” Jeralt said, really not feeling good about making a kid sad. 

 

“Then let me come with you!”

 

“And who's gonna take care of your old man if you come with us?” Jeralt asked, making Leonie pause before she frowned. 

 

“Alright…”

 

“Hey, come on now! No need to be sad!” Shez said, trying to cheer her up. “There’ll always be a place for you here when you grow up!” 

 

“You’ll get really strong one day,” Byleth added.

 

“I-I’m already strong!”

 

“Even stronger.” Leonie really wasn’t sure if she was trying to cheer her up or not…

 

“Now then, before we leave, we did have some stuff we wanted to give you,” Jeralt said, nudging his kids forward a bit. 

 

“Oh, right! Here, it’s from Byleth and me!” Shez said with a grin, as she pulled out a training weight while Byleth pulled out a hunting dagger. 

 

“I hope you like it.” 

 

“O-Oh, thanks!” The training weight was very appreciated, though Leonie couldn’t help but wonder about the dagger. She already had one, even if it was an old one…

 

“And here, I made it myself.” Crouching down, Jeralt handed her a wooden charm, making Leonie beam. 

 

“Th-Thank you, Captain! I’ll make sure to take care of it!”

 

“Heh, don’t worry about it if you don’t. Just make sure to take care of yourself.” Jeralt said, with a slight smile. 

 

“Of course, Captain!” Leonie saluted, before looking at the two sisters. “I’ll make sure to keep you to that promise, Shez! And you better watch out Byleth! I’ll get strong enough to beat you!” 

 

“Looking forward to it,” Byleth said, her tone even as ever, though Shez did frown for a moment. 

 

As they left, Leonie began to tearfully wave them goodbye, as the family waved back, heading to where the gold may take them.

"She needs to get her own rival," Shez said a day after they had left Sauin Village, while she and Byleth waited for Jeralt to come back with the payment from the count. 

 

"Who does?" 

 

"Leonie! She's nice and all, but she was clearly trying to make you her rival and you're my rival!" Shez explained, clearly miffed. 

 

"Hm. It's okay, you're still my rival," Byleth said, patting her on the head, "And my little sister." 

 

"H-Hey, we still don't know if you really are the older one! Dad thought I was ten when we met, so he might be wrong about how old I am!"

 

“You don’t know how old you are. You might be ten.”

 

“It’s been a year! I’m definitely not ten!”

 

“Eleven then.”

 

Shez glared at her newly official sister, before glancing up when she noticed Jeralt walking back into camp. “Dad! Tell Byleth I’m not eleven!”

 

“...Hi to you too, Shez. Byleth, don’t tease your sister.”

 

“Okay. Why do you have a book?” Byleth asked, because Jeralt did indeed have a book under his arm. Two books, actually.

 

“I asked Count Gloucester if he knew anything about studying magic and he gave me them for free. Well, to be specific he said they were part of my pay, but he still gave me the full price in gold too, so it was a decent deal all around.”

 

“Oh wow. The count sounds super generous–Wait, why do you have magic books?” Shez asked.

 

“Because I figured it was about time to follow up on the fact that you know how to use magic. It might have taken a while, but better late than never, right?” 

 

"Really!?" Shez asked, suddenly very excited. 

 

"Yes, but you know the rules." 

 

"No practicing without supervision," Shez responded, having heard it plenty of times. 

 

"Good." He handed the books over. "Now, I hope you're ready for a march, cause we're headed to Empire territory." 

 

“Huh? Why are we going there?”

 

“Apparently we did a good enough job with those poachers near Sauin that Count Gloucester decided to help us out with some more work,” Jeralt answered, “He had some recommendations for what nobles might be looking for mercenaries.”

 

“Wow, he must really like you!”

 

“That or he wants some Empire nobles to owe him.” He shrugged. “Either way, it means more work for everyone, so let’s get to packing up.

 

“Sir yes sir!” Shez saluted, before scurrying over to show Byleth her new books. And then get to packing up afterwards, of course.

It wasn’t unusual for the Jeralt Mercenaries to be on the road. They were a traveling mercenary band, after all, but it was the first time they’d traveled from one nation to another while Shez was a part of their group, and the young girl was pretty excited to visit a brand new country.

 

Maybe overly excited, given how much she was pestering the other mercs for details on the Empire of Adrestia.

 

"Come on, come on, can't you tell me anything?" Shez asked as she flitted about the mercenaries. 

 

"You're gonna tire yourself out if you keep moving around like that." Jeralt said, glancing back at the still moving girl. 

 

“But I want to know about where we’re going! This is my first time out of the Alliance!" 

 

"Heh, guess you should take your kids out more," Victor said, teasing the captain from his place in the procession. 

 

"...Hey, aren't you from the empire?" 

 

"Hm? Yeah, I used to work in Hrym territory." 

 

"Good, you can answer all of Shez's questions," Jeralt said, essentially dropping his kid on the merc. 

 

"Oh, what's Hrym like?" Shez asked, practically bouncing on her feet. Sighing as he realized his mistake, Victor shrugged. 

 

"Well, don't expect much from it. Haven't been there since the emperor decided to wipe out the Hrym family."

 

"Huh?" 

 

"I was only a guard, so I don't know all the details, but House Hrym wanted to join the Alliance, and even tried to fight for its freedom. Course, the emperor wasn't happy about that and squashed them. I decided to get out of there before things got bad." The mercenary let out a chuckle as he remembered his past. "My only regret is that I didn't loot the place before leaving." 

 

"Don't make me smack you," Jeralt said with a sigh. 

 

"Heh, sorry boss. Anyways, where was I…oh yeah, after the Hrym house got squashed, the other nobles weren't that happy with the emperor, leading to them leading a revolt against him. Don't know all the details about that though, other than apparently the Duke von Aegir being in charge of Hrym now." 

 

"Oh wow, the empire seems like a messy place…" 

 

"Well, it's not all bad. There's the opera house in Enbarr for example. I only ever went to it when I was guarding a noble, but the shows there are great. There was this one diva in particular who was amazing, they called her the divine songstress. Should try to see if she's still around, especially if she's still as hot as before." 

 

That last comment got Jeralt to smack him on the back of his bald head. 

 

“Yeah alright, fair,” Victor conceded.

 

“What was it like being a guard?” Byleth asked. There was a slight hitch in the march as the mercenaries registered that the captain’s normally incurious kid actually asked a question unprompted. Even one of the horses glanced back at her.

 

“Ehh, not that interesting. I mostly patrolled the town, kept my eyes out for trouble, and took tons of bribes.”

 

“You were a corrupt guard??” Shez asked, sounding fascinated.

 

“Oh hilariously corrupt. I probably took more bribes than anyone else in the guard. Half the time I wound up getting conflicting bribes, like ‘don’t look this way’ from one guy and ‘do look that way’ from another, and I still took them.”

 

“...Wouldn’t you get in trouble for that?”

 

“Nah, I was never caught. I’ve got one of those faces nobody recognizes, which makes it really easy.”

 

“Victor, don’t teach my kids anything weird,” Jeralt warned.

 

“Hey, they’re asking. Actually, here’s something I can tell you squirts, coming from a veteran merc to a couple of novices.” He smirked slightly at seeing Shez immediately scowl, though the real delight was seeing Byleth shoot him an offended glare. “When it comes to the battlefield, always remember that nobles are always more valuable than commoners.”

 

“Huh? Wait, why?”

 

“Because nobles are worth way more as hostages.” That earned him another smack from Jeralt. “Aw, c’mon, that one’s actually good to know! Nobles get upset if some commoner kills one of their type, so going for the capture is just good for living long.” 

 

There were some noises of agreement from the other mercenaries and even Byleth looked thoughtful for a moment, though Shez still looked mullish.

 

“That’s not how you phrased that at all,” she complained, earning a laugh from the shifty merc.

 

“Don’t get into the mercenary business if you’re upset about shady business. Though, uh, boss, you remember that Duke guy I mentioned? Duke Aegir?”

 

“Yeah?”

 

“Don’t take jobs from him. That’s just my thoughts there. Man’s a snake.”

 

Jeralt gave him a glance. “I didn’t think you had principles.”

 

“I’ve got one, and that’s don’t get fuc–uh…” He glanced at Shez, then cleared his throat. “‘Don’t get cheated’, and he’s a cheat.”

 

“Hm…I’ll keep it in mind.”

 

“That’s all I’m asking.”

 

“How’s he a cheat?” Shez asked, earlier annoyance turning back to curiosity.

 

“Lots of reasons, squirt. Biggest is that, somehow, he winds up not only in charge of Hrym after the Emperor squashes the viscount, but is the guy to incite the insurrection. Sure, they say all six great houses were in on it, but it’s really funny he’s the one winding up on top every time something goes wrong.”

 

“Huh…hey, what are the great houses? And what do you mean by ‘insurrection’? How’s that work? And hey, why do some nobles have von in their names but others don’t–”

 

Victor glanced at the child pestering him with questions, then turned his gaze towards his captain, who utterly refused to meet his eyes. 

 

Jeralt loved his kids, but if he had the opportunity to have someone else answering Shez’s questions…well, he considered himself a generally decent guy. Not decent enough to step in here though.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: And so, we say goodbye to Leonie and the alliance for now, and head over to the empire!

Red: I wonder what we might see while everyone's over there? I'm sure nothing big has been happening lately.

Indi: Clearly, but if something does happen, hope y'all will stick around to see it!

Mastering Magic

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

“Okay! Make sure to watch carefully! Dad says you’re my spotter!” Shez called out to her sister, who was sitting on one end of the new camp’s sparring field. There were some mercenaries around, but most were busy with their dad, out hunting down a giant wolf pack for one of the lords living in the Empire’s northeast corner.

 

Byleth tilted her head from where she sat, then glanced at the book on the ground next to her, titled “The Beginnings of Sorcery, A Primer on Magic; Vol 1”. “Okay. I think you should read your book first.”

 

“Huh? Oh, that book. I can do that later! This is the magic book!” Shez held up the tome in her hands, a simple brown and gray book. It didn’t look magical, especially compared to the fancy bright red cover the primer had, which was even decorated with little silver flames in the corners.

 

“...If you say so.” Byleth decided to pick up the primer and sat it in her lap as she watched Shez proudly face off against a very fearsome straw dummy.

 

“Behold! The power of ice!” she declared, and thrusted her hand forward. A small puff of frost poofed from her palm. 

 

Byleth clapped, politely.

 

“D-Don’t clap! That wasn’t–That was supposed to be an ice blast…hm…Ice blast!” That time, she managed a tiny icicle that launched from her palm and impacted the ground. “...Okay, that was maybe better–Don’t clap! No clapping!”

 

Byleth paused, her hands in position to applaud, then lowered her hands to her lap again, where they rested on the book. She considered things, then cracked the book open. 

 

The beginning was simple enough. It said some things about magic being part of the natural world, then went into how there were two major “types” of magic, White and Black. White magic was based in Faith, and black magic was based in Reason. As for what that actually meant, apparently “Reason” was magic based on a person enforcing their will on the world while “Faith” was magic drawn from and empowered by the user’s faith in the goddess.

 

“Hm…Shez, what’s ‘the goddess’?”

 

“Huh?” Shez blinked at her sister, then waved her hand to scatter away the ice that had grown on her fingers. “Nh, that’s annoying…anyway, the goddess is the lady that created the whole world and everything in it.”

 

“Oh, okay. Do you need help?”

 

"I know what I'm doing! Mom taught me how to use magic!" 

 

"And how long ago was that?" 

 

"...A few years ago, but I'm good!" 

 

"Okay, do you mind if I read to myself?"

 

"Eh, sure, just make sure to keep watching me too!" Nodding in return, Byleth began to read while making sure to glance up as Shez kept practicing. 

 

While it seemed this book would mainly focus on reason magic, with a small note saying to purchase volume two for a focus on faith magic, it did give a description about the differences in magic. Such as where reason magic was about channeling the magic around you, faith was about channeling the magic within you. 

 

Continuing on, it explained that magic was a very step by step process, and that these primers would assist in shortening the time between those steps. 

 

"So I have to imagine the sigil first…" Byleth said aloud, acting like she was talking to herself instead of to Shez, whose current icicle broke apart before it could be launched.

 

“Huh? Uh…sigil…huh…” Shez mumbled, before deciding to open up her tome again, “Uhh…oh, okay, there’s different symbols…”

 

“‘In the common school of thought, Reason magic can be divided into four major elements,’” Byleth continued, “‘Each with their own symbology’…’These elements are commonly held to be Fire, Thunder, Wind, and Ice.’”

 

“Hmph, knew that part already…”

 

“Hey Shez, they have a picture of the common sigils on this page.”

 

“Huh?” Shez looked over at Byleth, who had held up the book to show the artistically drawn symbols in question, and despite herself, Shez immediately looked at the sigil for the most basic ice spell. “Oh, so that’s what it–Ah, w-whatever! They have fancy symbols in this book too!”

 

“I know, I just thought I would show you.”

 

Shez huffed, a little annoyed, before turning and raising a hand. “Hm…Ice!”

 

That time, a symbol started to form in front of Shez’s hand instead of just a shard of ice, but she still only managed a slightly larger puff of frost. “Mrrh…”

 

“‘To call upon each element properly, one must envisage the result they desire within their mind. Black magic draws upon the inherent magic of the world, and it must be channeled properly’...Huh, that’s interesting. It says for ice magic, you need to draw on feelings of the cold, and it works best for people already familiar with the concept.” Byleth glanced up at Shez, who was pretending not to listen, and then back at the book. “Also the most basic ice spell is called Blizzard.”

 

“Hm…okay…” Shez thought back, picturing cold winters on the mountains she came from, and held her hand out, keeping both that thought and the image of the sigil in her mind. “...Blizzard!”

 

In a flash of white and blue light, the dummy was both frozen and pierced as spikes of ice erupted up from the point the spell hit.

 

“Ah! I did it…I DID IT! BYLETH, I DID IT!” Shez yelled, a bright, happy smile on her face at the gruesome demise of the unfortunate training dummy.

 

“Good, I knew you could.”

 

Shez’s face reddened before she smiled even brighter. She promptly hurried over to her older sister and grabbed her wrist to pull her up. “Okay now you do it!”

 

“Huh?”

 

“Yeah! I want to see what you can do!”

 

“...I haven’t tried to use magic before.”

 

“Yeah, and? I want to see what you can do!”

 

Byleth tilted her head in thought, then nodded. She had no idea what she was doing, so she might as well give it a try. “Okay. Can I have your tome? The primer says having a focus helps.”

 

“Oh, sure!” Shez happily handed it over, before “subtly” taking the primer from Byleth in return so she could start pouring through it.

 

Byleth felt her lips twitch in some amusement at the sight, before she faced off against one of the less frozen dummies on the field. She wasn’t completely sure what she was doing, but the primer said all mages had an “inherent affinity” for one element or another. The easiest way to figure out what it was was to just relax and think of what came naturally.

 

So as Byleth stretched out her hand and closed her eyes, she found herself picturing flames. The warmth of the campfire beside her dad and Shez, the heat of summer bearing down on her, and the first time she saw a building lit ablaze by bandits.

 

“Fire,” she intoned, and she opened her eyes as a crimson sigil formed in front of her hand and a ball of pure flames erupted from it, impacting the dummy and blowing it apart entirely into flaming scraps of cloth and straw. “Huh.”

 

“WOAH!” Shez exclaimed, eyes bright with excitement.

 

“Ah shit!” yelped a nearby mercenary who had most definitely just been working nearby and not surreptitiously ordered by the girls’ father to keep an eye on their practice so they didn’t set the camp on fire.

 

If he did do that though, such foresight would’ve been very fortuitous, as the mercenary managed to douse the flames before they could set anything ablaze.

 

Suffice to say, Byleth and Shez got a bit of a lecture on fire safety.

“Huh. Apparently ice magic used to be considered a type of wind magic,” Byleth noted, reading from the primer again while Shez continued practicing blasting some slightly hardier wooden dummies with ice shards. Byleth wasn’t allowed to keep practicing with those yet, mostly because Dalton, the merc that was supervising but pretending not to be, was pretty sure wood would be even worse to set on fire.

 

“What? Why?” Shez asked, half-distracted, which wound up sending the ice spike flying off into the tree line. “Oh, oops.”

 

“Careful! Gertrude can fix a lot but she can’t bring an eye back if you stab it out!” Dalton called from where he was sitting and whittling some figurines. Byleth made a mental note of that; if Shez was right and she was going to take over the band someday, she should know what her troops did for hobbies, right? 

 

Hm…should she ask when Dalton’s birthday was? It might be nice to get him something–

 

“Hey! By! What do you mean about the ice thing?” Oh, right.

 

Byleth glanced at Shez. “I think it’s because wind is cold. Or something like that. There's also something about some people thinking the ‘elements’ line up to the Saints…hm. Dalton, what are the saints?”

 

“Eh? Wait, how do you not know–No, wait…yeah, okay, I guess it would make sense you don’t know. Your pops doesn’t like the church much and everyone would probably assume you already know…” The mercenary shrugged. “The Four Saints are the followers of Saint Seiros, who saved Fodlan from the evil king Nemesis a thousand years ago. They helped found the empire and did a bunch of other important stuff.”

 

“Oh, okay.” That made sense to her. She didn’t know who Seiros or Nemesis were, but she could ask her dad later. 

 

“So what was that about the saints and the elements?” Shez asked.

 

“Just a side note about them being associated in religious texts. It’s not very specific. There’s also some stuff about dark magic, which I guess isn’t regular Reason magic.”

 

“It isn’t? Why not?”

 

“Cause it’s dark,” Dalton spoke up, “Speaking as somebody who’s actually gone up against a dark mage, dark magic’s nasty. It’s all about causing pain and doing damage above everything else. Though, I guess that’s true of all black magic? But you can use fire to light a fire, so…”

 

He trailed off, thinking, while Byleth continued to read. “‘Dark magic is not inherently evil, though some hold it to be the natural opposite of the light of the goddess. Where light may heal as well as harm, darkness is meant solely to damage and thus is the favored art of spellcasters intent on reaching new heights of power and destruction’.”

 

“Oooooo, that sounds really cool!” Shez immediately said.

 

"Well, even if it sounds cool, you should be careful. That type of magic can also be called curse magic, and I don't know about you two, but that seems like it can backfire." Dalton piped in as he finished a figurine. "And even then, it's pretty rare. The church isn't exactly a fan of it, so it's not easy to find info on it." 

 

"Aw, seriously?" 

 

"Yeah, it's not exactly banned, but it’s frowned on.” 

 

"Hm." Frowning a bit, Shez focused back on the dummy and began to think. 

 

"Shez?" A bit confused, Byleth looked up at her younger sister as she stood there for a moment, before seeing Shez raise her hand. And, rather than the white sigil that appeared before, a purple one appeared and a single, dark spike launched forward, missing the dummy as it lodged itself into a tree. 

 

"Yes! By, look! I did–" Was as far as Shez got before the spike suddenly exploded, sending chunks of wood flying all over as the three of them instinctively ducked. 

 

After a second, Dalton popped his head up first. He stared at the blackened ruin of what once was a decently sized tree. The wood wasn’t even burnt, that he could see; it looked more like it had somehow been leached of life, leaving behind withered, dried wood where it was struck.

 

A second later, Byleth took a look, followed by a sheepish-looking Shez. 

 

Dalton stared at the ruin for a few more seconds, then looked at the purple-haired girl, who winced and ducked her head. “...You know I’m going to have to tell your pops about this, right?”

 

“...do you have to?”

 

He looked back at the blown apart tree. A butterfly landed on one of the pieces of blackened wood and immediately turned to dust. “Yeah. Might need to get a priest too…”

 

Suffice to say, again, Shez was banned from using dark magic after Jeralt got back.

 

Though, when he did get back, the captain/namesake of Jeralt’s Mercenaries had some interesting news to report.

 

“We’re going to be heading to Enbarr for a bit.”

 

“Enbarr? The huge city?” Shez asked over dinner, staring at her adoptive father in curiosity and confusion.

 

“Yeah, the capital of the Empire. We’re going to be escorting a merchant caravan. I wouldn’t normally bring us around a capital, too much chance of getting caught up in some noble, royal, or imperial nonsense, but it’s paying a lot and…” He looked sad for a second, at least to Byleth’s eyes, before he tried to smile. “It’s something I’ve wanted to do. I hope you two don’t mind–”

 

“No way!” Shez beamed, eager and enthusiastic. “This is going to be great! I’ve never been to a city, and especially not a capital! I heard Derdriu, back in the Alliance, is enormous! Oh, but it’s by the water and–Wait, is Enbarr by water?”

 

Byleth watched her younger sister launch into another volley of questions for their exasperated father and felt a slight smile come to her face. She was getting better at those these days. Though…she felt a little curious for once. Why did her father look sad? What was in Enbarr that he wanted to do?

 

…Did it have something to do with her mother?

 

She hadn’t asked more after learning her mother’s name. It looked like it hurt her father to talk about, and she was content to know that little bit about her, but…if there was a chance Sitri had something to do with Jeralt’s melancholy, then Byleth was going to find out about it.

 

It just felt right to do.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: The wonders of magic! Which can be quite dangerous.

Red: Always practice magic responsibly, kids. Otherwise you might kill things accidentally instead of on purpose.

Indi: Or at the very least cause some property damage.

Red: Which is why you should always have a minder/spotter on hand, just in case.

Indi: Though gotta be careful, who knows, they might snitch on you

The Operatic Operation

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

The Empire was certainly interesting. It felt more…imposing than the Alliance. Something about the architecture, the people, the land itself…the air felt almost intense as their band traveled along with the merchant caravan they were hired to protect.

 

Byleth hadn't been paying much attention to the overly similar villages when they were in Leicester, but Adrestia definitely had her attention. It might have something to do with the insurrection that happened a few years ago, but she noticed there were several armed knights on patrol along the roads, especially around as they neared the major cities of the Empire. Major cities like Enbarr. 

 

It was the first time she had been in a capital city. The buildings were big and blocky, and some of them felt strangely ancient. The whole city had a feeling of age to it. Old, but strong. And completely filled with people.

 

She felt overwhelmed from the moment they entered, and when she heard that her father decided she and Shez had to stick by him if they wanted to walk around, she was thankful. 

 

Granted, they couldn't really do that when he was getting drunk, such as the previous night.

 

That wasn't the important point though. What was important was what he had mentioned when he was drunk. When she had gone to check on him, she had overheard him talking with another mercenary, where he mentioned he had been planning on traveling to Enbarr before, specifically to the opera with Sitri. To the Mittlefrank Opera Company, the place Victor had mentioned, the one with the “Divine Songstress”. They wanted to go, but then Sitri died, so it never happened.

 

As such, Byleth decided that not only she would disobey her father, she would go out with only shez, so they could buy tickets for the opera as a surprise for him! 

 

"Are you sure you know where to go?" Shez asked as they walked the streets of the capital. 

 

"Yeah, I made sure to get directions." Byleth's answer did little to ease Shez as they continued to walk, the younger sibling continuing to glance around. "You okay?" 

 

"Ah…yeah, just feeling kinda weird you know? Some of the people around here are strange." 

 

"How so?" 

 

"Well…you ever just look at someone and they just give you the chills?" 

 

"No." 

 

"Ah…well, can we just hurry up then?" 

 

Byleth nodded and took Shez’s hand, earning an annoyed noise from the purple-haired girl. “You don’t need to hold my hand.”

 

“I do if you’re nervous. Papa–...Jeralt did that for me, so I’m going to do it for you.”

 

“...Why’d you call him Jeralt?”

 

“I should be professional. We’re family, but he’s also my captain, so I need to get used to being professional when we’re around important people.”

 

“Huh. Alright.” Shez shrugged that off, though Byleth could feel her tense for some reason. The blue-haired teen gave a small glance around the crowd. 

 

There were a lot of people walking around, but the clothes in general were nicer than she was used to seeing. Lots of people wore those square hats scholars had, there were plenty of guards in full plate and even heavy armor, and most people were wearing the crimson colors of the empire. Even the clearly poorer citizens in brown or beige clothing seemed to like adding a splash of red to their clothes in the form of sashes or belts to mark their allegiance.

 

Then there were the strange people in black clothes and bird masks. Those did stand out. 

 

That didn’t necessarily mean they were evil and the reason Shez was getting a bad feeling, but Byleth did make a mental note of them. 

 

"Greetings, you lovely young ladies." Cut in a voice, breaking Byleth from her thoughts. Looking over, she saw a man who seemed somewhat older than the two of them, who was likely a noble with how well made his clothes were. "Would you care to join me for some tea?" 

 

"We're busy." 

 

“Too busy for tea? I’m sure that cannot really be true. Tell me, what are two lovely young ladies doing out on their own anyway? Running errands for your parents, perhaps?” He smiled. It looked unpleasant. “Perhaps I could assist you?”

 

Byleth moved in front of Shez. She was being quiet, and Byleth could tell she was still tense. “I must respectfully decline, sir.”

 

“It would be ‘my lord’, not sir.” The man held his arms behind his back and smiled again. Now that Byleth was seeing it, she knew what Shez meant about a smile not reaching someone’s eyes. “And I decline your declination. Allow me to be clear, young lady. Either we finish this conversation with you accepting my offer, or I, a nobleman of the noble house Korsch, will call the guards with evidence that you have stolen from me. As you seem woefully ignorant to how things work here, I will be blunt and state they will believe me over you every time.”

 

Byleth nodded. “Understood.”

 

Then in one smooth motion, she drew the dagger from her waist and drove it up through the soft part of the man’s abdomen.

 

His eyes bulged, but she pulled back and stabbed up again, harder, before pulling the knife back and wiping it on the nobleman’s coat. She took Shez’s hand and walked away with her in tow. She kept her ear out to see if “Lord Korsch” managed to say anything, but all she heard were some desperate, pained gasps before he collapsed and a nearby woman screamed.

 

She turned towards the scream, affecting a look of curiosity at the sight of a nobleman bleeding out on the ground, and when the guards quickly came by, one was nice enough to hurry her from the scene with a mention that it was something “children shouldn’t see”.

 

“Good work looking disturbed,” Byleth complimented as she walked away with Shez.

 

“...I…how did you do that?”

 

“Don’t ask too many questions while we’re still in public,” she cautioned, before glancing up at her taller, yet still younger sister. “He was dangerous.”

 

“Yeah, but…you just…did that? Without hesitating at all? A-And how didn’t we get caught??”

 

“I’m still not that tall.” For some reason, that admission felt…annoying? “He wasn’t especially big, but he blocked the view of the nearest guards instead of keeping them in his line of sight. He probably knew they wouldn’t approve, so his first instinct was to hide what he was doing. His words implied he knew what he was doing though, so I think this wasn’t his first time trying something like this. Either way, I’m wearing dark clothes right now, so there was less of a chance of any blood spatter showing up. The second stab was risky though. I should have been more careful even if his clothes were thick enough to catch most of it.”

 

Shez blinked at her. “...Uh…huh. Do you…think about things like that a lot?”

 

Byleth shrugged. It was a little stiff. She wasn’t used to shrugging. “I listen to people. I’m not good at interacting with them, so I just listen to the mercenaries in camp sometimes. Ezra used to be a ‘hired knife’ before he did official mercenary work, so I asked him to show me the best places for stabbing someone. He likes violets, so I gave him one and he was fine with the idea.”

 

“...you bribed one of dad’s mercs to show you how to stab people better?”

 

“Yes.”

 

“...Why?”

 

“In case something like this happened.”

 

Shez stared at her. She didn’t let go, and she didn’t stop walking, so things were probably fine. “Huh. You’re gripping my hand kind of tight, By.”

 

“Oh, sorry.” She loosened her grip and glanced up at her sister. “Better?”

 

Shez smiled. It reached her eyes. “Much! Hey, so where’s this opera place anyway? We’ve been walking for a while.”

 

“It shouldn’t be much farther. We need to buy ‘tickets’ first. I don’t know why we can’t just pay at the door, but that’s what Candace said.”

 

“Do you know everyone’s names?”

 

“I try to. You said I’m going to lead when Jeralt retires. So I’m going to be a good captain and know everyone.”

 

“Heh, sounds good to me! It might be hard to do when we get more people though. Oh, and just for the record, that’s twice you’ve saved me now.”

 

“Hm? Hm…yeah, it is.”

 

“That means you’re ahead of me, and I’m going to have to catch up!” Shez stated, clenching her free hand into a fist as she smiled. “So you better be ready! Next time, I’m saving your life!”

 

“...Okay.”

 

Her smile dropped into an annoyed look. “Feh. I’m not going to say you should be more excited, but I can tell when you’re just humoring me!”

 

“I don’t know what you’re talking about.”

 

“You do! You totally do! You’re smiling right now!”

 

Huh. So she was.

Jeralt sighed. “I really shouldn’t be encouraging this. I told you two to stick by me when you wanted to go out into the city and you completely ignored that.”

 

“Yeah, but it turned out fine!” Shez said, her hand in Jeralt’s as she and Byleth pulled him along, “We got fancy opera tickets and there wasn’t even any trouble!”

 

“There was some trouble,” Byleth admitted, her hand also in Jeralt’s. 

 

He gave her a glance. “What kind of trouble?”

 

“Trouble. I can explain more later.”

 

He sighed. “Trouble you can’t discuss in public then, sure. Alright, I’ll keep quiet for now. You two need to be careful though, this is a dangerous city. From what I’ve been hearing, some noble was even knifed earlier today.”

 

“O-Oh, uh, yeah, heh, uh, that’s something that did happen, yup,” Shez muttered, looking nervous.

 

“...Kids, please tell me you didn’t knife a noble.”

 

“W-What? Uh, um…”

 

“We didn’t knife a noble,” Byleth stated, before pulling him more insistently, “Come on. We have to be there for the opera.”

 

Jeralt felt like he should follow up on that, if just to make sure his kids weren’t about to get arrested. “...Why are you so insistent on going to the opera anyway?”

 

"You didn't get to go before." 

 

"Huh?" 

 

"I heard you talking yesterday, when you were drunk." No longer pulling at him to follow, Byleth looked up at Jeralt. "You wanted to go with mom, but weren't able to." 

 

"...Starting to think you two kids are too good for me."  

 

"Heh, the best dad deserves the best kids, no?" Shez said, smiling up at him. 

 

"Is that your way of saying you're going to behave from now on?"

 

"Eeeh… let's not get ahead of ourselves now." 

 

"I guess that's the best I'll get." 

 

"It will, now come on, we gotta move, these tickets were expensive, so they have to be good seats!" 

 

There were, in fact, no seats at all. While the Mittlefrank Opera Company was indeed open to the public, there was a difference between the noble and commoner sections. Nobles had booths above the commoners, their own private sections where they could enjoy the play in comfort. The commoners, meanwhile, had an open area in front of the stage that they were meant to crowd around in. And since many of them had been waiting around before the opera had started, it meant the three of them were near the back. 

 

Frowning, Shez did her best to look over the shoulders of the people in front of her, barely able to glance over, while Byleth had already resigned herself to being unable to see. 

 

"Alright, get on up," Jeralt said, grabbing onto the two to lift them up onto his shoulders. 

 

"H-Hey, what are you doing?" Shez asked, clearly embarrassed as she tried to steady herself. 

 

"It'd be a shame if we came all the way here and you two weren't able to see anything. This old man can at least hold you two up for the show." He might be getting older, but he was still strong enough to give his girls the best view he could give.

 

Byleth, meanwhile, seemed pleased at being able to see the stage, especially as the performance had begun. The narrator began to speak, telling everyone about the tale of love and tragedy that was about to begin. The story of two young lovers forced to fight on opposite sides. 

 

And while Byleth couldn't follow the story completely, she couldn't help but feel…sad as it went on. It was the tale of a young knight and a noblewoman, the daughter of a viscount, who first met as students at a monastery. The two became close, first friends then lovers, joined together under the same house, yet the knight lived in service to a baron who hated the lady’s family. The feud had lasted long, but only came to true blows after one insult too many saw the baron’s son dead and the viscount blamed.

 

The baron, who treated the knight as a son, was wounded by the viscount in the battle that followed, and the knight, in an attempt to defend his lord, killed the viscount then and there. Stained with the blood of his lover’s father, then young man was hailed as a hero and adopted into the baron’s family, yet the noble lady, now a viscountess, burned with hatred for she knew not the name of the man who murdered her father, merely that he was a knight adopted by her family’s most hated foe.

 

Banners were called in vengeance and the lady took the field. This time, the baron was slain and his castle sieged as the vengeful viscountess called for the head of her father’s murderer.

 

The knight, now a new baron, decided the only way to soothe the flames of her hate was to face her in such a duel. Armored fully, his identity hidden, he declared he would fight, if only she would spare those of his household. But no, she spat, she would never rest until she saw all of the Baron’s blood dead and buried.

 

And thus, the duel was fought, and the knight did die.

 

Only when he was struck down did the viscountess remove his helm, intent on seeing the face of her father’s murderer and only finding the visage of the man she loved instead.

 

The final song was her elegy for the lives lost in hatred, and a promise that never would she seek the end of the baron’s line, for though hate burned hot, vengeance was cold and empty.

 

And the curtains came to a close as the fire illuminating the stage was slowly put out. Silence fell upon the opera house, before it was suddenly broken by thunderous applause from the audience. The lights came back on as the curtains rose, the actors lining up to bow together as flowers began to get thrown at the stage. 

 

The actress playing the heroine in specific got a lot of attention, apparently someone called Dorothea, “the Mystical Songstress”, based on what everyone around them was saying. Despite how far they were from the stage, Byleth couldn't help but notice that, without the veil covering her face, she looked much younger than Byleth had assumed, as if she wasn’t much older than her. 

 

Though before she could look for much longer, she felt her father set her down, the older mercenary letting out a grunt as he rubbed his shoulders. 

 

"Didn't expect for the play to be that long," Jeralt said as they were let out. "Did you girls enjoy that?" 

 

"Yeah, it was nice, I guess?” Shez replied, “I didn't really understand what was happening, but the singing was nice! Oh, and so was the swordplay!" 

 

"It was very nice, but sad," Byleth said as they headed out of the opera house. "The lead actress was pretty." 

 

"...Huh?" Jeralt and Shez both asked, completely stopping in their tracks. 

 

"Hm?" Glancing back, Byleth tilted her head in confusion. "Is something wrong?" 

 

“No, no, it’s just–”

 

“You think she’s pretty??” Shez asked, an odd grin creeping up her face.

 

“Yeah? She’s pretty. She has a nice voice too.”

 

Shez’s smile was far too wide. Jeralt, meanwhile, let out a sigh. “Right, never thought this day would actually come…”

 

“...You two are acting weird,” Byleth noted, before turning to head back to the camp. 

 

“Hey so what else do you like about the singer girl?” Shez asked as she walked next to her sister, keeping pace and still smiling at her.

 

“Hm? Um…she has nice hair.”

 

“What else??”

 

“...Why are you asking?”

 

“Because you like her! You think she’s pretty!”

 

“Oh. Yeah, I guess. I don’t know her though.”

 

“Yeah but that’s how it starts in all the books! You see a pretty girl from afar, your heart starts beating fast and your face gets red and then–”

 

“Alright Shez, don’t pester your sister,” Jeralt said, putting a hand on her shoulder and steering her away from Byleth.

 

“Aw! But this is big! Byleth never said anyone was pretty before, this is definitely important!” She peeked around her dad, looking at her bemused sister. “Hey By, you should get her a flower! Oh, what kind of flowers do you think she’d like?”

 

“...I don’t understand what’s going on right now.”

 

“We can talk back at camp,” Jeralt said, “In fact, you two still need to tell me what trouble you had to deal with.”

 

And Shez’s smile immediately dropped. “Uh…heh, um, maybe we should keep talking about–”

 

She tried to pull away and Jeralt’s grip tightened. Not too hard, but enough to keep her moving along with him instead of scurrying off. “Come on Byleth. We can talk about your interest in girls afterwards.”

 

“Oh, okay.” That seemed strange to talk about, but alright. Were girls even that interesting?

 

Byleth considered the question as she headed back to camp with her family, and found her thoughts drifting back to that girl on stage. She was kind of interesting, now that she considered it…Hm. 

 

Something to think about later.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Hey Dorothea got to cameo! Shame Manuela already joined the academy as an instructor at this point.

Red: Yeah it's a funny thing, actually checking through the game's timeline to make sure we know when certain things happen. It means sometimes some people can show up while others are unfortunately out of the picture.

Indi: Such as a certain princess, sadly

Red: Yup yup. Well hey, maybe we can do something nice for her in the future.

Indi: Perhaps, but for now, hope y'all enjoyed the chapter!

Red: Thanks for reading! Also, told ya that graphic violence warning would be relevant.

So Your Daughter Murdered a Noble

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

So. So. So so so.

 

So Jeralt’s kids had murdered a noble in broad daylight.

 

More specifically, a creepy, predatory noble had accosted his girls in the middle of the city, a thought that nearly caused Jeralt’s hand to crush the mug he was holding in his grip as he recalled Byleth’s description of events, and his quiet, thoughtful, unemotional kid had driven a knife into the creep’s stomach. Twice, for good measure.

 

Now, Jeralt was not a man opposed to killing. He would be the largest hypocrite in the entire world if he said he was. He was, however, well aware that certain people were considered less okay to murder than others. Bandits and outlaws might have been anyone before they decided to take up theft as their career path, but that choice of theirs meant they were fair game to any merc looking to make some coin off of their bounty.

 

Nobles, on the other hand…They weren’t off-limits, not on the battlefield where anyone could die from a stray arrow or bolt, but Victor wasn’t wrong when he said nobles got upset at their own dying. And one of their own dying in the middle of their capital city, where they should be safe?

 

He let out a slow sigh, then glanced to the side as a scruffy, brown-haired man in leathers and a cloak sat beside him. “Well?”

 

“Well no one’s pointing to your girls as possible suspects, at least around the lowdown types,” Ezra said, raising a hand to call the bartender over, “I made a few suggestions that this Korsch guy ran afoul of someone with means to act on a grudge, in case it helps. Apparently he was a shifty type to begin with, the brother of some count’s vassal doing the usual brown-nosing courtier stuff.”

 

“Hm…did he work in one of the ministries?”

 

“I think so, but as a paper pusher at best. Might need to wait until Vic gets here to be sure, but little By didn’t pick the worst way of doing things. A noble gets stabbed in broad daylight and it’s not obvious who did it, people assume an assassin, not a kid.”

 

“Right. Don’t I have you to thank for her knowing how to do that?”

 

Ezra shrugged as he received his mug of mead. “Well if you want to actually thank me, I won’t say no, captain.”

 

Jeralt just sighed, massaging the bridge of his nose. “...Thank you for teaching Byleth how to gut a potential threat and get away with it. You’re still in deep shit for things turning out like this.”

 

“I can accept that. Worse comes to worse, blame it on me.”

 

“I’m not doing that.”

 

“One man can get away a lot easier than a whole band, captain.” Left unsaid was how unlikely it was that man could survive on his own, hunted by the Imperials.

 

“And I said that’s not going to happen. You’re not going to the noose for helping. I might break your jaw later though. Just a warning.”

 

“Thank you for the forewarning, captain. And hey, at least I’d get to spend more time with Gertie if you do.”

 

Jeralt raised an eyebrow. “Really? You and her?”

 

“Maybe? We’re seeing how it goes–Oh, hey, there’s Vic.”

 

Jeralt turned his gaze towards the second of his mercs he’d sent out. The bald, bearded man looked surprisingly weary, and didn’t greet him as he sat down and ordered an ale. Jeralt waited for him to down the drink before he spoke up, despite the sudden tension he felt in his shoulders. “Bad news?”

 

“Terrible news…ah, not about the girls though, that turned out better than I thought.”

 

Jeralt felt some tension ease, though he still frowned. “You mind explaining?”

 

“Right, I asked some of the guards. Subtly, of course–”

 

Ezra snorted and Victor shot him a look. 

 

“...Gonna ignore that. Anyway, I asked, from one former corrupt guard to some currently corrupt guards, what the story was with the stabbed noble. We’re mercs, we get interested if there’s coin to be made on vengeance missions. Now, half the guys I asked had no idea what I was asking about, and the other half barely gave a damn. Yeah, there was some talk of a minor noble being stabbed, but only four guys even knew his name, and when I asked for details, an account of me being a curious guy who likes to know the gory stuff, one guy tells me he’s sure it’s some gang with this weird scorpion mark, another thinks it’s some inter-ministry business, and the third’s blaming it on a jealous lover. As for Mister Four, he tells me a bit about what he saw and even mentions pushing two kids away from the scene, but he’s convinced it was done by someone from Brigid!”

 

Jeralt blinked. “...The island?”

 

“Yeah! Well, I think it’s an archipelago when it’s a bunch of islands, but yeah! Only one guy remembers there being kids anywhere nearby, and he didn’t even consider they could’ve done it. Now we could still kill him if we have to–”

 

“We’re not doing that.”

 

“Yeah that’s a shit idea,” Ezra said, “They’ve already got explanations for why this noble died, we kill a guard and suddenly it looks like a cover up and people will start looking.”

 

“...Ah, damn, that’s true.”

 

“Okay, so the girls might be in the clear,” Jeralt noted, relaxing a little. He did give Victor another curious look though. “What’s the terrible news you were talking about?”

 

“Oh, that. Right, so, you know how the insurrection happened a few years back? And Duke Aegir’s been holding the reins ever since?”

 

“Right?”

 

“Well, just a few days ago, the new imperial heir was announced.”

 

Jeralt blinked. “The new heir? They needed a new one?”

 

“Yeah, see, the Imperial Family has been under house arrest since the insurrection, right? The emperor and his kids were all under the ‘dutiful protection’ of the Prime Minister while things were settled. And that stupid bastard somehow let them all die.”

 

“...What?”

 

Victor sighed, nursing his drink. “They’re saying a plague hit the palace. Somehow, some way, the heirs caught it and started dropping like flies. Like that shit in Faerghus. We’re talking about eleven princes and princesses, all completely healthy before this, and all except one of them dies. The new crown princess, Edelgard von Hresvelg.”

 

“Goddess,” Ezra cursed, his brow furrowed, “All but one of them? How does that even…Saints, that’s insane.”

 

“You’re telling me. I can’t say I have a lot of love for the Emperor for what he did to Hrym, but Saints and Stars, his kids didn’t deserve that. Not that it’s stopping some pricks from saying the goddess sent the plague as divine punishment.”

 

Ezra leaned back in visible disgust while Jeralt let out a sigh. He tried not to think of his own kids. “...Aegir didn’t have anything to do with it, did he?”

 

Victor scoffed. “Don’t get me wrong, captain. I hate the guy as much as anyone, but he’d be deranged to let the imperial heirs die. He’s got his own boy and all the rest of the ministers have heirs and spares. The smart thing to do would’ve been to divvy them up, guarantee a royal marriage to anyone going along with his plans and tie their families to the Hresvelgs tight enough that the imperials would never get loose. Letting them die, or, Goddess forbid, killing them himself would’ve been shooting an arrow straight in his own foot. This is as bad for him as it is for anyone else.”

 

“Hm. Well, it’s not like we could do much even if he was involved.”

 

“Amen. Bastard should at least have the courtesy to resign in disgrace though. Hell, I’m surprised I haven’t heard about Marquis Vestra killing himself. Then again, the rat did turn on the emperor to begin with, so I doubt he will.”

 

“Does the Marquis usually kill themself if something happens to the royal family?” Ezra asked.

 

“Imperial family, and there’s a pretty famous story about it, actually. One prince a Vestra was sworn to died in battle and the Marquis burned himself alive in penance. After killing and flaying the men responsible, of course.”

 

“...Adrestians are insane.”

 

“Hey, Faerghans ain’t much better!”

 

“Don’t start this again,” Jeralt warned the two. 

 

Victor grunted. “Fine. Still, we should probably move on, captain. Aside from it just being a good idea in general to not be near the scene of the crime, we’re probably not gonna see a lot of work around here. All the nobles will be focused on getting favor with the new crown princess, and we can’t help with that.”

 

“Yeah, I suppose…Do you know how she is?”

 

“Heh. Being a dad does soften you up some, huh?”

 

Jeralt just gave him a flat stare.

 

“You know, I can actually see the resemblance between you and Byleth when you do that. Anyway, the poor girl’s apparently still sickly. Her hair’s all white and the Duke ain’t letting her out of his sight. Or at least not the palace. Probably doesn’t want his last shot to pass away.”

 

Jeralt felt like sighing, but…at the end of the day, there just wasn’t anything he could do. The princess might have it rough, but she wasn’t his problem. “Alright. Come on, let’s get going. Ezra, you’re paying.”

 

“Wait, what?”

 

“Consider it a way to make things up to me.” He pushed himself up from the bar and headed out to leave, ignoring the way Victor stuck his tongue out at Ezra. Somehow, his kids were the least childish people he had to deal with on a day to day basis…

 

Still, even if his men didn’t think there was a problem, a part of him still felt some concern that the death of a noble would suddenly catch attention, even interest. That someone would see this sudden death and decide it needed justice. And it was a truly terrifying thing to think of “justice” being aimed at his kids…

 

Fortunately for Jeralt and his nerves though, the news of Lord Korsch’s death was completely covered in the following week by something far more important.

 

Dagda and Brigid had just formed an alliance, and invaded Adrestia.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Man those plagues that only affects the Imperial family sure are a heck of a thing

Red: A true tragedy that so many people died by complete accident and definitely not deliberate murder through human experimentation.

Indi: Clearly, and that would be horrible. Ah well, nothing Jeralt could do about it, best get out of there.

Red: Such is the trouble of being part of the commoner class when bad things happen. You really don't get much of a chance to make an impact.

Indi: well, unless you have the right connections, but what are the chances of Byleth or Shez getting connections to a bunch of nobles.

Red: What are the chances indeed...anyways, thanks for reading!

Time for War

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Shez had never actually experienced a war. She’d been in fights, sure, and she’d seen skirmishes, but wars were different. Wars were bigger. 

 

Wars meant, even if you weren't involved, you would get dragged into it. 

 

After what had happened in the capital, Jeralt had decided to play it safe and lay low for a bit. Which meant when the war began, they weren't near any of the major cities, and as such did not know it had started. Until one day, when they were packing up camp, a group of Brigid soldiers, a scouting party as Jeralt would later describe them, stumbled upon their camp.

 

The next few moments descended into utter chaos as Dalton, the closest person to them, noticed some were injured and approached to ask if they needed help. His goodwill was met with a sword to the chest. 

 

Shez couldn't tell exactly what happened after that, other than a lot of blood was shed. Even Shez and Byleth were unable to stay out of it, as the duo found themselves crossing swords with a soldier, who seemed surprised that two young girls were able to keep up with them. 

 

Byleth lunged in, deflecting the tanned man’s sword and attempting to stab straight through him, but he was surprisingly quick and moved back before the blade could land. Shez watched for a moment as her sister fought the foreign soldier, who moved with a nimble quickness she hadn’t seen before, when she noticed another man of Brigid pin Ezra to the ground and raise a knife.

 

She was moving before she knew it, swinging her blade down at the Brigid man’s head, but he moved quickly, just like his friend, and lunged for her, stabbing forward rapidly with the sword in his other hand. 

 

Shez felt herself falling back, trying to keep steady under a flurry of blows as Ezra yelled something. She thought she saw him trying to get up, but his leg was bleeding, and Shez was on her own. 

 

She wasn’t scared, she was sure she could handle it, but each blow jarred her arms and she was getting pushed back more and more as the man sported a jaunty smile. “I am respecting your skill, girl. I will give you a death that is quick.”

 

And suddenly his other hand came around, the knife stabbing straight for her eye, and when she raised her sword to block it, his sword…hit something.

 

Shez blinked, then coughed. She couldn’t–Something happened to the air in her lungs and she couldn’t–

 

“Shh. Spirits shall take you now. Lay you to rest,” the man said, before pulling back his sword, dripping with blood, and swinging it straight for her head.

 

Not yet. You’re not dying yet.

 

His sword never reached her head. He stumbled back, blown by a sudden force as Shez felt strong, stronger than she’d ever felt before.

 

The man said something, something she didn’t recognize, and it felt warm all around her. There was something glowing by her head and another sword in her hand and she moved without thinking, a scream erupting from her mouth as she cleaved the man in half.

 

And then she passed out.

Shez blinked awake sometime later, in…the infirmary tent, from what she could tell. She’d been in there enough times to recognize it. Her shirt was off and she could feel bandages around her chest, which was weird because she felt fine. Maybe still a little sleepy?

 

There was a strange feeling for a moment there, as though something tried to well up, before it suddenly receded, leaving her…more confused than anything.

 

She sat up, then paused when she noticed Byleth was by her bed, her eyes closed as she rested on a chair. The blue-haired girl was holding a sheathed sword in her arms, for some reason, and as Shez leaned over to poke her face, her eyes immediately opened. “...Oh, good, you’re awake.”

 

Shez leaned back as Byleth suddenly thrust a canteen in her face. “Drink.”

 

Now that she was thinking about it, she was really thirsty…So after downing as much water as she could in one go, then going back for some more, Shez finally felt that her mouth and throat were no longer dry and she could speak just fine!

 

“So what happened? Did we win?”

 

“I don’t think the camp would still be standing if we lost.”

 

“Oh, yeah, that is kind of a stupid question…Um, where’s dad?”

 

“Talking with the Varley man.”

 

“The who now?”

 

“A knight from some nearby noble, Count Varley. Papa–Jeralt’s talking with him about work.”

 

Shez pouted. “You don’t have to be professional when it’s just us two!”

 

“It’s a good habit to get into. Dalton’s dead.”

 

“...Oh. Oh, huh.” Shez settled back. “That’s…huh.”

 

Now that she was looking, she did notice there were more beds filled than usual in the tent, and she could see Gertrude talking with some healer guy she didn’t recognize.

 

“Yeah. The…I think they’re called Brigidians, started the fight by slashing him. By the time anyone got to him, he was already dead.”

 

“Oh. That sucks. He was nice.”

 

“Yeah.” And that was all there was to say. “The Varley soldiers said that there’s a war going on. Dagda and Brigid joined forces to invade Adrestia.”

 

“Wow…um, who are Dagda and Brigid?”

 

“Some foreign countries. Brigid is an…archipelago, according to Victor. I don’t know much about Dagda, just that it’s farther away and bigger.”

 

“Can’t say you’re wrong there, kid, or that I know much more than you,” Jeralt said as he walked over to them and took a seat by Byleth. 

 

Shez immediately brightened. “Hi dad!”

 

“Hey kiddo. How are you feeling?”

 

“Great! I’m not sure why I’m even bandaged, I feel really good!”

 

“Because you were stabbed,” Getrude called out, before turning back to her conversation.

 

“...Yeah, what she said.” Jeralt sighed. “I’m glad you’re okay, Shez. You were out of it for some time." 

 

"Well like I said, I'm totally fine now!" 

 

"...Well, if you say so. We can talk about it more later. Just try to get some rest, okay? The knight out there isn’t giving us a lot of time to get ready." 

 

"For what?" Byleth asked, a bit curious. 

 

"We've been 'hired' to help defend Varley territory," Jeralt said, glancing over to see the new healer leaving the tent. "From the sounds of it, they aren't giving us much of a choice." 

 

"As Victor puts it, Varley is a coward, and is very willing to throw anyone under the carriage if it benefits him. As such, if we don't agree, we'll likely end up being called bandits and get attacked," Gertrude piped up, deciding to sit down too as she got a bit of rest. "Though it's better to defend a coward than get sent to the front lines, I suppose." 

 

"That's one positive, though I'd prefer to just leave the empire entirely and head back to Alliance territory to avoid this whole mess." 

 

"If only it were that simple. And for some reason, I'm also getting the feeling this job won't pay much." 

 

"Can't we just leave? I mean, they can't force you to stay, right captain?" Shez asked.

 

"There's too many injured for us to leave fast enough. Even if we can get away, we'd end up losing too many people in the process." 

 

"Will we have to fight more of those Brigidians?" Byleth asked. 

 

"Hopefully we won't, but we'll see." Getting up, Jeralt began to leave the tent before addressing Byleth. "Make sure she doesn't try to get up before we leave." 

 

"Okay." 

 

"Well, today has been a mess," Getrude said, getting up as well. "I need to smoke. Call me if anyone wakes up."

 

And after she left, Shez felt Byleth hold her hand, gripping tightly. This time, she didn't complain. 

 

"How are you doing, By?" 

 

"Better." 

 

"Sorry I worried you." 

 

"They started calling us things." 

 

"Huh?" 

 

"The Brigid people, they started calling us something. Candace said they were saying something about ‘demons'." 

 

"Wait, really? Did we get nicknames?!" Shez asked, almost excited until she saw the look in her sister's eyes. 

 

"I don't like being called a demon." 

 

Shez paused and reconsidered saying she thought it sounded cool. “Hm…well I’m fine with it, so I’ll be the Violet Demon and you can be…um…what’s a good name…?”

 

“...You’re too silly to be a demon.”

 

“Hey! I can definitely be a demon!” She paused. “Wait, why am I a demon anyway?”

 

“You started glowing and cut a man in half.”

 

Shez blinked. “I did? Huh. That’s weird.”

 

“Yep.”

 

“Wait, did you start glowing too?”

 

“No. I just…sort of…killed every Brigidian between me and you when I saw you collapse.” She glanced away, maybe a little sheepish. “I think it was maybe six of them…”

 

“...Hm. Does that count as you saving me again?”

 

“...Shez, don’t get competitive over this.”

 

“I’m just asking!” She did, however, make a mental note that she was going to beat Byleth’s record in whatever their next battle might be.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Turns out, getting accidentally ambushed by a scouting party can be quite dangerous.

Red: That it is! And thus, our family of mercs gets conscripted into a war against a foreign power. Y'know, as you do.

Indi: As one does if one ends up in Varley territory.

Red: Or just wind up being unlucky enough to be "helped" by Varley troops in general.

Indi: Yup yup, but hey, least they have monikers now! Not that Byleth is a fan.

Red: I'm sure she'll come around once Shez gets them some "Demon Sister" branded t-shirts.

Indi: Just gotta figure out what that glowing thing was first to make sure it's on the shirt properly.

Chapter 14 - War is Dull

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

War was surprisingly boring.

 

Maybe it was just where they were situated, but Shez had to admit to being bored more often than not. The Varley County was far up in the north of the Empire, closer to the Alliance than the sea, so the forces of Brigid and Dagda didn’t make it up there as often as she expected from that first encounter. They did still have to fight some groups, but they were mostly small scouting parties and Jeralt and Byleth were usually the ones going after them while Shez stayed back on “guard duty”.

 

She didn’t think that was entirely fair, especially since it meant she couldn’t try catching up to Byleth, but By was fifteen now and that meant dad was more willing to take her along than Shez, who still insisted she probably was as old, if not older, than her sister. Though she hadn’t won a spar against Byleth in a while…Well, either way, the downtime meant she had more time to practice her two sword style at least, which she was getting really good at!

 

Something about it felt really natural to her, like it was just easier using two blades than one. She could still use one just fine, but something about two felt better. Ezra said something about her being “ambidextrous”, so maybe that had to do with it?

 

Either way, she did still see some combat over the months, especially since they moved around. They were under contract with Varley, but that didn’t mean they couldn’t go fight in other territories that needed help. Apparently the count even encouraged it, since it made him look good to “lend his strength”.

 

The Brigidians she already knew a bit about from that first fight, so facing off against the quick moving islanders who tended to hold their blades in reverse grips and wore light clothing was something she got used to pretty quickly. The Dagdans were definitely rarer to fight and she usually had to hang back against them because they tended to be heavily armored and wielded weird spears called tridents. There were also apparently some skilled archers on their side, but she never went up against them.

 

And thanks to Byleth stepping up more, there hadn't been any more losses on their side. People still got injured, but her sister proved to be quite the tactical genius. To the point that some of the mercs were already treating her like a second in command! 

 

That being said, it seemed like the war was rough on other fronts, with an entire noble house seemingly being wiped out. Not that people seemed to mind, with some saying they deserved it for siding with the emperor during the insurrection. 

 

But, it seemed the empire was going to be launching a counterattack, with a different count apparently leading the charge. Shez didn't know counts could lead an army, but she wished they could work for him instead of Varley. 

 

Speaking of, it seemed that thanks to both Jeralt and Byleth, they were being invited to be congratulated by the count himself. Jeralt wanted to go by himself, but Varley had apparently asked for the 'Demons' to come with him. Which, on the one hand, she was getting recognition for her deeds, which was nice. On the other hand, she had been trying her best to get people to stop calling Byleth a demon so she was disappointed to hear the moniker stick. 

 

Regardless, Shez found herself being led into the Varley estate, standing behind Jeralt as she did her best to be professional. Everyone was wearing some fancier clothes than usual because apparently that was a thing nobles wanted.

 

"Presenting His Lordship, Count Gregoire Von Varley!" announced a knight, standing at attention as they looked up at the landing above them. Moments later, a purple-haired man looked down upon them, eyeing them all with mild interest and contempt. 

 

"You must be Jeralt the Blade Breaker then." 

 

"Yes, your lordship, you honor us with your presence," Jeralt said, with a practiced tone as he bowed towards the count. Byleth followed suit and Shez did so as well, though she lagged behind. 

 

"Hm, and those must be the 'demons' I've heard so much about. Are they truly your daughters?" 

 

"Yes, your lordship." 

 

"Hmph, it seems you've trained them well. My daughter could learn a thing or two for them." Shez suddenly found herself imagining a female version of the count glaring down at them and tried not to grimace. It would probably look bad. “You’ll forgive me if she does not join us. She has a weak constitution, and I can’t begin to imagine how dealing with people of your persuasion may affect her frail heart.”

 

…That sounded like an insult. Shez wasn’t sure how, but it did. And now she was wondering how long she was supposed to keep her head bowed.

 

“I understand completely, your lordship.”

 

“I doubt you do. Nevertheless, you have served my land well in your time here by handling that rabble that somehow made it this far. It’s madness to think Ochs and Nuvelle failed so miserably as to allow forces all the way to my territory. You have my gratitude. Now do be off, I have others to honor today and I really must move right along.”

 

Jeralt straightened. “Pardon me, your lordship, but there is the matter of our pay for aiding you in this trying time.”

 

Varley sneered. “You’ve been paid already.”

 

“No we haven’t.”

 

Jeralt’s immediate contradiction earned a scowl from Varley. “Ridiculous! Are you trying to say I am not a man who pays his debts? You’re just trying to extort me, and I will not have it! Guards, remove this rabble at once!”

 

The guards moved, then everyone froze at the sound of Jeralt cracking his neck. The Blade Breaker leaned his neck to the other side, letting it pop again, then rubbed a hand to it. “Sorry about that. I was getting stiff keeping my head bowed. Kids, let’s get going. We shouldn’t trouble the count with our presence anymore.”

 

“...S-See that you do,” Count Varley said, trying to get the last word in as Jeralt turned and left, with Byleth following him immediately and Shez trailing after with a frown on her face.

 

“Hey, dad, why didn’t you–”

 

“It’s not worth it to deal with a man like that. We have to pick our battles, Shez.”

 

“But this means we’re not getting paid at all!”

 

“Not by him, no. It’s why I’ve been charging the towns we’ve been helping. I never mentioned we had a contract with the Count to anyone, so as far as the people in his territory are concerned, we’re just ‘heroes’ that helped out. For a decent rate, of course.”

 

“Oh. Huh…Hm. But we can’t do anything about the Count?”

 

“Not everyone is going to be Gloucester, Shez. We can’t expect decent pay from every noble, but we can spread word around that Varley’s bad to work for.”

 

“So where next?” Byleth asked, completely unphased by everything that happened.

 

“Next, we’ll probably head west. We’re getting out of Varley County, and…it might be best to wait for Bergliez to handle the main part of the fighting. Things must be a real mess in the west if the enemy managed to get past the mountains…that or they came up from the southern coast, but I think there’s another Count in the way down there…”

 

Shez glanced at her dad as he started muttering under his breath, then spared another look back at the Varley castle. She was tempted to make some kind of rude gesture, but it would probably be a bad idea. Especially since she was pretty sure she spotted someone spying on them from a window…

The Dagda and Brigid War, as people were calling it, wrapped up pretty neatly all things considered. The king of Brigid, Donnacha Macneary, was killed in battle by the War Minister of Adrestia, Count Leopold von Bergliez and that essentially ended everything.

 

Shez wasn’t sure if she’d ever need to know the details of stuff like that, but it did mean the war was over. More importantly, it was Byleth’s birthday again, and Shez sprung for something nice!

 

“‘The Beginnings of Sorcery, Volume Two’,” Byleth read from the cover of the yellow book. Like the first volume, it had little decorative bits at the edges of it, but this time they were lightning bolts instead of flames! “Huh. Thank you.”

 

“You’re welcome! That one’s supposed to be all about Faith and Light magic, like the stuff Gertrude uses!”

 

Behind them, Jeralt couldn’t quite hide a wince, but thankfully Shez was distracted talking up how impressive her gift was, and Byleth was distracted by Shez. He knew, at some point, Byleth was probably going to interact with the faith of the goddess, but…He was probably being paranoid to even consider it a bad thing, right?

 

Meanwhile, Shez remained completely ignorant of her father’s concerns and much more interested in prodding Byleth to start trying out spells from the book.

 

“Hm…can we?” Byleth asked, glancing up at her father.
