“Ah…I suppose it should be fine. We’re not exactly in a great place for it though.” That much was true. They didn’t have a full camp set up for the night because they were currently passing through the Oghma Mountains. Specifically the part that separated the eastern half of the Empire from the West, which was far enough south from the monastery that Jeralt actually felt comfortable going there.

 

“Eh, we can set up a couple dummies near the edge of a cliff and let By give it a go,” Ezra suggested, uncaring of the annoyed look Jeralt gave him.

 

“Yes! Come on dad, please?” Shez pleaded.

 

Jeralt would’ve stood firm, but then Byleth looked at him too and he caught a hint of longing in her eyes, so a few minutes later, Victor and Ezra finished setting up a pair of training dummies near a cliff’s edge, far enough away from the camp that there wouldn’t be any more accidents, and aimed out into the distance so Byleth couldn’t possibly bring the mountain down on them. It might’ve been paranoid, but Jeralt felt his concerns were reasonable enough.

 

“Okay! Ready?”

 

“Mm. Just reading. This book is interesting. There’s a lot more about drawing the power from within you instead of–”

 

“Yeah yeah yeah, that sounds really interesting, but I want to see what you can do!”

 

Byleth gave her sister an annoyed look, then decided to just flip ahead to the more combative spells. She wanted to show off…which was a weird feeling. But she knew what Shez would enjoy seeing, so she picked out a spell that looked powerful.

 

She let out a slow breath and raised her hand, taking care to aim towards the dummy, and focused. If she’d been thinking a bit more, she would have considered using Shez’s tome for a focus, but as it was, she just let the magic gather. Which was more magic than she would have expected. A lot more magic, suddenly surging up as though it was waiting for her, and she felt as though she couldn’t stop herself as she intoned the word: “Seraphim.”

 

A brilliant, gleaming sigil formed in front of her hand before a blast of golden light launched from her palm. The orb it formed soared forward as though on wings of light, ripped straight through the dummy they had set up, and went flying off towards a distant mountain.

 

The Eisner family and their gathered mercenaries watched the ball of light shrink as it disappeared into the distance, before a dim flash in the distance heralded its impact into the side of the mountain.

 

“...Huh.”

 

“THAT WAS AMAZING! HOW DID YOU DO THAT!?”

 

Byleth had a second to turn before Shez tackle-hugged her, and she felt a smile come to her face as her excited sister showered her with praise for her feat.

 

“...” Jeralt, meanwhile, turned to Victor. “...No one lives around there, right?”

 

“No, no one should. There’s…some villages, but they’d be on the other side of the mountains, nowhere near the impact.”

 

“...It might not be that bad,” Ezra said, before noticing part of the mountain appear to start crumbling in a landslide. “...We should move camp.”

 

“I’m fine with that.”

Shez couldn’t stop smiling as she settled in that night. Sure, Jeralt did decide to move the camp for some reason and they had to march a bit, but after that, she and Byleth were allowed to keep on playing– practicing with By’s new magic book! Just no big spells, unfortunately, since they already broke one dummy and their dad had a rule about how magic practice ended whenever a dummy was broken beyond use.

 

“Mm…” She settled into her blankets, which felt nice and cozy in the cool mountain air. “Good night, By!”

 

“Good night Shez,” her sister replied, settling into her own cot beside Shez’s.

 

“Good night dad!” Shez called out, then giggled when she heard Jeralt snore in reply. She really did have it good. She didn’t think she’d have a family again, not after mom, but she really was just…happy. 

 

A part of her did still want to beat Byleth though. Maybe she should try learning more dark magic? Then she could be the Violet Demon and Byleth would be the…Ashen…light, thing…Dragon? Dragon might work, she did use fire too…

 

Shez yawned, then let herself drift off. It was important to be well rested…especially if she wanted to win against Byleth again.

 

“Perhaps I could help with that?” offered the strange white person in a void of floating–...

 

“...What.”

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Sadly no full Bernie cameo, but at least we can all agree, fuck Gregoire.

Red: Gregoire von Varley, definitely one of the top competitors for worst father in Fodlan.

Indi: Will say, it's still hilarious that he gets used as a scapegoat in Three Hopes

Red: Getting propped up as a target for assassination is honestly better than he deserves. Dude should be sent into exile on a raft.

Indi: Hubert would. He'd also make sure the raft has a hole in it.

Red: If he was feeling nice, he'd give Count Varley a bucket.

Indi: Shame that the bucket also has a hole in it.

A Voice in her Head

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

"Did you not request help-" Was about as far as the white person got before Shez tried to punch them in the face, only to end up going through their head. "My, how rude." 

 

"H-Hey, who the heck are you!?" Shez asked after catching herself, keeping her guard up as she faced the strange being covered in weird…weirdly familiar markings.

 

"Not even an apology, hm? Well, if you wish to call me something, you can call me Arval," Arval said, then they continued, "I am the one who saved your life some time ago." 

 

"Huh? You saved me? When did that happen?" 

 

"Do you truly not remember?" Arval asked, a bit surprised. "It was during the fight where you were stabbed. I gave you my power so you would not die." 

 

"Wait, are you talking about the glowy thing?" 

 

"I would not put it in such simple words, but yes. Were it not for me you likely would have perished that day." 

 

"Oh, uh…thank you?"

 

"Oh my, so this is what it feels like for someone to show gratitude, it is quite pleasant." Arval said, looking very pleased. 

 

"So, I'm not trying to be rude, but what exactly is going on? I'm pretty sure I didn't fall asleep in a void earlier." 

 

"Well, that is quite simple. We are currently in your mind," Arval explained, making Shez blink as she looked around. Some rude people said she was empty-headed, but she didn't think that was literal… "And I have called you here so we can speak. To be specific, I have been trying to call you for some time, but it was quite difficult setting up this connection." 

 

"Huh. So, not that I'm not grateful or anything, but why exactly did you save me?" 

 

"That is because you are a crucial piece to the world's cyclical nature." 

 

"...the world's what now?" Shez asked, making Arval sigh. 

 

"To put it simply, this is your destiny." And that got Shez's attention. 

 

"Wait, so I am destined to do something? What is it?" 

 

"That… I am not certain. All I know is that it is your destiny and I am here to help you with it. But one thing is for certain, that desire to grow stronger than your sister is what helped call me to you, and what I believe will help you fulfill your destiny." 

 

"Really? So you mean Byleth really is my destined rival?" Shez asked, feeling very excited. 

 

"I believe so…while I do not know what exactly your destiny is, I can feel it deep within myself that defeating her is key for that." 

 

“Oh, okay? So I just need to beat her in another spar?”

 

“...No, not quite. I don’t believe that is my meaning.”

 

“Well I’m not going to fight her for real, I don’t want to hurt her.”

 

“You do wish to surpass her though, correct?”

 

“Oh sure, then I get to be the older sister again!”

 

Arval stared at her for a few seconds, then sighed deeply as they placed a hand against their head. “I do not know where to even begin with that assertion…Fine, whatever your reasoning, your goal is clear. Surpass your sister and prove yourself better.”

 

“Yeah, okay. You’re not really saying anything I didn’t already know though.”

 

Arval just stared at her again. “...Perhaps I should have waited for you to be older…”

 

“Hey, I’m fourteen, that’s more than old enough to beat Byleth!” Shez declared, then paused. “Ah, wait, no, that would make Byleth older than me since she’s sixteen now…”

 

“...She would already be older than you by the basis of being a year older–”

 

“Hey, quiet! I can only be the older sister if I don’t acknowledge stuff like that!”

 

“So you are aware of your denial of reality then…Never mind. Just know that I will always be at your side, my partner in destiny.”

 

And then Shez woke up.

 

“...That was a weird dream,” she said, sitting up in bed and glancing over at Byleth. “Ha! Woke up earlier than her again!”

 

“Is everything a competition to you?” Arval asked, before raising a hand, “Peace, partner. Please do not scream out of nowhere and awaken the entire camp.”

 

“...You’re real?”

 

“Of course I am real! What in the world made you think any of that was not real?!”

 

“I don’t know, dreams are weird. One time I dreamt I was a fox. I think Byleth was a wolf? And dad was–”

 

“Would you focus, please?” Arval sighed. “Of all the people in this wide world, how is it I came to be partnered with an unfocused child?”

 

“Hey! I’m not–”

 

“Mrh? Shez?” Byleth blinked awake, before sitting up, tiredness turning to alertness as she looked at her sister. “What’s going on? Is there trouble?”

 

“Oh, no, I just–”

 

“Ahem.” Shez paused as Arval cleared their throat. “Partner, far be it for me to tell you what to do, but perhaps do not mention my existence to the sister you seek to defeat? You need every advantage you can get, after all.”

 

“Yeah but that’s stupid, of course I’m telling By about you,” Shez replied, before turning back to Byleth, “I’m talking to this weird white person I saw in my dreams. Their name’s Arval.”

 

“...” Byleth blinked. “Huh…Shez, are you being haunted by a ghost?”

 

“Am I?” Shez glanced at Arval, who had their face in their hands. “...I might be?”

 

“We should tell dad then.”

 

“Okay!”

 

“...I picked the wrong time to contact her,” Arval muttered to themself as they watched their partner in destiny hop up from her cot and start shaking her dad awake. To be fair to themself though, they really did not consider their partner would be this stupid.

“So you had a strange dream, and now the kid from that dream is hanging around?” Jeralt asked over breakfast, currently portioning out some of the stew for his kids.

 

“Mm hm!” Shez answered while in the middle of eating.

 

“Alright then. And is he saying anything weird?”

 

“I don’t think they’re a he? They’re like…kinda not a boy or a girl?” Shez shrugged, before helping herself to another spoonful of broth. “Mm! Oh, and Arval just says it’s my destiny to beat Byleth.”

 

“Ahhh. So they’re saying it’s your destiny, huh?”

 

“Yup! So you better watch out, By! Because I’m gonna beat you next time we spar!” she declared, pointing her spoon at her sister beside her.

 

“You can try,” Byleth replied, before simply grabbing her bowl and downing the remains of her soup. “Mm…More please.”

 

“C’mon kid, you’ve gotta leave some for the rest of the camp,” Jeralt chided, before turning back to the pot.

 

Byleth pouted, before jerking slightly when Shez poked her cheek. “Hey, what kind of dreams do you have? Any weird ones?”

 

“I guess. I usually dream of wars and stuff.”

 

“Ooo, any cool wars?”

 

“...I cannot believe any of this,” Arval, meanwhile, muttered from nearby where they were watching the family at breakfast, “He did not even ask any real questions! Well, I suppose that is to our benefit, but honestly, should he not show at least some concern for his daughter supposedly hallucinating??”

 

Jeralt, meanwhile, was internally panicking. Not too much, he was used to taking care of a kid most would consider unusual, but he also thought that his adoptive daughter wouldn’t have sudden issues like hearing voices and seeing what sounded like ghosts. Or, well, one ghost of ambiguous gender.

 

How did that even work? She dreamt of a ghost and now she’s seeing it? Should he be worried? Was this just another weird Shez thing? The girl had funny ideas about destiny, so maybe she just made up an imaginary friend! But, wait, did fourteen year olds have imaginary friends? He was three hundred years old, he had no idea what being fourteen was like! Much less a fourteen year old girl!

 

Should he get Gertrude? This wasn’t a health thing, was it? Though, no, no, telling Gertrude was premature, it might be something strange but benign like Byleth’s heart…Goddess, maybe it was something like that. Shez started glowing back in that first ambush with the Brigid folk, maybe she had some kind of…magical bloodline? Did that make sense? It didn’t seem like Crests or…Was Shez a baby dragon??

 

“Uh, dad? I think the soup’s boiling,” Shez pointed out and Jeralt cursed under his breath.

 

“Ah, yeah, looks like, I’ll just move it.”

 

“Okay! Make sure to use your gloves!” she warned just half a second too late as Jeralt gripped the pot’s handles with his bare hands.

 

“...” Jeralt was a strong, seasoned warrior. He knew how to handle pain. That was why he carefully set the pot down without spilling a drop. “...”

 

“...Hey, um, dad? Are you okay?”

 

“...Just fine. Give me…one second. I need to check the perimeter.” Jeralt moved towards the edge of camp, his reddened hands splayed because trying to clench them was pure agony. 

 

Shez, Byleth, and Arval all craned their heads to watch him leave, before the sisters settled back while the “ghost” raised an eyebrow at his departure. “Strange. Why would he be walking off into the woods–”

 

The scream of pain and deluge of curses that echoed out a second later answered that query quite succinctly.

 

Suffice to say, the family did wind up visiting Gertrude in short order, though not for Shez.

Jeralt might have had a tumultuous relationship with the Archbishop, but he was perfectly happy to praise the Goddess for healing magic. By the time his group had made it out of the mountains and to the next village, it was like his hands had never been scalded at all.

 

He made a mental note to give Gertrude a bonus next time he divvied out the pay. First and foremost though, was getting supplies at the village. While the village was a bit too close to Garreg Mach for his own preference, it was a rather bustling place, which meant they could get what they needed easily. 

 

"You must be the leader of this band of men," the village headman said as Jeralt checked the supplies they had purchased. 

 

"Hm? Did you need something?" Jeralt asked as he turned to look at the man. "We were planning on leaving tomorrow, but if you have a job for us, I'd be happy to hear you out." 

 

"Ha, that won't be necessary. I just wanted to make sure you were all okay, there was a rock slide that happened not so long ago, so I was wondering if you faced any troubles on your journey." At the mention of the rock slide, Jeralt did his best to remain even-faced. 

 

"So that's what that sound was. I had thought it was a giant wolf raising a fuss." 

 

"Thankfully no, but even so, to think such a tragic accident would happen near here…" 

 

"..." Jeralt almost didn't want to ask. "What accident?" 

 

"The rockslide I mentioned. Lord Arundel perished in it." The headman let out a sorrowful sigh. "To think such an honorable man would lose his life like this…may the goddess protect his spirit."

 

Jeralt, to his credit, was able to keep calm on the outside. On the inside however, he couldn't help but feel immense dread at that news. Had…Had his daughter accidentally assassinated the Empire’s regent?

 

"Ah, but if you don't mind me asking, where are you headed?" 

 

"To the kingdom," Jeralt said without hesitation, "The recent war is making mercs crawl out of the woodwork, so it's hard to find work." Well, that was believable for a lie he made on the spot.

 

"Aaah, well, we do have some furs to sell if you want. The kingdom can be quite cold, so I'd recommend you bundle up." 

 

"We'll take what you have. Haven't been to the kingdom since I was young, so it’s probably going to take some getting used to again." As they exchanged pleasantries, Jeralt spotted Victor nearby, so he excused himself to talk to the merc. 

 

"Change of plans, we're headed to the kingdom." 

 

"Eh? What the hell, why are we headed over there?" Victor asked, very clearly not pleased with having to head towards Faerghus. The only response he got in return was Jeralt muttering 'it happened again' as he brushed past him. 

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Eeeey, Arval is here!

Red: Everyone's favorite not-ghost! Well aside from Sothis, but it'll be a bit before she shows up.

Indi: Yup yup, definitely going to be fun having Arval show up early on.

Red: Now Shez gets someone to encourage her rivalry! For better or worse.

Indi: That she does! And clearly that's the most major thing to happen in the chapter.

Red: The most major thing! Well aside from the family heading to Faerghus now, that should be important.

Indi: gotta finish the trip around Fodlan after all

Red: That we do! I'm sure they won't be involved in any major events this time. Anyways, thank you all for reading and commenting! Comments are always appreciated!

Interlude - Agastya

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Thales of Agartha was many things. A powerful sorcerer. An immortal sage. The eternal leader of the only true humans in the land of Fodlan. 

 

And, at the moment, a curious mix of irritated and overly proud of himself.

 

The pride was understandable, given he finally had his Flame Emperor. The blood of that filthy beast’s consort may have once called themselves “emperors”, but it was by his hand that one of their ilk had become a true force to be reckoned with. One that would strike down the spawn of the Fell Star and bring the Agarthan people back to the world that was stolen from them.

 

The irritation was also understandable, given that before he could bring forth that most glorious of reckonings, he had to pose as one of the beast’s so-called “nobles”. Which meant instead of traveling instantaneously from one location to the next through the might of magic and technology, he had to travel in a damn carriage.

 

“You seem sour,” noted his companion for the journey, thankfully one of his people instead of those aggravating vermin he was forced to play politely with.

 

“Is it unreasonable to be? The beasts’ means of travel are as primitive as everything the abomination has a hold on.”

 

Pittacus shrugged, her shoulders bared by the black gown she wore. Black-painted lips curled in a small smirk beneath her veil. “I would think you would be happier, Thales. Or should I call you Volkhard in this shape?”

 

“Bah! I hear enough of that name from the degenerates trying to earn my favor,” he sneered, leaning back in his seat in the shape of that all too convenient “lord” he had overtaken. It should have been difficult finding a host of appropriate height and shape to wear properly, but it seemed fortune favored the true humans in just how convenient it was that “Lord Arundel” had a sister married into the imperial family. Thales may be a masterful manipulator, but he was not one to disregard the factor of luck in having favorable conditions arise. 

 

“Thales it is then. Still, you shouldn’t scowl. It may mar the face you’re using.”

 

He scoffed. “Nonsense. A guise of mine will never have any imperfections. Though I won’t disagree that I should be more joyful.” He let his lips curl into a smirk of his own. “It won’t be long now before Cleobulus upholds her end of the plan and puts an end to that ‘kingly’ bloodline the northernmost beasts crowd around.”

 

"And what of the Alliance? I don't seem to recall you mentioning any plans there." 

 

"As if I need to do anything there. Those pathetic beasts keep squabbling amongst themselves, barely held together by even the thinnest loyalty. With how half of them support the empire, it will be easy to keep them under our thumb once my Flame Emperor takes the stage." He allowed himself to chuckle at the thought. “Ah, though perhaps I’ll have someone handle that ‘sovereign duke’ of theirs. Myson has been bored keeping watch on the region, hasn’t he?”

 

“Myson gets bored whenever he isn’t allowed to play with those crest-altered beasts of his,” Pittacus complained, “You think he would be happy with consistent results, but he insists he can push the projects faster and further.”

 

“Far be it for me to quell a man’s ambitions. As long as he doesn’t start naming his projects again and keeps them from going too wild, I don’t particularly care what he does with filth.”

 

“Well, we can always let the wilder ones loose on the vermin. It’s only natural for larger beasts to devour the smaller creatures, isn’t it?”

 

“Ha! Only natural indeed.” Thales, wearing the face of Lord Volkhard von Arundel, laughed with a dark humor as his carriage trundled onward through the Oghma mountains. “Just as it will be only natural to see these lands returned to us once more. For it is our time to rise again, and reclaim all that was stolen from us!”

 

His mouth curled into a vicious smirk, though he did raise an eyebrow when he noticed Pittacus’s lack of response. In fact, the woman was inclining her head for some reason. “What are you doing?”

 

“...I thought I heard something. Actually…do you hear that?”

 

“Hear what? I don’t hear–” And that was when several tons of rock, stone, and loose soil crashed down on Lord Arundel’s carriage.

It had been centuries since Thales last felt agony on such a level. Slowly, blearily, he opened his eyes and attempted to focus. His vision was blurry and he felt the warm trickle of blood leak down his head.

 

“...What?” he muttered to himself, his eyes adjusting to a darkness he was far too familiar with. In front of him, he saw Pittacus. 

 

His fellow Agarthan was no longer sitting in her seat. No, she was instead splayed out across the floor–no, the ceiling; the entire carriage had flipped. Her mouth was open in a look of utter shock at her own demise, her veil lifted to show unseeing eyes and her white hair loose around her head in a tangled mess, already stained with her dark blood. 

 

And she was most definitely dead. The massive stone staked through her chest saw to that.

 

Thales breathed, slowly. His guise was still in place. He couldn’t focus on a warp though. He would have, were it not for his clear concussion. If he tried as he was, the likelihood that he would wind up split to pieces between here and his destination was far too high. Which wouldn’t be a problem, if the only damn medic around wasn’t dead on the floor in front of him!

 

He snarled and kicked her across the head in a moment of petty, vindictive anger. “What worth are you as a healer if you can’t even bother to live!?”

 

No matter. He would survive. He was Thales. He always survived.

 

It took some effort to extricate himself from the carriage, but even a landslide couldn’t trap him. The driver to his carriage, some worthless peon, had been splattered across the trail. Not important either though. 

 

He looked back to the wreckage of his transportation, then up at the mountainside that had tried to claim his life. “Hah. Ha! You see this, Fell Star? I cannot die! Not even nature can end my vengeance!”

 

He grinned through bloodied teeth, then raised a hand. Ebony and crimson magic swirled about his hand before he clenched his fist and wrenched it down, calling on his own mastery of the earth to bend it to his will! And with it, both the carriage and the evidence of his presence were buried even further.

 

Sure, some hint of the broken remains were still present, but he had assuredly flattened what remained of Pittacus. No need to allow the vermin any hint of his kind.

 

“Ha. I would thank you for your service, but you did prove truly worthless in the end,” he commented, before turning with a callous laugh, “I’ll be sure to let the people of Agartha know just how ignominious your end was–”

 

Far above Thales, amidst the broken rocks of the cliffside, a single, large boulder still remained unfallen, yet perched precariously atop one small outcropping. Without any external force to act upon it, this boulder would have likely remained in place for untold ages, a curious part of the landscape hanging like a sword above the heads of passersby. As it was though, the powerful magic of Agartha’s great leader shook not just the parts of the mountain he wished to break, but the parts nearby. Which meant the large boulder went from precariously perched to falling over.

 

Despite his centuries of alterations to his own body, Thales was, at the end of the day, still human. And when a very big rock falls onto a human head, no matter how self-important the mind inside it may be, the result is always the same.

 

Such came the ignominious end of Thales, leader of the Agarthans.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: You ever just decided to throw a massive curveball into the story

Red: Just for funsies. Because why not?

Indi: Cause fuck Thales, can't wait to show y'all what exactly this decision will lead to

Red: Yup! Because at the end of the day, removing Thales just allows for too many fun changes not to go for it.

Indi: What exactly those are? Well, you'll just have to wait and see.

The Cold Sucks

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

"The cold sucks!" Shez said from where she was bundled up in several furs while the mercenaries set up camp for the night. It had been some time since the team had arrived in the Kingdom, and much like a clock, Shez made sure to announce to the camp her displeasure each day at nearly the same time. 

 

"Hm." Byleth agreed, fairing a bit better than Shez, as she handed over some stew to her sister. Though it seemed the younger merc wanted to use it more to warm her hands with the bowl rather than eat it. "Jeralt says we'll be in a city soon." 

 

"Will it be warmer?"

 

"...The walls should help with the wind.”

 

Shez groaned, pulling her furs closer around herself. “Why’d we go up north in the Fall anyway? Isn’t it supposed to snow up here around Winter?”

 

“Probably. I don’t remember ever going up here before. Maybe when I was really little?” Byleth shrugged, the motion coming a little more naturally to her these days. “I can ask Jeralt later. Victor said Jeralt’s from here, so maybe that’s why we’re visiting.”

 

“It sounds really weird when you call dad by his name.”

 

“I told you why I do it–”

 

“Still sounds weird.”

 

Byleth sighed while Arval floated above the bunch of them, watching with some amusement. “I have to say, being unable to feel cold seems like quite the boon right now. Oh, and you do know your adoptive father is lying about his reasoning, correct?”

 

Shez glanced up at the strange being with an annoyed frown, prompting them to continue.

 

“I cannot help it if I happen to be better at listening than you are. Regardless, your captain-father seems quite convinced your sister, who, I might add, you have not attempted to defeat yet, assassinated another noble. Speaking of, what does he mean by ‘another’?”

 

“Byleth stabbed a noble in Enbarr for being creepy,” Shez explained, prompting Byleth to glance at her.

 

“Are you speaking to Arval again?”

 

“Yeah. They’re curious about a noble you assassinated.”

 

“I don’t think it counts as assassination unless it’s politically motivated. Ezra was arguing with Victor about that.” Byleth tilted her head, thinking. “Victor says you have to be a noble to be assassinated, but Ezra says it’s about motivation, not status.”

 

“Huh. You think Ezra’s ever assassinated anybody?”

 

“He most definitely has,” Arval commented while Byleth shrugged.

 

“Probably. He seems particular about it.”

 

“Don’t talk about people when they’re not here,” the potential assassin in question commented as he tossed some logs on the fire pit. Shez immediately made a happy noise and moved closer to it, prompting a grin from Ezra. “Careful there. Furs are warm, but fire can still catch on them.”

 

“I’ll be careful!”

 

“Hey, Ezra, did I assassinate the noble back in Enbarr?” Byleth asked.

 

“No, you killed him, there’s a difference,” was the immediate response.

 

“What’s the difference?” Shez asked.

 

“Killing is just the act of taking a life in general. It can be in self-defense or the defense of others, so it’s slightly more justified than murder, which is committing the criminal act of killing another, usually in a premeditated way. Though I guess spur of the moment does count as murder too, but I think we can use the ‘is he a prick’ qualification to say he deserved it.”

 

“...You’re really pedantic.”

 

“Why thank you.”

 

Shez didn’t intend that as a compliment, but okay. “...Hey, you’re from Faerghus, right?”

 

“Indeed I am! Rowe territory originally, in fact.” He grinned at the girls while grabbing a bowl of stew for himself. “Feel free to ask me anything you might want to know!”

 

“Oh, okay. Why does Gertrude call you ‘Dove’?”

 

“And how about we stop talking now.”

 

"How is the kingdom?" Byleth asked, trying to keep the conversation going. 

 

"Well, I haven't been here for some time, but I doubt it's changed its values. It's a lot more traditional than the other nations, got a big focus on knighthood, honor, and all that." Ezra explained as he began to eat. "You know, pledging yourself to some lord and then getting sent to die for them. 'Honor in death, dishonor in defeat' and such." 

 

"Were you a knight?" 

 

"I was a squire, and if I did become a knight, I likely wouldn't have joined this merry band. Though that path fell away when the knight I worked for decided to make me do his dirty work, and then threw me to the wolves when he got found out." 

 

"Oh, sorry." 

 

"Ha, there's no need to apologize. I managed to get away with my life, and learned I'm way more good with a knife than a sword and shield." Grinning, Ezra continued. "Besides, now I get to travel around Fodlan."

 

"Well if you want to travel so much, you could point us towards where the money flows best," Getrude said, sitting down next to Ezra and taking his half-empty bowl of stew from him to eat from it. 

 

"...well, we should avoid Galatea territory then, even the noble family there struggles financially. Gautier territory might be worthwhile, but that's on the ass end of the nation, and would mostly be defending against the Sreng, assuming they give us any work." Thinking for a moment, he continued. "Gaspard territory might be good. Haven’t met him personally but while I was in Rowe, I kept hearing about how well-loved Lonato was."

 

“Oh, that sounds like a good idea then!” Shez said, “You should definitely tell dad that! I don’t think he really knows where we’re going.”

 

Neither of the older mercs would say it outright, but she wasn't wrong there. It wasn't the first time that the Captain had changed plans, but this was the first time he did so without a new destination in mind. 

 

"Hey, I know where we're going," Jeralt said as he walked by. "Just because I haven't been to the kingdom for a long time doesn't mean I don't remember how to get around." 

 

"That's not what I meant and you know it!" 

 

"Before you start arguing," Ezra cut in, getting their attention. "I was just saying Gaspard territory might be a good idea, it's almost winter, so unless there's other mercenaries over there, we probably won't see much competition. If nothing else, we can probably get some rooms there, which is better than camping out in this cold." 

 

"I second that idea!" Shez announced, not raising her hand as she kept them in the furs. 

 

"Right, well, I'll keep that in mind," Jeralt said, already fully planning on going to that territory. "If nothing else, buying thicker clothing there would be good." 

 

“Exactly, captain. You can never been too warm when it comes to winters in Faerghus.” Ezra paused while Jeralt walked off to handle travel plans. “Well, unless that warmth is coming from frost sickness, then you’re just dying.”

 

“Frost sickness?” Byleth echoed, sounding curious. Well, more curious than her usual neutrality.

 

“Yep. It’s also called a cold fever. It’s when the cold seeps too far into your bones and tricks your mind into thinking it’s actually hot. I remember this poor bast–ah, this poor guy, when I was younger, who started ripping his furs off, thinking he was overheating. He went running off into the snow and we found his body a day later, completely frozen through.”

 

“Woah,” Shez murmured, her eyes wide, “That’s pretty scary…”

 

“You bet it is. Folks around here like to tell tales of the Winter Lady who walks in the blizzards, tempting wayward travelers to nestle into her bosom where they slowly freeze to death.”

 

“Huh. She sounds like a jerk.”

 

“That’s winter, Shezzy. The Goddess tests us all when the cold comes around.” He chuckled, before tossing another log on the fire. “Still, she’s generous enough to give us fire, so we can keep warm even in the times furthest from her light. That, and pegasi, so we can actually travel when the snow’s deep. Well, women can travel, they’re notoriously skittish around most men.”

 

“Huh? Why’s that?”

 

“Something about a maiden’s fair heart soothing their wild nature?” Ezra shrugged, then glanced at Gertrude with a slight grin, “Maybe you oughta ask Gertie, I’m sure she’d know much better.”

 

“You know better than anyone here that I don’t count as a ‘pure maiden’,” Gertrude chided, making Ezra’s face immediately redden.

 

“Hey, not in front of the kids.”

 

That earned a full eye roll. “You stab people for a living, but you get indignant if I talk about ‘bedroom affairs’ in front of the girls?”

 

“Well, it’s not appropriate, is it?”

 

“...Are you talking about sex?” Shez asked, and Ezra nearly choked.

 

“Gertrude talked to us about it already,” Byleth explained, which didn’t really seem to help all that much. “Jeralt asked her to.”

 

“I swear, men can be ridiculous,” Gertrude muttered, “Ask them to split a man’s belly and watch his guts spill and all he’ll ask is how much you’ll pay him to do it, but start talking about ‘womanly matters’ and suddenly they discover squeamishness.” 

 

“I think it’s more Papa–Jeralt didn’t know how to talk about it.”

 

“He’s been raising a girl for sixteen years, Byleth, and adopted a second one. He should’ve been planning ahead.”

 

“I think dad did plan ahead!” Shez spoke up, a grin on her face as she figured everything out, “After all, he planned for you to do it for him, right?”

 

“...Damn, I can’t refute that.”

The journey to Gaspard didn’t take too long. The roads were still largely clear of snow since true winter hadn’t hit yet, and the region wasn’t too far from the Kingdom/Empire border. Jeralt wasn't really one to visit the Kingdom for one, as aside from his own past, the lands weren't exactly the richest so work for mercenaries wasn't that common. 

 

That being said, it seemed the people of the territory were faring rather well, and were rather happy to greet the mercenary band. As for Gaspard himself…

 

"Greetings, you must be the leader of this band of mercenaries." A rather well-aged but still healthy looking old man greeted Jeralt when he was allowed into the manor. 

 

"That I am, thanks for meeting us like this." 

 

"I have no reason to turn away guests." Lonato said with a smile, before he looked over to the side where he noticed two young girls. "And who is this?" 

 

"My name is Byleth." 

 

"Heya, name’s Shez!" 

 

Jeralt tried not to sigh at his daughters’ introductions. "My apologies, it's their first time in the kingdom so they're not used to the cold." 

 

"No need to explain, the winters here are quite cold, and as a father I can understand wanting to keep your children warm and healthy." Lonato's smile kept on his face as he approached Jeralt. "Now, am I correct in assuming you're here looking for work?" 

 

"Or at least permission to stay nearby until the winter ends." 

 

"Heh, well as it just so happens, there have been some demonic beasts causing trouble nearby." Nothing Lonato's forces couldn't handle, but he wasn't about to let a father and his kids out in the cold. "The pay might not be much, but there are a few empty houses we can lend you and your men while you stay here." 

 

"Well, that sounds perfectly acceptable. Is there somewhere we can go to hash out the details?" 

 

"We can write up a contract in my office. As long as your daughter's don't mind waiting here?" 

 

"No worries dad, we'll be good!" Shez said, sending off the leader of the group as the two girls stayed behind. "Well, he seems nice." 

 

"Yeah." Byleth said, nodding as she settled into the chair she was in, before she seemed to notice something. "Who's there?" 

 

"A-Ah, s-sorry!" A young boy's voice was heard, apologizing at having been caught peeking at the two. Looking over, Shez saw a gray-haired boy, younger than her, looking at them from around a corner. 

 

"Oh, hey, are you the old guy's kid?" 

 

"Shez don't be rude." 

 

"I-If you mean Lord Lonato, then yes. I'm his adoptive son, Ashe," the young boy explained, sounding very polite. 

 

"Well it's nice to meet you Ashe!" 

 

"A-Are you mercenaries?" he asked, still a bit nervous. 

 

"That we are! You're looking at two of the strongest members of Jeralt’s Mercenaries!" 

 

"You still haven't beat Ezra in a fight,” Byleth commented. 

 

Shez’s confident smile immediately fell into an annoyed pout. “You don’t have to tell him that.”

 

“It’s good for you to be realistic.”

 

“And realistically, I’m going to be the strongest, so it doesn’t matter if I say it ahead of time!”

 

"But if I'm going to be the leader, shouldn't I be the strongest?" 

 

"Th-That's because you're the brains! A leader doesn't need to be strong, but they do need to be smart! You agree, right Ashe?" 

 

"U-Um, w-well, in ‘Loog and the Maiden of the Wind’, Loog was the strongest, so he was the leader, while the Maiden was the smarter one, but wasn't in charge." 

 

"...Huh. So wait, does that mean I'll be the leader?" Shez asked.

 

"Guess I'll have to be the stronger and smarter one," Byleth decided. 

 

"Wh–Hey, no fair, you can only be one of them!" 

 

"U-Um, s-sorry to interrupt,” Ashe interrupted, “But I wanted to ask, if you're mercenaries, have you been traveling around?"

 

"Hm? Oh yeah totally, we've been all over the Empire and the Alliance!" 

 

"R-Really? Have you done anything heroic?" Ashe asked, very interested in hearing anything they had to say.

 

"Of course, Byleth and I have done plenty of hero stuff! Like the time we saved that one girl…uh, what was her name?" 

 

"Leonie," Byleth answered. 

 

"Yeah, her!" Grinning, Shez patted an empty seat. "Come on, I'll tell you all about it!" 

 

"O-Oh, sure!" With an eager smile, Ashe sat down, ready to hear the story. Normally Byleth would have spoken up to correct Shez when she started exaggerating what the two had done, but…she and Ashe were having fun, and she'd hate to be rude to the son of their client. 

 

As such, Byleth just sat by as Shez regaled the younger boy with tales of their adventures, from their rescue of Leonie to their brief excursions in the Dagda and Brigid War. Though, to hear Shez tell it, one would think they fought against Dagda’s greatest generals instead of some bands of scouts and possible deserters.

 

Still, it was entertaining, kind of. Ashe seemed very interested, but Byleth was more enjoying just how excited Shez was to talk than the actual content of her stories. Which is probably why she was more aware of the large, broad-shouldered man that peeked into the room than her younger sister was. 

 

Shez didn’t even stop talking, too caught up in her tale of their “adventure through the mountains” to notice, and Ashe was completely enraptured, so it fell to Byleth to raise a hand in greeting to the new person.

 

He had short, dark hair and looked a lot like Lord Lonato, if younger and clean-shaven. He had the same kind smile as the lord too as he raised a hand in return, before moving slowly and carefully to a nearby seat, not making too much noise to avoid interrupting Shez.

 

“–and Byleth even brought down an entire mountaintop!”

 

“Wow, really??”

 

“Yup! That’s why she’s the Ashen Dragon, the most powerful mage to ever live!” 

 

Byleth blinked, a strange feeling of surprise hitting her at Shez’s new title for her. It was…nicer, sort of, than being called a demon…

 

“My, how very impressive!” the new man said, applauding Shez’s tale and making her stiffen for a moment in surprise.

 

“Christophe!” Oh, so that was his name. And Ashe clearly recognized him based on his happy reaction to seeing the large man.

 

“Heh, hello Ashe! I see you’ve made some new friends!”

 

“O-Oh, right, um, Christophe, this is Shez–” He gestured to Shez, who waved back with a bright grin once she decided this new guy seemed nice. “–and Byleth. They’re Sir Jeralt’s daughters.”

 

“Sir Jeralt? Sir Jeralt…ah, I think I know who you mean, though if I’m correct, it would be Captain Jeralt, not Sir,” Christophe corrected, “He’s a mercenary, not a knight.”

 

“Oh right! Ah, s-sorry about that.”

 

“Heh, it’s all fine! So, you two were keeping my little brother company?”

 

"Yeah, our dad is talking with your dad about contract stuff!" Shez said with a bright smile.

 

"Aaah, so I'm guessing we'll be seeing more of your group around here?" 

 

"Oh for sure! We’re gonna be helping clear out demonic beasts! And probably other stuff, depending on what type of problems you have around here.”

 

"I see, well if your tales are any indication, we can probably leave it all to you two," Christophe said with a smile. 

 

"We probably could!"

 

"Ah, Christophe, weren't you supposed to arrive earlier?” Ashe suddenly asked, “Nathan and Alice wanted to say hi to you before they went to sleep." For a brief moment, Christophe's smile faltered. 

 

"Just some issues the Western Church needed help with. I'll make sure to make it up to the two of them when they wake up." 

 

"I'm sure they'll be happy about that!" Though before the conversation could continue, Jeralt and Lonato returned. 

 

"Christophe? When did you arrive?" 

 

"Just now, father,” the knight said as he stood, a smile returning to his face, “Forgive me for not going to see you immediately, but I saw Ashe had made some new friends and I wanted to hear the tales of their daring adventures.”

 

Lonato chuckled with a warm smile on his face. “Ah, you have no need to apologize, my boy. Though I do think it may be time for certain young people to get to bed. It is quite late already after all.”

 

Ashe ducked his head, a little embarrassed. “O-Of course, Lord Lonato.”

 

The lord sighed, fondly amused. “I’ve told you before, Ashe, you can call me father.”

 

Ashe turned a little pink at the suggestion while Jeralt headed over to his own kids. “Alright, c’mon, up you get. Lord Lonato was generous enough to give us an actual house to stay in for the night, and your old man needs his rest.”

 

“Ha! If you’re an old man, Jeralt, I wonder what that makes me?” Lonato joked, before smiling again, “And the house is yours for as long as you wish to stay in Gaspard. I would hate to leave anyone out in the cold once Winter starts in earnest.”

 

“Well, I don’t know if we’ll be around here that long…but thank you for your hospitality.”

 

“It is no trouble at all. Have a good night, all of you.”

 

“Thanks again, Lord Lonato!” Shez said, waving to the old man as her dad led her away, a gestured copied by Byleth, much to Jeralt’s surprise. 

 

Well, if the kid has a good feeling about him, maybe we could stay a while, he considered while taking his kids over to the house Lonato indicated to him earlier. One of the lord’s knights led the way, and Jeralt couldn’t help relaxing a little as he walked.

 

After their problems in the Empire, he could do with relaxing for a bit.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: The perks of having a ghost friend, they can listen in on conversations that you can't. The cons, if someone doesn't know you have a ghost friend, you end up sounding crazy as you talk to yourself.

Red: Unfortunately, most people don't have ghost friends, so Shez is going to look quite weird for reasons other than her general weirdness. But hey, at least she's making some non-ghost friends too!

Indi: Yeah! And I'm sure nothing bad will happen to those friends.

Red: Aw, I'm sure it'll be fine. Nothing bad ever happens in Faerghus, right?

Indi: just ignore the story about people freezing to death.

Red: Honestly it's deeply amusing to me how every character from Faerghus has a story about how bad Faerghus sucks as a place to live. It might be a barren wasteland of ice and snow that no one should reasonably live in, but it's their barren wasteland.

Things Go Wrong Again

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Their time at Gaspard territory had certainly been peaceful; aside from the occasional demonic beast, there hadn't been much fighting for the mercenary band. Not to say that they didn't work; even when they weren't fighting beasts, they went around town helping out. Be it simply helping out with carrying something, or going out to hunt, the mercenary band had easily situated themselves into the town. 

 

Byleth and Shez in particular were often seen with the children of Lord Lonato. Ashe and his younger siblings were often enraptured by Shez’s grand tales, while Christophe would take the time to train the young duo when he was there. Apparently the young knight was quite impressed with the two, to the point that he suggested they enroll in the Officer’s Academy, an idea that was quickly shot down by Jeralt. 

 

When asked why, he made two simple points: 1. The Officer’s Academy is expensive to join and despite the mercenary band’s success, it would certainly eat into their coffers to try sending both Byleth and Shez there, and 2. He wasn’t comfortable leaving his daughters alone while he and his band continued to travel, and he highly doubted the Academy would be okay with an entire mercenary group staying in their town for a whole year.

 

Shez readily accepted the first reason, while Byleth was satisfied with the second.

 

“It is a shame though, I’m sure they would do excellently there,” Christophe noted as he watched the girls train in Lonato’s yard.

 

“Sure, they’d probably do great anywhere,” Jeralt admitted, “Call me overprotective, but I just don’t like the idea.”

 

“Say no more, I completely understand. We have to do what we can for our families.” There was an oddly wistful expression on the younger man’s face, one that looked a little out of place. “And, if I am being honest…while I enjoyed my time at the Academy, I can’t say I entirely agree with everything the leadership espouses.”

 

“...Careful there, Christophe. I’m not big on faith, but saying something like that could go very wrong for you depending on who you voice it around.”

 

Christophe just grinned though. “Not to worry, Jeralt. I had a feeling about you, that’s why I voiced it. I’m a more cautious man than I seem, I assure you!”

 

“Sure you are, pal. Sure you are.”

 

Their talk turned to more pleasant topics after that, much to Jeralt’s relief. He didn’t like the church, and he could understand it if Christophe didn’t like it either, it’s just…there was something in the way the younger man voiced his opinion that raised his hackles. Still, he put it out of his mind soon enough in favor of focusing on working through the winter. His band had hunkered down in Gaspard well enough, so there weren’t any concerns about anyone freezing, though they did have the occasional venture out into the surrounding territories for other jobs.

 

It was on one of those trips that they got the news about King Lambert. The king of Faerghus was dead, and Jeralt couldn’t help but wonder if it was just his luck that crap like this kept happening in every country he visited. 

 

A call to arms sounded out, to massacre the people of Duscur for their apparent transgression. It wasn't long before news of Duscur being annexed to the kingdom arrived in the territory, but for the people of Gaspard, the tragedy had yet to end. 

"Wow, I don't think I've seen anyone fish up that much, even in the summer," Ashe said, looking astounded at Byleth as she carried a pail full of fish in one hand while leaning her fishing rod on her shoulder. 

 

"Yeah, By has always been weirdly great at fishing," Shez said, not even trying to be competitive there since she didn’t even like fishing herself. 

 

"Fish are good." Was Byleth’s response as they continued walking. 

 

"Yeah but it's not like we're low on supplies or anything, so you don't need to get so much." 

 

"Hm-" Coming to a sudden stop, Byleth’s eyes snapped forward. "...Shez, wait here with Ashe." 

 

"Huh? By, what's up?" Letting go of the pail and rod, Byleth ran forward, leaving the two behind her as they let out a surprised yell. Arriving at the town, Byleth’s eyes narrowed as she saw several armored knights around Gaspard, with many townsfolk shrinking back and whispering to one another at the sight of them. What caught her attention however, was the amount of knights at the manor. 

 

"Hey, you there, don't move!" called out one of the knights who spotted her. Based on his movements, it was clear he was going to detain her. Not hesitating for a moment, she charged past him, slipping under his arm as she ran towards the manor. "H-Hey, stop her!"

 

Thankfully, despite not being as fast as Shez, her smaller stature meant Byleth was able to move around the knights before they could stop her as she arrived at the manor. 

 

"-u, stop what you're doing!" Came Lonato's voice from upstairs. "There's nothing here!"

 

Rushing upstairs, Byleth pulled out her sword and came to the sight of Lonato standing in front of Ashe's siblings as they cowered behind him, while a knight stood in front of him, making sure he didn't move. 

 

“Release Lord Lonato,” Byleth calmly ordered, keeping an eye on the knight in white armor as he turned towards her.

 

The knight scoffed, the sound reverberating in his helm. He had a broadsword at his side, but he hadn’t drawn it, which was the only reason Byleth hadn’t run him through already. “What’s this supposed to be? Do you allow children into your guard, Lonato?”

 

“I won’t warn you again.”

 

“Byleth, no!” Lonato suddenly said, holding a hand up while keeping the other in front of his younger children, “This man is a Knight of Seiros, you cannot fight him!”

 

Byleth frowned. “Like the saint?”

 

“What are they teaching commoners these days that you don’t even recognize a sworn sword of the goddess?” the knight complained, his hand resting on his sword. His armor wasn’t the heaviest, but platemail was still thick enough that she’d have to aim for his joints if she wanted to do any real damage. “I’ll give you one chance, girl. Lay down your sword, and perhaps I shall not strike you down for raising it in the first place.”

 

“...I have already given you my warning.” It wasn’t a fight she wanted, but if the knight insisted then she would not hesitate.

 

“Tch. Fine then. Take her,” he said, nodding to–

 

Byleth whirled, catching another knight’s blade before it could slice down on her, prompting a shout from Lonato and screams from his children. “YOU SWORE NO ONE WOULD BE HARMED!”

 

“I meant you should restrain her, Sergei,” complained the first knight, audibly irritated, before pausing as Byleth slammed a palm into the second knight’s chest and blasted him with a fireball at point blank range, sending him crashing into the wall behind him. “...Huh. You’re not just some brat then.”

 

Byleth kicked the fallen knight solidly in the head, slamming him further into the wall, before turning to lock eyes with the knight holding Lord Lonato hostage. “...One more chance.”

 

“Hm. I thought your previous warning was my last?”

 

“You told him to restrain me, and you swore to Lord Lonato you wouldn’t hurt anyone. I don’t think you want to.”

 

“I do not. It is my duty to investigate Lord Lonato’s estate following the accusations of treason against his late son, Christophe Gaspard.”

 

“...Late?”

 

The knight nodded. “He is deceased. Executed for his part in the Tragedy of Duscur.”

 

Byleth stared at him, then looked at Lord Lonato, who had gone completely white. “...What…?”

 

The knight didn’t regard him, keeping his eyes fully on Byleth. “Lower your sword, girl. You have already harmed one knight of Seiros. Do not make things worse for yourself.”

 

“...” Byleth raised her free hand towards the fallen knight and a light glow settled over him. “Heal. There. Now no harm has been done.”

 

“...Hahahaha, ah…Alright. I am willing to accept that.” He placed his hand on the hilt of his sword, before drawing it with the faint sound of steel sliding free. Or maybe not steel. Maybe silver, from the gleam of the blade. “What is your name, girl?”

 

“Byleth Eisner. I am a mercenary employed by Lord Lonato.”

 

“Eisner? …No, never mind. I am Gael, a knight in service of the goddess. My name is one She has given to me. Out of respect for your loyalty to your employer, I ask we adjourn to the field outside. I would prefer not to cause undue harm.”

 

“Okay. How many more knights are in the manor?”

 

“More than you can hope to face, girl.”

 

“We’ll see,” Byleth stated, straightening from her stance and looking towards Lonato, who seemed…lost, in a way she hadn’t seen before. His mouth was moving without forming words, his gaze completely unseeing.

 

The knight regarded him for a moment, then sighed. “Outside it is then.”

 

“Right–” The barest flash caught the corner of her eye, letting Byleth turn, moving her sword before it was wrenched from her grip, torn free by the hooks of a strange sword right before a shield emblazoned with a griffin smashed into her hard enough to send her all the way down the hall.

 

Unfamiliar pain blossomed across her face and chest, making it hard to focus, though her vision cleared in time to see the same sword from before, pale and strangely cracked with six hooks jutting from the sides of its blade, pointing straight at her throat.

 

“A kid?” murmured the woman standing over her. Another knight in white armor, this one not wearing a helmet, showing a tanned face and long, blonde hair.

 

“Damn it all, Catherine,” grumbled Gael as he moved out from Lonato’s lounge, “You didn’t need to do that.”

 

“Wh–Sir, she had a sword–”

 

“I had it handled. And now you’ve dishonored me.”

 

“...Hmph.” The woman, Catherine, regarded Byleth with cold, blue eyes. “So what do we do with her? She raised–”

 

“Nothing.”

 

“Wha–Sir! You can’t be serious! She raised a weapon against a Knight of Seiros! And did…whatever happened there to Sergei! You can’t tell me she had nothing to do with him!”

 

“Yes, I can. There was no harm done.” Gael glanced at the fallen knight and gave him a short kick to the leg. “Get up, you lazy bastard.”

 

“Gh, u-uh…w-wait, what–”

 

“I said get up.” Gael turned back to Catherine, his expression hidden but clearly disapproving, as further evidenced by him raising a hand and returning Byleth’s earlier favor, mending the pain she felt as she blinked in some surprise. “As I said, sheathe your sword. We’re done here.”

 

“But–!”

 

“Cassandra…? Why are you here?” Catherine went rigid, her eyes immediately darting towards Lord Lonato as he stepped out from the lounge. 

 

“I-I…I-I, ah…L-Lord Lonato, I need to…speak with you.”

 

“...You did it.” Lonato’s expression couldn’t quite be called surprised. There was recognition in it, realization, a dawning horror, and building anger all at once. “You killed my son.”

 

“...” Catherine swallowed. “...I-I wanted to t–”

 

“You killed my son. You murdered my son! YOU KILLED MY BOY!”

 

Byleth tried to push herself up. Something about the distress in the lord’s voice, the pain and hate in his eyes, made her want to move, to do something–And in a second, the sword was in her face again, Catherine’s eyes returning towards hers in a flash of something impossible to discern.

 

For a moment, it looked like she was going to run Byleth through when Gael’s hand caught her wrist. “I told you, you shouldn’t have been here.”

 

“But–Y-You don’t understand, sir, I was going to–”

 

“Murderers…Murderers, every last one of you!” Lonato snapped, his face red with rage and his eyes narrowed with hate, “GET OUT! GET OUT OF MY HOME! GET OUT OR I WILL KILL ALL OF YOU!”

 

“...You heard him. We are no longer welcome here,” Gael stated, before turning to regard Byleth one more time. “...Hm. Come on, both of you. We won’t find anything here.”

 

Byleth managed to sit up by the time the knights had left. Lonato had collapsed, his face in his hands as heavy sobs wracked his once powerful body. None of that anger was there, only pure grief and despair as the kind noble Byleth knew wailed in open sorrow. There was no noble lord here, only an old man crushed by the reality of outliving his own son.

 

And as she watched, a strange feeling took hold in Byleth’s chest. Something…she didn’t know how to describe. A raw feeling her muted emotions were unused to. There was nothing she could do here, no word of comfort she could offer with her limited experience, and no enemy she could fight. Because the enemy had already left.

 

For the first time…Byleth understood her sister’s desire to surpass her. Though, she didn’t think it was the same thing. Because Shez just wanted to beat her, not really hurt her.

 

Byleth wanted to kill Catherine.

It’d been a long time since Jeralt felt as terrified as he did now.

 

Gaspard was in chaos when he returned with his band. The word on everyone’s lips was “execution” as news spread of how Lord Lonato’s son had died, though that didn’t terrify him. No, what scared him down to his very core were the words “Knights of Seiros”, and, more than that, the knowledge that one of them hurt his kid. That Byleth had fought against them, and the only thing that kept her from being as dead as Christophe was their leader having some sense of restraint.

 

Even then, he wanted to do just like Shez was doing and simply take Byleth in his arms and hold her close so nothing could hurt her again. But he couldn’t, because he had responsibilities, and so he left his youngest daughter clinging to his eldest like a limpet to a rock and tried to figure out just what the hell happened.

 

The story made no sense. The idea that Christophe was involved in the King’s death just felt too impossible. Why would he? What could the young heir of a tiny lordship possibly gain from royal assassination?

 

He could think of a few things, but none of them fit properly. Lonato’s liege lord, Rowe, had a reputation, but then why wasn’t he investigated too? An entire nation was getting butchered in blame for the king’s death, but then some random lordling was also swept up in it? How? Why? And why would the church be involved then?

 

Too many questions raced through Jeralt’s head as he spent his days trying to keep things steady. A part of him wanted to leave the area completely, in case the knights came back, but paranoia of running into them on the road combined with the head of Lonato’s guard offering him a hefty pay to help keep the peace kept him in Gaspard. Even then, when he saw Byleth with an uncharacteristic scowl on her face as she hacked at a training dummy, he really did consider just bolting with her and Shez.

 

“I failed,” was her answer when he asked her what was wrong. “I was supposed to protect Lord Lonato but that knight beat me. She would have killed me.”

 

“...Kid…sometimes, we run into people we can’t beat–”

 

“I know that. You’ve told me. There’s no shame in retreating. She blindsided me. I know we can cheat. I know we should cheat. I was listening to her leader and she attacked me. She attacked me during negotiations and you can never do that because it breaks trust and means everyone will always look at you as an oathbreaker and she did exactly that and I couldn’t stop her.”

 

“...Are you angry?” It seemed impossible, but for the first time, he saw a genuine glare on his daughter’s face.

 

“He was crying. Lord Lonato was crying and she killed his son and she came here just to tell him that. She came here to hurt him and I didn’t stop her from hurting him. Who are the Knights of Seiros?”

 

“Kid…why are you asking that?”

 

“I want to know. Who are the Knights of Seiros?”

 

“...I think you need to calm down–”

 

“Tell me.” Her voice was sharp as she turned towards him. Her grip on her hilt was tight enough to make the blade shake. “Who are the Knights of Seiros? What are they? Why did they do this? What gives them the right?”

 

“The right? That…Kid–”

 

“Just tell me!”

 

He stared at his quiet, unemotive daughter as she snapped at him, her eyes set in a furious glare and her mouth set in an enraged scowl. There was no mistaking her expression for anything but angry, and he never expected to see it.

 

Carefully, he reached for her hand and uncurled her fingers from her sword’s hilt. Her fist was clenched tight and his hands weren’t especially dextrous, but he gradually worked the sword from her grip before he pulled his daughter into a hug. She didn’t pull back, but she didn’t lean in either. She was rigid until she started to shake.

 

It was hard to think she was sixteen already. She was growing more and more, day by day, and he should have expected things would change. He knew she was getting more expressive, but he never thought she would feel things this strongly. That she could genuinely get upset at something like this. But then, injustice had a funny way of bringing out emotion.

 

It was a while before Lord Lonato called on Jeralt again. The already old noble looked worn as he stared out the window in his office, his hands clasped behind his back. Some people would call his appearance dignified, but to Jeralt, he looked like a castle held up by a single support. One that was already cracked straight through the middle.

 

“...I am sorry.”

 

Of all the ways Jeralt expected this conversation to start, that wasn’t one of them. “For what?”

 

“Your daughter was hurt protecting me. I told her not to fight, and they tried to kill her anyway. I am sorry.”

 

“...Thanks. It’s…It’s rough, but I have a feeling you’re going through worse.”

 

“...” Lonato sighed, slowly, still not looking at Jeralt. “My son is dead. The Central Church executed him on charges of treason, blaming him for the Tragedy of Duscur. My son is dead and the truth has been hidden for what I can only assume is convenience. You do not believe my son committed the charges they accused him of.”

 

“I don’t, no.”

 

“...I am glad. It was my first reaction, yet…It is difficult to doubt people. I think we all expect others to be honest. It is a foolish expectation, but one we all hold, as long as there is some trust in our hearts. Though, perhaps ‘expect’ is not the correct word. Maybe it is ‘hope’...”

 

“...Is there a reason you wanted to speak with me?”

 

“You are a mercenary, Jeralt. You are not a knight. You are not beholden to any man except yourself. You will do your job admirably well, but it is merely a job at the end of the day. I was wondering if I may hire you for a job.”

 

“...” Jeralt had a bad feeling. “I can’t promise anything, but I can hear you out.”

 

“Thank you. I expected no less.” Finally, Lonato turned, looking at Jeralt. And it was impossible to mistake the look of restrained rage in his eyes. For some people, anger surged up like a fire, eating up everything and burning out once its fuel was gone. For others though, anger was like a pot of water set atop of an open flame. It simmered, it boiled, but it stayed in the pot unless something finally tipped it out. Lonato was that second type of person. “I want you to kill a woman named Catherine. She was once known as Cassandra Rubens Charon. She is now a Knight of Seiros. Is this something you can do?”

 

“...I can’t.”

 

“I see. She is the woman who almost killed your daughter.”

 

Jeralt felt himself tense on reflex, but he let out a sigh, calming down. “I had a feeling. I still can’t. I need to take care of my kids. I can’t do that if I go up against the Knights of Seiros.”

 

“I can pay you whatever you want. I’m not as wealthy as other lords, I know that, but I can give you as much as I can. Please.”

 

“...Lonato, I can’t. Please, understand. You still have three kids to take care of. Would you put them in danger?”

 

There was a moment where the anger in Lonato’s eyes seemed to flicker. A cool wind keeping the pot from boiling over. “...Very well. I expect you will want to leave soon. I am sorry to have kept you here for so long. Thank you very much for your service.”

 

He bowed his head, and Jeralt felt a flash of guilt that he tried to smother. “...” He wasn’t successful. “I could have my people look into things. Maybe we could find out the truth behind Christophe’s death. If that would help.”

 

“...” Lonato just shook his head. “No. No, you are right. I would not wish what I am feeling now on anyone I consider a friend. You have children to take care of, and so do I. Thank you for all your efforts. I hope your coming days are brighter than…I hope you take care.”

 

“Thanks. You take care too, alright?” And Jeralt left with a pit in his stomach. He wasn’t a hero, he could admit that much, but it felt wrong to leave things as they were.

 

Then again, he was a mercenary. And no merc would stick around somewhere there was too much risk and no real reward.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: So, guess they're not staying in the kingdom much longer

Red: Alas. Faerghus is a tragic place, filled with sadness. Except for that one duchy that has really good apples, they seem to be doing well for themselves.

Indi: If only Ezra recommended that place instead.

Red: That would've had a completely different result, yeah. Just a complete alternate timeline where they go to the Ifan duchy instead and zero problems came from it and nobody gets traumatized by Faerghus.

Indi: oh well, such is life. Anyways before we go, just wanted to recommend something! Apparently someone got inspired by our story to write their own called Blade Breaker and Bone Mender, yall should check it out!

Red: Yeah! It's very neat to see people getting inspired by our stuff! So give it a look! And thanks as always for reading!

Unfamiliar Anger

Chapter by RK3996

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

It was weird seeing Byleth actually be angry. Shez had gotten used to her adoptive older sister being very…well, she wasn’t really apathetic, exactly. That wasn’t the right word for it. 

 

It wasn’t that Byleth was an uncaring person, it’s just that she cared less than other people. Which still sounded bad, but it wasn’t! It was just how she was. Things that might make someone else mad didn’t bother her, and something that would make someone really angry would, at most, slightly annoy her. And it wasn’t like she didn’t react to things either, she would definitely react if someone, such as Shez, did stuff like poke her while she was trying to sleep and tried to steal food from her plate. It’s just that she didn’t react strongly .

 

So it was really, really weird seeing her so agitated ever since they left Gaspard.

 

“Eh, I wouldn’t get worked up about it,” said Candace when Shez brought up the subject while on kitchen duty, “She’s at that age where she’s bound to get moody. I remember being a real bitch when I was sixteen.”

 

“That’s not it, moron,” Victor chided, frowning at the dirty-blonde lancer from where he was dicing the meat for the night’s stew, “Weren’t you paying attention at all while we were back in Gaspard territory? She was friends with that lord’s son and then he went and got executed.”

 

“Oh, was that it? Huh. Hey, you think she had a crush on him?”

 

“What? Are you seriously asking that?”

 

“Hey, it would make sense. She’s also at the age to start noticing boys, so I wouldn’t be surprised.”

 

“...I don’t think Byleth likes boys,” Shez pointed out, glancing at the slightly taller woman who was stirring the pot while Shez peeled the vegetables. 

 

“She doesn’t? Huh…Yeah, I could see that, that makes sense.”

 

“Can you hold a consistent opinion for one minute?” Victor griped, and Shez came to the conclusion she really shouldn’t ask the other mercenaries for advice.

 

"Perhaps you would care to listen to my advice then?" Arval asked as Shez continued to peel. 

 

Letting out a sigh, Shez nodded, not wanting the others to hear her talk with Arval. 

 

"Good, now, while I feel odd advising you about your rival in this manner, but if, as you say, your sister does not react strongly to things, then should it not be obvious how badly this is affecting her from how she is reacting to it?" Arval asked as they floated by her. "As such, you have one of two options: you may either ignore this all entirely and let her deal with her emotions, or you can go talk with her." 

 

"...about what?" 

 

"You are her sister, are you not? I'm sure you can think of something to talk with her about," Arval said as they disappeared, which wasn’t helpful in the slightest. Clenching her teeth, Shez continued to peel the vegetables as quickly as she could so she could talk with Byleth. 

 

Minutes later, Shez was out of the kitchen tent, searching for Byleth. Who was easy to find as she spotted her on the training grounds, her sword smacking a training dummy hard enough to break it. Frustrated, Byleth kicked the broken dummy to the side as she began to set up another one. 

 

"Hey, By,” Shez spoke up, making her sister glance over at her. "I see training is going well." 

 

"Hm." Byleth responded, making sure the second dummy was stable. 

 

"So, uh, I wanted to talk, if you have the time?" 

 

"...Make it quick." 

 

"By…I don't really know what to say, but I'm really worried! You haven't been acting like yourself, and I don't like how bad you're feeling!" 

 

"Is that all?" 

 

"Wh–Hey, come on By, I'm trying to talk with you!" Shez said, feeling indignant at getting brushed aside like that. "You can't just ignore me cause you're feeling bad!" 

 

"I'm in the middle of training, you should go back to help with kitchen duty." 

 

"Seriously!?" Shez stared in disbelief as Byleth turned away from her so she could strike at the training dummy. "Don't ignore me!" 

 

The loud thwack of a sword hitting the training dummy was the only response she got. 

 

Gritting her teeth, Shez felt a swell of anger in her as her sister paid her no attention. As such, she did the only thing she could think of. Bringing her fist up, Shez punched Byleth across the cheek, knocking her to the ground.

 

Byleth blinked, genuine surprise crossing her face as she looked up at her sister. "Sh-Shez-"

 

"I win!" Shez shouted before Byleth could finish speaking. "So that means I'm the older sister now! That means you have to listen to me!" 

 

"That wasn't a fi-" 

 

"And as the older sister, I'm telling you, you aren't allowed to leave me behind anymore!" Shez shouted, feeling tears well up. "You can't go off on your own if you think something dangerous is happening! We're stronger together!" 

 

Byleth stared at her, her usually dull eyes wide with disbelief and confusion, before she pushed herself up. Shez clenched and unclenched her fists, hating the tears that threatened to spill from her eyes, but she kept her gaze steady on her sister as Byleth continued to stare at her, her cheek red where Shez punched her.

 

“...”

 

“...You can’t run off like that,” Shez insisted, “You almost…I wasn’t even there. I-I had to hear from Gertrude that you almost died. You can’t do that to me! You’re my sister, you’re not allowed to die!”

 

“...”

 

“S-Say something! Please, talk to me!”

 

“...You almost died before,” Byleth muttered with an unexpected heat in her voice. She couldn’t seem to let go of her sword, her grip shifting as a strange tension filled her body. “You were stabbed. I wasn’t.”

 

“Wh–Th-That’s different though! I have powers you don’t!”

 

“It is different. You killed the soldier that hurt you. I couldn’t do anything.” Her grip tightened on her sword. “I don’t understand why I feel like this. I never have before. I don’t understand it, everything feels tight and tense and there’s this pressure I can’t do anything about.”

 

“...You’re angry,” Shez realized. It wasn’t quite a revelation, or at least it shouldn’t be, but a part of her still thought her sister just couldn’t get mad the way other people did. “By, that’s natural. Remember the expression things I made years ago? Everybody gets angry!”

 

“I don’t.”

 

“Well obviously you do! What else would you call this?”

 

“I don’t know, I haven’t felt it before. I didn’t feel it when that noble harassed us, I didn’t feel it when you almost died, I’ve never felt it, so why am I feeling it now? I barely know Lonato, he was just a client, so why am I angry? You’re not.”

 

“Well, yeah, but I’m different from you. I don’t know why I’m not more mad, I just don’t get that angry when people die.” She shrugged. “I guess I’m too used to it.”

 

“...So why do you care that I almost died?”

 

Shez went rigid, feeling like her sister just punched her in turn. A flicker of concern crossed Byleth’s face.

 

“Shez?”

 

“How can you ask that? Y-You…You should know! Of course I’m more upset–It’s just different! You’re my family! Of course I care! You cared when you thought I died, right?” She hated how weak her voice got there, naturally shrinking back at what she was almost positive the answer would be–

 

“Yes. Yes, I did, I cared, I was…” Byleth’s breath shook, and Shez was shocked to see tears starting to prick at her eyes. “...I don’t understand. I don’t know what I’m feeling. I don’t know why it hurts…”

 

Shez hugged her sister. She just…It felt like the only thing she could do.

 

“...” Byleth was being hugged again. Something deep in her chest hurt like it never had before. She dropped her sword and wrapped her arms around her sister, startled by the sudden sob she let out. Though…she wasn’t completely sure which of them started crying. Just that she couldn’t bear to let go.

Some time later, Jeralt was face to face with his two daughters, both of whom were red in the eyes and their hands in an iron grip of one another. He had heard what had happened, the two girls didn't really make an attempt to be secretive earlier, so word got back to him quickly. Even so, he still took the time to prepare himself as he got ready for what was to come. 

 

"What are the Knights of Seiros?" Shez asked. 

 

Jeralt sighed. It was a long, deep sigh, carrying far too much weight with it. He looked at his kids, both unwavering as they stared at him, before he nodded, accepting this wasn’t a conversation he could put off any longer.

 

“The Knights of Seiros are the military arm of the Central Church. They’re a knightly order dedicated to upholding the will of the Goddess as the Church defines it. If the church needs something handled with violence, the knights are who they call on for it. And I used to be one of them.” He didn’t like the look Byleth gave him there. It was strangely startled and affronted. Not quite betrayed, but…He still didn’t like it. “Specifically, I used to be their captain. The leader of the knights as a whole.”

 

Byleth’s grip tightened around Shez’s hand. Shez looked at her, then back at her dad. “...Maybe we should sit down?”

 

“Yeah, that might be a good idea.” He didn’t have too much room in his tent, but he could at least pull over a chair while his kids sat on his bed. It gave him a moment to collect his thoughts. “...I was born in Faerghus a long time ago. I was a mercenary. Not really anyone special, but I did get lucky in a sense. I was hired to help guard the Archbishop Rhea, the leader of the church, on a trip through the kingdom, and I nearly died protecting her. She healed me, and I joined the Knights of Seiros.

 

“I was pretty good at it, I’m not going to lie. I became captain for a reason and things were fine. I followed my orders and protected the Archbishop. And then…I met your mother.” 

 

He looked towards Byleth, who just stared back at him, then glanced at Shez, who looked a little uncomfortable at hearing something so personal, but kept close to her sister anyway.

 

“...I won’t go into all the details, but I fell in love with her,” he continued, “I loved her more than anyone I ever met before. I loved her more than the sky loves the stars. I loved her enough to have a kid with her. And I was so happy to think I would have a family with her.

 

“And then she died. Rhea was the one that helped deliver you, Byleth, and she said Sitri died in childbirth…but something about it…She wouldn’t let me see Sitri’s body. And the way she held you…it felt like she wanted to take you away. The way she acted, the way everything looked…It broke whatever trust I had in her. So I left. I set a fire at the monastery and I abandoned everything I knew there because I couldn’t trust it any longer. I needed to keep you safe, and the monastery stopped feeling safe.

 

He sighed. “...I still don’t know if that was the right choice. I–”

 

“It was.”

 

Jeralt paused, then looked at Byleth. He didn’t expect her to interrupt him, but the look in her eyes was steely and certain. 

 

“If you didn’t leave, we wouldn’t have met Shez. So you made the right choice." 

 

"Y-Yeah! And you wouldn't have met everyone else either!" Shez exclaimed as well. "It's been…rough, but I'm really glad I joined you guys. If those knights are gonna be a problem, then that just means I have to get stronger so they can't hurt you two!" 

 

"I'll make sure they can't hurt you two as well," Byleth said with quiet determination. 

 

"..." Letting out a sigh, he leaned back in his chair. "I will say, I never would have thought taking you in would have led to something like this, Shez, but I'm glad I did." 

 

"I am too!" Shez declared, earning an agreeing nod from Byleth. "And now that we know this stuff, we can make sure to avoid the knights and the monastery!" 

 

"...Is this why you didn't want us to join the academy?" Byleth asked, looking thoughtful.

 

Jeralt nodded. "Yeah, the academy is at the monastery, so no way I was taking a chance with the two of you going there."

 

"Heh, well, not like we were ever going there anyways,” Shez dismissed, “And I doubt you'd ever take a job there." 

 

"Trust me kid, I don't plan on it. Now come on, we should get something to eat before only the vegetables are left in the stew," Jeralt said, getting up to get his daughters to do the same. 

 

"Well as the older sister, I clearly deserve first dibs!" 

 

"...right, you two really need to explain that thing of yours to me." Jeralt muttered as the trio went out, a family affirmed once again. 

Chapter End Notes

Indi: So we realized it was Byleth’s birthday and decided to drop another chapter, and big reveals is certainly quite the present for her!
