Red: Such a lovely birthday present: getting to feel genuine anger for the first time in her life and nearly breaking down emotionally because of it.

Indi: Yup yup, definitely an interesting thing with Byleth, her emotions are so normally muted it doesn't really show itself unless it's something very strong, which well, anger can be pretty strong.

Red: Yep. As Shez notes, Byleth's not emotionless, her emotions are just muted. Really if she did have things working right, she'd basically be in a berserk rage with the level of anger she's feeling. Course that means it's just pent up without a real outlet until she's finally pushed to react.

Indi: Yup yup, but hey, while it might not be the best first emotion to feel intensely, it's definitely not going to be the only one!

Red: But that's to come later! For now, hope you all enjoyed and thanks for reading!

The Years Between

Chapter by RK3996

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

“Captain, it’s time.”

 

Jeralt paused, then glanced up from his ledgers at his mercenary band’s longest lasting healer. Getrude looked oddly serious, which was…concerning. “Right…that time.”

 

“Yes.”

 

“...” Alright, what time could she mean? Time to move on? They’d only just gotten back into the Alliance after another trip into the Empire, so it probably wasn’t that…they didn’t have any jobs lined up either, which was why he was sitting in an inn instead of out in a tent. It was summer, so it wasn’t Byleth or Shez’s birthday…It wasn’t his anniversary either, and he was pretty sure Getrude didn’t even know when that was, nor would she care. She and Ezra had a thing going, but she didn’t look pregnant… “Yeah, I have no idea what you mean.”

 

“I figured, but I wanted to see if you would guess right.” He sighed at her blunt response, prompting a slight grin from her. “It’s time your daughters got new clothes again.”

 

“Again? Wait, really? What’s wrong with their old clothes?”

 

“Aside from the fact that Byleth tore through the shirt she was putting on this morning?”

 

He blinked. “That happened?”

 

“It did. I’m surprised you didn’t hear Shez mocking her for it.”

 

Well that did explain the laughter he heard earlier… “Are you sure we need to buy new ones though? We should have more clothes in storage.”

 

“Captain, you can’t just keep giving your daughters hand-me-downs. Byleth is eighteen and Shez is…whatever age she is. They’re growing girls with their own body types and you can’t just toss tunics at them and hope they’ll fit.”

 

“...Are you sure? We should have something–”

 

“Jeralt, your daughter ripped through a shirt because her boobs are too big. I’m buying her clothes today. Now fork over some coin for it or I’ll use the medical funds.”

 

“...” Jeralt sighed. “Fine, alright. Buy whatever they need. I was checking the ledgers today anyway so I’ll just make a note of whatever you spend.”

 

“Good.” With that, she walked off, and Jeralt returned to his accounting. Hopefully they wouldn’t rack up too big an expense.

“Do we really need new clothes?” Byleth asked as she followed Getrude and Candace through town. Shez was along with her, of course, wearing an admittedly ill-fitting orange tunic. “My coat is still fine.”

 

“You can’t walk around in just a coat, Byleth,” Gertrude chided, “There’s a word for that and you don’t want it associated with you.”

 

“Sides, is it really such a bad thing?” Candace asked, glancing back at the two girls, “It’s a girls’ day out! Youngsters like you oughta be happy to have fun like this!”

 

“What’s fun about clothes shopping?” Shez asked.

 

“Lots of stuff! You try things on, see how they look, pick it if it’s comfy and not too pricey, that sort of thing!”

 

“...I don’t really get how that’s fun?”

 

“You’ll know it when you try it! First things though, we gotta find a clothes place…Hey, Gert, which one’s the fancy type?”

 

“It depends. Some tailors are fancy.”

 

“Nah, tailors are the type that mend clothes. I think. It’s, uh….no, I know this one.”

 

“A boutique?”

 

“Yeah! One of those! They usually got good clothes for ladies. Granted, none of us are ladies in the noble sense, but we’re still women so it should work. I think.”

 

Byleth and Shez shared a look while Getrude tapped her chin in thought. “Well, if you spot a boutique, we could give it a try. We’re in Leicester right now, so they’re slightly less likely to throw us out for not being well-dressed enough.”

 

“Wait, how’s that work?” Shez asked, “I thought the point of a clothes shop was to buy clothes, why would you have to dress up for it?”

 

“Ask the nobility, Shez. The bourgeois make the rules, we just have to follow them.”

 

“That’s stupid.”

 

“It’s society. But let’s leave the heavy topics for later. For now, that looks like a nice place.”

 

And so the Eisner sisters were introduced to the enjoyable and/or frustrating activity that was shopping for clothes. Now, it wasn’t as though the concept completely eluded the two sisters, it’s just that their circumstances hadn’t really required buying clothes for specifically personal use before this point. More often, the two would, as part of their chores, put in an order for a bulk amount of clothes and armor when needed, and then just take whatever worked best for them.

 

Byleth tended to prefer black and gray clothes while Shez liked brown and orange, with the occasional splash of red in the mix, so they really didn’t have to worry much when it came to clothes they would like. Which also meant they hadn’t really experimented with styles before this point, and, well.

 

While it didn’t take long for Shez to pick out some simple dresses and tunics that she liked, ones that would be easy enough to armor up later and could be worn easily enough with what shorts and pants she also picked out, Byleth decided to experiment a bit.

 

“Uh, By? Did you rip through another shirt?” Shez asked.

 

“No, I didn’t. This one is just like this.”

 

Shez raised an eyebrow. “It’s supposed to show off your chest and belly like that?”

 

“Yes. I like it. The pink lining is nice.”

 

“Huh. Well I guess if you like it,” Shez said with a shrug, before idly considering if she should add something to spice up her own outfit. She liked what she picked out, but maybe it could be more colorful?

 

While Shez went off to explore her options, Byleth returned to her own exploration, starting with some leggings that looked interesting. And some heeled boots that looked interesting. And a detached shirt collar that looked interesting. And huh, those shorts looked cute. Oh, and so did that pendant with the tassel! Hm, maybe she should add more tassels to her clothes?

 

By the time Gertrude and Candance found Byleth again, they found her in a rather…interesting outfit. 

 

"Byleth, what are you wearing?" 

 

"My new outfit, what do you think?" Byleth asked, seeming excited about what she chose. 

 

"Uh…" 

 

"It looks great!" Candace said, grinning giving the younger merc a thumbs up. 

 

"Thank you." Byleth seemed quite happy that her fashion sense was appreciated, while Gertrude muttered to herself that at least it fit her. Thankfully they didn't have to wait long for Shez to come back, who was definitely more modestly dressed, even if the colors were a bit garish. 

 

"Hey, look what I found!" Shez said, gesturing to an over the shoulder cape, before moving it around her head. "Works as a cape and a scarf!" 

 

"Handy," Byleth noted, while Gertrude wondered where these two got their sense of fashion. 

 

"Well, is that all?" the medic asked, already doing some mental math about how much this would all cost. 

 

"Yeah, I think I'm good," Shez responded as Byleth nodded. 

 

"Great, then let's go pay!" Candance said, immediately getting the attention of a redheaded worker. 

 

"I can help you right here with that!" Anna said, all grins as she was ready to get paid. "Now all together that should be two thousand gold~!" 

 

"Eh? What are you talking about? This can't be worth more than twelve hundred," Candace immediately responded with a frown. "They weren't even proper outfits, it's different pieces they grabbed." 

 

"..." Anna's smile got very strained there. "Be that as it may, these are all made out of the highest quality material around, and I can guarantee you they're worth the price." 

 

"Worth market price, sure, but how much did you mark it up?" Candace asked, before glancing around the store. "I'm seeing plenty of things around here that seem to be twice the price than the usual." 

 

"I sincerely hope you aren't trying to accuse me of scamming my customers." 

 

"Of course not, just saying you want to make a profit, and I'm sure you made more than enough to let some things slide," Candance said, before smirking. "Though if you aren't makin’ that much, well, I can understand being in need of money. Why I'm sure I can spread the word around of you raising your prices cause you need the money." 

 

"..." Yeah the smile looked almost murderous now. "...Ah, my apologies, it seems those items were meant to go on sale. It seems you are right, they were meant to just be twelve hundred!" 

 

"Heh, glad we can do business then!" Candace said, smiling again. 

 

"Thanks, Candace, you really know how to help a gal save some money," Gertrude praised as she paid. 

 

"Kinda feel like Candance would be scary as a merchant," Shez muttered. 

 

"Oh, I was!" the blonde admitted, much to their surprise. "Yeah, it didn't go so well, cause people kept thinking I was trying to strongarm them into buying stuff." 

 

"...Huh." 

 

"Hm. I’m glad you joined up," Byleth said. 

 

"Aw, I'm glad I did as well!" 

 

"Heh, well come on now, sweet as this is, we shouldn't keep your dad waiting," Gertrude said, getting the kids to move along as they went back to camp. Mainly because she wanted to see how Jeralt would react to these outfits. 

 

It was a good decision all around, really, because seeing him nearly choke on his tea was hilarious.

"Hey Shez, do you mind helping me cut my hair?" Byleth asked her sister one day upon noticing how long her hair had gotten, already going down her back. 

 

"Hm? Oh sure!" Shez responded with a smile, tossing the book she was reading onto her bedroll. "You know, you don't need to cut it all the time. Look at me, my hair is super long and I don't have any problems with it.”

 

"I just don't like having long hair," Byleth said as she handed her dagger to Shez. "Gets in the way." 

 

"Fine, fine." Shez said, taking the dagger as she got to work on her sister's hair once they sat down. "Same as usual?"

 

"Yeah." Byleth responded, feeling her sister grab her hair and begin to cut it. 

 

"Hmph, just goes to show how much better you are since you don't have to worry about your hair mid combat." Arval commented. 

 

“C’mon, Arval, would you cut it out for once?” Shez requested, speaking freely with her partner since it was just her and Byleth, who didn’t mind if her sister talked to herself.

 

“Oh fine, if you insist. I will ‘cut it out’ just like you just cut out a bigger chunk of hair than you intended.”

 

“What?” Shez glanced at her partner, then looked at the clump of hair in her hand. Then she looked at Byleth’s hair and noticed it did look distinctly uneven. “Oh, that’s an easy fix.”

 

“What’s an ‘easy fix’?” Byleth asked.

 

“Eh, just cut a little more than I meant to. It’s fine, you wanted your hair short anyway, right? Here, I’ll just even it out,” Shez said, moving to grab hair from the other side. 

 

"Just be careful, okay?" Byleth asked as Shez tried to cut the same amount from the other side. 

 

"Uh…do you care about how short it is?" 

 

"I'd prefer it around my shoulders."

 

"...Ah." 

 

"Shez, if it's too much I can handle it-" 

 

"No no, it's all good!" Shez responded, even as she realized she got it wrong. Well, that’s fine, she could just cut from the other side…And then she frowned she noticed she actually cut too much there. So she tried to get it from the opposite side, and…Hm. “Huh…ah, okay, I think it’s…more even now.”

 

“...Shez, I’m feeling…something. And I’m not sure what it is.”

 

“Oh, uh…that’s probably joy! At how great your haircut is!” 

 

“Are you trying to make her look like your father?” Arval queried, floating above the two of them with a pensive look.

 

“What? No, she doesn’t look like dad…does she?”

 

“...Shez. Why would I look like dad?” Byleth asked, definitely feeling new emotions now.

 

“Uh…you don’t! You look great! I just need to take some from the back…probably.” 

 

Reaching up, Byleth tried to feel her hair, only to touch the sides of her head. 

 

"..." 

 

"...Maybe if I just-" Before she could try anything, Shez felt Byleth grab her hand. 

 

"Let go of the knife, and please leave the tent for now." Feeling very sheepish, Shez did, muttering out a sorry as she left the tent. 

 

"So it seems professional barbering is not in your future," Arval said, quite amused. 

 

"That only happened cause you distracted me!" Shez hissed out. 

 

"What distracted you?" Jeralt asked, walking up to Shez. 

 

"O-Oh, nothing dad!" 

 

"Hm, well, is Byleth okay? Wanted to check up on you two before we broke camp." Jeralt explained, before he heard the tent flap open. "Oh, Byleth-...why are you wearing a helmet?" 

 

Looking behind her, Shez winced as she saw Byleth wearing a leather helmet, normally reserved for sparring. 

 

"Felt like it," Byleth said, before walking past the two. 

 

"Hm, is she in a bad mood or something?" 

 

"Ah well, you know, probably just woke up on the bad side of the bedroll!" Shez tried to hurriedly explain. Looking at her sister, Shez couldn't help but wince once again at what she had done. She could probably make it up to her later, right? Right.

 

“Maybe you could even it out further by shaving her bald–”

 

“Shut up, Arval!”

“Alright girls, gather around,” Victor requested, gesturing for the Eisner sisters to take a seat at the same table as him, “Your old uncle Victor is going to be teaching you one of the most important lessons a merc can learn in this line of work: how to gamble.”

 

“...” Byleth exchanged a look with Shez, before they both said what they were thinking: “How is gambling important to being a mercenary?”

 

“You’re dad’s brother?”

 

Byleth paused, then sighed at Shez’s confused response while Victor laughed. “Nope, there’s no relation between us. I was trying for a term of endearment thing–Ah, never mind, it doesn’t matter. The real important part is making sure you two kids know what you’re doing when you inevitably run into someone looking to take advantage of you.”

 

“Stab them twice in the gut,” Byleth answered.

 

“That’s illegal,” Victor promptly responded, then paused, “Unless they’re an outlaw. Then, legally speaking, you can kill them however you want. Just don’t torture them because that’s a great way to get branded an outlaw instead because the nobles think you’re creepy.”

 

“Did you ever torture anyone?” Shez asked, genuinely curious.

 

“Nah, I’m not the type. Too squeamish,” answered the man the two girls had seen crush a bandit’s head with a warhammer just two days ago. “I did know a guy who did though and yeah, he was regarded as a real freak. Hm, that was a while back, thinking about it. I wonder what Metodey is up to these days…ah, never mind. My point is, there’s gonna be folks who will offer gambles and you might be pressured to join in. Or, hell, you might even think it’s fun to join in. If you refuse outright, it should be fine, but on the off chance you do decide to gamble, think back to this lesson so you know what to do. That being to cheat, enormously and without reservation.”

 

“Got it,” Byleth said, nodding to show her understanding.

 

Shez, meanwhile, just looked confused. 

 

"First and foremost is making sure you know how to catch a cheat," Victor said, pulling out a deck of cards. "There's plenty of ways to cheat, and plenty of ways to slip up." He set the cards between them. "Here, cut the deck for me–not with a knife. Just grab the deck and separate it in two." 

 

Sheathing her dagger, Byleth grabbed the deck, grabbing about half or so and setting it down next to the first deck. 

 

"Now then, let's start simple: guess which card I'm about to draw, and the closest guess to what card it is wins. Here, I'll start my guess: it'll be a three of clubs." 

 

"Hm…eight of hearts." 

 

"I'll go with a king then! Of clubs!" Grinning, Victor flipped the card over, showing a three of clubs. 

 

"And if we were betting money, you would have gotten cheated out of it. Second lesson, always make sure to shuffle the deck yourself, and third–" He flicked a card out of his sleeve. "Make sure it isn't tampered with beforehand." 

 

“...Wait, how’s that tampering with the deck?” Shez asked, “That card wasn’t in the deck.”

 

“Yes it was.”

 

“...h…huh?”

 

Victor chuckled, before going through what his sleight of hand step by step, showing where he’d stacked the card so it stuck out of the deck just enough for him to position it without them noticing and when he’d slipped the card up his sleeve to make sure the card he wanted was on top. “See? Now, that’s not the only way to tamper with a deck. You can do it in subtle ways like I did, or you can mark the cards ahead of time, if you’re using your own deck. There are ways to subtly mark them too, if you bend the cards in certain ways, but of course most of these tricks work better if you have a pal at the table helping you out.”

 

“Uh…huh.” Shez nodded, still looking a little lost while Byleth was quietly absorbing all the new information. “So…me and Byleth would do better if we were helping each other?”

 

“Exactly. Though you might want to let Byleth be the one helping you, Shez. You’re looking kinda lost.”

 

“H-Hey, I can do it! I just need to practice!”

 

“Sure, but there’s nothing wrong with not getting it. Like I said, it usually works better if there’s two of you cheating together. Like Byleth playing as the dealer and making sure you get the best cards at the table.”

 

“I don’t need help though,” Shez insisted, frowning, which prompted a chuckle from Victor.

 

“Shez, let me make something clear, alright? It’s okay if you’re not the best at everything. You can try to be, if you want, but you’re gonna have spots you aren’t as good in. You don’t see me trying to ride a horse like Candace or heal people like Gertrude, right?”

 

“Or stab people like Ezra,” Byleth suggested.

 

“No, I can do everything better than that stringbean. Aside from maybe lockpicking, I’m willing to give him that one, even if I could do the exact same thing with a big enough rock…my point is, there’s no such thing as being intelligent. You’re always gonna be smart in some ways and dumb in others. You won’t have the brains to do everything, so let other people pick up the slack, alright? You already know you’re stronger working with your sister than against her, so just keep that in mind when it comes to other stuff too.”

 

“…Hmph. I thought you were teaching us how to cheat, not trying to give life lessons,” Shez complained.

 

“Learning how to cheat is a life lesson, squirt. And hey, while I have you here, how about I impart another one? In this case, a lesson about cultural differences.” 

 

With that, Victor shuffled the deck together again before placing it back on the table. Then he placed two more card decks on the table with an amused grin on his bearded face. “Alright, what’s the difference?”

 

“...Uh…oh, uh, that deck’s red, that deck’s blue, and that deck is, uh...I guess that’s a kind of greenish color?” Shez offered.

 

“It’s olive green,” Byleth said, “It also has a shield on the back.”

 

“I was getting to that part!”

 

“Heh, you’re right enough, sure. The covers all look different. Flip them over though, and what do you see?” Victor asked while flipping the first card of each deck, showing a line of Aces.

 

“...Hey, wait, these two look weird,” Shez noted, pointing to the cards from the blue and green decks. “The symbols are all different.”

 

“Right you are, Shez. This one, from the Imperial Standard deck–” He tapped the card that came from his original deck. “–is an Ace of Spades. But this one here, from the Kingdom Standard deck–” He tapped the card from the blue deck. “–is an Ace of Swords, while this one–” And lastly, he tapped the card from the green deck. “–is an Ace of Snow. Care to guess where it comes from?”

 

“The Alliance,” Byleth answered, earning a grin from the burly merc.

 

“Exactly. You see, while most gambling houses you can name will use the Imperial Standard deck. It’s recognizable, everyone knows what’s up with it, there’s no worries. But some folks from the Kingdom, in all their infinite wisdom, decided an Imperial deck wouldn’t do for them, so they decided to change things up. Instead of the standard spades, hearts, clubs, diamonds, the Kingdom went for swords, cups, staves, and coins, and instead of Imperial Red, they went for Kingdom Blue.

 

Victor spread the cards out as he explained, showing that each of them was marked differently, and where the hearts and diamonds were printed in red ink, the cups and coins were printed in blue. “Not the brightest idea, given it meant Faerghan printing houses had to commission an entire different set of woodblocks to make their versions of cards, but they did it anyway because Faerghans are nothing if not stubborn dastards. Which leads us right over to the Alliance cards, which do things completely differently.”

 

Once more he laid out the cards and Shez blinked at the sudden wash of color. “Oh wow, these are pretty.”

 

“Ain’t they? See, these sets of cards went for something very different from the standard set, drawing off of old stories instead of recognizable implements and symbols. So for card suits, you have the snow, the flowers, the moons, and the gales,” he explained, gesturing in turn to the azure snowflakes, the crimson flowers, the golden moons, and the emerald spirals printed on each card, “Though I’ll add that these colors ain’t always consistent. The gales are always green and the flowers are always red, but sometimes you get decks with the snowflakes printed in silver and the moons colored a deep blue. Why the change up? Who knows. Way I heard it, it has to do with the seasons, though I personally think gold works for a better Autumn color than blue.”

 

“...Uh…huh. And…what’s all this supposed to mean?” Shez asked, “You’re trying to say something about the nations, right? And how everybody does things differently?”

 

“Oh sure, there’s that, but I’m also saying you need to check which deck someone’s using before you try to cheat them.” Victor barked a laugh as Shez frowned at him. “Ha! Ah, more seriously, consider this an easy way of looking at the countries around here. Adrestia sets the standard, Faerghus goes out of their way to do the opposite while still copying them, and Leceister goes off and does its own thing that’s barely even consistent.”

 

“Huh. Yeah okay, that makes sense,” Shez said, nodding along, “…Hey, could you show me some more card tricks?”

 

“Sure I can! And after that, how bout I show you two how to cheat at dice?”

 

“Heck yeah!” Shez cheered, a big grin on her face as Byleth idly studied the cards on the table. She understood what Victor was going for, but the metaphor seemed kind of silly to her. 

 

Even if there were differences in the symbols, they were all still playing cards at the end of the day. There wasn’t that much difference between them.

Riding on horseback in combat felt completely different than fighting on foot. You could have more speed, and each swing you made had more weight to it. However, it also had its difficulties… 

 

"Agh, come on!" Shez shouted as she missed a swing at a dummy, the horse she was on rushing straight passed it. "Why is this so weird?!" 

 

"You do tend to go for rapid strikes with two swords. So going for a heavy swing with one sword is completely different," Byleth noted as Shez came back, jumping off Argo as she grumbled. 

 

"Feh, don't see why I have to train for horseback." 

 

"It's handy," Byleth said, holding out an apple for Argo, the horse eating it before nuzzling against her hand. 

 

"Doesn't matter if it's handy if I can't hit anything." 

 

“It does matter to practice though. You never know when we might need to fight while riding.” She glanced over at their barrels of weapons. “Maybe you should try it with a lance? You might feel better with it.”

 

“I don’t know how you’re so good with everything you use,” Shez complained, pouting, “I swear, it’s like you have a natural instinct for any weapon someone puts in your hand.”

 

“That’s not true. I’m average with anything that’s not a sword.” She paused. “Or my fists, I guess.”

 

“Being average with everything is still better than being bad at some things!” Shez huffed, then glanced at the lances. “Maybe I should just try one of those? But that’s learning a whole different thing…is there a way to fight with two swords on top of a horse?”

 

“Probably. That sounds like a bad idea though.”

 

“Yeah, I guess…It would be kind of cool to be a strong knight like dad though…hm.” The thought of her, Byleth, and their dad all dressed up as full knights on horseback crossed Shez’s mind, and she had to admit it wasn’t a bad image. Byleth could probably be one of those fancy knights with the light magic in the stories, and Shez could be her dark counterpart! All dark and edgy and…hm, wait, did she have the right temperament to be a dark knight? Byleth was the stoic one, so…

 

“What are you thinking about?” Byleth asked, prompting a shrug from Shez.

 

“Just if I could be a scary dark knight. I’m not all stoic and stuff, so I think I have to go the other direction and act crazy instead.”

 

“...Don’t act crazy. People won’t hire you if they think you’re a murderous lunatic.”

 

“It’s part of the style!” Shez complained, pouting, before studying her sister with a speculative eye. “...No, you couldn’t be a dark knight. You seem stoic, but you’re way too soft on the inside.”

 

“...I’m soft?”

 

“Yeah, you know, you’re sweet. You don’t even like killing bugs.”

 

Byleth frowned. “They’re not bothering anyone.”

 

“See? Way too soft. You need your big, strong older sister to protect you!”

 

“Since when were you older?”

 

“Since last time, don’t think about it.” Shez grinned, before a thought occurred. “Actually, here!”

 

Byleth blinked as Shez suddenly handed her something. She raised an eyebrow as she looked at the small whistle in her hand. “...What is this?”

 

“A merc whistle! You know, like the one dad gave us when we were on lookout all the way in Sauin.”

 

“The one you took off with by accident?” She paused. “Is this that same whistle?”

 

“...Ehhh, might be. Either way! I figure you should have it! That way, if anything ever happens to you, you can blow it and I’ll come running!”

 

“...” Byleth lightly punched Shez’s shoulder.

 

“Hey! Rude! Here I am, offering to protect you, and you hit me!” She pouted, though she grinned about a second later. “You like it, huh?”

 

“...Yeah. I don’t have anything for you though.”

 

“Eh, I don’t need anything. As the older sister, I’m the one that protects you, you know?”

 

“Hm. As the actual older sister, I’ll make sure to return the favor.”

 

“As the actual actual older sister, I can tell you right now that you don’t need to.”

 

“Yes I do.” She paused. “Actually, I know what you could use. A tactics primer.”

 

“Wh–Hey! I don’t need one of those! I’m doing just fine with what I’ve got!”

 

“Yeah, I’ll make sure to write one up for you. That way you can learn everything you need from your much more experienced older sister.”

 

Shez narrowed her eyes. “...Get a horse. We’re going to joust for this.”

 

“Okay, sure. Don’t be upset when you lose.”

 

“Just for that, I’m not holding back!”

 

To very little surprise, Shez lost anyway. Turns out “not holding back” didn’t matter much when she really didn’t have the skills in that area to begin with. 

 

“This isn’t over yet!” Shez declared, shaking out her hand after her lance had splintered against Byleth’s shield, “Best two out of three!”

 

“I’m ready when you are,” Byleth said with an amused smile.

 

Shez didn’t fare any better on the second pass. Really, she fared worse, and that led to a very annoyed Ezra confiscating their laces and declaring that neither of them were allowed to joust without supervision again.

 

“You weren’t even doing it right,” he groused, tossing Shez a vulnerary to help with the bruises she got from hitting the ground, “You’re supposed to aim for the shields, not each other’s heads.”

 

“Don’t you still win if you knock the other person out though?” Shez asked before downing the healing brew.

 

“Sure you do, and then you get me coming around to smack you upside the head for knocking your sister out. Really, you would’ve won the first round since you broke your lance properly.” 

 

“Wait, really? Oh! That means we’re tied! So we can–”

 

“No.”

 

“But Ezra–!”

 

“Answer’s still no. Especially since these ain’t tourney lances, they’re for training, and breaking them is a waste. Which is why your new competition is to see who can fix the lance they broke better.”

 

“...You’re just upset because I would be an awesome dark knight.”

 

“...what the genuine hell does that mean?”

 

As Shez launched into an explanation of her beliefs regarding the dark knight aesthetic, Byleth simply got to work on repairing the lances that could be fixed. If they turned useless, they could always burn the remains as firewood; otherwise, Byleth was going to give it her best spot.

 

She wanted to win their competition, after all.

Chapter End Notes

Red: Time for a timeskip!

Indi: Might as well give Byleth and Shez some lighthearted moments after... well everything I suppose.

Red: They deserve a few nice things as we move on towards canon. Like new outfits! New haircuts! And life lessons!

Indi: Yup yup! Hope you all enjoyed it! Also, at the recommendation of someone, we wanted to test the waters and see if people here would be interested in us opening a discord for the story?

Red: If so we can probably get one set up pretty easy. But for now, thanks for reading!

A Fated Meeting

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

A simple stone throne upon which a young girl slept was what greeted Byleth in the void. Blinking in surprise, she looked around, finding nothing but darkness stretching out around her, the only light there illuminating the still sleeping girl. 

 

At least, she was asleep until Byleth heard her yawn. 

 

"Hm? Oh my, it seems I am not alone." The green-haired girl said as she noticed Byleth. "Though I must say, it is quite rude to interrupt someone's moment of rest. If you're going to do so, at least step closer so I know who you are." 

 

Cautious, Byleth did as she requested, ready for whatever she did. 

 

"Hm, I've never seen you before. Who are you?" 

 

"...I'm Byleth, a mercenary." 

 

"Is that so? You are rather young for a mercenary are you not?" 

 

"I'm twenty years old." 

 

"Naught but a child,” she said, as if Byleth was agreeing with her. "Ah, but I suppose that matters not, I shall be returning to my rest that you so rudely interrupted." Yawning, the young girl closed her eyes so she could go to sleep, the light in the area fading away.

"Hey, By, get up!" Eyes snapping open, Byleth was awoken by the sound of Shez shouting at her. Sitting up, she saw her sister’s grin as she peeked her head into where she was sleeping. "Heh, come on now sleepyhead, get up! Or does my little sister need some more sleep?" 

 

"...you didn't win the last match." 

 

"Yes, but a tie means we keep going with the last winner!" 

 

"Since when?" Byleth asks as she gets up. 

 

"Since I decided!" Shez declared with a laugh. "Now come on, dad wants to make sure you're ready for the long march we got ahead of us." 

 

"I made sure to prepare before I went to sleep," Byleth responded before pausing. "...hey Shez, how did you meet Arval again?" 

 

"Huh? Well, it was a dream. Least, I thought it was till I saw them when I woke up. Why do you ask?" 

 

"There was a little girl I saw while I was asleep. It seemed more than a dream." 

 

"Wait, really? There's more than one Arval?" Shez asked, her eyes looking over to the side. 

 

"How am I supposed to know?" Her ghostly friend asked, their words unheard by Byleth. "Though if it is anything similar, she likely will awaken her own powers, making her that much more difficult to defeat." 

 

"Well, Arval isn't sure, but you might get your own powers!" 

 

"Hm…that's-"

 

"Kids, get out here!" Jeralt’s voice caught their attention, an edge to his voice telling them something serious was going on. Immediately rushing out, both girls grabbed their weapons as they went to meet their dad. 

 

Who was hanging out with three people who seemed to be their age, if a bit younger. 

 

The trio seemed to be wearing uniforms of three different colors, red, blue, and yellow respectively. As the three of them noticed the sisters, Byleth couldn't help but feel the white-haired girl immediately begin to evaluate them with her gaze. 

 

"Get a move on kids, we have bandits to deal with." Jeralt said, explaining what was going on. 

 

"Wait, really?" 

 

"Yes, I would like to apologize for leading them here," the blond boy said, a tenseness to his voice. 

 

"If it helps, we can provide back up to you, our oh so wonderful saviors," the dark-skinned boy said with a mirth that didn't reach his eyes. 

 

"Eh, I dunno, if it's just some bandits, By and I can probably deal with it," Shez said. 

 

"We should still be careful," Byleth responded as she saw Ezra approaching. "Even if they're just bandits, we shouldn't underestimate them." 

 

"You got that right," Ezra said as he came up. "Spotted the bandits, they don't look well armed but there's a lot of them. We're in for some trouble if we just try to defend." 

 

"Then we should aim for the leader." Byleth suggested as she faced her dad. "They might scatter if the leader falls, you and the rest can focus on defending the town, while these three, Shez, and I act as an attacking force." 

 

"If you require our assistance, we would be glad to help,” the white-haired girl declared. 

 

"Good, Shez and I will lead the way," Byleth decided, walking past the three as Shez drew both her swords. 

 

"Heh, try not to fall behind~!" Shez teased as she followed alongside Byleth. 

 

Glancing behind her, Byleth could see the trio had armed themselves with an axe, spear, and bow respectively. It also seemed like they were indeed battle tested as they didn't show any hesitation in following behind them.

 

"I must say, you have a strange aura about you…if you really are a mercenary, show me what you can do," the white-haired one requested, speaking to Byleth as she stood by her. 

 

"Stick close then," Byleth replied as she looked out at the field before them to watch the bandits approaching. "Shez, you and Spear take the left side of the watchtower. Archer, make sure to cover us." 

 

"Got it!" Shez shouted, before immediately rushing forward. 

 

"H-Hey, wait, please!" Spear called to her as she charged forward. 

 

"She seems quite reckless," Axe muttered as she and Byleth moved to face off against some bandits. 

 

"She knows what to do," Byleth replied even as she split her attention between the bandits and Shez. 

 

"Get those brats!" screamed the bandits rushing towards Byleth and her companion. A rather large group, it seemed, which would be trouble to try to face head on, so best to make them scatter. Raising a hand, a sigil appeared for a moment before a ball of fire crashed into the bandit group, causing them to scream and scatter before an axe head buried itself into one of them. 

 

Not a bad showing from Axe. She clearly knew what she was doing, though Byleth wouldn't consider her an expert. Better than a novice, at least, and the white-haired girl showed some impressive strength with how easily she used the heavy weapon, striking with brutal blows that were more than enough to cut down poorly armed and armored bandits.

 

Byleth, meanwhile, brushed a hand over her blade and set it aflame, illuminating the area and drawing the bandits’ attention towards her. Some stumbled back at the sight and Byleth mentally marked them as likely cowards that would retreat if the more bold ones went down. So she focused on those bolder men, striding forward and decapitating the first bandit that seemed to be yelling orders.

 

There were screams and one bandit broke and ran, dropping his sword as he went, and Byleth continued on her way in the meantime, cutting down two more bandits before catching an axe blade and igniting the axeman on the spot. Fire had a way of making enemies rout, so Byleth was generous, if judicial, in her use of it. She didn’t want to set the forest alight, after all, so keeping a firm control of the magic she used to burn foes alive was a must.

 

A hiss of pain drew her attention back towards the white-haired girl. Byleth wasn’t completely sure if she was a client, considering she volunteered to help, but the girl was under her command at the moment so she flicked a hand, casting a basic Heal to mend the cut across her shoulder before Byleth moved in and stabbed straight through the swordsman fighting her potential client.

 

“Ah–Hm. I had that handled.”

 

Byleth just raised an eyebrow at the girl. “Focus on the spearmen. Swords are more flexible up close and you have to commit too much to the blow to deflect them properly.”

 

The girl blinked at her, but Byleth was already moving. She decided to demonstrate what she meant for the white-haired girl and found an axe-wielding bandit that was still trying to press the attack. She removed the head of his axe from its handle, then removed the top half of his head from the lower half. “See?”

 

“...I do see your meaning, yes.”

 

“Good.”

 

There were a surprisingly large number of bandits. Byleth made a mental note to ask Victor if any of the bandits here happened to have open bounties on their heads before continuing her work in collecting them. A glance over showed the other members of her group were handling the bandits well enough; Spear was backing up Shez as she cut her way through every foe in front of her, a whirlwind of death as usual that he was at least doing a bit to help by taking out the stragglers, while Archer picked off foes from a distance. It was always handy to have a balanced group, though Byleth kept herself focused as she looked for the potential leader of the bandits. There would be someone barking orders somewhere–

 

“Damn it, I’ll get at least one of you brats!”

 

Byleth was moving before the last word finished, turning to see a large, rough-looking brigand bringing an axe down on the white-haired girl as she stumbled backwards. Byleth threw herself forward, trying to bring her sword up and cursing the aggravating irony of the situation as the axe blade descended towards her head–

 

“What are you doing?” complained an oddly familiar voice as everything froze.

 

“...” Byleth couldn’t really respond, on account of being frozen. Then the world seemed to shatter and she was back in that dark void.

 

“Honestly, what were you trying to accomplish with that stunt?” the girl on the throne continued to complain, looking distinctly unimpressed with Byleth, “Are you trying to get me killed?”

 

Byleth blinked. “You? Why would you die?”

 

“Of course I would die if you did! Is it not obvious that we are connected? Ugh, and this is twice now you’ve interrupted my sleep…” The girl grumbled, before regarding Byleth again. “Well? Do you have anything to say for yourself now that I have aided you?”

 

“...Thank you?”

 

“Why do you phrase that as though it’s a question? Is gratitude so much to ask? I did deem you worth saving, so thank me properly!”

 

“...” Byleth placed a hand on her chest and gave the strange girl a deep bow. “Thank you for saving my life.”

 

“Hmph, there we are, much better! Now then, I am Sothis, though you may also address me as ‘The Beginning’. It is another name I am known by.”

 

“Ah, okay. I know how that works. You’re Sothis, the Beginning, then.”

 

“No, it isn’t a title, it is another name–Oh, never mind. You really are a dull child, aren’t you?”

 

“I’ve been called that.”

 

Sothis frowned. “You have? By whom? That is an immensely rude thing to call someone.”

 

“...” Byleth decided not to comment. “Do you know someone named Arval?”

 

“Arval? Arval…No, I can’t say that name stirs any feelings of familiarity in me.”

 

“Okay. My sister has her own strange ghost person in her head so I thought I should ask.”

 

“I am not a ghost! And why would I know a ghost, hm? Just because I am speaking to you does not mean I have knowledge of every mystical being in existence!” Sothis shouted, quite annoyed. "But that is not the important thing!"

 

"It's not?" 

 

"Of course it isn't, the important part is what are you going to do now!" Frowning, she pointed at her. "I may have stopped the flow of time, but that has only delayed the inevitable." 

 

"You stopped time?" 

 

"Yes, I am… not sure how I managed it, but we must plan what to do. This is only a temporary measure, so the axe will strike us down unless we do something." 

 

"Can I move while you have everything stopped?"

 

"No, I am not certain why, but that power feels beyond me. Even then, your body might not be able to handle the strain of moving while the flow of time is stopped." 

 

"Well…can you make it go backwards then?" 

 

"What? You mean reverse the flow of time?" That got Sothis to pause. "...Yes, I believe that is within my power. Though I must warn you, I can only send you back just a few moments. Though I trust you'll be able to make a far better decision now that you know what's to come." Moving her hands, a large sigil appeared, far more complicated than Byleth had seen before. "Now go, you who bear the flames within. Drift through the flow of time." 

 

And, Byleth watched everything slowly move in reverse, as if everyone was a puppet on strings. Eyes snapping towards the bandit leader, Byleth took a moment to study him and see the arc of his attack, as well as where he was coming from, letting her know how to properly counter. 

 

Normally she'd just blast him with magic, but she was still annoyed at the irony! 

 

As such, once she felt her body under her control again, she rushed forward, her sword parrying the brigand’s axe as he was in the middle of his yell. And, with his eyes distracted watching his axe fly away, he was left completely open for Byleth to thrust her blade forward, sinking it into his chest. 

 

"Guh-! …I never should have… listened to that idiot…" the bandit leader said, before falling over, his death making the remaining bandits flee. 

 

"...Are you okay?" Byleth asked the white-haired girl, noting that she had lost her axe at one point, and was seemingly going to defend herself with a dagger. 

 

"...How were you able to-"

 

"The Knights of Seiros are here!" came a loud, unfamiliar voice, instantly putting Byleth on edge as she spun around, getting into a defensive stance. "Hey, the thieves are getting away, go after them!" 

 

"Ugh, why him…" Looking to the side, she saw Jeralt had come over, riding Argo as he frowned at the knights. "Stand down kid, we're not getting into a fight with them." 

 

"...Okay." Still feeling tense, Byleth sheathed her sword, noticing Shez running up to them, with Spear and Archer close behind. However, before the one leading the knights could approach, a different voice called out to them. 

 

"Edelgard, there you are!" shouted an orange-haired boy, dressed in a similar uniform to the three, but lacking the colored cape. "My apologies for not arriving sooner, are you safe?" 

 

"Yes, Ferdinand," Edelgard, which was apparently her name, said with barely disguised annoyance. "Why are you here?" 

 

"As your trusted shield, I could not return to the academy while you are in danger! Especially not when leaving you with the likes of Dimitri and Claude. Who would know what–" 

 

"Ferdinand, I would ask you to refrain from making such comments out loud." 

 

"Ah, of course." Nodding, Ferdinand seemed to notice something. "Ah, Edelgard, are you hurt?!" 

 

"I was injured, but this mercenary here already healed me up." 

 

"Is that so? In that case, on behalf of the Empire, I, Ferdinand von Aegir, thank you for assisting our future emperor." 

 

"...Emperor?" Byleth asked, glancing at Edelgard. 

 

She seemed to steady herself at the question, the annoyance fading from her body in favor of a regal bearing as she gave Byleth a short bow. “Indeed, I am Edelgard von Hresvelg, Imperial Princess of the Empire of Adrestia. Thank you for saving my life from those thugs.”

 

“Ooo, wow, By! Look at you, saving a princess!” Shez teased, giving her sister a light shove on the shoulder, “How heroic of you~!”

 

“...” Byleth simply shoved her sister back before nodding to the apparent princess. “It’s no trouble. You were on my side, so I kept you safe.”

 

“An admirable attitude to take,” Spear said with a smile that didn’t look quite natural. Byleth had some experience with forcing a smile and the blond seemed like he needed to use actual effort to keep his up. “I must thank you as well, on behalf of the Holy Kingdom of Faerghus.”

 

“Oh? Ooo, is my buddy Lance actually a prince?” Shez asked, her interest turning from one royal to the other.

 

“Ah, yes, I am. I am Dimitri Alexandre Blaiddyd, crown prince of the Holy King–”

 

“Alright, we’re going to be here all night if you keep using the full title,” Archer interrupted, before raising a hand in greeting, “Hey there, Claude von Riegan, heir to leader of the Alliance. Not quite as ‘prestigious’ as the prince and princess here, but I like to think I’m a close equivalent.”

 

“Oh, you’re the new kid!” Shez exclaimed, earning a chuckle from Claude.

 

“I’m the ‘new kid’?”

 

“Yeah, Duke Riegan’s new kid. Well, grandson, I think? Remember By, we were in Leicester back when the other guy died.”

 

Byleth did recall that. She also remembered her father muttering about being cursed after he heard another major noble died while he was in their country. 

 

“Well that’s interesting. You two travel to Leicester often?”

 

“Oh sure, it’s where we get the most work. In fact, you may be familiar with our names!” Shez got the grin she tended to get when she was feeling boastful. Not for the first time, Byleth was glad she was good at keeping her face neutral. “For you see, we are the Eisner Sisters! Shez, the elder sister, otherwise known as the Violet Demon! And Byleth, the younger sister, also known as the Ashen Dragon! Defeaters of the Scorpions, slayers of the Red Tyrant, liberators of small villages all across Fodlan! And also daughters of the best merc in the business, of course.”

 

“That would be Jeralt the Blade Breaker then,” Edelgard noted, and Shez immediately grinned at her.

 

“Got it exactly! See By, told you we were recognizable.”

 

“She recognized dad, not us,” Byleth commented, prompting a pout from her younger sister, “Also, I’m older.”

 

“Hey, no, I still won last time! And I definitely killed more bandits than you! I took down thirteen, how much did you get?”

 

Byleth gestured towards the leader’s corpse. “I killed the leader.”

 

“...That’s still one, it shouldn’t count for more.”

 

“That’s not the rule we decided on.”

 

Shez mock-glared at her, then let out a groan as she let her head fall. “Yeah okay, I guess you’re older now…”

 

“...Excuse me, but I don’t quite understand…what that was,” Dimitri said.

 

“It’s a thing we do,” Byleth explained.

 

“Hhh…ah, yeah, I’m adopted so we’re not sure what my age actually is,” Shez explained, popping up from her fake despair pretty quickly. 

 

“We’re pretty sure she’s at least a year younger than me.”

 

“Yup, no way to tell. We’re probably twins.”

 

The gathered royals and nobles took a moment to look at the taller, openly smiling purple-haired girl in brown and red-orange clothes, before glancing at the shorter, neutral-faced, teal-haired woman in black and gray clothes, with the only real hint of color being some pink lining. 

 

“Sounds about right to me,” Claude said, grinning at the “twins”. “So, you usually work for the Alliance, huh?”

 

“Yup! Lots of Leicester nobles like to hire us to deal with stuff. We do work for the Empire nobles too, though we tend to work for small villages like this one too,” Shez explained, before grinning at Claude, “Why? Are you looking to hire us, your grace?”

 

“Heh, no need to bring out the fancy forms of address here. I’m not the duke yet, and Claude works fine for me. Besides, I was hoping to get to know you two better before jumping straight to making offers.”

 

Dimitri cleared his throat. “Then, if I may offer my own proposition, the Holy Kingdom of Faerghus could well use exceptional individuals of your skill. Please, do consider returning to the Kingdom with me.”

 

“I would think a prince would have more dignity than to beg for aid,” Ferdinand commented, making Dimitri straighten with a frown directed towards him, “Though if we are all making offers, then I, Ferdinand von Aegir–”

 

“Should let me be the one to speak with them,” Edelgard interrupted, giving her “shield” an annoyed look.

 

“Oh, of course Edelgard, you do need the experience in negotiating for yourself. Please, go right ahead.”

 

“...By your leave, I suppose.” Edelgard turned to the sisters, her annoyance carefully hidden by the time she faced them. “I will not belabor the point. As heir to the Adrestian Empire, I would be pleased to see your skills lent to the betterment of my nation.”

 

“Hmm…alright, alright, I hear all of you,” Shez said, nodding along, “And I know an easy way to solve this. Which of you can pay the best?”

 

Byleth elbowed her sister. “We’re under contract with Remire Village at the moment, so we’ll have to speak with our father.”

 

“I fully understand–”

 

“Really? You would so readily turn down an offer like this?” Ferdinand seemed put out. “If it is a matter of payment, I can assure you, the Empire is able to offer far more than a wasteland like Faerghus.”

 

Dimitri twitched. “...Ferdinand, I would request that you not openly insult my homeland.”

 

“Oh my sincere apologies, your highness. I am curious though, how much do you think you could offer our mercenary friends here from your meager coffers?”

 

“Wow, I knew things were bad between the Kingdom and the Empire, but I didn’t think Ferd would be so open about it,” Claude commented in a stage whisper to the two mercs, prompting a thoughtful look from Shez.

 

“Hm…you know, By, it would mean a lot of work for us if Faerghus and Adrestia went to war–Ow! Hey!”

 

“Not in front of the nobles,” Byleth chided, prompting an amused noise from Claude.

 

“Well I can tell you two are going to be fun. Think you might be coming back to the monastery with us?”

 

“Hm? You’re from a monastery–” Shez paused, before she frowned. “...Are you from Garreg Mach?”

 

“That’s where we’re coming from, yup. What, the Officer Academy uniforms didn’t give it away?”

 

“Haven’t seen them before. And, uh, no, we probably won’t be coming back with you guys then.”

 

“And why would that be?” Edelgard asked, ignoring the continued “discussion” between Ferdinand and Dimitri.

 

“Oh, you know.”

 

Claude raised an eyebrow, still grinning. “No, I don’t think any of us do. Are you two not so fond of the church or something?”

 

Shez folded her arms over her chest. “If you’re asking that question, you already know you shouldn’t be asking it.”

 

“Sounds a little recursive to me, but alright, I get what you mean. Shame though, I think it would’ve been fun to see you two around more often.”

 

“Alright kids, time to get packed up,” Jeralt said as he came over to their group, along with the mustachioed knight from earlier, “We’re moving out.”

 

“We are?” Shez blinked. “Wait, where are we going?”

 

“Garreg Mach Monastery,” their dad answered, before sighing, “Don’t make that face.”

 

Claude felt his grin grow and Edelgard raised an eyebrow as the two heirs saw the Eisner sisters clearly grimace at the thought of going to Garreg Mach.

 

“Ah, so these are your daughters then!” The knight, meanwhile, seemed happy to see them, judging by the bright smile on his friendly face. “Hello to both of you! My name is Alois, and I was your father’s comrade in arms back when he was the captain of the Knights of Seiros!”

 

“...Okay,” Shez replied.

 

Byleth was slightly more polite, offering him a nod. “It is nice to meet you.”

 

“Likewise! I must say, I wasn’t expecting a reunion like this with my former captain! I suppose you could call this a night of Seiros!”

 

“...”

 

“...”

 

The sisters looked at each other, as though confirming that they did hear the exact same thing.

 

"...Do you think it's too late to run?" 

 

“They have horses, they would catch up.”

 

“I don’t know, I think I could outspeed a horse.”

 

“I can’t.”

 

“Hm…maybe if I carry you…”

 

Claude had a big grin on his face, watching the interplay while Edelgard sighed in exasperation. “Oh you two are going to be great.”

Chapter End Notes

Indi: And here we go, first proper game event! Already with some changes as you can see.

Red: Yup! We've officially hit canon! And thus the divergences start to get shown more strongly as we move along. Not everything has changed, but there's been some small alterations along the way.

Indi: Will those alterations get bigger as we go along? Mayhaps.

Red: I suppose we'll have to see! For now, thanks for reading!

Indi: but before we go we have an announcement! We opened a discord! https://discord.gg/T7E9sWEJsv Hope y'all join!

The Monastery

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

"If I may ask, you mentioned fighting a 'red tyrant' before. What exactly did you mean by that?" Edelgard asked mid-march to Garreg Mach, the young mercenaries and students walking together behind the knights and rest of the mercs. 

 

"Heh, interested in hearing more of our exploits huh? Well I hope you're ready for the astounding tale of when By and I defeat a crimson demonic be-"

 

"It was a crawler that was weirdly red," Byleth cut in, getting Shez to stumble. "Ate some goats, so we were hired to take it out." 

 

"Aw come on By, how are we gonna get famous if we don't play up our achievements!" 

 

"Gotta agree with your sister here," Claude piped up, "If nothing else, you gotta know how to tell a story if you wanna impress someone."

 

Byleth shrugged in response. "I'm not one for embellishments." 

 

"Even so, fighting a demonic beast is no small feat. You should be proud of your accomplishments," Dimitri noted. 

 

"Though I'm sure you two have faced plenty aside from that," Edelgard guessed. 

 

"Oh yeah, totally, but that one was the first job By and I did on our own, so I'm pretty proud of it!" 

 

"Speaking of, I believe you've said you've taken jobs in the Alliance and Empire, correct?” Dimitri asked, “Have you not traveled up to the kingdom before?" 

 

"I don't see why they would," Edelgard commented. 

 

"Uh, we kinda had a job go sour there," Shez said, as Byleth took in some slow breaths. "But uh, mind telling us what's up between the Kingdom and Empire? Kinda out of the loop here." 

 

"Oh, allow me-" 

 

"I'll explain, Ferdinand," Edelgard spoke up, getting the orange-haired noble to stay silent. "Tensions have been quite high between the empire and the kingdom as of a few years ago, thanks to both the passing of my uncle, and the Tragedy of Duscur. While no evidence was ever brought forth to say the two incidents were connected, many still believe they are." 

 

Staying silent, Byleth couldn't help but notice Edelgard didn't seem particularly sad at mentioning her uncle passing away.

 

"Yes, but as the Prince of Faerghus, it is my hope that I can help mend the cracks between our two nations." Ferdinand audibly scoffed, but said nothing further as Dimitri tried to keep his pleasant smile in place. “That aside, are you two at all familiar with the Officer’s Academy?”

 

“Nope,” Shez promptly replied, “I’ve got no idea about any of it, and By’s probably got even less since she’s not especially curious.”

 

“Hm. That’s a rude thing to say about your sister.”

 

“She’s not wrong,” Byleth said, “Shez gets more interested in weird things than I do. She spent years trying to find the last book in this series on magic we have.”

 

“Hey, it’s not my fault they hid all the interesting stuff in the fourth book! Why even have a third when it was mostly repeating stuff in the first one, huh?”

 

“It wasn’t repeating anything, it was a more in depth look at complicated spells–”

 

“Yeah but it didn’t have any dark magic stuff in it, so it didn’t help me at all.”

 

“You’re a dark mage?” Edelgard asked, glancing at Shez with another appraising look.

 

“Oh yeah, I’m a natural at it. By’s the opposite though, she’s way better at light stuff than I’ll ever get. She’s also better at fire stuff while I’m…kind of good at ice? I mean, I’m decent at it, but I’m really more of a sword girl all around.”

 

Byleth shrugged. “We each have our specialties.”

 

"That we do! Speaking of, is that why you three have different color capes? Noticed you used different weapons." 

 

"Ah, no, the three of us are the leaders of the three houses of the academy,” Dimitri answered, “The houses are where students from each respective nation gather. The Blue Lions of the Kingdom, The Golden Deer of the Alliance, and The Black Eagles of the Empire."

 

"Each year students go to the academy in hopes of becoming skilled officers,” Edelgard continued, “Be they nobles or commoners." 

 

"Though it's mainly nobles,” Claude added, “Not that many commoners can afford to go. Edelgard’s class only has one commoner this year, for example." 

 

"And Dorothea has rightfully earned her place in the academy. That aside, the academy year had only just started, hence why we were out doing training exercises that night when the bandits attacked us," Edelgard explained, before letting out a sigh. "Thankfully it seems everyone was able to return to the academy safely thanks to the knights."

 

Byleth couldn't help but take note of that. It was already odd that Kostas blamed an 'idiot' for what occurred, but that could be written off as him blaming one of his subordinates for bringing the idea up. The fact that the academy had just started and the students just so happened to be training in the same area as the bandits, however, was oddly timed. Had they been hired by someone? 

 

"Yup, speaking of, you two should stop by if you have the time, plenty of faces and names you should get to know if you're planning on continuing the family business in the future," Claude suggested. "And if it helps you decide on working with the Alliance, well that's just a win win."

 

"Then I extend the same offer for you to visit the Black Eagles!" Ferdinand said, making Edelgard roll her eyes. 

 

"And of course my house would be more than happy to have you stop by," Dimitri added, rounding out the offers.

 

"Well I guess we'll see," Shez said without committing to anything, her eyes looking forward as Garreg Mach came into view. “...Wow, that’s a big place.”

 

It was. Garreg Mach Monastery was certainly the most imposing location the Eisner sisters had ever visited. Enbarr was close, but it was still a city, and didn’t carry the same kind of ancient majesty the castle atop the mountains did. Maybe the Imperial Palace would be comparable, Byleth considered, but then she never did see that directly.

 

“Big is one word for it, sure,” Claude commented with some amusement, prompting an amused huff from Byleth’s younger sister.

 

“Yeah yeah, laugh at the poor, simple merc girl. Sorry we can’t all live in giant palaces like your grace ,” she teased back, her smile taking any sting from the words as she overemphasized his title.

 

“Aw, I didn’t mean to offend. But if you’re missing out on that much, maybe you could come by Derdriu sometime and I’ll give you a tour?”

 

“Oh, but I wouldn’t want to impose on your noble sensibilities, your grace! I might track mud on your carpet!”

 

“Eh, it’s okay, I’m rich. I’ll just burn it and get a new one.”

 

Edelgard sighed while Ferdinand didn’t seem able to tell if he should be offended or not, staring between Claude and Shez in some confusion. Dimitri wasn’t much better, though he didn’t seem offended so much as he couldn’t tell if the two were mocking each other.

 

Byleth, meanwhile, simply flicked her sister on the back of her head, earning a yelp from Shez. Thankfully, she didn’t have to listen to her sister bantering with her new friend for much longer as the students went off to join the rest of their classmates.

 

“Make sure to swing by our classroom later!” Claude called out as he left, “I’d love to have you two if you join up!”

 

“Ha! No promises!” Shez shouted back, prompting a sigh from Byleth. Well, at least her younger sister was making friends. She always was better at being sociable.

 

Byleth felt a frown come to her face. Not because of Shez; she was more than used to her being better with people, at least on a first meeting. No, what was putting her on edge was a strange feeling of being watched…And it wasn’t long before she noticed the source.

 

As she looked up at the strange, green-haired woman staring down at her, Byleth couldn’t help but remember what Shez said to her back in Enbarr. That strange feeling of looking at a person, and immediately getting chills from the sight.

Garreg Mach Monastery was definitely the fanciest place Shez had ever been in. Big windows, clean floors, weird artsy stuff on the walls; all very fancy and pretty out of her usual realm of experience. It was kind of funny though, because Byleth actually seemed to be the more tense of the two of them.

 

“Hey, it’s gonna be alright,” she muttered to her sister, giving her a glance as they were led to meet the Archbishop. Which, wow, they were meeting a lot of important people today. “That Catherine lady might be dead already.”

 

“...That’s not really why I’m tense, but thank you,” Byleth mumbled back. "Kinda hope she isn't so I can beat her up."

 

"Pft, well, here's hoping she isn't then," Shez said, smiling at her sister as they continued walking. And well, she was ready for whatever happened, but who knows, maybe things will be okay? The three house leaders and that Ferdinand guy seemed nice enough, even if they didn't get along with one another. 

 

At least, she hoped they would, but she still felt very tense as two green-haired individuals came out to meet them in the audience chamber. 

 

"Thank you for your patience, Jeralt. My name is Seteth, I am the advisor to the archbishop," the bearded guy said, addressing only their dad. 

 

"Right. Hello." 

 

"It has been a long time, Jeralt. I wonder if it is the will of the Goddess that let us meet once again," the archbishop said, before her eyes moved over to Byleth. "If nothing else, I see she has blessed you with fatherhood." 

 

"Ah, yes, the two were born many years after I left the monastery." Jeralt said, getting Rhea to glance at Shez for a moment. "Sadly their mother passed away from illness." 

 

"...I see, my condolences." Rhea said, before looking back at the two girls. "So, you two are sisters?" 

 

"Ah, yeah! Twins to be specific!" Shez said, deciding to lie for the sake of her dad and sister. "Name’s Shez!" 

 

"...Byleth." 

 

"A fine name." Shez had a feeling she was only referring to Byleth there. "From the bottom of my heart, thank you for saving the students of this academy. Jeralt, I assume you already know what I wish to ask?" 

 

"Alois already asked in your stead. I'm honored you want me to rejoin the knights, but…" 

 

"Your apprehension stings, but I implore you to say yes. As for your…daughters, I assume Alois also informed you what I wish to ask?" 

 

"Ask us what?" Shez asked as she raised an eyebrow. 

 

"During the training exercise, one of the professors who was supposed to lead one of the houses this year chose to flee. As such, I cannot in good faith allow him to teach should he return. So, I wish to ask that your eldest join the academy as a professor. Your youngest would of course also be allowed to join as a student." 

 

“Woah woah woah, hold on, are you sure that’s a good idea?” Shez asked, prompting a slight frown from the archbishop, “I mean, I know I’m awesome, but I have no idea how to be a professor.”

 

“...I meant your elder sister, child.”

 

“Yeah? I’m the older one.”

 

“...” Rhea looked between Byleth and Shez, her small frown still present along with a very skeptical look.

 

Byleth, meanwhile, just shrugged. “I wouldn’t mind being a student. I don’t think you should make Shez a teacher though, she’s not that smart.”

 

“Yeah, exactly,” Shez agreed, nodding.

 

“...I was under the impression from Alois that Byleth was the elder.”

 

“...Oh, right, I took out the bandit leader so I'm the older one now.” 

 

“Ooooh yeah, forgot about that.” 

 

“I ask that you act seriously when in front of the archbishop,” Seteth chided as he looked at the two siblings, his frown very evident, “And Lady Rhea, are you certain–”

 

“I supposed they are just tired from their journey here,” the archbishop interrupted, ignoring her chamberlain, “For now, I must step away. Until tomorrow, farewell.” A smile on her face again, Rhea nodded to the trio, before she and Seteth left the audience chamber, heading back to her office. 

 

Byleth leaned to watch them leave, still not sure what she felt from that strange woman, but well aware that it was putting her on edge…That, and she could clearly see Seteth starting to complain to Rhea about her decision the instant he thought they were out of earshot.

 

“Well… I suppose that could have gone worse,” Jeralt muttered as he pinched the bridge of his nose. “Guess we don’t have much of an option.”

 

“We could always try fighting our way out.” 

 

“We’d have to flee Fodlan entirely if we did, and that’s assuming we manage to escape,” Jeralt replied to Shez, before leaning in to whisper. “Just stay on your guard, okay? I don’t know what she’s thinking, but she’s obviously planning something.” 

 

“Sure thing dad!” Shez said, grinning as Byleth nodded in response.

 

“So, you must be the new professor. My, Alois didn’t mention how handsome you are~!” Blinking, Shez looked over to see two people walking in, one of whom was leaning in close to her dad. 

 

“Er, no, you have the wrong person. That’d be her,” Jeralt said, gesturing to Byleth. “You two can handle things from here, good luck.” With a nod, Jeralt left, leaving them with the two new people.

 

 “Oh my, I didn’t expect you to be so young.”

 

“Just because one is young does not mean they are not competent,” the older guy said, before facing the sisters. “My name is Hanneman, one of the professors of this academy, and a crest scholar. If you have a crest of your own, I ask that you pay me a visit so I may study it if possible.” 

 

“And I am Manuela Casagranda, another professor here, but I am also the head physician, a songstress, and available~” 

 

“A songstress?” Byleth asked, apparently wanting to know about that. 

 

“Of course! In fact, before I came here, I was a member of the Mittelfrank Opera Company~ Perhaps you’ve been there before?” 

 

“Oh, By, didn’t we go to a play there before?” Shez asked.

 

“Yes, about six years ago.” 

 

“Ah, in that case, it was after I left, but you must have seen my protege, Dorothea? She’s actually attending the academy this year.”

 

Byleth paused, tilting her head in thought before nodding. “Right, we did see her. She was the girl playing the noblewoman in the play we saw.”

 

“Oh yeah! She was the Mystical Songstress!” Shez grinned, nudging her sister with an elbow. “You know, the girl you thought was cute~”

 

“Oh?” And it seemed that teasing immediately caught Manuela’s attention. 

 

“I said she was pretty, not cute,” Byleth responded, not that Shez accepted that.

 

“Pretty, cute, it’s the same difference! You liked her! You wanted to get her flowers, remember?”

 

“You were the one that suggested that.”

 

“Well, I'm sure she’d be happy to get flowers from a fan, but, as her mentor, I do hope you’ll watch yourself around her,” Manuela warned with a tone that made even Shez feel like she was getting threatened. 

 

“Now, now Manuela. I’m sure she’ll be on her best behavior,” Hanneman said, speaking up for Byleth. “As for now, why don’t you two go for a stroll around the academy? I’m sure you’ll want to familiarize yourselves with the area, and of course, my office is open if you’ll allow me to examine you for crests.”

 

“Hm, I guess you have a point, it would be a good idea for them to get to know the students too. If you can, stop by my office as well. As the physician I also need to make sure you have a clean bill of health.” 

 

“Ah, yeah. We’ll make sure to stop by later!” Shez said, before grabbing onto Byleth and pulling her out of the room. “Well…didn't expect to end up here.” 

 

“Yeah, especially as a teacher…or a student, in your case.” 

 

“...Think we can leave early if I do poorly enough?”

 

“They might only kick you out.” 

 

“Yeah, this place would probably try to get only me out…well, might as well make the most of it. Hey, do you think we should go to the marketplace for some flow–Gah!” Before she could finish her teasing, Shez felt Byleth elbow her in the side. 

 

“Let's just get this over with.” Byleth muttered as they went downstairs, finding someone waiting for them in the reception hall. 

 

“Hello. Is it correct to assume that you two will be joining the academy?” Edegard asked, the young emperor-to-be greeting the two as she got up from where she was sitting. 

 

“Yeah, By is gonna be a teacher apparently, and I guess I'll be a student?” 

 

Edelgard didn’t seem too happy with that information. “Pity. I was hoping you would be lending your services to the Empire. I don’t suppose you were told which class you’d be teaching?” 

 

“No, and they didn’t say which class Shez will be joining,” Byleth answered.

 

“I would assume they would put you two in the same class.” 

 

Shez shrugged. “Eh, dunno. That might sound fun, but also it feels weird to think of By as a teacher.” 

 

“Is that so? Well regardless, I hope to have the chance to learn from you two. Do either of you two have any questions about the Black Eagles?”

 

“Well, I haven't really met any of them… actually, do you mind if I ask a favor?” 

 

“Go ahead.” 

 

“You mind showing By around? Since she’s gonna be a teacher, she probably needs to learn more about this place than me.” 

 

“You still need to look around as well,” Byleth pointed out. 

 

“Yeah, but I can take my time, you’re the one who has to make the important choices as a teacher.” 

 

“I would be perfectly fine with escorting our new professor around the Academy,” Edelgard replied. She seemed kind of pleased with the suggestion, which Shez was happy to see. “Perhaps I could even convince you to consider teaching my class specifically?”

 

“Maybe,” Byleth answered with a shrug, before glancing at her sister. “Shez, don’t get lost.”

 

“Oh come on, you don’t need to tell me that. I’ll be fine!”

 

Byleth’s expression remained skeptical, but Shez didn’t pay much attention to that as she walked off. Plus, Arval popped out a moment later, so that took her attention instead. “Hm. Your sister feels different.”

 

“She does?” Shez glanced back towards Byleth, but she and Edelgard were already out of view. “How so?”

 

“I’m not sure. It likely has to do with that dream she claimed she had. Perhaps she has awakened her powers already and chosen not to tell you?”

 

“Ahh, that would make sense.”

 

“...You’re not bothered by her keeping information from you?”

 

“You’re kidding, right? When would she have told me? Around the knights or the nobles?” 

 

“Hmph. You could stand to be more concerned about this. Something unusual is going on with your sister. Perhaps a dormant power that will change her very being–”

 

“I know you don’t like her, Arval, so cut it out with the doomsaying,” Shez chided as she started to walk, just sort of meandering at the moment, though she kept her tone low enough to avoid looking like a weirdo talking to herself.

 

“It’s not doomsaying, I’m just saying you may be doomed.”

 

“That’s the same thing!”

 

“Is it? I didn’t notice.” Arval smiled slightly as Shez muttered under her breath about “sarcastic little pricks”, before giving a glance around the monastery halls. “I have to say though, I do share your sister’s discomfort with this place. There’s a disquieting feeling to the air here.”

 

“I guess? I just don’t like the knights,” she whispered, before very deliberately taking a staircase instead of continuing to walk towards the knights she noticed. “...I really hope that Catherine woman really isn’t here. I know Byleth wants payback, but that’s going to go bad if they go up against each other.”

 

“You’re actually trying to be the voice of reason? Did someone replace my partner when I wasn’t looking?”

 

“Oh ha ha, very funny. I can get worried about my family–Huh.” Shez blinked, staring into the room filled with bookshelves that she just walked into. “Is this a library?”

 

“Indeed it is, young lady,” a nearby old man said as he noticed her. He had a kind smile on his face while he rested on his cane, but something about him just set Shez’s instincts off. “Welcome to Garreg Mach monastery’s library. I am Tomas, the head librarian. Might you be a new student?”

 

"U-Uh, yeah, just wandering around and seeing what's… around." 

 

"Is that so? Well you are always welcome to visit the library should you wish to. We likely have the greatest collection of books in Fodlan, if I do say so myself." 

 

"Right, well, I'll make sure to stop by when I have the chance!" With a shaky grin, Shez immediately turned around to head out. 

 

"Is everything okay, partner?" Arval asked, peering curiously down at her.

 

"I honestly don't know. That old guy just set off all my instincts, so I didn't want to be there any longer." 

 

"...Yes, I suppose there was something odd about him. Not that I know what that is, just that he almost seemed familiar…" 

 

"...Arval, have you haunted other people before?" 

 

"Why would I do that if you are my partner in destiny?" Arval asked with a quirked eyebrow as Shez went back downstairs. "Regardless, I assume you're making no plans to go to the library again?"

 

"Why would I?"

 

"Perhaps they have that tome you were looking for?" 

 

"...Stop being right sometimes, Arval."

 

"I refuse." Letting out a huff, Shez began to wander around again. She had to admit, this place was far bigger once you were actually inside than it looked like from the outside, and she was starting to get worried she'd get lost easily here.

 

"At least you'll have me to guide you around, should you care to listen to me." 

 

"Maybe? Just didn't expect a monastery to be this big. I thought it'd be just a slightly bigger chapel." 

 

"And where did you expect the classes to take place?" 

 

Shez shrugged in response. "Dunno, never went to school before." Though her wandering did come to a stop as she arrived at the mess hall for the monastery, a rather delicious smell reaching her nose. "Oh wow, this place smells great." 

 

"Of course you'd be happy with this place." Shez chose to ignore Arval as she began to march up to the counter, ready to get some food, only to bump into someone as she went. 

 

"Oh, sorry–Shez?" A familiar looking gray haired boy looked surprised to see her. 

 

"Ashe? What are you doing here?" 

 

"I'm a student here." That explained the uniform. "What are you doing here? Are Byleth and Captain Jeralt here too?"

 

"Oh, uh, well I'm going to be a student here, and yeah, didn't you see Byleth? Pretty sure she was going to the classrooms, unless that empire princess took her elsewhere…" 

 

"Lady Edelgard? Ah, I can see why she wouldn't take her to the Blue Lions classroom then…" 

 

"She did mention things aren't well between the Kingdom and the Empire," Arval pointed out, making Shez realize it probably wasn't the smartest idea to send Byleth off with the princess. 

 

"Eh, I'm sure she's fine."

"Your sister is rather carefree isn't she?" Edelgard asked as she watched Shez walk off, leaving Byleth alone with her. 

 

"...Yeah," Byleth responded, suddenly very aware that it was up to her to be sociable without Shez helping her out. 

 

"If I may ask, since she mentioned being adopted, how did you meet? I understand that some mercenary groups might employ a chore child, but I was not aware a wandering band would adopt someone." 

 

"I shot her with an arrow." 

 

"...Excuse me?" 

 

"I was out hunting, and I accidentally shot her when she made me miss a deer," Byleth explained as if she wasn't talking about injuring someone. "I carried her back to camp after." 

 

"I…see. That must have been quite the first meeting," Edelgard muttered, unsure of what to say. "...she also mentioned being a natural dark mage? That's quite the rarity." 

 

"I guess," Byleth said with a shrug. "She picked it up easily." 

 

"Hm…ah, but where are my manners? I was going to show you the Black Eagles classroom. I promise you, they're not all like Ferdinand." 

 

"Do you dislike him?" Byleth asked, getting Edelgard to sigh as they began to walk. 

 

"It is not him so much as it is his father. Ever since the passing of my uncle, his father has been pressuring him to protect me. Not even my actual retainer is this suffocating," Edelgard complained, her annoyance quite evident. 

 

"...Do you want to spar?" 

 

"...That's a rather sudden question." 

 

"You seem angry, exercise helps me when I'm angry." 

 

“Hm.” Edelgard gave Byleth a considering glance. She hadn’t expected the mercenary to admit to having issues with aggression, particularly given how placid she appeared to be in general. It did bring to mind what Byleth had said earlier, about shooting her sister with an arrow on their first meeting…though perhaps Edelgard was simply seeing connections where there were none, given she also said it was an accident. “...I really should be showing you to my housemates.”

 

“We could do that afterwards.”

 

Edelgard gave the prospective professor another look, idly wondering if perhaps Byleth was more interested in working out her own aggression than aiding Edelgard with hers. She did seem intriguingly tense around the knights. “Hm. I may as well show you the training field then. Perhaps we’ll run into some classmates along the way?”

 

“Maybe. I’ll make sure to meet everyone at some point.”

 

“You certainly should, if you’re planning to teach my class,” Edelgard said, a slight smile coming to her face as she regarded her potential professor. She might not have been able to recruit her directly into the Empire, but if she could nudge the elder Eisner sister into favoring her faction…Well, who knew what the future held?

Chapter End Notes
