Indi: And so we got the first meeting with Rhea, and a bit more talking with the house leaders!

Red: Yup! It's a meeting of the faction heads! Well aside from a certain group of wolves down below. But for now, the sisters are getting used to the people and places around here.

Indi: Though of course, neither of the sisters are exactly happy with the situation they're in.

Red: Not very happy, nope. But hey, they should adjust soon enough. Or things will escalate into horrible violence. Probably not the latter but hey, it could happen.

Indi: Only one way to find out! Also, we started a second story called it was supposed to be simple, dealing with a time traveling Byleth!

Red: Yup! It's fairly different in tone, but hey, give it a look if you feel like it! Otherwise, thanks for reading!

Indi: And as said last chapter, we opened a discord so feel free to join! https://discord.gg/T7E9sWEJsv

Getting to Know the Students

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Perhaps Edelgard should have expected her activity with the new professor would garner attention. Seeing the future emperor of Adrestia walk off towards the training field with an unfamiliar woman would certainly pique interest in her classmates, so some deciding to see what was happening wasn’t out of the question by any means.

 

She didn’t expect a crowd to form though.

 

“Edelgard, I must protest this!” She also should have expected Ferdinand to show up once he heard what was happening. “You shouldn’t be sparring with this mercenary–”

 

“I’m sparring with our new professor, Ferdinand,” Edelgard stated. It wasn’t completely true, yet, but it would be. “Are you objecting to me receiving instruction from a faculty member now?”

 

“Ah–Well, no, I–Hubert, you talk to her!” Ferdinand demanded, looking towards Edelgard’s actual retainer, who was watching the redhead struggle with some amusement. If there was anyone who found Ferdinand more annoying than Edelgard, it was definitely Hubert, and he barely made that a secret.

 

So he simply nodded to his liege. “Do your best, your highness.”

 

“I intend to,” Edelgard answered while Ferdinand gaped at the audacity.

 

“YEAH! YOU GO EDELGARD!” And it seemed more of her classmates were present in the crowd. Not unexpected, and especially expected when it came to Caspar’s presence. The second son of Bergliez looked particularly excited to watch the proceedings, and he’d even dragged his usual companion, Lindhart, along with him, who seemed less than pleased with the interruption to his routine of studying or sleeping. “TAKE THE NEW GIRL DOWN! SHOW HER WE’RE THE BEST!”

 

…Well, she couldn’t fault his exuberance.

 

Still, she kept herself focused as she picked up the blunted training axe she intended to use, before turning to face her new professor. Before losing some focus as she found herself staring at said professor, who had removed her long coat and some of her armor to leave herself in a midriff-baring top and shorts. A top that also showed off a generous amount of cleavage. 

 

“...” Edelgard shook her head, regaining her focus as she strode out onto the field to face off against the so-called Ashen Dragon. A curious name to be sure, though one that appeared earned given her proficiency with flame magic. “May I ask why you chose to remove your armor?”

 

It wasn’t the first question she intended on asking, but it was a point of curiosity for the young woman as she watched the professor go through a short routine of stretches.

 

“You’re in your uniform, you’re not armored, it’s a basic spar,” Byleth answered in short order, before plucking a wooden sword from the ground she’d stabbed it into and striding onto the field with an intimidating confidence. There was complete surety in her motions, no hint of unease or even unfamiliarity despite this being her first time on the monastery’s training grounds.

 

She swung her sword once, twice, testing the weight in her hand and noticeably stopping her motion before either arc could complete. She had total control over the sword in her hand and Edelgard felt her estimation of the woman rise with the sight.

 

There was no way she was going to let any other class take this woman as their professor.

 

“Before we begin, do you have any stipulations for our spar?” Edelgard asked.

 

“Sure. Best of three points, each landed hit counts as a point. If blood is drawn, the spar ends, same as if one of us yields.” Edelgard didn’t intend to yield, so that rule was moot. “Other than that, you can feel free to use what you want.”

 

That was…interesting. Particularly with how the professor phrased it. Edelgard was free to use whatever she wanted to win the duel, but there was no mention of what limits the professor had.

 

“Understood. Then, shall we begin?”

 

“Sure.” And so it began.

 

Not that Byleth took advantage of the start to go on the attack. No, she was hanging back, waiting for Edelgard to come to her. The princess recalled what Byleth had said back in the forests, the type of advantage a sword had over an axe in close quarters, so she was leery of making the first move…still, one would never attack if they were always afraid of a counterattack, so she moved in at an angle, searching her professor’s guard for openings–

 

And then she flinched back as Byleth’s sword was suddenly inches from her face, narrowly missing as she jerked her head to the side.

 

Dimly, she heard an offended gasp from Ferdinand in the crowd, but she had no time to react as more thrusts and swings suddenly came for her, barely glancing off her axe as she brought it up for defense.

 

“Hm. You might do better with a shield in your off hand,” Byleth noted as she pulled back, studying the shorter girl. “You can use the axe blade as a pseudo shield, but it leaves you open and means you can’t press the attack.”

 

“...I was unaware you were intending to make this a lesson already, professor,” Edelgard commented, a slight frown coming to her face. The woman didn’t seem to think she was a threat at all.

 

“I’m supposed to be a professor,” she said as though that was answer enough.

 

“Should I take this to show you intend to lead my class then?”

 

“Hm…why not?” She shrugged. “I should probably wait to make the decision, but if I’m teaching you already, I might as well. Also–”

 

Edelgard winced as the sword suddenly jabbed into her shoulder, quick and efficient.

 

“Keep aware of the situation, especially when talking on the battlefield. If you can guarantee you won’t get hit, talk. If not, don’t.”

 

“Hm. One point to you then,” Edelgard affirmed, before tightening her grip on her axe. She had no intention of lowering her guard again while on the field with Byleth.

 

Something her professor appeared to approve of, judging by her nod before the two of them began their bout again.

 

This time, Edelgard stayed on the offensive, unwilling to give the professor a chance to decide the tempo of the fight. A strange awareness came over her as she did though, noticing now how her own swings differed from Byleth’s. Using an axe really was about committing to an attack; she could move it as easily as swinging a sword, but to actually do damage, she needed to follow through. A sword could flick in and out, stabbing or cutting, but an axe was a weapon of pure cutting force. It couldn’t be used shallowly, it needed commitment to each blow. So, then, how to work around the inherent advantages the lighter weapon had against her own?

 

A lance could beat a sword through its longer reach, but an axe would beat a lance by virtue of being too heavy to defend against. How could she use that advantage here though?

 

Her brow furrowed in determined focus, taking note of how her professor didn’t move to block her blows, just deflect them, redirecting their momentum and costing Edelgard the effort of having to pull back. Perhaps if she forced her to block them then…Edelgard pushed forward, gritting her teeth and swinging her axe with a brutal force for her professor’s head.

 

And this time, her professor caught the axe’s head on her blade, her eyes narrowing for the slightest instant as she was forced to block the heavy blow. Not that Edelgard was foolish enough to get into a struggle with the professor, instead rebounding her axe off the sword and then swinging all the harder on the return, aiming to at least force the professor to her knees–

 

And then the axe was smacked out of her hand when Byleth chose to swing for it instead of blocking.

 

“Not bad,” the mercenary noted, as though she hadn’t just completely disarmed Edelgard, “I can see what you were going for. You committed too much to the idea though. It’s not bad to be decisive, you just didn’t consider if I would go on the attack again. Would you mind picking up your axe again?”

 

The question took a moment to register, but Edelgard nodded once it did. A part of her felt strangely embarrassed, probably at losing so decisively in front of her classmates, but she did move over to her axe and pick it up, before returning to the professor.

 

“Here, like you were doing before.” She held her sword up in a block, similar to what she did before. “Axe blade right here, alright?”

 

“...Understood?” Edelgard frowned as she positioned her axe’s head in the same place it had been in while she was trying to batter down the professor.

 

“Alright, could you do that without both hands on the axe?”

 

“Yes? Where are you going with this?”

 

“Okay, swing down, but this time, keep the pressure up. Keep me locked in place, okay?”

 

Edelgard’s brow furrowed, but she did as requested, pushing down on her professor, who didn’t seem especially strained.

 

“Now punch me in the stomach with your free hand.”

 

Edelgard blinked. “Ah…excuse me?”

 

“You don’t have to if you don’t want to, but I’m very open right now. See? One hand on the hilt and my other hand is on the blade to keep things balanced,” Byleth explained, “So I don’t have any ability to block, at least not easily, if you follow up and hit me in the stomach. Or knife me, that’s also a potential move, though not one you want to do in a spar. Oh, and if you’re a decent caster, magic is also a move you could use in this position.”

 

“...Hm.” Edelgard glanced at her teacher’s bare midriff, which looked more firm than vulnerable, at least to her eyes, before frowning back up at her. “Would that work?”

 

“In the position you had me in, yup. It might not finish the fight, but it would be a solid hit that could potentially put me down. The stomach’s a vital area without a lot of natural protection since the ribs are more up around your heart. It might not be immediately lethal, but a stomach wound can be very debilitating.”

 

“I see…hm. And why didn’t you do anything like that in our fight? You’re clearly a skilled magic wielder, so why not bring that to bear here?”

 

“Because I would’ve killed you.”

 

The statement was so blunt and matter of fact, Edelgard needed a moment to actually register it. “...I am not weak, professor.”

 

“You’re not, no. But I kill people for a living. I can hold back, sure, but I don’t like the idea of risking it when you’re just starting out. Even then, if I were to seriously injure you, it might affect your ability to fight even if you were healed properly." 

 

"...One would think you were a fighting instructor before this and not just a mercenary," Edelgard noted, getting Byleth to shake her head. 

 

"I'm going to lead my father's mercenary group in the future, so I need to know these things." With that, Byleth stepped back so they could get into starting positions. "Whenever you're ready." 

 

Keeping a hand on her axe, Edelgard came to a realization that, at least at the moment, she had no way of beating the Mercenary in terms of skill. She herself had seen combat before, but there was no knowing just how that compared to the years of experience her professor had. That being said, she still wanted at least one point off of her, and if there was one thing Edelgard had, it was overwhelming force. 

 

And while it might be cheap to use her two crests against her, Edelgard was feeling petty enough to do so. Charging forward, Edelgard swung her axe with one hand, making it seem like she was listening to Byleth’s instructions, as she felt her crests empowering her. 

 

The slight widening of Byleth’s eyes were the only indication that she realized something was up as she chose to dodge instead of block. With a smirk, Edelgard slammed the axe onto the floor, causing cracks to spread which she quickly took advantage of as she flicked her axe, making debris fly towards the mercenary's face. 

 

Seeing her wince, Edelgard pressed the advantage, rushing forward to catch her professor off guard, her axe flying to strike–and she came to a stop as she felt her sword against her neck, Edelgard’s axe stopping against Byleth’s side. 

 

"Not bad." Byleth said as she rubbed her eyes clear. "That's a point for both of us I suppose." 

 

"...I thought I had you there." 

 

"You almost did. If you had changed your angle of attack, you would have. For reference, blinding your opponent means nothing if they know you're still in front of them," Byleth said after she cleared her eyes. "Still, you improved over the course of that fight." She gave Edelgard a small smile. "I look forward to teaching you." 

 

"...And I look forward to learning from you." 

 

"Thank you. I'm glad you're feeling better." 

 

"Excuse me?" 

 

"You don't seem angry anymore. It's good that you're not, anger is unpleasant." 

 

Edelgard blinked. She…did feel better. “...Huh.”

 

And with that, the match ended, and Edelgard felt herself stepping backward to avoid the sudden rush as a number of students crowded around the new professor.

 

“THAT WAS AMAZING!” The first and loudest of which was, of course, Caspar. The young man looked astounded at Byleth. "I didn't think anyone could beat Edelgard, and you did it no problem!" The young heiress refrained from commenting on his words. 

 

"I wouldn't say it was no problem, but it is a good thing she didn't actually strike Edelgard during the spar," Ferdinand commented, getting Caspar to stare at him in confusion and incredulity.

 

"Edelgard was a good sparring partner," Byleth said, somewhat agreeing with Ferdinand. 

 

"I must be admitting, I am quite shocked you were able to win against Edelgard," Petra said, doing her best to get her praise across. 

 

"Just goes to show how strong our new professor is~." Dorothea said, leaning forward towards Byleth, and Edelgard couldn't help but note how her classmate’s eyes wandered over their professor's body. "I must say Edie, you certainly brought us a good one~" 

 

"...Excuse me, you're Dorothea, from the opera company?" 

 

"Oh, that I am! I didn't think even mercenaries knew who I was." 

 

"My family and I saw a play you starred in years ago, it was really nice." The professor seemed to frown for a moment. "I would have preferred a happier ending though." 

 

"Wouldn't we all? Alas, that's how it goes on the stage. But I'm glad you enjoyed the play professor, maybe I can sing for you if we have the time during the school year~?" 

 

"That sounds nice." Byleth said, agreeing to the idea before glancing around. "Is this everyone from the class?" She asked, noting a few other students milling about and not approaching. At least one girl with light-brown hair was watching with an odd expression on her face.

 

"Well, there's also Lindhart but he fell asleep." Caspar said, gesturing to the mage who had fallen asleep on the floor. 

 

"Bernadetta is also in our class, but she did the running away when she heard a fight was going to happen," Petra said, explaining where their missing classmate was. 

 

“She ran away? Huh. We’ll need to work on that,” Byleth muttered, prompting a bit of amusement from Edelgard at the thought of their teacher trying to keep the easily frightened girl still. While she didn’t doubt her professor was capable, as clearly evidenced by their spar, Bernadetta wasn’t exactly easy to handle.

 

“If Ferdinand insists on trying to play at being your attendant, the least he could do is actually attend to you, my lady,” Hubert commented while handing Edelgard a handkerchief, his voice too low for their fellow students to notice as they gathered around the professor. 

 

“I sincerely hope he doesn’t try,” Edelgard replied while dabbing the sweat from her brow. “So? What do you think?”

 

“She’s capable, I’ll give her that. I do appreciate her holding back as well, though I doubt you feel the same, your highness.”

 

She raised an eyebrow. “Is that approval, Hubert?”

 

“It’s acknowledgement. Do you aim to recruit her?”

 

“I’ve made my interest obvious, though it seems the church may be trying to get a hold on Miss Eisner first, given her new position. Oh, and you might be interested in knowing the younger sister is a dark mage.”

 

Hubert paused, a brief flicker of interest crossing his dark eyes. “Hm. Well that is interesting.”

 

“She’s also adopted. That might not necessarily suggest anything…”

 

“But it is better to be careful than careless. If either become a problem…”

 

“Then we’ll adjust to the Eisner sisters. The elder is to be our professor and the younger is to be a classmate.” She glanced up at her attendant with a slight frown. “So no trying to threaten them away from me. I know how you are with Monica.”

 

“I have no idea what you mean, your highness. Though I will mention it is a good thing she lives in Ochs and not nearer to the monastery. I would prefer to have some advance notice if she decides to come visit. Again.”

 

Edelgard’s lips twitched in a moment of humor at the thought of her sometimes overly enthusiastic supporter, before she shook it off and turned towards her classmates. “Alright everyone! Do not crowd the professor, she still needs time to tour the grounds.”

 

“Oh, of course! And I would be glad to show you–” 

 

Edelgard stepped up to the professor and placed a hand on her shoulder, steering her away from Ferdinand. “No, Ferdinand, this is my task to handle as the house leader. Why don’t you find Professor Eisner’s younger sister? She’s joining as a student as well, so recruiting her–”

 

“Oh yes! That would be quite the boon to our house! Excellent idea, Edelgard! We’ll make a capable emperor of you yet!”

 

“...” Well now her earlier annoyance was returning.

 

“Hm. You want to spar again?” Professor Eisner asked, glancing at Edelgard, who did consider it for a moment.

 

“...No, we really should move on. There is much more to see around here, after all.”

“Oh wow, you’re a big guy,” Shez commented, staring up at the largest man she’d ever met. Or maybe the largest boy? He did have an Academy uniform on, after all. And he was staring at her in some confusion, which, right, that was a weird way to introduce herself.

 

“Ah, Dedue! Uh, sorry to bother you,” Ashe apologized in her stead, before glancing at Shez. “Um, Shez, this is–”

 

“Oh, no need to introduce us, I can do that myself!” she interrupted, before grinning up at the big guy. “Hey there, I’m Shez Eisner, also known as the Violet Demon and daughter of Jeralt the Blade Breaker! Also a mercenary up for hire, if you’re interested!” She paused. “Oh, and I guess a student here now, also.”

 

“...I see,” Dedue responded, mostly because he wasn’t completely sure how to respond to that sudden deluge of information. “It is nice to meet you, Shez. I am Dedue Molinaro. If I may ask, are you the mercenary who rescued his highness?”

 

“Oh, yeah! Well, my sister and I, but I was the one who mostly stuck by the prince.”

 

“Then you have my gratitude.” He placed a hand on his chest and gave her a bow, though he did pause at the sudden, seemingly excited noise she made.

 

“Ah ha, I knew you were someone important! You have that kinda noble look to you, you know?”

 

He blinked, not expecting that response in the slightest. And vaguely hoping none of the actual nobles of Faerghus just heard this girl compare him to one of them.

 

“So are you like a duke or something? I think that’s the rank below a king, right?”

 

“...I believe you may be confused. I am simply his highness’s retainer. I have no noble blood,” he explained.

 

“Oh, whoops…well are you still rich? Because, again, I am open to being hired if you need a bodyguard.”

 

Dedue raised an eyebrow at the much shorter and less visibly muscular woman offering to be his bodyguard. “I think I will be fine.”

 

“Ah, true, you do look pretty beefy…oh, hey, how much does being a prince’s retainer pay? Because if that doesn’t work out, we could totally use a big guy like you in our group.”

 

Dedue wasn’t sure if he should be impressed at just how mercenary this mercenary’s mindset happened to be. “No, thank you, I am loyal to his highness. However, if you ever have need of my strength, I would be happy to repay the debt that is owed for saving his life.”

 

“Well hey, I won’t turn down free help either!" Shez said, grinning before she decided to look around. "...Huh, hey Ashe, why are we in a greenhouse?" 

 

"...You're the one who led us here." 

 

"And why did you let me do that?" 

 

"I thought you knew where you were going." 

 

"Oh no, I'm terrible with directions, dad refuses to let me be the one with the map,” Shez explained to Ashe’s surprise. "But hey, at least this place is nice. You hang out around here often, Dedue?" 

 

"When I have the time to,” the giant responded, before he glanced at the gardener in charge who kept giving him wary looks. "But I should take my leave for now." 

 

"Oh? Are you heading somewhere? Mind if we tag along?" 

 

"My apologies, but I would not recommend lingering around a man of Duscur, lest rumors spread." 

 

"And that's a bad thing?" Shez asked, raising an eyebrow. "I'm a mercenary, I make my living off of rumors and word of mouth." 

 

"We were planning on meeting the rest of the Blue Lions, Dedue,” Ashe said, “It would only be right if we have her meet everyone together, right?" 

 

"...Very well, I was going to meet his highness anyways." 

 

"Nice!” Shez grinned. “Now, where are we going?" 

 

"His highness was still in the classroom when I came here. As well as many of our classmates." 

 

"In that case, let's go there! Mind leading the way, Ashe?" 

 

"I don't mind, aha." The young boy said with a smile as he led the way towards the classroom, which was the exact opposite way Shez had gone after leaving the cafeteria. Soon enough the trio arrived at the courtyard that led to the classrooms, a few students still milling about. Though it seemed someone in specific noticed the trio. 

 

"Wow, look at you Ashe, I look away for a bit and here you are with a beautiful girl at your side," a tall redhead said with a smirk. 

 

"I-it's not like that Sylvain!"

 

"Oh? In that case, if she's single, I'd definitely like to know her." 

 

"You could start by talking to me, you know." Shez said. "Name's Shez if you're wondering."

 

"Oooh, you're the mercenary Dimitri was talking about. Pleasure to meet you, I'm Sylvain Jose Gautier." 

 

"Heh, guess being buddies with a prince is definitely gonna help my rep." 

 

"I'm sure it will. In fact, I can already see people lining up to hire you. I certainly wouldn't mind doing so for some one on one time," Sylvain said with a flirtatious wink. 

 

"Hey man, it's your money. But if you're expecting anything, you're better off hiring a prostitute." Sylvain probably wasn't expecting such a crass response since he did a double take. "And if you're wondering how Ashe and I know each other, my dad's company got hired by his dad for a while." 

 

"My siblings really miss you and Byleth by the way,” Ashe mentioned, “I'm sure they'll be happy to hear that you're here next time I get the chance to write to them." 

 

Sylvain, meanwhile, managed to shake off his surprise in favor of some curiosity. "And may I ask who Byleth is?" 

 

"She's my sister, and before you try anything, she only likes girls," Shez warned, getting Sylvain to put his hands up in mock surrender. 

 

"Sylvain, you better not be bothering this girl," a blonde girl said, frowning as she marched up to him. "We already owe her for saving Dimitri. The last thing we need is you giving her  a bad impression of the Blue Lions." 

 

Shez shrugged. "Eh, you guys have been cool so far." 

 

"Regardless, he should know better." Letting out a sigh, she faced Shez before bowing to her. "You may call me Ingrid, and on behalf of the Holy Kingdom of Faerghus, I thank you for saving Prince Dimitri."

 

"You must be quite skilled if he needed your help. I look forward to beating you in a spar," a sharp-eyed, black haired boy said, as he stared Shez down. Or, well, tried to.

 

"Felix, don't be rude!" 

 

"And if you're looking for a spar, you'll have to wait. The Black Eagles are using it right now, apparently the house leader challenged someone to a spar." Sylvain explained, getting Ingrid to frown and Shez to look thoughtful. 

 

"Oh, wonder if that's where Edelgard took my sister." 

 

"Shez, was it?" Ingrid asked, getting the mercenary in question to nod. "You and your sister probably shouldn't be hanging around the people of the Empire, they're dangerous." 

 

"Really?" Shez asked, a bit amused. "Well, even if they are, not like it matters. None of you kids could touch us in a fight if we were being serious." 

 

"Is that so?" Felix asked, apparently taking that as a challenge. 

 

"Of course, the only one who can beat By is me, and By is the only one who can beat me!" 

 

"Neither of you have bested your father," Arval pointed out, which did get Shez to pause. Which, well…that was different, dad was dad, which she would point out to Arval if they weren’t in public.

 

“Hmph. Are you willing to test that?” Felix asked, still trying to stare her down.

 

And Shez met his glare with an eager grin. “Anytime you want to, I’m willing.”

 

“...” Felix regarded her for a moment, then smirked, clearly looking forward to it. Up until Sylvain opened his mouth again.

 

“Aw, look at that! Felix got his first date! I’m so proud!”

 

“Shut up, Sylvain! Would it kill you to think with your head instead of your–”

 

“Felix!” Ingrid cut him off, looking scandalized and prompting a laugh from Shez.

 

“Okay, you guys are pretty fun. Is this everybody?”

 

“Ah, no, there’s actually two more girls,” Ashe answered, “Mercedes and Annette, who should be…somewhere around here, I think. Oh, and his highness, of course. And a few other students.”

 

“Well alright, let’s go find them! C’mon Ashe, you’re my guide.”

 

“H-Huh? Oh, uh, alright–W-Woah, slow down!” he tried to request as Shez grabbed him by the wrist and started dragging him off, much to Sylvain’s amusement.

 

“Ah, they grow up so fast.”

 

“Hm? Who are you referring to?” Dimitri asked curiously as he came over to the gathered group.

 

“Hmm…would it be funnier to tell you, or leave it a secret?”

 

Ingrid and Felix just sighed before getting back to what they were doing, leaving Dimitri’s question unanswered and the blond prince increasingly confused.

“And here we have the gardens,” Edelgard stated as she continued showing her future professor around the Academy’s grounds, “Specifically, these are the outdoor gardens many students will gather in for leisure during their free time. It is not unusual to see tea parties hosted at the tables set out here–”

 

“Is that Shez?” Byleth interrupted, catching the princess off guard. Partially because her professor had been content to let her talk up until this point, but also because the younger Eisner sister was indeed sitting at one of the tea tables alongside some students she recognized as being from the Blue Lions.

 

“Mmm~! Oh wow, this is good–Ah hey By!” And it seemed she noticed the two of them as well, as she suddenly sat up and began waving at her sister. “Hey, come join us! And bring the princess too!”

 

"Okay?" Without another word, Byleth walked off, heading to the table expecting Edelgard to follow. Which… there was a slight chance she might be convinced to join a different class, so best not leave her alone with the Blue Lions. "Hm? Is that you Ash–mh?" 

 

"Tastes great, doesn't it?" Shez asked after cutting off her sister by shoving a tart into her mouth. "Apparently we can just have these whenever!" She smiled brightly, ignoring the stare her sister was giving her, which slowly went away as she ate the tart, her faintly annoyed expression fading as she tasted the pastry.

 

"Well not whenever, but we don't mind if you wanna join us for our tea parties whenever Mercedes and I make some treats, right?" Annette asked as she looked at her companion. 

 

"The more the merrier," the older Blue Lions member said with a gentle smile.

 

"...Can I have another?" Byleth asked, staring at the plate of treats. 

 

"Go ahead," Mercedes allowed, before looking at Edelgard as Byleth grabbed another tart to eat. "What about you, Edelgard, would you like one?" 

 

"...I would hate to impose."

 

"Nonsense, if anything you're helping us. We're not going to be able to finish this off ourselves, and I would hate for them to grow stale." 

 

"...Well if you insist." The treats did look rather delicious, and Edelgard did her best to school her features as she bit into one. “...”

 

Edelgard took a seat at the tea table.

 

“So what’ve you been up to, By?” Shez asked, “I heard something about a spar out at the training ground.”

 

“Yeah, I sparred with Edelgard,” Byleth answered, inclining her head towards Edelgard before pausing as Mercedes poured her a cup of tea. “Thank you.”

 

“You’re very welcome,” the older blonde said with a smile, before giving her a curious look, “Miss Byleth, was it?” At her nod, she continued. “Your sister was telling us that you are going to be a professor here.”

 

“Oh yeah, have you picked out a class yet?” Annette asked, also curious. Edelgard decided not to speak up, wagering that the professor might be bothered if she were interrupted, and her wager paid off as the woman nodded.

 

“Yeah, I’m probably going to be teaching the Black Eagles. I already trained with Edelgard and the rest of her class seems nice.”

 

“Ah, dang, I guess Edelgard got to you before we could then,” the redhead commented with a little grin, “It would have been fun having twins join our class, even if one would be the professor.”

 

Edelgard raised an eyebrow at the mention of twins, remembering Shez’s earlier claims, before simply shaking her head and accepting an offered cup of tea from Mercedes. The conversation moved along to how the two sisters knew Ashe, who seemed curiously flustered at being the only boy at the table, and Edelgard listened with some interest as they talked about their brief time in the kingdom.

 

“I really thought I would be able to handle the cold better since the mountains I came from could get pretty cold and snowy in the winter, but it was completely different,” Shez commented.

 

“Yes, winters in Faerghus do tend to be remarkably harsh,” Mercedes agreed, “I was originally from Adrestia, so the cold can still catch me off guard sometimes.”

 

“Oh hey, that’s neat. We spent a lot of time in the Empire, though dad’s actually from Faerghus.”

 

“Oh really? Heh, I guess you didn’t inherit our ‘cold blood’ then,” Annette said, “So where are you two from if you weren’t born in Faerghus?”

 

“I’m from the Alliance, actually! Ordelia territory specifically, I think. Right, By?” she asked, glancing at her sister, who nodded but didn’t add anything in favor of taking another tart. It seemed the new professor had something of a sweet tooth.

 

Edelgard also happened to notice Shez answered in the singular there. Not unexpected given that she admitted to being adopted, but it was interesting that she was also attempting to pretend she and Byleth were twins. Looking at the two of them…Edelgard was fairly certain Byleth was indeed the elder of the two, while Shez was likely closer to Edelgard’s age than her sister’s despite being taller. Byleth simply looked more mature between the two of them, so it raised the question of why Shez was attempting such an easily seen through deception…

 

"There you two are, I've been looking everywhere for you!" A voice shook her out of her thoughts as Claude came up to the small party. "Here I was waiting for my new friends to come visit, only to find out you went to have a tea party,” Claude said with mock offense.

 

"Oh sorry your grace, I guess I lost track of the time while having fun," Shez mockingly replied with a smile. 

 

"Well if you're really sorry, you can make it up to us, isn't that right Hilda?" Claude asked his pink-haired companion who seemed to have been dragged along with him. 

 

"Oh yeah totally! I'm sure there's plenty a pair of big, strong mercs like you two can do to make it up to us," Hilda said, buttering up the two mercenaries as she's wont to do. 

 

"Heh, too little, too late, Claude, both of them have already chosen what class they're going to join," Annette said with a smug smile. 

 

"Ah but you forgot! Transferring between classes is allowed for students, so who knows, we might end up stealing Shez away." Claude glanced at Byleth. “Not sure if we can steal a professor too, but hey, I’m willing to give it a try.”

 

"Transferring?" Byleth asked, not bothering to wipe the crumbs away from her mouth. 

 

"Students are allowed to transfer between classes should they wish, this mainly happens should one wish to learn under a different professor," Edelgard explained

 

"Or if they want to try and get close to someone from a different class. After all, with the right connections you can do anything," Claude added, "As such, it's only fair you let these two meet my class, don't you think?" 

 

"Just don't come crying to me when your classmates wish to transfer over to the Black Eagles," Edelgard said, deciding to not try and force Byleth to stay. 

 

"Eh, if you want I'll toss Lorenz your way," Claude said as Byleth and Shez got up, though the former was stopped as Edelgard pulled out her handkerchief. 

 

"Professor, you have crumbs around your mouth," she said, handing her the handkerchief. 

 

"Oh, thank you." Taking it, she cleaned the crumbs off, before pocketing the item. 

 

"Uh, professor, you're not supposed to keep that…" Annette said a bit surprised to see her do so. 

 

"I'm not?" 

 

"It's fine, just please return it later," Edelgard allowed, waving them off as she reached for another treat. 

 

"So, I know you two were just having a tea party, but are you feeling hungry? No better way to get to know someone than over a nice meal," Claude asked as he led them to the mess hall. 

 

"I already ate earlier, but I don't think By has." 

 

"You're in for a treat, professor! The classes here might be a drag but the delicious food helps make up for it," Hilda said with a smile. "Getting to try food from all over is great!" 

 

“That it is, a perfect place for a feast whenever the need arises,” Claude agreed, before looking at the sisters. “And what's a feast without companions? A rather sad one if you ask me, hence why the Golden Deer are here if you want to join.” 

 

“There you are, Claude. I was starting to wonder if you were even going to return,” a rather posh sounding guy said as he walked up to the group. “If you’re not even going to attend a party you plan, then I wonder how well you’ll be able to lead.” 

 

“Well I needed to get our guests of honor,” Claude replied, gesturing at the said guests. 

 

“Oh, my apologies, I didn't see you there. I presume you two are the mercenaries who saved Claude? On behalf of the alliance I, Lorenz Hellman Gloucester, apologize for the trouble he might have dragged you into.” 

 

“Gloucester?” Shez blinked, then grinned, “Oh, hey, are you the count’s kid?” 

 

“I am the son of Count Gloucester, yes. Why do you ask?”

 

“We’ve worked for you dad a couple times! The first job By and I were on was one he hired us for.” 

 

“Is that so? Well it seems my father’s eye for talent continues to stay true if you truly are so skilled. If I may ask, what work have you done for him?”

 

“Helping my village for one,” a familiar orange-haired gal said as she walked up to them. “Hey there Shez, Byleth. How’s the captain doing?” 

 

“Oh hey Leonie!” Shez greeted with a grin, “Dad’s doing fine! Well, less good now that he’s around here. I don’t think he likes…Well, I think he has a few bad memories that this place is bringing back.”

 

“Really? Huh. I heard he was the former knight’s captain, so I guess it might have something to do with that...”

 

“Oh, you are the daughters of Jeralt the Blade Breaker then,” Lorenz realized, “Yes, that does make sense. I must say, your father has a well-earned reputation for reliability.”

 

“Not to interrupt all this interesting talk of mercenary lineages,” Claude interrupted with far less shame than he was pretending to have, “But we still need to introduce the new girls to everybody, right? After all, I can’t properly poach you two if you don’t know everyone.”

 

“Ha! Well if you insist on showing me around, your grace, go for it!” Shez said, “Just know I’m the type of girl to keep to a contract, so you’ll have to be pretty convincing if you want me to switch over.”

 

“Well I won’t say no to a challenge! Come on, let’s show you around!”

 

As Claude and Shez headed to chat with the other Golden Deer around, Lorenz let out an aggrieved sigh. “I have no idea how he thinks he can lead the Alliance when he’s so willing to traipse off on whatever venture catches his interest.”

 

“Aw, come on Lorenz, Claude’s not that bad,” Hilda replied, prompting an amused noise from Leonie.

 

“So if he’s not so bad, why are you hanging back with the rest of us instead of joining the tour?”

 

“Well maybe I would prefer to get to know the older sister, huh? Byleth, right?”

 

“My name is Byleth, yes.”

 

“Wow, you’re really monotone. How did that happen when your sister’s so lively?” Hilda asked, before laughing a little at herself, “Though I guess I’m one to talk, considering how different me and Holst are.”

 

“Ah yes, and how is your brother, Hilda?” Lorenz inquired, turning his attention to the most noble of the women gathered near him.

 

“Oh, uh, good, I guess? I mean, it’s not like I send him letters everyday, so I’m not going to know immediately.”

 

“Oh? Why not? I would expect you to be more dutiful in keeping up contact with the future lord of your house.”

 

“Right, looks like they’re talking about noble stuff now.” Leonie sighed, before grinning at Byleth. “So, while they chat about pedigrees or whatever, care to share what you’ve been up to since I saw you in Sauin?”

 

“A few things,” Byleth answered.

 

“...You’re about the same as ever, huh?”

 

She shrugged, her attention more on Claude and Shez as the former introduced the latter to the rest of the Golden Deer. Aside from Hilda, Lorenz, and Leonie, there seemed to be two more boys sitting together who contrasted heavily with one another, and two girls sitting more away from the rest of the group.

 

“Starting things off, here’s Raphael Kirsten and Ignatz Victor, two bonafide knights-in-training,” Claude explained as he gestured to the two boys in question, a large, extremely muscular blond and a short, skinny boy with glasses and olive-green hair. 

 

“Hey there!”

 

“H-Hello! Ah, are you one of the mercenaries that rescued Claude?”

 

“Hey now, I didn’t need rescue,” Claude complained, prompting a smirk from Shez.

 

“Oh really, your grace? So those bandits were just trying to hunt you down to have a tea party?”

 

“I sure hope not, otherwise the fact you cut straight through most of them is going to be really awkward to explain to the knights.”

 

“Eh, you’d be surprised. Anyway, so Raphael Kirsten and Ignatz Victor, right? That’s kind of funny, we have a Victor back in our company.”

 

“Oh, really?” Ignatz asked, a little curious.

 

“Yeah but it’s his given name, not his family name, so I’m pretty sure you two aren’t related. Especially since he’s from the Empire and closer to Raphael here in height and build.”

 

That caught Raphael’s attention. “Seriously? Wow, I didn’t think I’d run into someone dedicated to building muscle like I am this quick! Can I meet him?”

 

“Oh sure, though he’s definitely not as bulky as you are. Kind of more on the hefty side these days, though don’t let that fool you, he’s still really solid.”

 

While that conversation continued, Byleth nudged Leonie and pointed to the quiet, blue-haired girl eating on her own and the short, white-haired girl reading a book at the dining table. “Who are those two?”

 

“Hm? Oh, the girl with the blue hair is Marianne. She’s Margrave Edmund’s daughter, from that northern house. I think she might be shy, she doesn’t really interact with people unless she has to. And that’s Lysithea with the book. She’s some type of magic prodigy despite being one of the younger students. She’s alright, but she gets snippy if you bring up her age.”

 

Byleth nodded to that information, then paused, noticing another girl who seemed deeply nervous just to be in the mess hall. The short, purple-haired girl was staring at the menu like it was going to launch itself at her if she made the wrong move, when she wasn’t looking all around herself as though expecting an ambush. “Do you know her too?”

 

“Uh…not really, no. I think that’s…Bernadette, I think, from the Black Eagles.”

 

“Do you mean Bernadetta?”

 

“Oh yeah, that was it.” Leonie shrugged. “Like I said, I don’t really know her.”

 

“Hm…Thank you for the information.”

 

“Huh. Didn't expect you to actually thank me–And she’s walking off, okay…”

 

Byleth walked over to the small, shaky girl. “Hello.”

 

“AH!” She wasn’t expecting her to immediately scream. “A-A-A-Ah, s-s-s-sorry! Sorry, I-I’ll get out of your way, I’m sorry, don’t kill me!”

 

“I’m not planning to kill you. Are you Bernadetta?”

 

“AH!? H-How do you know my name?! A-A-Are you an assassin!?”

 

“I’m a mercenary. Or a professor now, I guess,” Byleth answered as she regarded the plainly terrified girl. She wasn’t sure exactly what she was doing wrong, but it wasn’t a pleasant feeling. “I heard you ran away from the training yard when everyone else in your class was gathering there. I’m going to be your professor going forward, so–”

 

“AAH!?! Y-YOU ARE!? Aaahh, then I made you mad because I ran away and you’re going to execute me in front of everyone as a lesson!?!”

 

Byleth felt a flicker of actual concern. “No, I’m not. Are you–”

 

And then the other girl promptly sprinted in the opposite direction, screaming out, “PLEASE DON’T KILL ME!” as she went.

 

“...Hm.” 

 

“Wow. What did you say to her?” Leonie asked as she walked up to Byleth.

 

“...I don’t know.”

 

Maybe this teaching job would be harder than she considered…

Chapter End Notes

Red: And so we meet, well, everybody! Well pretty much everybody, we haven't shown off some the churchfolk and a certain group of Abyss dwellers yet.

Indi: Yup yup, they'll come eventually I'm sure. As it stands now, we have met the students at least! As well as the reveal of hey, yeah Monica is around. Granted she's over in Ochs but still. Wonder what happened there.

Red: I wonder what happened indeed...Anyways thanks as always for reading! We have a discord and another FE3H story up at the moment, so feel free to check both of those out. Link in the previous chapter and all that.

Indi: Thanks for reading!

The Apprentice

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

"Captain, there you are!" Pausing in his conversation with Alois, Jeralt looked over his shoulder to see Leonie waving at him as she ran up. 

 

"Oh, Leonie, I didn't know you were here," Jeralt said, a bit surprised to see the young hunter. 

 

"Oh, my, did I forget to mention?" Alois asked. "Yes, your apprentice is a member of the Golden Deer. I guess you could say she's your deer apprentice." 

 

"...So how have you been Leonie?" Jeralt asked, moving the conversation along. 

 

"I've been doing great! Alois has been telling me all sorts of stories about you!" 

 

"He has huh?" he asked, glancing at his former squire. 

 

"Ah yes, Leonie here was quite excited to find out I used to work with you, so she has constantly been asking me about stories involving you. Constantly . Ah, though I promise you I've said nothing but the best." 

 

"Yeah! I didn't know you were a knight captain! You're even greater than I thought!" 

 

"It's not that impressive," Jeralt muttered, before he noticed the charm around Leonie's neck. "You kept that old thing?" 

 

"Well, yeah? Why wouldn't I? It was a good luck charm from you!" Leonie said, holding the charm. "In fact, I kept all those gifts you guys got me!" 

 

"Really?" 

 

"Yeah! I mean, the training weight is a bit too small now, but it's still handy when I want to weigh something down!" Leonie said, before giving a sheepish smile. "Funny enough, the knife Byleth gave me was also really useful, since the one I had ended up breaking a week later." 

 

“Heh. Well I’m sure she’ll be happy to hear you got some use out of her gift." 

 

"Well…maybe. Ah, but, how have things been for you Captain? I'm sure you have plenty of stories to tell!" 

 

"Nothing that glamorous," Jeralt said, letting out a small sigh. "I'm sure the kids can probably tell you more than I can." 

 

"Well sure, but I want to hear from you!" 

 

"Is that so…? Well, the kids have gotten much stronger. Shez is still as reckless as ever, but she has the skills to back it up now," Jeralt said, as he began to reminisce. "Her and Byleth actually started taking missions on their own some years back." 

 

"They did?"

 

"Yeah, I still make sure it's nothing that dangerous, but they've been doing good. Though if you were to listen to Shez, she'd act like they were all world-ending threats." 

 

"Aha, nothing wrong with exaggerating a tale when you're retale-ing them," Alois said with a grin. 

 

"Hm…Byleth is the opposite of Shez as usual," Jeralt continued, not acknowledging the pun. "She's got a good head for when it comes to tactics, and is even preparing to take over for me if I ever retire." 

 

"...Really?" 

 

"Yeah, I think it's mainly cause Shez is pushing her towards it," Jeralt explained. "She's good at it, at least. I'm not planning on retiring any time soon, but if I ever did, I know the group would be in good hands." 

 

"...Hm." Leonie couldn't help but frown a bit. She always knew there was a chance one of the two sisters would take over the captain’s mercenary band; they were the captain’s daughters, so it was to be expected they'd probably end up leading. That being said, a part of her couldn't help but feel a bit…annoyed at the idea of that arrogant merc being in charge. 

 

"You know, since I used to be your right-hand man, I wonder if that makes Byleth my junior if she really will be taking over for you," Alois considered, mirth evident in his voice. 

 

"Pretty sure she could teach you a thing or two, Alois–" 

 

"Sorry about leaving so quickly, Captain! There's just something I need to check!" Leonie suddenly spoke up, catching Jeralt off guard as she sprinted away. 

 

"Huh, wonder what came up…"

Dashing through the monastery, Leonie looked around, trying to find any sight of the sisters as she did. They had apparently already taken off from the feast, though it was a bit too early for them to be asleep. 

 

She didn't expect to find them with Byleth pinned down on the ground by cats and dogs while Shez laughed at the sight.

 

"Seems you got quite the fanclub, By," Shez teased, crouching down as she reached for one of the cats, only to yank her hand back as it scratched her. "Ow." 

 

"Don't be rude,” Byleth said to the cat in question, giving it small scritches under its chin. 

 

"...I see you two have met the monastery pets," Leonie muttered, not sure what else to say. 

 

"Oh, they're not a bunch of wild animals?" Shez asked. 

 

"No, the monastery keeps them since they help chase away rats and such." 

 

"Huh, well that's neat," Shez said as Byleth continued petting the various animals cuddling up to her. Shaking her head, Leonie regained her focus. 

 

"Hey, Byleth, I want to spar!" 

 

"Oh, sure." Grabbing the cat that was resting on her head, Byleth gently set them down, before gingerly stepping around the animals. "To the training grounds?" 

 

"Yeah!" 

 

"Hey, don't think I'll be staying out of this!" Shez shouted, following behind the two as they went off. 

 

"Ah, sorry Shez, I want to spar with Byleth first," Leonie apologized, keeping her eye on Byleth. 

 

"Is ‘first to three strikes’ okay?" Byleth asked, grabbing a wooden sword as they arrived.

 

"Nope, I want to go until one of us yields!" Leonie stated, getting Byleth to pause for a moment. 

 

"...Okay, let's just make sure to be careful,” she cautioned, though she wasn’t bothering to put on a helmet or any training armor, which prompted a frown from Leonie.

 

“Are you that sure you’re not gonna get hit here?” the redhead asked as she grabbed a training spear for herself.

 

“Hm? It’s just a spar,” Byleth said with a shrug. Her eyes lingered on the padded wooden spear in Leonie’s grip, then she nodded to herself. “Alright. Shez, can you give a count?”

 

“Oh, sure! Three!” The two young women faced each other. “Two!” They readied their weapons. “One!” And then they charged in, Leonie thrusting her spear straight for Byleth’s face in a move that would have done a lot of damage in a real fight. 

 

She made sure not to overextend herself too so she could pull her sword back when the first thrust missed–Then Byleth clotheslined her, smashing the younger commoner straight off her feet and sending her crashing to the ground. “Gh–!”

 

“Wow, that was a hard hit,” Shez commented, impressed, “You’re actually taking this seriously, By?”

 

“Hm…I am, yeah,” Byleth agreed, frowning for a moment at the winded redhead on the ground, before she relaxed as Leonie pushed herself back up, shaking herself out.

 

“Phew…I didn’t yield,” she stated, readjusting her grip and narrowing her eyes towards Byleth, who nodded.

 

“I know. Ready?”

 

“Ready!”

Some time later, Leonie felt…frustrated. Very frustrated. In large part because she was on her back again, this time after Byleth hooked her ankle with her foot while shoving her back.

 

She’d tried to catch the arrogant merc’s wrist but that just got Byleth to deliberately fall with her and now Leonie’s ribs were aching from the elbow the captain’s daughter drove into her sternum.

 

“Are you okay?” Byleth asked from where she was sitting on the ground beside her.

 

“…’m good,” Leonie grumbled. Well, half-grumbled, half-wheezed.

 

“Mm. Throwing dirt in my eyes was a decent move,” she complimented, though Leonie just huffed in reply.

 

“You still kicked my ass that time.” She couldn’t deny that, especially after Byleth fully slammed her into the dirt.

 

“Hm.” 

 

Leonie let out a little aggrieved sigh. She knew the captain’s daughter had more experience than her and the idea she’d be even stronger than the last time they met seemed obvious, but it still stung at her pride to be on the consistent losing side.

 

"You've gotten stronger." Byleth noted, as she got up. "You'll make it far as a mercenary." 

 

"Huh?" Looking up at the mercenary, Leonie saw her extend a hand towards her. 

 

"Guess that means you'll be joining the team once you graduate," Byleth said, matter of factly.

 

"I-I will?" 

 

"Yeah, unless you didn't want to," Byleth said with a frown. 

 

"Of course she wants to!" Shez butted in, slinging a hand over Byleth’s shoulder. "Though, you gotta get your own rival, got it? By's my rival!" 

 

Leonie blinked, then snorted, giggling. “Alright, I won’t steal your rival, Shez. Though do you have anyone you’d recommend me going up against instead?”

 

“Hm…good question…”

 

“Maybe you could be her rival,” Byleth suggested.

 

“Me? Well I guess I could–Wait, no, that’s not how it works! You can only have one rival!”

 

“Really? Why?”

 

“That’s just how it works! It’s like…a law of, uh…writing or something!”

 

“There’s never been a protagonist that has more than one rival?”

 

“...Uh…hm. That’s a good question…” She tilted her head, before shrugging. “Yeah, alright, do you want to be my rival, Leonie?”

 

“...Sure? So…can Byleth also be my rival or is that not allowed?”

 

“It’s not allowed,” Shez decisively stated. And that was that.

Chapter End Notes

Red: Have some Leonie. She's around.

Indi: That she is! Was fun to do this chapter, and helps show that she has a much higher opinion of Byleth than she does in the main game.

Red: Yup! She does still think Byleth's kind of arrogant, though that's almost better than her first impression in canon considering she just went from "hey you're new" to "hey I'm hostile to you".

Indi: Yup yup, though she also isn't Byleth’s rival this time around cause Shez forbids it lol.

Red: Only Shez is allowed to be Byleth's rival! No one else gets to be!

Strange New Abilities

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Jeralt didn’t really know what to make of his new, old office. It was…bizarre, being back at the monastery, and finding things both had and hadn’t changed as much as he expected.

 

Still, that was something he could focus on later. For now, he was just glad conversations in his office weren't easy to listen in on.

 

“So you had a dream of a strange person too, but yours is a girl with green hair instead of Shez’s weird white person,” he began, his attention focused on Byleth for the moment, though Shez looked like she wanted to chime in.

 

"Did you get cool powers too??" Shez asked, leaning in closer. 

 

"Yeah, she was able to turn back time." 

 

"...what?" Jeralt asked, his eyes widening.

 

"During the fight, I wasn't able to block an attack, but she stopped time and then turned it back, which gave me another chance to defeat the leader," Byleth explained, thinking back on what happened.

 

"...that sounds so much cooler than what I can do.” 

 

"Excuse me?" Arval asked, some genuine offense in their voice. 

 

"You know what I mean, Arval! Your stuff is cool too, but can it do something like this?" Grabbing a book off their dad's desk, Shez tossed it at Byleth, fully expecting her to grab it with her time powers. Only for it to end up hitting her straight in the face. "..." 

 

"...I did say she was the one turning back time, right?" Byleth asked, rubbing her forehead, "I don't think she will unless it'll be a serious injury." 

 

"Sorry." 

 

"Hmph, what good are these so-called time powers if she herself cannot use them at will?" Arval mocked, feeling quite smug. 

 

Jeralt, meanwhile, couldn't help but wonder just what exactly this meant. As far as he was aware, Sitri wasn't able to do these things. Was it something Rhea had done? 

 

She had apparently awakened them that night which… it was too strong of a coincidence for it to not involve the archbishop. Just what was she planning…?

 

"So, is that girl here?" Shez asked, looking around. 

 

"No, she's asleep," Byleth said as she shook her head. "I think she likes to sleep a lot." 

 

"Heh, so her partner cannot even bother being out and about to help, hm?” Arval continued to sound very smug. “Just goes to show how much better I am as your partner, Shez." 

 

"There's another thing I wanted to mention," Byleth said, getting their attention. "During the bandit attack, the leader said something weird. About how he shouldn't have 'listened to that idiot'." 

 

"And what does that mean?" Shez asked.

 

"They might have been hired to attack the students," Byleth said before explaining her thoughts. "While it is possible that it's just a coincidence, it's odd these bandits just so happened to be there when they were training. Even more so that they attacked even with the knights there."

 

"But they're dead now, so what does it matter?" 

 

"That doesn’t get rid of whoever hired them." Jeralt said, thinking over what Byleth said. "I'm sure these brats are used to people coming after them, but someone willing to take out the three heirs of the nation and possibly anger the church in the process isn't someone we can just ignore." 

 

"So what, you gonna try and find stuff out?" Shez asked, quirking an eyebrow. 

 

"I'll try, but not sure how much we'll find out with the bandits gone." Jeralt said with a sigh. "For now, we should go and meet the Archbishop. I doubt Seteth will be happy with us if we make them wait." 

 

"Oh, right, time to officially join the classes," Shez muttered as they got up. "Heh, hope you're not going to be lonely without me Byleth." 

 

"It's only for the year," Byleth said, before smiling. "Besides, we'll still have each other's backs in case anything bad happens." 

 

"You got that right, though feel free to come crying to me for help if you can't handle your class." 

 

"Same for you." 

 

Letting out an amused huff at their back and forth, Jeralt led the two to the audience chamber where Rhea and Seteth were waiting for them, as well as the two other professors.

 

"Hello there, I hope you have been enjoying your time here," Rhea greeted them as they walked in. "I've heard you've gotten close to all three houses." 

 

"Speaking of," Seteth spoke up before anyone else could respond. "While I am personally against it, it's time for you to choose which house you'll be leading. Normally this would be discussed between the professors, but it seems your colleagues are allowing you to choose which class you want."

 

"You are new here, so Manuela and I decided allowing you to do this would help make you feel more at ease," Hanneman said. 

 

"Though we're more than happy to assist you should the need arise," Manuela added. 

 

Byleth nodded to both of them. "In that case, I would like to teach the Black Eagles." 

 

"Is that so?" Rhea asked with a smile. "Well, it seems the goddess has decided to bless the Black Eagles with two strong-" 

 

"Ah, actually," Shez spoke up, cutting Rhea off and getting Seteth to frown at her, "I was hoping to join the Blue Lions." 

 

"I would ask that you not interrupt the Archbishop again." 

 

"It's okay, Seteth," Rhea said, trying to calm him down, "May I ask why you wish to be in a different class, child?" 

 

"Eh, it just seems funner this way. Besides, I can always just transfer over if things don't go well, right?" 

 

“Hm…I suppose if that is what you wish, though I am surprised you did not choose to stay with a member of your family.”

 

“Is it that surprising? I figure it’ll be better to branch out, right?” Shez grinned. “Besides, I hear the Eagle house and the Lion house are natural rivals, so it’s perfect for me!”

 

Rhea didn’t seem to know what to make of that while Seteth sighed, looking annoyed. “None of the houses are ‘natural rivals’. They are each equal in their standing.”

 

“Yeah but one’s red and one’s blue and those are opposing colors. Isn’t that the whole reason the Kingdom chose blue to be it’s color? So they could be the opposite of the Empire?”

 

“That is a fascinating question that I am sure will be answered in your lessons, child,” Rhea said, deciding to wrap things up. “Though I will mention the color of the Black Eagles is black.”

 

“Oh yeah…wait, why’s the princess wearing red then?”

 

“It was good speaking with all of you,” Rhea continued, completely ignoring Shez, “May the Goddess's light continue to shine down on all of you forevermore.”

 

“...She didn’t answer my question,” Shez complained after Rhea left with Seteth in tow.

 

“The colors of the Empire are black and red, so, despite the name, it is traditional for the leader of the Black Eagles to wear a red cape instead of a black one,” Hanneman decided to explain, “It helps the house leader stand out properly due to the standard uniform of Garreg Mach being primarily black.”

 

“Ohhh, that makes sense. Thanks!”

 

Hanneman smiled, his mustache curling slightly with it. “You’re very welcome. It is only right for me to aid you, given you are joining the house I plan to teach now that Professor Byleth has made her selection. Ah, speaking of, given that the archbishop and her chamberlain have left earlier than I expected, I believe that leaves it up to me to mention the upcoming Mock Battle.”

 

“Mock Battle?” Byleth repeated.

 

“Indeed! It is traditional that in the first month of the Academy’s school year that the professors and students take to the field in one large battle, to test the students’ capabilities and get them used to combat.”

 

“It’s not as big of a spectacle as we’ll be seeing later in the year with the Battle of the Eagle and Lion, but it’s a good rehearsal for the new students,” Manuela added.

 

“Indeed it is, and I will note that I seem to have gained quite the advantage this year with our newest student,” Hanneman noted with amusement, “How long have you been a mercenary, Miss Shez?”

 

“Hmm…officially, I guess five or six years since dad didn’t want us fighting immediately,” she explained, considering if she should mention her previous mercenary experience and deciding not to. It’s not that she didn’t like the professors, but her dad was still wary of this place and she didn’t want to give away too much…which she probably should’ve thought of before mentioning important stuff like being adopted to the house leaders.

 

“Oh so you realized that on your own,” Arval noticed. 

 

Meanwhile, Manuela frowned at that information. “While I won’t get into what I think about your previous career, especially one you participated in at such a young age, I will point out that is a pretty big advantage you have over the other students, most of whom haven’t experienced combat at all before the mock battle.”

 

Hanneman huffed, crossing his arms over his chest. “I can see what you’re doing, Manuela. You’re just trying to take away the advantage my class has.”

 

“Wouldn’t you do the same in my situation? Still, I do think it might be better for you to sit this battle out, Shez. Like Hanneman said, we’re trying to get the students used to combat, and we can’t very well do that if you completely dominate the field.”

 

“Hmph, using my own words against me now, I see how it is…” Hanneman grumbled, before sighing, “Unfortunately, I may have to agree with Manuela here. Though I will point out that Shez is not the only one of our students to have seen combat.”

 

“Ah, so, hold on, am I not doing this mock battle thing?” Shez asked, genuinely confused.

 

“It appears that will be the case, though I do plan to further discuss this matter with my fellow professors.”

 

“Ah…hm.” Shez wasn’t completely sure how to react to being declared too strong to join in a battle with the other students. On the one hand, it was pretty disappointing. On the other, she did like having her strength acknowledged, though… “Wait, hang on, why’s Byleth joining in then? She’s also a merc.”

 

“The professors’ role in the mock battle is more to be supervisors and field commanders. While defeating a professor does remove the House they belong to from the battle, at least as far as scoring is considered, that factor is mainly there as incentive for the students to consider strategy and defensive tactics instead of simply charging one another and getting into a brawl.”

 

“...so she’s like a client they’re supposed to protect?”

 

“Precisely. She may give instructions and aid where necessary, but this battle is about the students, not the teachers.”

 

“That’s really the case for both of the school battles, but I’m sure everyone will be at a more even level for the second one,” Manuela added, “So there’s no issue with you joining in then.”

 

“Huh…okay, I guess,” Shez conceded, shrugging.

 

“Great! Now that that’s decided, would you two mind coming with me?” Manuela asked the two sisters, “I really should give you two a physical sooner rather than later.”

 

“Ah, before that, I was actually wondering if you two would consider joining me in my office instead,” Hanneman said, “I have in my possession a device for analyzing potential crests an individual may have, and I would be quite interested in seeing if the two of you possess crests yourself. Your father does have one, correct?”

 

Jeralt, who had been watching all of this without jumping in, mainly because he wasn’t a teacher and didn’t really feel like it, glanced up at being mentioned. “Ah, yeah, a crest of Seiros. I think it's a minor one, probably.”

 

“Well I would be happy to check for you, if you are interested.”

 

“Not really.”

 

“Hm. Disappointing, but not unexpected.”

 

Manuela sighed. “Fine, play around with your toy. Just have these two see me afterward.”

 

“Yes yes, of course. Now then, shall we?”

“How fascinating!” Hanneman exclaimed, staring in clear interest at the strange, not fully there symbol his thingamabob produced. 

 

Shez had no idea what any of this crest research stuff meant, so she wasn’t really sure why a weird shape was fascinating. She did know, since she went first, that she apparently didn’t have a crest. Which was…kind of weird? Because she had Arval, but they weren’t a crest thing, apparently.

 

Byleth did have one though, even if it was a weird wibbly thing that Hanneman didn’t understand, though it wasn’t long before he was muttering about a potentially undiscovered crest and getting really into the idea. 

 

“I doubt he’ll have much more to say to you at this point,” Arval pointed out, “That is the frenzy of a scholar with a new discovery. It’s not something you can break through easily.”

 

“...So, uh, professor? I think me and By should get going now, right?” Shez asked, glancing at her sister, who shrugged.

 

“Hm? Oh, yes, of course, Manuela’s request. Yes yes, go on ahead, though I do hope you wouldn’t mind coming back later, Professor Byleth. Perhaps I could get a clearer image with more readings…”

 

“Okay,” Byleth replied, not really caring either way before she turned to leave with Shez.

 

As for Shez herself, she still wasn’t completely sure how to feel here. Sure, she knew her sister was strong and great, but it was a weird feeling having it confirmed that she just had something inherent that meant she would be better than Shez. Though, Shez did still have Arval, who was completely unique, so it wasn’t like she didn’t have something special too. It was still a strange feeling though.

 

Then Byleth nudged her, taking her out of her thoughts. “Eh? Oh, what’s up?”

 

“You were thinking a lot.”

 

“...I can do that, it’s not unusual.”

 

“It is for you.” It was as faint as always, but there was enough of a hint of humor in Byleth’s voice that Shez wound up smiling. 

 

“Oh like you’re the big thinker here?”

 

“Between the two of us, yeah. You always go charging ahead.”

 

“Only because I’m good at it! I’m built tough!”

 

“You’re built fast. That’s not the same thing as tough. Remember when you tried on that heavy armor Victor found?”

 

“Hey, I was getting better with that stuff.”

 

“No, you weren’t.”

 

“I could’ve! I just need more practice with it!”

 

“You want to practice with heavy armor? I did see some knights wearing some. Maybe we could ask.”

 

“...It’s not fair when you call my bluffs.”

 

“Don’t bluff badly then.”

 

The two bantered some more, Shez’s mood improving along the way, before they reached the infirmary and it was time for their check-up.

 

“So is this one of those things where we undress or what?” Shez asked as she sat on one of the infirmary beds, idly swinging her legs while Manuela checked out Byleth. It was a reasonable question in her mind considering her sister was already down to her top and shorts.

 

“If you want, though I would prefer it if you at least kept your underwear on. We wouldn’t want there to be any scandalous rumors about teacher/student relationships, now would we~?” Manuela teased, before returning her attention to Byleth. “Now then, you two have lived in a mercenary band for most of your lives, right?”

 

“All my life,” Byleth admitted.

 

“You know, I did notice you two seem to make very singular statements about your lived experiences despite being ‘twins’.”

 

“Oh, uh, yeah, we should probably explain that,” Shez said in the middle of undoing the armored bits of her outfit. “Uh…great, it’s getting hard to keep track of what I said to who…well, anyway, the basic thing is that I’m actually adopted.”

 

“Ahh, that does explain quite a bit, like the fact that a supposed twin is clearly years younger than her sister.”

 

Shez paused. “Years younger? Wait, how many years?”

 

“Hm?” Manuela glanced over at her, before looking back at Byleth, considering the two of them. “Well…if I had to hazard a guess, I would say Byleth is in her early twenties, while you seem to be closer to the house leaders in age. So…maybe seventeen or eighteen?”

 

Manuela wasn’t expecting Shez to abruptly drop backwards onto the infirmary bed with a soft *fwump*. “...Shez? Are you alright?”

 

“So she’s at least two years younger than me?” Byleth asked, and if Shez wasn’t busy staring up at the ceiling in utter defeat, she would’ve been very surprised to see the amused grin currently on Byleth’s face.

 

Manuela didn’t know her that well yet, so the grin wasn’t shocking to her, though she was a little amused to see the elder Eisner’s stoicism break so readily. “I’m guessing you don’t know for sure how old she is?”

 

“Nope. Shez has always insisted she’s my age or older. It’s good to confirm she really is my little sister.”

 

Shez groaned. “This is the worst day of my life…”

 

“You’re ridiculous, you know that?” Arval asked, equally rhetorical and mocking.

 

"Well, as I said, it's just a guess,” Manuela said as she brought out a notepad. "But for now, let's begin the examination, shall we?" 

 

"Hmph." Shez at least sat up, even if she still kept an exaggerated pout on her face as Manuela examined her first. 

 

"Hm, well, you certainly are quite healthy," Manuela said while she seemed to be casting a spell to examine Shez. "You do seem to have a nasty scar but it doesn't seem to have left any damage on your lungs. Whoever healed you must have been quite skilled." 

 

"Oh, Gertrude is the healer of the group! Yeah, she's pretty great!" Shez said, keeping it a secret that Arval was the one who had apparently healed her after she awakened their powers. 

 

"Is that so? Well I'll have to make sure to ask her if we can swap advice when I have the chance," Manuela commented, before pulling out a stethoscope and placing it against Shez’s back. "Breathe in deeply for me." And as she did, Manuela nodded. "Good, everything seems in order, you get my seal of approval to attend the academy." 

 

"Would I have not been able to join if I didn't?" 

 

"Well, I can't really make you leave, but as a physician I definitely would prefer not to send a student with a serious health condition out into combat," Manuela explained, before muttering to herself, "Not that any noble would listen to me if I told them not to let their children join." 

 

"Is everything okay with the students?" Byleth asked. 

 

"Well, as a physician I can't divulge any personal information. What I can say is I hope you can keep your students safe," Manuela said, before moving over to Byleth. "Including any who switch to your class from the others, and I promise you I'll make sure to take care of any of yours if they want to swap over." 

 

"Of course," Byleth responded, making Manuela smile as she began to examine her. 

 

"Hm, quite healthy as well. I must say, I was quite worried when you said just how long you were in the-" Manuela suddenly came to a pause as she seemed to notice something. Pulling up the stethoscope again, she placed it against Byleth’s back. "Take a deep breath for me." 

 

Doing so, the sisters could see Manuela frown as she moved the stethoscope around. 

 

"Byleth, do you feel any discomfort in your chest?" 

 

"No?" 

 

"This is… very disconcerting," Manuela said as she pulled away. "I can't find a heartbeat." 

 

"Oh, yeah, By doesn't have one of those," Shez answered. 

 

"...excuse me?" Manuela asked.

 

“Yeah, dad says it’s a condition she’s had ever since she was a baby. Kinda freaked me out one time.”

 

“We were sharing a bed and Shez thought I died,” Byleth explained, prompting a huff from her sister.

 

“Well yeah, duh, that’s freaky! Luckily, I kept my composure–”

 

“You started crying.”

 

“I-I did not! Anyway, yeah, it’s just a thing Byleth has.”

 

“I…how is that possible?” Manuela muttered to herself, frowning while Byleth shrugged. 

 

"Not sure. It hasn't really bothered me before." 

 

"Even if you say so, that's not really something I can just ignore." 

 

"Oh, maybe it has to do with that crest thing," Shez considered, remembering what Hanneman said. "He says By has an undiscovered crest or something." 

 

"...Hm, I have heard about crests being able to physically affect someone, such as being able to heal from something without the need of spell, but I've never heard of someone not having a heartbeat…I'll need to ask Hanneman about what he discovers." She considered Byleth again, before raising a hand and murmuring under her breath as a white glow settled over her palm. “...Hm…well that’s interesting. It’s almost as though there’s something in the way…You do seem healthy otherwise, and…”

 

She suddenly pressed her fingers to Byleth’s neck, earning a confused glance from the mercenary. “Hm…There is a pulse here. At least, something of one…you haven’t had any medical issues before now, have you? No shortness of breath or dizziness?”

 

“No. I haven’t had any issues.”

 

“So it’s not a symptom of a lowered heart rate…I guess I really do have to chalk this one up to weird crest magic. That being said, I will ask that you come by immediately if you begin experiencing any discomfort or the like," Manuela requested, before letting out a sigh. "For now, it's almost time for class, which we really should be getting to. Oh, but don't worry Byleth, you'll have until after the mock battle to prepare your lesson plan. Until then, you can have your students self-study, or do some physical training." 

 

"Thanks for letting me know," Byleth said as she got dressed. 

 

"Well, hopefully classes aren't boring," Shez commented.

Classes were indeed very boring. Nothing against Hanneman, but Shez wasn't really interested in learning about crests for a starting lesson, especially since she herself didn't have one. Though she had to admit, he was passionate if nothing else. 

 

Even so, by the time classes ended for the day, Shez ended up going on a jog, deciding to use up her restless energy she had built up during the class. Thankfully, with how big the monastery was, she had plenty of space to move around in. 

 

"See you tomorrow~" came a rather cheerful voice, making Shez look over as she saw a familiar student waving off a knight. 

 

"Oh, you’re Dorothea!" Shez said, bringing a hand up in greeting. 

 

"Hm? Oh, you must be Professor Byleth’s sister. I hope your first day of class went well." 

 

"Eh, bored but otherwise okay. Mind if I ask how By's class was?" 

 

"Well, she did her best, though everyone was pretty rowdy," Dorothea said as she let out a small laugh. 

 

"Heh. Ah well, hopefully she gets better at it once she gets used to it. Hope you don't mind helping her out." 

 

"Well I imagine Edie will be doing most of the helping, but how can I say no to helping out a fan? Speaking of, I hope you enjoyed the play you went to all those years ago." 

 

"Ah, well, if I'm being honest, I didn't really get it, but you were a very nice singer!" Shez admitted, "By really did like the show though! Heck, it's the only time I ever heard her call someone pretty." 

 

"Oh? Is that so?" 

 

"Yeah, it, uh…" Scratching her head for a moment, Shez thought of what to say. "By has trouble expressing herself sometimes, so it was a surprise to hear her say that." 

 

"Well, nothing wrong with the strong silent type." 

 

"Right, and I'm not saying there's anything wrong with her. Just, you know, I wanna make sure that she's happy. Now, I'm not saying you should take her on a date or something, but I'm sure she'd be happy to be your friend." 

 

Staying silent for a moment, a smile spread across Dorothea's face. "Heh, I have to say, the Professor is quite lucky to have such a nice little sister." 

 

"Ah, well, thanks." Shez said, feeling a bit bashful at her words. "Just making sure to look out for her, she'd be lost without me." 

 

"Is that so?" 

 

"Yeah, I mean, who knows what she’d do without my help?" Almost as if on cue, a purple-haired girl came running past them.

 

"STOP CHASING MEEEEEE!" She screamed out as moments later Byleth came running behind her without a word. 

 

"...See what I mean?" 

Chapter End Notes

Indi: For people who know about a certain Three Hopes paralogue, the mock battle is gonna be very fun

Red: That it will be! Though things won't go exactly the same, as I'm sure you can all imagine. Aside from that though, Byleth and Shez sure don't keep a lot of secrets.

Indi: Granted in the game Byleth also let things slip, like casually telling Dorothea that one time that her heart doesn't beat.

Red: Oh sure, it's honestly funny. I feel like she would have told anyone interested that Sothis was in her head if she was actually asked.

Indi: Just casually tell people about the ghost living in her head and the time powers she gave her.

Red: I mean hey, why not? Anyways, thanks for reading everybody!

The Day of the Mock Battle

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

“Hm…is the professor going to be late?” Ferdinand wondered, glancing around the field where most of their class had gathered. “She really should be on time for this sort of event. It would reflect badly on all of us if she–”

 

“She’s getting Bernadetta,” Edelgard answered, trying not to let too much annoyance show. Though, with Ferdinand, that was always a difficult prospect. “You do remember that she was the one who told us to gather here, correct?” 

 

“Which is why it’s bad that she isn’t here now!” he insisted, “I realize Bernadetta can be…difficult to find at times, but should the professor really ignore the entire class just for her sake?”

 

“Professor Byleth did tell us to get ready, Ferdie,” Dorothea reminded, “You know, get our equipment, do some stretches, limber up, that sort of thing. Unless your nobility means your muscles don’t get stiff.”

 

"Of course they do not! I always ensure that I do my proper stretching and warm ups when I wake up!" Ferdinand said, sounding quite proud of himself. 

 

"In that case, just make sure your gear is ready," Edelgard commanded with a sigh, really wishing her professor hadn't chosen Ferdinand to be part of the team. Add in the fact that she had apparently also chosen Bernadetta because she was 'surprisingly fast' meant they had an uphill battle. 

 

"Sorry I'm late." Speaking of, it seemed the professor had arrived, walking up with an unconscious Bernadetta under her arm. 

 

"...Professor, what happened?"
