"She keeps running away from me for some reason,” Byleth explained with a small frown on her face. "She ended up exhausting herself when I tried to bring her here, so I don't think she'll be able to be in the mock battle." 

 

"...I see. Well, have you given any thoughts for who will be replacing her? I can offer some recommendations should you wish.” Though, aside from Lindhart, any of them would be a good choice to take up the empty space. 

 

“Yeah, Emily Korsch.”

 

Edelgard blinked. “Excuse me?”

 

“Huh?” came the surprised voice of a rather plain looking, brown-haired student, standing off to the side, away from the main group, like an extra in a play.

 

“...May I ask your reasoning, professor?” 

 

“She holds herself well. Even if she hasn’t been joining in during combat practice, she’s always light on her feet and can move quickly.” 

 

“O-Oh, no, I'm not that great,” Emily said, very clearly lying. It was almost sad how plainly a flash of irritation crossed her face at being singled out before she managed to affect a nervous expression.

 

“I think you could help.” The professor didn’t seem to notice though. Or perhaps she did and simply didn’t care. “It’s a good opportunity, right?”

 

“I-I really shouldn’t. I-I mean, I’m not worthy to stand with such prestigious people!” She looked like she was holding back genuine disgust at her own simpering. 

 

Edelgard was almost tempted to let her join simply for the amusement factor she would bring to the field. However, she did have her responsibilities as a house leader. “Professor, I along with Dorothea, Hubert, and…Ferdinand would suffice as a full team, would we not? I realize it’s not what you planned for, but I’m sure we would suffice.”

 

“Hmm…I guess. I thought it might be a good opportunity for her though,” Byleth relented, “Are you okay with joining, Dorothea?” 

 

“Of course, Professor! I’ll show the other classes not to underestimate us!” Nodding at her enthusiasm, Byleth walked over to Caspar and extended Bernadetta to him. 

 

“Can you keep an eye on her?” 

 

“Oh, sure professor!” he said with a grin as he took the unconscious girl. “Hey, Lin, you know any spells that could help with exhaustion?”

 

“Not unless someone cast a sleep spell on her,” the tired sounding student said, sitting on the grassy field since he wouldn’t be involved in the battle. In fact, he seemed quite relaxed as he seemed to be reading a tome about crests. 

 

“Is that why you are always falling over?” Petra asked, “Such a spell is sounding devious.” 

 

“Nah, that’s just how Lin is.” 

 

“Do make sure to take care.” Byleth said, before regarding the students she’d take into combat. “Now then, I'll have to rethink my plan…” 

 

“Was your idea not to split into teams of two?” Ferdinand asked. “Clearly the idea can still work: Dorothea and Hubert in one, with Edelgard and I in the other.” 

 

“No, it’ll be one mage and one melee combatant in each group,” Byleth said, shutting that down. “It’s a simple tactic, but an effective one.” 

 

“In that case, Lady Edelgard and I will be on one team,” Hubert suggested. 

 

“No,” Byleth said, shooting another idea down. “In terms of magic capabilities you are stronger then Dorothea, so having you and Edelgard on one team would make it unbalanced. Not to mention you won’t always be working with someone you’re used to. This isn’t just a battle, it’s also to test how capable you all are.”

 

“...Hmph. Very well, I shall follow your command for now, but if we were to lose this battle, well, we shall only have you to blame.” 

 

“I am the field commander, so it’s only fair.” 

 

“Speaking of, how shall we be moving, Profesor?” Edelgard asked as they began to walk towards their starting position. “We have been given a rather disadvantageous starting point compared to the Lions and Deer, and I fear if we attempt to attack one, we may end up getting surrounded by the other.” 

 

“If we focus on the Lions first, but not if we attack the Deer first,” Byleth said as they started getting ready, “The Blue Lions are too focused on honor, so they won’t attack someone from behind.” She stopped to think for a moment. “Well, since Shez isn't going to be allowed to fight, they won’t.” 

 

“The Lions are a rather straightforward lot aren’t they?” Hubert mockingly noted. 

 

“That’s if they are as noble as they claim to be,” Ferdinand replied. 

 

“Aside from Felix, I doubt any of them would rush in to attack us,” Dorothea pointed out, “Sylvain might, but he would be easy to handle.” 

 

“Hence why Ferdinand and Hubert will lead the way to the Golden Deer while you and Edelgard will follow behind and keep an eye out in case any Blue Lions attack us.”

 

“A sound strategy, professor.” And with good timing, Byleth heard her dad speak, his voice being amplified to carry across the field. 

 

“I’m sure you all understand already, but the house that defeats the other two houses wins this battle. Defeat is decided when a house loses all its members, or if their ‘commander’ is taken out. Fighting is to go on until either blood is drawn, or someone yields, in which case they are to leave the battlefield.” Sounds simple enough. 

 

“Are you ready, professor?” Edelgard asked, as Byleth noted she was affixing a shield onto her off hand.

 

“I’ll make sure we bring home the victory.” 

 

“So confident. This will be interesting,” Edelgard said with a smile. 

 

“Let the mock battle commence!”

“Well well! It seems fate favors me today! To think I, Ferdinand von Aegir, would be fortunate enough to face off against my rival in nobility on this day!”

 

“Ahahaha! You think of yourself as my rival? Oh no, you are quite mistaken my foolish friend, for I, Lorenz Hellman Gloucester, stand above all other nobles in my most esteemed bearing!”

 

“Ha! And here I thought you were a gentleman! But now I clearly see just how inflated your arrogance is! Not to worry though, I, Ferdinand von Aegir, shall gladly puncture that ego of yours!”

 

“As though you could! For I, Lorenz Hellman Gloucester–”

 

“...” Hubert watched the…whatever this was in front of him continue on, and briefly considered just blasting Lorenz in the chest. And maybe Ferdinand too for good measure…Really, as he considered it, and as the two nobles continued their pontificating, the ideal gradually grew further in appeal to the point that he was actively wondering why he wasn’t.

 

“Very well! Hubert, stay back! I shall handle this matter on my own!” Hubert started slightly at being addressed by Ferdinand, before just raising an eyebrow at his “partner” for the excursion. He couldn’t help but wonder if the professor had done this deliberately to get Ferdinand out of the way. If so, he would commend her for the decision, if not for the fact that he had to deal with the idiot in the meantime.

 

“Stand aside, Ignatz! This is a matter of noble honor, and I shall handle it on my own!” They even sounded the same…Though there were slight differences to their arrogance, almost akin to subtle flavorings. Ferdinand was a richer hubris born of well-meaning stupidity and ideals he would never live up to while Lorenz was, perhaps, more of a bitter vanity, underscored by inane standards he could never truly meet because of his own natural inadequacies. Not that the fool would ever acknowledge any of them.

 

“...So, um…should we be fighting?” And then there was Ignatz.

 

“Do you want to fight me?” Hubert asked, turning up the natural menace his voice carried as he glanced down at the shorter boy as though he were a bug barely worth considering crushing.

 

“...a-a-ah, w-well…w-we are still in the middle of a battle–”

 

There really was no response to that aside from blasting the younger man in the chest with a weak ball of magic. Nothing anywhere near dangerous, but enough to knock him solidly off his feet and, therefore, out of the battle.

 

“...ow…” Ignatz groaned from the ground while Hubert turned his attention back towards the noble idiots circling each other like a pair of dogs trying to assert dominance. It was ridiculous in all respects and he was fairly certain his time would be better spent anywhere else…up until he noticed a new face stumbling out of the trees nearby.

 

“–swear, the monastery has gotta be in this direction–Eh?” Shez Eisner, younger sister to their newest professor and member of the Blue Lions house, blinked in obvious confusion at the scene she just wandered into. “Uh…”

 

“Hm? Wait, aren’t you–”

 

“Shez? What are you doing here?” Ferdinand asked a moment after Lorenz noticed her presence. “Did the Academy allow you to join the mock battle after all?”

 

“Huh? Oh, uh, no, wait–”

 

Hubert just had an idea.

 

“Well well well,” he intoned, affecting curiosity as he gazed at the mercenary-turned-student, “It seems the Blue Lions aren’t as honorable as they pretend. To think, they would have their classmate secretly join the mock battle so they would gain an advantage!”

 

Hubert didn’t often raise his voice, but this time he wanted his accusation to carry. He really had to work to keep the grin from his face as Ferdinand and Lorenz turned towards the confused mercenary in abject shock.

 

“What?! How dare they!”

 

“Shez! I expected better of the professor’s sister!”

 

“Wha–Woah woah, hold on, that’s not–”

 

“Lorenz! Shall we put aside our differences at this moment?” Ferdinand requested, leveling his spear towards Shez, “It is clear the Lions have deceived us all!”

 

“It most certainly is, and they shall pay for this dishonorable act!”

 

“H-Hold on, I seriously have no idea what you’re talking ab–” But neither idiot listened, instead charging her with their spears raised and ready. 

 

And a moment later, Hubert stepped to the side so Ferdinand wouldn’t hit him as he sailed past, launched by a very frazzled mercenary. Ignatz, in his prone position, was less than lucky given Lorenz landed straight on top of him.

 

“Okay, just–Could someone explain what just–”

 

“HEY!” That was Caspar’s voice.

 

Hubert glanced over at the trees where the son of Bergliez was positioned, a look of genuine offense and outrage on his face. “So the Lions are cheating!”

 

“Wha–Oh, no, no, I didn’t–”

 

“It’s too late for excuses! Petra, come on, let’s take down these cheats!”

 

“Yes! We will be having the vengeance for our comrade who is beaten!”

 

Hm. That wasn’t quite what Hubert intended to happen, though–

 

“Hey, the Lions and Eagles are sending out more people!” That was…Leonie’s voice, wasn’t it? “Raphael, Lysithea, come on! Let’s go back up Claude!”

 

“You got it!”

 

“Of course! We won’t let them get away with this!”

 

Hubert watched, somewhat nonplussed, as the remaining members of the Deer, sans Marianne, quickly rushed to back up their leader, which, in turn–

 

“I knew it. Looks like the Deer couldn’t be trusted to keep to the rules after all,” Felix grumbled as he drew his sword and rushed into the fray.

 

“Ah–Hey, Felix!” And was quickly followed by Ingrid.

 

“Oh, this might be trouble…hey, wait up!” And then Sylvain–

 

“Hey, I’m coming too!” Oh, even Annette. Well, that was the entire Blue Lions house on the field then. That would probably disrupt Dimitri’s defensive intentions, given how he had deliberately chosen and positioned his team, which might be good for Lady Edelgard…though it also meant his lady was severely outnumbered now. And he doubted Bernadetta and Linhardt would be of much aid…

 

He glanced towards the treeline and felt a smirk come to his face when he noticed a person of interest staring in visible confusion at the growing melee. “Lady Korsch, it seems the entire house is joining the battle.”

 

“Emily” looked at him for a moment, a flicker of contempt showing in her eyes that warred with the genuine bewilderment there. “What are you–”

 

“Go help out.”

 

She bristled. “You don’t give–”

 

“You’re a lesser noble seeking favor from the future emperor. It is only reasonable for you to take a chance to raise your prestige. So go help. Now, if you kindly would.”

 

She shot him a delightfully venomous glare, before charging into the fray as the mock battle spilled into a genuinely chaotic melee. If it weren’t for Lady Edelgard’s presence on the field, Hubert might have simply sat back and watched. Perhaps had a picnic, had he thought to bring the proper supplies.

 

Alas, a retainer’s work was never done.

Byleth was probably the most confused she’d ever felt. And given how Shez tended to be, that was actually saying something for her. 

 

Things seemed to have been progressing smoothly: Hubert and Ferdinand had moved on ahead to scout out the Golden Deer while Dorothea and Edelgard kept an eye out for the Blue Lions. With how the Lions seemed to be focusing on defense, they decided it would be safe to join up with the others, only to be caught by surprise as they saw several students yelling and charging the field. 

 

“Gotta say, I always knew the captain was one for underhanded tactics, but I didn’t think I’d see you use them right away!” Leonie shouted as she stabbed her spear at Byleth, the young teacher dodging the attack while she blocked a sword strike from Felix. 

 

“This is as good a chance as any to test myself against you!” Felix declared, before having to jump backward to dodge a thunder attack from Dorothea. 

 

“Who are you guys calling underhanded!? You're the ones who decided to rush us without warning!” 

 

“Heh, sorry about this Dorothea, but if it makes up for it, I promise I’ll take you out on a date after this~'' Sylvain flirted, before ducking as Lysithea tried to blindside him by sending a ball of miasma his way.

 

“I must admit, I always wanted to cross blades with you, but I never thought it’d be like this,” Ingrid said, leveling her spear at Edelgard with a noticeable edge to her voice.

 

“If it’s a match you want, then very well, I won't back down.”

 

…Yeah, Byleth didn’t know what to make of this. But Felix was charging at her again so she did what came naturally and deflected his swing before punching him in the face. 

 

Maybe a little harder than intended, but if it kept him out of the fight, then she could always fix up the damage later. Leonie would be trickier to take care of with her longer reach, but it looked like she was joining Lysithea in trying to take down Sylvain, so–

 

Then there was a familiar flash of light in the distance and Byleth felt a frown come to her face. “Hm.”

 

She snapped her fingers and all the students present couldn’t help but look her way at the loud boom of thunder that echoed out. A few flinched, but more didn’t, which was mildly interesting, but not something she was going to focus on. “Things have gotten out of hand. I’ll be right back. Anybody who wasn’t assigned to their teams before the battle started should leave the field now or I will–” What was a good punishment as a teacher? “–give them detention. Or something.”

 

She glanced at Felix. “...I might just punch you in the face. It’s up to you which you would prefer.”

 

Her piece said, she moved towards where her sister had unleashed her “awakened form”, as Shez decided to call it after several hours of arguing with herself, or more specifically Arval, about what its name should be.

 

“Hm. Well that is a curious power,” Sothis noted in Byleth’s head, “Or…no, I would not call it vile, but it is grotesque, wouldn’t you agree?”

 

“...Hm.” That was a troubling word to refer to Shez’s power with. But she could ask Sothis about it later. For now, she needed to see what pushed Shez to use it to begin with.

 

From the looks of it, it was being attacked by a large portion of the Golden Deer and Black Eagles forces at once. Including a number of reserve students who shouldn’t have been on the field to begin with.

 

“Oh, hey professor,” greeted Claude from above her.

 

“Hi Claude. Why are you in a tree?”

 

“Well I’d like to say it’s for a vantage point, but Shez kind of tossed me up here,” he explained, which did explain why he was hanging from a tree branch by his ankle. “I think she got upset after I decided to have everyone on my team attack her at once.”

 

“Ah. Why?”

 

He shrugged. “She’s pretty obviously the strongest person on this side of the field and I wanted to win.”

 

“You can’t get girls to like you by beating them up.”

 

“Oh, now you tell me–Wait, was that a joke?”

 

Byleth ignored him, instead walking through the tree lines and gingerly stepping around fallen students, before she noticed Hubert, who looked a little exasperated. Probably because Bernadetta was clinging to him.

 

“...”

 

“...”

 

“...Should I ask?” 

 

Bernadetta squeaked, ducking her head behind Hubert at the sound of Byleth’s voice, which brought a frown to the professor’s face while Hubert sighed. “Apparently I’m not as terrifying as Shez.”

 

“...You sound disappointed.”

 

“Wouldn’t you be? I actively cultivate this image and yet there she is, traumatizing an entire school year through pure violence.” He sighed, shaking his head. “The world truly is unfair.”

 

“Hm. How much did you have to do with this?”

 

“You’re suspicious of me? What could I have possibly done?”

 

“You’re smirking.”

 

“That’s just what my face looks like.”

 

“...Ingrid wants to duel Edelgard.” She paused. “Don’t kill her.”

 

“You know you could be more subtle in your attempts to be rid of me, but fair enough. Come along, Bernadetta. We can find you a better hiding place than my back.”

 

With that handled, Byleth turned her attention to Shez, who was in the middle of proving her theory that Emily Korsch was actually pretty capable right by going after the Eagle student, who was managing to hold her own, if with increasing frustration as she was forced back by the whirlwind of violence that was Shez when she got going.

 

So Byleth rolled up her sleeves, metaphorically since she was wearing her coat on her shoulders at the moment, adjusted her arm guards, and strode onto the field before catching her sister’s wrist on a backswing, grabbing the back of her head, and fully slamming Shez’s face into the grass before she could react. Gently, of course. She didn’t want to break her nose again.

 

“...mfh…”

 

“Hello Shez. Is there a reason you knocked out two classes worth of students?”

 

“Mrhghhl mrrrfh.”

 

“They attacked you first?” She raised an eyebrow before raising her sister’s head.

 

“Bwah–Ugh, did you have to shove me into the grass? I got some in my mouth.”

 

“You were ‘awakened’. I know how you get when you’re like that.”

 

“Okay, that’s fair, but now I have grass stains on my face.”

 

“Why are you on the mock battlefield anyway?” Her eyes narrowed. “Did you get lost again?”

 

“...”

 

“...” She sighed. “Shez–”

 

“I-I was heading back to the monastery! I think…i-it shouldn’t be that hard to find, it’s really huge!”

 

“But you’re over here. Not over there. Why were you out of the monastery to begin with?”

 

“Okay that’s…kind of a long story, mostly starting with me trying to find this place at the market that Ashe mentioned–”

 

“Ah, one second.” Byleth released her sister’s head and stood up, glancing at Emily, who looked completely bewildered at what she was seeing. “Good work. Please leave the field though, you’re not supposed to be in this exercise.”

 

“...Y-Yeah, whatever you say, teach,” she muttered, glaring at Byleth for a second before continuing to look confused by Shez as she walked off. 

 

“Hm. Thought so,” Byleth muttered to herself as she confirmed Emily really was more aggressive than she let on. The girl seemed really resentful, which…well, based on her family name, Byleth had a feeling why that might be. But that was something she could handle later.

 

For now, she helped Shez up to her feet. “You and I are talking to Hanneman after this.”

 

“Aw, what? Why?”

 

“Because you should know how to disengage instead of escalate. That, and you knocked out most of the student body.”

 

“...I mean…that’s…probably exaggerating?”

 

“At least a few of those students are Blue Lions.”

 

“...Oh. Whoops…To be fair, I don’t know everyone yet.”

 

“Come on. I’m going to get Manuela and we can start healing the students that need it. Also, you’re telling dad.”

 

“Awwwww…fiiiiine…” Shez whined, pouting heavily as her sister led her off the field.

 

So ended the first mock battle of the school year. Unsurprisingly, all three classes were disqualified. 

Chapter End Notes

Indi: It's very funny to know that in Three Hopes canon Shez beat up all the houses during the mock battle. And well, we decided to have a bit of fun with that idea.

Red: Speaking of, does anyone else find it weird that Monica is in that mission? Like the Mock Battle is supposed to happen before the class's first real mission as practice, so, like...did they hold it after she was rescued instead? How many months did Shez even spend at Garreg Mach in Hopes? It had to be at least 2 if she had a mission but then why is Monica there...

Indi: Clearly she asked Kronya for permission to join the Mock Battle before going back to the dungeon.

Red: Perhaps? Oh and everybody, say hi to Emily, who most definitely is just an OC like the mercs and not someone who matters.

Indi: Yup yup, just there to fill space really.

Red: Yup, no significance or importance whatsoever, much like every other extra in the 3Hs. Aside from the ones that become weirdly plot relevant. Like Myson. What in the world is up with Myson...

Indi: I suppose we'll never find out. Anyways, hope y'all enjoyed!

Interlude - The Three Sages

Chapter by RK3996

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

The library of Garreg Mach Monastery was a peaceful, quiet place most days. The students knew to keep quiet amidst its hallowed shelves and it was rare for there to be much noise beyond the scritching of quills on paper and the quiet chatter of scholarly monks deep in research.

 

So the sound of heavy footfalls and aggrieved muttering stood out far more than it normally would, especially when the aggravated young woman who was stomping so aggressively slammed her hands on the front desk and glared directly at the head librarian.

 

“Tomas. Could we please…talk? I need your help with something,” the student known to most as Emily Korsch growled out, glaring directly at the kindly old man, who regarded her with nothing more than slight bemusement at her appearance.

 

“Oh? Well, of course I would gladly help any young student who needs my aid. Please, tell me what is troubling you.”

 

“...I don’t mean right here ,” she hissed, “It’s something…private.”

 

“Ah, well I’m sorry to say I don’t think I could be of much help in private matters…ah, perhaps Selene could help you? Selene, if you wouldn’t mind, could you come over here please?”

 

Emily’s eyes narrowed, before she glanced at a woman in the white robes of a priestess, who smiled at the head librarian. “Yes Tomas? Oh, hello young lady. Is there something you need?”

 

“...Yes, there is. But I was hoping to talk to Tomas about it.”

 

“Oh, you don’t need to worry about troubling me with it! I’ve been happy to help around here ever since Tomas let me.” The woman smiled sweetly, earning a faint, enamored sigh from one of the nearby and more easily distracted monks. 

 

“And you’ve been a wonderful help ever since, Selene,” Tomas praised, “Why, I’m sure one day you could easily replace me here.”

 

“Oh, that’s very sweet of you to say! But I’m sure you still have plenty of years here left in you! So don’t try to foist it off on me too quickly, okay?”

 

Tomas chuckled. “No need to worry about that. Now then, I really should get back to my duties. Thank you again for thinking of me, young lady.”

 

“...Sure,” Emily muttered, glancing at Selene again before the priestess led her towards a more private room so the two could chat about her problem.

 

And once the door was closed and locked, Selene’s hand was around Emily’s throat as she shoved her against the wall.

 

“You stupid little shit, what do you think you’re doing?” the now scowling “priestess” growled in the younger woman’s face, “In what world do you think one of these damned whelps would come crawling to a librarian of all people for solutions to their problems!?”

 

“G-Ghhhlk, l-l-let g-g-go-” She did, and Emily collapsed to the floor, coughing as she tried to get air back into her respiratory system.

 

Selene regarded her with a cold gaze, all anger vanishing as though it had never been, before she unlocked the door and opened it, allowing Tomas to enter. The elderly librarian straightened from his perpetual stoop as he gazed down at his subordinate, a single raised eyebrow showing a reaction beyond the benign placidity still worn on his face. “Well?”

 

“H-Hhh…d-damn bitch–”

 

“Shut it, brat,” Selene said, locking the door again, “You’re the idiot who decided she couldn’t be bothered to go through the proper channels. You wanted a meeting, you’ve got it, now share what information you have already.”

 

Emily rubbed her throat, before shaking off the remaining pain. “Why the hell is there another one of us here?!”

 

Selene blinked. “What?”

 

“You heard me! That purple-haired bitch, the one pretending to be the new professor’s ‘sister’! Who the hell is she and why is she here!?”

 

“Hold on, that–There shouldn’t be another agent here, that doesn’t make sense.”

 

“It doesn’t, no,” Tomas noted, some curiosity entering his tone, “By ‘purple-haired bitch’, you refer to the one called Shez Eisner, correct?”

 

Selene glanced at him. “‘The one’? Not ‘the beast’?”

 

“Perhaps. It depends on what our young friend has to tell us.”

 

Emily swallowed, before pushing herself to her feet. “...She started glowing during that stupid mock battle. She had…I don’t know, some kind of halo? And markings down her face. White ones.”

 

“Shez…” Selene muttered, as though testing the name on her tongue.

 

“Is there something you recall?” Tomas inquired.

 

“No, that’s the problem. I should know if that was a project name.”

 

“You inherited Pitt’s files, correct?”

 

Selene wasn’t the type to wince, but she did frown slightly more than she was already. “...We’re using that name then. Hm. I did, and she didn’t have anything on the subject of a ‘Shez’. Are you familiar?”

 

“No. That is interesting…A ‘halo’, you said? Or was it more of a crown?”

 

Emily blinked. “Uh…no, it was behind her head.”

 

“How interesting…How could a mere beast have…no, we don’t have enough information to decide anything.”

 

“She’s an individual of interest then?” Selene asked.

 

“She might be. She caught my attention already, though it was brief. She seemed put off by my appearance.”

 

“As though she recognized you?”

 

“Not quite. It would be very interesting though…Regardless, we will observe this beast called Shez. If she possesses something of interest, we will discover it soon enough.”

 

“What? That’s all we’re doing?!” Emily wasn’t happy with that. “She’s a threat, we should–”

 

“You won’t be doing anything, Kronya,” Tomas reminded, “Not until you position yourself properly at the Hegemon’s side.”

 

“How can I do that!? I just look like some random vermin! You were supposed to get me that red-haired beast, the one that was already close to her! How am I supposed to fulfill any of my objectives when I’m stuck at the bottom rung!?”

 

“By being clever for once in your life. You want to be something more than Thales’s mad dog, don’t you? So work for it.”

 

“But Solon–!”

 

“No names,” Selene chided, prompting Kronya to glare at the older woman.

 

“Or else what, Bias? ”

 

“Well if you want to insist on risking discovery, I won’t stop you,” Bias said, regarding her junior with a cold gaze. “And neither will I save you when the abominations come to eat you alive.”

 

“If that is all then.” Tomas adjusted his posture again, settling into his “normal” stoop. “Do not attempt to contact me in this way again, Kronya. I won’t have you jeopardizing everything we are working towards because of some foolish impatience. Am I understood?”

 

“...Understood, sir.”

 

"Good. Now go, the last thing we need is anyone getting suspicious because you had us meet up like this," Bias said, before unlocking the door, getting Kronya to glare at her before she left. "...still, we should figure out if Myson or Cleobulus might have sent someone else. Those two have gotten far too arrogant." 

 

"Only once we confirm whether or not Shez is one of us," Tomas said as he began to head out. Though, knowing those two, it was far too likely they wanted to one up the other. Those two were far too idiotic, particularly without Thales to reign them in. If they weren't careful, they would all end up destroying one another as though they were mere beasts. 

"There you are, my king."

 

“Ah, Cornelia!” greeted the king on his throne, a goblet in one hand while the other rested on the lower back of the woman in his lap. Or, to be more specific, the wretched drunk known as Rufus Thierry Blaiddyd slurred a reply from his position on a leather chair in his lounge, his wine-stained shirt open to bare most of his chest while his free hand lazily groped the rear of the scantily clad courtesan cuddling up to him while he was being entertained by another barely dressed dancer. “To what do I owe the pleasure, milady Arnim? Have you a care to join my revelries?”

 

Cleobulus of Agarthan smiled through the stolen lips of Cornelia Arnim, regarding the useful wretch in front of her with a pleasantry far too thick to allow even a hint of the seething contempt beneath it show. It almost became difficult with how clearly the king-regent was leering at her breasts, but she was quite practiced at her role. “Unfortunately not, my king. I merely wished to speak with you regarding some matters we previously discussed.”

 

“Oh, that. Alright, off,” he commanded, pushing the woman in his lap up, prompting a surprised noise from her.

 

“Ah, do you wish us to leave, your grace?”

 

And Rufus’s smile immediately dropped. “It’s your majesty! I am the king, understood? Now get out before I have you beaten for insulting royalty!”

 

The woman stiffened, but nodded hurriedly and left along with her cohort. 

 

Rufus watched them leave, then sank back, pressing his hands to his face. “Goddess, what is wrong with me? I shouldn’t have…I should apologize–”

 

“No, you shouldn’t, my king. It is as you say, you are the king. You can’t let your lessers disrespect you,” Cornelia said as she approached him, putting a hand on his shoulder in a gesture he would probably take as comforting. She mainly used it as a way to steady herself as she leaned down towards him though. “A king must be strong and proud, and we both know how strong and proud you are.”

 

“...yes. Yes, of course.” Rufus breathed slowly, dragging his hands down his face before he looked up at his only real confidant. “What did you want to discuss? Is this about that order you used to belong to?”

 

“Not quite, though it is related.”

 

“Mnnh….look, if your mages need more funding, they can have it. Or is this about the crest stones again?”

 

Cornelia chuckled. “Ah, you’re getting colder, my king.”

 

“I am, hm?” A slight smile crossed his face, the tension starting to bleed from his body as he looked up at his advisor. “Well, what then?”

 

“Before that, it might interest you to know that some bandits attacked your nephew during a training exercise out in Barnabas territory.”

 

He blinked, before a complicated look crossed his face. “...And…is he dead?”

 

She smirked. “Tragically, he still lives, my king.”

 

“...Hmph. Having fun, are we?”

 

“My apologies, you just looked so adorably hopeful,” she teased, pretending it was affection rather than malice that prompted her to dangle his guilt-ridden hopes in front of him. “It does leave open an opportunity though. The monastery failing to care for its students is something we could press.”

 

“...Should we? Faerghus exists because the Church gives it legitimacy. Pressing them might be more detrimental than beneficial.”

 

Cornelia smirked again. Every so often, her favorite mongrel did show a glimmer of intellect in that drink-addled head of his. “True, true. It’s just something we should keep in mind, should we ever need justification to, say, declare the Academy cannot be trusted to care for its students.”

 

“...Hm. It would be difficult. The Officer’s Academy is a popular institution, many nobles have fond memories of the place, and if there were no fatalities…No one important died, right?”

 

“No, just the bandits.”

 

“Pity,” the regent muttered, before a flash of guilt crossed his face that brought a bigger smile to his advisor’s face.

 

“That aside, we really should get to the meat of the matter.”

 

The way his eyes flicked towards her body just made her smirk all the more. “...and that would be?”

 

“It’s not a matter we need to address immediately…in fact, it might be good to give ourselves a few months to prepare, but…” She grinned. “I think we really should look into the Empire’s part in the Tragedy of Duscur.”

"Myson, we have a report from Solon!" announced an Agarthan dark mage as he hurried to his superior, drawing some attention from the other bird-masked mages within the laboratory.

 

“...” The warlock whose attention he sought didn’t reply though, instead keeping his shadowed eyes on the “caskets” lined up along the walls. In particular, he kept his eyes on the metallic box marked with the Fell Star’s symbol, the “Crest of Flames”.

 

“...Er, Myson? Sir?”

 

“Is it important?”

 

The mage jolted, then nodded. “Er, yes, I believe it is, sir. He reported that there is another Agarthan at the abomination’s monastery. One he was not informed of.”

 

The warlock glanced at him, then held out his hand for the slate containing the message. Once the mage handed it over, he perused it without a response, studying the contents…and then gripping it tightly enough to crack straight through the material. “...Hm. I see. Odesse.”

 

The project leader, marked by the clothes of a dark bishop, looked up at being addressed. “Yes sir?”

 

“Keep an eye on the revival project. I have matters requiring my attention.”

 

“Understood, sir.”

 

The halls of Shambhala shone with artificial light. Nothing close to the daylight that was just out of reach, but bright enough to keep the Agarthan people from fully descending into madness in the depths of their great city. A city that buzzed with a hurried energy under its new leadership.

 

Myson knew the value Thales had. It was impossible to deny that their great leader had carried Agartha through its darkest days since the Fell Star and its abominations turned their baleful gaze upon the only true humans upon this accursed world, but neither could he deny that the old man had been a weight upon their backs. 

 

His leadership had carried them, certainly, but it clung to them too, dragging them down even as he claimed he would raise them up. What else could explain how it took over a thousand years to even get as close as they were now to liberation? Thales had his place, but now that he was dead, it was time for change.

 

As he arrived at his former leader’s room, Myson glared up at the inert apparatuses he could not access. If the blind old fool had to die, he could have at least provided entry to his systems. Losing the Javelins put them at a distinct disadvantage they wouldn’t have to deal with if the dastard had truly trusted anyone.

 

It only goes to show that Thales truly was unworthy of the leadership he held. Not like Myson, who had a hundred projects running and a thousand more churning in his head. If the Javelins were inaccessible, then he would merely create better weapons. If the Flame Emperor could not be brought to heel, then he would make his own King of Liberation. And if he truly must face the so-called “Children of the Goddess” directly…then he would simply make gods of his own.

 

A smile came to his face at that thought. To build a god…Only one Agarthan had tried to do similar in their history. And wasn’t it quite the sign that a girl with his power would appear at this time?

 

A girl with the power of Epimenides…It truly was a new dawn for the people of Agartha.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: So for those curious, after the events of the Brigid and Dagda war, the Korsch family saw a small rise in fame thanks to one of theirs dying at the supposed hands of a Brigidian. So of course they would send the daughter of the head of the family to the Officer's Academy.

Red: And, well, since things were tripped up a bit for the Agarthans, they adjusted their plans. Lots of adjustments in plans are going on for all of them.

Indi: Yup yup, and since the Korsch's were still minor nobles, it would be far easier to replace her, and no need to wait till midyear to sneak her in. Course it also means she doesn't have the same benefit Monica did in being able to hang around Edelgard as easily.

Red: Yeah, Kronya has a more difficult job this time around. Such a tragedy for her, oh no, so sad.

Indi: Meanwhile Byleth has the complete wrong idea about 'Emily' which will definitely make things interesting

Red: Yup! But that's for later! For now, thanks for reading and commenting! We always appreciate it!

Aftermath

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

So, it turns out accidentally stumbling onto the mock battlefield and causing all the students to rush to the field too gets you in trouble. Apparently, even though it was only practice, it was incredibly disrespectful to tarnish the traditions of the academy. At least, according to the rant Seteth gave them once they got back to the monastery and the disapproving lecture Jeralt personally gave Shez, though she was pretty sure the only reason he was giving it was because Seteth was so annoyed. As such, they were all assigned to something Shez knew all to well. 

 

Chore Duty. 

 

To be specific, it seemed that it was to be expected that the students assist with chores every week, to help build up discipline and such. But thanks to their actions at the mock battle, rather than having only to help out with chores one day out of the week, they were expected to do so every day for a full week. And while normally Shez was used to chores, turns out there was one here she didn't expect: Pulling out weeds. 

 

"I can't believe I have to do this rather than spend my time studying." Doesn't help that one of the people she was assigned with kept complaining. 

 

"Come on Lysithea, the more you complain the longer it'll take." Not that Shez didn't understand, turns out having to kneel down to pull weeds out was killer on her back. 

 

"I don't want to hear that from you! You're the one that got us into this mess!" 

 

"Technically, it's Ferdinand and Lorenz's fault for charging her first without bothering to talk to her," Edelgard chimed in from where she was pulling out weeds. Technically she didn't even need to be there, since the students who had already been part of the mock battle, and those who didn't rush in, weren't getting punished. Even so, she volunteered to do so, saying as the house leader it was her fault for not being able to control her housemates. 

 

"Yeah, I was just defending myself!" 

 

“And I suppose fighting everyone else on the field was just defending yourself too!” Lysithea snarked.

 

“Yes! Basically!”

 

Lysithea rolled her eyes, grumbling under her breath, while Edelgard glanced at Shez in some interest. “Speaking of the mock battle, I was wondering if you could tell us what that strange power you used was. I had heard you didn’t have a crest, so I admit I am curious.”

 

“Oh, that? That was my awakened form!” Shez declared, as though that meant anything to the two of them. After noticing her fellow students were just staring at her, she blushed slightly and bent back down. “Ah, heh. Well, basically it’s just a thing I can do. I get stronger and faster for a while. There’s no real downsides to it at all! …Aside from maybe getting kind of wild while I have it active.”

 

“Hm. So it is something of a berserker state?” Lysithea asked, getting a little curious despite herself.

 

“I guess? I don’t completely lose it, it’s just when there’s tons of people all around me that I don’t recognize immediately and are being aggressive, I just kind of…let loose? I didn’t hurt anybody too bad though, right?”

 

“You didn’t, no, though you certainly made an impression on everyone,” Edelgard noted.

 

“Well hey, that’s a good thing, right? I’m a mercenary, if I’m leaving an impression, that means people will want me on their side!”

 

Lysithea scoffed. “Or they’ll be terrified of you like Varley.”

 

“To be fair to me, I’m pretty sure Bernadetta was already scared of me, for some reason. Probably because of Byleth?”

 

“Perhaps,” Edelgard replied while making a mental note to ask Bernadetta about her fear towards the Eisner sisters, “Well, hopefully you can keep a grip on that power of yours for your mission this coming month.”

 

“Oh yeah, the professors mentioned that. So we basically get a job assigned to us every month? Do we get paid?”

 

“Almost every month, sometimes there are other activities that take precedent, and no, we do not get paid.”

 

Shez pouted. “That’s lame. Especially since it sounds like we’re just escorting some supplies that are coming up to the monastery. Kind of doubt we’ll run into anything interesting on a job like that.”

 

Lysithea huffed. “Well what did you expect? You are still a student, even if you were a mercenary.”

 

“I guess. What about you, Lysithea? What have they got your class doing?”

 

“We will be joining the knights on patrol of the countryside within Garreg Mach’s territory.”

 

“Wow. That actually sounds worse than mine.”

 

Lysithea puffed up, glaring at Shez. “And what is that supposed to mean?! Do you think they are assigning me to easy missions because I am a weak child in need of protection!?”

 

“...You’re hearing a lot of things I didn’t say. You might want to get that checked out.” Ignoring her indignation, Shez glanced at Edelgard. “How about you, Princess? Is your class doing anything interesting?”

 

“You know you can just call me Edelgard, yes? As students, we’re all on equal standing.”

 

Shez shrugged. “Blame Claude, he got me calling him ‘your grace’ all the time.”

 

“I’m fairly certain you started doing that all on your own,” Lysithea grumbled.

 

Edelgard tried to avoid giggling at the byplay. Despite her words, she couldn’t go acting like a schoolgirl just because her classmates were being amusing. “It seems the Black Eagles have been assigned to hunt down some bandits this month. The remaining Iron King bandits, to be specific.”

 

Shez blinked. “What? Seriously!? How come we’re doing escorts while you’re hunting bandits!?”

 

Edelgard shrugged. She had some ideas, but she wasn’t about to share them. Aside from a deflection, of course. “Perhaps because our teacher is a famous mercenary? They may have greater faith in her combat expertise.”

 

“But I’m a mercenary too! Uuugh, this sucks…”

 

“Now who’s whining like a child?” Lysithea commented, amused.

 

“Bleh…hey, Edelgard, let me join your house.”

 

Edelgard blinked. That was remarkably easy. “...Are you certain? That seems like an extreme course of action to take just because you dislike the mission you’ve been assigned.”

 

“...Yeah, you’re right, I shouldn’t jump ship that eagerly…” Shez sighed. “Well I guess there’s nothing for it. Sometimes you just get a lame job like guarding a turnip farm while your dad gets to do cool stuff.”

 

“That’s not quite the situation here.”

 

“You guarded a turnip farm?” Lysithea asked.

 

“Oh, yeah, it was an easy job I had to do because I, uh…” Shez grinned sheepishly. “I kind of jumped off a cliff to see if I’d survive it.”

 

“What?!”

 

“Hey, I lived, didn’t I? I was trying to get stronger from–”

 

“How does jumping off a cliff make you stronger?!”

 

“Well what doesn’t kill you makes you stronger, right? And that didn’t kill me.”

 

Despite her best efforts, Edelgard couldn’t stop herself from giggling at Shez’s statement, said with such confidence and surety that the princess really couldn’t see the potential threat in her midst as anything other than a genuine idiot.

Carrying a bucket of horse feed with her, Byleth made her way to the stables. A part of her couldn't help but feel a bit annoyed that she was also getting punished because things got out of hand, but at least stable duty wasn't that bad. She was used to helping out her dad with Argo, so she had some experience at least. 

 

"Gotta say, never thought of using buckets full of horse food as weights, it's very handy!" Raphael said with a grin, casually bringing his bucket up and down as he worked out. Which… hm, he did have a point.

 

"Leave it to you to see the bright side of this." Sylvain commented as he followed along. 

 

"Heh, come on Sylvain, what's there to complain about? I mean, we get to work out our muscles and hang out with horses!"

 

"Well, at least the view will be nice," Sylvain commented as he checked Byleth out. 

 

"I guess the stables do look nice. Do you like horses?" Byleth asked, misunderstanding what he meant. 

 

"Well I am planning on focusing on mounted combat," Sylvain said, "I mean, it'll get me plenty of practice for when I ask someone out on a romantic horse ride." 

 

"Oh, I hope you have fun on that, Sylvain!" Raphael cheered.

 

"Thanks buddy. What about you, professor? I'm sure someone as experienced as you must have plenty of romantic escapades to share." 

 

"Not really." 

 

"Really? You're telling me you've traveled all over Fodlan and you don't have even one single romantic story to tell?" 

 

"No." 

 

"Huh, haven't even kissed a single girl?" 

 

"Why do you keep asking?" 

 

"Just curious. But hey, if you’re ever interested I know a great place in town where plenty of cute girls hang out. Wouldn't mind being your wingman." 

 

“What’s a wingman?”

 

“Oh, wow, you really are inexperienced. Uh…think of it like a fellow merc who’s covering your back–No, wait, that doesn’t work…Hm, I need to work on my metaphors.”

 

“You should ask Hanneman about that, he’s your professor,” Byleth replied as she brought the feed over to the horses.

 

“I don’t think metaphor practice is on the class schedule, professor. Hm…hey, quick question, but have you ever kissed a guy?”

 

“Why would I kiss a guy?”

 

“Yeah I should have expected that answer…Ah well, it’s good to confirm.” 

 

“Do you like guys, Sylvain?” Raphael asked, hoisting one of the buckets up to a horse, who looked a little bewildered at being offered food so directly.

 

“Ah, that’s not how you do that,” Byleth said, heading over to correct him while Sylvain chuckled.

 

“No, that’s not what I was getting at. Though there was that one…Ah, let’s just say I prefer pretty people, I’m not one for the rugged types,” Sylvain answered.

 

“Yeah, that makes sense,” Raphael said, nodding before focusing back on Byleth as she showed him how to properly feed a horse. Apparently it involved setting up the bucket on the stall so the horse could eat on its own.

 

“We have a lot in these buckets though, and there’s a lot of horses here, so we’ll want to divide them up,” Byleth explained, “There should be some empty buckets to fill.”

 

“Got it! I’ll get right on that, professor! Don’t worry horses, it’ll be food time soon enough!”

 

Sylvain chuckled at the big guy’s enthusiasm, before pausing as he noticed someone else in the stables. “Speaking of pretty girls…”

 

He shouldn’t be surprised to see Marianne around, he’d heard she preferred to stick around the stables, though it was interesting to see her speaking softly to that one horse of hers. Or, no, wasn’t that a different horse?

 

Definitely looked bigger than her usual horse, more akin to a war horse, so it was a bit surprising to see her talking so softly to it. 

 

"Hey there Marianne, didn't expect to see you here. I thought you didn't get punished?" Sylvain asked, getting Marianne to jolt in place as she turned around. 

 

"O-Oh, hello, Sylvain," the meek girl greeted, keeping her eyes turned downward as she turned around. "I-I just came by to check on the horses." 

 

"Aaah, well if you're here, you mind helping me out? I'd love to learn from an expert." 

 

"O-Oh, n-no, I'm not an expert, I just like horses."

 

"Argo seems to like you," Byleth said, walking up since she apparently knew the name of the horse. 

 

"O-Oh, is he yours?" Marianne asked, getting the professor to shake her head. 

 

"Argo is my dad's horse, but I help take care of him. He doesn't warm up to people easily, so you must have made a good first impression," Byleth said as she moved up to Argo, the horse leaning into her touch as she raised her hand. 

 

"H-He is a very gentle horse," Marianne said with a smile, getting Sylvain to stare at Argo ,who was probably the most intense-looking warhorse he'd seen.

 

"Woah, this horse is huge! I didn't know a horse could have these kinda muscles!" Raphael exclaimed, coming over as he saw everyone crowding around Argo. "What does it eat to get so huge?" 

 

"He likes raisins, dad tends to mix it into his hay whenever he eats." 

 

"A-Ah, Dorte likes raisins as well." 

 

"I'll make sure to bring some for him next time." 

 

"Th-Thank you," Marianne said with a slight smile, getting Byleth to smile back. 

 

Hm, she had heard Marianne was shy, but she seemed easy to talk to. Maybe because they both liked horses? Hm… maybe finding a common ground with Bernadetta would help with her easily frightened student. But what did they have in common…

 

Well, they were both good at running so maybe that would work…

Even with the extra chores they had to do, the students still had classes to attend to. And the students of the Black Eagles were quite eager to see what exactly their mercenary-turned-professor had in store for their lesson. Sure, she might seem a bit off, but clearly they would be able to learn plenty from her. 

 

Edelgard herself even made sure to sit at the front of the class, ready to see what the Ashen Dragon brought to them. 

 

"How many of you have killed before?" 

 

They certainly weren't expecting that question though. 

 

"...Professor, may I ask why you are asking us that?" 

 

"The mission we were assigned to involves disposing of bandits, and many of you have yet to see actual combat. I'm not sure why we were assigned this mission so early into the year, but if we are to accomplish it, then I need to know who will hesitate in combat and who won't,” Byleth explained. “So please raise your hand if you’ve killed another human being before.”

 

The professor raised her own hand, making it clear that she not only had but was fully comfortable with admitting that fact. Not unsurprising, given her career, but it was remarkably blunt for an educator.

 

So, in return for that bluntness, Edelgard openly raised her hand. To no one’s surprise, Hubert also raised his with a faint smirk on his face, though a few of their classmates seemed surprised that Ferdinand was among their number.

 

“Professor, I must object to the phrasing of your request!” Ferdinand said, frowning, “I have never once killed an innocent person! I have only dealt with bandits and brigands that threatened the innocents of the Empire!”

 

“Okay? I didn’t say ‘raise your hand if you’ve killed someone innocent’. I don’t think any of you would be raising your hand if that was the case.” Hubert made a faintly amused noise there, which made Bernadetta flinch. Odd that she was sitting so close to him to begin with though. Regardless, the professor continued. “Bandits are still human, Ferdinand. You should keep that in mind.”

 

Ferdinand continued to frown, crossing his arms over his chest. “They might be human, professor, but you can’t tell me they haven’t given up the right to be treated as such by becoming outlaws.”

 

“Yes I can. Ferdinand…No, everyone. I want to be very clear right now. A bandit is a human being. A thief is a person. No matter who they are, no one was born into this world completely alone. The men and women we are going to face more than likely have or have had families. They have friends, they have hobbies, they have likes and dislikes. They have loved and laughed and cried just the same as all of us. It isn’t unusual for bandits to be people who have fallen on hard times. Some are mercenaries who were cheated by an employer. Some are foreign soldiers that were abandoned by their lords. Some are deserters that fled from armies they were forced into. Some were merchants, farmers, or even nobles that were ruined and have chosen to fight rather than lay down and die.

 

“And they will kill you if you allow them to.”

 

The professor’s tone was deadly serious as she stared out at the class, looking carefully to make sure everyone met her eyes.

 

“They are people. Do not forget that. They are also willing to kill you. Do not forget that either. As outlaws, as Ferdinand has put it, the only thing that awaits them if they are captured is the sword or the rope, and that means they will fight us to the death to avoid that fate. The fact that most of you are nobles won’t deter them from that. In fact, they are more likely to target you because of that fact. Spite is the most powerful motivation a bandit has and these are a ragtag group that just lost their leader. Do not give them any chances because they will not extend any courtesy to you.

 

“I won’t force any of you to kill on this mission, but it is a mission that demands you be willing to kill. I will keep all of you safe. None of you will die if I can help it, but I cannot be everywhere, and you will need to do your best to keep yourself safe. To that effect, I will be partnering each of you up to ensure you remain as safe as possible. If you have any preferences for a partner, I will be taking that into account going forward, though I do not guarantee I will accept your choice if you simply wish to partner with a friend.”

 

Edelgard blinked, caught off guard by how easily the professor transitioned from her speech on the realities of hunting bandits to talking about pairing up the students, as though this were a mere class trip.

 

“Are there any questions?” Professor Byleth asked as though it were the most natural thing in the world.

 

Bernadetta, of all people, raised her hand.

 

“Yes Bernadetta?”

 

“...c-c-c-can w-w-we s-stay i-in o-our rooms i-instead of g-going?”

 

“No, Bernadetta.”

 

“O-Oh…”

Chapter End Notes

Indi: for anyone curious, no Hubert did not get punished. He technically didn't break any rules, so he got off scot free. For now.

Red: Hubert wins! Though with a slight blow to his ego, admittedly, from how Bernie's more scared of Shez than him.

Indi: Meanwhile Byleth is doing her best with her first proper lesson.

Red: Doing her best, but might be coming off a little intense there.

Indi: I'm sure she'll get better at it.

Red: But that's for the future! For now, thanks for reading!

Plagiarism and Preparation

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

“You plagiarist!”

 

Byleth chewed on the bit of fish in her mouth before glancing up at her sister, who was frowning at her front across the table. She continued to chew, not answering, before finally swallowing. “Hi Shez.”

 

“Oh don’t give me that!”

 

“...Don’t say hi?”

 

“You know what I mean! ‘They loved and laughed and cried just like us’, huh? Says the woman who has never done any of those things?”

 

Byleth shrugged. “It was a good line.”

 

“That you stole from dad! That was the exact same speech he gave us on our first bandit hunt!”

 

“It wasn’t the exact same one. I modified it for the situation.”

 

Shez scoffed before actually sitting down, still glaring at her sister indignantly from across the table.

 

“You should eat your food before it gets cold,” Byleth noted, “How did you even hear about my speech anyway?”

 

“Dorothea told me, duh! She was talking about how intense you were about this bandit hunt thing and guess what? She quoted you word for word so I know exactly how much you ripped off from dad!”

 

“Mm. Is that the fried pheasant?”

 

“Huh? Oh, yeah, the Derdriu style one. I figured I’d give it a try since it’s from Claude’s fancy city. What did you get?”

 

“Bourgeois pike. It’s apparently fancy.”

 

“Huh. Is it good?”

 

“Pretty good. Not sure if it’s fancy though.”

 

“Ah, yeah, I guess it–Wait, hang on, I was mad at you!”

 

Byleth pouted. “Aw, I thought I distracted you. Oh well. Also, I love you and dad, so I have loved before.”

 

“You know that’s not what I meant! I’m also pretty sure that’s not what that saying means. I think?” Shez frowned to herself.

 

"Excuse me professor, do you mind if I sit here?" A tired sounding voice caught their attention as they saw Lindhart approaching. 

 

"Oh, sure Lindhart." 

 

"Thank you." The student said before sitting down with them. "Now, professor, is it true that you have an undiscovered crest?" 

 

"According to Hanneman." 

 

"Yes, he's been quite excited about it, hence why I came here. You see, I have an interest in crests myself, so I was hoping you'd let me study you." 

 

"...how so?" 

 

"Oh nothing too intrusive, just a few samples, such as a lock of hair, or the like." 

 

"...You do know how weird that sounds, right?" Shez asked the green-haired boy. 

 

"Is it? I personally think it's a much better option than blood. Ah, speaking of, professor, I was hoping you'd let me stay on the sidelines in the upcoming mission. My specialty is primarily healing magic, so I won't be much good on the frontlines." 

 

"I'll keep that in mind, and if you just need hair-" Reaching down, Byleth pulled out her dagger, before cutting off some hair to hand to Lindhart. 

 

“By, don’t give random guys your hair,” Shez chided, frowning at Lindhart.

 

“It’s just hair. Besides, Lindhart is one of my students, so he’s not some random guy.”

 

“Still!”

 

“Thank you, professor,” Lindhart said, ignoring the byplay as he took the hair and placed it in some type of sample bottle. Then he glanced at Shez. “Hm…Could I request yours too? I heard you don’t have a crest, but you apparently displayed some type of ability at the mock battle.”

 

“Apparently? You didn’t see it?”

 

“I was asleep, so no.”

 

“Oh, huh. How the heck did you sleep through all that?”

 

“I’m a very good sleeper. So?”

 

“Huh? Oh, yeah, no, there’s no way I’m giving you any of my hair.”

 

“Shame,” Lindhart replied before yawning as he got up. "Well if you change your mind, feel free to find me. I have some research to do." 

 

"Make sure to get some rest before class tomorrow," Byleth advised as he left before turning back to Shez. "So, you're friends with Dorothea?" 

 

"I guess? She's probably the one I talk to the most from your class. Besides, why wouldn't I want to get to know my sister's first crush~?" 

 

"I don't have a crush on her," Byleth reiterated. 

 

"So you say~!" Shez teased. "Still, are you gonna be okay on the mission of yours? Dorothea seemed nervous about it all." 

 

Byleth shrugged as she finished her fish. "The bandits aren't strong, but I need to make sure everyone is ready for it." 

 

"Well you got that new power right? I'm sure it'll be okay with that. Not to mention the Princess is pretty strong right?" 

 

"Yeah, she's going to be in charge in case we split into two groups while fighting." 

 

"Well that's a start! And besides, if there's any trouble, you can always ask me for help with training them!" 

 

"I have a feeling if I do you'd just beat them up until you think they're decent." 

 

“What’s your point? That’s still training!” Shez argued before her smile seemed to soften, "Still, you need to take care too, By. You get attached to people easier than I do, so I wanna make sure you're okay." 

 

"I'll be okay. Try not to show off so much on your mission." 

 

"Pft, not like I'll be able to. Not much I can do for an escorting thing aside from walking slightly faster than everyone else." 

 

"You'd probably get lost if you got too far ahead." 

 

"We'll be going in a straight line, how am I going to get lost??" 

 

"How'd you get lost on your way to the monastery?"

 

"...I'm never gonna live that down, am I?" 

 

"I certainly won't let you," Byleth teased, making Shez pout. 

 

"Feh, at least let me eat my meal in peace," Shez complained before beginning to eat, "Oh, this is actually pretty good." 

 

"Can I have some?" 

 

"No." 

 

"Aw."

The silent scratching of a quill was the only noise in the room as Byleth prepared for the upcoming mission. She was rather lucky to have the month to prepare for what was to come, but without any knowledge of where the battle would take place, all of her plans would ultimately be guesswork. 

 

If nothing else, having a near-even split of melee and ranged students meant she could partner everyone up no problem. And of course, she would be able to further pair up the groups with her and Edelgard as the respective leaders should the need arise. That being said, it was still difficult, several of the students hadn't killed before, and there was no way of knowing how they would react. Bernadetta and Lindhart in specific didn't seem like they might take it well, given how the former was scared easily, and the latter might have an aversion to blood based on his request for samples he gave her. 

 

"My my, but you are taking this rather seriously." 

 

“I have to,” Byleth answered without looking up at Sothis, “It’s my job to keep my students safe and happy.”

 

“You certainly took that idea to heart quite quickly.” Sothis floated over her vessel’s shoulder, glancing curiously at the papers she laid out. “Would it help to discuss your tactics with me? I may not have all my memories yet, but I am sure I can offer plenty of wisdom!”

 

“How does this look then?” Byleth asked, as she slid a paper over so Sothis could read it. 

 

“Hm? So you are planning to make that young archer your partner for the mission? I’m not certain how much help she would provide with how skittish she is.” 

 

“Hence why I’m partnering up with her. She might not handle combat well, so I'll need to keep an eye on her.” 

 

“I suppose I can see the logic. In that case, may I suggest partnering up the young brigid girl with that sleepy healer rather than that boastful noble? Protecting the healer is quite important, so having someone who can react quickly would be a boon to him rather than someone who rushes in.” 

 

“Hm… that makes sense. I suppose I can have Dorothea pair up with Ferdinand then…”

 

“The young songstress does seem to keep a level head, so she would be capable of keeping him focused. Hopefully at least. I suppose that explains why you are having that dark and brooding one paired with the short brawler?”

 

“Caspar doesn’t keep track of his surroundings, so Hubert can cover him there.”

 

“And may I ask your reasoning for having the young emperor-to-be paired with that minor noble?”

 

“She tried to hide it, but Emily raised her hand when I asked if anyone had killed. Edelgard is strong, but if we do end up splitting the class in two, she might not be ready to have to keep an eye on someone who hasn’t killed before, while keeping track of everyone else. That, and Emily was able to keep up with Shez, even if she was on the defensive, so she could help cover the other team.”

 

“True, though you might wish to discuss the matter with the future emperor beforehand. I don’t think the two much like each other.”

 

“You noticed that? I was hoping it was something small. Emily seems resentful, but it should be something she can work past, right?”

 

“Perhaps. Or perhaps not. It depends on where that resentment comes from.”

 

“Hm…Okay. I’ll talk with both of them beforehand. I needed to discuss these plans with Edelgard either way," Byleth decided, getting up. 

 

"Ah, before you go." Moving in, Sothis grabbed onto Byleth’s face. "I don't know how well I will sleep if I were to behold something tragic, so I shall grant you the power to turn back the hands of time, but know this power is not infinite." 

 

As she said this, Byleth felt something rush through her, as if suddenly energized. 

 

"...How many times can I turn back time?" 

 

"If I were to hazard a guess…three times. Once those three are done, you will have to recover before you can use any more. Perhaps I'll be able to gain more in the future, but for now, those are your limits."

 

Nodding at that, Byleth collected her papers. "Thank you, Sothis." 

 

"Heh, you've gotten better at showing gratitude. I suppose you aren't as much of a child as I thought," Sothis said, before she faded away. 

 

"Hm." Leaving her room, Byleth made her way to Edelgard’s room, seeking to speak with her first. Thankfully while the sun was starting to set, it was still light out, so she was likely still awake. And thankfully she was as Byleth knocked on her door. 

 

"Who is it?" 

 

"Edelgard, I needed to discuss some things with you." 

 

"Professor?" It seemed she was surprised to hear Byleth knocking, but she still opened her door a few moments later. "Was there something wrong?" 

 

"No, I simply wanted to discuss the upcoming mission. As the house leader, I imagine you would have your own thoughts on my plan." 

 

"I suppose so. I am just a bit surprised you came this late in the day. One would think you would have discussed this after class or the like." 

 

"Oh… should I go?" 

 

"No, you're already here so I suppose it will be fine. May I know what exactly your plans are?" Nodding, Byleth handed over her paper of the planned teams to the young heir. 

 

"...Hm." A frown became evident on her face after she read. "I can understand your reasoning, but might I suggest Miss Korsch be your partner instead? I do not think we would work well together." 

 

"If you can tell me why you do not like her. I can tell you and her resent one another, but if it's only something minor then I won't change the plans." 

 

"..." That made Edelgard’s eyes narrow for a moment. "I would not call it resentment, but I fear that she might be more focused on attempting to curry favor from me rather than be a useful partner." 

 

"But you seem okay with Dorothea?" 

 

“There’s a difference,” Edelgard stated, her voice firm. “Dorothea is a commoner trying to rise from her position. She had nothing and has gained much through her own work and merit. Emily is a noble born in luxury who is trying to gain more for herself.”

 

“Hm…don’t most nobles want that though? The lower ones want to rise higher.”

 

“And the higher nobles wish to hold onto their positions. I am well aware of that, professor, and I dislike it. I do not mind a person trying to rise on merit, I do mind when they try to rise through nepotism. Spirit should matter more than blood, and I’ve seen little of Emily that makes me think she’s anything other than another greedy noble seeking favor she feels entitled to. You said it yourself that she’s resentful. Are you sure that wouldn’t make her more of a danger to me than a help?”

 

Byleth shrugged. “She’s still a student. It would be weird for her to try to hurt you, especially if she wants to curry favor with you.”

 

Edelgard frowned. “So you’re willing to risk it?”

 

“I want to help all of my students,” Byleth explained, “I think that means I need to push you all sometimes. I can’t help Bernadetta if she’s going to hide away all the time, so even if she’s afraid, I have to give her that push.”

 

“...” Edelgard’s frown deepened. “And you think I’m afraid of Emily?” 

 

“No, I think you don’t like her. I want to see if that can be fixed." 

 

"There is nothing to fix, professor," Edelgard stated, her voice carrying a finality to it. 

 

"...Very well, I apologize for taking your time," Byleth replied, before bowing to her and leaving.

 

"..." Edelgard said nothing else as she closed her door. With a faint bit of unease settling down on her, Byleth walked towards Emily’s room, hoping this would be easier than what just occurred.

 

"What!?" And she instantly sounded irritated when Byleth knocked on her door. 

 

"...It’s me, your professor," Byleth answered, hearing a groan of anger from the other side in response. She almost flinched as the doors were almost violently opened as Emily opened the door with barely contained irritation in her eyes. 

 

"Did you need something, professor?" she asked, trying to keep a nice tone to her voice and largely failing. 

 

"...I wanted to talk to you about the upcoming mission." Byleth said, not wanting to anger another student. "Specifically who I was going to partner you up with." 

 

"Oh? And who would that be?"

 

"I had planned on partnering you with Edelgard," That seemed to surprise Emily. "But it appears as if there are some issues between you two." 

 

"O-Oh, issues? With Lady Edelgard? I don't know what you're talking about." Despite her words, her eyes seemed to harden. 

 

"Is that so…this might just be my guess but you almost seem to resent her." 

 

"W-Why would I resent her?" She asked, before reaching for her door. "Look, I don't know what you're trying to insinuate, but I'm having none of it. Good night!" And with that, Byleth got a door slammed in her face. 

 

"..." Byleth felt the urge to let out a sigh, but she stayed silent as she went back to her room. She could figure things out later. Hopefully.

The next day Byleth accidentally woke up a bit late, since she had stayed up changing her plans, as well as writing up what supplies she’d need for everyone. Thankfully, she managed to get to class right before the bell rang, so she wasn’t late. That being said, aside from Lindhart and Emily, she was the last person to arrive in the classroom. 

 

“Morning, everyone,” Byleth greeted the class as she walked in.

 

“Morning, professor!” Caspar greeted.

 

“Hello there, professor,” Petra also greeted. 

 

As she reached her desk, Byleth couldn’t help but notice only those two had greeted her. Looking up, she noticed Edelgard giving her yet another calculating gaze while Hubert seemed to be outright glaring at her. Ferdinand, meanwhile, seemed to be only frowning, and Dorothea looked away from her with a small huff. As for Bernadetta…well, she was just hiding under her desk. 

 

“Hey professor, do you mind if I ask you something?” Caspar asked as he raised his hand. 

 

“Of course Caspar, what did you want to ask?” Byleth replied, trying to ignore the unease she felt. 

 

“So, I tried to think about what you said yesterday, but I don’t get it. I mean, the bandits are bad guys right?” 

 

“...You can be a bad person and still be a human, Caspar.” 

 

“No, I’m pretty sure you can’t. Isn’t that what ‘outlaw’ means? They’re bad guys, so the law doesn’t protect them.”

 

“They’re still human though. Human doesn’t mean good. Humanity is neutral.”

 

“Don’t we say someone has ‘humanity’ when they show kindness?” Hubert pointed out, his tone mocking, “I think that would mean it is ‘good’ then, wouldn’t you?”

 

“Yeah, see? Hubert gets it!” Caspar said with a grin, which made Hubert’s smirk falter into a sigh of exasperation. “So if you do bad stuff, you’re inhuman, right? So your speech doesn’t make a lot of sense, professor.”

 

“...” Byleth felt like she was being made fun of. Though Caspar did seem earnest…Things were still weirdly tense now and she wasn’t sure why. “Okay, I don’t think my meaning came across, so I’m just going to say that bandits belong to the human species. I don’t know about the rest of that, they’re just part of the species. Does everyone agree on that point?”

 

“Uh…I guess?” Caspar replied, before looking at Hubert, for some reason. Though the dark-haired student did seem to be considering the question, and smirked again when he came up with a reply.

 

“I don’t know, professor, I have heard bandits be called ‘subhuman’ before, so–”

 

“Hello Lindhart,” Byleth greeted as her sleepiest student wandered in, internally thankful for the interruption.

 

“Hm? Oh, hello professor. Thank you again for the hair samples.”

 

That prompted a fair amount of bewildered staring from her students. 

 

“...We’re starting the lesson now,” she decided, turning away from her students in favor of writing something on the board. She wasn’t sure what it was going to be yet, but she could probably come up with something as she went along.

 

Teaching really was harder than she thought…

Chapter End Notes

Indi: the problem with entering a school meant for nobles, you're pretty much walking into a minefield with no idea what's going on.

Red: Yup! So many grudges, connections, and politics that you have to carefully step around unless you want your life to become really difficult.

Indi: It definitely doesn't help when the house leader of the class you join is suspicious of your sister, and by extension you, because of your sister's apparent connection to a group that made Edelgard’s life a living hell.

Red: And while Edelgard is pretty sure Shez is an idiot (and she's not wrong), anything that might raise her suspicions towards the Eisners is going to really raise them high.

Indi: But well, I'm sure Byleth be able to figure something out. If nothing else we promise to bully Hubert later for bullying Byleth.

Red: He'll deserve it.

First Assignment

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

In the days leading up to the mission things had certainly been… difficult. A nervous energy had settled across the class which only grew as the day grew closer. 

 

It didn't help that several of Byleth’s students were starting to be on guard around their professor. As it stood, only Lindhart, Caspar, and Petra didn't seem to agitated when around her. It felt very…uncomfortable compared to how the students were before. 

 

Still, she would do her best to make sure everything would go well! She even made sure everyone was fully prepared and stocked for the mission! …Even if she did have to dip a bit into her own funds. One thousand gold was nowhere near enough for her whole class… 

 

So, with her own money used, she made sure everyone had brand new gear and a vulnerary if necessary. Thankfully, the Anna at the market was willing to give a discount for the bulk order. Still felt like she was being gouged though…

 

"Professor, we are almost at the Red Canyon. I do hope you are prepared and won't lead us into battle so absent-mindedly," Hubert said, bringing her out of her thoughts as she remembered what was happening. 

 

“You don’t have to worry, Hubert. I’ll keep my focus when it’s time to fight,” Byleth answered.

 

“See that you do.”

 

That was an odd response, but then Hubert had been one of those students that was on guard around her now. She didn’t know what she did to upset him, but it probably had to do with Edelgard being upset with her, which also seemed to make Ferdinand and Dorothea upset with her and Byleth genuinely didn’t know how to deal with any of that. She was not prepared for more than half her class being annoyed with her specifically; pre-battle jitters made sense, plenty of new fighters had that, but only Bernadetta seemed to be experiencing that specifically.

 

“I-Is it too late to go home?” she whimpered, clutching her bow as though it were a shield. Hm. Maybe Byleth should get her a shield? Most archers didn’t use one since it would throw off the weight of their arms, but maybe she could just wear it on her back like a turtle.

 

While Byleth contemplated the practicality of giving Bernadetta an actual shell to hide behind, Edelgard watched her professor with a newfound suspicion. The woman was already unusual, but suddenly trying to push Kronya on her not long after Shez was clearly shown to have some connection to Those Who Slither…It was difficult to believe that either Eisner sister could potentially belong to that group, but she needed to consider all possibilities going forward.

 

Ever since Thales’s passing, she had been given more freedom from Those Who Slither, but that did not mean she was completely free. And while she was the one who had planned on running into Jeralt’s Mercenaries 'by chance', there was still a slight possibility that said mercenary group had already been infiltrated. If she were to truly change Fodlan for the better, then she couldn't leave anything up to chance. 

 

"Gold for your thoughts, Edie?" Dorothea asked, bringing her out of her thoughts in favor of focusing on the songstress. 

 

"Just… thinking about our professor, I suppose." 

 

"Nothing pleasant I imagine? You had quite the serious face there," Dorothea guessed as they walked close to one another, "Yeah, I fully understand. Mercenary or not, that speech of hers was far too intense. Heck, it almost sounded like she was parroting off something she heard someone else say rather than her own words. It makes me wish her sister joined our class to act as a buffer." 

 

"Hm." Edelgard gave a noncommittal noise in response, not wanting to give her own thoughts away. 

 

"Well, hopefully this mission will be over soon so we can head back to the academy. Are you up to head to town with me, Edie? There's this shop I've been wanting to go visit for a while." 

 

"If I have the time." 

 

"Great, I'll make sure to hold you to it!"

 

"Is everyone ready?" Byleth asked as they arrived at where the bandits were hiding out. 

 

"N-No!" squeaked out Bernadetta.

 

"Don't worry Bernadetta, stick close to me and you'll be okay." Those words probably would have been comforting, if they weren't said in her usual deadpan way. "I trust you all remember who your partnered up with?" 

 

For the most part, the partnership was as she had planned, but with a slight change. Rather than Emily and Edelgard working together, Byleth had swapped Emily and Ferdinand around. Which meant the minor noble was partnered with Dorothea, not that Emily seemed happy about it either way. 

 

"Yeah, Professor! Come on, let's go kick some ass!" Caspar shouted, ready and eager to charge. Nodding as it seemed everyone was ready, Byleth drew her sword. 

 

"Very well, before we go, I'll say this: if any of you need to retreat for any reason, then do so, and make sure to have your partner escort you to the knights. Nothing good will come from fighting beyond your limits, but in the event you do need to retreat, send a spell up into the air to let me know you are retreating. Send two if you're in need of immediate rescue.

 

"I have also been informed that there are two paths ahead, one to the north and one to the west, once we get past this bridge. I shall be leading the main charge to the north, while Edelgard shall be leading the western charge. Petra, Lindhart, you two shall be in her group after we split ways."

 

“I have understanding, professor. I will be doing the best!” Petra affirmed, nodding sharply while Lin sighed.

 

“Are you sure we can’t just do well enough? I don’t really want to be ‘the best’.”

 

“Ah…I do not have understanding. Is ‘the best’ a something to be doing or a something to be being?”

 

“It can be either. You can do your best, or you can be the best,” Byleth explained, before nodding her head to the group, “So do your best to be the best, everyone. I know you’ll succeed.”

 

With her piece said, the mission began.

Dorothea never considered herself a fighter.
