Sure, she was taught how to defend herself, and had been in her own fair share of scraps defending herself or others, but there was a difference between that and what she was doing now. The worst she had done before was break a creep’s arm. Now, even while it was sheathed, she couldn't help but focus on the weight of the sword at her side. 

 

She didn’t know why her professor had given her a sword, when it was clear she only intended to use magic for the mission, but she found the intense mercenary a bit too unnerving to say no to. A part of her had wished Manuela had been in charge of the Eagles instead, but, well, too late for that to happen. Letting out a sigh, she couldn’t help but glance at her ‘partner’ for this mission. She’d never actually talked with Emily, but her poor acting aside, it was clear she held everyone there in contempt, so she wasn’t exactly happy about teaming up with her. 

 

Not that she had much time to think about her as the mercenary-turned-professor began the battle by directing an opening salvo of magical attacks straight at the pair of axe-wielding brigands standing guard at the bridge. Once the two fell over before they even had a chance to react, the Eagles rushed in, with Edelgard leading the charge. 

 

If this was a play, Dorothea would almost say Edelgard and even Ferdinand looked like gallant heroes as they cut down two more bandits. As it stood Dorothea couldn't help but grimace at the sight, especially as Caspar smashed a bandit with his fist, letting out a battle cry while Petra finished the archer next to him in one move. 

 

Shaking her head, Dorothea followed behind, before her attention was caught by Emily rushing forward as soon as Edelgard’s group broke to the west. 

 

“Ah, wait!” 

 

“Don’t break ranks!” Byleth shouted at Emily, who didn’t listen as she drew her sword, immediately slashing a bandit’s arm open before stabbing him in the chest as he screamed. Dorothea couldn't help but think Lindhart was lucky to be with the other group as he definitely would have fainted at the sight if he stuck around. 

 

“Hubert, Caspar, group up with her!” Byleth shouted as she blocked an axe hit from a bandit while Emily made no attempt to return to the group. 

 

Despite her own trepidations, Dorothea raised her hand as the two students followed the professor’s orders. Gritting her teeth, she sent a bolt of thunder into the bandit, knocking her away from the professor before she could swing again. She did her best to tune out the scream of pain.

 

“Thank you,” Byleth said, before her eyes scanned over to the west, able to make out Edelgard’s group fighting in the distance. “Bernadetta, can you take out the mage the bandits have over there?” 

 

“E-Eh!?” The archer squeaked, having not even drawn her bow once during the mission so far. “B-But w-what if I hit s-someone on our side!?”

 

“You can do it, trust me,” Byleth assured, her tone even. Dorothea was starting to understand what Shez meant by her having trouble expressing herself since she still said that in her usual monotone. Shakily drawing her bow, Bernadetta aimed, before letting the arrow loose, closing her eyes before it could land to see if it hit the target or not. 

 

Not that Dorothea could blame her since her own gaze turned away from the arrow, which let her notice something behind Bern. Slowly shambling up, the bandit that Dorothea thought Emily killed was still alive, and gripping a dagger. Channeling her magic, Dorothea shouted as the bandit rushed towards Bernadetta. 

 

“Bern watch out!”

Edelgard couldn’t help but note that facing the bandits in the canyon was very different from fighting them in the forest. Leaving aside the change in scenery, she wasn’t on the defensive this time and actually charging in to hunt them down felt…harder to justify, almost. It was also something of a surprise to see them here in the Red Canyon to begin with, given that, with Kostas’s death, she hadn’t had the opportunity to direct them anywhere in particular. She might even blame it on fate, if she believed in that kind of thing. 

 

Either way, she had little time to think about principles after the professor began the engagement by directing an opening salvo of magical attacks straight at the pair of axe-wielding brigands standing guard at the bridge. Once the duo was dead, their teams went straight into battle, and Edelgard led the charge along with Ferdinand. 

 

A fighter fell to her axe while Ferdinand drove his spear through the chest of another thief. Meanwhile, Petra handled the archer in their group and Caspar crushed another bandit’s skull beneath his fist. “Ha! That’s one for me! Who’s next?!”

 

Well, at least he was enthusiastic. She could focus on her classmate’s reactions later; she had a mission to complete. Though, even as she said that, she did notice Linhardt looked pale already from the gore strewn around.

 

“Linhardt! Focus!  We’re heading west!” she shouted.

 

“Ah–R-Right. Ugh, it’s just…no, don’t think about it,” he muttered, hurrying along to catch up as Petra and Ferdinand moved ahead. The majority of the bandits appeared gathered at some type of ruined shrine up ahead, and she could hear shouts and panic as they realized they were about to be hit from multiple sides.

 

Edelgard raised her shield as arrows started flying towards her, feeling some satisfaction as they bounced straight off the metal. “Find cover!”

 

Ferdinand and Petra hastened to obey while Lindhart stuck by her. Not quite the formation the professor planned, but it was working well enough as they kept the ranged bandits’ attention. She could see a healer among their number, who might be a priority target–Or at least he would be if he hadn’t just gone down gurgling from an arrow piercing straight through his throat.

 

“Hm. Good work, Bernadetta,” Edelgard murmured under her breath, making a note to praise the girl in person later, before charging forward as the archers faltered, in large part because a ball of darkness slammed into one’s head and rendered it down to blackened bone in less than a second. “And good work, Hubert.”

 

A part of her wished she had been the one in charge of the main strike force so she could keep an eye on everyone, but as it stood, this secondary path was both lower and had several rocky outcroppings blocking her sight of the others. Which meant she had little else to focus on besides the remaining bandits, one of which was standing in the middle of some ruins.

 

“OH COME ON!” whined one of the bandits, “I only just got to be boss! This is horseshit!”

 

“Ha! Did you think fortune would favor you, thief?” Ferdinand asked, grinning confidently as he leveled his spear at the bearded brigand wearing a bandana. “I would ask you to lay down your arms, but we both know–”

 

What he knew wasn’t immediately clear, given the bandit snarled in pure rage and flung his axe full force at Ferdinand’s skull at far too close of a distance for Edelgard to get in the way and block–Then Ferdinand was on the ground and Edelgard felt an actual flash of alarm before she realized their professor had just tackled him out of the way before blasting the bandit leader straight off the platform with a bolt of lighting through the heart.

 

“Ah–P-Professor!?” Ferdinand exclaimed before Byleth got off of him, her eyes scanning the area for further threats.

 

“Hm…I saw sixteen. How many do we have dead around here?”

 

“H-Huh? Ah–W-Wait, you just–You just saved my life–”

 

“Yeah, it happens. Eyes open, we need to confirm the bandits are handled,” she stated quite bluntly–

 

“Y-You’re bleeding!”

 

“Hm?” Byleth brushed a hand against her head, frowning as she searched for a wound before wincing slightly as she found it near the side of her head. “Ah, that’s annoying. Hm…I don’t think the axe blade hit me, this might be a scrape from the fall.”

 

“A scrape!?”

 

“Scrapes can bleed, it happens…hm, maybe the axe did nick me? Though I think there would be more damage then…Head wounds bleed more than most, so I wouldn’t worry.” She rooted around in her coat before pulling out a flask and simply downing the vulnerary, all while clearly keeping an eye out on the surrounding area. “Hm…Edelgard, do you see anything?”

 

The future emperor started at being addressed, before she felt her face heat slightly in embarrassment at realizing she’d just been staring at the professor. “Er…no, and I think the sounds of fighting just ceased.”

 

“Right. Are you okay Ferdinand?”

 

“...Y-Yes, of course! I am perfectly fine, thanks to you, professor!” Ferdinand grinned as he picked himself up, though he did frown slightly at the dust now marring his clothes. “Er…ah, so is that mission accomplished then?”

 

“Once we check to make sure all the bandits are handled, yes. Also, our job was to kill all of them. Don’t ask for surrender with that objective.”

 

“Ah, well, I wasn’t actually intending to ask that, it was more…”

 

“You were taunting him then. That’s fine, but save that for when the enemy is already dead or no longer a threat. He had an axe, he was still a threat,” the professor bluntly explained, before walking to the edge of the shrine and hopping down. 

 

Somewhat curious, Edelgard found herself looking over the edge as the professor strode over to the bandit leader, the hole in his chest visibly smoking from the bolt that had gone through it, before she calmly swung her sword down on his neck and severed his head in one blow.

 

“Eugh.” Ferdinand had also moved over to peek, and when Edelgard looked at him, he returned her gaze with a slightly sheepish smile. “I, ah…she has a very…efficient way of doing things.”

 

“Efficient is one word for it,” Edelgard replied. The fact that the professor had leapt in again, this time to save Ferdinand…Well, it didn’t rule out ulterior motives. It was just hard to imagine that she might have them with how blunt she tended to be.

 

As for the rest of her class, everyone else seemed to be fine…though she did notice both Dorothea and Hubert seemed to be staring at “Emily”, who was absolutely drenched in blood and actually smiling. So. Hm.

 

“Huh, is that it?” Caspar asked, glancing around, “Did we get all of them?”

 

“It looks like it,” Professor Byleth said as she returned with a bloodied bag in hand, “Good work, everyone. I’ll ask the knights to perform another sweep to check for stragglers and clean up, but you all did very well. Good work.”

 

There were some smiles and, in Caspar’s case, a cheer at the praise, before everyone began making their way back towards the monastery. They would meet up with the knights first and then be on their way back, though Edelgard did hang back, partially to make sure everyone was present and accounted for on the way back, and partially to speak with her professor after the fact. Though she was surprised to notice Bernadetta was also hanging back instead of running straight for safety.

 

In fact, the smaller girl actually went right over to the professor instead.

 

“A-A-Ah…I-I-I’m s-s-sorry you were stabbed because of me!”

 

Edelgard blinked. What?

 

“I-I d-didn’t even see that thief a-and–” Bernadetta squeaked, though not from her usual fright. No, it was more out of surprise as Byleth suddenly gave her a pat on the head.

 

“You did fine. Sometimes that happens. I’m not mad.” Byleth smiled. It was small and a little stiff, but there was a clear smile there. “Good work out there.”

 

“...Y-Y-You’re n-not m-m-mad?”

 

“I’m not mad.”

 

“A-And y-you’re n-not l-lying?”

 

“I’m not lying either. I think you did a good job. Thank you for doing your best.”

 

“...” Bernadetta ducked her head with a little blush on her face, fidgeting with her fingers. “M-Mm…”

 

“Do you want me to buy you a shield? I know you’re an archer, but you could wear it on your back.”

 

“H-Huh? U-U-U-Uh…th-th-that sounds h-heavy? A-Ah, n-n-not th-that I d-don’t like your i-idea, please don’t be mad!”

 

“I’m not mad. We can figure something else out.” Byleth tilted her head, thinking. “Do you like horses?”

 

“H-H-Huh? I-I-I, u-u-u-uh…I-I-I’m n-not…s-s-sure?”

 

“Hm. That might be something to explore. You should probably head back now, I think Edelgard wants to talk to me too.”

 

“A-Ah!” Bernadetta stiffened, noticing Edelgard. “S-S-Sorry! I-I-I d-d-didn’t m-mean t-to g-get i-in your way!”

 

“That’s quite alright, Bernadetta–And she’s already running.” Edelgard sighed as she watched the shorter girl sprint past her. “It’s hard to believe she’s the same age as me sometimes.”

 

“Right, she’s seventeen,” Byleth noted, “Eighteen this year as of the twelfth of the Ethereal Moon.”

 

Edelgard paused, then regarded her professor curiously. “You know her birthday?”

 

“Yeah. I looked up everyone’s birthdays in the registry. I’m sorry I missed Hubert’s, but I made sure to get Ferdinand flowers for his.”

 

Edelgard blinked, thinking back to Ferdinand happily declaring how he had a secret admirer who left flowers on his doorstep. “I think he might have misinterpreted that gesture, professor.”

 

“He did? How?”

 

“Hm…Well, never mind. I’m sure Hubert wouldn’t mind receiving a birthday present. A month late, admittedly, but still.”

 

“Maybe I should…I did get some stuff for my sister’s classmates since two of them had birthdays this month and I did give Raphael some smoked meat for his…” The professor nodded to herself. “Very well, I will get Hubert something too. Do you know anything he would enjoy in particular?”

 

“Coffee beans and board games,” Edelgard answered with a smile.

 

“Okay, thank you. Did you have something you wanted to talk with me about?”

 

“...No, not especially. I just wanted to make sure everyone made it back fine.” Though…well, it was a risk, but she may as well ask. “I will admit though…are you really just concerned for Emily’s well-being? You don’t have any ulterior motives?”

 

“Oh. Yeah, I have one.” She shrugged. “I killed her uncle.”

 

Edelgard blinked. “...Hm. Would you care to explain?”

 

“Sure. I think I mentioned being in Enbarr at one point to you before. I went to the Mittelfrank Opera Company with my dad and sister. Shez and I wanted to make it a surprise for our dad, so she and I went to get tickets ahead of time. We encountered a noble in the street who made advances and threats towards us, so I stabbed him in his vitals and left him to die on the ground. Then I noticed there was a girl in the registry that shared the same family name as him, so I looked into her and found out what connection they had.” She shrugged again. “I don’t feel guilty for killing him, but she’s my student, so I need to make sure she’s safe and happy. I don’t know if she knows, but she seems to hate it here, and I can understand that, so I want to make things right.”

 

“...I see. Do you plan to share this information with her? Because I will point out, you just admitted to murdering a noble. That is a crime that people would take notice of.”

 

“I’m not sure yet. I might. It could clear the air between us.”

 

“...” She genuinely was that honest, huh? “Professor…I’m not sure you have a correct idea of what type of person Emily is. She’s…trouble. And I would prefer you not hand her any rope she may attempt to hang you with.”

 

“Alright, I’ll keep that in mind. I’m not decided yet. She does seem kind of sadistic, so it would probably be a bad idea. I’m still keeping it in mind though.”

 

“That’s all I ask, professor,” Edelgard replied while wondering if she needed to take steps to remove the “trouble” that was Emily Korsch. 

 

She also couldn’t help but think, on the way back, that she’d just learned another element of interest to her professor’s character. Because yes, she was the type of person to remember birthdays and get gifts even for people outside of her class, and she was also the type of person to murder someone without hesitation the instant they showed themself to be a threat to her loved ones. Which definitely made her dangerous…but also potentially useful. It all just depended on if Edelgard could keep her on her side…and that meant she had to solve the mystery of Shez Eisner as well.

 

She really did have her plate full. Especially since it wouldn’t be long before she had to don a familiar guise again.

 

Soon enough, the Flame Emperor would have to appear once more…

 

In the meantime though, Edelgard watched as her professor was chewed out by Seteth for trying to bring a severed head back into the monastery.

 

…She really had no idea what to make of such an utterly bizarre woman.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: So for anyone curious, we don't really plan on showing any character deaths before Byleth turns back time to save them, but if at any point you see Byleth suddenly save someone, then it's save to assume she turned back time.

Red: Yup! As neat as the divine pulse is, it'll be a little tricky to display from Byleth's perspective, so expect it to largely be shown from outside.

Indi: that being said, we will confirm that she did see both Ferdinand and Bernadetta die this chapter.

Red: Very brutally at that! Its times like these that it's probably good she's emotionally muted. Course, as she gets more attached to them, well...Suffice to say, Byleth might have her aggressive side come out at times.

Indi: Until then she'll be keeping herself entertained with the thought of turtle Bernie.

Right onto the Next Problem

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

So that was a good first assignment! Sure, Byleth might have seen two of her students die, but she was able to save them, so she felt proud of herself. Even if she did get yelled at afterwards. If she wasn't supposed to bring back the head they should have said so… 

 

Still, she felt good, so she made sure to get a nice breakfast before her meeting with Rhea for the next mission. 

 

"Hey, By, how'd your mission go?" Shez asked, sitting across from her. 

 

"Went well. Apparently we aren't supposed to bring back bandit leader heads."

 

"Seriously? Then how are they gonna know we actually took them out?" Shez asked, getting her sister to shrug. 

 

"How'd things go for you?" 

 

"Eh, pretty boring. Only problem we faced was some wolves, and it wasn't even big ones, just normal wolves." Shez sighed. "Didn't even have to fight."

 

"Well, at least nothing bad happened? But hopefully your next mission is more exciting." 

 

"It better be!" Sighing again, Shez leaned back in her chair. "Have you gotten your next mission?" 

 

"Not yet, I was going there after I ate." 

 

"Well I just hope my mission is cooler than yours this time. Heck, apparently you went to a sacred place?" 

 

"Ah, yeah. Zanado, apparently it was where the goddess lived." 

 

"Seriously? It must have been impressive." Byleth shrugged in response. 

 

"It was mainly some ruins but…it felt familiar…" 

 

"Wait, really?" 

 

"Yeah, I've never been there before, but it felt like I had." 

 

"...huh. That sounds creepy." 

 

"I guess." 

 

"So, aside from that, is everything good with your class?" 

 

"...I'm not sure. They started getting agitated around me, but now they're not, so I don't know if they like me or not." 

 

"Well, it's still early in the year, so I guess we'll see. And hey, if anyone causes you problems, tell me and I'll beat them up for you." 

 

"...you shouldn't beat them up." 

 

"Eh, I'm a student, I can get away with it." 

 

"...I don't think that's how it works." 

 

"That's for future Shez to figure out." 

 

"I don't think future Shez likes current Shez."

After a nice breakfast, Shez began to walk around the monastery. Morning classes weren't really held on the first day of the month while the professors got their missions for the month, which meant she had plenty of free time. Granted, she didn't really know what to do yet, since her fellow Blue Lions seemed on edge for some reason and she didn't know why. 

 

Part of her felt like it wasn't her place to ask since it seemed like it was a thing with all the Lions, so she gave them some space. Which meant she ended up lost again while walking. 

 

"How'd I end up at the cathedral…" She muttered to herself as she looked around, trying to find someone she knew. "Oh, hey, Lysithea!" 

 

"Hm? Oh, what do you want?" 

 

"Wanted a bit of help if you don't mind. I was trying to get to the marketplace, but I got lost." 

 

"...How did you get lost? For that matter, how did you not realize that until you got to the cathedral? You had to cross a bridge to get here!" 

 

"I dunno, this place is just way too big." 

 

"Hmph, I'll agree with you there, the monastery grounds are too far spread out. It feels like it takes forever to get to one place from another. N-Not that I get lost like some child!" 

 

"...I didn't call you a child." 

 

"And you shouldn't! I'm a fully capable, mature adult!" 

 

"...Look, can you just help me get back to the marketplace?" 

 

Lysithea scoffed, affronted. “Of course I can! Follow me!”

 

“Alright.” And so, on Shez went, following after the shorter girl. The much shorter girl, whose legs weren’t as long as hers, so she actually wound up walking slower than she usually would to make sure she didn’t overtake her.

 

“Y-You don’t have to walk so slowly! I can keep up with you just fine!”

 

“Alright, if you say so.”

 

A few minutes later, Shez jerked as a panting Lysithea tugged at the back of her shirt, stopping her in her tracks. “Why did you go to the stables!?”

 

Shez blinked, then glanced at Argo, who was staring at her placidly from his stable. “Oh, huh. That’s weird…oh, hey Marianne.”

 

“...H-Hello?” the blue-haired girl greeted before Lysithea grabbed Shez’s wrist and started pulling her away.

 

“Honestly! How in the world do you function in your day to day life?!”

 

“Huh? Hey, I’m not that bad! It’s just easy to get turned around here!”

 

“You walked into the stables! How do you even do that unintentionally?!”

 

“I was taking a shortcut! Look, the marketplace is right over there, right?”

 

“THAT’S WHERE THE POND IS! Ugh, follow me, now!”

 

Shez pouted, but let the shorter girl lead her along before something else caught her attention. “Oh hey!”

 

“What–Gah!” Lysithea yelped as Shez changed directions, getting dragged along by the taller girl’s sleeve for a moment before she managed to steady herself and walk along with her properly. “Ugh, honestly, what is wrong with you?!”

 

“Nothing! I just saw–Ah, hey, here we go! Hey Victor! Hey Candace!”

 

“Hm? Oh, hey Shezzy!” greeted the lean, dirty-blonde lancer with a cheerful, gap-toothed smile across her freckled face, “It’s been a while!”

 

“Yeah it has! What’ve you two been up to? I haven’t seen you around at all!”

 

“We’ve been around here,” Victor answered, the hefty, bald, bearded merc raising a bushy black eyebrow at his captain’s kid, “The captain’s staying here so most of us mercs have just been sticking around since he still pays us ‘n all. You didn’t know?”

 

“Oh, uh…yeah, uh, I definitely knew! I was just busy with classes. Heh, you know how it is, not a lot of freetime and all.”

 

“Is that so? Cause Byleth’s been visiting us whenever she gets a chance.” He crossed his arms over his chest, his dark beard hiding the slight grin he had. “Are you saying you get less free time than a professor?”

 

“...Uh…ah, hey! Meet Lysithea!” Shez deflected, pushing her shorter friend forward.

 

“Ah-H-Hey, don’t just–...er.” Lysithea gulped, staring up at two of the roughest people she’d ever seen. “...Hello. My name is Lysithea von Ordelia. It’s nice to meet you.”

 

“Oh! I know that name! Cordelia’s one of the big houses!” Candace exclaimed with a bright smile, earning a sigh from Victor.

 

“She just said it’s Ordelia. No ‘C’.”

 

“See what?”

 

Victor rolled his eyes, before nodding to Lysithea. “Nice to meet you, kid. Good to see Shez is making friends. Speaking of, Shez, good on you for making friends with nobles, it’s good to get those connections.”

 

“Oh yeah, I know, but Lysithea is just helping me out right now,” Shez explained, “I was trying to find the weapon shop around here.”

 

“You mean the armory or the blacksmith?”

 

“...Uh…” Shez glanced at Lysithea.

 

“Why do you think I would know–No, actually…the armory should be where you would want to go if you wish to buy equipment directly, while the blacksmith handles specialty work, like repairing weapons and forging special orders.”

 

“Oh wow, you are smart.”

 

Lysithea blinked, before puffing out her chest. “Of course I am! Did you think I wasn’t?!”

 

“Huh? Uh, no, that’s not what I said?” Shez looked confused, before just shrugging and glancing at her mercenary friends. “Well it was good to see you two again. I’ll try to come by and hang out again!”

 

“Sure thing, Shez. You just do what’s best for you, alright? And make sure people are paying you for whatever work you do,” Victor reminded.

 

“Bye Shezzy! Say hey to Byleth for me! And have fun with your little friend!” Candace said, earning an affronted look from Lysithea.

 

“Little?!”

 

But the blonde mercenary didn’t pay her any mind, instead just ambling off towards one of the vendors, which earned a little laugh from Shez. “Oh, that poor guy.”

 

“Hmph…What? What do you mean? Are you referring to the bald man?”

 

“Who, Victor? No, he knows how to handle Candace, he’s fine. I meant the merchant.” Shez grinned as she turned and started heading for the armory, walking slowly so Lysithea can keep in step with her without falling behind again. “Candace is kind of an airhead, except when it comes to three things. The first, any kind of steed; they immediately catch her interest and she adores pegasi especially. The second, actually fighting; she’s probably one of our best spearwomen and she’s cold and efficient when it comes to a fight. And the third, haggling.”

 

“Haggling?” Lysithea asked dubiously.

 

“Yup! She gets intense, and Saints help you if she thinks you’re trying to cheat her. I’m pretty sure that Anna girl still holds a grudge,” Shez explained, before stopping herself before she could bump into another familiar face. Which meant Lysithea wound up running into her.

 

“Gh–Hey, watch it!”

 

“Ah, sorry–”

 

“O? Well hello Shez and Lysithea,” Dorothea greeted, looking surprised to see them both, “I wasn’t expecting to see you two together. Are you having some kind of outing?”

 

“Uh, sort of? It’s more Lysithea was helping me find the armory.”

 

“Against my better judgment,” Lysithea muttered under her breath, though not quietly enough to avoid noticing from Dorothea, who giggled.

 

“Well it’s very nice of you to lend your aid to our directionally challenged friend!”

 

“Hey, I’m not that bad,” Shez complained.

 

“Oh really? So then you weren’t the one who wandered onto the field of the mock battle by complete accident?”

 

“...That was one time.”

 

“There’s only been one mock battle,” Dorothea teased, making Shez huff. “Ah, though, I did have one thing I wanted to say the next time I saw you.”

 

“Huh? What’s up?”

 

“I wanted to apologize. I, well…I made some rude remarks about your sister the last time we spoke, about how intense she was being.”

 

“You did?” Shez frowned in thought– “Oh, right, you did! Well, to be fair, I’ve used that word to describe Byleth a few times.”

 

“Yes, but you’re her sister. There’s a difference in how you regard her versus how an acquaintance like me does.”

 

Shez scratched her head, frowning. “Dorothea, are you feeling guilty about something?”

 

“Oh, um…h-hm, that was blunt…I suppose. It’s just…she saved Bern and Ferdie so readily. She put herself directly into harm's way to keep them from being hurt and she barely cared that she was wounded in the process…I guess I just feel…shallow after that, for assuming she was just trying to scare us when she genuinely wanted us to be prepared for how dangerous those bandits turned out to be.”

 

"Ah, yeah, Byleth isn't really the type to try and scare people intentionally. She's really blunt but also pretty honest. Though, back up for a moment, what happened with Bernadetta and Ferdinand?" 

 

"Did she not tell you?" Dorothea asked, a bit surprised. "During the mission, some bandits almost got the drop on Bern and Ferdie, and she was hurt saving them. We almost didn't realize she was even stabbed until Bern freaked out." 

 

"...Is that so?" 

 

"...I guess it really wasn't that big of a deal if she didn't mention it to you." 

 

"No, I'm pretty sure it is a big deal, she's just a dumbass sometimes," Shez said, before letting out a sigh. "Thanks for telling me, I'll make sure to talk to her later." 

 

"Well do try and go easy on her. We already made class difficult for her last month, the last thing we need is her getting angry." 

 

"I don't even know if Professor Byleth can get angry," Lysithea said with a huff. 

 

"Ah, well, she can. It's not pretty, but it takes a lot to get angry," Shez said before muttering. "Kinda why we didn't want to come here." 

 

"What does that mean?" Lysithea asked. 

 

"It's nothing. Anyways, thanks for telling me Dorothea, see you around." 

 

“Oh, alright. Well, have fun you two!” Dorothea said with a smile, before giving Lysithea a thumb’s up for some reason.

 

“Huh. What was that about?”

 

“...Who knows? Now I do hope we can be done with your errands already, we’ve wasted enough time as it is.”

 

“Ah, yeah, sorry about that. Well hey, let’s–” Shez paused, mostly because the instant she started walking she wound up colliding with someone. She almost thought it was Lysithea at first, since the person was pretty short, but that didn’t make much sense since Lysithea was standing to her side.

 

“Eep!” squeaked Bernadetta, holding up the book she just bought like it was a shield. 

 

“Huh? Oh, hey Bern–”

 

“D-DON’T KILL ME!” 

 

Shez blinked as the short girl promptly fled in the opposite direction, before she seemed to realize that would take her past the gates and instead fled down an alley. “...Huh. Did I do something?”

 

“Who knows? You’re a tall mercenary who hangs around with ruffians. Not only that, but she’s plainly terrified of your sister. It would almost be a surprise if Bernadetta wasn’t afraid of you.”

 

“Huh. I guess that’s true. Still feels weird though.” Shez tilted her head, thinking. “...I kind of understand why By was chasing her now.”

 

“...Is this some kind of predatory instinct?”

 

“No, I just want to figure out why she’s afraid of me now. Though I guess she is pretty small and rabbit-like, huh? She probably would be fun to chase…”

 

“...” Lysithea just sighed before grabbing Shez’s wrist and pulling her along again. Honestly, it was a wonder the distractible girl was able to get anything done.

As she stood outside of Rhea’s office, Byleth took a quick breath to steel herself and kept her face even as she entered. Waiting inside for her were Seteth and Rhea, the latter of whom smiled at her. 

 

“Hello there, professor. I see you are eager to start the month off. Why, you’re here even before Professor Hanneman.” 

 

“...I simply felt it would be rude to keep you two waiting for whatever mission my class will get assigned this month.” 

 

“On that we can agree. Do make sure to keep that attitude going forward,” Seteth interjected. 

 

“Hm. Sure. So what is our mission this time?”

 

“A lord in the kingdom has apparently begun to raise arms against the church,” Rhea explained, “While the Knights of Seiros will of course handle a majority of the conflict, I want for your class to be a part of the rearguard and assist in the aftermath.” 

 

“I see…” Well, if the knights would be more involved this time, then it would be safer for her students at least. Might be handy to read up on knights tactics to be able to coordinate with them… “What exactly would we need to do to act as the rearguard?” 

 

“Well, war zones are unpredictable, so while we don’t think any of the students will need to be in combat for this mission, there is a chance you may need to deal with any remaining forces that evaded the vanguard. Aside from that, you need only assist if the knights ask for help.” 

 

“Hm… So, we’re only expected to sit back and watch? That sounds odd for a mission.” 

 

“Even so, it is by the will of the goddess that you take this mission. The mission will also be useful in demonstrating to the students how foolish it would be to turn their blades on the church.” 

 

“..” Byleth tried to not let it show how much it unnerved her how easily Rhea was able to say that. “...I see. If I may ask, where exactly in the Kingdom will we be going?”

 

“To Gaspard territory.” 

 

“...Excuse me? Gaspard territory, as in…Lord Lonato’s territory?”

 

“Ah, yes, are you familiar with the territory?”

 

“...I was there, long ago.” 

 

“Hm, well there is no worry if you do not remember the land well. As has been stated, you shall only be part of the Rear Guard. Not to mention you shall be accompanied by members of the knights, including Holy Knight Catherine.”

 

“...Catherine?”

 

“Yes, a fine young knight that I’m sure you will get along with. It was my desire that she meet you here, but as I have said, you arrived early… Would you care to wait a little longer for her to arrive?”

 

“No.” Byleth immediately responded, getting Seteth to scowl. “I mean… I really should be getting back to my class, and I would hate to take up any more of your time.” With that, Byleth bowed, before immediately walking out before anyone could say anything else. 

 

“Is everything alright? I have not seen you fidget before…” Sothis noted a bit of worry in her voice as Byleth walked downstairs. 

 

“I’m okay, I’m just…” Clenching her fists to stop them from fidgeting, Byleth tried to ease herself as she tried to ignore the heat swelling up in her. “I think I need to hit something.”

After managing to buy a new sword, since her last one had started getting damaged beyond repair, Shez was able to make her way back, mainly due to Lysithea. 

 

"You owe me one for wasting my time!" the young mage said, once they got back to the courtyard leading to their classrooms. 

 

"Oh, uh, sure? I don't mind doing a quick job for you if you need it," Shez said, before thinking. "Though if I do a good job, mind telling others about how great I am?" 

 

"...You are very lucky Professor Manuela doesn't mind if we're a bit late to class," Lysithea complained with a huff, before heading off to her class. 

 

"See you Lysithea!" Shez replied, waving her off as she went to her classroom. Well at least there weren't any more weird comments about Lysithea not being a child. Heck, maybe her luck was turning around and she'd have a good mission this month.

 

"Please tell me you aren't serious, Professor Hanneman!" Was the first thing she heard as she walked in to hear Dimitri yelling. 

 

"I'm afraid I am, Prince Dimitri. That was the mission given to us this month." 

 

"And why were we given that mission instead of the Black Eagles!?" Ingrid said, standing up yelling. 

 

"I am not certain why Lady Rhea has chosen to hand out the missions as she did, but her decision has been made." 

 

"So normally I wouldn't care, but she does see how bad of an idea it is to give Empire students a mission in Kingdom territory, right?" Sylvain asked, his usual mirth not there. 

 

"Uh, I feel like I missed something important," Shez said as she walked in. 

 

"Just what mission we didn't get," Felix scoffed. 

 

"Wait, did we get another escort mission or something?" 

 

"No, we were asked to deal with bandits but…" Trailing off, Dedue glanced at Ashe. 

 

"...The Black Eagles were assigned to deal with a rebellion that's being led by my father," the young, freckled boy explained. 

 

Shez paused. “...You mean Lord Lonato?”

 

“Yeah.”

 

She slowly nodded, taking in the conflict on her friend’s face, before glancing at their professor. “Professor Hanneman…could you be more specific?”

 

The professor sighed, looking even older with the clear weariness he felt. “Lord Lonato of House Gaspard has raised a force in an open rebellion against the Church of Seiros. His justification for his actions is his claim that Archbishop Rhea had his son executed under false pretenses. He claims she is a corrupt tyrant who will kill anyone who speaks out against her and must be overthrown. Due to his grievance being with the Church itself, it was decided that the Knights of Seiros would handle his rebellion instead of the Kingdom of Faerghus.”

 

“And we’re going along with them?”

 

Hanneman shook his head. “We are not. Our class will be traveling to Siward territory in the Alliance to deal with a group of bandits called–”

 

“Professor!” Dimitri interrupted, “I must protest this decision! We all know the tensions that exist between the Empire and Faerghus at this time! How will it look to send Imperial nobility, including their princess, to kill a lord of Faerghus?!”

 

“I am aware of the optics of the situation, Dimitri, but the decision is not mine to make.”

 

“This is ridiculous!” Ingrid exclaimed, “Are we really going to let Adrestians spill more Faerghan blood!?”

 

Hanneman sighed. “Ingrid, I would like to remind you of where I happen to come from before you make further remarks like that.” From where she stood, Shez could see Mercedes shift uncomfortably as well. 

 

“Ah–...I am sorry, professor. I let my emotions get the better of me.”

 

“It’s quite alright. I understand this is a tense time for everyone, but we mustn’t let it overwhelm us.”

 

Dimitri straightened, a frown still on his face. “...Professor Hanneman, may I speak to Professor Byleth? Perhaps we could arrange to swap our missions?”

 

“I don’t think Lady Rhea would accept that…but very well, there is no harm in trying.”

 

“Thank you, professor.”

 

“Oh, I’ll come with,” Shez offered, “It might help out if I’m the one asking with you, right?”

 

“Oh, well…yes, I suppose if you think it will help,” Dimitri agreed, nodding to her before he made his way out of the classroom. To no one’s surprise, Dedue got up too to follow him, prompting a sigh from Hanneman.

 

“Well I suppose we can just have a free study period for this class.”

 

Meanwhile, Shez followed behind Dimitri and Dedue, idly glancing up at the big guy again. “So hey, how are you feeling about all this?”

 

“I don’t think my opinion especially matters here.”

 

“What? It definitely does! I’m asking for a reason, right? Besides, uh…Well, I’ll admit I don’t know much about Duscur, but I know what Christophe was accused of.”

 

Dedue glanced down at her. “Did you know Lonato’s son?”

 

“Ah, yeah, I did. You know how I knew Ashe already from my dad working for his…ah, yeah, that’s his dad that’s going to…hm.”

 

“You didn’t realize?”

 

“I did, it just…sort of hit me there. I have kind of a weird relationship with death. A lot of people I cared about died, so I just…don’t care all that much. Except sometimes I think about it and it just suddenly hits me that it still matters. I don’t know, is that weird?”

 

“It’s one way of looking at things,” Dedue answered, “I have my own thoughts on death. It is difficult not to. I find it easier to devote myself to a cause than to dwell though.”

 

“Yeah, I get that.”

 

Ahead of them, Dimitri struggled not to join in their conversation. He had no place in it, not when he was so directly haunted by the dead. The voices almost felt louder since the mission was given, rising in indignant fury as he found himself wondering, not for the first time, if the Empire really might have been behind the Tragedy…

 

Though he wouldn’t have a chance to address that concern as he found himself blinking in mild surprise at the sight of a completely empty classroom. “...Er…This is the Black Eagle’s classroom?”

 

“Huh? Oh, hey, did we get lost?” Why did Shez sound happy about that?

 

“Why do you sound happy about that?” Why did he ask that…

 

“Well it shows it’s not just me who gets lost in this huge place!” Shez replied, smiling brightly as Dedue peered past Dimitri into the classroom.

 

“The banners along the walls are Adrestian. This is the Black Eagle’s classroom.” He decided not to mention it should be impossible to get lost on the way to the classroom in question, given that it was right next to theirs.

 

“Aw! And here I thought I found a kindred spirit,” Shez grumbled.

 

“Ah…I’m sorry for disappointing you?” Dimitri apologized.

 

“Nah, it’s fine. Still, where’d they go? Class should still be in session, right?”

 

"Perhaps professor Eisner took her class somewhere? She might be leading them in a training exercise…" 

 

"Would they have left all their belongings if that was the case?" Dedue pointed out, noting how all their textbooks and such had been left on their desks. 

 

"Was there an emergency?" Dimitri asked, though he doubted there was. Sure, the classroom walls and doors were thick, but surely they would have heard if something was occurring… 

 

"Emergency!" Looking over, the three saw Caspar running around the corner, and nearly crashing into them as he did. "H-Hey, outta the way, I need to get Professor Manuela!" 

 

"Caspar? What happened?"

 

"Professor Byleth and Jeritza are beating each other up at the training grounds! Now outta the way so I can go get Manuela!" 

 

"What? Dedue, go with him for pro–Shez?" Rushing off before Dimitri could finish speaking, Shez ran toward the training grounds. And it seemed the Black Eagles were there, about five of the students in a crowd watching a fight go down. 

 

"Professor, Jeritza, stand down! This spar is going too far!" Edelgard shouted with a look of genuine concern. Which was reasonable, given the professor and the combat instructor were currently beating the ever-living hell out of one another.

 

A pair of wooden swords laid discarded and broken on the ground nearby as a brutal blow to the jaw drew blood from a smiling Jeritza, a look of pure glee on what could be seen of the masked instructor’s face. He barely wavered, instead responding with a vicious hook that made Byleth’s head snap to the side, a sight that made Shez flinch, an unintentional noise of genuine distress slipping out that was covered by Byleth screaming in rage and outright tackling Jeritza, bringing him down to the ground and raising her fist to cave his skull in right before a sudden deluge of cold frost rained down on her, sending a shock through her mind and snapping her out of her fury.

 

“Gh…ah…sorry,” she muttered down to Jeritza, who blinked up at her, his crazed grin still in place before it seemed to twitch.

 

“...Ah, so you’re not going to continue then,” he murmured, before frowning up at her, “Would you mind getting off of me? I feel this may get awkward for both of us otherwise.”

 

“Oh, right.” Byleth stood up, brushing some frost from her hair with a sigh. “Sorry Shez–...”

 

Byleth stared at her students. Her students stared back. So did Shez, who let her hand lower with a sigh of relief, and Dimitri, who was staring with an indescribable look on his face.

 

“...” Byleth cleared her throat, her face reddening as ducked her head. “...I believe I said you all had a free period.”

 

“...I…think I can speak for everyone when I say we were curious about what you had planned, professor,” Ferdinand spoke up.

 

“...Professor, is this about Lonato?” Dorothea asked, prompting a flinch from Byleth that made the songstress’s expression turn from horror to sympathy.

 

“...” Byleth took a slow breath. “Class dismissed.”

 

“But, professor–”

 

“Class dismissed. I am in a compromised emotional state that has left me unfit for teaching. Class is dismissed.”

 

Dorothea looked to Shez, who gave her an awkward smile back. “I’ll, uh…yeah, it’s fine, we’ll talk. Catch up with you later?”

 

“...Alright.” She nodded before glancing at Ferdinand and Petra. “Come along Ferdie, Petra. We should leave things here.”

 

“Huh? Ah, yes, I suppose–Oh, wait, but what about her highness–Ah!”

 

“Now, Ferdie,” Dorothea insisted while pulling him along by the arm. Petra, meanwhile, studied her professor for a moment before nodding.

 

“You have much rage, Professor. I have understanding of that sensation. We should be talking later.” 

 

“...Alright.” 

 

Her piece said, she walked off, leaving the professor with two house leaders, her sister, and Hubert, who was doing a pretty good job of being his usual looming self.

 

“So, uh…” Shez glanced at her house leader, then at her sister’s house leader, then over at her sister. “...Who wants to go first?”

 

“What was that?” Edelgard asked, deciding she should be first.

 

“...I have anger issues,” Byleth stated, which made Hubert snort.

 

“That much is obvious.”

 

Edelgard gave him an annoyed look before marching up to her professor. “You know what I mean! You nearly beat Jeritza to death! Why?!”

 

Byleth grimaced, then paused as she heard Jeritza mutter “if only” under his breath. She decided not to address that at the moment, because…yeah, that was something. “...I wanted to work out my aggression by sparring with Jeritza. I lost my temper. I am…feeling that aggression because I was there when Lord Lonato received the news that his son had been murdered–...When his son had been executed.”

 

“You’re not telling me everything,” Edelgard stated, frowning up at her teacher.

 

“Edelgard!” Dimitri cut in, “Please, Professor Eisner is clearly distressed! You can’t just hound her for answers!”

 

She glared back at her fellow house leader, then looked back up at Byleth. “...I expect answers later then. It matters to me if your ‘emotional state’ is ‘compromised’.”

 

“Okay. Later then.”

 

Edelgard didn’t look pleased, but she left with Hubert in tow, the dark-haired boy taking a moment to regard the two sisters with open interest before he left. 

 

Dimitri sighed, scratching at his head. “I don’t know how she can be so…Never mind. Are you okay, professor?”

 

“I’m fine.” She frowned. “Why are you here?”

 

“Ah…it’s nothing. Er, we can speak later. My apologies for bothering you.”

 

Byleth furrowed her brows as he left, before looking at Shez, who tried to smile back at her. “...Need a hug?”

 

“...Please.”

 

The sisters took a moment to hold each other tight, before Shez frowned down at her shorter, older sister. “Is it just about Lonato? I’m sure you would get mad about that, but you looked ready to kill the masked guy over there.”

 

“...Did you forget his name?”

 

“What? No, no, he’s…” She heard it just a little bit ago, what was it– “Jeritza!”

 

“Yes?” the masked man in question asked, glancing up from where he was picking up the broken equipment.

 

“Oh, nothing, I was just asking my sister why she tried to kill you.”

 

“Ah. If you learn the specific reason, please inform me. I would not mind doing this again sometime.”

 

Shez blinked. “Uh…Wait, are you asking her out?”

 

“No. I just want to fight her again.”

 

“Oh, okay. No offense, I just don’t think you’re her type.”

 

Byleth poked her sister, making her jolt with an indignant noise. “Stop trying to influence my love life.”

 

“Mn–Well I’m not wrong, am I? Does he look like your type?”

 

“I don’t have a type.”

 

“Really? Like, no preferences at all?”

 

“I feel like I should not be present for this conversation,” Jeritza stated, before doing the reasonable thing and just walking off with a slight awkwardness in his step, his busted lip still dripping blood.

 

“Ah, I should have healed him,” Byleth realized.

 

“Ehh…I think he’ll be good. Now c’mon, what’s up? The only person I think ever provoked you into trying to kill them like that was…” Shez trailed off as she noticed a dark expression crossing her sister’s face. “...Oh. She’s back at the monastery, huh?”

 

“Yes. Thunder Catherine.” The only person Byleth ever genuinely hated.

 

“Ah…yeah, that’s going to be–”

 

“EDELGARD! I CAN’T FIND MANUELA, SHE WASN’T AT–Huh?” Caspar blinked, staring in confusion at the much emptier training area. “Uh…hold on, where’d everybody go?”

 

“Uh…I guess off to do their own stuff?” Shez offered, before giving Caspar a confused look, “What took you so long anyway?”

 

“Well I was trying to find Manuela, but she’s not in the infirmary! I couldn’t find her at all!”

 

“...Caspar, I think she’s teaching her class right now,” Byleth said.

 

“Oh. Ohhh…Yeah, that would make sense. Huh.” He shrugged. “Well, is everything okay here?”

 

Byleth glanced at her sister, then shrugged. “We’re good.”

 

Shez frowned a little, but… “Yeah, we’re all good here! Thanks for trying!”

 

“Oh, no problem! I’m glad it wasn’t something serious!”

 

Shez glanced at the bruise forming on her sister’s cheek. “Yeah…nothing serious.”

Chapter End Notes

Indi: You know I wonder who remembered what was coming up after the first mission

Red: I'm sure plenty of people did, though I wonder if anyone guessed the Lions might have a problem with it.

Indi: Political tensions be around and all. Course Byleth is dealing with her own anger issues.

Red: Yeah, this isn't going to be a good time for anybody.

Indi: Yuuuup. But well, it'll need to be dealt with eventually.

Red: Let's just hope Byleth can get her anger issues out in a positive, healthy way, that doesn't involve enormous amounts of pain for all involved or any further issues being developed for her.

Indi: I guess we'll see if she does!

Recuperation

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

After making sure her sister had healed herself up, and was properly laying down in bed before she left, Shez was off to do the one thing that seemed like the best course of action. That was to, of course, talk to her dad. 

 

"Hey dad, you better not be busy!" she shouted, walking into his office, catching him off guard since he was reading some reports.

 

"Mind telling me why you're coming in so loudly?" 

 

"Byleth and Jeritza almost killed each other cause Byleth met Catherine."

 

"What!?" Pushing himself up out of his seat, Jeralt nearly charged off before Shez stopped him. 

 

"It's…well it's not okay, but they're not fighting anymore and I made sure Byleth was in her room before coming here." 

 

"..." Letting out a heavy sigh, Jeralt collapsed into his chair. "That damn Rhea…if I had known she was assigning Catherine to this mission, I would have fought harder to make sure Byleth wasn’t given it…”

 

"Speaking of, why exactly are students having to deal with a rebellion? I'm not the best at politics, but it seems like a bad idea based on how the Blue Lions are acting." 

 

"Technically, the students are only part of the rear guard, so they shouldn't have to deal with any fighting. Aside from that, Rhea is using this as a way to teach the students not to turn against the church." 

 

"So she's just showing off how strong her knights are?" Shez asked, feeling disgusted. 

 

"Try not to say that so loudly. Last thing we need is to piss someone off," Jeralt said, sighing again. "But that's pretty much it." 

 

"Ugh…this place continues to be great…just make sure to check on Byleth later, okay?" 

 

"I will. Thanks for telling me," Jeralt thanked as he rubbed his head, feeling his age again. "I'll see what I can do with the upcoming mission, okay?" 

 

"Yeah, thanks." Leaving with a frown, Shez couldn't help but feel restless as she began to make her way down. 

 

"I must say, I knew your sister was not fond of that knight, but I didn't think this would happen." 

 

"Not now, Arval." 

 

"Do not misunderstand me, partner. While I may not like your sister, even I do not wish to see her like this. It may be your destiny to defeat her, but there is nothing to gain from defeating the downtrodden." 

 

"...thanks?" 

 

"Do not mention it. Also, that Riegan child is waiting for you." 

 

"Huh?" Blinking, Shez saw Claude was indeed at the bottom of the stairs. 

 

"Hey there, Shez. Heard there was a scuffle?" 

 

"Not up for any banter right now, Claude." 

 

"I get it, something bad happened so you're not in the best of moods. But as your friend, I want to check up on you. From what it sounds it was fairly serious." 

 

"It is." 

 

"Hm…how about we head somewhere else so we can talk?" Claude said, before gesturing to her to follow him. "Come on, it'll do you good to have someone to talk to." 

 

Huffing, Shez followed behind him, with the two ending up in the greenhouse, currently devoid of students or gardeners. 

 

"So, mind telling me what happened?" Claude asked.

 

“...Ah, well…I don’t remember if I’ve explained this to you yet, but basically a few years ago, my family and I worked for this guy called Lord Lonato, the same one the new mission is about. He’s also Ashe’s adoptive dad, and…well, some of the Knights of Seiros came by his place, I guess looking for evidence. By had a run in with them and…I wouldn’t say she hates all of them or anything, but they put her on edge.”

 

“Hm…She must have really liked Lonato then. Or his son?”

 

“Ahh…I can’t really speak for Byleth.” Shez shrugged. “I wasn’t there for it, she kind of just…ran ahead of me and into trouble. It was scary, but she was alive afterwards, so that’s all that matters.”

 

Claude nodded, looking thoughtful. “Well, it’s good to know what set her off…unless there’s more?”

 

“...You’re kind of nosy, you know that?”

 

He just grinned. “I’ve been told that before, sure. Sorry, it’s just interesting. The rumor mill is working overtime since the news spread that the newest professor and the combat instructor apparently fought until their weapons broke and then started punching each other. It’s almost like something out of a story, you know?”

 

“It’s not nearly as cool when it’s your own sister involved…” Shez muttered, glancing away from him.

 

“...Yeah, I can understand that. Kind of wish I had siblings like how you have Byleth. Having someone in your corner like that…anyway, it’s not all fun. I actually had a few of my classmates wanting to pass along well wishes to Teach. Leonie and Marianne both wanted me to say they hope she’s okay if I ran into you first, and Lysithea even asked me to check up on you.”

 

Shez sighed. “Not that I don’t appreciate the concern, but could you pass along to Lysithea that I’m not completely helpless? I know I get lost easily but that doesn’t mean I’m hopeless.”

 

“Hey, all I said is that she’s worried. As for whether she thinks you’re actually completely incompetent or not, I can’t say, but I’m willing to bet it’s the latter.”

 

“...So she does think I’m competent?”

 

“Maybe! Ask her yourself. I think she had fun spending time with you today, so why not?”

 

“She did? Huh. Bit of a surprise to hear." 

 

"Well she didn't seem as annoyed as she usually is when mentioning why she was late, so there's that." 

 

"Oh what's this, a secret rendezvous in the greenhouse?" A voice Shez didn't recognize caught their attention as the two looked over to see a tanned blond walking into the greenhouse. "Didn't think I'd stumble onto one of these so early into the year."

 

"Huh?" 

 

"Hm…" Glancing over, Shez could see Claude studying her for a moment. "Well, she is attractive, though maybe a bit too brash for my tastes." 

 

"...Shut up Claude," Shez said with a sigh. 

 

"Hey, just giving my own thoughts." 

 

"Ha, well if you two do decide to have a rendezvous in the future, I'm gonna warn you, the greenhouse isn't the place for it. People get mad if you accidentally step on any of the plants," the knight said, which, right, she was a knight. "Ah, but if you don't mind me asking, mind telling me if you know where Professor Eisner is?" 

 

"...why are you asking?" 

 

"I was hoping to have a spar with her, went by her classroom but it was empty, and some students said she dismissed class early?" 

 

"...She's not feeling well, so she's getting some rest." 

 

"Ah, damn it. Was hoping to face off against her. Oh well, I have plenty of time to do so." 

 

"We'll make sure to pass on the message, Thunder Catherine." 

 

"Yeah, I'll-...wait, did you say Catherine?" Shez asked, getting Claude to quirk an eyebrow. 

 

"That I am, Holy Knight Catherine, and if you're in the Black Eagles class, we'll be working together at the end of the month." 

 

"...I'm in the Blue Lions." 

 

"Oh, cool, that was my house back when I was at the academy!" 

 

"...Right, Claude, we can talk later," Shez said, before heading out of the greenhouse, brushing past Catherine without a word to her. 

 

"...Did I interrupt something important?" 

"Professor, are you awake?" Byleth’s eyes slowly opened as she heard someone knocking on her door. As she got up, she felt a twinge of pain in her jaw and realized she didn’t properly heal herself after her fight with Jeritza. 

 

"Professor it is nearly no– oh, hello" Edelgard cut herself off as the door opened, showing a disheveled looking Byleth. 

 

"Hello, Edelgard." 

 

"...Professor, are you aware that classes have already started for today?" 

 

"Oh, sorry, let me get ready," Byleth said, about to close her door so she could make herself look at least a bit presentable before class. Though before she could, Edelgard stopped her. 

 

"I already took the liberty of telling everyone to have a free study day. That and I have a feeling you may still be emotionally compromised, as you put it."

 

"I'm doing better, I can teach-" 

 

"Professor, as your student, I do not think it would be wise for you to teach today. Especially if something were to happen to cause you to slip into a state of anger again." 

 

"I…" No, Byleth couldn't say that wouldn't happen, especially with the mission this month and who'd she be working with… 

 

"See, professor? Your thoughts alone are working you up." 

 

"...Okay, classes can be self-study for today. Did you need anything else?" 

 

"Yes actually. I was hoping you'd indulge me in a request." 

 

"What would that be?" Byleth asked as she saw Edelgard give her a small smile. 

 

"Would you care to join me for tea?" 

Chapter End Notes

Red: Short one this time! Mostly just the aftermath of last time and some set up for next time.

Indi: What exactly happens next time? Why tea time of course, though what happens after that is a mystery~

Red: A mystery~ Also, say hi to Catherine everybody! Been quite a few years in story since our characters have seen her.

Indi: I'm sure everyone is happy to see Catherine.

Clearing the Air

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

“Huh. The tea tastes different,” Byleth noted after taking a sip, her head tilted curiously at the teacup in her hand, its sides covered in small red flower designs.

 

Edelgard tried not to laugh, though she did let a smile show. “I imagine it would, professor. This is Bergamot. It’s a more citrusy blend compared to the sweeter tea Mercedes and Annette were having.”

 

“Huh…What do you prefer?”

 

“In general? I suppose I prefer stronger flavors. Bergamot and the Hresvelg Blend are my favorites, though I will admit, it feels a little egotistical to call my family’s particular blend my favorite.”

 

“I don’t think there’s anything wrong with that. Did you grow up drinking it?”

 

“...My elder sister introduced me to it. Perhaps that accounts for some of it. She passed away, so I suppose I associate it with…happier memories.”

 

“Right, I heard about that.”

 

Edelgard paused. “You did?”

 

“Mm hm. I mentioned we were in Enbarr a few years ago, right? I remember Victor being upset because he heard the princes and princesses all got sick." Edelgard had a slight  frown at that. "He was really mad at that Duke Aegir person because of it, though he didn’t really like the duke to begin with.”

 

“Hm…And Victor would be a member of your father’s mercenaries?”

 

“Right, I should have mentioned. Do you want me to introduce you two? He’s in town right now with the others.”

 

“Perhaps another time. I am a little curious as to why he holds such strong opinions towards matters regarding the Empire though.”

 

“That’s because he came from the Empire. From Hrym specifically, so he doesn’t like Duke Aegir because of what happened to Hrym, and he doesn’t like him even more because of how he led the Insurrection.”

 

“Ah…I suppose it didn’t occur to me that a mercenary would…Hm.”

 

Byleth watched Edelgard think for a moment, then took another sip of her tea. There was a citrus taste to it, though she couldn’t really place what fruit it tasted the most like… “Mm. I think part of it is that Victor likes kids, so he didn’t like imagining what happened. Ezra, another mercenary, calls him a ‘soft heart in the body of a brute’.”

 

Edelgard’s lips twitched in sudden amusement. “They sound like quite the characters. Though we should probably get back on topic.”

 

“About the tea?”

 

“No, not about the tea. About you, professor.” Edelgard settled back. “We need to discuss your anger issues.”

 

“...I guess we do, yeah.” Byleth took another sip of her tea, taking note that the warmth was pretty relaxing. Combined with the nice setting and the small pastries that were available, it was pretty obvious that the princess was trying to get her relaxed for this talk. It wasn’t a bad move and she could appreciate the gesture. “What do you want to talk about then?”

 

“I would like to hear, in your own words, where this aggression comes from.”

 

“Okay. I told you about Lonato. I didn’t mention that the Knights of Seiros came to his house and started ransacking it so they could find evidence of his son’s ‘treason’.”

 

“You don’t believe it was treason.”

 

“I don’t. I don’t know why the church killed him, but I think they lied about the reason.”

 

“I understand. What happened with the knights?”

 

“I found one named Gael keeping Lord Lonato and his children, the two youngest, in one room. Lonato was my employer and I didn’t know who the knights were, so I drew my sword and told him to let the lord go.” She took a slow breath, trying to soothe the fire in her body before it could grow. “I realize that it was foolish of me, in hindsight. He was a grown man and I was still short at sixteen. He was in full plate and I wasn’t dressed for battle. It didn’t matter, because I was supposed to keep Lonato and his kids safe since he was the client.

 

“Thinking back…I know Gael didn’t want to actually hurt anyone. He told off another knight for trying to attack me, and I think he was trying to get me out of the house and away from the other knights so they wouldn’t try to kill me. It’s hard to tell though. We were negotiating, in a sense, when…” She took another breath and loosened her grip on the teacup so she wouldn’t break it. “Thunder Catherine smashed her shield into me. She also disarmed me of my sword. It happened quickly, and she held me at sword point. I think she was going to kill me. She was willing to and protested when Gael told her to leave me alone.

 

“Then Lonato saw her and called her a murderer because he realized she killed his son. I don’t know exactly what happened, but he was sure of it and she reacted like she did. So I don’t know why she was there. The only thing I could think of was that she wanted to hurt him further. To mock him with his son’s death, maybe. I don’t know if that’s true, and I can’t be sure. Not unless I actually interact with her, and I don’t…think that would be a good idea.”

 

“Why not?” Edelgard asked, and Byleth blinked at the immediate response.

 

“...Because I think I would try to kill her.”

 

“Hm. Are your emotions really that out of control? I find that hard to believe, given how you usually are.”

 

“Yeah, I know. I’m…I don’t know why I’m like this. Emotions are difficult for me. I can tell what other people are feeling, I’m not oblivious, it’s just that my own emotions don’t come up easily. Everything is…muted. It helps to look at Shez and see how she feels about things to understand how I’m supposed to react, but I just don’t feel things strongly. Except for anger, apparently.”

 

“Hm…Was that time with Lonato and Catherine the first time you felt anger that extreme?”

 

“Yeah.”

 

"And have you felt it since?" 

 

"No, I… there are times where I feel irritated, it gets easy to slip into that feeling. But I thought I had a handle on those emotions." She let out a sigh. "Guess I was wrong." 

 

"Hm… Professor, this might just be my assumption, but it seems that the problem doesn't just stem from your anger, but the rest of your emotions being unable to balance you. It is easy to focus on one thing, unintentionally or not, if it seems that much bigger than the rest."  

 

"...So am I just supposed to live with this then?" Byleth asked as she stared at the tea.

 

"..." Staring at the mercenary before her, Edelgard remained silent. It was…different seeing her like this. From the stoic mercenary, to one full of anger and now to one who looked so very vulnerable. She hadn’t known the professor for long, but it felt wrong for her to be like this. 

 

Edelgard let out a small sigh as she prepared herself. "In the past, there was someone who hurt me deeply. I hated him more than I ever thought I could hate someone else. And then one day, he died." Seeing the cup in her hands trembling, she set it down. "In the moment, I felt relieved that he was finally gone. Yet afterwards…despite what I felt, I realized I would never find closure.

 

"I may be unable to understand your anger, but I can say this much. If you don't face your problems, you will never be able to grow past them." 

 

“...” Byleth slowly nodded. “You’re right. Thank you.”

 

“You don’t need to thank me. Just resolve your issue. I’m getting tired of all these ‘free study’ periods.”

 

“Right, I need to rethink my lesson plan. We’re behind now. Hm…I’ll think about it later. For now, do you know where Catherine is?”

 

“...I’m not sure why you think I would.”

 

“Oh, alright. I assumed you would. You seem well-informed.” She glanced over to the bushes. “Hubert, do you know where Catherine is right now?”

 

“...” There was a faint noise like an aggrieved sigh, before Hubert stepped out from his cover with a faint frown. “You knew I was there the whole time.”

 

“Yeah. I live with Shez. I need to keep situationally aware because she doesn’t.”

 

That prompted a slight smile. “Well, that I can fully understand.”

 

“...I resent whatever implication you are making there, Hubert,” Edelgard chided.

 

“I didn’t mean you, your highness. Regardless, you should be able to find Thunder Catherine at the Knight’s Hall. She appears to spend most of her time either there or at the training yard.”

 

“Understood. Thank you, Hubert. And thank you for the tea and advice, Edelgard,” Byleth said as she stood.

 

“You’re welcome, professor,” Edelgard replied, “Would you like to do this again sometime?”

 

Byleth blinked, a brief look of surprise crossing her face before she nodded. “Sure. Just ask me whenever and I’ll be up for it.”

 

Edelgard smiled and waved off the professor, watching her leave before she glanced up at Hubert. “That went well.”

 

“I suppose. I didn’t realize I’d been so obvious though.”

 

“I think it wasn’t obviousness on your part so much as skill on hers. And she is quite skilled. Not to mention driven, thoughtful, and loyal.”

 

“And she has a grudge against the knights. You know, you could have allowed that grudge to fester instead of resolving it. It would have made for a decent lever to push her with.”

 

“I don’t need someone blinded by rage on my side, Hubert. You saw how she was with Jeritza. That type of fury would make her a liability.”

 

“True enough, I suppose. Jeritza on his own can already be quite the handful." 

 

"Yes, well I suppose we should go back and tell the others that she'll be teaching again on Monday." 

 

"She is quite the lucky one to not have to worry about Sundays," Hubert mused as he followed behind his liege to the classrooms. It seemed the rest of the class was just as restless as the professor was as when they arrived they found none of them studying, and in fact several coming up to her. 

 

"Hey, Edie, is everything okay with the professor?" Dorothea asked, concern evident on her face 

 

"Yeah, she's not still hurt cause I wasn't able to find Manuela yesterday, right?" A small bit of guilt was evident in Caspar’s voice. A curious change from his usual boisterousness. 

 

"She's doing fine,” Edelgard reassured, “The professor is simply attending to personal matters for today, but she can get back to teaching on Monday." 

 

"May I be offering that we do something for her?" Petra asked, equally worried for their teacher. 

 

"Yes, I would hate for our professor to end up like that again. Perhaps we should ask her if she needs assistance with anything when she gets back?" Ferdinand mused.

 

"We'll have to wait and see when she returns," Edelgard said, heading to her seat. "For now, let's just make sure we don't get too far behind."

 

"U-u-um… the professor isn't m-mad at us, r-right?" Bernadetta managed to squeak out, before trying to sink into her chair as Edelgard looked over at her. 

 

"I think we would be hard pressed to make her mad at us." 

 

"Her sister on the other hand, not so much," Lindhart cut in, getting Bernadetta to squeak. "She was quite offended that I asked for a lock of the Professor's hair to study." 

 

"...Lin, that sounds weird,” Dorothea pointed out. 

 

"The professor didn't think so. She cut off some of her hair there and then for me." 

 

"...I shouldn't have to say this, but don't ask the professor for her hair," Edelgard muttered, getting no response from him as he focused on his book. 

 

"...Well, speaking of hair, I did want to ask you something, Edie," Dorothea said. 

 

"And that would be?" 

 

"Well, you know how I asked if you would go into town with me? Do you think we should ask the professor to go with us? It feels like I should make it up to her after how we were last month." 

 

"And what exactly does that have to do with hair?" 

 

"The place I wanted to go to is a hairstylist! And they apparently have some cute accessories too, and, well, no offense to the professor, but she definitely seems like the type to need help when it comes to fixing up her hair." 

 

The professor’s hair did tend to be quite loose and messy… “Very well then. I’m sure the professor wouldn’t mind being invited along.”

 

“Yes! Aw, you’re the best, Edie!”

 

Edelgard smiled at the praise, even as she couldn’t help but wonder what Dorothea would think of her if she knew just how many dark deeds she had already committed. And how many more she was planning to commit…

Catherine, wielder of the Thunderbrand and Holy Knight of Seiros, didn’t usually have a lot of downtime. She normally had duties to attend to or tasks to handle that would keep her busy for weeks or even months at a time, so just being back at the monastery without anything to do until the next mission was making her restless. She never liked sitting still, ever since she had to sit through tea parties as a little noble girl needing to learn etiquette. 

 

It didn’t help that the mission coming up for her was…a complicated one.

 

She let out a slow sigh as she stared up at the ceiling, laying back on a couch in the lounge. One leg was propped up on her knee and her arms rested behind her head, forming a sort of pillow as she just… She believed in Lady Rhea, more than anything. She still saw Lonato’s face in her mind though, perfectly recalling the moment when he realized she was the one who sold out Christophe.

 

She should have listened to Captain Gael and stayed away, but–

 

“Thunder Catherine.” Oh? That was a new voice.

 

Catherine glanced over at the woman standing beside the couch, taking note of her teal hair and cobalt eyes, before she shifted to sitting up in one swift motion, her feet on the floor as she raised an eyebrow at the woman wearing a gray coat over a black and pink top. “Yeah? If you’re looking for me, you found me.”

 

“I heard you were looking for me.”

 

“...Oh! Yeah, that’s right! You must be the new professor then!” She grinned as she pushed herself up from the couch, her grin getting wider when she noticed the new professor was shorter than her. “So you’re the one everybody’s been talking about! Heh, I must’ve missed you earlier, I was planning to introduce myself after you got the mission from Lady Rhea.”

 

The woman just nodded. “Is it Thunder Catherine or Dame Catherine? I don’t want to be impolite.”

 

“...Not exactly what I expected you to say, but alright. Thunder Catherine isn’t really a proper title, but I like it better than ‘Dame’. You can just call me Catherine though, I don’t need a title.”

 

“Understood.” Wow, this girl had a really dull voice. It was hard to tell if she was just like this naturally, or if she was holding herself back for some reason. 

 

“You know you don’t need to be so stiff around me, right? I’m just interested in the new professor everybody is talking about.” She let her smirk get a bit sharper. “I want to know why Lady Rhea seems to think you deserve special treatment. I can’t really see why, considering you don’t seem to be anything more than a skilled mercenary, and I’ve seen better than you before.”

 

“...Four years ago, my father was employed by Lord Lonato of House Gaspard. I worked for him too,” the woman said in the same completely flat tone even as Catherine’s eyes widened, “I attempted to defend him from the knights I saw ransacking his house, and you blindsided me before holding me at swordpoint and threatening to kill me.”

 

“...Huh.” Now that Catherine looked, really looked, she could see the resemblance between the girl she encountered then and the woman that was facing her now. She worked her jaw, thinking about the kid that stared up at her back then. The hair and eyes were the same. “...Guess the Goddess does work in strange ways. Do we have a problem?”

 

“I have a problem with you, yes.”

 

“Uh huh. It seemed like it. You’re being pretty stiff there, professor.” Catherine grinned, though the smile didn’t reach her eyes this time. “If you joined up looking for vengeance, I have to say, I admire your commitment.”

 

The woman shook her head, her eyes never leaving Catherine’s. “I never wanted to come here. Lady Rhea insisted. She also insisted I teach. I don’t mind that. It’s been tricky, but not too bad so far. I don’t mind the other knights either, so you don’t have to worry about that.”

 

“Who said I’m worried?”

 

“My name is Byleth Eisner. You didn’t ask for it. That’s rude.”

 

“...Heh. Well you did distract me with this talk about you holding a grudge. So, Eisner, what should I expect here? Are you going to sabotage the mission against Lonato?”

 

“No. A mission is a mission.”

 

Catherine frowned, staring into the other woman’s eyes. “...You really mean that, huh? Well, aren't you heartless.”

 

That broke through whatever calm facade Eisner was trying to put up. And while she wouldn’t admit it outloud, Catherine felt a jolt up her spine at the sudden, hate-filled glare the professor gave her. She’d been on the receiving end of a lot of glares in her life, the worst probably being Lonato’s on that fateful day, but even that paled in comparison to the sheer murderous rage in Byleth’s gaze.

 

This woman genuinely wanted her dead.

 

Then it was gone in an instant as the professor regarded her with a calm that had to be forced. “...You wanted a spar, right?”

 

“...I was asking for one, sure. Though I’m not sure I should go for one when you look like you want to tear my head off with your bare hands.”

 

“I think that’s a very good reason why we should have a spar. I have issues with anger where you are concerned and I almost killed a coworker because of it. I would like to work things out in a controlled environment so I won’t do that again.”

 

It was hard to tell if that was meant to be a threat or if Eisner honestly believed she’d be less agitated after a spar. Catherine had her doubts, because anger like that didn’t just disappear after one fight, but… “Alright, if you insist. Just don’t think I’ll let you kill me.”

 

“I wasn’t planning to.”

 

Catherine huffed in some amusement, but kept her eyes on the shorter woman as she led the way towards the training yard. “I’m surprised you’re letting me follow behind you. Wouldn’t you want to keep your enemy in sight?”

 

“You’re a knight. You’re not supposed to be cowardly enough to attack an unaware opponent.”

 

Her grin twitched. “You know, most people raising a blade towards a Knight of Seiros would have been put to death for it.”

 

“I’m aware. I wasn’t then, but I am now.”

 

“So what’s this supposed to be then?”

 

“It’s what I said. I want to fight you to work off this anger.”

 

“You can’t expect me to believe that.”

 

Eisner stopped and looked back at her. “Catherine, I need to do this. Either I fight you in a controlled environment, or I allow this feeling to fester and risk losing control of myself at a moment that could harm my students or my family. I would prefer the former over the latter.”

 

“And how’s fighting me going to help? Is this really just to blow off steam?”

 

“Yes. It will help. Please accommodate my needs at this time. We are both working for the monastery, so I would prefer our relationship be cordial.”

 

“But that’s just it. This is just a job to you, isn’t it? You don’t have any real loyalty to the Church or to Lady Rhea.”

 

“...I don’t want to talk to you, Catherine. I want to fight you. Let’s do that at the training yard, in a spar.”

 

“And what if I wanted to fight you here and now?” she asked, placing her hand on the hilt of her sword.

 

“That’s a stupid idea. We’re in the middle of the monastery and there are staff and students around.”

 

“I think I could finish things without getting any of them hurt.”

 

Byleth stared at Catherine. “...I see.”

 

Then she turned and started walking for the training field again. 

 

Catherine frowned as the woman turned her back on her. She could easily pull Thunderbrand free and cut down the potential threat in front of her…but, then, an honorable knight didn’t strike down an unaware opponent.

 

“Cheeky bitch,” Catherine muttered under her breath as she followed the new professor the rest of the way. 

 

“Hello Professor Byleth,” greeted Jeritza as the two arrived, and Catherine couldn’t help but stare at the combat instructor actually greeting someone politely, “Have you come by for another spar?”

 

“Hello Jeritza. I have, but I was planning to spar with Catherine this time. Can we use the field?”

 

Jeritza glanced at Catherine. The tall, thin guy stared, as though sizing her up, before apparently disregarding her in favor of looking back at Byleth. “Are you certain? I would be a better opponent for your needs.”

 

“...” Catherine wasn’t sure if she should be offended. And was a little confused by what was going on here.

 

“...No thank you. I would prefer to spar with Catherine.”

 

“Hm. Perhaps later then? I did enjoy our previous time together.” Okay, now Catherine wasn’t sure if “sparring” was supposed to be a euphemism or not.

 

“Maybe? I’m just going to fight Catherine for now though. Thanks for the offer.”

 

“Very well. I am here if you change your mind,” he said, before walking off.

 

“...Are you okay?” Catherine asked once he was far enough away, “He seemed kind of pushy there.”

 

Byleth blinked at her. “...Uh…Yes, I’m fine. Jeritza’s okay. I don’t mind him.”
