“You sure? That just seemed…” Catherine trailed off, remembering who Byleth happened to be. Though…still. “I’m just saying, if he seems like he’s coming on too strong…”

 

“Huh. Yeah, okay.” She regarded Catherine with an odd look, one that was hard to discern with her dull gaze. “Jeritza was the one I almost killed. I’m not sure why he wants to spar again after that.” She looked over at the instructor, then shrugged. “I don’t think it’s my place to say. We should get our swords ready.”

 

“...Yeah, alright.” And soon enough, Catherine was facing off against the newest professor, her hands on the dulled broadsword in her grip. 

 

Eisner stood across from her, one hand on her own sword, her other hand free. It wasn’t a duellist’s pose, so…maybe she left the other hand free for casting? It was hard to be sure, but there was no unease in her stance. The woman really was practiced at this sort of thing.

 

“This is a foolish idea,” muttered Sothis in Byleth’s head, “You can’t be sure you’ll really hold back in a fight, not with this fury bubbling beneath your skin.”

 

Byleth merely took a slow breath, before nodding to Catherine, affirming that she was prepared.

 

“Ready?” Jeritza asked, acting as the referee. Not that either woman really thought he’d step in if things looked like they were escalating. Which was reasonable, because he wouldn’t. He would, however, raise his hand and lower it swiftly to start the march, as requested. “Begin.”

 

Neither swordswoman hesitated. Both rushed forward in a series of swift strikes to test the other’s mettle. There was no wavering in their steps nor their swings, and Catherine felt an unintended grin spread over her face as she gained a sense for how the other woman fought.

 

While it annoyed her to admit it, Eisner definitely was skilled. There was strength behind her blows, despite mostly keeping to one hand, and she had a strong awareness of her surroundings. The moves she made were quick and efficient as she pressed her attack, but, what was probably the most interesting part to Catherine, she wasn’t going for any cheap shots.

 

For someone who harbored a grudge against her, the professor was fighting Catherine like this genuinely was a spar. There were no sudden attacks, no aiming for her head or eyes, and the one time she suddenly thrust her hand forward as though she were going to cast, she pulled it back with a frown on her face, the motion clearly done on reflex instead of intentionally.

 

Catherine didn’t even press her advantage at that misstep, instead taking the moment to disengage and examine the other woman, who looked barely winded from their exchange. Byleth wasn’t even sweating yet, and that honestly made Catherine want to fight all the harder. 

 

“Come on, you can come at me harder than that,” she encouraged, not even caring to hide her grin.

 

“...I suppose I can,” Byleth replied, before lunging in with a sudden thrust that Catherine deflected.

 

More thrusts were soon to follow, clearly aimed at pushing Catherine back, so the knight instead stepped in close and responded with a heavy swing to knock the professor off balance. Byleth didn’t falter for long though, moving with the motion to swing hard at Catherine’s shoulder. Easy enough to block, and then it was back to exchanging blows as Catherine pressed her attack, cutting quicker and quicker.

 

The professor was good, that much was clear, but Catherine liked to think she was better. She was a genuine swordmaster, after all, and she started putting a bit more “oomph” into her swings. Faster, sharper cuts kept Byleth on the defensive, her grip on her sword adjusting to compensate before another heavy swing sent her skidding back.

 

But Catherine didn’t let up, moving straight into the professor’s guard and keeping up with her onslaught. She actually felt kind of impressed to see Byleth hold her own. Not once had Catherine’s blade actually connected with the professor’s body. She always moved out of the way just in time or brought her sword up to block, preventing any real damage to herself as the fight dragged on.

 

Even still, she wasn’t invincible, and Catherine smirked to see a bead of sweat rolling down the side of Byleth’s head. She thrusted her sword forward, deliberately overextending as her blade scraped against Byleth’s, holding it back yet leaving Catherine open if the former mercenary wanted to punch her. And, to her amusement, the professor did try to swing for her, which meant it was fully fine for Catherine to block that blow with her arm, leaving only one hand on her sword, before aiming a kick for the professor’s side.

 

Byleth’s eyes widened and she brought up her knee to block, falling for the feint and letting Catherine yank her sword back before driving it into the professor’s sternum. 

 

Maybe a little too hard, given Catherine actually knocked Byleth to the ground there. “Ah, crap, are you okay?”

 

“...Ow.” Byleth replied, laying flat on the ground. She moved her hand to her chest, massaging the spot where Catherine landed her hit. “That hurt more than I expected.”

 

“Well, a training sword is still a weapon. Just be glad it wasn’t a real one or we probably wouldn’t be talking now.”

 

“I am aware.” She lifted her head. “You’re good.”

 

“Heh. Well, not to brag, but I am one of the top Knights of Seiros for a reason.” Catherine crouched down beside the fallen professor. “So…how are you feeling now?”

 

“Better. I would have lost to you if we had fought for real years ago.”

 

“...And that thought makes you feel better?”

 

“Not that thought specifically. It’s just…Why did you go to Lonato’s?”

 

Catherine sighed. “...It’s stupid. I was stupid. I can’t say I’m much better these days, but back then, I was so stupidly sure of myself that when…Well, after what happened with Christophe, I thought I could actually make things right. I thought I could apologize and make him understand why things had to be the way they did. And I didn’t think for a second that explaining I’m the reason his son is dead would set him off. Stupid, right?”

 

“Extremely, yes.”

 

Catherine snorted, then gave Byleth a glance. “So are you just naturally that dull-voiced? Or are you still holding back some anger?”

 

“My voice is naturally like this. And I'm also holding back some anger," she responded, getting up. "I'm still angry at you for what you did, but I'm angry at myself for not being strong enough." 

 

"It was just a spar, you know." 

 

"And you would have been much stronger if you used that sword of yours," Byleth said, staring directly at Catherine. "I still have a long way to go before I can pay you back for blindsiding me."

 

"Not sure if I should take that as a threat or not." 

 

"Take it as you will." Catherine had to admit that, unintentionally or not, the young professor could get under her skin. 

 

"Are you done sparring?" Jeritza asked, coming up to the two. "Would you not want to cross blades with me again?" 

 

"Jeez, Jeritza, you really have to work on your game. Pretty sure there are better ways to flirt with someone than to just ask them to fight you." And that got both of them to stare blankly at Catherine. "...What?" 

 

"Perhaps another time," Jeritza said before leaving. 

 

"Yeah, I'll see you later Catherine," Byleth said as she left as well.

 

"Starting to think I misread that…" Granted, she also didn't really know the combat instructor that well. He tended to keep to himself so the only thing she knew was that apparently he was referred to the academy by the Prime Minister of the Empire. Still, he wasn't the main interest at the moment. 

 

She wasn't sure what to make of the new professor. She was skilled, definitely above the average merc, but even if this was a serious fight Catherine was sure she'd be able to win. Even so, there was something off about her. Nothing she had seen there had told her why Lady Rhea had hired her, but… normally Catherine was able to figure out what crest someone had, especially after a fight, yet for whatever reason, she couldn't tell anything about the professor's crest. 

 

"I'm definitely gonna have to keep an eye on her…" 

Chapter End Notes

Indi: It's really interesting seeing how many people assumed Catherine and Byleth meeting would be a bloodbath. And had this been an actual fight it definitely would have been, but because Byleth was holding back and only using a sword, she ended up losing.

Red: Yeah, as many of you have guessed, if Byleth were actually trying to kill Catherine, this fight would have gone completely differently. She's got a lot more tricks up her coat sleeves than just swordplay.

Indi: As is, that didn't happen, partially cause Catherine misread what was going on their with Jeritza and cut some of the tension, but mostly cause of Edelgard’s words.

Red: Yup! So things haven't gone completely horribly, yet. There's still Lonato coming up though.

Indi: I'm sure things will go great there, but we got plenty of time to go before we get there, including next chapter which should be a more chill one. And if you want to make sure to read it when it comes out, feel free to join the discord! https://discord.gg/T7E9sWEJsv

Red: For now though, thanks for reading!

A Day Out

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

"There you are, Professor!" Dorothea greeted the approaching blue-haired mercenary as she and Edelgard waited for her by the monastery gates. "I was starting to wonder if you weren't going to be able to show up." 

 

"Sorry, Dimitri wanted to know if he could talk with me, but I let him know I had to go to town first." 

 

"Hm… I wonder if it has to do with the mission this month…" Edelgard guessed. 

 

"Hey now, none of that, today's one of our days off, so none of that serious talk!" Dorothea cut in, before beginning to push the two out of the monastery. "You need to properly rest and relax to be at your best! Isn't that right, professor?" 

 

"Ah, yeah. Pushing yourself too far can be bad." 

 

"See? Professor’s orders that we take it easy!" Dorothea said with a smile. "Hence why we're going to a hairstylist! It’s the perfect place to sit down, relax, and share some gossip~" 

 

"What are we doing?" Byleth asked, having not actually asked before why the two had wanted her to accompany them. 

 

"Getting our hair cut and styled of course! No offense professor, but you definitely need it. It almost looks like you cut off your own hair with a dagger or something." 

 

"I do," Byleth answered completely sincerely. "Sometimes I ask Shez to do it, but I cut my hair when it's getting too long." 

 

"...Professor, you really need to take better care of your hair. After all, how are you going to charm anyone like that? Though I guess the rough and gruff type might help you charm someone." 

 

"Why are people so interested in my love life?"

 

"Excuse me, professor?" Edelgard decided to speak up, not wanting to be completely left out. 

 

"Shez keeps trying to influence it, Sylvain asked if I kissed any guys or girls, even Catherine thought Jeritza was trying to flirt with me, and then there was that time with Manuela when I found her drunk…" 

 

“Ooo! Now that’s what I meant when I mentioned gossip, that all sounds very interesting!” Dorothea cheered, before giving the professor a sideways glance, “Though, I have to ask, what exactly happened with Manuela, professor?”

 

Curiously, and to the immediate fascination of both girls with her, Byleth actually turned a little pink as she glanced to the side. “Ah…she gave me some advice about not getting with men who can’t ignore ‘a little mess’.”

 

“Oh? Is that all?” Dorothea asked, her curiosity piqued.

 

“...I think if I mention anything else, it will be embarrassing for Manuela.”

 

“Professor, the fact that you’re not mentioning anything else leaves far too much room for people to get the wrong idea,” Edelgard explained.

 

“It’s less of what she said and more the lack of clothes she had on when she said it.” Both Eagles paused at the mental image that presented, before they independently decided they would never mention that part to anyone else for the sake of Professor Manuela’s dignity. Byleth, meanwhile, continued, still faintly blushing. “She also said I was pretty, which felt nice.”

 

“Oh? Are you not used to compliments, professor?” Dorothea asked, getting her thoughts back in order quickly enough to respond.

 

“Not really. Not about my appearance, at least.”

 

“Then it makes perfect sense for us to make today about your appearance! You really are beautiful already, professor, so just think of how you’ll look after a trim! Hm, and perhaps after, we could see what makeup and clothes would work best–”

 

“Why don’t we focus on one thing at a time, Dorothea?” Edelgard suggested, noticing that Byleth looked a little overwhelmed.

 

“If you insist, Edie, though you can’t tell me you wouldn’t want to see our professor dressing up.”

 

“I have a feeling you and I have very different ideas of what it would mean to ‘dress her up’.”

 

“Why Edie, you can’t think I would try to take advantage of our poor professor! Besides, shopping for lingerie should be saved for at least the second date.”

 

“...Um…what?” Byleth asked, starting to feel…odd about this outing. Not bad, exactly, just…Hm.

 

Dorothea just giggled though, which didn’t help. “Nothing, professor~! Now come along, the stylist is just up here, and then we can get to sharing all those interesting details about the people invested in your love life~!”

 

“...” Dread was an emotion Byleth didn’t feel often, but as she saw Dorothea’s eager smile and felt Edelgard’s considering gaze, she was pretty sure that was the exact emotion she felt at the moment.

 

Then she actually sat down in the barber’s chair and it turned out to be surprisingly cozy. Having her hair brushed felt nice and brought back memories of when she was small and her dad would try his best to take care of her naturally long and messy hair. Usually to little effect, but it was the thought that counted.

 

“Soooo~?” And then Dorothea spoke up again and that feeling returned. “Come on, professor, you can’t talk about how interested people are in your love life and then not tell us anything about it!”

 

Edelgard glanced over at the two, not saying anything as she sat back for her own trim. Mostly because she was somewhat curious too, even if she wouldn’t admit it.

 

“Mm. I know you talk to Shez. You’ve probably already heard everything from her.”

 

“I’ve heard a few things, certainly, but there’s a big difference between hearing things secondhand and firsthand,” Dorothea explained with a teasing smile, “Besides, is it a bad thing that your little sister wants you to be happy?”

 

“It’s not. I like how much she cares. It’s just kind of annoying sometimes. Shez likes to push things.”

 

“I seem to recall a conversation we had where you said a push could be what someone needs,” Edelgard noted.

 

“...I did say that,” Byleth admitted, “I think there’s a difference between a professor doing it and a sister doing it though.”

 

“There certainly is, in that it is a younger sister’s prerogative to needle her elders about their love lives.”

 

“Mm.”

 

Dorothea giggled at the expression on her professor’s face, before deciding to have mercy and move along. “As for the other people interested in your love life, do feel free to slap Sylvain the next time he tries to involve himself.”

 

“Hm? Why?”

 

“Because he’s a cad, professor. An incorrigible flirt with no real care for those he tries to woo. A rake and a roustabout, as the songs say.”

 

“There are songs about Sylvain?”

 

“There are songs about the type of man he is. I imagine he tried to ask about any attraction you might have towards men as a prelude to his own advances.”

 

“Uh…No, not really. I think he was just curious.” Byleth shrugged. “He seemed fine with me being uninterested.”

 

“Really? I have to say, I find that hard to believe.”

 

She shrugged again. “It’s what happened. I remember Raphael asked him if he liked men and he said he just likes ‘pretty people’. Oh, and Sylvain offered to be my wingman before that.”

 

“Professor, that’s completely inappropriate,” Edelgard chided, “He shouldn’t be making offers like that, especially considering your position.”

 

“Oh I completely agree, Edie,” Dorothea agreed, “He would be a terrible wingman. Now, if you happened to need a wingwoman–”

 

“Dorothea!”

 

“Joking~!”

 

“Hmph.”

 

“...I still don’t know what that is,” Byleth admitted, “I even asked some of my father’s mercenaries and they didn’t have any answers.”

 

“They didn’t?” Dorothea said, looking curious, “I would think a group of hardened mercenaries would be well aware of such things.”

 

“Mm…to be specific, when I asked, Ezra just choked and started coughing, Gertrude started laughing, Victor said he’d tell me when I was older, and Candace just patted me on the head, for some reason. So I think they do know, it’s just none of them are helpful.”

 

“Hm. Would those be the officers of Jeralt’s mercenaries?” Edelgard asked.

 

“...I guess? They’re the ones that tend to be giving orders to the rest of them. I don’t think my papa–my father really assigned official ranks.”

 

“That sounds disorganized.”

 

“It usually works fine. I think other mercenary groups just have one leader directing things. It’s kind of like that with us, but…I don’t know. I know I’m going to take over when my father retires though.”

 

“Oh? You plan to inherit the family business then?” Dorothea asked.

 

“Yeah. I…Hm. I guess this professor thing does throw that plan off. I’m not sure I would put Shez in charge though. She’s good at fighting and she can lead small groups, but she’s really bad at navigation and she’s not that good at tactics. I think she’s comfortable just being a mercenary, though I know she wants to be the best she can be.”

 

“Hm…How did you and Shez meet?” Edelgard asked, “You said before that you shot her with an arrow.”

 

“Well. I hadn’t heard this story,” Dorothea said, looking at her professor with some surprise.

 

“Ah, yeah. I was hunting for food and I didn’t notice her. I was…I think thirteen at the time. I brought her back to camp because I knew my father could help with things, and then Shez just stuck around.”

 

“...Huh. And…how old was she when this happened?” Edelgard inquired.

 

“Shez said she was twelve, but my father thought she was ten. That didn’t stop her from insisting she was the same age as me or older until a month ago when Manuela pointed out she looks closer to your age than mine.” Byleth glanced at Edelgard, her expression completely serious. “She was devastated.”

 

“...I…see.”

 

Dorothea giggled. “Poor Shezzy. She really looks up to you, huh?”

 

“...Huh. I didn’t really think of it like that,” Byleth admitted, “I think it’s more that she’s competitive though.”

 

“She can’t be both? Competition and admiration don’t have to be exclusive, you know.”

 

“I guess. So, how much longer does this haircut stuff take?”

 

“Oh I’ve been done for a while,” the hairdresser admitted, “You just asked for a basic trim to clean things up. I was just letting you girls chat since you seemed invested.”

 

“Oh. Uh…well, thank you.”

 

And with that all done, Byleth was greeted with her brand new hairstyle! Which…well, was basically her usual one, it’s just her hair looked a lot straighter and smoother and some of the messier parts were cut down. “Huh. I look nice.”

 

“You certainly do!” Dorothea praised, “Ah, but before we go!”

 

Byleth blinked as Dorothea suddenly put a pink headband on her head. “...Huh. What’s this for?”

 

“I thought it would look cute on you! And it certainly does! Right Edie?”

 

Edelgard paused at being addressed, before taking note of the professor’s new accessory. “...I suppose it does go well with your hair.”

 

“Doesn’t it? And I did notice you seem to like pink from the highlights of your outfits, so why not try adding a little more color to your wardrobe?”

 

“...Yeah, okay,” Byleth agreed, idly checking herself in the nearby mirror. The headband did look cute…And it was a gift. So…why not?

 

“So, what next?” Dorothea asked, “We have the rest of the day free, don’t we?”

 

“True…I heard there was a shop for sweets. We could go there.”

 

"Sounds like a plan! What do you think, Edie?" 

 

"Well…I suppose I can indulge myself a little," Edelgard responded, not wanting to make it obvious she was excited for it. 

 

"In that case, why not indulge us about your love life on the way~? It’s only fair now that the professor has shared~." 

 

"There really isn't much to say," Edelgard admitted. "The most would be offers for an arranged marriage, not that any were accepted." 

 

"Well I suppose that's one thing you can look forward to for the year Edie~ I can see it now, the future emperor and the love she meets while at the academy, and all the trials they face together! It sounds like something out of a play, if you do say so myself~" 

 

"...Yes, I suppose it does," Edelgard quietly responded. 

 

"What about you, Dorothea?" Byleth asked as they arrived at the sweets shop. "You seem popular." 

 

"Hm~ I suppose I am, of course I haven't met anyone worth mentioning. Most of the nobles I've met are far from tolerable personality-wise and the knights I've dated are far more interested in just saying they went out with a famous diva then coming back for another date." Dorothea frowned as she spoke. "Why, I once met with one who was just trying to get tickets to the opera so he can take his actual fiance." 

 

“Wow. That’s rude.”

 

“Isn’t it? If that was all he wanted, he could have just asked instead of trying to string me along like some doe-eyed schoolgirl.”

 

Byleth frowned. “Do you want me to talk with him?”

 

“Ha! Ah, there’s no need for that, professor. I know what ‘talking’ means in this context and I assure you, you don’t need to go out of your way to get vengeance for me. People like that are annoying, but if I went out of my way to spite every idiot who wanted to get something from me, I would be spending more time plotting than I do singing.”

 

Edelgard, meanwhile, made a mental note to find out who this particular knight happened to be. She didn’t think of herself as the vengeful type, but if there was the potential for this man to be a problem down the line, well, it was only right Hubert heard of it.

 

Such thoughts could be saved for later though as the three ladies–well, technically a princess, a songstress, and a mercenary-turned-professor–headed inside the sweets shop. Moments later, the trio were seated at a table outside with a box of confectioneries between them and three bowls of sorbet, one for each of them.

 

“Mm~! Oh, this is delicious~!” Dorothea praised, “We really must visit here more often~!”

 

“Take care not to overdo it, Dorothea,” Edelgard chided, “It may be nice to go out for sweets every once in a while, but we do still have responsibilities.”

 

“Mmm, if you say so, Edie. Though I can’t help but notice you’re already half-finished with your own bowl~”

 

Edelgard reddened, before ducking her head and simply having another scoop of sorbet in lieu of responding, earning another giggle from Dorothea.

 

“Mm. Do you think I can get another?” Byleth asked, her own bowl already completely finished.

 

Dorothea couldn’t help but laugh at the sight, smiling in clear delight as Edelgard frowned. “Professor, you made a complete mess of your face again. Here–”

 

“Oh, no need.” Byleth fished a handkerchief from her coat pocket and used it to clean her face, prompting a curious look from Dorothea when she noticed the design of this particular handkerchief. Including the obvious double-headed eagle insignia on it.

 

“Professor, isn’t that Edelgard’s?”

 

“Hm? Yeah, she said I could keep it.”

 

“She did, did she?” Dorothea glanced at the future emperor with a small smile, who immediately blushed.

 

"I said she could return it later!" Edelgard said, defending herself. 

 

“Aw, how generous of you, Edie~! Oh, Professor, if you’re going up to get another bowl, would you mind getting one for Edie too?”

 

“Oh, sure. I’ll be right back. Do you want the peach one again?” Byleth asked.

 

“Er…yes, thank you, though I still have some left.”

 

“That’s fine. I’ll have the rest if you don’t finish.”

 

Dorothea giggled as the professor left, before fixing Edelgard with an amused expression. “So, going after the professor, are we~?”

 

“W-What? No! No, of course not, that was just–All I was doing was being helpful, Dorothea.”

 

“If you say so~!” she chirped, not at all believing her friend for a second and giggling as Edelgard mullishly ate her remaining sorbet. It didn’t help Edie’s case at all that she obviously sat up straighter when the professor returned.

 

"H-Hm, professor, perhaps we shouldn't be having too many sweets." 

 

"Hm? But they taste good." 

 

"Yes, but they can be unhealthy if you have too many," she said, despite also digging into the peach sorbet. 

 

"They can be?" 

 

Dorothea giggled. "Heh, let me guess professor, you haven't had sweets before." 

 

"Had some with that tea party, but never before the academy." 

 

"Well in that case, I can see why you want to enjoy yourself, but at the very least might want to be careful with the sorbet. Might end up getting a brain freeze if you aren't careful." 

 

"Brainfreeze?" 

 

"It's a head pain people can get from eating or drinking something cold." 

 

"Oh…so that's why my head hurts…" 

 

"...Perhaps we've had enough for today, professor," Edelgard said, before raising a hand out to stop Byleth from eating more, only for her to keep trying. It took both the princess and songstress to stop their professor from trying to eat more sorbet. It was certainly interesting to see how stubborn she could be over something so small…

"Hey By, there you are!" Shez shouted, making Byleth look over, blinking in surprise as she saw her sister pushing Dimitri towards her. "We need to talk to you!" 

 

"Shez, there is no need to interrupt the pro-"

 

"She's not doing anything so it's not interrupting, right, By?" Shez asked, before taking a look at her sister. "Did you cut your hair?" 

 

"Hairstylist did. Dorothea took Edelgard and I into town." Bringing her hand up, she offered a box of confectioneries to Shez. "Here, I brought some for you." 

 

"...okay I really want to know what happened, but Dimitri has to talk to you first." With that, she shoved Dimitri forward a bit. "Otherwise he'll never ask." 

 

"Ask me what?" 

 

Letting out a sigh, Dimitri faced Byleth as he stood straight. "Professor, I wanted to speak to you about the mission your class received." 

 

"...What exactly do you want to talk about?"

 

"I was wondering if it would be possible that our classes could swap missions? I understand that this is something we would need to talk about with Lady Rhea, but it is my belief that sending Empire students to deal with a lord of the Kingdom will not end well." 

 

"...I really only know what you all have told me about the issues between the Kingdom and the Empire, but I can see why you would think so. Are the rest of your classmates in agreement?" 

 

"Yeah, no one really thinks it's a good idea for your class to take it," Shez piped in, "Even Professor Hanneman said the 'optics' didn't look good. Besides, this way you don't have to work with Catherine, right?" 

 

Dimitri frowned. “Is there a problem with Lady Catherine?”

 

“A personal one,” Byleth answered, “We’re working on it.”

 

“Hm. Well, if it would be better for the two of you to avoid going on missions together, then that’s all the more reason for us to switch assignments. That is, if you would not mind?”

 

“I don’t. I’ll ask my class what they would prefer. I don’t know if it matters though. Lady Rhea is the one that assigns missions, so I assume she would have the final say.”

 

“Really? I was under the impression Seteth was the one handing them out…Hm, though I suppose he is ultimately only carrying out her wishes, correct?”

 

“...No, you just had the wrong impression.”

 

“Oh.”

 

Shez glanced at her house leader, then frowned at her sister. “Hey, come on By, be nicer to Dimitri! He’s sensitive!”

 

“...I am?”

 

“Ah, sorry, your highness,” Byleth said, before fully bowing her head in apology.

 

“...I feel as though I am being made fun of.”

 

“Would it be better if I knelt?”

 

“Please don’t.”

Chapter End Notes

Indi: You know, at a certain point, we'll need to update the tags so everyone knows what the endgame is in terms of romantic pairings.

Red: True, we will. At the very least, we'll need to point out the main ones for Byleth and Shez. As for everybody else...eh.

Indi: Yeah there will be side pairings, what exactly they are though, well they'll pop up here and there.

Red: It all depends on who we think has decent chemistry/a cute paired ending.

Indi: Ye, but until then, hope y'all enjoyed the chapter!

Making Arrangements

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

The next day, Byleth waited in the Archbishop’s audience chambers alongside Edelgard, Dimitri, and Hanneman. As the leaders of the Black Eagles and Blue Lions, it was to be expected the four of them would be involved given their upcoming request. One which Byleth would have to make as it seemed, odd as it was to say, that Rhea favored her. 

 

She wasn't exactly sure what it was about her, as she had no real experience teaching, and while she was certainly strong, her spar with Catherine showed there were others stronger still. Even so, she ended up in a teaching position at a prestigious academy, and had been given far bigger missions than the other professors had so far. It was easy to say that it was simply bad luck her class had to deal with bandits but… it was clear Zanado was a holy land, one that people weren't allowed to enter, and yet her class was told to do so. 

 

It would have made more sense for the knights to handle it, far safer, and that way her students didn't walk over sacred land. 

 

Barely even a day had passed after that mission before she was told to stomp out a rebellion. While Byleth herself had never dealt with a rebellion, even she could tell just what that meant, even if they would just be the rearguard…

 

Regardless, Rhea kept giving her these missions, and most would be honored to have the trust of the Archbishop but…

 

Rhea didn't like Shez. 

 

No, that was probably unfair. She never expressed any dislike to Shez, but when it came to the two of them, Rhea didn't pay Shez any heed. As if the only one that mattered was Byleth. 

 

And that mattered to Byleth. It was one thing to hear from her father that Rhea wasn’t trustworthy, that Rhea had something to do with her mother’s death and her father just couldn’t trust the strangely familiar woman, but seeing how little interest she had in Shez took that strange fascination she seemed to have with Byleth and made it aggravating.

 

But Byleth wasn’t going to focus on that. She was here at her student’s behest, so she was going to stay professional. Even if a part of her wanted to avoid the archbishop entirely.

 

“Good morning, everyone,” Lady Rhea greeted them as she walked into the audience chamber along with Seteth. She looked as composed as ever, her hands folded together as she took her typical position with her chamberlain behind her. “To what do I owe the pleasure of having two professors and two house leaders seeking an audience with me so early in the month?”

 

“I wouldn’t quite call it pleasure, Lady Rhea,” Professor Hanneman began, taking the lead in negotiations. Byleth was pretty sure this would be a negotiation, not just a matter of asking and receiving. “My fellow professor and I, along with our students, wished to speak with you regarding the matter of this month’s mission.”

 

Rhea regarded him with some curiosity. “Go on.”

 

He nodded. “To be clear, both of our houses, the Blue Lions and the Black Eagles, have expressed reservations with the choice to assign the Black Eagles House the mission of accompanying the Knights of Seiros to the site of a rebellion within the Kingdom’s territory. The current leader of the rebellion, Lord Lonato of House Gaspard, is a noble of Faerghus, and our students believe, not without reason, that sending a class primarily composed of Adrestian nobles on a mission that would more than likely involve the killing of Kingdom citizens could potentially worsen relations between Faerghus and Adrestia.”

 

“Hm. Is this true, Dimitri? Edelgard?”

 

Both house leaders placed their hands over their hearts and bowed to the archbishop, before Dimitri spoke first. “Lady Rhea, I am not alone among my classmates in believing that sending Adrestian students to handle a matter that is ultimately the responsibility of the Holy Kingdom of Faerghus may send the wrong message to the nobility of the Kingdom. In this time of heightened tensions, we feel there is too great a risk that the situation could worsen if it appeared that nobles of the Empire were allowed to interfere in the Kingdom’s affairs, even at the behest of the Church.”

 

“I have to agree, your grace,” Edelgard stated, “Since the death of my uncle Volkhard and the horrific assassination of King Lambert of Faerghus, groundless conspiracies have circulated among the courts of both of our nations that the two events are linked. I do not believe it is an unfounded concern that tensions may be inflamed by the Black Eagles being sent on a mission that our fellow classmates feel so strongly about.”

 

“Hm. But it’s not really a matter of the Kingdom to handle, is it?” Seteth pointed out, “Lonato specifically declared that his rebellion was against the Church of Seiros, not against the Holy Kingdom of Faerghus. That means it is a matter of the Knights of Seiros to handle, and that naturally extends to the Officer’s Academy.”

 

“With all due respect, Seteth,” Dimitri began, “Lonato is still a noble of Faerghus. I can agree that in this particular instance, his actions do make him a matter for the Church and the Knights to deal with, but even still, care should be taken in who specifically is selected to handle this matter.”

 

“The Black Eagles are students of the Officer’s Academy before they are citizens of the Empire,” Rhea said, her tone polite but chiding, “Just as all faithful are children of the Goddess before they are citizens of their nations. The Goddess does not care for mortal boundaries, and neither should her faithful take umbrage with those she has chosen to carry out her will.”

 

“That’s not how it works.”

 

All eyes turned towards Byleth as she bluntly contradicted the archbishop’s words. Dimitri’s mouth snapped shut, his own response dying before it could be spoken as he glanced at the archbishop. Edelgard, meanwhile, simply regarded her professor with further interest.

 

As for the archbishop herself, no surprise showed on her face as she turned to her newest professor. “And what do you mean by that, child?”

 

“People don’t look past things like homelands that easily. Everyone in my father’s mercenary band was united under his leadership, but that didn’t stop them from arguing or making comments about each other based on where they came from. It never escalated to fighting, but that was because we were all working together.”

 

“Then you do see my point then.”

 

Byleth shook her head. “It’s not the same thing. My father’s mercenary band is like this monastery.” She ignored the offended look Seteth gave her. “People from different nations come here and unite under your leadership. That’s one thing. Faerghus and Adrestia are like two noble houses, just on a bigger scale. They have their own responsibilities and people to care for. If one of them hires a mercenary band to clear out problems on their land, that isn’t a problem. But if the other house hires mercenaries to go into their rival’s land, even if it was still to handle problems for them, then that rival is going to get upset.”

 

“The Church of Seiros isn’t a mercenary band,” Seteth stated, frowning at her.

 

“It’s an analogy.” Byleth paused, then glanced at Dimitri. “A metaphor is a type of analogy. Metaphors are more specifically comparing two unlike things, usually in a poetic sense.”

 

“...thank you?”

 

She nodded, then faced the archbishop again. “It’s not quite the same situation. Here, it’s more like if the mercenary band, which is the Knights in this analogy, decided to take along members of the rival house…let’s call it House Crimson, on a mission assigned to them by House Azure. House Azure is fully within its rights to be upset with…the Silverheart Mercenaries, because they don’t want members of House Crimson to be on Azure lands. If the Silverheart Mercenaries decide to bring the members of House Crimson along with them anyway, even if it is to clear out a giant wolf that’s causing trouble on House Azure’s lands, then things could escalate between the two houses anyway, and the Silverhearts would be at fault for causing the conflict, and that can be really bad for a mercenary band.”

 

“The Church of Seiros still isn’t a mercenary band,” Seteth repeated, his arms crossed over his chest.

 

“...Yes. I know. Do you…not know?”

 

Seteth’s eyes narrowed at her. “I know what a metaphor is.”

 

“Okay. Good work.” She gave him a thumbs up. He kept glaring at her. She lowered her hand.

 

“...While I can see what point you wish to make, child, it is the will of the goddess that these assignments be given as they are,” Rhea explained, “Fodlan requires aid in many places, for though the goddess is merciful, it is by mortal hands that it is made turbulent.”

 

“Lady Rhea, if I may,” Dimitri began again, “It is our intention to prevent further…turbulence among our peoples. We do not disagree that Fodlan needs safeguarding, we just believe we could safeguard just as well, if not better, through a different arrangement. If the Black Eagles were sent to deal with the bandits we were assigned–”

 

“Dimitri, I appreciate your reasoning, but you should not question the will of the goddess.” Though her tone was patient, it was hard not to hear the reprimand in Rhea’s voice.

 

“With all due respect, Lady Rhea, isn’t it also the goddess’s will that we humans make choices of our own?” Edelgard inquired in an equally polite tone, clearly intending no offense. “While some choices are clearly poor ones, we shouldn’t ignore the human element here. It is our duty as rulers to act in a manner befitting our people and guarantee their prosperity. All that to say, I’m having trouble understanding why our assignments have been arranged so specifically. May I ask for your guidance on this matter?”

 

Rhea regarded the young princess of Adrestia, the sole heir of a thousand year old bloodline, and smiled slightly at the memories her unwavering gaze brought her. “I will gladly offer guidance when needed, Edelgard. Am I to understand that you both hold these deep reservations over what should be a simple matter?”

 

“We do.”

 

“Yes, we do.” Both future rulers answered, one after the other, and Rhea regarded them thoughtfully.

 

“...Very well then. I thank you both for being so forthright in bringing this matter to my attention. As such, I am willing to make an adjustment as needed. Though you have also brought quite the concerning prospect to my attention, that of the worsening relations between the Empire and the Kingdom. As such, rather than having the Black Eagles House alone be assigned to the mission in question, I propose that both Black Eagles and Blue Lions join forces in order to mend the relationship between these two great nations.”

 

Dimitri and Edelgard blinked, visibly caught off guard, and shared a look on instinct, attempting to confirm what they just heard was correct. 

 

Hanneman, meanwhile, nodded slowly, rubbing at his beard with a small frown. “It is a solution, certainly. Though I don’t think it entirely removes the issue of Adrestian nobles facing Faerghan citizens, even treasonous ones…Ultimately though, I do not have an objection to our two houses participating in the same assignment. Professor Byleth?”

 

Byleth shrugged. “I guess it works. It would be like inviting people from House Azure over to act as minders for the Crimson vassals, right?”

 

“Are you still on about that?” Seteth asked with another frown.

 

“It works, doesn’t it?”

 

“Ah, professor, before we continue, I wanted to ask,” Dimitri began, glancing at Byleth, “How are things between you and Catherine?”

 

Edelgard tried to avoid letting her irritation show. Of course the lion prince couldn’t be subtle for one second…

 

“Hm? Is there some type of trouble between you and Catherine?” Seteth asked, looking towards Byleth too.

 

“It’s fine. I don’t like her that much. We can still work together.”

 

“Truly? I could have her removed from the mission if you require, child,” Rhea offered, and it was hard to miss the looks everyone gave her, especially as Dimitri’s jaw outright dropped from the blatant favoritism on display.

 

“That’s fine,” Byleth replied, “Like I said, we can still work together. She’s a good fighter and she’d be good to have along.”

 

“Of course. Though, if you happen to have any further troubles with anyone in the church or the knights, please, let me know.”

 

“Yeah, okay.” Byleth glanced at the house leaders and Hanneman, who had all managed to regain their composure before Rhea noticed. “Do any of you need anything else?”

 

“Ah, no, I do not believe so.”

 

“No, professor, I have said all I wished to say.”

 

After Dimitri and Edelgard’s responses, Hanneman clapped his hands together. “Well then, it seems we have no further problems! Thank you very much for hearing us out, Lady Rhea.”

 

“Of course. May the goddess ever watch over you.”

 

And thus ended the meeting between the archbishop and the quartet of professors and house leaders. Yet that was not the end of matters, as Byleth showed by turning to Hanneman once they all left the audience chamber.

 

“Hey, Professor Hanneman.”

 

“Hm? Oh, you need not call me professor, Miss Eisner. We are colleagues, after all.”

 

“Oh, okay, Mister…um…”

 

“Essar, my colleague. Though I suppose we could just use our given names, if that would not be too familiar.”

 

“It’s really not. Also, I had a question. What’s a wingman?”

 

Hanneman blinked, a reaction shared by Dimitri, who paused to listen while Edelgard let out a sigh. “Pardon?”

 

“A ‘wingman’. In the context of dating specifically. I tried looking up the term but I couldn’t find a definition. I did find some information about metaphors though, which was helpful.”

 

“Ahh, that does explain your allegorical tendencies back there…Well, I would never want to leave a colleague ignorant, I will admit, I am curious where you heard that term to begin with.”

 

“From Sylvain.”

 

“What?!” Dimitri exclaimed, sounding scandalized, “Professor, I can’t apologize enough for my classmate’s conduct! In fact, I’ll go get him! He needs to make things right!”

 

He ran off, prompting a sigh from Hanneman. “Oh dear, I had better head that off. My apologies, professor, we can reconvene later. Take care!”

 

Byleth watched as Hanneman hurried after his student, leaving her alone with Edelgard. “Hm. He didn’t explain what it meant.”

 

“Perhaps it’s better not to ask, professor,” Edelgard suggested, “It’s a silly topic to begin with.”

 

“I guess. Hey, do you know what a wingman is?”

 

“Of course I do. It…” Edelgard frowned. “...It has something to do with wyverns, I believe. Something…metaphorical.”

 

“Like the wyverns and the pegasi?”

 

“The what?”

 

Byleth paused. “...Hm. I guess I need to explain sex to you. That feels like something it would be important for nobles to know before now.”

 

Edelgard stared at her professor, genuinely too caught off guard to even get embarrassed. “...Professor, that…what are you talking about?”

 

“Don’t worry, Gertrude should still have those books about it. I’ll get them. I guess I should make it a full lesson just in case? Hm…I’ll think about it.”

 

Edelgard watched her professor start to walk off, then considered the enormous awkwardness that would inevitably come from having the stoic mercenary attempt to explain sex to her class in particular. “...Wait, professor! You really don’t need to!”

 

Unfortunately for her, Byleth had longer legs than her, and was quite difficult to catch.

Archbishop Rhea settled back in the seat behind her desk and let out a slow sigh as she eased into the comfortable leather. “Hm…Seteth. What do you think?”

 

Her chamberlain and closest confidante let out a sigh of his own in response to her question. “...I hate to admit it, but the new professor did make a decent, if childish, analogy earlier. Really, House Azure, House Crimson, and the Silverheart Mercenaries aren’t bad names at all, particularly if one were trying to illustrate politics on a basic level. Though perhaps ‘The Silverheart Knights’ would be better?”

 

“...Seteth.”

 

“No, you’re right, the mercenary aspect is a core component. I couldn’t in good conscience remove it, not without fundamentally altering the story she put together…”

 

Rhea sighed again, this time with more exasperation as she massaged her head. “Not that part, Seteth. I meant the concession I made. As well as if the political situation between the Kingdom and the Empire truly is so dire that my students consider the mere act of sending the incorrect class tantamount to igniting the alcohol stores.”

 

"Ah yes, admittedly I don't keep up to date with all the goings on but… it is quite clear there are tensions between the classes alone, and while the relationships have remained cordial, there is no saying what could set it off."

 

"I see… perhaps we should set up more inter house events?" It wasn't the best solution she will admit, but it was one nonetheless. If she was to bring back her mother then a time of war would only make things more difficult for her. 

 

"Hm… I can try to see what we can concoct. There is the choir festival that's coming up, perhaps we can convince the teachers to have more of their students participate?" 

 

"It is a start. Let us pray that the goddess can guide us through these turbulent times." 

 

"Hm…" Seteth seemed deep in thought, getting Rhea’s attention. "...House Golden would be too straightforward for a third noble house. Perhaps House Verdant, given a deer's dietary preferences?"

 

"...I see we shall have to discuss this later."

Sadly for Byleth, her questions on what a wingman were would remain unanswered, as she had something else to focus on right now. As they would be working together for the mission, Hanneman suggested they teach the classes together to better prepare them. However, with the classrooms themselves being too small for two classes, they ended up in the courtyard so they weren't cramped. 

 

However, the problem with this became evident as most students were clearly keeping to their own class. 

 

"Hm…this could be going better," Shez said to herself. Not unreasonably, considering the two classes were basically forming their own separate clumps on opposite ends of the makeshift “classroom” set up on the grass. The Black Eagles were a little more spread out among the desks, but the Lions looked like they were minutes away from forming a defensive wall and declaring their portion of the courtyard a sovereign nation.

 

Mostly because of Ingrid, who was making a point of sitting as far away from the Black Eagle students as she could, though Mercedes and Annette weren’t really helping things by deciding to sit with her. They probably had good intentions like making sure she wasn’t feeling left out, but add in Ashe also sitting close by and Felix being his usual standoffish self and things could be going better.

 

It definitely didn’t help that Sylvain tried to greet the “lovely ladies of the Eagles” and Dorothea made a point of moving as far away from him as possible, made all the worse by Petra following her to ask what was wrong with Sylvain. Then there was Bernadetta hiding under the desk and Linhardt sleeping again.

 

Meanwhile, the house leaders and their retainers were up at the front and trying to be cordial despite the awkwardness, especially since their professors seemed to be busy trying to figure out what their lesson plan for the day was.

 

“Hm…” Shez glanced over at the Eagles, wondering if she should take a chance on the more sociable of the bunch. Dorothea was usually nice, but it would be kind of awkward to approach her after Sylvain’s screw-up, right? Ugh, social stuff was hard when it involved nobles…Maybe she should try Caspar? He seemed nice. Competitive too, which Shez could appreciate–And he just joined Dorothea and Petra, great. It made sense, sure, they were the most lively of the classes at the moment, but it was super inconvenient for Shez…

 

Maybe she should try Ferdinand?

 

She looked at Ferdinand, who somehow already had stacks of notes and books in front of him as he wrote at a rapid pace. She decided not to try Ferdinand.

 

Which left the other odd girl out of their groups.

 

Which hm… something about her also seemed weirdly familiar…

 

"Is that not the girl who was able to defend herself against you during the mock battle?" Arval asked, looking over at Emily. 

 

"Oh right, that's probably how I know her," Shez replied, wiping away her previous sense of familiarity. With a grin, she approached the brown-haired girl. 

 

“Hey!” Shez greeted as she slid into the seat next to Emily, who looked extremely bored as she stared up at the front of the “classroom”. Not really at anything, just in that general direction, though she still visibly startled at the sound of Shez’s voice.

 

“Gah–Ah, what? What are you doing?”

 

“Sitting with you. I figured since today’s about ‘inter-house relations’ and stuff, I should at least sit by an Eagle, right?”

 

“...” Her stare was extremely suspicious for some reason. “...And you sat by me specifically, because?”

 

“Well, part of it is that you’re sitting on your own so it’s easier to just come up and start talking, but most of it is because you actually kept up with me while I was in my awakened form.”

 

“...Is that what it’s called?”

 

“It’s what I call it!”

 

“Huh…So…Where are you from?”

 

“Well all over the place, mostly, since my dad and sister are mercenaries, as am I of course, but if we’re talking about places of origin, I’m actually from Ordelia over in the Alliance.”

 

Emily’s eyes widened for a second before she regarded Shez with…well it was kind of hard to tell what she was regarding her with. It wasn’t suspicion, but more like Shez had confirmed something? Which was kind of weird. “Really. I’m actually from…Hrym, myself. I was born there, at least.”

 

“Oh hey, small world! That’s right on the border, right?”

 

“Yeah, practically the same land. The place I grew up in was pretty cavernous. How about you?”

 

“Oh, I grew up in the mountains! Just me and my mom, plus some villagers but they don’t really count.”

 

Emily huffed in some amusement. “No, they really don’t. Your mom, huh? What was her name?”

 

“Periander! How about you, who did you grow up with?”

 

She snorted that time, actually smiling a little. “Oh, you know. Standard family stuff. I grew up hunting down beasts and vermin.”

 

“Oh, you hunt? Well I guess that makes sense. Was it more for sport or for food?”

 

“Sport, mostly, though I guess there was some necessity to it. Still, you wouldn’t really ‘eat’ vermin, now would you?”

 

“Eh, I’ve eaten a rat when I was hungry enough.”

 

Emily blinked, then gave her a look that was half-disgusted and half-impressed. “...are we being literal about ‘eating’ right now?”

 

“Yeah? Why wouldn’t we be?”

 

“Oh, just…well, it’s dirty, isn’t it?”

 

Shez shrugged. “Food’s food when you’re hungry.”

 

“...Huh. You’re…interesting, Shez.” She glanced towards the front, towards Byleth. “...So what’s the story there? You just happened to find the former knight’s captain and his whelp and joined up with them?”

 

“Pretty much? I mean, there’s some specifics to it, sort of a hunting accident thing and I didn’t know who he was at the time. Not that it really mattered, at that point I was just looking for a new mercenary group to join up with. Everything else sort of…happened naturally after that.” She paused. “Also you probably shouldn’t call Byleth a ‘whelp’. I know you’re a noble and all, but most people consider that rude.”

 

Emily scoffed. “Fine. I swear, you sound like…Selene. She’s always nagging me about staying ‘polite’ and ‘avoiding violence’. I was sent by this damned church to kill bandits, was I not supposed to enjoy myself?”

 

“Probably not. I know I’ve gotten weird looks for counting my kills on a mission.”

 

“You do that?”

 

“Oh sure, it’s mostly a competitive thing though. I want to prove I can do better than Byleth, so I usually keep track of my kills to show I got more than her.”

 

“Ah, showing your superiority then. I can respect that.”

 

“Oh yeah, so who’s Selene?”

 

“Ugh. An annoyance who thinks she knows better than me. I can introduce you to her later, though…then again, she did get on my case last time…let’s just ignore that for now. I’m more curious about what your plans here are anyway.”

 

“Oh you know, the basic stuff. Graduate and make a name for myself.”

 

“Ahh. Basic, but I can respect it. Do I get to know any specifics, or…?”

 

“Eh, I’ll tell you when I figure them out.”

 

“Heh, you tease. Fine, I’ll try to be patient. It’s what everyone says I need to do at this stupid place anyway.”

 

“Yeah, I can’t say I’m the monastery’s biggest fan either, especially with the Knights and how weird the archbishop is,” Shez muttered, before glancing at her new friend, “How about you? Anything you want to do?”

 

“Hm…Fight, hunt, kill. Bathe in the blood of my enemies and reign supreme over the vermin. That sort of thing.”

 

Shez just nodded along. “So nothing really specific either, huh?”

 

“Not really. I wanted to win a certain someone’s approval, but he’s dead now, so that can’t happen.”

 

Shez would’ve asked a follow-up question to that, because wow was that statement loaded with implications, but she was interrupted by Professor Hanneman finally addressing the classes. “Alright, class! Or, classes, as the case currently is. Professor Byleth and I have decided, going forward, we shall be focusing on a different lesson plan than we initially, well, planned.

 

“Due to the importance of the upcoming mission our classes will be cooperating on, we will forgo our previous subjects in favor of focusing on theoretical and practical tactics. As such, I will be lecturing for the first portion of our shared class time, followed by Professor Byleth. I understand we are doing things quite differently than usual, so thank you all for being so accommodating! Now, to begin–”

 

“Uuugh, great, back to this shit,” Emily grumbled, propping her head up on her hand as she barely pretended to listen along. At least she was keeping quiet enough that Hanneman and Byleth didn't hear her. Still, Shez did at least make an attempt to listen as Hanneman was talking about what exactly they would do as the 'rear guard'. 

 

For the most part, it seemed that they would be simply traveling alongside a small squad of knights, and dealing with any remaining knights loyal to Lord Lonato while the vanguard dealt with the main forces. There were of course many other factors to take into consideration too, or at least that’s what Hanneman was saying.

 

"That is what our classes shall be focusing on. I shall be providing several examples on what may occur during our mission, while Professor Byleth shall have you actively practicing them afterwards." 

 

"During practical practice, I'll be splitting you into two groups, one 'defensive' and one 'offensive'." Byleth explained, before looking over at Ingrid as she raised her hand. "Yes, Ingrid?" 

 

"I assume we'll be split between classes and change which side we're on in between attempts?" she asked, getting Byleth to shake her head. 

 

"The groups will be a mix of each class. If we keep the classes split, then we'll only end up hampering one another while in combat." 

 

"Professor, are you certain that is a good idea?" Ferdinand asked, "I can see the value in what you are saying, but at the same time, we may just end up at odds with one another in training." 

 

"Anyone who disrupts training will be reprimanded, and any further disruptions will see them getting punished. Anyone who actively endangers another student will be severely punished." Byleth said leaving no room for negotiation. "Hanneman, you can continue." 

 

"Thank you." With a nod, Hanneman faced the class again. "Now, let's start off with a simple example," Hanneman said as he began to draw on the chalkboard, making a few rudimentary trees to symbolize a forest and some dots to symbolize the students. "The most likely scenario we shall face will be encountering random stragglers on our march." He marked some random x's on the map, before making an arrow pointing where the dots would be going. 

 

"Can anyone tell me what the best course of action for our march would be?" 

 

"Find the stragglers and beat them," Felix said, as if it was simple. 

 

“That is more of a goal than a strategy, Felix. Perhaps you can give a more concrete plan?" 

 

“I’m a warrior, not a tracker. How should I know how to find them?”

 

“Ah, are we doing the hunting then?” Petra asked, “I have much experience with matters of hunting. May I be knowing what the…ah, the terrain. May I be knowing what the terrain is like?”

 

“An excellent question, Petra! Knowing the terrain is extremely important when it comes to figuring out how best to face your foe, particularly when they have a homeland advantage. Now, the Gaspard territory is a region in southern Faerghus that is easily accessible from Garreg Mach via travel through Magdred Way–”

 

As Hanneman continued his lecture on the geography of the region, Shez felt her attention starting to slip away from the lesson. She wasn’t great with maps in general so the information was just sort of drifting out of her brain as she heard it. Hanneman could be interesting, but when the topic already bored Shez, she just couldn’t focus even if he was being passionate about it. And he wasn’t being enthusiastic at the moment, so yeah, it wasn’t a big surprise her mind started to wander and she wound up poking an equally bored-looking Emily in the side.

 

The other girl jerked, then shot her a glare that Shez returned with a grin instead. 

 

“...” Then Emily poked her back, jabbing her finger hard into Shez’s side.

 

“Gh-Mn.” Shez frowned as her new friend grinned, before trying to jab her back, only to get her hand slapped away instead. Which just turned her small diversion into an actual competition! 

 

So the pair promptly spent the next few minutes of class time attempting to jab each other as hard as they could while still being subtle enough not to get caught. It was pretty fun, up until Shez wound up poking Emily a bit too hard and was full on punched in the face.

 

“Shit–” Emily cut herself off with a genuine wince, “That was–It was just reflex–”

 

“Sh!” Shez hissed, ducking her head and glancing around to make sure no one saw that, despite the fact that she was the one who’d just been hit. Thankfully, it looked like everyone was more focused on the lecture…though she did grimace when she noticed Byleth plainly staring at her with an unimpressed look. She gave her sister a sheepish wave, before sitting back with a little huff as she felt at her nose. “Ow…you have a really good hook.”

 

“...uh…thanks? Are you…You good?”

 

“Yeah, of course. It’s gonna take more than a pretty noble’s dainty punch to lay me out,” she teased.

 

“...Well fine, I won’t ask the next time I deck you.”

 

“Oh so there’s going to be a next time?”

 

“Shez, Emily, don’t talk during the lecture,” Byleth spoke up, making a number of their classmates glance at the pair, prompting a scowl from Emily and another sheepish grin from Shez. 

 

“Ah, sorry! We’ll be good!”

 

Byleth just nodded, prompting a half-amused, half-annoyed noise from Emily. “Teacher’s pet.”

 

“Hey, it’s different when the teacher’s my sister.”

 

“Sure it is. It means you’re sucking up to your big, strong ‘sister’ instead of trying to score points with the faculty. Lucky for you, she’s both, so you only have to brown-nose once to get double the rewards.”

 

Shez narrowed her eyes at the Eagle student, before smirking and giving her a light kick under the table.

 

“...” Emily turned back to her, her expression flat and unamused…aside from the small twitch to her lips as she tried to hide a grin. “You realize this means war, right?”

 

“Sure does. Just don’t kick me out of my seat, alright?”

 

“No promises.”

 

She didn’t, though it was a near thing.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: And so begins the inter house training, as well as the first meeting between Shez and Kronya.

Red: Quite the friendly first meeting for the pair. Or at least as friendly as Kronya can get.

Indi: Yup yup, mainly thanks to her thinking Shez was speaking in code there.

Red: Which, well, Shez certainly said some odd things "in code" there.

Indi: that she did, as for how the training and that potential friendship shall go? Well I guess yall will have to see later.

Red: That you shall! For now though, thanks for reading!

Team ups and Training!

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

"For the purpose of this exercise the 'defenders' will only need to evade the 'attackers' for thirty minutes for them to win," Byleth explained to the students as they gathered in the field where the mock battle was held. "The attackers will start together while the defenders will be spread out throughout the forest." 

 

"If we beat up the other team, do we win?" Caspar asked as he stood with the defense team, consisting of him, Ferdinand, Dimitri and Annette. 

 

"That is also an option." 

 

"Hmph, you're welcome to try," Felix challenged as he stood with the attacking team, consisting of him, Ingrid, Edelgard, and Petra. 

 

"Oh I'm going to do more than try!" 

 

"Do keep in mind this is only an exercise so excessive force will not be allowed. If you are forced down to one knee or start bleeding, you're out," Byleth said, before nodding to the defense team. "If you will follow me, I'll guide you to your positions." 

 

"Good luck guys!" Shez cheered them on from the sidelines. It wasn’t her turn just yet, she was just excited to see the match play out. 

 

"Let's do our best!" Annette also cheered on as she followed her team. 

 

"Then in the meantime let us develop our plan," Edelgard said, trying to immediately take charge. 

 

"What's there to plan? She tracks them and I beat them." Felix responded as he gestured at Petra. 

 

"Leave it to me!"

 

"Not that I doubt Petra's abilities, but chasing them down one by one may take too much time." 

 

"As if they'll be hiding. With how loud those two Black Eagles are, they'll practically be begging us to find them,” Ingrid said.

 

Felix smirked. “And the boar will be even worse.”

 

“Felix!”

 

“There is a boar?” Petra asked, confused.

 

“No, I believe he’s referring to Dimitri,” Edelgard explained.

 

“Ah! This is the metaphor! Professor Byleth was explaining this to me.”

 

“His highness is not a boar!” Ingrid snapped, before glaring at Felix, “And Felix–H-Hey! Don’t walk away from me!”

 

“We’re in the middle of a competition. Either help out or stay standing around gossiping about the boar with your new best friends.”

 

“Wh–That’s not–Ugh, you’re impossible sometimes, you know that!?”

 

Edelgard sighed as she watched the blonde stomp after her classmate, clearly intent on lecturing him further. “This is going to be difficult…”

 

Or, well, it would have been, if Caspar hadn’t decided he would rather be on the attack by “ambushing” them. Which consisted of him leaping from a tree with a war cry while swinging a wooden axe straight into the ground because he missed them entirely. And then the axe happened to get stuck in the dirt.

 

Suffice to say, it was fairly easy for all four of the attackers to subdue him after that.

 

“Really, what was he thinking?” Ingrid asked after Caspar was sent off the field without his weapon, “The whole purpose of the exercise is to stay on the defensive, not just attack out of nowhere like some wildman.”

 

“Caspar is…enthusiastic,” Edelgard elected to say, deciding to be charitable to her classmate, “I won’t disagree that it has caused him more problems than he would have otherwise though.”

 

“Then shouldn’t you be fixing that? You’re supposed to be his house leader, after all. Or are such things beneath her royal highness?”

 

Edelgard frowned at the blatant hostility. “Should I take that to mean that your house leader takes an active role in correcting his housemates’ issues?”

 

“Of course! His highness has been a perfect leader, one who would never do something as foolish as–...” Ingrid trailed off, largely because their group had come to a clearing where Dimitri stood at attention, his spear in hand.

 

“Ah, there you are! You will go no further, for I shall protect my fellow defenders directly!”

 

“...”

 

“...” Edelgard glanced at Ingrid. “To be fair, he isn’t directly attacking us. He is still acting on the defensive.”

 

“...Please don’t try to comfort me.”

 

Dimitri blinked. “Comfort you? Is something wrong?”

 

“No, there isn’t,” Felix said as he stepped from the trees he’d been searching, wooden sword in hand, “Especially not now that I have a chance to settle things with you, boar.”

 

“Felix…very well then. Though you are my friend, I shall not hold back–Ow!” Dimitri exclaimed, a hand immediately going to his head where a rock had just bounced off of it.

 

“P-Petra! Don’t throw rocks at his highness!” Ingrid protested.

 

The Brigidian princess just looked confused though. “Are we not meant to be making the defenders be bleeding? Professor Byleth said to have blood drawn is to be disqualified, correct?”

 

“Ah–W-Well, still!”

 

“It’s fine, Ingrid,” Dimitri said, waving off her concern as he tossed his spear aside, “Petra acted within the bounds of the exercise. Now I think I’m going to go ask the professor to heal this, because…ow.”

 

Felix, meanwhile, grunted irritably before just heading off into another part of the woods, aiming to track down another one of the defenders. He didn’t, though Petra did manage to find Ferdinand, who had actually bothered to hide.

 

“So it seems you’ve caught me…but I will not be going down without a–Ow!”

 

“You know, I don’t think the professor had throwing rocks in mind when she laid out the parameters of this exercise,” Edelgard noted after Ferdinand wandered off, rubbing the bruise on his head.

 

“I doubt the professor had much in mind with how vague those ‘parameters’ were,” Ingrid grumbled, prompting frowns from both Eagles.

 

“Do not be insulting the professor,” Petra said, glaring at Ingrid.

 

“Huh? I wasn’t, I just–”

 

“You were. You are saying she does not have much in her mind, that is an insult.”

 

“That’s not what I meant!”

 

“Do not be lying to me! You are thinking I am being stupid too?”

 

“I-I didn’t say that!”

 

“But it is what you are meaning! You are being insulting the entire of this time!”

 

“You’re both being stupid,” Felix interrupted, scowling at both of them, which was the exact wrong thing to say as Petra visibly stiffened. “We still have a–”

 

“I AM NOT STUPID!” Petra snapped, glaring straight at Felix and actually stepping towards him, her hand tight around the rock still in her grip.

 

Felix blinked, before his eyes narrowed. “Then stop acting like it.”

 

Petra’s eyes widened before a genuine snarl came to her face–And then Edelgard punched Felix straight in the face.

 

“Felix!” Ingrid exclaimed as her friend stumbled back, before glaring at Edelgard. “What was that?!”

 

Edelgard shrugged, idly shaking out her hand. “I believe that was me disqualifying myself for deliberately injuring a team member. Petra’s more useful as a tracker, so it’s better I leave than she does. Your problems are with me, right?”

 

“...” Staying quiet, Ingrid stared as Edelgard walked off, leaving her with Petra and Felix, who was getting up from the punch, his cheek already bruised. 

 

"Hmph, didn't expect someone so small to be so strong," Felix said, a bit of interest in his voice. 

 

"Seriously? That's what you're focused on?" Ingrid asked, very exasperated. 

 

"...I shall continue the hunt," Petra said, before Ingrid stopped her. 

 

"Wait, Petra." Frowning, Ingrid tried to think of how to say what she wanted. "I'm sorry, I genuinely don't have anything against you, especially as a prisoner of the empire." 

 

"...I am not just a prisoner. Edelgard is my friend. Any insult you speak of her, or our professor, is one I shall not stand," Petra said, surprising Ingrid. 

 

"That–I don't understand how you can think of anyone from the Empire as your friend after what happened to your people." 

 

"...None of my classmates were in the conflict. They are not the ones who were fighting, much like how I did not fight back then. I may not have understanding of your anger, but I do not believe any of them hurt you." 

 

“They…It’s more complicated than that.”

 

Petra shrugged. “If you are saying so, I will not further be arguing. I am not agreeing, yet I am willing to be putting aside our conflicts to be finishing our assignment.”

 

“...” Ingrid sighed, then tried to smile. “Yes, we should get back to the exercise. We should still have some time to find Annette and win this, right?”

 

They didn’t. Or at least they didn’t have enough time to actually find Annette before the exercise ended, because the smallest Lion actually did her best to hide the entire time instead of trying to fight the attackers.

 

“Yes! I knew hiding in the trees would work!” Annette exclaimed with a happy grin after the professor announced her team the winners of the exercise.

 

“Oh, I should have thinking of that before,” Petra commented, half-disappointed and half-impressed, “Tree tops are very safe places to be hiding.”

 

“Right? Though I can’t take all the credit, I actually got the idea from seeing Caspar scramble up into the trees so quickly early on!” Annette grinned over at her teammate, who looked a little sheepish. “Though it looks like they found you anyway, huh?”

 

“...Ah, yeah, uh…Well, it’s more like I let myself be found! Because I never run from a fight!”

 

“So you just jumped into a fight you couldn’t win,” Felix commented, ignoring how most of his classmates were looking at the obvious bruise on his face.

 

“Hey, I would’ve had a chance if my axe didn’t get stuck!”

 

“Don’t swing your axe into dirt next time, Caspar,” Byleth chided, “As you discovered, it can get stuck in the ground really easily. You also would have done actual damage if that hit landed. Just because the weapon is blunt doesn’t mean it can’t cause injuries.”

 

“Ah…sorry about that, professor.”

 

“It’s okay, you’re learning.” She turned to the rest of the teams. “Dimitri, you need to be more aware of your surroundings. You also can’t be on defense all on your own. A sacrifice play isn’t the worst move to make, but it does remove your ability to help after the fact.”

 

“I understand, professor.” Dimitri bowed his head, which had been healed up by the professor without even a scratch remaining. “What do you think would have been better?”

 

“Hm…considering how the match played out, it would have been better for you, Caspar, and Ferdinand to form a defensive line while Annette hid. All three of you are decent melee combatants and joining together would have allowed you to cover each other's weaknesses and defend from things like sudden projectiles.”

 

The boys couldn’t help but glance at Petra. “...Yes, that probably would have been better.”

 

“I suppose my issues were much then same then, professor?” Ferdinand asked.

 

“Sort of. You did try to hide, which wasn’t a bad plan since you were on your own at that point, though you did have the exact same outcome as Dimitri once you decided to fight, so you should also work on your spatial awareness. We can figure that out later though. Moving onto the attacker team, I can’t say you did well despite managing to eliminate three of your opponents.”

 

“Professor, if I may.” Edelgard stepped forward. “I take full responsibility for how things went. I did not lead my teammates properly and I struck one of them in a moment of anger. Our failures were my responsibility.”

 

“I was paying attention, Edelgard. I know what happened,” Byleth quite bluntly stated, making it clear to everyone on the attacker team that the professor was fully aware of their arguments, “That said, if you want to take responsibility, that’s fine. You are the house leader and arguably the leader of your team, though you did not take much of a leadership role past the beginning of the match. Should I take that to mean you didn’t think you could lead the Lions in your group?”

 

Edelgard frowned, before glancing at her teammates. Truthfully, she’d been willing to let things play out as they did, to a point, because she could tell Ingrid would be combative and Felix would be dismissive. That didn’t mean she should have left things as they were though, especially considering she had classmates with similarly difficult personalities. “...I didn’t think of it that way, professor, but you’re right. I should have been a stronger leader to my teammates, even if they aren’t in my house.”

 

Byleth nodded. “If you want to lead, you need to lead everyone on your side, not just the people you like the best. On that subject, Felix, you didn’t work with your team at all. This was a team exercise, so that means you’ve failed.”

 

Felix frowned. “What do you mean I failed?”

 

“I meant what I said. Your team lost, remember? It doesn’t matter if you succeed in your individual goals if you don’t achieve your overall objective. You didn’t do either anyway, so you failed and we’re going to need to work on that.”

 

He scowled, but didn’t reply, just crossing his arms over his chest as he glared mulishly at the professor.

 

“Ingrid, I think you already know where you went wrong.”

 

“...I do, professor,” Ingrid admitted.

 

“Tensions are easy to rise and hard to quell. People say personal feelings don’t have a place on the battlefield, and they shouldn’t, but they tend to appear anyway. Just remember, it doesn’t matter where your comrades come from as long as they’re on your side.”

 

“...But how can I be sure they’re actually on my side?” she asked, sounding ashamed to even be asking it but clearly having trouble.

 

“Common interest. As long as you know they share the same goal you do, that’s all you need. Finally, Petra, good work with the rocks. That was smart thinking.”

 

Petra blinked, then smiled. “Ah, thank you professor! I am glad to be hearing my idea was a good one.”

 

“It was. Unexpected projectiles are difficult to defend against and even rocks can be extremely dangerous to the unprepared and undefended. For the record, I leave the parameters vague on purpose because on the battlefield you'll need to be able to think on your own. Being able to think up plans on the spot, will save you in combat should things go awry." With her piece said, she walked up and patted Petra and Annette on the head. "Good job." 

 

"Thank you, professor!" 

 

"Hmph. You, Petra, was it?" Felix asked, getting the Brigid girl's attention as Byleth went to get the next group of students. "I want you to throw rocks at me." 

 

"...May I be asking why?"

 

"I'm not going to let myself get taken out as easily as the boar, so I want to train my reflexes. You throw things quickly," Felix said, as blunt as ever. 

 

"I see. And will you be apologizing for your words and actions in the forest?”

 

Felix grimaced. “I don’t see why I should.”

 

“Then you will not be seeing the things you wish to be seeing. Apologize, or the rocks will be coming to the back of your head.”

 

His scowl deepened, before he let out an aggrieved sigh. “Fine. I’m sorry I called you stupid. Can we get  on with this now?”

 

“Hm…You are being very lucky that I am wishing to throw rocks at you anyway. Be warned, I shall not be holding back!" With a firm nod, Petra grabbed several more rocks so she could assist him in training. 

 

Glancing over at Ingrid, Edelgard gave her a curt nod, before walking back towards where the rest of her classmates were. As for Ingrid herself, her mind couldn't help but wander to Petra’s words, before she let out a frustrated huff and headed back to her own classmates.

The next practice mission faired a bit better as the attacking team of Bernadetta, Dorothea, Dedue and Ashe seemed to actually make a plan of attack while the defending team of Hubert, Linhardt, Mercedes and Sylvain were able to use the number of mages on their side to their advantage. 

 

Not wanting to draw too much attention thanks to his size, Dedue would follow behind to cover their rear while Ashe and Bernadetta would take the lead to search for anyone hiding. With the front and rear decided, Dorothea, as the most sociable of the team, took on the leader role and took center position to give commands. 

 

That being said, they were still up against rather smart students. Stumbling across Linhardt, who appeared to be surrendering, they were unable to see the trap laid for them. Before they could apprehend him, they ended up getting blinded by a flash of light magic from Mercedes. A pair of yelps from Bernadetta and Ashe were able to tell Dorothea what was going on as she and Dedue retreated, only to run right into Hubert, who hit Dedue straight in the leg with a ball of magic.

 

“Gh!” the large student grunted as he fell to a knee, before frowning over at Hubert.

 

“Don’t look so angry. The professor said either we draw blood or bring you to a knee, and I like to think I took the kinder option,” Hubert taunted, before aiming his hand at Dorothea, “Hello Dorothea. I would suggest you surrender now to spare yourself any extra–”

 

Then he had to duck Dorothea’s responding shot as his fellow mage smirked. “Now Hubie, you should at least buy me dinner before trying to get me on my knees~”

 

“Well hey, if he’s not going to take you up on it, mind if I accept that offer?” Sylvain asked as he poked the head of his spear against Dorothea’s back.

 

“...Right, I forgot about you.” Dorothea sighed, before raising her hands in surrender.

 

“Good, that one went better,” Byleth began a few minutes later, once everyone was gathered again, “Good planning on both of your parts, Dorothea, Hubert. The formation was a good idea, Dorothea, though it left you vulnerable to traps, as you saw.”

 

The songstress sighed. “Yes, that one trap did completely upend everything we wanted to do…I’m not sure what I could have done better though.”

 

“Hm…It depends. I wouldn’t say there’s much you could have done better, so much as done differently.
