"Yeah, I can see why… but well, we're all here, so you can rely on all of us… well, maybe aside from Petra," Shez muttered, looking over at the Brigid girl who looked ready to keel over in the cold. 

 

"Why are these l-lands so cold…" 

 

"Eesh, guess we really are lucky you guys aren't here when it's snowing," Sylvain commented. 

 

"W-What is this s-snow you speak of?" 

 

"Uh, well, it's kinda like frozen rain? Though I guess that's more hail…" 

 

"F-Frozen r-rain?! That is sounding dangerous!" 

 

"It's not that bad," Byleth said as she overheard them talking, "Though it can block the door if it piles too high. Made Shez freak out once." 

 

"Hey, I didn't freak out!" 

 

"You threw yourself out the window cause you thought we were trapped." A small frown appeared on her face. "You didn't even bother opening the window first." 

 

A loud bark of laughter from Emily told Shez she was going to get teased heavily about that when they went back. More concerning though was the fact that Shez could clearly see most of Blue Lions nodding along like what she did was a perfectly normal thing to do. The only one that wasn’t was Mercedes and she looked equally concerned by her friends’ standards of normalcy.

 

“Heh, I’m glad to see you’re all keeping your spirits high back here,” Catherine called out as she caught up with their procession. Well, not exactly “caught up” since she was coming from the front. "That's good, a very important thing to have when marching." 

 

"Thank you Lady Catherine. We're honored to be able to fight alongside a Holy Knight like you," Dimitri said.

 

"No need for the flattery, if you wanna show your gratitude just make sure to do a good job." 

 

"With the wielder of the Thunderbrand on our side, I wonder how much we will be able to do," Edelgard commented. 

 

"Quite, one must wonder why he would incite a rebellion given the forces the church has," Hubert mused, getting Byleth to glance over at Catherine with a small frown. 

 

"...Whatever his reasons, we have a mission to accomplish. Just make sure-" 

 

"Report!” called out a church soldier as he ran up to them, “Lonato's forces are much larger than expected, they were able to slip past the vanguard using the fog for cover!" 

 

"What? What forces could he even have?" Catherine asked, shock evident on her face, before Byleth abruptly moved, grabbing Ingrid by her shoulder and pulling her backwards. 

 

"H-Hey, what's the big-" A sharp whistling noise cut her off as an arrow flew past right where she was standing. 

 

“DOWN!” Catherine immediately shouted, prompting the students to duck in case of any further archer fire, “Shields up if you have them!”

 

Byleth frowned, trying to peer through the mist. With how low the visibility was, it was unlikely that whatever archers were out there had a clear enough view to actually hit any of them properly; the first arrow was probably just aimed towards whatever sound the archer picked up in hopes of hitting the enemy, which wasn’t something a master archer would actually do. Even a standardly trained one would probably hold until their commander gave the word.

 

She didn’t have enough information to make any big guesses, but her instincts told her she was either dealing with someone masterful enough to spot and aim at an individual target in the middle of heavy fog, or a complete amateur who just aimed at the loudest sound they heard. And, at the moment, the latter might actually be more dangerous to her students.

 

“We shouldn’t bunch up,” she stated, directing her words towards Catherine, “If we’re all together, any archers the enemy has have a greater chance of hitting someone so long as they aim in our direction.”

 

“True, but we don’t want anyone getting lost in the fog either, right? Besides, Lonato shouldn’t have enough soldiers to surround us properly,” the knight replied.

 

“Hm…He’s a minor lord. He shouldn’t have that large a force to begin with.”

 

“Exactly, so let’s be cautious here. We take down anyone that we see come through the fog.” Catherine glanced back at the pair of swordsmen she brought with her. “You two, with me. We’ll head in while this bunch stays back. I’m gonna assume you can keep the students safe, professor.”

 

Byleth nodded. “I will. Try not to die.”

 

Catherine smirked. “Don’t worry, I’ll make sure to last so you can get a rematch.”

 

As she headed forward, moving carefully into the mist with her back-up, Ingrid glanced back at Byleth. “Ah…th-thanks for that. Though…shouldn’t Professor Hanneman be the one leading us?”

 

“He rode ahead earlier to speak with the knights forming the vanguard,” Byleth answered. “You’re stuck with me. Sorry.”

 

“Honestly, I would think anyone would prefer having the professional mercenary at their side instead of a crest scholar in a situation like this,” Edelgard pointed out, her shield still raised as her eyes scanned the thick fog, “No disrespect meant to Professor Hanneman, of course.”

 

“You’re not incorrect,” Dimitri agreed, keeping his own watch as the students felt the tension in the air starting to grow. It wasn’t helped by the obvious scent of freshly spilled blood on the wind. “...We can’t hold this position forever though. We should have more than enough people to handle any threats out there, and we can’t take the chance that the enemy could get past us.”

 

“A-Are y-you sure w-we can’t just stay here?” Bernadetta asked, “S-Staying on defense sounds good to me! Defense always won more back in class!”

 

“Hm…Light the torches in our supplies,” Byleth ordered, “There’s a forest to the north. We’re going to avoid going there in favor of sticking to the fields. There’s already too little visibility to risk it, but there’s a high chance of enemy soldiers hiding there specifically because of that low visibility, so I want a portion of you on our northern flank to keep us defended. Catherine was headed to the southwest, so we’ll focus our efforts westward. Anyone with shields, comes to the front with me. Lancers can form our back row, sword fighters cover our flanks, archers and casters at the back. Also, Bernadetta, fire an arrow in that direction.”

 

“H-Huh? M-Me?”

 

“Yup. Here, right about…” Byleth raised her hand, before pointing at a specific spot in the thick fog. “There. Shoot an arrow right there.” 

 

Nobody could really tell what she was pointing at, which only made Bernie’s nervousness worse, but she still pulled back the string of her bow anyway. “P-Please don’t hit anybody on our side…”

 

She let the arrow loose, and a second later the students heard a scream of pain, prompting a nod from Byleth. “There, that should draw them out.”

Shez was pretty sure she’d never take another job in Faerghus again if she could help it. The cold was bad, the fog was worse, and while she fully understood why Byleth was taking things slow and steady to make sure all the students stayed safe, dear Goddess was she getting exhausted by how slow everything felt.

 

Which was probably more evidence of her skewed sense of how battles should work than a real indictment of how speedy things were going considering she’d already cut down three people. 

 

“Jeez, this is dull,” muttered Emily, so Shez at least knew she wasn’t the only one thinking it.

 

“How can you say that?” Ashe asked, frowning at her.

 

“Because it is! I’m itching to run into the fray here!”

 

“Pretty sure that would get you blindsided,” Shez pointed out, “I can agree that things are going slow, but By’s right about it being safer.”

 

“I don’t want ‘safe’, I want to gut someone!”

 

“...Are you always like this?” Ashe asked, looking unnerved. Which was fair, considering how Em tended to be.

 

“The girl’s a psychopath, of course everyone is disturbed by her,” Arval pointed out, completely unnecessarily because Shez was already aware of that. It just didn’t bug her that much. “Oh don’t make that face at me, you’re the one who decided to be friends with her.”

 

That wasn’t what Shez was trying to convey with her face, but whatever. 

 

“I see we’re feeling quite chatty on this end.”

 

“Oh, hey Hubert,” Shez greeted, familiar enough with the tall boy’s weird cadence that she didn’t need to glance back to know it was him, “What’s up?”

 

“Just curious how things are looking on this flank. It’s quite difficult to spot things in this fog so I’m almost feeling left out. I’m sure you can sympathize, Ashe.”

 

“Huh? Oh, uh…I guess? I don’t really…yeah.”

 

“Quite. One might even say this fog appears unnatural,” Hubert commented, looking directly at Emily. Who didn’t catch the hint at all and wasn’t paying attention to him.

 

Ashe, meanwhile, looked thoughtful. “Hey, yeah, that is true. It’s strange that the fog is so thick this time of year. It should be lightening up, at least more than this.”

 

“You see my point then. It does seem very unnatural. Perhaps as though it was being caused by something,” Hubert continued, glancing at Shez now. “...Perhaps some form of magic?”

 

“Huh? Is there magic that can do that?” Shez asked.

 

“...Yes. There is. A rare type of magic. Some type of fell art, for instance. That certain groups may have knowledge of.”

 

“Huh. Like who?”

 

“...Oh, shit, is that what this is?” Emily asked after a second, and Hubert found himself reevaluating his impressions on the intelligence of the two girls because that was far too genuine of a question to be an attempt at deception. “Alright, guess that makes this easier!”

 

And she promptly broke rank and sprinted off into the mist, prompting Shez to stiffen in surprise.

 

“EM! Don’t just run off like that!” she called out before running off after her in the exact same way.

 

“Ah, wait! Shez! Emily!” And Ashe hurried after the pair too, leaving Hubert with a half-amused, half-bemused look on his face.

 

“...Well, this should have an interesting outcome.”

By the time Shez found Emily again, the fog was actually starting to fade. And the reason for that became clear soon enough as she discovered her friend pinning a dark mage to the ground and messily stabbing him in the chest over and over again.

 

“...Hey, Em, I think you got him,” Shez said, before noticing Ashe caught up to them. “Oh, hey Ashe.”

 

“...What in the world is wrong with you?!” Ashe asked, which felt kind of rude before Shez noticed he was staring right at Emily. Which was more fair.

 

“Oh what, a girl can’t relieve some tension~?” Emily teased, before pulling her dagger free and wiping it on the dead mage’s robes, “Not that this wretch was all that fun to go after. These magic types just don’t know what to do when you get too close to them~.” She smirked over at Ashe. “It’s the same for archers, in my experience~”

 

“Alright, we get it, you’re very scary, Em,” Shez replied, before looking around the field as her friend frowned at having her fun ruined, “Hm…do you see anybody that looks important?”

 

“Lonato.”

 

“Yeah, exactly, like Lonato–...” Shez glanced back at Ashe, then followed his line of sight towards the ruins at the end of the path. 

 

There, striding out from the pillars of some long ruined building, was the familiar sight of Lord Lonato of House Gaspard, his white hair hanging loose around his head as he regarded the three students from atop an armored warhorse. “...I see the Central Church was not satisfied with taking one son from me.”

 

“Oh? This is the beast we’re here to put down then?” Emily asked, regarding the old man with a faint interest before Ashe pushed past her.

 

“Lonato! Why are you doing this!?”

 

The Lord of Gaspard regarded his adoptive son for a moment, before looking towards Shez. “I remember you. Jeralt the Blade Breaker’s daughter. The younger one. Does your father work for the Knights of Seiros now, girl?”

 

“...I think you should answer Ashe, sir,” Shez replied, inclining her head towards her friend, who was staring at his adoptive father with a look of genuine betrayal.

 

“I would think my reasons were obvious. The Central Church is corrupt to its core! Rhea is an infidel who has deceived the people and desecrated the Goddess! The only righteous answer for her crimes in the death she has so readily delivered unto any who dare speak out against her heresy!”

 

“What are you talking about!? Lonato…what could justify doing this!?” Ashe questioned, “I saw the people out in the mist! They weren’t soldiers, they were townsfolk! Villagers that should have been under your protection!”

 

“Those who follow me are righteous crusaders who seek a better world than the cruelty we are trapped in by that vile witch! They are all bolstered by the blessings of the Goddess Herself! It does not matter what their origin is, only that they seek to fight for the truth!”

 

“So you sent untrained ‘civilians’ to die against fully armed and armored knights?” Emily noted, sounding amused, “You really are quite the vicious beast! I’m almost impressed!”

 

“Would you shut up!?” Ashe demanded, glaring at Emily, “Lonato isn’t a beast! He’s a kind man! A good man!”

 

Lonato’s gaze softened at Ashe’s defense of him, before he urged his horse forward. Shez’s eyes couldn’t help but go to the spear in his hand as the treacherous lord spoke. “You know the truth, Ashe. You know that Christophe was murdered by these heathens. Can’t you hear his soul screaming out for justice? 

 

His gaze turned towards Shez again. “Your father agreed with me. He knew the truth of the matter, that the Central Church could not be trusted, that Rhea was a liar and a monster! I know he would have joined me were he able! Will you not do the same!?”

 

“...Yeah, sorry, but whatever you have going on here has nothing to do with me,” Shez replied, “I don’t like Rhea, but I’m here to do a job. Or an assignment, I guess, since I’m a student.” She lifted one of her swords, pointing it at the Lord of Gaspard. “So either surrender or don’t. I’d prefer it if you do give up though, for Ashe’s sake.”

 

“...Just an ignorant child then, unwilling to accept reality. Fine then. I will end you before life’s cruelties have a chance to ruin that naive innocence.”

 

“Lonato, no!” Ashe yelled, “Please! I don’t want you to die!”

 

“I shall not, my foolish son. For I have virtue and the goddess herself on my side!” Lonato declared, before his horse broke into a full gallop, charging straight at the three students.

 

A smirk crossed Emily’s face, amused by the fool’s mad last stand, before it dropped when Ashe suddenly tackled her, pushing her out of the way of Lord Lonato’s charge. Shez, meanwhile, simply waited until the lord was close enough, his spear thrusting straight for her face, before she vanished in a violet flash that brought her right up on his horse’s back.

 

Lonato jerked back, genuine surprise in his eyes as he attempted to bring up his shield, but Shez was nothing if not fast, and her foot slammed into his chest, knocking him straight out of the saddle.

 

The Lord of Gaspard crashed to the ground with a heavy thud, followed by Shez as she landed far more easily on her feet. She moved towards the lord, her swords in hand, before she jerked back, bringing them up to deflect a sudden spear thrust from the old man, who made it to his feet far faster than she would have expected.

 

“You should have gone for the kill, girl,” Lonato growled, before stabbing straight at the young mercenary as she found herself getting pushed back by his ferocity.

 

“Lonato, stop, please!” Ashe yelled, getting up from the ground and running at his adoptive father, completely forgetting his own weapon as he tried to just get his father to stop, right before Lonato whirled around and slammed the shaft of his spear against the boy’s head. 

 

There was no pause from the old man, no moment of hesitation at what he had just done, he just moved straight back into trying to stab through Shez as though nothing had happened, completely uncaring for the son he’d left collapsed on the ground with a massive wound across his head.

 

Shez felt her eyes widen at the sight, before a scowl came to her face and she vanished again, appearing behind Lonato and stabbing at his back only for his shield to catch her blades. There was a dark look in the old man’s eyes as he shoved her back, cold and furious. “Don’t think that trick will work twice on me, you vile witch.”

 

He suddenly raised his shield, blocking a thrown knife before he directed a scowl towards Emily, who looked genuinely furious as well, though for what reason, he couldn’t care less. “Wait your turn. I’ll kill you next.”

 

“No, you won’t,” came a strong, authoritative voice as Thunder Catherine strode onto the field.

 

“Thunderstrike Cassandra…Come to taunt me with my son’s murder again?” Lonato asked, his eyes locked on the object of his hatred.

 

“I don’t answer to that name, Lonato. And I don’t have anything else to say to you.” Thunderbrand crackled in her hand, crimson energy flickering about its blade, stained with a mix of blood and steel after Catherine had cleaved through the armored knights of Lonato’s guard. 

 

“Fine. I don’t want to hear any justifications for your vile zealotry anyway.”

 

“Kids, get Ashe out of here,” Catherine ordered.

 

“Don’t tell me what to–!”

 

“But I can win this!” Shez shouted, interrupting Emily, “I know I can–”

 

“He’s not going to go down without you killing him, kid,” Catherine stated, “And I don’t think you want to do that.”

 

Shez hesitated, a conflicted look crossing her face, which Lonato decided to take full advantage of, suddenly stabbing towards her. 

 

"Watch out!" Arval shouted out to her, too late as the blade was about to pierce her, before a ball of flame caught him in the chest and sent him skidding back as Byleth Eisner stepped forward with a look of genuine rage on her face.

 

"Don’t you dare hurt my sister.”

 

With a flick of her hand, a healing light glowed around Ashe’s unconscious body, mending the wound in his head and stirring the boy awake as he blinked. “H-Huh?”

 

“By!” Shez exclaimed, surprised and happy to see her sister, which did bring some of her anger down.

 

“Hi Shez. Sorry, but I really want to kill this one. Could you handle the stragglers?”

 

Shez blinked. “Oh, uh…are you sure? I mean–”

 

“He k–...He was going to kill you, Shez. I’m going to kill him.” She glanced back at Ashe. “Sorry.”

 

“...P-Professor, please, can’t you try–”

 

“He made his choice.” Byleth turned away from them, and nodded to Catherine. “With me?”

 

“...Sure thing, professor.”

 

Lonato scowled, glaring at the two women. “You blind fools! Are you truly so enraptured by–”

 

Then a second fireball nearly took his head off, and would have if he hadn’t raised his shield in time. Not that it helped him much as Byleth and Catherine charged in with a flurry of blows, both their blades wreathed in lightning as they struck at the old lord. No more words were exchanged; none could be.

 

All that was left was the quick and methodical removal of every defense Lonato had as his spear was first struck from his grasp, then his shield was completely rent to scrap, and finally the pair of blades cut straight through his breastplate and his chest underneath, ripping through him in a bloodied X across his torso. 

 

Blood spat from his lips as Lonato stumbled backwards, his eyes still clouded by hate. “G-Gahh…th-that…vile woman…sh-she took…everything…”

 

Before he finally fell back with a crash, left with nothing but one last look at the foggy sky. “Christophe…f-forgive me…”

 

“...I’m sorry I couldn’t protect you back then,” Byleth muttered, staring down at the body of the once kind lord.

 

“...” Catherine sighed. “I never thought things would turn out like this. I never wanted it to.”

 

“You made your choices. You can’t take them back now.”

 

“I know.” Catherine clapped a hand to Byleth’s shoulder. “I’m sorry.”

 

“...Thank you.”

 

She nodded, gave Byleth’s shoulder another pat, then turned to walk off.

 

Byleth stared at the body for a few more seconds, then turned away too, going to check on her students and leaving Lonato’s body laying in the grassy field. Even in death, it was impossible to miss the regret on his face.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Yeah this mission didn't really have a happy ending

Red: It did not! Just, nope, no way it would end well. Lonato's too angry to stop and his people are too loyal to stand down. It's a moment made for tragedy.

Indi: And whatever Byleth may have thought, the moment Shez was in danger was the moment her mind was made up in what to do.

Red: In a world where Lonato was willing to even slightly step down, there might've been a shot for him to make it out alive. But he didn't and therefore made a choice he couldn't take back.

Indi: I'm sure Byleth can handle the trauma.

Talk of Tragedy

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

"Is everyone okay?" Edelgard asked once the battle had come to an end. Lonato was dead and his remaining forces were, well…also dead. Untrained civilians didn’t have much of a chance when facing off against trained combatants.

 

"Ah, no major injuries, Lady Edelgard," Ferdinand responded. "We've already healed up the minor ones as well." 

 

"C-Can we go home now?" Bernadetta asked, trembling as she gripped her bow. 

 

"Once the knights finish their sweep we will," Edelgard responded as she scanned her class. Despite Ferdinand's claim, it was clear he was merely putting on a brave face, especially given how shaken most of their class seemed. 

 

"Maybe we should sit down for now?" Dorothea asked, trying to put a smile on. "If we're going to wait, no sense in just standing around, right?" 

 

"That is true. In that case, everyone, make sure to rest and recover before we march back," Edelgard commanded, which seemed to be the right thing to do as a good deal of her class immediately collapsed onto the ground. "Hm, has anyone seen the professor?" 

 

"She went to find a river." Surprisingly, it was Emily who responded there, the student leaning against a tree. The disguised student scowled before pointing off in a direction. "That way." 

 

"Hm…Hubert, make sure to keep an eye on everyone. I shall return soon enough." 

 

“Of course, your majesty.”

 

"Ah, should I go with you, Lady Edelgard?" 

 

"Ferdinand, please stay here, I need to discuss something private with her," Edelgard responded, feeling thankful that he didn't press the topic as he moved to sit down. Walking off, Edelgard made sure to keep her guard up. While she was certain any remaining militia would surrender at sight of her, she still had to keep careful. 

 

That aside, she couldn't help but wonder what her professor was doing. She understood that she had her history with Lonato and Catherine, so Edelgard wanted to make sure her professor was okay. Thankfully, the river she was trying to find was nearby and she easily spotted the mercenary-turned-professor crouching down near it as she splashed water upon herself. 

 

"There you are, professor," Edelgard called out, before frowning as Byleth didn't respond. "Professor?" 

 

Walking up to her, Edelgard reached up to place a hand on her shoulder, making the mercenary flinch in response. 

 

"Ah, Edelgard, I didn't notice you," Byleth responded, turning to look at her. 

 

"Are you okay, professor? It's not like you to let someone sneak up on you." 

 

"I was just focusing on cleaning myself off," Byleth responded in the same tone, before she stuck her hands back into the water. There was nary a trace of blood on them even as she wrung them in the water. 

 

"...Professor, I heard what happened with Lord Lonato. Do you want to speak about it?" 

 

"There's nothing to talk about, we completed our mission, and now we wait to head back," Byleth responded, "Did anyone get hurt?" 

 

"...No, professor," Edelgard answered, "If I may ask, how close were you to Lord Lonato?" 

 

"Not especially. He was a client, if one I failed," Byleth answered. "Though…I can't help but wonder if I hadn't failed, would things have ended up like this?" 

 

"I suppose that is something we all have to wonder about our own failures," Edelgard said, looking down at the water herself. "Even now, I can't help but wonder what my decisions will cause." 

 

"Right… being the emperor means you'll need to decide big things." 

 

"Yes, it also means I cannot afford to hesitate or falter either. As the Emperor I may face issues with any reforms I establish, and may even likely have to end a rebellion like this one should they arise. Even if someone I care about is leading them." 

 

"That sounds… tough." 

 

"Such is the price of being the one in charge. Even if I end up like Lonato and end up sending citizens to their deaths for a just cause, I must continue onward. Though I suppose that's easier to say now since I am just a student." 

 

"...Hm." Byleth brought her hands out of the water. "I don't think I could ever do that." 

 

“Truly? You seem skilled as a commander though.”

 

“Right. And I want to keep everyone under my command alive. I don’t think I could sacrifice people. I just…” She sighed, before brushing her hands on her clothes. “I understand there will always be a risk of death in battle. But I’m not going to let anyone die for me if I can prevent it.”

 

“Hm…perhaps that’s the difference between a commander and a ruler…” Edelgard mused, before shaking her head when Byleth glanced at her, “Never mind. We should get back to everyone." 

 

"We should," Byleth agreed as she stood up, "Hopefully the knights will finish their sweep soon." 

As Edelgard went off to find Byleth, the Black Eagles couldn't calm down as they waited for the knights to finish their sweep. One student in particular couldn't help but let out a frustrated yell. 

 

"Agh! What was the point of this!?" Caspar yelled out as he stomped his foot, "They didn't even need us, it was just a bunch of townsfolk!" 

 

"..." Ferdinand clenched his jaw, frustration evident on his face. 

 

"One can only wonder just what led Lord Lonato into doing this…" Hubert muttered. 

 

"It doesn't matter what reason he had! He led a bunch of innocent people to their deaths!" Caspar shouted again. 

 

"Oh why are you complaining? Townsfolk or not, the fact that they rebelled makes them 'outlaws' doesn't it?" Emily asked, a mocking grin on her face. 

 

Caspar stiffened, his gaze turning towards his classmate. “What the hell? What is wrong with you?!”

 

"...How could you say that?" Dorothea asked, equally taken aback by Emily’s mockery. 

 

"How could I say that? I'm not the one who was arguing about the morality of killing 'subhumans' now was I?" she asked again, making Caspar flinch. 

 

"How are you having the knowledge of that? You were not in the class," Petra questioned with a faint frown. 

 

"What, do you think I skip out on class all the time? Just because you don't notice me doesn't mean I'm not around," Emily said, pointedly staring at Hubert with that line, making him bristle in response. "Either way, don't act like you're better just because you only kill 'bad guys'. Who knows, maybe one day one of you might be a 'bad guy' we go up against? Because regardless of what side of that I'm on, I certainly won't hesitate." 

 

Ferdinand stood straighter with a deep frown on his face. “We are all part of the same class, Emily, and citizens of the Empire as well! There is nothing that would cause us to fight each other like that!”

 

“Pfffft–HA! Aw, you can’t believe that, Fer- dee ,” she mocked, smirking at the tall redhead, “Wasn’t it your dear old daddy who turned against the emperor, hm? You can’t tell me you forgot~. I’m sure Edel didn’t~. So I wonder how long it’s going to be before Adrestians start spilling Adrestian blood again~! Though who’s to say it’ll even be the good princess that decides to take her vengeance, hm? Maybe there’ll be a commoner uprising, or the big bad general in charge of the military decides he should be at the top of it all?

 

Her smirk widened as she stepped closer, playful and cruel as Ferdinand grimaced, clearly unhappy. “Don’t think for a second that you’re safe because of lineage or authority or that special, noble blood of yours. The most powerful man in the Empire can get splattered by a rock on complete accident. Do you really think you won’t get dragged into the violence when Edel decides your daddy’s gotta go? Because you and me, we both know it’s coming. And when he goes, well…I see a whole lot of people here whose parents were part of that Insurrection that got all her siblings–”

 

“Korsch.”

 

Emily paused, then glanced over at Hubert with a mocking smile. “Oops. What, you don’t like being reminded that your own daddy betrayed the Imperial family?”

 

“I am well aware of what my father has done,” he replied in a low, dangerous tone, “You’re not doing yourself any favors by dredging up the past.”

 

“Ooo, how scary~ Though speaking of favors, none of you are doing any favors to yourself by acting like you're on some moral high horse. Murder is murder, no matter who you kill," Emily said, a smirk on her face. Which faded away to annoyance as Byleth and Edelgard walked back to the group. 

 

"..." Byleth glanced around the group, seeing the obvious tension in the air. As well as several glares aimed at Emily. Aside from Bernadetta, who was hiding as far behind a tree as she could get. "...We should head back to the monastery." 

 

"Professor?" Looking at Byleth, Edelgard felt a bit surprised. 

 

"There's not much else we can do here. I'll make sure to deal with any trouble in case the church gets angry we went back early," Byleth said, before nodding to the class. "All of you deserve to be able to rest in a bed, not on the ground in the cold." 

 

"Well, I certainly won't argue with that," Lindhart muttered, finally speaking up as he stood up. "I'll go on ahead."

 

Silently Byleth watched the students begin to walk off, before she glanced at Edelgard. "Make sure none of them wander off, I'll catch up soon." 

 

"Try not to take too long, professor," Edelgard said, nodding as she walked towards the group. 

 

"Emily, a word." Byleth called out to the minor noble before she could walk off. 

 

"Hm? What do you want?" 

 

"Are you okay?" 

 

"...Huh? What's with the sudden question?" 

 

"You were in the fight with Lord Lonato, right?" Byleth asked. "I didn't check earlier, but were you injured against him?" 

 

"Feh, as if I would get hurt by an old man like him. Also, why are you still calling him 'Lord' Lonato? You were the one who killed him." 

 

"..." Byleth’s face tightened. "Yeah, I did. He was a good man, and I still had to kill him. Regardless of what I thought of him, he nearly killed Shez. You can say I was being selfish, but between the two, I would choose my sister every time." 

 

"...Heh, not so much of a goody two shoes are you?" 

 

"I never said I was," Byleth responded, "All I want to do is make sure the people I care about are safe." 

 

“...Hmph. Sure, whatever,” she muttered, walking away without another word.

 

Byleth watched her leave and let out a little sigh. She knew this mission was going to be messy no matter what happened, but she didn’t think it would be this bad. 

 

And she still couldn’t get that image out of her head. The memory of a time that hadn’t happened, one where Lonato had readily stabbed her sister straight through the chest.

Shez wasn't sure what she should feel. She was glad none of her classmates got hurt, but that didn't mean it was all okay. She reached her hand up, about to reach over to Ashe as her friend cried over Lonato. 

 

"Please don't beat yourself up, Ashe. We did what we had to do." Only to immediately bring her hand back as Dimitri spoke up. 

 

"I… I know. I'm sorry." Ashe said, wiping away his tears. 

 

"Ah…Hey Ashe, why don't you go check on your siblings?" Shez suggested, not really sure what else to say. 

 

"Y-Yeah, I should… check on them and the town," Ashe said, trying to put on a brave face. "I-I'll return as quickly as possible." 

 

Nodding to the two, Ashe ran off, leaving Shez alone with Dimitri. 

 

"That… I've had to deal with rebellions before, but that was the first time I've had to fight civilians, those I've sworn to protect…" the prince murmured.

 

"...I've uh, never had to do something like this either," Shez responded, unsure of what else to say to that. 

 

"I would imagine so. Captain Jeralt does not seem like the type of man who would accept such work," Dimitri said, before he frowned. "How is your sister doing? I had heard that she was the one to…deal with Lonato." 

 

"...Her and…Catherine." Shez really wasn't sure how to feel about that. She knew it was their mission to work with her but…Why would Byleth be willing to work with the knight who nearly killed her? And to take out Lonato? Gritting her teeth, Shez couldn't help but feel angry. 

 

She had hoped that maybe they could have talked Lonato down. Maybe it didn't have to end with his death. But then…

 

“There wasn’t anything you could do there,” Arval assured, “Your sister made that quite clear.”

 

“...” Shez let out a breath and turned back to Dimitri. “So…You fought in a rebellion before?”

 

“Ah…I did, yes. It was in the west, though…more north from here,” the prince explained, his gaze turning northward, “...Would you believe I cannot even remember the name of the lords that rebelled? They were minor in the grand scheme of things, seeking independence from the kingdom after my father’s death. They claimed their lands shouldn’t belong to Faerghus, for they were once their own independent nation…hm. It is…interesting to think that these ‘men of Mach’ wanted independence from Faerghus just as Faerghus wanted independence from Adrestia…”

 

“Uh…neat? Why’s that important?”

 

“I’m just…thinking of the parallel. That was the battle where I…ah, never mind. We already have far too many tragedies marring this day to discuss my failings.”

 

“Oh, alright, if you say so.” Shez shrugged, not really getting why Dimitri brought that stuff up if he didn’t want to talk about it. “Should we head back to everybody then?”

 

“Ah…yes, I suppose we should.” Weird, he seemed kind of disappointed.

 

Arval sighed. “Partner, he clearly wants to talk about his ‘tragedy’ here, he is just being overly polite. Talk to him.”

 

“Oh, uh…hey Dimitri! Tell me about…that thing that happened!”

 

Dimitri blinked. “Er…which thing are you referring to?”

 

“You know, the thing you said was a failure. What’s up with that?”

 

Arval sighed again. “You are a master of tact, partner.”

 

“Ah…well, it…To make a long story short, I showed a side of myself that I didn’t intend to during the battle against the rebels, and Felix witnessed my…savage actions. He did not take it well.”

 

“Oh, that’s why he’s such an asshole to you?”

 

Dimitri blinked, then pretended to cough. “I would not…he has his reasons.”

 

“Well what are they? Because I’m pretty sure there’s some kind of rule where you can get in a lot of trouble for insulting royalty, right?”

 

“They are…I really shouldn’t speak of Felix’s behalf–”

 

“Okay, then tell me what you’re thinking. You can’t speak for Felix, sure, but you can speak for yourself. Why do you think he’s mad all the time?”

 

“...A few reasons, I imagine. His brother died for my sake, and while fighting alongside one another, he saw that I…enjoyed it.”

 

“Enjoyed fighting? That’s not that weird. I mean it’s kind of hypocritical for him to get mad at that when he’s always picking fights.”

 

“Killing. He saw me enjoy killing.”

 

Shez blinked. “Ohh…uh, hm. So that's it then…”

 

He sighed. “So now you know. And I can tell you are revising your opinion of me as well. I understand, I am a monster-”

 

“H-Hey, hey, look, I don’t think you’re a monster. I think it’s…weird that you like killing, that’s not really something I would hope to hear from a king and all–Hey, no getting sad! I can see your face getting sad!” 

 

“Ah, a-apologies, I just–”

 

“No! Shush! Just…okay! You’re not the first friend I’ve had that’s homicidal, and you’re nice! Seriously, you’re not even that aggressive, you’re like…I dunno, I guess animal-wise I’m supposed to call you a lion since that’s the Faerghus thing? But you’re more…friendly? I don’t know what lions are like, by the way, I’m just trying to say you’re not a bad person despite liking to murder people–No, hold on, that wasn’t how I meant to say that. I mean, it’s not like you stalk the streets looking for victims, right? You just get too into it when you’re fighting.”

 

“...It…There is…more to it than that. I do not…enjoy that side of myself, but it does exist. And I understand why it would horrify those around me if ever I were to embrace it. No one should enjoy hurting others, much less killing them.”

 

“Yeah, but people do. I mean, look at Emily. She’s pretty much an outright sadist, but she’s still my friend. Stuff like that…it’s not all there is to someone. And from what she’s told me, she put those urges towards hunting, not murdering commoners, so that’s a good thing you could maybe try?”

 

“...You are referring to the act of hunting, and not the part about murdering commoners, right?”

 

“Wha–No, of course I mean the hunting part, not the–...” She frowned, scrutinizing the prince. “Was that a joke?”

 

He tried not to smile. “I was just asking for clarification.”

 

“...Feh. Alright, if you’re feeling good enough to poke fun at me, then you’re good enough to admit you have more good qualities than bad ones! So knock it off with the sad stuff.”

 

“Right, of course.” Dimitri did his best to smile. “Don’t worry, I’m feeling better.”

 

“...Okay, good. Hm…hey, do you think we should follow Ashe and check out Gaspard? You know, make sure things are okay?”

 

“Hm…while I do see the kind intentions behind that gesture, I do not think it would be the best idea to go there directly after killing so many of the town’s citizens.”

 

“Oh. Ah, yeah…yeah, that’s a good point.” And that brought down the mood again.

 

Shez let out a sigh. Hopefully next month's mission will be easier. 

Chapter End Notes

Indi: This chapter was partially inspired by a comment someone said in which they hoped Byleth would use the Eagles' words against them, and while Byleth isn't cruel and would not do so, Emily wouldn't have those reservations

Red: Yep! So thank you to that commenter for inspiring this!

Indi: Kinda a fun thing that thanks to Shez, Kronya thinks she has an easy in now and just, doesn't even need to try with her classmates now. Meanwhile everyone else is dealing with trauma.

Red: And then there's Ashe and Dimitri, who are trauma personified. Well, Ashe is for the moment, Dimitri meanwhile is always like that.

Indi: I'm sure things will get better for everyone. Eventually.

New Month, New Problems

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Claude sighed. It was a long, drawn out sigh, one designed to attract attention from a certain purple-haired classmate of his. Not the pompous one or the easily frightened one, but the mercenary one, who was currently sitting at the same table as him in the mess hall.

 

She didn’t notice, apparently too invested in the meat skewers she was trying, so he decided to sigh louder and longer, really putting in some weary, “woe is me” oomph into it. Still nothing. So he decided to try again and was promptly jabbed in the shoulder by Hilda.

 

“Would you knock it off? She’s not going to notice.”

 

“Mmf? Notice what?” Shez asked, glancing across the table at the two of them. “Woah, hey Claude, when did you get here?”

 

“...Okay, point taken, no more being subtle with Shez,” he decided, before grinning over at his mercenary friend, “Hey Shez. I was just thinking that it’s a shame your class basically got to spend an entire month with the Eagles while us poor Deer were left out in the cold.”

 

“I don’t think you can really say that considering how cold Faerghus was when we went up there,” Shez replied.

 

“The metaphorical cold. The cold of loneliness, as we were left abandoned by our friends and classmates as they went on their own special mission.”

 

“It wasn’t that special. We killed a civilian militia and Ashe’s dad, so it was actually pretty depressing.” He wouldn’t guess it from how casual her tone was. “Dimitri took it kind of hard. I think he thinks he should have done more? But he was more lively when I saw him earlier today so I guess he’s fine.”

 

"Well he is going to be the king of Faerghus, so I guess that's to be expected. From what I've heard, the nobles of that house have had to put down some rebellions before, so they're probably used to it. Same can't be said for the Black Eagles though," Claude mentioned, glancing over at Ferdinand, who seemed quite restless as he tried to enjoy his tea. 

 

"...Yeah, even By and I haven't done something like that before, so it must be tough on them," Shez said as she let out a sigh. "Guess I'm just too used to the mercenary lifestyle to think about how stuff like this is affecting them." 

 

"Ah, but it's that same experience that helped make sure they all returned back, so I say that makes it even," Claude said with a wink. "Though I must say, the Lions and Eagles getting trained by two skilled mercs is quite enviable. Why, at this rate, the Golden Deer won't stand a chance at the Battle of Lion and Eagle." 

 

"Heh, guess that means you'll have to find your own merc." 

 

"You wound me, my friend! You'll send me out alone in this cold dark world without any help? And here I thought a mercenary of your caliber had more honor than that." Claude sighed dramatically. "To think, first the older sister plans on stealing one of my own, and now the little sister can't even spare any kindness." 

 

Shez quirked an eyebrow. "What's that about By stealing?" 

 

"The professor is obviously planning on stealing Marianne away, of course." 

 

"Wait, what?" Hilda asked, surprised at that revelation. 

 

"Isn't it obvious? She and Marianne have been spending plenty of time together with the horses, and they even had tea together. Clearly she's planning on stealing the members of our house, starting with her." 

 

"...uh, pretty sure that's just By being nice," Shez replied. 

 

"Yeah, like, it's nice Marianne has another friend, but I'm not sure how well she'd do in a different class,” Hilda said, “Heck, it sounds like Ferdinand and Linhardt are a bit too overbearing for her from what she said." 

 

"Wait, seriously? I can get Ferdinand being too much, but half the time I see Linhardt he's practically falling asleep, and the other half of the time he's actually asleep." 

 

"I'm just going off what I heard. Granted, Marianne didn't tell me directly, it was more so her muttering." 

 

"Hm…well, I'll check with By, just in case." 

 

"If you're going to do that, why not also ask how my house can team up with hers, or yours if we can?" Claude asked, trying to get the topic back on track. "After all, it's only fair we get to have a little fun too, no?" 

 

"Why don't you ask her then? I don't even know what mission we'll have this week and until we have that info, there's no telling what it'll be like." 

 

"Hm…true. I can't help but wonder if it'll be more exciting than having to deal with a rebellion." 

 

"Not sure how it can be." 

"Our mission this month is to assist the knights in defending the monastery against an assassination attempt on the archbishop,” Byleth bluntly stated to her class after she received the mission. 

 

"W-What!?" Bernadetta squeaked, nearly falling out of her chair. 

 

"It's just one thing after another isn't it…" Lin muttered, slumped on his desk. 

 

"To be specific, the knights themselves will be defending the archbishop, while we, along with the other Houses, will be patrolling the monastery on the Rite of Rebirth to ensure nothing happens," Byleth explained, trying to ease the tension. "We've even been allowed to choose where to patrol." 

 

"To further add on to what the professor said, we believe the assassination attempt may be an attempt to hide what the perpetrators might truly be after," Edelgard said, getting her classmates to look at her. "As such, we will need to find what places they might be likely to strike."

 

"C-Can I just patrol my room?" Bernadetta asked, getting Edelgard to sigh. 

 

"...Hm." Said sigh abruptly stopped as she saw her professor actually think about that. "The dormitories are where several nobles are residing, so they might try to steal any valuables there…" 

 

“A-Ah! I don’t want any thieves coming into my room!” Bernadetta yelped, looking even more worried.

 

“I don’t think you’ll have to worry about that, Bernadetta,” Ferdinand said, “Excuse me for saying so, professor, but I don’t think it’s likely anyone would fake an assassination attempt on the archbishop just to steal some things from the students.”

 

“We have to consider all possibilities,” Byleth countered. "As such, we'll be working with the other classes to ensure we're evenly spread out. If you find anything worth reporting, then do make sure to inform Professor Manuela and Professor Hanneman." 

 

"Well that's good. Who knows, maybe this month we won't have a tough mission," Dorothea muttered as she leaned back in her chair. 

 

"Heh, I dunno about you, but I'm fired up to fight some real bad guys!" Caspar shouted, not wanting to sit still. 

 

"As long as we are not fighting in the cold, I shall be ready," Petra said with a nod. 

 

"...If any of you need to, then take it easy for the investigation,” Byleth said, “There will be many eyes on watch, so not everyone needs to assist." 

 

"Professor?" Edelgard gave Byleth a surprised look. 

 

"We trained a lot last month, it's important to recover so we don't strain ourselves," Byleth explained, though Edelgard felt that wasn't the full story as the professor moved to the chalkboard. "For now though, we have a lesson to start. A few of you were interested in my technique to keep warm while in cold regions, so we will be focusing on magic studies for today.”

 

“Aw, c’mon,” Caspar whined, already looking annoyed, “I’m never good with this reason stuff…”

 

“It’s just an opening lesson, Caspar. I’m sure by the end of it, everyone should be able to cast at least a basic spell, though we might have some difficulties actually teaching the warming technique to those who can’t cast fire spells.” Byleth tilted her head in thought as she started sketching some basic sigils and diagrams from her books on magic. “If it helps, I can show you how to set your weapons on fire with magic afterwards.”

 

“Wait, really? Then alright, let’s do this!”

 

Edelgard did her best not to sigh or roll her eyes at her classmate’s enthusiasm. Instead, she paid attention to the professor’s lesson, which she did have to admit was fairly basic in terms of magical education. That didn’t make it useless though, especially as the professor took the time to make sure everyone could cast at least a basic version of an elemental spell, and there was some practice afterwards as everyone gave their new abilities a try.

 

Unfortunately for Bernadetta and especially Petra, it turned out their own “natures” didn’t mesh well with fire at all. Bernadetta turned out to be better with ice and thunder magic, while Petra only managed to form a basic wind spell, much to her disappointment.

 

Caspar, however, was the most vocally disappointed, as he discovered that it was actually very difficult to light a weapon on fire without causing the whole thing to fall apart. 

 

“Agh, how do you do this!?” he asked Byleth, looking frustrated at the charred axe in his hand.

 

“Hm…I think part of the problem is that you have to be doing calculations in your head the whole time,” Byleth explained, picking an axe up from the pile to help demonstrate, “The actual mathematics tend to vary. It’s not as simple as saying it’s arithmetic or calculus, it’s more about remembering a sequence of symbols and how they relate to each other. The sigils formed when magic is used does have specific meanings to it. I tend to think of it as ‘fire’ plus ‘control’ added on top of ‘blade’, where blade represents a changing variable. That variable has to be marked as ‘non-consumable’ because fire naturally wants to burn whatever it’s attached to, which is tricky to do. You can’t convince ‘fire’ to recognize the variable as ‘fire’ because then it reacts to it like it’s a competing flame…Sorry, am I making sense?”

 

Caspar crossed his arms over his chest and nodded firmly. “Totally! I just don’t get it at all!”

 

“Ah. Hm…maybe I could ask the blacksmith if he can make you a magic axe?”

 

“Oh wow, would you?? That would be awesome!”

 

“Sure, why not? I was just going to get you flowers for your birthday, but a magic axe sounds better.”

 

“A magic axe sounds way better! Wait, you know it’s my birthday today?”

 

“Yup. I like to keep track of these things.”

 

“Aw man, you’re the best, professor!” At least he was happy by the end of the lesson. The same couldn’t be said for the pair of students who came up to Byleth after class though, while the professor was reading through some papers at her desk.

 

“Professor? Do you think we could talk for a moment?” Dorothea asked, prompting Byleth to glance up at her and Bernadetta, who seemed as fidgety as usual.

 

“Sure, what do you need?”

 

“...” Dorothea took a breath. “I wanted to ask…Does it get any easier? The…” She sighed. “Killing people, like we did on the assignment.”

 

“I don’t think I’m the right person to ask that question to.”

 

Dorothea paused, before frowning in some concern. “...What do you mean, professor?”

 

“I mean it’s always been easy for me.” Byleth glanced at Bernadetta when she noticed her flinch, but decided not to mention it at the moment. “I don’t like killing, but I don’t feel anything when I kill. I don’t take pleasure in it. I just don’t hesitate.”

 

“...R-Really? B-But you l-looked sad,” Bernadetta said, before stiffening, “A-Ah! I-I’m s-sorry, d-d-don’t be mad!”

 

“I’m not mad at you, Bernadetta. I didn’t realize I looked sad. I told Petra before, but I have trouble with emotions. I just don’t care the same way other people do. It’s not a bad thing that you two care. You might want to ask someone else about this though. I don’t think I’ll be very helpful.”

 

“...” Dorothea took another breath, though she smiled this time. “I guess I am just different from you then, professor. I...Well, I’m willing to accept that it’s what I need to do, even if I don’t like it.”

 

Byleth nodded. “I hope you never do like it. Killing is unpleasant. Do what you need to, and make sure to survive.”

 

“...I will thank you for admitting you’re not good at this sort of thing though,” Dorothea said, her smile taking on a hint of humor, “It does help to know that it isn’t easy for you, just in a different way than it’s difficult for me.”

 

Byleth didn’t entirely get what she meant, but she nodded regardless. “I hope this helped. Bernadetta, did you want to ask me anything specific?”

 

“H-H-Huh?! A-Ah, n-n-no! I-I’m f-f-fine!”

 

“Huh? But I thought you wanted to–”

 

“I-I don’t! B-Bye!” And Bernadetta promptly ran in the other direction, which…well, Byleth had hoped they were moving past that point, but she supposed it would take some more time.

 

“Oh dear, there she goes…ah, see you, professor! Hopefully we can have a more lighthearted chat next time,” Dorothea said before she headed out too.

 

Byleth waited until the songstress had left before she glanced at the entrance to her classroom. “Did you want to talk too, Ferdinand?”

 

There was a pause, then the heir to House Aegir entered the room with a slightly sheepish look. “Ah, I see you have some very strong observational skills, professor! And here I thought I was completely hidden in the doorway, haha!”

 

“You weren’t.”

 

“...Yes, well, ah…so! How are you today, professor?”

 

“I’m fine. How are you?”

 

“Good! Excellent, really, I actually recently acquired an exquisite tea set and…and I, ah…” Ferdinand trailed off, seeming to lose track of his thoughts. “...I, ah…I think…I understand what you meant before. When you were talking about bandits.”

 

Byleth stared at her student, then nodded. “Do you want to take a seat?”

 

“No, no, I should stand for this…I think. I…It feels like a topic I should be standing for, isn’t it? I mean…It’s strange. I think…I still believe there is a difference between the average, ordinary commoner and a bandit. A fundamental difference! Because bandits choose to become thieves when other people, many in similar situations, do not.”

 

“Okay.”

 

He paused. “O-Okay?”

 

“Okay. I disagree with you, but I acknowledge that’s the viewpoint you hold. I’m not here to argue with you, Ferdinand. I’m here to help, and you look like you need help.”

 

“...I…Wait, professor, you don’t need to get up,” he protested as Byleth stood, but she still got up from her seat and went over to get a chair for him.

 

She set it down in front of her desk, then took her seat again. “Please sit down.”

 

“...” Ferdinand sat. It felt…strange. Like he was a boy again, sitting in front of his father’s grand desk, a symbol of his position as the prime minister. Then he looked again and it was just his professor, sitting at her usual teaching desk. “...It felt different. Lonato’s rebellion.”

 

Byleth just nodded, silent and patient.

 

“I…I don’t understand how he could have involved innocents in the way he did. A lord’s duty is to protect his people, but he…he used them! It doesn’t matter if they volunteered, he should have told them no! It isn’t their place to fight, it’s the duty of knights and soldiers! Not untrained commoners given the bare minimum of weapons and armor!”

 

His fists clenched in his lap. “It is a noble’s duty to…to protect people! They shouldn’t drag the innocent into their own personal vendettas! He let so many of his people die, and for what!? He should have known his goal was impossible! Not just impossible, completely mad to even attempt! How could he throw his own people away like that?! He might as well have set their houses ablaze for all the good he did them!

 

“They even called him a good lord! They said he didn’t deserve to suffer anymore! His people loved him and he treated them like garbage! How could he do that!?! All just for his own worthless greed!?! HE–...” Ferdinand took a shaky, furious breath. “...I apologize, professor. It was unbecoming of me to raise my voice like that.”

 

“It’s okay,” Byleth reassured, “It happens when people get angry. It’s not wrong to be angry at injustice.”

 

“...I just…how many orphans did he leave behind? He likely devastated his entire territory, and I know he had children he essentially abandoned. And for such a meaningless reason too…” He unclenched his fists and flexed his fingers, hoping to remove what little stiffness that was there. “...I don’t know how he could be so cruel.”

 

“People are willing to do horrible things for their families.” Byleth pretended not to notice the way Ferdinand flinched. She wasn’t exactly pleased to see further evidence for her theory that Ferdinand wasn’t just talking about Lonato. “In Lonato’s case, I think he cared more about the injustice of his son’s death than what would happen afterwards.”

 

“...You knew him before, right, professor?” Ferdinand asked, “Did you…What did you feel, when you had to kill him?”

 

“...Sad, I think,” Byleth answered, “I was angry because he would have killed Shez, but I think I was sad too. Emotions are complicated.”

 

Ferdinand huffed in wry amusement. “I am well aware of that fact, professor. It’s…strange, how varied the heart can be. You can love someone, even idolize them, and yet still feel such…genuine horror towards them that you’ll just…” He sighed. “I am getting off topic. My apologies.”

 

"You can talk about what you want, I'll be here to listen." 

 

"Thank you professor. I must admit being able to… express myself like this has certainly helped." 

 

"If you ever want to do it again, feel free to ask. It's my job to help my students after all." 

 

"I'll make sure to remember that Professor. Ah, but I have one more thing to bring up." At the inquisitive tilt of her head, he continued. "It was about this month's mission, I did have one suggestion, it may benefit us to keep an eye on stables. It may not be their true intention, but setting a fire there could cause a panic to occur as the horses run wild." 

 

“Hm…that’s a good point. I’ll recommend a portion of the guard keep watch over the stables then. Thank you for the suggestion.”

 

A slight smile returned to Ferdinand’s face. “You’re very welcome, professor. Anything I can do to help!”

 

“You are very helpful, Ferdinand. Don’t lose that enthusiasm, okay?”

 

His smile got even bigger and Byleth ruthlessly squashed the part of her that wondered if she just made a mistake. “Thank you for saying so, professor! Very well, I shall continue to strive to be the very best noble I can be! I will become Lady Edelgard’s closest confidant and prove my father wrong!” What? “Or my name isn’t Ferdinand von Aegir! Ahahaha!”

 

Ferdinand continued to laugh as he stood and turned on his heel, heading for the doorway full of noble pomp and grandeur. Before pausing halfway there and turning back towards Byleth. “Ah, actually, I did have one more question. Do you know how I am like a bee?”

 

“...what?”

 

“It is a thing Dorothea said to me that’s been plaguing my mind–Actually, never mind! This is a puzzle she has given me to unravel, and I shall not ask for aid! Thank you again professor! May you have a lovely rest of your day!”

 

“...Okay. Thank you.” Byleth watched Ferdinand leave, then sank back in her chair, frowning to herself. “...How is he like a bee…?”

 

She tilted her head back, staring up at the ceiling. “...Ferdibee von Hiver…”

“Huh. You don’t see that everyday,” Jeralt murmured to himself as he noticed both of his daughters were at the dock overlooking the monastery’s pond. Seeing Byleth there wasn’t unusual, especially since she’d really taken to fishing at the pond in her downtime, but Shez rarely had the patience to sit still long enough for the hobby. “...Eh, might as well see what the occasion is.”

 

“Hmmmm…” Shez stared into the water, almost glaring at the fish in there as she sat on the dock. The fish that were plentiful, but weren’t going near her hook at all. “Mrgh…I thought fish were supposed to like worms?”

 

“They do,” Byleth replied, sitting beside her sister and keeping her rod far steadier.

 

“Then why don’t they like my worm??”

 

“Not sure. Maybe they’re just not biting today.”

 

“...” Shez looked at her sister, then looked at the bucket beside her sister, which was currently overflowing with a number of herrings, loaches, trout, and even a pike. Then she looked at her own bucket, which currently had a goby and a live crayfish inside it. “...”

 

“...” Byleth normally had a very easy time keeping her face neutral. She was having a surprisingly difficult time at the moment though.

 

“Hey kids,” Jeralt greeted as he came over to his daughters, taking a seat beside Shez with a fishing rod of his own in hand. 

 

“Oh, hey dad! What’s up?” Shez greeted while Byleth simply gave her father a nod of acknowledgement, too focused on fish for the moment.

 

“I saw you two down here and decided I should take a break. Hope you don’t mind your old man joining you.”

 

“Nope! The more the merrier! Well, so long as you don’t steal all my fish.”

 

“I don’t think you’ll need to worry about that.”

 

“Oh? And why’s–Dad, come on, even I know you need to put a hook on the string,” she complained.

 

“The line,” Byleth corrected, which prompted her sister to try to poke her in the side. Byleth, however, simply deflected the attempt with a quick hand before returning to her fishing, prompting a chuckle from her father.

 

“Well if you want to help me out, I wouldn’t mind. You know these old hands aren’t as dextrous as they used to be.”

 

Shez huffed, then glanced at Byleth. “Hey By, why don’t you help dad? You’re the master fisherwoman here.”

 

“Okay,” Byleth agreed, pulling her hook in before setting the rod aside and getting up to help her father out.

 

“Thanks kid,” Jeralt said as he pretended not to notice Shez swapping her and Byleth’s buckets.

 

“It’s no trouble,” Byleth replied. She tied the hook to the line easily enough, then returned to her place on the dock and cast her line out again before taking a seat. After a second, she glanced at “her” bucket, then picked out the crayfish inside and set it on her shoulder where the small crustacean settled down surprisingly calmly.

 

Shez snorted at the sight and couldn’t stop herself from giggling, which definitely wasn’t helping her attempts at fishing.

 

Jeralt grinned at the sight, then settled in. Despite Shez’s claims, the fish were definitely plentiful and it wasn’t long before he had a decently sized bullhead wriggling on his hook.

 

“...That’s just not fair,” Shez complained while Byleth made a faintly impressed noise at the sizable catfish. 

 

“What can I say? I guess experience triumphs over youthful vigor again,” Jeralt teased.

 

“Mrgh.” Shez went back to grumbling, glaring mulishly at the water, while Jeralt noticed a flicker of…something, cross Byleth’s face. She was still happy, at least from what he could tell, but there was something under it as her eyes lingered on Shez a little too long.

 

“...So, hey, how have things been going for you two?” Jeralt decided to ask after he cast his line back out. 

 

"Eh, about the same I guess. Claude was being all annoying cause he felt left out after the mission we just had." 

 

"...He felt left out because he didn't help against the rebellion?" 

 

"Yeah I don't know what's up with him, but hey, we're technically working together this month," Shez said as she shrugged her shoulders. "Oh, speaking of, apparently the Lions are gonna be guarding the vault, in case they try to take any weapons there." 

 

"Hm, that makes sense… hey, do you know where they might target?" Byleth asked as she began to reel something in. 

 

"Kid, there's so many valuable things here, even I don't know them all. Besides, as the acting knight captain, I'll be too focused on keeping Rhea guarded.” A thought occurred there that he decided to voice. “Meanwhile, you two should keep an eye out for your house leaders.”

 

“Huh? Why’s that?” Shez asked, looking surprised. 

 

“Just a thought I had. There’s a lot of important heirs here this year and they already had someone go after them.”

 

“They did?”

 

“The Iron King bandits, remember? Call it a hunch, but it seems too coincidental that they were in the right place at the right time to go after the prince, princess, and…whatever the Riegan’s kid title would be,” Jeralt explained, “Odds are, they were hired for the job and given details on where they were. And if we consider that, we should also consider that this new bunch might be after them too.”

 

“I dunno, that sounds pretty far-fetched,” Shez replied, “Not everything’s connected, y’know?”

 

"True, it might be paranoia, but I might also be right. Either way, I'd make sure to tell those brats to keep an eye out for themselves." Jeralt paused, noticing that the fish managed to slip out of Byleth’s line as he said that. 

 

"...Hm." 

 

"Hey, By, something up?” Shez asked, “You're being quieter than usual." 

 

"Everything is okay.”

 

Yeah, Jeralt didn’t believe that for a second. "Come on kid, we won't be able to help if you don't tell us.”

 

"...In the mission, I had to use that power," Byleth finally responded. 

 

"Wait, really? Is that how you saved Ingrid?" Shez asked, completely surprised. "Wow, that power of yours really is amazing."

 

"...Must be weighing on you though. Even if you managed to stop it, you still had to experience it," Jeralt sympathized, as Byleth began to shift in place. 

 

"...That wasn't the only time I used it that day." 

 

"Huh? Who else did you save?" Shez asked, before Byleth silently looked at her. "...Oh." 

 

"...What happened?" Jeralt asked, feeling a faint sense of dread.

 

"Lonato…he stabbed Shez. I wanted to talk to him, but…when I saw that, I didn't care." Byleth’s grip tightened on her fishing pole. 

 

“Her power is that strong?” Arval muttered, before huffing in the back of Shez’s mind. “Well, at least she is using it for a good cause. I suppose there’s at least a use for it if it can keep you safe, partner.”

 

“...Well, hey, Arval approves, in their own weird way,” Shez said, smiling over at her sister, “So it sounds to me like you did good!”

 

“...Shez, you would have died,” Byleth stated.

 

“Yeah, and that’s kind of uncomfortable to hear about, but you saved me! Everything worked out fine, right?” 

 

"It did this time, but what about next time? What if I'm not there to save you when something happens?" 

 

"...” Shez frowned. “I'm not weak By, I don't need you to save me all the time." 

 

"I know!" Byleth shouted, catching the two off guard. "I know you're strong… but…" Almost imperceptibly, Byleth began to shake. 

 

"...Kid, are you afraid of something happening to her?" Jeralt asked, mostly concerned but also kind of amazed. He never thought…Well, she was expressing herself more often…

 

“Really? You’re actually…scared for me?” Shez, meanwhile, didn’t know what to say to that at all. “You…By, you know I can handle myself, right?”

 

“...I saw you get stabbed through the chest, Shez–”

 

“Yeah, but I would’ve been fine!” she insisted, interrupting her sister, “It’s not the first time–”

 

“You’re not invincible, Shez!”

 

“I know I’m not, but I’m stronger than you think I am!”

 

“I know how strong you are!”

 

Shez felt a frown coming to her face as Arval made a noise of realization. “So she does think you’re weak. Weaker than her, at least. She did take your fight against Lonato. You were the one handling things there…And she did decide to kill him simply because she was angry.”

 

“Would you stop?!” Shez snapped, before pausing when she saw Byleth blink, “Ah, not you–...No, you know what, you need to stop too! I’m not weaker than you and I don’t need to be protected!”

 

“...” Byleth trembled, and Shez felt her own anger falter at the sight before her sister suddenly glared at her. “...Yes, you do. You’ve always been too reckless. Why did you go running off into the fog? Did you really want to fight Lonato that badly!?”

 

“Wh–Hey, I went in because I was trying to keep Em safe!”

 

“So it’s fine when you do it then?”

 

“Yes! It is! Because I’m strong! And you were the one who killed him! I could have beat him and kept Ashe from losing his dad!”

 

Byleth outright scowled, something that sent a strange sense of alarm through Jeralt as he started to think he really should intercede here. “Alright, come on girls, you’re–”

 

“You were losing,” Byleth bluntly stated, “He was an armored paladin with years of experience and a weapon with a much larger reach than you could have overcome. He would have kept you at bay until a hit connected or until he wore you down and then he would have killed you.”

 

Shez stiffened, affronted, then scowled right back. “I still could have beat him! I could have cut his head off in my first move and the only reason I didn’t is because I didn’t want to! Because he was my friend’s dad and–”

 

“And what would have happened afterward? The knights would have executed him. He was a dead man already, all you did was put yourself in danger–”

 

Shez opened her mouth, about to interrupt, when she suddenly felt a hand on her head, startling her out of her anger. Across from her, Byleth was reacting much the same as Jeralt placed his hands on both his daughters’ heads. The pair stared at each other for a moment, before they both looked up at their dad, who was looking back at them with a faint expression of concern.

 

“...Alright. Let’s take this down a notch before anyone says something they’ll regret, okay?”

 

“...I don’t need to be babied,” Shez complained, though she didn’t make any motion to brush her father off.

 

“I know you don’t. Neither of you do. But a dad worries, you know?” He let out a sigh, before smiling down at the two of them. “I don’t think I’ve seen you two get that heated before. Usually when you argue, it’s Shez insisting on something while you just give one word responses, kid.”

 

“...This was different,” Byleth grumbled, ducking her head to glare at the dock. 

 

“I noticed. You’ve gotten a lot more expressive over the years.” He glanced at Shez. “And you’ve gotten a lot stronger too. Still reckless though.”

 

“Hey, I said–”

 

“I know you went to rescue your friend. I’m not going to fault you for that. Just try to keep yourself safe, okay? You two are supposed to outlive me, not the other way around.”

 

“...mmph. Don’t act like you’re going to keel over any day now,” Shez grumbled.

 

“Please don’t,” Byleth agreed, glancing up at her father again with a small look of concern.

 

“Okay, okay, no jokes about my mortality, I get it. But in exchange, I want you two to put this aside, if you can. It’s a shame what happened to Lonato. I can’t pretend I don’t understand where he’s coming from, but he made some very bad choices in how he decided to handle his grief. It’s rough, but we can’t change what happened.”

 

“...Could we?” Shez asked, glancing at Byleth.

 

“We cannot,” Sothis responded, her voice echoing in Byleth’s mind, “The point to change that man’s fate has long passed. You would be but a child again should you make the attempt, assuming such a thing would not simply destroy you completely and utterly.”

 

“Hm. Sothis says it isn’t possible,” Byleth reported, prompting a scoff from Arval.

 

“How convenient. Useful when she wishes to be, yet useless when you make a simple request.”

 

Shez rolled her eyes, then tried to grin at her sister. “Arval’s being a pain.”

 

“Rude! All I’m doing is being a good partner and staying by your side!” the not-ghost protested, “Why not ask her why it’s so impossible, hm?”

 

“Ugh, fine.” So Shez asked, and Byleth replied back with what Sothis told her.

 

“...Yeah, you’re not doing that,” Jeralt immediately said.

 

“Hmph. What a horrific power,” Arval muttered, and Shez…felt a part of herself kind of agree. The idea that it could alter things that much, or even kill Byleth just by using it…

 

“...Okay, so no changing history that much. Saving someone’s life, sure. Doing…that, no.”

 

“I don’t think I can anyway,” Byleth replied, shrugging, “I’m pretty sure my changes are limited to the day they happen.”

 

“Hm. That is good to know,” Arval noted while Shez just sighed, scratching at her head.

 

“Right, this is all starting to give me a headache…Hey, By, you wanna just spar a bit? Might help.”

 

Byleth considered matters, then nodded. “Sure, that works.” Before remembering something important. “Oh, yeah, what should I do for this guy?”

 

She pointed to the crayfish still resting on her shoulder, which didn’t seem to have been bothered by any of the arguing at all.

 

“...Is that thing even alive?” Shez asked, reaching over to poke at the crustacean and yelping when it pinched her finger instead. “Ow! Jerk!”

 

“Seems alive to me.”

 

“Well I’m pretty sure people have bowls if they want to keep fish,” Jeralt suggested, “Speaking of, we should probably take your catches in if we don’t want them to rot.”

 

“Oh yeah! Great point, dad! After all, I’ve gotta show the fishkeeper just how much I caught!” Shez said, her grin returning full force as she picked up the bucket Byleth had filled with fish.

 

“...” Byleth stared as Shez started heading off, before lifting her fishing rod–

 

“No trying to hook, trip, or hit your sister,” Jeralt reprimanded.

 

“...” Byleth lowered the fishing rod, before deciding to just content herself with her new crayfish, which was clearly better than any of the fish Shez stole from her.

 

She may have lost the battle, but Byleth won a friend, and that was what truly mattered.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Happy turkey day, have some trauma and arguing!

Red: The true spirit of the holiday. Food and arguments with family.

Indi: But hey, hopefully things turn out fine.

Red: Hopefully! Oh yeah, we didn't get around to mentioning it in this chapter, but feel free to assume varying levels of trauma for the Blue Lions also.

Indi: Most of them are doing okay. Ashe, well. He's trucking along at least.

Red: That he is. But anyways, hope you all have a nice turkey day and thanks for reading!

Interlude - Sage Advice

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

The monastery was a quiet place at night. In the dark, the ancient structure had a strange, somber quality to it. It was not empty of life, for there were still those who would wander even in the nighttime, but it was quiet, and silence had a way of making even the liveliest of locations feel melancholy.

 

The town beneath Garreg Mach didn’t have that same presence, but it was still quieter than it would be in the daytime and it was far less guarded than the monastery itself. In other words, it was quite useful for those seeking to have clandestine meetings.

 

“What do you think?” the first person there asked the second to arrive, staring up at the monastery in the distance. It was still in sight from their place at the town’s outskirts, appearing small, yet somehow looming over them all the same.

 

“...Garreg Mach is an impressive sight,” the second individual remarked, their voice distorted by the white mask they wore, resembling a human face marked by flames. It fit to their helmet, guarding their face from sight. “I despise what it stands for though.”

 

The first person scoffed, resting her hand on her own mask. Hers resembled a bird, much like those worn by those called dark bishops, though it was deep crimson instead of a metallic black. Her robes were black and lined with golden markings, vestments of a faith she cared little for. “Your standards for ‘impressive’ are quite lacking. The world once had a thousand sights more majestic before it was stolen away by the abominations. But then, why should you care? You have little reason to.”

 

“I have reasons of my own to oppose the Nabateans. The history you speak of does not matter to me.” The Flame Emperor regarded her contact with open distrust. “You have a great deal of gall to summon me like this.”

 

“Yet you came when called, so it’s not really arrogant of me, now is it?” Bias waved a hand, dismissing her own words. “Forget it. I’m not interested in playing power games with a child. I get enough of that with Kronya.”

 

“Hm. You are being indiscreet.”

 

“Who is here to listen? I took precautions, Flame Emperor. I will know if there are issues.”

 

“...Very well. Then talk.”

 

Bias sighed, not quite slumping. “I swear, I wasn’t nearly this bad when I was young…I came here to talk you about your little 'assassination plot' you're trying to pull off."

 

"..." 

 

"I must say, it was a tad sloppy, but it worked. It's certainly impressive how much these knights will drop almost everything when it comes to their precious archbishop." 

 

"Get to the point." 

 

"Quite the impatient one aren't you? Very well. We have a shared interest, do we not? While we would certainly love it if you did eliminate the leader of the abominations, revealing the truth of Seiros's tomb certainly seems worthwhile." 

 

"And you want to be involved with my plans?" 

 

"As I said, mutual interest. Really, it's like you're paying me back for not ousting you to the beasts." 

 

"Do not threaten me." 

 

"I am simply stating the facts," Bias said with a small titter of laughter, "But if you wish for a sign of my goodwill, I could offer weapons and armor, perhaps to that 'death knight' of yours?" 

 

"...You know of my men," the Flame Emperor stated as they regarded Bias. They knew little about their “contact”, but what they did know was that she carried more authority than “Emily”, and that made her dangerous.

 

"Of course. Though you may not have kept contact, we have our own sources." 

 

The Flame Emperor regarded the infiltrator with annoyance. “It is your people who broke contact first. Am I to arrange my plans based on what I think you may desire?”

 

"For now, no. What you can do, however, is lend us your knight."

 

“...You need the Death Knight’s aid? Why?”

 

“He is a powerful force that would be useful for our purposes. Should any of the abomination’s ilk take notice of our presence and attempt to intervene, he would be a boon in removing them.”

 

“Hm. And why would I aid you in this way? Regardless of the weaponry you offer, I see no reason to aid you." 

 

“It does show a continued willingness on your part to aid our cause. We do share the common goal of removing the abominations from power, do we not? And you know well enough that my people can offer much to you.”

 

The Flame Emperor silently regarded Bias for a few moments, then scoffed. “The fact that you are negotiating with me rather than ordering it be done shows how much your position has weakened. Thales truly was the pillar supporting your enterprise, was he not?”

 

“...I won’t disagree with that. We have more than one pillar though. Even if he bore much of the weight, there is enough support that we may build more to keep things…stable.”

 

“That is not how it works. A load-bearing pillar cannot be easily replaced, not without damage, and whatever other pillars you have, they cannot move into his place without disrupting their own. It’s how Aegir was able to push you out without Thales to keep him cowed.” She tilted her head. “You work best in obscurity, do you not? If there are those willing to support you, then you grow more bold, but you cannot touch Aegir because of how protected and public he is. He knows too much, but you cannot strike at him without risking discovery and death. And because he is in the way, you cannot get to me. Am I incorrect?”

 

Bias shrugged. “You’re right on all counts.”

 

“...”

 

“You look surprised. Or as much as you can be in that helmet of yours. Still, you’re correct. Thales wanted you as a pet instead of a mere beast, domesticated and willing to hunt down our prey, but Myson let you slip your leash. I’m not surprised to see you turn feral. Annoyed, but not surprised. 

 

“The issue is that I’ve been sent to reestablish contact, to see if you’re willing to accept a new collar. Failing that, well…Solon has his ideas of how things should go. I have my own. All I will say is that loaning your knight will make things easier for us all.”

 

“...Solon. Tell me about him.”

 

Bias paused. “Is that a condition for gaining the use of your knight?”

 

“The Death Knight is one of mine, but he is willful. I make no guarantees that he will be as helpful as you desire. But I will aid you if you are willing to share information. I know of Thales, and I recall the names Solon and Myson. So, tell me about them.”

 

“...Ah, of course, they were both involved in the Hegemon project,” Bias muttered, thinking, while the Flame Emperor’s armor hid any reaction she may have had. “...They are the Sages of Darkness and Thunder, leaders of our people, in a sense.
