Solon is one of our people’s greatest scientists, having fathomed greater depths of darkness than any other still living, and Myson is…Well, he’s decent enough, I guess. Overly focused on his own personal projects at times, to the point that he’s really allowed things to slip in Adrestia…but you’re aware of that part, of course. Otherwise, he is capable and competent, if better as an agent than a leader.”

 

“...hm. Who are the other sages?”

 

“I feel like you should be owing me for each of these questions I answer.”

 

“Consider each one answered a mission you may use the Death Knight on.”

 

Bias made a faintly pleased noise there. “Useful…Very well. Among the sages, there are those greater and those lesser. Light and Dark hold the greatest power, and the lesser elements support them. As such, there is Chilon, the Sage of Earth, who followed Thales and acted as his guard. He was not there when Thales died, so you can imagine his current anguish. Thales himself was the Sage of Light, but that matters little now. Another deceased member of our order was the Sage of Wind, and another living member, Cleobulus, is Sage of Water. I myself am the Sage of Fire.”

 

“...Your…’order’ has two sages at the monastery then. That seems dangerous.”

 

“Perhaps. Solon has plans, and I am meant to guard him. We do not want another Sage of great importance to be lost to us. Or, worse, to fall into enemy hands.”

 

“...I see. One final question then.”

 

“That will be a third mission we are allowed to use the Death Knight on then, yes?”

 

“Yes. Is Shez one of you?”

 

Bias blinked beneath her mask. “That girl again…She is Agarthan, yes. I do not know her purpose here though, and I would prefer not to speculate.”

 

“...I see. She is of ‘Agartha’ then.”

 

“If you want to repeat what I said, sure. And as I said, I don’t know why she’s here. Kronya seems interested in her, which doesn’t say much if anything good about ‘Shez’.” She shrugged. “Figure it out on your own if you’re so curious. She isn’t my problem.”

 

“I would think one of your own people turning up in an unexpected place would be ‘your problem’.”

 

“Well it’s not. Unless she becomes directly relevant to me, I’m not interested.” Left unsaid was the interest that Solon had taken in the strange young Agarthan. Bias had no reason to tell the Flame Emperor everything, after all.

 

“Fine. You have three missions you may enlist the aid of the Death Knight for. Inform me of what they are beforehand or the deal is off.”

 

“Adding conditions after the fact? My, Thales really did train you well.” She smirked, because even with how much the Flame Emperor’s armor hid, there was no mistaking the flash of anger there. “I’ll make sure to report that you’re perfectly willing to work with us going forward.”

 

“...Say what you want. But know that there is no ‘partnership’ between us. This was a transaction. Nothing more. Any arrangements made from this point onward will be temporary.”

 

But she was willing to make such arrangements, and that was good enough for Bias. 

 

“Of course, your majesty.” She bowed, the gesture filled with mockery, before straightening. “Have a good night now. Little girls shouldn’t be out after dark like this.”

 

Edelgard scowled beneath her helm as the monster in front of her vanished, but she let it be. Those Who Slither in the Dark did have their uses, even if she would dismantle them in time just as she would the Church.

 

Which brought her back to the thought of Shez. Having it confirmed that the younger Eisner was indeed an ‘Agarthan’ did feel like something of a relief, in a strange way. She didn’t know the girl’s purpose here, but she knew her origins, and that could be worked on. Especially with the confirmation that she wasn’t part of the same faction as Bias and Solon.

 

The fact that Those Who Slither even had factions was a fascinating revelation. The idea that they were not one whole, but a set of groups who may have their own motivations and desires, along with the confirmation that not one but two of their leaders were deceased…It opened up opportunities. Especially if the faction Shez belonged to happened to oppose Solon’s…

 

The Flame Emperor turned and made her way back to where she would change from her disguise once more before returning to the monastery, her mind still awhirl with thoughts and considerations. Most significantly, the thought that she knew, specifically, who among the Agarthans had headed the project that mutilated her and killed her siblings.

 

Edelgard was not someone who focused on vengeance. It was a distraction and a danger; a detriment to creating a better Fodlan.

 

Even still, it was good to know who among her enemies could not be allowed to live.

Chapter End Notes

Red: It's funny what can happen when certain writers realize that the Death Knight wouldn't have his iconic armor if Edelgard wasn't working with the Agarthans.

Indi: Yuuup. Though at least Edelgard is on a more even ground this time around. Minus Bias threatening to oust her identity as the Flame Emperor. But hey at least Bias made sure to have the meeting outside of the monastery unlike Thales.

Red: I swear, Thales had a thing about airing his plans in the most easy to overhear locations possible. Azure Moon would have turned out at least a bit differently if he'd bothered to practice some discretion.

Indi: Yuuup. Also Agarthan lore!

Red: Agarthan lore! Which isn't canon in the slightest but hey, it's valid here!

Indi: I mean anything can be Canon since they barely have anything in the game. Speaking of Canon in this story, it might be time to show Shez’s planned endgame next chapter.

Red: Perhaps, perhaps. For now though, thanks for reading!

Honest Conversation

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Shez huffed to herself as she walked around the monastery, no real destination in mind while she was lost in her thoughts. It had been a day since the incident at the dock, so she had been able to think some more, and while she was able to see where Byleth was coming from… 

 

"...I'm not a child," Shez muttered, idly kicking a rock that was in her path. 

 

"That sister of yours can be quite cruel," Arval commented, making Shez frown. "Honestly, she's probably just afraid to admit you're the stronger fighter." 

 

"Even if I am, we're supposed to be stronger together…" she muttered again, before deciding to look around to see where she was and realizing she wound up in the tea gardens. "Well, not the worst place to wander to." 

 

"That moronic Claude!" Blinking as she heard a rather angry sounding voice, Shez looked over to see Lysithea walking nearby, a scowl on her face. 

 

"Everything okay?" Shez asked, getting Lysithea to turn her glare towards her. 

 

"What do you want?" 

 

"Uh, just wanted to see if you were okay, you seem kinda pissed." At her words, Lysithea huffed. 

 

"Claude is being an idiot as usual. First he acts like it's his business when I go to sleep, and now he makes fun of me for my suggestion on where the perpetrators might strike!" 

 

"He did?" 

 

"Yes! I suggested they might go for the library, and all he had to say was 'what, are they too busy to just check them out?'. Even if he didn't like what I said, he didn't have to mock me like I'm some child!" 

 

"Yeah, Claude tends to default to mocking," Shez agreed as she rubbed the back of her head. "I mean, I don't really hang out at the library, but there's some pretty important books in there, right?" 

 

"Yes! There are many important magical tomes and historical documents! And it's not merely a matter of intruders stealing them, they might try to destroy them all!" 

 

"And let me guess, he didn't let you explain that?" 

 

"Before I could he was already dismissing Raphael's idea of them going for the food storages." With that said, she pouted. "Of course, he made no attempt to treat him like a child." 

 

"Yeah, that definitely sounds rough. I get what you're going through, By decided to start treating me like I need to be babied after the mission we just had.” 

 

“Really? You? Aren’t you a professional mercenary?”

 

“A strong one at that! Hell, I've been doing this since I was younger than you.”

 

“And yet you also treat me like a child.” 

 

“Ah… yeah, I can see why the things I said came off like that. Sorry about that.” 

 

“Hmph, just make sure not to do so again.” 

 

“Though I gotta say, even if you are young, you put in a lot of effort. You’re already way better than me with dark magic from what I've seen of you training.” 

 

“...You’re a dark mage?”

 

“Yeah? Did I not tell you? I know how to cast a few spells.” 

 

“Who taught you?”

 

“No one really, just came to me naturally I guess. Maybe my birth parents were also dark mages, but I don't really remember anything about them.”

 

“...Is that so?” Lysithea murmured, already assuming things about how Shez got these powers. 

 

“Yup. Hey, actually, since we’re talking about it, mind teaching me about magic? Might be nice having a mentor.”

 

“...You want me as a mentor?” Lysithea asked, already sounding pleased at the idea.

 

“Yeah, since we’re both being treated like kids, we might as well work together to show them!”

 

"Hmph, well if I have time in between my studies, I suppose I could help you out. Though don’t think I'll go easy on you!" 

 

"I'd never dream of it!" Shez said with a grin. "Hey, if you're not busy right now, why don't we get something to eat before starting?" 

 

"Well, I was already planning on getting something to eat. So we might as well eat together if you're hungry." 

 

"Great! Let's go!" Grinning, Shez led the way.

 

"Wh–Shez, you're heading to the dormitories!" 

 

Keeping her grin, Shez let Lysithea lead the way!

Byleth tried her best to keep her mind focused on other things while she made her way to the audience chambers to talk with Rhea. She still didn't particularly like the Archbishop, but she still had a job to do. And the best way to know what to protect was to ask the one being targeted. 

 

"Hello there, child. Have you been well?" Rhea asked when Byleth approached her, a gentle smile on her face. 

 

"...I am, yes," Byleth answered as she glanced around. "Is Seteth busy?" 

 

"Yes, he had some business to attend to." Rhea said. "That is to say, he is preparing things for his sister's birthday." 

 

"It's Flayn's birthday?" 

 

"Not yet, she was born on Saint Cethleann day. It is quite the blessing for young Flayn." 

 

"Huh, good to know." She’d have to get her something. Flayn wasn’t technically a student, but it would probably make the girl happy to get a present.

 

"Quite, though I do hope you didn't come here just to learn about her birthday." 

 

"No, I wanted to ask about this month's mission." 

 

"Oh? Are you worried for me?" 

 

"...Jeralt will be in charge of your protection, you'll be safe," Byleth said, not wanting to admit that she wasn't worried. "What I wanted to ask is if there was anything in the monastery you would want protected?" 

 

"Oh?" That seemed to actually surprise her. 

 

"There is a chance the perpetrators might have a secondary mission when they come. My class is having trouble deciding what to protect, so I wanted to know what you would want to protect." 

 

“Ah, I see. Then you believe this assassinaton attempt may be a cover for another purpose?”

 

Byleth shrugged. “I said they might have a secondary mission. They might still be coming to kill you, but if most of the monastery’s security is focused on you, it leaves other areas vulnerable.”

 

“Of course, I can understand your rationale…If I may offer a suggestion then, I would think the Holy Mausoleum would be a place of importance to protect.”

 

“Hm. And…what’s that?”

 

Rhea seemed faintly amused by the question, her smile twitching in apparent humor. “The Holy Mausoleum is the resting place of Saint Seiros. Her remains are interred there, and it would be a significant blasphemy were they to be disturbed.”

 

“...” That sounded really stupid.

 

“Did you wish to say something, child?”

 

Byleth paused. Something of her skepticism must have shown, which was…strange. She thought she was keeping her face as neutral as it usually was… “I don’t understand why they would want a corpse.”

 

“The body of Saint Seiros is no mere corpse,” Rhea gently chided, “Her remains are held sacred by the faith, for she was the first to spread the word of the Goddess to the people of Fodlan.”

 

“Right, she killed Nemesis and founded the Empire.”

 

Rhea blinked. “Oh, I did not realize you already knew of that story.”

 

“I heard it years ago. Nemesis was an evil tyrant, Seiros fought him with her saints, then she made the empire and the church afterwards.”

 

“Heh. That is not incorrect, though it is a somewhat simplified version of the tale. Regardless, that is my suggestion. You may accept or ignore it as you choose.”

 

“...You know you’re my employer, right? You could just order me to guard that place if you think it’s important.”

 

Rhea’s ever-present smile took on a sad quality that made Byleth vaguely uncomfortable. “I realize, yet I suppose I was hoping you could look past my position, child. It is rare that I am able to speak to anyone as simply Rhea, instead of as the archbishop.”

 

“...I was here on business, I don’t think treating you as…Rhea is really appropriate.”

 

She sighed. “That is true. My apologies. Perhaps I am being too familiar. You are Jeralt’s kin, so I feel as though we may have a connection. Though, perhaps I am being presumptuous.”

 

It was strange how tense Byleth felt. She couldn’t help thinking back to that day, years ago, when she and Shez asked their father about the Knights of Seiros and he told them…everything.

 

“...May I ask if Jeralt ever spoke of me?” Rhea inquired, and Byleth had the strangest feeling as she stared at the woman who helped deliver her as a baby. And who might have killed her mother.

 

Fear was a new emotion to her. A strange, chilly sensation that hit when she thought of Shez or her father dying. This new emotion was different though. Like a creeping sensation along her back, a strange dread at being in this woman’s presence.

 

“...He did.”

 

“All good things, I hope?” Rhea said, and her smile was almost painfully hopeful, like she really did want Byleth’s father to have a good opinion of her. And it almost hurt to see it fade at Byleth’s lack of response. “...Perhaps not then. I suppose I cannot blame him. My position oft requires a certain sternness of word and action to maintain the sanctity of the faith. It can be frightening for some, though I do hope I have not given you cause to fear me, child.”

 

She had. Maybe not directly, but everything Byleth knew made the woman in front of her feel like someone she couldn’t trust. Not for a second. But she wasn’t about to say that. “You haven’t.”

 

“I am glad.” And she genuinely looked it. “May I ask, did he ever tell you of our first meeting?”

 

“He did. He was a mercenary, he was hired to help protect you, and he nearly died doing it.”

 

“That is all true,” Rhea confirmed, “Jeralt saved my life. He threw himself into harm's way to save me from death. He was a very brave young man. Very young at the time, in fact. He could not even grow a full beard back then!”

 

The archbishop smiled, full of fondness and good humor, and Byleth felt all the more uncomfortable for it.

 

“I imagine then that he told you of how he joined the Knights of Seiros?”

 

“Yes.”

 

“Ah, of course, I did think he would, given you said he told you…I digress. I seem to be talking in circles now. I do enjoy speaking with you though.”

 

“...” Byleth didn’t know what to say to that. Part of her wanted to ask ‘why’. Another part wanted to know what Rhea did all those years ago, what happened to her mother, everything. But the largest part just wanted to leave. “Is that all then, Lady Rhea?”

 

“...I suppose it is. My apologies if I have made you uncomfortable, child.” Was it that obvious? “I do hope you might be willing to visit again. Perhaps not for business, but simply to chat.”

 

“No, thank you. I’m busy,” Byleth replied, before turning and walking away as fast as she could without looking like she was running from the archbishop and that strangely hurt look she had when Byleth refused her.

“-and that is all for today, class,” Hanneman concluded, turning away from the blackboard and towards his students, “Remember to study hard, as we will be having a test at the end of the week!”

 

Shez frowned at her notes. She was…pretty sure she knew enough about the leadership skills of previous Faerghan generals, but maybe she should stop by the library for once? But then she might run into that Tomas guy again and he still felt off to her.

 

“It is an interesting sensation, don’t you think?” Arval asked as she started packing her stuff away, “Not exactly familiar, per se, but–Oh? Never mind, it looks like we can’t converse at the moment.”

 

“Huh?” Shez glanced up at Arval, then paused when she saw Sylvain instead.

 

“Heh, hey there! Saw me coming, huh?”

 

“Ehh…something like that. What’s up?”

 

“What? I can't come over and chat with a cute classmate?”

 

Oh, it was one of those conversations. “Nope, not really. I’ve got better things to do than be flirted at.”

 

“Ah, that’s not really why I wanted to talk. I mean, sure, I wouldn’t mind flirting if you were up for it–”

 

“I’m not,” Shez replied, slinging her satchel of school supplies over her shoulder, “So see ya.”

 

“No, hold on, I actually did want to talk,” Sylvain quickly said, prompting a sigh from his classmate.

 

“Okay, I guess I’m not doing anything, so I’m up to hear whatever it is. What’s up?”

 

“Well, maybe we could find somewhere more private to chat–”

 

“Sylvain, come on.”

 

“I’m serious. I don’t want to talk about something you might find uncomfortable for other people to hear.” At her skeptical look, he continued. “It’s about you and your sister.”

 

“Oh. That.” She grimaced. “I guess our argument was kind of…in the open.”

 

“Yeah, it was kind of hard not to notice, though I don’t think anyone listened in. Or at least was close enough to listen in on.”

 

“...Did you try to listen in?”

 

“Hey, I’m not that bad,” he complained, “Besides, argument aside, I just noticed things seemed to be tense between you two. I guess I just wanted to make sure everything was okay.”

 

“Yeah, things are fine…mostly.” Shez sighed. “I just…yeah, maybe we should go somewhere less open to talk about this. Though if you invite me to a bedroom, I’m gonna deck you.”

 

“Hey, message received!” And moments later, the two settled in a corner of the monastery’s halls, far from most of the foot traffic.

 

“Alright, talk to me. Are things really so bad you decided you need to get involved?” Shez asked, leaning against the wall as Sylvain stood beside her.

 

“I’d say it’s more that I want to keep things from getting that bad. I, ah…kind of have experience with this sort of thing. I have an older brother and…well, he was born without a crest.”

 

“Huh. Okay?”

 

He sighed, smiling wryly. “Alright, I guess it’s not too obvious since you two grew up as mercenaries. See, the way it goes in the nobility in Faerghus is that the heir needs to have a crest. I’m sure you’ve heard the stories, how we’re descended from the Ten Elites and how we all have relics that react to crests. You need a crest to wield them and each one is worth a thousand men, or so the stories go.

 

“Crests are everything to nobles. It’s proof the Goddess favors us, or so people say. And if you’re born without a crest…well, you’re not the favorite.”

 

“Okay? So…your brother was born without a crest, and then you were born with one?”

 

“Exactly. Though, that’s not all of it. After Miklan, my brother, lost his mother, our father married specifically to make me. He needed an heir with a crest, and the instant I was born, Miklan lost what should’ve been his. And he hated me for it.”

 

Shez frowned. “That’s not fair at all. You didn’t ask to be born with a crest. You didn’t ask to be born at all.”

 

“True enough, but I was. And, well…” He chuckled without any humor in it. “He made sure I knew how much he hated me. Tried to kill me a few times, even. All because I had a crest and he didn’t.”

 

“...Hold on, you can’t seriously think that’s what’s going on between me and Byleth.”

 

“It’s not? So you can tell me you never felt resentful towards her because of her crest.”

 

She scowled in the face of his skepticism. “It’s not that! I’m mad that she’s acting like I need protection!”

 

“So you never once thought she had an unfair advantage? That you would have been better off if she didn’t have a crest?”

 

“I never thought I would be better off! I–Look, sure, it felt weird when I learned she had one, but I didn’t hate her for it!”

 

“And that’s good!” Sylvain insisted, “I don’t want you to hate her! I just don’t want things to turn out like they did with me.”

 

“...They’re not going to. I don’t hate Byleth. I’m just upset that she wants to baby me. It’s not the same as what happened to you.” Shez let out a breath, relaxing some of the tension that built up in her. “I just want her to know I’m as strong as her.”

 

“Stronger,” murmured Arval, and Shez felt a flash of annoyance at the sound of their voice.

 

“...Alright. I won’t keep arguing that. Just…I feel like it’s unfair to you.”

 

“I’m not weak, Sylvain. You don’t need to protect me either.”

 

“...heh. Fair enough.” He slouched against the wall and let out another sigh.

 

“...” Shez settled next to him after a second, content to stare at the opposite wall. “...What do you think of Byleth anyway?”

 

“Well, if I’m going to be honest, my first thought is that she’s completely gorgeous and probably has the third biggest set of breasts I’ve ever seen.”

 

“...Wow, you really are a pig.”

 

“Ouch. Hitting me right in the heart there, Shez.”

 

“I could hit you for real if you want.” She paused. “Third biggest?”

 

“Yup. Professor Manuela’s are bigger, but she’s still the second biggest. The absolute biggest goes to the court mage back in Faerghus, this lady named Cornelia. Now those things are absolutely massive. Praise the goddess for low cut dresses and the ladies who like them.”

 

“...I really feel like I should deck you on principle now.”

 

“If you do, just don’t aim for my face. It’s my only redeeming quality.” He grinned as Shez laughed at his bad joke, before he settled back again. “...And, if I’m continuing to be honest, I’ve gotta say, I’m kind of jealous of her.”

 

Shez glanced up at him. “You are?”

 

“Yup. See, for us nobles, having a crest means that’s all anyone is ever going to value us for. We’re the subject of envy and desire because of the blood we have, and those of us ‘lucky’ enough to be born with one immediately become valuable. I was tested at birth to make sure I had one, and that was all I needed to become the heir. And now, all I have waiting for me is a future as a studhorse, producing enough crested babies to be the next generation of Gautier lords keeping the wheels of society turning. Why do you think I never stick with the women I flirt with? It’s because they all want the same thing: wealth and status from a man of good breeding.

 

“For how vaunted my position is, I was born without any freedom. Meanwhile, your sister got to live the free life of a mercenary. Nobody pretended to like her, nobody demanded she pick a spouse to carry on the line, no one had any expectations of her at all. She didn’t even know she had a crest until she came here. How lucky is that? She gets all of the benefits and none of the downsides. What else is that but unfair?

 

He laughed again, though it was darker this time. Uglier, almost. “It feels like she has an unpaid debt, getting to live the easy life like that. Maybe someone ought to collect on it…” 

 

After a second, Sylvain chuckled. “Ah, never mind. Hope I didn’t scare you there, Shez. Most ladies like a dark and brooding noble.”

 

He glanced at her, then felt his body tense on instinct at the look Shez was giving him. There was no smile on her face. No hint of humor, but no hint of concern either. Her eyes were narrowed as she stared up to him, and he felt himself back up, only to hit the wall.

 

And Shez moved closer to him. Despite the height difference between them, he felt himself staring up at her as she slammed her hand into the wall beside his head, glaring straight into his eyes. There was a fiery orange gleam in there that he hadn’t seen before and white markings down her scowling face.

 

“I like you, Sylvain,” she said. Her tone implied the opposite. “Don’t pile your self-pitying bullshit on me or my sister. And if you ever threaten Byleth again, I’ll kill you.”

 

She pushed off the wall and stalked away, her hair still glowing that fiery orange.

 

Sylvain watched her go, then look at the blackened hole beside his head in the vague shape of a hand. Despite being solid stone, it reeked of rot. He felt a nervous laugh bubble up as he realized his legs were bent and barely supporting him. 

 

“H-Hah…well…so much for an honest conversation…”

“Professor, can I ask why you seem so discomfited lately?” Edelgard inquired, directing the question towards her professor across the tea table.

 

Byleth paused, before setting down her teacup. “Ah…Do I seem especially…discomfited?”

 

“You do. You’ve been on edge.”

 

“I have good reason to be. People might be trying to assassinate the Archbishop.”

 

Edelgard raised an eyebrow. “I suppose that is a decent reason. I believe there may be more to it though.”

 

“...We should focus on our mission for the month. I’ve been investigating likely points of attack for infiltrators and I believe it would be good to spread our patrols out to those areas.”

 

“I understand completely, and I would appreciate it if we could discuss these matters further. Perhaps during class time and not leisure time?”

 

Byleth blinked, then glanced at the tea table with all its snacks and such. “...Right, that is a good point. I don’t really want to talk about my…discomfit though.”

 

“Discomfort, professor.”

 

“Right, thank you.”

 

“...” Edelgard decided to take a gamble. “Is it about Shez?”

 

“Huh? Oh…I hope not. I was hoping things were better between us…did she say there were problems?”

 

The princess shook her head. “I have not had cause to speak with her recently. I presume this issue relates to our previous mission though.”

 

“...Yeah. We argued about it. I was…I felt scared for the first time because I saw her get–nearly get hurt.”

 

“You did? Hm…I suppose that makes two emotions that you can feel strongly now.” Edelgard mused as she sipped her tea, Hresvelg blend this time. "Forgive me if this sounds rude, but has she not been in dangerous situations before as a mercenary?" 

 

"She has but… this time was different, she let down her guard. If I was just a bit slower, he would have stabbed her through the chest." Byleth said, unable to get the image of Shez bleeding out of her head. 

 

"I see. Does that mean you don't want her to participate in combat then?" 

 

"No, I just don't want her to be reckless anymore," Byleth muttered. 

 

"I suppose I can understand that. To lose one's family is tragic." 

 

"Ah, sorry," Byleth apologized as she remembered what happened to Edelgard. 

 

"No need to apologize, professor. We all have our own fears, but I believe they can be used as a reminder to not allow anything like that to happen again. Or ever happen, in this case." 

 

"...If I can ask, what happened to you?" 

 

"That is a rather vague question, professor. What exactly do you mean?" 

 

"This is just my guess but whatever happened to you seems to motivate you greatly but…if it was just that sickness, you would be more focused on learning about healing and medicines, and not trying to grow stronger." 

 

"...you are quite perceptive, professor." 

 

"I have to be, with how reckless Shez is." 

 

"..." Setting her tea cup down, Edelgard flicked her wrist, seemingly giving out a signal as some nearby bushes rustled, telling Byleth that Hubert left. "...Before I begin, I must say, there really is a strange aura about you. It makes me feel as if I can really trust you." 

 

"I'll take that as a good thing." 

 

"You should. Now… you know what happened to my siblings, correct?" At Byleth’s nod, Edelgard took a sip of her tea to calm her nerves. "Before I tell you, you must swear to not tell another soul." 

 

"I swear," Byleth said with no hesitation. 

 

"Heh, your honesty can be quite refreshing, professor. If I am also being honest, then that story is just a cover, meant to hide what really happened. My family was… experimented on. There were those who wished to gain something from us, and it cost my siblings their lives." 

 

"Oh." Byleth wasn’t sure what to say. 

 

"While I would prefer not to go into details, there was a reason I alone survived, and was named the heir of the Empire. The future of the Empire, of everything, depends on me," Edelgard said, resolute as she stared at Byleth. 

 

"...I see. So that's why you're always appraising me. For the future you want to make." 

 

"I really should not be surprised by how perceptive you are." 

 

"Perhaps. Still, if I can help you find a better future, even if it's only as a teacher, then I will." 

 

"...Thank you, my teacher." 

Chapter End Notes

Red: In which Sylvain puts his entire foot in his mouth.

Indi: Yeah turns out the support that would normally be with Byleth doesn't go well with Shez in this setting.

Red: Byleth's willing to let threats to her well-being slide. Shez is very unwilling to let threats to Byleth slide. Ironic, given her own issues with Byleth trying to protect her.

Indi: Yup yup, also, for anyone curious why Shez’s romance tags are two separate ones, well, it's a kinda thing that the more we wrote, the more we saw that while Byleth was going down the polycule route, Shez just has unintentional harem protag energy if that makes sense.

Red: Honestly she mind wind up with more tags depending on how things go. She's got that dense harem protag vibe and it's funny to mess around with it.

Indi: guess we'll see. Either way, feel free to imagine Shez and Lysithea dating while Kronya is sleeping on their couch refusing to leave.

The Youngest Dragon

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Flayn was having a very interesting year at the monastery! To be specific, it was her first year there, but it was still exciting! Sure, her father might not have let her join as a student, but being able to interact with all the students was ever the delight, even more so when the mysterious band of mercenaries arrived! 

 

She didn't know much about them, but Lady Rhea seemed to trust them, even if her father didn't, so they were probably nice people. And the daughters of the leader were quite the duo, be it saving the house leaders, causing quite the stir at the mock battle, or just the general shenanigans at the academy, they quickly became the talk of the town as it were. And while she herself had yet to meet the younger sibling, the elder was ever so much a delight! 

 

It was quite amusing seeing her seem so surprised that Flayn and Seteth were related, even if it was just the slight widening of her eyes. It wasn't the first time someone got the wrong idea, especially with how stern her father was. 

 

It was a shame she was unable to attend the academy as a student, as it seemed quite fun with the two of them. Perhaps she'd have a chance next year, provided the elder remained as a teacher anyways. Though, as she thought this, she saw the younger Eisner sister sitting together with Leonie in the dining hall, the former glaring at the book in her hands. With a smile, she approached the two. 

 

"Greetings, you must be Shez Eisner," Flayn greeted with a curtsy, catching Shez off guard as she looked up from her book. 

 

"Oh, uh, hi?" Shez said back, seemingly unsure if she should get up to curtsy as well. "Uh… Leonie, is this one of your classmates?" 

 

"Seriously? You don't know who Seteth’s sister is?" 

 

"Oh, she's Seteth’s-..." She paused, then looked at Flayn, before glancing back at Leonie. "Are you sure?" 

 

"Pretty sure you're the last person who should be surprised at how different siblings can be." 

 

Shez raised a finger, thought for a second, then lowered it. “Yeah okay, that’s fair. It’s just…Seteth’s really tall and harsh-looking, and this girl’s small and soft, like one of those plush things.” She paused, then glanced at Flayn, who was not small and soft and was frowning at her in response. “Hey so what’s your name anyway?”

 

“My name is Flayn, and I am neither small nor soft,” Flayn replied quite firmly.

 

“...Hm…” Shez stood up from the table, showing that she was indeed much taller than Flayn and prompting a bigger frown from the shorter girl. “I don’t think you can argue with me on the small part, you’re pretty short, and you look really soft. I probably can’t test that part though, not without Seteth getting really mad.”

 

“...How were you planning to test ‘softness’?” Leonie asked with a raised eyebrow.

 

“Pinch her cheeks, duh.”

 

“I firmly request you do not do that,” Flayn firmly requested.

 

“Yeah, okay. So did you need something?”

 

"Well, I came to say hello, but you have been quite rude."

 

“Oh. Ah, sorry, that’s my bad, I wasn’t thinking. Probably should, I just talked with Lysithea about not treating her like a kid…Okay! Let’s start from the top again!” Shez grinned, then tried her own attempt at a curtsy. It didn’t really look right, but she gave it a try. “Hi there! My name is Shez Eisner, also known as the Violet Demon, daughter of Jeralt the Blade Breaker and sister to Byleth the Ashen Dragon!”

 

Flayn’s frown turned to a bright smile at Shez’s full, proper introduction and curtsied in turn. “Hello Shez! My name is Flayn, sister of Seteth the grouchy chamberlain. It is a pleasure to meet you!”

 

“Pff–Is his title really ‘the grouchy chamberlain’?” Shez asked, grinning.

 

“It is what people call him,” Flayn replied, acting innocent, though her own smile showed her humor, “I have also heard him called ‘the stern watchman of the monastery’ and ‘sour, dour Seteth’.” Left unsaid was how it was a certain aunt of hers that happened to call him the latter. “Ah, and, um…this may be strange to ask, but your sister is not an actual dragon, correct?”

 

“Pretty sure she’s not. She’s just good at fire magic and I wanted her to have a cool title like mine. She doesn’t like being called a demon, so I figured calling her a dragon would be good. Dragons and demons are kind of opposites, right?”

 

“What? How are they opposites?” Leonie asked while Flayn just nodded.

 

“That makes perfect sense!”

 

Leonie blinked. “It does?”

 

Shez, meanwhile, grinned wider. “Hell yeah it does! Heh, glad someone else recognizes my genius! You’re pretty cool, Flayn.”

 

“I am? Ah, well thank you for saying so!”

 

“Yeah, no problem! Hey so are you a student here? You’ve got the uniform, kind of, but it looks different.”

 

“Ah, well…I am not officially a student,” Flayn admitted, “I wish to attend, but my brother did not want me to join any of the classes this year. Ah, but I will most definitely be joining next year!”

 

“Alright! Then I’ll look forward to seeing you then!”

 

“Uh, Shez, we only attend the Academy for a year,” Leonie pointed out, “You’ll graduate by next  year.”

 

“Oh, right. Huh…Well, dang, guess we won’t have classes together then. But you do hang around the monastery anyways, right? Maybe we can hang out.”

 

“I would love that!” Flayn exclaimed, smiling brightly, “I have spoken with the other students at times, but I haven’t really ‘hung out’ with someone before!”

 

“Oh, then you can hang out with us right now! C’mon, sit!” Shez insisted, taking her seat again and patting the spot next to her. So of course Flayn eagerly accepted the offer!

 

“Thank you! Ah, so what are you two doing?”

 

“I was having lunch, and Shez was glaring at her book,” Leonie answered.

 

“I’m not glaring, I’m concentrating,” Shez explained, pointing to the ornate black book, “This stuff’s complicated.”

 

“Oh? What is it about, if I may ask?” Flayn inquired.

 

“Dark magic. I’m pretty good at it, but I don’t know a ton, so Lysithea helped me out and gave me this book of it. Some of the bigger spells get really complicated so it’s been tricky for me to figure out.”

 

“Oh, I see.” Flayn wasn’t quite sure how to feel about that revelation. She wasn’t particularly fond of dark magic, especially with the memories it brought up, but she was impressed to see Shez was working hard to better herself. “Well, I’m sure you’ll get it soon enough!”

 

“Heh, thanks! How about you? Do you have anything going on today?”

 

“Oh, not especially. It is my birthday, so I imagine Seteth has some surprise planned–”

 

“It’s your birthday?” Shez interrupted.

 

“Huh. Your birthday is on Saint Cethleann’s Day?” Leonie asked.

 

“Yes to both questions!” Flayn answered with a bright smile. "It was quite fortuitous for me to share a saint's birthday." 

 

"Right, uh…" Glancing around, Shez grabbed a sweet bun off a plate she was eating from. "Here you go!" 

 

"Oh, thank you!" Flayn said, quite happy to have a delicious treat. 

 

"You really need to eat more than just sweets, you know," Leonie said, frowning at Shez. 

 

"I do eat more than that, I’m just having these because Lysithea says sugar helps the brain!" 

 

"Pretty sure she just says that so she can get away with having as many sweets as she can." 

 

“Nah, I’m pretty sure she’s right. She’s really smart.”

 

“I’m not denying that, but she can still lie. That girl has a really big sweet tooth.”

 

"Well, until proven otherwise, I'll take her advice." 

 

“I think Lysithea makes a good point,” Flayn mentioned in between munching on her treat, “My mind works much better after having something sweet.”

 

“Ah see? Proof!”

 

Leonie sighed. “No offense, but I don’t think Flayn’s an expert on the subject.”

 

“She might be. How about it, Flayn? Are you an expert on food stuff?”

 

Flayn paused mid bite then felt a smile come to her face. “I would not call myself an expert, but I have created many dishes that my brother has called extraordinary!”

 

“Really? Heh, you know, I’m something of a cook too. Think they’d let us make something if we asked the kitchen?”

 

“Oh, certainly! We should go right now!”

 

“Ha! Yeah alright, let’s do it!” Shez said, pushing herself up from the table before quite casually picking Flayn up from her seat and setting her down, earning a surprised blink from the shorter girl.

 

“Huh. Um, you are very strong, Shez, but please do not do that again.”

 

“Oh, sorry. Okay, no picking you up without permission, got it.” Shez gave her a thumbs up while Leonie let out a sigh.

 

“Shouldn’t that be obvious? You shouldn’t be grabbing anyone.”

 

“Hey, I did it without thinking! Besides, I’m pretty sure I saw you pick up Ignatz once.”

 

Leonie waved a hand. “That’s different, he’s a classmate.”

 

“...I don’t get how that’s different, but alright. Anyways, c’mon Flayn, let’s go make something!”

 

“Let’s!”

 

About half an hour later, Shez stared at the bubbling, blackened ruin in the pot that Flayn was happily stirring, taking note of what looked like chunks of what she thought had to be fish in it, because she’d been cutting up a Teutates Pike for the dish, and yet…whatever those lumps were, they didn’t look like fish.

 

“...Hey Flayn?”

 

“Hm? Yes Shez?”

 

“What did you say this dish was called again?”

 

“Immortality Stew! They say it makes those who dine upon it hardier and more durable!”

 

“...Huh.” She stared at the…concoction in the pot, taking note of how it seemed somehow both purple and green in parts of it. The colors vaguely reminded her of when her dad’s mercs had been hired to hunt down a demonic beast. The chunks looked almost like that thing’s blue-gray scales, and the broth was vaguely like the poison saliva it had… 

 

“Do not eat that.”

 

Shez paused, then glanced at Arval, who had a deeply disturbed expression on their face.

 

“That is the single most toxic brew I have ever seen. You would die. Or at least have severe stomach troubles for the rest of the day.”

 

“...” Shez turned her gaze back to the Immortality Stew. She couldn’t help but think that stew was supposed to be easy. You just put things in a pot and boil it. So how did… “Uh…hm. Hey Flayn, you said it was your birthday, right?”

 

“Hm? Yes, I did! You gave me a bun as a present, remember?”

 

“Oh sure, I remember, but I just had a thought that we should do something bigger to celebrate! Like, say, heading into town! We could go buy some more sweets and…maybe a cookbook, also.”

 

“Oh! That sounds like a wonderful idea! Though, is it fine to leave the stew on the fire like this?”

 

“Oh totally. I’ve cooked before, remember? I’ll just tell the kitchen staff about it, they can do whatever they want with it.”

 

“Ah, very well then!” Flayn hopped from her stool and began undoing her apron while Shez moved over to one of the cooks and very quickly muttered to them that no one should, under any circumstances, eat from that pot in particular, before heading out to help Flayn enjoy her birthday, far from any kitchens.

 "So, do you live at the monastery?" Shez asked as they walked around the town.

 

“I do, but I only recently began living here. My brother decided it was best for me to move here, and I’m quite glad with that decision.”

 

“Huh, where did you live before?”

 

“Ah…I would prefer not to talk about it,” Flayn replied, not wanting to explain that she lived in Zanados.

 

“Oh, uh, sure. Sorry if I brought up bad memories.”

 

“Well, not so much bad, just lonely ones.” 

 

“Hm. Then it’s a good thing there’s so many people around here!”

 

“Quite! This is the first time I’ve been able to go out shopping, much less with a friend. Brother doesn’t let me go out shopping, though he makes sure to go out when I request something and he has time,” Flayn explained, a smile on her face as she looked around town.

 

“Huh. You know, he almost sounds more like your dad.”

 

“H-Huh? Wh-Why would you assume such a thing!?” Flayn asked, worried her cover was blown.

 

“Uh, I was just joking?” Shez responded, wondering why Flayn was acting like that.

 

“O-Oh, okay good. Uh…oh hey, those are also students of the academy, no?” Flayn inquired as she pointed over at Lorenz and Sylvain…who were attempting and failing at flirting with townsfolk. Which, while funny, did make Shez frown as she looked at Sylvain.

 

“Yeah, we probably should stay away from them.” 

 

“Oh, that’s a bit funny. Brother also said the same thing to me about those two.” 

 

“Huh, guess Seteth isn’t that bad.”

 

“He also said the same thing about you and your sister.”

 

“Maybe you shouldn't listen to him sometimes.”

 

Flayn giggled. “Perhaps. He’s often far too protective, though I can understand his concerns. Well, some of them. I don’t think his insistence that I not speak with any male students is warranted.”

 

“Wait, seriously? He actually said that?”

 

“Something to that effect…though I can somewhat understand his reasoning, looking at those two,” she noted, referring to Sylvain and Lorenz, who weren’t having any more luck with their “contest”. Especially since Sylvain was just punched in the stomach.

 

“Oh, ouch. Shouldn’t have gone for Gertrude.”

 

“Oh, you know her?”

 

“Yeah, she’s a mercenary from the same company as me. Maybe we should go say–...Actually, let’s not go say hi to her, she’d be a bad influence.” She did smoke, after all.

 

Flayn paused, then pouted. “Now you are sounding a good deal like my brother.”

 

“Hey, he’s not completely wrong. Just mostly. I’m a great influence, for instance! I’m pretty sure if we train together, I can help you get super strong!”

 

“Ah…I’m not sure that’s the same type of influence my brother is talking about…” Flayn paused again, considering Shez’s suggestion. And wondering just what it would be like to have big muscles… “...Raphael has helped me grow stronger by aiding me with my battle cry. Would it be something like that?” 

 

“Oh sure, stuff like that is important. Helps you keep your mind focused.” 

 

“Really? Raphael didn’t mention that…” 

 

“Well, he is a lot more muscular than me, so I guess he does his screaming for another reason…hm…no, no, I focus on speed, big muscles would get in the way.” She tilted her head, crossing her arms over her chest. “I think. Because you’re heavier? Right?”

 

“Uh…I believe so?” Though, now that Flayn thought about it, she used to be pretty big in dragon form and she was still fast then. 

 

“Hm…we should find someone smarter than us,” Shez said with a nod, before glancing around to find someone. “Hm…can’t ask Sylvain, he’s terrible and I don’t like him…Lorenz would be too pompous about it…Oh hey! HEY LYSITHEA!”

 

“Hm? Shez? Why are you yelling?” the mage asked as she glanced over at the pair, a small bag in hand.

 

“Hey, do muscles make you slower?” 

 

“...” Lysithea glanced at Flayn. “Can you explain why she’s asking that?”

 

“Oh, we were talking about training together, and Shez started to wonder if she should train to get bigger muscles.” 

 

“...Yes, Shez, muscles make you slower. Also I thought I was your mentor? Why are you suddenly trying to be more muscular?” 

 

“Oh, do magic and muscles not go together?” 

 

“Mages wear light enchanted clothes and usually aren't the most defended. So as it stands being big and muscular just means you’ll be a bigger target. So if you want to be fast and use magic, getting big muscles isn’t the best option.” 

 

“Huh. Yeah that makes sense,” Shez said as she nodded. “Oh yeah, so what are you doing out here?” 

 

“I was asked to do some errands. The storage was running low on soap so they asked me to get some for our class chores.” Lysithea glanced between the two. “So what are you two doing here?” 

 

“Oh, it’s Flayn’s birthday, so we were shopping for a cookbook for her, and maybe some sweets. Do you wanna join?”

 

“...Well, I might as well come along to make sure you don’t get lost.” 

 

“Pff, like I could get lost here. C’mon, I know exactly where I’m going!” Shez declared, before walking right towards the gates leading out of town, prompting an annoyed noise from Lysithea and a confused sound from Flayn.

 

“Er…is that where the cookbooks are sold?”

 

“No, she’s just stupid. Come along, let’s catch up to her,” Lysithea decided, leading the way as Flayn smiled. She really should head into town more often.

"If you had wanted to go into town, you could have asked me and I would have gone with you," Seteth chided, a frown on his face as he looked down at a pouting Flayn, who had seen Shez and Lysithea off earlier after their nice day on the town. 

 

"Is it really so wrong that I hang out with a friend?" 

 

"I never said that, I just want to make sure you're safe, and I don't think ‘hanging out’ with a mercenary is safe." 

 

"Shez is my friend, and I kindly ask that you treat her as such!" 

 

"Friend or not, you should still be careful. She has already caused a lot of trouble at the Academy, and I don't want her to be a bad influence on you." 

 

"Hmph, I fail to see how buying a cookbook can constitute as a bad influence," Flayn responded, getting Seteth to sigh. She neglected to mention them running into a bear while trying to find Shez outside the monastery walls. Lysithea and Shez easily dispatched it, so it wasn’t like it was an actual problem. 

 

"Just please make sure to inform me if you're heading out again, okay?" 

 

"Excuse me," Looking over, the father and daughter pair saw Byleth approaching them, some flowers in hand. "Is everything okay?" 

 

"Nothing that should matter to you, professor. Did you require something?" Seteth asked, turning to face her. 

 

"A few things. First, Flayn, were you the one who made the stew in the kitchen?" 

 

"Oh, that I was! Shez and I were cooking before we decided to head out into town together." 

 

"Right, Dimitri wanted to know who cooked that, apparently he enjoyed it." 

 

"He did?" Both Flayn and Seteth asked, the latter sounding far more surprised. 

 

"Yeah, apparently he liked the texture? I didn't have any myself, but it sounded interesting. Oh, but I wanted to give you these." Extending the flowers she had, Byleth handed over the bouquet of forget-me-nots to Flayn. "You like these flowers, right?" 

 

"Oh, absolutely, thank you professor!" Flayn said, smiling as she took the bouquet. "How did you know?"

 

"I notice these kinds of things," Byleth replied, before glancing at Seteth. "Actually, when is your birthday? The records I have only list the student’s birthday." 

 

"There is no need-" 

 

"Brother's birthday is on Saint Cichol's day, and he quite enjoys fishing if you want an idea for what to get him!" Flayn cut in with a smile. 

 

"Fishing is enjoyable," Byleth agreed with a nod. "I actually caught a crayfish recently, that I'm keeping as a pet." 

 

"You did? May I see them?" 

 

“Of course, I named them Snappy.”

 

“Oh what a wonderful name!” Flayn said, smiling as she followed behind Byleth. Sighing, Seteth watched the two walk away…then started to think. If Professor Byleth was keeping a pet, then it would likely be in her room. Which meant she was leading Flayn to her room…

 

“Professor, get back here! I need to discuss with you what is and isn't appropriate conduct!” Seteth shouted, chasing after the two.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Flayn finally arrives! Haven't really had a good space to slip her in, but hey, her birthday was during this month so might as well let her join in that way!

Red: And she immediately befriends Shez! Who is definitely a good influence on her, for sure.

Indi: The greatest influence, don't listen to what Seteth says.

Massacre at the Mausoleum

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

“So, my Deer will be handling the reception hall while your Eagles patrol the cathedral and Hanneman’s Lions keep watch over the vault,” Manuela said, glancing up at her fellow professors as they stood around a map of the monastery, “Does that all sound right?”

 

“It does,” Byleth confirmed, before pausing, “Were we going to send anyone to keep an eye on the stables, or are we ignoring that idea?”

 

“Oh, I can send a few of my kids to keep watch over there if you really think it’s such a concerning idea,” Manuela offered.

 

“We should make sure we don’t spread out too far,” Hanneman noted, “If there really is an attack tonight, we don’t want any students to get caught isolated from everyone else.”

 

“Right. Where’s Rhea going to be during this?” Byleth asked.

 

“At the Goddess Tower, giving a sermon to the faithful. We shouldn’t need to worry about her. The Knights of Seiros, your father included, will be guarding her with their lives.”

 

“We do have quite the selection of guards for Lady Rhea,” Manuela said, “Thunder Catherine, Shamir the Distant Archer, and…Well, Alois will be there too.”

 

“Hm…Okay. It sounds like she’ll be safe then.”

 

“Oh? Are you worried for our archbishop?”

 

“No. The primary objective is to keep her safe, so it’s good to know I won’t need to divert resources to do so.”

 

Manuela blinked. “...Well, I can’t fault your pragmatism. Though you should be careful on how you phrase that sort of thing.” 

 

“Hm…should we have a plan in mind in case one of our houses does encounter unexpected troubles?” Hanneman asked his fellow professors. 

 

“Hm. It might be good to have a student be ready to go ask for assistance,” Byleth offered, “Someone who is a fast runner preferably.” 

 

“That makes sense,” Manuela agreed, “At the very least they should inform the knights if they do find intruders.” 

 

“Though they should also make sure not to cause a panic,” Hanneman pointed out, “It is a very important day after all, and with how many noncombatants there will be at the ceremony, who knows what might happen if chaos were to erupt.” 

 

“That’s also true, and I would hate for anyone to get hurt. Hopefully we don’t end up facing any problems, and the knights on patrol have everything handled,” Manuela said with a sigh. “This year has been quite hectic, and we haven’t even reached the halfway point. I hope we’ll be able to get to the grand ball so the students can have some fun.” 

 

“Grand ball?” Byleth asked.

 

“Oh right, we haven’t told you. Near the end of the year, we tend to hold a ball for the students. You know, let them eat and dance, maybe let some romance bloom,” Manuela explained with a fond smile. One that turned mischievous barely a second later. “Why, there’s even a legend that if a man and a woman go to the goddess tower and make a vow together, it’ll come true.”

 

“Really?” 

 

“Do keep in mind that no one is allowed in the goddess tower outside of the rite of rebirth,” Hanneman interrupted, frowning at his fellow professor, “I would think you would know not to spread any rumors, Manuela.” 

 

“Aw, what's the harm in having a little fun? Besides, I'm sure everyone will be busy dancing the night away~!” She sighed. “Shame we’ll have to be chaperoning the entire event.” 

 

“Because someone needs to make sure the students don't break any rules.” 

 

“I know that, you don’t need to get all huffy with me.” 

 

“Huffy? I’m just reminding you-” And as their argument continued to pick up, Byleth began to slowly back away from them. 

 

“Good luck you two,” she said, before leaving, though neither really noticed as their argument started getting more heated. 

“Hm, it seems the Rite of Rebirth is about to begin. Shall we be assuming our positions?” Hubert asked Byleth as the Black Eagles waited in the cathedral. 

 

“Yes. Petra, are you ready to go for backup in case anything happens?” 

 

“Of course professor! None shall be as swift of leg as I!” 

 

“I think you mean swift-footed, Petra,” Dorothea gently corrected.

 

“Good. Now remember everyone, if anyone does come by here, our primary goal is to stop them from escaping,” Byleth stated, “Don’t do anything dangerous if you don’t need to, and make sure to fall back if need be.” 

 

“I-I’ll make sure to k-keep that in mind!” Bernadetta squeaked, looking ready to bolt already.

 

“I’m sure everything will be okay,” Edelgard reassured, “Even if the enemy manages to sneak their way in, I doubt they’ll have many men with them.” Besides, she thought, the only dangerous one would probably be the Death Knight, who likely wouldn’t listen to any soldier the slithers were controlling. 

 

“We should still be careful, but for now, everyone, make sure to keep an eye out.” Byleth instructed, dismissing her students as they all moved to hide. It took some time, but eventually the class saw several robed figures who looked like priests approach where they were hiding, making their way to the mausoleum beneath the cathedral. 

 

“Seems we hit the mark, my teacher,”  Edelgard said from where she was crouched by Byleth before they stood up, signaling to the class to follow them as they chased the ‘priests’. 

 

And it seemed they were indeed correct as they walked into the mausoleum and saw several figures moving about the vast room, examining what seemed to be coffins and taking up defensive positions. Including the apparent leader at the other end of the room, a man in the clothes and bird-like mask of a dark mage, though Church white instead of the standard black, who seemed to spot them. 

 

“Those central church dastards spotted us! Quick, hold them off!” he shouted, before focusing on the coffin he was next to, trying to undo a magical seal. 

 

“They’re after the tomb of the Saint Seiros. What would they want with some bones…” Edelgard muttered, trying to keep up appearances, before she spotted the Death Knight. “Hm, that one seems dangerous. We should try–” 

 

And whatever she was about to say was cut off as the Death Knight threw his scythe straight across the room, the massive weapon nearly cleaving Byleth in half if she didn’t block it. Even then, she skidded back from the force before she managed to fling it away, though it quickly returned to the Death Knight’s hand in a flash of blood-red light.

 

“FINALLY. WORTHY PREY.” the demonic figure intoned, before his horse rear back and charged straight at Byleth, who felt her eyes widen–

 

No, she didn’t have time to think. “MOVE!”

 

Her students hastened to obey, most moving on reflex, and Byleth internally cursed as she took notice of just how many other foes there were all throughout the room. Monks and mages made up the bulk of the force–Then she was rolling out of the way, her mind racing as the black horse nearly ran her down.

 

She had to duck again, a scythe blade swinging over head, all while Edelgard stared in shock nearby. The Death Knight shouldn’t be going after the professor, he had no reason to–And Edelgard felt herself cursing in her own thoughts as she remembered that night when she first saw the professor genuinely angry. Which was also when she had nearly beaten Jeritza to death. Of course his more vicious personality would take an interest in the professor, and Edelgard was a damned fool not to realize it!

 

“Professor–!”

 

“FORGET ME! I’LL HANDLE HIM!” Byleth shouted, and Edelgard felt the strangest pang of fear because her professor never shouted. “DO NOT DRAW HIS ATTENTION!”

 

She pointed straight at the leader of the invaders at the end of the room, her arm outstretched behind her as she kept her eyes straight on the Death Knight. “He’s the one we need dead! Keep your eyes out, stay in groups of four! Edelgard, Ferdinand, Hubert, Dorothea, left side! Linhardt, Caspar, Bernadetta, Emily, right side! NO ARGUING, JUST MOVE!”

 

Edelgard swallowed her response, and simply nodded, moving to obey as she hoisted her axe and shield.

 

“Wait, we can’t really leave her–”

 

“Ferdinand, now is not the time for this!” Edelgard insisted, shooting her classmate a scowl, “The professor gave us our order, now hurry up!”

 

“I SEE. SO YOU SEEK TO KEEP OUR BOUT BETWEEN US. VERY WELL.” The Death Knight inclined his head, respecting Byleth’s decision…before he started to laugh. “FINALLY…COME! LET US SEE IF YOU ARE ABLE TO KILL ME!”

 

Byleth didn’t reply. She wasn’t just waiting for him to make a move, she was preparing, and her sword glowed with light as she imbued it with as much magic as she could manage in the moment. There was no chance this fight could be taken as anything less than deadly seriously, especially with the time limit of the mage attempting to open the coffin at the end of the room.

 

But she had no time to think about that. She had every disadvantage in this fight: her opponent’s scythe had a longer reach in addition to obvious magical properties, he was on horseback, and she had to keep an eye out for her students. The only solution, considering all of those factors, was to remove those advantages.

 

A near impossible prospect, but one she had to go for as he urged his horse to charge her again. So she flung a fireball straight at his face.

 

The Death Knight swung straight through the ball of flame, dispersing it easily, though his distraction meant another one slammed straight into his horse’s face a second later. Unfortunately for Byleth, the Death Knight’s steed was not one that reacted to having flames burst against it. The armor it wore dispersed the damage, but more than that, it didn’t even react to having fire that close to its eyes.

 

“PALTRY TRICKS. COME, FACE ME WITH YOUR TRUE FURY!” the Death Knight ordered as he aimed to run her down.

 

Byleth frowned, but a fight like this wasn’t the kind of thing that made her angry. It just made her focus. 

 

She moved again, leaping to the side and lightning crackled around her free hand before a bolt caught the knight in the side, earning an actual grunt of pain before he turned and thrust the spearpoint of his scythe towards her, which she had to drop to avoid. Dodging to the side wouldn’t be easy with how wide the blades of his scythe were, yet she had to move quickly to get back to her feet. Being prone in front of a man on horseback was certain death; she’d seen what hooves could do to a human body and if she fell under a warhorse, she would die, simple as that.

 

So how did a swordswoman on foot fight against an armored knight on horseback? Simply put, she didn’t.

 

There was a reason why cavalry was king on the battlefield, and Byleth hadn’t thought to bring any sort of polearm that might give her enough reach to do damage. There was the option of wearing him down with magic–Something that seemed equally difficult as she was forced to leap over a coffin to avoid another charge–but armor like that would disperse fire and thunder, assuming she could even hit him.

 

Then she noticed an arrow plink off his armor and turned her attention towards Bernadetta, who looked absolutely terrified to see her shot be completely ineffective. But it did give Byleth an idea, because there was a nearby archer aiming at her students.

 

“GET BACK HERE!” the Death Knight snarled as his opponent fled from him. Fled, like a coward! He urged his steed after her, his mouth curled into a vicious scowl beneath his helm, when an arrow nearly took his eye. A narrow movement saved him from losing his sight and he felt that very same eye widen as he saw his foe wielding a bow she’d ripped from the hands of an archer she had decapitated.

 

The Death Knight had no need of something as worthless as a shield. He desired a fight to the death, after all, and an emphasis on defense would get in the way of that. But he did come to understand why some people would use them as an arrow nearly punched through his breastplate.

 

“Thank you, Bernie! Focus on the enemy though!” Byleth shouted, drawing another arrow from the dead man’s quiver and launching it straight towards center mass, focused on guaranteeing hits over trying to be fancy with it. If she could put an arrow through the knight’s eyes though, well, she wouldn’t be unhappy with that result.

 

“INTERESTING…” The Death Knight’s foe truly was shrewd, though a fight at a distance was not what he desired. He wanted to hear the clash of steel, enjoy the reek of blood in the air, and feel her fists breaking his body once more. He needed her fury…and that thought drew his eye towards the small archer girl that tried to put an arrow in his shoulder.

 

…His master could accept one death.

 

The Death Knight spurred his horse forward, eyes locking on his target–Then his body seized as thunder crashed into his back. He urged his steed back, the beast obeying without hesitation as he whirled to face his intended foe–Then he heard the beast scream at the sensation of steel biting into an unarmored part of its body.

 

His looked down, trying to catch sight of his foe, though he only did once he lifted his eyes and saw her leap from a coffin, blade shining as she swung it for his head.

 

“FINALLY!” he cheered, swinging his scythe in turn and catching her blade on its pole. 

 

Byleth grit her teeth as the knight pushed her back, landing and rolling to her feet on the ground–Before her eyes widened in genuine surprise as the knight fully leapt from his horse and tried to bring his scythe down on her head. It missed her by inches, cutting some hair as she ducked, before she raced in close, trying to take advantage before he could bring it back around.

 

She scored a cut across his chest, not deep enough to put him down, and he connected with a kick to her chest that sent her back, not quite knocking the wind from her lungs–

 

The Death Knight lunged, raising his scythe high before lightning filled his vision, a bolt of thunder crashing against his head. The smell of burnt air filled his nose, almost overtaking the scent of blood. He almost felt thankful for his master and her allies for killing all who stood in their way; the reek of spilled blood made this fight ever more enjoyable. 

 

He continued his advance, swinging in wide arcs to try to cut down the first foe in ages to make him truly feel alive. And she proved her mettle just as he hoped, deflecting or dodging every swing and returning with strikes of her own that scored against his armor, scratching the surface. He twisted and spun his scythe, uncaring of what blows she might land in favor of seeking her blood. He could see the light fade from her blade as sweat beaded her skin, the song of battle wearing down on her even as it invigorated him. It wasn’t enough though. She needed more rage if she were to face him properly, so how could he–

 

Then his attention was caught by more figures in white entering the tomb. He considered them, wondering if they were allied to his master or perhaps foes he was allowed to butcher while allowing his foe a moment of reprieve to catch her breath. He could feel he was on the cusp of something and it would not do to end things too soon.

 

“Hurry! We must seize the remains of Saint Seiros before–gulrk–!” 

 

The Death Knight tilted his head as the man in white went down with an arrow through his throat, regarding the young man in a Garreg Mach uniform following in after him with a bow in hand. More students arrived, striking at the rest of the intruders, but the boy with the yellow cape seemed important.

 

“I really hope that was one of the bad guys,” Claude muttered to himself, before noticing the Death Knight. “Woah. Hey, Teach, are you doing okay over there?”

 

The Death Knight tilted his head the other way, thinking. That boy wasn’t one of his master’s vassals. He could certainly afford to kill that one.

 

“I’m fine! Ignore the knight, just help Edelgard handle the intruders!” Byleth ordered.

 

“I don’t think I have to,” Claude pointed out as, across the room, Edelgard batted a sword out of the lead mage’s hands before crushing his head against the casket with her axe. “Wait, is that–”

 

The sword spun through the air before clattering to the floor by Byleth’s feet. She stared at it for a moment, a strange sense of confusion and familiarity hitting her all at once, before she had to move again as the Death Knight decided to swing his scythe down at her.

 

She rolled to her feet, the strange sword in her hand as the knight chuckled, a low, dark sound that reverberated through the room.

 

“SO THAT IS IT…EXCELLENT.” The Death Knight let his bloodlust flow into the Scythe of Sariel, filling its blade with murderous intent. The scythe began to gleam just as the sword in his foe’s hand started to glow. Beneath his helm, the Death Knight felt a truly joyous smile begin to spread across his face. “COME! LET US FINISH THIS!”

 

He heard voices, cries from the students, before he swung just as she did. He saw a flash as the blade extended, moving unlike any sword he had seen before. Then he felt his armor split, and a laugh spilled from his lips as he felt blood well at his chest. “YES! YES!”

 

He turned, looking at his greatest foe, who turned to face him just the same. And just like him, there was a wound across her chest. He saw her spit blood from her lips, but she was still alive, still focused on him and him alone. He felt enraptured, his heart racing as blood spilled from his wound. Yet it was too shallow. They weren’t finished yet.

 

“Stop!” he heard his master command, a hint of uncharacteristic fear in her voice, but she need not fear. He had found exactly what he was looking for.

 

It almost came as an annoyance then when he noticed a second woman sprinting at him with her sword drawn. Any other time, he might have been delighted to see Thunder Catherine joining the fray, yet he only felt disappointment at how the climax of their battle must be postponed.

 

He swung still, forcing her back lest she lose her nose. “Grh–You won’t get away with this!”

 

“AS THOUGH I CARE. FAREWELL, ASHEN DRAGON. I LOOK FORWARD TO OUR NEXT BOUT.” And then he was gone as though he had never been.

 

“...” Byleth just stared at where the knight had been, her body still tense from the fight as she felt…strangely dizzy.

 

“Grh…dastard!” Catherine spat, before turning to look at the professor, “Hey, are you–Ah!”

 

She caught the shorter woman as she suddenly slumped, before noticing just how much she was bleeding. “Ah, damn it all! Get a healer over here, now!”

 

And as Marianne and Linhardt, moving faster than most of the students had seen him move before, hurried over to the professor, Claude decided to just…take things in for a moment. Because if he was right, the sword the professor was still holding was exactly what he’d been looking for.

 

Not only that, but it was pretty interesting seeing Edelgard hurry to her professor’s side too, despite not being a healer like Catherine called for…And then, of course, there was that last thing that caught his eye.

 

“...So hey, did that knight guy just leave his horse here?”

Chapter End Notes

Indi: You know, someone once commented that they wanted Byleth and Jeritza to go fight again completely feral. Well shout out to you Lumidae! Hope we delivered lol.

Red: There's always something fun about small changes resulting in natural, yet unexpected consequences. Bonus fun if it happens to be something our audience guessed ahead of time.

Indi: Yup yup, and well, now Byleth has to deal with almost getting cut in half.

Red: Not completely though! Still mostly intact! More "cut open" than "cut apart".

Indi: Well only one way to find out what happens afterwards, see you next time!

Interlude - The Death Knight

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Jeritza sighed to himself, then downed another elixir before tightening the bandages around his chest. He often disliked his other side, the monstrosity that hungered within him for blood and death, but never more so than when the damned fool went and caused him trouble after the fact. It was always him who patched up the wounds once the bloodshed was done, because it was not the place of the Death Knight to do any actual maintenance.

 

There was a knock at the door to his quarters and he felt a frown come to his face. “I am indecent. Do not enter.”

 

And yet, the door was opened anyway and he felt a deeper spike of annoyance at the thought that he’d have to kill a witness before he recognized the white hair of his employer. “Lady Edelgard. And Lord Hubert. Hello.”

 

His employer did not look pleased. Jeritza watched as the heir of Vestra closed the door and briefly considered if this was the point at which the young man would execute him. He felt the Death Knight immediately begin to rise at the idea, displeased at the thought of dying outside of combat.

 

“What in the world was that?” Edelgard demanded, scowling at him.

 

“...I presume you refer to my actions within the Mausoleum, rather than my poor attempt to get you to leave. As to the latter, I thought it best I not be seen bandaging my chest soon after the Death Knight received a wound across his.”

 

“That part is understandable. What I meant is why did you attack the professor? You were supposed to hold back!”

 

“That was my intention, yes. However, do you recall the time at which Professor Byleth requested she spar with me?”

 

Edelgard pinched the bridge of her nose. “Please don’t tell me my suspicions were correct…”

 

“If your suspicions were that the Death Knight desired to fight Professor Byleth again because of the brutality she showed during the spar, then I apologize, but you were entirely correct.”

 

His employer groaned again, placing her face in her hands in a display of exasperation while Hubert regarded Jeritza with a raised eyebrow. “‘Professor Byleth’, is it? Not ‘Professor Eisner’?”

 

“She is a colleague and an equal on the battlefield. The Death Knight is quite certain she is the one who will finally put an end to our torment.”

 

“And that means he’s going to go after the professor whenever possible,” Edelgard noted, looking up from her hands, “Meaning you’ve just become an enormous liability, Jeritza.”

 

“Indeed,” Jeritza agreed, “I apologize. However, I should be able to keep a firm enough control of him to avoid causing issues while attending to my duties at the Academy. If we meet again on the battlefield though, I can make no promises.”

 

Edelgard sighed. “Unfortunately, that is likely unavoidable. I already promised Those Who Slither that you could be used for three missions.”

 

“I am aware. I will still do my utmost to carry out your orders, yet I cannot guarantee the Death Knight will not cause issues of his own volition.”

 

“So our circumstances are much the same,” Hubert noted, earning him a frown from his lady, “You know I’m right, your highness. We always knew the Death Knight was an issue. For as useful as Jeritza is, he comes with an unfortunate addition that will always mean he straddles the line between useful and detrimental.” He glanced at Jeritza. “No offense intended, of course.”

 

“I have no issue with your words, they are all correct.”

 

Edelgard glanced between her two vassals, then sighed again. “Okay, fine, we’ve established there will be problems because of the Death Knight. We can’t avoid that. What we can look at is how to mitigate it, along with what we should do moving forward. Especially given the issue of my…owing Those Who Slither.”

 

Then there was another knock at the door and all three of them paused.

 

“...I am indecent, do not–” Jeritza began before Hubert simply locked the door. “Ah. I should have done that earlier.”

 

“You should have, yes,” Hubert replied, before the knock came again.

 

“Lady Hresvelg, Lord Vestra, I know you two are in there,” came the voice on the other side, one that made Hubert frown while Edelgard’s eyes widened in recognition, “Do let me in before I’m forced to report how two students are in the same room as an ‘indecent’ instructor.”

 

“...” Hubert slipped a knife from his sleeve as he took the door handle, before pausing when Lady Edelgard shook her head.

 

“It’s one of them,” she explained, before moving past him and opening the door herself.

 

Selene smiled cheerfully as she was allowed entrance, stepping inside quite casually before nodding to Edelgard. “Thank you very much for holding the door for me, your highness. Would you mind closing it as well?”

 

Edelgard frowned but did so as Selene looked around the bedroom. “My, you truly do have quite barren living quarters, Instructor Jeriitza. I would think the heir of House Hrym would liven up his living space at least a little. Wouldn’t you?”

 

“I have no need of decoration,” Jeritza responded, “Who are you?”

 

The priestess smiled, then curtsied with her robes. “I am Selene, a faithful member of the Church of Seiros. I come from the Empire originally, though I consider the Kingdom a second home after a lengthy pilgrimage there. I am also wondering just what you were thinking, you stupid bastard, when you completely botched the mission into the Mausoleum.”

 

Jeritza blinked. It wasn’t the words that caught him off guard so much as the fact that the woman’s tone hadn’t changed in the slightest even as she spoke them. “...Ah. You are a member of Those Who Slither in the Dark then.”

 

“...Great Sages, is that actually what you call us?” Selene asked, glancing at Edelgard, “I’m actually offended. I didn’t think that could happen.”

 

“Oh? Do the words of us ‘lowly beasts’ matter so much to you then?” Edelgard asked in turn, crossing her arms over her chest.

 

“Sticks and stones may break bones, but words wound just as deep, girl. But I’ll save the lessons for your professor to teach, presuming she still lives after this lout decided he’d prefer to carve her up.”

 

“She is going to live, and we were just discussing that.”

 

“Horrible news, and excellent, then I don’t have to waste time reiterating the point where he allowed the armor we so generously gifted him to get sliced up. Though did you mention the part where he left his horse behind, yes? You know, the one also outfitted with Agarthan armor.”

 

Edelgard frowned. “So that’s why you’re involving yourself.”

 

“You put special armor on a horse?” Hubert asked, prompting Selene to roll her eyes.

 

“Your ‘Death Knight’ is the one that requested full armor, so obviously we’re not going to half-ass it.”

 

“What happened to the Death Horse then?” Jeritza asked, before pausing as everyone stared at him. “What?”

 

“Did you honestly name your steed ‘The Death Horse’?” Hubert asked.

 

“Yes. He is the horse of the Death Knight, therefore he is the Death Horse.”

 

“That does make sense,” Edelgard noted.

 

Selene, meanwhile, slapped a hand to her face and groaned something akin to ‘useless animals’.

 

“Hm. So is that all you wish to discuss with us?” Hubert asked the false priestess.

 

“Hmph. I would ask that you keep that armor from being studied by the Church, if possible. Aside from that, leash your pet better. I would hate to think he could disrupt our own plans when it comes time to call in our favors.”

 

“We still succeeded in our objective,” Edelgard rebutted, annoyed with the sage’s arrogant tone, “The tomb of Seiros was proven to be empty. Even if there was something unexpected inside.”

 

“Ah yes, the Sword of the Creator, which you allowed the Church to so easily reclaim.”

 

Hubert raised an eyebrow. “Oh? So that’s what that sword was.”

 

Selene made a disgusted face. “Don’t pretend ignorance. It would have been a boon if we could have acquired it and now it’s bound to go back under even tighter security.”

 

“...Hm. Are you certain?” Edelgard asked.

 

“Certain of what? That the beasts would rather keep their greatest weapon close at hand?”

 

“I don’t doubt that, it’s just…the Sword of the Creator lacked a crest stone, yet it reacted in the professor's presence.”

 

Selene paused, then frowned. “That…shouldn’t be possible. It would make sense to keep the stone separate from the relic if they did not wish it to be used, but…No, that thief shouldn’t have any descendants, should he?”

 

“And what ‘thief’ would that be?”

 

“Hm? Oh, that ‘King of Liberation’, as you call him. The fool would have been little more than a bandit were it not for my people’s aid.”

 

Edelgard blinked, before her brow furrowed, thoughts racing at the offhand revelation Bias had let slip as though it barely mattered.

 

Bias scarcely noticed though. “Perhaps we should keep a closer eye on that professor of yours…”

 

“...” Edelgard had a thought. “Isn’t that what Shez is there for?”

 

“What?” Bias raised an eyebrow, then paused, her eyes widening. “...That bitch. How long has she been planning…No. No, never mind. Hresvelg, I’ll…I will contact you later.”

 

“I would prefer any correspondence to her highness go through me first,” Hubert stated.

 

“Fine, I’ll talk to you first then, Vestra,” she replied, and Hubert kept his features schooled at the unexpected acquiescence, “I just…need to think about…Could Solon know? He seemed curious, he must have suspicions…”

 

Edelgard and Hubert shared a glance, before Edelgard elected to speak. “Bias.”

 

The Agarthan paused, then looked towards the princess with a frown. “Try to keep that name off your lips while we’re still in the monastery.”
