“Very well, Selene. I wanted to ask though if, perhaps, there might be something we could do to aid you.”

 

“...what? You…You’re offering to help me?”

 

“I am. It sounds as though your faction may be dealing with a splinter group. The one operating under Cleobulus, perhaps?”

 

“...How did you…”

 

“She’s the only sage unaccounted for in your description of their duties. You mentioned seven, two are deceased, you are one, Solon is another, and Myson and Chilon are accounted for. So that leaves the last one, who sounds as though she may have betrayed your people.”

 

“...” Bias just stared at her, her mind visibly racing, before she straightened. “...That depends. The girl, Shez. She infiltrated the ‘Jeralt Mercenaries’. Can you check if they were in the Oghma Mountains five years ago?”

 

“Easily,” Hubert assured with a smirk on his face.

 

“...Good. Good. Then, if you can do so…I believe I might owe you a favor in turn.”

 

Edelgard nodded, hiding any hint of her true feelings as the Agarthan willingly placed herself in their debt.

 

“...We’ll speak again soon,” Bias decided, before turning for the door. She paused a moment later though. “Solon has plans for that girl. I may have plans as well. Do not kill her under any circumstance.”

 

“If you insist,” Hubert replied with some amusement, while Edelgard simply nodded in reply.

 

“...Oh, and your horse is in the stables,” Bias offered, nodding to Jeritza.

 

“I see. So the Death Horse has been imprisoned then…how unfortunate.”

 

“...I…I’m not going to follow up on that, goodbye.” And so she left, which let Edelgard sink into Jeritza’s desk chair with a sigh of relief.

 

“...Hubert, we can’t waste this opportunity.”

 

“You’re right, we cannot. Though I would like to know what that opportunity is, your highness.”

 

She glanced up at him, no longer bothering to hide her smile. “The opportunity to turn a ‘sage’ against her fellows. Especially with how readily she suspected another of her number.”

 

“Assuming she actually does suspect such a thing and wasn’t putting on an act for our benefit.”

 

“Assuming that, true. But we do have to assume there are some bouts of honesty coming from Those Who Slither, especially when they allow it to slip from their lips without thought.” And what fascinating information she garnered from those small slips. To know the Agarthans considered Nemesis a thief who needed their aid as well as learning that Shez more than likely belonged to the faction under this “Cleobulus” person, who was apparently a woman…There were puzzle pieces there, though she didn't have everything to fit them all together.

 

She would though. Soon enough, she would know all she needed to make her vision a reality. Though, in the midst of all that, a part of her couldn’t help but consider her professor…and just what she might think when Shez’s deceptions were unveiled.

 

A part of her…really didn’t want to do that to her professor. But…she wouldn’t look back. She couldn't. Not if she wanted to create a better world.

Chapter End Notes

Red: In which Edelgard continues to get the wrong idea while receiving way more information.

Indi: But hey, good news, Byleth is alive, if grievously injured.

Red: More injured than I think people realized, considering how casual everyone was last time. Though, then again, we did have the Death Horse to focus on.

Indi: Worry not, the Death Horse will, eventually, be free from his imprisonment!

Red: One day, he shall ride again!

The Week without Byleth

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Preparing for the day felt… difficult. For all her talk of being ready to send people to their death, almost causing the violent demise of her professor showed Edelgard that her heart wasn't as hardened as she hoped. Letting out a sigh as she tied her hair with her ribbons, the young princess walked out of her room, though she paused quite quickly when a small meowing caught her attention.

 

Glancing down, the princess saw a Hresvelgian Whisker rub up against her legs. With a sad smile, she crouched down to pet the cat. 

 

"My apologies, I seem to have forgotten to get you your treats for today," Edelgard apologized, even as the cat leaned into her touch, purring as they did, "I'll make sure to bring you some later." 

 

The cat let out another mew, before curling up in front of her door. 

 

"I really should come up with a name for you…" Edelgard muttered, wondering what kind of name would honor the cat for ensuring no…pests got into her room. Ah, though she should focus on getting to class first. 

 

…Whiskerton the Great. 

 

No, wait, she shouldn't get distracted. Bidding the cat farewell, Edelgard commenced her walk to the class, then idly noted Hubert slinking up behind her as she went from walking alone to walking together.

 

Things around the monastery were hectic, as she had assumed. It was to be expected, given that the Tomb of Seiros had not actually contained the corpse of Seiros, but a relic weapon. Perhaps that was why Rhea had ordered for the immediate execution of the Western Church members? It was a foolish decision, of course, to send them to their deaths without even questioning them. Apparently she hadn’t even bothered to hear their last words before putting them to the sword.

 

Not that it was surprising. The Archbishop had spent far too long stuck in her ways, and in the history of the church, dissenters were almost always put to the blade. Unless it was the Kingdom of course, back when they had rebelled and were given sovereignty after a bloody war. 

 

A part of her idly wondered if, should she succeed, she would be remembered in the same light. A glorious hero who freed the lands from a corrupt evil…

 

What a foolish notion. 

 

"Hey there, Edelgard. You certainly seem down," Claude greeted, his usual grin on his face. 

 

"I would think that would be obvious," Edelgard responded, “Professor Byleth was nearly killed.”

 

"Yeah, but I didn't expect you to take it so badly. I mean, here I thought we were similar in that regard. Though I suppose you're more naive than I thought." 

 

"Did you require anything besides insulting Lady Edelgard?" Hubert asked, glowering at the house leader. 

 

"I did in fact, no need to worry there Hubert, my man," Claude replied, uncaring of the glare he received. "Just had to ask since you're the one who was fighting against that robber. That was a relic weapon, right?" 

 

"And what if it was?" 

 

"Well I'm just curious is all. I mean, as far as I know, Seiros didn't wield a relic weapon. Not to mention how the sword was the only thing in the coffin. In fact, thinking about what I know of Fodlan’s history, wasn’t it her mortal enemy Nemesis that had a relic weapon that just so happened to be a sword?”

 

“Are you trying to make a point with this history lesson? Or are you truly so enamored with the sound of your own voice?” Hubert taunted, his annoyance obvious.

 

"Can't it be both? Claude asked. "But if you want me to get to my point, I will. Did Teach tell you what her crest is?" 

 

"Professor Byleth doesn't know what her crest is, so I fail to see how she would tell me," Edelgard answered. 

 

"Is that so? Well I was just curious, might have just been a trick of the light, but from my perspective it looked like she immediately dived at the sword. Said sword also seemed to react to her crest," He looked directly at Edelgard. "And I'm sure an Adrestrian princess like you has to know what crest Nemesis had." 

 

"..." Edelgard's frown deepened. Was it possible that Byleth had the same crest as her? In that case…Was she actually a descendant of the King of Liberation? 

 

"Hm, based on your reaction, you didn't know. Guess our stoic professor is one to keep secrets after all," Claude mused. 

 

"..." No, that wasn't accurate. If Byleth did have that crest, then she likely did not know. Though… was it possible someone else knew? Was that why Rhea was so interested in Byleth…?

 

"Oh? You look like you’re thinking about something interesting there. Care to share your thoughts with me? You know, in the spirit of inter-house cooperation and all that.”

 

"I am not one to spread rumors, Claude. Even more so when it comes to the professor. Besides, would it not be better to ask Shez, or Captain Jeralt?" 

 

"Hey come on now, I'm not that callous to try and pry them away from Teach's bedside." 

 

"Then I suppose you'll just have to wait. Now if you'll excuse me, I have class to attend," Edelgard stated, brushing past him. 

 

"I see he continues to be a thorn," Hubert muttered as they entered their class. Unsurprisingly they were the first ones there, as was the usual. It was a bit odd, thinking about how consistent things could be at a time like this. After Edelgard and Hubert’s entrance, it would always be Ferdinand, happily greeting them as he sat nearby. Soon afterwards Petra would show up, usually after a morning jog, with Caspar rushing in after his own training. The professor would show up soon after, going over her lesson plan for the day, as she quietly greeted everyone. 

 

In immediate contrast, Dorothea usually walked in afterwards, cheerily greeting everyone. The last student to show up on time was always Bernadetta, the mousey girl slinking in and trying to go unnoticed. The final two students tended to be a coin flip on who would arrive last; Lindhart with his tendency to oversleep often wandered in a few minutes after lessons began, while Emily just came in whenever she wanted. 

 

The fact that she would show up at all was probably a miracle, really. 

 

Which meant it came as a large surprise that the first one to show up after them was Emily. 

 

"...tch, of course you're here early," Emily muttered, looking away from them. Sitting down at the back of the class, the disguised Agarthan said nothing else. 

 

"...I'm surprised to see you here so early," Edelgard responded, noting Emily restlessly bouncing her leg up and down. 

 

"When I show up is my own business," Emily grunted, a scowl on her face. "Being here is supposed to make me stronger, right?" 

 

"I was unaware that you were actually taking the lessons here seriously." 

 

"Not like I tell you what I do," Emily snarked, before looking away from her. Letting out a sigh, Edelgard turned back to her desk, before pulling out her own textbook to self study. She could only hope their professor would awaken soon. 

"Until further notice, I shall be acting as professor for the Black Eagles," Jeritza stated, having walked into the classroom the next day. 

 

"..." Edelgard could only find bitter irony at the situation at hand. Her original plan at the start of the year was to get Jeritza as her professor, and to think she would actually get that, albeit temporarily. 

 

"I am unaware of the lessons Professor Byleth had in mind, so for now, we shall head to training grounds for some practice," Jeritza stated, “Pair off as you wish to. I am uninterested in fighting any of you, so do not bother me.”

 

“...” Ferdinand raised his hand. “Er, professor, are you certain this is the best course of action–”

 

“Yes. Go to the training grounds, now.”

 

"Great, so we have a combat addict in charge now," Dorothea muttered as the students got up. "Could be worse I suppose. If we had Seteth instead, he'd probably just lecture us all day." 

 

"Yes, at least this keeps us active," Edelgard responded, which the class did need in the moment given how down the mood was.

 

"True. Anyways Edie, are you busy after class? I was thinking of visiting the professor." 

 

"Ah…My apologies, but I will not have the time to visit the professor for now," Edelgard declined, finding it inappropriate to visit her given her involvement in what happened. 

 

"Oh, really? Well, you should make sure to visit her when you have the time," Dorothea suggested with a smile. 

 

"I will. If nothing else, I will make sure to visit when she awakens." 

 

"Hey! Professor Jeritza! Come on, let's spar!" Caspar immediately shouted upon arriving at the training grounds. 

 

"I said I am uninterested in sparring with any of you." 

 

"Yeah but I wanna spar with you!" Caspar declared. 

 

"Well at least he's still as lively as ever…" 

 

"He does have the right idea," Ferdinand noted as Caspar continued to bug Jeritza. "That night at the Mausoleum just showed how much further we have to go to match the professor." 

 

Not just the professor really. Even if it was the Death Knight fighting, Edelgard had underestimated the weaponry the Agarthans wielded. If she was pious, she would have said it was a miracle Byleth survived. As it stood, it was thanks to Lindhart and Marianne that she had been stabilized in time for Manuela to take over. She should make sure to thank them when she had the time. 

 

"Excuse me, I hope I'm not bothering you." Breaking out of her thoughts, Edelgard glanced over to see Mercedes standing near the entrance to the training grounds, Annette standing behind her. 

 

"Hm? Did you require something?" 

 

"Not at all, I just wanted to see how you all were doing." Mercedes responded, walking up to Edelgard to watch the training going on. Surprisingly Caspar had managed to convince Jeritza to spar with him, though it was more him deftly blocking Caspar's attacks with one hand. 

 

"Yeah, I mean… we know Professor Byleth is okay, but you know…" Annette trailed off, unsure of what to say. 

 

"Thank you for your concern, though at the moment, we are simply waiting for her to recover," Edelgard responded, "And there was no need to skip classes to check on us." 

 

"Oh, no we're not skipping class! Professor Hanneman assigned us to free study today because he had something to discuss with Lady Rhea," Annette interjected. 

 

"I also wanted to check if you and the rest of the Eagles were up for some treats,” Mercedes explained, “I was already planning on baking some for Shez, so I wanted to see how much I should make." 

 

"...Well, I would hate to deny your gift," Edelgard allowed.

 

"Wow! Jeritza, are you okay!?" Caspar suddenly shouted, catching their attention as the students looked over to see the instructor crouching down, grasping his chest, his mask knocked clean off his face. 

 

"It is… an old woun," Jeritza responded, pushing himself up as he moved over to grab his mask. Edelgard heard a small gasp beside her as Mercedes got a good look at the instructor without the mask on. 

 

"Is something wrong?" 

 

"Oh… it's okay, just… Professor Jeritza reminds me of someone I knew," Mercedes responded, before muttering something to herself. 

 

Frowning, Edelgard glanced between the two, before noting some…similarities between the two. Though…It couldn't be, could it?

Wandering around in a daze, Shez couldn't help the listless feeling she was experiencing. She wanted to stay at Byleth’s side, but after the third day, Manuela had practically kicked her out, saying that staying there wouldn't do her any good. A part of her had wanted to argue, but even she knew better than to start yelling in the infirmary. 

 

Though before she could wander any further, she bumped into someone. 

 

"Oh, sorry about that," Shez apologized. 

 

"I-It's okay…" Marianne responded, the bluenette's eyes cast downward. 

 

"Still, I should have been paying attention to where I was walking," Shez noted, giving her a small smile. "Are you heading somewhere?" 

 

"...I was going to see how Professor Byleth was doing." 

 

"Oh, right, you helped save her at the Mausoleum, right?" 

 

"I-I didn't really do much," Marianne said, nervously wringing her hands. "L-Lindhart and Professor Manuela did most of the work. Really, I probably made things worse…" 

 

"Uh, I dunno about that. I mean, By was pretty badly hurt and you're good with faith magic, right?" Shez asked with a frown. "I mean, I heard you rushed in right away to help her." 

 

"...I-I didn't want Professor Byleth to die." 

 

"Exactly! So you helped save her!" Shez responded with a grin. "So I don't know who's been saying you made things worse, but point them out to me so I can beat them up." 

 

“H-Huh? U-Um…n-no one…a-actually said that…to me, directly, I mean…” Marianne mumbled, fidgeting a little with her hands, “...I-Is Professor Byleth going to be okay?”

 

“Of course she is!” Shez declared with a grin, burying down her own worries, “She’s going to be just fine! So just, uh…pray for her! You like praying, right?”

 

“...I-I s-suppose that would be something better to pray for…um…I-I’ll make sure to…”

 

“Yeah, that sounds good, oh, or maybe you can join her class instead?”

 

“O-oh…I don’t k-know about that…”

 

“Well, whatever you choose, I’m sure By will appreciate it.. Uh, I should probably get going now though. Have a good one!”

 

“Y-You too…”

 

Shez waved the bluenette off before walking along without any idea of where she was going or what she should be doing now. Maybe she should ask her dad for work? His office was right by the infirmary so he’d been checking in on Byleth about once every hour, so maybe if she worked with him, she’d have an excuse to–

 

“You need something, kid?”

 

Shez startled, shaken from her thoughts before looking at some woman she didn’t recognize at all. “Oh, no, I’m good.”

 

“Hm. Is there a reason why you came to the knight’s quarters then?”

 

“Huh?” Shez looked around, then winced as she realized she really was in the place all the knights usually hung out in. “Ah…sorry, no. I was just…I dunno, just kind of walking around. It’s no big deal, uh…uhhh…you person whose name I totally know.”

 

“This is the first time you’ve spoken to me,” the blue-haired woman wearing black and turquoise noted.

 

“Oh. Oh good! Alright, new person then, hi there! This your first time at the monastery?”

 

“I’ve been here longer than you have. And I’ve been at the monastery since the start of the month.”

 

“...You were?” Shez didn’t quite glance at Arval, but she did want to double check on that.

 

“Hm…I do think I have seen her around,” Arval answered to her silent query, “Your sister talked to her at least once.”

 

“I was,” answered the woman to Shez’s verbal query, “Shamir Nevrand, former mercenary and current Knight of Seiros.”

 

“You were a mercenary??” Shez asked, immediately curious, then paused, “Oh, you’re a knight of Seiros…”

 

“Hm. Usually people are more disappointed by the mercenary part than the knight part.”

 

“Really? Being a merc is much cooler though.” Shez tilted her head, still a little curious. “So did you run with any groups I’d know? I worked with a few before getting adopted by my dad–Oh, right, I’m Shez Eisner, by the way! Jeralt the Blade Breaker’s second daughter!”

 

“I know who you are. You make yourself pretty obvious. As for my time as a merc, that’s in the past." 

 

"Huh, you sure? I mean, I'm not a knight but I think being a merc is better."

 

"Heh, better not let anyone else hear you. Besides, I owe Lady Rhea for taking me in, and my partner would probably throw a fit if I left."

 

"Really? They a part of the knights as well?" 

 

"Yeah, you probably met her already. She's Catherine." 

 

"...Not to be rude but my opinion of you has drastically lowered because of your taste in women." 

 

"...I'm gonna ignore that because Catherine told me what happened with her and your sister in the past. Also, I meant we're partners because we were assigned to one another." 

 

"Aaah. Well still, you seem okay so I'm sure you can do better than her."

 

"Hmph. What about your taste in women?" 

 

"Uh… I guess I don't really have a specific taste in people?" Shez said with a shrug. "I'd probably just say someone strong, since I'd prefer them being a merc alongside me." 

 

"Already planning on returning to the merc life?" 

 

"Well, yeah, duh. This place is nice and all, but I prefer being able to travel around. So I guess if I got with someone they'd have to be okay with that as well." 

 

"Strong and likes to travel huh? Such refined taste you have," Shamir said with a smirk. 

 

“Hey, it works for me! I’m a gal with simple tastes!” Shez replied, grinning too.

 

“You know Catherine fits both of those standards.”

 

“...Okay, now you’re messing with me.”

 

“I might be.”

 

“Hm…alright, new standard. Strong, likes to travel, and has never tried to kill me or my sister.” Shez paused, a thought occurring. “Hm…maybe ‘has never tried to kill my sister’. I dunno, I’ve read some stuff where enemies turn to lovers and that sounds kinda nice.”

 

“Speaking from personal experience, it doesn’t go great.”

 

“...Okay now I’m really curious. You can’t just say that and not explain!”

 

“Hm…maybe. I know you’ve got nothing better to do, but I probably have something I should be taking care of.”

 

“Aw! But you can’t even name what you have to do!”

 

“I can probably think of something.”

 

"Feh, fine, I'm going," Shez said with a pout. Probably best to leave before Catherine came by if this was the knights’ quarters. 

 

"There you are." Blinking as someone called out to her as she left the knights’ quarters, Shez glanced over.

 

"Oh, hey Lysithea, how's it going?" 

 

"I should be asking you that." Lysithea responded. "Though I can do that later. I wanted to know if you were up to train your magic." 

 

"Oh, uh, I guess I'm not busy, so sure? Any reason why?" 

 

"Is it not obvious? As your mentor it's my duty to help keep your mind off things. So come on." 

 

"...Heh, thanks Lysithea," Shez said, smiling in response as they two walked together. 

Jeralt felt tired. A part of him always felt a bit weary, be it because he was worried about his kids, or just because of all the work he had to focus on. Right now however, he just didn't even want to stand up from his desk. 

 

He was an old man, he knew he had lived far longer than most people had. Even so, when it came to his kids, he always hoped they'd end up outliving him. And yet, despite that hope, both of them had nearly died. Shez back during the war, and now Byleth, against some guy dressing up like he was Death himself. 

 

"Hey there, Captain." Gertrude greeted as she walked into his office. Dropping down into an empty chair, she let out a sigh. 

 

"Please tell me Ezra found something." 

 

"Nothing concrete. Hell, all he can find is that there used to be someone going around cutting down bandits and the like, but the armor he has now is new. Aside from it also being pitch black," Gertrude answered as she pulled out her pipe to smoke. "Though, I do have one guess at least." 

 

"Which is?" 

 

"Seems like any sightings of this guy happen either in Empire or Garreg Mach territory. So he's likely not a part of the Western Church," Gertrude surmised. "Though, if he is a mercenary, he's certainly a bloody one." 

 

“Hm. A ‘black knight’ is nothing new. The Empire alone probably has thousands of knights in black armor. A Death Knight though…” He frowned. “Custom work like that has to have some trace to it…good armor is still expensive for anyone who isn’t noble and that was a full suit of some kind of steel. Maybe Umbral…did you check the armor that horse of his had?”

 

“Yeah, Candace made sure to get it appraised by the smiths. They had to check it on the horse though, the rowdy thing got agitated whenever anyone tried to take it off and the stablemaster didn’t want it to hurt itself. Or anyone else, mind.”

 

“Hm…and?”

 

Gertrude sighed. “Umbral was a good guess, but it’s not that. No one’s really sure what it is. If we can get it off the horse, we could maybe bring it to a specialist, but that might take some time. Whatever steel it is, it seems solid. Not easy to break off, at least.”

 

Jeralt frowned. “That sounds about right…apparently that dastard on the horse took every hit without flinching until the kid got that relic sword. That was the only thing that cut into that armor of his…hm. I’d consider asking a noble if we could borrow one of theirs to test it, but that probably won’t go well.”

 

“They are notoriously stingy with those things.”

 

"Hm… I could try ordering Catherine to use her sword, but she'd probably take offense to having to use her sword on a horse." 

 

"And I'm pretty sure Candace would try beating you up if you ordered someone to cut down that horse." 

 

"That too." Jeralt sighed. 

 

"Uh, Captain? Can I come in?" Leonie asked, peeking in through the doorway. 

 

"Did you need something Leonie?" 

 

"Not really, I just… wanted to see how you were doing," Leonie answered as she rubbed the back of her head, before trying to give him a bright grin. "I mean, as your apprentice I have to make sure you're okay!" 

 

"Pft, aw, seems the big bad Blade Breaker still has to have kids look out for him," Gertrude teased as she put out her pipe. 

 

"Shut it Gertrude," Jeralt said with a huff. "There's no need to worry about me, Leonie." 

 

“Well, still! It’s good to check, right? Things…Well, I kind of got there late, maybe if I…ah, never mind that! We’re talking about how you’re doing! So…how are you doing?”

 

"About as well as this old body will let me." Jeralt jokingly responded. 

 

"Well, that's good, but you know…" Leonie made a vague gesture to the room next door. 

 

"...Like I said, don't worry Leonie. I'm stronger than I look and so are my kids. Knowing her, she'll probably be ready to go any day now." 

 

"...Yeah, Byleth is pretty tough. Still got a ways to go before I can match her," Leonie admitted with a sigh. 

 

"Don't sell yourself short Leonie. You've got your own strengths over Byleth and Shez. Besides, you've got your whole life ahead of you to get stronger." 

 

"Heh, man, here I was coming by to try and help you feel better and you end up turning the tables." 

 

"That's the captain for you," Gertrude piped in. "Though it's easy to turn the tables on him." 

 

"Really?" Leonie asked as Gertrude got, wrapping an arm around her shoulder. 

 

"...Gertrude what are you-" 

 

"Of course, that old lug couldn't even tell his kids about the Pegasus and the Wyverns without having me be the one to talk to them." Gertrude teased as she pulled Leonie out of the room. 

 

"...Really?" Leonie asked again, a bit surprised. "But that's something basic, right?"

 

"Pft, oh kid you have no idea about how much of a mess the captain can be." Gertrude said with a smirk as Jeralt let out a sigh. 

 

He really needed a drink. 

As she gently brushed Dorte’s mane, Marianne couldn’t help but glance at the newest addition to the stables. It was hard not to. The armor-clad stallion was an intimidating sight compared to everyone else there; even the stable master avoided him. Aside from leaving some feed for the horse, which he seemed to be ignoring… 

 

“U-Um…I’m sorry, but you really should eat…”

 

The horse neighed in response

 

“O-oh, n-no, the stable master wouldn’t poison you.” 

 

He whinnied. 

 

“W-Would you like me to bring you some new feed…u-um, what exactly is your name?

 

Another whinny. 

 

“O-Oh, The Death Horse…o-okay.” Nodding in response, Marianne walked away to get some fresh feed for him. Moments later, he was eating from the new bucket as Marianne watched him. Which is the sight Shez walked in on as she entered the stable. 

 

“Oh, hey Marianne, how's it going?”

 

“O-Oh, hello again S-Shez. I-i’m just feeding The Death Horse.” 

 

“...Eh?”

 

“Th-That’s what he said his name was.”

 

“Wait, you can understand him?”

 

“Y-Yes?”

 

“Then can you ask him about his rider??”

 

“Oh…l-let me try…” Turning around, Marianne began to talk to the horse as Shez looked on, unsure of what the horse was saying. “U-um…He says he’s not a ‘snitch’, so he’s not telling me anything…”

 

“Hm, well can you tell him something for me?” At her nod, Shez glared at the Death Horse. “Tell him that next time I see his rider, I’m kicking his ass.” 

 

“O-Oh…” She turned to the horse, though it seemed she didn’t need to repeat Shez’s message given the baleful look in The Death Horse’s eyes. The intimidating steed chuffed in a distinctly rude way. “Er…h-he accepts your challenge?”

 

“Good! …Also, ask him if he knows any other black horses. He looks cool and I kinda want one.”

 

Marianne was starting to think she shouldn’t have shared her “talent” with Shez.

"In time's flow...see the glow of flames ever burning bright…"

 

Rhea had experienced many things throughout her many years on this land. Be it Anger, Joy or any of the other countless emotions they were ones she had grown accustomed to. Yet, not even she could grow accustomed to fear. 

 

Be it when her mother died, her family went into their deep sleep, or even when war tore apart the lands she wished to keep united, she hated how weak it made her feel. So it was no surprise that fear gripped her heart when she had heard Byleth had almost died. 

 

"On the swift river's drift, broken memories alight…"

 

It was foolish to think that perhaps she was the vessel in which her mother returned, but Rhea wanted to have faith that she would be. Perhaps that was why she came by every night to sing while she slept. In hopes that it would rouse her from her sleep. 

 

She couldn't help but wonder, would this be like when Seteth and Flayn slept? Would she remain in this state for a thousand years, only to return to see everyone she knew gone…? 

 

Reaching out, she gently caressed Byleth’s face. 

 

"Mother, please return to us… we all need you," Rhea whispered as she began to hum, hoping Sothis had heard her. 

 

No matter how long it took, she would bring back her mother. For the sake of the world. 

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Shez is going to want a 2v2 fight between the Death Knight and Death Horse VS her and Byleth.

Red: Yes, Shez will be taking the place of the horse. She's taller and faster, and thus better for the role.

Indi: Yup yup. Probably faster than a horse, especially if she uses her awakened form.

Red: Ignore the fact that she has to turn into a purple ball of light to move that fast.

Indi: I'm sure it'll all be fine. I mean, at the very least it won't be the first time Byleth almost gets killed by the Death Knight if things go poorly.

Rest and Recuperation

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Sothis sighed on her throne, frowning down at Byleth, who was simply sitting on the floor because she was kind of tired of standing in this weird void place. “I suppose that mess could have gone worse. You saved your students and that dusty tomb, so, really, that’s a mission accomplished, right?”

 

“...Yes, I–”

 

“Except for the part where you got your chest cut open!” And there was the aggravation Byleth was expecting the weird girl that lived in her head to have. "What were you thinking?! You had another charge left!" 

 

"I needed to keep it in case that knight tried to attack any of the students again." 

 

"But he was completely focused on you! He might have tried to rile you up, but he stopped doing that when you started fighting seriously!" 

 

"I couldn't take that chance," Byleth responded, getting Sothis to let out an aggravated sigh. 

 

"You're lucky you had people nearby who could heal you, or things would have been worse. Along with whatever that sword was." 

 

"...Where did that sword come from?" 

 

"Did you not notice? The mage pulled it out of the tomb. Though for a tomb, it seemed rather bereft of a corpse." 

 

Byleth frowned in thought. "I felt like I saw that sword before…" 

 

Sothis made a thoughtful noise. "It is quite the mysterious blade. It reminds me of the one that Catherine uses, though it seems to lack the stone hers has." 

 

"Hm…" Shaking her head, she tried to focus on something else. "Was anyone else injured?" 

 

"For someone who doesn't show it, you are remarkably soft-hearted. Aside from some cuts and bruises, no one got injured. Though they were quite lucky none of the other intruders had a weapon like that knight. It reminds me of that power your sister has with how vile it felt." 

 

"...What?" Byleth said, frowning. "You said that before, that the thing Shez does is vile. Why?" 

 

"Hm…it is odd to describe, as it's more of a feeling but…it feels like my antithesis. Something so completely and utterly different from myself that I can't help but wonder how your sister has it…" Sothis wondered while Byleth couldn't help but feel strange because of what she said. She knew her sister had weird powers, but she couldn't imagine her being anything like that knight. "Well, no matter. Regardless of what happened, you need to recover now. Do make sure to take it easy, it's not just your life on the line." Despite her words, Sothis's tone was rather soft. 

 

"Okay," Byleth said with a nod as the light in the void began to fade. Or, perhaps, as the darkness faded into light…

Blinking as she woke up, Byleth could see light coming into the room, letting her see that she was in the infirmary. A light snore caught her attention, and she noticed that Shez and Jeralt were at her side, the two having fallen asleep in some chairs. Sitting up, Byleth couldn't help but hiss in pain as she clutched her chest. She could feel bandages wrapped tight around it under the patient’s gown she was wearing.

 

"Hrng?" Stirring awake, Shez rubbed her eyes as she reacted to the noise. "What's going–By! You're awake!" And Shez immediately tried to hug her, only to flinch back as Byleth let out a pained grunt. "S-Sorry."

 

"It's okay, it just hurts more than I thought I did." 

 

"Of course it does! You almost got cut in half!" Shez shouted, which seemed to get Jeralt to stir awake at the loud noise. "What were you thinking!?" 

 

"...I wanted to make sure my students were safe. The knight kept targeting me, so I had to fight him so he didn't attack anyone else." 

 

"Oh, so you can be reckless but I can't?" Shez asked, getting Byleth to frown. 

 

"I wasn't being reckless. I was fighting alone because the knight would have killed any of the students in one hit." 

 

"Alright, no arguing while one of you is injured," Jeralt said, having finally come to. "Now, were you being serious about that, kid?" 

 

"...Emily tried to attack the knight from his blindspot while Edelgard tried to cover me. It only took him one attack," Byleth answered, making a pit drop in Shez’s stomach. "Whoever he was, he was dangerous, and I just had to last as long as I could before help could arrive." 

 

"...Fine," Shez said, frowning as she sat back down. "I don't like it, but I get it." 

 

"Either way, it seems like you're not going to be active for a bit,” Jeralt added, “Whatever weapon that knight was using wasn't normal. The healing spells your students used seemed to barely have an effect on the wound and the church’s doctors didn’t do much better, so it isn't properly healed yet. And I have a feeling Professor Manuela is really gonna let you have it if you let your wound open up."

 

"...Hm." Frowning, Byleth laid back down. "What about classes?" 

 

"Don't think those are important right now," Shez muttered. 

 

"I think Rhea already figured something out with that, so you'll probably hear about it later." Almost as if he called her, Rhea appeared, walking in with a concerned look on her face. 

 

"I heard you three talking from down the hall. I hope you don't mind me intruding." Byleth stayed silent, unable to meet the Archbishop’s gaze and unable to deal with the concern she showed. 

 

"We were just talking about you, so I don't think so,” Jeralt replied, “Byleth here was just wondering what exactly would happen to her class while she recovered?" 

 

"Hm…" Frowning as she observed the bandaged professor, Rhea spoke. "For now, Jeritza will be instructing your class until you recover. Furthermore, depending on the state you are in, your class may not receive a mission this month." 

 

"...Well, at least some of them will be happy with that," Byleth muttered. 

 

"...There is one last thing, something Hanneman informed me of. It seems he has discovered what your crest is," Rhea said, a smile on her face. 

 

"Wait, really?" Shez asked. 

 

"Yes, he was able to realize it after you used the Sword of the Creator. It seems you hold the Crest of Flames, a crest which was thought to have been lost to history," Rhea explained, getting Byleth to frown. 

 

"The crest of the tyrant?" Which in turn made Rhea frown. 

 

"The crest itself is not a symbol of tyranny, it was a blessing of the goddess that Nemesis abused. A blessing that I hope that you use not only for your students, but for all of Fodlan." A smile reappeared on her face. "As such, I wish to entrust upon you the Sword of the Creator." 

 

"What?" 

 

"Excuse me, Lady Rhea, not to dismiss such an honor, but isn't that sword a holy relic of the church?" Jeralt questioned, looking skeptical. 

 

"It is, but if this truly is a blessing by the goddess, then it is not one I can ignore. Did it not also save your daughter when she needed it?" 

 

"That’s…that is true…" 

 

"Though I will admit, this must be much to hear so soon after waking, so I shall not force the responsibility upon you, and will wait to hear your decision for when you have recovered," Rhea said with a gentle smile, as though there wasn’t any pressure for Byleth to accept anyway.. 

 

Still, she didn’t really have a decent reason to turn down the sword…so she nodded in return "Okay.”

 

"Thank you. Now, I do believe your sister has classes she must attend, and Jeralt has his own duties to perform, if I'm not mistaken." 

 

"Pretty sure missing one day won't matter…" Shez muttered.

 

"You should go to class, Shez,” Byleth encouraged, “I'll be here when you're done." 

 

"...Fine, I'll bring you food later." 

 

“Thank you.”

 

Shez paused at Byleth’s response, then gave her a little grin. “Hey…make sure to take it easy, okay? You really worried me there.”

 

“I will. Promise.”

 

Shez nodded to her sister before heading out, leaving Jeralt to sigh and push himself up from his chair. “Right, I guess I should go too. You coming with, Lady Rhea?”

 

“Hm? Oh, well…I did wish to speak with Byleth perhaps a bit more.”

 

Byleth felt herself immediately tense at that thought, prompting a glance from Jeralt, before he looked back at Rhea. “Then I’ll stick around. Better we leave together, right?”

 

“That is not necessary, Jeralt. I can find my way through the monastery easily enough. I have lived here for some time, after all.”

 

“Sure, but you were also the target of an assassination attempt pretty recently. Besides, you can always visit the kid later, when she’s feeling more up to it.”

 

Rhea…pouted, which was not a look Byleth ever expected to see on her face. “Those matters were handled. I sincerely doubt there is a threat to my safety here and now. Though, I suppose if you insist.” She glanced at Byleth with a soft smile. “Take care, child. Rest well.”

 

“...Sure. Thanks.”

 

And with that, Byleth was alone, which let her lay back with a faint sigh. Her chest still ached, though it was duller…then a thought occurred.

 

“Hey, Sothis.”

 

“Hm? What is it? Did you really need to call upon me right as I was about to go back to sleep?”

 

Byleth ignored the girl’s annoyance. “Rhea said I wouldn’t get assigned a mission this month.”

 

“Yes? And?”

 

“The Rite of Rebirth was on the twenty-sixth. There were still a few days until the end of the month. Did I sleep for a week?”

 

Sothis paused. “...Hm. Perhaps. If so, neither your father nor your sister thought to mention it.”

 

“Right…” It probably wasn’t a big deal then.

Apparently being unconscious for a week was a much bigger deal than Byleth expected because she was pretty sure everyone in the school decided to come in to check on her.

 

Starting off, strangely enough, with Seteth and Flayn. Well, not that strangely in Flayn’s case, but a little strangely in Seteth’s.

 

“I just wanted to confirm that it was true Lady Rhea decided to give you the Sword of the Creator.” Oh, that explained it.

 

“Mnh, brother! Be nicer! Professor Byleth was injured protecting the church!”

 

“Yes, well…” Seteth cleared his throat. “Good work there. Do make sure to get your rest. You slept quite strongly for…Well, never mind.”

 

“Hmph.” Flayn huffed, before leaning towards Byleth and pretending to whisper to her, though her voice was loud enough to carry anyway. “Do not mind my brother, he was actually quite worried about you and made sure to visit every day.”

 

“I only visited because I was chaperoning you,” Seteth complained, before glancing at a nearby vase. “Ah, the flowers by your bedside need to be watered again, let me just handle that.”

 

And he promptly did, all while ignoring the smug smirk Flayn was sending his way. 

 

After the green-haired siblings came some more familiar faces from the Knights of Seiros, consisting of Catherine, Alois, and Shamir. Well, Shamir wasn’t especially familiar to Byleth, she was pretty sure they’d only talked once, but she could recognize the woman.

 

“Hey there, professor,” Catherine greeted, “How’s the bed rest going?”

 

“...Good? I don’t think you can be bad at bed rest.”

 

“Yes you can,” Shamir contradicted, “Just look at Catherine.”

 

“Hey, I can sit still! Sometimes! When I need to!”

 

“See?”

 

“Haha! Ah, it does my heart good to see my colleagues joke around so readily,” Alois said with a smile, “Just as it does me even better to see you awake, professor! You gave Captain Jeralt quite the scare there.”

 

“I did? He didn’t mention that.”

 

“Oh sure, he was just the biggest worrywart the entire time you were out! I tried to tell him to relax and I’m pretty sure he nearly punched me!”

 

“Didn’t you try to make a joke about it?” Shamir pointed out.

 

“Oh yeah, he did,” Catherine said, before frowning in thought, “What was it? Something about…’come now, captain, you should get some rest! Unless you think your daughter’s getting enough for both of you!’”

 

Alois sighed. “I will admit, that may have been a poor attempt at lightening the mood. Though, you know what they say, laughter is the best medicine! Then again, I feel if I told you one right now, you’d be laughing in stitches !”

 

“...” Byleth stared at Alois, then glanced down at her own chest. “Did…Did Manuela have to stitch me up?”

 

“Yeah, she did. It was really bad,” Shamir stated.

 

“...Hm.”

 

“Yeah, you might want to work on your comedic timing, Alois,” Catherine suggested, frowning at her fellow knight.

 

“Thyme-ing? But I’m not cooking!”

 

“...” Catherine, at that point, just decided to grab Alois by the back of his armor and drag him out of the room. “See you later, professor! Take it easy!”

 

“Ah, yeah, okay,” Byleth replied while giving the blonde knight a little wave, feeling kind of weird to see Catherine be so friendly with her. Then again, Catherine did help her twice, and…was being pretty nice in general. And she didn’t…really feel that angry at the sight of her anymore? So…huh.

 

Then she noticed Shamir was still there. “...Hi?”

 

“Hey. Don’t mind me, I just wanted to see what everyone was talking about.”

 

“...People are talking about me?”

 

“Sure. Not everyday someone can wield that fancy super sword. That, and I’ve heard a few things about you, like how you and Catherine sparred, how you two later took down Lonato together, and a few other things. You seem popular around here.”

 

“Oh. Okay.”

 

Shamir seemed faintly amused by that. “Alright, see you around. Catherine seems to like you, so that makes you okay in my book.”

 

Byleth blinked at that, then sank back in bed as Shamir left. The idea that Catherine actually liked her was…confusing. But…that didn’t sound too bad either. Maybe she really should do something nice for her…later though, she was kind of sleepy.

 

Of course, she didn’t get much sleep when her next visitor decided to announce himself. “Professor! I heard you were awake and I–”

 

“Ferdie, please, this is still an infirmary,” Dorothea chided Ferdinand as the two of them entered. Which was kind of interesting, so Byleth sat up to look over at the unusual pair.

 

“Ah, see? The professor is awake! No need to worry!”

 

“You still shouldn’t shout while coming in to check on the sick and injured.” Dorothea’s frown at Ferdinand turned into a smile as she looked towards Byleth. “Hello professor. How are you doing?”

 

Byleth shrugged. “Injured. I apparently have stitches.” She ignored how that made her students grimace in favor of tilting her head in mild curiosity. “I’m surprised to see you two together.”

 

“Is it really so unusual? Why, I think the two of us make for a truly effective pair together!”

 

“...I just wanted to keep Ferdie from disturbing you when he came to visit,” Dorothea bluntly stated, which seemed to take some of the wind out of Ferdinand’s sails before he rallied.

 

"Yes, as some of your best students, we felt it only proper to come visit you right away! We would have all visited, but Dorothea said it would be improper for everyone to visit at the same time." 

 

"That's because she needs to take it easy, and she can't do that if everyone is crowding around her," Dorothea said with a frown. "Even the students from the other classes wanted to visit, though I'm not surprised. I mean, between you and professor Jeritza you win everytime." 

 

"Yes, Professor Jeritza certainly has a very… hands off approach to teaching. I don't think we've done much else besides sparring." 

 

"Ah, should I start teaching again?" Byleth asked.

 

"No no professor, you stay in bed, we'll make sure to keep up our studies in the meantime,” Dorothea reassured, “Though, if I can make a request, I will ask you to put a bit more focus on faith magic when you get back. I figured it might be handy to have another healer on the team, you know? Especially with how Lin can be." 

 

"Ah, speaking of, I was wondering if I could ask for some horse combat lessons?” Ferdinand requested, “I myself am already quite adept at horse riding, but I'm not used to battling on top of a horse." 

 

Byleth nodded, a little glad to hear her students were exploring new things. "I'll see what I can do." 

 

"Heh, thank you professor,” Dorothea said with a smile, “Don't worry, I'll make sure to patch you up if you ever get hurt again!" 

 

"And though I may be Lady Edelgard’s shield, I promise to rush to your aid if you need it!" Ferdinand assured.

 

“...Thank you.” Byleth said with a small smile of her own as the two left, before Caspar and Bernadetta walked in. Were they waiting outside? 

 

“Hey there Professor! Are you feeling better?” Caspar asked, his concern evident despite how boisterous he still was. 

 

“Doing better,” Byleth replied, before glancing at Bernie who seemed to shrink away. “Are you two okay?” 

 

“Of course we are! And don’t worry, we’ll make sure to get stronger so you won't have to do all the tough fighting on your own next time! Isn’t that right, Bernadetta?”

 

“...I-I’m s-sorry I w-wasn’t able to help, p-professor! Y-You s-said not to d-draw his attention, b-but I still tr-!” 

 

“Bernadetta, you were very brave that night. Maybe we should try getting you a new bow?” Byleth suggested, doing her best to calm Bernie. It was hard to tell if it worked, considering Bernadetta just ducked her head and started mumbling.

 

“Heh, isn’t that great Bernadetta? That knight won’t know what hit him once we get new gear and start training!” Caspar, meanwhile, was fully into the idea. “Oh, speaking of, Professor, do you mind asking those merc friends of yours if I can train with them? With how strong you are, I’m sure I can learn a thing or two from your buddies!”

 

"I’ll make sure to ask them. Take care, okay?” 

 

“Sure thing, Professor!” 

 

“...Th-Thank you, professor.” And as they left, Linhardt and Petra came in, confirming Byleth’s thought that her students really were just waiting outside to come in in pairs of two.

 

“Professor, have you been recovered well?” Petra asked.

 

“Maybe a bit more sleep will do her well,” Lin said, walking over and handing a book to Byleth. “Here, to read while you’re cooped up.” 

 

“Oh, thank you.” Byleth turned it over, feeling some curiosity pique when she saw it was titled “The History of Adrestia”.

 

“Don’t mention it, It’s just a book I had lying around,” Linhardt said as he yawned. "Though I do hope you recover quickly. I can barely take a nap with how loud everyone else is being." 

 

"Linhardt is meaning well by his words, he has been quite restless since that night," Petra said with a smile. 

 

"I just think it would be a shame if the professor died before I could study her crest." Linhardt replied. “It’s not everyday a crest long thought missing suddenly reappears, not to mention her being able to wield a relic weapon sounds quite fascinating.” 

 

“Well, I’m not sure how well you can study me while I’m here, but I’ll do my best to help.” 

 

“Ah, good. Thank you, professor.”

 

“Be resting well, professor!” Petra encouraged, “I am hoping you will be recovering quickly!”

 

“Thank you, Petra,” Byleth replied, before a thought occurred, “Are you having any trouble with Jeritza’s training?”

 

“Oh, um…No, I am not having trouble with his training. He has not been doing much of teaching, but it is easy to have understanding of combat training. Though it is strange it is all we are doing."

 

“Okay. Do you want to come by after class and have some lessons here?"

 

Petra blinked. “Oh, that would be most helpful! Ah, but you are meant to be resting, professor.”

 

Byleth shrugged. “I’m not doing anything else. Besides, I like being useful.”

 

“...Um, may I be asking what that is meaning then? You are having many uses?”

 

“...I guess? I meant that I enjoy being helpful though.”

 

“Ah, I have understanding!”

 

“Well, if Petra is getting some tutoring, then you wouldn’t mind if I came along too,” Linhardt suggested, “You two can do whatever you want to do while I study the professor…or get some sleep. The beds here do look comfy…”

 

“I’m fine with that,” Byleth agreed. It was fine if Lin decided to take naps after class, though she wasn’t completely sure if Manuela would be happy with his presence. She could ask her later though, after saying goodbye to her two most recent visitors.

 

And then Byleth waited. She continued to sit up, looking towards the door to the infirmary. She waited some more. Then it finally opened and she felt a sudden, happy feeling…that turned strangely disappointed when she saw who actually came in.

 

“Hey there, Teach!” Claude greeted, raising a hand with his usual grin, “How’s it going?”

 

“Hi Claude. It’s going well enough.” Byleth craned her head. “Is anyone else with you?”

 

“Heh, sorry to disappoint, but it’s just me for now. Of course, I didn’t mention to anyone that I was visiting, so don’t feel too bad. I’m pretty sure Hilda’s already planning to put a little something together to help you feel better. Lorenz might say he’s doing the same, but I’m sure he’s just looking to show off how magnanimous he can be.”

 

“Oh, okay.”

 

“So who were you expecting to be with me? Leonie? Marianne?”

 

Byleth paused. It would make sense for those two to visit. It wasn’t who she was expecting though. “It’s fine. How are you doing? You weren’t hurt during the fight, right?”

 

“Oh, no, I’m fine. I came in at the end there. I wasn’t even really leading the cavalry, just managed to show up on time to see you go up against that freaky skull knight. Or ‘Death Knight’, as he’s apparently called.”

 

“...Death Knight. That makes sense.” He was probably the deadliest foe Byleth had ever fought before. “What have you heard about him?”

 

“Hey now, I’m just starting to look into the guy, you can’t expect much yet,” Claude complained, though he was still grinning, “I can tell you there are some bad rumors about him though. A monstrous figure that rides people down in the night and leaves them in bloodied chunks. Not the kind of guy you want to go up against unprepared.”

 

Which Byleth had been. She was getting too complacent. She was too used to mercenary work and it had been a long time since anything actually challenged her in that field. She needed to be ready next time…Hm. Maybe she should train her students in multiple weapons?

 

“Coin for your thoughts, Teach?”

 

Byleth paused, then glanced at Claude. “...Just that I need to be better prepared for next time.”

 

“I can understand that. I imagine that fancy new sword of yours might come in handy then.”

 

“Oh, yeah, the Sword of the Creator…” Byleth frowned.

 

“Hm? Why the long face, Teach?”

 

“...It’s nothing.”

 

“You sure? C’mon, it’s just me here, and I swear I won’t go sharing anything juicy you might decide to tell me.”

 

“It’s not really ‘juicy’. It’s…The Sword of the Creator was Nemesis’s sword, right?”

 

Claude nodded, a little slowly. “That is what I’ve heard, yup.”

 

“And I have Nemesis’s crest. The Crest of Flames. What does that mean?”

 

“Well, either that’s the world’s biggest coincidence…or there’s a connection.” Claude regarded the professor, trying to hide the fascination in his eyes. “Do you think you might be related to him?”

 

“...I don’t see how I could be.”

 

“Well he was a king, right? The King of Liberation. He probably had some descendants, right?”

 

Something about that didn’t sound right. Byleth wasn’t sure what it was, but it just didn’t. “I don’t…think so. I don’t know, but I’m not sure if that’s it…”

 

“Hm…your dad has a crest, right?”

 

“Yeah, a Crest of Seiros.”

 

“Interesting…so if it didn’t come from his side, well…” His grin widened as a thought occurred. “What about your mother?”

 

“...I never knew my mother. She died.”

 

That made his grin falter. “Oh. Uh, sorry about that.”

 

“It’s fine, you didn't know.”

 

“Still, you have my condolences. Though, uh…do you know anything about her? I’m not trying to push, I’m just curious.” He was definitely pushing the subject, but when would he get a chance to satisfy his curiosity like this?

 

“...Hm. I know she lived here,” Byleth considered, a frown coming to her face as she thought. If her mother did live here, then there should be some information about her here, right? That would make sense…

 

“She did, huh?” And that was something Claude was absolutely fascinated to hear. 

 

Unfortunately for him though, that was the point that Manuela opened up the infirmary door. “Hm? Claude, what are you doing here?”

 

“Oh, hey Professor Manuela. I just decided to visit Teach, see how she was doing, that kind of stuff,” Claude explained, not showing the slight disappointment he felt at having his investigation interrupted. He wasn’t expecting Manuela to start grinning though.

 

“Oh really? You just came to visit then? It wasn’t so you could ask the professor for her blessing?”

 

Byleth blinked. “My blessing?”

 

“To court your little sister, of course.”

 

Claude felt himself stiffen on reflex at the sudden focus Byleth fixed him with, her eyes locking on with an intense interest.

 

“That’s not really–We’re just friends, professor,” he tried to explain.

 

“Oh I don’t know about that,” Manuela continued, heedless of how she was signing Claude’s death warrant based on the look Byleth was giving him, “Two students from separate houses, hanging out like you two do? And let’s not forget how she gave you that hug for saving her sister.”

 

“I really didn’t do anything, I just showed up–Teach, seriously, that’s not–” Was he seriously losing his composure here?? “...I should go.”

 

Byleth watched as the Golden Deer’s leader hurried from the room, then tilted her head, considering things. “Hm…You were making fun of him, huh?”

 

Manuela grinned. “Just a bit. It’s fun to tease, don’t you think?”

 

“It is.” And Byleth felt a rare grin come to her own face. “Especially when Shez has been needling me about my romantic life for years now.”

 

"Well in that case you best tease her about it as well, from what I've heard your sister has been hanging around quite often with many students, so you'll have plenty of options to take~" 

 

"I'll keep that in mind." Byleth said, already ready to do so. 

 

"Speaking of, what about you professor, has anyone caught your eye~?" 

 

"...Ah, it seems my wounds are acting up, I should probably sleep." Byleth said in a deadpan as she laid down, closing her eyes to pretend she was asleep.

 

Manuela let out an amused huff as she sat down at her desk. "Fine fine, just make sure to tell me if your wounds actually do start hurting," she said as Byleth settled in for her recovery time.

Byleth’s time spent at the infirmary went by faster than expected, even if, aside from some light exercise and such, she wasn't allowed out of the bed. It was still nice having company though, and there wasn't much time outside of nighttime when she was alone. 

 

Ezra came by to play chess with her, Victor and Candace wanted to play poker with her, and also tried to sneak her some booze which they said would help. Sadly for them, Gertrude found out what they were doing so they got in trouble, while the healer in question helped Manuela out with check-ups and such since she was the one who helped take care of Byleth as a mercenary. 

 

Students from other classes would also come by to see how she was doing. Apparently Ingrid wanted to make sure she was fine since Byleth had saved her from that arrow back on the Magdred mission and, as the heir of House Galatea, it was upon her honor to pay her back. Ashe brought her a book to read, while Annette and Mercedes made her some treats, though Manuela stopped her from eating them all right away. Dedue was also nice enough to send some flowers, even if Dimitri was the one to actually deliver them. 

 

The Golden Deer, meanwhile, were also happy to show their concern, as it seemed Hilda and Lorenz did in fact plan a surprise for her, though according to Leonie it was mainly Hilda getting Lorenz, Ignatz, and Raphael to prepare everything. Even so, it was nice seeing them come in with flowers for her, as well as a few get-well gifts. Though Lysithea said she was only there to make sure she was actually well, since, according to her, trying to teach Shez while her sister was injured seemed to be impossible. 

 

Her students also made sure to visit every day, whether to just check up on her or to tell her how everything was going. Bernadetta thankfully seemed to be doing okay even if she was terrified of Jeritza, while Lindhart complained about not being able to nap as often now during lessons. Caspar, meanwhile, was more than happy to tell her all about the spars he had against Victor, which he seemed to be losing in, not that it stopped the young boy from being enthusiastic. 

 

Though, as nice as it was to see everyone visit… 

 

"-And then he has the nerve to say I'm squawking at him! Honestly, the nerve of that Felix." Coming out of her thoughts, Byleth turned to look at Dorothea, who had been talking about her day. "Can you believe he actually said that?" 

 

"...Ah, yeah, he definitely did." Byleth responded, getting Dorothea to pout. 

 

"Lost in your thoughts, professor?" 

 

"Sorry, just…have Edelgard and Hubert been busy? I'm not surprised Emily hasn't visited, but I thought they'd at least drop by." 

 

"Wait, they haven't visited?" It seemed Dorothea was also surprised at that info. "I know Edie said she wouldn't have the time to visit when you first woke up, but she said she'd visit you when she could…" 

 

"Is she okay?" 

 

"She better hope she isn't, because I'm going to go drag her here right now." 

 

"Ah, I'm sure she has her reasons." Even if Byleth was disappointed she didn't come visit…

 

"And what reasons could there be?" Dorothea asked, frowning before she thought for a moment. "Oh… I wonder if it's because you got injured. With how Edie is, I wouldn't be surprised if she blames herself for not being able to help you in the fight…" 

 

"I was the one who told her not to get involved, she shouldn't be blaming herself." 

 

"I know, but you know how Edie can be, professor. I mean, it makes the most sense, she was genuinely the most worried, and was even the one to carry you up here once Manuela said to." 

 

"She did?" 

 

"Yup! Our poor Edie has trouble showing it, but she does care, albeit in her own way." 

 

"I see… thank you, Dorothea." 

 

"No need to thank me, I still need to drag her here first. After all, she's not going to make any progress if she doesn't show up, you know?" 

 

"...right." Progress on what? "Still, thank you Dorothea. I'm glad you're in my class." 

 

"Think nothing of it. But if you really want to thank me, you can try introducing me to someone nice." 

 

"Still haven't found someone?" 

 

"Not yet at least, but I still have plenty of time to try. I'm sure I can find someone decent by the end of the year." 

 

"You deserve someone better than decent. For what it's worth, I think anyone would be lucky to be with you, and if they can't see that, then it's on them." 

 

"How kind of you professor, but you really should be saving words like that for someone else. Unless you want to be the one to take care of me in my old age, hm~?" Dorothea asked, obviously teasing. 

 

"Do you want me to?" Byleth asked, not catching onto that, which caught Dorothea off guard. 

 

"I wasn't–I was just teasing, Professor." 

 

"Oh, okay. I wouldn’t mind though. I’m not that rich, but I could work hard to keep you happy.”

 

Dorothea blinked at that, her face turning a little red at how sincere her professor sounded. “A-Ah, well, I, um–”

 

“Um, professor?” 

 

Byleth paused, then glanced over at a familiar voice. “Are you looking for me, Marianne? Manuela’s out for the moment.”

 

“Ah, y-yes, I was looking for you–O-Oh, I’m sorry, I didn’t realize someone was already here,” Marianne apologized as she noticed Dorothea, “S-Sorry, I-I’ll come back later–”

 

“Oh, no need to! I, ah, was planning to go get Edie anyways! So you two can have your talk just fine, don’t mind me!”

 

“Bye Dorothea,” Byleth said, waving to her student as she hurried away, giving Byleth and Marianne some privacy. That was nice of her. “What did you need, Marianne?”

 

“...U-Um, w-well…I don’t really want to bother you while you’re resting…” she mumbled, fidgeting with her fingers.

 

“You’re not bothering me. I’m not doing anything right now and I’m always happy to talk to you.”

 

She smiled faintly at that, before shaking her head. “S-Sorry, that…I shouldn’t be so happy to hear that…u-um, b-but…P-Professor, i-if it’s not too much trouble…c-could I join your class?”

 

“Oh, sure,” Byleth agreed.

 

Marianne seemed surprised by how little hesitation the professor answered her with. “O-Oh, w-well…th-thank you. I look forward to attending your classes then.”

 

“I look forward to having you. Though it might be a little while before I’m cleared to teach classes again."

 

“Th-That is fine. Um…I-I s-suppose I should t-try to get to know my new classmates…” she mumbled, a little smile coming to her tired face.

 

“You should.” Byleth tilted her head, considering which students would be best for Marianne to talk to. “...Hm. It might be good to pair you and Bernadetta up for a bit…”

 

“...P-Professor?”

 

“Just thinking. You and her are similar, so I'd think you’d get along. And with how soft spoken you both are, I don’t think you’d scare one another.” Byleth explained. “I want to make sure you’re comfortable in my class, so having a friend in it would be nice, right?” 

 

“...T-that it w-would Professor. T-thank you.” 

 

“No need to thank me… hm, maybe you can try talking with Dorothea first? She’s really nice, and I know she wants to learn some faith magic.”

 

“O-oh, I-I would never p-presume to know enough to t-teach anyone.” 

 

“Just think of it as helping each other out.” Byleth said as she looked up at Marianne. “Dorothea will definitely appreciate you helping her, and she’ll help you out when you need it. That’s what friends do.” 

 

“...D-do you really think they’ll want me as a friend?” 

 

“Of course, you’re a very kind girl Marianne. We’ll be happy to be your friends.” 

 

“Y-You don’t think of me as a nuisance?”

 

“I would never,” Byleth stated, being completely sincere even as Marianne wouldn’t meet her gaze. 

 

“...” For a brief moment, Byleth thought she saw tears well up in her eyes before she rubbed them away. “A-Argo and Dorte both miss you, I-I’m sure they’d be happy to see you when you can.”

 

“I’ll visit them as soon as I can, maybe we can introduce them to your new friends after you properly join my class.” 

 

“...I-I’m looking forward to it, Professor.”

 

The two of them chatted a little more after that, about how Marianne’s classes were going and what she was doing in her free time, before Byleth’s newest student finally took her leave. And then it was just back to laying down and resting for the professor. She considered reading one of her books, but…eh. She could take it easy for now.

 

Of course, right as she thought that, the door opened again. Though no one entered.

 

“Go on, Edie! The professor was asking to see you!”

 

“Dorothea, you don’t need to push me! I was going to visit on my own time, you don’t need to–”

 

Byleth sat up, maybe a little too fast from the sudden flash of pain that went through her. Still, she was up in time for Edelgard to see her as she came in. Dorothea was behind her, as was Hubert, which was also nice to see, though Byleth was more focused on her house leader, who did indeed look guilty for a moment before she schooled her features.

 

“...Hello professor. How are you doing?”

 

“Hello Edelgard.” Byleth smiled. “I’m doing better.”

Chapter End Notes

Red: A bit of downtime for the professor and some visits from her students! Including one more student than before.

Indi: You know, I always see people talk about how Lysithea, Ingrid and Sylvain are honorary Eagles, which I completely get, but also I very rarely see Marianne get brought up as one in fanfics, even though in cf she genuinely believes and supports Edelgard’s cause.

Red: Recruiting students from other houses in CF is definitely the most interesting of the bunch since the characters have to justify why they're joining Team Edelgard and some have legitimately good reasons for it. Fodlan's broken, so it's no wonder plenty of them can find common cause with the person who says she can fix it.

Indi: yup yup, some are there to keep their loved ones save, others are there cause of their distrust of the church, and some are there cause they genuinely believe in Edelgard. It's really interesting seeing the changes that happen with CF

Red: And speaking of Edelgard, she certainly took a bit to visit her poor professor. Someone might be feeling guiltier than she expected...

Indi: She might have experienced freedom with Thales’s death, but also her heart is not as hardened as she expected it to be.

Red: Some people have noticed that so far, but yeah, Edelgard's gone through a few changes due to Thales's early removal. And I suppose we'll see how much further those changes will go.

Indi: Until then, hope you all enjoy!

Extra - The Cursed Student

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

"And that's it for today's lessons! Do try to finish the worksheet by tomorrow morning," Manuela said as class came to an end, "And Raphael, if you need assistance, please make sure to ask someone." 

 

"Sure thing, professor!" Raphael responded as he got up. 

 

At the back of the room, Marianne tried to silently collect her supplies so she could step out right away. 

 

"Hey, Mari!" Flinching a bit at the loud noise, she looked over to see Hilda approaching. "Did you actually transfer over to the Black Eagles?" 

 

"A-Ah, yes. S-Sorry." 

 

"No need to apologize," Hilda said, even as she pouted, "But if you're going to, why don't we get some tea later?" 

 

"U-Um, how about tomorrow?" Marianne suggested, which seemed to surprise Hilda. 

 

"Really? Looking forward to it!" The bubbly pink-haired girl said, smiling as she walked away with a hop to her step. Marianne meanwhile let out a sigh of relief. That wasn't that bad, she didn't say no at least. 

 

"Hm~? Going to have tea with Hilda huh?" Once again, Marianne flinched, backing away from Dorothea as the songstress leaned in close. "Ah, sorry, didn't mean to scare you." 

 

"N-No, i-it’s my fault, I apologize." 

 

"You really don't need to, I just wanted to check up on you. Professor Byleth said you'll be transferring over?" 

 

"...Y-Yes. D-Did you need something?" 

 

"Not really, just wanted to let you know if you needed anything, feel free to ask~," Dorothea said with a wink, "The professor wanted me to help make sure you fit in well with everyone else. Whenever you're ready, that is." 

 

"...M-Maybe some other time." 

 

"Of course, whenever you want~!" Dorothea replied with a wide smile, before heading off. 

 

Okay, that went okay. Maybe being in this new class would be okay? …Should she introduce herself to her new house leader? 

 

Taking a deep breath, Marianne made her way to Edelgard, who was currently talking with Hubert. 

 

"U-Uh." 

 

"Hm? Yes?" And both their sharp gazes turned to her, making her immediately regret her decision. 

 

"Did you require something?" Hubert asked with his usual tone. 

 

"N-No, sorry for bothering you," Marianne responded, her gaze downward as she walked away. That was stupid of her. Why did she think she could just go up to someone and talk to them like that?

 

Maybe she should have just stayed in the Golden Deer. Professor Byleth was so nice to her but… if she learned the truth of her crest… 

 

"Hey, you!" Flinching once again, this time from a much harsher sounding voice, Marianne turned to see a scholar of some sorts approaching her. "You're Marianne Edmund, are you not?" 

 

"Y-Yes, I am Marianne von Edmund. Who are you?" 

 

"I'm a crest scholar, and I've been searching for you." 

 

"Y-You have?" Marianne asked, taking a step back. 

 

"Yes, I knew about your father," The scholar said, making Marianne stiffen, "So I wanted to meet you. You have the same crest-"

 

"I don't have a crest!" Marianne shouted, panic filling her as she realized her secret might get exposed. 

 

"Nonsense, your adoptive father paid a hefty sum so you wouldn't be examined, correct? He obviously wants to keep your crest a secret, so you must-"

 

"N-No, you're wrong. I don't have a crest at all," she denied again, feeling her breath quicken. 

 

"Stop lying, I know you have the crest of-" 

 

"Excuse me, why are you bothering my classmate?" A sharp voice cut in, getting both of their attention as they turned to see Edelgard approaching.

 

"Ah, your highness. It is nothing you need to worry about. I'm simply trying to conduct some crest research." 

 

"Is that so? From where I'm standing you're harassing someone," Edelgard stated as she moved between the two. 

 

"Harassing? I would never do such a thing! It is my duty as a crest scholar to study crests, and surely you must understand the importance of studying the Crest of Maurice!" Marianne felt terror grip her heart as he announced her crest. 

 

"...You're from the empire are you not?" Edelgard asked. 

 

"Why yes, have you heard of me?" the scholar asked, sounding pleased. "Or do you simply wish to make sure any findings get attributed to the Em-" 

 

"I'll give you one chance then. Leave this girl alone or you shall be exiled from the Empire." 

 

"E-Excuse me!?"

 

"I shall not repeat myself. As the future Emperor it is within my power to do so." 

 

"Why you-" Scowling the crest scholar left, not wanting to see if she was bluffing. As he left, Marianne felt her breath quicken as Edelgard turned to her. 

 

"I-I don't-" 

 

"What did you wish to speak about earlier?" Edelgard asked, surprising Marianne. 

 

"...D-Did you not hear what he said?" 

 

"About your crest? What about it?" 

 

"D-Do you not know about it?" 

 

"I have heard of the crest. Is that what you wanted to speak to me about? If that's the case, then I have no interest in it." 

 

"N-No! If you know what crest I have, then you have to know about the legends surrounding it! About the bad luck it brings!"

 

"Your point being?" Edelgard asked, before pausing "...That may have come off harsher than I meant. It is true that I do not understand the circumstances you've been through, but I do understand that the professor wants you to join our class, so I shall take her word on it. I care not about your crest, only what you can do." 

 

"Th-That…" Marianne looked away, unable to meet the piercing stare of Edelgard. 

 

"...You've suffered much because of your crest, haven't you?" Edelgard asked, making Marianne stiffen. "Let me say this, even if your crest brings bad luck, there is no need to worry on my behalf. Instead, it is my duty as your house leader to help you. Were I to falter simply because of 'bad luck', I would be unfit to be the emperor." 

 

"...Y-You're just saying that." 

 

"Perhaps I am," Edelgard admitted, before she gave her a small smile, "You'll just have to see if I am. Now then, I had wanted to introduce you to the rest of your new classmates, but perhaps that should wait until tomorrow. Until then, I wish you a good day." Edelgard bowed to her–to her! Of all people!–before walking away. 

 

"..." Staying silent, Marianne felt a strange emotion in her, one she wasn't used to… Shaking her head, she walked off. 

 

Mindlessly walking to her room, Marianne kept her gaze downward, something she was accustomed to doing, but this time, something caught her eye. 

 

"Oh?" Reaching down, she grabbed a small case that seemed to have a small animal embroidered on it. "How cute…" 

 

"A-Ah! Th-That's mine!" shouted a panicked voice, almost making Marianne drop the case before she turned to see Bernadetta standing nearby. "W-Why do you have that?" 

 

"I-I'm sorry, I just noticed it! I-I just w-wanted to see w-what the a-animal on it was," Marianne replied, not wanting to anger the Black Eagle. 

 

"...H-Huh? You don’t know about hedgehogs?" 

 

"...I-Is that what it's called? I-I don't think they're c-common in the Alliance," Marianne explained, still holding the case. 

 

"R-Really? B-But they're so adorable! Everyone should know about them, I mean, how many other animals grow spines on their backs to keep themselves safe!" Bernadetta exclaimed, suddenly very excited. 

 

"Oh, is that why they have spikes?" 

 

"Yeah, they roll up into balls so the spines keep them completely covered," Bernadetta explained with a smile, "Makes me wish I could do something like that…" 

 

“That does sound nice,” Marianne mumbled in agreement, prompting a slightly bigger smile from Bernadetta.

 

"It does! Are there, um, any animals like this in the alliance?" 

 

"Oh…not off the top of my head. Though I do have an encyclopedia if you want to borrow it." 

 

"I-I can??" Bernadetta asked, seeming excited. "W-Well, I can find a book about Empire animals, if you want." 

 

"Th-There's no need to put yourself out for me." 

 

"I-It's not a big deal! I-I mean, I don't really have anyone t-to talk about with these kinds of things…" 

 

"...Well, if you would have me, okay." 

 

"Th-Thank you! A-Ah, r-right, a-ah, I should introduce myself, right? M-My name is Bernadetta." 

 

"...Ah, yes, I know who you are, Bernadetta." 

 

"Y-You do? S-Sorry, I-I tend to s-stay in my room, so I d-don’t really know anyone outside of my class." 

 

"Oh…well, in that case. My name is Marianne von Edmund, and I'll be joining the Black Eagles."

Chapter End Notes

Indi: It still kills me that Marianne doesn't have a support with Edelgard.

Red: Yeah you'd think she'd have one, though Edelgard doesn't have many outside-house supports to begin with, which is a shame. A few could definitely be fun.

Indi: Also, while it's not shown here, Edelgard told Hubert to stay behind cause clearly Marianne ran away because of him. Edelgard, meanwhile, has been taking lessons from Dorothea on how to be 'personable' so clearly she can handle things.

Red: Edelgard is so much better at this social activity stuff. A true genius at interpersonal connections, really.

Blue Lion Blues

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

It felt kind of mean to even think it, but Shez was really starting to dislike being in the Blue Lions’ classroom. After a week of being scared her sister would never wake up, the relief she felt at seeing Byleth open her eyes again was pretty soundly smothered by the heavy atmosphere that settled over everything once their next mission was announced.

 

Apparently a group of bandits managed to steal a relic from a noble house. That wasn’t too bad, in Shez’s opinion; really, it sounded like the start off to a fun story. The problem was that the relic was a crest weapon, specifically one called the Lance of Ruin, and it had been stolen from House Gautier, otherwise known as Sylvain’s family. And not only that, but the leader of said bandits happened to be Sylvain’s older brother Miklan. The one he’d told her about.

 

Speaking of, Shez and Sylvain…well, they didn’t really talk now. Things had already been rocky after he thought it was a good idea to spill all his problems on Shez and then threaten her sister in the same breath, but then Byleth actually got hurt and…Well, call it bad timing, but Shez didn’t really want to interact with him after that point. Not when she couldn’t help but see him as a genuine threat to her sister’s well-being.

 

To be fair to Sylvain, he at least recognized there was a problem and kept his distance too, but that just led to everyone else noticing their problem and apparently that meant they all needed to have an opinion on the subject. The worst was Ingrid trying to apologize on Sylvain’s behalf because she thought he’d tried flirting with Shez again. It was an awkward conversation, to say the least, especially because Shez wasn’t comfortable actually sharing what Sylvain said with how private most of it was.

 

So yeah, there was one friendship potentially ruined, and right as the mission of the month was basically focused on the guy in question.

 

“Shez? Are you feeling okay?” Mercedes asked, sounding concerned, “You seem to be staring into your tea." 

 

"Eh, just thinking. The mission this month seems pretty big, huh?" 

 

"Yes, it does…I knew Sylvain didn't have the best relationship with his family, but I never thought his father would request his class to handle his brother…" Mercedes muttered. 

 

"Hm…hey, do either of you two know about the knight we'll be working with?" Shez asked, wanting to change the subject away from Sylvain. 

 

"Yeah, I think I do!” Annette answered, “I saw him earlier, but he ran away after he saw me." 

 

"Wait, really? Why would he run away?" 

 

"That knight…he's my father,” she admitted, “He's using a different name, but I'm certain he is!" 

 

Shez blinked. "Huh. Not trying to be rude, but that doesn't explain why he ran away." 

 

"No, it’s okay, I can understand why you would ask. After the tragedy of Duscur, my father blamed himself for not being able to save the king. He…left my mother and I behind. I didn’t know where he went to, but I knew the Church took in knights like him, and now I found him!”

 

“Oh, Annie, that’s wonderful!” Mercedes said, smiling happily at the news.

 

Shez, meanwhile, had a confused frown. “That sounds great, but didn’t you just say he ran away from you?”
