"Ah, yeah… I don't know why, but he's been avoiding me. Even before now, he hasn't contacted me or mother, but he can't keep running forever! I'll make sure to bring him back home so he can apologize to mom!" 

 

"...Hm. Do you want me to beat him up?" 

 

"Huh?" It seemed that surprised both Mercedes and Annette with how shocked they looked.

 

"Sh-Shez, I'm not certain how that could help." 

 

"Well, her dad left without a word, yeah? I might not know everything going on, but it sounds shitty that he's avoiding you. So if I beat him up he won't be able to run away so you can talk to him, or just drag him home." 

 

"...Th-Thank you for the offer Shez, but I don't know if that'll help. Father might be old, but he's still a knight, so I would hate for you to get hurt." 

 

"Hmph, I'm sure I can take him on, but fine. Still, if you need any help, feel free to ask. Parents should look out for their kids, and he has a lot to make up for if he's actually been gone for a bunch of years." 

 

"Well… I appreciate the offer, so thanks Shez. Who knows, if he proves to be a hassle I might just take you up on it," Annette jokingly said. 

 

"Just say the word." 

 

"Shez, a word please." Glancing up, Shez found Dimitri standing nearby with Dedue behind him. 

 

"Oh, uh, sure?" A bit confused, Shez set down her cup, before getting up. "Thanks for the tea, Mercedes, Annette." 

 

"See you later, Shez!" 

 

"Always a pleasure." Waving goodbye to the two, Shez followed behind Dimitri as he led her somewhere to speak. 

 

"How are you doing Shez?" Dimitri asked once they found a quiet location. 

 

"Uh… okay I guess? I'm glad Byleth is awake at least." 

 

"Yes, it's good to hear she's recovering, though I'm truly sorry we weren't able to arrive faster." 

 

"No need to apologize,” she replied, deciding not to mention that this wasn’t the first time Dimitri had apologized for it, “We just gotta make sure to get there on time next time." 

 

"Yes, well, that does bring me up to what I wanted to talk about. As I've heard, that knight is quite the dangerous foe, who has been causing trouble for many years. It seems what happened at the Mausoleum was just the latest incident of his. Your sister might have been his latest victim, but I swear it'll be his last. On my honor as the prince of the Holy Kingdom of Faerghus, I swear I will help you get vengeance." 

 

"....U-Uh, Dimitri, has anyone ever told you how intense you can be sometimes?" 

 

He blinked. "Excuse me?" 

 

"Like, thanks for the offer, but I'm not going to go out and seek revenge, I just wanna make sure my sister is okay. Which, side note, don't call her a victim okay?" 

 

"...I understand my words may not have been the best, but do you truly not want to seek revenge?" 

 

"I mean, sure, if I get the chance to take a shot at the guy, I'll go for it. But I'm not going to go off on a revenge quest, I wanna make sure By is fully healed up first. If she wants revenge, then sure, we'll ask for your help, but until then I'm not going for it." 

 

"..." Shez wasn't completely sure, but it kinda seemed like Dimitri was confused by what she was saying? "...I see, you're prioritizing care. I can understand that. Still, we must not be hesitant, lest more victims arise." 

 

"...I said not to call By a victim. She's not a damsel in distress, Dimitri." 

 

"My apologies, I meant no offense." 

 

"Yeah, sure," Shez said, frowning, "If that's all, then I'm going." Without waiting for another word, Shez turned around and left, vaguely hearing Dimitri call out to her for a moment. She wasn’t sticking around to hear anything else though.

 

Shez sighed, scratching at the back of her head. She didn’t like how complicated things were getting…and she probably should’ve said something to Dedue there. Said hi, at least.

 

“Ugh, today sucks…” she grumbled, before pausing as she heard…muttering?

 

“C-Come on Bernie, the professor bought you a new bow a-and everything, y-you need to do this…” Bernadetta muttered to herself, her hands tight on her brand new longbow. She stared at the entrance to the training hall, trying to muster up the courage to go in there… “A-Ah, n-no, I-I shouldn’t, th-there’s going to be people in there and they’re going to see me and they’ll know I’m terrible…hhh, b-but the professor…b-but, well, technically she didn’t get up and buy it, right? She had one of those scary mercenaries help…a-and they’ll probably kill me if I don’t practice with it, oh no–”

 

“Hey Bernie,” Shez greeted, before blinking as the shorter girl outright screamed in fright before brandishing the bow at her. Though, not like someone would brandish a bow; she was holding it like it was a lance, for some reason.

 

“S-STAY BACK–O-Oh, w-wait, it’s–AH! STAY BACK!”

 

“Okay, I guess you’re still terrified of me.” Shez frowned. “Hey, Bernie, why are you so terrified of me?”

 

“A-AS IF YOU DON’T KNOW!”

 

“...But I don’t know.”

 

“D-DON’T LIE!”

 

“I’m not lying. I genuinely don’t know why you’re so afraid of me. Or…mad at me? Is this what it looks like when you’re mad at someone?”

 

“...” Bernadetta gave her a very suspicious look, but stopped pointing her bow at Shez in favor of holding it to her chest. “...y-you really don’t remember? B-But you glared right at me!”

 

“What? When did I glare at you?”

 

“W-When you were leaving my house!”

 

…When did Shez go to her house? “Uh…could you give me some more context? Because I still don’t know what you’re talking about.”

 

“Y-You should! I-It was, um…f-five years ago, I think, a-and your father was working for my father and my father didn’t pay your father and you glared at me when you left!”

 

“...” Shez frowned, then closed her eyes, trying to think. Five years ago, and Bernie’s dad didn’t pay her dad… “OH! You’re Count Varley’s daughter?!”

 

“AH DON’T BE MAD!” Bernadetta yelped, before Shez’s words actually registered. “Wait–Huh? H-Hold on, you…didn’t know that I’m Gregoire von Varley’s daughter?”

 

“No? How would I?”

 

“...M-My name is Bernadetta von Varley.”

 

“Yeah but you could’ve been a niece or something. Wow, I didn’t guess that at all. I thought for sure his daughter would be some haughty, callous jerk like he is. But you’re so…” She gestured to Bernadetta.

 

“...h-hm. I-I know I’m pathetic, you don’t need to say it…”

 

“What? No, I mean you’re tiny and skittish, not all ‘ohoho’ and vain. How the heck did you come from a huge jackass like that?”

 

“...W-Well, my father tied me to a chair so I would be more quiet and ladylike…”

 

“...Oh. Oh I see.” Shez nodded. “I’m going to kill your dad.”

 

“W-What?! W-Wait, y-you can’t! He’s…I mean…w-well he’s…okay, he doesn’t have any redeeming qualities, but you still shouldn’t!”

 

“I’m not actually hearing a reason why I shouldn’t.”

 

“H-He’s the Minister of Religious Affairs! Th-The whole Empire would go after you!”

 

“Okay, I’ll just ask Edelgard if I can first.”

 

“N-No! Th-That’s…w-wait, would that work…?”

 

“Probably. Though…okay, give me a while to figure it out first. I should probably ask Byleth for a plan first…”

 

“P-Please d-don’t tell Professor Byleth about this…”

 

“Mm…okay, fine, we’ll save that for later. For now, uh…what were we talking about…oh, right, yeah, I’m not mad at you. I kind of forgot about that until you brought it up.”

 

“...B-But now you remember a-and you want to kill me!?”

 

“No? Look, Bernie, I promise I’m not going to kill you. Byleth likes you, you’re my classmate, and you seem like a nice girl, so no, I’m not going to kill you. I have zero reason to! Heck, I have more reason to keep you alive because Byleth likes you!”

 

“...sh-she does?”

 

“Yeah, she does. And I’m sure I’ll like you too once I get to know you. So, hey, what are you up to right now?”

 

“O-Oh, um…” Bernadetta glanced at the bow in her hands. “I-I was going to h-head to the training hall t-to try out my new bow…u-um, th-that scary mercenary bought i-it for me b-because of the professor…”

 

“Oh, the big, bald, bearded guy?”

 

“N-No.”

 

“Really? Then, uh, the kind of wiry guy with the goatee?”

 

“N-No?”

 

“Uh…the stern lady in healer clothes?”

 

Bernie shook her head. “Mm mm.”

 

“...the blonde one?”

 

“Y-Yes! Her! Sh-She’s terrifying…”

 

Shez considered what she knew of Candace…then nodded. “Yeah, that makes sense. Well, hey, why don’t I come with you? We might as well hang out some more, right?”

 

“H-Huh? U-Uh, I-I don’t know–Eep!” Bernadetta squeaked as Shez took her by the shoulder and steered her towards the training hall. “A-Ah, w-w-wait, I-I changed my mind! I-I’m fine! I’m completely fine! I-I can practice better at night anyway!”

 

“C’mon Bernie, it’s fine. We’ll just get you set up and–Oh hey, I didn’t know Ashe and Felix were in here.”

 

Bernadetta didn’t either and she made a mildly terrified noise at the sight of the two boys. Not that they were doing anything especially terrifying, considering Ashe was just practicing striking at a dummy with a lance, and not really doing that well at it, while Felix was practicing sword forms. Though the black-haired boy immediately paused once he noticed Shez.

 

“Hey, Shez, get over here. I need a sparring partner.”

 

“Oh, sure, just give me a bit.” Guiding Bernadetta over to where targets were set up, Shez made sure she was facing them. “There we go, just call me over if you need any help.” 

 

“O-Okay…” With that, Shez walked over to where Felix was, before catching a sword he tossed. 

 

“Not wasting any time huh?” 

 

“We’re going up against someone with a crest weapon, and even if he was disowned, Sylvain’s brother was trained from birth to be a military leader. Of course, that just means he’s that much more worthy of an opponent.” Felix explained. “Speaking of, your sister has a relic weapon now, right?” 

 

“...Yeah?” 

 

“Good, tell her to heal quickly, I want to be able to face off against someone who can wield a legendary weapon like that,” Felix said, as he got into his stance.

 

“...Felix, I know you’re not one for tact, but my sister almost died, maybe wait till she’s recovered to say something like that.”

 

“She lived, didn’t she?”

 

“...” Shez stared at Felix, dead silent. “...”

 

“...What? Say something,” he demanded. He tried not to show it, but something in her stare was…discomforting. 

 

“...” Shez just held her sword out and dropped it on the floor, before turning on her heel and leaving with her hands balled into fists.

 

“Wh–Hey! We were going to spar!” he complained, but Shez didn’t reply or look back. “...the hell is her problem?”

 

“What is wrong with him!?” Shez growled under her breath, though the deep scowl on her face faded quickly when she nearly ran into someone. “Ah, sorry–Oh, hey Em.”

 

“Hey yourself,” Emily greeted, raising an eyebrow, “You look fit to kill someone.”

 

“Heh. No, I’m not that pissed off…though I did agree to kill Bernie’s dad for her.”

 

“...Oh, the mousy girl? Huh, I didn’t think she had it in her,” Emily muttered, sounding impressed. Which Shez wasn’t about to touch.

 

“So what are you up to? Going to train?”

 

Emily gave Shez a look like she was being an idiot and crossed her arms over her chest. “Why else would I be going to the training grounds?”

 

“I dunno, maybe a secret rendezvous?”

 

She scoffed. “The training grounds are way too open for any meetings. You should know that–Look, never mind. Unless you’re planning to go train with me, get going with whatever you were doing.”

 

“Alright, alright. And, ah, no, I don’t think I’m going in there right now. Though I’m kind of curious what brought this on. I haven’t seen you around the training grounds before.”

 

“...” Emily sighed, looking irritated. “It’s because of that knight. Him and your sister.”

 

“Oh. Yeah, okay, I can understand that.”

 

“Good, then I don’t need to explain myself. Just know this, Shez. I’ll use this place to get as strong as I need to. Stronger than you, stronger than your sister, and strong enough to beat anyone I ever have to face. You got that?”

 

“Heh. Yeah I do! But don’t think it’ll be easy! I’m getting better every day too! So you’ve got a long way to go if you want to get to my level!” she encouraged with a big grin, earning an amused huff from her friend.

 

“Sure, talk big, but it won’t be long before I’m the one on top~. Now, seriously, if you’re not sticking around, get out of here. I have shit to do.”

 

“Heh, sure Em. See you around!” Shez said, waving to her friend as she headed off.

 

Then, after walking for a few seconds, Shez paused again as a thought occurred. “Oh, shit, I just left Bernie there without a word…ah, she’ll probably be fine. Em’s one of her classmates, she’ll be nice.”

“...Oh damn it all,” Shez muttered, her bad mood returning rapidly when she noticed who happened to be standing outside of the infirmary.

 

“–don’t understand why you won’t even try to–Oh, Shez!” Ingrid perked up upon noticing her classmate, which was kind of nice to see. What wasn’t nice to see was who she was with, and Sylvain seemed to agree based on how he winced once he noticed Shez.

 

“Oh, this is going to suck…”

 

Shez could agreed to that, though she really didn’t want to considering who was saying it. “Hi Ingrid. Hey Sylvain. Are you two here to see my sister?”

 

“I was planning on it, but Sylvain doesn’t want to, for some reason,” Ingrid complained, frowning at her friend.

 

“It’s just…Well, Shez knows why it’s a bad idea.”

 

Shez felt her frown return as Sylvain passed the buck to her, something he noticed and grimaced to see. “Yeah, I can think of a reason.”

 

“...” Ingrid glanced between Sylvain and Shez with a concerned frown of her own. “Okay, what is going on between you two? Shez, I know Sylvain can be bad, but even he wouldn’t take advantage of the professor while she’s injured. He’s not that terrible.”

 

“I know he's not that bad. It’s a different concern.”

 

“And what is that concern? Come on, you two have been avoiding each other for weeks now. I’m starting to think something really bad happened here and it’s worrying me.”

 

“...” Shez glanced at Sylvain. “...Do you want me to say anything?”

 

“...” He sighed. “Sure, you might as well. It’s not like I deserve any better.”

 

“Sylvain?” Ingrid looked genuinely worried by this point and the sight made Shez’s stomach turn. “What happened?”

 

“Sylvain talked to me,” Shez answered, “He wasn’t flirting, he just wanted to check in with me after I had an argument with By. It was a nice gesture. Kinda thoughtful, honestly.” He looked surprised to hear that, but Shez ignored his reaction so she could keep going. “He talked about how much he hates his crest and how it ruined his life, and then he mentioned how he’s jealous of my sister because she didn’t have to deal with the problems of being a noble. He mentioned her owing a debt and making her pay for that crest. I took it as him threatening my sister, and I told him if he ever threatened her again, I would kill him.

 

Shez shrugged, trying to ignore the stunned look on Ingrid’s face. “I guess he’s thinking I would take it badly if he visited my injured sister after saying that.”

 

“Would you?” Sylvain asked.

 

Shez stared at him. “...Yeah. I would.”

 

“...I…Shez, I…Sylvain wouldn’t do that,” Ingrid tried to say, though she looked like she was still trying to get her thoughts in order, “I know he’s a lot to deal with, but he wouldn’t hurt anyone.”

 

“I know you believe that, but you grew up with him, Ingrid,” Shez replied, “You’re close, so sure, I can believe that you’re sure he wouldn’t hurt my sister, but I’ve only known him for a few months, and all I know is that he says he doesn’t like seeing girls cry, but makes them cry anyway. So, sure, I can believe he’d swear up and down that he’d never hurt a hair on my sister’s head. But I’m sure as hell not leaving him alone in the same room as her.”

 

“...That’s fair,” Sylvain said.

 

“What? Sylvain?” Ingrid looked at him. She still looked lost, like she’d just had part of her world turned upside down.

 

“She’s right, Ingrid. I can swear all I want that I didn’t mean it, but she has no reason to trust me and plenty of reason to think I’m lying.” He glanced at the infirmary door, then let out a sigh. “...I’m sorry. No matter what I feel, I shouldn’t have said that. And I know I shouldn’t take my problems out on other people. I just…I’m just kind of pathetic like that.”

 

“Sylvain…”

 

“...” Shez let out a sigh of her own. “...I don’t think I’m gonna stick around after this month.”

 

Both of her classmates paused at that, before staring at her in confusion.

 

“At the academy?” Sylvain asked.

 

“No, I’m still sticking around here until the year is up. It’s just…I don’t think I’m doing good in this class. I’m just not enjoying it, you know? So…I don’t know for sure if this is it, or what I might decide later, but I thought I should let you two know since you’re here and all.”

 

“...W-Wait, Shez, you don’t have to leave!” Ingrid insisted, “Please, I know things might be rough right now, but–”

 

“Alright.”

 

She paused, then looked up at Sylvain with wide eyes. “Sylvain!”

 

“Hey, if it’s what she wants, it’s what she wants. I’m just sorry for my part in it driving you off, Shez. I swear, I didn’t want this.”

 

Shez huffed, grinning a little. “Yeah, I know, you’d rather keep all the pretty girls by your side.”

 

“...” He looked surprised at her teasing, before he tried to grin back. “Yeah, you know me…I don’t like making girls cry, but it seems to be all I’m good at.”

 

“I’m not crying, jerk. I’m mad. There’s a difference.”

 

“Oh believe me, I know that.” He sighed again, deeper and longer than before. “...I know it doesn’t mean much, but I swear to you, I will never do anything to hurt your sister. I might not have much honor, but on what little I do have left, I promise you that.”

 

“...well, they do say a knight of Faerghus will always keep their oath.” Shez shrugged. “...Do you want to come in? Hang out with me and Byleth for a bit?”

 

“...Heh. Ah, maybe some other time? Before we head out for the mission, at least.”

 

“Sure. I’m sure she’d like to say hi.” She glanced at Ingrid. “The offer’s open to you too, if you want.”

 

“...Huh? Oh, uh…Actually, I think I’m going to decline for now too. I think…” Ingrid looked up at Sylvain again. “...I think Sylvain and I should talk for a bit.”

 

A pained look crossed Sylvain’s face for a moment, before he nodded to her request.

 

“Okay. See you two around, alright? I wouldn’t mind talking some more, if you’re up for it.”

 

“Ah, sure. Thank you, Shez.” Ingrid smiled, though it was a troubled one.

 

“...Yeah. I’ll see you around, Shez.” Sylvain looked conflicted, then just nodded to her. “Thanks for giving me another chance.”

 

“Yeah yeah. Just don’t ruin it or I’ll tear your balls off.”

 

“...Eesh. You think we could just stick to the death threats next time?”

 

“Eh, if you insist.”

 

Shez waved off her classmates…her two friends, then turned to the infirmary door. “...I really hope this thing’s thick enough that nobody heard anything…” She shook her head, then slapped her cheeks. “Alright, c’mon. You’re visiting By, be happy. Woo, alright, no more angst, time for happy!”

 

And with that, she pushed the door open and headed inside. “Hey By, how’s it–Oh?”

 

“Oh, hey Shez,” Byleth greeted from her usual bed, sitting up again with her legs crossed and five playing cards in her hands. Because apparently she had a card deck with her, and was playing poker with Edelgard.

 

The Imperial Crown Princess looked faintly annoyed at her hand, before she glanced over at Shez. “Oh, hello. I didn’t know you were visiting.”

 

“Well I didn’t know you were going to be playing poker in here, so that makes two of us,” Shez replied, before pulling up a chair to Byleth’s bedside, on the same side as Edelgard so she could peek at her hand. “Oh wow, that’s bad.”

 

“I am aware, yes, though I am also fairly certain you shouldn’t be giving that away to my opponent,” she chided, looking irritated.

 

"Yeah but I'm pretty sure By already knew." 

 

"You do have a bad poker face, Edelgard." 

 

"..." Letting out a sigh, Edelgard tossed her cards onto the bed. "Fine, I fold." 

 

"Pft, it's a real good thing you're not playing for money. By might not cheat like the others do in cards, but you'll have a hard time reading her if you haven't known her for a long time." 

 

"You're getting better at least. It doesn't seem like you just learned how to play. Do you want to play again?" 

 

"No need to comfort me, and no, I really should be going. I would hate to intrude upon your time with your sister," Edelgard said as she glanced at Shez. 

 

"Okay, see you tomorrow?" 

 

"...Of course, professor. I'll see you then." With a bow, Edelgard left, and if Shez hadn't been watching her leave, she would have missed Hubert slinking out of a corner to follow behind. 

 

"...You know, sometimes I feel like that guy might be Edelgard’s ghost friend," Shez muttered, before turning to face Byleth, "So, how are you feeling?" 

 

"Better. Manuela says I'm healing quickly, both Hanneman and Lin say it's probably because of my crest."

 

"Huh, that's handy. Though, you know, if you had Arval I'm sure you would have been up and ready by now." 

 

"Yeah, I guess crests aren't that big of a deal," Byleth responded back, amused. "I mean, you can just summon a sword out of nowhere, I have to find one that just so happens to work with my crest."

 

"Heh, you hear that Arval? She's admitting you're better than her powers." 

 

"Of course, that’s only natural,” the voice in her head said, sounding smug, “Her powers may be frightening, but as my partner, you'd obviously end up with something better." 

 

"Hm." Tilting her head, Byleth frowned. "Sothis is mad at what I said. And that turning the hands of time is infinitely better than a sword." And that got Arval mad.

 

"Uh…Arval says that at least he can make sure to heal his partner right away." 

 

"...Sothis says her powers can help save other people." 

 

"...Why are we arguing for the ghosts in our head?" 

 

Byleth shrugged. "Seems rude to ignore them." 

 

"Yeah but they're being stupid." And that got an angry squawk from Arval and Sothis, though Shez couldn't hear the latter. 

 

"True. When are you going on your mission? It's fairly north in the Kingdom, yeah?" Byleth asked, ignoring how her words further incensed the spirits. 

 

"Not sure. Probably a week before the end of the month, at least. Either way, I'm sure your students are glad to not have to go to the kingdom again. Don't think any of them want to deal with that cold again." 

 

"I definitely don't," Byleth responded, making Shez laugh. 

 

“You’re the one that has magic to keep her warm though!”

 

“Still.”

 

"Hope I'm not interrupting," Jeralt spoke up as he leaned in from the doorway. 

 

"Oh, hey dad, something up?" 

 

"No, just…I wanted to show you two something. I already got permission from Manuela for you to come with me." As he spoke, they noticed he had some flowers in hand. 

 

"Uh… sure?" Glancing between themselves, Byleth and Shez felt a bit worried. Still, Shez helped her sister get out of bed and get dressed as Jeralt waited outside. 

 

"Where are we going?" 

 

"Something I should have shown you before," Jeralt said, leading the sisters downstairs. 

 

It felt weird, they were used to their dad being quiet sometimes, but he was never… solemn like this. Silently following him, the trio further made their way down, until they arrived at a graveyard. Confused, Byleth looked around, before her eyes stopped on one. 

 

Sitri.

 

"Oh." 

 

“Huh? What, what did you–” Shez paused as she noticed the grave too. “...uh…”

 

She glanced at her sister, who was just…quiet. Which wasn’t unusual for Byleth, but she was staring right at the grave too, which made her silence…kind of uncomfortable.

 

“...” Shez looked back at her dad, who was just watching too, and tried to smile. “Uh…this, um, feels…kind of private, so I’m just gonna–”

 

Then Byleth took her hand in hers. 

 

Shez paused, then looked at her sister, who seemed…Well, it was hard to tell. Byleth always did have a stoic face. So Shez just gave her sister’s hand a reassuring squeeze, and felt a smile come to her face when she saw Byleth relax slightly, some of her tension fading at her presence.

 

Byleth let go of her hand after a moment, then moved up to the grave and crouched down, just examining it for the moment. “...What…should I do?”

 

“...Well, I know some people, uh…talk at graves,” Shez offered, standing behind her sister. She still felt…kind of awkward, being her, since Sitri wasn’t her mom, but…she put a hand on Byleth’s shoulder and moved next to her. Still standing, but at her side now. “It helps, I think.”

 

“...Hello mama,” Byleth murmured in a small voice. She swallowed, her throat strangely tight. “It’s nice to meet you. I wish I could have known you while you were alive.”

 

She reached up, taking her sister’s hand again, and tugged, encouraging Shez to crouch beside her before she continued. “This is Shez. She’s my sister. You wouldn’t have met her because she had a different mom, but she’s family. I think you would have liked her. She’s the best sister I could have ever asked for.”

 

“...J-Jeez, it’s like you’re trying to make me cry,” Shez mumbled, her throat tight too, before she smiled at the grave, “H-Hey there, uh…H-Heh, sorry, I don’t know if I should call you Sitri or Missus Eisner or…I-I guess I wouldn’t mind calling you mom too. You’d, um, be the third one I’ve had. My second mom’s name was Periander, and I bet you two would have liked each other. She was really smart and thoughtful, and I think you’d be similar, you know? Though, uh, I guess that’s guessing a lot about you, but…I’m sure you would’ve been great. I’m kind of sad I didn’t get to meet you either.”

 

Jeralt smiled, faintly, as he watched his daughters talk to his wife’s grave. It felt like it should be strange, living as long as he had and yet still feeling her loss so very strongly, but he didn’t mind it too much. It meant he was still human, despite everything.

 

He kept that thought in mind as he stepped next to his daughters. The two glanced up at him, looking nothing alike and nothing at all like him. But that didn’t matter, because they were his kids. And he smiled as he handed Byleth the flowers. “Here. I think your mom would like these. They were her favorites.”

 

“...” Byleth swallowed again, and Jeralt felt a faint pang of surprise and sadness to see a tear roll down her cheek for the first time he could remember seeing. Then she smiled, and that small hurt faded completely.

 

“Thank you, papa,” she murmured, before glancing at Shez, who nodded to her with an encouraging grin. One Byleth couldn’t help but return with the biggest smile either of her family members had seen before she faced the grave again and laid the flowers down in front of it. “I hope you like them. It was very nice to meet you. Thank you for giving me life.”

 

They stayed by the grave for a time after that. Byleth leaned on Shez, emotionally drained but still smiling faintly as her sister wrapped an arm around her, giving her a hug. For a moment, everything else seemed to fade, and it was just the Eisner family, all together in one place.

 

…Shez was never going to let anyone hurt her sister. Never again.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Man it's wild to think how far this story has come from Byleth shooting Shez with an arrow.

Red: And how far we still have to go. Like this is still relatively early in the school year and we've got many plans for things coming up.

Indi: Including a small little detour we have coming up next!

Red: Just a small one, not too big. Probably.

Indi: Eh I'm sure it'll be fine, I mean, how big can the sewers be.

The Secrets of the Monastery

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Shez frowned to herself as she watched the stars overhead. She still felt listless and she wasn’t sure why. Byleth was fine, right? She was alive, but…things hadn’t gone back to normal yet.

 

Byleth was still in bed most of the time, staying in the infirmary so Manuela or Gertrude could keep an eye on her, the latter taking over while the former had classes to teach, and that meant the world still felt out of balance to the purple-haired merc. It was a weird feeling. And one she didn’t really like.

 

“I suppose your trepidation is only natural,” Arval commented, floating alongside her, “Your destined rival was felled by a truly monstrous foe. One would most certainly be off put, even if she had completely recovered by now." 

 

"...Yeah. I get what you mean," Shez responded, sighing as she sat up, stretching her arms as she did. As nice as it was to look at the stars from a rooftop, it definitely wasn't easy on her back. 

 

"Now, I think we should be–hm? What is that?" Arval suddenly asked, glancing down. Following their gaze, Shez looked down as well, spotting not only the house leaders, but a student from each house with them. "Well that is certainly an odd group."

 

"Huh." Well Shez was certainly interested. So it came to no surprise she would hop down. 

 

"Let's just hope we're not marching to certain doom," Claude said as Shez landed behind him. 

 

"What's that about doom?" Shez asked, getting most of the group to yelp in surprise at her sudden appearance. Which, well, was completely unintentional, but she was definitely going to savor the feeling. 

 

"Shez? What are you doing here?" Edelgard asked, narrowing her eyes at her like she didn’t just squeak in fright. 

 

"I was hanging out on the rooftop until I saw you guys down here." 

 

"And why were you on the rooftop?" Claude asked as he quirked an eyebrow. 

 

"Thinking about stuff. Why are you guys hanging out together this late?" 

 

"Ah, Claude saw someone suspicious, so we were hoping to follow them. Which we should get to doing before they get away," Dimitri answered. 

 

"Oh this is already sounding like a pain," Lindhart muttered. 

 

"But before we go, I did have a suggestion to make that Edelgard cruelly struck down,” Claude interrupted, turning Edelgard’s annoyed glare towards him, “But I figure I might as well ask you Shez: Do you think we should ask Teach to join us?" 

 

"Not at all!" Shez immediately responded, "Edelgard has the right idea, By is still recovering." 

 

"Yeah, I don't think it would be a good idea for Professor Byleth to come along," Ashe spoke up. 

 

"Heh, it seems you've been outvoted, Claude. Now come on, we might as well get this over with,” Hilda said with a grin while Claude let out a dramatic sigh. 

 

"Alright, I see a losing battle when I see one," Claude admitted before he began to lead the way through a hole in the wall. 

 

Letting out an amused huff, Shez followed along with the group, stepping close to Edelgard. 

 

"Hey, thanks for making sure By didn't get dragged along."

 

"...It's only natural I wouldn't want to put her in a dangerous situation when she's injured," Edelgard responded, "Though I suspect she likely would have come along if one of us did ask her." 

 

"Yeah, By can be like that. She really likes you guys, so she focuses more on protecting all of you instead of herself." 

 

"Yes, that has been clear since the first mission. I never expected to meet a self-sacrificing mercenary like her." 

 

"Yeah, By can be dumb sometimes. Hence why I tend to keep an eye out for her." 

 

"...May I ask why exactly you didn't join the Black Eagles in that case?" 

 

"Well, I do want her to get out a bit more. Like, obviously she's still going to need my help, but I can't always be the talker, you know?" Shez responded, "I mean, she's going to eventually take over the mercenary group, so that means she'll be the one accepting missions." 

 

"Hm…I can see the logic there," Edelgard said, before she began to study Shez. "...What if I were to hire Jeralt’s Mercenaries once you all leave the academy?" 

 

"Woah, really?" Shez asked, before she blinked. "Huh… that's right, you guys made that offer back at the start of the year… heh, well if you pay well, I definitely wouldn't say no." 

 

"In that case, care to regale me with more tales of your journeys? The more I know, the better I'll be able to pay."

 

"Oh sure! In that case…Hm, I already told you about our daring adventure against the Red Tyrant…oh, I know! Allow me to regale you, your highness, with the tale of the Cruel Machinations of the Scorpion Gang!" 

 

Edelgard did her best to suppress a giggle as Shez launched into a clearly exaggerated tale of her and Byleth dealing with a smuggling ring. Well, it wasn't exactly what Edelgard was asking about, but might as well listen to hear if she heard anything important.

"And that's when I came crashing through the window, blades at the ready as Byleth and I took on the scorpion boss!" Shez said to her crowd of classmates, all of whom had become invested in the story as they walked. 

 

"You didn't go get back up?" Dimitri asked, a bit surprised. 

 

"Of course not, By and I are invincible together!" Shez responded with a grin, "Why would we ask for backup?" 

 

"Hm, I dunno, seems like you'll definitely need back up," a new voice piped in, getting the students’ attention as they saw a tall, muscular man approach them. He smirked while cracking his knuckles. "Around here you'll definitely need more than this small group if you want to survive." 

 

"Identify yourself!" Dimitri demanded, even as he and the house leaders got into defensive positions. 

 

"Hey now, don't you know it's only polite to introduce yourself first? Especially if you're going to be intruding on someone's home." 

 

"Eegh, you live down here?" Hilda asked, frowning at him. 

 

"That we do! And I refuse to allow any invader trample upon our home!" another voice said, getting their attention as a posh-looking blonde walked up. "Especially if they mean to eliminate the good people of Abyss!" 

 

"Abyss?" Claude asked, curious about that tidbit. 

 

"For the record, I don't plan on eliminating anything so feel free to ignore me," Lindhart said. 

 

"Ha! You cannot fool me! The eyes of Constance von Nuvelle can see through your lies!" 

 

"Nuvelle?" Edelgard muttered, surprised at that name. 

 

"So, you guys mind calming down and telling us what's up?" Shez asked, raising a hand to catch everyone's attention. 

 

"That's what I want to know," spoke yet another voice. This time two people arrived: a pretty boy with lavender hair and a bored looking girl with dark skin and red hair. "I mean, here we were, minding our own business, only for a bunch of students with weapons to come visit us. I'm sure my friends and I would love to hear what you're doing." 

 

At that, Shez heard a rock get kicked behind her, catching her attention as she turned around to see several goons behind them. 

 

"A-Ah, guys, any way we can try escaping?" Ashe asked, pulling out his bow. 

 

"I don't think we have the option," Dimitri responded as the other students brought out their weapons. 

 

"Heh, glad to hear!" Shez shouted, pulling out her own sword, “I've been waiting for a fight!" 

 

“Now you’re speaking my language!” the big guy yelled back, raising his hands to show a pair of wicked looking gauntlets affixed to them, “You better get ready, because you’re about to face the Indomitable King of Grappling!”

 

Hilda blinked at that statement, a thoughtful look crossing her face even as she readied her axe and the rest of the students prepared for a fight.

 

“Well this is going to be a mess,” the pretty boy complained, before looking at his compatriots, “Try not to kill anyone, alright? We’re looking for information here, not a bloodbath.”

 

“Ha! Don’t worry, Yuri, I’m just gonna put these kids to bed!” the King of Grappling declared, before taking the lead as he and all the other goons rushed right in.

 

Shez felt a big grin come to her face as she lunged for the “King”, summoning her special sword to her hand and diving right into the fray. Though since that Yuri guy told his guys not to try to kill anyone, she decided to be nice and not just start cutting off heads. Shallow cuts and some kicks to knock people out were the way to go this time around!

 

Though she did reevaluate her plan to hold back once she actually got close to his Kingliness and the guy nearly knocked her flat with a punch that just barely missed her head. “Woah! Looks like that title of yours isn’t just for show, your majesty!”

 

"Ha! Of course it isn't, I'm not the Majestic King of Grappling for nothing!" The man boasted with a toothy grin before following up his attack with one to her gut. Dodging by transforming into a trail of purple light, Shez backed away from him before coming back to kick a goon who was about to attack Dimitri from behind. 

 

"In that case, let me introduce myself! I'm the Invincible Violet Demon! Feel free to give up if you're afraid!" 

 

"Ha! Why would the Undefeated King of Grappling give up against some no name punk!" 

 

"..." Shez’s eyes narrowed in response, before she suddenly appeared in front of him, kicking him in the face. "How's that for no name punk–Woah!" 

 

Shez yelped as a firm hand tightened around her leg, before she went flying through the air from a strong toss.

 

"Starting to think your sister was right with no taunting your opponent if they're still a threat," Arval oh so helpfully chimed in as Shez twisted in the air to land. 

 

Huffing, she rushed back into the fight, only to dodge a slash from the pretty boy, Yuri. 

 

"Violet Demon, huh? I've heard of you. You're one of those mercenary sisters who joined the academy, aren't you?" 

 

"What about it?" Shez asked, grinning as they clashed blades, "If you're planning on hiring me you choose the wrong way to go about it!" 

 

"Come now, surely you have a price," he commented, before jerking back as an arrow went flying towards his face, courtesy of Ashe, “Watch it! A face like mine shouldn’t get scratched up!”

 

Before she could thank her friend for the assist, Shez had to dodge a blast of magic sent at her by Blondie– No, wait, her name’s Constance, she mentioned that. Right, keep track!

 

Tucking and rolling, Shez got ready to fight again, before pausing when she realized the bored looking redhead was just leaning against a wall. 

 

"You uh, not going to join?" 

 

"Nah, they got it handled." 

 

"Hapi, you could at least pretend to help!" Yuri shouted, letting Shez know the last member of their group's name. 

 

"Fine," Hapi agreed with a sigh, before blinking. "Oh." 

 

Before Shez could ask what she meant, the wall next to them burst open and a crawler, as its name would imply, crawled through the hole in the wall with several more behind it. 

 

"Shit!" Getting up, Shez did the first thing that came to mind. That being, grabbing Hapi to get her away from the sudden demonic beast. 

 

"Uh, why are you holding me?" 

 

"I'm getting you away from that thing!" Shez shouted. 

 

"Oh." Well, it seems she doesn’t realize I summoned those things. Guess she’s a well-meaning idiot, Hapi thought to herself. 

 

"Hey! She's trying to kidnap Hapi!" Though it seemed not everyone picked up on that, as made evident by Constance’s yell. “I knew these scoundrels were up to no good!”

 

"I'm not kidnapping anyone!" Shez shouted while the lead crawler began to chase her, up until Edelgard slammed her axe into its side. 

 

"How about a ceasefire until we take these things out?" Edelgard asked while she backed away from the lead crawler, leaving a bloody furrow in the writhing monster’s side. 

 

"Well that sounds like a lovely idea," Yuri responded as he eyed the crawlers, "If you survive this, I'll even be willing to let you explain yourselves without siccing Balthus on you."

 

"I'm definitely up for that if it means not dealing with him," Claude said as he fired a curved shot at a crawler. 

 

"Hey come on, I'm not that bad!" 

 

"You're pretty bad, B," Hapi muttered after Shez put her down, before a swarm of dark energy flew from her raised hands and began biting down on a crawler as Dimitri speared the beast. 

 

"If it gets things over with," Lindhart muttered, sending a cutting gale that actually sped up Ashe’s arrows as they were launched, sending them plunging deep into the monster he targeted.

 

"Well, at least we aren't fighting each other!" Ashe said, trying to look on the bright side. 

 

"Ugh, I am so glad I brought a hand axe. This is already such a pain and I’m not about to get monster guts on me!" Hilda complained, before throwing the axe as hard as she could at the nearest crawler, getting the beast to wail as the blade slammed hard enough into its head to send it falling over. "Oh, yay I did it!" 

 

"Congrats, just a couple more to go," Claude snarked. 

 

"In that case, best get to work!" Shez shouted as she charged into the fray, grinning in delight as monster blood stained the ground. 

“Alright! Now that was a workout!” Balthus declared with a big grin, his fists raised in triumph as he stood atop a fallen crawler, his foot planted firmly on the beast’s head, “Ha ha! But these things were no match for the Almighty King of Grappling!”

 

“Huh. Wasn’t that the one you took out?” Shez asked Hilda, pointing to the axe embedded deep in the big worm’s neck.

 

“Eh. Tall, buff, and burly can take credit if he really wants to,” Hilda decided, waving a hand dismissively, “It’s better that way, makes sure people don’t start getting weird ideas of putting expectations on a cute, helpless girl like me.”

 

“I dunno about helpless…”

 

“Oh, so you agree that I’m cute~?”

 

“Well yeah, duh, you’re adorable,” Shez replied without hesitation, before pausing, “Oh hey, I think everybody else is meeting up over there with the new people. C’mon, let’s go!”

 

"Fine fine," Hilda huffed as Balthus got off the Crawler, a grin coming to the big guy’s face as he looked over the pair of young ladies. 

 

"Heh, never thought I'd see little Hilda with a girlfriend!" 

 

Hilda paused, raising an eyebrow at him. "Huh? But I'm not even dating Marianne yet…wait, how do you know my name?" 

 

"Aw, come on, you don’t remember me? It's me, Balthus." 

 

"...Baltie???" Hilda asked, confusion turning to shock once she recognized him.

 

"Yup, and don't worry, I won't tell Holst about you dating someone!" 

 

"Baltie, I already told you, I'm not dating anyone, yet. And I'm definitely not dating Shez ." 

 

"...Ouch?" Shez said, having caught the emphasis in her voice.

 

"Oh, you know what I mean. Do you really think the two of us would work out together?" 

 

"....Eh, yeah, that's fair." 

 

"See? And besides, it's a bit hard to try and date Marianne since she's in a different class now." 

 

"...You could always join the Black Eagles," Edelgard offered, deciding to stop pretending she wasn’t listening to their conversation, which earned a huff from Claude. 

 

"Stop trying to poach my classmates." 

 

"No offense, Edelgard, but as nice as it would be to be in Marianne's class again, I feel like you'd expect too much of me," Hilda said, "I mean, I might be willing to join the Blue Lions cause Dimitri is more of a pushover, but I don't think you'd let me get away with anything." 

 

"...I'm standing right here," Dimitri said with a frown on his face. 

 

"I can't believe what I'm hearing! You'd actually abandon me Hilda?" Claude asked, an overly dramatic tone in his voice. 

 

"I mean…probably, yeah. Besides, Lorenz would probably be a better fit for your retainer." 

 

"Okay now you're just being cruel to me," Claude complained, “You really want me to take the most pompous noble in Fodlan as my retainer?”

 

“I believe Ferdinand would argue that point,” Edelgard noted.

 

“Seriously Edelgard? Are we really going to compete over who has the most pompous noble in their class?”

 

“If we’re having a competition like that, I’d like to put Coco in the running,” Hapi offered, earning an affronted look from Constance.

 

“Pompous?! I am not pompous! Though I will agree that I am far more noble than anyone else who may lay claim to such a title!”

 

“Didn’t your house lose its standing?” Linhardt asked with his usual amount of tact.

 

“Temporarily! For you see, I, Constance von Nuvelle, shall ensure my house rises from the ashes once more and takes its rightful place as one of the premiere noble houses of Adrestia! Ohohohoho!”

 

“...Yeah, alright, she’s a strong competitor for the title,” Claude agreed, nodding to Hapi.

 

"Well, as entertaining as this is, I do believe it would be best to discuss why exactly your group is down here,” Yuri brought up, eyeing the students. 

 

"Well, we came down here cause Claude apparently saw someone suspicious," Ashe explained. 

 

"It's not everyday a bandit decides to sneak into Garreg Mach, after all," Edelgard continued. 

 

"Or for students to find a group of people living under it,” Dimitri stated. 

 

"I see. Well, it’s for the best to avoid talking about this place on the surface. Most that are in the know aren't exactly fond of us down here. Abyss is a place of refuge for anyone who needs it, regardless of what they might have done in the past," Yuri explained, "Though that also leads to trouble, hence why we assumed you were attacking us." 

 

"Does this happen that often?" Dimitri asked. 

 

"In the past few months, yes. We've been dealing with some mercenary attacks, and while we don't know who they're working for, we're not exactly going to let them push us around." 

 

"Oh, do you need help?" Shez asked.

 

"You would offer your help so easily?" Constance inquired in return. 

 

"I mean, yeah? I was looking to work out some stress anyways so this helps." 

 

"In that case, I want to help out too!" Ashe piped in. "If people need help, then I won't ignore them." 

 

"You guys could at least try to get something out of this,” Claude muttered. 

 

"Come on now Claude, where's the harm in helping them out?" Dimitri asked. 

 

"Excellent. In that case, I suppose we might as well show you around the place before we get to work," Yuri said with a smirk. 

 

"I'm sure Aelfric will also appreciate the help," Balthus pointed out.

 

"Aelfric?" 

 

"Yeah he's a big wig up in the church. He's also the guy in charge around here. I'm sure you'll think he's great when you meet him!"

“Woaaaaah, there really is a town down here!” Shez exclaimed, staring with wide, interested eyes at the underground town called Abyss.

 

“What, did you think we were lying?” Yuri inquired with an amused grin, “Do I look like the type to lie?”

 

“Yep.”

 

“My, you are a blunt one. Well, either way, welcome to Abyss!” he declared, turning to the group and throwing his arms wide with a smirk, “There aren’t many rules down here, but I’m sure I don’t need to tell the fine students of Garreg Mach that they aren’t allowed to rob, assault, or kill any of the residents of our fine city down here.”

 

“We would never do anything of the sort,” Dimitri assured, frowning at the very idea, which earned a roll of the eyes from Hapi.

 

“You’re a real good guy, huh Blondie?”

 

“Oh, ah–Well, thank you, I do try to be.”

 

“A real genius too,” she muttered, prompting a grin from Yuri.

 

“Leaving aside my surly friend’s sarcasm for now, I do believe we should get around to actually introducing ourselves now. Or at least all of you should introduce yourselves, since I’m sure you overheard us mentioning each other’s names already.”

 

“Oh, right, of course,” Dimitri agreed, before placing a hand on his chest, “I am Dimitri Alexandre Blaiddyd, the Crown Prince of Faerghus and a student at the Officer’s Academy. And these two are my fellow classmates in the Blue Lions house, Ashe Ubert and Shez Eisner.”

 

“It’s nice to meet you,” Ashe greeted, his eyes lingering a little on Yuri as he tried to figure out where he’d seen the older teen before.

 

“Aw, I wanted to introduce myself,” Shez complained with a pout.

 

“You know you still could, Shady,” Hapi pointed out.

 

“Oh, true. Alright then, I’m Shez Eisner, the Violet Demon, a legendary mercenary and daughter of Jeralt the Blade Breaker! Also the sister of Byleth Eisner, the Ashen Dragon, who is also cool.”

 

“Ooo, a legendary merc, huh? Funny, I don’t think I’ve heard of you,” Balthus commented with a grin as Shez bristled.

 

“I have,” Yuri noted, smirking, which earned a grin from Shez.

 

“Alright, you’re my new favorite.”

 

“Heh, keep that up, Shez, and people might start thinking you’re fickle,” Claude commented, amused, before raising a hand in greeting, “Hey there, Claude von Riegan, and my friend who your friend already knows is Hilda Goneril.”

 

“Hi Baltie! And Baltie’s friends!” Hilda greeted, playing up her cheerful, cute aspects to make a good first impression. Well, a good second impression. “It’s nice to meet all of you! I hope you’ll be nice to me~!”

 

“Laying it on a little thick there, huh Hilda?” Balthus commented, which put a damper on her attempt.

 

“Aw, come on, Baltie, what are you saying?” Hilda asked with a pout. 

 

“To finish introductions, I am Edelgard Von Hresvelg, house leader of the Black Eagles,” Edelgard introduced, before glancing at Lindhart who seemed to almost be dozing off until she cleared her throat.

 

“Oh, I thought you’d introduce me so I wouldn’t have to.” He lazily raised his hand. “Lindhart.” 

 

“Well, feel free to wander about, though try not to get lost. Abyss has yet to be fully explored by anyone so who knows what’s down here.” Yuri said, getting Shez to grin at the thought of finding–

 

“You’re not wandering about,” Arval instantly interjected.“Knowing you, you’d wind up getting lost in here and appearing in Sreng when you exited.” 

 

“...” Now Shez was curious if this place did lead to Sreng. Maybe it even had secret passageways to the three nations' capitals…Well now she had to explore. 

 

“Excuse me my friend.” Or she would have if Yuri didn’t walk up to her. “I wanted to ask you for help.” 

 

“Oh? With what?”

 

“Well, we’ve been having a bit of a problem with some mercenaries down here for a bit. So I was hoping you might be willing to help out with a plan we have.” 

 

“Heh, well I’m not going to say no, but we’re going to need to talk about payment first. I’m by myself so you don’t have to pay full price, but still, I’m not cheap.” 

 

Yuri couldn't help but smirk. Well, she’s going to be fun.

Chapter End Notes

Red: And so we visit the sewer people! Otherwise known as the Ashen Wolves! We in the DLC now!

Indi: Yup yup, and don't worry, Byleth will be joining in next chapter, cause boy do we have plans for this.

Red: Many plans! Plans we hope you all enjoy! For now though, thanks for reading!

Cardinal Virtue

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Classes still hadn’t started back up for Byleth. She could understand why, since she’d been injured, but it was starting to bother her that she wasn’t teaching even when she felt up for it. Apparently getting her chest cut open made people worry about “recovery time” and stuff like that, which was definitely a new experience for her. She’d never been injured that badly before, and any injuries she did take tended to heal more quickly than whatever the Death Knight had done to her.

 

So that meant the professor of the Black Eagles spent most of her recent days just hanging around with her students or her family, when she wasn’t resting. And when it was the middle of class time and nobody was visiting, well…Byleth wasn’t the type to get bored easily, that was more Shez’s thing, but after a full week of bed rest and light exercise, even she was starting to get restless.

 

Then her father had work to do again and Shez was busy with classes so the chances of her keeping occupied decreased significantly. Still, she was at least allowed to walk around the campus now, so she started exploring a bit…and wound up going to her mother’s grave. 

 

She wasn’t sure why, exactly. Her feet just carried her there. The real surprise was seeing someone she hadn’t met before standing at the grave and holding a bouquet of flowers, just like the ones Jeralt brought before.

 

“–sorry it’s taking so long. I hope I can see you soon,” the man mumbled, before placing the flowers beside the vase that was already there. A touch Byleth decided to add a little while ago. Then he turned and his eyes widened. “Oh, I…did not expect to see anyone else here. Ah…my apologies, you just…look quite familiar.”

 

“...Hello,” Byleth greeted in return, before glancing at the grave. “...Did you know my mother?”

 

“Oh. So you are her daughter, I see.” The man nodded to himself, lost in thought, before he shook his head. “Ah, pardon me, my sincere apologies. I am Aelfric Dahlman, a cardinal of the Church of Seiros.” He placed his hand on his heart and bowed with a slight smile. “And you must be Sitri and Jeralt’s daughter then. I must say, I did not expect to run into you here.”

 

Byleth shrugged. “I was just visiting my mother. It’s nice to talk sometimes.”

 

“Ah, of course, I can understand that. Believe me, I understand that very well, haha…” He cleared his throat somewhat awkwardly. “My apologies, as I said, I was not expecting to run into anyone, much less Sitri’s daughter…and I appear to be repeating myself.”

 

“It’s okay, it happens. How did you know my mother?”

 

“Ah, well, we grew up together, here in the church. Has, ah….Has Jeralt told you much about her?”

 

Byleth shrugged. “Some. I know it’s hard for him to talk about her. Did you know Jeralt too?”

 

“Yes, I did. I knew both of them quite well. I was raised as an orphan here and Sitri was easily my best friend. As for Captain Jeralt, I couldn’t help but idolize him. Not that I ever really measured up to him, but you know how it is.”

 

"I guess." 

 

"Is Captain Jeralt here by any chance?" 

 

"He's on a mission. Not sure when he'll get back." 

 

"Ah, that is a shame. If I knew he had returned, I would have made time to visit him…" 

 

"How didn’t you hear about him?" 

 

"Oh, I've been quite busy. I've been tending to my flock in Abyss." 

 

"...Abyss?" She’d heard that name before.

 

"Oh, my apologies, that was a slip of the tongue, but…" He looked around. "I suppose it wouldn't be bad to talk about it. Have you heard about Abyss?" 

 

"No.”

 

"Heh, well, that’s not really a surprise… ah, but to explain, Abyss is a place where those seeking refuge can hide. Many of them are those who cannot seek shelter up above for one reason or another. I myself am the caretaker of the people residing down there." 

 

"Huh…that sounds nice," Byleth said, getting Aelfric to smile. 

 

"Thank you. Would you like to visit? I'm sure you'd enjoy talking to those down there." 

 

"Hm…okay, I don't have anything else to do." 

 

"Wonderful news. Here, I'll lead the way," Aelfric offered with a smile. Walking ahead, Aelfric gestured for her to follow. "If I may ask, were you the one who left the vase of flowers?" 

 

"Yeah. It felt nice to do." 

 

"I'm sure Sitri was happy to see them. It did surprise me when I saw them though. I'm the only one who tends to her grave, so I didn't expect to see them." 

 

"I see. Though Shez was the one who chose the vase," Byleth said, before realizing Aelfric wouldn't know who she was. "She's my sister. Jeralt adopted her a few years ago." 

 

That prompted a small smile from him. "Today is just full of surprises I see." 

 

"Professor, there you are!" Blinking, Byleth turned to see Leonie and Petra approaching her. 

 

"Is something up?"

 

"Not really, we were just wondering if you saw where Claude or Edelgard went?" Leonie asked, glancing at Aelfric for a moment before focusing on her again. "Claude mentioned something about seeing someone suspicious appear out of nowhere, so he dragged Edelgard off with him." 

 

"Linhardt and Hilda have also vanished, so we were having hopes you saw them." 

 

"Are they missing?" Byleth asked, some worry for the students coming up through her muted emotions. 

 

"Ah, I think I might know what might have happened," Aelfic spoke up, "There's a chance they might have stumbled upon Abyss." 

 

"Abyss?" Leonie repeated, raising an eyebrow.

 

"Perhaps it would be better if we hurried along, Byleth," Aelfric said, getting Byleth to nod before Leonie spoke again. 

 

"Hey, I don't know what this Abyss thing is, but I'm not letting the captain's daughter go off with some random stranger!" 

 

"Yes, as her student, I shall be protecting her while she is injured," Petra firmly stated. 

 

"Oh dear…Byleth, perhaps we should just have these two accompany us to save time?" 

 

"Yeah, that sounds good." Byleth said, nodding, before a thought occurred, “Hm…we should bring a Blue Lion.”

 

Aelfric blinked. “Pardon?”

 

“Yeah, to balance things out. We have a church person–” She pointed to him, before gesturing to Leonie and Petra. “–a Golden Deer and a Black Eagle. We should get a Blue Lion so we’ll have all four.”

 

“Ah, I have understanding,” Petra said, nodding to the professor’s logic while Leonie raised an eyebrow.

 

“...Yeah, I don’t get how that’s supposed to make sense. Though…hm, I guess I haven’t checked if any of the Blue Lions are missing…" 

 

"In that case, we should check quickly," Byleth said, before leading the group to find a lion. One who they found rather quickly. "Oh, hello Dedue." 

 

"Ah, professor, have you seen his Highness?" the young man from Duscur asked, worry evident in his voice. "I haven't seen him since yesterday." 

 

"Oh, he's probably with Claude and Edelgard then," Byleth concluded, nodding, "We were just about to go see him. Did you want to come along?" 

 

"If it means finding his highness, of course." Dedue nodded. 

 

"All right, let's go," Byleth declared, pumping her fist, before turning to Aelfric, "Do you mind leading the way?" 

 

"Of course not," the clergyman said with a smile, "Come along now, I'm sure my flock will be happy to see you." 

 

With that, they began to make their ways into the depths of Garreg Mach. Deep down, until the narrow passageways opened up into enormous caverns.

 

“Wow, this is crazy!” Leonie exclaimed as she looked around the massive ruins underneath the monastery, “There’s an entire village down here! How does no one know about this place?”

 

“You would be surprised by the types of things the Church keeps secret,” Aelfric replied with a hint of amusement in his voice, “In comparison, Abyss is almost mild as far as hidden truths go. Some even say this city hidden beneath Garreg Mach existed before the monastery did and it was only later that the Church settled the mountains above.”

 

“What, really? But that would make this place over a thousand years old, right?”

 

“Garreg Mach is a place of history, young lady. You shouldn’t be too surprised to see its history is a long one.”

 

“Yes, the monastery is having a history of much longness,” Petra agreed, “It is like the ruins in my homeland, where the ancient spirits are resting.”

 

"This place does seem to hold an ancient air to it," Dedue muttered as he glanced around for any sign of Dimitri. 

 

Aelfric smiled at the conversation. “Indeed, the history of this place really is fascinating. I would like to share more of what I know, but we really should be on our way–”

 

“Hold on.” Byleth stopped and held up a hand, making the group pause.

 

“Byleth? What is it?”

 

“...Aelfric, what’s that big structure?” she asked, gesturing towards a large building they were coming close to.

 

“Ah, I believe it was once a reception hall, though it wasn’t long ago it saw use as an underground arena,” the cardinal explained, “It should be abandoned now though.”

 

“Hm. I just saw a heavily armed group enter through that entrance.”

 

“...Oh. Ah, perhaps it is less abandoned than I expected…”

 

“Hm. Dedue, Petra, to the front with me. Leonie, you can keep Aelfric safe, right?”

 

“Huh? Ah, yeah, I definitely can, though are you sure you should be taking the lead?” the orange-haired student asked, visibly worried. “I’m willing to admit you’re pretty tough, but aren’t you still injured?”

 

“I’m healed enough,” Byleth stated, before drawing the Sword of the Creator and heading for the arena.

 

“...Did you have that under your coat this whole time?”

“You know, I’m starting to think we should have brought more people,” Claude commented as he loosed an arrow into another merc’s head.

 

“Hm. Perhaps,” Edelgard replied, catching a mercenary’s sword on her shield before splitting his skull with her axe, “Though you were the one who insisted on the three of us going right away.”

 

“Hey, I didn’t realize our new friends would be ambushing this many mercs at once!” He nocked another arrow, aimed, and fired straight into the back of an assassin trying to creep up on Hilda, who was busy carving her own bloody swathe through the baddies along with that childhood friend of hers. “Besides, we did at least get some of our pals on our side!”

 

“True, Lindhart has been surprisingly helpful for once,” Edelgard commented. She bashed her shield into an armored merc and drove its side into his neck, crushing his throat between the steel and the floor. “Who else would you have brought along, had you had the chance?”

 

“Hmm, good question…honestly speaking? I think I actually got the team I’d pick for myself with Hilda and Shez here. Maybe I’d bring the rest of the Deer, but for a three person team, I think we’d be doing great!” He punctuated his statement by loosing another arrow, this one sailing across the arena to catch an assassin in the wrist before he could try to stab Dimitri. “And hey, at least we got Ashe from the Lions. He’s probably one of the better options aside from Shez.”

 

Edelgard huffed in some amusement. “Yes, I have noticed you tend to favor Professor Eisner’s sister. Ashe is one of the ‘better options’ though?”

 

“Oh sure, I’m always in favor of having another archer around. Volleys go a lot better when you can blot the sky out with arrows. Having Ignatz and Leonie is pretty good for that kind of thing.”

 

“Ah, I see. I admit though–” Edelgard moved to block an arrow before it could catch Claude in the side, then ducked her head so her fellow house leader could shoot the archer in question right in the eye. “–I am curious who you consider the best options out of the Lions.”

 

“Hmm…Shez is at the top, for sure, then I think Ashe works just fine. Dedue’s got that big guy appeal going for him, can’t go wrong with a solid wall of muscle, but he’s also super loyal to Dimitri so that means he’s a package deal with him. Then I guess it’s a toss up with the lancers and the casters. All of them can be effective in different ways, but my opinion varies a bit. I guess out of them I’d go for Ingrid first? She’s kind of a stick in the mud, but there’s some fun to be had there.” He considered things while looking across the battlefield, a slight smile coming to his face as he tracked Shez slicing her way through a squad of enemy mercs. “Oh, and the worst is definitely Felix.”

 

“Oh? What’s so bad about Felix?”

 

“Have you heard how he talks to Ingrid and Dedue? Guy’s a prick. I have no idea how the rest of the Faerghus Four are friends with him, but I feel like it’s just inertia by this point, like they liked him once upon a time and those good memories keep them hanging around–”

 

“Look alive, people!” Yuri called out from his own spot in the fray, his sword darting out and cutting through the legion of mercs they were having to deal with. Their newest maybe-friend was still going strong from all appearances, barely looking winded as he split a man’s chest with his sword. “It looks like one more wave is incoming!”

 

“Oh, great, just what we needed,” Claude complained, earning an amused noise from Edelgard.

 

“And here I was getting invested in your opinions on our classmates.”

 

“Heh, then ask me about them again after this, I’ve got plenty to share!”

 

“What the hell is this!?” the mercenary in the lead exclaimed once he saw the gore-stained arena. His jaw dropped, but he shook it off quickly, before pointing his sword towards the two house leaders. “Damn it, if this is a trap, we’re turning it around! Go for the important-looking brats–”

 

And then the upper half of his body exploded into flames, prompting panicked shouts among his cohorts that were rather quickly cut off by a whip-like sword shredding through a good amount of their number. The ones that weren’t didn’t far much better though as some familiar faces came in and promptly started cleaving through throats and chests with a sword and an axe.

 

“Is that Petra and Dedue?” Claude asked, raising an eyebrow at the sight of his fellow students.

 

“Is that the professor?!” Edelgard exclaimed, her own focus fully on the sight of her teacher appearing out of nowhere to carve through several mercenaries at once. Which was understandable since she really should be resting.

 

“Oh, that’s probably why that guy exploded.”

 

“Ah–Oh, true, that would make sense.”

 

“Friends of yours?” Yuri asked, prompting glances from his fellow house leaders as he appeared right beside them.

 

“Yup,” Claude replied, unphased, “Blue-haired lady is one of our professors and the other two are our classmates–Oh hey, Leonie’s there too.”

 

“She is?” Edelgard frowned, trying to catch sight of the redhead before nodding as she saw the commoner in question stab through a mercenary with her lance. “So she is.”

 

“Heh, looks like we really are getting that back up I wanted. So hey, Yuri, do you mind letting your friends know not to kill our friends?”

 

“Oh sure, the more the merrier. Hey, Wolves! The three ladies and the large man down that way are on our side!” he called out, catching the attention of his own “classmates”.

 

“We have reinforcements? Since when?” Hapi asked, staying by Ashe as she and the archer provided covering fire. Or covering darkness, in Hapi’s case.

 

“Oh? So some good samaritans have come to our aid then! Ahaha, fortune truly favors us!” Constance declared, prompting a sigh from Linhardt as he tried to keep the crazy mage between him and the enemy.

 

“What was that about hot ladies coming to save us?” Balthus asked, right in the middle of crushing the windpipe of a mercenary he had in a chokehold.

 

Edelgard sighed. “Well, this should be…interesting.”

 

“Aw, you make it sound like we’re gonna make a bad first impression, princess,” Yuri teased, grinning, “Don’t worry, I’ll make sure everyone’s on their best behavior once we finish up here.”

 

“Somehow, I doubt that.”

 

“Phew, it looks like we’re reaching a lull in the–Is that Dedue?!?” Dimitri exclaimed as he came up to his fellow house leaders, his eyes widening in shock as he noticed his retainer smashing his way through armored mercenaries.

 

"Bit slow on the uptake there, Dimitri," Claude responded. "Though I suppose our sudden saviors are probably the best surprise we'll get–" 

 

“You pieces of shit, you killed all of my men!” shouted a mercenary captain, visibly seething beneath his assassin’s helm as he caught the house leaders’ attention, “I might go down here, but I’ll take you with–!”

 

And that was when a leaping horse landed straight on top of the merc, demonstrating to all the students there what it looked like when a warhorse’s hooves made contact with a man’s head, which was quite similar to seeing a melon smashed with a warhammer.

 

“THE DEATH HORSE RIDES FREE ONCE MORE!” declared the Death Knight upon his steed, his black horse rearing up with a bloodthirsty whinny, “THE SCENT OF FRESH BLOOD HAS DRAWN ME TO THIS PLACE! WHO SHALL THE WORMS FEAST UPON TONI–AH.”

 

Then he noticed the house leaders.

 

“...”

 

"..."

 

“...”

 

“...Is he also a friend of yours?” Yuri asked, glancing at the students while the princess of the group was fully glaring at her absolute idiot of a subordinate.

 

“...” It was a little hard to tell, but Claude was pretty sure he could see sweat dripping down the Death Knight’s helmet. “...IT APPEARS…THAT THE TIME IS NOT YET RIGHT FOR MY SCYTHE TO CLAIM YOUR LIVES. BYE.”

 

"...Well I was about to say that was the worst surprise but now that was just the weirdest." 

 

Edelgard pinched the bridge of her nose as the Death Knight vanished. “Honestly, what a nuisance…”

 

“Not normally how I’d describe a hulking knight in a skull helmet who nearly killed my professor, but you’re not wrong,” Claude commented, “Speaking of, hey Teach!”

 

"Oh, there you are." Byleth said, quite casually as she cut the throat of a remaining mercenary. "Who's your friend?" 

 

"The name's Yuri, I'm in charge of the little band down here. Am I correct in assuming you're Shez’s sister?" 

 

"Yeah, nice to meet-"

 

"By!? What are you doing down here!?" Shez shouted, having approached the group right after the fighting stopped. "You should be in bed!"

 

"You really should be resting, Professor," Edelgard agreed. 

 

"I dunno, she looks fine to me," Yuri contradicted. 

 

"No sense in making her leave if she's already here," Claude agreed in turn. 

 

"How about we head back to the town before we continue this discussion?" Dimitri suggested before the argument could start. 

 

"That sounds like a good idea,” Byleth agreed, “Though we should make sure Aelfric doesn't get left behind." 

 

“Aelfric is with you?” Yuri asked, a bit surprised as the clergyman jogged up to the group. 

 

“My apologies, I fell a tad behind there,” Aelfric said as he looked over the students, “Thank you for assisting my flock in their time of need.”

 

"Hey, weird dude,” Shez spoke up, frowning, “Did you bring my sister down here?" 

 

"What did you just call Aelfric?!" Constance asked, agape at the audacity. 

 

"Ah, please calm down," Aelfric said as he raised his hands. "And yes, I did. I wanted her to meet my flock." 

 

"And why exactly is that?" 

 

"Shez, calm down. He's a friend of Sitri and Jeralt." 

 

"...oh. okay, sorry about that," Shez apologized, backing off. 

 

"It's alright, I can appreciate how protective you are of your sister,” Aelfric replied with a smile. "Though I hope you're okay with us showing her the town." 

 

"Yeah, sure, okay," Shez huffed, looking neither sure nor okay with that suggestion.

 

"Thank you. In that case, I hope you don't mind if I ask you a favor, professor," Aelfric said as he smiled, catching Byleth’s attention.

So, apparently Aelfric wanted Byleth to help teach the Ashen Wolves. She didn't particularly mind that favor really, as she was ready to start teaching again, so what were four more students? Well, technically five since Marianne just joined her class… hm, should she try recruiting from other classes? She liked the idea of having more students… 

 

Though, that thought took a backseat as she began to look around the Abyss, checking in on the students that she brought with her. 

 

"Hey By, come on, you really should go back to get some rest." While also trying not to be annoyed by Shez. She couldn't really blame her, since she had acted the same after Shez had almost died against Lonato, but still. 

 

"I'm fine Shez. My wounds don't even hurt anymore." 

 

"...I kinda want to poke you to prove that they still do hurt, but I also don't want to hurt you." 

 

"Then I guess you just have to be okay with me being down here," Byleth responded, getting Shez to huff as they walked around. Their first stop being a scrap pile. 

 

"Woah, guys, look at this!" Leonie cried out from the scrap heap. "Who threw this away!?" she asked, holding up a dented hexshield. 

 

"Eh, you'd be surprised at what people throw away," Balthus commented as Leonie kept digging through the heap. 

 

"But that's a hexshield! I could scrape together money for a year and still not have enough coin for one! It's not even badly dented!" Leonie yelled, before pulling out a lance. "This isn't even in bad condition, it's just really rusted! This can easily be fixed!" 

 

"Eesh, I don't think even anyone down here is this excited about the scrap heap," Balthus muttered before glancing at Byleth. "Well, as you can see, this is the scrap heap. Any gear that gets thrown away topside ends up here, and you can usually find something good down here."

 

"Good to know. It definitely seems useful." 

 

Shez huffed, amused this time. "Pft, looking to get something new to replace that sword you have, By?" 

 

"No, but it's still handy to know about." 

 

"Yeah, sometimes you find something in good condition that's worth a decent amount of gold,” Balthus added, “Always handy to have when I need some booze." 

 

"...Hm." Byleth nodded to herself. "I'm going to see how everyone else is doing." Turning on her feet, Byleth headed out, with Shez following behind her. “You don’t need to follow me.”

 

“What, I can’t hang out with my sister?” Shez replied, acting casual despite how obvious it was that she was still keeping an eye on Byleth, “Besides, I can be your guide down here!”

 

“Oh, alright. I didn’t realize you knew that much about Abyss.”

 

“Oh totally! I know everything there is to know about the abyss! In fact–Oh, hey, haven’t been in there before,” she commented before heading off towards what looked like a library.

 

Byleth sighed at her sister’s antics, but followed along to find her hanging out with Claude.

 

“They have forbidden books down here?” Shez asked, looking at the tome Claude was holding.

 

“That they do, Shez, that they do. It looks like anything the church bans winds up down here. Pretty convenient for me, right?”

 

“Yeah, really convenient. Though you’re probably gonna get in trouble if you try to bring any back up with you.”

 

“That’s only if I get caught with them.”

 

Well there was only one thing for Byleth to do after hearing that, which was heading right over and taking the book Claude had in his hands away from him.

 

“Wha–Aw, c’mon Teach, you don't trust me?”

 

“I trust you. I just find it funny to catch you off guard.” Claude blinked at that frank admission before Byleth turned the book over in her hands. “Huh, no title.”

 

“Ooo, a mystery book,” Shez said, staring curiously at the blank cover and earning a chuckle from Claude.

 

“Yeah, it looks like a fair few of these are damaged. Soooo, would you mind giving that back so I can try to find out what it is?”

 

Byleth ignored him and opened the book up herself. 

 

"...’How to compliment a lover’." 

 

Claude blinked. “Huh?”

 

Shez, meanwhile, glanced at her friend with a slight grin. “Oh? You’re interested in that kind of stuff, Claude?”

 

"No I'm not!" Claude argued, almost reflexively from what it seemed. 

 

Byleth tried not to smile. It was a bit more difficult than usual. "Hm…you know, just because you're trying to court Shez doesn't mean you should read a book about pick up lines." 

 

"PFTT!" Shez started laughing loudly at that, holding her gut as she doubled over in laughter. "A-Aw~! Does his highness have a crush on me~?" 

 

"Hey now, I'm not Lysithea," Claude deflected, immediately throwing his fellow Deer under the carriage without hesitation.

 

“Pft, oh please, Lysithea doesn’t have a crush on me,” Shez replied, waving the suggestion off, “She’s just teaching me magic. I mean, I guess she’s my buddy? But yeah, there’s no crush there.”

 

Byleth sighed, sharing an exasperated look with Claude before she returned the book to its place on the bookshelf and picked out a different one. “Hm…Claude, I think most of these are books on dating.”

 

“What? Seriously?” Claude frowned as he went over to the shelves and started looking through, his frown getting deeper before he abruptly shut the book he was reading. “...Right, going to be awkward going into that room with the saint statues now…”

 

“What? Why’s that?” Shez asked, moving over to look at the book Claude had, though he tossed it to Byleth before Shez could get it. “Ah–Hey! C’mon, I wanted to read that!”

 

“Yeah, no, you didn’t.”

 

Byleth, meanwhile, opened up the book, read a few lines, then placed it back on the shelf…before she casually picked out one that looked more interesting and slipped it into her coat before Shez would notice. 

 

"I can see why so many of these books were banned," Byleth said, "Try not to stick around here, Claude." 

 

"Fine fine," Claude muttered, shaking his head as Byleth and Shez left.

 

"So… Lysithea is teaching you magic?" 

 

"Yeah, she's pretty skilled at dark magic, so it's nice having someone help me out with that!" Shez explained with a grin. "Though, like I said, she doesn't have a crush on me." 

 

"And if she did?" Byleth asked, deciding to needle Shez in return for all her previous teasing. 

 

"Ah…huh…Well, she's cute. You know, like an angry rabbit. Though she's also a noble, so not sure how well being a traveling merc will help with dating someone who has to stay somewhere." 

 

"Hm…so she's cute, huh?" 

 

"...Oh you are not turning this around on me." 

 

"I'm just repeating what you said," Byleth said, a small grin on her face as she walked ahead of Shez, looking for the other students. 

 

Thankfully, they didn't have to go far as they found Dedue and Dimitri talking with one another. 

 

"Your highness, I must ask that you not go on such a dangerous mission without letting me accompany you." 

 

"My apologies Dedue, I had no idea it would be so dangerous to begin with. As it is, I only intended to follow Claude to see what exactly he had seen." 

 

"It was still dangerous. You should have gotten more back up," Byleth said, getting their attention. 

 

"I understand that, professor. Still, at least things turned out well?" 

 

"Thankfully." 

 

"I owe you some gratitude as well, professor. Thank you for bringing me along on this mission," Dedue said, bowing to her. 

 

"No need to thank me," Byleth replied as she nodded to him. "Just make sure to keep an eye on him." 

 

"I can take care of myself, professor," Dimitri responded, mostly in good humor. 

 

"I'm sure." Byleth nodded to him too before walking off with a silent Shez in tow. "You're being quiet." 

 

"Ah, yeah, it's just…a bit awkward is all. Since I'm planning on transferring out." 

 

"Ah…did you want to talk about it?" 

 

"I mean, what's there to talk about? I'm not enjoying it as much as I would like, so I figured the Golden Deer would be a better choice." 

 

"Hm…Well, if that's what you want to do." 

 

"Yeah, guess I lucked out by being the student instead of the professor huh? I get the option to leave, rather than stay like you gotta." 

 

"...I guess so. Still, I think I'd stick with the Black Eagles even if I had the option. It was… rough at the start, but I enjoy being with them. I've helped them and they helped me." 

 

"Really?"

 

"Yeah…It’s thanks to Edelgard that I was able to…at the very least confront my issues with Catherine. I don't know if we're friends, but at the very least, I know I have a ways to go before I can fight her again." 

 

"Hm…well, that explains that…" 

 

"Yeah. Also, interesting that you're joining the class that Claude and Lysithea are in." 

 

"By, I swear to the goddess-" 

 

"I'm just pointing that out. And also how Leonie, your rival, is also in the class. Not to mention Hilda, who you apparently called adorable."
