"...You're really lucky you're injured right now or I'd punch you." 

 

“Aw.” Byleth pouted. “My baby sister is being so mean to her poor, injured older sister. How cruel.”

 

“...” That twitch was new. “You know, maybe I’ll just join the Wolves instead and live underground for the rest of my school year.”

 

“Alright, I’ll make sure to tell papa. Try to get some sun or you’ll get pale.”

 

“...You could at least pretend to entertain the idea.”

 

“No. Besides–”

 

"–I forgive you, ahahaha!" Turning her head towards the loud laugh that caught her attention, Byleth saw Constance standing by Edelgard and Petra. 

 

"Ah, excuse me?" Petra asked, seemingly very confused. 

 

"There is no need for you to be excused!" 

 

"What's going on?" Byleth asked as she approached the group. 

 

"Oh hello, Professor Byleth, correct? Allow me to properly introduce myself! My name is Constance von Nuvelle!" the blonde Ashen Wolf declared as she fanned herself. "I must thank you again for coming to our rescue!" 

 

“She didn’t do much,” Shez muttered, but Byleth ignored that.

 

"Just glad I could help, but what’s going on here?" 

 

"If I can explain, I believe Constance is trying to say she bears no ill will to Petra for what happened during the Dagda and Brigid war,” Edelgard suggested. 

 

“And I don’t! If I am to restore House Nuvelle, then I cannot be stuck in the past mired with grudges!” Constance stated. “Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have some spells I must practice!” Turning on her heel, Constance walked away. 

 

“Ah, wait!” Petra called out, following behind her, leaving Edelgard alone with the sisters.

 

“Hm. Professor, are you sure you should be walking around?” 

 

“I’m good, I’m already healed up,” Byleth said, pouting a bit at how much people kept trying to get her to rest. 

 

“Nah, you’ve got the right idea, your highness! By definitely shouldn’t be walking around like this!” Shez declared, clapping a hand to her sister’s shoulder, “She’s so frail and weak right now, she should really just lay down and let her super strong sister handle everything for her–GH!”

 

Byleth lowered her elbow from where she’d rammed it into her sister’s stomach. “I’m fine, like I said.”

 

“...Very well… Professor, while I have you here, I did want to ask you something.” At her nod, Edelgard continued. “You’ve traveled across Fodlan before, correct? I wanted to know if you could tell me about your travels, perhaps after you left Enbarr?”

 

“Oh, is this about the Dagda and Brigid War?” Shez asked, “By mentioned she talked to Petra about it before, so I think we’re cool on that front? Hm, maybe I should talk to her too?

 

Edelgard paused, not expecting that response. “...It wasn’t exactly what I was thinking of, but you were a combatant in that war?”

 

“Oh sure! Well, kind of? I hung back since I got stabbed, so Byleth was on more missions there.”

 

“Our mercenary band was hired by Count Varley to protect his territory during it, before Count Bergliez counter-attacked,” Byleth elaborated, “We mostly hunted down scouting parties that made it past the mountains though. That and the occasional band of deserters. Like Shez said, I talked with Petra about it before.”

 

“Hm, I see. Yes, I suppose you would want to discuss the subject with her…May I ask what you did after that though?”

 

Byleth tilted her head, thinking. “We went west through the mountains, then up into Faerghus.”

 

Edelgard nodded as though Byleth just confirmed something for her. “Understood. Thank you, professor, for satisfying my curiosity.”

 

“That’s all you wanted to know?” Shez asked, “Would’ve thought you’d be asking for something more interesting than that.”

 

Edelgard shrugged. “I was just curious. I doubt your journey had anything of interest after that point.” An interesting look came to her eyes. “Was there?”

 

“Hm…well Byleth learned light magic, that was pretty cool. Uh…then I guess we went to Faerghus after that? Which sucked, it’s super cold up there.”

 

“Yes, I can’t say I’m too fond of the Faerghus cold either,” Edelgard murmured.

 

“Oh, you’ve been up there too, princess?”

 

“Some years ago, yes. It was…well, perhaps I will tell the story later. For now, weren’t you checking on everyone, professor?”

 

“Oh, right. See you later then,” Byleth said before heading off once more with Shez in tow, the younger mercenary still sticking close to make sure her sister was okay. The last of her students to find would be Linhardt, and he was bound to be either studying something or napping, which meant he would probably be in the library…but she was just there and only saw Claude, so hm. Where was her sleepy student?

 

In front of a pagan altar, apparently.

 

“Oh, hello professor. And Shez too,” Linhardt off-handedly greeted, busy staring up at the huge statue of a winged goddess, “I must say, it is fascinating to see a statue like this directly beneath what most would consider the home of Fodlan’s own goddess. I wonder if that would make our friend here a trespasser or a guest?”

 

“Probably a guest, yeah?” Shez said while Byleth idly studied the statue, “I don’t think the goddess minds if another god decides to relax in her basement.”

 

“You have a more tolerant view of faith than most, Shez. Still, it is a shame we have no easy access to knowledge regarding the gods of other lands. The Church may say there are no true gods but the Goddess herself, yet other lands often worship entire pantheons. It raises questions, don’t you think?”

 

“Careful there, friend. It might be fine to ask questions like that down here, but you’ll probably get accused of blasphemy if you ask similar things up top,” Yuri chided as he walked over to them with a faint grin on his face. “And I’d hate to lose a friend so soon after meeting them.” 

 

“But something like this is far too fascinating to just keep to myself. I wonder if I could find some texts on who this god is…” 

 

“I’m sure you can find something. Plenty of secrets tend to squirrel themselves away down here.” He turned his gaze towards Byleth with a faint smile. “I'm sure you have your own that you want to keep." 

 

Byleth shrugged in response. "I guess. Hey, do you know where Hilda or Ashe are?" 

 

"Can't say anything about the young boy, but as for the Goneril girl, I believe I saw her visiting the wayseer. She certainly seemed interested when she learned what exactly she does.” Tilting her head in confusion, Byleth went to where he gestured, before finding Hilda sitting at a table where a cloaked woman had her hands over a crystal ball. 

 

“Oooh, that’s definitely going to be blackmail material~”

 

“What is?” Byleth asked, getting Hilda to look at her. 

 

"Oh hey there Professor, Shez!" Hilda greeted them as she looked back on them. "You'll get a kick out of this, this lady can see how close people are!" 

 

"She can?" 

 

"Yeah, well, specifically she can see who's closest to someone. Oh, can you check to see who the professor is closest to?" Hilda asked the seer, who let out a sigh before focusing on her crystal ball. 

 

"Hm…it seems she is closest to her sister." 

 

"Pft, I could have told you that," Shez said with a grin. 

 

"Aw, that's no fun,” Hilda complained, pouting, “How can I tease her about that?" 

 

"...You know I can hear you, right?" Byleth asked.

 

"Oh well, at least I have something to tease Shez about," Hilda said with a sigh, as she hid a smirk. 

 

"What are you talking about?" Shez asked. 

 

"Oh you know, I decided to ask who your 'mentor' is closest to~" 

 

"Huh?" 

 

"Oh?" Byleth seemed very intrigued all of a sudden, which made Shez pause. 

 

"...H-Hey, I already said she didn't have a crush on me!" 

 

"Really~?" Hilda asked in a teasing tone, catching Shez off guard. Looking between the two, Shez felt her face begin to burn, before she took off running. 

 

"Hm… feels nice turning the tables on her," Byleth said, nodding to herself. "Make sure to take care, Hilda." 

 

"Sure thing, professor!" 

 

Walking out, Byleth began to look for Shez before she could get lost, only to find Ashe speaking with Hapi. 

 

"Oh, hello there Professor Byleth, how are you feeling?" 

 

"I'm doing okay, have either of you seen Shez?" 

 

"Nope, and do you mind getting this kid to stop bothering me?" Hapi said, getting Ashe to look sheepish. 

 

"A-Ah, I was just curious as to why she can apparently summon demonic beasts by sighing. Though I guess it's something personal." 

 

"It is." 

 

"Hm, sorry to bother you Hapi. Ashe, we should meet up with everyone else." 

 

"Right, professor!" Ashe said, giving an apologetic smile to Hapi as they walked away. "Also, did Shez go somewhere?" 

 

"Hm, hopefully not. She might get lost easily down here, and who knows what's down here."

"...Well shit, where am I?" Shez asked, looking around as she realized she might have gone too deep into Abyss. 

 

"Maybe don't go running down several hallways in the underground town next time,” Arval suggested as they appeared behind her. 

 

"Well what was I supposed to do?" Shez asked as she tried to backtrack her way out. 

 

"Don't get flustered over the possibility of someone having a crush on you?" 

 

"Easy for you to say." 

 

"It is, and it should be for you as well. You don't have a crush on her, right?" 

 

"I don't. I mean she's my friend and all, but… I dunno, I've read stuff involving romance before, I just never thought I'd actually have to deal with stuff like that," Shez muttered as she kept walking. 

 

"Well get used to it, or else your sister will begin to tease you about it, and I refuse to allow you to lose purely from embarrassment," Arval responded, before Shez walked into a wide open room. 

 

"Okay, I think we're getting somewhere," Shez said as she looked around. Though it was still creepy with how quiet things were down here… 

 

"Anyone there?" Shez called out, getting no response. "Ugh… Seriously, how big is this place?" 

 

"...Partner." 

 

"Hm? What's up Arval?" Shez asked, glancing up at the spirit, who wordlessly lifted an arm to point somewhere in the dark. Following their arm, Shez saw what they were pointing at. 

 

In a strangely illuminated part of the room, a body lay down on a stone table. The woman, wearing a white gown, her long green hair spilling out around her head, seemed to be resting, as if she could wake up at any moment. And…the more she looked at her, the more Shez saw the similarities between the strange woman and…her sister. 

 

“What the hell…?”

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Probably not what exactly what they expected, but shout out to maskedbiker71 for unintentionally guessing that Shez would find her dead mom(#3) down in Abyss

Red: And thus many a plan is derailed by Shez's tendency to wander and get herself lost.

Indi: However will Aelfric recover from this? If he can anyways, who knows he might just crash and burn immediately.

Red: Well, Indi and I know if he crashes and burns. The rest of you though will just have to speculate!

Indi: Until then, hope you enjoyed!

Digging Deeper

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

"Oh, there you are, Professor," Edelgard greeted as Byleth walked up. 

 

"Hey, have you seen Shez?" Byleth asked, getting Edelgard to blink in surprise. 

 

"No? I thought she was with you." 

 

"She was, but I can't find her." 

 

"Eh, Shez is a strong girl, I’m sure she can take care of herself," Claude said.

 

"...That is true, but she has also admitted to getting lost easily," Dimitri responded. 

 

"Oh, that isn't good…perhaps while you go on your mission, I can look around for her?" Aelfric asked, getting Byleth’s attention. 

 

"Mission?" 

 

"We’re going looking for what we think those mercenaries are after." Yuri answered. 

 

"Yes! While we cannot say for certain, our dear Aelfric has informed us of a legend that they might be seeking," Constance stated, "The fabled Chalice of Beginnings, said to have the power to raise the dead!"

 

"Hm. Well, okay,” Byleth accepted, “Good luck with that. I'm going to try and find Shez." 

 

"You're not going with us?" Balthus asked. 

 

"It would be best to find her before she gets truly lost," Dedue noted. 

 

"In that case, I shall go with the professor! None are as good at tracking as I!" Petra declared.

 

"Hey, I don't know how good Brigid hunters are, but don't underestimate my tracking skills!" Leonie cut in with a grin, earning a challenging smirk from Petra in reply. 

 

"Well, sticking around here does sound like it's not as much of a hassle…" Hapi muttered. 

 

"I volunteer to stay in the town in case Shez comes wandering back!" Hilda said, eager to not put in the effort. 

 

"Seconded," Lindhart said with a yawn. 

 

"Ah, I don't know how well splitting the group will be," Aelfric said. 

 

"Are you sure? I mean, there's so many of us, that I'm sure we can cover both objectives easily," Ashe responded, getting Aelfric to frown. 

 

"Hm… it would mean some of us are here in case any more Mercenaries attack," Edelgard muttered. 

 

"Yeah, don't worry, I can-" And before Byleth could assure the protection of the Abyss, a loud yell cut her off. 

 

"BY!" Shez shouted, as she came running up. 

 

"Oh, there you are-..." Byleth couldn't help but trail off as she saw what her sister was running up with. Namely a body in her arms. 

 

“What are you doing with Sitri!?” Aelfric exclaimed, which earned him a lot of surprised stares.

 

“Sitri? Who’s Sitri?” Claude asked.

 

“My mother…” Byleth murmured, stunned, before moving closer to Shez. Aelfric took a half-step towards her too, but stopped himself while Byleth stared at the body of her mother. “How did…Why is she down here? She should be buried at the monastery…”

 

“I don’t know! It’s insane, right?” Shez agreed, looking about as baffled as most of the students felt, “I just found her down here and she looked so much like you and I don’t even get why she’d be here??" 

 

"I don't either…" Byleth said, staring as she felt… something ache in her. 

 

"...Ah, perhaps we should find somewhere to lay her down for now?" Aelfric suggested, trying to figure out what to do for his plan. 

 

"f I may, Aelfric, you seemed surprised that Shez had the Professor’s mother," Edelgard spoke up, staring at the monk. 

 

"Well, yes, why wouldn't I be?" 

 

"It was your specific wording. Normally one would be surprised at seeing the body of someone they thought passed away long ago, rather than ask what someone was doing with them." 

 

"You better not be accusing Aelfric of something," Balthus interrupted, cracking his knuckles with a glare. 

 

"Hey now, I'm not saying Edelgard is right, but it is suspicious, especially since Aelfric is supposed to be in charge down here," Claude noted. 

 

Constance scoffed. "I refuse to listen to such baseless accusations!"

 

"Yeah, Elfie isn't a bad person," Hapi agreed.

 

“Everyone, please, be at peace!” Aelfric interrupted, holding up his hands to ward off any violence as the groups of students started to square off, “Please, all I did was misspeak–”

 

“That’s a pretty shoddy excuse,” Claude pointed out with a faint smirk, keeping his eyes on the Wolves, who bristled at his comment.

 

As the tension continued to grow, Byleth silently stood by Shez, before reaching out to hold her mother. Concern evident on her face, Shez handed her over. 

 

"..." Byleth couldn’t think of what to say as she stared down at her mother. All she could do was stare at her, looking like she was resting peacefully. And the next thing she knew, drops of water seemed to fall upon Sitri's face. Concern filled Byleth as she knelt down to try and clean off Sitri's face. 

 

"...Byleth," Shez said, getting her sister’s attention as she knelt down too. Reaching up, Shez wiped the tears off her sister's face, before pulling her into a hug. 

 

Nearby, the tension seemed to fade away as the sound of Byleth crying caught the attention of everyone. 

 

"...Shez, perhaps you should take the professor and her mother up to the monastery," Edelgard suggested, getting Shez to silently nod as she stood back up. 

 

"W-Wait, I don't know if it's a good idea to take her," Aelfric cut in, trying to stop them. 

 

"...Yes, perhaps we should figure out why exactly she is down here," Yuri said. 

 

"I don't care about that," Shez responded, glaring at them. 

 

"Are you sure? I mean, she was supposedly buried, correct? Then someone must have dug her up, though the question is who would be debased enough to do so," Yuri said, a curious tone in his voice. 

 

"Ah, yes, to defile a grave is a horrible thing to do! Whoever did this, must pay for it!" Dimitri stated. 

 

"They're probably also perverse," Claude noted, “I mean really, what kind of freak would dig up a lady just to keep her around? Sounds like a real sicko.” 

 

"I-I am not! I didn't even dig her up, I found her down here!" Aelfric shouted, immediately realizing his mistake as everyone stared at him. 

 

"...Aelfric?" Constance broke the silence, staring at him in disbelief. "Please tell me you misspoke there as well." 

 

"Well he obviously did misspeak. He said too much there," Claude commented with a smug smirk. 

 

"Hey, you shut up!" Balthus shouted, before he turned to face Aelfric. "Come on, Aelfric, he's wrong, right?" 

 

"...” Aelfric wracked his mind for an excuse, another option beside admitting the truth…and couldn’t come up with anything. “Ten years ago, I found her body down here. I didn't dig her up, I swear to the goddess that I would never do that to Sitri."

 

"Why didn't you tell anyone!?" Ashe asked, completely taken aback. 

 

"Who was I supposed to tell?! I…after Sitri passed away all those years ago, I lost my trust in Rhea. And to suddenly find her body down here even though she was supposed to be buried? How could I ever talk about that?" 

 

"You could have at least… buried her or something," Hilda muttered, unsure of what else to say. 

 

"There are several methods of funeral rites," Petra said, agreeing with Hilda. 

 

"It may not be my place to speak, but you should have at least told the professor," Dedue spoke up as he stared down at the monk. 

 

"How could I have explained this to her? Sitri…she died twenty years ago, and yet it's like not a single day has passed…" 

 

"It's still her mom! Her and the captain have the right to decide what to do with her!" Leonie shouted. 

 

"...I was weak. I found a body that seemed… almost perfectly preserved down here and… I was afraid that if I touched her, she might have crumbled away. Hence why I left her there. I even set up wards that were supposed to guide people away from her." Aelfric sighed, trying to keep up the lie as he glanced at Shez. "I guess they weren't as effective as I thought." 

 

"...Yeah, sure. Look, I don't care what kinda reasons you have, but Byleth and I are leaving, and we're taking missus Sitri with us," Shez said, keeping a protective arm around Byleth. 

 

"That…" Aelfric tried to think of what to say. 

 

"Excuse me, but weren't you just telling us about the chalice of the beginnings? An item that could supposedly raise the dead?" Lindhart asked, as he raised his hand. 

 

"...what?" Shez asked, having not heard of that. 

 

"I-I only heard about that legend! I never went out to seek it!" 

 

"Yeah, if Elfie was really looking for it, he would have asked us to help him find it or something." 

 

"I don't care," Byleth said, getting everyone's attention, "I don't care about what reason he had, or whatever this chalice is. I'm taking my mom, and I'm going to bury her." 

 

"..." Aelfric sighed, knowing he had lost. “Of course, I can allow that. Though, if I may, I would like to at least speak to Lady Rhea before you do. I understand I have been cowardly by not taking these steps before now, and I hope you can forgive me.”

 

“Pretty sure you should mention what happened to dad before you talk to Rhea,” Shez pointed out, still frowning at Aelfric.

 

“Yes, of course. I’ll make sure to let Jeralt know too. I owe him that much. But, please, I don’t think it would be a good idea to carry Sitri through the monastery as she is. At the very least…she should be prepared for burial.”

 

"...Okay," Byleth said, frowning even as she agreed. "I'm… going to find somewhere to lay her down." 

 

"Ah, the Ashen Wolves have our own makeshift dormitories, if that would work," Constance offered. 

 

"Thank you," Byleth said, before following behind the blonde noble. 

 

Aelfric sighed, before steeling himself. "Yuri, if you would please keep an eye on everyone, I'll make sure to return as soon as I can." 

 

"Of course," Yuri accepted, nodding to Aelfric as the monk left. "Perhaps it would be best if we all took a moment to relax, lest the tension returns." 

 

"That sounds for the best," Edelgard agreed, before following behind the two sisters, though giving them some space as she waited outside the dormitories. Surprisingly, it wasn't Constance that walked out first, but Shez. 

 

"Ah, hey there, princess," Shez greeted, giving her a slight wave. 

 

"Hello…how is the professor doing?" 

 

"...about as well as she can be, I guess," Shez muttered, "You mind doing me a favor? I'm going to be going on the monthly mission soon, so I won't be able to keep an eye on Byleth while I'm gone, so I was hoping you could help with that." 

 

"...Of course, if there is any way I can help, then I'll gladly do so." 

 

Shez smiled. "Heh, you know, I know it hasn't been that long, but thanks for being friends with Byleth."

 

That gave Edelgard some pause. There just…wasn’t any hint of guile or deception in Shez’s voice. From all indications, she genuinely meant that. “...You are welcome. Though I will note that she is my professor and I am her student. We’re not exactly–”

 

“Nah, you’re friends, I can tell. So, again, thanks.”

 

“...” Edelgard huffed, a small smile of her own creeping up her face. “You are welcome. It's the least I can do after all she's done." 

 

"Oh yeah, didn't she save your life when we first met?" Shez asked, before a grin spread on her face. "What, don't tell me you got a crush on her because of that?" 

 

"...I would appreciate you not mock me. I have no such feelings towards Professor Byleth." 

 

"Sure, sure. Just keep in mind, even if you're a princess, you gotta have my permission," Shez teased, getting Edelgard to huff. 

 

"Ah, am I intruding in something?" Constance asked as she walked out. 

 

"Not at all," Edelgard said as she turned to her. "Is the professor okay?" 

 

"Of course. I made sure she went to sleep since she looked absolutely exhausted," Constance stated before turning to Shez. "And I would like to offer my sincerest apologies for what Aelfric has done. If I was aware of what he kept hidden, I would have made him come forth about it." 

 

"...Look, no offense, but I don't know any of you guys. I don't know how much you do know, I'm sure you mean well, but you can see why I'm not going to trust you, alright?" 

 

"Yes, of course. In that case, I just have to show you the sincerity of House Nuvelle!" Constance declared, getting Shez to look confused at her sudden exuberance. 

 

"There you guys are." Looking over, the trio saw Hapi standing nearby. "Yuri said we should talk about what to do." 

 

"I thought we were going to wait for Aelfric to return?" Edelgard pointed out. 

 

"Yeah, but we still have to deal with those mercenaries. I'm not sure what exactly Elfie might have been planning, but those guys are still the immediate danger." 

 

"..." Shez let out a sigh. "Hey, Edelgard, do you mind sticking by my sister?" 

 

"You want me to stay by her? What about you?"

 

"Look, I already said I don't trust these guys. So whatever they do, I'm keeping an eye on them. And I want to at least keep someone I trust keeping an eye on Byleth." 

 

"...Very well, I promise to keep her safe." Edelgard said, nodding to Shez. As they walked off, Edelgard entered the dormitory. Seeing her professor silently sleeping, she couldn't help but…contemplate her plans. Shez was an Agarthan, of that she was sure but… even so, it was clear Shez did love her sister…. 

 

If she was tricking her, Edelgard would make sure Shez paid for it, but for now, she wouldn't tell Bias what she learned. 

Sometime later, Edelgard felt a yawn threaten to leave her mouth as she looked over her professor. It had been a long time since the expedition group had left, and while it was hard to keep track of time down here, it definitely felt like it was getting late. A part of her idly thought that Hubert was likely panicking at not being able to find her, before she was broken out of her thoughts by a tray of food being shoved in her face. 

 

Jolting backwards, Edelgard followed the tray to see Leonie smiling down at her. 

 

"Hey there, you really need to make sure to get something to eat." 

 

"Oh, thank you, Leonie," Edelgard said, taking the tray from her, 

 

"No problem, just hope you don't mind that I made it. It's nothing fancy but it's filling," Leonie said as she sat down next to her. 

 

"It looks delicious," Edelgard complimented before she began to eat, almost immediately gagging as she did. 

 

"Yeah, I did my best, but well, the food they have down here isn't great." 

 

"I-I see." Edelgard coughed slightly, trying to clear the taste. "I understand that this place might be a refuge for criminals and the like, but one would think that since it's still connected to the church, that they would at least have the funds for good food." 

 

"Eh, it's not that surprising. I mean, it's nice that the church gives us free food and all, but we still had to pay to come here. Hell, I'm going to be in debt for at least a few years after I graduate." 

 

That got Edelgard to blink in surprise. "You will?" 

 

"Yeah, this place isn't cheap after all, and unlike Ignatz and Raphael, I'm not part of a merchant family. My entire village had to scrape the funds to send me here." 

 

"...I see." That was something Edelgard hadn't really thought about before. Given her own wealth of funds, it never occurred how much the entry fee would be to commoners. Really, most commoners would normally only be able to join if they had a noble patron…

 

"Something up, Edelgard?" 

 

"Ah, no, you just gave me something to think about for my reforms for when I become emperor," Edelgard said, before looking around. "Where is Ashe?" 

 

"Oh he's sitting outside. Cause it's apparently inappropriate for a guy to enter the girls dorm!" Leonie shouted, directing the last part to the door. 

 

"It is!" Ashe shouted back, getting Leonie to laugh. 

 

“Hahaha! Ah, anyways, how’s Byleth doing?”

 

“Still asleep,” Edelgard replied, “I think she may have exhausted herself more than she expected with the combat earlier.”

 

“Yeah, that sounds like her. She’s always been arro–ah, confident, as long as I’ve known her. I used to think it was some sense of superiority she had, the way she seemed so cool and collected all the time, but…” She scratched her head, letting out a sigh. “I guess I let my own ideas of what she’s like get away from me when I was younger.”

 

“Hm. How long have you known the professor?”

 

“Not that long. I just met her and her sister a few years ago. I was thirteen, I think Byleth was fourteen since she’s a year older, and Shez…I’m not actually sure? She’s always been kind of tall for a girl and it’s tricky to tell. If I asked Shez, she’d probably say she was fourteen too, or even fifteen, but Byleth would probably say she was eleven?” Leonie shrugged. “My point is, I mostly met them for a few days before they had to head out again. I liked Shez immediately because she saved me from some poachers that were attacking our town, and I didn’t like Byleth at all because she seemed super arrogant to me. I didn’t really get that she was just…I don’t know if there’s a word for it? Just, weird, I guess.”

 

"Ah, yeah, I get what you mean," Ashe said, having listened in from outside. "It's a bit different for me but… it's silly to think about now, but back when I first met Shez and Byleth, I thought of them as some invincible heroes cause of the stories Shez used to tell me and my siblings. After what happened to Christophe… it became obvious that they were just kids, like me. I never actually got to say goodbye to Byleth when she left, and…Shez just looked so worried about her when she said goodbye." 

 

Edelgard hummed, considering matters. If Shez had been part of Jeralt’s Mercenaries since she was that young… "It is strange to think about them like that, but it's easy to forget that the two of them are our age, despite their years of experience." 

 

"Yeah, that's true. Heck, isn't Mercedes older than Byleth?" Leonie asked.

 

"I think so, yes," Ashe confirmed. 

 

"Hm…" Edelgard let out a small sigh as she got up, tray in hand since she had finished eating. "Well, I suppose that is something to-" Feeling something run over her foot, Edelgard was unable to keep the instinctive scream out of her mouth, practically flinging the tray out of her hands as she backed away from the rat that scurried across the floor. 

 

"What happened!?" Ashe yelled running in with his bow drawn as his eyes scanned the room.

 

"M-My apologies. I just felt a r-rat scurry over my foot," Edelgard muttered, really wishing she had brought Whiskerton down with her. 

 

"Oh, is that all? I thought you just really didn't like the food I made," Leonie joked, trying to ease Edelgard’s nerves with a laugh. 

 

"Well, at least it wasn't anything bad?" Ashe said, going over to grab the now dented tray. "I'm just glad that didn't wake the professor up." 

 

"Huh?" Confused, Edelgard glanced over to Byleth. That was…odd. She didn't know how exactly the professor slept, but one would think a mercenary would have awoken at a sudden loud banging of a metal tray hitting a stone wall. Yet, it looked as though she was still peacefully sleeping. 

 

"...Professor-" And before she could get any further, a loud scream from outside cut her off. 

 

"FIRE!" Instantly on guard, Edelgard rushed towards the door. 

 

"Both of you stay here!" Edelgard commanded as she went towards the source of the scream.

 

A scowl came to her face as she spotted the raging fires that had begun to consume parts of Abyss. The ramshackle wooden buildings were lighting up quickly, catching like tinder as she spotted more mercenaries in rough armor, led by heavy knights in full plate.

 

“RUN AWAY, LITTLE RATS!” one of the armored mercenaries yelled, the hammer in his hand smashing one of the town’s few guards off his feet, “DON’T THINK WE WON’T KILL EVERY LAST ONE OF–”

 

Edelgard’s fireball caught the distracted mercenary in the head in an eruption of flames and molten steel as he went from yelling to screaming. Edelgard didn’t slow though, drawing on the strength of her crest as she slammed her palm into his chest and cast another Fire, silencing his screams in an instant. 

 

“Wha–CAPTAIN!” another armored mercenary yelled, staring in shock and horror as her leader crumpled, “YOU LITTLE BITCH! I’LL TAKE YOUR HEAD!”

 

“Wait, the boss wanted the students alive–!” a mercenary in mage robes called out, but the knight wasn’t listening, instead charging for the princess as she took the hammer and shield from the fallen captain.

 

Edelgard took a breath as she recalled seeing her professor do so many times before, then angled the shield. When the knight charged, she moved, letting the armored knight’s spear skid off the shield, bringing her in close enough for Edelgard to swing the hammer straight into the mercenary’s head. She didn’t even notice her crest flaring up as she did.

 

The enemy mercenaries did though, and more than a few jaws dropped as they saw a tiny waif of a girl smash the head off of a fully armored knight. The lieutenant’s helmeted head flew free in a spray of blood, before Edelgard stepped forward with an imperious glare.

 

“H-Holy shit…h-how did…”

 

“So that’s what a crest can do…”

 

“G-Goddess, she’s a monster! F-Fuck this, I’m not dying for some damned cult, no matter the gold they’re giving me!”

 

Edelgard stiffened, before her eyes locked on the mercenary that spoke last, who froze before he could run. “...What did you just say?”

 

“H-Hhiieeee!” the man squealed, before turning and running along with the rest of his mercenary band as a scowl came to Edelgard’s lips. 

 

“Pathetic cowards…" Scoffing, Edelgard turned to the nearest resident. "You, are there any buckets we can use to carry water over?" 

 

"Y-Yes, miss." 

 

"Then bring them over, we need to hurry before the fire gets any worse!" 

 

"O-Of course!" the man responded as he began to gather other residents to carry water over. Nodding as she sees them move, Edelgard went back to the dormitories to inform Leonie and Ashe what happened. 

 

Her heart stopped as she saw the bodies of mercenaries on the ground, arrows and spear wounds littering their bodies. Rushing forward, Edelgard found Ashe and Leonie on the ground, groaning in pain. 

 

"What happened!?" Edelgard asked, crouching down by the two, silently cursing herself for not having any bandages on hand for the two. 

 

"S-Some mercenaries came rushing towards us after you left," Leonie explained, holding her bruised arm. 

 

"Th-They took the professor," Ashe managed to gasp out as he tried to push himself up. 

 

"...what?" Feeling her blood run cold, Edelgard ran into the room, and found that the bed where her professor was, lay empty, while Sitri's body remained on hers. Gritting her teeth, Edelgard slammed her fist into the wall hard enough to crack it. 

 

Someone was going to pay dearly for this.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: So things keep going off the rails.

Red: Indeed they do! Sitri is found, but now Byleth is missing, and meanwhile, Shez is off doing the actual plot.

Indi: Edelgard meanwhile begins to think she might be able to trust Shez, and also gets a newfound perspective on Byleth as well.

Red: So yeah, hope you all like how things are going and look forward to the next one!

Shez Eisner and the Chalice of Beginnings

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Shez had to admit, she would normally be really, really happy right now. She was on an adventure, searching for a mysterious artifact, and fighting a legion of ghostly warriors! It was the type of story she’d read about as a kid! Normally, this would be the best thing to ever happen to her!

 

It’s just, well, her sister wasn’t there. She didn’t need to have Byleth by her all the time, she wasn’t that clingy, but it did mess things up a little since Byleth was still injured and then there was that stuff with that weirdo Aelfric guy and Missus Sitri. It just made things feel weird, and while she wasn’t about to get distracted in the middle of a fight, it was still kind of a downer, like a cloud hanging over everything.

 

“You doing okay over there, Shez?” Claude called out, catching Shez’s attention as she cut through a ghost-knight’s neck, splitting its phantom head from its phantom neck before she hopped off its ghost horse. Which also vanished when the knight did, which was weird.

 

“Yeah, I’m fine! Any luck on the chalice hunt?”

 

“Not much, though Dimitri and crew found a giant living statue.”

 

Shez’s eyes immediately lit up with obvious interest and excitement. “WHERE!?”

 

“Over that way–And she’s gone already.” Claude huffed in some amusement, before raising his bow and loosing an arrow into another phantom cavalier, killing it and the horse at the same time. Somehow. “Hm…I wonder if the horses are part of the ghost, or it just leaves when the knight dies?”

 

Not hearing his query, Shez rushed towards where Claude gestured, finding Dimitri and Dedue up against a giant statue, who was currently trying to smash Dedue into the ground as Dimitri circled around it. And while she definitely wanted to help her friend, she couldn't help but grin at how freaky looking it looked, since its head had a knight helm, while its chest was a lion face. They also had two shields bearing the Crest of Seiros on its shoulders. 

 

And as interesting as that was, Shez immediately rushed in to slash at the statue. 

 

"Begone from this place!" the statue shouted as it tried to retaliate. 

 

"It can talk!?" Shez shouted in surprise while dodging its arm. 

 

"Now is not the time to be in awe," Dedue reprimanded, smashing his axe into the statue while he had some slight reprieve. 

 

"But this is awesome!" Shez shouted back, only for her excitement to end as Dimitri’s spear pierced the statue, causing it to stutter, before falling limp. "Aw, damn it." 

 

"I'm sorry?" Dimitri apologized, not really sure what the problem was. 

 

Letting out a huff, Shez looked at the statue, before noticing something hanging from it. "Is that a key?" 

 

"Huh… so it is…" Dimitri muttered. "Oh, I believe I heard Yuri mentioning something about stones that looked like they had keyholes in them?" 

 

"In that case, guess it's up to me to save the day!" Shez shouted as she grabbed the key, before running off! 

 

"Shez, you're running away from the battle!" 

 

She turned around and began to run off again! In the right direction!

 

“Eh? What are you doing back here?” Claude asked, prompting Shez to pause.

 

“...Uh…hm…” She frowned. “...I have no idea where I’m supposed to bring this key.”

 

“Ahh. Well, I can’t exactly help with that.” He glanced upwards. “Why not ask the mopey Lady Nuvelle up there?”

 

“Hm?” Shez glanced up at the noble on her pegasus and a grin came to her face. “Good idea! Be right back!”

 

And she promptly vanished in a flash, which earned a slightly worried look from Claude. “Did she just…?”

 

Meanwhile, all the way up in the air, Constance von Nuvelle abruptly found herself feeling somewhat cramped as a random young woman appeared on her steed with her. “Ah, so this is how I die. How appropriately pathetic…”

 

Shez blinked. “Uh…jeez, you really don’t handle the sun well…why do you ride a pegasus if you’re not good with bright spaces?”

 

“I apologize for my incongruous abilities…”

 

“...For your what–No, never mind! Where’s the statue thingy?”

 

"My apologies for not understanding what you mean…" 

 

"This thing! Where does this thing go!" Shez said, shoving the key in front of Constance. 

 

"Oh… well, I may be mistaken, but there is a large source of magical energy over there," Constance said as she pointed at an area near the cliff. 

 

"Thanks!" 

 

"There is no need to thank-" And before she could finish putting herself down, Shez disappeared again. "...She truly was in a hurry to get away from me." 

 

Shez, meanwhile, appeared by the cliff face and immediately noticed a stone podium that had a hole in it. 

 

"There we go!" With a grin, she shoved the key in, before hearing a small rumble. Glancing around confused, Shez heard the sounds of battle die down as the statues went limp and the phantoms disappeared. 

 

"Huh? Is that it?" Balthus asked, looking around as if he wasn’t covered in scrapes and bruises. 

 

"Don't tell me you want to fight more," Hilda complained with a sigh as she sat down on a large rock. 

 

"Yeah, I'm good," Hapi agreed from atop her horse, petting its mane as she wandered over.

 

"Ah, the stone is glowing!" Petra suddenly exclaimed, pointing behind Shez, which got the mercenary to turn around and look at the cliff. On the stone, four crests began to glow, before the rock crumbled, revealing a hole in between them. 

 

Walking over, Shez immediately reached into the hole. 

 

"Partner, please at least be cautious when it comes to mysterious holes," Arval muttered, only for Shez to cheer as she brought out a chalice. 

 

"Woo! Guess you can add relic hunter to my list of achievements!" 

 

"Well, sounds like you're having fun," Yuri commented with a smirk, "Though are we sure it's the right item?" 

 

"Oh sure it's totally the… uh…" 

 

"The Chalice of Beginnings, and at the very least it's a highly magical relic," Arval chimed in.

 

"Yeah, it's the chalice!" Shez said with a grin. 

 

"Well I can't say for certain," Lindhart started, "But I think if we found a chalice hidden behind a barrier decorated with the Crests of the Four Apostles, guarded by golems that bore the Crest of Seiros, underneath the monastery…well I think it's safe to assume." 

 

"Nice! In that case, let's go!" Shez declared, beginning the march back to Abyss. 

 

"Well someone is in a hurry," 

 

"The sooner we are returning, the sooner we can help the professor," Petra said as she moved to catch up with Shez. 

 

"It’s a good point. And if nothing else, we should hurry back before it gets too dark," Dimitri added.

 

"Yeah, that'd probably be for the best. Come on, Coco," Hapi called to her friend as she urged her horse to walk back to the tunnel, before pausing as the statues began to make a whirring noise. 

 

"Huh?" Blinking in confusion, Hilda looked up at the statues, before shrieking as they suddenly started going wild. "Wh-What the heck!? I thought we won already!" 

 

"Guess we gotta fight some more!" Shez exclaimed, making an immediate about face with a bright grin. 

 

"Ha! I was hoping to beat up some of these things!" Balthus yelled, until some nearby crashing of trees got everyone's attention as they saw a much larger statue emerging. "...Well shit." 

 

"Ha, what's the problem big guy? Are you starting to–" was all Shez could say before she got scooped up by Balthus while he and everyone else began to run back to the tunnels. "Hey!"

 

"As the Intelligent King of Grappling, I say we save the fighting for when we aren't facing a giant!" 

 

"Balthie I think that's the smartest thing you've said in your life!" Hilda shouted, surprisingly keeping pace with the much taller guy. 

 

"Hey I've said plenty of smart things! Like the time I outwitted a bounty hunter by–!" 

 

"I'm sure you can tell us all that fascinating story when we aren't in mortal peril!" Yuri shouted over the crashing noises of the statues chasing them. 

 

"We're almost to the tunnel, they won't be able to fit through the doorway!" Dimitri shouted when they almost reached their goal. 

 

"You better not jinx us your highness!" Claude responded as he ducked into the tunnel. 

 

"If need be you can leave me behind to distract them," Coco offered, which made Shez think it was a good thing the blonde was on a pegasus with better survival instincts than her. Thankfully, her personality went back to normal as the steed dived into the tunnel. "Ah, move quickly! The genius of the Nuvelle House cannot perish here!" 

 

"Ugh, why did I agree to this…" Lindhart muttered as he entered last, breathing heavily. 

 

"Cause of this thing?" Holding up the Chalice, Shez grinned. "Now come on, we gotta-"

 

A loud crash got their attention as the group looked back towards the entrance and saw one of the statues crash into it, cracks forming around the doorway. 

 

"...I told you not to jinx us," Claude said as the massive statue backed up to ram again. 

 

"Every cute lady for herself!" Hilda shouted as she began to run again. Which was probably for the best as moments later the statue rammed in hard enough to break through the wall. 

 

“Ooo, wow, these gold ones are strong,” Shez marveled. If she was being honest, a sight like that was even kind of intimidating. But it also made her really want to try taking it on… “Hey, Yuri!”

 

“Is now really the best time to talk–” Yuri blinked as his hands moved on reflex to catch the chalice Shez just threw at him. “...What?”

 

“Hold that for me!”

 

“Partner, this is a terrible idea,” Arval warned as Shez turned to the golem with a grin, summoning her sword and pointing it at the big metal monstrosity. 

 

“HEY BIG GUY! YOU GOT A NAME?”

 

“Shez, what are you doing?!” Dimitri exclaimed while Claude stared at his reckless friend in baffled exasperation.

 

“I don’t think a giant statue is going to have a–”

 

“Agarthan weaponry detected. Response Selected: I bear the name Marcelle,” the golem answered, before twirling a golden spear in its twisty hand as it shone with a holy light,  “And your soul shall join all those who dared to profane these sacred grounds!”

 

“Oh, big gal, not a big guy. Gotcha!” Shez replied, before shifting away from the blast of golden light and darting in close to score a cut across the big golden lady’s lion chest. Which was very hard to cut through with her standard sword, but surprisingly easier with her magic sword, which kinda made sense? Magic sword probably was made of better stuff than her regular steel.

 

Hm, now that she thought about it, what was her sword made out of? As she considered that question, Shez shifted around Marcelle to slash at the Lion Lady's back, then looked at everyone else. 

 

"What are you waiting for? I'll catch up later!" she shouted, still cutting at the giant golden golem all the while.

 

"Ah, I am not thinking the professor will be happy if we leave her," Petra noted, drawing her sword again.

 

"And I am not leaving her to fend for herself!"  Dimitri shouted as he brandished his spear. 

 

"Ha! In that case!" Grinning, Balthus rushed forward, jumping up into the air and slamming his fist into the helm of Marcelle. "Bet you I can take this thing out first!" 

 

"You're on!" Shez shouted back with her own grin. 

 

"They can't be serious…" Lindhart muttered in exasperation as Dedue rushed forward without a word to aid Dimitri. 

 

"Ohohoho! Do not think I shall let this chance to show off the ingenuity of House Nuvelle slip by!" Grabbing onto the reigns of her pegasus, Constance flew towards the battle, readying her own spell as she did. 

 

"Great, they're all idiots…" Holding back a sigh, Hapi watched as the students fought Marcelle, the mages among them hitting the golden golem with blasts of magic while the melee fighters either went for direct strikes or moved to the statue’s blindspots. 

 

"Guess she fits right in with us," Yuri noted, watching Shez fight alongside his classmates with some weary amusement.

 

"Ah, there they are!" Blinking, Yuri turned around and found a group of mercenaries standing nearby. "There it is! The boss was right, that purple-haired girl has the treasure thing!" 

 

"..." Yuri began to silently curse Aelfric for making things more difficult for him. That, and his hair was lavender, not just ‘purple’.

 

"How the hell did they find out about the Chalice?" Claude asked as he drew an arrow. 

 

"I don't think that matters right now," Hilda grumbled, letting out a sigh as she brandished her axe, “I should have argued harder to stay behind…”

 

“I couldn’t agree more,” Linhardt muttered, stepping next to Hapi…or more accurately putting his fellow mage and her horse in between him and the mercenaries.

 

“Well at least I found some kindred spirits,” the redhead muttered before another battle began in the underground, this time between the backline and the bandits flanking them. Which was slightly easier than dealing with the golden golem, though the bandit brawlers still put up a decent fight.

 

“Ahahaha! Foolish statue, you are no match for the mystical might of–Eep!” Constance squeaked as her pegasus reared back to avoid catching a spear of light in the side, “H-How rude! You could at least let me finish!”

 

“Interlopers shall not be tolerated,” Marcelle rumbled, her chest cracked and the metal that made up her body visibly denting and tarnishing under the student’s onslaught, “Thieves. Descrators. Allies of the Great Enemy. You shall all perish.”

 

“‘Great Enemy’?” Dimitri muttered, a frown coming to his face, before grimacing as Dedue stepped in front of him to catch a spear strike on his shield, “Ah, thank you, Dedue!”

 

“It’s fine, your highness! Just keep behind me!”

 

“Great work, Dedue! Just keep Marcelle focused on you!” Shez shouted, before shifting into her awakened form and hopping up the golem’s spiky body to stab her magic sword straight into the Lion Lady’s throat, piercing into metal instead of flesh. It still made the giant stiffen and twitch like someone who had been stabbed in the neck, so Shez was pretty sure she dealt a solid blow there. “Heh, sorry about that, Lion Lady, but I’m pretty sure we need this chalice more than you do.”

 

The golem twitched again before it seemed to focus on Shez. “A-A-A-Al-lert. En-nemy Iden-Iden-Identified. Agarthan S-S-S-Sorcerer, Pri-Pri-Priority One. Zanado shall be avenged–”

 

Shez blinked as the whole thing seemed to lock up, steam spilling from between its joints. “Eh? What was–”

 

“Partner, move!”

 

Arval didn’t normally shout, so Shez was already off the shoulder the instant their words registered. Which was a good thing, given a massive beam of light neatly seared through where she was just standing, taking a good chunk of Marcelle’s shoulder with it.

 

“Ah, hey! What was–Oh shit.”

 

Even Shez could feel her bravado fade when she saw the other golden golem from outside making its way into the catacombs, alongside what seemed to be a squadron of lesser stone golems, all of whom seemed to be focused on her. “Ah…Right! We’re running now.”

 

“...Yes, we are,” Dimitri agreed, slowly backing up before he noticed Marcelle turn her head in his direction, still apparently active and ready to fight, “...Shez, what in the world did you say to them?”

 

“Uhhh…not sure.” She paused, then raised a hand in greeting towards the other Lion Lady. “Hey, do you have a name too?”

 

“Shez!”

 

“What?? I’m curious! She seems important!” And the only response Shez got in response was another massive beam of light from the new Lion Lady, who barely missed thanks to being damaged. "Right, running!" 

 

Not waiting another moment, Shez began to run, leading the group that were fighting against Marcelle to where everyone else was fighting bandits. 

 

"Hey, Boss, we're getting out of here!" Balthus shouted, as he rushed past Yuri, shoulder checking the bandit Yuri was fighting. 

 

"Finally," Yuri huffed, before he began to run. 

 

"Tallyforth comrades!" Constance shouted, sending a small barrage of spells at the bandits to get them to back off enough for everyone to start running. 

 

"Hey, get back here!" one of the bandits shouted, not noticing the golems approaching them. 

 

"Th-Th-Thieves, all-allies of the d-desecrators!" Marcelle declared as they descended on the bandits. 

 

"Guess it was a good thing those bandits showed up," Yuri noted as screams of pain and several bloody breaking noises were heard from the tunnel behind them.  

 

"Indeed. Those beings are not hitting two birds with one arrow," Petra agreed, getting Yuri to let out an amused huff. 

 

"Yeah but those things are going to still try to chase us down later, right?" Hapi asked. 

 

"Oh, idea!" Grinning, Shez turned around, and brought her hand up as she got a spell ready. 

 

"Uh, Shez, what are you doing?" 

 

"Something smart!"

 

"Something really stupid," Arval muttered. 

 

Ignoring her partner's words, Shez began to form several Dark Spikes that shot out, stabbing into the walls and ceiling behind them. 

 

"Uh, is that safe-" Before Hilda could finish her question, the spikes exploded. Almost immediately a plume of dust flew towards the group, making them cough heavily before Lindhart was able to clear the air with a spell. What was once an open tunnel was now collapsed, nary an opening in the rubble. 

 

"There we go!" 

 

"...Thank you, Shez, but perhaps you could warn us next time?" Dimitri asked. 

 

“Yeah, I’m pretty sure we’d all appreciate a heads up before you cause a cave in,” Claude commented.

 

"Eh, it's fine, I made sure not to shoot near us," Shez responded, "Now come on, we gotta go! Yuri, you still got the chalice, right?" 

 

"Do you think I would have lost it after all that?" he asked, somewhat amused as he held up the Chalice. 

 

"Never hurts to make sure!"

 

"Quite right, and with the Chalice surely I am a step closer to restoring my house!” Constance added, “Why I'm sure Edelgard is practically waiting for me to return with it!" 

 

Shez gave her a side-eye. "I’m pretty sure she's probably busy making sure By is okay, actually." 

 

"Oh there is no need for that, your sister is still asleep." 

 

"Huh? I mean, it's been a few hours so I'm sure she's awake." 

 

"If I did not cast a sleep spell on her, she likely would be." 

 

"...What?" 

 

"Surely you understand! That poor girl looked absolutely exhausted! Trust me, that spell will ensure she has some proper rest and will wake up completely refreshed!" Constance boasted. 

 

"Huh. Well, if you say so," Shez muttered. She could admit that By looked like she needed her rest, though it still sounded inconvenient. Well, hopefully Byleth was awake by the time she got back.

“WHAT DO YOU MEAN THEY TOOK BYLETH!?”

 

Edelgard met Shez’s enraged gaze with a composed stare. She showed no hint of pain despite Shez’s shout being loud enough that she was confident everyone in Abyss had heard it. A part of her idly noted this was the first time she had seen the possible Agarthan’s “awakened form” this close to her, and that it was a decent sign that her emotions were genuine. “I mean what I said. While you were gone, bandits attacked Abyss. I went out to deal with them, but apparently more attacked Leonie and Ashe while I was gone and escaped with the professor.”

 

"HOW ARE YOU BEING SO CALM!?" Shez shouted again. 

 

"I've had nearly an hour to collect my thoughts," Edelgard responded, her hands clenched behind her back, "Including what seems to be their demands." 

 

Saying this, Edelgard held out a parchment, which Shez immediately snatched away. 

 

Quickly, Shez began to scan the paper to see what they wanted. 

 

‘We have abducted Cardinal Aelfric and the girl. We can guarantee their safety, for now. If you want to help them, meet us tomorrow evening in the ruins of the old chapel. Bring the chalice. Know that if you alert the knights, their lives will be forfeit.’

 

"...They want the chalice in exchange for Aelfric and Byleth." 

 

"What? They have Aelfric too?" Balthus asked in surprise. 

 

Taking in a small breath, Shez let go of the paper before walking over to Yuri. "Hand it over." 

 

"Excuse-"

 

"Hand the Chalice over. Now." 

 

"Uh, not that I'm disagreeing with you Shez, but we do have to have a plan," Claude spoke up, before stiffening slightly as Shez glared at him for a moment. 

 

"The plan is to hand the chalice over and save my sister." 

 

"And we need to wait till tomorrow to do so. We don't know where the bandits are hiding," Edelgard pointed, keeping steady as Shez glared at her. "It also said not to inform the knights but…I doubt we can keep the disappearance of a Cardinal and the professor a secret." 

 

"At the very least we must inform Lady Rhea," Dimitri stated, "Even if the Knights don't get involved, surely she can provide some help." 

 

"..." Letting out a frustrated noise, Shez tried to calm herself down. "...how are Ashe and Leonie?" 

 

"Recovering, apparently the bandits had orders to not kill any of the students. Which begs the question of how they knew there were students down here." 

 

"Huh? Didn't we fight some mercenaries before? Of course they'd know we're down here," Hilda said. 

 

"We didn't leave any of those mercenaries alive. There was no way for word to spread." 

 

"They also apparently knew Aelfric is a Cardinal," Lindhart said, reading the fallen paper. "That's supposed to be a well kept secret in the church. So whoever these people are working for is well connected." 

 

…Grumbling to herself as the students began to plan, Shez walked off. Despite the fight she had just been in, she was feeling restless again, and wanted to hit something again. 

 

"Shez?" Turning around, Shez found Edelgard following her. 

 

"What do you want?" 

 

"...I understand any apologies I have may ring hollow, but even so, you trusted me to keep the professor safe, and I failed you. However, I swear to you that I will make sure we save her." 

 

"..." Shez sighed, trying not to snap at her. 

 

"I also might…have an idea of who took the professor." 

 

"Huh?! You do?!" 

 

"Yes. The mercenaries mentioned a cult, and there were a group of dark mages working with them. While I cannot be certain, I've had to deal with a cult like that in the past. No matter what, I will not let those people harm her." 

 

"..." Shez scratched the back of her head. "Look, no offense, but it’s kinda hard to take you on your word with what happened." 

 

"I understand that. I would honestly be surprised if you did. Were I in your situation, I likely would have gone charging off on my own." 

 

"Hm. That’s weird. I dunno why, but something about you reminds me of By," 

 

"I do?" 

 

"Yeah, both of you are pretty clumsy with your emotions," Shez teased, with a small grin to show she was joking, "And you both get attached to people easily." 

 

"Shez, this better not be another attempt to mock me." 

 

"It's not. I'm just saying, you're hiding it well, but you're pretty angry right now aren't you?" 

 

"I don't know what you mean," Edelgard responded, before Shez pointed down at her hands. Glancing down, Edelgard noticed that the palms of her gloves were stained with blood thanks to how hard she was clenching her fists. 

 

"Must have not noticed, huh?" Shez asked. 

 

"...That I did not," Edelgard responded. 

 

"You should make sure to get someone to check that," Shez advised, "For now though… I'm going to try and get some sleep." 

 

"Yes, that sounds for the best," Edelgard agreed with a nod, "I'll make sure to tell you what we're going to do." 

 

"Thanks, Edelgard." 

 

Watching her walk off, Edelgard took in a quick breath. She needed to send a message soon, before anything could happen.

Slowly drifting awake, Byleth became aware of two things immediately. The first being she was sitting up against a wall rather than a bed. The second being that she was currently tied up. 

 

Snapping fully awake as the second of those facts set in, Byleth tried to break free of the rope. Though that was easier said than done given that she was missing her weapons and also had a Silence spell cast on her so her magic couldn't work. Looking around, she realized she was something that looked like a former storage room, some broken shelves nearby being the only thing in there with her. 

 

"-ould you bring the wrong girl!" Blinking as she heard Aelfric's voice, Byleth stopped moving as she tried to listen in to what was happening.

 

"Hey, my men listened to your orders! You told us to bring the sleeping girl, and we did!" Someone shouted back. 

 

"And I specified a green-haired woman!" 

 

"Teal is a type of green!" At that, Aelfric let out an aggravated sigh. 

 

"No matter, we can get Sitri later. As long as we get the Chalice then the plan can continue." At the mention of her mom's name, Byleth began to struggle again as she let out a muffled shout. "..." 

 

Moments later, the door to the room opened, and Aelfric stood at the doorway. 

 

"Mng!" Byleth tried to shout at him as she struggled. 

 

"...You have to understand, I didn't mean for things to go like this. You just need to play along for a bit. Once I have the chalice, then I can bring Sitri back." The cardinal smiled as best he could. It looked more like a strained rictus. “You’ll have your mother back. I know she’ll be happy to see you. I just need a little more time.”

 

Byleth stared at him. It was strange. Aelfric should look completely insane, spouting lines like that, but he looked and sounded the same as he had when he talked to her beside her mother’s grave. 

 

Somehow…that was scarier.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Shez Eisner and the Chalice of Beginnings, coming to your local library!

Red: It has everything! Big fights! Evil cardinals! Kidnapped sisters! An adventure for all ages!

Indi: Speaking of kidnapped sisters, Byleth sure is having a time with her accidental kidnapping. Turns out these bandits need you to be very specific with colors.

Red: Seriously, they got it wrong twice. First with the green hair, then with the purple hair. They're bad at their jobs.

Indi: At least with Yuri he actually had the chalice. They just completely botched it with Byleth

Red: Colorblind bandits aside, hope you all enjoyed our second chapter of the new year! There'll be many more to come!

Indi: That there will be, hope y'all stick around!

Verrat

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

As night descended upon Garreg Mach, so did the Flame Emperor as she waited at the outskirts of the monastery. It was dangerous, what she was doing. Being the one to initiate contact with Those Who Slither could be taken as a sign she was willing to work with them more than she already had. If she wasn't careful, they might try pushing for more…

 

"I must say, I didn't expect to come out here because you asked me to," Bias said after she appeared in a flash of magic, a mocking tone to her voice. 

 

"...I have the information you wished to know. I felt it only appropriate to inform you of it," the Flame Emperor responded, getting Bias to stiffen before leaning forward with an impatient eagerness.

 

"Well? Out with it, tell me!" 

 

"Jeralt’s Mercenaries were not in the Oghma Mountains five years ago. By that time, they had already entered Faerghus territory," she lied, keeping her tone even, aided by the distortion her mask provided. 

 

"What!? That's impossible, she had to have been there!" Bias shouted, which really wasn’t conducive to keeping their meeting secret, "How do you know she didn't lie to you!?"

 

"I asked her sister. Professor Byleth would have no reason to keep where she was a secret. As it stands, there is little chance they are the ones you are seeking." 

 

"..." Letting out a frustrated growl, Bias vented her frustrations by shoving her hand against a nearby rock jutting out of the ground. It seemed she remembered she shouldn’t draw attention, though the fact that the rock began to melt where her hand touched gave Edelgard a good indication of just how enraged the sage was. That, and the level of power she appeared to have.

 

"...There is something else I require from you,” she said, catching the sage’s attention again, “Are you involved with the plot happening in Abyss?" 

 

"What?" Bias asked after she calmed down, "That dingy town? What would I want to do with that?" 

 

"So you are aware of the town then?”

 

“Ugh, as though I wouldn’t be. It’s too close to the monastery to be a decent source of testing materials though, so Solon wrote it off.”

 

“I see. And you’re not involved with what is happening down there?”

 

"I would need to know what is actually happening to be involved," Bias said with a scoff. 

 

"...Very well, I shall take you on your word." 

 

“You do that…So that’s it? She can’t have been there?” She stared at Edelgard, her agitation obvious even with her face concealed. “And you’re sure of that?”

 

“I am completely sure,” the Flame Emperor replied.

 

“...Bah. Fine. I’ll find my own answers.”

 

The Flame Emperor watched Bias stomp away, agitation obvious in every step. She considered the possible benefits she may have just lost out on, what she could have gained by simply giving the sage the answer she wanted, but…

 

She shook the thought off. She made her choice already; there was no taking it back and it would be a waste of time to dwell on it.

 

Once she arrived back at an appropriate location, Edelgard began to remove her armor. While she did, she began to think about what Bias had said to her. 

 

If the bandit attacks and Byleth’s abduction weren’t a plot by the Slitherers then who was behind it all? The existence of the cardinals was something only the upper echelons of the Central Church should know, so was there a schism within the church that led to Aelfric’s abduction? For that matter, why would they also take the professor as well? It would be one thing to take the relic weapon, but to kidnap Byleth too… 

 

Unless…that wasn't the initial plan. If the perpetrators had knowledge of the Cardinal, then surely they would know who the professor was. In that case, why wasn't her name specified on the paper?

 

Blinking, Edelgard came to a sudden realization. 

 

The mercenaries had already known about her, Ashe, and Leonie being present in Abyss, and the fire was an attempt to distract them. However, there was no need for the mercenaries to distract the students if they already had the cardinal in their grasp. Even more so since they had nothing to gain from kidnapping Byleth…unless she wasn't their actual target. 

 

If the perpetrator had just demanded the Chalice, it would greatly narrow down who could have told the mercenaries of Aelfric’s status. Yet, if they were after Sitri , rather than Byleth, then their knowledge of her existence further narrowed the possibilities down. And if that supposition was accurate, then it was remarkably obvious who the perpetrator had to be.

 

Edelgard scowled. If the Cardinal thought he could play them like fools, then she would play along, for now. But he was mistaken if he thought he could get away with this.

Rhea had lived a very long time. She’d seen things the majority of humanity would regard as impossible, and done things that would shake the foundation of the entire continent, were they to become known. 

 

Even then though, she found herself almost constantly stymied and baffled by humankind and the absolute nonsense they would get up to.

 

“...” She looked at Alois, who was standing at attention. Then she looked at the students gathered in front of her, of which there were a shockingly large number crowding her audience chamber. She did not look at Seteth, because she had honestly hoped he wouldn’t be present for this kind of conversation for a number of reasons, and she idly sent a small prayer to her mother than Jeralt wouldn’t find out about his youngest daughter’s “adventure” before she managed to settle things. “...To be clear, Miss Eisner, your sister, Professor Byleth, was abducted by mercenaries hired by an unknown cult in order to claim a mysterious, ancient relic known as the Chalice of Beginnings.”

 

“YES! Do I need to repeat everything for you?! You have working ears, right?!” the young woman complained, which Rhea decided to allow because she was obviously distressed.

 

“Miss Eisner! Mind your words in the archbishop’s presence!” Seteth, however, had no such sympathy.

 

“Oh, my mistake, I actually meant to say shove it up your– ”

 

Dimitri put a hand on Shez’s shoulder at the same time Claude put a hand over her mouth. “Please, pardon Shez’s words, Lady Rhea. She’s very distressed by her sister’s disappearance.”

 

“Yeah, she’s not taking it great,” Claude added, then moved his hand before Shez could bite it.

 

"You really should be careful partner, less they decide to hold you in a cell for attacking someone of importance," Arval advised, unheard by anyone besides Shez, who settled back, still irritated but trying her best to stay calm.

 

“Not to worry, children, I take no offense. It is entirely understandable that young Shez would be worried for her sister,” Rhea replied with appropriate magnanimity as she tried not to show any hint of her own internal turmoil. Along with attempting to ignore the pink wyvern in the room…Or, well, green wyvern, as the case may be.

 

To think they would find Sitri down there…She really should have gotten a coffin for her, at the very least, but the fire happened and Jeralt vanished and she never got around to it…A part of her idly wondered if she could fully put the blame on Aelfric so that Jeralt wouldn't murder her. 

 

Goddess, her thoughts were morbid these days…

 

Now, certainly, from the outside, it looked as though Aelfric had been abducted along with Byleth but she didn’t believe that for a second. To think, she made Aelfric a cardinal and yet he never bothered to come to the meetings even once. How was she supposed to induct someone into her inner circle if they didn’t bother to show up??

 

"For now, I think it would be best to leave this to the knights." 

 

"Pardon me, Lady Rhea," Constance said, speaking up, "But for the sake of those taken, I believe it would be best to not have the knights involved given their letter explicitly said to not involve them." 

 

"It would be for the best to at least make it seem we're playing along," Yuri noted. 

 

"Yeah, and besides, Shezster is strong, so she'll probably be more helpful than any knight," Hapi commented, which did earn a frown from Seteth and a slight pout from Alois. 

 

"Yeah, she might not be as strong as me, but she definitely has the speed to make up for it." Balthus added in. 

 

"...Very well, I understand where you're coming from,” Rhea decided, “I shall allow you to act, and use the Chalice as you should require." 

 

And that, as expected, earned Seteth’s ire. "Lady Rhea, you can't be serious!" 

 

"I am. Seteth, you must understand how poorly things will go if we do not listen to their demand of leaving the knights out of this. Not only do we risk the lives of Professor Byleth and Cardinal Aelfric, but we may also lose the Sword of the Creator." 

 

“But you’re talking about sending students to deal with people willing to abduct a cardinal! Who knows what they could be capable of!?”

 

Rhea did her best to avoid pointing out the majority of her cardinals just worked menial jobs around the monastery outside of their gatherings. It wouldn’t do to let slip to the students that the head cook was actually important to the politics of the church…

 

Shez, thankfully, directed attention away from that potential gaffe by scoffing. “Oh come on, I fought a giant lion lady yesterday, I can handle a bunch of sister-stealing bandits.”

 

Seteth blinked. His internal conflict was visible as he tried to decide if he should ask or let that be, before deciding on asking, which was good for Rhea because she was both curious and concerned. “‘Giant lion lady’?”

 

“Yeah, you know, the big statue people. Their leaders are gold and have lions on their chests. Oh, and the one I fought is named Marcelle, she told me that.”

 

…why in the world would Marcelle give a student its name? Rhea wondered, before discarding that thought as, hopefully, irrelevant. She briefly considered going down and talking to the golems, but dismissed that thought too as not being worth the effort. It would take the good part of a day and she really had too many things on her plate already to investigate something that was bound to be pointless anyway. “I am afraid I know little of what you speak of, child. The monastery is ancient and its mysteries are vast. Some tales speak of ancient guardians, though I think it holds little relevance to our current crisis.”

 

“Ah, right, Byleth is more important! So can we get to saving her already!?”

 

"Before that, we must make sure we're fully prepared," Yuri said, "We don't know what exactly these men are planning, so having a plan of attack would help make sure neither of them are hurt." 

 

"...Geh, fine. But the moment the plan is ready, we're going!" 

 

"Of course. Though, if I may, I would like to speak to Yuri alone," Rhea requested, looking at the leader of the Wolves, "So if you would all leave, I would appreciate it. That includes you, Seteth." 

 

Despite her kind tone of voice, it was clear Rhea wasn't going to argue this. 

 

“Oh? Why only Yuri–” But of course someone had to push it.

 

“That wasn’t an invitation to ask questions, Claude.”

 

"...very well. Do try to be quick about it," Seteth said to Yuri, before bowing to her and escorting the students and Alois out. He had to actively steer Claude out, which was a mildly amusing sight. 

 

"Well, it seems we're in quite the sticky situation." Yuri said once they were alone. 

 

"That we are…to think Aelfric was after the Chalice of Beginnings…" 

 

"And it's easy to guess what he's planning. I don't suppose you'll mind telling me why exactly our mercenary friend’s mother was in the Abyss like that?" 

 

"...” Rhea sighed, cursing her own past indolence. There were a great many things she should have handled, but never did. “I had Sitri entombed down in the Abyss after her passing. I know Aelfric was close to her, but I did not know he would actually try to revive her." 

 

"And sacrifice the Wolves in the process." 

 

"...I shall have my knights act quickly, while you handle Aelfric." 

 

"Of course, thank you, Lady Rhea. Though I can't help but wonder what our dear Aelfric is planning. We still have Sitri's body so clearly he must know he can't revive her that easily." 

 

"Yes, it shouldn’t be possible for him to do anything…” Still, memories of her own past failure rose up, unbidden, in her mind anyway. She frowned, thinking back to a screech of a monstrosity that should not have been. “Hopefully, we can end this before anyone gets hurt."

Silently sawing away at the rope binding her arms with a broken piece of a shelf, Byleth felt a small twinge of annoyance at how thick the rope was. It also didn't help that Aelfric kept coming in to cast a Silence on her to make sure she couldn't use her magic. 

 

"One would think he would at least treat you more kindly," Sothis muttered as she appeared next to her. "He's doing this all for your mother, yet he hardly seems to be paying attention to you." 

 

Huffing into her gag, Byleth could feel the rope start to give way, just a bit longer…Pausing, she looked up to see the door open, Aelfric walking inside holding a tray of food. 

 

"Here you go, it's not much, but you should still make sure to eat," Aelfric said, setting the tray down by her and removing her gag. "I'm sorry for all-" 

 

"Why are you doing this?" Byleth asked, glaring at him. 

 

"I…did you not hear me before? So that Sitri can return to us." 

 

"You didn't even know I was here until recently. You were just doing this for yourself." 

 

"I-!" Aelfric cut himself off before his anger could rise too far. "...it's fine if you don't understand. Things will be better when she is back. I'll have the chalice and the blood of the four apostles, so all shall be well." 

 

"...The Apostles?" 

 

"Ah, that's right, you didn't hear about that. The Chalice is supposed to be used in a ritual using the blood of the apostles to bring someone back to life. They tried this before in the past, long ago. It's my belief that they simply did not use enough blood." 

 

"What?" Byleth looked at him in confusion before something clicked in her mind. "...The Ashen Wolves." 

 

"...yes, it will be a tragedy, but one that cannot be avoided." 

 

"That…you're going to kill them? To try and revive my mom?"

 

"Of course. I would do anything for your mother. Surely you and Captain Jeralt must agree with me." 

 

"..." Byleth felt a sense of dread build up in her as she stared at the man who claimed to be a friend of her mother and father. "...You're insane." 

 

"..." Aelfric let out a sigh. "It's okay that you don't understand. You never met her, so you don't have a desire to bring her back. It's almost sad when you think about it. That I care more about Sitri than her own daughter." 

 

Despite herself, Byleth couldn't help but try to move away from him. 

 

She steadied herself though, trying to keep calm. "...I might not know her, but even I can tell she would never forgive you if you did this." 

 

"It doesn't matter if she forgives me or not." Aelfric said, even as he frowned. 

 

"But you're still going to put that guilt on her!” she yelled, a sudden anger rising up, “Everyone who gets hurt or dies because of your plan would be something she'd have to live with!" 

 

"Why don't you understand! Things will be better with her here–gah!" In one quick motion, Byleth brought her legs up to kick Aelfric straight in the chest when he tried to approach her. Crashing to the floor, the cardinal gasped for breath before pushing himself up with a pained wheeze. 

 

"You-..." Cutting himself off again, Aelfric took in a deep breath. "...You'll be freed once everything is over. Until then, you'll remain here." 

 

Getting up, Aelfric cast another Silence on her again, before walking out. 

 

Taking a moment once she was alone, Byleth tried to settle her nerves. She wasn't sure how Aelfric could have ended up like this, but she wasn't going to let him succeed in his plans. 

 

"Well, he certainly made a mistake," Sothis commented with a smirk, before pointing over at the tray of food Aelfric had left behind. More specifically, at the knife that was on the tray. 

 

"Hm. That's useful." Shifting her position, Byleth began to crawl over as best as she could, aiming to grab the knife. 

 

"But honestly, what could that man be thinking? Those who have already passed away should remain as such. Trying to bring someone back will just cause undue sorrow to the one that can't accept their passing," Sothis muttered as Byleth began to cut the ropes. 

 

"Let's just make sure he doesn't cause the death of anyone else," Byleth responded. Even if a small part of her did want to meet her mother, to get to know the woman who brought her into this world, there was no way she’d let anyone be hurt for it to happen.

Fidgeting slightly as they made their way to the abandoned chapels, Shez kept a hand resting on her sword. She wanted to rush on ahead, but she also knew that could put Byleth in danger. 

 

"A word of warning," Edelgard said, walking alongside Shez. "Keep an eye on Aelfric." 

 

"Huh? What are you talking about?" 

 

"Call it intuition, but just keep an eye on him," Edelgard continued, before moving away from her, leaving Shez a bit confused. 

 

"She is right, there is something suspicious about him," Arval added, "He was definitely hiding something when we interacted with him back in the Abyss." 

 

"That's obvious…" Shez muttered, before pausing as Constance approached her, her eyes downcast. 

 

"Before we arrive, I once again offer my words of sincere apologies, even if they are worth nothing." 

 

"...Constance, you really don't need to apologize so often. You didn't know what was going to happen." 

 

"Even so, if need be, I will throw away my meager life so your sister and Aelfric return alive." 

 

"Hey now, no throwing away your life, Shady Lady," Yuri interjected. "We're all making it out of here alive, okay?" 

 

"Yeah, the booze at the party after this is gonna taste bad if any of us die!" 

 

"There's gonna be a party?" Hapi asked as she glanced at Balthus. 

 

"Of course! I mean hey, we found a relic and are going to save two people, so we might as well celebrate!" 

 

"Fair enough." 

 

Letting out an amused huff, Shez found her nerves calming down a bit as they arrived at the meeting place to find a group of mercenaries staring them down. The leader of whom, a skinny, brown-haired guy, was not only holding Aelfric, but had the Sword of the Creator at his waist. 

 

"HaHaHa! You certainly took-" 

 

"Hey you son of a bitch, where's my sister!?" Shez cut him off as she glared at the bandit boss. 

 

"Huh? Who the hell are you?" the leader questioned, scowling at her. 

 

"Shez Eisner, the sister of the person you kidnapped, and the merc who's gonna murder you if you don't bring her out here!"
