"The message said you would exchange both the cardinal and the professor in exchange for the chalice, but as far as we see you are reneging on the deal," Dimitri stated. 

 

"What? You can't hand the chalice over to them, it's irreplaceable!" Aelfric shouted. 

 

Shez scowled. "So is Byleth, and so the deal isn't happening until you bring her out!" 

 

"And what's to stop us from just killing all of you if you don't hand it over?" the leader asked with a smirk. "I don't know if you can tell, but I have a bonafide relic weapon here!" 

 

"One that doesn't have a crest stone in it, which means it's practically useless outside of Teach's hands." Calling his bluff, Claude smirked in return, which made the lead merc bristle. 

 

"Regardless of how strong you think you are, you can't seriously imagine being able to outrun the knights forever if you kill several students and a cardinal," Edelgard taunted. 

 

"Ha! As if the Great Metodey is afraid of the knights!" 

 

"Well, good thing we have our own plan," Yuri said. Though before he could give the signal, a sharp whistling sound could be heard. At the sound, Shez immediately smirked.

 

"Huh? Who the fuck is making that noise?" Metodey asked with a scowl. Though before he could find the source, he let out a scream of pain as a knife was thrown into his arm. Letting go of Aelfric as he screamed, Shez appeared in front of Metodey, shoved the cardinal back, and slashed him across the chest. “GAH! K-Kill them! KILL ALL OF THEM!”

 

Shez would have kept going to cut the boss’s head off, but she was too busy dodging back as the other bandits charged in with axes and a number of them all around the valley started popping up. “Jeez, where do these guys find each other?! We’ve killed so many of your men and you’ve got like a hundred more!”

 

“I-It’s called having backing, you stupid bitch!” Metodey yelled back, clutching at the cut across his chest as he let a pair of better armored mercs step in front of him. Some of his earlier confidence returned as the rest of the Academy brats suddenly had to deal with his reinforcements and he sneered at the violet-haired student. “And now, thanks to you, the cardinal dies–!”

 

Then he heard, of all things, a sigh. Which wouldn’t really be enough to catch his attention, were it not for the sudden *fwump* noise he heard behind him and the shadow that seemed to block out the sun. Then he turned around and saw the giant bird regarding him with a hungry eye. “...well that’s just not fair at all.”

 

The bird did not care, and it was only a well-timed leap backward, along with a shove to his subordinate’s back, that got Metodey out of the way as the bird’s beak snapped down, lifting the screaming merc up as it tried to crack through the steel armor. Fortunately for the mercenary, his armor was strong enough to keep him alive.

 

Unfortunately for the mercenary, the annoyed bird had a solution to the oddly tough and screaming nut it was trying to eat, and promptly started smashing it against a nearby rock.

 

Even Metodey couldn’t help but wince at the crunch, though when he turned away, he found that everything else he could see was worse, because apparently the band of students he’d been accosting weren’t a bunch of limp fops that would be easy to push around, but genuine monsters who were absolutely demolishing his goons.

 

“Wha…What are you idiots doing?! It’s just a bunch of noble brats!” he shouted, raising his sword, “Just get in and kill–GAH!”

 

And then he was screaming again because an arrow went through his hand.

 

“Not all of us are nobles!” shouted some orange-haired girl with a bow, which was about as baffling of a statement as Metodey could expect in this situation.

 

“Is now really the time to assert your commonality?” Constance asked, frowning at Leonie.

 

“That’s not the right word,” Yuri commented, prompting a scowl from the pegasus rider before a cloud moved and she bowed her head in apology.

 

“My sincere apologies for my–”

 

“FUCK! MY HAND! I NEED THAT, YOU BRATS!” Metodey snapped, before trying to calm down–Which was extremely difficult when a giant bird just landed nearby, prompting him to beat a hasty retreat from that. “Hm-hm-hm, right, not dealing with that–”

 

“Oh, you up to take me on then?” Shez asked, smirking as the bandit boss flinched back.

 

“Gh–You again! Fhh…fine! I didn’t want to use this with how much I could get from selling it, but I’m not dying to some brat playing knight!” he snapped, before grabbing the relic sword at his waist and drawing it. Metodey sneered again, his confidence returning yet again as he leveled the strange sword at the stupid girl–And then he felt a wrenching sensation as the sword suddenly felt far too heavy and fully dislocated his shoulder with a sickening sound. “...aaaAAAAAAAGH–!”

 

“Eugh. That looks nasty,” Shez muttered as the guy kept screaming.

 

Metodey, meanwhile, was having the worst day. Fortunately for him though, the pain did cut out as a tray smashed into the side of his head hard enough to knock him out.

 

Shez beamed as her sister pulled her sword from the unconscious bandit boss’s mangled hand. “Heh, hey By!”

 

“Hi Shez. Thanks for rescuing me.”

 

Shez beamed, bright and happy to the point that Byleth was pretty sure if she had a tail, she’d be wagging it. “Heh, you’re welcome! Though I’m pretty sure you got loose on your own there.”

 

“Still. Thank you.” She turned, looking out at the chaotic battle unfolding and feeling a faint smile come to her face as she saw all the students working together to cover one another and take down the mix of mercenaries and monsters. “Let’s clean things up here.”

 

“You got it! The Violet Demon and the Ashen Dragon, back on the battlefield together!” Shez declared, sounding downright giddy, “Let’s do it!”

 

“Yeah, shouldn't leave this all up to them,” Byleth agreed, her faint smile fading into her usual stoic appearance, before the two rushed forward. Immediately going into her awakened form, Shez barrelled straight through a group of armored soldiers, sending them flying, before a certain whip-like sword snaked through the gaps in their armor to slice them as they fell. 

 

As the screams of those knights were quickly cut off, the sisters continued their fight, easily moving in sync as they fought together. Despite being the younger sibling, Shez definitely looked the most dangerous with her twin blades and obvious excitement, leading the mercenaries to target Byleth. Which turned out to be a bad idea, as despite being less visibly threatening, she was skilled enough to knock people off their guard with a punch to the face, or a parry of their weapon. Which meant Shez could run in and cut them down, taking every opportunity given by her sister to score another kill.

 

And that was before the Silence wore off and Byleth could bring her magic to bear. Not only did her sword weave and stab, cutting and piercing through whatever foes she had to face, but fire and thunder rained on anyone unlucky enough to be trying to fight her students as she called out orders, coordinating attacks while Shez acted as her primary fighter, darting in to support whoever needed it and absolutely destroying whatever mercenary or bandit tried to get in her way. 

 

The demonic beasts were a little trickier to deal with, but definitely not impossible for the Eisner sisters. Oh, and everyone else, of course. It wasn't long for the battle to come to an end, and for a swell of pride to grow in Byleth as she saw her students unharmed. 

 

Though that quickly faded as she threw her regained dagger, the blade burying itself into the wall next to Aelfric before the cardinal could even speak. 

 

"Hey! What was that for!?" Balthus shouted. 

 

"It seems our professor is well aware of what this man is up to," Edelgard said, raising her axe at Aelfric as she did. A small part of her was, admittedly, somewhat miffed that she couldn’t be the one to reveal the plot she’d figured out, but that was a silly part that she clamped down on with practiced ease. She most definitely did not pout. 

 

"Wh-What are you talking about?" Aelfric asked, as he looked at Byleth, his eyes pleading for her to-

 

"You were going to sacrifice the Ashen Wolves to bring back my mom." Uncaring of his pleading, Byleth began to approach the corrupt cardinal. 

 

"...What?" Hapi asked, staring in confusion. 

 

"Aelfric, my horrid ears must be deceiving me, for what I heard cannot be the truth, right?" Constance asked, some concern cutting through her morose malaise.

 

"O-Of course it isn't! There is no way I would harm my flock!" Aelfric denied.

 

"Really? So it doesn't matter that Lady Rhea has Sitri's body and has buried her already?" Yuri asked. 

 

"What!?" Aelfic felt a flash of anger hit him before he tried to calm himself. 

 

"My mom died when I was born. You need to accept that, Aelfric," Byleth said, leveling her sword at him. 

 

"...Of course you wouldn't want her back. She died giving birth to you, the child who makes no sound," Aelfric muttered as he began to glare at Byleth. "It wasn't just Rhea who killed her, it was you as well, wasn't it!?" 

 

"What the hell is wrong with you!?" Shez shouted, stepping in front of Byleth to glare at Aelfric, “You asshole! You’re the one who stole her body and sent those bandits after your people! They were setting fires down there!”

 

“That doesn’t matter! Everything will be fine once Sitri comes back! But you…” He scowled, glaring at Shez and Byleth before turning his gaze towards Yuri. “You should think very carefully about what you’re doing here.”

 

“I did, ‘boss’. And I decided since Lady Rhea already knows everything and knew you were up to no good from the start, I might as well turn on you now instead of letting your plans continue.” Yuri gave him a mocking grin. "I really should thank you for bringing all your soldiers along, it made saving my people pretty easy." 

 

“You–How dare you…”

 

“‘Saving your people’?” Balthus questioned, glancing at Yuri with a frown, “Hang on Yuri, what’s that supposed to mean?”

 

“It’s supposed to mean our good cardinal here abducted my mother and held my former gang hostage to make sure I would play along with his plan,” Yuri readily explained, “Which included gathering all of you up so you could be sacrificed. Ah, sorry about that, by the way. I was looking for a way out of it, but I was prepared to go as far as I needed if I couldn’t save them ahead of schedule.”

 

“Uh…wow, that’s heavy. Not sure if I should be pissed at you or not.”

 

“It would be a fate befitting a wretch like me,” Constance mumbled while Hapi looked from her friends to Aelfric, a building feeling of betrayal showing through her usual attempts at controlling her emotions.

 

“Elfie…did you seriously…does that mean you were the one that put me down in Abyss…?”

 

“SHUT UP!” Aelfric demanded, glaring back at the Wolves, “Don’t–Don’t look at me like that! I was the one who helped you to begin with! Isn’t it only right that you help me in return!?”

 

“You…You’re talking about murdering them!” Dimitri exclaimed, and Aelfric’s eyes widened as he noticed just how many of the students had gathered, “You cannot call that repayment!”

 

"Yeah, this is pretty underhanded even by my standards," Claude muttered as he kept a hand on an arrow, ready to aim if necessary. 

 

"Aelfric, please, just stop. My mother wouldn't want this," Byleth pleaded as she stepped closer.

 

"What do you even know…" Gritting his teeth, he raised his hand, a sigil already forming. "WHAT DO YOU EVEN KNOW-" 

 

Coughing up blood, Aelfric looked down to see the Sword of the Creator piercing his chest. His arm falling to his side, Aelfric soon fell to his knees. 

 

"..." Pulling her blade free, Byleth stared down at the Cardinal, who looked up at her in return. 

 

"Ah…Sitri…? You… returned to me…" Seeing a small smile on his face, Byleth watched as the light left Aelfric’s eyes as he slumped over. 

 

Unable to look away, Byleth felt… something uncomfortable as she started down at the man, wondering just how someone could look at peace after dying. Feeling a hand on her shoulder, she looked over to see Shez standing behind her. 

 

"Let's go back, By." 

 

"..." Nodding in response, Byleth turned away, drawing an end to this story.

Chapter End Notes

Red: I wonder how many of you thought we'd have the whole Umbral Beast fight? Because we actually did have plans for it until things took a turn and we decided to cut Aelfric off in the middle of his plots instead.

Indi: Mainly cause adding in Shez can throw things off completely. Ah well, I'm sure things are fine, and Byleth doesn't have to deal with the fact that she cut off the possibility that her mom might have been able to come back to life.

Red: Yup yup, definitely won't have the issue of "what if". Which is a pretty interest "what if" to work with. I mean, we know the whole ritual would've failed horribly, but what if it didn't? It's a fun question to ask.

Indi: Meanwhile Rhea reexamines her own failures

Red: She's got a lot of those.

What makes a family?

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Byleth didn't say anything on the trip back to the monastery. Everything that happened still felt…uncomfortable to her. She didn't know why, she had only met Aelfric recently. If anything, she should be checking on the Ashen Wolves. 

 

At that thought, she stopped in her tracks before turning to the Wolves. 

 

"Are you okay?" 

 

"There's no need to worry about me, my friend," Yuri replied with his usual smile. No hesitation to his words, no hint of trouble, he didn’t seem like he needed to think about his answer at all. 

 

"Yeah, I mean…the booze is gonna taste bad for a while, but nothing I can't get past," Balthus replied with slightly more hesitation. 

 

"I'm already used to stuff like this, so I'm used to it," Hapi said, and Byleth decided not to comment on how she repeated herself. 

 

"..." Constance looked down at the ground. "The pain of betrayal is something a wretched being deserves." 

 

"Ah…" 

 

"No need to worry there, friend,” Yuri reassured, “Shady Lady here just isn't good with the sun, so don't take what she says seriously." 

 

"Yeah, By, she acted pretty differently when she was underground, remember?" Shez reminded.

 

"Oh…" Byleth seemed to think for a few moments, before pulling her coat off herself and throwing it over Constance. 

 

“Gah–W-What? What in the–...Oh. Oh, I see! What a brilliant decision, professor!” Constance praised, “To think, the solution to my other self could be found so readily!”

 

“...Coco, you just have a coat covering your head,” Hapi pointed out, “Can you even see like that?”

 

“Sight is entirely unnecessary in a situation such as this! Because…well…” She sighed. “I…I did not expect things to happen like this. I had hoped…but perhaps this is for the best.”

 

“Ah, no, Constance is still being mopey Constance!” Balthus exclaimed, “The coat’s not working!”

 

“It is working perfectly fine, you oaf! I can be upset without being my other self!"

 

"...Why don't you four go back to the abyss for now? I'll talk to Rhea and inform her of what happened." 

 

"You sure, my friend?” Yuri asked, “It does seem like a very important discussion to be had with her." 

 

"I dunno, I wouldn't mind going somewhere deep into Abyss and letting out a big sigh," Hapi commented, which earned a grin from Balthus.

 

"In that case, I'm definitely up to bash some monster heads!" 

 

"Honestly, I would agree to go with you, but who knows how seriously these scoundrels will take it," said the former noblewoman still under a coat. 

 

"I insist. You all need the rest," Byleth affirmed.

 

"Well alright then," Yuri agreed with a shrug, before glancing at Shez. "Make sure to take care." 

 

"Hm? Sure thing," Shez responded as the Ashen Wolves began to walk off, Hapi biting back a sigh as she grabbed Constance's hand to make sure she didn't get lost. 

 

"Ah, in that case, why don't we let the professor handle things from here?" Ashe suggested. 

 

"As the house leaders, we really should go along with the professor-" 

 

"Nah, they got it handled. Come on Mister Prince, I wanna see your spear techniques on the training grounds." Cutting him off, Leonie wrapped an arm around Dimitri’s neck and began to pull him along, much to the prince’s surprise. 

 

"I ask that you not pull his highness like that," Dedue insisted as he followed the pair. 

 

"Please don't tell me now Dimitri might poach a classmate…" Claude groaned, prompting a giggle from Hilda.

 

"Pft, well, good luck with that Claude. I don't know about you, but this girl needs to hit the sauna." 

 

"I am not understanding, to poach is to hunt without permission, yes?” Petra inquired, “What hunting is Dimitri doing?" 

 

"Ask me again after I had a nap," Linhardt answered. Well, he didn’t really answer anything, but still. 

 

Letting out a small sigh at her classmates’ antics, Edelgard gave the sisters a nod, before following behind her fellow students. 

 

"..." Scratching the back of his head, Ashe glanced at Byleth. "...Is it okay if I bring flowers for Missus Eisner later?" 

 

“...Sure. I think she would appreciate that,” Byleth replied with a small smile.

 

Ashe smiled back before heading off, leaving the sisters alone. Shez let out a sigh once he was gone, then gave Byleth a pat on the back. “You doing okay?”

 

“...Not especially. Everything feels…off.”

 

“You did have to kill your mom’s old friend. That’ll throw anybody off.” Shez frowned. “Come to think of it…hey, By, next time there’s any kind of person you don’t feel great about killing, why don’t you let me do it instead?”

 

Byleth blinked. “...I would hope that there’s never a person I feel great about killing.”

 

“You know what I mean.”

 

“No, I don’t. That sentence was ridiculous.”

 

“Gasp! Rude! See if I’ll ever offer to kill someone for you again!” Shez glowered at her sister, before breaking into a giggle that made Byleth smile. “Seriously though, name anybody, I’d do it.”

 

“I’m sure you would,” Byleth replied, giving her sister a pat on the head and making her pout.

 

“You know I have to lean down when you do this, right? Because you’re so short?”

 

“I’m not that short.”

 

“Nah, you’re totally a shortie.”

 

“What does that make Lysithea then?”

 

“That’s a question I can’t answer without future pain, so I’m not gonna. Besides, she’s fifteen, right? She could still wind up taller than you. Some people get late growth spurts.”

 

“Defending your lady’s honor from your dastardly sister. How cute.”

 

“I can think of a lot of words to describe you, By, and dastardly is not one of them. Short definitely is though.”

 

Byleth huffed, though she did have a small smile on her face as she continued to banter with her sister on the way up to Rhea’s office. It did fade once they got there though.

 

“Hey Professor Seteth,” Shez greeted, raising a hand to the chamberlain, who sighed.

 

“Miss Eisner, I am not a professor. In the context of the Academy, I would technically be the Headmaster, but I am primarily Lady Rhea’s chamberlain.”

 

“Oh, gotcha, Sir Seteth.”

 

Seteth pinched the bridge of his nose, before looking at Byleth. “Hello Professor. I presume everything has been resolved then?”

 

“Yeah. Can I talk to Rhea?”

 

He frowned and Byleth prepared herself for some kind of denial or annoyed remark– “Are you alright, professor? You seemed distressed.”

 

“...Ah, uh…I’m not doing that well, no. I want to talk to Rhea about it.” She felt herself tense as the thought occurred that she would have to tell her father that she killed his friend. “Can I? Please.”

 

“You may,” he allowed, “She’s already expecting you.”

 

“You want me to hang back?” Shez asked, giving her sister a glance.

 

“...Yeah. I think we–me and her, we should talk about this…about everything.”

 

“No problem! I can just chat with Seteth.”

 

Byleth tried to ignore how the chamberlain’s face fell as she entered the archbishop’s office and found Rhea waiting for her.

 

“Hello child. I must admit, I am surprised to only see you here.”

 

“I thought the students should get some rest. And…that we should talk. Privately.”

 

Rhea smiled. “I had been hoping we could for some time, though I suppose these circumstances are not quite what I was hoping for…Would you like to tell me what happened?”

 

"...Aelfric refused to stand down, so I had to kill him. All of the students, including the Ashen Wolves, returned unharmed." 

 

"...I see. That is… painful to hear. Though I know he nearly committed a grave sin, he was still someone I cared deeply for. I saw him like a child of mine, much like how I saw your mother." 

 

"...How long have you known?" 

 

"Since you arrived. Though I know Jeralt might have had his reason for keeping your existence a secret from me, it was obvious the moment I saw you that you were Sitri's child." 

 

"..." Byleth felt her body tense up. Try as she might, she couldn't get Aelfric’s words out of her head. 

 

"...Is there something you wish to say, child?" 

 

Staring up at her, Byleth found herself unable to stop the words from coming out of her mouth. "Did you kill my mother?" 

 

Rhea couldn’t have looked more shocked if Byleth had outright punched her. Confusion, horror, offense, and even anger warred across her face before she managed to regain some semblance of composure, but even that was wavering in the face of such a question. “What…? I–Child, how could you think that?"

 

"Jeralt told me what happened. About how you never let him see Sitri's body, and how you acted around me. Aelfric…before I killed him, he told me that that you–that we killed her. What happened to my mother?" Byleth demanded to know, as she tried not to look away from Rhea. 

 

"...Oh, child." Taking a step forward, Rhea flinched back as Byleth reflexively drew her dagger and stepped backwards. 

 

“Don’t–D-Don’t try…” She swallowed, trying to keep some composure as she realized the archbishop wasn’t trying to hurt her. That the movement towards her wasn’t hostile, that she looked hurt, not angry. “...s-sorry. Sorry, I…N-No, no, you need to tell me. Please, I…I need to know. I need to know what happened!”

 

“...Child, I would never hurt Sitri. I loved her. She was my daughter in every way that mattered.”

 

“Then what happened?!” Byleth snapped, a mixture of anger and grief for someone she’d never met welling up in her chest. 

 

Rhea seemed to wilt under Byleth’s accusatory gaze. “I…failed her. I failed her like I have failed many before her, though in this case…” She took a breath, and then met Byleth’s gaze steadily. “I was the midwife for your birth. I helped as best I could, but your mother had always been sickly, ever since she was young. The strain of birth was difficult for her, and she likely would have passed away even if…”

 

“...” Byleth blinked tears from her eyes, her breathing not quite ragged, but getting there. “E… E-Even if?”

 

“You would not have survived either,” Rhea explained as she relived the events of that day, “You were born cold and without breath. Without intervention, you would have been dead, but your mother did not accept that. And so…I did something that I…were I in that circumstance again, I would have made the same choice. 

 

“Sitri asked me to exchange her life for yours. In essence, I gave you her heart. With the last of her fading life, I ensured you would survive, and she passed in peace because of it.”

 

“...Her heart?" Byleth clutched her chest,  thinking of how her heart didn't beat. But…it was her mother’s heart? “She…died for me?”

 

“She gave her life for yours. And I know it is a trade she would have willingly made again were it ever required of her.” Rhea gave a small, sad smile. “She loved you, child. You were hers, and she loved you so very dearly.”

 

“...” Byleth swallowed, her throat tight again. Her heart didn’t beat, but she could feel it ache. “...”

 

“I see this question must have been hanging over your head for as long as you have known me.” The archbishop let out a sad little laugh. “Your discomfort in my presence makes a great deal of sense now.”

 

“...Yeah. Yeah.” Byleth let out a slow breath, one hand still resting on her chest. “Thank you for telling me.”

 

The tension hadn’t left her body. She still felt strange in Rhea’s presence. But knowing the truth…it did change things.

 

Her grip on her dagger loosened and she sheathed it again before it could fall from her fingers. “Sorry. I…I’m sorry. I didn’t…”

 

“It is fine, child. Believe me, I have done worse in the throes of grief,” Rhea replied, smiling sadly. She hadn’t expected to see so much of herself in the young woman.

 

"...Did you already bury my mom?" 

 

"No, not yet. I…In the past, I didn't have the strength to bury her, and even now I don't. I think it would be for the best if Jeralt decided what to do, if that is alright." 

 

"...yeah. Yeah that sounds good." 

 

"If I had known that keeping the truth of what happened was the reason Jeralt had left all those years ago…" Rhea let out a sad sigh. "I know it may be far too late to ask this, but I pray that you give me another chance." 

 

"I'll… think about it." Byleth responded, getting Rhea to smile. "What will happen to the Ashen Wolves?" 

 

"...I shall need to find someone to keep watch over Abyss but…given that Aelfric was the one to establish it, then the Ashen Wolves will likely be disbanded." 

 

"Oh…Will they be okay?" 

 

"That is up to them. They aren't shackled to Abyss anymore, so they can do as they wish. Regardless of what they choose, I hope that you can guide them." 

 

"I'll do my best." Byleth glanced up at Rhea. "...Thank you, for telling me the truth." 

 

"...Of course, child. And once again, I'm sorry," Rhea apologized, inclining her head as Byleth left. 

 

"The 'truth' huh?" Sothis mused. "I can't help but wonder if she even knows how to tell the whole truth…" Staying silent, Byleth wondered as well as she walked out towards where Seteth and Shez were. 

 

"So hey, are you and Rhea related?" Was the first thing Byleth heard as she walked out. 

 

"What?" 

 

"Just wondering, I mean, you both got the green hair, albeit different colors, both of you are pretty important to the church, and you both have birthdays on Saint days, like how Flayn does too!" 

 

Seteth sighed. “Miss Eisner, hair color does not denote relation. Do you think I am also related to young Linhardt?”

 

“...Are you?”

 

“No. Let me put it a different way, are you related to Lorenz or Bernadetta?”

 

“...Am I?? Ordelia is really close to Gloucester…”

 

Seteth did his best not to groan as Byleth walked over and patted her sister on the head. “Oh, hey By. You finish talking to Rhea?”

 

“Yeah, I’m done. Now…I guess we should go talk to dad. Or at least…figure out what we’re going to say when he comes back.”

 

"Ah… yeah." Nodding to her, Shez glanced at Seteth. "Thanks for keeping me company, see ya Seteth." 

 

Byleth noted how grateful he seemed now that Shez was leaving. 

 

"So…what exactly happened?" 

 

"Mom… apparently gave me her heart when I was born. It was the only way to save me." 

 

"..." Shez grabbed onto Byleth. "...Missus Sitri sounds like a really nice person." 

 

"Yeah…It might be wrong to say, but I can't help but wonder…If Aelfric did succeed…would she be around? I…I really want to know her, to tell her about you, and everything we've been through and everyone we met." 

 

"...Yeah, that sounds like it would have been nice," Shez said, as she did her best to grin. "So we gotta make sure to tell her plenty when we visit her grave." 

 

"Hm… that sounds nice." 

 

"Exactly! Who knows, maybe the afterlife is in need of mercs too, so when we go there, she can put in a good word for us!" 

 

"...I feel like I would want to retire by that point." 

 

"...Yeah, fair enough. So, did anything else happen?" 

 

"Ah… apparently Rhea saw my mom as her daughter." 

 

"Huh…wait, does that make her our grandma?" 

 

"..." Byleth began to think. "...Does it?" 

 

"I see no reason why it should," Sothis chimed in. "Family is chosen, even if they are of blood. She has no valid claim in being family lest you wish for it." 

 

"Sothis says only if we want to have her be our grandma… and I'm not sure if I want to," Byleth said, frowning. "I feel like she's still hiding something important. So I don't know if I can trust her." 

 

"Right, in that case, she's not family," Shez agreed with a smile. "We already have each other and dad. We don’t need to add anybody that we don’t want!" 

 

Back in her office, Rhea felt inexplicably sad for some reason, but disregarded the sensation because that happened a lot anyway.

 

“Anyways, what do you want to do now?” Shez asked, “We’ve still got a lot of the day to go and I’m sure nobody will mind if we just hang out.”

 

“...I am pretty hungry, actually,” Byleth admitted, “Food first? Then we can try to figure out how to explain all of this to Jeralt.”

 

“Oh I’m sure telling him about all this won’t be too bad. Dad’s pretty understanding.”

Jeralt didn’t understand anything. In fact, he was pretty sure he’d lost his ability to understand languages completely because everything his daughters had told him was completely insane.

 

I wasn’t even gone for a week. How the hell…?

 

"..." He let out a heavy sigh as he leaned back in his chair. He thought for a moment, trying to latch onto something. "...You two are okay, right?" 

 

"Yeah. I think so," Byleth responded, giving a close proximity to a smile. 

 

"Well, you don't have to worry about me,” Shez added, “By was the one who dealt with the big stuff." 

 

"Right…and everything Rhea said?" he asked.

 

"...I think she's still hiding something, but I think she told the truth there," Byleth replied, “Ah, about mom giving her life for mine, I mean. I’m…not completely sure if the heart part is literal, since it doesn’t sound physically possible, but maybe it’s a magic thing?”

 

"...sure." Jeralt let out a tired sigh. "So that's why she never told me anything…heh, you think you know someone, and they keep so many secrets from you." Or kidnap your daughter and try to resurrect your wife from the dead. What the hell, Aelfric?

 

“How long have you known Rhea anyways, dad?” Shez asked, curious, and Jeralt considered how honest he should be. The hypocrisy wasn’t lost on him.

 

"I was…a bit older than you are now I think. I was just barely starting out when I first met her." 

 

"Wow, sounds like someone got a lucky break. I mean, meeting someone that important when you're young means you'll have connections, right?" 

 

"Well… it was thanks to her that I met Sitri at least," Jeralt muttered. 

 

"...Papa, do you think stopping Aelfric was a mistake?" Byleth spoke up.

 

"..." Reaching over, Jeralt gave his kid a pat on the head. "No, it wasn't. Sitri… She was the kindest person I ever knew. I don't think she could have lived with the knowledge that four people had to die for her." And Aelfric really must’ve lost it if he thought otherwise.

 

"You know, Missus Sitri sounds alot like By. If she was around we'd have two worrywarts fussing over everyone." 

 

"...I don't fuss." 

 

"By, Dorothea told me you're using your own money to help pay for things for the class." 

 

"We keep getting sent on dangerous missions, I want to make sure they're well equipped," Byleth said, with a slight pout, "Besides, I don't fuss over the mercenaries." 

 

"That's cause you're not in charge of them yet. Heck, I bet you'd probably give anyone a raise if they said they needed it." 

 

"..." Byleth glanced at Jeralt. "Are any of them in need of money?"

 

"See what I mean!" Shez said with a laugh as she poked at Byleth. 

 

"Hmph." Byleth continued to pout while she looked away from Shez. 

 

Jeralt smiled at his daughters’ antics, though it faded as his mind turned to more serious topics. "So…that just leaves what to do with Sitri's body…" 

 

"...I think we should bury her. I might not like the church, but this is where mom grew up, right?” Byleth said, “So she'd probably want to be buried here." 

 

"Yeah, that sounds like a good idea," Jeralt agreed with a smile. "I'll make sure to talk to Rhea about that." 

 

“You know, it’s weird that she just left Missus Sitri down there in Abyss,” Shez pointed out, “Should we ask her why? Because that is super weird. Like she wouldn’t just forget, would she?”

 

“I don’t think she’s that stupid.”

 

Elsewhere, Rhea sneezed.

 

Jeralt, meanwhile, thought back on what he knew of the archbishop. “...Let’s leave that for later.”

 

"...Should we ask why she still…looks like that?" 

 

"Ah." Jeralt thought for a moment. He wouldn't be surprised if Rhea had tried to give her some of her blood in hopes that would help her get through the birth. It was the only explanation he could think of. "...It's probably some kinda spell she put on her." 

 

"Maybe?"

 

"Hm… hey, Byleth, should we go get some flowers?” Shez asked, “I mean, I know we're not burying Missus Sitri right now, but still." 

 

"Yeah, we should. Mom would love that." 

 

"That she would. And I have to say, I'm glad you two aren't fighting anymore," Jeralt said with a small smile. "I'm sure Sitri is happy too…though, that reminds me." 

 

Fishing around in one of his pockets, Jeralt brought out a small pouch. Pulling it open, he brought out an intricate ring. 

 

"Ah, is that…mom's?" Byleth asked, staring right at it.

 

"Yeah, it's the only keepsake I have of her…heh, probably should have gotten one for myself if I knew I was going to have two kids." 

 

"Shouldn't that be something By gets, not me?" Shez asked. 

 

"You're as much a family to mom as I am," Byleth responded as she nudged Shez, "Though I'm surprised you're not trying to make it a competition." 

 

"...pft, what, the first one to get married wins? Kinda a weird competition don't you think?" 

 

“You seem to have a few suitors already.”

 

“What? No I–Wait, who’s this even about this time?”

 

Jeralt raised an eyebrow. “...So you have ‘suitors’, huh?”

 

“No! By’s just being dumb, again,” Shez insisted, “Besides, she’s the one with the crush!”

 

"I don't."

 

"She does?" 

 

"Yes she does! Dorothea told me you gave her a flower!" 

 

"You did now, huh?" Jeralt asked, suddenly very interested. "You know there's nothing wrong with admitting you have feelings for someone, right?" 

 

"I know that, but I also don't have a crush on her." 

 

"Come on By, you gotta at least be interested in someone." 

 

"Just because I find someone pretty doesn't mean I want to date them," Byleth protested, "Besides, even if I was, that doesn't mean they want to date me." 

 

"Well I think Edelgard does want to date you." 

 

"Now you're just messing with me." 

 

"What's so hard to believe about someone wanting to date you?" 

 

“I just don’t see why they would want to.”

 

“Byleth, you’re objectively hot and you like wearing shorts, stop being dumb.”

 

“...what does my sense of fashion have to do with this?”

 

Jeralt felt like he shouldn’t be here for this conversation, so he just stood up and left while Shez let out an exasperated groan.

 

"..." Byleth glanced down at her outfit. "I like it at least."

Chapter End Notes

Red: Man, Jeralt sure missed out, huh? Wife's body was found, old friend went crazy and kidnapped his daughter, and an entire underground town was discovered at the monastery. He needs to stop taking business trips.

Indi: Meanwhile Rhea finally learned why exactly Byleth is afraid of her.

Red: Yup. Maybe this will make her reflect on her past actions and understand that Byleth is an individual with her own wants and dreams outside of being a vessel for the goddess?

Indi: Or maybe she'll just ignore any guilt and push it under a rug.

Red: Naaaaaah, when has Rhea ever ignored reality in favor of a comforting fiction? ...Oh wait.

A Brand New Day

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Byleth let out a slow sigh as she walked around the monastery. She couldn’t help but focus on Shez’s comment about her fashion. Well, she could focus on something else, but she really didn’t want to think about Aelfric and how tense that entire situation made her feel. So much like all the thoughts of her students dying, she shelved those elsewhere. 

 

“Should I buy something new…?”

 

“Greetings Professor, nothing to report today!” Blinking, she looked over to see the gatekeeper standing nearby. “Is there something on your mind?”

 

“...A few things. Hey, quick question, you see a lot of people thanks to your job, right?” 

 

“That I do! Were you looking for someone in particular?”

 

“No, I just wanted to ask if you noticed any fashion trends around now?” 

 

“Uh…my apologies professor, I don’t really take notice of such things,” the gatekeeper said, frowning apologetically, “May I ask why you want to know?”

 

“Just thinking of trying something new.” 

 

“Hm…students tend to change into the summer uniform around this time of year, so maybe something like that? Though I guess it’s not that hot this year…”

 

“Summer uniforms…got it, thanks Gatekeeper,” Byleth said, nodding in response.

 

“Of course, Professor.” Waving her goodbye with a smile, unaware of what he set in motion.

"What are you wearing?" Sothis asked as she looked down at Byleth. 

 

"Apparently it's a 'summer uniform' that the students have in case it gets warmer around here," Byleth responded as she looked at herself in a mirror, admiring the white blouse and tan skirt that conformed to her body, "Decided to try something different since apparently my sense of fashion isn't great."

 

"And why are you wearing that?" 

 

Byleth shrugged in response. "It was the best option." 

 

"What?" 

 

Byleth didn't answer, and instead began to stretch a bit as she tried to see how well she could move in the outfit. "Hm…a bit more restrictive than my usual outfit. Probably shouldn't wear it in battle." 

 

"..." Sothis let out an annoyed sigh. "Fine, I might as well see what happens." 

 

A bit confused about her response, Byleth put on her pink headband to finish the outfit. Hm…should she get Dorothea a gift as thanks? She'd been wearing it practically everyday, so it seemed only fair… 

 

Something to consider later. Once she was ready, Byleth left her room, though she made sure to feed her pet crayfish before she did. 

 

"Hm, it's a shame Shez is already on her mission today, would have been nice to hear what she thinks about my outfit," Byleth muttered to herself, and partially to Sothis as she walked. Though as she did, she couldn't help but notice the stares that were on her as she walked. Doing her best to ignore them, she made her way to her class. 

 

"Hey, ByBy, any reason for the new outfit?" 

 

Blinking, Byleth glanced over to see Hapi standing nearby with Constance, the latter of whom was staring at the ground. 

 

"Felt like it. Also hello there you two, did you need something?" 

 

"There is nothing I could ask for that would be worth wasting your time." 

 

"Coco wanted to join your class, and I figured I might as well come along,” Hapi interpreted, “Course then she started getting like this after we got out in the sun, and stopped walking." 

 

"Oh, well, sorry, I don't have my coat right now," Byleth apologized, though Constance just sighed. 

 

"There is no need to apologize for one such as me." 

 

"Hm. Well, if you two want to join, I'd be glad to have you be part of the Black Eagles. Good timing too, since this is my first proper day back as the professor," Byleth said, nodding to the pair, “What about Balthus and Yuri?”

 

"Yuri-bird is sticking to Abyss for now, and B is joining the Golden Deer cause of some job or something,” Hapi explained, “Sounds like we’re lucky to have you back in charge of the class.”

 

"I am unworthy of such a blessing." 

 

"Right, we should get you into the class," Byleth decided, before grabbing the former noble to pull her towards the class, where most of her students already were. "Morning everyone, we have some new people joining us." 

 

"Why yes! I, Constance von Nuvelle, shall be joining your class!" Constance declared, immediately bouncing back to her usual haughtiness once she was out of the sun.

 

"Hey there," Hapi greeted with a wave. 

 

"Ah, professor it's-" Ferdinand started to greet, before he suddenly faltered as he saw Byleth’s new attire. "H-Huh?" 

 

"...Um, professor, may I ask why you're wearing a summer uniform?" Dorothea asked, staring slightly confused, but also with some interest as her eyes moved up and down. 

 

“I felt like wearing something new," Byleth explained. 

 

"...and how did that translate to wearing a uniform?" Edelgard asked, looking away with a slight blush on her face. 

 

"Oh, I asked the gatekeeper for help. He didn't really know anything about fashion, but he mentioned that 'students tend to change into the summer uniform around this time of year, so maybe something like that?'." 

 

"...Thank you, Gatekeeper." Dorothea muttered. 

 

“Dorothea!”

 

“What? Come on, Ferdie, a girl can like what she likes!” 

 

“How rude! Hapi and I grace you all with our presence, and you ignore us!” Constance complained.

 

“Oh, hey there! Sorry, guess we’re just excited to see the professor back,” Caspar apologized with a grin. “Nice to meet you!” 

 

“Y-Yeah! It’s n-nice having you back, P-Professor!” Bernadetta greeted as enthusiastically as she could while hiding behind Hubert, all while keeping a cautious eye on the new students. 

 

“I suppose between you and Jeritza, you are the better choice,” Hubert admitted. 

 

“Wow, ByBy, you sure are popular. It’s kinda amazing” 

 

“The Professor is full of amazement,” Petra agreed.

 

“Hmph, about time you got back,” Emily muttered as she entered the room, “Good, I’m tired of hearing everyone complain about you being gone.” 

 

“...I’m glad you’re being more honest, Emily,” Byleth praised. 

 

"..." Letting out an annoyed huff, Emily went to sit down, ignoring everyone else. 

 

"Now then, I guess Lindhart will probably show up soon, so for now, we should get ready to start our lesson." Byleth said, nodding before she paused as someone else entered the room. 

 

"Ah, Professor Byleth, I was unaware you were already returning to teach," Jeritza said as he stood by the doorway. 

 

"Oh, did I forget to mention it? Yeah I've been given the all clear. Thanks for covering for me."

 

"If you wish to thank me, we can spar later," Jeritza responded before noting her outfit. "...What are you wearing?"

 

"A summer uniform." 

 

"...I see. It is inappropriate," Jeritza noted as he left, finding such an outfit completely unfit for combat. 

 

"Oh." Byleth meanwhile frowned. She actually liked the uniform… Was her own sense of fashion that bad? 

 

"Ah, wait, it nearly slipped my mind in the commotion,” Ferdinand spoke up, pulling his eyes away from the professor, “But did you say your name was Constance Von Nuvelle?" 

 

"Why yes, I did, and am I correct in assuming you are Ferdinand Von Aegir?" 

 

"That I am! I can't believe it's actually you Constance, I haven't seen you in years!" 

 

"Oh, do you know one another?" Dorothea asked. 

 

"Of course! Though I haven't seen her in years." 

 

"Hm, actually, I guess we should make sure to properly meet our new classmates," Byleth said with a nod, before she glanced around and spotted Marianne. Standing a bit away from the class, the reserved girl seemed to be a bit overwhelmed, so Byleth decided to try and not draw attention towards her. She just gave the girl a reassuring smile, which she returned shyly.

 

"Haaahn…” Linhardt yawned as he entered, before noticing the two new classmates, “Oh, hello. I didn’t know you were joining us. Would you care to tell me about your crests now?”

 

Hapi raised an eyebrow. "Is that all you care about?" 

 

"What else is there to care about?" 

 

"Come now, Linhardt,” Ferdinand reprimanded, “Clearly we should at least prepare some tea for our new classmates first before entering such discussions."

 

"My my Ferdinand, skipping class to have tea? I didn't know you had it in you." 

 

"I did not suggest such a thing!" 

 

"I dunno, today sounds like a good day to not do school work!" Caspar declared, full of his usual enthusiasm.

 

"Only for a bit, we'll still be working later," Byleth stated as she walked to the chalkboard, frowning as she realized the lesson she had ended off with last month was still written on there. What had Jeritza been teaching them…

 

Unbeknownst to her as she began to clean the board, Dorothea kept her eyes forward and low, taking note of how her skirt hugged the professor’s hips, before she quietly muttered to Edelgard. 

 

"You know, I'm not that religious, but I think we should thank the goddess for this lovely view."

 

Edelgard stiffened, her face reddening, and cleared her throat. “Th-That isn’t an appropriate comment, Dorothea.”

 

“Ah, but you agree, right~? Hm, I suppose it has been hot lately, maybe I should fish out my summer uniform too? And I bet you would look cute in yours!”

 

"I have no interest in wearing that uniform," Edelgard responded, "As the house leader, I must show my pride in our house with my current one." 

 

"Fine, fine, always so serious~" Grinning, Dorothea glanced back at Byleth. "Though you really should make sure to hurry up Edie, or else someone might snatch her away first." 

 

"I already said it's not like that," Edelgard muttered, huffing as she looked up at Byleth…It really was odd that, despite how revealing her usual outfit appeared, the coat really did hide a surprising amount of her figure. 

 

"Did Jeritza really only have you guys spar while he was in charge?" Byleth asked, a rare bit of annoyance in her voice while she went over her planner that had been left of her desk. 

 

"Yes, he said he was only an instructor of combat, so that is all he did," Petra answered. 

 

"I told him what some of my lessons I had planned were and he didn't even listen…great now we're a month behind." She was openly frowning now, looking about as irritated as the class had ever seen her be. They had seen her completely furious before, but seeing her annoyed was certainly different. “Hm…I suppose this does give the new students a chance to catch up while we review…The fact that he spent so much time with combat training probably means it’s okay to ignore that for now as well.”

 

She seemed to think for a moment as she went over her notes. 

 

“Might be a good idea to have a group review…” Byleth muttered, before glancing back up at everyone. “Right, hope you’re all ready, cause I’m going to make up for lost time.” 

 

Letting a smile grace her features, Edelgard prepared herself for the lesson. It was good to have her professor back.

“Alright, I’m glad to see all of you have kept up your own studies as well,” Byleth complimented at the end of class, giving them all a thumbs up. 

 

At the back of the class, Marianne couldn't help but shrink away as Caspar let out a loud cheer at the praise. It was definitely going to take some getting used to with this new class, especially with how different Byleth was compared to Manuela. She always knew the mercenary was nice, far nicer than she should be to someone like her, yet she didn’t expect to feel so welcomed in the first class with her. Especially as Byleth approached her after class.

 

“Hello, Marianne. I hope you were able to follow everything well.” 

 

“O-Oh, yes, there’s no need to worry about me.” 

 

“That’s good. Still, if you need help on anything, feel free to ask. I’m not exactly sure what Manuela's lessons have been like, but I hope I can match her.” Byleth paused for a moment. “Might be a good idea to ask her for help on Faith lessons…” 

 

“W-Well, I would hate to compare you two,” Marianne muttered, which was true for her at least. Even if she didn’t spend as much time with students after class, Manuela was a very passionate teacher. Albeit a bit too passionate at times… And the occasional hangovers she had weren’t great… 

 

“Okay. Oh, though I did want to ask, I’ll be having the students do some mounted training soon, if you could help me with that. The horses in the stables seem to really like you, so having someone help keep them calm would be appreciated.” 

 

“O-Oh… w-well, since you asked, okay.” 

 

“Thank you,” Byleth said with a slight smile. “Oh, one other thing, do you think I poached you?”

 

“...E-Excuse me?”

 

“Just something Claude said. He claimed that his classmates were being ‘poached’, so I wanted to see if you thought that.”

 

“...I-I don’t belong to C-Claude,” Marianne muttered, a bit confused by what the professor was saying. Strangely, she felt…a little annoyed too. “D-Did he say I did?”

 

“Hm? Not really. I think he means it in a classmate sense, since he’s the house leader.”

 

“O-Oh…th-that does make more sense…” She frowned at herself for jumping to some stupid conclusion like that just because he had been prying–because he was trying to help. Just, trying to help. She was the one causing problems, as always…

 

“Marianne? Are you okay?”

 

Marianne stiffened, startled out of her self-recrimination. “A-Ah, s-s-sorry, p-professor. I-I was, um…I-I’m sorry.”

 

“It’s okay. I’m glad to have you be a part of my class.” The professor smiled and Marianne felt her face warm up. “I hope I can help you be the best you can be.”

 

“...a-ah…th-th-thank you, p-professor,” Marianne mumbled, ducking her head in the face of the professor’s overwhelming sincerity.

 

"Did you want to have some tea later?" 

 

"O-Oh, sorry. I-I had plans to have tea with H-Hilda already. Though…she might be okay with you joining?" 

 

"Glad to hear, I'll make sure to bring some treats," Byleth responded, before leaving with a nod. 

 

Giving a small wave in response, Marianne took in a small breath. She might not be worthy of this kindness, but maybe coming to the Academy was worth it...

Seteth walked the monastery halls with a look of intense concentration on his face while he read some papers in hand. Everyone nearby gave him a wide berth as he walked; no one wanted to get in the way of the stern chamberlain on the best of days, and they definitely didn’t want to be in his way when he looked so focused. Surely, for someone so important to the function of the church, his task must be something of grand importance, so he should not be interrupted. And, perhaps to him, it was indeed quite important. 

 

For he was stuck on the fable he was currently writing. 

 

He had to admit, it was rather annoying how he couldn't get that idea Professor Byleth had used as a metaphor out of his head. As such, he felt it necessary to approach her to ask if she could expound upon that metaphor she used. 

 

At least, that's what he thought, until he saw her wearing a student’s uniform, idly chatting with Balthus as she did. 

 

"Professor, what are you wearing!?" Seteth practically yelled as he approached the two. 

 

"Why do people keep asking that? It should be obvious,” Byleth responded in lieu of an answer. 

 

"And it should also be obvious why you shouldn't wear such a thing!" 

 

"Aw, come on, lighten up and just appreciate the view, pal," Balthus said with a grin, which faltered when Seteth glared at him. 

 

"Balthus, was it? I understand you may be older than the average student, but you are a student of this academy once again, so making such comments about a professor is inappropriate." 

 

"Ah, right." 

 

"I thought it looked cute," Byleth muttered to herself, pouting, earning an annoyed look from Seteth.

 

"'Cuteness' has no bearing on this conversation! You can't be wearing a student's uniform while you're a professor!"

 

"Oh. Hm." Well that sounded unfair to her, though she ignored that feeling in favor of focusing back on the chamberlain. "Did you need something, Seteth?" 

 

"Ah, yes, I did want to speak with you about something. Do you have some time?" 

 

"Sure, take care, Balthus." 

 

"Will do, see you," Balthus said, making sure to avoid saying anything inappropriate in front of Seteth. 

 

As Seteth left with Byleth in tow, the chamberlain couldn't help but think about the professor at his side. He might not know all the details, but…he had heard enough of the situation in Abyss. It was odd to hear that Rhea had apparently had someone she…saw as a daughter. In the eighteen years he had been there, Rhea hadn't once mentioned Sitri. Not that he could blame her, Seteth wasn't really one to speak about his wife either. Even so…

 

Was she really just someone she had adopted? Her body had been perfectly preserved, something that wasn't normal for humans, but…it was for Nabateans. Had Rhea found someone and had a child? Was that why she was so willing to trust Byleth…? 

 

It was odd to think of the former mercenary as someone he could trust but…if she was family, then maybe he could extend some trust. 

 

"So, what did you want to talk about?" Byleth asked as they found an empty place to talk. 

 

"Ah, well, I wanted to ask about that metaphor you said some time ago. About the Silverheart mercenaries." 

 

"Oh? Any reason why?" 

 

"My own interest I suppose you could say," Seteth responded. "Specifically, I wished to know if you had any particular idea on how things could progress from the story you described." 

 

"Oh?" 

 

"Yes, I was thinking about how it could have a happy ending, if possible. If we add in 'House Verdant' then that would be three houses that each have their own tensions with one another." 

 

"Well…I suppose finding a reason to work together would be one." 

 

"So you say, but it seems faith hasn't been working as a reason to unite." 

 

"That's because Faith isn't tangible." At his confused expression, Byleth continued. "Faith…from what I've seen is different for everyone. For some, it's a source of comfort. For others, it could be a motivator. It can be a sword or a shield depending on who wields it. Especially with how they view it." 

 

"How so?" 

 

"Take me for example. I'm not exceptionally faithful, but I can still use faith magic, right?" 

 

"...yes, that is quite peculiar." 

 

"I don't think so. When I consider this type of magic…I have faith in my family, and in those I care about. Even so, I want to make sure to keep them safe," Byleth explained, "There are also those who use faith for negative means, like the Western Church who infiltrated the monastery during the Rite of Rising, or the Southern Church who tried to enact an insurrection." 

 

"And those people are heretics who went against the goddess' teachings." 

 

"Even so, they still had 'faith', even if it's in heretical things. So if faith is to be something that brings everyone together, then it needs to be something tangible, like if the goddess were to descend again." 

 

"...Hm." Well, it would be a deus ex machina for the goddess to suddenly descend and put an end to the conflict, but it is a children's fable… "I see. Thank you for your input." 

 

"No problem. Did you need anything else?" 

 

"Not at the moment. Though I will say that you really should change, such attire isn't appropriate for a professor of the Academy." 

 

"Oh, okay," Byleth said as Seteth walked away. She had to admit, she was kind of disappointed that her experiment with fashion went so poorly.

 

Well at least her usual outfit was perfectly appropriate to wear.

"Oh, professor, any reason for the change back to your usual outfit?" Dorothea asked, having nearly bumped into Byleth as the latter was entering the cafeteria as the former was leaving. 

 

Shrugging in response, Byleth looked down at herself. "Apparently my clothes weren't appropriate, and I kept getting stared at." 

 

"Really?" 

 

"Yeah. I know I'm not really someone that knows alot of fashion, but I thought I looked cute," Byleth said before frowning. "Though I guess I was wrong. Lorenz saw me earlier, and said something about how Sylvain was missing out by not being here before laughing in his usual way." 

 

"..." Dorothea tried not to immediately jump to conclusions, because she didn't think Lorenz was that much of an asshole. She'd still talk with him later, but for now she focused on Byleth. "Well I thought you looked cute." 

 

"Oh, thank you." 

 

"No need to thank me, professor. Though, you really shouldn't take what others say to heart like that. You should wear what you want, and I definitely think you should wear that outfit again~." 

 

"Hm…Still, I suppose it would be better if I had a better idea on fashion. Would you be able to help me with that?" 

 

"Oh? You want my help?" 

 

"Yeah? You seem very trendy, and you did pick out this hairband for me," Byleth explained, reaching up to touch said gift. "So I think you'd be able to help me pick out cute outfits." 

 

"Aw, I'm touched, professor! Though I will say, I didn't think you'd like that hairband so much." 

 

"Why wouldn't I? You got it for me as a gift." 

 

"Heh, well in that case, I certainly don't mind helping you out later."

 

“Thank you, Dorothea. Ah, though I can wait until you have free time from your dates.” 

 

“Oh, no need to worry there, my schedule is quite free at the moment,” Dorothea responded, refraining from mentioning she had been turning down dates while Byleth was recovering so she could check up on her.

 

“Oh, okay. Hm…what kind of outfits would be good for this weather anyway?”

 

“Well, what do you normally wear when it’s hot out?”

 

“This.”

 

Dorothea probably should have seen that coming. “Then that’s a good starting point! I’m sure we can find plenty of shorts and short skirts around, though we might have a bit more trouble finding tops that show off your chest like that. The clothes around here do tend to be on the more modest side, though I will say you can really pull off a blouse, professor~”

 

“...Yes? It’s pretty easy, they come with buttons.”

 

“...” It was times like these that Dorothea remembered Professor Byleth and Shez were sisters. “I mean you look very cute in a blouse, professor.”

 

“Oh. Ah, thank you. Hm…I guess a blouse and a skirt would be good teaching clothes…Then again, Manuela wears that dress…I wonder how that would look…”

 

“...A-Ahem.” Dorothea cleared her throat to get Professor Byleth’s attention and interrupt that line of thought before she did something dangerous like actually dress like Manuela. Such a sight might actually kill poor Edie…and possibly other members of the Eagles class, based on how many of them couldn’t help but stare whenever the professor was facing away from them. Though, to be fair, with those hips of hers in that tight skirt…She was getting distracted again. “Let’s save asking Manuela for fashion advice for later.”

 

“Oh, should we? She does look pretty…but a lot of people tend to stare at her too. Hm.” Byleth frowned, thinking. “...I wonder how Shez is doing?”

 

“Huh?”

 

“Oh, sorry. My mind drifted a little. I just remembered one time after I bought this outfit and we were going through a town in Leicester, I think around Siward. Some guy made rude comments and Shez punched him in the face.” A faint smile graced her features. “It was funny. He didn’t seem to realize he’d been knocked out until a second afterward and then collapsed like a sack. Then his friend tried to grab Shez and I broke his arm. I think we’re still banned from that bar.”

 

Her smile grew. “Papa was pretty proud of us after that, though he tried to pretend he wasn’t. Victor said we should celebrate it, since it’s apparently an ‘Eisner Family Tradition’.”

 

“Pff-” Dorothea tried to stifle her laugh. “To get kicked out of bars?”

 

“Yup. Papa–Ah, Jeralt has been banned from at least five bars in every nation, from what he’s told me. Though most of them are because he never pays his tabs.”

 

That time, Dorothea couldn’t help but giggle. “Hahaha! Your father is quite the character! Though don’t worry, I’m sure Shezzie isn’t going to be starting any bar brawls since the Lions have those knights escorting them.”

 

“...Hm. Knights of Seiros can go to bars, can’t they?”

 

“Professor, even if they can, I don’t think they’re going to while they’re on a mission.”

 

“Hm…Well hopefully they don't, the kingdom doesn't really have a drinking age I think." 

 

"They don't?" 

 

"Not that I could see. Though I imagine when you live in a place where you get thrown in rivers in full armor to train as a kid, they don't really care when you drink." 

 

"...The kingdom actually does that?"

 

"From what I read, yeah. It seems very dangerous though, since it gets cold up there." 

 

"...Huh. Well, I guess being a knight in the Kingdom definitely won't be part of my future plans." 

 

"I would hope not, because then you'd probably transfer over to the Blue Lions." 

 

"Aw, is that your way of saying you'd miss me?" 

 

"Of course. I'd miss any of you if you went to a different class." 

 

"Heh, well don't worry, I definitely don't have any plans to leave. Even if I end up finding someone to sweep me off my feet in a different class, I'll still be part of the Black Eagles~" 

 

Dorothea meant every word of that too, but when she saw Byleth smile brightly at her reassurance, she found herself getting all the more resolved. No matter what happened, she wanted to be by the professor’s side.

Chapter End Notes

Red: A few little scenes of Byleth getting back into the swing of things.

Indi: Yup yup, checking in on some characters and such, figured Byleth deserved a small break after everything that's happened.

Red: Shez, meanwhile, is off on the Miklan mission, which should be the next chapter.

Indi: Yup, we didn't forget about that, the black tower will be happening, as well as everything that happens with it. But for now, hope y'all enjoyed Byleth trying out fashion, as well as a gatekeeper appearance!

Red: Truly the most important appearance in this chapter.

The Bonds of Family

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Shez still really hated the cold in Faerghus. It wasn’t too bad at the moment, since the moon being Verdant Rain meant they were in summer instead of the still fairly chilly spring, but Faerghus as a whole just seemed to permeate cold whenever she visited. It didn’t help that it was the rainy season too, so they had to delay their march a couple times to take shelter when it got too heavy.

 

Apparently rain in cold areas could mean hail started falling instead of water, which just confirmed for Shez that only crazy people actually wanted to live in Faerghus.

 

It didn’t help that the mood was still really heavy. Felix’s dad had come by to visit so he was in a worse mood than usual and being annoyingly surly, which seemed to be putting Sylvain and Ingrid more on edge than they already were. Though at least those two seemed to still be fine with each other; really, Ingrid seemed to be being nicer to him in general after that talk they had, so at least things hadn’t fallen apart there.

 

Then there was Gilbert, their escorting knight for the mission. Also known as the guy who couldn’t more obviously be Annette’s father if he tried. And he really wasn’t trying.

 

"Hey, Gilbert, mind if we talk?" Shez asked as she went up to him. 

 

"Hm? Did you need to ask something about the mission?" the knight asked as he rested while they waited for the rain to stop. 

 

"Well, I wanted to ask, you're Annette's dad, right?" That seemed like a bad question to ask as it made the already stern-faced knight frown.

 

"Unless you have something to ask about the mission, then you should focus on resting." 

 

"Uh, it was just a simple question-" 

 

"If that is all, then I ask you to leave me be." With that he turned away, making it very clear he didn't want to talk with her anymore. 

 

"..." Turning around, Shez walked over to Annette. "Annette, your dad sucks." 

 

“H-Hey! Shez, you shouldn’t say that!” she complained, “He’s still my dad…”

 

“Yeah, well, you deserve better than someone who doesn’t want to be,” Shez grumbled, before noticing the hurt look on Annette’s face. “Ah, I’m sorry. It’s just that you really do deserve better. He’s a grown man, he shouldn’t be ignoring you like this.”

 

“...I know. But…But he’s still my dad, and I still want him to be my dad. You know?”

 

“I guess…Maybe it’d help if I hit him?”

 

Annette blinked, then giggled. “Shez, you can’t just punch my dad to make him acknowledge me.”

 

“No, see, that’s the smart part. It’s not just one punch, I’m gonna keep beating him up until he’s finally ready to go home and be a family man.”

 

“I don’t think that’s how that works, Shez. Also you really shouldn’t try to beat up a Knight of Seiros, you can get in trouble for that.”

 

“Not if he doesn’t know it was me. I could wear a mask. Oh, or put a bag over his head!”

 

“...” Annette gave her a concerned look. “I think you might be taking this idea too seriously, Shez. Please don’t actually beat up my dad. I’ll just…try to work this out myself, okay?”

 

“Alright, if you insist. But seriously, if you ever want me to punch him, just ask. I’ve already made the same offer to Bernadetta, I don’t mind extending it to anyone else with parental problems,” Shez said, before pausing, “Well, maybe not Felix, his issues with his dad seem more complicated than his dad just being a jerk.”

 

“Hey, my issues are complicated too!” Annette pouted.

 

“Oh sure, but I think punching your dad would actually help you, whereas Felix would probably prefer to punch his dad himself if it came to it.”

 

“...that does sound like Felix…”

 

“Hello Annie, hello Shez,” Mercedes greeted as she came over to their part of the overhang. “What are you two chatting about?”

 

“Oh, bad dads and my offer to beat them up if requested.”

 

Annette giggled. “Yeah, Shez thinks it might help with, well…yeah.”

 

“Oh, well I would not mind helping out in that case. I can certainly heal Sir Gilbert up afterwards, so you can feel free to go all out.”

 

“Pff–Mercie, come on! Don’t encourage her!”

 

Shez grinned. “Aw, but I respond way better to positive reinforcement! Actually, hey, Mercedes, do you have any bad parental figures that need beating up? If you’ve got good folks, the offer doesn’t apply, but I will beat up anybody else as offered!”

 

“Oh, no, you don’t need to. Thank you for the offer though.” Mercedes smiled. “I’ll make sure to tell you if I need anyone beaten up, though I don’t think it is very likely I’ll need that help.”

 

“Okay, but like I said, the offer still stands!” The two girls giggled again and Shez felt herself grin, her mood lightened a bit. Though she did notice Mercedes seemed a bit wistful. "Everything good there, Mercedes?" 

 

"Oh, yes, I'm just…thinking about something back at the monastery." 

 

"Anything I can help with?" 

 

"No, just…someone I need to talk with, and I've been trying to work up the courage to do so." Mercedes gave the two a small smile. "I think when we get back, I might try to talk with them." 

 

"Oh, well good luck, hope it all goes well!"

 

Though her good humor didn’t last too much longer as they continued their march to Conand Tower. Well, half-march, half-ride. The Church provided horses, which made things easier as the Blue Lions made their way towards the abandoned fort set between Fraldarius and Galatea territory.

 

Sylvain’s mood seemed to only get worse the closer they got to the fort, while Gilbert continued to stonewall Shez’s attempt to speak with him, and honestly she was just not in the mood to even bother asking what was up with Felix and his dad right now. Which meant she ended up riding near Ashe as Annette and Mercedes chatted with one another. 

 

"So… how have you been, Ashe?" the young mercenary asked, feeling a bit awkward since she hadn't talked with her friend one-on-one since the Gaspard mission. 

 

"Doing better, I think. My siblings got taken in by the local church and they seem to like it based on the letters I've gotten," Ashe responded, even as his hands trembled as they gripped the reins. "Ah, but have you heard what's happened to the Western Church?" 

 

"Uh, I heard they were the ones behind the assassination plot, but aside from the ones who got captured and executed, I don't know much else." 

 

"From what I've heard, several members of the Western Church have been arrested, and they've already been replaced, handpicked by the Royal Mage Cornelia and Regent Rufus." 

 

"Huh… that's pretty fast isn't it? I mean, I'm not sure how church stuff works, but replacing important people takes time, right?"

 

"Officially, they haven't fully replaced them," Ingrid explained as she rode near. "Lady Rhea has yet to give them her blessing, but Cornelia is someone highly important to the Kingdom, so I wouldn't doubt her choices getting the okay." 

 

"Huh… who exactly is Cornelia? All I know is what Sylvain told me, and well, it's Sylvain." 

 

"I'm not even going to ask. For reference, Cornelia is a great mage who saved the Kingdom from a plague before," Ingrid explained after letting out a sigh. "Her word carries great weight, so it may take some time, but I'm sure the Western Church will have a new bishop soon enough." 

 

"Huh. Well, it's none of my business at least. We can talk more about this when we get back, after we deal with the bandits. Will say, as much as the rain sucks, it's gonna be handy for the attack." 

 

"Really? How so?" 

 

"In my experience, anytime the weather sucks, the bandits on watch tend to slack off. Not to mention from what they told us, if they recently pillaged, they're probably getting drunk off their asses." 

 

"Huh, I guess Professor Byleth didn't get all the brains."

 

"Hey, I'm smart sometimes too!" 

 

"Tell that to your grades," Ingrid shot back, getting Ashe to laugh. 

 

Grumbling to herself, Shez stayed silent until the march came to a stop and the tower came into view. It's not her fault she couldn't remember the name of some random general during that test. "Wow, that thing is huge." 

 

"Yeah, seems like the perfect place to turn into a bandit base. Already fortified, and gives you a view in every direction," Sylvain muttered as Professor Hanneman came up to the students after talking with Gilbert. 

 

"Alright class, from what the scouting knights have informed us, there doesn't seem to be anyone on watch outside the tower, but we must still approach with caution as they can still see us from inside the tower. Gilbert shall be leading the charge into the tower, but we are not to solely rely on him." 

 

"From what we were told, it seems all of the bandits are inside the tower, so we shall be focusing on reinforcing our vanguard," Dimitri said, "Shez, Ingrid, can I trust you to protect us as our rearguard?" 

 

"Of course, your highness!" 

 

"Sure, though feel free to ask for help if it proves too much for you guys," Shez responded as she got off the horse. 

 

"Arrogance leads to mistakes," Gilbert intoned, wielding a greatshield. "Experienced mercenary or not, you would do well to remember that." 

 

"Right," Shez deadpanned as her classmates got ready for combat. Though she had to admit, this was the first time she was going up against someone with a relic weapon, so she couldn't help but wonder how that would go. 

Badly. It would go badly. But not in the way anybody expected.

 

As far as the actual bandit fight went, it was standard fare; the goons at the bottom of the tower were all drunk, so they were easy to take out, and from there it was a matter of clearing the way up the tower to where the bandit’s boss lurked. The thing is though, fortresses were made to be hard to invade. It came with the territory of being important strongholds for a nation’s army, and the long, winding path towards the center turned their assault into a slog, especially as more problems made themselves apparent.

 

The first being that there were a lot of bandits and plenty of them were much better equipped than the Lions expected. There even were a few fully decked out in genuinely tough platemail, looking like proper, if dingy, armored knights. 

 

Adding onto that was the second problem, which was that the fortress was built so soldiers on the upper levels had view of the lower levels, which meant once one of the bandits happened to notice Gilbert stomping along, the alarm was raised and suddenly those surprisingly well-equipped bandits were coming straight down to meet Shez and her friends.

 

And then, of course, there was the third problem: reinforcements from the lower levels, who proved to be the biggest pains in the ass as they nearly pincered Shez’s class between them and the goons on the upper levels.

 

Still, things went well enough. Professor Hanneman was smart and made sure everyone was well-equipped to handle the threats coming their way and despite Gilbert being about as subtle as a brick, he was actually pretty hardy and did a good job of helping them deal with the sudden ambushes from behind. Though he did also fall behind because he was a slow old man, so…

 

Anyway, the Blue Lions managed to get their way to the top well enough, which meant it wasn’t long before they came face to face with Miklan, boss of the bandits and Sylvain’s disowned brother.

 

“What the hell is this?” growled the scarred redhead, glaring out at the students from his spot on the upper floor. The lance in his hand was unmistakably a relic, one with an actual crest stone in it, unlike Byleth’s new sword. “Did those self-righteous dastards really send a bunch of noble brats to come steal my damn birthright?!”

 

"Pretty sure you lost the right to that years ago," Sylvain said, getting the glare focused onto him. 

 

" You. Of course you would come to ruin something else for me," the bandit leader growled out, venom dripping from every word, “If it weren’t for you–!” 

 

"Just shut up already! I'm tired of hearing you blaming me for something that isn't my fault!" 

 

"Then I'll just kill you! Slaughter the men and capture the women, but leave that one for me!" Miklan shouted, ordering his men as he pointed at Sylvain with the lance. With that, the final battle of the tower broke out.

 

Shez had to admit, even though he was complete scum who deserved execution, Miklan was a surprisingly tough fighter. The fact he had heavy armor and a relic probably helped, but from what she saw of his moves, the man knew how to fight and had actual training instead of the improvised styles most bandits developed. 

 

Not that she actually fought him; whatever he and Sylvain had going on seemed way too personal, so she stuck to taking down the remaining bandits while Sylvain and Dimitri took the lead on breaking through the dastard’s defenses and scoring actual hits that pushed him back further and further as the weapon in his hand glowed brighter and brighter.

 

Thunder boomed outside the tower as Miklan snarled another insult towards his foes…and then the stone began to bleed. Black liquid surged up Miklan’s arm as though it were alive, and it wasn’t long before the bandit started screaming as it dug under his armor and into his skin.

 

“What the hell…” Sylvain breathed, staring as the Lance of Ruin consumed his brother. 

 

Miklan screamed one last time as the liquid surged up over his head and dug into his eyes, and then something else started screaming.

 

“Is that…So this is where those creatures originate from,” Arval muttered in Shez’s mind while she stared at the black demonic beast that had just formed right in front of them. “I should have known. What a foul existence.”

 

The monstrosity roared, spit dripping from it’s massive maw before it surged forward, its massive hand lunging down to grab one of the bandits that hadn’t retreated yet.

 

“W-Wha–N-No! Boss–!” 

 

A sickening crunch echoed out as the black beast smashed its prey against the ground before throwing the broken corpse against a wall. There was no longer any intelligence in its gleaming red eyes, not even a hunger for flesh like others of its kind. All it had was malice, and it was directed right at Shez and her classmates.

 

“Your highness, get behind me!” Gilbert ordered, stepping in front of Dimitri–Who just pushed past him without hesitating.

 

“There’s no time for that! This beast is a threat to everyone here! And if we allow it to escape, it will be a threat to everyone in Faerghus!” Dimitri gazed up at the beast, his grip tightening on his spear. “I’m sorry it had to come to this, but there’s no way back now. This monster has to die.”

 

“He’s being awfully dramatic right now,” Arval noted, unimpressed, before floating beside Shez, “Well, partner? You’ve dealt with creatures like this before. Shouldn’t you lend your expertise?”

 

“Should I? This one’s kind of different.”

 

“Are you referring to your classmate’s personal investment or the beast’s black hide? Either way, it doesn’t change the fact that it needs to die. And that your classmates have little heed for tactics.”

 

“I’m not exactly the tactical type either, Arval,” Shez muttered, before grinning a little, “Though I guess that makes me the right girl for the job here. HEY DIMITRI!”

 

The prince paused, glancing over at his classmate just as her shout caught the beast’s attention. “What is it, Shez?”

 

“Big guy’s like these take a lot of hits, but sometimes their hides are weaker to certain weapons! Plus, the more you wear ‘em down, the easier they get! So I’m gonna distract it while you guys skewer it!”

 

“Distract it!?” Hanneman exclaimed, the professor catching up right in time for him to hear Shez’s brilliant plan. “Young lady, now isn’t the time for heroics–”

 

And then Shez let loose her awakened form, her eyes and hair glowing a fiery orange while white markings appeared across her face before she rushed straight in, moving faster and hitting harder as she scored deep cuts across the beast’s hide.

 

“...Could she always do that?” Annette asked as their classmate carved through the thick armor of a massive demonic beast.

 

“Ah, yes, she could,” Hanneman noted, “It came up during the crest examination and she used it during the mock battle, though I did not realize her empowered form was this effective…Ah, and we really should be helping her now. Come on students, we have a beast to put down!”

 

Massive monstrosity though it might be, the black beast soon found its intimidating entrance didn’t quite live up to its ability, at least when it came to several people surrounding it and repeatedly attacking its increasing weak points. Every wound Shez left on its body was another opening for the others to strike at. Lances plunged into open wounds, arrows sunk into its flesh, magic rained down on its head, and all the while, Shez kept ripping gaping tears straight through the beast’s hide until it was a screeching, writhing mess, too disoriented to do little more than flail at whatever last caused it pain.

 

Of course, that flailing was still extremely dangerous, so it was best that the students keep their distance, but it wasn’t long before the thing was stumbling, its struggles getting weaker by the second.

 

“...Can’t say I wanted it to end like this,” Sylvain muttered, staring at the pitiful wreck his brother had become.
