“Nor can I,” Dimitri agreed, “But there is nothing more we can do than end his misery.”

 

“...Yeah, you’re right.”

 

And with that, the two friends took advantage of the beast’s stunned state to drive their lances up into its chest, piercing what would have been its heart, were it still human. Whatever they hit was still vital though, and the pair stepped back to avoid the beast’s death throes as its screeching turned more pitiful than intimidating.

 

Then the beast died, and its form burst away, leaving only the corpse of Miklan with the Lance of Ruin in his limp hand.

 

“Goddess…the beast is gone, yet Miklan and the lance remain,” Gilbert muttered at the sight, “What sort of–”

 

“Oh, is it over?” Shez asked, startling the knight as she suddenly appeared by his side, “Huh, that was convenient, it usually takes a lot more effort to get rid of the corpse, wow.”

 

To the surprise of most there, Sylvain snorted at Shez’s statement. “Well we’ve still gotta bury the body, so if you really want to get on that…”

 

“Awww, but I hate that part,” Shez complained as everyone noticed her markings were still in place. And that one of her swords had actually broken during the fight.

 

“...Were you cutting through that beast’s hide with a broken sword?” Dimitri asked.

 

“Hm? Hm, yeah, looks like it, that’s kind of funny, though now I need a new sword, can I have yours?”

 

“...Pardon?”

 

Sylvain couldn’t help it. “C’mon Dimitri, a girl asked for your sword. You should know what to do in this situation.”

 

“...Sylvain, your brother’s dead on the floor right there. Is now really the time?”

 

“Eh, it’s what he would’ve wanted.”

 

“What??”

 

“Or, well, it’s what I want and I just hate his guts even now, so yeah.”

 

Dimitri sighed as Ingrid came up to Sylvain. Rather than slap him upside the head though, the blonde just took Sylvain by the wrist and started leading him away, earning a confused blink from the redhead before he just decided to allow it and followed his friend.

 

“...So have you been holding back in all of our spars?” Felix asked with a scowl, prompting a glance from Shez.

 

“Yeah, duh, I would kill you if I didn’t.”

 

Felix scowled even deeper at that statement, then turned his glare towards the sword in Shez’s hand. “Hmph. Show me your sword.”

 

“No. I don’t like the way you asked that. Say please.”

 

“Er, Shez, is your…current state influencing your thoughts at all?” Dimitri asked, earning a pause from his glowing classmate before the glow suddenly faded and she shook her head.

 

“Bleh. Okay, I’m good. Did I insult anybody?”

 

“You said you would kill me if you fought me seriously,” Felix stated, still irritated.

 

“Oh. Ah, well, the thing is, I probably would? Like, if we fought, fought, I’d probably be trying to kill you, right?” She paused, thinking. “Though, then again, you’re a noble and Victor always says you should aim to capture nobles alive for a ransom.”

 

“...Are you sure your mental state isn’t still being altered?” Dimitri asked.

 

“Huh? No, I think I’m good. So are we cutting off Miklan’s head for this job or what?”

 

“...Hm. No, I do not believe that is necessary. Let’s just retrieve the relic and be on our way.”

 

"Uh, you sure that's safe? We just saw someone get turned into a giant monster from wielding it." 

 

"Hence why Sylvain will be holding it, since he has the crest of Gautier. What we saw was a punishment of the goddess for wielding a relic weapon without a crest, so Sylvain will be safe." 

 

"...if you say so,” Shez agreed with a shrug, “Gotta say, this crest stuff is really weird." 

 

"Do you require another lesson?" Hanneman asked as the Blue Lions made their way back down the tower, all while the knights cleared away the bodies behind them.

 

"No, just…it's weird I guess. All this happened because he didn't have a crest?" 

 

"Yes, it did,” Dimitri said, “While I do not agree with Margrave Gautier for disinheriting Miklan, it is true that crests are of grave importance to the kingdom. They are the blades we use to fight off invaders and to keep our lands safe. The Gautiers have long since held off invaders from Sreng, which grants them many special privileges in the Kingdom, but, as such, it is necessary for the heirs of Gautier to bear their crest, so they may wield the relic weapon." 

 

"Okay, I get that, but are they really that important?” Shez asked, “I mean, I've met many strong people who don't have crests, and just cause you have a crest doesn't mean you’re strong." 

 

"In that, we can agree on. A crest alone cannot be used to measure ability, but even so, there's a reason this tradition has stood the test of time. If we didn't put any stock into crests, then bloodlines with the crests would dwindle, and the blades we use to defend our land would soon be forgotten." 

 

"I dunno, that seems like it's mainly just affecting you nobles. It's like you said, a crest isn't a measure of ability, so it shouldn’t also be something people rely on so much." 

 

"To be clear," Hanneman interjected. "As a Holy Kingdom, Faerghus is able to enjoy its sovereignty by the blessing of the goddess and the Church of Seiros. To turn away from those blessings could be tantamount to blasphemy, in the eyes of some." 

 

"I guess? Still seems weird to me." 

 

"I suppose it must be because your father's mercenary band hasn't really traveled in Faerghus often,” Dimitri considered, “Though I will say, House Gautier is a bit of an exception. Other house heads from different families have been known to not have crests. Ingrid's father, for example, bears no crest." 

 

"Though Miss Ingrid does have a lot of responsibility on her shoulders as the only one of her siblings to have a crest," Hanneman inputted. 

 

"Yes, perhaps things would have been simpler if her elder siblings or Miklan had also been born with crests," Dimitri said with a sigh, getting Shez to stop walking.

 

"...Dimitri, I know you mean well, but you really say some stupid shit sometimes." 

 

The prince blinked. “Pardon?”

 

“If Miklan was born with a crest, Sylvain wouldn’t exist,” Shez bluntly explained, “And I don’t know as much about Ingrid’s family, but do you think she would exist either if any of her brothers had been born with crests? Because from how it sounds, noble families up here only seem to have as many kids as they need to in order to get an heir with a crest.”

 

“Ah…well, that is not entirely correct. Duke Fraldarius had Felix after his first son was revealed to have a crest, so–”

 

“Right, but is that what would’ve happened with Sylvain’s dad? Or Ingrid’s family? Would either of your friends exist if their siblings had crests?”

 

“...” Dimitri sighed, then tried to smile. “Well, I’ll admit, you make a fair point. Dwelling on ‘what if’ doesn’t really help, does it?”

 

“Nope. What happened, happened, and you just have to deal with it from that point on.”

 

“...Yes, that is very true,” he murmured, his head lowering in thought, all while he tried to ignore the whispers in the back of his mind, speaking in the voices of the long dead. Dwelling on ‘What if’ would not help any of them…

The trip back to the monastery was rather uneventful, as the rain finally let up, allowing them to return faster. The only thing of note was Gilbert leaving the group as he went to help the villagers who had lost their homes thanks to the bandits. Shez understood why he was doing it, but at the same time, it meant Annette lost her chance to talk to her dad until he showed up at the monastery again. 

 

Sylvain was also a bit more quiet, the young man trailing behind the group as he had the lance of Ruin on his back. Apparently Hanneman was going to make a case for him being able to keep the spear at the request of his father, which Rhea probably wasn't going to be happy with. Honestly Shez still thought it was probably a better idea to lock it away with what happened to Miklan, but it wasn't her decision. 

 

Speaking of her decisions…

 

"So, are you actually going to transfer classes?" Ingrid asked. 

 

"...Yeah, I think I am. Nothing against you guys, but I think this was just a bad year to join the Blue Lions, you know?" 

 

"I can understand that at least. It was certainly hectic. Don't think this means I'll go easy on you during the Battle of Eagle and Lion. Though, do you mind telling me which class you're joining?" 

 

"Not sure. Either class seems like a good choice, if I'm being honest. Though I imagine you'd prefer it if I joined the Golden Deer." 

 

"...If I'm being honest, yes." 

 

"Mind telling me why exactly you don't like the Black Eagles?" 

 

"It's not them specifically, just more so the Empire in general. You know about the Tragedy of Duscur, right?" At her nod, Ingrid continued. "Back then, many people lost their lives… including Felix's brother and… my fiance, Glenn." 

 

"Oh, uh, my bad. Didn't mean to bring up bad memories like that." 

 

"It's alright, I should talk about this… back then, when it first occurred, I hated the people of Duscur. I still carry some anger there, really, but…rumors started to spread that the people of the Empire were behind it, in some misbegotten revenge for their regent who passed away in an accident. At that, my anger could only grow. Why would they target so many for something that was just an accident? Why did so many great people have to die…" 

 

"That… I guess I can see what you mean. If Byleth was killed I'd be angry too, but they're just rumors, yeah? And like, the tragedy happened four years ago, right? Pretty sure everyone in the Black Eagles still would have been kids back then… well, maybe aside from Hubert, that dude looks like he's been alive longer than my dad," Shez said, cracking a joke and making Ingrid laugh. 

 

"...You know, Petra said something similar. For the longest time I wasn't sure why she'd be okay with working alongside the people who subjugated hers, but I think I get it." Ingrid shook her head with a rueful smile. "If nothing else, I'll trust that your sister is a good judge of character." 

 

"You should, By might not act like it, but she picks up on things easily!" 

 

"I suppose so," Ingrid agreed, before glancing over at Dedue. "...I should probably talk to Dedue when I get the chance." 

 

"Well we're almost back, so you'll have plenty of chances," Shez replied as they arrived at the town surrounding the monastery. "But I think I'll focus on taking a warm bath first." 

 

"Never quite developed that cold blood huh?" 

 

"Nope! The warmer the better!" Shez said, smiling before she noticed a blonde girl approaching the group with flowers. She seemed kinda familiar, but she didn’t look like a student, considering the white blouse and navy blue skirt she was wearing weren’t from the usual uniform. 

 

"Here you go Dedue, happy birthday." Huh, that sounded a lot like–did her hair just turn red? 

 

"Oh, thank you?" Dedue asked, unsure of who was handing him flowers as the girl nodded in response. 

 

"How'd the mission go, Shez?" she asked as her hair turned brown.

 

"...By, is that you?" 

 

"Yeah?" 

 

"...Why is your hair changing colors!?" 

 

"Oh, right." As if finally acknowledging her now black hair, Byleth grabbed a few strands. "It's a spell Constance did. It should be gone in a day or two, apparently." 

 

"And the new outfit??" 

 

"Do you like it?" Byleth asked, looking down at herself. "Dorothea helped pick it out for me. I felt like getting some new clothes." 

 

"...I'm joining the Black Eagles." 

 

"Sylvain!" 

 

"What?? Can you blame me??" 

 

"No, but I can hit you." 

Chapter End Notes

Indi: To be clear, Sylvain isn't actually joining the Eagles, but we felt that ending off on a lighthearted joke would be good.

Red: It's still funny that the easiest way to recruit Sylvain is to play as Female-Byleth. Just instantly brings him over with the power of shorts and tights.

Indi: Fight against your friends and nation cause the new teacher is cute. Meanwhile Gilbert is being Gilbert.

Red: Ah, Gilbert. You might've noticed, dear readers, that we try to give most characters a fair shake in our stories with the awareness that they have their own motivations and reasons for what they do, and while their choices might not be the best, they're still made with what they believe to be good reasons. Gilbert's no different, but hoo boy is it a bad look to abandon his family completely and then not even try to get back in contact.

Indi: The most wild part to me is how he actively ran away from her in Three Houses when she got to the monastery.

Red: Yeaaaaaah. What's with Faerghus men and massive guilt complexes? I swear, it's a huge problem with them.

Indi: Among the many other issues. Like seriously Shez grew up in a snowy mountain village and she still wasn't ready for the cold and harsh winters of Faerghus.

Red: Well at least she got out while she can and will never have to go back. Ever. Probably.

Welcome Back

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

“Pss pss pss! C’mon kitty!” Shez encouraged, trying to get the cute little black kitty cat to pay attention to her. “Ugh, By makes this look so easy…do I need to get on my back? Is that it? I swear, she can just lay down and suddenly there’s a cat using her chest as its pillow–”

 

“Shez? What are you…doing?”

 

Shez blinked, then glanced over at the sudden voice interrupting her catcalling, in a more literal sense of the word. “Oh, hey princess. What’s up?”

 

“I believe that is what I was asking you,” Edelgard replied with a small frown, before she noticed a familiar kitty lazily watching the violet-haired student, “...Are you bothering this kit–ah, this cat?”

 

“Hey, I’m not bothering him! Well, I think. I’m just trying to get the kitty cat to come over to me. Byleth pets these little guys all the time and I wanted to get in on that. Though, I'm not having much luck," Shez explained, before turning back to the kitty. 

 

As she did, she let out a small gasp as she saw the cat get up and slowly approach her. Only for it to walk right past her and rub up against Edelgard. 

 

"..." 

 

"..." Edelgard tried to keep an even face as Shez looked up at her with a look of complete betrayal. 

 

"...Is this because I teased you back at the abyss?" 

 

"I am not doing this on purpose," Edelgard defended herself, feeling a bit bad as she ignored the meowing Whiskerton. "Regardless, I didn't know you liked cats." 

 

"Well, I guess they're okay. Just keeping myself busy," Shez responded a little mulishly, though she still scooted over and a big grin spread across her face once she managed to pet the kitty.

 

"Oh?" 

 

"Yeah, the mission today was my last with the Blue Lions. Starting tomorrow, I'm officially a Golden Deer." 

 

"Hm, I'm surprised you didn't ask to join the Black Eagles if you were planning to switch classes. I do remember you asking to join near the start of the year." 

 

"Well, maybe later in the year, but as is, I'm just trying to have fun." 

 

"Attending a prestigious academy is certainly not a place that most people would go to have fun." 

 

"Yeah, but it's not like I joined willingly." Letting out a huff, Shez stood up, which prompted a small, unamused mew from Whiskerton. "Besides, I'm already a professional mercenary. Aside from making some friends, it's not like I'll get anything big from being here." 

 

"The future leaders of the three nations are currently attending, so I wouldn't say you would not get anything." 

 

"And it's not like I'm going to swear loyalty to them," Shez responded, "Like, if the school were to suddenly shut down or something, it's not like I'm going to stay over in Derdriu with Claude. If he had any immediate problems I'd help him out, but I'd leave right afterwards to meet up with By. Or vice versa, I guess, if By comes to meet me first." 

 

“Hm…but wouldn’t having a noble patron be a boon for a mercenary?”

 

“Sure, it’d probably be great, but my family has always been fine traveling around. I don’t know how long dad’s going to stick with this Knight Captain thing, but my plan is to go wherever Byleth goes.”

 

“And what if she were to stay at this Academy?”

 

Shez paused, then shrugged. “Then I guess I’ll wander around for a bit. I could stick around here, maybe, but I could probably get some work with some of the people I’ve met here, right? Maybe work for Dimitri for a year or two, then hop over to Claude? Or hey, if you’re paying, I wouldn’t mind working for you.”

 

“...You really do have a remarkably mercenary mindset."

 

"Well, yeah. I was one even before I met By and Dad." 

 

"You were?" 

 

"Yeah, I didn't see much fighting back then, but it was pretty much all I could do after mom died. Mom didn't really talk with anyone from the village, so no one was that interested in taking me in," Shez explained, "Hell, I'm lucky dad decided to keep me around, or else I'd have to wander around till I found another group to work with." 

 

"Hm…that sounds rather sad." 

 

"Yeah, but it comes with the territory. I don't have to worry about my family or the 'officers' cuz they're strong, but new faces keep coming and going for one reason or another. If I worried about trying to keep everyone alive, then I'd get stuck in a rut. That's why it's By’s job to keep everyone alive, while it's mine to make sure there's no one around to hurt them." 

 

"Hm…and if you were to end up on opposite sides?" 

 

"Not happening. There's not enough money in the world to make me want to fight against By in a war." At that, Shez grinned. "We're a package deal, you want one you gotta hire the other." 

 

"Well I'll certainly keep that in mind." And she would. The sisters were plainly loyal to one another, more than anyone outside of their family. That could be leveraged easily.

 

Hubert would probably suggest holding one hostage to ensure the compliance of the other, but Edelgard was certain, from all evidence provided, that such an action would only ensure she had an enemy for life where she could have made an ally. And she would much rather have the Eisners on her side than any of Those Who Slither in the Dark.

 

"Thanks! Anyways, I was going to have a small little party later with Dedue since it's his birthday. Did you want to come along?"

 

"Oh, I would hate to intrude, but do send along my well wishes." 

 

"Sure thing, take care!" Shez said with a grin before she walked away, feeling thankful that her sister had some nice students in her class.

Slamming her fist onto the table in front of her, Bias glared at nothing as she tried to figure out just what the hell was happening. 

 

It doesn't make sense! If Shez hadn't been the one to kill Pittacus, then who was? There was no way it could have just been an accident! For all his many, many flaws, Thales wasn't the type to die in a mere accident, and even if Pittacus wasn't as strong, she should have been smart enough to escape an attack. 

 

However, even if Shez was innocent, and Bias certainly disliked admitting that possibility, that didn't mean she was completely without use. For an Agarthan to show up here, with no notice from Myson, meant it was clear where her loyalty lay. If Cleobulus had indeed gone rogue, then they needed to find out what she was planning. 

 

On the one hand, the fact that Shez had made contact with Kronya was a showing that she was willing to work with them. On the other hand, she was actively avoiding Solon, something she would only do if she did know who he was disguised as. Something most rank and file wouldn't know, while Cleobulus would. 

 

There was also the possibility of Myson getting too big for his britches and sending someone without informing them. Regardless, the only way to know for sure was to extract the info from Shez directly. Now, how would they do that…?

 

"I see time has done little for that anger of yours," Solon commented as he entered the backroom, looking down at the cracked table. 

 

"Forgive me for trying to figure out what a potential traitor might be planning," Bias shot back, "When was the last time we had any word from Cleobulus?" 

 

"What she is doing is of no matter, you foolish child," Solon scolded, "Even if she has gone rogue, she is still working to erode the kingdom. And even if she plots against us, she cannot hope to face us with the forces of that pathetic nation. There was a reason Thales chose to usurp the empire as the force we would use against these vile beasts."

 

“Ah yes, of course, the empire we barely have a hold on anymore.” Bia scowled, her eyes narrowed as she tried to think. “...Could the hegemon be lying to us? If that brat Shez actually was–”

 

“Cease your prattle,” Solon ordered and Bias felt herself stiffen at the command. For a moment, she felt like a mere apprentice again, laboring under her mentor’s critical eye. “There is no value in investigating a matter long settled. Thales is dead, and we must move on for the sake of freeing the world from the abominations that seek to rule us.”

 

“In that case, interrogating Shez is our best option, so we may learn what she is planning! Even if Cleobulus can’t defeat us directly, she is a thorn we cannot ignore.”

 

“Bah, fine. If you wish to frolic among the beasts, go ahead. The ‘lions’ are hosting a party of some type in the dining hall. If you’re so desperate to learn, then make your excuses to be there and be off.”

 

Bias grimaced, but nodded to her mentor. She was used to harsh words from the elder sage. He was always like this, thinking himself better than everyone all while he called himself the Saviour of Agartha…it was almost enough to drive a woman mad. 

 

Keeping her thoughts to herself, Bias began to walk away. 

 

Easily shifting back to the facade of the ever pleasant nun, Selene gently smiled at any who looked her way. A part of her idly wondered if she should just blow her cover so she wouldn't need to hide here anymore. It was disgusting having to pretend to be a nun for that horrid beast that pushed her people underground. Perhaps, once this was all over, she would be allowed to be part of the team that destroyed the monastery. If nothing else, seeing the Cathedral burn down would bring her great pleasure. 

 

Soon enough, the Agarthan arrived at the dining hall to find the Lions were indeed all there, apparently celebrating the beast from Duscur for some reason. There seemed to be two groups in particular, with the prince, two of the females, and the gray-haired rat gathered about the massive beast while ‘Shez’ was in a separate gathering with a few of the ‘noble’ heirs. 

 

Frowning, Selene began to move closer to hear what they were saying. 

 

“I can’t believe the time for summer uniforms came and went while I was dealing with my piece of crap brother,” the Gautier beast complained, “Why is the goddess so cruel to those that deserve it the least?”

 

"...Alright what are you complaining about now?" asked the Galatea, completely confused. 

 

"Apparently Professor Byleth wore a summer uniform while we were gone and Lorenz, of all people, made sure to let me know how much of a shame it was that I missed it. Apparently that coat of hers seriously hides how great the professor’s hips look." 

 

"...So I didn't know you were friends with Lorenz," Shez commented, trying to pivot the conversation away from the topic of her sister’s figure.

 

"Oh, not really. We just had a few friendly competitions here and there." 

 

"Oh? What kind?" Shez asked, her interest piqued. 

 

"Of the flirting variety." Ah yes, Selene was well aware of Gautier’s attempts at 'flirting'. One would think being a nun would mean she would be free from such advances. They would be sorely mistaken.

 

"...With each other?" 

 

“What? No. If I was flirting with a dude, he’d have to be way prettier than Lorenz.”

 

“Do you ever actually listen to yourself speak?” Fraldarius asked, already looking done with this conversation despite contributing to it.

 

"I prefer listening to ladies talking." 

 

"Then stop talking already," the swordsman snarked. 

 

"I don't think Sylvain could survive if he couldn't talk," Shez commented, “It’s basically breathing for him.”

 

“Hey, come on now, I can keep quiet! I’m great at staying quiet!”

 

“Then prove it,” Fraldarius ordered, scowling as he did. 

 

"Nah I don't feel like it," Gautier responded, getting Shez to laugh as his two fellow lions let out a pair of sighs.

 

"..." Bias, meanwhile, could only question how these people happened to be the ones who got to live in the sun. The False Goddess these beasts worshipped was truly a cruel thing to favor such wretched–

 

"Did you want to join?" Turning around with a start, Bias found the dull-eyed beast standing behind her. 

 

"Excuse me?" 

 

"It looked like you were interested in the party," the professor explained, glancing over her shoulder towards the chattering vermin. 

 

"Ah, well, no, I was just curious, that's all." 

 

"Okay. Feel free to join if you want to," the dullard said with a nod, before walking past her to join in. With a barely disguised scowl, Bias watched the newly minted professor greet the students and her sister. The two seemed close, and that sent an unpleasant pang through the sage’s chest. For a brief moment, she wondered if killing one would make the other come after her in revenge. A part of her wanted to, if just to share the pain around.

 

No matter. She would just have to deal with both if it came down to it.

“Mmf, woo, might have overdone it today,” Shez mumbled to herself as she walked along the darkened halls of the monastery, dimly lit by lantern light in the evening.

 

Of course, with Arval, she was never just mumbling to herself. “My word, could it be? The bottomless pit you call a belly has actually been filled? Quick, alert the Knights! A harbinger of the end times has made itself known!”

 

“Uuuugh, shut it, Arval. It’s not just the food, it’s the sweets. Didn’t expect Mercedes to get that into baking for Dedue. I swear, she must’ve been trying to show off with all those cakes…”

 

“That was impressive, admittedly. A shame I can’t taste such pastries, though I suppose I can derive some satisfaction from your own enjoyment, my gluttonous partner.”

 

“If I’m a glutton, what’s that make By?”

 

“Hm…a gourmand? Though I wouldn’t call her a connoisseur by any means.” They huffed, faintly amused. “I don’t think there’s even an item on the menu that sister of yours dislikes.”

 

“Yeah, she’s never been picky…hm. Hey, Arval, where are we?”

 

“...Partner. Are you telling me you were walking without a destination in mind?”

 

“No, I was heading back to my dorm.”

 

“...Your dorm is on the first floor. We are on a second floor. Do you see where there may be an issue in your thinking?”

 

“Oh…Well, huh. To be fair to me, this place is really easy to get lost in.”

 

“Ah, I thought I heard a voice.”

 

“Yeah, duh, I’ve been speaking–” That wasn’t Arval’s voice.

 

Shez blinked, then turned around in some surprise to see that weird librarian guy. “Oh, hey…you.”

 

“Hello yourself, young lady. Are you lost?”

 

“Nah, not really. I’m just taking a walk to settle my stomach,” Shez lied, “I ate too much at dinner, you know how it is.”

 

“Hahaha, yes, I’m quite aware of how youth tends to lead to overestimation of one’s abilities. Or, in this case, capacity for consumption. Ah, but I digress. I’ve been hoping to talk to you for a time, young Miss Eisner, but you never come by the library unless by accident.”

 

“Oh, well, y’know. I’m busy with student stuff,” she lied again. She wasn’t sure what it was about this guy, but something about him just felt off to her. It was a weird feeling too, like he was familiar but not.

 

“Still, I was hoping to speak to you, and I am quite glad I have finally cornered you.”

 

Arval frowned. “I don’t like that word he just used. ‘Cornered’ is an unpleasant turn of phrase for a mere conversation.”

 

“Well, you found me. So what’s up?” Shez asked while wondering if she would have to fight an old man.

 

“Your mother’s name was Periander, was it not?”

 

Shez blinked, completely caught off guard. “Ah–Hold on, what? You knew my mom?”

 

“Not directly. I was aware of her, as I was aware of many individuals of interest operating within our community. You see, your mother actually stole something very important from us." 

 

"...She did?" Shez asked, taking a step back. 

 

"Yes, it was something of an experiment you see, meant to grant someone the power of a God. However, for some reason, your mother decided to steal it and ran away." 

 

"Sorry to say, I don't know what you're talking about. Mom didn't tell me much about her past." 

 

"Is that so? Have you not wondered about that ability of yours? That mysterious blade you seem capable of summoning seems quite powerful, doesn't it? Far stronger than any other you've seen, I imagine." 

 

"Heh, thanks for the compliment, but nah, not interested in finding out," Shez said, taking another step back, debating whether she should try jumping out the window or risk one of the students' rooms. 

 

"Really? I myself find it quite intriguing. And I suppose if you don’t, then that just means you're a failed experiment, does it not?" Tomas said, bringing his hand up as he formed a sigil. 

 

Shez had only a moment to jump back, trying to create some distance between her and the librarian, before she felt herself falling over as everything turned dark. 

 

The last thing she heard before everything went black was Arval shouting in panic, and the yowling of a cat.

Chapter End Notes

Red: So that's both Eisner sisters abducted at this point. I wonder if that means Jeralt is next on the list? Or will we just go for Byleth again?

Indi: Or maybe all three? Who knows, only time will tell. Either way the Agarthans are making moves!

Red: It was about time. They've just been hanging out for a while now, letting folks like Aelfric and Miklan take up the antagonist role.

Indi: and trust us, we got plans for how this will end.

Red: That we do! So we hope you all tune in next time! See you then!

Kidnapping

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

"Hello again, Professor Byleth. It’s always a pleasure to see you at the beginning of a new month," Rhea said with a smile on her face, “I hope classes have been going well for you now that you’re back to teaching.”

 

Byleth gave a polite smile in return. "Yeah, it feels nice being able to teach again, especially with so many new students." 

 

"Let's hope it is not too hectic for you. For now though, we must speak about this month’s mission-" 

 

"Rhe–Lady Archbishop!" Seteth yelled, panic evident in his voice as he ran into the audience chambers. "Flayn is missing!" 

 

"What?"

 

"Seteth, please calm down,” Rhea requested, “Tell me what happened." 

 

"Professor, have you seen her anywhere!?" Seteth asked, clearly unable to calm down as he focused on Byleth instead. 

 

"No, do you want me to help look for her?" 

 

"Please, she might be in danger!" 

 

"Professor, perhaps you would allow me to discuss things with Seteth first?" Rhea asked.

 

"No, if she's missing we should look for her right away,” Byleth stated, “I can get my students to help out if need be." 

 

"...you're right, time is of the essence. Seteth, inform the other professors. Professor Byleth, please tell your own class as well. We'll have the knights search the town, so the students shall scour the monastery." 

 

"Very well." Bowing to Rhea, Byleth glanced at Seteth. "I'll make sure to find her." 

 

"Thank you, Professor." 

"Flayn has gone missing?" Edelgard asked, trying to keep a sign of shock in her voice. 

 

"Yes, we'll be searching for any sign of her,” Byleth explained, “If you find anything then you're to immediately inform me." 

 

“Of course! We will scour the entire monastery for her at once!” Ferdinand declared, practically volunteering to lead the charge.

 

"Hm, I imagine the knights have already started searching the Abyss, but Hapi and I shall meet up with Yuri to see if he has heard of anything!" Constance said, also already making plans, which earned her a side eye from Hapi.

 

"Hm…I heard Flayn has a major crest. Perhaps she was kidnapped because of it?" Linhardt guessed. 

 

"Are we sure she got kidnapped? For all we know she just ran away,” Emily muttered, prompting a frown from Dorothea.

 

“Is now really the time to suggest a girl like Flayn might have eloped?”

 

“Did I say anything about eloping? Who would even want her like that? She’s tiny.”

 

“You’re shorter than Edie.” 

 

"Any guesses we make now will be purely conjecture. What we need to do is get information first," Hubert interrupted, his own tone even and firm as the noble and commoner glared at one another. 

 

"Yeah, we need to get out there right away!" Caspar decided, ready to take up the charge!

 

"Oh no, I hope nothing bad happened to her…" Bernadetta mumbled, not at all willing to take up any charge.

 

"I pray the goddess is protecting Flayn," Marianne murmured, clasping her hands in a hopeful prayer instead of participating in any sort of charge.

 

"For now, we should spread out. Make sure to be careful everyone." Nodding, Byleth dismissed her class before they all went out to look for Flayn. 

 

"Professor, if I may." Turning, Byleth noticed Edelgard and Hubert approaching her. "I wanted to discuss what we were going to do. If we are to search for Flayn, then we must work on the assumption she did get kidnapped, and didn't just run away." 

 

"Yeah, Flayn wouldn't run away,” Byleth agreed, “Seteth may be overbearing but they do care for one another." 

 

"Glad we are in agreement,” Edelgard said, thinking up her next words carefully. While she had no love for Rhea’s kind, if Those Who Slither were able to successfully take Flayn away, then it would cause too many problems down the line. So while she did agree to letting Jeritza kidnap her, there were no stipulations she couldn't foil their plans. "For now, let's try to see who would benefit the most from kidnapping her. It likely isn't someone looking to make a profit since they left no message of any sort, so their goal must be beyond a monetary reward."

 

“We can also assume she’s alive. There would be no point in abducting her if simple murder was the objective,” Hubert chimed in. “It’s only logical.” 

 

“Hm, I’ll keep that in mind. You make sure to be careful, they might not stop at just Flayn,” Byleth said, nodding to them before going off, leaving the two alone in the room.

 

“How much time do you think we have, Lady Edelgard?” 

 

“A few days at most. They’ve probably already extracted her blood, but whatever they might be planning will take more resources than whatever they have at the monastery here,” Edelgard guessed, “We should still be careful not to let them know we’re working against their plans.” 

 

“I doubt Emily will be smart enough to notice, and Bias seems far more interested in Shez. Given that said girl might also be working against them, that only leaves Solon.” Yes, the final Slitherer in the academy. Perhaps if she had stayed in contact with them she would know who he was disguised as, but as it stood, all she knew was that he was a member of the staff. Though that was enough for her to warn Monica never to be alone with any member of the staff when she went to the academy.

 

“For now, just attempt to look busy with the search, and try to point the professor to Jeritza if she finds no leads.” 

 

“Very well, Lady Edelgard.” 

Trying to find someone missing was quite the challenge for Byleth. Rescuing people was never her forte as a mercenary, especially since Shez could travel much faster than her and warp away with the people she found, so all she could really do was walk around the monastery and investigate as best she could, which mostly involved asking people what they knew. Though that led to its own problems, she kept getting pointed towards different people: Alois, Gilbert, and even Shamir were pointed to as suspicious individuals. 

 

Not that they had anything to do with it. Sure, she might not know Gilbert or Shamir that well, but the former had only just returned from assisting in the Kingdom, while the latter had Catherine vouching for her. And while she might still have her issues with Catherine, Byleth could at least be sure of her loyalty, if nothing else.

 

“Hm, it really is odd, there’s been no demand for a ransom, and the perpetrator was able to grab her without anyone noticing. Maybe it was someone she knew?” Claude guessed as Byleth was asking around for more info. “She might have gone along willingly if it was someone she trusted.” 

 

“But Flayn doesn’t really know anyone that well. At least not enough to follow someone out of the monastery without telling anyone.” 

 

“Hey Claude!” Looking over, the two saw Ingrid and Sylvain approaching. “Have you seen Shez?”

 

“Not today, why do you ask?”

 

“What do you mean you haven’t seen her? Didn’t she transfer over to your class?” Sylvain asked.

 

“First I’ve heard about this. She certainly wasn’t in my class when Manuela told us the news about Flayn.” 

 

Byleth felt strange. Like there was a pit opening in her stomach. “...When was the last time you two saw her?” 

 

“Uh, back at the party last night? She went off to her dorm afterwards. We haven’t seen her since.” 

 

“...You don’t think Shez might have–” Whatever Claude was about to say, Byleth didn’t hear as she ran off, immediately going to Shez’s room hoping to find her sister had just overslept.

 

“Wait for us!” It seemed the three students were worried too since they followed behind her, but she wasn’t focused on that. 

 

And while Byleth had felt fear before, it hadn’t prepared her for the sudden panic that hit when she saw her sister’s bed was empty.

 

“...No no no no,” she murmured, before moving into the room and throwing the covers off the bed, as though that would help. “Shez? SHEZ!?”

 

“Hey, professor–”

 

“No, hold on, just–” Where had she last seen her? She left after dinner, they said good night, Byleth had gone out to visit her mother’s grave–

 

“Professor, you need to calm down–”

 

“I’m calm. I am completely calm. I need to find my sister.”

 

“Teach, your hands are on fire.”

 

Byleth paused, then shook her hands, dispelling the burning magic that had been gathering there. “I’m fine, I’m calm–When did you all last see her?”

 

Sylvain and Ingrid exchanged glances before the redhead spoke, “Like I said, we saw her yesterday at the party. I know she went off when she wanted to get some rest, but we didn’t see her after that.”

 

“What were you doing?”

 

He blinked, but Ingrid answered for him. “After the party, we were talking about our childhood. About…expectations and how bad things could be. It was something we should have gotten to before, but…regardless, I said good night to Sylvain at…ah, I’m not sure what time exactly, but it was in the evening.”

 

“...”

 

“Hey, professor, you don’t actually suspect us, right?” Sylvain asked, making Byleth pause.

 

“...No. I don’t think so. It wouldn’t make sense, she likes you two.” But that would make it easier if they wanted to hurt her. 

 

“Hey, Teach.” Claude caught her attention next, placing his hand on her shoulder. “We’ll find her. Try to avoid getting paranoid, okay? Trust me, it does more harm than help.”

 

“...Right. Okay. Sorry.” Byleth felt itchy. LIke she needed to move. “I need to ask around. I need to…I need to find her, now. Her and Flayn.”

 

“Okay, and we’ll all help with that. You don’t need to worry.”

 

But she was worried. She was more worried than she’d ever been in her life. 

 

So to the shock of most of the monastery, Byleth ran as quickly as she could through the grounds, getting a couple of startled cries from students who had to jump out of the way to not get run over by her. Jeralt in particular nearly jumped out of his chair as Byleth crashed through the door to his office. 

 

“Woah, kid, what’s the rush-”

 

“Have you seen Shez?”

 

“Huh? No, I haven’t. What happened? Did she take something of yours?”

 

“When was the last time you saw her.” 

 

“When she went on the mission to Conand Tower. Byleth, what’s going-...” Jeralt trailed off as he saw the look in her eyes. “What happened?”

 

“No one’s seen her. She wasn’t in her room and she wasn’t in the Golden Deer or Blue Lions class.” 

 

“Okay Byleth, try to stay calm. Shez is strong, she’s probably not in danger.” 

 

“Then why hasn’t she just warped back!?” Byleth shouted, before feeling Jeralt’s hands on her shoulders. 

 

“It’s going to be okay. We’ll find her. And if anyone has hurt her, we’ll make them pay.” 

 

As he said this, Byleth noticed how his hands were shaking as he held her, as if holding back his own anger. Gritting her teeth, Byleth swore to herself that she wasn’t going to let anything happen to her sister.

“ Shez has gone missing?” Edelgard asked without having to feign shock this time. She genuinely was surprised, though…

 

“Yes, she has. The same things as before still apply, search the grounds, interrogate the staff.”

 

“I don’t believe ‘interrogating’ the staff was part of your instructions last time,” Hubert pointed out.

 

“It wasn’t, but now it is,” Byleth insisted, “I realize I’m acting differently now that it’s my own sister in danger. I feel bad about it and I’ll apologize to Seteth later, but I’m still searching for Flayn, I just need to find Shez too. I think it has to be connected, which means either the same person grabbed both of them or there’s a larger group in play.”

 

Edelgard knew there was a large group in play, which was why her suspicions were raised. She knew Jeritza was the one to abduct Flayn, Bias had informed her of that ahead of time, but…Hm. Had Shez actually been working with them all this time? Or maybe Bias hadn't believed her lie… Still, why would she be so obsessed with Shez…?

 

…Had Shez assassinated Thales? 

 

“Just, please, inform me if you hear anything,” Byleth requested, before she outright sprinted off.

 

“My, she can certainly move quickly when she wants to,” Hubert noted, before glancing at Edelgard again, “Your highness?”

 

“...I’m just considering matters.”

 

“May I ask what thoughts you have?”

 

“I…I’m not sure what I’m thinking yet.” A part of her was considering just how deep in the plots of Those Who Slither in the Dark Shez could actually be, whether the girl was more involved in the abduction of Flayn than Edelgard realized, or if her suspicions were completely unfounded and Shez really was as ridiculous as she acted. Though, in fairness, Kronya’s existence proved that the Agarthan infiltrators could be genuinely stupid.

 

Another part though was more focused on the distress her professor was experiencing. The obvious anxiety in every movement as she practically sprinted across the monastery grounds, speaking to as many people as she could to piece together what their movements were. It was…surprisingly upsetting to see her normally unflappable professor genuinely upset. 

 

This wasn’t a moment of vulnerability that Byleth was sharing with her. It was genuine panic for the sake of her sister.

 

And that panic continued as the first day of their search came to a close without any success. Neither Flayn nor Shez had been found, and Edelgard couldn’t help but notice some newer faces poking around the monastery as she headed to class the next day. It seemed Captain Jeralt was taking the situation seriously enough to call in his mercenaries to start investigating.

 

“Professor, if need be, you could suspend classes again,” Ferdinand suggested as their professor arrived, her hair messier than usual and bags visible under her eyes.

 

“...That’s a good point. Right, I should have done that. I think…did everyone do that? I’m going to talk to the other professors, bye.” And she promptly left.

 

“...U-Uh, so, wait, are we allowed to leave?” Bernadetta asked, confused.

 

“M-Maybe we should get back to searching?” Marianne suggested. 

 

“Would anyone care to assist Hapi and I in Abyss?” Constance offered, “Yuri and the knights have been scouring it, but I imagine they would appreciate more eyes down there.” 

 

“I’ll go down with you. Haven’t had much luck up here, so might as well go down there.” Dorothea said, volunteering as Caspar got up too.

 

“I’ll come with you! If there’s any baddies that need taking down, I’m with you!”

 

“Heh, it’s appreciated, Caspie. Just try not to go after any of the Abyss folk by mistake, okay?”

 

“Hm…I wonder, just what sort of connection does Shez and Flayn have?” Linhardt muttered as he tried to figure out what was going on there. “They’re not related, and only one has a crest. There were no demands either, so it wasn’t because of Seteth’s or Jeralt’s position…” 

 

“There is no time to be wasting! The sooner we move, the sooner we save them from being childnapped!” At Petra's words, the class got up, filing out as they began their search once more. 

 

“Emily, a word,” Edelgard said, getting the girl to stop, who was looking more surly than usual.

 

“What?” She scowled as she faced them. “If this is about Shez, I don’t know anything.” 

 

“Is that so?”

 

“They don’t tell me anything, so for once we’re in the same position. For all I know, she’s the one who grabbed Flayn.” 

 

“Hm. Somehow I doubt that.” 

 

“If that’s all, then I’m going,” Emily grunted, marching out without another word. 

 

“Hm…seems we have to keep going for a bit longer,” Hubert mused. 

 

“...Should we investigate the staff quarters today?” 

 

“I know what you’re thinking Lady Edelgard, but we must not give Those Who Slither in the Dark reason to believe we’ve betrayed them. Not to mention there is still the possibility that Shez is working with them.” 

 

“...” Staying quiet, Edelgard's mind drifted to the look on her professor’s face as she walked in this morning. The chances that Shez were working with Those Who Slither were almost nil. She was too open, too idiotic, too attached to her sister. But…Kronya believed she was Agarthan. And there was evidence to point to it.

 

The possibility was greater than zero, and that meant it was too high to throw caution to the wind.

 

“It may not end well, but for the sake of the future you wish to create, sacrifices must be made.” 

 

“...You’re right. For the sake of a better Fodlan.” 

 

The second day of investigation went about the same, with no one able to find anything. Byleth nearly ran herself ragged as she ran to and fro, the only ones matching her fervor being Seteth and Jeralt, as the latter had his mercenaries investigate every inch of the town they could. Some suspicions were raised about Jeritza, but by the time they were, the sun had already set, meaning it was far too late in the day to properly investigate him. 

 

Retiring for the night, Edelgard began to wonder whether she should risk telling Byleth the next day or not. Such thoughts plagued her as she went to sleep, and with the thought of Byleth worrying about her own sibling, it was only to be expected that her nightmares visited her once again. Memories of her siblings crying out for help, of her father being unable to save her. 

 

Of herself, being too weak to do anything for them. 

 

“Edel…delga…Edelgard?” Shooting awake as someone began to knock on her door, Edelgard gasped for breath as she was freed from her nightmares. 

 

“W-Who’s there?” 

 

“It’s me, Byleth. Are you okay?” came the tired voice of her professor. 

 

“...G-Give me a moment,” Edelgard responded, getting up to get dressed, lest she open the door in her nightwear. Moments later, she opened the door, and found her professor standing there, looking even more exhausted than earlier. “Professor? Why are you still awake?” 

 

“I was still looking for clues when I heard noises coming from your room. Is everything okay?” 

 

“...Just some nightmares, nothing I am not used to. Should you not try to get some rest?”

 

“I’m okay. I took a nap earlier. And besides, I found something.” Lifting her hand up, Byleth showed off a flower styled hairclip. “This belongs to Shez, I actually found it outside your room, she must have been up here when they grabbed her.” 

 

“She was?” Edelgard asked, shocked once again. Had it happened in the middle of the night? 

 

“I think so, she’s always had it since I gave it to her, so it must have fallen off,” Byleth said, holding onto the hairclip gently. 

 

“...I understand, professor, but perhaps you should rest for now. If we were to find Shez tomorrow, you won’t be any help if you’re too tired.” 

 

“No, I can’t stop, Shez might be in danger.”

 

“Professor, please, you need to get some sleep. I can assure you that as soon as you wake up, we’ll resume the search once again.” 

 

“..” Byleth seemed to want to argue for a moment, before she stopped, letting Edelgard grab her by the hand to lead her back to her room. “...Huh. Just remembered something.” 

 

“What is that?”

 

“You know how you asked about my travels? I remembered something that happened in the Oghma Mountains. Shez and I were practicing magic, it was the first time I cast light magic, and it was a big one,” Byleth said, a fond smile on her face. “Shez was really impressed, especially since it caused a rockslide.”

 

“...What?”

 

“Oh, don’t worry, Ezra said it was okay, there weren’t any villages on that side apparently,” Byleth explained, a bit delirious as the exhaustion hit her. “Did spook dad though, went to the kingdom afterwards.”

 

“...It was an accident?”

 

“Mm? Ah, yeah. I tried the…the light spell, the big one. One of the big ones, I think.” Byleth yawned, not noticing the look on Edelgard’s face.

 

“I see…We should get you to bed, professor. We can discuss more ideas in the morning.”

 

“Mm…alright. Just…we need to be fast. Need to make sure Shez is safe.”

 

“We’ll do that, professor.”

 

Edelgard led her professor to her bedroom, then saw her off for the night, only closing the door once she had seen Byleth flop onto the bed and fall straight asleep. Then she returned to her own room, shut the door, and placed both hands over her mouth as she crouched down and tried to stifle the hysterical laughter that threatened to bubble up out of her.

 

Knowing that monster Thales really had died in a complete accident, had been killed by a teenage girl showing off to her little sister–It was almost, almost enough to make her think there really was such a thing as divine justice. There wasn’t, she knew that, and that actually made it better because the rotten bastard had died because of random chance! No grand final battle for him, just crushed under a landslide, squashed like a bug with a rock!

 

For the first time in a long time, Edelgard’s composure broke, and she just laughed and laughed at the thought of the worst monster she had ever known dying so pathetically.

Byleth blinked, slowly, waking up in her bed and wondering how she…No, she knew how she got there. She should thank Edelgard later…when she wasn’t so tired.

 

She let out a slow yawn as she sat up. She was still wearing everything from yesterday, which was kind of annoying. It wasn’t the first time she’d fallen asleep in her clothes, but she’d gotten out of that habit now that she had a specific room to rest in…And her brain was still focused on inconsequential things.

 

“Your student was right. You needed the rest,” Sothis commented as Byleth pushed herself up from the bed.

 

“I know. It still bothers me. I should be searching for Shez. Flayn too.”

 

“You’re of no use to anyone if you drive yourself to exhaustion.”

 

“I know,” Byleth repeated, some annoyance flaring up.

 

“You’re aware, but I don’t think you accept it. At least you’ve been eating, but you really should be taking further care of yourself.”

 

“I can do that when Shez is safe.” She stretched, grunting at the sensation of her tense muscles straining until her back popped, prompting a brief sigh. She glanced at the sleeves of her coat and gave the front of her shirt a tug. “...Clean enough.”

 

Sothis sighed, watching as her host ignored her own hygiene in favor of heading for the door, though she blinked when she noticed who happened to be waiting outside. “Oh?”

 

“Edelgard?” Byleth blinked. “Ah, did you need something?”

 

“Professor, I might have an idea,” Edelgard said, her voice firm and her gaze steady, “Call it a hunch, but I think I might know who abducted your sister.”

Chapter End Notes

Indi: You're right Edelgard, it is hilarious

Red: It's still a part I like looking back on. Splattering Thales's head was just too fun of a choice we made and the ramifications have been equally fun to plot out.

Indi: Speaking of plot ramifications, boy is next chapter going to be a doozy. And don't worry, we'll also be seeing papa bear Jeralt in action!

Red: Yup! I know a few folks were disappointed he didn't go beat the crap out of Aelfric, but the next chapter should make up for that. Tragically, he just didn't fit in that great when we were plotting it out that time.

Indi: Yup yup, as for how things will go, well we'll see next time!

Revelation in the Dark

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Shez felt a dull pain aching throughout her body as she stirred awake. She blinked, slowly, trying to spot something in the dark room around her before she tried to get up. The cold feeling of steel binding her arms to her torso soon let her realize that wasn't going to be an option. The chain around her kept her bound to the floor. 

 

"W-Where am I?" she asked, looking around, before spotting someone else with her. "F-Flayn?" 

 

The only response she seemed to get was the light rising and falling of the green-haired girl’s chest, telling her she was still breathing. Struggling in her chains, Shez tried to crawl over to her, before some tapping on the floor told her someone was approaching them. 

 

"It’s about time you woke up." Looking over, Shez found Tomas the librarian staring down at her. All at once, the memories of last night hit her and Shez scowled.

 

"You dirty dastard, let us go!" Shez shouted up at him, before trying to use her awakened form, only to stop as Tomas raised a hand and a large sigil formed under Flayn. A moment later, several dark spikes manifested around Flayn, pointing straight at the unconscious girl.

 

“Do not attempt anything. She is more useful to me alive, yet she is still useful dead.”

 

“Wha–Let her go!” Shez shouted, even as she stilled her movements.

 

“Hmph. To think one who wields the power of Epimenides would want mercy for one of these abominations…Truly such a disgrace.”

 

"What are you talking about?" Shez questioned, glaring up at the old librarian. "What the hell is an Epi-knees?" 

 

"Hm…did your 'mother' truly not tell you anything? Such a shame. You'll end up dying without knowing a thing. You truly are a failure." 

 

"H-Hey, that's not funny, let go of me already!" Shez shouted, struggling again in her chains. 

 

"Please don't tell me you're falling for this, Tomas," spoke a new voice, getting Shez to look over and see someone in black robes and a red bird mask approaching her. Crouching down next to Shez, she grabbed her face with one hand to make her look up at the mask. "What is Cleobulus planning?" 

 

"Who the hell is that?" Shez asked, unsure of what she was being asked–Then her head snapped to the side as she received a harsh backhand in response. 

 

"Don't pretend. Tell me what Cleobulus is planning and I'll make your death quick." 

 

"I don't know who that is, asshole!" Even through the mask, Shez could tell whoever this was was scowling at her. 

 

"You expect me to believe that!?" she suddenly yelled, her grip tightening on Shez’s face. "Why did you–Ah!" Yanking her hand back, Bias scowled down Shez, who defiantly glared back at her after biting down on her finger. "So you don't want an easy death…" 

 

A dark energy began to gather in her hands, only to get interrupted as a different masked mage rushed into the room. 

 

"Lady Bias, Lord Solon, they found us! The Death Knight is on his way and it's only a matter of time until the beasts chase after him!" 

 

"Tch, that Knight truly is useless. We were better off not recruiting him." 

 

"No point in whining. It's sooner than we hoped, but just buy us time until we're ready to leave,” Solon ordered, making Bias pause.

 

“What? No, I’m not done here! She needs to tell me–”

 

“This ignorant child doesn’t know anything.”

 

“Bullshit she doesn’t! Even if she wasn't there–”

 

“Does it matter?”

 

Bias blinked behind her mask, then stared at her fellow sage in blatant confusion. “Of course it does! If Cleobulus killed–”

 

“No, she didn’t. From my own investigation, a sudden landslide is what caused the initial incident. Perhaps it was caused by external means, or perhaps it was simply ill luck, but neither option truly matters. What matters is that they are dead, and we have what we need before us." 

 

“Wha–You can’t be serious!”

 

“Be silent, Bias.” The old man glanced at the door. “We’re not alone.”

 

The door opened again, letting Shez see an armored knight wielding a massive scythe walk right in, his skull-faced helmet showing a pair of glowing eyes as he regarded the pair of mages. 

 

"YOU ARE STILL HERE. WHY?" 

 

"That doesn't matter,” Bias replied, audibly annoyed, “Just get to work defending this location until we can leave." 

 

"VERY WELL. THEN THAT IS TWO OF THE MISSIONS I OWE.”

 

"What? What the hell are you talking about?"

 

"KIDNAPPING THE GIRL WAS THE FIRST MISSION, THERE WAS NO AGREEMENT OF DEFENDING YOU, OR OF HER BEING INVOLVED," The Death Knight stated, gesturing to Shez, “THEREFORE THIS IS THE SECOND OF THE MISSIONS I OWE.”

 

"You don't get to twist-!" Whatever Bias was about to say was cut off as the Death Knight placed his scythe against her neck. 

 

"DO NOT ANGER ME. IT IS MY MASTER'S COMMAND THAT I AM SERVING YOU FOR NOW, BUT THE MOMENT THE PACT ENDS, I AM FREE TO DO WHAT I WISH." 

 

“Hmph. Quite the talent you acquired for our ends, Bias,” Solon commented, earning another glare from her. “Very well, hold them off then. We’ll want to leave the beast behind.”

 

“VERY WELL.” The knight turned away, uncaring of what his so-called allies wanted.

 

“...Filth,” Bias cursed under her breath, before looking back at Solon, “We’re taking this brat then?”

 

“Perhaps. I’m considering matters.” Solon regarded Shez with a curious eye, making the girl scowl back at him.

 

“You try to take me with you and I swear, I’ll kill every last one of…whatever you’re supposed to be!”

 

“You can’t seriously be trying to lie to us right now,” Bias growled, prompting a laugh from Solon. “What’s so funny?”

 

“You really are far too easily irritated. You always have been, ever since you were a child. Stubborn, willful, and easily angered. I really must say, I’m disappointed you haven’t realized that this girl really is as ignorant as she appears.”

 

“...That’s…She can’t be! She’s working for Cleobulus!”

 

“A name she plainly does not recognize. Here, allow me to demonstrate.”

 

Dark magic suddenly poured off of “Tomas” as his false guise melted away, revealing the true face of Solon. And Shez couldn’t look more shocked if she tried.

 

“...W-What? How did…That’s just like…”

 

“Like your ‘awakened form’? Not quite, child. What you see before you is the true face of humanity.” He smirked, leaning on his staff as he crouched down. “Your ‘awakening’ represents a more…simple version of what we can do. Of what your people are capable of.”

 

“...My people?”

 

“The people of Agartha. The true people of this land you call ‘Fodlan’. Those who guide the cycle of this world.”

 

“...W-Wait, that…that can’t be right.”

 

“You know it is. As I stated, I knew your mother, girl. A traitor to our people who fled the responsibility she should have carried out.”

 

Bias blinked. “What? What do you mean by that?”

 

“Exactly as I said. Periander was a scientist who refused her orders in favor of ‘rescuing’ her so-called child and acting as a mere caretaker, rather than carry out the project she was assigned. Fitting then, that she died like a beast of some common sickness.”

 

Shez stiffened, the insult cutting through her racing thoughts as she glared up at the old man in front of her. “Don’t you dare talk about my mom like that!”

 

“I will talk of traitors however I wish to. But I digress.” He stood again, before glancing at Bias. “Do you see now? The girl is of more use to us at our side than dead for some mistaken vengeance. Particularly when, from all evidence, it is Thales’s own stupidity that killed both him and your sister.”

 

“...” Bias stared at him. “...What does that mean?” 

 

“Dark magic brought down the cliffside around the carriage. Thales knew of a spell to shake the very earth and bend it to his whim. It is only logical then to presume he had a hand in his own demise.”

 

“...How is that logical?! You think it’s more likely he killed himself than someone might have wanted him dead!?”

 

“Simply put, yes. Again though, I do not particularly care for any ‘truth’. I seek what I always have, the salvation of this world from the abomination and its spawn. Thales’s death matters nothing to my cause, and Pittacus’s demise matters even less. So stop whining, apprentice, and perform your role properly.”

 

“...” Bias glanced at Shez again, who glared straight back. “...It does matter–”

 

“No, it doesn’t. Thales had his place, but he–”

 

“I DON’T GIVE A SHIT ABOUT THALES!” Bias screamed, “This is about Pittacus! I couldn’t give less of a shit if that bastard died a thousand deaths, but she was my sister! My twin! You can’t tell me that doesn’t matter!”

 

“It doesn’t.” Solon’s voice was steady, calm, and cold, yet Bias looked as though he’d punched her in the gut. “You are being irrational, your mind clouded by meaningless emotion. If there is even a single thing of worth that you have learned from me, it should be the fact that nothing matters besides the vengeance of our people and the righting of the cycle. Purge this worthless sentimentality from your mind, apprentice, or you will inevitably meet a fate much the same as your sibling.”

 

Bias stared at Solon, silent and still to the point that Shez almost felt bad for her, before she placed a hand on her chest and bowed her head. “Of course, mentor. My apologies.”

 

Solon watched her leave, then regarded Shez again, who grimaced at his gaze. “Hm…”

 

“What the hell do you want?” she growled back, before flinching as he suddenly reached down and cupped her chin, staring directly into her eyes. “G-Gh–L-Let go!”

 

“...” Solon simply studied her, before a faint, amused smirk crossed his face at what he saw in the depths of her eyes. “...Not a failure after all then. Very well, my predecessor. I bow to the wisdom of my elder.”

 

“W-What?”

 

“Nothing you need to care about, child. Sleep now. This is all merely a nightmare, and one you shall awaken from soon enough.”

 

And with a flash of darkness, she was out again.

Rushing through the darkened underground, Byleth slashed through another mage standing in front of her, her mind completely focused on finding Shez as an archer ahead of her had but a moment to pull out an arrow before a spear pierced him, nailing him to a wall before Jeralt took it back by ripping it straight through the dying man’s chest. 

 

"Hm, so this is the might of the Blade Breaker and Ashen Dragon when they work together." Hubert mused, casting a miasma spell on an armored knight as they came around the corner. 

 

"Yeah, gotta say, still feeling jealous your class got her as your teacher," Claude said, shooting an arrow at the knight to finish him off. 

 

“You should have tried harder to recruit her then.”

 

"Hey, how was I supposed to know Edelgard was going to immediately pounce on her? I wanted to bide my time and not seem so eager." 

 

“Is now really the time to be arguing about this!?” Lysithea complained while blasting another knight with her own bolt of darkness, “We’re trying to rescue my apprentice!”

 

"Sure sure, we can argue later," Claude allowed, firing another arrow. "Eesh, how many soldiers do these people have? Gonna run out of arrows." A flash of light caught his attention and he aimed at a teleport sigil, only to pause as he saw Dimitri appear. 

 

"Where am I now?" the young prince asked, looking around in confusion. 

 

"Hey there Dimitri, bout time you Lions showed up." 

 

"Oh, Claude, finally, I was getting tired of ending up in random locations," Dimitri said, stepping out and surveying the location. "It seems you've worked hard already, allow me to clean up." 

 

Rushing forward, Dimitri stabbed through one of the remaining soldiers as the rest of the Blue Lions began to appear from the sigil. 

 

"If you have things handled here, we're going on ahead!" Byleth called out to them, as she and Jeralt rushed forward. 

 

"Hey, I'm going with you!" Lysithea called out as she chased after them. 

 

"Heh, guess I can take it easy now." Claude said, idly holding the last arrow in his quiver. Glancing around, he realized something. "Hey, Dimitri, where's Edelgard?" 

 

"She said she was going to keep informing everyone of what was happening. Though I wonder just who is left to tell..." 

 

"Is that so…" Thinking to himself, Claude could only wonder what the Imperial Heiress was up to. 

Busting through the final doorway of the underground base, Byleth and Jeralt found themselves against the last of the soldiers, with two drawing their attention. 

 

"IT SEEMS THE TIME OF OUR BATTLE HAS BEGUN." 

 

"Just shut up and fight them already!" the mage in a red bird mask shouted, before immediately casting a spell she had been charging at the two. Bringing her sword up, Byleth slashed through the fireball, before the father and daughter pair charged at their enemies. 

 

"Where's my daughter you dastards!?" Jeralt shouted, cutting through the soldiers between him and the Death Knight as Byleth swung her sword, making Bias duck as it extended, the chain whip wrapping around a different mage before cutting him in half. 

 

Clashing scythe against spear, the Death Knight began to chuckle. 

 

"SO YOU ARE THE ASHEN DRAGON’S FATHER. GOOD, PERHAPS YOU SHALL BE EVEN BETTER PREY THAN SHE WAS!" 

 

Jeralt growled. “And you’re the dastard that tried to cut her down. Congratulations, you’re the first guy to ever piss me off this badly!”

 

“GOOD! SHOW ME THAT RAGE!” 

 

As her father and the Death Knight clashed, Byleth raced in, focused and silent as she slashed at the red-masked mage. Bias felt a snarl come to her face as leapt back, shoving another lesser mage in her way as she gathered her magic and unleashed hell on the brat in front of her–Who caught the flames on her sword and let the blade become wreathed in them.

 

“Ha. Alright, no playing around then.” Bias flung her hands out as flames surged up her arms and wrapped around the walls and sealed off the entrance, bathing the room in a sudden fire that made her own men yelp and flinch back, trying to avoid the fires now licking up their robes. Not that it bothered Bias, who continued unleashing blast after blast of flame at Byleth as she continued trying to strike at the troublesome mage, only for the Death Knight to suddenly lunge in the way.

 

“FACE ME!”

 

“Wh–Damn it, focus on one person at a time!” Jeralt snapped, before trying to spear the dastard, only to get forced back into a clash with him as the Death Knight turned his attention back Jeralt’s way.

 

“I CARE NOT WHO I FACE, ONLY THAT I HAVE BLOOD!”

 

“L-Lady Bias, please cease your spell!” one of the dark mages requested, “We’re going to burn alive–”

 

And then he caught a blast of miasma to the chest and went crashing to the ground, prompting a curious glance from the sage. “Hm? Well, look at you. Impressive spellcasting for a child.”

 

“I am not a child!” Lysithea snapped, casting a swarm at the obvious leader of the mages, only to blink in shock as Bias simply grabbed one of her subordinates and shoved him in front of the spell. “W-What?! Why would you–”

 

Bias didn’t answer, instead pushing the struggling mage away as the dark insects stung and bit at him, before launching a roaring fireball straight at Lysithea, only for Byleth to cut through it as well.

 

“Tch. You’re getting damn annoying with that sword of yours, beast.” Twin sigils formed over her hands as flames surged up from the floor, yet Byleth was undeterred, swinging her sword out and slicing across the room towards the sage, who simply kicked the severed head of one of her subordinates in the way, knocking the blade off course. Byleth drew her sword back, about to rush the sage, when another soldier in black tried to drive a lance into her side, drawing her attention away as more black-clad fighters tried to cut her down.

 

“MAGE! CEASE WITH THE FLAMES!” The Death Knight shouted, aggravation clear in his voice as even he started to feel the heat. Perhaps even worse than the others because of his thick armor.

 

“Nothing but complaints from everyone around me today,” Bias grumbled, before snapping her fingers, ceasing the burning flames and allowing more students to enter through the entrance she’d sealed off.

 

“NOT THAT PART!”

 

“What? You didn’t specify.”

 

“Professor!” Dimitri shouted as he entered, running over to aid Byleth in her fight.

 

“Captain!” Leonie also shouted, immediately moving to try to help Jeralt as the Death Knight backed up.

 

“HM. FINE! IT DOES NOT MATTER HOW MANY OF YOU THERE ARE! ALL OF YOU ARE MERELY FOOD FOR THE–GH!” And then Claude’s arrow caught him straight in the chest, piercing through the plate and into his collarbone.

 

“Word to the wise, don’t monologue mid fight,” Claude commented, then paused. “Hm, that’s actually pretty hypocritical of me to say, now that I think about it.”

 

“FOOLISH BOY. IT IS NOT ENOUGH TO DRAW MY BLOOD! I CANNOT BE FELLED SO EASILY!”

 

“Sure, which is why we were giving Lysithea time to charge up.”

 

The knight paused, his gaze immediately going to the young mage who was finishing up forming a set of dark magic sigils before casting the strongest spell she currently knew. And the Death Knight felt his eyes widen at the sight of a dozen dark spikes forming all around him before they all drove into his body at once. “GAH! H-Hhaah…D-DO YOU REALLY THINK THIS IS ENOUGH TO–”

 

Jeralt didn’t wait for him to finish. He just raced in and drove his spear into the Death Knight’s chest, plunging as deep as he could go and driving the knight to the ground in a heavy crash. “That was for my daughters, you dastard.”

 

“G-GHhhhhhh…N-NO…N-NO, N-NOT YET, I-I STILL HAD-”

 

Then a white light settled over him and the knight’s dimming eyes burned an even brighter red as he surged up, punching Jeralt straight in the face and knocking the man back.

 

“Captain!” Leonie cried, before she grit her teeth and rushed in, trying to stab the knight too, only for a wall of flame to block her way.

 

“Ah ah~! As much as I dislike him, I have reason to keep that one alive,” Bias chided, before she jerked her head to the side, avoiding a javelin that had nearly gone through her eye. “Ah, and it looks like the peons are all dead.”

 

Indeed they were, and Byleth was glaring straight at her while Dimitri leveled his remaining spear at the witch. “Surrender, now!”

 

“Alright, I give up.”

 

“...” He blinked. “I…what?”

 

“I give up. You win. I can’t beat all of you children along with that dull-eyed beast and her withered husk of a father. So I surrender.”

 

“W-WHAT ARE YOU DOING?” the Death Knight growled, ripping the spear free from his guts while Jeralt glowered, rubbing his jaw.

 

“What are you trying to pull here?”

 

“Me? Why would I be trying to pull anything?” Bias asked, audibly amused, before glancing over to the side, “How nice of you to join us, your majesty.”

 

“Bias.”

 

The students and the Eisners all paused at the distorted voice that sounded out, before they all got their first look at the Flame Emperor as the masked individual strode over to the Death Knight.

 

“Leave, Death Knight. You have nothing more to do here.”

 

“...MASTER, I CAN STILL FIGHT.”

 

“No, you can’t. Go.”

 

The knight straightened, then, to the students’ surprise, bowed his head to the masked figure before vanishing in a flash of magic.

 

“Such a kind ruler,” Bias mocked, prompting the Flame Emperor to turn their attention her way.

 

“I could not say the same of you.” The masked individual turned to the students, the professor, and the captain, regarding each in turn with a strange gaze. “Captain Eisner. I must apologize. I did not realize my allies intended to steal your daughter.”

 

“Allies, huh? That big dastard there called you ‘master’,” Jeralt noted, his gaze cold, “I think that makes you two more than allies . And even then, you sure as hell should pick better ‘allies’ if these are who you want to work with.”

 

“‘Want’ is a very strong word, Captain Eisner. And not the best one to use there.”

 

“How cruel, Flame Emperor. And after we have given you so much.” A new voice drew everyone’s attention towards a familiar, elderly man that just about everyone in the group recognized on sight. “You’ll make an old man weep.”

 

“Tomas!?” Dimitri exclaimed, his eyes widening as the elderly librarian smiled at their group. It was a kind, friendly smile that was completely at odds with the current situation.

 

“WHAT!? But–But you–!” Lysithea stammered, her eyes wide too as an uncomfortably familiar feeling began to creep along her back.

 

“Seriously? The old guy was in on all this?” Leonie murmured, raising an eyebrow.

 

“Hello, your highness, Lady Ordelia, and mutt,” Tomas greeted, his friendly voice carrying an obvious undertone of mockery, “You all look shocked. Though I suppose few of you would expect to see me down here.”

 

“I sure as hell didn’t,” Jeralt responded, his eyes narrowed, “Gotta say, I didn’t think the librarian of all people would be a traitor.”

 

“Traitor implies I was ever on the church’s side to begin with. The correct word would be infiltrator. Or spy, if you wish to put it more simply.”

 

“Well jeez, and here I thought those conversations we had were just some nice, friendly chit chat,” Claude commented, his eyes narrowed as he kept an arrow nocked, “I don’t appreciate being lied to, old-timer.”

 

“The irony in your words is palpable, young man. I suppose it is a shame to put an end to our talks though. You were an entertaining conversationalist. Much like a dog excited to hear the words ‘play’ and ‘fetch’.”

 

“Alright, you’ve made your point, you’re a very scary old man,” Jeralt groused, glaring irritably, “Considering how you’re talking, should I assume you’re the dastard in charge here?”

 

“You would be correct. I am also the man who abducted your daughter.” The man’s eyes flicked towards the Sword of the Creator as its blade bounced off the magical shield he had prepared, prompting him to regard Byleth with faint amusement. “How reckless. You could have hurt me there, you know?”

 

“I intended to,” Byleth replied, the first words she’d spoken since entering the underground chambers.

 

“Tomas…why are you doing this?” Dimitri asked, stepping forward, “How could you ally yourself with these…monsters?!”

 

“I have no cause to answer you, beast. Though I will make note of your deep ignorance of this situation.” A cruel smile crossed the elderly man’s face. “I am not allied with anyone here. They are allied with me.” He gestured to his left, towards the mage in the bird mask. “The sage you have found yourselves having so much trouble with is my apprentice, Bias. A skilled practitioner who I essentially raised myself.”

 

“You’ll make me blush,” Bias grunted, barely playing along, not that Tomas seemed anything but amused by her irritation.

 

“And of course, you’ve met the Flame Emperor. Our wayward agent who has gotten up to quite the trouble even without our aid. I do believe you dealt with that bandit they hired to kill you quite handily, and then of course there was the aid offered in that feeble lord’s rebellion and the treacherous church’s graverobbing.” 

 

The Flame Emperor clenched their fists as the students looked at them with clear alarm. “Do not speak for me.”

 

"You truly have gotten quite free spirited haven't you?" Tomas mused before he smirked. "Perhaps throwing you into a dungeon again would make you more willing to put the leash back on?" 

 

A burst of fire from the Flame Emperor put the students on guard, until it dissipated as they held back from attacking Tomas. 

 

"Heh, it seems some of Thales’s teachings have managed to stick." 

 

"Enough of this crap! Where’s my daughter?" Jeralt demanded to know, tightly gripping his spear. 

 

"Safe and secure, for now anyways." 

 

"What do you want with her?" Byleth asked, her eyes moving between the three to make sure no one attempted anything. Her frown deepened as she saw Bias quietly move to grab the javelin lodged into the wall.

 

"Nothing, for now. She may have her uses, but there is little use I have for someone ignorant of her true heritage." For the briefest moment, the Flame Emperor went still. 

 

"What the hell are you talking about?" Jeralt asked, glaring at him. 

 

"Hm…perhaps a demonstration is in order?" With his smirk growing, a purple light seemed to surround Tomas. "This guise has no more use, afterall."  

 

For a brief moment, his gaze met another's, a singular 'Black Eagle' in the group. Emily stared back, not quite sure how to react, not really even sure what was happening, but palming a dagger as her superior allowed dark magic to wreathe his form.

 

With a bright flash, Tomas was gone, and in his place stood Solon, his dark eyes bright with malicious amusement as the Agarthan smirked at the shocked faces. 

 

"Hm…somehow, this feels less dramatic despite the bigger crowd. No matter. Captain Jeralt, was it?" Out of the corner of his eye, Solon watched Emily stiffen, before she began to quietly move over to her target. He let his smile grow ever so slightly.

 

"What?"

 

"I will gladly hand your daughter over, but it's only right if you offer something in exchange, no?" he suggested with a smirk as Kronya stood behind Jeralt, knife ready to pierce his spine.

 

"If you want my spear in your gut, sure." 

 

"You aren't the first to make such an offer, but I digress. At least I will get to enjoy the sight of your painful de–...d..d-maawhk–” Solon choked, blood spilling from his mouth as he coughed, before his eyes darted down to the javelin that had been rammed through his back and out his chest.

 

A knife fell to the floor with a faint clatter as Solon gasped, clutching at his bloodied chest, his eyes widened with pure shock. For a moment, he turned his head, staring at the Flame Emperor, only to register that she looked as shocked as he did. “W-W-Whah…”

 

“Wrong way, mentor,” Bias said, before she let go of the javelin’s shaft.

 

Solon turned, and even Jeralt felt his stomach turn at the look of shock and betrayal on the old man’s face. “B…B-Bia-aa…?”
