“Hm. So you weren’t lying earlier then. You didn’t kill Pittacus or Thales,” she noted, almost conversationally, at most faintly intrigued by his disbelief. “That’s a shame. It would’ve been more pleasant if I could wrap up this whole ‘vengeance’ thing more easily. Ah well.”

 

And then she snapped her fingers, and the old man erupted in flames. He didn’t have a chance to scream, if he even could, before he was reduced to blackened ash. Even his bones burnt away, charred past the point of holding together.

 

“What…Why would you do that?!” Dimitri exclaimed, “He–He said he was your mentor! That he raised you!”

 

“Hm?” Bias glanced towards the prince, her head tilting much like the bird her mask resembled. “Yes, that was all true. Really, simply calling him mentor puts it in such a low light. He was my father in every way that mattered.” She couldn’t help but grin at the boy’s growing horror. “And I hated his filthy guts. So you can imagine my elation right now.”

 

“...You’re twisted. What kind of monster are you?!”

 

“Wouldn’t you like to know? But, as my late mentor would say, I have no cause to tell you. Flame Emperor, do you require my aid in escaping?”

 

“...I have no need for your aid,” the Flame Emperor answered. Even through the distortion in their voice, it was plain to hear they were disturbed.

 

“Heh. If you insist. But I do still owe you one, remember? So we’ll talk soon.” She regarded the students again then gave them a jaunty wave. “Ta ta~!”

 

Then she vanished, and a moment later, after a small glance towards Byleth, the Flame Emperor vanished as well.

 

Tension stayed in the air as everyone stared at either where their enemies were previously standing, or at the pile of ash that was Solon. The clatter of a sword falling to the ground broke the silence as Byleth ran forward, going towards the end of the room. 

 

"They're here!" she shouted, once she found Shez and Flayn. Reaching down, Byleth began to pull on the chains, trying to unwrap them from her sister. 

 

"Professor, allow me," Dimitri said as he came up, before grabbing onto the chains, and pulling with all his might, making them snap. Byleth briefly thanked him, then pulled the remaining chains off Shez, freeing her. 

 

Idly aware of the other students healing any injuries or checking on Flayn, Byleth looked directly at her sister. A faint bruise on her cheek was the only injury she seemed to have; otherwise, it seemed like she was just asleep. 

 

"Come on, let's get her out of here," Jeralt said, reaching down to lift Shez up. Silently nodding, Byleth followed behind them as all the students made their way out of the underground chambers. 

 

But, as she walked, something caught her eye. Kneeling down, Byleth grabbed something off the floor. A strange, curved knife, one like nothing she had seen before.

Keeping a steady pace, Edelgard made her way to the staff quarters after tossing her Flame Emperor armor, her mind racing at what had occurred. 

 

She had already assumed the Slitherers had started to descend into factionism, but she didn't think it was bad enough to see Bias betray her comrade–her mentor, who she claimed was like a father–in front of everyone like that. Even more so, confirmation that Shez didn't even know she was one of them. That changed her perspective on the girl entirely, and it meant something else as well.

 

Edelgard had been completely wrong. 

 

It was…harder to admit than she expected. She was preparing for a war, she knew she would be sending people to their death. In theory, she was fully ready for innocent deaths to be on her shoulders. In practice, however… 

 

She shuddered. She couldn’t forget the panic in Byleth’s eyes, the distress at seeing her sister was gone. Her innocent sister, who knew nothing of the people of Agartha, nor of the atrocities they were responsible for. 

 

For a brief moment, she wondered if they would have even found her alive if she had told Bias the truth. 

 

Was Edelgard really willing to condemn someone to death simply because of their origin? No. No she was not. She was better than that. She had to be better than that.

 

Self-recrimination could come later though. For now, she hurried to the knight’s quarters just in time to see Jeralt exiting with Shez in his arms.

 

“Hey, princess,” he greeted, nodding to her, “Excuse me, gotta get her to the infirmary.”

 

“Ah, of course.” She stood aside, letting him pass as she noticed Seteth hurrying over with the knights in tow.

 

“Edelgard, where is Flayn!? I heard–” The chamberlain paused, his panic fading as Byleth exited with Flayn on her back. “FLAYN!”

 

“It’s okay. She’s okay,” Byleth reassured, shifting her weight as Flayn slowly blinked awake.

 

“Mmh…ah, brother?”

 

“Flayn…y-yes, it’s me, I’m here,” Seteth said, moving close as Byleth let Flayn down. The chamberlain quickly began checking his sister over, helping her stand as the other students excited and the knights moved in, heading into the quarters and the underground chambers beyond.

 

“Make sure to find everyone,” Byleth requested, “There were some type of teleportation sigils down there that scattered the students around. We don’t want anyone to get lost down there.”

 

“Of course, professor,” the knight replied, and then Byleth’s attention turned towards Edelgard.

 

“Thank you for getting everyone,” were the first words she said, and they sent a pang of guilt through the princess. Even if Edelgard hadn’t told Bias the truth, that she had even once been willing to abandon Shez to her fate…

 

“...It was the least I could do. I am sorry I was not there to help.”

 

“You helped. Calling in reinforcements is still helping and messengers are an important part to any force.” She paused. “Hm. I should get back to teaching soon, I can feel myself already planning out a lesson based around the importance of reinforcements and messaging on the battlefield…”

 

Edelgard felt her lips turn up into a slight smile. She let it happen, because she might as well show some positivity here. “I think it would make for a good lesson, professor.”

 

“Then I’ll add that to the lesson plan then. Oh, and Edelgard, do you think we could have tea sometime soon?”

 

She paused, a flash of confusion hitting her. “Ah…well, if you insist, professor. Though, shouldn’t you be focused on taking care of your sister?”

 

“Don’t worry, I will. I just think we need to talk. Okay?”

 

“...Of course, professor.” And there, the sinking feeling in her stomach returned as her mind raced, trying to think of why her professor would want to talk so soon after her sister’s abduction and if it could be that she’d already figured out–

 

And then her professor patted her on the head. “Thanks. Take it easy today, okay? I’ll see you soon.”

 

“...” Edelgard just stared as her professor moved past her, heading in the same direction Jeralt had gone. She watched Byleth leave, and felt her gaze still lingering after her long after she was out of sight.

 

Her heart was still racing by the time she returned to her room. She simply closed the door, went to her bed, and laid down while hugging one of her pillows to her chest, thinking back to the smile her professor had given her. And as Edelgard felt her face warm, she came to a deeply distressing realization.

 

She was infatuated with her teacher.

 

“...oh no.”

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Oh my goddess Solon is dead!

Red: What a tragedy! ...Anyways.

Indi: More importantly, Edelgard has a crush!

Red: The true revelation! Nobody saw it coming!

Indi: But yeah this was a chapter we were excited to publish, some people were able to call Solon dying, but I don't think anyone thought Bias would do it. But hey this is our story, fuck the main villains.

Red: Hope it works for everybody, but we did have this planned for a bit now, ever since we decided to make the random pair of Agarthan Gremories down in Shambhala actually twins. Well maybe not from that exact moment, but it definitely developed as a thing, especially after Thales died early in.

Indi: Yup yup, and some of you might have wanted Kronya to have saved Shez, but hey don't worry, we got something special planned there.

Red: Very special! But for now, thank you very much for reading and we hope you enjoyed!

A Return to Peace

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

“Well, the good news is that I can give Shez here a clean bill of health,” Manuela said, smiling at Jeralt and Byleth as the two visibly relaxed. Jeralt more obviously than Byleth, though it was clear the older Eisner sister was happy to hear her sister was fine. “Whatever magic that ‘Solon’ man used, it really did just put her to sleep and the bruising on her face isn’t too bad. It should fade quickly with just a simple healing spell or even go away naturally.”

 

“Sweet, so I can leave now?” Shez asked, already sitting up in bed and prompting a huff from Manuela.

 

“Wait until I’m done, please. If you’re going to be joining my class, you’ll need to learn at least a little patience.”

 

“Mmf.”

 

“You said that was the ‘good news’,” Jeralt noted, “I take it that means there might be some bad news?”

 

“Yes, though it’s something small. Mainly that I noticed Shez had a small mark near her wrist, as though something had punctured there,” Manuela continued, prompting a frown from Jeralt, “I’m not sure quite what it might be, but there’s a vein there that makes it relatively easy to draw blood.”

 

“Hm. So, what, you think these people wanted Shez’s blood?”

 

“Perhaps? I was planning to check Flayn to see if she had similar marks, but Seteth’s being stubborn there.” She sighed. “Honestly, that man is far too overprotective. I’m a medical professional, I’d have a better idea of any issues she might have and yet he hasn’t once allowed her to even receive a check-up here. It’s almost insulting.”

 

“Yeah, I can see how it could be. Then again, he did just nearly lose his sister, so being protective is understandable,” Jeralt noted, glancing over at Shez again, who still looked annoyed at having to be in bed. “Gotta say, as much as I appreciate the work you do, I think I could stand to be in here less often.”

 

“That’s understandable, though there was at least a month between visits here.” With a smile, she leaned forward. "Though, perhaps you would prefer to visit for more personal reasons?" 

 

"...Right, Professor, if you're gonna flirt with my dad can you at least let me leave first?" Shez asked, getting an amused huff from Manuela. 

 

"Is that your way of saying I have your permission to~?" 

 

"As long as it isn't in front of me, sure. Doubt he’s gonna say yes, but if you really want to go for it–"

 

"I'm standing right here you know," Jeralt sighed as he rubbed the back of his head. "Listen, I'm flattered, but a young lady like you can do better than an old piece of leather like me. You're better off finding someone closer to your age." 

 

"Oh my, it's certainly been some time since someone has called me young lady," Manuela said, a light pink dusting on her cheeks. 

 

"Right, come on By, let's go," Shez said, getting out of bed and grabbing her somewhat awkward-looking sister to drag her along. 

 

"Ah, make sure to tell me if anything feels off!" Manuela called out, a bit annoyed at Shez leaving without getting the all clear from her. 

 

“Sure thing!” Shez called back, before letting out a huff, “Right, not gonna go back there unless I can help it.”

 

“Shez, you should take care of your health,” Byleth chided as she let her sister continue to drag her along.

 

“I do take care of my health! I just don’t like laying in bed all day!” She huffed. “I have no idea how you did that for a whole month.”

 

“It wasn’t even a month and I’m not as impatient as you,” Byleth replied, electing not to mention that even she’d gotten a little stir crazy the longer she’d sat there, “...Hey, Shez, do you feel okay to talk about what–”

 

“Ah, hey, there you are.”

 

The sisters paused, looking over to see Cyril approaching them. 

 

"Lady Rhea was hoping you could stop by, and since you're not busy you can go now," he answered.

 

"Uh, I guess?" Shez said, frowning a bit. 

 

"Is it something important?" Byleth asked. 

 

Cyril shrugged in response, "She just told me to get you,"

 

"...Okay." Nodding, Byleth moved to follow her, with Shez walking behind him. Arriving at the audience chamber, they found Rhea and Seteth waiting for them. 

 

"Hello there, I'm glad to see you are well after what happened." 

 

"Ah, thank you. Uh, how's Flayn?" Shez asked, awkwardly glancing at Seteth. 

 

"She's doing well. Tired, but well nonetheless," Seteth responded, before his gaze turned to Byleth. "Professor, words alone will never be enough to express how thankful I am for you saving Flayn. I am in your debt." 

 

"No, you don't need to be. If anything I should apologize," Byleth said, frowning as she shook her head. "When I learned Shez had been taken as well, my focus shifted almost entirely to saving her. I almost feel like I didn't take saving Flayn as seriously."

 

"...Yes, I suppose I can understand that. Saving someone you know can be a different feeling than saving someone from your family. For that, I cannot fault you,” Seteth responded as his features seemed to soften for a moment. "Were I in your position, I would have felt the same, and regardless, you still managed to save her." 

 

"So, uh, why exactly did they try to take her?" Shez asked.

 

"That…I'd prefer not to go into the details, but the blood running through her veins is special. In the wrong hands it can be dangerous. I tried to keep it a secret, but if those seeking it have already appeared, then the only thing I can do is to leave the monastery and hide with her." 

 

"Brother, wait!" Flayn called out, seemingly listening in from the doorway as she came in, still a bit pale from what happened. "I do not like what you are thinking! I don't want to go into hiding once more." 

 

"Flayn, please, you must understand why I’m making this decision! If we stay here we'll be targeted again!" 

 

"And do you truly think they won't find us once again?" 

 

"She's not wrong." Shez interjected. "I… don't exactly know what's going on with those guys, but if they found out your secret once, then I doubt they'll give up easily. Besides, leaving means you'll have to protect her by yourself, right?" 

 

"That-" 

 

"She is not wrong, Brother. In fact, I think I have the perfect solution! If you are that worried, then would it not be best to make sure I stay near someone who has fended them off not once, but twice?" Flayn suggested with a ‘cunning’ smile. "Such as, perhaps joining Professor Byleth’s class?" 

 

"I'd be happy to have you in my class," Byleth said with no hesitation, making Flayn smile. 

 

"...I must admit, that is a good point,” Seteth conceded, “Despite my initial trepidation, you've proven time and time again to be trustworthy. Can you promise me you'll keep her safe?" 

 

"Of course." 

 

"I look forward to class!" Flayn exclaimed, her smile getting all the brighter.

 

"Which you can do once you have properly rested. Seteth, why don't you help your sister return to her bed?" Rhea suggested. 

 

"Of course, thank you Archbishop. Come along, Flayn." Walking over, Seteth took Flayn’s hand to guide her out. Glancing over her shoulder, Flayn waved goodbye to the two sisters before they left. 

 

"Now then, since we are alone, can you tell me what exactly happened?" Rhea asked, keeping her tone gentle. Even then, the atmosphere seemed immediately much more tense.

 

"..." Staying silent, Byleth glanced at Shez, not wanting to speak up without her being okay with it. 

 

"..." Frowning, Shez tried to think of what to say. “Alright, uh…hm. I guess…from the top, I was walking to my room–Wait, should I start with that part? Or…no, yeah, alright, I was lost, specifically, because the monastery’s way too big and I wound up going upstairs–”

 

“Shez. Your room’s on the first floor.” Byleth gave her sister a skeptical look. “...Were you trying to visit someone?”

 

“What? No, I got lost, like I said.”

 

“That seems a little much, even for you.”

 

“Hey, I was distracted! Look, can we save the comments for later? I’m telling a story!” Shez huffed, before frowning. “Right, okay…I was lost and I met that librarian guy, Tomas, who was actually this old man…Solon! That’s right, that one guy called him ‘Lord Solon’, and the other lady there was Bias. He apparently wanted to speak with me, and had to 'corner' me cause I was avoiding him." 

 

"May I ask why you were doing so?" 

 

"It's…weird to describe, when I was near there was this…uncomfortable feeling with him. So I avoided the library as much as I could, honestly the only reason I ever got books from there was cause someone else got them for me. Anyways, he apparently knew my mom." 

 

"He did?" Byleth cut in, surprised at that revelation. 

 

"Yeah, she…he called her a traitor to her people.”

 

"...Her people?" 

 

"Solon said they were…called the people of Agartha." 

 

"...What?" Rhea felt her blood run cold at that. She hadn’t expected to hear that name, hadn’t ever thought it would come up again–And if Shez was one of them…Rhea closed her eyes, taking a moment to steady herself. She needed to be calm here. 

 

When she opened them again, Shez looked nervous. “Uh…is that bad?”

 

It was an inane question. That anyone could think the Agarthans were anything but a genuine evil–But, no. She had to remember, she was speaking to a child. One that Byleth favored, no less. So she had to remain calm, and hear her out.

 

“It is…concerning,” Rhea elected to say, “I would like to hear more of what was said before speaking further on the subject though.”

 

"Well…Like I said, there was Solon and Bias, along with that Death Knight guy. Though I'm starting to think that guy was a mercenary," Shez explained, before continuing at their confused looks. "He apparently was only supposed to do three missions for them, and trying to defend them was the second." 

 

"Hm…I wonder. He seemed to be working for the one they called the Flame Emperor. It doesn't seem like that person is friendly with the 'Agarthans', but is working with them at least," Byleth guessed, though in Rhea’s eyes that mattered little. If this person was working with the Agarthans, then they needed to be put to death immediately. She would not tolerate another Nemesis.

 

"Let's leave assumptions aside for now. Is there anything more you can tell us?" 

 

"Hm…well, apparently I have the power of something called Epi-knees." 

 

"Epines?" Frowning, Rhea tried to search her memory to see if she could remember any Agarthans by that name. 

 

"Yeah, I don't…exactly know what that means, but I was apparently a failure or something. So I guess whatever they were planning didn't work. The only other thing…that Bias lady apparently wanted revenge for her sister." Shez frowned at that. "I don't know what exactly happened, but two people got killed. I don't remember the first one's name, but her sister was named Pittacus. She…that Bias lady is a bitch but…If something like that happened to Byleth, I don't know if I could act differently." 

 

A part of Rhea felt only contempt at the idea of sympathizing with any Agarthan, a part that also felt a surge of vindictive pleasure at the thought of those monsters suffering further, but she could not allow that part of herself to influence her decisions. She knew loss, she still felt it keenly, and she could understand Shez’s mentality. She was a child with no context of the atrocities those vicious heretics had committed, so it was no wonder she felt the stirrings of sympathy for someone who had a sibling as she did.

 

It didn’t change what the Agarthans were.

 

“I understand. It does not change the fact she abducted you and sought to harm both you and several students and faculty members, child. Do not allow sympathy to cloud your judgment.”

 

“Right, sorry. It’s just…I didn’t really know anything about where I come from. I still don’t, really,” Shez admitted, “That my mom was one of these people…it feels weird, you know? Especially since it sounds like she wanted to get away from them…”

 

Well, Rhea could at least give Shez’s mother some credit in abandoning those monsters.

 

"...May I ask about your mother?" 

 

"Ah…well her name was Periander and…she died before I met By and Dad. She…she was really nice, always made sure I was taken care of. We didn't really talk with anyone else in the village, but I felt happy with her. She passed away cause of an illness and we didn't have the money to pay for medicine. It's…kinda weird to think. She always said she found me in the woods one day, though I guess that was just a cover story.

 

Shez couldn't keep the sad frown off her face. "Mom… always did her best for me. So it's strange to think that she and I are related to them. Though…maybe they're not all bad?" 

 

"Child, I understand that your judgment may be skewed because of your mother, but you should not believe such a thing so easily. If that were the case, then others would have abandoned them as well, no?" 

 

“...Yeah, that’s a good point. But…what were they even trying to do? They grabbed me for that Epi thing, and they wanted Flayn for her blood, I guess? But, why?”

 

“I’m afraid we cannot know the truth of our enemy’s purpose without further information,” Rhea replied with a patient smile. It was better she be sympathetic to the child. If she could bring one of the Agarthan people to her side…it was a strange thought, but the idea of redeeming one of their kind did appeal, in an odd way. With that thought in mind, she turned her gaze towards Byleth. “Perhaps you could enlighten us, professor? You fought these infiltrators directly, after all.”

 

Byleth straightened, folding her arms behind her back as she settled in to give her report, beginning with how she had gathered the students and her father to quickly go after them.

 

"After we fought the Death Knight and Bias, the Flame Emperor and Solon appeared. It seems the Flame Emperor had a hand in the bandit attack that led to Shez and I joining the academy, as well as Lonato’s rebellion and the raid on the tomb of Saint Seiros, though that is only if we are to believe Solon’s words," Byleth explained, she remembered what happened. "There was…a mention of the Flame Emperor apparently acting on their own, with Solon wishing to get them under his control…if I were to hazard a guess, they might have been like Shez, though one who was considered a 'success' to them." 

 

“Huh? Wait, you think this guy’s like me?” Shez paused. “...Does that mean he’s my brother??”

 

“Shez, no.”

 

“Think about it though! Oh goddess, I have an evil brother…I wonder if he’s my twin?”

 

“...” Rhea didn’t know what to say to that. “...” She really didn’t know what to say to that. So she just turned to Byleth. “What else do you recall?”

 

“Hey, don’t ignore me!”

 

“It was after that point that Bias elected to quite literally stab her apparent mentor and father figure in the back with a javelin,” Byleth reported, also ignoring Shez, “She appeared to be under the impression that he had murdered Pittacus, her previously mentioned sister, and another individual named Thales.”

 

Rhea stiffened. She knew that name. She remembered that name. He was alive? Though, no, he was dead, that was what Byleth’s words implied, but how long had he been alive? Had he survived to the present day? How could that… “I see. Did either Solon or Bias state anything in regard to those two individuals and the manner in which they died?”

 

“No, they didn’t.”

 

“Uh…well, I remember Bias was really upset about her sister’s death,” Shez said, thinking back to what she remembered of that conversation, “I think they were twins? And she didn’t care at all about that Thales guy. I don’t think either of them really liked him all that much, there was something about how he didn’t really matter or whatever. Oh, and that Solon guy thought he killed himself, I think.”

 

Rhea frowned. “Hm…so they didn’t know anything about the circumstances of his death?”

 

“Uhh…I think Solon knew something? There was…something about magic and…earth? Like rocks, I guess?” Shez shrugged. “They also thought I was working for somebody named…Cleo-something. I don’t think I’ve ever been hired by somebody named that though. Bias got pissed off when I didn’t know what she was talking about though, smacked me in the face and everything.”

 

Rhea grimaced slightly at the evidence of physical harm, though it did act as proof that these supposed Agarthans cared little for Shez’s well-being. Odd how a bruise could be evidence in the young woman’s favor… “Well, I am sorry you went through such a harrowing experience here. The monastery is meant to be a safe place for our students.” She sighed. “Though I suppose there has been a great deal of danger this year…”

 

"There has, but we can't focus on that," Byleth responded, "For now, we just need to make sure everyone is safe." 

 

"Yes, that is true…" Rhea let out a sigh. "I ask that neither of you two mention what was talked about here for now. Please make sure to get some rest for now, and send Catherine in." Nodding, the two sisters left, and a moment later, Catherine came in. 

 

"Did you need something, Lady Rhea?" 

 

"I want you to up the guard around the monastery. I’ve already informed Jeralt, but I would prefer we reinforce security as soon as possible. I doubt there could be another infiltrator on the staff already present, not after we discovered the truth behind Tomas and his accomplice Jeritza, but we should ensure no one else makes their way in.”

 

“Yeah, alright. And, uh…do you want me or Shamir to keep any kind of eye on the Eisners?”

 

Rhea paused, frowning in thought, before she shook the idea off. “No, I doubt they’ll need an escort. Or a shadow.”

 

“You sure? Shez claims she got lost all on her own, so giving her a minder in general might be a good idea.”

 

“No, I would rather not aggravate her, or Jeralt for that matter. Perhaps you can let the knights know to ask her if she’s going in the right direction if they see her meandering.”

 

“Alright, I’ll let them know. If that’s all?” At Rhea’s nod, Catherine saluted and left the chamber, before letting out an annoyed sigh. She still wasn’t sure why exactly Lady Rhea cared so much about the Eisners having a good opinion of her, but she wasn’t about to sabotage her boss. 

 

Though she could at least admit to herself that any poor dastard that went after Shez was going to face hell from Byleth. 

It was weird how quickly things could go back to normal after a big event, but, honestly, Shez was pretty happy to get back to her average routine. The blood-stealing weirdos that tried to abduct her were no longer a factor in her day-to-day life, so back to classes she went!

 

Which of course meant getting to know her new classmates! Which, well, she already kinda knew them, but getting to know them better! 

 

"Now then, before class finishes for today, I just want to inform you all that there will be no mission this month. After what happened with Tomas and Jeritza, the knights will be investigating around the monastery, and until further notice, you will be asked to stay within Garreg Mach and not go into town unless given express permission." 

 

"What? Come on professor, you can't be serious!" Hilda immediately complained. 

 

"...What happened with Jeritza?" Shez asked in a low whisper to Lysithea, who stared at her in disbelief. 

 

"Did no one tell you?" Lysithea asked. "Jeritza was the Death Knight." 

 

"What!?" In her surprise, Shez might have said that a bit too loudly. 

 

"Yes, did you want to ask something?" Manuela asked as she raised an eyebrow at Shez.

 

"N-No, sorry about that," Shez apologized, bowing a bit as she heard Lysithea let out a huff and call her an idiot under her breath. 

 

"Well I'm sure there's plenty of things we can do at the monastery, in fact, why don't we have a feast to celebrate our new classmate joining the class?" Claude suggested, immediately earning a cheer from Raphael. 

 

"Yeah! Meat party!" 

 

"Hey, don't forget about me!" Balthus called out. "You guys didn't throw a feast for me!" 

 

"Pretty sure that's cause of how hectic things got," Leonie commented.

 

"Oh yeah…well, either way, I'll forgive you guys if you make sure there's booze!" 

 

"There will be no such thing at our festivities," Lorenz chided. "I understand that you may be a brute, but none of us are old enough to drink." 

 

"I mean, I am, but don't think they'd let me drink at the monastery," Leonie pointed out, "Unless they're okay with that?" 

 

"The church does respect the drinking age of respective nations. That being said, I doubt they'll be okay with you drinking around minors," Manuela informed, not that she could scold anyone with how bad her drinking habits were. 

 

“Aw, dammit, guess I’ll have to visit Abyss later,” Balthus muttered to himself. 

 

“Do try not to have too much fun during the feast! And make sure to keep in mind the knights might come by to ask you questions if they need to.” 

 

“Sure thing, professor! Come on Ignatz, we have a party to start!” Raphael said, a large smile on his face, before he grabbed the smaller boy to carry him out.

 

“Wha–Raphael, I can walk on my own!” the bespectacled boy protested, to little effect as he was carried away. 

 

“Heh, guess we should get a move on before Raphael finishes off all the food before the feast even begins,” Claude said with an amused smile as he followed behind along with Hilda, who didn’t look as happy.

 

“Hmph. It’s a shame Marianne isn’t around to join.”

 

“Not like she likes this kind of thing.” 

 

“Still!” 

 

Trying to hide her amused smile at Hilda’s pout, Shez followed behind her classmates. Was certainly fun learning this was going to be a common thing for her now, since Claude definitely liked his feasts. Though according to him it was a Golden Deer only thing, so no inviting her sister, apparently. 

 

“Hm…hey, do you mind if we speak in private?” Lysithea asked as the Golden Deer watched Balthus and Raphael have an arm-wrestling competition. 

 

“Oh, sure. Good luck Raphael, I still have five gold on you!” Shez cheered on as she got up. Following behind the shorter mage, the two found themselves in a secluded area where they could talk. “What’s up?”

 

 “I…wanted to talk about what happened in the underground,” Lysithea said, unease evident in her voice. “About what Solon said.” 

 

“Oh uh…mind telling me the specifics? He said a lot of things to me beforehand, but I don’t know what exactly he told you since I was out of it.”

 

“He said you…had your uses. Do you have any idea what he meant by that?”

 

“Ah… Right…” Frowning, Shez seemed to be thinking deeply for a moment. “He said something…he called me a failed experiment. I don’t know what he meant by that, but it was apparently to give me some type of power.” 

 

“...and you don’t remember anything about it?

 

“No, from what he said, it kinda sounds like they started doing it when I was born. As far as I remember, my first memory is waking up in a bed with my mom bringing me food.” 

 

“...I think I know who was behind what happened to you,” Lysithea said, trembling a bit. 

 

“Wait, you do?” Shez asked, surprised.

 

“It’s only a theory! I just…I can't say anything for certain. I just have an idea of who it could be.”

 

“...Hey, Lys, we don’t need to talk about this if you’re not feeling up for it. Just, uh…can I ask something real quick?”

 

“Th-That depends on the question,” Lysithea said, trying to ignore the stammer in her voice. She shouldn’t feel nervous, she was just with Shez, but…she was certain she knew who these people were, and the thought of them still terrified her. “But go ahead, I’ll answer it if you really want me to.”

 

“Alright. Does it have to do with how you’re also really great at dark magic?”

 

“...I despise your implication that I only have these powers because of those people–”

 

“Woah, what? No, that’s not what I meant!”

 

“ But! I cannot deny that my talent with dark magic was likely influenced by their effects on my life. And…yes, they did affect me. And I’m not talking about it right now, okay!?”

 

“Okay! Okay, that’s fine by me! I don’t mind if you don’t want to talk about it.” Trying to keep a smile on her face, Shez kept her gaze on Lysithea. "Just… whenever you feel up for it, I'll be up to talk about it, okay?" 

 

"I know, I just need time to think about it first."

 

"...Thanks for trusting me with this, Lys." 

 

"Hmph, if you are to be my apprentice, then it's only right we learn about each other, right?" 

 

"Well well, here I knew you two were close, but I didn't know you were that close." Interrupting the moment, Claude walked up his usual smile on his face. "Didn't know you were growing up so quickly Lysithea." 

 

"Wh-Shut up Claude!" Lysithea yelled, her face getting flushed. 

 

"Aw, no need to get so embarrassed. It's all a part of getting older," Claude teased, getting Lysithea to glance at Shez for a moment, before she ran off in embarrassment. 

 

"What the hell, Claude? You know she doesn't like getting treated like a kid," Shez complained, frowning at her house leader. 

 

"Eh, I'll apologize to her later. Just wanted to talk with you for a bit," Claude explained. "Specifically, as your house leader, I felt it only right to follow up on what happened." 

 

"Starting to think I should just gather everyone around so I don't have to repeat myself so often…"

 

"No need to, just wanted to make sure you're okay," Claude said without his usual inquisitiveness.

 

"...Were you listening in on us?" 

 

"Just the tail end of the conversation, I swear," he said with a wink, "Though if you feel like telling me about it, I won't say no." 

 

"Look, just, I still don't know how much of what he said was true or not, okay? For all I know, he was completely lying." Though she had a feeling he wasn’t.

 

"Hm… is that so?" Claude asked, still intrigued. "Well, I'll take your word on it. Though I hope you don't mind if we talk later as well." 

 

"Just don't eavesdrop when I'm talking with someone, okay?" 

 

"Sure thing. Now come on, we have a party to get back to. Speaking of, you lost out on the bet." 

 

"Wait, really? Dammit!" Charging back in, Shez went to check to see if she had actually lost, while Claude stayed behind. 

 

"Hm…" A sister who could wield the Sword of the Creator and had the Crest of Flames, and a sister with no crest, but who had her own special powers, and a powerful sword of her own. Maybe it shouldn't be just the Church he should try investigating…

Sometime later, Shez laid down in her bed, staring up at her ceiling as she let out a sigh. Whatever her powers were, they seemed to come from a dark place, one that might have hurt others… 

 

She let out a slow sigh, not noticing as the spirit she was attached to manifested beside her bed. A small frown crossed the pale being’s face, his eyes narrowed for a moment, before he put a hand to his head and feigned some pain.

 

"Ugh…what happened?" 

 

"Arval? Where have you been?" Shez asked, sitting up once she heard the voice of her partner.

 

"I do not know. I suppose I feel… drained," Arval stated, the spirit looking tired as they appeared once again before Shez. "Last I remember was that old librarian cornering us, and then the next thing I know, I awakened here. I…feel as though all my energy is gone." 

 

"Ah… hey Arval, does the word Agartha seem familiar?" 

 

"Agartha? …Agartha…" Saying the world to themself, Arval seemed to be testing it, as if it did spark something. They looked thoughtful, considering, before picking an answer. "...It feels familiar. Perhaps in a more positive manner than negative.”

 

"Really? Well, that still doesn't help much…" Shez muttered, frowning to herself. "You also missed a whole lot…hey Arval, your power isn't anything bad, right?" 

 

"Hm? What do you mean?" Arval asked. 

 

"Just… thinking about something. What the Tomas guy told me is rubbing me the wrong way." 

 

"Hm…well, I can promise you this. You are my partner in destiny, and I would never betray you," Arval reassured, smiling down at her, "If I was against you, I would have just guided you to a den of demonic beasts long ago." 

 

"Hey! I'm not dumb enough to fall for something like that!" Shez said, getting Arval to quirk an eyebrow. "...I would have fought my way out." 

 

"If you say so, partner. For now, I shall get some rest, and you should do the same," they said, before dissipating, leaving Shez with just her thoughts. 

 

"..." Sighing, she laid back down. Her mind drifted to her awakened form. "..."

 

She wouldn't use it again, not unless it was necessary.

"Before we start, do you mind if I ask you a favor?" Byleth asked as she and Edelgard sat down for tea. 

 

"O-Oh?" Cursing herself for the slight stutter, Edelgard composed herself. "What exactly do you need?" 

 

"Can you have Hubert leave?" Byleth said, keeping her voice low. "This is something I only want to discuss with you." 

 

"Ah." Edelgard couldn't help but stiffen, as for a brief moment, fear that she had been found out gripped her heart. "...very well." Sending a discrete signal, Edelgard heard the bushes nearby rustle for a moment as Hubert moved away. 

 

"Thank you," Byleth said, with a small smile. 

 

"...So, what exactly did you want to discuss, professor?" 

 

"It's about something I discovered when we rescued Flayn and Shez." Byleth said, getting Edelgard to pause. 

 

"...What exactly did you find out?" 

 

"I think there might be another infiltrator in the monastery," Byleth said, getting Edelgard’s breath to hitch. "Aside from whoever that Bias person was." 

 

Stay calm, Edelgard thought to herself as she sipped from her tea. Don't show any faults. 

 

"...what exactly makes you think that?" 

 

Reaching into her coat, Byleth pulled out a knife. A distinctly Agarthan looking knife. 

 

"When we were leaving the area, I found this on the floor. No one we were fighting had this knife, but someone dropped it," Byleth said, her brow furrowed. "I don't know what it's made of, but I think it's the same as the Scythe Jeritza was using." 

 

"It is?" Edelgard asked, trying to seem curious. Which quickly shifted into shock as she saw Byleth bring the knife up to cut her palm. "P-Professor!?" 

 

"It's just a light wound, but–" Showing her palm where a light trail of blood was leaking, Byleth tried to heal it, and while it partially closed, it didn't fully heal up. "Whatever this material is made up of, it seems to be specifically meant to go against faith magic." 

 

"...You didn't need to cut yourself like that, professor." 

 

"I wanted to demonstrate what I discovered." 

 

"And how exactly does this mean there's an infiltrator?" 

 

"Someone dropped the knife, but it was only after the fight ended. And it was where everyone was standing," Byleth explained as she frowned. "I don't want to think any of the students might be an imposter, but the possibilities are too high right now." 

 

"...And may I ask why you're sharing this with me rather than Lady Rhea?" 

 

"Because I trust you." With a sheer sincerity that baffled Edelgard, she continued. "The only ones who it can't be are Flayn and Shez, since they were held captive, and you, who wasn't even there. If I were to tell Rhea, then she might interrogate everyone and make it obvious we know what's going on." 

 

"...I see."

 

"And… if I'm being honest, it's just a feeling I have. You've said I have a strange aura about me, and it feels like you do too. Whatever it is, it makes me feel like I can trust you." 

 

"...Is that so?" Keeping herself steady, Edelgard’s mind raced. On the one hand, a part of her felt elated to be trusted by her professor, but on the other hand, she was being trusted despite actively lying to her. 

 

"Yes, I don't have any plans yet, but I just want you to keep an eye out for anything suspicious." 

 

"...Of course professor." She could work with this. If she worked this properly, she could have both Selene and Emily out of the monastery. She just had to plan things properly. 

 

"Thank you." Grabbing the knife, Byleth hid it in her coat again. "Now then, we still have to plan what to do for the Battle of Eagle and Lion next month as well." 

 

"I would think that wouldn't be as important," Edelgard said, getting Byleth to shake her head. 

 

"Even if the infiltrators are the bigger problem, we still can't ignore what's to come. Besides, with how the mock battle ended up being a mess, it's only proper I help bring victory to the Black Eagles next time, right? Not to mention, I did promise to bring you victory." 

 

"..." She just had to squash down the feeling of infatuation. She was the Flame Emperor, someone who would bring forth a new age for the people of Fodlan, free of the crest system and the tyranny of the Church. 

 

"I have to say, I didn't think I'd end up enjoying being a teacher this much. I'm really glad we met, Edelgard."

 

"...Me too, professor." But, for now, she could enjoy these peaceful days. 

Chapter End Notes

Red: Rhea's got some pretty big blindspots about how safe the monastery actually is.

Indi: There are so many infiltrators it's hilarious.

Red: Like, not counting Edelgard and Hubert since they aren't actually in disguise, we still have Kronya and Bias hiding out there, and only Byleth has an inkling that a student might be in on it.

Indi: Which didn't really get narrowed down since Edelgard got everyone to help to really stick it to the Agarthans.

Red: Ironically making herself the least suspicious to Byleth. But yeah, meanwhile, everyone else is adjusting back to the student life. Gotta get back to those classes and deep dark secrets.

Indi: so many secrets, and of course those interested in them. Anyways hope y'all enjoyed, just as a heads up we started a story for Engage, though it's just a short vignette thing!

Red: Yup! Feel free to check that out, should be pretty easy to find. Thanks as always for reading!

Clearing the Air

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

“Did you hear? They’re saying Tomas was the one behind the abduction of those students,” one monk mentioned to another in the depths of the library.

 

“What? I thought it was that combat instructor, Jeritza von Hrym?”

 

“It was, but Tomas was apparently the one behind it.”

 

“Really? But he was such a sweet old man…”

 

“Well you know what they say about those you least suspect. Granted, I think anybody could have suspected Jeritza was up to something. He was always wearing that weird mask.”

 

“True…well, what happened? I heard there was a fight in the knight’s quarters.”

 

“Ah, Captain Jeralt took care of things, from what I heard. Him and his daughter, that new professor, killed Tomas but Jeritza managed to get away.”

 

“Really?? Oh that’s scary to think, he could still be out there then…hm. Hey, how do you think Sister Selene is taking it? She and Tomas seemed really close.”

 

“Good question. I can’t imagine she’s not upset.”

 

Further in the library, the woman known to most as Selene, a nun of the monastery, hummed quite cheerfully to herself as she stocked the shelves with returned books, enjoying the simple repetition of the activity as she moved along. 

 

Tragically, the happy mood she had cultivated was broken quite suddenly as she felt a familiar brat grab her by the front of her robes and pull her close.

 

“What the hell was that?!” Kronya, in her standard guise of Emily Korsch, hissed in her face, her eyes narrowed in genuine anger.

 

“...” Bias simply gripped the young woman’s wrist and started to squeeze. “Let go. I don’t want to rip these robes when I break your wrist.”

 

“...bitch,” Kronya cursed, letting go. 

 

Rather than break her wrist as stated, Bias simply let go as well. It was a kindness the idiot in front of her hadn’t really earned, but one she was willing to grant. “What do you want, brat? I’m not interested in playing confessional.”

 

“...Are you–You can’t be serious! You–You murdered Solon!” she hissed, just barely remembering to keep her voice down.

 

“Would it help if I said it was on the orders of our leaders?”

 

“What–It was?”

 

“No, of course not. I was just asking if saying that would help.”

 

Kronya scowled. “Then why!? What could possibly justify killing one of our own!?”

 

“...Ahahaha–Hahahahahaha–” Bias covered her mouth with hand, trying to stifle the laughter that threatened to echo through the entire library as her composure nearly broke from what was quite possibly the stupidest question the brat in front of her had ever asked.

 

Kronya, meanwhile, stepped back slightly, an unfamiliar discomfort filling her at the sight of her superior nearly cracking completely right in front of her. Sure, she knew her question was hypocritical; Kronya had killed plenty of her lessers for failure before, but that was different. Those were peons, worthless in the long run. None of them were a sage, and especially not their people’s greatest living mage. Even if he had been an old asshole.

 

Finally, Bias regained some composure, and simply smiled at Kronya, who could still see hints of that amusement dancing in her superior’s eyes like flickering flames. “You really are a good little puppy, aren’t you?”

 

“Wha–” Whatever offense Kronya felt was cut off by confusion as Bias patted her on the head. “...W-What?”

 

“It really is no wonder Thales kept you around. Vicious, but loyal. Not like that cold bastard Solon. You know he investigated Thales’s demise, right? And he found evidence of foul play, but he kept it quiet, because it didn’t matter to him.” Bias grinned. “He was willing to hide everything so long as he got to play as the great savior of this world.”

 

“...I…what are you talking about?”

 

“I’m saying he had to go, puppy. A callous man like that, who cares nothing for the lives under his command, can’t be trusted. Sure, if someone fails, kill them, that’s how it works. But to disregard their lives entirely, to act as though even the death of our great leader doesn’t matter…well, a man like that would be willing to sacrifice anyone. Could you really say he wouldn’t, if it seemed convenient?”

 

“...” Kronya wasn’t sure what to say to that. Would Solon have sacrificed her?

 

…If it was for the good of the world, he would have. That old creep always went on and on about that kind of thing.

 

“...But you were the one who killed him,” she pointed out, still on guard.

 

“I was, but does anyone need to know that? The only people who know that truth are here at this monastery, and who among them would report to our superiors? The students, who know nothing of Agartha? The Death Knight, a mad dog who didn’t even witness the moment? The Flame Emperor, perhaps? Though, she doesn’t trust us, now does she? Perhaps she could use that information to ruin us, or maybe she’ll use it to keep us close. Do you have an idea of which choice she would make?”

 

“W-Wait, there isn’t an ‘us’ here, you’re the one–”

 

“Who killed Solon, yes. We’ve gone over that. Every other witness of merit, our poor Agarthan brethren, was slain along with him. And it was the spear of that princely brat that killed him, wasn’t it? All I did was burn the body to make sure it wouldn’t be used by our enemies.” Bias smiled. “It would make things much more convenient if he died by that boorish lion’s hands, wouldn’t it?”

 

“...” Kronya felt a strange shiver go up her spine. It dawned on her that Bias truly didn’t care what Kronya said. If she made herself an inconvenience, Bias was going to kill her. That they were in the middle of enemy territory didn’t matter. There was no mistaking that glint in the sage’s eyes, not when Kronya had that exact same look many times before when she was dealing with an inconvenient lesser.

 

And she really didn’t like being on the other side of that look.

 

“...F-Fine. Fine. The prince killed him. Everything else was just a tragedy. I get it.”

 

“I knew you would. Believe me, pup. I’m a much better master to have than Cleobulus or Myson. Now scurry along, if you would. Be a good schoolgirl, and I’ll let you know if I ever need you for anything.”

 

“...” Kronya turned and left, unhappy to show any deference to the mad sage, but well aware that it was her only choice if she wanted to leave the library alive.

 

Bias watched her leave with a faint smile, then turned to the shelves, tilting her head in thought. “...Hm. Perhaps it’s time I branch out…Fire alone is quite limiting. Wouldn’t you agree, your highness?”

 

“...” Edelgard stepped around the shelves with a frown, staring at the disguised sage. “You’re being careless.”

 

“What can I say? I’m grieving the recent death of my father and a surprising betrayal by a colleague. I’m allowed to be upset.” She smiled. “And I do take steps to ensure I am not overheard, princess. Now do you want something from me?”

 

“I want to know what your plans are. You ki–”

 

“Careful now, princess. You should be quieter in the library. Why don’t we find somewhere better to speak?” And without waiting for a response, she turned and started walking.

 

Edelgard clenched her jaw, her eyes narrowed, before she followed, well aware of Hubert keeping a careful eye on both of them. If the sage tried anything, he would intervene.

 

She didn’t, though the walk to the storeroom was tense and uncomfortable. Not that Bias seemed even slightly fazed. “You really should be more careful, princess. You could have at least asked to meet me outside of the monastery." 

 

"Talking to you here lessened the chance of you attempting to pull something on me." 

 

"Hm, if you say so. Though you never know. I don’t really have much to lose at this point. Really, I should just leave. Nothing is keeping me here with Solon's death." 

 

"...And why aren't you?" 

 

"Because I still owe you, and because of Solon’s words before everything happened, I know for sure that Shez is innocent." With a smile, she pat Edelgard on the head, making her stiffen before she smacked her arm away. 

 

"Don't touch me." 

 

"Aw, and here I thought we could work well together. Surely an Emperor can do with more help from the shadows?" She smiled at her. It wasn’t a pleasant smile. “You told me the truth, princess. I appreciate that.”

 

“...Hm. Do you truly wish to avenge Thales that much?”

 

“No, I don’t give a damn about him. Whoever killed him killed my twin though. So I want to find whoever did it and kill them. Simple as that.”

 

“...I see.” That was a problem then. She couldn’t let Bias kill her professor under any circumstance.

 

"Heh, there's no need to be so tense. You already helped rule out Shez, so that beloved professor of yours isn't in danger. And I doubt any of those Eagles could have been involved. Really, it seems everyone you care about is safe from me," Bias mused with a smirk, "Ah, but a fair warning. Kronya seems on edge right now, so she might lash out if pushed too much." 

 

"Hmph. I'm surprised you haven't thrown her under the carriage yet." 

 

"Oh, that's still an option. The thing is, she might not be a sage, but she's still dangerous. If she sees herself going down, she'll try to take whoever she can with her. Cornered rats, as they say." Bias shrugged. “If you want my advice, and I doubt you do but I’m going to give it anyway, just leave her be for the moment. She doesn’t have anywhere to go, especially since she has no reason to trust going to Myson or Cleobulus will turn out better for her than riding things out with me.”

 

“You’re hoping she’ll take the safe, familiar option instead of risking uncertainty then.”

 

“That’s one way of looking at it. The thing is, we Agarthans know our places in life. She won’t bite because she’s trained not to. And if she does, she dies. It’s that simple.”

 

“...You’re asking me to afford you a great deal of trust, especially given how you killed your own superior.”

 

“I did, true. And, really, under most circumstances I would likely be in some real trouble just for surviving while he died, since it was my job to keep him alive. But I have resources to bargain with and my placement near the abominations gives an advantage my fellow sages of equal standing wouldn’t want to lose.” She smirked. “And that’s an important part to note here. With Thales and now Solon dead, I don’t have superiors. The other sages are of equal rank to me, rivals instead of leaders, and that means they need to work carefully. Especially with how divided things are right now.”

 

“And how divided are they?” Edelgard questioned, “If you want me to trust you–”

 

“Hold on now, princess, I’m fine with telling you what’s going on. Maybe not all the details, I do need some reasons for why you should keep me around too, but to keep things simple, Myson is in charge of our operations in Adrestia while Cleobulus handles things in Faerghus.”

 

“Hm. And the third remaining sage, Chilon, he’s in the Alliance?”

 

“No, he’s probably in Adrestia too right now. He’s not exactly a subtle man and our people have never been particularly interested in Leicester. I assume it’s because you Adrestians sided with our ancient enemy while the Faerghans have always been easy to manipulate. Nemesis was even from those lands, if you can believe it. Almost makes them our ‘natural allies’,” she joked, smirking.

 

Edelgard frowned, wondering if she was supposed to take anything in particular from that…and deciding she might as well ask as long as Bias was willing to answer. “Is Dimitri involved with this ‘Cleobulus’?”

 

“I doubt it. She had a hand in that Tragedy up there, but if Cleobulus had successfully suborned the prince, odds are she would be keeping him close instead of letting him wander to Garreg Mach.”

 

“She could have her hand forced by circumstance. The nobles would want him to attend the Academy for tradition’s sake.”

 

“True, but I doubt it. I can’t see the lion prince as anything more than a hapless idiot stumbling in the dark and grasping at shadows. Maybe he’ll blunder into causing us trouble, but I doubt he’ll be anything more than the boar his ‘friend’ derides him as.” She huffed, amused. “Really, it’s a show of how weak he is that he hasn’t put down that yapping hound yet.”

 

“Killing the heirs of a noble house usually carries consequences,” Edelgard noted, giving Bias a warning look.

 

“I know, I know, no touching the students. I wasn’t planning to anyway, but you have my solemn oath that I especially will not harm any of your house,” she swore, though her smile made it hard to trust her words, “Besides, you’re the one that should keep an eye out. That Riegan mutt was peeking around not long after our little event, likely seeking some hint of Solon’s intentions.”

 

“...That makes your continued presence here remarkably dangerous. If he finds a connection–”

 

“Don’t worry, I’ll be out of your hair soon enough. I have other things to handle while I can. I just didn’t want to burn this disguise if I can avoid it. Having access to this monastery is quite useful, as I’m sure you’ve found, and I would hate to lose it. I just need to be careful in how I move, and I assure you, I am very careful when I want to be. If that is all, your highness?”

 

Edelgard felt like she should talk more. Maybe tell her about Professor Byleth’s investigation, though she disregarded that thought almost immediately. Setting this woman after the professor for any reason was a bad idea. She almost wanted to ask more too, to see if she could discover something else from the loose-lipped Slitherer, but… “Are you willing to tell me anything about Myson or Cleobulus’s plans?”

 

“Not for nothing, princess. Besides, you assume I know everything.”

 

She expected that answer. “Very well then. That is all.”

 

Bias smirked, amused to watch the Imperial princess turn towards the door, her discomfort hidden by a mask of stoicism as she tried to pretend she wasn’t fleeing–Then the sage paused when she saw Edelgard turn around.

 

“...I doubt it will mean much, but…I understand what it is like to lose loved ones.”

 

Bias scoffed. “Trying to get me to sympathize with you, princess? Don’t forget our positions here. What you are, and what I am.”

 

Edelgard’s eyes narrowed. “I know you are a monster. I don’t want your sympathies. I just…never mind.”

 

“You’re too soft, princess,” the sage called out before Edelgard could leave, “You should harden that heart of yours before someone wounds it.”

 

“...That advice is far too late.”

 

With that, the princess left, and Bias was alone again.

Kronya wandered aimlessly through the monastery, unsure of what to do. She couldn't trust her superior, but she also knew going against her would label her a traitor, even if she managed to get away. 

 

This was supposed to be a simple mission, damn it! Just infiltrate the monastery and get close to the princess, but no, she just had to warn the red-headed beast so they missed their chance there. Now all she had was this useless disguise that Edelgard saw through immediately! Why couldn't they have just let her keep dealing with traitors!? 

 

It was only a matter of time until Bias saw her as more trouble to keep around; it was clear to the younger Agarthan that she was already expendable. 

 

"Dammit!" 

 

"Uh, everything okay?" Turning on her heel, Kronya found Shez standing nearby. 

 

"W-What do you want?!" 

 

"Nothing? Just checking on you. You seem like something is pissing you off." 

 

"It's nothing that involves you," Kronya responded, scowling. 

 

"Uh… okay? You sure you don't want to talk about it?" 

 

"Why do you care?" She didn't know what Solon meant, but… if she was really ignorant about her nature… 

 

"I mean, you're my friend, right?"

 

"...Excuse me?" 

 

"Yeah, I mean, sure you got your issues. I mean, a lot of issues really, but we're still friends, right?" 

 

"..." Taking a step back, Kronya's scowl deepened. Even if Shez was an Agarthan, she was no better than a beast if she truly cared about other beasts like they were her 'family and friends'.  She wouldn't stoop so low, she'd figure out a way to come out on top, even if Bias or anyone else was against her. 

 

"...Guessing it's something personal then," Shez said, a bit sheepishly. "Well how about we go train? You said you wanted to get stronger, right?" 

 

“Why would I want to!? You’re just some…you’re just…” Somehow, she couldn’t get the insult out. Why couldn’t she? She couldn’t really–

 

Kronya stiffened as Shez put a hand on her shoulder. She was about to snap at her when she saw the concern on the girl’s face and the words died in her throat.

 

“Hey, are you okay? You’re looking really upset right now.” Shez smiled, trying to be reassuring. “Whatever it is, I’m here for you, okay?”

 

“...” She knew she should shove Shez away. She knew she should outright punch the other girl in the face, if not cut her throat for being some kind of…discarded reject. But her body wasn’t moving. “...I really want to hit something.”

 

“Heh, alright, then let’s head to the training yard! We can find some dummies to smash! You ever tried using a warhammer before? It’s weirdly cathartic to break stuff with one.”

 

“Why would I use a hammer?” Kronya asked derisively as she allowed Shez to start leading her onward.

 

“Like I said, it’s cathartic! Besides, hammers are really good against heavy armor! For some reason. I don’t know exactly, probably something about blunt stuff working better, but By mentioned it before and she usually knows her stuff.”

 

Kronya rolled her eyes, but followed the chatty girl anyway. Thinking about it, she would need allies if she wanted to break away from Bias and survive in this place, right? And this idiot thought of her as a friend already, which was better than any of these other beasts…

 

Though, thinking about it some more…if she couldn’t get close to Edelgard, why not throw her lot in with a different beast? One that didn’t know anything about her at all? Yeah, that made sense, and since Shez was already close to that Claude guy, Kronya had an easy in!

 

Yeah, the more she thought about it, the better of an idea it sounded! That von Riegan brat was bound to be way easier to manipulate than Little Miss Flame Emperor, so clearly this was the best plan!

 

“Hey Shez,” Kronya spoke up with a sudden smile, catching the girl’s attention, “How easy do you think it would be for me to transfer classes?”

“And that concludes my report on everything that happened in the underground chambers,” Jeralt finished, his arms folded behind his back as he stood at attention in front of Lady Rhea in her audience chambers. The archbishop looked worn out by the end of his summation, her shoulders slumped with more exhaustion than he’d ever seen on her before. “Do you have any questions?”

 

“Goddess…” Seteth muttered from his place beside Rhea, looking genuinely horrified, “Rhea, you don’t think–”

 

“I know, Seteth. Believe me, I have already…Never mind.” She took a breath, then focused on Jeralt again. “The woman, Bias. You are certain she said that a man named Thales was dead?”

 

“Apparently she thought Solon killed him along with someone else named Pittacus,” Jeralt answered, “I’m guessing you already heard that from Shez.”

 

“I did, though she had some trouble recalling the specifics of the matter. Still, she did give a number names that were important. Solon, the leader of these conspirators. Bias, his apprentice and murderer. Pittacus, the murdered twin to Bias. Thales, an unknown individual of some significance who was also killed. And Cleo, some type of rival or threat to them.” Rhea tried to smile. “Altogether, it was actually an impressive amount of information for someone in her situation, even if there is still much to investigate. Still, I do not hold her difficulties against her, Jeralt. Anyone would have trouble remembering things properly after such an experience.”

 

“Anyone would, yeah. So why did you decide to interrogate her without me there?”

 

Seteth frowned. “That’s not what happened, Captain–”

 

“It’s fine, Seteth. Jeralt has his reasons. I am sure you would feel similar if I were to request to speak with Flayn alone after her own traumatic experience,” Rhea said, prompting a slight frown from her chamberlain, before she looked back to Jeralt, “It was not my intention to speak with Shez so soon. I intended to speak with Byleth, but Shez was with her and Catherine decided to bring them both.

 

Jeralt didn’t look like he believed her, and that prompted a slight, disappointed frown from Rhea. “Do you really trust me so little, Jeralt?”

 

“I have kids to take care of, Rhea. I can’t afford to trust you like I did before.”

 

“...That is quite blunt, but…I suppose I can understand.” She sighed. “Thank you for your time, Jeralt. You may return to your duties.”

 

“Yeah, no.” She blinked at the refusal while Jeralt stood firm. “You need to talk to me, Rhea. I need to know who these people are and why they went after my kid.”

 

“...Jeralt, I understand your concern–”

 

“No, you don’t. Otherwise you would have told me that Aelfric had stolen my wife’s body and tried to resurrect her and kidnapped my daughter, and I wouldn’t have had to hear it from her instead. You would have told me what happened to Sitri and why Byleth’s heart doesn’t beat, back before I left. You would be telling me, right now, who these people are and how they’re connected to Shez. You wouldn’t be keeping me in the dark just because the truth is uncomfortable, you would tell me just what the hell is going on here and why my family keeps being put in danger.”

 

His tone was calm and even through every word, with barely a change in inflection, and yet Rhea felt as though every insistence was a blow.

 

"Captain, I understand where you're coming from, but that is no way to speak to the Archbishop," Seteth reprimanded, frowning, "Once we have discussed things properly, then you will be informed." 

 

"Right, Rhea, how much have you told your aide about me?" Jeralt asked, wanting to see how much he knew. 

 

"...I have known him for much longer than you, Jeralt," Rhea said, before looking over at Seteth. "And Jeralt holds my blood within him, Seteth." 

 

"....I see." 

 

"And Jeralt, before I tell you, you must know that…what I have learned may lead to many issues not just for your family, but all of Fodlan. I understand you want to protect your family, but if we are not careful, then we may throw the entire continent into chaos.

 

“I am not certain why your youngest was targeted, but it seems those behind her abduction still have plans for her. I already instructed the knights to keep an eye on Shez so if anything were to happen, she would be safe."

 

Jeralt stared at her, stone-faced. "You're still avoiding the question of just who these people are." 

 

"...Very well. They're an enemy of mine that I have long since thought dead. I do not know what exactly they are planning, but the last time I fought them they nearly destroyed all of Fodlan. Once I'm done having my knights investigate the monastery, I'll be having them on missions to investigate the nation for any clue on them. I pray that I can have your assistance on this." 

 

"Fine, but no more secrets, okay? If you find anything out, you tell me right away." 

 

"Of course, Jeralt. I swear to you," Rhea said, trying to keep the guilt off her face. Maybe one day, he would understand just what exactly she had planned… 

 

Soon enough though, Jeralt left and it was only her and Seteth in her office once more. Rhea let out a slow sigh and sunk back in her seat, resisting the urge to massage her temples. “We need to up the security around the monastery. Perhaps if we call the other knights back…” She grimaced. “If only we could still trust the Western Church, I could have their forces reinforcing ours…”

 

“Yes, it is a concerning matter, Lady Rhea. As is what Captain Jeralt discussed earlier.” She paused and looked up at her chamberlain, who was facing her with his hands behind his back. “Such as the circumstances behind Lady Sitri’s origins.”

 

For a moment, Rhea felt as though the world had stopped around her. Then Seteth’s words registered and her eyes widened, before narrowing. “...Would you care to explain what you mean, Seteth?”

 

He held up his hands. “I don’t mean it as an accusation. I understand…I understand that things have been difficult for you these past thousand years. I wasn’t here to help, nor were any of the other saints that fought alongside us. You have had to work on your own, without any aid from another of our people. Still…it does appear you have found those you can care for, even if you cannot trust them as deeply as you would wish to.”

 

“...” Of all the places Rhea had thought this conversation could go, this was not one of them. “I…appreciate your words, Seteth. Thank you.”

 

“Of course. I hope you understand, I am on your side, Lady Rhea. It took some time, but after the revelations of what occurred in Abyss, the truth of the matter became clear. There are other matters we should discuss when we can, but I understand now why you have been so set on keeping Byleth Eisner here as the new professor.”

 

“...” Rhea couldn’t help but blink. “You do?”

 

“Indeed. The truth became clear when I looked into the events that occurred. Why Lady Sitri’s body did not decay with time, your relationship with her…I suppose I have been foolish not to notice before, but it is difficult to speak of lost loved ones. Even now, I find it difficult to speak of my own wife…”

 

“Ah, yes, it is difficult…to be clear, Seteth, you are aware of…” She tried to find a way to phrase her plans tactfully. “...Of young Byleth’s nature?”

 

“I am. Just as I am aware of Sitri’s connection to you, Rhea.”

 

“...I see.” Rhea did her absolute best to keep herself steady. Hope and dread warred in her mind as she stared at her chamberlain. Her brother. “And what do you think?”

 

“I think you should tell Jeralt sooner rather than later, but I have no qualms with your decisions otherwise,” Seteth advised, "The longer you hide it, then the more difficult it will be for him to accept it." 

 

"Ah…I see what you mean." Would he be able to accept her plan? "Though it may still be early for me to tell him, given what just happened." 

 

"Hm…Yes, it may shock him more than you meant," Seteth mused, "Would it be okay if I were to inform Flayn?" 

 

Now that definitely came as a shock to Rhea. "You wish to inform her?" 

 

"Yes, I'll make sure to tell her that she is not to tell anyone, but I'm sure she would be delighted to know the truth." A rare grin appeared on his face. "Truth be told, that is partially the reason why I trust Byleth now." 

 

"...I must admit, I never thought you would be so accepting of this." 

 

"Trust me, it came as quite the shock for me as well. Though I'm sure Jeralt and Byleth will be more than understanding." 

 

“...” Rhea was starting to wonder just when Seteth became so accepting. 

 

"Though I must say, I never thought you of all people would have a lover." Rhea would be eternally grateful Seteth was looking away from her at that exact moment because she was unable to stop her eyes from bulging in shock. "To think, if I had joined you sooner, I could have met your daughter." 

 

“...” Rhea was starting to realize Seteth just completely misunderstood what was going on. 

 

"While I understand that, as the Archbishop, you cannot let it be known you had an illicit relationship, you should still inform Byleth as well, as it would help clear the air between you two." 

 

"...I see. Thank you for your advice on the matter." Rhea was practiced at keeping calm in the face of sudden issues. Or at least she liked to tell herself that. If she were being honest, she felt like she was sweating up a storm right now. “...To be clear, you support my, ah…” She cleared her throat, trying to figure out how to even begin addressing Seteth’s incorrect impression.

 

“Rhea, I wholeheartedly support your attempts to get closer to your granddaughter, and I am sorry I was not here to support you in your time of loss.” He bowed his head, before smiling. “I am also somewhat curious as to who managed to capture your heart enough to have a child with.”

 

“...I-I think that is a conversation we should have at a later date.” When she actually had an idea of who her false lover should even be.

 

“Ah, yes, of course. Er, if I may ask…is he no longer with us?”

 

Oh no, he’s asking follow-up questions. “...ahh…he is…no longer present. At the monastery.”

 

Seteth blinked. Then frowned. “I see. Was he a member of the church?”

 

Would it be better if ‘he’ was?? “Seteth, I think we should save this conversation for a later date. I appreciate your support in this…trying time, and, ah…perhaps we should move onto other matters? You said you had more you wished to discuss with me.”

 

“...Well, yes, I did wish to address your obvious attempt to break the taboo with that ‘rite of resurrection’ ritual,” Seteth replied, his tone turning flat and unamused.

 

“Ah. Yes. That…To be clear, Seteth, the rite was enacted during a moment of weakness and I have not made any other attempts since its failure,” Rhea explained, lying through her teeth, “I had just lost everyone close to me and…and I thought if I only had mother back, everything would go back to normal. So…I apologize, but I did what I thought was right.”

 

“...” Seteth sighed. “I understand, Rhea. I do, truly. But the taboo is in place for a reason. To revive someone from the dead…you know as well as I that it is the only true commandment of the goddess. Still, I believe she would forgive you for that moment of weakness, and it is heartening to know you have learned your lesson.”

 

“...Yes. Yes, I have.” Well, she was already lying to Seteth, so it wasn’t like this changed much. It was the first time she had to invent a false husband though…would it be too awkward if she asked one of her cardinals to pretend?

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Rhea’s life has become a comedy of errors.

Red: Which is marginally better than the tragedy of errors it was previously.

Indi: Marginally. Meanwhile we finally see Kronya's reception to what went down! And well, maybe something starting to develop there.

Red: Yep! Turns out what needs to happen for Kronya to start moving away from Those Who Slither is a nice, strong shock of realizing her superiors don't care about her in the slightest.

Indi: And well, who else to throw her lot in than someone who's clearly easy to manipulate and also the girl who she totally isn't into.

Red: The perfect plan! Clearly this won't awaken anything!

Day to Day

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

"Hey, I'm transferring out." Blinking, Byleth turned to face Emily. 

 

"Are you sure?" 

 

"Yeah, it’s not worth it staying in this class," she bluntly stated, getting Byleth to frown. 

 

"Oh…okay. I'm sorry I wasn't able to help you feel more at ease in my class," Byleth apologized. 

 

"Eesh, don't make it about yourself," Emily complained, frowning. "I just think I'll be a better fit in the Golden Deer." 

 

"Oh, Shez’s class?" 

 

"Yeah, what about it?" 

 

"Hm, well, I hope you enjoy your time there," Byleth said, nodding to Emily, who was already walking away. Straightening up, Byleth made her way to her class, feeling a bit disappointed. Sure, Emily didn't get along with her classmates, but a part of her had been hoping that would change. It also made her feel like she had made a mistake somewhere… 

 

"Nothing you can do about it. You can't force someone to like you," Sothis remarked.

 

"Still feels like a shame…" 

 

"Hmph, quite the greedy child you are. You have so many students in your class, and you want even more?" 

 

"...It would mean the other classes would have less forces during the Battle of Eagle and Lion." Byleth noted, musing over that possible idea. 

 

"There you are, professor!" Pausing, Byleth turned her head to see Flayn coming over. 

 

"Oh, hello Flayn, is everything okay?" 

 

"Uh…more or less? Constance decided to try out a new spell and well… I think you should just go see,” Flayn said, gesturing for her to follow. A tad wary, Byleth followed Flayn, heading to their classroom. 

 

And, well, it was hard to describe what she was seeing. 

 

"Ferdinand, when this is over, don't think you'll be getting off easily," Hubert muttered, his hands on Ferdinand’s chest as he tried to push him away. 

 

"You say that as if I'm enjoying this!" Ferdinand shouted back, his arms on one of Hubert's shoulders. 

 

"Can you please stop arguing already?” Edelgard requested, her hands on the desk in front of her, making no move to help them as Dorothea sat next to her with a slight smile, her hand on her back. 

 

"C-Can someone please just help me!? Lindhart is too heavy for me to move!" Bernadetta whined from somewhere on the floor as Byleth heard Lindhart let out a small snore. 

 

“Oh, hey professor!” Caspar greeted with a wave of the axe in his hands. Which. Huh.

 

“...Ah. You’re all stuck to each other,” Byleth figured out, prompting a sigh from Edelgard.

 

“Yes, we are. Thanks to a certain heiress of House Nuvelle.”

 

“Oh! Lady Edelgard, should I take that as confirmation that you intend to reinstate my household?!” Constance asked, visibly excited. And also standing with one hand on her hip and the other on her fan.

 

“I can’t do that at the moment, Constance. In part because I am stuck to my desk. ”

 

“Who else is stuck?” Byleth asked, glancing around the room and noticing that Marianne had her hands pressed together while Hapi seemed to have hers stuck against her lap.

 

“M-Mm…th-this is fine, professor. I, uh, d-do not need to use my hands…r-right now…I-I guess.”

 

“...Mari, I know you like praying, but I think even you’ll get tired of having your hands stuck in that position.”

 

Petra, meanwhile, simply had her hands raised and was making a point of not touching anything. “Greetings, professor. This situation is one of some trouble.”

 

“Seems like it. Flayn, you’re okay?”

 

“Ah, yes! I made sure not to touch anything as I left, so I’m completely fine, professor! I don’t know if my hands will stick to anything, but I know you and Emily weren’t here to have the spell affect you, so I’m sure the both of you could help!”

 

“Emily transferred out today.”

 

“...Oh. Hm. That does make things more difficult…”

 

“Constance, do you have a counterspell for accidents like this?”

 

Constance scoffed. “This is no accident! My spell worked perfectly as intended!”

 

“...You intended to stick your classmates to each other?”

 

“Well, no, I did not, but I did successfully guarantee Caspar would not lose his axe again!”

 

“Yeah, see? It’s super stuck here!” Caspar said, gesturing with said axe. 

 

“I do see that, but I also see your other classmates are being very inconvenienced. Do you have a way to counter the spell?”

 

“Of course not!” Constance huffed, sounding offended. “Why would I create a spell to demonstrate the ingenuity of House Nuvelle, only to then create another spell that goes against its exact purpose?!”

 

“Hm…but what about a spell that counters all spells?”

 

Constance blinked. “...you’re a genius! Ah ha, this is why you’re my attendant!”

 

“I’m your professor.”

 

“Irrelevant!”

 

“Constance!” Edelgard snapped, making the blonde stiffen. “How long is this going to last?”

 

“Oh, er…well, previous testing has shown that this spell does have something of a time limit, so it should not last more than an hour.”

 

“...Did you just say we’re going to be stuck like this for an hour?” Hubert asked with a distinctly menacing tone to his voice.

 

“Presumably less, given that we’ve already been stuck like this for a few minutes!”

 

“...” It was probably a good thing Hubert’s hands were stuck.

 

“Okay, in that case, I’ll just start the lesson. No one needs to take notes for this part,” Byleth said as she made her way to the front of the class, idly helping Bernadetta off the ground and moving Linhardt over to a chair, which did still leave the purple-haired girl in the very awkward position of sitting in his lap with her hands pressed to his chest. “For now, please take your seats and don’t touch anything.”

 

“Oh, of course professor!” Flayn said before pulling out an empty chair at a desk and immediately realizing she got her hand stuck to the top of the chair. “...Oh.”

 

“...” Byleth sighed. “Alright, that’s my fault, I should have thought of that.”

 

“Ah, it’s okay professor! I think I can just-” Flayn put her other hand on the chair to adjust it, then immediately realized her mistake. Again. “...Hm. This is more difficult than anticipated.”

 

“It’s fine, just stand if that works better. Now then, for this week, we’re going to be covering–”

"Hey, you're Lysithea, right?" Emily asked, staring down at the diminutive mage who was in the middle of studying. 

 

"Hm? Oh, you're…Emily right? Did you need something?”

 

“Yeah, uh…You’re really great at magic.”

 

“...” Lysithea narrowed her eyes. “Are you patronizing me?”
