“What? Why the hell would you think–Wait, no. I’m not getting mad, because we’re just…talking. About magic, which is a thing you like.”

 

“Would you get to the point already? Why are you talking to me?”

 

"I saw what you did with the Death Knight. That was impressive," Emily said, doing her best not to sound angry. 

 

"Oh, well, I suppose it was." 

 

"Yeah, I mean, I don't use magic myself, but that really packed a hit," she continued, trying to seem relaxed. "So I was thinking that, since you and Shez already practice together, we could practice too. You know, since Shez and I already spar a lot together." 

 

"Hm… I suppose I can see the benefit in that. Though just to be clear, I already have one apprentice, and I'm not taking another." 

 

"Why would I want-" She cut herself off before she said anything rude. "Right, I get that. Besides, like I said, I don't use magic myself. Better with a bladed weapon." 

 

"Very well, it would benefit us both to know how we fight if we're to be in the same house together." 

 

"Great, looking forward to it!" Smirking as she turned away, she did her best to stop herself from laughing. Her plan was already going great! Two of the strongest Deer members were already in her pocket, and it was only a matter of time until the rest fell in line! 

 

"What a weird girl…" Lysithea muttered to herself as Emily walked away. 

 

"Now then, who should be next…" Walking across the courtyard, she paused as she saw the pink-haired beast clearly struggling to hold a crate. It was a wonder she could even hold it up with how much she was shaking. "What are you doing?" 

 

"Oh, is that you, Emily?" Hilda asked, seemingly glad to see her. "Nothing much, Professor Manuela asked me if I could help take some stuff over to store away. Shez was going to help me, but then Professor Manuela had her do something else." 

 

"...I see," Emily said, as she began to walk away. 

 

"Oh, if only someone as strong, or maybe even stronger, than her were able to help me out." Until she heard those words and immediately turned back to grab the box. 

 

"Just give it here," she grumbled as she took it away. Frowning as she took it, Emily noted that sure, the box was a bit heavy, but not enough to make anyone struggle. This Hilda girl must really be weak… 

 

"Oh, thank you Emily! I owe you one!" 

 

"I'm just doing this so you don't drop this." 

 

"Still, you're super strong! I thought it would take me forever to carry the crates, but you can probably take multiple at once!" 

 

"...Crates?" 

 

"Yeah, there's three of them, but I'm sure someone as strong as you can probably take them all at once! Heck, I don't even think Shez could carry that many." 

 

"Hmph, of course I'd be able to carry them all! I'm gonna be stronger than anyone else so this is nothing!" 

 

"Great! Here, let's go get the rest! I knew you were going to be reliable Emily~" 

 

Smirking to herself, she followed behind the pink beast. These students really were easy to manipulate, especially with how she already had one indebted to her. 

 

Grinning to herself, Hilda tried to make sure Emily didn't see her face. Seemed the new girl reacted to praise and comparisons to Shez quite positively! Oh she was definitely going to be handy~.

"You know, I gotta say, getting a closer look at this thing makes me realize how freaky looking it is," Shez remarked as she studied the Lance of Ruin. "I mean the name is already weird, but this thing looks like it's made out of bone." 

 

"Oh good, I'm not the only one who noticed that," Sylvain said as he held the Lance out for her. 

 

"Well, I wouldn't say it's made out of bone, since I doubt bones would make good weapons, but whatever material it's made out of is certainly strange…" Ingrid muttered. "I wonder if I could ask my father if I could see Luin to compare them." 

 

"Eh, probably shouldn’t. Might end up with another arranged marriage proposal if you ask for something that important." 

 

"Huh? What's up?" Shez asked, as she straightened up. 

 

"Nothing to worry about, just some offers my father has received," Ingrid replied. 

 

"Sounds like it is something to worry about," Shez said, frowning. "But if you don't want to talk about it, okay." 

 

"Heh, that's a surprise. With how much you keep butting in with your sister's love life I thought you'd jump at the chance to talk about Ingrid’s," Sylvain teased. 

 

"Hey, there's a difference between trying to get my sister to open up, and a friend dealing with something personal," Shez shot back. 

 

"It really isn't that big of a deal," Ingrid said, trying to move the conversation along. "That aside, how are things in the Golden Deer?" 

 

"Oh, pretty good. Emily actually joined up too, and I think she's having fun. Well, at least, she's trying harder to get along with this class?" 

 

"Really? Don't suppose that means I can take a chance if she isn't as surly~?" Sylvain asked.

 

"Yeah I'm pretty sure she'd probably still hit you if you tried that." 

 

"Not the worst rejection I've gotten at least." 

 

"Sylvain, please don't,” Ingrid requested. “I don't even want to think of how much of a mess that will be." 

 

“Yeah, it probably won't go well. Emily’s kind of unpleasant if she doesn’t like you, and I’m pretty sure her family raised her to have a low opinion of the Kingdom in general,” Shez noted, “She actually started being nicer to Dedue when she learned he’s from a different country.”

 

“Wow. Gotta admit, didn’t expect to hear that,” Sylvain said while Ingrid frowned.

 

“Why are you friends with this girl again?”

 

“Well I’m friends with you, right? Sometimes people have little prejudices they gotta get past.” Ingrid frowned at Shez’s summation, but she also couldn’t really contradict her. “I kind of get the feeling she hasn’t really had friends before now, so I guess part of me just wants to help her out, you know? Besides, the way I see it, she's the type to get along better with someone after a good fight. So she'll probably warm up to everyone after the big one next month."

 

"...admittedly, I still have my reservations, but I can see what you mean." 

 

"Yeah, let's just hope this one doesn't become a mess like the mock battle," Sylvain said with a smirk towards Shez. 

 

"Hey! That was an accident! And I already got permission to join in next month!" 

 

"Hm… I dunno, I still think you should make it up to us. Maybe by cluing us in on your house's plans for the battle?" 

 

"Oh, that's simple, I'll just be beating up whoever's in a different house." 

 

"..."

 

"..." 

 

"Hey, it's worked for me so far. If you're looking for big plans, you'll have to ask Claude." 

 

"Not surprised there. Though I gotta say, now that we're down your strength, we're definitely going to be in a tight spot in the battle. Can't even brag about having a relic weapon with how your sister has one too." 

 

"Eh, I'm sure you guys will figure out something. Dimitri has to have some plan in mind, right?" 

 

"He probably does, though it'll likely need some polish." 

 

"How so?" 

 

"You know how Dimitri is. When it comes to being a leader, he can be a bit too softhearted," Ingrid said with a sigh. "He might end up playing it safely again. Which yes, it's not a real battle, but if he's not willing to lose soldiers in a mock battle, then I can't help but wonder how he'll do as a king." 

 

"Hey, come on now Ingrid, no need to talk about something so serious,” Sylvain chided, “It'll just be a fun fight." 

 

"Yeah, though if you're that worried about losing, feel free to surrender already," Shez teased as she smirked, getting Ingrid to huff. 

 

"Don't think it'll be that easy. One way or another, the Blue Lions will be taking the victory!" 

 

"Heh, bring it on!"

The sound of wood hitting wood sounded out throughout the training grounds as Dimitri trained on his own. Keeping his focus intently on the wooden training dummy, he failed to notice the cracking sounds coming from his training spear until he brought it back, ready to thrust into the dummy, only for the spear to break as his grip tightened. 

 

Letting out an irritated sigh, he reached down to grab broken scraps. 

 

It was getting…harder, to control his strength. His anger continued to boil ever since he saw that dastard betray one of her own. He just couldn't understand it, what kind of person would kill the person who raised them!? What sort of vengeance could bring something like that about!?

 

Feeling his fists ball up, Dimitri was dimly aware of the broken wood in his hand getting crushed even further. 

 

Would…Would he ever kill someone he cared about if it meant appeasing the dead? 

 

The spirits seemed to roar to life at that, as if daring him to ever show hesitancy again. 

 

"I'm sorry, it was just a stray thought." Dimitri muttered to himself as he begged for them to leave him be. 

 

"Dimitri?" A voice broke him free from the spirits as he looked over, finding Professor Byleth standing nearby.

 

"Professor? Did you need something?" 

 

"I thought I heard something loud," she said, glancing down at the broken spear. "Isn't it a little late to be training?" she asked, getting Dimitri to realize that the sun had indeed already set. 

 

"Ah, my apologies, I lost track of the time," Dimitri explained, before getting back to cleaning. "I'll make sure to replace the damaged spear." 

 

"Hm…do you want to spar?" 

 

"Excuse me?" 

 

"You seem angry and a spar might help. It did for Edelgard when I first joined." 

 

“Ah, no thank you, professor. I don’t think I should be sparring when I’m agitated like this,” he replied, before regarding the professor somewhat curiously, “Though I didn’t realize Edelgard had her own issues with anger.”

 

“Not really, it’s more that Ferdinand was annoying her and sparring helped her unwind. I can also understand why you might want to avoid sparring while angry.” She glanced at the training field, recalling the moment she’d nearly beaten Jeritza into the ground. It was almost funny to think that if she had killed him then while lost in her fury, he wouldn’t have been able to cut her open in the mausoleum or kidnap Flayn. Though she probably would have gotten in trouble for killing an instructor out of nowhere, so hm…

 

Dimitri, meanwhile, couldn’t help but remember that night too. “...How did you work past that anger, professor?”

 

“It took a while,” Byleth readily answered, turning back to the blond prince, “People helped me. I talked with Edelgard a few times about it, Shez was there for me, and I could actually confront Catherine about the problem I had with her. We sparred, and I didn’t lose my temper. Then we fought together and…I didn’t expect to have to kill Lonato. It’s horrible. I was angry because of the injustice he suffered, but I was the one to kill him because he wanted justice.”

 

“...You put your duty above your vengeance,” Dimitri noted, and he could hear his father call him a spineless worm right as his stepmother reminded him that he had a duty to avenge them.

 

“I did. I still can’t say I like Catherine. She acts friendly…she is friendly, but she’s also zealous. I would like to believe she has a good heart, but I still don’t want to be around her if I can avoid it.” She paused, thinking. “Hm. I’ll still probably get her something for her birthday though, it’s coming up and that’s just good manners.”

 

Dimitri felt a slight smile come to his face at the change in topic. “You’re very kind to keep other’s birthdays in mind so readily. It seems you’re always planning a celebration for one or another.”

 

Byleth shrugged. “It’s a nice thing to do. Things are peaceful right now, so why not celebrate when there’s cause to?”

 

“A very good question, professor…Ah, if I may ask, when is your birthday?”

 

“It’s on the twentieth.”

 

Dimitri blinked. “Of this month?”

 

“Yup.”

 

“Well, I’ll keep that in mind then.”

 

That earned a slight smile. “Thanks. How are you feeling?”

 

Dimitri paused. “...Better, I think.” It wasn’t quite a lie. He wasn’t quite as agitated now.

 

“Hm…My problem was resolved because I could talk with Catherine and get to know her. I don’t think that’s possible with Bias.”

 

“No, I doubt it is…” He sighed. “I just…That woman admitted that old man, Solon, raised her. That he was as good as a father to her, and she murdered him. And I know he was an evil man! He abducted Shez and he made it clear he was fine with doing worse, but… 

 

His fists clenched. “...I can’t get that look of betrayal he had out of my mind. He looked…He looked like what I can only imagine a father might look like if it were his own child murdering him.”

 

The image of his own father’s body drifted through Dimitri’s mind and he shuddered. “...What could drive a person to do that?”

 

“...I don’t know,” Byleth admitted, “She said she hated him.”

 

“She did. She…She said she thought he killed two people, Thales and Pittacus,” Dimitri recalled, “And…I don’t know. Were they her family? Did she really want vengeance so badly she was willing to murder her own father for it? And then to realize he had nothing to do with it then and there…”

 

“I don’t think either of us can figure out what her motive was. We can speculate, but unless we get a chance to talk to her again, we won’t know what was really going through her mind.”

 

"...Somehow I doubt she'll be willing to speak to us about it." 

 

"Maybe. We won't know until it happens," Byleth said, as she offered a hand to help him up. 

 

"I suppose so," Dimitri responded, taking her hand to get up. "Thank you for this talk, Professor." 

 

"It was no problem. Even if you aren't my student, I still want to make sure to help you," Byleth said. "You're a good person, Dimitri. Just remember to ask for help if you need it. At the very least, you can train better if someone's assisting you." 

 

"I'll make sure to keep that in mind, Professor. Though for now, I should try to get some rest."

 

"Goodnight, Dimitri." 

"I fail to see the issue," Hubert said as he talked with Edelgard. "The professor has put her full trust in you. Does that not mean she is that much easier to control?" 

 

"I know, but if we lead her along, then it may end up backfiring on us if she were to learn our association with Bias." 

 

"Then we simply have to make sure she doesn't find out. As it stands the only ones who could tell her are Bias and Kronya, which means we just have to get rid of them," Hubert noted. 

 

"..." Letting out a sigh, Edelgard decided to focus on something else. "That is true. Though I can't help but wonder what she's planning… are they going to attempt something with Shez again?" 

 

"It is certainly possible, assuming what Solon said was indeed the truth." 

 

"If we keep assuming that she is working with them, then we won't get anywhere." 

 

"It never hurts to be too cautious," Hubert advised, “But I digress. Kronya has clearly shifted her objective, whatever it may be now. If we can indeed presume Shez truly is someone who is ethnically ‘Agarthan’, yet not a member of Those Who Slither in the Dark, then there lies the question of what her goal is.”

 

“We assumed that her mission here was to get close to me. Presumably then, her shift in priorities comes at Bias’s order…assuming she is still working with Those Who Slither.”

 

“You think she may have defected?”

 

Edelgard gave Hubert a flat look. “I think Bias quite literally stabbed her superior in the back. Whatever their goals may be, I think it is safe to assume she was going against orders to do so. Which means it’s not a question of ‘if’ she has defected, but what she plans to do now that she has.”

 

“Hm…but do our enemies know that she has defected? If she can remove an obstacle to her in such a way that hides her involvement, such as by murdering him with an enemy’s weapon…though that leaves Kronya as a loose end for her. Unless Kronya was on her side from the beginning…”

 

Edelgard sighed. “We don’t know enough about the dynamics between the Agarthans to be sure who is part of which faction, or even what those factions are. We know Thales is dead and Bias seems to want to avenge her sister…how long do you think she can stay here?”

 

“If the Church was smart, they would already be investigating their staff members to try to root out any other potential infiltrators. If she stays, then the chances of her getting caught rise by the day.”

 

“...” Edelgard sighed again, genuinely frustrated. “I thought we finally had a handle on our enemies, yet only now is it obvious I had no real concept of how many moving parts there are in their organization. Presumably Myson and Cleobulus lead opposing factions now that Thales is dead, but whose side is Bias on? And what about Kronya? That knife the professor found had to be hers, but why would she drop it? Did she mean for it to be discovered? She had it on her person, so she intended some use for it down there…”

 

“Why would a person hide a knife up their sleeve?” Hubert asked, rhetorically, “Presumably, our former classmate was looking to perform an assassination while everyone was distracted. Then Solon died and she didn’t carry it out. Though, to be specific, we have no evidence that she carried out any assassination. It is quite interesting that no Agarthans aside from Kronya and Bias survived that operation. And, if our schoolmates are to be believed, Bias played a part in ensuring that was the case. Quite a few of them were horrified at how readily she threw her allies into danger to save herself.”

 

“...Then…could it be that Kronya is the one defecting?” Edelgard suggested, looking thoughtful, “If not for loyalty to Solon, then she could be trying to get away from a superior who doesn’t mind killing her if it will save herself.”

 

“Well we could always ask her.”

 

Edelgard huffed. “That’s not funny, Hubert.”

 

“It was just a suggestion,” Hubert responded with a low chuckle. “Regardless, as it stands, our highest priority would be to figure out what exactly Bias is planning.” 

 

“...I think I know what it is. Or at least, I know who she is targeting, even if she herself doesn’t.”

 

“Would you mind explaining that to me?” 

 

“With everything that has happened, it slipped my mind to tell you, but I discovered the truth of what occurred at the Oghma mountains all those years ago. Or more specifically, who caused it,” Edelgard said, before explaining what their Professor had told her. 

 

She had to admit, there was something funny about Hubert falling into the near hysterical laughter she had previously fell into.

Claude had to admit, he wasn’t sure why exactly a minor noble from the Empire decided to transfer over to his class, but it was funny seeing her accept Lorenz’s offer for tea with a strained smile. From what he did know of Emily Korsch, the girl was surly, standoffish, aggressive, and probably a sadist. In other words, probably the funniest person Lorenz could try to work his “charms” on.

 

Though he seemed to have his work cut out for him since it looked like Emily had no idea what the difference between tea blends were. Or as she called it, leaf water. It was probably the most taken aback he had ever seen the posh noble get, and it wasn’t long before Lorenz declared that it was up to him to teach her about the grandness of tea. 

 

Well if nothing else, it'll keep Lorenz busy so he'll stop bothering me. 

 

"Wow, I think that's the first time I've seen a girl say yes to having tea with Lorenz," Hilda noted as she walked by, a bit amused as Emily got dragged off while visibly holding herself back from attacking Lorenz. "Poor girl." 

 

"I'd feel sorry for her if she wasn't planning something," Claude replied as he turned his attention to Hilda. "Goes from not wanting to get close to anyone, to suddenly trying to be all buddy buddy. Bit obvious, don't you think? It'd be one thing if it was just Shez, but the other day I saw her trying to seem interested in Ignatz’s paintings." 

 

Hilda giggled. "Well I'm not going to complain if she is trying to get in my good graces. That girl will do anything with the right words." 

 

"Hm, that is true." Claude definitely found it hilarious seeing the Imperial noble try to 'charm' her new Alliance classmates, only to end up getting manipulated by them. Or just dragged along with whatever the classmate in question was interested in. “Do you think she’ll try to get a taste for meat to endear herself to Raphael?”

 

“Pff, you’re a little late on that guess, Claude. I’m pretty sure she prefers meat to begin with from how she started digging into those Gronder skewers last night.”

 

Claude let himself laugh there. “Seriously? Now I really am curious what Lady Emily’s upbringing was like to get her to turn out like this.”

 

“Well as far as I know, she’s just from some small family in the Empire. No real lands or titles to speak of, just a lordship and a manor in Enbarr.” Hilda shrugged. “I’m not about to make guesses on how she was raised, that’s the kind of thing I leave to smarter people.”

 

“Aw, but it sounds like you have at least some insights.”

 

“Nope! You can stick to all that rumor mongering while I do some proper, important things for a young lady of my station.”

 

“Like go invite Marianne for tea again?”

 

Hilda pouted. “Well how else am I going to get to hang out with her? Though it’s not like I’m even guaranteed to get some time alone with her since her professor came along last time.”

 

“Really?” Claude raised an eyebrow. “So you’ve been having tea parties with Teach?”

 

“Just the one so far, though I guess I can admit that she’s actually pretty nice. It’s funny, you see her from a distance and she just seems like a scary, if kind of cute, mercenary, then you talk to her and she’s weirdly monotone and inexpressive, but then you talk some more and it turns out she’s actually a sweetheart. It’s hard to believe people call her by a scary name like ‘The Ashen Dragon’ after you hear her chatting about all the cats around the monastery and how she has their breeds and favorite foods memorized.

 

“Heck, I can see why Marianne joined her class. I mean, Professor Manuela is nice and all, but she's kind of a mess, and doesn't interact with the students as much as Professor Byleth does. If I were in her shoes, I'd probably join a class with a teacher that makes me feel more comfortable." 

 

"Aw, are you saying you wouldn't stick around with me?" 

 

"Depends, the homework Professor Manuela assigned us seems to be a bit much for little old me." 

 

"I'm sure our new classmate would love to help you with that," Claude said with a smirk. 

 

"Yeah, I don't think any of the three newbies are gonna be much help in the brains department." Hilda responded with a light giggle. "Emily seems way more focused on getting strong, Shez makes it clear she's not the brains between her and her sister, and Baltie is well… Baltie." 

 

"Speaking of, how's Holst doing? Have you written to him about Balthus?" 

 

"Yeah, it was probably the fastest I ever got a letter back once I told him. If he wasn't busy guarding Fodlan's Throat, he probably would have made his way over here right away," Hilda said, sighing at how her brother could be. "He was really tempted to though. Apparently the Almyrans haven't made any move all year, though he says that could mean they might be planning something big." 

 

"...They are?" Well, that was worrying. 

 

"Yeah, Holst was surprised too. Though who knows, maybe they'll finally stop attacking." 

 

"Somehow I doubt that." Hm…that was odd. The western lords weren't the type to just stop their attacks, not when there was glory to be won. Getting their asses kicked didn’t even stop them, since one would just attack right after another lord was forced back. If the attacks halted completely…did something happen in Almyra? 

 

Claude got the distinctive feeling something big was going to happen, and he didn't like it.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Adjusting to day to day life with everything that happened, which includes kronya totally manipulating her classmates!

Red: She's such a skillful manipulator...truly an unparalleled genius.

Indi: Yup yup, speaking of day to day life, next chapter is going to be a special one, since as we're going with the Canon date, it's Byleth’s birthday!

Red: Yup! Which should be a fun time for all! For now though, thanks for reading as always!

Byleth’s Birthday

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

"...D-Does the professor look like she's waiting for something?" Bernadetta asked Marianne, whispering as she looked at Byleth. The former mercenary was sitting at her desk, sitting up straight and looking at her students expectantly. 

 

"Maybe she just wants to make sure we finish our work properly?" Marianne suggested as she glanced at the sheet before them full of questions involving night battle tactics. 

 

"If it was that big of a deal, she'd say something," Lindhart said from behind the two as he let out a yawn. 

 

"Hm… it's weird, I feel like there's something at the tip of my tongue but I don't know what it is…" Caspar muttered. 

 

"Maybe we should just ask her?" Flayn asked, though she didn’t want to be the one to do so. 

 

"Why don't we just finish our work for now before assuming things about our professor?" Edelgard cut in. She actually had finished her work already, so really it was everyone else that was the problem. 

 

"Aw, but Edie, you have to admit she does look cute like this." 

 

"You shouldn't make inappropriate comments about our professor, Dorothea," Edelgard complained, getting Dorothea to blink. Though before she could ask what Edelgard’s comment was about, the bell rang, signaling the end of class. 

 

"Ah, please make sure to finish the work when you have the time, but you have until the end of class on Monday to finish it, so no rush," Byleth said, as the students began to get up. 

 

"No worries professor, I have already finished the assignment!" Ferdinand boasted as he handed the paper in. As did a few other students, minus the boasting. 

 

"Thank you," Byleth said, taking the papers before pausing as she heard the door open. "Dimitri?" 

 

"Sorry to intrude, Professor, I just came by to deliver something," the blond prince said as he walked up to the teacher and handed her a box. 

 

"Oh, thank you Dimitri," Byleth replied as she opened the box, and found a brooch inside that had a blue gem in its center. 

 

Beside her, Edelgard heard Dorothea let out a gasp as she saw the gift, while the Imperial Heiress herself felt her brow furrow. Why did Dimitri suddenly bring the professor a gift? …Was he competition–was he attempting to seduce the professor?

 

"I hope it's to your liking professor, I had asked for some help choosing it from my classmates. On behalf of all the Blue Lions, we wish you a happy birthday." 

 

Oh, it was a birthday gift- 

 

What. 

 

"That was it!" Caspar suddenly shouted, before running out of the classroom in a hurry. 

 

“Oh, whoops. Hey, professor,” Linhardt called out, raising a hand, “I forgot it was your birthday. Can I get you a gift tomorrow?”

 

“That’s okay, Linhardt,” Byleth accepted while taking out the brooch and tilting her head as she tried to figure out where to attach it to her shirt.

 

“Great, I’ll get it to you then. Or next week. When I remember.”

 

Edelgard, meanwhile, couldn’t help but notice her other classmates were being less than calm about obviously forgetting their professor’s birthday, judging by the frenzy of whispering she was hearing. She, however, remained perfectly calm as she pushed herself up from her desk, prompting a glance from Dorothea.

 

“Oh? Heh, so, Edie, do you happen to have something–”

 

“I don’t see why I would,” she muttered, trying to keep her voice low, “I have no obligation to get my teacher a birthday gift.”

 

“Oh, so you do have something special planned then~.”

 

“Why do you say that?”

 

“Well otherwise you would be doing the same thing as Hubie.”

 

Edelgard paused, then glanced towards the front and saw Hubert inclining his head towards the professor. “Happy birthday, professor. Congratulations on living for another year.”

 

“Thank you, Hubert.”

 

“...That’s good enough?” Edelgard mumbled, before her eyes narrowed, because of course that wasn’t good enough. She may not have an obligation to give a gift to her professor, but she was a princess of Adrestia, she could most definitely give a better gift than just some well-wishes!

 

Dorothea blinked as Edelgard pushed away from the desk and left the classroom, trying to avoid looking hurried as she practically fled the room. “...Hmm…well, no need to comment on that when she’s not around to hear it. Now, what to do for our lovely professor?”

 

While Dorothea considered her plans for the professor’s birthday and Edelgard continued to not-hurry her way to the markets, the rest of the Eagles scattered across the monastery grounds, some quicker than others, as they tried to figure out what would work as a gift for the professor’s birthday.

 

As the students left the classroom in a hurry, Caspar came running back into the classroom, holding a small box which he handed to Byleth. 

 

"Sorry about that professor, it completely slipped my mind," the young man apologized.

 

"It's okay," Byleth said with a smile as she opened the box, finding a new whetstone in it. 

 

"Hope you like it professor! It probably won't help much with a relic weapon, but I'm sure it'll still be handy!" 

 

"Thank you Caspar," Byleth said, her smile widening. "I've been meaning to get a new one." 

 

"Ha, nice! Glad I got something good!" he said, before looking around. "Hey, where'd everyone go?" he asked, getting Byleth to shrug. 

 

Sometime later, as she chatted with Shez while they went to get something to eat, they were approached by Flayn, who seemed to be out of breath as she came running up to them.

 

"P-Professor! H-here you go!" Flayn said, after taking in some deep breaths, and handing her a book of fables. "I hope you like it!"

 

"Thank you Flayn, I'll make sure to read it when I have the time," Byleth replied, getting the young girl to smile brightly, happy that her gift worked well. 

 

"Pft, she seemed like she was in a rush," Shez commented once Flayn scurried away.

 

"I think they forgot it was my birthday," Byleth explained as they continued walking, "So they're rushing around." 

 

"Oh, wow. Well, this'll be fun," Shez said, smiling too, though her smile was a bit more mischievous. She was perfectly happy to stick by her sister's side so she could see the rest of the students scamper around, desperate to look like they’d remembered. Which went about as well as she expected, since, mid-lunch, Hapi came up to them, and handed Byleth an arithmetic textbook. 

 

"Here you go, Chatterbox. It's from Yuri and me,” she said, walking away before Byleth could thank her. 

 

"...huh. Well, least it's nice?" Shez guessed as Byleth opened the book, and immediately noticed writing in the margins that made it seem like Yuri had the book for some time. 

 

"Mm. It's the thought that counts." 

 

"Professor!" Bernadetta yelled out to the sisters as she came scampering towards them, only to trip on the way over. The bag she held in her hands flew into the air, only for Byleth to swiftly catch her student, steadying her and grabbing the bag before it could hit the ground. "A-Ah, s-sorry!" 

 

"It's okay," Byleth replied, before looking at the bag in her hand. "Is this for me?"

 

"O-Only if you want it!" Bernadetta said, blushing before she squirmed free of Byleth’s grip and ran away, calling over her shoulder as she went. "I-I hope you enjoy it!" 

 

"...I really need to apologize to her for leaving her in the training grounds that one time," Shez muttered, getting Byleth’s attention as she opened the bag and found some cookies in it. 

 

"What happened?" 

 

"Eh, I'll explain later," Shez said, before reaching over to try and grab one of Byleth’s treats, only to pout as Byleth moved the bag away. "Rude." 

 

Leaving the mess hall after finishing their food, the duo were soon approached by Marianne, who kept her eyes down. 

 

"I-I’m sorry for forgetting your birthday, P-Professor," she murmured as she handed over an owl feather that seemed to have been made into a charm. "I hope t-this makes u-up for it. H-Hilda helped me make it." 

 

"No need to apologize, Marianne," Byleth said, taking the charm. "And thank you, it looks lovely." 

 

"H-Hm." Bowing to her, Marianne left, seemingly flustered. 

 

"Heh, someone's really popular," Shez teased. 

 

"I'm just glad my students like me." 

 

“There is much to be liking about you,” Petra noted as she walked up, a book in hand. “Here you are, Professor, I hope you are having much to learn from this.” 

 

Looking at the book, Byleth noted that it seemed to be a book about Brigid’s language.

 

“Thank you, Petra, this is lovely.”

 

“I am glad you are enjoying my gift. If you need any help with understanding, you must only ask.”

 

“Of course.”

 

"There you are my attendant!" Constance said, coming up with a wide smile, being her bright self thanks to there being an overcast sky that day. "I hope you're ready, for I, Constance von Nuvelle, have the greatest present for you!" 

 

"Just to make sure, is this another experiment?" 

 

"Of course not! Unless you would prefer helping me with another experiment?" 

 

"Maybe tomorrow," Byleth said, before Constance led them back to the courtyard. 

 

"Here we go, this should be the perfect area for it!" Constance declared, smiling as she faced the two sisters. "Now, I hope you are ready for a dazzling Nuvelle performance!" 

 

With a flick of her fan, a fireball formed above it, before it went straight up into the air, exploding midair as it formed Constance’s crest. Feeling their eyes widen, both Byleth and Shez watched in awe as Constance began sending more fireballs into the air, each one of them bursting in the air to form different symbols, before ending with the familiar sight of the twin-headed black eagle. 

 

"And such is the grand magic of House Nuvelle!" 

 

"Constance, that was amazing!" Shez immediately cheered as Byleth clapped. 

 

"Very impressive. I'd love to see it again." 

 

"Heh, well, I hope you're ready for when I perform this again! Next time it won't just be fire-" 

 

"Constance! What do you think you're doing!?" Seteth yelled out, as he marched up to the trio. 

 

"A-Ah, well, I was just performing my magic for-" 

 

"Recklessly firing magic into the air can get people hurt!" 

 

"Sorry about that Seteth," Byleth apologized in her stead. "Constance just wanted to perform something for my birthday. I should have asked her to do this elsewhere." 

 

"Oh, is that so?" Seteth asked, a bit surprised at the news. His gaze seemed to soften for a moment, much to the sisters’ surprise. "...As thanks for saving Flayn, I'll let you off easily. Though don't do something like this without permission." 

 

"O-Of course, my apologies," Constance said, trying not to anger the chamberlain before she hurried off.

 

"Well, that could have ended better," Shez muttered. "Hopefully Constance is up to do that again, cause that was fun." 

 

"It would be nice if she did." 

 

"There you are, Professor!" Ferdinand shouted, a smile on his face as he came up to them. "I had noticed that your armor looked like it was getting worn out, so I wanted to give you some new oil and wax!" the young noble said with a smile as he handed the gift over. 

 

"Oh, thank you Ferdinand. That's very thoughtful." 

 

"Glad you like it!" Ferdinand smiled once again before bowing to the two. 

 

"Guess that means it's my turn~" Blinking, the two sisters saw Dorothea walking up to the two. "I’m a bit disappointed I didn't get to you earlier, cause Constance already had a performance for you, but I hope you still like mine~" 

 

"Oh? What's that?" 

 

"Heh, well it's not everyday someone gets a personal performance from a songstress of the Mittlefrank Opera Company~ Though you’re free to join in watching if you want Shezzie~” 

 

“Ah… nah, I just remembered I have something to do. Hope you two have fun!” Shez said, smiling at the two as she waved them off. 

 

“Hm, well that’s not surprising. I knew she didn’t really get opera stuff, but it’s a shame she turned down the offer.” 

 

“I can talk to her later if you want.” 

 

“Pft, no need, Professor. Now come on, let’s go find someplace nice for this!” 

Walking back through the monastery after managing to order and purchase a gift for the professor, Edelgard did her best to not seem like she was looking for Byleth. Sure, she might have paid extra to get the gift made as soon as possible, but it was only to thank the professor for all the help she gave them. Really, it was like a gift from all the Black Eagles and not just her.

 

Such was the reason that she had the pendant bear the mark of the Black Eagles. 

 

Taking in a deep breath, she put the box into her pocket as she began to look around. From what she could see, everyone else in the class had already given her a gift, which meant her’s was the only one left. Well, aside from Lindhart, but who knows when he’d gift her something. 

 

Though… was it odd for her to be the last one? It was a bit late to think so, but being the last one meant she’d likely think of her gift the most. Not that she wanted her to think of her, of course. Really, this gift was just an obligation, since she was the house leader, and Byleth was their professor. 

 

Pausing as she heard someone singing, Edelgard looked over and saw Dorothea seemingly performing a solo act to their professor. Who was smiling enraptured in her performance. Not that she could blame her, Dorothea was a famous songstress for a reason, and her months away from the opera company did little to nothing when it came to rusting her skill. 

 

Seeing the performance come to an end, Edelgard waited, not waiting to interrupt. 

 

 “So, what did you think, Professor?” 

 

“It was amazing. Even if it was just you by yourself, this was far beyond the play my family saw when I was young.” 

 

“Well I was just starting out back then, so of course I'd get better~”

 

“You definitely did, I hope I get to hear you sing again.” 

 

“My my, you are quite the flatterer~” Dorothea said, with a teasing grin. “If I didn’t know any better I’d say you were serious when you said you’d take care of me~”

 

Edelgard…didn’t quite know how to react to that. The immediate reaction was a strange sense of hurt, but she immediately pushed that down under the obvious reality that she had no context for the conversation Dorothea was referring to. Add in the songstress’s teasing nature and the fact that Edelgard had no cause to even feel hurt in this circumstance, and it made no sense to react poorly to a simple teasing comment.

 

“I wouldn’t mind,” Byleth replied, and that gave Edelgard some pause because that was harder to disregard.

 

Dorothea sighed though. “Really professor, don’t get a girl’s hopes up–Oh? Oh hello Edie~!”

 

Ah, she was noticed. 

 

Edelgard composed herself and stepped forward, nodding to Dorothea first before facing her professor. “Hello professor. On behalf of the Black Eagles House, I would like to give you a present for your birthday. Thank you for your efforts as an instructor thus far.”

 

And with that said, she presented her gift, contained in a velvet-lined case. She held it out to the professor, who took it, and then Edelgard had to fight down any reaction when she saw the bright, happy smile that appeared on her professor’s face.

 

“Thank you very much, Edelgard.” She took the pendant from the box and held it up, staring at the black eagle on the pendant with a small smile before she set the box down and put the pendant on. 

 

“...As I said, it was a gift from the class as a whole,” Edelgard reiterated while trying to ignore how the pendant sat on Byleth’s chest…and also fighting down a flash of irritation when she noticed her professor had also pinned that stupid brooch Dimitri got her to her shirt. “...And I think it is better to show your affiliation to the class you are actually teaching.”

 

“Hm? Oh, okay. Should I wear this all the time then?”

 

“...” Edelgard grimaced, wondering why that question happened to make her face warm up. “Do what you want with it. It’s your gift.”

 

“Okay. I’ll make sure to wear it then.”

 

“If that is what you want.”

 

“It is.”

 

“...Good, then. If that is all, I should be going.”

 

Edelgard did not run away from her professor. She kept very composed as she left her professor to her own devices…and tried her best not to sigh when Dorothea said her goodbyes and followed right after her.

 

“So, a gift from the whole class, hm~?”

 

“That is what I said, yes.”

 

“One that happens to bear the specific heraldry of House Hresvelg~?”

 

“The black eagle on a red background is the symbol of the Black Eagle House. It represents the House at the monastery, not the Imperial Household.”

 

“Really? So that little eagle didn’t happen to have two heads?”

 

Edelgard actually paused for a moment there, thinking back to the pendant and wondering, for a second, if she actually did give the professor a pendant with a two-headed eagle on it, which would send the exact wrong signals she wasn’t trying to send at all– “The eagle on the flag is gold, there’s a difference.”

 

“...Hm, is everything okay Edie? You’re acting a bit strange today.” 

 

“There is nothing odd about how I am acting.” 

 

“Sure, I mean, it’s not like you’ve always gotten flustered before whenever I brought up you and the professor.” 

 

“...As the future Emperor of Adrestria, pursuing any form of relationship with a mercenary would be improper.”

 

“Right, and what about all that stuff about you changing the empire and doing away with the nobility system? I’m pretty sure if there are no nobles, it wouldn’t matter if the emperor got with a mercenary.” 

 

“I am doing that for the betterment of the empire, not to pursue some… flight of fancy,” Edelgard responded, making Dorothea frown

 

“Edie, come on, you need to tell me what’s up. I can’t help you if I don’t know what’s wrong.”

 

“There is nothing up, Dorothea. It is simply the truth of the matter. My dream comes first before all else, and I must devote myself to it until I achieve it.” 

 

“...Edie, you really shouldn't lie to yourself like this.” 

 

“I’m not, thank you for your concern Dorothea, but I am perfectly fine,” Edelgard said, ending the conversation then and there before marching away. This was how things were meant to be: even if her classmates and professor agreed to help her wage war against the church, she would still be the emperor who brought the end to many. Let them find comfort amongst themselves as she carried the burden alone. 

 

“Ah, Lady Edelgard, there you are.” Well, maybe not completely alone.

 

Edelgard smiled slightly as she turned to see Hubert. “Hello Hubert. I was wondering where you were.”

 

“I should say the same for you. Why did you go running off the marketplace earlier?”

 

“...” Edelgard cleared her throat, her face reddening a little. “I…will admit, I forgot that it was the professor’s birthday. I wanted to keep it in mind, but…well, with everything that happened…”

 

“Ah, I see. Well, there’s no need to worry, we can simply say my gift is from the both of us.”

 

“No, I did manage to commission a–...Your gift?”

 

He nodded. “Yes, I had no plans to originally do so, but after learning of her…contributions to the Empire, I elected to send her a tome of rare magics that was in House Vestra’s possession. I believe it should be adequate for her needs, given her abilities as a mage.”

 

“...That’s better than my gift.”

 

Hubert blinked. “Pardon?”

 

Edelgard didn’t respond, instead stomping off in an aggravated huff because apparently she couldn’t trust anyone in this damn academy.

“Well well, I think this is the first time I’ve ever seen you this happy,” Sothis commented as she floated behind Byleth, who was busy placing all her new gifts on her desk, from Caspar’s whetstone to the very pretty black and red tome Hubert had sent her. 

 

Everything aside from her pendant, of course; Edelgard wanted her to wear it, so she was going to keep it on.

 

“Today was really nice,” Byleth said, smiling down at the pendant as she held it up, studying the little eagle on it. Interesting that it had two heads instead of one. Maybe the crafter made a mistake? She kind of liked it though, it gave it a kind of unique look.

 

“I can tell. You’ve had quite the foolish grin on your face ever since you received that pendant you’re so enamored with.” 

 

“I like it.”

 

“No need to pout at me, I didn’t say it was a bad thing.” Byleth wasn’t pouting though? “Though you may wish to rethink your promise of wearing it at all times. You wouldn’t want to accidentally crush it while sleeping.”

 

“...I don’t think I could do that. Could I?”

 

“Your chest is heavy enough to.”

 

Byleth blinked at that, and would have responded if a knock on the door hadn’t caught her attention. She headed over and felt another smile come to her face as she saw three very familiar faces standing on the other side.

 

“SURPRISE!” Shez and Leonie shouted, both of them grinning as Jeralt chuckled. “Happy birthday Byleth!”

 

Byleth giggled, a bright, happy smile on her face at her family’s appearance. “Thank you very much!”

 

“...”

 

Then she blinked, noticing the stunned looks on Jeralt and Shez’s faces. Even Leonie looked a little surprised. “...Uh…is something wrong?”

 

“...No, not at all,” Jeralt answered, his smile returning full force as Shez abruptly gave Byleth a big hug.

 

Byleth blinked again as her sister hoisted her up, Shez’s own laughter echoing out as she swung her around. 

 

“Alright, alright, let her down,” Jeralt requested, “I know it’s a big deal, but you can’t carry her to the party.”

 

“I bet I could!” Shez immediately replied, prompting an amused noise from Leonie and a pout from Byleth.

 

“Let me down.”

 

“Nope~! C’mon, the party’s in town!” 

 

Leonie laughed as she saw her friend start carrying her sister off towards town, before glancing up at Jeralt. “So, uh…this might be a weird question, but was that the first time Byleth has ever laughed?”

 

“It is, yeah.” Jeralt sighed fondly as he watched his kids. Shez had a big grin on her face as she still carried her sister along while Byleth wasn’t really resisting, though she did keep poking Shez’s forehead to show her disapproval. “You might’ve noticed, but Byleth has never been that good with emotions. The fact that she’s laughing…well, I guess this place is better for her than I expected.”

 

“Heh. Well c’mon captain, we can’t be left behind here!” Leonie insisted, grabbing Jeralt’s wrist and pulling him along.

 

“Alright, alright, don’t tug so hard. I’m an old man here,” he mock-complained, following along as they all headed down to a nice tavern he’d found. Technically, the students weren’t supposed to be going out into the town outside the monastery, but being the knight’s captain had at least some perks to it.

 

He did end up in trouble when both Leonie and Byleth wound up completely wasted though, while Shez complained about not being able to drink a drop herself. It was a good thing the next day was an off day as they both ended up nursing a hangover. You never forget your first one, and it definitely seemed neither of the two would as they spent most of the day in their rooms. 

 

Maybe he should teach them about moderation when he got the chance… even if it was a lesson he himself didn’t follow. 

Chapter End Notes

Red: A very happy birthday to Byleth! Not posted on her actual birthday because we'd have to wait months for that.

Indi: Yeah that would have been something. Instead Byleth’s birthday comes now, and with some drama that she has no idea is going on!

Red: Byleth is unprepared for romantic drama. She was also unprepared for hangovers. These two things may or may not be related, depending on what happens next chapter.

Indi: Eh, I'm sure things will be fine.

The Consequences of Indulgence

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Byleth’s head hurt. That was the main thing she could think about when she woke up again. Just…absolute agony in her head, and that was even with her deliberately keeping all sources of light covered after she woke up earlier and found that the sun wanted to kill her.

 

“The sun doesn’t want to kill you, it’s an inanimate ball of hot gas floating in the sky,” Sothis chided, which earned a whine from Byleth as she buried herself further in her den of blankets and pillows, “Ugh, seriously? You know you have to get up at some point.”

 

“Mnhhghl…” Byleth replied, making a very articulate point about how it was a free day and she had no obligations to get up at all. It wasn’t even a holiday, there was no feast or event, she had zero reason to do anything but skip the day entirely.

 

“You can’t just ‘skip’ a day! You need to actually get up and do things! You have bodily functions that need to be taken care of!”

 

“Hhhhhhh…” Byleth responded, complaining that her own body was clearly desiring rest above all other things, and stating that the annoying girl in her head should shut up for a bit.

 

“You only have yourself to blame, you know. Though, honestly, what was your father thinking, letting you drink so much?”

 

“Mfh.” Byleth peeked up from her covers, frowning up at Sothis. She didn’t mind that her dad let her try every drink on the menu and she didn’t blame him for having fun either…though she was having a bit of trouble remembering exactly what she did.

 

Let’s see…went to the tavern with Leonie, Shez, and her dad. Met up with the usual crowd of mercenaries and also Alois, who was there too. She vaguely remembered him making friends with the mercenaries, and…she was pretty sure Victor and Candace actually laughed at his jokes, which probably contributed to them extending the invitation for him to join up if things didn’t work out with the knights.

 

Alois had been flattered, but insisted he couldn’t, on account of how he had a family to support and his own vows of knighthood. 

 

“Sorry to say,” he said, “But I just can’t afford to be a mercenary! Why, my wife would be so angry if I left just like that, I'd be begging for forgiveness so much I'd be a mercy-nary!”

 

Byleth groaned, the very memory of that stupid joke bringing her actual physical pain in the moment.

 

“I swear, you’re ridiculous,” Sothis complained, “You’re a grown woman, you can’t just laze around all day in your–”

 

Then there was a knock at the door and Byleth winced again, before letting out a slow sigh. It was one thing to complain to Sothis, but if someone actually needed her for something, she probably should get up.

 

So the professor pushed herself up from the bed, ignoring the faint ache in her head as she fumbled for a glass of water at her bedside. She drank, then poured the rest of it over her head in an attempt to wake herself up better. After a moment of shaking the water out from her hair, Byleth finally stood from the bed completely and grabbed her coat. The usual gray one, not the darker one she’d received as a present from the mercs, though she did plan to wear that one when she had the opportunity.

 

For now though, she pushed her arms through the sleeves, enjoying the faint bit of cozy feeling they provided, before heading over to her door and opening it up.

 

“Hello?” Byleth rasped. She didn’t expect her voice to sound so rough, but she was tired so it could be excused.

 

Edelgard, on the other side, stared at her. “...”

 

“...?” Byleth blinked, a little blearily, before covering her mouth as a yawn slipped out. “Mh…Sorry. I drank too much last night. My family wanted to celebrate my birthday and we went to a tavern.”

 

“...I see.”

 

“Mm. Sorry, I’m not…I’m a little out of it right now. Did you need anything?” She furrowed her brow. “It is a free day today, right? I didn’t miss class?”

 

“...No, you did not miss class, Professor. I think you should close the door right now.”

 

“...” The non-sequitur took a moment for Byleth to parse and she stared at Edelgard in some confusion after her words registered. “...Why? I thought you wanted to talk.”

 

“You’re in a state of undress right now, professor. Please close the door.”

 

“...” Byleth blinked. She glanced down at herself. She promptly shut the door.

 

On the other side, Edelgard took a deep, calming breath as she tried very hard to forget what she had just seen. She most definitely did not dwell on how adorable her teacher looked with a messy bedhead, nor did she think about the fact that her teacher was still wearing the pendant Edelgard had given her. No, those topics were entirely too innocent for her brain to be focusing on at the moment–And then she shook her head because she was fairly certain that was the exact reverse of what she was intending. 

 

She could dwell on her professor’s messy hair or the fact she still liked her pendant. She could even take note of the fact that her professor also seemed to be wearing a bangle around her wrist that had a golden deer on it. Those were perfectly normal things to think about, rather than the apparent fact that her professor preferred to sleep in very little clothing, or the somewhat interesting revelation that her professor’s favorite colors appeared to be pink and navy blue.

 

“...”

 

Edelgard decided to leave. Checking up on her professor could come later, when said professor was wearing more clothing.

 

A few moments after she left, Byleth opened the door, now actually wearing clothes she could go out in public in, before blinking as she saw that no one was there. “Oh.” 

 

Hm, she hoped she didn’t scare her off…

“Happy birthday, Dorothea," Byleth greeted a few days later as she handed her student a magical tome. 

 

"Oh, thank you professor!" Dorothea replied, smiling as she took the book. "I have to say, this isn't something I usually get as a gift." 

 

"Is it bad?" Byleth asked, frowning. 

 

"Oh no, of course not. People just tend to gift me with jewels and the like," Dorothea explained, thinking about all the nobles hoping to win her favor. "So it's a bit refreshing actually. Speaking of, I see you're still wearing Edie's gift~" 

 

"Well, she did ask me to wear it," Byleth replied as a small frown appeared on her face. 

 

"Hm? Is everything okay, professor?" 

 

"Is everything okay with Edelgard?" Byleth asked.

 

"Aw, thinking about another girl on my birthday~?" 

 

"Ah, sorry," Byleth apologized, a bit of worry in her voice. "I just think she's been avoiding me." 

 

"She has?" 

 

"Yeah, outside of class she hasn't really been talking to me. She even declined having tea together." 

 

"Really? Honestly, what are you thinking Edie…" Dorothea muttered. "Well, while I'm not sure why exactly she's doing this, I can assure you it's nothing against you." 

 

"Are you sure?" 

 

"Yeah, Edie is just being a bit stubborn right now," Dorothea said with a sigh. 

 

Byleth frowned. "Do you have any idea how to help her?" 

 

"Hm…well, it might help if you tell her what you think of her?" 

 

"What I think of her?" 

 

"Yes! Like, say, whether you like her or not." 

 

"I do like her, she's my student." 

 

"Ah, well, that's not exactly what I meant. Like, have you ever looked at her and felt your heart skip a beat?" 

 

"My heart doesn't beat," Byleth responded with a frown. 

 

Dorothea huffed. “Professor, be serious. I want to know if you have any affections for Edie. Ones that go beyond teacher and student.”

 

“...” Byleth continued to frown, though it was more thoughtful. “...I don’t think I understand the question. She’s my student.”

 

Dorothea sighed and grumbled something under her breath that Byleth didn’t quite catch. Something about someone being oblivious? “Hm…professor, is there anything in particular you like about Edie?”

 

“Anything in particular…she’s very smart and determined. When she sets her mind to something, she’s going to do it no matter how difficult the task is. I think that’s admirable.”

 

“...Not exactly what I meant, professor, though I can agree. Hm…Professor, you might be teasing me when it comes to taking care of me when I grow old, but what if Edie were to ask you that?”

 

Byleth blinked, taking a second to parse that question, before looking at Dorothea with some concern. “Is Edelgard in trouble?”

 

“...” Dorothea placed her hands over her face and sighed again, trying to avoid showing her professor just how incredibly exasperated she was. “...What if Edie offered to take care of you, professor?”

 

“I don’t think I can work for her until my contract with the church expires. I wouldn’t mind working for her in an official capacity though.”

 

“...” Dorothea dragged her hands down her face, then fixed Byleth with a very direct stare. “Professor, do you have any romantic interest in Edie?”

 

Byleth blinked at the unexpectedly blunt question, then actually considered it. “...I don’t think so. I…huh.” She frowned. “...I…don’t know what romantic affection feels like. I know I love my dad and Shez because they’re my family, and I like all of my students. I’m not sure what it would feel like to be attracted to someone in that way so I don’t know if I could even recognize it.”

 

“...Well that’s disappointing,” Dorothea commented, pouting.

 

“Ah, sorry.”

 

“No, it’s not your fault. I’m the one getting silly ideas in my head here.”

 

“It’s okay. My emotions just work weirdly sometimes. I’m getting better at it.”

 

Dorothea didn’t really know how to reply to that, especially with how earnest the professor sounded. “Well then, why don’t we save the talk of romance for later then? If Edie’s so unwilling to have your usual teatime, perhaps I could substitute~?”

 

“Oh, sure, if you want to. You like the sweet-apple and Albinean berry blends, right?”

 

“That I do! You know, it really is impressive how many things you keep memorized.”

 

Byleth shrugged, a little more comfortable now that she was on a more familiar conversation topic. “Part of my job is making sure everyone is happy and healthy, so I just keep the things that make people happy in my mind.”

 

“I wonder, does that come from being a mercenary captain’s daughter, or is it just a natural talent?”

 

As the two made their way towards the gardens and continued their conversation, Byleth did feel her mind drifting back to the earlier topic. What did romantic attraction feel like? And…could she be attracted to her student?

 

Was that even possible?

 

...She needed to think about this more.

 

"Oh great, I can already tell this is going to be a bigger thing than it should be," Sothis muttered, faintly annoyed.

 

"It's important," Byleth responded, frowning. "I need to take my student's feelings seriously."

 

"Ugh, I suppose...well at least you don't have anything else to worry about right now."

In the middle of the night, a light shuffling could be heard in the library as a certain sage disguised as a priestess poured over several tomes. Beasts though they might be, Bias had to admit the people living freely up here certainly knew a thing or two when it came to magic. Not much; they were still far behind the Agarthans when it came to sorcery and technology, but it was still enough for the sage to begin building new theorems as she studied. 

 

Though, as she read through the tomes she had acquired, her mind drifted to Kronya, and how the little puppy was clearly frightened. She wasn't even trying to be subtle in trying to gain new allies. Nevertheless, it was fun seeing her scramble around, so she would let her live, for now. Not to mention that, with just the right words, Kronya would still prove a valuable source of information on the young, ignorant whelp called Shez. 

 

Chuckling to herself, Bias began to wonder who she should target next. If it wasn't the wayward stray who killed her sister, then it was likely someone else who worked for Cleobulus, though the question of who did the foul deed was still a mystery. One she intended on solving…

 

The sound of a door opening broke her out of her thoughts. Looking over, she suppressed a scowl at the sight of the purple-haired brat. Schooling herself, she put on a slight smile. 

 

"I'm sorry, but the library–" A purple flash of light cut her off as Bias found herself knocked onto the floor, the student pinning her down as she felt a blade against her neck. 

 

"Explain to me why you killed Solon."

 

“...” Bias glanced at the blade at her throat, noting the design, then glanced up at the girl pinning her down. Her eyes were fully orange and glowing with a fiery intensity that illuminated the white markings on her face. “...Huh. You don’t have the power of Epimenides…you are Epimenides.”

 

“An obvious deduction. Answer my question,” the great sage ordered in a very different voice from the stray’s usual tone, pressing the blade closer.

 

“Solon showed no care for Thales’s death. It meant the possibility of him being the one to murder our leader rose to a level I found unacceptable. And even if he wasn’t, I found his callous attitude warranted his removal from his position,” Bias answered quite readily, still regarding those fiery eyes with more interest than apprehension.

 

“I see. Who was Pittacus to you?”

 

That question prompted a frown. “...My twin. We were born together, from the same source.”

 

“And that is the real reason you killed him then. An emotional reaction to his disregard of your sister’s demise.” Epimenides let the sword fade with an annoyed sigh. “A remarkably volatile reaction for a sage, though I cannot say it is uncharacteristic for those of your position. Fire best lends itself to passion in the old schools of thought…Regardless, your murder of your fellow sage was foolhardy and detrimental to the cause of our people.”

 

“Perhaps. I am endeavoring to make up for that unfortunate loss,” she stated, before regarding the great sage with some curiosity, “So what is this, exactly? I can hear from the timbre of your voice that you are not ‘Shez’. The girl’s personality appears to be distinct from your own as well, so you are not simply wearing her flesh.”

 

“Shez is my vessel,” Epimenides answered, gazing down at her as he stood, “That I exist within her is a strange yet fortunate circumstance, particularly with the coincidence that is her relationship to the Fell Star.”

 

“...Ah. Her ‘sister’ then.” The idea explained things. Not how the Fell Star could have returned, but it did explain the professor’s stranger qualities.

 

Epimenides sneered, disgust visible on the face he wore. “Correct. I will not fault my vessel for her ignorance, though it will need to be corrected. A…fraction of myself had been attempting to encourage her down the proper path prior to my awakening, yet she is a willful girl prone to stubbornness. Regardless, the time is not right. The Fell Star has gifted its vessel with powers that would make a direct attack unfeasible in most circumstances. Which means I must either finish her off in one blow, or, should that fail, use the Spell of Zahras." 

 

At his words, Bias stiffened and shuffled back. 

 

"Ah, so you do know about it." 

 

"...Solon has mentioned it, but as far as I'm aware he was the only remaining Agarthan who knew the spell." 

 

"What a foolish man he was then, to keep such secrets. A truly unfortunate tendency among those who hold such knowledge," Epimenides remarked almost wistfully, "Even if the spell is forbidden, keeping the knowledge to oneself means it is gone once you perish." 

 

"...Th-There is another you can-" 

 

"You still have your uses, I won't use you for the spell. As for that other one…what is her name?"

 

"Kronya. She was Thales’s lapdog, and from the newest generation of Agarthans, of the caste Bellatores," Bias explained, not wanting to anger the great sage. 

 

"Hm…and who remains from my time?" 

 

She shrugged. “I don’t know. Do the names Cleobulus and Myson mean anything to you?" 

 

"I see…the Agarthan people truly have fallen since I've been gone," Epimenides noted as he sighed.

 

Bias felt a prickle of offense, but buried it down. "What is your plan, great sage?" 

 

"Hm… for now, we must bide our time, so that we may strike when the time is right. Until then, I'll be the one contacting you if need be," he said, before looking at Bias. "And I suppose you want the full truth of what occurred." 

 

"...Who was it?"

 

"Who else but the Fell Star." 

 

Snarling, Bias felt flames burst from her hands, before Epimenides placed his blade against her throat again. 

 

"Do not attack her. The powers she has are too grand to underestimate. We will have our revenge, but until then, you must wait." Feeling her hands tighten up into fists, Bias made the flames dissipate. "Good. Now, are you in contact with Cleobulus or Myson?" 

 

"I can contact Myson,” she responded, fighting down the rage that came with realizing that bitch of a princess had lied to her. Did she know all along? She had to, that’s why she lied. Everyone’s a fucking liar. “Cleobulus, on the other hand, hasn't attempted to contact us back. It is my belief she has gone rogue." 

 

“Much like you have?” At her flinch, he sighed. “Do not fear so readily, I shall not harm one of my people without due cause.”

 

“...You have due cause,” she noted, prompting a slight smile from the great sage.

 

“I do, yet I am a forgiving man. For now, I have need of your aid. Prove yourself and there shall be no need for punishment," Epimenides said as he began to walk away, though he paused after a moment. "Ah, but one last thing." 

 

"Yes, great sage?" Bias asked, only to stiffen as he turned his gaze towards her, glaring intently. 

 

"Never harm my vessel again." Leaving without waiting for a response, Epimenides made his way back to his vessel's bedroom. In the silence of the night, he couldn't help but chuckle at the situation. 

 

To think, the vessels of the great sage and of the fell star would end up being raised together as siblings. The cycle of this world was truly a cruel one. 

 

And behind him, watching with eyes filled with a growing hate, remained the sage of flames, who felt an increasing urge to burn it all down.

Chapter End Notes

Red: Happy Valentine's day everybody! Here, have a short little chapter about the dangers of drinking too much and the importance of understanding relationships.

Indi: It's very important to know, and to properly talk things out.

Red: Yup yup. You've gotta be open and honest in communication. Otherwise there can be misunderstandings and feelings can be hurt.

Indi: or the potential lost of dark magics. Good thing Epimenides is here to make sure those spells don't get forgotten.

Red: Good ol' Epimenides! Such a helpful fellow. Also props to anybody who guessed he'd already woken up.

Indi: Yup yup, anyways hope y'all enjoy this chapter, and if not, well who knows maybe something else will happen this valentines day!

Speaking of Romance

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

"Now then, I suppose we should actually fill you in on the details for the Battle of Eagle and Lion," Manuela said as the three professors sat together for a meal, "Though I suppose if I don't, that'll just give my class another edge." 

 

“Manuela! Don’t try to sabotage our fellow professor!” Hanneman reprimanded, frowning towards his colleague…before an amused smile crossed his face, “The smarter move is to be open and honest and make sure our newest colleague feels indebted to her wise senior who so generously explained everything. So, on that topic–”

 

“Oh so sabotage is too much, but bribery is just fine?”

 

“It is not bribery, I am simply doing a favor to my colleague. And if she wants to return that favor–”

 

"Now it just sounds like you're splitting hairs." 

 

"I'm doing no such thing, now stop interrupting me." 

 

"I'm just pointing out the hypocrisy in your-" 

 

"So what was that about the Battle?" Byleth interrupted, not wanting the two to start arguing again. 

 

"Oh, right, well for comparison, the Battle will be a mock battle like the one we had at the start of the year. Of course it'll be far above that one in scale and grandeur," Manuela explained. 

 

"For starters, all the students will be competing, and while us professors will be participating, it is the house leaders who will be taking the role of field commanders," Hanneman elaborated, "To show how far they have come from the start of the year." 

 

"Though it should be noted that you can't just focus on protecting the commander. Unlike the mock battle, this one will be using a point system. Every opponent one of your students defeats will be a point, while professors count as five points." 

 

"And the house leaders?" Byleth asked.

 

"Five as well, but should the house leader fall, that house will immediately have to withdraw." 

 

"So you can't just play it safe and wait for the other two houses to take each other out. It's not fun that way, after all," Manuela added, prompting an eye roll from Hanneman, though he thankfully didn’t decide to argue with her. 

 

"Another thing to keep in mind is that each house will be given an additional squad of soldiers, to better help simulate war while making it so it's not just the students. Though of course, everyone will have blunted weaponry." 

 

"Hm…” Byleth rubbed her chin, thinking. “And what about positioning?" 

 

"That was actually determined by random chance," Manuela chimed in. "A map should be delivered to you later showing the field so as to better prepare for the battle, as well as the starting position of all of our classes." 

 

"There will also be a prize for the class that performs the best,” Hanneman added, “Though I would like to note that the prize should not be the main goal." 

 

"Is that why your class hasn't been able to win for the past two years?" 

 

"Just to be clear, there's not going to be any mission this month, right?" Byleth cut in before they could start arguing.

 

"Oh, no. Aside from your usual lessons, you're free to do as you wish to prepare for the battle with no worry about a mission this month." 

 

"Hm, good to know." 

 

"Now then, do you have any questions?" 

 

"Not really. Ah, though I was hoping to talk to you in private later Manuela," Byleth added, hoping she wouldn't be busy. 

 

"Of course, I'd be glad to." 

 

"Please take care not to fall for any scheming Manuela might plan," Hanneman requested, getting her to gasp. 

 

"I would never dream of scheming up something when my colleague comes looking to me for advice!" Manuela scolded him as Byleth began to tune out the conversation. She did like her colleagues, but at the same time listening to them argue could get a bit annoying. 

 

Thankfully the argument didn't go on for too long, and Byleth found herself in Manuela’s office. 

 

"So, what exactly did you need?" 

 

"How do I know what romantic attraction is like?" 

 

"...well that's certainly a question to ask. Are you interested in someone?" 

 

"I don't think so. I just… someone asked me if I was interested in someone in particular, and I felt… odd not knowing if I was or not. I know I can find someone attractive but… I've never actually felt interested in someone." 

 

"..." Letting out a sigh, Manuela leaned back in her chair. "Well this is certainly heavier than I thought it'd be." 

 

"Sorry." 

 

"No need to apologize, we all have our own troubles in our own way. Honestly I'm surprised you came to me to ask this question, given my own track record." 

 

"It felt… weird wanting to talk about this with Jeralt or any of the mercenaries." 

 

"I get that…just to make sure, you were taught about the Pegasus and the Wyverns, correct?" 

 

"I was. Gertrude made sure to teach us." 

 

"Oh that's great, I definitely didn't want to have that conversation," Manuela said, letting out a laugh. "So, I'm assuming you've never dated anyone?" 

 

"Never stuck around in one place long enough to do so." 

 

"I suppose that's the trouble with being a wandering mercenary." Manuela hummed. "Well, for starters, there's nothing wrong about not knowing what you like. Plenty of people spend their whole lives thinking one thing only to realize what they actually like when they're older. Hell, I've met people who are perfectly fine without romance or the like." 

 

"It would be easier if I at least knew if I liked something or not…" 

 

"Well take this advice with a grain of salt from someone who’s met plenty of people who don't like her, if you want to know if you like something, you should try to experience it first." 

 

"....So, I should try dating someone?" 

 

"Not right away, but it would help you realize something about yourself. There's only so much one can learn from observing." 

 

“Hm…okay.” Byleth nodded. “Thank you for the advice, Manuela.”

 

“Anytime, my fellow professor~! I may not be all that lucky in love myself, but my door’s always open if you want to chit chat about matters of the heart~.”

 

Byleth nodded and thanked her fellow professor for her time again before she headed out, still thinking to herself about the strange reality of romantic attraction she was now aware of. Sure, she was used to her sister trying to get involved in her love life before, but it was always something that seemed… distant, and unimportant. Maybe she should take Manuela’s advice… 

 

"Please don't tell me you're going to just ask the first person you see on a date," Sothis said, her tone already full of exasperation. 

 

"I wasn't going to do that." At least now she wasn't. "At the very least… I should probably ask someone I know, right?" 

 

"Don't ask me that," Sothis complained, before their conversation was interrupted. 

 

"Professor, there you are!" Glancing over, Byleth could see Dorothea approaching while an exasperated looking Ingrid followed her. "We need your help!" 

 

"What's wrong?" 

 

"It's nothing, professor," Ingrid got out before Dorothea spoke up again. 

 

"It's not nothing! Some jerk is trying to marry Ingrid! You have to help us, that man's entire fortune is soaked in blood!" 

 

"It is?" 

 

"Only according to rumors. Rumors which I might add only Dorothea has brought up." 

 

"Hm, well, we should check out, just to make sure, right?" Byleth asked. "Better safe than sorry." 

 

"Exactly! Thank you professor! You two wait here, I'll go see if I can find anyone else to help us!" With that, Dorothea sped off, leaving the two behind.

 

"Honestly, what is with that girl? We've hardly even talked and she seems so invested already…" 

 

"Dorothea is like that," Byleth noted as they waited. "She cares easily and… I think marriage is important to her. So I think she wants to be able to help make sure your marriage is good." 

 

"I suppose so. Still, I apologize for bothering you professor. You saved me once, and I might end up owing you another depending on how things go." 

 

"It's no bother. You might not be one of my students, but you're still a student nonetheless. Though if you do want to make it up to me, you can always transfer over so the Blue Lions aren't as strong for the battle." 

 

"Ha, while I will admit it would be interesting to learn from you, I'd rather not leave my classmates floundering," Ingrid joked back as they waited for Dorothea to return. Though Byleth couldn't help but wonder just how difficult it would be to find out stuff about this would-be suitor.

So it was laughably easy to find out stuff about this guy. It was as if he didn’t even try hiding his illegal activities. Everything from bribery, to threats, to even hiring assassins to deal with rivals. He was almost laughably evil. 

 

"So, I know I'm the last person you probably want to hear this from, but I think your dad really needs to be more thorough with background checks," Sylvain said as he rode by Ingrid. 

 

Ingrid sighed, looking frustrated. “I realize. What gets me though is that it was just so obvious! How can there be a noble this corrupt and still in power!?”

 

Dorothea tried not to snort. It would go against her image. “I’m sorry to ruin your image of the world, Ingrid, but Adrestian nobles in general do tend to be this bad.”

 

“And here I was, trying to look past my prejudices…” She sighed again, before tugging slightly at her shirt with an uncomfortable look. “That aside, we probably should have picked a different route to take back to the monastery.”

 

“What, can’t stand the heat?” Shez teased from her own steed, looking amused by the discomfort the Faerghan members of their little group were displaying as they passed through the Valley of Torment, paradoxically one of the most treacherous yet also safest routes to take up to the monastery, in large part because no bandit group wanted to hang around the volcanic landscape.

 

"Just think of this like training! If you can get used to something like this, then wearing armor in hot weather won't be a problem!" Caspar shouted, wiping away his own sweat. 

 

"I have a feeling you two are taking this as revenge for when you had to go up to the kingdom…" Annette muttered, not fairing the best while Mercedes seemed to be doing a bit better after she removed her shawl. 

 

"I have to admit, it is a bit much." 

 

"I have to say, I always imagined the name ‘Valley of Torment’ was exaggerated. I guess it really isn't," Ashe muttered, as he looked around the volcanic area. 

 

"Hm, so what do you want us to do when we get back Ingrid?" Byleth asked, glancing at the blonde student. 

 

"Isn't it obvious? We're gonna go kick his ass!" Shez shouted, before Ingrid shook her head. 

 

"For now, I think it would be best to send this information to my father. If we were to attack my ‘suitor’ right away, then it'll only end up putting pressure on my father." 

 

"But we can probably attack him afterwards," Sylvain said with a wink. 

 

"For once I find myself in agreement with you," Dorothea teased.

 

"Hey, I'll take what I can get." 

 

Ingrid rolled her eyes. "Ugh, let's just get back to the monastery already." 

 

"Not so fast, you brats!" shouted a rough voice, catching their attention as they saw a group of bandits in their path. "Hand over the girl!" 

 

"Does he mean me?" Ingrid asked, already gripping her spear as her pegasus began to flap its wings. 

 

"Ah, I bet that noble hired them!" Annette shouted. 

 

"Here to take Ingrid and make sure we can't talk," Dorothea muttered, a sigil already forming as she got ready to cast a spell. Though, before anyone could make a move, Byleth frowned as she stared off into the distance.

 

"Ingrid, can your steed handle two?" Byleth asked, already getting off her own horse. At her nod, Byleth continued. "Dorothea, get on with her. Their main target will be Ingrid, so we have to make sure she's covered." 

 

“Oh, of course!” Dorothea immediately moved to get on the same pegasus as Ingrid, pressing up against the blonde’s back as she settled in. “I hope you don’t mind me being so close~”

 

“I’m fine with it, just try to keep your focus,” Ingrid replied, before glancing back at Byleth, “Are we just trying to escape them, professor?”
