“You are. You’re their priority, so we need to get you to a safe distance. Sylvain, Annette, Mercedes, and Ashe, all of you stay with Ingrid and eliminate any threats that get close. Shez and Caspar, you’re with me.”

 

“What are you going to be doing, professor?” Ashe asked, readying his bow as he moved up towards the front of their formation with Sylvain.

 

“Killing every other bandit before they can get to you.”

 

“ALRIGHT! Now that’s a plan I can get behind!” Caspar exclaimed, ready and eager.

 

“Sounds good to me!” Shez agreed, hopping off her own horse and drawing her swords, which did get Byleth to pause in thought for a moment. 

 

“Hm. We should do some mounted combat training after this. At the very least, everyone should be able to fight while riding if necessary.”

 

“Yeah yeah yeah, teaching plans later, for now, I’m gonna kill more guys than you,” Shez insisted before hurrying off, shifting into a violet light that moved easily across the lava and reforming in a dropkick to one bandit’s face.

 

“Ah hey, no fair! That magic stuff is cheating!” Caspar called out as he hurried after her.

 

“...Are those two really going to be alright?” Mercedes asked, a little worried.

 

“It’s fine, I’ll keep them safe,” Byleth answered, “Now you five make sure to keep Ingrid safe. Then we can go find and kill the noble that organized this.”

 

“Ah, professor–No, never mind, we can talk about that later,” Ingrid decided, “Come on everyone! Let’s get back to the monastery!”

“Oh, I hope Professor Byleth is okay,” Mercedes said in a worried tone, looking back down the path they’d taken to the monastery. Their group hadn’t had too much trouble getting away from the bandits; Sylvain and Ashe had led things for the most part, with the redhead easily breaking through the clustered bandits while the gray-haired boy shot down those that scattered. 

 

Annette and Dorothea had further helped by raining thunder and wind down on anyone coming after Ingrid, while Mercedes herself had made sure to heal any injuries that her classmates may have suffered. Their quick escape did, however, mean they had gotten away far faster than expected and the professor’s team wound up being left behind. Which, yes, was the intention, but it was still concerning, which was why Mercedes had come back to watch the path while Ingrid and the others went ahead to report what happened. Well, most of the others.

 

“I wouldn’t worry too much about the professor,” Dorothea reassured with a smile, patting the blonde on her shoulder, “She has a knack for getting out of tricky situations.”

 

“I suppose–Oh, Dorothea, your hat.”

 

“Hm? Oh, yeah.” The songstress chuckled wryly as she patted her bare hair. “It looks like I lost it in all the commotion. It’s a shame, but as cute as it is, it’s just a hat. Besides, I notice someone doesn’t have her usual shawl either.”

 

“Oh, yes, I did leave that with my horse…well, I can retrieve it later, I am sure.” She smiled at Dorothea. “Hopefully before Sylvain notices and decides to make any comments.”

 

Dorothea blinked, not really expecting a remark like that from the lovely blonde, and then had a brief moment where she tried not to glance at Mercedes’s chest. Judging by the slight, amused smile Mercedes had though, she noticed anyway. “R-Right, well, the professor has Caspie and Shezzie with her anyway, so I’m sure things will be fine.”

 

"You really trust Professor Byleth, huh?" 

 

"Well why wouldn't I? Things might have been a bit shaky near the start of the year, but she's proven to be quite the reliable professor~ I mean, I asked her to help out and she agreed with no hesitation. She might be a bit teasing at times, but I definitely can't imagine having another professor." 

 

"Sounds quite fun indeed. It makes me wonder how things would be if she was in charge of the Blue Lions," Mercedes mused, "Though I suppose if she was, we'd likely have been the ones going up against the Death Knight." 

 

"Ah yeah, that jerk still has to pay for what he did," Dorothea said with a frown, before noticing Mercedes looking sad. "Uh, everything okay?" 

 

"Oh, sorry, I was just getting a bit lost in thought…is the Death Knight really Jeritza?" 

 

"Yeah? I don't know who else it could have been with how scary that guy can be, not to mention how he disappeared after the Death Knight left as well." 

 

"....I see," Mercedes muttered as she frowned. 

 

"...Something you feel like sharing?" 

 

"Just something I can't shake from my head, I think I might know who Jeritza is," Mercedes said, a wistful look on her face. "I think he might be my little brother, Emile." 

 

Of all things Mercedes could’ve said, Dorothea wasn’t expecting that. "H-Huh? You're related to him?" 

 

"I'm not certain, but the more I think about it, the more likely it seems," she explained, "I can't help but wonder how he ended up like this. He used to be so kind and gentle…" 

 

"Ah… sorry about what I said." 

 

"No need to apologize. I can understand why you feel that way," Mercedes replied, a gentle smile on her face. "I just hope I get the chance to meet him again." 

 

"Well, I guess we'll need to find out more about those people who kidnapped Flayn and Shezzie." 

 

"It would be a start," Mercedes noted, before she noticed something. "Ah, there they are." 

 

Turning her head, Dorothea could see the trio returning, Byleth at the front while Shez and Caspar followed behind, the two in quite the animated conversation, likely about the battle they had. Behind them a trail of horses followed, one of them having Mercedes' shawl fluttering in the breeze. 

 

"Hey there professor!" Dorothea said, grinning as she waved at them. 

 

"Sorry if we're late, they had a surprising amount of reinforcements," Byleth explained as she dismounted the horse. 

 

"Yeah, it was wild! But we managed to beat up all the bad guys!" Caspar said, giving the two a thumbs up. "I'm still fired up for some more!"

 

"No more fighting for today, make sure to get some rest." 

 

"Aw, come on professor, you can't tell me you're not still raring to go!" 

 

"Pft, if it's that big of a deal, I'm up to spar with you Caspar," Shez offered. 

 

"Nice! Looking forward to it!" Grinning, the two made their way into the monastery as Mercedes grabbed her shawl. 

 

"Thank you professor." 

 

"No need for thanks," Byleth replied as she began to lead the horses back to the stables. With nothing better to do, Dorothea followed behind her. 

 

"Heh, seems we managed to save the day, huh professor?" 

 

"I'm glad we could help Ingrid," Byleth said, before pausing, "Ah, I wanted to apologize." 

 

"Hm? About what?" 

 

"The offer I made. I've been thinking about it, and I can understand why it would come off as insincere," Byleth said, before bowing to Dorothea, "Sorry." 

 

"...Huh? Ah…do you mean the one about taking care of me?" 

 

"Yeah. I meant it, but I can see why it wasn't a good thing to do," she continued, frowning a bit. "You deserve to be with someone who loves you, and I don't even know if I can love like that." 

 

"..." 

 

"Thank you for helping me realize that Dorothea," Byleth said, looking like she would step away before she remembered something. "Ah." 

 

Rummaging around in her coat, Byleth pulled out a hat, before placing it on Dorothea’s head. 

 

"There you go. I’m glad I could bring this back," she said, a small smile on her face before she walked away. 

 

"..." Dorothea stared at her professor as she left, before she reached up and covered her crimson face with her hat. She took a moment to think of the fact that Byleth had been sincere in all those moments with her. She was used to empty words from those who wanted her attention, nobles who wanted her for a short time, to use for fun or even prestige before leaving her alone again. So to know Byleth wasn't teasing….

 

She tried to ignore her beating heart and flushed face as she watched her professor walk away. "...H-Hm." 

 

Dorothea couldn't help but think of how lucky Edie was that she was a good friend. Otherwise…well, she shouldn’t think about it. It wouldn’t do to tempt herself into stealing her friend’s crush.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Fellas you ever write a love triangle in in which two of the people are actively stepping back for the sake of the other two?

Red: We haven't even gotten to the part where they try to set up one love interest with the other love interest yet. This is going to be nonsense.

Indi: Yuuup. But hey were are officially in battle of Eagle and Lion month! Which also means, at least some, paralogues.

Red: Yup! We figured it'd be fun to include a few, in part because Shez in the mix can change things up.

Indi: This one doesn't get that much change up, but it does get a good jumping off point for Byleth to develop an interest in romance, while also getting Dorothea to admit she is interested in Byleth.

Red: Yeah, ramifications for later. But for now, thanks for reading!

The Garreg Mach Fishing Tournament

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

"A fishing tournament?" Byleth immediately found herself interested as she looked at Seteth. 

 

"Well, calling it a tournament is perhaps a bit much,” the chamberlain corrected, “After what happened last month, I wanted to do something for Flayn, and she requested a feast full of fish. Once I mentioned this to Rhea, she suggested making it an inter-house competition to help bolster camaraderie and to make it easier on me so I do not have to fish on my own." 

 

"I see. Is it just for the students?" 

 

"In terms of the prize, yes. Though you are free to join if you wish." 

 

"It sounds like fun," Byleth agreed, a faint smile coming to her face. "I'll make sure to participate." 

 

"Thank you." With his part said, he glanced down at Byleth, noting that she seemed to be wearing a rather modest sundress at the moment. "I must say, your new sense of fashion has been a welcome change." 

 

"Oh, thank you. Dorothea helped me pick it out." 

 

"...She did? I admit, that is a bit of a surprise." 

 

"She's good with fashion," Byleth said with a shrug, "Either way, it feels nice wearing pretty clothes." 

 

"Is that so?" Seteth asked, receiving a nod in return. 

 

"I never really thought of myself as pretty, so I never considered wearing stuff like this. Though as Dorothea said I don't need to care about what others think and should wear what I want." 

 

“I see. Well, I won’t complain about your reasons for wearing such attire. I hope to see you at the fishing tourney. I'll make sure to stop by later, but I need to get some supplies from the marketplace first.” With his piece said, Seteth nodded before turning around and walking away. 

 

As he did, Byleth made her way to the pond, ready and eager to have fun!

 

“I must say, I never expected a fishing competition to be an event at the Academy,” Lorenz murmured as Byleth passed by, frowning at the fishing line he had, “I can’t say I have much experience with the activity, though my father has expressed some fondness for it.”

 

“Really? Huh, wouldn’t expect a big time noble like him to be into something so ‘common’,” Leonie replied, her own pole already ready to go, “Hey, lemme help you with that.”

 

“Hm? No, I’m sure I can–Leonie, you don’t need to aid me with this.”

 

“Hey, you helped me out with that heavy lifting, so now I’m paying you back. Besides, the captain showed me how to tie a line to a hook plenty of times, so I know what I’m doing.”

 

Byleth smiled faintly as Lorenz sighed in exasperation before she moved along, idly taking in the sight of so many people gathered at the fishing pond. It seemed like almost every student was there already, along with plenty of the monastery staff and clergy.

 

"Ah, professor, there you are!" Ferdinand greeted her, fishing rod in hand as he stood next to Flayn. 

 

"Oh, hi Ferdinand, I didn't know you liked fishing." 

 

"Well, I would not say it's part of my repertoire of skills, however I felt it only appropriate to join in to better welcome our new classmate," Ferdinand said with a grin, "I also felt like this would help make up for my blunder with that gauntlet."

 

"Th-There is no need to do that, Ferdinand," Flayn responded, a bit embarrassed, "I already said it was my fault for messing with that weapon." 

 

"Even so, it's only right as a noble that I make it up to you!" 

 

"Hm. Try not to scare away the fish by being too loud, Ferdinand," Byleth warned, a bit amused as his confidence faltered for a moment. 

 

"I see…Well, I suppose I shall have to show the dignity of a noble and remain as quiet as I can during this tournament," Ferdinand decided with a nod before heading over to cast his line. 

 

"Honestly this is starting to feel bigger than it should be…" Flayn muttered as she followed behind him. 

 

Feeling a smile on her face, Byleth glanced around, seeing how everyone else was doing, glad that the students seemed to be having fun, and were even competing amongst themselves, such as Caspar and Ashe trying their best to catch the biggest fish. Other students, meanwhile, seemed more focused on their excitement for the food to come, like Ingrid and Raphael. 

 

Though she also couldn't help but notice the few students that weren't there. 

 

"Ah, professor, can you be helping me?" Petra asked, breaking her out of her thoughts. Glancing over, she saw the young Brigid girl holding the hook for her fishing rod. "I am not used to fishing in such a manner." 

 

"Oh, okay, how do you normally fish?" Byleth asked, as she took the rod and hook to tie it for her. 

 

"In Brigid, fishing by spear or net is more common. There are also those with skill that fish with only their hands," Petra explained, "I was attempting to do so, but the fishman said that was not allowed." 

 

"...huh. Now I kind of want to try fishing like that…" Byleth muttered as she finished tying the hook. With a quick glance, she noted how Edelgard and Hubert weren't there, though the two had been busy after class lately so that wasn't a surprise… "Do you know where Dorothea is?" 

 

"Ah, she said she is not a fan of the smell fish are having." 

 

"Oh, really?" Byleth frowned at that. They were going to have tea later so that wasn't good…she’d just have to try to clean up before then. "Thank you for telling me. Did you want some more help fishing?" 

 

"I believe I am good, thank you," Petra said, nodding to her before she walked over to the pond, which got Byleth to notice a different group. 

 

"This is stupid," Emily grumbled as she glared at her fishing lure. 

 

"On that, we are in agreement," Lysithea muttered in response. 

 

"Look, I get it, it's not the funnest thing to do, but come on, it's a competition and I don't want to lose!" Shez shouted, which definitely didn't help their chances since she was just scaring the fish away. A quick glance around showed that Hilda and Claude seemed to be the only Golden Deer not at the pond, which, hm…there could be a few reasons for that, but for now, Byleth had a sister to check in with.

 

"Hey there you three. Having fun?" 

 

"No," Emily and Lysithea immediately responded, getting Shez to laugh. 

 

"About as much as I can anyways," Shez said with a grin. 

 

"That's good. Are Claude and Hilda not joining?" 

 

"Pinky isn’t a fan of fishing," Emily replied. 

 

"And apparently Claude doesn't see the point in joining the tournament since he can just 'reap the rewards' later," Lysithea added with audible annoyance.

 

“...Is Claude planning to steal the grand prize?” Byleth asked, concerned, which earned a snort from Shez.

 

“Nah, he just means he’s going to enjoy the feast once everybody else does the work. Heh, it’s times like this that I remember he’s a noble.” She paused, before glancing at her friends. “Ah, no offense.”

 

“Why would I be offended?” Emily asked, which seemed to take the wind out of Lysithea’s sails as she went from puffing up in indignation to deflating with a faint frown.

 

“Yes, well…indeed, it would be childish to take offense from a simple comment like that.”

 

"Aren't you a kid?" And she immediately puffed up again at Emily’s comment. 

 

"Come on Em, you know she doesn't like that!" Shez said, speaking up before Lysithea could as she mussed up Emily’s hair. 

 

"Regardless of whether I like or dislike it, it's a simple fact that I am not a child!" Lysithea still complained.

 

"Alright, fine, just let go of me!" Emily shouted back, trying to push Shez away while the latter had a big grin on her face the entire time. For a brief moment, Byleth wondered if she should stop the pair as they continued roughhousing. That ended as the two went tumbling into the pond, splashing Lysithea with water as they did. 

 

“Hm.” Maybe she should–

 

“Do not use the divine pulse for a situation like this,” Sothis chided in the back of her mind, “Let the idiots reap what they have sown.”

 

Byleth wouldn’t put it quite like that, but she did feel a little amused at seeing her sister push herself back up while spitting out a fish that had gotten into her mouth. “Blegh! Ugh…huh, does this count as catching one?”

 

“G-Ghh…Shez, you idiot!” Lysithea snapped, glaring at her ‘apprentice’ while Emily came up a moment later, also with a fish in her mouth, though she seemed to be deliberately holding it there, considering she also had two more fish in her hands. 

 

“Hh! T’ld y’!” she said through the fish in her mouth, before letting the bloodied pike drop onto the shore, “See! Diving in and grabbing the fish works way better!”

 

“Huh. You’d probably be very popular in Brigid,” Byleth noted, which earned a confused blink from Emily.

 

“I would?" 

 

“Well she’s not with me!” Lysithea snapped, glaring at the brunette, “Do you idiots really have to roughhouse all the time!?”

 

“Well we don’t have to–” Shez began, before pausing when she noticed a very annoyed fishkeeper standing beside her sister, “Ah…hey, uh, so! Me and Emily caught–”

 

“Get outta the pond.”

 

“Yessir.”

 

And thus, Shez and Emily were banned from the fishing tournament.

 

“Ah well, guess it wasn’t meant to be,” Shez said, shrugging, before glancing at her still dripping friends. Lysithea was still actively glaring at Emily, who smirked back at her before deliberately shaking her hair out to splash the shorter girl with more water. Which prompted Lysithea to start gathering darkness in her hand and Shez immediately stepped between them at that point. “Ah, hey! No more fighting! C’mon, how about we try out the sauna instead of hanging out here? That’d probably help dry us off at least, it’s hot in there, right?”

 

“That is not how…ugh, fine, whatever. You still owe me for splashing me!" Lysithea shouted as Shez began to lead the duo away. 

 

Off to the side, Byleth was apologizing to the fishkeeper, who had turned his annoyance towards her. 

 

"As a professor, you really should keep a better eye on the students, especially your sister." 

 

"I know, I'll make sure that she doesn't do that again. Is there any way I can make up for it?" 

 

"Just make sure no one else goes diving in the pond," he grumbled as he walked away. 

 

Silently, Byleth found herself thankful that she wasn't banned from the pond as well. 

 

“Would you have used the divine pulse if you were?” Sothis needled, prompting an immediate nod from Byleth, “...You really are ridiculous sometimes, you know that?”

 

Byleth let out a small huff at that, before moving over to a quiet pair of students where she could fish in peace. Though it was a bit of a surprise to see Ignatz sitting next to Lindhart. 

 

"Oh, hello there professor." 

 

"Hello Ignatz, are you having fun?" 

 

"Well, I wouldn't say that," Ignatz admitted as Byleth sat down next to him. "Though it is very relaxing to be able to space out and appreciate the scenery. I guess that's something Linhardt and I agree on, haha." 

 

"..." Byleth glanced over at Linhardt. "He's asleep." 

 

"Oh…" Ignatz blushed at that. "I guess that's egg on my face." 

 

"Well, at least Linhardt doesn't seemed bothered by you," Byleth said, attempting to console him as she tossed her line. 

 

"Well, I suppose that's good," Ignatz replied, still visibly embarrassed as he stared back out at the water. "Though I have to say, it's nice that the monastery seems more peaceful. Well, ignoring what happened with Shez and Flayn I mean." 

 

"Hm?" 

 

"Oh you know, things don't seem as tense anymore. I might not know everything that happened between the Empire and the Kingdom, but things were certainly tense at the start of the year. And I guess…everyone being able to work together to save Flayn and Shez helped fix that, at least partially anyways." 

 

"Hm…yeah, I can see that," Byleth agreed, glancing over to where Shez had walked off. For a brief moment, she thought that maybe joining the academy hadn't been a bad idea. "...So hey, what exactly is the grand prize for this tourney?" 

 

"Ah… you know, I never asked," Ignatz admitted with a sheepish grin. 

 

"Oh…Well, I guess it doesn't matter," Byleth said, as she felt her lure get pulled, instantly reeling it in and catching the struggling fish. With a small smile, she nodded to herself. Off to a great start already. 

Sighing to herself, Edelgard looked out over the tourney that seemed to be in full swing with the students enjoying themselves. A part of her was considering joining in, until her gaze landed on Byleth, fishing on the dock. It was certainly…difficult, knowing that the person she held affection for and one of her closest friends were seemingly pursuing one another, yet it was something she had to accept.

 

If anything, this situation made things easier for her since she could now focus on her own goals. Taking in a deep breath, she turned around, ready to leave. 

 

"Lady Edelgard!" 

 

Or she was, until she heard a familiar voice. Glancing over, she found a certain redhead that she definitely didn’t expect to see approaching her. 

 

"Monica? What are you doing here?" 

 

"Why, to see you of course! My father asked me to deliver a report to you, and I felt it only appropriate to do it in person." Edelgard paused as she realized Monica was speaking in code. 

 

"I see. Well, best to discuss that right away."  She gave her vassal a polite smile. “It will be good for the two of us to catch up as well. You must be busy lately if you’re handling business for your father.”

 

“I certainly am, but it’s work that I enjoy!” Monica replied with a bright smile, before pouting, “Though it is a shame I couldn’t join you in attending the Academy this year. At least I get to see how lovely you look in the uniform though!”

 

…Right, that part probably wasn’t code. Unless it was. Hm.

 

Either way, talking in the middle of the fishing tournament was a poor way to be discreet, so the two moved over to the currently unoccupied tea gardens. Along the way, Edelgard noted Hubert was following, as usual, and had a visible frown on his face once he noticed Monica.

 

“Ah, the tea garden. You know, I only sat out here about twenty-three times when I was attending,” Monica noted with a faint smile upon taking a seat, pulling out a portable tea set to serve tea. “Twenty-one of which were meetings with the Imperial nobles of interest attending at that time who seemed like they could be useful connections, while the remaining two were with Alliance nobles. Aloysius Albany and Siegward Siward, to be exact–”

 

“Monica, are either of those two relevant to our current discussion?”

 

“Oh? Oh, no, I don’t think they are. Ah, do you think they might be, Lady Edelgard?”

 

“No.” Edelgard refrained from sighing. “Would you care to make your report now, Monica?”

 

"Of course!" Grinning, Monica reached into her satchel and brought out a stack of papers which she handed Edelgard. "To begin, my father wanted me to discuss some recent findings in our land which he would graciously like to give to the Imperial House." 

 

Opening the report, Edelgard found the image of an axe greeting her. Not a relic weapon, but a sacred weapon. One bearing the Crest of Seiros based on the image in the corner of the page. 

 

As Monica began to talk about one thing or another to make this seem like official business, Edelgard continued to read the report on what she had found. 

 

While sacred weapons were generally not as powerful, they were no less useful than hero relics. The fact that anyone could use them without health concerns made them highly sought after, especially since if one did have the correct crest, the weapon would resonate with it and heal the wielder. The fact that this was both an axe and a weapon that resonated with the Crest of Seiros was quite the added benefit. 

 

"Good work, Monica," Edelgard idly said, almost missing the pleased noise Monica made at her praise. Focusing on the report, Edelgard flipped to the next page and found a sketch of Lake Teutates. She briefly paused as she noticed the words 'phantom warriors(?)' next to it. Apparently, there was a story in the area that involved some type of test to prove your worth, but since Monica had been alone, she chose to retreat rather than risk herself, per Edelgard’s instructions. 

 

Hm. It definitely seemed worth returning to in the future. The last time Edelgard had heard of “phantom warriors” being involved in something church-related was during the Chalice of Beginnings incident. At that thought, her mind drifted back to that event, and how evident it was that corruption ran rampant in the church. How else could they explain how Aelfric was able to do all he did without notice? 

 

If Rhea had been a better leader, such events would not have happened. Lady Eisner's body would have been buried, thus ensuring her professor never had to deal with the trauma of finding her mother's corpse down there. She also wouldn't have been kidnapped as a result and had to deal with whatever insane ramblings Aelfric had–

 

"Your highness?" Monica spoke up, breaking her out of her thoughts. 

 

"Oh, sorry Monica. Did you say something?" 

 

"I wanted to ask if everything was okay. You haven't had any tea and you're gripping the report rather tightly. You only do such a thing when you have something heavy weighing down on your mind." 

 

"Ah, my apologies. Much has happened during my time at the academy," Edelgard responded, grabbing her cup of tea to drink. The bergamot flavor did help calm her down slightly as she tried to push past her thoughts. 

 

"Oh, would you care to talk about them? I'm always glad to assist in any way I can, Lady Edelgard!" 

 

"It's nothing Monica. Why don't we just focus on your report? You did come all the way out to the monastery so I would hate to ignore why you came here." 

 

“Oh certainly! Do you have anything specific you would like to ask about?” Monica asked while scooting her chair closer so she could flip the page for Edelgard, “I actually found this page pretty interesting. Sure, it’s just some details on market trends, but you never know what you can find on sale!”

 

Such as a relic, apparently. Curiously, it was one that wasn’t listed in any official records, according to Monica’s gathered notes, which also included the detail that her father, Baron Ochs, had managed to find the strange pair of gauntlets through an underground market.

 

Edelgard made a mental note to utilize Baron Ochs's black market connections more often, if it could get access to items like this. “Hm. This is a curious marking.”

 

“Isn’t it though? I don’t recognize it, which makes it absolutely fascinating!” Monica said with a bright smile. Understandable, given Edelgard had tasked Monica with investigating crest related matters and the redhead had taken that as a reason to memorize every single crest on record. 

 

“Hm. I do. This is a crest of the apostles,” Edelgard noted, “Chevalier, specifically.”

 

“Oh? Oh how amazing, Lady Edelgard! I should have expected you would recognize it on sight!”

 

“...” Edelgard cleared her throat. “I know who could use it. He would need to be hired.”

 

“Understood! I will prepare blackmail at once–”

 

“No, not like that.” She paused. “The man in question is fairly shameless, so I don’t think that would even work that well. Ah, but leaving that aside, how did your travels go?”

 

“Very well! I actually visited Duke Gerth recently and he was nice enough to give me a lovely accessory. I’m not sure I can wear it though, it doesn’t seem quite right for me,” Monica continued, turning another page and pointing at another relic. One meant to be worn on the hand, from the look of things, though it wasn’t like the gauntlets from earlier. “Apparently it was found over in Dagda of all places. Perhaps you could find a use for it, your highness?”

 

“Perhaps.” It wasn’t likely though. Judging from the crest symbol sketched on the page, it would work with Yuri’s crest, and he wasn’t what Edelgard would consider reliable. Balthus wasn’t either, but he could at least be hired. Maybe Yuri could too, but…Well, at the very least she could keep the relic out of his hands. “Do give my regards to Duke Gerth if you’re in his territory again.”

 

“Gladly, Lady Edelgard! As a loyal subject, I’m sure he would be very happy to hear from you!”

 

For a brief moment, Edelgard remembered a point before the school year, where she had an opportunity to speak with the Minister of Foreign Affairs. She recalled quite easily how deeply the man had bowed his head as he choked out an apology for what happened to her siblings. If she’d allowed it, she was certain he would have prostrated himself on the floor for it.

 

Guilt wasn’t something Edelgard liked to use, but if it could keep someone on her side instead of supporting another insurrection…

 

"I'm sure…Is there anything else of note?" 

 

"Quite, I also found a lovely book and necklace, though I don't think either are for me," Monica continued, as Edelgard turned the page, finding the image of a tome and a gem set into a necklace, both of which had the Crest of Lamine. 

 

Well Jeritza likely wouldn't be able to use the tome, but the gem could be useful to him… though, Mercedes did have the Crest of Lamine… a possible avenue to explore in the future. 

 

"Oh, and recently we managed to gain a contract with an Anna, and her connections will definitely be useful in the future." 

 

"I see, good work Monica," Edelgard praised again, getting Monica to beam in response. 

 

"Oh, hello there, are you Edie's friend?" Blinking, the two glanced over to see Dorothea approaching. 

 

"Oh my, are you the mystical songstress, Lady Dorothea?" Monica said, getting up and approaching the student. 

 

"Heh, I take it that you're a fan then?" Dorothea asked, a bit amused. 

 

"Of course! There's no girl in the empire who isn't a fan of you! When Lady Edelgard mentioned you were attending the Academy this year, I couldn't help but feel saddened that I wasn't able to wait a year before attending!" 

 

"Oh, Edie wrote about me?" Dorothea asked as she glanced at Edelgard, who felt a tad embarrassed. 

 

"Of course! Of the ten letters I have received from her since she arrived at the academy she has mentioned you in seven of them!" 

 

And now Edelgard felt all the more embarrassed. 

 

"Really?" It didn't help that Dorothea seemed far more amused now. 

 

"Of course, the only people she has mentioned more are Hubert, who was mentioned in each letter, and a Professor Eisner, who was mentioned in nine letters."

 

Edelgard felt incredibly grateful that Monica was looking away so she couldn't see how flustered she looked. 

 

“Ooo, really? The professor gets mentioned in almost every letter?” Dorothea grinned over at Edelgard. “Should I assume the only one she wasn’t in was from the start of the year, before she arrived?”

 

Edelgard cleared her throat. “Dorothea, Monica, it’s impolite to discuss my mail.”

 

“Oh, sorry your highness!” Monica immediately apologized, though she paused when she noticed the hint of pink at Edelgard’s cheeks. 

 

"Sorry Edie~." 

 

"Ah, my apologies Lady Dorothea, but you really should refer to Lady Edelgard by her proper title," Monica said, looking away from Edelgard. 

 

"She can refer to me as she wishes, Monica," Edelgard stated, calming down a little. 

 

"And if we're talking about 'proper titles' there's no need to call me 'lady',” Dorothea added, “I'm just a commoner, after all." 

 

"Even so, you're an inspiration!” Monica insisted, “So it's only right that I refer to you as such!" 

 

"Well…I suppose if it means that much to you. Though I would still prefer just being called by my name." 

 

"Hm…well, okay then, Dorothea." 

 

"Thanks Monnie~" Dorothea said with a grin, making Monica blush from the nickname. "Glad I could meet one of Edie's friends." 

 

"O-oh, n-no, I would never presume to be Lady Edelgard’s friend! I simply wish to do my best as her vassal!" 

 

"There's no need to call yourself just my vassal Monica. You're a treasured ally," Edelgard praised, instantly making Monica flustered, which amused Dorothea in turn. 

 

"Well, since you're here, would you like to meet Professor Byleth? I'm sure you're curious about how she is in person," Dorothea offered. 

 

"Oh, well, I will admit, I am a bit curious," Monica admitted. 

 

"Then I believe she'll still be by the pond if you wish to see her. For now I think I'll return to my room to finish reading this report," Edelgard said, standing up as she finished her tea. 

 

"Oh, you don’t want to come with us, Edie?" 

 

"I have official business I need to attend to, so that takes priority." Edelgard explained, before walking away, getting Dorothea to sigh. 

 

"...Ah, Dorothea, if you don't mind me asking, has anything happened to Lady Edelgard recently?” Monica asked, “Nothing in her latest letters have informed me of what could be putting her in such a bad mood." 

 

"Hm…well, it might have something to do with our professor." 

 

"What? Has this Professor Eisner been harassing her??" 

 

Dorothea huffed in amusement at the redhead’s scandalized tone. "No, of course not. The problem is that Edie has been avoiding her, mainly because of her feelings." 

 

"Excuse me?" Monica paused as she remembered the face Edelgard had after mentioning the professor. "Does Lady Edelgard…?"

 

"Yup, and for some reason she's acting as if such a thing is impossible." 

 

"Ah…" Monica frowned at that. "Her highness has been through much, so that is not a surprise. She is not one to be easy on herself." 

 

"Edie does seem to act like she has the weight of the world on her shoulders." 

 

"That's because she does!" Monica declared, before realizing she’d been a little too enthusiastic, "Ah, I mean, as the future Emperor, there is much she'll need to be ready for, though it often means she has to neglect her own care as a result." 

 

Dorothea sighed. "Yeah, that seems like Edie. Though I have to admit, I'm surprised you seem to be taking this so well. I mean your own crush seems pretty obvious to me~." 

 

"A-Ah, well, just because I've accepted Lady Edelgard might have a crush doesn't mean I've given up! And besides, I still need to make sure that Professor Eisner is worthy!" 

 

"Worthy of what?" Byleth asked as she walked by, getting the two girls to look over…and pause as they saw her carrying four buckets full of fish. 

 

"...Uh, professor, what's with all the fish?" 

 

"A cart broke in front of the entrance to the dining hall, so I had to take the long way around to take this to the kitchen," Byleth explained, before she suddenly realized something, and took a step back. "Sorry about that." 

 

"About what?" 

 

"You don't like the smell of fish, right? We might need to reschedule our tea time later as well since I'll probably smell like this for a bit…" Byleth muttered before she glanced at the redhead. "Do you like how fish smell?" 

 

"Pft- Professor, I don't think most people would have an answer to suddenly being asked that." 

 

"They don't?" Byleth asked, a bit surprised. "I guess I'm just used to it. Though at least I haven't tried catching fish with my mouth."

 

"..." Monica was aware that the Professor had 'eccentricities' thanks to the letters she had received, but that had been overshadowed by how Edelgard had described her as a confident warrior, a skilled teacher, and a master tactician. Now that she met her in person though, Monica couldn’t help but wonder if Lady Edelgard had been too generous in her descriptions.

 

No, she shouldn’t doubt her highness! Even if this professor was a complete weirdo, if Lady Edelgard said she was capable, then she was definitely capable!

 

At the very least, she was certainly a very capable fisher.

 

“Hm. You’re not a student here,” Byleth noted, pulling Monica from her thoughts.

 

“Ah, my apologies, I haven’t introduced myself!” Monica curtsied, smiling at Lady Edelgard’s favored professor. “My name is Monica von Ochs, heiress of House Ochs. It is nice to meet you, Professor Byleth Eisner.”

 

"Hi there, did you want to join the academy?" 

 

"Oh, well while I would love to be in her highness’s class, I already graduated last year." 

 

"Oh…is that a problem? Balthus graduated before and he's attending again." 

 

Monica paused. She genuinely considered the idea of joining the academy again, perhaps longer than she should have, before shaking it off. 

 

"My apologies, but I have very important business that I have to do outside of the academy for her highness, so I cannot attend once again." 

 

"Oh." Monica had to admit, she couldn't help but feel a bit bad at how disappointed the Professor sounded. "Well okay, feel free to drop by whenever you want to." 

 

"Believe me, if I could, I would drop by at least once a month. As it stands however, I have to content myself with just receiving letters from her highness." 

 

"I see. Thank you for helping Edelgard." Monica had to admit, it was a bit impressive she was able to bow without dropping any of the fish. "Now if you'll excuse me, I need to take these to the kitchen staff." 

 

With that, she walked past them into the dining hall. 

 

"...I must admit, she is certainly not how I expected her to be." 

 

"Yeah, that's the professor for you. First impressions are very misleading when it comes to her." Dorothea thought for a moment before wincing. "And I suppose second impressions too, since we completely misunderstood her." 

 

"Yes, Lady Edelgard has mentioned such in her letters." Granted, in that situation, the ‘second impression’ was the belief that the professor might be working with her enemies, before the next letter let Moinca know she was wrong. Even Lady Edelgard could make mistakes on a rare occasion. Even then, the fact that she admitted it and learned from it just made her all the more impressive!

 

"So, since the Professor and Edie are going to be busy, did you want me to show you around?" 

 

"Oh, there's no need to. I completely memorized the layout of Garreg Mach when I was here," Monica said, before continuing at Dorothea’s confused look. "I have a perfect memory, so I can memorize anything. For example, I might have only seen you perform once, but I can fully remember the play you performed in despite it being three years, two months, and five days since I've seen it." 

 

"Oh? So you remember all the details?" 

 

"Of course I do! I mean, I didn't get a good seat at the opera house, so I wasn't able to get a good view of the stage, but I remember everything about the performance. The specific play was 'Broken Moon Pearl' and I love your portrayal of Lady Tomar! Two loves split apart by destiny with only a magic pearl being the only connection they had left had me in tears!

 

"You even managed to improvise expertly when your co-lead forgot his lines! 'Ah, does the goddess take your voice away to punish us?' I don't think there was a dry eye in the crowd that night!"

 

Dorothea blinked in the face of the redhead’s enthusiasm, then giggled. “Oh my, I didn’t think I’d meet such a huge fan today. It’s a shame you haven’t been able to see more of my shows. I would love to see you in the audience again some time~”

 

At her words, Monica couldn't help but blush as the songstress teased her. 

 

"W-Well, thank you for the kind words! If I ever have the chance to visit the opera house again, I'll make sure to take it!" 

 

"You could always ask Edie, I'm sure she could get you some tickets easily." 

 

"Oh, I would hate to impose on her highness like that. Though I'll do my best to visit when you return to the opera house and cheer you on!" 

 

"Is that so? Well, in that case I'll make sure to cheer you on too, though I hope you don't mind that I'm helping Edie with her crush as well." 

 

"Oh, of course not. While I will of course want to make sure whoever Lady Edelgard pursues is worthy of her, she is free to love who she wishes, no matter how many they may be!" 

 

"...H-Huh?" Now it was Dorothea’s turn to get flustered. 

 

"While Lady Edelgard isn't one for traditions, it is common for the Emperor to take on several spouses. So if she wishes to follow said tradition then I will ensure to vet any and all potential candidates!" 

 

"...W-Well, you're certainly quite open. Ahem." Dorothea pretended to clear her throat, before giving Monica a little glance. “And, ah…do you happen to be interested in Edie too?”

 

“Oh I adore Lady Edelgard! If she allowed me to, I would cherish her for all my days! But if she’s interested in someone else, that’s fine. I just need to make sure they’re good enough for her, and if they’re not, well, I don’t doubt her highness’s judgement, but I will be forced to work with Hubert to deal with a problem like that, so you can understand why it might be annoying.”

 

Dorothea blinked. “...Do you have a problem with Hubie?”

 

“Oh so many problems, yes. Him, and to a lesser extent Ferdinand, get to be at her side at all times, while I have to content myself with rare visits, as I am just from a barony. While I am glad to be able to help her highness, I can't help but think I'd be able to better help her if I were at her side." 

 

"So…you're jealous of them?" 

 

"...I would not put it like that, but I suppose that is a fair observation," Monica mumbled, "Though her highness has allowed me to join her inner circle, I only wish I could do more for her. Especially after all she has been through." 

 

"Ah…yeah, what happened to her family was horrible." 

 

"..." Monica kept quiet, as her mind instantly brought forth memories of the past. Of how angry Edelgard had been when she stood by her 'Uncle'. It was before her father had become Baron;  her own uncle had not yet died in the war that was just then starting, and the false Arundel along with Duke Aegir had called a gala to announce the new crown princess.

 

Some people might regard it as strange to be blessed with a perfect memory. As far as Monica understood it, memories became hazy over time. Lady Edelgard, for instance, confessed to her at one point that she remembered nothing of her time in Faerghus, given that it had been overwhelmed by her memories of…Well, Monica disliked thinking of that time. She hadn’t experienced it herself, but she remembered the haunted look on her highness’s face with complete clarity.

 

It was during that gala that Monica noticed things were different with Lord Arundel. The way he spoke, the look in his eyes, how he picked up a wine glass with his right hand instead of his left like he had before when attending a function at her uncle’s castle, a gathering of minor lords that hailed from the western half of Adrestia and hoped to gain further influence through the brother of the emperor’s consort. He was friendlier then. Well-mannered, but not arrogant. Not like the man who had stolen his face and talked so readily and merrily with Duke Aegir right after the demise of most of the imperial family.

 

It was after his imposter’s death that Monica talked to Lady Edelgard again, mentioned her suspicions, and her highness recognized how useful she could be. And once they really started talking…Well, Monica could admit, in the privacy of her own mind, that it wasn’t long before she had fallen for the future emperor.

 

"Hm? Monnie, is everything okay?" Dorothea asked, breaking her out of her memory. 

 

"Oh, my apologies, it's easy to get lost in the past for me sometimes." 

 

"Right, because of your memory." 

 

"Yes, though I am thankful for this memory, especially since it means I can write down all of Lady Edelgard’s exploits in the future. While I'm sure there will be countless plays and stories about her, I want to make sure there is at least one written account that has no embellishments or falsehoods." 

 

"Is that so? Well I'm sure Edie would appreciate that more than the opera I teased her about." 

 

"Oh? Were you planning on writing one for her?" 

 

"I might have made up a couple lines on the spot, but I'm not a playwright by any means. Though I imagine if I was you would want to go over anything I wrote." 

 

"Only to make sure it shines a proper light on Lady Edelgard, though I imagine as one of her closest friends you wouldn't write anything negative about her." 

 

"Edie might be a bit too serious for her own good sometimes, but I can assure you I wouldn't say anything bad about her." 

 

"I'm very glad to hear that! Ah, actually, if you're not busy, do you mind telling me more about her time at the academy? While Lady Edelgard has told me about major events, I want to make sure I don't miss anything." 

 

"Well, since everyone is busy with that fishing tourney, I might as well spend some time with you. I'll do my best to fill in the gaps~" Dorothea agreed with a grin. Though that changed to a confused expression as Byleth walked out of the dining hall. 

 

Specifically she had walked out while carrying several different plates, all filled with different fish dishes. Including a plate balanced upon her head. 

 

"Uh, professor, what are you doing?" 

 

"Taking these dishes to eat." 

 

"All of them?" 

 

"No, half of them are for Flayn." For a small moment, Monica could have sworn she seemed smug there. "She told me I was the best." 

 

With her piece said, Byleth walked off, making sure to give the two a wide berth as she did. Monica had to admit, it was almost impressive how she could easily carry so many plates, as it was far more than she had seen head maids carry. 

 

It also made her wonder if she should start being a tad more eccentric if this was Lady Edelgard’s type…

Letting out a satisfied sigh, Shez walked out of the sauna as she stretched her arms. “That felt great!”

 

"I'll take your word on it," Arval muttered, following behind her as always. 

 

“Ugh, how could you like that torture?” Emily asked, her face still flushed with heat.

 

“You didn’t have to stay if you didn’t like it.” 

 

“As if I would admit defeat.” 

 

“Hmph, so who's the childish one now?” Lysithea snarked, even as her skin remained reddened as well. 

 

“You’re lucky I'm not in the mood to argue,” Emily grumbled. 

 

“Good, now then, since I have no intention of rejoining that fishing tourney, I’m heading to the dining hall for some cake.” 

 

“What’s that?”

 

Lysithea immediately stopped in her tracks, before staring straight at Emily, who blinked at the sudden attention. “You don’t know what cake is???”

 

“Uh…” For all her faults, even Emily could recognize when she said something that would blow her cover. “No, I know what it is, it just…slipped my mind because of the heat. I don't have it often." 

 

"You're don't?? Don't tell me you're like Felix…" 

 

"Uh…" 

 

"Oh, I know what's going on. Emily doesn't really eat the food here often,” Shez explained, “I guess she likes cooking for herself? Either way, she probably doesn't know how to make cakes." 

 

"Yeah, that," Emily said, thankful that Shez covered for her, "I don't even like them that much." 

 

"What?!" Emily was starting to realize she should have done a bit more effort in trying to keep her cover. "Right, we're fixing this." 

 

"Fixing what?" Emily asked, confused as Lysithea walked away, expecting them to follow. 

 

"Guess we're following her?" Shez said, walking behind Lysithea, getting Emily to huff as she followed her. Soon enough, they arrived at the dining hall, which seemed to be full of people bringing in buckets full of fish. 

 

"Okay, you two wait at a table, I'll have the cake ready soon!" Lysithea ordered as she went into the cooking area. 

 

"Well, might as well get something to eat while we wait," Shez muttered as she looked around the bustling dining hall, before grinning. "Oh, hey Dedue! Are you on cooking duty today?" 

 

"Hello Shez, Emily. No, I'm just making some fish stew for his highness. He felt bad that he wasn't able to participate without accidentally cracking a fishing pole," the giant said as he stirred a pot, before nodding over to the side. "Mercedes is the one on cooking duty." 

 

Glancing over, Shez saw the gentle Lion apparently assisting Lysithea. 

 

"Well alright then, mind if we have some stew?" 

 

"If you would like," Dedue said, before he grabbed some nearby bowls to serve the two. 

 

"Thanks!" 

 

"Yeah, thanks," Emily muttered as she immediately grabbed her spoon to eat some. "...Dedue Molinaro." 

 

"Hm?" 

 

"If anyone ever insults you again, tell me and I'll stab them for you." 

 

"..." Dedue wasn't sure if that was a compliment or not. 

 

"I think we have underestimated how violent your friend is," Arval muttered, faintly disturbed, though one side of them was also somewhat impressed.

 

"Emily, I think you can just say it tastes good," Shez muttered while Emily walked away so she could eat the rest of her stew at a table. 

 

Emily mumbled something in return, her mouth full of stew. 

 

"Seriously what kind of food do you eat back home?" Shez asked as she ate, albeit at a slower rate. 

 

"We didn't really eat," Emily managed to get out. "We only had these nutrient things. Flavor wasn't really that important." 

 

"Oh…hm, well, I'm glad I helped you eat the food here," Shez said with a grin. She had no idea what a ‘nutrient thing’ was, but eh. Probably some weird vegetable.

 

"There you go!" Lysithea said, as she suddenly placed a slice of cake in front of Emily, before placing one by Shez as well. "I guarantee this will help you change your mind on cakes!" 

 

"Eh?" Frowning a bit, Emily reached over to get some. 

 

"Don't use the spoon you used for the stew! I brought you the fork for a reason!" 

 

"Jeez, someone's in a bad mood," Emily muttered as she put the spoon down, before grabbing the fork to eat some cake. And her eyes widened as she placed a forkful in her mouth. 

 

"Uh, Emily, all good there?" Shez asked, a little concerned by the stunned look on her friend’s face.

 

"...Is this what soft tastes like?"

 

“...What?”

 

Emily didn’t answer her. She was too busy shoveling the cake into her mouth.

 

“...I think you converted her, Lysithea.”

 

“Hmph! Of course! Everyone should love cake!” Lysithea declared with a smug smile.

 

"Well it is a good cake," Shez agreed as she ate her own slice, "Makes me wish I could have it everyday." 

 

Lysithea paused as she heard that, feeling her face warm up as she looked away. She let out a quiet huff as she tried to calm herself. 

 

Honestly, she could stand to be a little less honest , Lysithea thought to herself. Even if that was something she liked about the silly mercenary.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Surprise Monica! A bit different than she is in hopes, but well, different circumstances and all.

Red: She'd still have her Houses haircut, after all, though she would be wearing a different dress at least.

Indi: Yup yup, felt it would also be fun to play around with how exactly this Monica became a trusted member of Edelgard’s group, and well, all leads back to Byleth and Shez lol

Red: It tends to do that. Meanwhile, Kronya experiences cake.

Indi: It's kinda funny how despite legit being a horrible person, Kronya tends to be fun to write.

Red: Eh, horribleness is relative. Yes she kills Jeralt in Houses, but she hasn't done anything to harm our protags in this timeline so nobody cares. Just ignore the trail of blood and death in her backstory.

Indi: Yup yup. I wonder how things will go for her in Simple.

Dealing with Disputes

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

"Ah Shez, there you are." Blinking as she heard Lorenz calling out to her, the merc looked up from her book and over to see the noble approaching her and Lysithea as they sat in the gardens. "I've been looking for your sister. Do you perchance know where she may be?" 

 

"Oh, she went on a mission with Alois and Shamir. Something about Almyran pirates?" Shez answered as she closed the tome she was reading. "Why, what's up?" 

 

"Ah, that's a shame. I can understand why a task like that would take importance, but I was hoping to recruit her assistance for a mission of my own." 

 

"Well hey, if you need any help, I'm up for it!" Shez declared, hopping to her feet. 

 

"Wh-Hey! I thought we were studying together!" Lysithea protested, pouting as she got up. 

 

"While I would hate to intrude upon you two seeking to better yourselves, I will admit that having your assistance will be quite the boon," Lorenz said with a smile. "You see, there is a land dispute that my father asked me to handle. It seems Acheron has gotten quite big for his britches and wants to push some old claim that could hardly be considered valid at this point." 

 

"Oh, that dude," Shez recalled, frowning. "He tried to skip out on paying us once." 

 

"Yes, that does sound like him," Lorenz sighed.

 

"Honestly, when will he stop causing problems?" Lysithea huffed.

 

"So, are we going to beat him up then?" 

 

"Well, officially my father only asked me to handle the dispute. Though if Archeron seeks to use force, well I suppose it would only be right we respond with force, no?" 

 

"Ha, I like the way you think, Lorenz." 

 

"Thank you. Now then, I suppose we should ask the rest of our house if they're willing to help." 

 

"Yeah, it's probably our only option, since By took her class with her, and the Lions are apparently dealing with a gang up over where Sylvain’s territory is." 

 

"Well, if nothing else, that brute Balthus will be useful. He mentioned being indebted to my father, so it's only fair he works it off," Lorenz decided as the trio went to find their classmates. Hopefully they were willing to help.

"So why exactly don't you just get rid of this guy? If he's trying to take your territory then he has to go," Emily stated as if it was the most obvious thing in the world. To be fair, it was a question most of their group was considering as they traveled to the disputed territory.

 

"Ah, Lady Emily. I understand that, coming from Adrestia, you may have very different ideas of how the aristocracy is meant to be treated in the event of a dispute. In Leicester, the nobility is meant to be equal! We cannot simply execute one of our own because of a minor dispute," Lorenz explained. 

 

"...Wouldn't it be more convenient if he was dead though?" 

 

"It would in the short term, but we can't do that without it being more inconvenient down the line," he elaborated, "He is technically in his right to bring up this dispute, so unless he goes too far, the most we can do is drive him off." 

 

"Yeah, the Alliance would fall apart if they were at each other's throats for every single dispute that happened. Heck, we'd probably already be at five wars already thanks to Claude and Lorenz alone," Balthus said with a bark of laughter. 

 

“I would not go that far,” Lorenz replied with a slight frown, “Claude and I may have our disagreements, but nothing he has said has ever warranted an outright war for the sake of my honor.”

 

“And what about what you’ve said to him?” Leonie asked with some obvious humor.

 

“Hmph. If my simple criticisms of our house leader were enough to drive him to seek military retribution, then he has clearly shown he is unworthy of any leadership position.”

 

“Speaking of, where is Claude?” Raphael asked, looking around for the house leader. 

 

“Claude and Hilda are helping Professor Byleth, Raphael,” Ignatz explained. “Apparently he was interested in what the Almyrans were up to.” 

 

“Oh, that makes sense,” Raphael said with a big grin.

 

“Well, at least he’s finally taking his duties seriously,” Lorenz muttered. “Maybe he’ll finally have something commendable about him.” 

 

“Hey, Lorenz, you said we can’t kill that noble guy unless he goes too far, right?” Emily asked, before pointing ahead of them. “Does that count as too far?” 

 

Looking ahead, Lorenz paused when he saw the vast amount of soldiers Acheron brought. 

 

“Did the man bring his entire personal force for this?” Lorenz wondered, a bit stupefied. “He truly is a fool.” 

 

“So is that blond-haired twig the one we have to go after?” Emily asked, spotting Archeron off in the distance. 

 

“Accurate, and yup,” Shez said, pulling out her swords. 

 

“Well in that case, I’ll go get him, the rest of you kids can stay here,” Balthus declared, cracking his knuckles as an excited grin spread across his face. “Gotta work off my debt somehow.” 

 

“Don’t call me a kid!” Lysithea snapped, though her protest was drowned out by Emily’s shout.

 

“Hey, you’re not the only one who’s gonna have some fun!”

 

“We are not here to have fun, and I refuse to stay behind while you throw yourself into the heat of battle. I was the one to ask you to come along, so I’ll be the one to handle Archeron!” Lorenz stated, frowning as he stared at the infamous weathervane of a noble in the distance. 

 

“Heh, guess that means we know who's going on the offensive.” Grinning, Shez glanced over at Leonie. “You’re in charge of defending this location, got it, Leonie?” 

 

“Don’t worry, I’ll make the captain proud!” 

 

“I’m sure you will! And you mind staying with her, Lys? I figure you can keep the fort safe from anyone that gets too close.”

 

“Hmph, of course I can,” Lysithea stated, glowering up at her student, “Just get going already!”

 

“Heh, come on Ignatz, can’t let them do all the work!” Raphael encouraged with a big grin.

 

“R-Right!”

 

“Fine then!” Lorenz decided, “Those of you who wish to press the attack, with me! We’ll seize the drawbridges and cut off the routes his forces can take until we are ready to seize Acheron himself! Remember, we need not kill him! Once his escape is cut off, the coward will most assuredly surrender!”

 

“Got it, boss!” Shez said, grinning over at her classmate before quickly charging the first enemy soldier she saw. 

 

As the startled axe wielder went down in a spray of blood, Emily huffed in a mix of amusement and annoyance. “Don’t think I’ll let you get ahead of me!”

 

“Wow, and I thought I could be competitive,” Leonie commented as she watched the brunette jam her saber into a swordsman’s throat and rip it through his neck. 

 

Lysithea huffed in annoyance, prepping a pair of spells as she saw the enemy starting to rally as they realized they were being attacked. “Trust me, you haven’t seen how annoying those two can get when they’re trying to train.”

 

“Eh, I don’t know, I’ve gone up against Shez a few times so I think I have a good idea of it. For now though…” She decided to pull out her bow and nocked an arrow before sending it flying into an enemy mage’s chest. “Do you feel like keeping count of how many you get?”

 

“...I see you and Shez share some habits.”

 

“That’s not a no.”

 

“Hmph! I’ll handle double the enemies you manage to strike down!”

 

“I’m starting to think some of our classmates are way too competitive,” Ignatz commented with some concern as he saw the duo of Shez and Emily get joined by Balthus, who seemed more than eager to crush some bones with his fists.

 

“Yeah, they are!” Raphael agreed with a big grin, “Doesn’t it make you wanna get right in there with ‘em?!”

 

“Ah, that’s not exactly–Oh okay, he’s already heading in…” Ignatz sighed as his friends continued smashing and slicing their way through the enemy before deciding to focus on supporting them where possible. Starting by aiming for an enemy pegasus knight–Who Leonie just shot off her steed and into the river.

 

“Ha! That’s another one for me!” the exuberant redhead called out, echoed by an irritated response from Lysithea and followed by screams of pain as the young mage let loose her frustrations on the enemy in the form of flesh-melting dark magic and swarms of summoned insects.

 

“...Hm. I’d say I should join the defensive team, but I don’t think they need the help,” Ignatz muttered to himself, before trying to find something to do as his friends continued decimating the enemy forces.

 

Meanwhile, across the river, a certain lord named Acheron Lethe Phlegethon was having to rapidly reassess his life choices as he watched his forces getting outright slaughtered by schoolchildren. 

 

“WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE DOING!?” he practically screeched, “THEY’RE JUST SOME ACADEMY BRATS! HOW ARE YOU LOSING?!”

 

“OH GODDESS THE BUGS ARE EATING MY EYES!” answered one of his goons, who was having a very bad day.

 

Acheron cringed at that gruesome response, then shook his head. “R-Right, this can still be salvaged…I haven’t lost yet! I just need to…to…ah, ah ha!” He grinned as he saw two of his men returning from raiding the nearby towns. “Excellent! As long as I can get something out of–”

 

And the one on the left was promptly punched so hard by the blond brute that he flew into and through a nearby tree. “Ah ha! That’s another one for me, Balthus!”

 

“Ah, damn, I’m gonna lose my bet at this rate!”

 

“...They’re…making bets?!” Acheron asked with genuine offense, before shaking it off. “No, never mind, I still have–WHY IS HE DEAD TOO!?”

 

The second thief had no answer for the weathervane because he was facedown in the dirt with an arrow sticking out of his head.

 

“Gh–N-No, no, I can still…I can most certainly still salvage–”

 

“Hello Acheron.”

 

Acheron screeched, whirling to face the heir of Gloucester as Lorenz leveled a spear at him. “W-Wha–Y-You! What is this supposed to be, hm!? You can’t honestly think a tiny brat like you could possibly kill me!”

 

Lorenz, who was visibly taller than Acheron, didn’t even bother with a sigh or a frown. “You have no right to be here, Acheron. You can still walk away though and retain some dignity as a noble.”

 

“Ha! You have no idea who you’re dealing with! I can easily take down a brat like you!”

 

Acheron flung his hand out, casting a fireball that soared past Lorenz completely as the violet-haired noble moved right in and smashed the butt of his spear into the side of Acheron’s head, sending him straight to the ground.

 

“AUGH! O-Ow, ow, o-oh goddess, am I bleeding!?” Acheron touched his head, then nearly fainted as he felt a trace of blood there. “Argh! W-W-Wait, wait, I give up! I lose! I surrender! Please don’t kill meeeeeeee!”

 

“...” Lorenz was too dignified to sigh in this situation.

 

Emily, however, was not, and outright scoffed as she walked up. “We’re seriously sparing this guy after all that? We can’t just push him in the river and claim he drowned?”

 

“No, Lady Emily, that would still cause more problems than it solves. Even if it would be remarkably satisfying. For now, I need to take this man and go see my father. Good work everyone, I'll make sure you're all well rewarded for your help here," Lorenz said, before hoisting Archeron up to pull him along while the remaining soldiers either surrendered or absconded. 

 

"Hah, speaking of rewards, I'm pretty sure I ended up taking out the most guys," Balthus boasted. "So guess that means I win." 

 

"Weren't you just complaining about losing the bet to Raphael?" Shez asked as she glanced at the burly blonde. "How many did you take out, big guy?" 

 

"Uh, honestly I forgot to keep track, so guess I don't win." As usual, the cheery guy didn't seem that bothered. 

 

"Hmph, not like it mattered. Clearly I was the one who took out the most," Emily stated. 

 

"You sure? Pretty sure Shez took out more people while you dealt with the stragglers," Leonie teased, getting the minor noble to scowl. 

 

"Uh, I didn't take out as many, but I did deal with one of the thieves so that has to count for something, right?" Ignatz asked. 

 

"Hmph, I can't believe all of you are arguing over something as foolish as this," Lysithea complained with a frown. 

 

"Quite right, there is no need for such squabbling," Lorenz said, before grinning. "Though for the record, taking the enemy commander is worth extra points if we are using the Battle of Eagle and Lion as our point system." 

 

Archeron could only stare in horror as he watched the students bicker amongst themselves about who had 'won'. What kind of monsters had they let into the academy this year…though, maybe he could take this chance to sneak away…

 

Said attempt was quickly foiled as the orange-haired commoner used the end of her spear to trip him, making him fall and break his nose as he hit the ground. 

 

"AH, I'M BLEEDING AGAIN! GODDESS SAVE ME!" 

 

That time Lorenz did let out a sigh, briefly wondering if he should take Emily's suggestion to let him drown. 

Some time later after they returned to the monastery, Lorenz happily drank his tea, relaxing after the battle, before his peaceful moment was interrupted as someone sat across from him. 

 

"Hey there Lorenz, heard you were busy while I was gone," Claude noted, his usual smile on his face.

 

"Just a simple land dispute, nothing I couldn't handle," Lorenz responded. 

 

"So you say, but I heard your father also ended up giving you the relic of House Gloucester." 

 

"Is that jealousy I hear in your voice?" Lorenz asked with a smirk. 

 

"Even if I was jealous, it's not like I can use it," Claude shot back. 

 

"Ha. Then it’s good that you can acknowledge you can't do everything," he replied as he sipped his tea. "And, well, if nothing else I can commend you for actually helping Professor Eisner against those Almyran pirates." 

 

"Oh, those weren't Almyrans. Just some normal bandits calling themselves Almyrans." 

 

"Really?" Lorenz asked, before sighing as he shook his head. "Honestly, how foolish could those bandits be?" 

 

"Well that's a surprise. Almost thought you wouldn't believe me." 

 

"I wouldn't say I trust you, but I am willing to admit that things would have been a disaster if those bandits went too far. It's one thing to deflect the Almyrans at Fodlan's Throat, but if they had been able to launch a successful strike on Derdriu, well, war would be inevitable," Lorenz assumed, before letting out another sigh. "All while those bandits got away, their pockets lined with stolen riches none the wiser of what their actions caused." 

 

"You know, that may just be the smartest thing I've heard you say."

 

"Hmph, you're quite lucky I'm in a good mood. Now, if you're not going to join me for tea, I ask you to leave me alone." 

 

"What, not going to ask Emily to another tea party?" 

 

"Shame though it might be, she is not a fan of tea, and prefers coffee instead. She sadly fails to notice the subtle intricacies of a fine brewed cup of tea." 

 

"Well, I'm not busy, so might as well keep you company. I did want to discuss some plans for the upcoming battle, and as it turns out, Hilda isn't a fan of planning." 

 

Lorenz paused. “And you wish to discuss those plans with me?”

 

“I did just say that, didn’t I?”

 

“You did. My apologies, your offer simply caught me off guard.”

 

“Hey, we might argue sometimes, but I know you’re a smart guy, Lorenz. That and I’m pretty sure you learned your lesson about ‘noble duels’ on the battlefield after last time.”

 

Lorenz faked a cough to try to hide his embarrassment. “Yes, well, I would say there is precedent for nobility to deliberately seek out one on one matches on the battlefield in order to-”

 

“Are those matches usually interrupted by random mercs wandering in?”

 

“...Not typically, so you can understand my surprise when it did happen.” He sighed, then his smirk returned to his face. “Though I will note that this time we do have that exact mercenary on our side.”

 

“That we do. So how about we start off with that?” Claude grinned. “What do you think is the best way to use our mercenary friend?”

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Ah Acheron, Fodlan’s punching bag.

Red: A man who has really earned that position. He's not the worst person in Fodlan but he's definitely one of the more pathetic and obnoxious ones.

Indi: And also hilariously dumb, with how he keeps switching sides even at the worst times.

Red: Maybe we'll see him switch sides at a stupid time in this story too? Though who would he even side with?

Indi: I guess we'll have to see.

A New Promise Made

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Deep in the depths of Garreg Mach, down in the town known simply as Abyss, a certain Imperial Princess was frowning to herself as she read through the “Encyclopedia of Fodlan’s Insects”. The title of the catalog did not match its contents in the slightest, owing to an attempt by the writer to hide what exactly they had written down in its pages: a description of items banned by the Church.

 

Currently, Edelgard was on the passage regarding a “metal-mold printing machine”, an apparent upgrade in all respects to the woodblock printing presses utilized by publishers across Fodlan. She had known that the church held back technological progress, keeping the people of Fodlan at the level they wished of them, but that information had primarily come from the Agarthans back in her days of being under their thumb. As such, it was only right for her to verify it, and lo and behold, she found the exact evidence she wanted.

 

More than that though, she felt a growing irritation the more she read. To think, her people could have had so much more. If these advanced printing presses had circulated, wouldn’t the illiteracy among the commonfolk decrease? They would have easier access to books of all types, and to presume they would instead be led astray by “misinformation”...

 

She closed the book with an irritated sigh.

 

“Well well, so there really is a princess snooping around us commonfolk.”

 

Edelgard paused, then let out another annoyed noise as she glanced over at the Abyss’s so-called boss. “Hello Yuri. I thought Constance let you know I was coming.”

 

“Oh she did, I just thought it would be fun to see you for myself. Any reason you’re interested in the ‘forbidden texts’ we have down here?” He grinned. “If you’re looking for the smutty stuff, it’s a shelf over.”

 

“...Thank you for the directions, but that isn’t what I’m looking for.”

 

“More of a fan of ‘insects’ then, huh?”

 

“I might be. You’ve read these books then?”

 

“Sure have. I imagine you’re the type that lets that sort of thing bother you though.”

 

She frowned. “It doesn’t bother you that the church is deliberately curtailing technological development that could aid the people of Fodlan?”

 

“It would if I let it, but I don’t, so it doesn’t.” He smirked. “I’m guessing you don’t buy the bits about the potential dangers then, huh?”

 

“Even if there were dangers, it should be up to the people of Fodlan if they wish to explore them. It is not the role of the church to keep the masses ignorant for the sake of their own control.”

 

“See, I don’t think you believe that. I think you believe that’s exactly the church’s role. You just don’t like it.”

 

Her frown deepened. “Are you accusing me of something?”

 

“Is there something to accuse you of? Heh, but no, I’m not. I’m just curious where you want to take this. You seem like the type who would start looking into all of these advancements even if they might cause problems. Take the ‘black water’, for instance. What use do you think a liquid that makes toxic gas when burned could have?”

 

“...Potentially, it could fulfill the same uses that people currently burn alcohol for.”

 

“Heh. So, for instance, when soldiers roll a burning cart into an enemy and let it explode. Sounds like the exact kind of weapon the church doesn’t want developed.”

 

Edelgard grimaced. “...Wouldn’t it see more use in Faerghus regardless? Your people live in very cold areas, Yuri. Wouldn’t something that burns intensely be useful for cold winters? In fact, could it not work well in something akin to a fireplace? As long as there is a siphon like a chimney to vent the smoke through, the toxic gas would not be an issue.”

 

“Assuming it doesn’t linger and come back down, sure, you might have a point. But can you guarantee it?”

 

“Of course I can’t, which is why people should be able to experiment! We are not children in need of guidance!”

 

“Oh really? If people don’t need guidance, then what’s the point of nobles?”

 

“THERE IS NO POINT! All there is are long standing traditions upheld by those in power who refuse to let go of it!” she snapped, before pausing as she saw the interested glint in Yuri’s eyes. “...My apologies, I seem to have gotten carried away.”

 

“Aw, you’re gonna leave it there? And here I was hoping to hear more. It’s not often I hear from a royal that the entire noble system is pointless.”

 

“...Hmph. I understand that it does have a point, that being a thin veneer of stability. I simply think there are better ways for things to be done.”

 

“Sure, sure, I won’t argue that part. I wouldn’t be living in Abyss if I thought the world was fine as it is. I’m just…interested in your politics, let’s say. Especially with how aggressive you got there.”

 

Edelgard frowned. “Are there going to be issues between us, Yuri?”

 

“No, I don’t think so. So long as you’re not trying to hurt the people of Abyss, I don’t really care about what reforms you’re going to ram through the instant you take the throne. Though try to avoid getting the Church to declare war on you as a heretic, alright? That kind of thing would definitely cause trouble for us down here.”

 

“Hmph. If you desire protection for your people, I would gladly extend a place to them.”

 

He paused, then studied the young princess in front of him. “...Huh. You actually mean that. You’re weirdly honest for a royal, you know that? But I digress. Your professor's looking for you.”

 

Edelgard blinked. “She is? Wait, is she down here?”

 

“Sure is. I told her I would get you, so we better not keep her waiting, right?”

 

“...You are remarkably infuriating.”

 

"I have been told that on occasion,” he said with a smirk that made him all the more infuriating. Sighing, she followed behind him, and found her professor in the Wilted Rose inn, playing poker. And apparently cleaning house since the people she was playing with were loudly complaining as she took their gold. 

 

"Come on, you gotta be cheating!" one of the players shouted. 

 

"Now now, if you can't prove she's cheating, then you'll just seem like a sore loser," Yuri chided as he walked up. "Especially coming from someone who was caught quite easily last week when he tried to cheat." 

 

At the reminder of his mistake, the abyss resident let out a huff, before deciding to go get a drink with the gold he had left. 

 

“Thanks, Yuri,” Byleth said, getting up before her attention turned to Edelgard. “Hello Edelgard, how are you doing?” 

 

“Fine, Professor. Was there something you needed?” At her question, Byleth nodded. 

 

“Yuri, is there somewhere private Edelgard and I can speak?” 

 

“Well, I can’t guarantee much in terms of privacy, but the Wilted Rose is an inn if one of the rooms will suffice.” 

 

“It will,” Byleth said, before nodding to Edelgard to get her to follow. Moments later, they found themselves in a rather sparse room that only had a bed and a small stand next to it. “Sorry for following you down here, I felt we could converse freely down here.”

 

“...What exactly did you need to discuss?” Edelgard asked. Her plan had been to avoid her professor unless needed, but if she was seeking her out like this…

 

“I wanted to know if you had any ideas for who the infiltrator might be,” Byleth explained as she leaned against the wall, while Edelgard sat on the bed. “I haven’t had much luck in figuring out who it might be.” Going up to her students and asking if they’d lost a weapon wasn’t working.

 

“Ah, yes, I do. At the very least, I do not believe it to be any of the Black Eagles. I know most of them from before, so I'd notice any changes in their personality, and they have nothing to gain from replacing Dorothea,” Edelgard said, which immediately made Byleth look relieved. 

 

“I’m glad to hear you say so, I would hate to think one of them had been part of it,” she replied, though she frowned after a moment. “Though, I don’t want to think it was any other student…”  

 

“...hm. Well, for now, why don’t we think of who they would benefit from replacing?” Edelgard suggested, trying to be careful with her words. “It would likely have to be someone noble, so we can probably ignore any commoners, but trying to replace someone of high status would also have its negatives. For starters, it would be harder to pull off, and it would be easier to notice someone of their position acting differently with how many people would know them.” 

 

“Hm… that does narrow it down a bit,” Byleth muttered, still not happy to be suspecting the students. “It would help if we knew what those people were doing… and whatever that Flame Emperor was planning.” 

 

“Ah, yes, the Flame Emperor.” Edelgard tried to keep herself calm. “Hubert mentioned them. Some mysterious individual who could command the Death Knight?” 

 

"Yes, exactly. The Death Knight referred to them as his ‘master’. I don't know what exactly the Flame Emperor is planning, but even if they don't have the same goals as the people that kidnapped Shez, they seem to be working together," Byleth explained, her frown returning. 

 

"...Suppose you did have a chance to learn," Edelgard said, taking a slight risk. "If the Flame Emperor were to tell you his plans, would you listen?" 

 

"..." Byleth's face seemed torn for a moment, her usual muted expression turning conflicted. "...It's hard to say, but I think so, yeah. 

 

"I must admit, that is a surprise to hear,” Edelgard admitted, watching her professor’s reactions, “Whoever the Flame Emperor is, he did still aid the people who abducted your sister.”

 

"I know, but I had a conversation with Dimitri, about Bias and why she might have betrayed Solon. He wants to know why, and as an instructor, I need to set a good example, right?" 

 

Edelgard frowned. “So you want to know your enemy’s motives?”

 

“...I don’t know if he’s my enemy yet. He didn’t seem happy with what went on there, and…it’s just a thought, but the first time I saw the Death Knight, he was working with the Western Church. If I assume Solon was telling the truth when he spoke down there, then the Flame Emperor was acting on their own when it came to aiding them with the Death Knight."

 

“So you think there are two distinct groups here then. Solon and Bias in one, and the Flame Emperor and the Death Knight in the other.”
