“Exactly. Though I think it’s more accurate to say that the first organization just has Bias as a leader now.” She paused, thinking. “That’s assuming it’s not even bigger than we think. They did have a lot of people helping them in the underground chambers and the dark mages among them seemed to be part of Bias’s group from how they referred to her. She didn’t seem to particularly care for them though…that or she already decided to kill Solon and wanted to get rid of all the potential witnesses.”

 

“...Hm. You don’t think the Flame Emperor could be the one backing them?”

 

“No, it’s definitely the other way around. The way Bias and Solon talked to him was too mocking. They weren’t deferential at all. Especially with how Solon mentioned putting a leash on him." Byleth frowned. "It's…hard to say, but I can't help but wonder if he was someone like Shez."

 

"Excuse me?" 

 

"Just…a random thought. It's not that important, especially since I don't have any more information."

 

“So you’re saying we don’t have enough evidence either way.” Edelgard was becoming entirely too familiar with that phrase…how could she trust her own decisions if they were being made in ignorance? At least she knew for certain that the Church of Seiros and Those Who Slither in the Dark were, as a whole, still her enemies. The problem came with how uncertain she was of everything else.

 

“That’s true, but we can still speculate. For instance, the Flame Emperor didn’t plan for Shez to be abducted, but he didn’t mention Flayn. Add in how the Death Knight was helping them and I think it’s probable that Flayn was the original target and Solon altered things by going after Shez. I think because of that ‘heritage’ Solon mentioned.”

 

“And what do you think about that?” Edelgard decided to ask, “About the chance that your adoptive sister may have a connection to these people.”

 

“...I don’t think it matters. Or…I don’t want it to matter. I don’t think it should matter where Shez comes from, but if these people are going to keep coming after her because of it…” Byleth shook her head. “Never mind. I can figure that out later. I had another idea I wanted to bring up. Do you remember Kostas?”

 

Edelgard paused, then frowned, trying to look thoughtful rather than alarmed. “...that would be the bandit leader, correct? The one who previously led the Iron Kings.”

 

“Right. He was hired to attack you, Dimitri, and Claude by the Flame Emperor. Solon confirmed it before he died. Or, at least, he said he’d hired a bandit to attack them, and that fits with Kostas attacking you three, which makes me think the Flame Emperor might be after crests specifically. You, Dimitri, and Claude all have crests, right? Seiros for you, and Blaiddyd and Riegan for those two. Add in Cethleann from Flayn…well, I feel like it might be more significant if they were all the crests of the saints or the elites, but I think he might just want the blood of crest wielders in general.”

 

“...” Edelgard considered her response. Byleth was getting dangerously close to something near the truth, even if she was going down the wrong path. “So you think they wanted to capture us instead of kill us?”

 

“Maybe. It could have been a way to get access to your corpses and get your blood that way.”

 

“...You have quite a morbid mind, professor.”

 

Byleth shrugged. “It helps to keep every idea in mind. Especially if we want to figure out what the Flame Emperor wants… though, I can't help but wonder, are crests that big of a deal?" 

 

"...People do believe them to be the blessings from the goddess, professor." 

 

"And? The Flame Emperor might want them to get stronger, but aside from being stronger, I don't see why people in general want them so badly," Byleth said, frowning. "I mean, I have a really important crest, but that doesn't make me better than anyone else. I still can't beat Jeralt in a fight, and Catherine was able to win our spar together. Dorothea might not be as skilled in magic as others, but she really only started learning while at the academy. With enough time and practice. I'm sure she could surpass anyone else with reason magic." 

 

"Yes, exactly!" Edelgard couldn’t stop the elation she felt at what her professor was saying. "Someone's worth shouldn't be determined just because they have a crest or not! A person's merit should be what determines their value!" 

 

"...I think that might be the most passionate I've seen you been, Edelgard," Byleth noted, making the heiress realize how emotional she had just gotten. 

 

"Ah, my apologies, Professor." 

 

"Don't apologize. I want to hear more about what you think. There's still a lot I don't know about crests, or how people view them." 

 

"I think I would give a rather skewed view on them," Edelgard admitted. 

 

"I think most people would. Their views would likely be on the opposite ends from yours, from what I can tell, so I want to hear what you think." 

 

"...Crests are nothing but a blight on this world. We elevate those who have them, while those who don't are casted to the side," Edelgard said, a frown marring her face. "I'm sure you've noticed how favored you are, Professor. You might have only discovered you had a crest upon coming here, but you were still able to become a professor at a prestigious academy, were given a relic weapon, and seem to have the archbishop’s trust, to the point that she was willing to remove a holy knight from a mission because you expressed a dislike of her." 

 

Byleth nodded, though she looked a little…uncomfortable. “Yeah, there is that…Edelgard, how much do you remember of what happened with Aelfric?"

 

"...I remember what occurred." 

 

"While I won't argue that my crest might have had a hand in some of her decisions, it's not the main reason I think she's like that," Byleth explained, reaching up to place a hand on her chest, her heart as unbeating as ever. "Rhea was the midwife for my mother when I was born. She could only save one of us, and my mother begged her to save me." 

 

"...Oh." What else could she say? She had made another mistake. 

 

"I… think she's still hiding something, but I also think she wants to make up for not being able to save my mom,” Byleth continued, “Especially since she apparently saw her as a daughter." 

 

"I see… I'm sorry professor, I misspoke," Edelgard apologized, looking away from her. Though, her mind couldn't help but focus on the part about Rhea apparently viewing Lady Eisner as a daughter…

 

"It's okay, you didn't know," Byleth said, forgiving her, "I've misspoke with you before." 

 

"I suppose you have," Edelgard responded, letting out a mirthless chuckle. 

 

"Even so, I'm glad we can speak like this again." Byleth smiled at her. "I was starting to worry you were going to keep avoiding me for the rest of the year." 

 

"Ah, my apologies Professor, I had no intention of doing so," Edelgard lied, fully planning on doing exactly that, having only come to talk to Byleth because the professor had come searching for her. 

 

"It feels nice talking with you. I'd hate to not be able to." 

 

"...It is pleasant, yes." 

 

"I'd like to hear more of what you think of crests and the like if you have time." 

 

"You would?" 

 

"Yes. We're friends, aren’t we?" 

 

"...Friends, yes," Edelgard said, counting herself lucky with just that. Even if she was never forgiven for her actions, she still wished they could be friends when the time came. "...There is another thing I want to tell you, about why I view crests like this." 

 

Tilting her head in curiosity, Byleth waited for her to continue. 

 

"Do you remember what I told you about my siblings? How we were experimented on?" At her nod, Edelgard took in a deep breath. "What they did to us, they wanted to try and endow us with a major crest. Of my siblings, I was one of the few to already have a crest, minor though it was. To them, that wasn't enough, they needed a future Emperor to be peerless. What better way to do that, than to have one who wields a major crest? To that end, they violated our bodies." 

 

Clutching onto her arm, Edelgard remembered the nights they would cut her open in their experiments. 

 

"It wasn't just my family, many others were experimented on, countless innocents died in their attempt to perfect their process. In the end, I was the only one left, the fruit of all their terrible experiments." Biting her lip, Edelgard began to taste blood. 

 

"..." At the deafening silence, Edelgard found herself unable to look up, to see what expression her professor had. "...Who did this?" 

 

"I'm sure you've heard of it professor, the insurrection, led by Duke Aegir," Edelgard said, scoffing at the thought of the man. "Even now, they have the empire under their thumb, as my father remains powerless to do anything." 

 

"Okay. This won't be the first time I've had to kill a noble, so another six won't matter." At that, Edelgard blinked, before looking up to see Byleth’s face twisted in anger. 

 

"P-Professor?" 

 

"I don't care what reasoning they had, you shouldn't have gone through that. No one should have, so they should pay for it." 

 

"..." Laughing in disbelief, Edelgard did her best to compose herself. "As much as I'm loath to admit it, killing them will only cause more problems. They will see their due justice in time, but until then, they'll have to remain." 

 

"....If you say so." 

 

"I do. Thank you professor, for believing in me," Edelgard said with a smile. "There is one more thing I want to show you."

 

"That is?" 

 

"My crest, the major one they gave me." Raising a hand, a familiar crest formed above it. 

 

"The Crest of Flames…" Byleth said, her eyes widening in surprise. 

 

"Yes, the same one you hold. Though it is not a power I wished for, it is one I shall wield. I swore a silent oath, for the sake of everyone who was lost to grant me this, to make a world where such meaningless sacrifice is never again sanctioned. I will change the world, no matter what it takes." 

 

"...I see," Byleth said, staring down at the imperial princess, "...You really are admirable, Edelgard. Someone like you really does deserve to lead." 

 

"Professor?" Surprised, Edelgard let the crest dissipate, not expecting her to say that. 

 

"Back when I was a mercenary, I might have been ready to take the job of leading them from Jeralt, but I was only ever expecting to prioritize them. Even now as a professor, my views on who to take care of don't reach far outside this monastery," Byleth admitted, "And here you are, already wanting to make the world better for everyone else. It makes me wish I could be as determined as you are." 

 

"...Th-There is no need for flattery professor." 

 

"It's not. I said it before, I'm not one for embellishments," Byleth stated, before bowing to her. "I might just be a mercenary, but I vow to help you in your goal of bettering the world." 

 

"...You have done far more than you think, Professor." 

 

"I'm glad to hear that." Reaching out, Byleth offered Edelgard a hand to help her off the bed. "Now come on, it's getting late, and no offense to Yuri, but these beds don't seem the best place to sleep." 

 

"...I suppose so," Edelgard said, before tentatively reaching out to grab her hand, hoping this would be one vow that wouldn't be betrayed.

“Huh. You’re going to be going to the empire then?” Shez asked, prompting a nod from her sister.

 

“That is my plan, yes. I made a promise to Edelgard and I intend to see it through,” Byleth said as they had lunch together. "I don't know when it'll happen, but I want to help her out." 

 

"Hm…" Shez glanced across the dining hall towards the three house leaders eating together. "Gotta say, didn't expect you to do something like that." 

 

"I know, but…I want to help her out. Is that weird?" 

 

"Nah, if you want to do it, go ahead." Shez leaned back as she stared at the ceiling. "Huh, guess that means I'll be hanging out in the empire as well."

 

"You don't have to come along if you don't want to." 

 

"As if I can leave you alone. Besides, it's not like it's a bad thing. Working for the future Emperor sounds like it could be fun, and I can always travel with the mercs to other nations if I want to go around." Shez couldn't help the sad smile on her face. "Just feeling a bit weird is all." 

 

"Ah…" Byleth almost took back what she had said but…no, she wanted to help Edelgard, to be at her side… "Sorry…" 

 

"Come on now, no need to be sad," Shez comforted as she reached over and patted her sister on the head. “It’s just, I never thought you’d take such a big step on your own like that.” 

 

“...I’m still the older sister.”

 

“I know,” Shez smiled as she remembered the young quiet girl who wouldn’t do anything without being told to do so. “You’ve really grown up, By.” 

 

“...I just said I'm the older sister.” 

 

“Pft, that’s not what I meant,” Shez said as she chuckled. “Alright, come on, I need to give Edelgard my blessing.” 

 

“Blessing for what?” Byleth asked, looking confused as Shez got up to walk towards the house leaders. It was pretty rare to see all three of them hanging out, but then they were probably talking about important stuff for the battle thing.

 

“Hey, Edelgard, you have my blessing!” 

 

“-I’m telling you–Wait, what blessing?” Edelgard asked, caught off guard by Shez’s sudden declaration. 

 

“To marry my sister, of course.” 

 

Edelgard blinked, before her face went completely red. Thankfully, there was a distraction in the form of Dimitri spitting out his tea, so she could recover from that…thing that just happened. Which was. Hm.

 

…A small part of her decided to keep that in mind in case things didn’t work out between the professor and Dorothea, before the rest of her managed a response. “Thank you.” Wait, no, wrong response–

 

“Shez, why is Dimitri coughing?” Byleth asked as she followed after her sister. Thankfully for Edelgard, it was at enough of a distance that she apparently didn’t hear the previous exchange.

 

“Oh, he just heard something surprisingly interesting,” Claude mentioned with a small smirk, earning an immediate glare from Edelgard.

 

"Can we just get back to what we were talking about?" Edelgard asked about to eat her vegetable stir fry, before Hubert suddenly appeared. 

 

"Lady Edelgard, there is something important I feel like we must discuss," Hubert said, even as he glared at Claude. 

 

"Very well." Thankful that she had an out, she stood up to leave with Hubert, leaving her tray on the table. 

 

"Pft, didn't think she'd get that flustered." Grinning, Shez couldn't help but note how fast the princess ran away. 

 

"Hm," Frowning a bit, Byleth glanced over at Dimitri. "Do you need help Dimitri?" 

 

"No, it's alright, I really should be going," Dimitri said as he stood up with a complicated expression. 

 

"Aw, not going to finish your food, your princeliness?" Claude asked. 

 

"I wasn't that hungry," he responded as he left in a hurry. 

 

"Well there goes that plan…" Claude muttered. 

 

"Hm, well I hope everything is okay," Byleth said, a bit worried, before she glanced down at the trays. "We should return these." 

 

Saying this, she grabbed the forgotten fork to have a bit of the vegetable stir fry.

 

"Ah, wait professor-" Claude started before Byleth ate the food. 

 

"Hm?" 

 

"...I was just trying to say it's not exactly the best manners to eat someone else's food," he said, trying to keep his poker face up. 

 

"Oh, okay." Setting the fork down, Byleth grabbed the two trays to return them rather than finish eating them. 

 

"Everything good there Claude? You look a bit off" Shez noted. 

 

"Yeah, everything is okay," Claude said with a smile, trying not to focus on the empty bottle he had in his pocket. 

 

Well, it wasn't lethal, so maybe it was okay he accidentally poisoned the professor?

Chapter End Notes

Red: Something of an in-between chapter this time, where Byleth and Edelgard have an important talk and we lead up to the Battle! Well, probably. Maybe after the next chapter. There's a lot of lead up, it's a big battle.

Indi: That there is! A very important promise made, and an important reveal. Speaking of important stuff, it was always quite odd how Claude was always about poison in game, but never actually got to poison anyone.

Red: Yeah it's a funny thing. Perhaps under normal circumstances, he'd be too cautious to make the attempt, but a certain merc on his side emboldened him? Either way, it definitely was the wrong move to make, so that might be why.

Indi: Well it's not lethal at least. Ah well I'm sure it'll be fine.

Red: Probably! Anyways, thanks for reading as always and we'll see you next time!

Last Minute Preparations

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Making sure her armor was properly secured, Shez looked over her gear one last time. Two swords, a concoction, and a dagger, though the last item wouldn't be seeing any use during the Battle. Well, probably. She wouldn’t be using it on any classmates, though it was good to have a dagger for utility in general.

 

Satisfied with her check, Shez nodded to herself and headed out of her room, before letting out a loud yawn as she did. 

 

"Well, seems someone didn't get enough sleep," Claude noted, apparently waiting outside of her room. 

 

"Ugh, I don't know why, I made sure to go to bed early yesterday," Shez replied, rubbing her eyes as she spoke, "Don't know why, but I've been having trouble sleeping lately." 

 

"Really? Any reason in particular, or are you just sleeping weirdly?" 

 

"Eh, dunno, just been having weird dreams. Like I'm talking with someone, but it's all hazy." 

 

"Well try to keep your mind off that stuff for now, the plan is gonna fall through if you get distracted." 

 

“Right, right, big plan…” Shez yawned again. “Mnh…it’s alright, I’ll be good. Just need to start moving to wake myself up!”

 

“Alright, if you say so.” Claude glanced at his friend, taking note of just how tired she seemed as he walked with her. “Does this have anything to do with that guy who claimed to be Tomas?”

 

“Huh? Oh…yeah, huh, I guess it could? I didn’t really think it would, but maybe he cast a curse on me or something?”

 

“I think it would’ve gone away when he was killed if that was the case.”

 

“I guess? It doesn’t really feel like that though…it’s not like I’m having nightmares, you know? I don’t really feel all that shaken about getting captured, just kind of pissed off.” She huffed, annoyed. “I don’t like anybody making me feel helpless.”

 

“I don’t think anybody likes feeling like that,” Claude commented, letting a hint of his own bitterness slip into his voice. He didn’t want to get into his past, but it was a way of showing he sympathized so he could afford a little lowering of his guard.

 

“Yeah, but it’s just…it bugs me when I have to be ‘saved’.”

 

“Hm…so if someone offered you a hand up, you’d slap it away?”

 

Shez blinked, glancing at her friend. “Uh…no, I don’t think so. By’s done that for me, so–Wait, that’s not the same thing.”

 

“You sure? I’m just saying, it’s not a bad thing to rely on your friends,” said the guy who didn’t want to rely on anyone. Claude was aware of his hypocrisy, but hey, being a noble required at least some hypocrisy to function. Besides, if it got his mercenary friend to start relying on him, that was a good thing, wasn’t it?

 

“Sure, I get that, it’s good to have comrades and everything like that. I just don’t like the idea of being saved, you know?” She sighed, annoyed. “It’s…there’s a difference between someone helping you and someone saving you, I think. And I don’t like having to be saved.”

 

“Alright, I get your point,” he said with a lazy smile, “You’d rather not be the princess in a tower waiting to be saved from the demon.” 

 

“Heh. You know, that kind of story becomes really funny when you think of how the only princess we know is Edelgard and she could definitely rip apart any demon that tried to grab her.”

 

“Ha, true! I really can’t see her ever being helpless…though did you know she’s scared of rats?”

 

Shez blinked, then glanced at a grinning Claude. “Really?”

 

“Really, Leonie mentioned it to me. Not what you’d expect, huh?”

 

“Yeah huh. That’s actually kind of cute. Guess she is a noble girl at heart, huh?”

 

“Careful there, she’d probably knock you out if she heard you call her cute. That or Hubert would just poison you.”

 

“Eh, I’ll be fine. Byleth’s their teacher so I’m off limits!”

 

Claude laughed at the smug look on his friend’s face, before lightly shoving her shoulder. “Alright, c’mon, let’s be serious. And no comments about how it’s hypocritical for me of all people to be saying that.”

 

Shez simply kept her mouth closed, though she was still smiling as she walked along with her friend, her earlier exhaustion fading as they went to join the other Golden Deer.

 

"So, just want to double check before we meet up with everyone, you're good with underhanded tactics, right?"

 

"Oh, sure, dad says that stuff is good in a fight and all. Why are you asking?" 

 

"Just wanted to make sure," Claude responded before they came into view of the Golden Deer. 

 

“Hey, there they are!” Raphael called out when he saw them, waving with a big smile.

 

“Ugh, finally. I had to get up early for this, you know? You could at least be here on time,” Hilda complained, prompting a raised eyebrow from Leonie.

 

“I had to wake you up.”

 

“I know! Which is why I got up early!”

 

“Could we please maintain some household discipline for once?” Lorenz requested, something Lysithea nodded to.

 

“Honestly, you’re all so childish!”

 

“Yeah I’m not gonna take that from the class runt,” Emily snarked, immediately earning an offended glare from Lysithea.

 

“How dare you! You’re not even that much taller than me!”

 

“...I’m a good ten centimeters taller than you, kid.”

 

“That’s not actually that tall,” Shez noted, prompting glares from both her friends. “What? It’s not. You’re shorter than Edelgard, Em.”

 

Emily paused in thought, her frown deepening the more she considered that point.

 

“Uh…does height really matter all that much?” Ignatz asked, before flinching when Emily glared straight at him.

 

“Alright, c’mon people, let’s get serious,” Claude said, catching everyone’s attention, “And please save all comments for how I shouldn’t be the one saying that for afterward, alright?”

 

Hilda, Lorenz, and Lysithea all closed their mouths.

 

“Great! Okay, so, good news people! We’re not the most screwed out of the three Houses on the field today! That honor’s going to the Blue Lions, and we actually have a decent shot at winning this because of it!”

 

“I thought you were going to be serious,” Lorenz commented.

 

“I am! This is my serious face.” Claude pointed to his own very serious face. “Right now, we have a number’s advantage on the Lions, but the Eagles have a number’s advantage on us. Adding into that, the Lions have more relics than we do. The fact that we have one is pretty nice, everybody thank Lorenz for that–”

 

“Thank you, Lorenz!” Hilda chirped, prompting a blink from the violet-haired noble.

 

“Oh, well, you are very welcome Hilda–”

 

“Back on topic, people!” Claude ordered, despite branching off topic to begin with, “What I’m saying is that we have a great chance of winning this time around, especially since Lorenz and I came up with what I think is a pretty solid plan for handling our enemies. It takes a bit of subterfuge, which took a while to get Lorenz to agree to, but if we play our cards right here, it’ll be the Deer taking the win from the Eagles and Lions.”

 

“Heh, then what are we waiting for?” Shez asked with a big, eager grin on her face, “Let’s get to it!”

The march towards Gronder Field wasn’t a particularly lively one for the students of the Blue Lions House. As a whole, morale seemed to be fairly low among the folks from Faerghus, particularly seeing as they all felt the absence of one of their classmates all the more keenly now that she was going to be fighting against them.

 

“Is everyone going to be moping for this entire march?” Felix complained after a long stretch of silence, “If so, you all might as well just go back to the monastery now and let me handle the battle.”

 

“Ah, I was wondering when we might hear from you, Felix,” Sylvain commented, “You never did do well with too much quiet.”

 

"Shut up, Sylvain,” Felix said as he scowled. 

 

"While I wouldn't put it like Felix did, I will admit it's important to keep morale up," Dimitri said, putting on a smile. "We might have a lot of work ahead of us, but that doesn't mean we can simply give up before we start." 

 

"And while we may not have the numerical advantage, that doesn't mean we don't have our own advantages," Ingrid added in. "Neither the Golden Deer or the Black Eagles will have aerial combatants aside from that von Nuvelle girl, who might not be the most reliable with how she is out in the sun." 

 

"Which means we'll need to make sure you stay up there, Ingrid. Can't let our ace in the hole get taken out easily," Sylvain said, smirking. 

 

"Not like they'll be able to. The only archer that team has is that Varley girl," Felix muttered, not expecting her to be much help. Even if he did want to know how she was able to disarm him that one time… 

 

"Though we should make sure not to underestimate them. Professor Byleth does seem to be able to come up with plans quite easily," Mercedes noted. 

 

"But as long as we make sure to take out Edelgard, the professor won't be a problem," Ashe added. 

 

"Yeah! The other houses won't know what hit them!" Annette said, pumping her arms. 

 

"Just make sure to be careful. Mock battle or not, it would be unfortunate for anyone to get injured," Dedue mentioned as he followed close behind Dimitri. 

 

"Yes, that is true," Dimitri agreed, before he looked around at his classmates. "Even so, I'm relying on all of you so we can win. Let's make sure to show everyone what the Blue Lions are made of!" 

 

At his rally, the Lions cheered, or in Felix's case, let out a semi-amused huff, before they continued their march to Gronder. 

As she returned from her pre-battle discussion with the other professors, Byleth took the moment to survey the battlefield. While the map of Gronder was detailed, getting an actual view of the field was always a positive. In a sense, there were both positives and negatives to her class's position. 

 

The river meant that the other classes wouldn't be able to easily approach them, but it also meant that her class was also limited in terms of approach. Not to mention it was deeper than it appeared, so trying to cross it would be difficult. With only two bridges, it was fairly obvious where they would be heading once the battle started. 

 

Hm… maybe she should see if anyone was interested in learning to use flying mounts, or if they could learn warp magic…

 

"Professor, I trust the discussion with the other teachers went well?" Edelgard asked once Byleth arrived where her class was waiting. 

 

"Yes, it was nothing major, just wanted to make sure we all understood the rules," Byleth answered, before she felt a sudden wave of nausea hit her. Stumbling a bit, she managed to right herself as she placed a hand over her mouth. 

 

"Professor, are you okay?" Edelgard asked, almost reaching over to grab Byleth when she noted how pale she seemed. 

 

"I'm okay, probably just had some bad breakfast." Byleth responded as she drank some water from her canteen before glancing at her students, as well as the assembled soldiers that they were given for this battle. "Are you all ready?" 

 

"Of course we are Professor!" Caspar immediately responded. 

 

"There's no way we'll lose!" Flayn stated, smiling as she did. 

 

"I simply wish to not drag you all down to my level…" Constance mumbled.

 

"As ready as I'll ever be," Hapi added. 

 

"We’re all more than ready, professor!” Ferdinand declared.

 

“I-Is it too late for me to go home?” Bernadetta asked, completely contradicting him, though Marianne did give her a reassuring pat on the shoulder.

 

“Don’t worry, I’m sure we can do this…I hope….maybe…”

 

“I am most ready, professor!” Petra declared while Linhardt sighed next to her.

 

“I really should have argued that I should sit this one out…”

 

“Well, if everyone is really ready, then why don’t you give us a speech, Edie?” Dorothea requested with a smile, “I’m sure that will raise morale!”

 

“A fantastic idea Dorothea!” Ferdinand said, not noticing how Dorothea’s smile fell at his agreement, “It is only natural that our future Emperor give us all a rousing speech to start the day!”

 

Edelgard sighed under the onslaught of enthusiasm. “Very well.”

 

Byleth stepped to the side, letting Edelgard take “center stage”, as it were. 

 

"We've been through plenty this year, but I would not have been able to do it without your help. The banner of the Black Eagles does not just represent the empire, but all of you as well." Edelgard said, as she looked at all her classmates. "Today, we will face whatever our opponents throw at us head on, and achieve victory together! Now let's go, and make ourselves proud!" 

 

Her speech prompted cheers from the more exuberant of her classmates and some of the gathered soldiers, and even the less enthusiastic of the eagles at least cracked some smiles at their leader’s speech. Aside from Ferdinand, who just looked thoughtful.

 

“Hm…it could have been longer,” he commented, prompting a sigh from Dorothea.

 

“Ferdie, the battle starts in ten minutes.”

 

“Still!”

Chapter End Notes

Red: And here's the lead up! Next chapter, we have the battle proper!

Indi: Just some pre-battle thoughts before everyone goes into the battle.

Red: And some set up for how things will probably go. Regardless, next one's going to be big!

Indi: Things will be hectic during the battle, but we hope y'all will enjoy it!

The Grand Battle at Gronder Field

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

“Another year, another battle,” Seteth commented from his place atop the cliff overlooking Gronder Field. Beside him stood Rhea, and on her opposite side stood an unexpected face. “I didn’t think you would be joining us, Captain Jeralt.”

 

“Eh. Both my kids are participating, so I might as well watch,” the grizzled captain replied, before glancing at the standard bearer behind him, “You got that flag alright? I could hold it instead.”

 

“Huh? O-Oh, no, I’m fine. Thank you for the offer though, sir,” the cavalier replied, prompting an amused noise from Rhea.

 

“Jeralt, you are the captain of the knights,” she reminded, “You should not be trying to take up your subordinate’s tasks.”

 

“I’d argue that me being the captain is a great reason to take up the jobs people don’t want,” he replied, “I’m not really leading well if I’m not willing to help out, right?”

 

“I-It’s fine, captain! Really, it’s an honor to be holding up the church’s flag like this!” the cavalier insisted.

 

“Alright, if you say so.” Jeralt shrugged, before glancing at Rhea. “So, do you usually just stand up at the cliff here?”

 

“I do, yes. It is a good vantage point for watching the battle.”

 

“Sure, but I mean do you usually stand here the whole time? You don’t bring out any chairs?”

 

“You’re the captain of the knights,” Rhea repeated, still clearly amused, “You can stand.”

 

“Fine, but I’m going to complain the whole time.”

 

“Really now? Whatever happened to that stoic and stalwart young man that was always so serious when he stood by my side?”

 

“He grew up, Rhea. It happens.”

 

Rhea sighed, a little fondly. “It always does, doesn’t it?”

 

Meanwhile, beside them, Seteth was side-eying all of that as he started wondering if Rhea was being completely honest with him about Jeralt being “just a friend”. Though, no, Jeralt had been married to Rhea’s daughter, he wouldn’t be flirting with her…though, Seteth didn’t really know Jeralt that well…and maybe he had a type?

 

His thoughts on the matter would have to wait as some of the knights at their side began to play on their trumpets. Composing himself, Seteth looked out over the field, watching all the students and the soldiers ready for the battle. He looked over at the standard bearer, before nodding. 

 

"It is time." With that, the flag was raised and immediately they heard the rallying cries as the students charged forward. 

 

The Battle of Eagle and Lion had begun. 

Charging through the forest, Shez kept a toothy grin on her face as she led the squad that was an integral part of Claude's plan. 

 

"Shez, hold on, you're not supposed to strike out on your own!" Or she would be, if Lorenz hadn't volunteered to 'lead' the squad first. 

 

"Come on, Lorenz, you're on a horse! If you can't keep up, that's on you!" 

 

"And what about the rest of us?!" Lysithea shouted, doing her best to keep up from the back. 

 

"Aw, need someone to carry you?" Emily teased, getting Lysithea to scowl. 

 

"Hey, come on now, we can save the fighting against each other for after we win!" Balthus said, rounding out their squad. 

 

"There will be no such thing!" Lorenz shouted back, frowning as he held Thyrsus in one hand. "Now keep your wits about you-" 

 

Be it by his own skill or the relic weapon he held, Lorenz was able to raise a barrier in time to block a Thoron spell aimed straight at him. 

 

"Aw, I was hoping to even the playing field a bit." Came the ever melodic voice of Dorothea, almost making them miss the sound of a familiar whip sword cutting through the air until Balthus deflected it, getting a slight cut on his forearm where his gauntlets did not fully protect him. 

 

"Hm, this is a bigger challenge than I thought we'd face right away," Byleth said as she, Caspar, and Dorothea walked out from behind the trees. 

 

"It doesn't matter how many there are, we'll take them all out!" Caspar said, gripping his axe. 

 

"Hmph, it seems Lady Edelgard is underestimating the Golden Deer if she thinks you three are enough to face us," Lorenz said, keeping a barrier up. "Even if she wields the Sword of the Creator, the Professor isn't the only one with a Relic!" 

 

"You hear that Professor? Lorenz is getting quite the big head. Though here I was thinking all nobles were good with math," Dorothea mocked. 

 

A slight rustling in the trees above them was the only warning Emily got as she swung her saber above her, catching Petra’s blade as the Brigid girl attempted a sneak attack, before jumping away as it failed. 

 

“Hello Emily! It is good to be seeing you again!” Petra called out with a smile, holding her sword at the ready.

 

“Heh, likewise! Outta that bunch of pricks, you were almost tolerable,” Emily replied, grinning too, “That and I always did want to see what you were made of~”

 

“Ah, this is your taunting, yes? Then I will be looking forward to the spilling of your guts as well!”

 

“That’s more of a threat than a taunt, Petra,” Dorothea commented before calling down another bolt at Lorenz, who deflected it with his staff and tried to return with a wave of magic arrows.

 

“Hm.” Byleth made a mental note to talk to Lorenz about his use of the relic afterwards, noting that he seemed unused to wielding a staff instead of a lance, while also catching her sister’s swords with her own as Shez went straight for her.

 

“Heh, don’t tell me you’re getting distracted on the battlefield, By! Who was it that always told me to pay attention to my surroundings?” her sister teased, pushing down with her pair of blades. Before she blinked at how pale her sister looked. 

 

“The same person who told you not to start chatting with the enemy mid-battle,” Byleth reminded, before shoving forward to knock Shez back and bringing her sword up to catch a ball of darkness that nearly collided with her. “Good use of distraction though.”

 

“Aw, thanks!” Shez replied, beaming, before swiftly moving between Byleth and Lysithea, blocking the professor off from targeting the group’s caster.

 

“Hmph.” Lysithea frowned, trying to find a good angle of attack, then taking note of Balthus getting into a fight with Caspar. He’d already knocked away the smaller boy’s axe and the two were exchanging blows with their fists, so maybe she should back him up–Then she noticed a plume of smoke rising in the distance. “What in the world!?”

 

“Hm? My word, is that–” Lorenz was about to ask, staring at the clear flames on the other side of the trees, before he grunted as a returning volley of Sagittae collided with his chest and sent him crashing to the ground.

 

“Sorry Lorenz, but you know what the professor says, no getting distracted on the battlefield!” Dorothea chided with a perhaps overly large smile.

 

“Ugh…you do have a point, Dorothea, and I suppose this is my loss–Hey!” Lorenz yelped before he could finish his speech as Lysithea grabbed his staff from him.

 

“I need it more than you!” was her prompt response before Lysithea used Thyrsus to launch a ball of light straight for Petra, catching her in the side and knocking her off her feet.

 

“...Why do all my fights get interrupted?” Emily complained, frowning, before just moving right along to try attacking Dorothea, who caught her swing with a levin sword. “Huh? Since when do you–”

 

“Since the professor suggested we all bring back-up weapons,” Dorothea replied with a grin, “Surprised?”

 

“A little, yeah. Thought you were some type of songbird.”

 

“I’ve been called that, certainly, but all birds have talons, my dear Emmy, and I always was decent at swordplay up on stage~”

 

"Heh, guess I'll have to clip those talons," Emily taunted a smirk on her face, pushing Dorothea back as she got ready to attack. 

 

Meanwhile, Lysithea charged up another spell and aimed at Caspar, waiting for Balthus to give her a clean line of attack, until Shez suddenly grabbed her arm. 

 

"What do you think you're doing!?" Shez asked, a little panicked as she stared at Thyrsus in her hands. Did she not know what happens if you use a relic without the right crest?

 

"Wha–Why did you interrupt me!? I know what I'm doing!" Lysithea shouted back, trying to yank her arm free. Noticing Byleth moving to help Caspar against Balthus, Shez made an executive decision. 

 

"Everyone, pull back! Balthus, knock over some trees!" Shez shouted, pulling Lysithea closer to pick her up as she began to run away, much to both her and Emily’s displeasure. 

 

"You got it!" Balthus shouted, punching Caspar in the gut hard enough to wind him before immediately knocking some trees over to cut off the path as they moved away. 

 

Frowning as the Golden Deer got away, Byleth couldn't help but wonder just what exactly Lysithea was doing. She had a minor crest of Charon, so why would she so readily jump to using the Thyrsus…? 

 

"So, professor, what exactly is going on over there?" Dorothea asked, healing Caspar so he was still good enough to fight. Meanwhile, Petra had been knocked out from the earlier attack, so that was one of theirs down. 

 

"Ah, that's Hubert's plan." 

 

"Of course Hubie would start a fire…" 

 

"Don't worry, it's under control," Byleth said, before gagging when she felt some bile rise up her throat. She braced herself against a tree, trying to keep steady as she felt another pang of pain in her stomach. 

 

"Professor?!" Dorothea exclaimed as she moved over to her, concerned that she might have gotten hurt during the fight. 

 

"Just some stomach issues. I can still fight,” Byleth responded as she tried to clear her throat. "Come on, the sooner we win the sooner I can rest." 

 

"If you say so, professor!" Caspar shouted, before a thought occurred. "Oh, should I carry Petra somewhere first?" 

 

"I already admitted my loss, so I might as well carry Petra out," Lorenz conceded as he bowed to the Eagles. "I must say, it really is impressive how you were able to keep up with us. I see my father was right when it came to saying how skilled you are, Professor Eisner." 

 

Byleth smiled in response, trying to ignore how much her stomach was killing her as the Black Eagles continued on. 

When the battle had commenced, the Blue Lions vanguard immediately rushed towards the central platform of the battlefield. Keeping a smirk on his face, Sylvain led the charge of cavalier soldiers, using their fast mobility to reach it as quickly as they could. 

 

"No offense Ashe, but a part of me wishes Mercedes kept using a bow so she'd be the one riding with me," Sylvain commented to his passenger. 

 

"...None taken?" Ashe responded, not really sure what to say to that, before focusing back on the central platform. "Ah! The Black Eagles are about to take it!" 

 

"Really? Eesh, can't let us have any advantage huh?" Sylvain asked, before bringing his hand up to his mouth and letting out a loud whistle, signaling to Ingrid to flank them. Moments later the sight of pegasus knights began to fly down, slashing at the Black Eagles before rising back up before they could retaliate. As mean as it might be, Sylvain found himself a bit amused that among the spells aimed up at the Pegasus, there was also the occasional arrow that missed by a wide margin. 

 

Though if anything her failure to take down Ingrid seemed to motivate Bernadetta to run faster, since they saw the mousey girl sprint to reach the top of the platform and collapse by the ballista. 

 

"Well, it seems we're gonna need to do some scaring," Sylvain muttered, before raising the Lance of Ruin and aiming at the platform. "Charge!" 

 

Pulling out his own arrows, Ashe began to fire as well, aiming at any soldier or Black Eagle that was on the platform. 

 

"AAAH! HUBERT YOU SAID IT'D BE SAFE UP HERE!" The two heard Bernadetta yell while she took some more wild shots. 

 

"It appears I miscalculated. Oh well, nothing to do-" 

 

"EVERY BERNIE FOR HERSELF!" Bernadetta shouted again, before immediately running away. 

 

"Wait, Bernadetta!" Flayn called after her, following behind her despite just reaching the top of the platform. "The enemy is the other way!" 

 

"Honestly, why is it so difficult to find good help nowadays?" Hubert grumbled as he was left alone with a couple of knights, who didn't seem like they would be able to hold off the cavaliers and pegasus knights.

 

"Sorry buddy. If it helps, I'll make sure to apologize to Edelgard for you," Sylvain said with a smirk as they reached the top. Once they did, Ashe hopped off the horse and aimed his bow at the mage before noticing a…distinctly sweet smell. 

 

"Is that so? Well I'm afraid that'll have to wait until after the battle," Hubert smirked as a small fire appeared over his finger. 

 

Eyes widening, Ashe began to back away. "Sylvain, watch out–!" 

 

Up in the air, Ingrid's eyes widened in shock as she saw the central platform go up in flames, a surge of panic hitting her before she realized Hubert had set the sides of the platform on fire instead of the platform itself, surrounding the group in flames instead of outright setting them alight–Jerking back, Ingrid was barely able to dodge an arrow aimed straight at her head. Following where it came from, she spotted Bernadetta who let out another volley of arrows alongside some archers, with some of them being able to take out her fellow knights. 

 

"Retreat!" Ingrid shouted, falling back, only briefly noticing that Flayn cast a rescue spell to extract Hubert from the ring of fire before the Church’s knights could do the same for him while they rescued everyone else, disqualifying them in the process. "They tricked us…" 

 

As much as she didn't like it, she couldn't help but admit the plan was brilliant. None of them expected Edelgard to nearly take out three of her classmates to wipe out the Cavaliers and two of the Blue Lions. It actually made her worry about what she might do next.

 

A worry that was shared by her professor and house leader.

 

“Did they really set fire to the central platform!?” Hanneman exclaimed, audibly baffled, “That’s been there for decades now! That ballista was practically an antique!”

 

“Hm. Edelgard certainly has a ruthless side to her,” Dimitri muttered as he stared at the growing flames. He took note that some pegasus knights from the church were actually flying over to put it out with a mix of wind and ice magic, so the whole thing wouldn’t be completely destroyed. Still, it was quite the move to make in what was meant to be a school exercise.

 

“Yes, it is rather impressive,” Hanneman admitted, misunderstanding Dimitri’s comment, “Even if it is an extreme decision…well then, your highness, now that our strategy of seizing the high ground has quite literally gone up in flames, what do you propose?”

 

“Hm…LIONS! HOLD FIRM!” he called out, catching the attention of his classmates, “Our foes have to come to us if they want to win–”

 

“Isn’t that what lost you the last mock battle, boar?” Felix yelled back, a scowl on his face, “You can’t tell me you actually want to hold back now, especially after those Adrestian bastards nearly roasted Sylvain!”

 

“That’s not–”

 

“Felix! That is an entirely inappropriate attitude to take towards your commanding officer!” Hanneman shouted back with a frown on his face, “You can’t bring these squabbles to the battlefield, especially when you have no idea what your enemy might do next!”

 

“Golden Deer spotted to the east!” called out one of their scouts, catching all their attention.

 

“Damn it, is Claude really pressing the attack right now?” Dimitri asked, readying himself for the crafty Leceisteran to make an appearance.

 

“Ah, no your highness! It’s Miss Eisner, actually!”

 

That prompted a blink. “What? Why would Shez be–”

 

“Ha, looks like I really will be getting a good fight today!” Felix declared before heading towards the merc, prompting a grimace from Dimitri and a sigh from Hanneman.

 

“Right, clearly Felix’s discipline issues are far greater than I realized…Regardless. Your decision, your highness?”

 

“Well, it seems our foes have indeed come to us.” And knowing Shez, he really couldn’t afford to just leave her be. “Everyone, we’ll handle the Eagles in time! For now, we strike at the Deer!”

 

Meanwhile, towards that end of the field, Shez paused as she spotted the stone platform surrounded by people in blue. “Wait, that’s not our base.”

 

“Wh–Shez?! Did you really carry me towards the enemy!?” Lysithea snapped, before trying to push off her friend, “A-And let me down already!”

 

“Oh, right, sorry–Crap!” Shez wound up dropping Lysithea completely as she had to bring her swords up to block Felix’s sudden strike. “Gh–Oh, hey Felix!”

 

“This isn’t the time to chat, it’s time to–!” And then Felix was clocked by a passing Balthus.

 

“No time for you, kid, we’ve gotta take down that prince!” the muscular former Wolf/current Deer declared, sprinting towards the source of the most points. He didn’t get all the way there since Dedue moved to intercept him, blocking the buff brawler with his shield and nearly delivering a fight ending blow with his mace if Balthus hadn’t managed to disengage.

 

“Better get moving or you’re gonna fall behind, Shez!” Emily called out as she ran past, heading towards the prince too, though she had to deal with some blasts of wind from Annette and balls of light from Mercedes on the way.

 

“Wait, we’re just going for it then–Ah, crap, sorry Lys!” Shez apologized, grabbing Lysithea off the ground and yanking her up. “You okay?”

 

“...” Lysithea spat out a clump of grass, then glared at Shez, who looked increasingly sheepish. “...Never do that again.”

 

“Oh, sure, you got it. Though I think we need to fight the Lions now.”

 

“Oh please, I can handle that,” the youngest deer declared, before stepping forward with sigils of light and dark magic forming around her hands.

 

Across the field, Dimitri frowned as he saw his friends engaging their enemy classmates. A part of him wanted to jump into the fray, but Shez hadn’t joined in yet, so all he could really do was order their reserve soldiers to go aid his classmates– 

 

“Hm? Is that Lysithea?” Hanneman wondered, prompting a confused glance from Dimitri who looked in the direction his professor was staring–And then he promptly tackled Hanneman off the platform.

On the other side of Gronder Field, Edelgard felt a frown come to her face after she knocked out yet another Lion-affiliated soldier that had decided to try to charge the Eagle's fortified line. “That explosion wasn’t one of ours, was it?”

 

“Don't tell me you had Hubert blow up another part of the field, Lady Edelgard,” Ferdinand chided from atop his steed, frowning down at his house leader.

 

“I didn’t. Though I can’t deny the possibility Hubert decided to do so anyway…” Her vassal could try to go over her head when it came to some matters, though she was fairly certain he didn’t have some back-up plan to kill one of the other class leaders during the battle. His fire plan was already pushing things and he actually talked to her about it beforehand.

 

Speaking of explosions though, she did notice a series of yellow sparks shoot up from Constance’s position up in the air, their class’s morose flier proving particularly helpful as she indicated what Claude happened to be planning.

 

Edelgard jumped back, noting the padded arrow that went flying by her face as she turned towards her rival house leader. “Hello Claude. I was wondering when you would be making an appearance.”

 

“Well so much for the element of surprise,” the heir of Riegan complained as he jumped down from the trees with a mock-frown that turned into his usual grin, “That numerical advantage of yours is coming in really handy, huh?”

 

“A leader knows how to use what she has, particularly when it comes to negating whatever advantages her enemy might have.”

 

“Still, sending two squads just to wreck my and Dimitri’s plans? It definitely throws off my divide and conquer plan.”

 

“Where is the rest of your house anyway, Claude?” Ferdinand asked, “Also skulking through the treeline?”

 

“I could ask you the same. Even ignoring your two interception squads, aren’t you missing three mages?”

 

“They’re not missing,” Edelgard denied, “They just stayed on the other side of the bridge to flank your attempt to ambush us.”

 

On cue, a number of magical blasts slammed into the treeline, followed by several yelps and screams. From what Claude could make out, that was probably Raphael and Ignatz getting taken out already, which left him with Hilda and Leonie to back him up. Well, that and his surprise.

 

Still, he made a show of sighing in annoyance. “Well there goes that plan. It’s a shame, I really was hoping I could get you too stretched thin to counterattack.”

 

“Consider it a lesson for the future, Claude,” Edelgard replied with a proud smile, “Quantity and quality will always win out against someone who has neither.”

 

“Oof, going right for the throat there, your highness.” He smirked. “Unfortunately for you, I did have one more plan.”

 

She raised an eyebrow, not yet approaching him. And while it was reasonable for her to be cautious, Claude did feel a little amused at the thought that she could end things here just by pressing the attack. Having a reputation for tricky schemes did tend to keep people on guard. “And what might that be?”

 

“Easy. It’s the rat at your feet.”

 

He wasn’t expecting her to shriek that loudly the moment his words registered and he couldn’t help but laugh when she buried her axe straight into the ground at her feet. “A-Ah…nh, that wasn’t funny–”

 

“You cur…”

 

Claude blinked, not expecting Ferdinand von Aegir, the second-most pompous noble in the monastery, just behind Lorenz, to actually sound genuinely pissed off–And then he was ducking a spear thrust that, were it not padded, probably would have taken his head off.

 

“Woah! Ah, hey, Ferd, I think you might be–”

 

“You would make a mockery of what she went through!?” Ferdinand snapped, continuing to press an attack that felt a lot more lethally intended than Claude felt was appropriate for a mock battle.

 

“Uh, what? What was–” He jerked to the side, letting the spear miss his head, then blinked when it smashed straight into the tree behind him hard enough to break the wood. “...I’m gonna run now.”

 

“GET BACK HERE, CLAUDE, AND TAKE YOUR THRASHING LIKE A NOBLE!” Ferdinand shouted as Claude took off running into the wood, all while Edelgard stared in genuine shock at her “shield’s” unexpected rage. Which, wait…did he know about…?

 

She shook her head, focusing back into the moment. It was a question for later. For now, she should hurry after them to make sure Ferdinand didn’t actually kill Claude. Though maybe a bit of thrashing was justified…

 

Claude, meanwhile, wasn’t quite in fear for his life yet, though he did make some mental notes about what would startle Edelgard but aggravate Ferdinand and that there did seem to be something deeper there. More than that though, he was kind of disappointed he didn’t actually get to do his big plan reveal–

 

“Oh, hey, Hilda!” he called out upon spotting his friend hiding behind one of the trees.

 

“Claude? What are you–What happened to the thing you were gonna–”

 

“Change of plans, save me from Ferdinand!”

 

She blinked. “From Ferdinand–”

 

To her credit, she did move pretty quickly once she spotted the orange-haired noble about to slam his lance into the side of Claude’s head, catching it instead on the head of her axe.

 

“Ah, Hilda. So you weren’t taken out by the volley of magic earlier,” Ferdinand noted, bringing his spear back around and stabbing towards the pink-haired girl.

 

“Nope! If there’s one thing I’m good at, it’s staying out of the way of trouble!” Hilda said, before trying to close the gap in almost direct defiance of her previous statement. Something Ferdinand was actually unwilling to let her do, instead backing up while stabbing forward with his lance to keep her at bay.

 

“Ha! As the professor says, the main advantage all lance wielders have is range!” he said with a grin, some of his usual demeanor returning, “You cannot break through my defenses if you cannot reach me!”

 

Then Hilda grabbed his lance and ripped it out of his grip before throwing it into the trees.

 

“Ah ha, a foolish choice!” he declared, promptly pulling out a sword, “The professor also said to always have a back-up weapon!”

 

And Hilda promptly smacked that out of his hands too.

 

“And yet I planned ahead and brought a third weapon!” Ferdinand declared while pulling out an axe–And then a padded arrow smacked him in the face.

 

“Alright, that was getting silly,” Leonie said from her perch in the trees, before glancing at Claude, “Hey Claude, what happened to that big plan of yours?”

 

“It’s still going on!” he called back, his earlier confidence returning now that there wasn’t a redhead after his head, “I’m sure by now our new friend’s managed to take out their line of–”

 

A small fireball caught Leonie in the chest, knocking her down from her perch with a yelp right before Hilda just barely caught a blunted axe on her own before it could take her out of the game completely.

 

“Hm, good reflexes,” Edelgard noted, before pushing harder and actually getting her fellow axe wielder to buckle.

 

“H-Heh, thanks, but it’s nothing special,” Hilda replied, before gritting her teeth and trying to push back against the…actually taller girl, huh. “What the heck, you’re taller than me?”

 

“Yes? You didn’t notice?”

 

“Not really? We don’t hang out much.”

 

“Hm, true. Well we could always rectify that.”

 

Hilda blinked. “Okay, never thought you’d invite me to hang out.”

 

“Hey Edelgard, could you please stop trying to poach my classmates?” Claude requested as he aimed his bow at her, “Seriously, we only just made up for Marianne leaving with Shez joining.”

 

“Didn’t you ‘poach’ one of mine in turn? You really have no room to complain,” Edelgard replied, keeping her focus on Hilda. Which was understandable considering they were having an axe clash, but Claude did still feel a little insulted.

 

“You mean Emily? Oh sure, she’s been doing great with the Deer, way more sociable than she ever was with you Eagles. Guess she just needed time to spread her wings?”

 

“Claude, as fun as this kind of banter, sort of flirting thing is to listen to, could you just shoot her already?” Hilda requested.

 

“Aw, but I still haven’t even gotten to unveil my secret plan!” Claude complained, audibly amused.

 

“You can gloat after you actually beat the person we came to take out!”

 

“Yeah, alright. Sorry Edelgard, it’s been fun, but–” And then Claude was struck by lightning.

 

“My apologies for interrupting your climactic showdown,” Constance apologized as her pegasus touched down, her hand still outstretched and sparking with the remnants of the thunder spell she cast, “I know a wretch like me has no place in intervening in a clash between such brilliant lords–”

 

“You did fine, Constance,” Edelgard replied as she disengaged from Hilda, who let out a little sigh that was half-relief, half-disappointment.

 

“Well there goes our win…you just had to gloat, huh?” she said, pouting at Claude, who coughed out a bit of smoke. 

 

“Well…so much for that…” And he flopped backwards, ending the Golden Deer's chances of winning the battle.

 

The sound of trumpets began to ring out, signaling the defeat of the deer. 

 

"Hm, Constance, not that I don't appreciate the help, but why did you land?" Edelgard asked, glancing at the blonde.

 

"My apologies, but despite how worthless I am, your plans would go awry if I were taken out. Once the young Almyran boy was able to take out Lindhart and Hapi, he aimed to make me fall from the sky like I deserve." Her explanation made Edelgard blink. 

 

"Cyril?" 

 

"Yeah, apparently Claude got permission to let him join the class,” Hilda explained, “That little kid is actually surprisingly good with the bow." 

 

"Hm… I had heard he was apprenticing under Shamir…" Well, it was a good thing Claude focused far too much on his gloating. "Constance, I need you back in the air. Send the signal: everyone is to regroup so that we can finish off the Blue Lions!" 

"Gotta say, Manuela, I knew you were impressive, but I didn't think you'd be this good with the sword," Dorothea said, complimenting her former mentor. 

 

"Don't knock yourself short Dorothea, it seems my colleague has been teaching you well," she complimented back as their blades clashed, all while Dorothea’s classmate and professor dealt with the soldiers Manuela had backing her up. 

 

"Well I did have two very good teachers to show me how to fight," Dorothea complimented, before charging her magic though the sword to try and shock Manuela. Pushing her back, the older songstress felt her arm get a bit numb and wasn’t able to move away fast enough to prevent a shock that made her grit her teeth. 

 

"Well, it seems this won't be easy," Manuela grumbled, getting ready to cast a spell before she heard the trumpets sound out. "Oh, great, guess that means we lose." 

 

"Aw, I was hoping to be able to face off against you," Dorothea muttered, a pout on her face.

 

“Heh, I suppose we can't have everything~" Manuela teased as she glanced over at the other professor and student there, the latter who was on the ground panting in exhaustion. The former, however…

 

"Uh, Byleth, are you okay?" Manuela asked, concern evident in her voice as she saw the former mercenary hunched over. 

 

"Yeah, I'm good. Just-" Whatever she was about to say was cut off as she threw up. 

 

"Professor!?" Dorothea shouted as she rushed over to Byleth. "Are you okay??" 

 

"My stomach feels like it's stabbing me," Byleth managed to get out before she threw up again. 

 

Frowning, Manuela walked over to Byleth as she pressed a hand against her back as a green glow settled over it. 

 

"...Byleth, I think you've been poisoned." 

 

"WHAT!?" Caspar shouted, finding his second wind once he heard that despite all the knights he’d had to fight through. 

 

"Oh…who would poison me?" Byleth asked, audibly confused and equally audibly sick.

 

"I think we should focus on getting you some medicine first," Manuela said, helping Byleth up as Dorothea got on her free side to also help her stand. 

 

"Yeah, I don't think you should stay on the field, professor." 

 

"Yeah, that sounds like a good idea…" Byleth agreed, trying not to throw up again. "You don't need to help me off the field, Dorothea." 

 

"Nope, I'm helping you get to the medical tent." 

 

"Yeah, don't worry professor, I'll make sure to tell Edelgard what happened, so don't worry!" Caspar chimed in, his energy fully returning…for about a second before he had to take a second to catch his breath. “Oof, feels like an afternoon training with dad…”

 

“Caspie, you come along too,” Dorothea insisted, “We can have someone else tell Edie what happened.”

 

“Aw, c’mon, I can–”

 

“No arguing from the injured and exhausted!” Manuela firmly stated, before continuing to pull Byleth along, who was looking pale and sweaty as she tried her best to keep the contents of her stomach from spilling out again.

 

Though a thought did occur to her. “Oh, Manuela, you might want to talk with Lorenz about how to wield a magic staff, it seems he isn't used to fighting with something that isn't a spear–Ghm-”

 

“Yes, yes, you can give me notes once we get you to the infirmary, professor, now come on!”

 

"Okay," Byleth managed to get out as she took in deep breaths. "Good work, Caspar, Dorothea." 

 

"Heh, no need to thank us professor, it's thanks to you we made it this far." 

 

"It was Edelgard’s plan," Byleth deflected as they approached the medical tent. 

 

"Still, I’m not sure how well things would have gone if you weren't here to teach us. You two make an amazing pair, you know," Dorothea praised.

 

"You're incredible as well. Starting to think I might need to learn magic from you." 

 

"Hm, is that so? I don’t know, Professor Dorothea doesn't have the same ring to it as Professor Byleth." 

 

Manuela let out a small huff, unsure if she should speak up with this obvious, if odd, flirting going on. Well, for now, she'd just focus on what exactly Byleth was poisoned with and help with that. 

 

"Oh, the signal," Byleth muttered as an image of an axe and a spear clashing appeared in the air, courtesy of Constance. "Hopefully everyone is okay."

Edelgard frowned as she glanced over in the direction of the Golden Deer encampment, wondering if something happened to her classmates since no one had come over even after the signal had been sent. Had they experienced more trouble than they expected? A fair number of the deer's stronger members hadn't been part of the group meant to ambush her, so it's possible… 

 

Leaving Shez and Balthus aside, she still wasn't aware of Kronya's full strength, and Lysithea was a veritable walking magic bomb with her crests. A part of her wondered if she reached out towards the mage and admitted she had dual crests as well, would she be willing to come to the empire? 

 

She let out a small sigh. No point in focusing on that now. 

 

"It seems it's just down to us,” Hubert muttered as he glanced over to the remaining Eagles. Constance was still in an aerial battle against Ingrid while Marianne and Flayn healed the princess and her retainer. "That Ingrid is certainly a tenacious one. I think Bernadetta is going to have nightmares for weeks with how she dived down at her to destroy her bow." 

 

"Is she okay?" Marianne asked, worry evident in her voice, though she unintentionally flinched as Hubert turned his gaze towards her. 

 

"Oh, she's fine!" Flayn said with a smile. "It might have been terrifying, but Ingrid didn't hit her! Bernadetta only panicked and ran away, saying she couldn't fight anymore even though she still had a spear on her." 

 

"Hm." It seemed Bernie still needed a bit of help with her confidence. Edelgard shook the thought off, facing her remaining classmates. "Well, even so, with these numbers we'll be able to defeat the Lions with ease, especially since their remaining forces are likely tired from fighting the Deer." 

 

“You’re not incorrect, Edelgard.”

 

The group of Eagles all paused, then looked towards the voice that just interrupted them, finding, who else, Dimitri along with his two remaining Lions, Dedue and Annette. 

 

Hubert promptly tried to blast the crown prince with a ball of darkness, though it was blocked by Dedue’s shield as the large student glared at his counterpart. “Ah well, can’t blame me for trying.”

 

“I think I can, Hubert.”

 

“Our retainers’ rivalry aside, hasn’t anyone told you it’s rude to eavesdrop, Dimitri?” Edelgard asked as she stepped forward, axe in hand.

 

“I’ve been told that, yes. Though I do think it’s somewhat more rude to nearly set your classmates on fire.”

 

She shrugged. “The flames were controlled. I wouldn’t set my own people ablaze.”

 

“Uh, doesn’t that mean you’re fine with setting us on fire?” Annette asked.

 

“Is there a point to this?” Edelgard asked, ignoring the question since she doubted the Lions would like her answer, “Or did you just want to get the last battle of the day over with? Unless you wish to surrender outright. I would be quite happy to accept that outcome.”

 

“No, I think I still have enough of a chance for surrender to be unpalatable,” Dimitri responded, “But, in the interest of avoiding further possible injuries, I was wondering if you would consent to a duel between the two of us, Edelgard.”

 

"It seems your side is the one who needs to worry about injuries," Edelgard said, noting how their healer had apparently been taken out. Little did she know that Mercedes had actually stayed behind because Dimitri accidentally cracked Hanneman’s ribs with that tackle of his.

 

"Hence my request. Come now Edelgard, I'm sure you are also wondering who would win in a match between us," Dimitri said, leveling his spear at her, hoping to egg her on. "Or are you saying you can only fight me with someone backing you up?"

 

Edelgard frowned at his taunt, about to decline it before she paused. While he was clearly trying to go for his only chance at winning, it was also a good chance for her. Her numbers were also low, and without the professor there to aid them, it left her as the only melee combatant, which could leave her allies in danger if Dedue rushed…

 

"...Hmph. Very well. I must admit, I have been curious about crossing blades with you. As the house leader it's only right I bring victory to my house," Edelgard said, approaching Dimitri. 

 

"The same goes for me," Dimitri responded, as the two met in the middle of the houses, their weapons in hand as they prepared to fight. 

 

Taking a deep breath, both heirs faced one another before they charged, signaling the final match of the Battle of Eagle and Lion. 

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Sadly no big confrontation between Shez and Byleth here, mainly because they'd end up decimating Gronder.

Red: Well, on a decent day they would. Byleth probably wouldn't be up for it this time around.

Indi: Yeah, turns out that poison Claude made was actually kind of effective, even if it didn't hit the target he wanted.

Red: More effective than intended, really. But, well, you never know how somebody might react when you tamper with food. That's why it's a bad thing to do!

Indi: As for how the battle will end, well we'll see next time!

Red: See you then!

The Final Clash and Aftermath

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

The clash of weapons echoed out over Gronder Field amidst gasps and cheers from the crowd surrounding the pair of royals battling one another. Encouragement was shouted from both sides, though it was noticeably louder on the Black Eagles side of things, if just because there were slightly more people.

 

"D-Do your best,” Marianne tried to cheer on as Edelgard dodged a stab towards her face, moving in quickly to strike with her axe.

 

“You can do it, your highness! I know you’ll win this!” Annette yelled, watching her future king block the heavy hit before retaliating with a swing of his lance.

 

“You’re almost there, Edelgard!” Flayn pumped her fist, a big smile on her face as she saw Edelgard bat aside another strike with her shield before charging in.

 

“Go for it, Dimitri! Beat her down!” Shez encouraged, prompting a surprised look from Annette.

 

“Shez? Why are you here?”

 

“Huh? Oh, I heard there was a fight going on over here so I came by to watch.”

 

“...Can you do that?”

 

Shez shrugged. “Nobody said I couldn’t.”

 

Meanwhile, off to the side, the pair of retainers stood side by side as their lieges battled.

 

“...You know, I don’t plan to intervene in Lady Edelgard’s duel,” Hubert stated, glancing up at Dedue, “You don’t need to watch over me.”

 

“Were you in my position, would you believe that?” Dedue asked.

 

“Hm…that is fair, I suppose. It is fascinating being on the other side of suspicion like this though.”

 

Back to the fight itself, Edelgard blocked more strikes from the prince of Faerghus, noting how his strength was actually putting dents in her shield. It would be impressive were she not on the other side of it. As it was though, she might need to get a new shield after this battle.

 

From a defensive position, she could study her foe, and it led her to the conclusion that staying on the defense simply wasn’t feasible. He wasn’t tiring, he was strong enough to potentially break through her defenses entirely, and his longer reach lowered the chance of successful retaliation. So she decided to take a page from her professor’s book, starting by throwing her shield at his face when there was a brief lull in his onslaught.

 

Dimitri ducked on instinct, eyes widening at the unexpected move, but he was a trained fighter and he didn’t let his distraction last long enough to be taken advantage of, lunging right in and catching Edelgard’s axe as she swung in a wider arc than he expected, using one hand and catching the shaft of his spear on the dull blade, pushing it as she closed the gap and, before he could fully piece together what she was doing, driving her fist straight into his stomach.

 

Dimitri choked, spit flying from his mouth as the air was driven from his lungs. He tightened his grip, trying to prevent himself from dropping his spear outright, then winced when he heard the sharp crack of wood as he wound up breaking it instead. With the wood splintering, Edelgard had a free opening to slam her axe into his chest in a blow that knocked him fully off his feet and to the ground with a rough thud, another grunt slipping out as he hit the dirt.

 

“Your highness!” Annette gasped while Shez let out an annoyed groan.

 

“Dang it. That’s twice today the guy I backed lost…”

 

"That's it, that's the end of the Battle of Eagle and Lion! And the winners are, the Black Eagles!" Seteth called out, his voice being enhanced to call the battle. 

 

"You've certainly gotten quite strong, Edelgard," Dimitri noted, sitting up as he reached a hand up, asking for help to get up. 

 

"No need for the praise," Edelgard said, grabbing his wrist to pull him up. "We might have won, but it could have gone the other way if we faced off against one another again." 

 

"Still, you were quite remarkable." 

 

"Not sure how remarkable using sheer numbers can be," Claude chimed in as he walked up, bandaged from his earlier lightning strike. "Really hoping we never have to fight for real." 

 

"Yes, that would be regrettable," Dimitri agreed, rubbing his sore chest. 

 

"Hm. Oh, Shez, were you the one to defeat the professor?" Edelgard asked, pivoting away from that. 

 

"Huh? Wait, By got taken out?" 

 

"I would assume so, since she didn't come once the signal was launched," Edelgard said, neither of the two noticing Claude stiffening for a moment. 

 

"Weird. I mean, I guess they might have fought Manuela and the knights she had, but last I remember she still had Dorothea and Caspar aiding her, so I don't think Manuela could have taken her out…" 

 

“Ah, ha, uh…about that…” In most circumstances, Claude wouldn’t have spoken up. Hell, he hadn’t before this point out of somewhat foolish hope that things would pass without incident and he wouldn’t have any problems. But if Professor Byleth was actually getting sick from his slip up…well, a part of him did still want to evade the consequences. “I think she might’ve eaten something bad, actually. She was looking sick earlier.”

 

“She was?” Shez asked, immediately worried, while Edelgard frowned.

 

“When did you see Professor Byleth? She was in an entirely different part of the field.”

 

“Just a little while ago, as I was heading over,” Claude answered, an excuse easily coming to him, “I was coming from the medic tents and I saw her going there with Manuela.”

 

“Wait, she’s feeling that bad? Right, okay, I’m gonna go check on her,” Shez decided, nodding to everybody, “I’ll catch up with you guys later! Just gotta make sure she’s okay, you know?”

 

“Oh, of course Shez,” Dimitri agreed, which did prompt a small frown from Claude since the blond prince wasn’t her house leader anymore and shouldn’t be making that call, “Actually, do you know what she ate? We might need to check the food stores if she actually is experiencing food poisoning.”

 

“Oh, uh…no, sorry, I wasn’t paying attention. By tends to eat a lot anyway, so, y’know,” she replied, bouncing her leg a little anxiously to get going.

 

“Well if it was food poisoning, it might have to do with the poisoned food Claude attempted to feed his fellow house leaders two days ago,” Hubert offered. 

 

“Eh? Really? You think it was–” It took a second for Hubert’s words to fully register for Shez, and when they did, there was a visible flash of orange in her eyes before she managed to rein it in. "What?" 

 

"In my defense, it's non-lethal," Claude quickly said as Shez glared at him, "And you said you were okay with underhanded techniques." 

 

"I meant kicking someone in the dick!" 

 

"Putting aside your apparent attempt to poison me,” Edelgard spoke up, annoyed, “If the professor wasn't your target, why didn't you give her the antidote?" 

 

"I mean, I haven't made one yet," Claude admitted. 

 

"Honestly, this is why amateurs shouldn't mess around with poisons. If it was me, I would have just used a sedative," Hubert joked, getting most of the students to stare at him in shock, while Shez, and to a lesser extent Edelgard, glared at him. 

 

"Look, Hubert, the only reason I'm not punching Claude is cause he's my friend. I don't know you that well." 

 

"So you're saying I should start with you?" 

 

"Ha, good luck with that, I made myself immune to poison!" 

 

"...What?" Surprisingly, it was Marianne who spoke up first. 

 

"Yeah, I used to eat a bunch of poisonous mushrooms to build up my immunity. I actually started by casting a mire spell on myself, but that was a bit too obvious so I got grounded. With the mushrooms though, it just looked like food poisoning." 

 

"..." A silent feeling of horror fell upon the students as they stared at Shez. 

 

"...Shez, I'm not religious, but why in the name of the goddess would you do that?" Hubert asked.

 

"To get stronger, duh." 

 

"How are you still alive??" 

 

"Cause I'm strong!" Shez shouted, completely ignoring the blank stare that Arval, the entire reason she made it past thirteen, was giving her. 

 

"...Can we go check on your sister?" Arval asked. 

 

"Oh, right, I need to check on By!" Shez shouted before she ran away, heading directly to the medical tent and leaving baffled schoolmates in her wake.

 

“Shez, please don’t burst into a medical tent without announcing your presence,” Manuela chided as Shez did exactly that, though the mercenary pretty much ignored her professor in favor of going to her sister’s bedside.

 

“By!! How are you feeling, what happened?! Wait, I know what happened–How are you feeling!?” Shez questioned, earning a somewhat exasperated sigh from her sister, who looked like shit and was holding a bucket. One that smelled pretty bad already so Shez was not putting her face anywhere near there.

 

“Hi Shez. Did my class win?”

 

Shez blinked. “Is that seriously the first thing you want to ask?”

 

“Yes. Did we?”

 

“...” Shez frowned, annoyed. “No, my class won.”

 

“Don’t lie to me, I was with Manuela when your class was eliminated. Did the Lions or the Eagles win?”

 

“...hmph. Eagles.”

 

“Yay–” Byleth stiffened, before putting her face in the bucket and vomiting, which made Shez wince.

 

“...What would you have done if I said the Lions won?”

 

“Mhff…been sad. Probably still vomited too. Just with sadness.”

 

“...Well I’m glad your vomit was happy?”

 

"There you are Professor," Edelgard said as she entered the tent, a bit of worry in her eyes as she glanced down at the bucket. "How are you feeling?" 

 

"Glad we won." 

 

"...I'm not sure if that's what we should be focusing on." 

 

"Here you go professor!" Dorothea chimed in as she entered the tent holding a small bottle. "I managed to get Hilda to give this to me, it should help. It's one of her floral oils, so it'll help with the smell." 

 

"Oh, thank you," Byleth said, as she took the bottle with a free hand. "...Do I drink this?" 

 

"Professor, no," Dorothea denied as she took the bottle and opened it. "Just hold it under your nose when the smell starts to get overwhelming." 

 

"Right," Byleth agreed, trying to focus on the bottle.

 

"Honestly, what was Claude thinking?" Edelgard muttered. 

 

"Hm?" 

 

"He apparently poisoned you." 

 

"...” Byleth looked more confused than angry. “Why would he poison me?" 

 

"Cause he was trying to poison Edelgard and Dimitri so they'd be sick during the battle," Shez helpfully explained. 

 

"...Oh." Her sister frowned and narrowed her eyes. "He shouldn't do that." 

 

"By, please get angry at him poisoning you instead of him almost poisoning them…" 

 

"I am angry at that, but I’m also angry that he tried to poison his classmates. Well, not quite classmates, more like–urp-” And back to the bucket she went.

 

Edelgard winced, before glancing at Manuela. “Will she be okay?”

 

“She should be. The poison seems to induce flu-like symptoms, for the most part, so while that is dangerous, she should be fine with some added healing and bed rest. From what I can tell, the main reason it’s this bad is because she kept fighting through the symptoms instead of bowing out earlier.” She sighed. “I suppose we’ll have to postpone any celebrations. Especially since we’ll need to discuss Claude’s punishment for poisoning a professor and attempting to poison his fellow house leaders. I'm also bound to get in trouble as well since I didn't even notice he was planning something like this." 

 

"Oh, you don't have to postpone any party because of me," Byleth tried to say. 

 

"Nonsense, professor,” Dorothea retorted, “It wouldn't be the same without you." 

 

"Dorothea is right,” Edelgard agreed, “Celebrating without everyone after a hard won victory would feel rather hollow."  

 

"It wasn't that difficult, it was an easy victory," Byleth said, an amused expression on her face.

 

"Hey, that's not what you said earlier!" Shez shouted, "You said the fight would be difficult!" 

 

"Did I? I don't remember," Byleth claimed, looking away from her sister.
