"I suppose it's okay to let victory go to our heads this time," Edelgard said, a smile coming to her face. 

 

"Yeah, I mean, two houses were aiming for us, and poisoned our professor, but we still won,” Dorothea commented, “Just goes to show which house is the best~" 

 

"Well I won't disagree with that. In that case, we'll need to celebrate after you recover, professor," Edelgard continued, looking over to see Shez poking Byleth in annoyance. 

 

"Yes, we can celebrate our easy victory," the professor replied, ignoring the finger jabbing her shoulder. 

 

"It wasn't that easy!" Shez immediately responded, making Byleth laugh. 

 

A full beat passed as the students there realized they were hearing her laugh. 

 

"...h-hm, yes, I'm looking forward to it," Edelgard said, blushing a bit. 

 

"Heh, you have a lovely laugh, professor," Dorothea noted as she giggled. 

 

"Oh, thank you-" And Byleth once again put her face in the bucket, cutting the heartwarming scene short. 

Claude felt some sweat trickle down his back as he came to the conclusion that he had vastly underestimated just how much trouble he would get in for poisoning a professor. He probably should have thought it through some more, and probably should have worked faster on the antidote, but he thought he’d calculated the risk well enough.

 

Now though, as he faced down the angry glares of the archbishop, her chamberlain, and the captain of the Knights of Seiros, he was starting to think he might be bad at math.

 

“Claude,” Seteth began, apparently electing to be the first speaker of the trio, “What in the world possessed you to attempt to poison your fellow house leaders?”

 

“...Competitive spirit?” he tried, which was a bad move considering Rhea literally growled at him.

 

Seteth didn’t look any happier. “Claude. You attempted to poison the house leaders of Black Eagles and the Blue Lions. Not only are they your classmates, who you should know not to harm in such a way, but they are the Imperial Princess of Adrestia and the Crown Prince of Faerghus respectively. And you, the future sovereign duke of the Leicester Alliance, decided it would be acceptable to poison them. Do I need to state why that idea should have never entered your head to begin with?”

 

“...” Claude had to admit, he should have seen this coming. It seemed simple enough, just get both of them and have it be blamed on a stomach bug. Easy, simple, got rid of two competitors before he had to deal with them, nothing he hadn’t done before. The problem, as he was discovering, was that they didn’t laugh things like that off in Fodlan. “I was hoping to get an advantage in the battle. I was told it was supposed to be treated like a real war, so I thought some…dishonorable tactics could be allowed.”

 

“They are not,” Rhea stated, her voice low and furious, and Claude found himself reminded that this was the woman who really ran the continent of Fodlan. “If you had succeeded, you very well could have started a war between every nation in Fodlan, you stupid boy.”

 

He winced at the insult, fighting down the urge to bristle at it. “It wasn’t–”

 

“I don’t care if it was a minor poison meant to induce sickness!” she snapped, shoving herself up from the desk, “The act alone would be enough to justify the entirety of House Riegan being accused of attempted assassination and put to the sword because of it! Derdriu would have burned because of your attempt to gain ‘advantage’! And yet, even as disaster was averted by mere luck alone, you still managed to poison a professor of this academy!” She glared at him, and maybe it was a trick of the light but it seemed like her pupils narrowed. “Give me one good reason not to have you expelled from the Officer’s Academy here and now.”

 

“...” Claude did the only thing he could think of. He bowed his head. “I’m sorry. I didn’t think. All I can say is that it seemed like a good idea in the moment, and I didn’t think about what consequences there could be. I’m sorry Professor Byleth was hurt because of me, and I’m sorry I ruined what should have been the biggest event of the year. I screwed up, and I accept full responsibility for it.”

 

“...” Rhea still glared at him, internally warring with the protective instincts that told her to damn all reason and have the boy thrown from the monastery’s walls, before Jeralt nudged her. She turned her gaze towards him and found her captain staring calmly back, his own anger hidden completely. “...hmph.”

 

Rhea sat back down, still annoyed, but willing to let Jeralt step forward.

 

“Good that you’re at least willing to admit your mistakes, kid,” the captain of the knights commented. Whatever anger he might have felt, he wasn’t letting it show as he decided to play the mediator here. “You screwed up, like you said, and that means you’re going to need to make it right. So how do you do that?”

 

"Well…I definitely need to apologize to Teach. As for how I'll make up for it…I feel like that should be up to her. I can say plenty of things I'd do to make up for it, but if she isn't satisfied with it, then it'd mean nothing." 

 

“...” Jeralt sighed. “Alright, good answer, kid. I can accept that.”

 

Claude couldn’t help his slight smile. “Thanks–”

 

“But that doesn’t mean you’re off the hook.”

 

Claude paused. “Uh…in what way?”

 

“In the way that Rhea’s still pissed off, and I don’t think you’re getting out of here with just an apology.”

 

“I am right here, Jeralt,” Rhea chided.

 

Jeralt gave Claude a pat on the shoulder. “Feel free to start groveling at any time.”

 

“...” Claude got the feeling that Jeralt was a lot angrier than he let on. If anything, despite being the only one scowling, Seteth seemed to be the least angry out of the three of them. As he got down on his knees, Claude couldn't help but note that it was definitely interesting how angry Rhea was about Byleth in specific. 

"Hey, Teach, how are you doing?" Claude asked, knocking on Byleth’s door even as he opened it.

 

"Oh, hi Claude," Byleth greeted from her bed, which…well, she still looked a bit sick, but she wasn't angry, so maybe that was a good thing? "Why did you poison me?" Scratch that. 

 

"Well…I wasn't exactly planning on poisoning you. It was just a sort of backup plan." 

 

"Okay, why did you think that was a good idea?" 

 

"Aw, come on Teach, I'd have thought a mercenary would be more understanding," Claude joked, hoping to ease the tension. 

 

"Yes, because I'm a mercenary. You're a noble." Byleth frowned. "There are different standards." 

 

"Oh? That's a surprise to hear." 

 

"It shouldn't be. Like I said, I understand wanting to use poison, but that doesn't mean I'd use it. As a mercenary, I might use dishonorable means in battle as needed, but there's still supposed to be some sense of conduct. If word spreads out that Jeralt’s Mercenaries use poison, we'd receive less contracts because we'd be looked down upon. That goes even more so for a noble. 

 

“A noble, especially one who will become Duke, is expected to act in a certain manner. If this had been an actual war, yes, your method could have gotten you victory, but then your allies would look upon you in suspicion. If someone is so willing to blatantly use poison just to get an advantage, then what's to stop them from using other methods their allies don't agree with?" 

 

"...You know professor, not that I'm trying to argue, but doesn't one of your students threaten to poison people all the time?" Claude pointed out.

 

“Hubert’s just like that. Besides, his position is different. He’s not the lord, Edelgard is. He might be noble, but he’s ultimately subordinate to her and that means he has different standards that apply to him. It’s understood that he’s Edelgard’s bodyguard, and that means it’s accepted he might be more willing to take harsh actions that she wouldn’t.” Byleth shifted slightly, folding her legs under the blanket and sitting up straighter. “If Edelgard poisoned someone, it would signal to everyone that she’s willing to use dishonorable tactics in a way that violates standard convention. If Hubert poisoned someone, it would be understood that he’s doing it to protect his liege.

 

“Even then, there would likely be consequences for it, depending on the circumstances, and that’s why he’s the one doing it. Hubert’s willing to take any blame that might fall on Edelgard otherwise. As long as Edelgard’s hands remain clean, he’s served his purpose, even if that means he’ll be regarded as someone who can never be trusted.”

 

She shifted again, before moving the pillow behind herself to prop herself up better. “You also have to consider the context. No one likes poison because it takes a moment you should be safe and makes it threatening. If everyone says ‘Claude will poison you at meals’, then no one will be willing to take meals with you. All of a sudden, eating with you is a danger, and one that can’t be looked past once that reputation sticks. If you, the poisoner, offer food at a negotiation, then that’s not a peace offering, it’s a threat. It doesn’t matter if you mean it genuinely, it doesn’t matter that you’re trying to be nice, the mere idea that you might have poisoned it will stick with people, and soon you’ll find that no one’s really willing to eat with you.”

 

“...Eesh, when you put it like that…” It was almost funny. Here he was, a guy who loved celebrations and feasts, who never once felt safe at meals. Not until he was sure no one had decided the ‘half-breed’ should have an ‘allergic reaction’ again. “I guess I see your point, Teach. I messed up. I’m sorry.”

 

“Apology accepted. You should probably apologize to Dimitri and Edelgard for the attempt too, make sure there are no hard feelings. And you should talk to your classmates about it too.”

 

Claude blinked. “Huh? Uh, why’s that?”

 

“Because you didn’t tell them you were planning to do something like this. That means you either didn’t trust them to know about your plans, or you thought they would stop you and wanted to do it anyway. It shows you don’t have any confidence in your allies and means now they’ll have to worry that you’ll make decisions without any input from them at all. That’s dangerous for any group, since it means people might start looking to break away from you rather than be associated with someone dishonorable, but it’s especially dangerous for you because you’re not a prince, you’re a noble among other nobles. 

 

“Dimitri can expect the other Lions to follow him because they’re loyal to his family. Edelgard can expect the other Eagles to follow her because they’re loyal to her throne. Their higher positions mean the other nobles are obligated to follow her. Meanwhile, Lorenz, Hilda, and Lysithea are your equals in standing, and Marianne would also be if she hadn’t joined my class instead.” …Was that a subtle dig at him? “Add in that Leonie, Ignatz, Raphael, and Balthus don’t have any reason to be loyal to you unless you’re willing to employ them, and a move like this could be taken as proof that you don’t trust any of them. That’s dangerous.”

 

“...Hm.” The problem was…he actually didn’t trust any of them. He could trust that they’d work with him while their interests aligned, but actually telling them about his plans…

 

“Oh, and Cyril’s probably going to be mad because Rhea’s upset with you.”

 

“Ha, yeah, that sounds about right. Maybe he’ll simmer down when I mention part of my way of resolving things involved promising an increase in ‘donations’ from Riegan once I graduate.”

 

Byleth blinked. “...Claude, did you bribe Rhea?”

 

“Yes,” he replied, shamelessly, “Though it’s more like she extorted me.”

 

“Huh.”

 

“I also can’t help but notice you didn’t bring up Shez there, Teach.”

 

“Well yeah, she’s obviously mad at you. I didn’t think I needed to say it.”

 

She didn’t, but it did kind of hurt to hear her confirm it. Well not really ‘hurt’, it just…felt bad. Kind of.

 

"The fact that you don't have a black eye or something is probably the best sign that she is willing to forgive you. Also, and this is my personal opinion, I don't think you're good for her." 

 

"..." Well that last bit threw him for a loop, especially with how serious she was. "Come on, Teach, there's no need for jokes here. It's not like I was actually trying to date her. No way in hell I'm getting in Lysithea’s way. Or Emily’s for that matter. They can start going at each other's throats, not me." 

 

"Good, then all you have to do is start showing some trust in others," Byleth advised, "I understand that there are times where you aren't sure if you can trust someone, but if you're going to be fighting together, you have to extend some trust. I'm not saying to go around, and tell everyone all your secrets, but they should at least know what you're planning when it comes to a fight." 

 

"...yeah, alright," Claude muttered, before shaking his head. "Well, before I go, is there anything you want me to get you?" 

 

"I'm good." Byleth said, before pointing towards the corner of the room. Turning his head, Claude paused as he saw the frankly absurd amount of flowers and medicine that had been tucked away, likely all from the students. 

 

"..." 

 

"I'm quite popular," Byleth said, a smile on her face. Maybe it was a trick of the light, but to Claude’s eyes, it seemed vaguely smug.

Chapter End Notes

Red: It's kind of funny how Claude-focused this chapter turned out.

Indi: Ye, is kinda funny in retrospect. But hey so ends the battle with the Eagles winning!

Red: I'm sure some people are disappointed, but it shouldn't have been that big a surprise. Byleth did pick their house, after all.

Indi: And hey its not like it was a clean sweep. Most of the Eagles were taken out, and Byleth still got poisoned, though she's doing better.

Red: Yup! I'm sure she'll be up and moving by the next chapter or so. Gotta actually have that celebration, after all.

Indi: And I'm sure it'll be a nice and chill celebration.

Red: For sure, for sure. And for now, thanks for reading!

After the Aftermath

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

"You know, Professor Byleth probably got lucky she got the flu, otherwise Seteth would have lectured her for hours. I have a feeling he's probably pretty pissed that Flayn was involved with that scheme the Eagles had," Sylvain commented. "Probably not happy his sweet little sister was in danger there." 

 

"I don't see why you aren't more upset, you were almost set on fire," Felix said through a scowl. 

 

"Eh, not really. Sure the horses got spooked but the fire was actually pretty controlled," Sylvain added, before smirking "Though I didn't know you were that worried about me, Felix~"

 

"I wasn't!"

 

"Still, we should have realized something was up with how three support fighters were the ones leading the charge on that end," Ingrid muttered, "If Sylvain hadn't taken the moment to taunt, things would have ended up very differently for them." 

 

"Eesh, please don't tell me I'm going to get blamed for us losing." 

 

"Then take things seriously next time," Felix snarked, looking away from him in a huff. 

 

Letting out a sigh, Ingrid leaned back, not wanting to get caught up in Felix's bad mood. Though as she did, she noticed someone she wanted to speak to. 

 

"Hey, Bernadetta," Ingrid called out to the archer, making the young noble squeak. 

 

"Y-Yes?" She asked, eyes widening as she saw who was calling her. "A-Ah! S-Sorry for attacking you!" 

 

"...There is no need to apologize," Ingrid said, keeping her voice even. "I just wanted to talk, I'm a bit surprised about the plan you helped pull off. Were you forced to do so?" 

 

"Wh-what? N-no. I mean, it was s-scary, yeah, but Edelgard and P-Professor asked if I was okay w-with it," Bernadetta explained, forcing herself not to run away under the blonde’s scrutiny. 

 

"Really? Then that was all acting?" 

 

"O-Oh, n-not at all. Th-Those relic weapons are really scary! A-Ah, n-not that I'm saying you're scary for using them!" Even if she did feel like they were. 

 

"Hm…I see," Ingrid noted, before letting out a sigh. "Regardless, it's our loss. I'll make sure to learn from this experience." 

 

"A-Ah, are you saying you're gonna come after me for revenge!?" Bernadetta squeaked out, before running away. "Forgive meeeeeee!" 

 

"..." Shaking her head, Ingrid decided not to think about that right now. 

In the training grounds, the sound of wood impacting cloth sounded out as Ashe struck a wooden dummy with a spear. The young man had a frown on his face as he stabbed forward, remembering how he wasn’t able to do anything in the battle to help his teammates or even take out one of their opponents. Feeling frustrated, the former thief vowed to get stronger– 

 

"Oh, I didn't expect to find someone here." Blinking at the sudden voice, he looked over to see Ignatz walking into the training grounds. "I hope you don't mind if I join you." 

 

"Oh, I don't," Ashe replied, pausing in his own training. "I didn't think anyone else would come by here." 

 

"Ah well, I wasn't planning on coming here earlier, but I wasn't much use in the Battle, so I was hoping to get a bit of training in." 

 

“Right, I can understand that.” Ashe laughed a little, scratching at his head. “I’m just…I’ve been trying to be a knight, but I don't know if it’s going that well.”

 

“Oh, really? I, ah…well, I think I’m much the same, actually,” Ignatz admitted, “I’m here to become a knight for the sake of my family, but…well, I guess I can’t help but feel a little useless right now.”

 

“...Useless, huh?”

 

“Yes, it’s…well, it’s rough to admit it, but I’m not sure I really have a place here…Even aside from the fact that I’m a commoner among nobles, everyone else in my class is just so impressive! Even the other commoners, Raphael, Leonie, and certainly Shez, they’re all just so much better than me at fighting. I don’t have muscles like Raphael, I’m not much better at a bow than Leonie, and I’m certainly not a one man army like Shez.” He sighed, smiling ruefully. “I guess all I have to do is try to get better at what I can do, right?”

 

"Yeah, I know that feeling. I'm good with picking locks, but that skill doesn't really help in combat," Ashe admitted with a sigh. 

 

"Well, I'm sure you can still become strong enough to be a grand knight." 

 

"Thanks for saying that," Ashe said with a smile, before pausing. "Do you want to train together?" 

 

"Oh, are you okay with that?" 

 

"Well, if we're going to be here commiserating together, we might as well do it while training, right?" 

 

"Aha, I can see the logic there," Ignatz agreed as he smiled. "In that case, I hope I don't drag you down." 

"Lady Edelgard, you wished to speak with me?" Ferdinand asked upon entering the house leader's room. 

 

"Yes, please close the door behind you," Edelgard said, pushing herself up from her desk. 

 

"Of course." He responded with a smile as he did as she requested. "To what do I owe the pleasure?" 

 

"Ferdinand… what did you mean by 'what I went through' during the battle against Claude?" she asked, getting the noble to falter for a moment. 

 

"A-Ah, well, clearly it was wrong of him to use any fear of an opponent during combat to get them to drop their guard." 

 

"That's not what I meant," Edelgard said, her tone sharp, "Do you… know what happened to me?" 

 

"Ah…" His smile twisting into a frown, Ferdinand sighed. "...Yes, I know what my father did to you." 

 

"...How long have you known?" 

 

"A few months after your uncle had passed away," he admitted, his hands clenched into fists. "I was going to ask my father if we could visit you, when I chanced upon a meeting he was having with a suspicious individual named Myson… I wasn't able to catch all the details, but I heard them talking about the… experiments they did to you." 

 

"And why didn't you say anything?" 

 

"Because I couldn't believe it! My father, the man I idolized… how could I believe he would do that to children?" Ferdinand asked through a strained expression. "But, the more I thought about it… the more I saw how different you were… I tried to search for evidence, but either my father hid it well, or he destroyed what evidence there was." 

 

"Is that why you coddle me then?" 

 

"It was the only way I could think to make it up to you…" 

 

"I don't need to be coddled, Ferdinand," Edelgard stated, standing at her full height, and somehow making the taller noble feel small. "What happened has already happened. I don't need to be protected from something I already survived." 

 

"Then what was I supposed to do!? The more I dug, the more I found out how many crimes my father had committed! Yet I was unable to find enough evidence of any of them to prove…if at the very least I can make sure nothing happens to you again, then-" 

 

"I'm not a child, I don't need a caretaker," Edelgard interrupted him. "If you want to make up for it, then treat me with respect." 

 

"...You know, it is oddly amusing. Back when you were announced to be the heir, I couldn't help but scoff at the idea. Edelgard, of all people becoming the emperor? That child who would never separate herself from her older sisters or mother? I was even planning on taking it upon myself to challenge you, to see if you were worthy of being Emperor but…you went through all that, and still you remain so strong…" Ferdinand muttered, his eyes downcast. 

 

"If I am to ensure no one is to go through something like that again, then I cannot be weak. An Emperor does not need a nanny." 

 

"...You're right. My apologies, Edelgard." 

 

"Thank you," Edelgard responded, her eyes softening after a moment. "If you are to be my shield, I expect honesty." 

 

He looked up, surprise flashing in his eyes. "You would still have me?" 

 

"Despite your…eccentricities, you are still a valuable ally, Ferdinand. I swear that I will help you make your father see justice for what he has done. Though perhaps we should clear the air with Hubert first. He has had many things to say about you trying to be my retainer." 

 

"Hmph, well I have several things to say about him as well,” Ferdinand replied, settling back on familiar ground, “The retainer of an Emperor should not skulk about like he does." 

 

"Please don't start arguing with him…" Edelgard requested, letting out a sigh and hoping the headache she felt coming didn't actually arrive. 

"I can't believe we lost," Lysithea muttered, angrily staring at the tome she was reading, until she heard someone knock on her door. "What?!" she called out, annoyance clear in her voice. 

 

"...I brought some sweet buns," Shez called out from the other side. "Figured we can have a snack before the feast later." 

 

"..." Marching up to the door, Lysithea pulled it open, snatched the plate of buns from Shez, and tried to close the door. 

 

"H-Hey! Wait a moment!" Shez said, managing to stop the physically weaker girl from closing the door on her. 

 

"Shut up, I don't want to talk to you right now!"

 

"But I do!" Shez said, managing to get into the room. 

 

"Ugh… you know, if it wasn't for you, we would have won," Lysithea complained, frowning as she took the plate of sweet buns for herself. 

 

"Okay, a bit harsh, but winning that fight didn't matter as much as making sure you were fine. Why did you try to use Thyrsus? Don't you know what happens if you try to use a relic weapon without the right crest?" 

 

"Of course I do." 

 

"Then why did you try to risk yourself like that? The fight wasn't serious enough to do something like that." 

 

"I wasn't risking myself!" Lysithea snapped back before she bit down on a sweet bun. 

 

"Look, I don't know if you've seen what happens to someone if they use a relic weapon, but I did. That thing would have turned you into a monster–" 

 

"I have a crest of Gloucester!" Lysithea shouted. 

 

Shez blinked. "...Huh? Wait, what do you mean? I thought you had a crest of Charon?" 

 

"...I do. I have both," Lysithea admitted, looking away from Shez, "That's what I wanted to tell you about before. The reason I'm so…naturally Inclined to dark magic is the same reason I have two crests." 

 

"Ah…do you want to talk about it?" Shez asked, trying to speak softly.

 

"Hmph… back when Hrym tried to revolt, my family tried to assist them. We were punished for it and the empire sent several people to keep an eye on us…" Frowning, Lysithea took another bite from the sweet bun. "Among them were several mages who…experimented on us. The end result was that I gained a second crest, but even that was considered a failure to them…" 

 

"What do you mean?" 

 

"My body was left weakened…I was never the strongest person beforehand, but I was left far weaker, and…I likely won't live past my twentieth, if I can even reach that." 

 

"What?" Shez asked, feeling her blood run cold. 

 

"That's why they considered me a failure. What's the point in making a powerful mage if she'll die in a decade?” 

 

"That, wait, no, you can't be serious–" 

 

"WHY WOULD I LIE ABOUT THIS!?" Lysithea screamed at her. "This is something I've lived with since I was young! There is nothing I can do about it!" 

 

"..." 

 

"I don't know if it was those people in specific who captured you, but I am certain they worked with whoever did it. I will never forget their sickly pale skin…" 

 

"Th-There has to be something that we can do!" Shez said, not wanting to think about her friend dying, "I mean, you can't have tried everything!" 

 

"I did! Nothing my family could find could remove this crest they put in me!" Lysithea shouted back. "I've accepted my fate, so now all I can do is make sure my family is okay once I'm gone!" 

 

"Well I haven't accepted it!" Shez shouted with genuine distress in her voice.

 

Lysithea stiffened, before glowering at her. "Why do you care so much?" 

 

"I just… I'm not good with people I know dying. So I just don't think about it. But that's always been after they died. What am I supposed to do when someone I know tells me they're dying?" Shez asked, her frown staying. "I don't… want you to leave. I like being around you. Sure, you might be harsh sometimes, but that's just a part of you. And knowing that one day that might just be gone…" 

 

"...That won't change anything. Like I said, my family has already tried-" 

 

"Then I'll find something, I swear!" Grasping her hands, Shez looked directly at Lysithea. "I know I'm not the smartest, but I'll do whatever I can to find a way to help you. So don't give up on life just yet!" 

 

"I-It's not that simple–"

 

"I don't care if it isn't! I'm not going to give up, so you shouldn't! So you better be ready to live a long life, cause I'm gonna make sure you do!" 

 

“...” Lysithea felt herself wavering for a moment as an emotion she hadn’t felt for a long time welled up in her chest. Was she really feeling…hopeful right now? She couldn’t…she couldn’t afford to think like that. But something about Shez…made her want to believe her. “...F-Fine. I suppose we may as well try…Though I am not sure what you think you can do.”

 

“Oh, uh…oh! I know about the people that did this! Kind of? I know they’re from some place called Agartha and Rhea knows about them!”

 

Lysithea blinked. “What? Wait, what??”

 

“Yeah, it’s a whole thing–Here, let me explain. Rhea told me not to tell anybody but I think this is more important,” Shez said, looking around as if she was worried someone might pop out. "After that thing with Tomas, Byleth and I talked with Rhea. She didn't outright say anything, but she seemed to know about them. So the church probably has to have something about them." 

 

"I–Would they?" 

 

"There's a chance they might! Just… are you okay with me telling Byleth about this? Rhea seems to like her a lot, so we might have a chance to learn more about them if we have Byleth ask her." 

 

"...” Lysithea stared at her for a moment, not sure if she could dare to hope, but… “I'll trust you. If you think she can help, then okay." 

 

"Thanks!" Grinning widely, Shez pulled Lysithea into a hug. "I'll get back to you as soon as I can!" Shez said, getting up as she got ready to leave. "Ah, but don't forget the feast! Even if you live a long life, you gotta make sure to live it to your fullest!" 

 

Watching the young mercenary run out, Lysithea could only stare after her as she felt her heart thumping in her chest. 

 

"...I-Idiot," she mumbled to herself, her face turning pink. 

Byleth was feeling pretty good, all things considered. Sure, she’d been poisoned not that long ago, but it passed pretty quickly and she’d gotten so many well-wishes, she honestly felt like it was a pretty fair deal.

 

“Seriously? Don’t be happy that you were poisoned!” Sothis complained, sounding annoyed as Byleth walked along towards the dining hall, where the students and faculty were finally going to celebrate their victory/losses at the Battle of Eagle and Lion. Well, it wasn’t so much that they were celebrating losses as it was they were celebrating doing their best…but also Byleth was going to celebrate the fact that everyone else lost while her class won. “You are a truly ridiculous child…Speaking of children, are you really willing to simply leave things as they are? That Riegan boy poisoned you, and yet he’ll see no punishment for it at all!”

 

“He’s being punished. He had to apologize and bribe the church.”

 

“That is scarcely a punishment! You would think they would seek further retribution, rather than simply pretending your ailment was a simple stomach flu.”

 

Byleth shrugged. “I don’t care about punishment. It’s better that he learned and won’t do it again.

 

“Would you have said the same if one of your students had been poisoned?”

 

“...If Claude had poisoned one of them I would have punched him.”

 

"...Why must I be stuck with a self-sacrificing fool?" 

 

"I'm not self-sacrificing. I just don't like seeing people I care about get hurt." 

 

"Then think about what would happen to me if you die!" 

 

"..." Byleth paused as she thought about, trying to figure out a response to that. "...I just won't die then." 

 

Sothis could only stare at Byleth as she said something that made complete sense to her and her alone. Ignoring the spirit in her head, Byleth continued on to the dining hall, arriving just as the feast was on full swing.

 

"There you are, my teacher. I was starting to worry that you hadn't yet recovered from your illness," Edelgard greeted, a smile gracing her features as Byleth walked in. 

 

"Really? I was starting to think it was something else," Claude said, noticing them. "Guess she isn't mad about being used in a 'sacrifice' squad." 

 

Sothis made an offended noise. “He hasn’t learned anything!”

 

"How many times do I have to say this? It wasn't called a sacrifice squad," Edelgard complained, equally annoyed at his phrasing. 

 

"Well you do have to admit if something had gone awry, two squads of your classmates, as well as your professor, would have been taken out," Dimitri noted. 

 

"I was completely confident in all their skills to be able to accomplish the mission," Edelgard said, before smirking. "Besides, at least I didn't knock out my own professor by tackling them." 

 

"I-I was just trying to keep Hanneman safe!" 

 

"Hey! Let the professor hang out with the rest of us!" Caspar shouted, managing to squeeze through the house leaders and grab Byleth’s arm to pull her towards everyone else. 

 

"Aw, come on 'big bro' you can't pull a girl like that," Dorothea teased, almost making Caspar stumble. 

 

"I am having trouble understanding. Caspar is smaller than you, why are you calling him 'big'?" 

 

"Pretty sure she's just messing with him, Petra," Hapi explained. 

 

"Oh, I see, it is friendly banter!" 

 

"Come now my attendant! It is time for you to lavish praise upon us, especially to me, as my reconnaissance was paramount to our victory!" Constance stated, letting out a laugh as she did. 

 

"I'd prefer being allowed to leave this feast so I can nap," Lindhart muttered. 

 

"Come now Lindhart, where's your sense of comradery?" Ferdinand asked. 

 

"Perhaps he is simply tired from actually helping in the battle? Unlike a certain someone, he didn't end up getting his weapons pulled out of his hand," Hubert mocked, smirking, even as his tone wasn't as sharp. 

 

"W-What was I supposed to do!? Ingrid dived down right at me!" Bernadetta squeaked, misunderstanding where the jab was aimed. 

 

"N-No, you did wonderfully, Bernadetta," Marianne reassured, trying to calm down the Archer. 

 

"Everyone did great!" Flayn cheered, the green-haired girl smiling widely. "I never thought joining a class would be as fun as it is, and I'm glad I joined the Black Eagles!" 

 

"..." Smiling, Byleth couldn't help but feel the swell of joy as she looked upon her students. "All of you were incredible. You've come so far since I first met you, and I'm sure all of you will go even further." 

 

With that, she approached her students and began to give them all a pat on the head, making the students get a bit flustered at the praise. 

 

"Now come on, let's enjoy-" 

 

"Byleth! We need to talk!" Blinking as she heard her sister call her by her full name, the professor felt her hand grab before she got dragged away. 

 

"Shez?" 

 

"Sorry, this is important!" she shouted as she ended up dragging her all the way to her room. 

 

"What's going on?" Byleth asked, a bit worried. 

 

"Okay, this is important. Lysithea and I really need your help," Shez said, sounding completely serious. 

 

"What do you need?" 

 

"You saw how Lysithea tried to use Thyrsus right?" Shez asked, getting Byleth to nod. "She has a crest of Gloucester, along with the crest of Charon." 

 

"What?" Byleth had to hold herself back from asking 'like Edelgard?'.

 

"Yeah, those guys who tried to take Flayn and me were behind it. That's not the important thing though, we need your help to see if Rhea can tell us anything about them." 

 

"Can I ask why?" she asked, wanting to help but also wanting to know why Shez seemed so desperate.

 

"Whatever they did to her…apparently it'll kill her. As far as she's aware, she doesn't even think she'll be alive in five years."

 

"...What?" Byleth asked, feeling her own blood run cold as her mind flashed to Edelgard. 

 

"Just, we gotta do something to help her! So please!" 

 

"...Okay, just give me a bit, I need to talk with someone first," Byleth said, leaving her room as her own mind raced. 

 

Why hadn't Edelgard mentioned that? Did she not know, or did she not want her to worry? 

 

Gritting her teeth, Byleth felt an unpleasant rage she hadn’t felt in a long while swell up again. Whoever these Agarthans were, they were going to pay. 

 

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Secrets getting spilled all over the place.

Red: Very important secrets! Lots more people are getting info about the Agarthans now and it's going to be interesting going forward.

Indi: And some more secrets shall be shared in the next chapter! Shame they won't get to properly enjoy the feast lol.

Red: Alas, tis the nature of celebrations to be interrupted by drama. No downtime! Only problems!

Indi: They'll have downtime eventually! Probably. I guess we'll see!

An Important Talk

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

"Edelgard, can I talk with you?" Byleth asked upon returning to the feast. 

 

"Oh? May I ask why?" 

 

"Something important, if we can talk in private," Byleth responded.

 

"Oh~? Seems like this might be important, Edie. Why don't you go on with her~?" Dorothea asked, nudging her friend. 

 

"I-I'm sure it's nothing like what you're assuming, Dorothea."

 

"Still, you should go on ahead! I'll make sure no one follows to bother you two," Dorothea said, giving her friend another nudge. 

 

"Thank you, Dorothea," Byleth replied, nodding at her student before she glanced at her other student. "It won't take long." Letting out a small sigh, Edelgard got up to follow her.

 

"What did you want to speak about, professor?" Edelgard asked, faintly curious. Staying quiet for a moment, Byleth made sure no one was nearby or trying to listen in, before she faced Edelgard again.

 

"Edelgard, about what you told me about before, about what happened back in Enbarr. Were there any… side effects?" Byleth asked as they stood in a corner of the entrance hall. 

 

"Well… my hair lost all pigmentation for one," Edelgard responded warily.

 

"That's not…" Frowning, Byleth took in a deep breath. "How much longer do you have to live?" 

 

"...How did you find out about that?" 

 

"I found out someone else went through the same thing, and that they might not live long either."

 

"..." Letting out a breath, Edelgard composed herself. "I assume you mean Lysithea?" 

 

"Did you know?" 

 

"I had my suspicions but… nothing I could confirm without asking her," Edelgard said, looking away from Byleth. "Yes, while I doubt my condition is as drastic as Lysithea’s, I did lose a portion of my lifespan. If those that experimented on me were correct, I'll live to be fifty, but not much more. Long enough to live a decent life, I suppose, though it’s entirely possible that my health will start failing earlier." 

 

"...Is there any way to reverse it?" 

 

"In theory, yes. In practice… it is not something I have spent much time on." 

 

"Why not?!" 

 

Edelgard paused, not expecting the sudden show of concern from Byleth. "Because…These crests might be a curse, but I need their power. I already told you what I want to accomplish, Professor. Even if it takes my entire life, I will accomplish my goals. If I can help Lysithea, then I will, but I won't relinquish this power until I no longer need it." 

 

"That… then let's go to Rhea at least, I'm sure she can-" 

 

"No!” she immediately interrupted as a jolt of panic went through her, “Professor, you absolutely cannot tell her about this!" 

 

Byleth blinked, not expecting such a vehement reaction. "Why not? You both have a common enemy with the Agarthans, don't you? 

 

"Do you think the church would be fine with what we are discussing? They hold crests to be sacred above all else, and we are talking about removing them,” Edelgard said, thinking fast, “Do you think Rhea will truly believe us if we tell her we just want to remove a crest from Lysithea and I? Can you swear to me that you completely trust her?" 

 

"I…want to trust her," Byleth murmured, her hesitation obvious. 

 

"But do you?" 

 

She didn’t. She knew that the instant the question was asked. She wanted to trust Rhea, but she just…didn’t. Not when she knew the archbishop was still hiding things from her.

 

“...What do you want me to do then?” she asked, feeling unusually off balance. “I…Shez wants to talk to her, to learn more about the Agarthans so she can try to help Lysithea.”

 

Edelgard felt her heart stop for a moment. If Rhea learned about Lysithea, how difficult would it be for her to learn about Edelgard’s own experiences? Would she think to look? What would she do in that circumstance?

 

She couldn’t assume her enemy was unintelligent, she knew Rhea had run the Central Church for a thousand years, if she was presented with a girl who had two crests and lost the pigmentation in her hair as a result…And what if she did find out? The Church valued crests, Rhea valued crests, if she learned there was a way to grant people more than one crest–

 

“Edelgard?” 

 

Her teacher’s voice cut through her swirling thoughts and Edelgard took a steadying breath. She was strong. She wasn’t going to let what happened to her happen to anyone else.

 

So she fought down the images in her mind of being chained down again, only this time with the Knights of Seiros standing over her instead of those horrible mages in their bird-like masks, and faced her professor again. “I’m sorry to ask this of you, professor, but please refuse your sister’s request.”

 

“...Are you sure, Edelgard?” Byleth asked, the concern in her voice obvious, “It could help.”

 

“It could. But it could also destroy everything I’m working towards. So, please, professor. I promise, I’ll do everything I can to help Lysithea once I am able, but I cannot take a risk in trusting Rhea right now.”

 

“...Okay.”

 

At her teacher’s acceptance, Edelgard felt a swell of relief, though she tempered it when she noticed the conflict present on her teacher’s normally stoic face. “...I presume there is a condition though?”

 

“Yeah. I want you to talk to Shez and Lysithea about it. If I’m going to be denying Lysithea the help she might need, she deserves to hear the reason why.”

 

“...” She sighed. “...That is a reasonable point, professor. I can accept your condition.”

 

It was hard to miss the relief on her professor’s face as she agreed. Edelgard knew there was a risk here, trusting so many with her secrets, but…she wanted to, hypocritical though it may be. 

 

It might be foolish, but she wanted her teacher by her side.

Shez felt sick to her stomach. She’d been surprised when Byleth came back with Edelgard and even more surprised when the two of them asked to talk with Lysithea, but she’d gone along with it and brought her friend over to join in. She hadn’t expected Edelgard’s story though. And the more she heard, the more horrified she felt to have any connection with those monsters.

 

“There will be many things I have to do, but once the year ends, I will be crowned emperor, and I promise to use everything that I have to help you,” Edelgard vowed, “There were some documents left behind at the palace by them, which may assist us in helping you.” 

 

“To think they could even do this to someone like an imperial princess…” Lysithea said, stunned at the revelation. “I had thought it had only happened to my family because of the power we lost…” 

 

“That…are you sure we can’t talk with the church for help?” Shez asked, her head still swimming with all this new information.

 

“Think about it. These Agarthans are a group the populace knows nothing about. I assume your father also had no knowledge of them, and yet he was a knight captain,” Edelgard explained, trying to be rational. Or at least sound it. “We already know the church destroys classified documents, and the Agarthans themselves are likely only known to Rhea as a long forgotten enemy of the church. Even if they still have documents about them, they likely won’t have anything about what sort of abilities they have.” 

 

“...I will admit, I can understand your logic,” Lysithea said. 

 

“Hey, wait,” Shez said as something came to mind. “Why did they leave you alone? Lysithea was supposed to be a ‘failure’ but you were what they wanted right? Then why aren’t you under their control or something?” 

 

“...That is because their former leader passed away, and the one that took over after him seemed to have no interest in trying to leash me,” Edelgard explained, thinking about the Agarthan named Myson who Ferdinand had brought up. The one Bias had confirmed had a hand in the experiments run on her. “Duke Aegir was tasked with keeping an eye on me, but his incompetence led to me having more freedom than they intended.”

 

“...Was it your uncle?” Byleth asked, causing Edelgard’s breath to hitch. 

 

“Huh? What about her uncle?” Shez asked. 

 

“When we first met…you never once seemed sad about your uncle's passing,” Byleth continued, addressing Edelgard, “And he had also been involved with the insurrection, right?” 

 

“...The man I had called my uncle was replaced a long time ago. It likely happened sometime after he took me to the kingdom,” Edelgard said, steeling herself. “Mourning the man I once knew won't change anything. All I can do is march onwards to the future. To that end, Lysithea, once the year is over, will you come to the empire with me? It may be difficult, but if the two of us are there, then a way to reverse this will become that much easier once the time comes." 

 

"...Can you promise me that even if this fails my parents will be okay?" the young girl requested.

 

"H-Hey, don't act like we’ll fail without even trying!" Shez spoke up. 

 

"I'm not! Just…I want to make sure my family is taken care of even after I pass away. That's what I wanted to focus on, but if I am to turn my attention elsewhere, I want your word they'll be okay." 

 

Edelgard nodded solemnly. "I swear it upon the Hresvelg name, that your family will want for nothing. It is the least I can do for how the empire has made you suffer." 

 

"Thank you," Lysithea said, the tension in her body slowly releasing. 

 

"Perhaps it would be best if we retire for the night?" Edelgard suggested. "We can discuss what to do at a later date." 

 

"Ah, yeah, probably for the best. Here, come on Lysithea, I'll help you to your room,” Shez offered. 

 

"I don't need your help," the mage muttered, even as she accepted her hand. 

 

"...I must say, I didn't expect this conversation," Edelgard managed to say after the two left the room. "Though…it feels good being open about this." 

 

"Even an Emperor needs help," Byleth said, relieved that her sister had gone along with their change in plans. "No matter how strong you are, you can't change the world on your own." 

 

"...Perhaps you're right, professor," Edelgard admitted. "You said you would assist me when it came to achieving my goal, correct?" 

 

"Yes. Though I may be under contract with the monastery right now, I'll do everything I can to help you," Byleth said, before pausing. "Though don't let Jeralt know I said that. I don't think he'd appreciate it if I accepted a contract without knowing any details." 

 

"Ever the mercenary, aren't you?" Edelgard asked, letting out an amused chuckle. "Regardless, I look forward to your assistance during my eventual reign." 

 

"I'm looking forward to it as well," Byleth said, smiling. 

 

"Thank you. Now, you should head back to the festivities. It's only right that you get to enjoy yourself." 

 

"Aren’t you coming along?" 

 

"No, there is much I need to think about. Though if you would, could you tell Hubert to come by? I need to discuss what we talked about with him." 

 

"Hm. I can’t say I’m surprised Hubert is already in the know…Very well, just make sure not to stay up late," Byleth requested, bowing to her before she left. Letting out a sigh, Edelgard collapsed onto her bed. She was certainly going to be in for it knowing how displeased Hubert would be about sharing so much. 

 

Still, it felt good being honest, and she would need allies for what she was planning. No matter how long it took, she would gather the forces she needed and change the world, even if it cost her her life. 

"So, how'd it go~?" Dorothea asked once Byleth sat down so she could properly join the feast. "You were gone for quite some time." 

 

"Ah, I just had to talk about something important with Edelgard," Byleth explained, grabbing some meat skewers so she could eat. 

 

"Really? Would that be what you told me about before?" 

 

"Oh… should I have told her about that?" Byleth inquired, a bit curious. 

 

"...well, it might have helped," Dorothea said, internally sighing. "I mean, if you ask me, it does seem like couples are starting to form."

 

"They are?" 

 

"Of course, you just need to keep an eye out," Dorothea explained, glancing around the room for examples. "Hilda certainly seems to be trying with Marianne, and I have to admit, there is something cute about Bernadetta not finding Hubert as scary anymore." She noted as she saw the pink-haired girl leaning close to the blue-haired one, while the anxious archer seemed to be fidgeting a bit more now that Hubert had left. "And you can't tell me Constance doesn't feel something for Hapi. If it was anyone else, she probably would have cast one of those weird spells of hers on them for shoving food in her mouth." 

 

"Huh…" 

 

"Yup yup, so what do you think? Made any progress yourself?" 

 

"Not particularly…" Byleth admitted. Those thoughts had taken a backseat recently. "I talked with Manuela a bit and she gave me some advice but…I think, at the very least, I won't be dating anyone until the year ends." 

 

"Really?"

 

"Yeah. I still don't know how that stuff feels but… for now, I think I want to focus on making sure all of you graduate." 

 

"You know professor, just cause you're in charge of us doesn't mean you can't take care of yourself too," Dorothea noted with a mock pout. 

 

"I know, but… the advice Manuela gave me was to just go on a date with someone, and if I'm being honest, I don't know who I would go on a date with," Byleth admitted. "So for now, I'll focus on this job, and then I'll think about romance." 

 

"Hm…well, if nothing else, I have to admire your dedication," Dorothea praised.

 

"Hm." Bringing the meat skewer up, Byleth began to eat. "Still no luck on your end?" 

 

"Nope. I mean, Ferdinand asked if I wanted to have tea together, and well… tea is one thing, but I can't really see myself spending my life with him. That's not even to go into how bad the others can be. All Felix seems to care about is flailing his sword about, Sylvain is an entire mess unto himself, and Ingrid… she's cute, but she doesn't seem to be interested," Dorothea muttered with a huff. 

 

"Hm… what about Edelgard?" Byleth asked, getting Dorothea to choke on air. 

 

"E-Excuse me?" 

 

"You two are close right? You don't ever seem to say anything negative about her, and even since the start of the year, Edelgard admired the hard work you put in." 

 

"She did?" 

 

"Yeah, even if you came here cause you wanted to find someone to marry, you've still given it your all. I'm sure Edelgard would be happy to be with you." 

 

"C-Come now professor, you certainly chose the weirdest times to joke around," Dorothea said, feeling a bit flushed. Before Byleth could speak, Dorothea stood up. "Anyways, why don't you go hang out with everyone else? I'd hate to take up all your time!"

 

Frowning a bit at how quickly Dorothea left, Byleth couldn't help but wonder if she went a bit too far there. She didn't mean anything bad by it, but…

 

Sighing, she focused on eating for now. Romance should be the last thing on her mind, her students were in danger, and who knows what else would happen this year. Until this was all settled, she would give it her all to keep them safe. 

Chapter End Notes

Indi: You know people have been joking about the love triangle where each end is trying to get the other two together.

Red: Understandably so, it's a fun idea to work with. These goobers all want each other to be happy and yet they forget about their own happiness.

Indi: Yup yup, will definitely be fun having this be a thing going forth. I'm sure they'll figure things out eventually. On a side note, it's been very fun writing Daughters as a slow burn while Simple is not at all.

Red: Yep, we've got quite different stories going on there. So you know, maybe check out that one if you haven't yet.

Indi: Or our other two stories we have going on, they're very different from this.

Red: That they are! One's another 3H story featuring Byleth as a demon, and the other is an Engage story featuring Alear being very dragony. So feel free to check those out too! For now though, thanks for reading!

Interlude - Prionsa

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

“Good people of Fhirdiad, lend me your ears!” 

 

The voice of the king-regent, Rufus Thierry Blaiddyd, Grand Duke of Itha, echoed out through the streets of Fhirdiad, which were almost silent as its citizens gathered in the square in front of the palace, clamoring to see the king upon his stage.

 

“For too long, our proud Kingdom has languished!” His voice rang loud and clear, a shocking sound for many who had never even heard the regent speak. “In the past decade we have suffered greatly! Pestilence, famine, and violence have ravaged our people! Bandits have run free, allowed to steal even our holiest of relics for their own cruel ends! Invaders from foreign lands have threatened what little peace we have, and even the heirs of our great houses have not been kept safe! Mere months ago, the heiress of House Galatea was even abducted by an Adrestian noble and only barely saved by the Knights of Seiros, who should have never allowed such danger to come to her to begin with!

 

“We all know of the tragedy that befell our royal family, wherein my own brother was viciously murdered by the devils of Duscur! And yet despite this horrific crime, we were not brought justice! We had to seize it with our own hands! And that, my people, is why I speak to you today!

 

He thumped his fist against the breastplate of his armor, for a moment looking exactly the picture of a grand warrior king in the eyes of the populace. “I stand here with the knowledge that you have suffered! That we have suffered! For as your king, I weep for every tragedy that befalls our gracious people! And as your king, I swear an oath to you, my people: No more! No more shall we fear the violent, the cruel, and the foreign! We shall stand strong and true, for the Goddess has gifted us with a most gracious opportunity!

 

“As many of you know, the Western Church betrayed Archbishop Rhea.” Not many truly knew that, and there were many gasps among the crowd. “What you may not have known was the true depths of their betrayal, for the Bishop who led that rotted bastion of corruption was in fact a traitor to this very kingdom! For he was the cur who rallied the dogs of Duscur to murder my brother! To murder your king!”

 

Shock and horror spread through the crowd, scandalized gasps ringing out followed by angry calls. 

 

Rufus held up a hand, his head bowed, hushing the crowd. “I know, my people. I understand your fury, for I feel it just as strongly! Yet we cannot falter in this time of trial! The Goddess rewards the stalwart, and so it has been chosen that the Western Church be reformed! A new Bishop has been selected, one who bears no sin of corruption, but has been chosen by our very own Lady Cornelia, she who saved our people from the ravages of plague!”

 

There was a smattering of applause and cheers from plants in the audience, encouraging genuine positivity among the masses as the court mage beside her king bowed her head with a humble smile.

 

“To that end, I present to you Sergei of House Gideon, the new Bishop of the Western Church!” 

 

The man in question wasn’t especially outstanding. He had the standard brown hair of most Fodlaners and a short beard, lending him a slightly more grizzled look, particularly given the suit of silver armor he wore, his helmet held under one arm. He placed a hand on his chest and bowed to the people of Faerghus, a gesture that caught many by surprise.

 

“Good people of Fhirdiad, in the name of the goddess, I promise to serve you faithfully as a sword of the faith.”

 

“Indeed he shall!” Rufus agreed, taking center stage again, “For Faerghus is in need of a sword! No, not merely a sword, but a lance! One capable of piercing through the hearts of those who would do us ill! Thus I have decided Faerghus shall have its lance! A new one, crafted in the honor and faith of our people! And those who wield it shall be the storm, striking with our fury at those who seek our ruin!

 

“Today, my people, I declare the formation of the Tempest Knights! The new Protectors of Fodlan!” He gestured again, prompting a second man forward, one in azure armor decorated with silver lightning. And the man, clad in his gleaming armor, thrust his lance skyward, its body black and its head yellow as a boom of thunder rang out and a bolt of lightning raced from the sky, striking the head and casting the surroundings in a rainbow of color.

 

Shock turned to elation as the citizens of the kingdom saw what could only be an indication of divine favor. Cheers rang out for their king, cheers he had never once heard before. And King Rufus Thierry Blaiddyd smiled, for he finally had the adoration he knew he deserved.

“That was disgusting,” ‘Sergei’ commented once his helmet was back in place, hiding the revolting features of the vermin he’d had to pose as.

 

“Aw, you have no passion for theater, Chilon,” Cleobulus chided, mock-pouting and earning a shudder of disgust from her colleague.

 

“I have no interest in whatever ‘production’ this is meant to be, Cleobulus. I only aid you because–”

 

“Because I have a better chance of actually seeing the vengeance of our people finally be accomplished?”

 

“Because you requested it.”

 

“And you just want a purpose again. That’s fine, I can accept that. So long as you’re willing to play along with me and Rufus.”

 

Chilon sneered. “‘Rufus’? You care for the vermin’s name?”

 

“Ha! Ah, Chilon, you really are such a simple man. Then again, you did earn your sagehood through strength and stature…regardless, Rufus isn’t vermin, he’s a pet. A domesticated beast has its uses, doesn’t it?”

 

“Ah, I see. And did you lay with this ‘pet’ of yours yet?”

 

A flash of genuine anger crossed Cleobulus’s borrowed face before she smoothed it out into a far too calm smile. “Be careful, Chilon. You’re not playing bodyguard anymore. This isn’t Shambala, and you’re not just an upjumped door guard with a fancy title. You have duties to uphold, and if you ever accuse me of bestiality again, I’ll castrate you on the spot, so make sure you uphold those duties properly.”

 

Chilon blinked beneath his helm, thrown off by the complete lack of change in tone as his fellow sage delivered her threat, before his attention was taken by the king’s arrival. 

 

“Ah, what a beautiful day!” Rufus said with a far bigger smile than Cornelia was used to seeing on his face. Well, aside from when he was busy with his “dancers”. He turned his attention towards her almost immediately upon seeing her, eager for approval. “How do you think it went? They were cheering for me, certainly, but do you think it was genuine?”

 

“Of course it was, my king. You did a wonderful job out there,” she praised, ignoring the noise of disgust Chilon made. 

 

Thankfully Rufus didn’t notice, still near-euphoric from his success. “Ha! Ah, what a wonderful day! Thank you, Cornelia! I couldn’t have done it without your guidance!”

 

He wasn’t wrong about that, but Cornelia knew when to preen and when to demure. “You give me too much credit, my king. The people are merely seeing the charisma you have always had.”

 

That and the slight alterations she’d made to help his mood and keep him from being so melancholy and guilt-ridden all the time. Sure, some may call that “drugging his food”, but she preferred to consider it medication for his ills. She was posing as a healer, after all, so she knew what she was talking about.

 

“They are, aren’t they?” He laughed, unable to hide his delight. “It won’t be long now before the people adore me far more than they ever did Lambert! Though, right, we still need to get rid of Dimitri. Have you killed him yet?”

 

Cornelia giggled. “Aw, how very vicious, my king~. Do remember we need a reason to be rid of him first though.”

 

“Hm, right…why not use Patricia then?”

 

Cornelia paused. “Oh?”

 

“Patricia. Through her, Dimitri is related to that Adrestian princess. We’re already stirring up aggression towards Adrestia, we can frame the Tragedy as purely her plot to put the Kingdom and the Empire under the reign of her two brats.”

 

“Hmm…that is an interesting starting point, my king. I will keep it in mind for our plans going forward.” It would be an interesting point to follow. Long dead Patricia could work very well as a scapegoat in many respects, particularly if they leaned on Arundel as a conspirator murdered to keep the secret. Or perhaps an innocent victim of his sister’s diabolical plots? Either one could work, but the main point was to turn Faerghus even further against Adrestia. 

 

Poor Thales’s grand design was faltering ever since his little project diverted from his plans, wandering away without his stern hand to hold her leash, so it was up to Cleobulus to set things right. 

 

If the people of Agartha could not have their Flame Emperor, then she would give them a Storm King.

Chapter End Notes

Red: Hey everybody, look at what Rufus is up to! Isn't he doing such a good job?

Indi: He's being such a great king who is totally gonna make Faerghus great again.

Red: That he is! Oh yeah and there's also these two other people there too. They're probably not important.

Indi: Every king needs their aides, I'm sure they aren't secretly controlling things.

Red: How could they? He's doing such a good job, I'm sure it'll be completely fine.

An Unexpected Invasion

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

"Thank you for coming here. This month's mission is of grave importance," Rhea stated with utmost seriousness as she looked at the professors before her. 

 

"It definitely seems like it if we're getting the mission together," Manuela noted, glancing at Byleth and Hanneman. 

 

"We will do our best to accomplish whatever mission you have for us," Hanneman said as Byleth nodded.

 

"Thank you. Now then, normally this mission would be one given to the knights. However, thanks to everything that happened with Tomas and the Flame Emperor, I tasked them with scouring Fodlan to find any leads on them. As such, the mission will have to fall on your students." 

 

"What exactly is the mission?" Byleth asked. 

 

"The Almyran army is invading, and House Goneril has requested assistance. From what we were told, it's likely the largest invasion force the Almyrans have used." 

 

"W-What!? Lady Rhea, you can't be serious!" Hanneman exclaimed, astonished at her request. 

 

"I know we just had a mock battle meant to simulate war, but sending the students to fight an actual war is a little…" Manuela trailed off, not wanting to finish what she was saying. 

 

"It is with a heavy heart that I give you this mission. I understand that this might be dangerous, but we cannot allow foreign invaders to desecrate Fodlan," Rhea said as her eyes hardened. "If we do not stop them at the Locket, then who knows how far they will be able to get." 

 

"...Can the other nations not assist?" Byleth asked. 

 

"The kingdom is still undergoing its own turmoil as they replace members of the Western Church, along with their own sudden invasion from Sreng. The empire, however, is making no move to assist, so there is no other choice." 

 

"Who will be assisting us?" Byleth inquired, at the ready.

 

"I will be sending what forces I can spare from the Knights of Seiros, as well as whatever the Alliance themselves can spare," Rhea stated, "It is my understanding that Holst Goneril will be leading the defense as well." 

 

"Ah, the hero of Fodlan’s Locket will be there then,” Hanneman noted, “That does provide some measure of comfort, at least…" 

 

"How long do we have until we depart?" 

 

"Only a few days, I'm afraid. You will need to get your classes ready by the third," Rhea responded. 

 

“Lady Rhea, that's not much time at all," Hanneman noted, frowning deeply. 

 

"It is all I can afford you." 

 

"...Very well, I understand this is a time of crisis.” He sighed, then nodded firmly. “I will do my utmost to ensure my students are prepared for what they might face.”

 

“It’s the least all of us could do,” Manuela agreed, a rarity for her, her voice uncharacteristically serious, “We’ll make sure everyone makes it back safely.”

 

“We will,” Byleth agreed, her mind set. If her students were in danger, then she would simply have to end the war quickly.

Claude breathed out a slow, tired sigh as he stared up at the ceiling of the Golden Deer’s classroom. “War with Almyra, huh?”

 

It would be wrong to say he hadn’t seen it coming. The words on the wind made it too obvious something like this was going to hit. Faerghus was busy, Adrestia was selfish, and that left it up to Leicester to try to beat back the “barbarian hordes” of his own countrymen.

 

“Wow, you look down. What’s up, Claude?” Hilda asked, plopping down in the seat beside him.

 

“Oh, just disappointed Cyril’s addition to our class was overshadowed,” he replied, grinning over at his pink-haired pal, “How about you, Lady Goneril? Feeling happy we’ll get to visit your big brother?”

 

“Ugh, don’t remind me.” Now it was her turn to pout. “Couldn’t the Almyrans pick a better time to invade? We have the ball next month, I don’t want to get bogged down fighting off invaders with my overbearing brother…”

 

“Eh, it probably won’t last a month, so no need to worry about that.” Especially if he was right about who was leading the invasion. Of his half-siblings, Shahid had an excellent mix of vanity and stubbornness that made him a massive pain to deal with, yet also slow to accept ideas like ‘maybe you need more than just numbers to win a fight’. The invasion reeked of his type of grandstanding, which almost made Claude crack a smile before he remembered this time his older brother’s arrogance would result in a lot of people dead.

 

He let those thoughts clear from his head though, instead directing his grin towards Hilda. “Speaking of, do you happen to have a date in mind for the ball? Maybe a certain winged deer who flew off to join the eagles?”

 

Hilda frowned at him, though he could tell she was amused. “Winged deer? Really, Claude?” 

 

“What? It’s an apt metaphor. Or allegory? One or the other.”

 

“Sure, sure. And how about you, huh? Do you have anyone you’re interested in?” she deflected, not even bothering to pretend to answer his question, “Maybe a certain mercenary?”

 

“You’re gonna have to be more specific than that, Hill. Do you mean the mercenary in our class, the future mercenary who’s also in our class, the mercenary that’s teaching, the mercenary that isn’t teaching, the mercenaries in town–”

 

She lightly punched his arm, pouting. “You know who I mean!”

 

“I do? Hm…ah, I get it. Though don’t you think Shez would get mad if I asked her dad on a date?”

 

“You’re doing what now?” Shez asked, blinking in confusion as she stopped a few feet away from them.

 

“Oh Claude was just talking about how he wants to ask you to the ball next month,” Hilda lied without a hint of shame, fully throwing Claude under the cart in a cruel act of disproportionate retribution.

 

“Oh, sure, if you wanna.”

 

Claude blinked. He had to admit, he wasn’t expecting that response.

 

Neither was Hilda. “Really?”

 

“Sure, why not? We’re buds and it’d probably be fun, right?” She paused, her thoughts seeming to catch up with her. “Wait, no, I’m mad at you.”

 

“You are? For what?” Hilda asked while Claude winced.

 

“He poisoned Byleth.”

 

“What?? When did this happen??”

 

Claude held his hands up when Hilda immediately glared at him. “Hey, it…alright, it was a stupid move I made back before the Battle of Eagle and Lion, I didn’t mean to poison her specifically, and I’m sorry I didn’t tell you about it.”

 

Hilda blinked. “...Okay, I’m actually more surprised you apologized to me, but also what the heck, Claude? Why would you try to poison anyone to begin with? I thought you were just being weird when you talked about all that poison stuff you’re into.”

 

“...Hilda, did you think making poisons was just my hobby or something?”

 

“Yes? Duh? It’s like, I make stuff sometimes, but it’s not like I ever use them to try to kill people.”

 

“You know there’s a difference between poisons and perfumes, right?”

 

“Yeah but it could still mess someone up if I put perfume in their food.”

 

“Uh, guys?” Shez spoke up, looking confused, “Are we still on the same topic?”

 

“Oh, right, sorry Shez. Yeah, I guess Claude would be a bad choice for a date then,” Hilda admitted, prompting a huff from Claude.

 

“I could still take her.”

 

“Claude, you poisoned her sister. I’m pretty sure that takes you out of the running for dateable guys.” Hilda paused. “Actually, Shez, what’s your type?”

 

“Huh? Uh…I dunno? I guess…well rule one, they can’t hurt or threaten my sister, so that means Sylvain’s off the table.”

 

That got Claude and Hilda to pause. “Wait, did he hurt Teach?”

 

“No, no, he threatened her, it was a whole thing. I think he was trying to cheer me up? It’s been a while since then, but I told him I’d kill him if he messed with her so he backed off.”

 

“Is that why you left the Lions?” Hilda asked.

 

“Eh, partially? I thought I’d have more fun with you guys and I have been so it still feels like a good choice.” She pointed at Claude. “Still annoyed though.”

 

“Right…Is there something I can do to make it up to you?”

 

“...Hm…make me house leader.”

 

“Lorenz would kill me,” Claude bluntly stated.

 

“Ah, true, he would…” Shez tilted her head, as though listening to someone. Something she tended to do when she was thinking, so Hilda didn’t think much of it while Claude watched her with his usual curiosity. “Ahh, that’s a good one…alright, I’ve got it! Claude, hire me to go to the dance with you!”

 

Claude blinked. “...Uh, what?”

 

“You have to pay me to be your date to the dance.”

 

He blinked again while Hilda covered a snort, before she started to giggle. 

 

“...So…hold on, you want me to hire you to be my date?” he asked.

 

“Yup! You pay for all the fancy stuff too, the dress, the make up, whatever else I need to look like a fancy lady having the biggest date of her life! And, and here’s the important part, you need to fork over the gold in front of everyone there. You pay for me to get ready, then when we meet up at the ball, you pay me directly, there in front of everyone, to be your date, so everyone knows his grace, the great Claude von Riegan, had to pay for a date to the dance.”

 

“...That’s the most vindictive thing I’ve ever heard of,” Claude stated with awe in his voice, genuinely impressed by the sheer audacity while Hilda outright laughed. “I…Yeah, okay, I’ll take you up on that.” Then he smirked. “Just so you know though, I’m not the type of guy who takes stuff like this lying down.”

 

“Yeah yeah, you’re very scary. But hey, if you won’t lie down for me, I’ll just have to slam you into the floor,” Shez teased, before glancing at Hilda, “So hey, Hil, can you help out? You seem like you know what you’re doing with fashion stuff.”

 

“Ooo, I was hoping you would ask~!” Hilda beamed. “Any ideas to start off with?”

 

“Whatever makes the biggest dent in Claude’s wallet.”

 

“Ah, no restrictions at all then~! Awesome!”

 

Claude sighed, well aware this wasn’t going to end well for him. But, well, he knew there would be consequences for screwing up. Honestly, he was surprised Lorenz hadn’t shown up just from the rumor to demand he step down as house leader…Well, no reason to look a wyvern in the mouth. “Think we can move along now? Maybe focus on the mission instead of the ball?”

 

“It won’t save you, but sure,” Shez agreed.

 

“...Right, ah…hey, Cyril, what do you think about what’s coming up?”

 

“I think you’re getting what you deserve,” the young Almyran answered from his place a table over.

 

“...I meant about the whole ‘invasion’ thing.”

 

"I don't have anything to say. Lady Rhea says we need to defend Fodlan so I will." 

 

"Really? So you don't have any problems with fighting Almyrans?" 

 

"Should I? None of them probably remember me," Cyril admitted, "Though… I am worried about any kids that might get captured during the battle." 

 

"Well, in that case, let's go squeeze in some training," Shez said with a grin, thankfully turning away from her plans to financially ruin Claude. "You don't have to worry about them if you're strong enough to make sure nothing happens to them!"

 

"Sorry, no can do, still have some chores Lady Rhea wants me to handle," Cyril responded, making Shez falter a bit as he left.

 

"Well… hopefully the other classes are up for training." 

"I must admit, an Almyran invasion is not an event I ever thought I'd be involved in," Dimitri mused after his class got the news. "I have no idea how we'll fight them…" 

 

"Don’t overthink things, Boar. All we have to do is beat them," Felix said as if it was the simplest thing in the world. 

 

"And how exactly do you plan on fighting their wyvern soldiers?” Sylvain asked, “Last I checked, unless you're planning on chucking your sword at them, you're not going to have much luck hitting them." 

 

"They have to fly down eventually, I'll just strike them then." 

 

"Still, we should make sure to be careful. We may have had time to train with pegasus knights, but wyverns move completely differently," Dedue pointed out.

 

“He’s right about that,” Ingrid agreed, leaning in to join the conversation, “Wyverns tend to be more aggressive in general. Pegasi will charge at the enemy if you urge them, but wyverns will actively attack whatever they register as a threat to their rider. And that’s not even getting into the ones that can breathe fire.”

 

“Oh wow, I didn’t expect you to know so much about wyverns, Ingrid. That’s really impressive,” Annette complimented, prompting a slight blush from the blonde.

 

“It’s not that impressive. My family’s territory borders the Alliance so we’ll see wyverns every so often. More in the summer than the winter though, they really don’t like the cold.”

 

“Shame that probably won’t be a factor over at the Locket,” Sylvain pointed out, “Leicester tends to stay warm, right? And we’re only going to start entering winter at the end of this month.”

 

“So we probably won’t have an advantage in that sense,” Mercedes notes, “Perhaps I should take up training with the bow again? Archers are supposed to be quite effective against flyers, correct?”

 

“Huh. Maybe I could be useful this time then,” Ashe considered, though his comment went unnoticed as the discussion among his classmates continued in earnest.

 

Meanwhile, one classroom down, a similar discussion was taking place among the students of the Black Eagles, though with a slightly different tone. And a bit more of a geographical focus.

 

“Then the mountains are being the ‘neck’, and the ‘locket’ is being the fortress?” Petra asked, looking at the map spread out over her table in some confusion.

 

“Not the fortress, the fortresses!” Ferdinand corrected, “Fodlan’s locket is a series of fortifications designed to prevent any Almyran invader from seizing the throat!”

 

“Throat? Oh, it is a throat…why is it a throat?”

 

“You know, I’m not sure about that either,” Caspar admitted, scratching his head.

 

Linhardt sighed. “It’s because some people think Fodlan looks like a dragon’s head.”

 

“They do?” Hapi leaned over, staring at the map too. “I don’t see it.”

 

“Is it not obvious? Here, if you would look southward, into Adrestian territory–” Constance explained, tracing a finger over to Fodlan’s western shore, “–you can find Fodlan’s Fangs! The lower half is where House Ochs sits, while the uppermost is where House Nuvelle once resided!”

 

“Ah, I am remembering the fangs, yes.” Petra nodded, before tilting her head, trying to make out what actually looked fang-like of the landmass. “...They are meant to be fangs?”

 

“Of course! The Fangs of Fodlan itself!”

 

“I…do not have understanding. It is looking like land to me.” She tried tilting her head the other way. “...Or maybe lips?”

 

“What? Where are you seeing lips?”

 

“See? This is the upper lip, and this is the lower. Or…jaws? Is jaws more correct?”

 

“Well jaws does sound more appropriate,” Ferdinand commented, now scrutinizing the map too. “Hm…actually, what does that make the Bay of Enbarr then? Oh, perhaps instead of part of the mouth, the upper ‘jaw’ would be something more like the nose? Then that would leave Hevring as the upper jaw and the bay as the open mouth!”

 

“What?! Nuvelle is not a nose!” Constance snapped, oddly offended.

 

“Yeah, I don’t think that even works,” Hapi mentioned, “Dragons are like wyverns, right? Their nose is part of their upper jaw, like a snout.”

 

“...Hey, wait, horses also have that going on,” Caspar realized, “Does that mean horses are related to wyverns?”

 

“Horses are mammals, wyverns are reptiles,” Marianne spoke up, much to her own surprise.

 

“Oh. Wait, what’s the difference?”

 

“...Mammals have hair and give live births. Reptiles have scales and lay eggs.”

 

“Ohhh…hang on, don’t birds also lay eggs?”

 

“Y-Yes, but reptiles don’t have feathers.”

 

“Huh. Hey, wait, fish also have scales, does that–”

 

“Caspar, you can find this information out really easily if you look in any biology book.”

 

“...Well fine, keep your secrets.”

 

“Back on topic,” Ferdinand interrupted, pointing to the map again, “What in the world is this portion of the continent meant to be then? If Nuvelle and Ochs are the fangs, or the jaws as might be more appropriate, what does that make Hresvelg territory?”

 

“...Maybe a wing?” Hapi offered.

 

“Dragons don’t have wings on their heads, right?” Caspar asked.

 

“They most definitely do not,” Flayn affirmed while having a bit of trouble actually seeing the map due to her taller classmates being in the way.

 

“I see our classmates are taking the impending invasion well,” Hubert commented with some amusement from where he stood with Lady Edelgard.

 

“They really are childish sometimes,” Edelgard replied, before sighing, “Then again, I suppose none of us expected a foreign invasion in the middle of the year. Nor for Rhea to decide we should be involved.”

 

“It is an interesting decision on her part. One might think sending several noble heirs to the frontlines of a conflict with a foreign nation is a poor decision on her part.”

 

“It could be, though I think it more likely she’s attempting to foster unity among us.” Edelgard rubbed her chin, thinking. “I wonder if the tensions between Faerghus and Adrestia have shaken her complacency. Especially now that Adrestia is outright refusing to send aid to Leicester.”

 

“It is a fascinating choice our dear friend the Prime Minister has decided to make. Perhaps certain elements are encouraging his decision-making?”

 

“Perhaps. We might also be seeing the consequence of Aegir being left to run things. Why would he ever waste the Empire’s military for the benefit of his neighbors? Particularly when, from his point of view, he’ll need that military to handle Almyra if they successfully occupy Leicester.”

 

“Speaking of Aegir…” Hubert turned his gaze towards the most annoying noble he had the misfortune to know. One who happened to have more information than Hubert happened to be comfortable with.

 

Edelgard nodded. “I know. I suppose I was so used to seeing Ferdinand as this obnoxious extension of his father that I never considered he could be an asset to my goals.”

 

“...That wasn’t exactly what I meant, your highness.”

 

“I know what you meant, and I said what I meant. Ferdinand would be more useful on our side than he would be if there were any unfortunate accidents.” She glanced up at her retainer. “That means no arranging such accidents.”

 

“While I would never want to question your judgement–”

 

“Don’t patronize me, Hubert. We’re not in the position to carelessly discard allies. We know who we can’t trust, so when it becomes apparent there is someone we can, we can’t waste the opportunity on paranoia.”

 

“And do you truly think Ferdinand is one such trustworthy individual?”

 

“I think he is the type of person who will have issues with the choices I plan to make, but he is also someone who has seen the ideals he upholds are not being held to.
