"Hmph, well, regardless, I give whoever courts Constance my well wishes. If she truly wishes to restore her house, then she will require all the assistance she can get." 

 

"Sometimes I don't know if you're a nice dude or not, Lolo," Hapi muttered. 

 

"Speaking of being taken, I heard you're going with someone to the ball," Mercedes mentioned, riding close to Shez. "I don't suppose you'll need help with your makeup?" 

 

"Eh? Why would I wear makeup?" 

 

"Oh, come now Shez, it's a ball! Of course you should make sure to get ready for it." 

 

"Huh…yeah you know what, sure, Hilda is already helping me with getting dressed." 

 

"Oh?" That got Mercedes's attention. "Hilda, do you want to help me make sure Shez is ready for the ball?" 

 

"Ooo, sure!" 

 

"Can I join in~?" Dorothea asked as she held onto Edelgard; the young songstress didn’t want to fall off the horse, so the only real solution was holding her highness around her waist. The princess, meanwhile, was doing her best to avoid getting flustered as she held onto the reins. Not that she had much luck when her gaze met Byleth’s for a moment, only for the professor to give her a thumbs up. 

 

“We’d be glad to have you!” Hilda called out, grinning over at the lucky songstress.

 

"....You three do know the ball isn't till next month right?" Shez asked, though she didn’t get an answer as the fancier ladies started chatting. Sighing, Shez focused back on riding, before noting that they were about to arrive at Garreg Mach. And it also seemed like someone was waiting for them. "Oh, hey dad!"

 

Standing by the gates leading to Garreg Mach, Jeralt grinned, waving at his daughters as the two approached him. 

 

"Hey there kids," Jeralt greeted, before handing a box to Shez. "Here you go, happy birthday." 

 

A moment of silence dropped over the students as the words he said register–

 

"It's not her birthday," Byleth cut in, frowning. "You're early this year. It's on the twelfth." 

 

“It is? Damn it, I overcorrected,” Jeralt muttered, looking annoyed.

 

"Aw, don't worry dad, I don't mind," Shez responded, opening the box and finding some beast repellent inside. "Thanks!" And then she immediately extended a hand out to Byleth as if expecting something. 

 

"...You're lucky I brought it just in case," Byleth muttered, before fishing in her pocket and brought out a necklace. One that had a very…crudely designed horse hanging from it. 

 

"Oh…did you make this?" 

 

"I gave the blacksmith the design for the mold." 

 

"Huh. You know what, I'm not surprised." 

 

Byleth paused for a second, as though listening to something, then frowned. “What is that supposed to mean?”

 

“...It means it’s a really cute, thoughtful gift! Thank you!”

 

“Hm. You’re welcome.”

 

“...Pardon my interruption, professor, but didn’t you just say it wasn’t Shez’s birthday?” Lorenz asked.

 

“I did. I tend to bring her an extra gift because pa–Jeralt always forgets. It’s a tradition.”

 

"Yup! I get a gift from her on my actual birthday, and another when dad gives me his!" Shez explained.

 

"...Why exactly is that?" 

 

"I don't want Jeralt to feel left out." 

 

Jeralt sighed. “I’m right here, kid.”

 

“You already knew.”

 

“...Yeah, I did.” He sighed again. “Well, how’d it go with the visiting Almyrans?”

 

“Pretty good!” Shez answered with a grin, “I went up against this guy called the Undefeated and sent him running!”

 

“Oh really now?” Jeralt asked, already planning to get the real story from Byleth later, “How about you tell me about that over your birthday dinner?”

 

“Sweet! Hey, do I get to drink beer this time? I’m the older sister now, so I think I should be allowed to!”

 

‘Oh, you’re still doing that. Hm…Nah, sorry, you’re part of the Alliance class so you can’t drink by Alliance standards.”

 

“I can’t?? Wait, what’s the drinking age for the Alliance?”

 

“Good question.” And with that, Jeralt turned and walked away.

 

“Ah–H-Hey! Don’t walk off! C’mon, you should know the answer to that!” Shez protested as she followed him from atop her horse, who seemed unbothered by all the commotion. 

 

"...So, just to make sure, her birthday is not for another couple of days, correct?" Lysithea asked Byleth. 

 

"Yeah, so there's no rush." 

 

"Hmph, it's not like I was going to be in a rush," Lysithea responded, which was a complete lie since the present she had purchased hadn't arrived yet. 

 

"Hm…" Byleth gave her a small thumbs up. "Good luck." 

 

“H-Hmph, I don’t need luck…but thank you though.”

When it came to her birthday proper, Shez grinned widely at the sight of her sister standing by her door, a wrapped package in her hands. 

 

"Here you go-" Before she could finish Shez snatched it out of her hands and began to open it. 

 

"Thanks!" Shez said with a grin, before finally managing to take off the parchment wrapping. Though once she did, Shez could only stare at the book she had in her hand, its purple cover and the symbol on the front making it quite obvious what she was looking at. "Volume four of the magic primer…" 

 

"Took a bit, but I managed to find it," Byleth said, a small smile on her face. 

 

Wrapping her arms around her sister, Shez easily lifted her up in a hug. "Aw, thank you, By!" 

 

"...Let go of me." 

 

"Nope, this is my privilege as the big sister!" Shez replied, grinning as she carried her sister towards the courtyard. "Now come on, I'll get you to your class!" 

 

"I’m pretty sure we'd be faster if I walked." 

 

"Nope, I think this works just fine!" Shez responded, amusement evident in her voice as she walked towards the classrooms. Byleth felt her face heat up a bit as the students began to watch the two, though she didn’t bother to break her sister’s grip just yet. She could have some fun, even if Byleth was going to get revenge for it later. 

 

"What are you even doing?" Emily asked, staring in disbelief at the two. 

 

"I'm thanking By for the gift she gave me!" Shez declared, not noticing how Byleth kept her expression studiously neutral when she noticed the potential infiltrator.

 

"...Right, I'm not getting involved," Emily decided, heading off to the Golden Deer classroom while some of her classmates stopped to stare.

 

“Shez, I don’t think it’s appropriate to be carrying around a professor,” Lorenz pointed out, though he sounded a little unsure.

 

“Nah, it’s fine! It’s my duty as the big sister to carry By!” Shez declared.

 

“...I…see. Hm. I suppose I don’t really have the context for commoner traditions…”

 

“Yeah, that’s not a commoner tradition,” Leonie commented, “Those two are just weird.”

 

“I don’t know about that,” Raphael said, “I carried Maya around all the time when she asked for it.”

 

“Really? Huh, maybe it’s a sibling thing. Hey Ignatz, you have an older brother, right? Does he ever carry you?”

 

“Huh? Um…no, not that I…hm, actually, I think he did lift me on his shoulders one time at a festival when I was young…”

 

“Huh. Guess it is a sibling thing then. Hm, wonder if it’s the same for noble siblings…hey Hilda, did Holst ever carry you around?”

 

“All the time, duh. Heck, Baltie carried me a few times too,” she said, pointing her thumb back at the tall student.

 

“Ha, that’s right! Y’know, I probably could still carry you–”

 

“Yeah, no, don’t try. I absolutely refuse.”

 

“Yes, while that may be allowable between siblings, I highly doubt it would be appropriate for a man of your standing to be carrying a noblewoman like Hilda,” Lorenz commented.

 

“...Uh, Lorenz, you know I used to be a noble, right?”

 

“You were?”

 

“Hey, that’s not important right now,” Leonie interrupted, “The important thing here is finding out who else has siblings and if this carrying thing really is consistent for everybody!”

 

“...I…suppose that is the topic at hand, true,” Lorenz admitted, “I may have siblings, but I have never done such a thing. Perhaps it would help me form a better relationship with them..." 

 

"Well as an only child, I find this topic riveting, but we did have something planned, didn’t we?" Claude asked, giving his class a grin. "And, not that I mind you being here Teach, but don't you have a class to go to?" 

 

"Tell Shez to let go of me." At her response, Claude glanced at Shez. 

 

"...Fine." After she was set down, Byleth smoothed out her clothes, before nodding to the Golden Deer and heading off to her class, prompting a pout from Shez. “Feh. I could’ve kept carrying her.”

 

“I’m sure you could carry Teach all day, Shez, but that would get in the way of our plans!” Claude said with a grin, looping an arm over Shez’s shoulders as he led her into the classroom. "For you see, unlike those Black Eagles, we actually bothered to remember when birthdays happen." 

 

"I mean, to be fair, Byleth doesn't really bring up her own birthday often," Shez pointed out, defending the other house, before perking up. "So, what do you have in store for me?" 

 

"Why just a simple little thing," Claude replied, before gesturing to a table where a bunch of presents were being lined up by their Almyran classmate. "Thanks again Cyril!" 

 

"I only did it cause Lady Rhea said I should try to get along with you guys more. You did ask Professor Manuela for permission to do this, right?" 

 

"Of course–" 

 

"What are you guys doing?" came the voice of said professor, looking in at her rearranged class. "You do know we still have class today, right?" 

 

"Of course we do, professor, but you see, I actually need your help with something,” Claude said, sidling up to their professor, “I might have accidentally brought some Almyran booze from when we stayed in the Locket, so I was wondering if you could help me safely dispose of it." 

 

"Aw what, you're asking her but not me?" Balthus asked, frowning. 

 

"...Hm, well, I suppose I should make sure that's not in the hands of any of the students,” Manuela replied, staring at the bottle of amber liquid before simply taking it from Claude. “Fine, you have until I return to have your little party." 

 

“Your work is as appreciated as always, professor!” Claude called out as she left, a clear grin on his face. “She’s not coming back.”

 

“Oh she definitely isn’t,” Hilda agreed, before pulling Shez over to the table, “Now come on, Shez! You’d better open my gift first~!”

 

“Ha! Okay, okay, let’s see what you guys got me!” Shez agreed, happily picking up the present Hilda indicated and getting right to work in seeing just what her classmates decided to get for her. Said present being a resin bottle full of flowers. "Ooo, this looks pretty." 

 

"Glad you like it~" Hilda said, smiling as Shez looked over the bottle. "It took a lot of effort to make, so you better appreciate it!" 

 

"I will!" Shez said, setting it down as she reached for the next present, and finding a rose brooch waiting for her. "Heh, pretty easy to guess who this is from." 

 

"Of course, my magnificence shines through even my gifts!" Lorenz stated, quite proud of himself. 

 

"Well it's pretty, I'll give you that," Shez responded, opening the next present and… finding a ticket? 

 

"It's for my family's inn! Feel free to stop by and stay for free when you want to!" Raphael said with a big smile. 

 

"Thanks big guy! I'll make sure to come one day!" Shez replied, giving him a thumbs up. 

 

"Looking forward to it!" As she pocketed the tickets, she grabbed the next box. 

 

"Aw, here I was hoping you'd end up saving the best for last," Claude said, mock disappointment in his voice. 

 

"Pft, well guess I still am," Shez teased, opening the box and finding a jar in it. "Uh, what is it?" 

 

"Poison," he answered, getting everyone to stare at him.

 

"..." Shez in particular had a very flat, unimpressed look directed towards him.

 

"Heh, what, did you actually believe that?" he asked, a grin on his face, "I might make poisons, but I'm not going to give one as a gift to someone. Fun fact, there are some poisons that can actually be used to make a medicinal salve, which is what I actually gave you." 

 

“...You gotta work on your sense of humor, buddy.”

 

“Yeah, too soon, Claude,” Hilda commented.

 

“Ah–...yeah, well, that is actually a medicinal salve. A small amount should help with sore muscles while a bit more can do a lot for scrapes and small wounds.”

 

“Huh…that is actually pretty nice,” Shez admitted. “Thanks, Claude. Though I’m getting you a joke book whenever your birthday comes up.” 

 

“It already passed.”

 

“For the next one then.” Setting the salve down gently, she grabbed the next present, and found a bottle inside. 

 

"It's an amber sweetener," Lysithea explained at Shez’s confused look. "It’s quite tasty when you want a dish to be a bit sweeter." 

 

"...You mean I can pour this on stuff and make it taste better?" 

 

"Yes?" Lysithea let out a small squeak as she got hugged. "Wh-What??" 

 

"Here I thought the food here wouldn't get any better!" Shez said, grinning as she pulled back from the hug as she looked at the bottle. 

 

"...J-Just make sure not to waste it. It's quite expensive." 

 

"Jeez, guess the little lady is winning so far," Balthus remarked with a grin. 

 

"I-It's not a competition!" 

 

"Sure it isn't." Letting out an amused huff at her classmates' antics, Shez grabbed the next gift, which was a rolled up parchment which had… a rather simple drawing of Rhea on it. 

 

"Lady Rhea said I should give you something I think you would like," Cyril explained.

 

"Aw, thanks Cyril!" 

 

"It looks great Cyril, I didn't know you liked drawing," Ignatz commented, getting the Almyran to shrug. 

 

"Heh, well I'll make sure to take care of it," Shez said, smiling as she grabbed the next gift. This one being an actually labeled medicine. 

 

"Ha, after what happened to your sister and Leonie I figured you should have this whenever you actually do go drinking,” Balthus explained with a grin, “Trust me, it works wonders." 

 

"...Is there any reason why you didn't give Byleth or me this when we were sick?" Leonie asked.

 

"Eh, I was running low on funds at the time," Balthus responded, getting Leonie to huff. 

 

"Pft, well I'll make sure to remember this when I can." With that, Shez grabbed one of the last two gifts, this one being from Leonie, which happened to be a bracelet with a charm that looked like an arrowhead. 

 

"A good luck charm from yours truly," Leonie said with a smile, "Made one for Byleth and the Captain too, but I figured you should get yours first!" 

 

"Aw, matching charms sound great! Thanks Leonie!" 

 

"Ah, I guess that only leaves my gift," Ignatz noted, letting out a nervous laugh. 

 

"No need to feel nervous Ignatz," Shez reassured, grabbing the wrapped up gift, and finding… a painting of her, and her family. There she was, pulling Byleth into a hug as Jeralt stood close behind them. 

 

"I, uh, hope it looks alright, I was mostly going off of simple models–" And Ignatz went quiet Shez hugged him, pulling him in tightly.

 

"Thank you, Ignatz." 

 

"A-Ah, I'm glad you like it," Ignatz said, blushing a bit as she broke the hug. 

 

"Of course I do! I'm sure the others will love it when I show it to them! You know, you'd probably make a killing as a painter." 

 

"O-oh, that's kind of you to say, but it's just a hobby," Ignatz responded. 

 

"Hm…Hey, Ignatz, could I learn to draw as well as you?" Cyril asked, looking at the portrait. 

 

"Oh, I suppose? Did you want some lessons?" 

 

"It would be nice to draw something like that for Lady Rhea," Cyril admitted. 

 

"Heh, guess that means Ignatz won," Claude remarked with a smirk, "Not only did you make Shez emotional, but you even got our new classmate interested." 

 

"It's still not a competition!" Lysithea complained.

 

Letting out an annoyed huff, Emily looked away from her classmates as she sat by herself. She couldn't understand this tradition of gift giving these people did, and honestly, she didn't care to learn. Hearing the chair next to her get pulled out, she glanced to see Shez sitting next to her. 

 

"Hey there!" 

 

"I don't do presents," Emily said before Shez could speak further. 

 

"Yeah, I got the feeling," Shez replied, not bothered, "Still doesn't mean you have to sit out of everything." 

 

"I'm not, I'm just… thinking about something," Emily said, her mind drifting back to how Byleth had called the Golden Deer her friends. 

 

"Well, want to talk about it?" 

 

"...I'd rather not," Emily admitted. 

 

"Well, in that case, we won't. That being said, we're still going to hang out," Shez said with a smile as she grabbed Emily’s hand, "So come on, all our friends are waiting." 

 

"...Our?" 

 

"Yeah? I mean, unless I got it wrong, I'm pretty sure they're your friends." 

 

"...hm." Staying quiet, she got up, and followed Shez to where the classmates were still talking. Well, arguing and teasing more than just chatting. Still, maybe Professor Byleth wasn't wrong…

Byleth watched from a distance as her sister happily pulled her friends along to the dining hall, where her big birthday feast was about to take place. In particular, she could see Shez was leading Emily by the wrist, chatting happily back at the shorter girl as a look of exasperation showed on the possible infiltrator’s face. Exasperation…and some affection that was obvious to see.

 

“You know she is likely a danger to Shez if your suspicions are correct,” Sothis pointed out, floating beside her.

 

“...I know. I…I know that.”

 

“You recall how the other infiltrators targeted Shez in particular, do you not? They wanted her for some foul purpose. What is to say Emily is not attempting to get close to her for a similar end?”

 

“...I don’t think she is. She’s not that good at manipulation. She’s been running errands for Hilda for a while.”

 

“Unless that is a deception.”

 

“Yeah…but I don’t know for sure.”

 

Sothis sighed. “You know there is more evidence for it than against. And the princess you favor thought your ideas had validity.”

 

She did. Back in Fodlan’s locket, Edelgard hadn’t denied the idea that Emily might be an infiltrator like Tomas. What she pointed out was that there wasn’t definitive proof. That if they made a false accusation, then they could potentially destroy Emily’s life. That it would be better to wait, see, and make sure, and not act hastily.

 

And if she were being honest…Byleth didn’t really want to accuse Emily. She was her student, even if she wasn’t in her class now.

 

“Do you really think you may be wrong, or are you allowing your sympathy for this girl to override your common sense?” Sothis asked, her voice simply logical, not argumentative.

 

“...I’m leaving her alone because I don’t want to be right. Because she’s Shez’s friend. And I know that’s stupid of me. I just…I don’t want to hurt her.”

 

“Shez, or Emily? Because, while we do not know the mechanics of how these infiltrators operate, we know that if there ever was a real Emily Korsch, she is more than likely dead so this girl could take her place.”

 

“...Yeah. Yeah, that’s probably true. And…a part of me does think if there was a real one, she deserves some kind of justice. But I don’t know if that’s true. And I don’t want to hurt anyone just for a maybe.”

 

“Hm…then I will merely add that you should remember where you found that dark dagger. A person does not draw a blade if they do not intend to use it.”

 

“Mm.” And that was another question. Why would she draw a weapon like that down there? The possibilities were unpleasant…but there were also more of them than just the worst case scenarios. “I don’t know what she was planning. I don’t think we can know unless we ask her.” 

 

Byleth took a small breath, thinking. “We’ll keep an eye on her. And if something goes wrong…we have the divine pulse to make it right.”

 

“Do not use the power I granted you as a crutch,” Sothis warned, “The choices you make should matter.”

 

“They do. Even if no one else knows about them, they’ll matter to me. And right now…I’m going to trust that Emily is friends with Shez.”

 

“...” Sothis sighed. “That is incredibly sappy, but very well. If you wish to give this girl the benefit of the doubt, I will not argue against it. I merely caution that letting a scorpion on your back may see you stung. People cannot change their natures easily.”

 

“...I don’t agree with that. I think being able to change who we are makes us people.” She smiled faintly. “I know I’ve changed.”

 

“Hmph. I said they cannot change easily, not that it is impossible. Just make sure to keep those you care for safe.”

 

“Always,” Byleth agreed, before walking towards the dining hall to join her friends and family. She hoped the worries she had would amount to nothing, but if there were ever problems…she would do what she had to.

 

She just hoped she could keep everyone safe…

The rest of her birthday went very well as Shez enjoyed the rest of the day with her friends. She even received some more gifts from the other houses too! She definitely appreciated the cloak she got from Sylvain in case she ever had to go to the kingdom again. The curry comb she got from Ingrid also made her remember when she talked about being a dark knight… hm, she should try training on horseback again. 

 

The bracelet she got from Dorothea was also nice, even if it did make her think she was starting to have a lot of accessories. And while she had read ‘Loog and the Maiden’ before, she was happy to have a copy that Ashe gifted her. 

 

"Seems someone is going to get spoiled rotten at this rate," Arval commented after her birthday dinner with her family and the mercs. 

 

"Shush you," Shez retorted, an amused expression on her face despite the teasing. "It's been a busy year, getting to relax on a day like this is necessary!" 

 

"Hm, I suppose that is true. Though the year is almost over. Soon enough, you'll be free to journey once more." 

 

"Well…maybe not right away," Shez said, thinking about Lysithea going to the empire. "Gonna have some things I need to check on first." 

 

“I imagine you do. Your friend Lysithea will come first, won’t she?” they acknowledged, “She and the crests she was cursed with.”

 

“Yeah…it’s weird, you know? It feels like crests cause more problems than they fix.”

 

Arval kept their smile from growing too wide. "Indeed. If they truly were a blessing of the ‘goddess’, then she is a remarkably cruel deity.”

 

"Eh…Maybe? I still don't really care for the church but… I dunno. There's a bunch of weird stuff going on, and there's still those Agarthans we have to deal with…" 

 

"Yes, there is that matter to address, but for now, you should get some rest, my partner. It is getting late." 

 

"Yeah, I guess it is. Goodnight Arval." 

 

"Goodnight, partner," Arval said, smiling as Shez laid down in bed. The smile dropped soon afterward as he considered his vessel, who was far too attached to the Fell Star. If she knew what he was planning, she would fight him. It didn’t matter that her fate was ordained, she would resist it out of a misguided affection, and he could not allow that.

 

And the sage Epimenides, lingering despite having passed from this world long ago, drifted down beside the girl that was his vessel. He could not sit on the bed, though he mimicked the action as he pet his young vessel’s hair. Unable to touch, but trying nonetheless.

 

She was flawed, but she was still his.

Chapter End Notes

Red: Another birthday chapter! We did one for Byleth, so of course we're doing one for Shez!

Indi: That we are! And a bit of followup from the end of last chapter.

Red: Yup! As one might expect, Byleth doesn't really want to suspect a student. And as one might also expect, Edelgard sure doesn't want to have an infiltrator revealed when that infiltrator could take her down too.

Indi: It's a castle of cards are got going on and everyone's afraid to knock it over!

Red: But hey, don't mind that! Today is Shez's day! Time to focus on her!

Indi: Yup yup, and for now, hope y'all enjoyed!

The Lone Wolf

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Yuri Leclerc was many things; most would call him a thief or a scoundrel, though when he was in the Empire, nobles called him quite the songbird. He was rather fond of “boss”, if he had to pick a title for himself. 

 

But right now…he was bored. He'd never say it out loud, but it was a lot less fun since his fellow Ashen Wolves started hanging out on the surface with everyone else. Sure, they still came back down to Abyss most days, since their rooms were still down there and they had to sleep eventually. Even so, it was quieter. Especially since the only students coming down there were Leonie, looking for things in the scrap pile, or Edelgard and Claude, who kept reading the banned books. 

 

Which meant he was often on his own now. 

 

Letting out a sigh, he pushed himself up from where he was sitting. Well, if he was bored, he might as well drum up his own fun. With a quick journey up, Yuri found himself up topside. Pretty quickly, he realized it was still pretty early in the day since none of the students were milling about. Given that it wasn't the end of the week, that meant they were probably still in class. 

 

Hm…going to the Black Eagles class was the immediate option, but Byleth would likely notice him right away. The Golden Deer was also no good since Balthus would definitely make a ruckus if he spotted him. Which left the Blue Lions as his destination. 

 

It was easy enough to find his old classroom, not like they ever moved things around up here, and he casually moved in to sit beside a gray-haired kid who he was pretty sure he remembered from one place or another.

 

“Huh? Ah, Yuri?” Well that was a good indicator that the kid knew him.

 

“Shh, no talking in class,” he chided with a smirk, deciding he could piece together the freckled kid’s identity as things went along.

 

“Oh, right, sorry.” Polite boy. Cute too. The type who would be the darling of noble ladies looking for an earnest knight to keep them company. He had that sort of boyish look that made him seem honest, which made him an easy mark…though, no, he wasn’t. The kid was keeping an eye on him out of the corner of his eye; not especially suspiciously, but there was an interest there…though, to be fair, Yuri had just sat right beside him out of nowhere. Anyone would be curious in that situation.

 

Now, was he one of the students Yuri had interacted with on his last few visits up? No Lions had shown up in Abyss lately, he’d recognize them if they did, so where did he know him from…Ah, that was it. Lord Gaspard’s kid, the adopted commoner. Good to solve that mystery, though as for his name…Ashe, that was right. Didn’t he have a couple siblings? Probably named Dust and Grime if they fit the theme…

 

Idle thoughts aside, Yuri found himself paying more attention to the people than the lesson. Hanneman was the same as ever. The old man was a decent educator, maybe a little long winded, but nice enough. Towards the front though, there was the most interesting man in the room: his highness, the Prince of Faerghus, good old Dimitri. And sure enough, he was right alongside his big buddy, Dedue of Duscur. And wow, that was a massive man. Seemed even bigger than the last time he saw him. Built like an ox seemed like a solid descriptor, though he might be considered more of a castle wall instead.

 

One part of Yuri couldn’t help but draw some comparisons. Balthus could probably take the big man in a fight, but it would be an interesting one to watch. Probably a sight a lot of people would pay for too…hm, he should see how good of a grappler Dedue was first. He was a man built for physical fighting, but that could lend itself to heavy armor and axes over fisticuffs and that wouldn’t be nearly as fun as a pair of bulky brawlers in traditional war master garb going at it.

 

Though he did hear the good prince had quite some strength himself, which didn’t quite lend itself to the parallel of “lean princely man and his buff right hand man” that Yuri sort of saw going on. A shame, he could have pretended to be Dimitri’s evil doppelganger. 

 

As for the other front row folks, the short redheaded girl who couldn’t seem to stop bouncing her knee even as she took notes was probably the Dominic girl. Not the heir, but the baron’s niece, which did make Yuri idly wonder what Simon was up to these days…but he could figure that out later. For now, his eyes drifted over to Lady Dominic’s tall, blonde, and pillowy pal, who was taking notes just as attentively. She seemed like the type who’d be very at home in a monastery like this; one of those caring, pious girls that went into the clergy to happily live their lives for the goddess…at least on first impression. 

 

Speaking of first impressions, Yuri distinctly remembered his first impression of Mister Sylvain Jose Gautier, who was sitting right beside Ingrid Galatea, as one might expect. The Faerghus Four were well known for a reason, though it was interesting to see little Felix was sitting all by his lonesome. Perhaps he was in his moody phase?

 

Well, whatever. He had time to figure out what the Lions’ quirks were, especially since none of them had noticed him aside from Ashe. It should make introductions fun later down the line. He was certainly curious if Sylvain would mistake him for a girl again.

“Uh, so, why were you in class with us?” Ashe asked once class ended, glancing up at–Then he noticed Yuri had already left and he had to hurry to catch up with him, “A-Ah, hey!”

 

“I just thought it would be interesting,” Yuri answered, glancing back at him with a faint smirk, “I used to be a Lion before I became a Wolf, so I wanted to see what it might be like to wear the mane again.” 

 

"Uh… so, did you like it?" Ashe asked, unsure of what he was saying. 

 

"It wasn't bad. Hanneman is the same as ever, and the class this time around seems livelier than my old class. Course, I wasn't particularly close to any of those students." 

 

"I see…um, hey, can I ask why you were in the abyss? You just went missing a few years back, right?" 

 

"Why would anyone go into hiding, my dear boy? I'm sure you can come up with your own story. Perhaps I did something like you did in the past." 

 

"Ah–wait, how do you know about that?" Ashe asked, a bit taken aback. 

 

"You don't become someone in my position without knowing things," Yuri responded, which wasn't exactly a lie. He had heard plenty of dirt about plenty of people, but he mainly heard about Ashe from Rowe complaining that Lord Lonato took in some thief kid.

 

"Well hey there Yuri, any reason you decided to come visit?" Claude asked, the Golden Deer leader noticing the two chatting in the courtyard. 

 

"Do I need any reason to visit the lovely monastery?" Yuri asked in turn with a wink. 

 

“I wouldn’t say you need a reason, but I imagine you have one. C’mon, you can tell me! Are you visiting friends? Seeing the sights? Or maybe looking for someone in particular?”

 

Yuri just grinned. “It’s cute that you’re trying to get info outta me. Cute, but not really effective. You have to at least try to bribe me before I start sharing~.”

 

"Aw, and here I thought helping you out in Abyss was enough of a bribe already." 

 

"Hm, that’s true. Guess I should go talk with Shez then since she saved the day back then." 

 

"What was that about me?" Shez asked, catching wind of what Yuri said as she passed by. 

 

"Oh you know, I was just feeling like I should go talk with my helpful friend who saved the day back in Abyss. Who knows, I still do owe you, how about I take you on a date?" he inquired with a flirtatious wink. 

 

"...You know, no offense Yuri, but you seem like the kind of dude who'd leave me with the tab after sneaking out." 

 

"Ouch, not one to mince words, huh?" Not entirely inaccurate, though he usually saved that for nobles he was trying to scam. 

 

"It's part of my charm. Either way, no thanks."

 

"Can't hurt to ask," Yuri said with a smirk, "But I know a losing battle when I see one." 

 

"Well in that case, why don't you just hang out with us for now?" Claude offered, "I'm sure there's plenty we can talk about." 

 

"My apologies, but I already have my own escort," Yuri replied, gesturing to Ashe. "Unless this young knight would prefer to leave me on my own." 

 

"O-Oh, well, I'm not doing anything, so I can show you around." 

 

"Excellent. In that case." Yuri grinned at the deer. "I hope you two have a good day." 

 

With that, he walked past them, well aware of Claude’s analytical stare as he did. Claude was certainly a mystery he was interested in as well, but in a give and take relationship, he definitely seemed like the type to take more than give. Not that Yuri was any different, but he at least knew well enough when to cut his losses. 

 

Shez on the other hand…Well, he wouldn't call her naive, but she was refreshingly blunt. It was probably more accurate to say that first impressions tended to stick with her. Which, of course, meant she'd end up trusting anyone who made a good first impression unless something big happened to change her mind. Well, Yuri at least hoped he wouldn't end up on her bad side. 

 

"So…where exactly do you want to go?" Ashe asked as he followed behind Yuri, which wasn’t quite how a “guide” should work. "I mean, do you even need someone to show you around?" 

 

"That's your way of saying you don't want to hang out with me?" 

 

"N-No!" 

 

"Heh, well, just felt like having some company," Yuri admitted. "And you just so happened to be the lucky one who gets to show me around." 

 

“A-Ah, alright…um, well…I guess we can try…maybe the library first?”

 

“Nah, I think I want to get something to eat,” he decided before heading towards the dining hall.

 

“...why did you ask me to guide you then…?”

"Gotta say, the food up here beats that of Abyss any day of the week," Yuri noted after he finished off his food. "Though it is missing that home meal touch." 

 

"Ah, yeah I get what you mean. It's not the same without my little siblings around," Ashe mentioned. 

 

“And how are they doing? Everything well on the homefront?”

 

“Oh, they’re adjusting…after Lonato…well, um, apparently Sir Gwendal was put in charge of their welfare for the time being so they can at least stay at Lonato’s manor, and there are people from the church making sure they’re cared for.” Ashe sighed. “It’s…going to be difficult though. I can’t imagine trying to take responsibility for the territory will go over well since I used to be a commoner. Not to mention how I tried to stop Lonato during his rebellion. I wouldn’t be surprised if some people blame me for his death…”

 

“True, you might have some troubles in the future, but isn’t living in Faerghus all about trying to overcome adversity?” Yuri grinned. “I seem to recall that being a virtue nearly everyone extolled in the knightly circles. ‘Strength in the face of adversity, weather the cold, endure the famine, fight through the plague’, that sort of stuff.”

 

“Oh, did you try to become a knight?” Ashe asked, obvious curiosity leaking into his voice.

 

“No, but I spent plenty of time around knights. You pick a few things up here and there,” he replied, before taking note of a certain blue-haired professor walking in with an interesting pair of students. He recognized Ingrid readily enough, given he’d already spotted her earlier, but the short, skittish, purple-haired girl…Well, he knew Bernadetta was the right age to be here, so he shouldn’t be too surprised.

 

“Hey professor!” Yuri decided to call out, raising a hand to catch her attention, “If you’re looking for somewhere to sit, why don’t you join Ashe and me over here?”

 

“Oh, okay.” She nodded, before heading over to the menu to order while both Ingrid and Bernadetta gave him skeptical looks. Well, Ingrid gave him a skeptical, studying look, while Bernadetta looked frightened by the sudden change in plans…up until she actually started looking at him. Then she couldn’t help but stare.

 

It seemed he was recognizable. Probably not a good thing, given his last encounter with her, but if he wanted to interact with the professor, he had to take some risk there.

 

"Gotta say, this is quite the pair you have with you," Yuri commented, noticing the trio all had plates of vegetable pasta salad, though Ingrid had brought along a plate of fried pheasant too. 

 

"I'm here to mediate," Byleth responded, sitting between the two students.

 

"Ah, is everything okay?" Ashe asked, making Ingrid look a bit sheepish. 

 

"It's… something that may have been my fault," Ingrid admitted, while Bernadetta tried to shrink into her clothes. 

 

"Ingrid apparently broke Bernadetta’s door,” Byleth explained, “She fixed it, but I wanted to make sure everything was okay." 

 

"Really? I didn't think the knights of Faerghus made a habit of breaking down doors," Yuri remarked. 

 

"It was a one time thing!" Ingrid shouted though she immediately regretted it as Bernadetta squeaked. 

 

"What exactly happened?" Ashe inquired, trying to distract the easily frightened archer.

 

"A-Ah, Ingrid came by b-because the professor was training her, and Ingrid realized she hadn't seen me in the training grounds for some time…" 

 

"I went to go fetch her and…when she didn't come out of her room, I took it upon myself to take drastic measures," Ingrid elaborated after Bernadetta trailed off. 

 

"While it is impressive she was able to kick the door off its hinges, I wanted to make sure everything was okay," Byleth finished. 

 

"I'm not sure if I can accept that compliment at the moment," Ingrid said with a frown. "Though while I will apologize for the door, I still think it was for the best that she joined in on the training." 

 

"B-But what if there was someone scary in there!? I m-mean, th-there was that one time I got trapped in there with Felix and Emily after Shez left me…" 

 

"She did?" Byleth asked, a bit surprised. "I'll make sure to talk to her." 

 

"A-Ah, n-no, it's okay, professor!" 

 

"Well…while I can't speak for Emily,” Ingrid began, deciding not to mention how unpleasant the surly Adrestian tended to be, “Felix isn't… as bad as he might seem." 

 

"You sure? He seemed to be quite moody from what I saw," Yuri noted, "Unless he's just not a fan of Hanneman's lessons." 

 

"Well, they admittedly aren't usually what Felix wants to focus on," Ingrid commented, "Though, how do you know about Professor Hanneman's lessons?" 

 

"Oh, Yuri used to be part of the Blue Lions a few years ago, apparently,” Ashe answered.

 

"He was? Huh… well, I did see him working for Count Rowe in the past, so that makes sense." 

 

"Heh, if you count being adopted by him as working, then sure," Yuri responded. "And if I remember correctly, you came by to talk with Gwendal about something. Mind If I ask what it was about?" 

 

"Ah… I was… cleaning up a friend's mistake." 

 

"Sylvain?" Byleth asked, to which Ingrid nodded. 

 

"Yes, he angered Lord Gwendal by flirting with his daughter."

 

"Aaah. Well, for what it's worth, I didn't mind his flirting that much," Yuri responded, getting a skeptical look from Ingrid. "For the record, Gwendal doesn't have a daughter. Though I do consider him like a father." 

 

“...Oh! Oh, um…well, you do look really pretty,” she noted, staring at Yuri’s face with a thoughtful expression, which earned a smirk from him.

 

“Nice to know my looks are appreciated~ Really, he’s not the first to make that sort of assumption and I doubt he’ll be the last so long as I keep these dashing good looks of mine.”

 

“Ah…right, so, I did want to say I’m sorry, Bernadetta,” Ingrid apologized, focusing back on the shorter girl, “I was too hasty–Well, maybe hasty isn’t the right word…I acted without thinking, and I’m sorry I destroyed your door and scared you like that.”

 

Bernadetta, however, wasn’t paying attention to her. In fact, she was staring at Yuri with a thoughtful expression, which, well, he had a feeling she might piece things together, though he did kind of want to put off that conversation for later. Perhaps in a less public setting? But, well, if she was looking…

 

“Hello there, Bernie~ Are you so completely entranced by my beauty that you’re at a loss for words~?”

 

“H-H-Huh!? A-Ah, n-n-no–I-I-I m-mean, u-uh, y-yes–N-No, wait wait wait! I-I-I–”

 

“Yuri!” Ah, and that earned a frown from Ingrid. “Don’t tease Bernadetta like that!”

 

“Oh, alright, I’ll focus my attention on you then if you insist~” Ooo, he actually got her to turn a little pink there.

 

She grimaced a second later though. “Please, I grew up with Sylvain, you’re going to have to step up your game if you want to make me blush.”

 

“Ha, well if you want to make it a challenge for me, then sure, I’m up for it~”

 

“Yuri.” And that was an interestingly chiding tone from Byleth there. “Stop teasing my students.”

 

“Oh? I didn’t think Ingrid transferred.”

 

“Stop teasing students in general.”

 

“Aw, that’s no fun. Well can I tease you instead?” he asked with a grin, “You are rather easy on the eyes after all." 

 

"Thank you," Byleth said, nonplussed as she ate her salad. 

 

"Aw, no reaction?" 

 

"I'm not interested in romance." 

 

"Turned down twice in one day, starting to think I'm losing my edge." 

 

"I'm sure you'll recover." 

 

Letting out an amused huff, Yuri got up, deciding to cut his losses and leave. A moment afterwards, Ashe followed behind him, making him grin as he glanced at the Lion. "You're quite the earnest man, aren't you?" 

 

"Well, you said you needed an escort, right?" 

 

"That's true. I'm just surprised you've stuck around my side this entire time," Yuri said, before tussling his hair. "You're going to be quite the heartbreaker in the future, aren't you?" 

 

"W-What you're talking about?" 

 

"Well hey there Ashe, who's your friend here?" Sylvain asked, a grin on his face as he looked at Yuri. 

 

"O-Oh, hey Sylvain. This is Yuri." 

 

"Yuri huh? You know, I remember reading that Yuri can be another name for a lily, and gotta say, you're definitely as pretty as a flower," he said with a wink. 

 

"Well, better than your last attempt to flirt with me," Yuri noted with a smirk. "What was it you said all those years ago? 'Hello there Chickadee, how about you let this rooster into the henhouse?' I believe it was." 

 

Yuri had to admit, as fun as it was seeing Sylvain’s eyes widen in shock as he remembered meeting Yuri before, Ashe's grimace was far more hilarious. 

 

"Oh, well, uh…right." 

 

"Is that offer still on the table or…?" He couldn't help the smirk that crossed his face as Sylvain immediately turned around to leave as his face turned red. "Oh I am going to have so much fun joining the Lions again."

Chapter End Notes

Red: You know, I just realized this is twice we've used "The Lone Wolf" as the title for a Yuri-focused chapter in one of our Three Houses/Hopes stories. Funny how that happens.

Indi: We're bound to have some overlap. Either way, we wanted to thank everyone for getting us to 1000 kudos!

Red: Yup! So here, have this little extra thing showing what Yuri's up to. We do have all the other Wolves around, after all, so we might as well find a place for him too.

Indi: Yup yup, and we hope y'all enjoyed it!

Back to Class

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Ethereal Moon, a month of respite for the students of Garreg Mach Monastery. For many, this particular moon was what they were looking forward to all year, as it was the time of the monastery’s grand ball. A special occasion where they may all eat, drink, and dance the night away. There was even the chance for romance to bloom. 

 

However, not all was well for the students. For one class in particular it was a time of great strife and pain, in which a sacrifice must be made. One of their number would be thrown to the wolves, never to recover again should they fail. Yes, for the Blue Lions it was the worst time of the year. 

 

The White Heron cup was upon them. 

 

Dimitri took a deep, troubled breath as he looked out over his friends and classmates. “Friends, I come to you with an important question. One that will decide the fate of the Blue Lions House going forward: Who should be our representative for the White Heron Cup?”

 

“Why don’t you do it?” Sylvain suggested, earning an immediate frown from Dimitri.

 

“Sylvain, you’re my friend, so I’ll let that slide.”

 

“...Not sure how that could be taken as an insult, but, uh, thanks?”

 

"I haven't danced since I was a child, Sylvain, if I were to try now I'll just make a mockery of myself," Dimitri explained while Mercedes did her best not to laugh as she remembered the image Byleth had brought up. 

 

"Oooh, in that case, I wanna volunteer!" Annette offered,  immediately jumping up, causing relief to fall over most of the Blue Lions as she did. 

 

"Oh, I didn't know you could dance, Annie," Mercedes remarked. 

 

"Well, I mean, I haven't really been taught or anything, but I'm sure if I give it my all I'll do fine!" 

 

"You did have nice footwork when you were singing," Felix noted, almost making Annette fall over. 

 

"Felix, you weren't supposed to say anything about that!" 

 

"I do remember saying I didn't agree to your deal." 

 

"Well well, didn't expect Felix to go after little Annette~" Sylvain teased. "I mean, getting to hear her sing and dance, it sounds like you two are quite close." 

 

"I'm doing no such thing. All I did was overhear her in the greenhouse," Felix said with a frown. "Besides, I'm pretty sure Claude also heard her once before, given that song I heard him singing to himself-" 

 

"AAAAAH THAT’S IT, I'M NOT VOLUNTEERING!" Annette yelled, her face scarlet as she ran away. 

 

"Oh, I hope you'll excuse me, I'm going to go make sure she's okay," Mercedes said, getting up to follow Annette.

 

Sylvain sighed. "Well, there goes that plan. Good going, Felix." 

 

"How is it my fault? I was saying she was a good fit for the position!" 

 

"Either way, we're down a volunteer." 

 

"Maybe we should just have Professor Hanneman choose?" Ashe suggested. "If none of us want to volunteer, we might as well leave it up to chance." 

 

"Honestly, do none of you know how to dance?" Yuri asked, a bit astounded. "I know Faerghus likes to focus on knighthood above all else, but I would think at least some of you were taught how to dance." 

 

"Kinda hard to learn how to dance when you're trying to swim in a full set of armor," Sylvain noted. 

 

"Or fighting a pack of wolves with just a sword," Ingrid said.

 

"Or just trying to make sure your house doesn't get encased in snow…" Ashe muttered. 

 

Not for the first time since joining the Blue Lions, Dedue felt very worried for his classmates.

 

"Hm, well, as an olive branch to my new classmates, I suppose I might as well volunteer to do away with this negativity,” Yuri offered, “I may never have been officially taught, but I did spend enough time around nobles back in the empire to pick up a thing or two." 

 

"Oh, that's great Yuri-" 

 

"That being said, I expect to be paid back for this. Unless any of you want to volunteer." He was met with silence. "Excellent, in that case, I might as well practice a bit." And might be a good idea to scope the competition. He was confident enough in his skills, but it would only be proper to know who he was going up against.

"Okay so that's…two votes for Ferdinand, three for Flayn, and seven for Dorothea," Byleth stated as she noted down the final tally.

 

"Well, it is a shame I wasn't chosen, but I will cheer you on nonetheless Dorothea!" Flayn said, smiling at her classmate. 

 

"Aw, thanks Flayn~! If it helps, I did vote for you," Dorothea replied, smiling at her shorter classmate. 

 

"Yes, as much as I wished to show off my own moves, I couldn't help but vote for you as well Flayn. The eagerness you showed set my own noble heart ablaze!" Ferdinand declared, smiling brightly.

 

"Perhaps it was for the best you didn't win, Ferdinand. Though I may have voted for you, I do seem to recall you making quite the fool of yourself back when I attended a ball your family was hosting," Constance remarked, laughing into her fan. 

 

"I remember no such thing! Perhaps you were just so dazzled by my moves that you misremembered it? Isn't that right, Lady Edelgard?" 

 

"...Perhaps it is for the best that you choose to fight as cavalry, Ferdinand," Edelgard noted, getting her class to laugh as she also remembered his…dazzling moves. 

 

"Well, guess that settles that. Was kinda obvious Dorothea would win," Hapi muttered. 

 

"It really was. Logically speaking, the one most skilled at dancing should be the one to do so," Linhardt added, bored with the proceedings already.

 

"I-I'm just glad I don't have to be the one to do it, I'm already dreading the ball…" Bernadetta commented, not looking forward to having to dance in front of so many people.

 

"...we don't need to dance, right?" Marianne asked. 

 

"Come on you two, it'll be great!" Caspar said, grinning at his classmates. "Tons of food and fun!" 

 

"Hm…will they be allowing traditional Brigid dances?" Petra asked.

 

"There is no rule stating what dances are allowed," Hubert noted. 

 

"I'll check to make sure it's all okay," Byleth said, nodding. "I should probably also read up on dances to help Dorothea practice." 

 

"Oh, thank you Professor. Do you have any experience?" 

 

"None at all, but I have read up on dancers. Apparently if you win, the church will reward us with materials to let you be one on the battlefield." 

 

"Hmph, how preposterous. So should we expect her to perform a ballroom dance as we fight?" Hubert snidely asked. 

 

"Not exactly. Traditionally dancers on the battlefield help raise morale by inspiring troops, and supposedly the winner of the contest will also be awarded with garb that has been enchanted to increase their speed," Byleth responded, "So even though I don't know how to dance, I'll do my best to help." 

 

"Heh, in that case, I'll do my best!" Dorothea declared, a grin on her face. "Though if you want to help me practice, then it's best to get some in-person practice instead of reading some books." 

 

"Ah… are you sure? I've never really danced before." 

 

"Of course! In fact, why don't we all practice together? I mean, even if I'm the one competing, the ball is still happening at the end of the month~" Dorothea said, grinning. 

 

"...Hm, that is true, and our mission this month is only dealing with some bandits, so we don't have anything big to deal with," Byleth considered, thinking for a moment, before nodding. "Okay, today's class shall be dance practice." 

 

"W-What!?" Bernadetta squeaked.

 

"Great, in that case, come on then! The courtyard would be better for this!" Dorothea said, leading some of her more eager classmates out, while those not looking forward to the dance trudged behind. 

 

"Well, I must admit, I never thought I would have 'dance practice' as one of my lessons at the academy," Edelgard said to Byleth, "Not to be rude, but would I be able to skip this? I actually am a skilled dancer as it is." 

 

"You are? I'm surprised you didn't volunteer." 

 

"Yes, I quite enjoyed dancing when I was younger. Though, as you can plainly see, I wasn't the most eager to do so," Edelgard pointed out, looking out at the courtyard as she saw Dorothea instruct some of their classmates, "And I have no interest in being a dancer on the field as it were. It would be quite difficult dancing in a full set of armor." 

 

Byleth couldn't help but imagine that, making her giggle for a moment. 

 

"I suppose that would be inspiring in its own way," Byleth said, missing the slight smile on Edelgard’s face from hearing her professor giggle. "Oh, if you are a skilled dancer, would you be able to dance with Dorothea so I can have an example?" 

 

"...Professor, if I may ask, are you… attempting to accomplish something between Dorothea and I?" 

 

"I think you two would be cute together." 

 

Edelgard felt her face warm at the admission, though she wasn’t sure how to feel about it. Her professor was the person she had feelings for, so being told she was trying to nudge her towards another woman was…confusing. Though, she did feel her eyes turn towards Dorothea, noting the kind smile on her face as she led Petra through a few steps of a waltz. 

 

“...H-Hm.” How in the world was she supposed to respond to a statement like that?

 

Byleth, meanwhile, felt her smile grow as she saw Edelgard staring at Dorothea with a very obvious blush. She was definitely the best matchmaker! 

"So… how exactly do we break this news?" Claude asked Hilda and Lorenz. 

 

"How does someone even do that with this type of news?" Lorenz asked in turn, frowning as he looked at his class, squabbling amongst themselves about who'd be made to be the representative. 

 

"I mean… it would probably be best just to tell her right?" Hilda suggested, really not happy, that she had to be involved as Claude’s retainer. "She's not gonna be happy if we keep this a secret and she finds out from someone else." 

 

"...Very well. My father is the one attempting to handle matters, so it's only right I do so as well." Lorenz decided, frowning as he prepared himself. 

 

"Right, thanks Lorenz. I'll make sure to keep the class occupied while you do," Claude offered, trying to put a smile on his face as he approached his classmates. "Hey there everyone, any luck on choosing the sacrifice?" 

 

"Oh yeah, it's gonna be Emily," Shez said, getting said student to slam her hands on the desk. 

 

"I never said yes!" 

 

"I can do it if she doesn't want to,” Raphael offered, “I'll make sure everyone has a fun time laughing!" 

 

"Raphael, you're not supposed to make people laugh at the white Heron cup…" Ignatz pointed out.

 

"As much as I don't like to admit it, a noble would probably be a better option for this," Leonie noted with a frown. "Pretty sure any dances I know aren't going to be a hit." 

 

"I have no interest in dancing either. I've been neglecting my studies, so I'll be focusing on that." Lysithea said, thinking about how she was already making preparations for going to the Empire. Though that was cut off as Lorenz tapped her shoulder, gesturing for her to follow him. 

 

"I mean, I'd be willing to do it if someone paid me," Balthus muttered as the mage and cavalier left the classroom. Lysithea could hear Hilda begin to try and nudge Emily into agreeing as they left, so odds were the Adrestian noble really would be their ‘sacrifice’.

 

"What do you want?" she asked her taller classmate after they walked a bit further, not wanting to be overheard by the Black Eagles practicing in the courtyard. 

 

"Ah… Lysithea, have you heard about what has happened in the Alliance?" Lorenz asked, trying to broach the topic carefully. 

 

"Nothing as of late. Why, what happened?"

 

"Well…after the Almyran attack, several nobles began to...take political action, attempting to expand their own powers and such. As it turns out, Archeron is one of those nobles." 

 

"Hm? And what did that blowhard do?" 

 

"He has made an attempt to try and raise his house into great house status. To that end, he has taken over Ordelia territory." 

 

Lysithea went still, her eyes going wide. "...What?" 

 

"He is using the Almyran attack as an excuse to say that despite its status as a great house, Ordelia made no attempt to help." 

 

"Th-That's because it doesn't have the power to do so!" 

 

"Exactly. That lack of power is the leg he is using to stand on to try and force this. And since no other great house attempted to help during the attack either, all of them are keeping quiet." 

 

"That–They can't just do nothing!" 

 

"It's difficult. I understand what you're thinking, but Archeron has made his demands, and has said if they aren't met, he will attempt to secede to the Empire, saying he is already in contact with Duke Aegir," Lorenz explained, frowning, "My father has taken your family under his protection, so they are safe, but as he is part of the pro-Imperial households in the Alliance, there is little he can do under such threats without jeopardizing the connections he has." 

 

"..." 

 

"My father will attempt to figure out something, but until then he will ensure your family is–Lysithea?!" Lorenz called out in surprise as the mage abruptly pushed past him, and ran towards Edelgard. 

 

"Edelgard, what the hell!?" she called out the princess, breaking her out of her stare as she tore her eyes from where she had been watching Dorothea and Byleth practicing. 

 

"Lysithea, what is the matter?" 

 

"Isn't it obvious!? Why is Acheron attempting to secede to the Empire with Ordelia territory!?" Lysithea demanded to know, getting the practice to stop as everyone heard what she was saying. 

 

Edelgard’s eyes visibly widened in surprise, before she moved to fully face the younger girl. “What are you talking about?”

 

“I’m talking about Acheron! The Weathervane of House Phlegethon! Why is he threatening to secede to the Empire with my parents’ territory!?”

 

“...” Her frown deepened, her eyes glancing towards Lorenz for a moment before she looked at Lysithea again. “Lysithea, I need you to explain to me what happened. I haven’t heard of any of this.”

 

“How couldn’t you?! Lorenz said–!”

 

“Lysithea, pardon my interruption, but I believe Edelgard when she says she knows nothing of what happened,” Lorenz cut in, trying to head off Lysithea’s anger before he looked towards the imperial princess, “Though I will note that it is concerning that Acheron is apparently operating with the backing of the Imperial Prime Minister.”

 

“...Lorenz, Lysithea, please explain to me what you mean,” Edelgard requested, her tone noticeably getting colder after the Prime Minister was mentioned.

 

“Acheron stole my parents’ land,” Lysithea explained, scowling, “He’s trying to push to join the Round Table and he occupied Ordelia territory to make that happen! Apparently my parents are only safe because Lorenz’s father is sheltering them–Ah, thank you for that, by the way.”

 

“Ah, no need to–”

 

“But now that he’s occupying our land, he’s saying he’ll secede to the Empire if his House doesn’t get to become a great one!” she continued, verbally barreling over Lorenz along the way, “And–And he just–How could he even do that?!”

 

“...Well, he has shown himself to be very opportunistic–”

 

“I KNOW THAT PART, LORENZ! I don’t understand how he did it! Didn’t we fight his forces off easily just a few months ago?! How could he possibly muster enough military power to take over Ordelia territory to begin with!? Is the Empire really helping him that much!?”

 

“I don’t think so, but I plan to investigate,” Edelgard stated with a deep frown on her face, “Let me assure you, Lysithea, I had no idea Lord Acheron was making a move like this." 

 

"At the very least I've heard no word of my father being in contact with Archeron," Ferdinand said with a frown as he came over, "I can assure you if he is behind this, he shall properly pay his dues!" 

 

"Professor, my apologies, but I shall need to step away for the moment," Edelgard stated, getting Byleth to nod as she frowned. 

 

"So, I don't really know what's going on, but a bad guy took over Lysithea's place right?” Caspar spoke up, “Then let's go beat him up!" 

 

"It's not that simple, Caspar. It'd be one thing if he was just making an attempt to seize Ordelia’s land, but the fact that he was already able to take over the territory without anyone noticing, all while aided by unknown forces means we cannot act rashly," Lorenz responded, not noticing how Byleth perked up at the words ‘unknown forces’. 

 

“...Lysithea, can I speak with you for a moment?” the professor requested, prompting a curious look from Lorenz and a slight frown from Ferdinand.

 

“Professor…does the name ‘Myson’ mean anything to you?” the ginger noble decided to ask, earning an alarmed look from Edelgard that she barely managed to hide while Byleth frowned, thinking she might know where he was going with this. Lorenz and Lysithea, meanwhile, were just confused.

 

“No, it doesn’t. It might relate to who I am thinking about though. May I ask who ‘Myson’ is?”

 

“A warlock that my father associates with.” Even Ferdinand couldn’t miss the gasp Lysithea let out there.. “One I harbor certain…suspicions towards.”

 

“F-Ferdinand, does this Myson person belong to a group–” 

 

Edelgard cleared her throat, catching everyone’s attention. “I believe this matter may require more…subtlety to discuss.”

 

“Oh, not to worry, Edelgard. I am the very picture of subtlety!” Lorenz assured. No one, aside from Ferdinand, looked reassured.

 

“...Be that as it may, Lorenz, we’re still in the courtyard,” she pointed out.

 

“Oh, that is true. Well, I’m sure we can find a more private location to discuss this matter then!" 

 

"...I'm sorry Lorenz, but this is a private matter between Edelgard and Lysithea," Byleth said, getting Lorenz to frown before he shook his head.

 

"I'm afraid that I can't sit this one out, professor. As it is, I do feel some guilt for allowing this situation to occur in the first place. It was my decision to spare Archeron when I dealt with him a few months ago and if I had taken action then." 

 

"I understand, and I appreciate your stance. However, I think it would be better if we talk privately first. We can tell you the details when it’s possible, but for now, can you write back to your father to ask for more information on what happened in Ordelia territory?”

 

"..." Letting out a sigh, Lorenz frowned. "Very well, that does sound like it could help, but I request you tell me as soon as you can!" 

 

At his request, Edelgard nodded. "Now then, I believe we should head back into the classroom to discuss this." 

 

That didn’t sit well with her retainer. "Lady Edelgard, I don't-" 

 

"Hubert, please make sure no one enters the room while we discuss things," Edelgard said, her tone making it clear it was an order, not a request. 

 

"...Very well, Lady Edelgard," Hubert agreed, glowering as he did. Soon enough, the four of them were in the Black Eagle classroom, the doors closed to give them privacy. 

 

"Ferdinand, who is Myson?" Lysithea demanded to know. For a moment, Ferdinand glanced at Edelgard who nodded in return. 

 

"Both she and the professor are aware of what happened to me."

 

"...As I said, he is a warlock my father keeps company with. While I have no definitive proof of what he did, he, along with my father, committed a horrible atrocity," Ferdinand explained, "I haven't seen him in years, but if Archeron is being truthful about working with my father, I wouldn't be surprised if Myson has been a middleman of sorts." 

 

"It also means that the people Myson is working with might also be taking a more proactive role," Byleth noted. 

 

"For that matter, who exactly are these people?" Ferdinand asked. 

 

"They're apparently from a place called Agartha. They also seem to be performing several experiments in an attempt to create a human weapon," Lysithea explained, and as she did, Ferdinand glanced between her and Edelgard, a look of understanding crossing his face. 

 

"I see…" 

 

"One thing is certain, if we are to act, we must do something about Duke Aegir first. With Ordelia under his control, trying to do something to Archeron can put those still living under that territory in danger, particularly if he has Aegir’s backing," Edelgard said, before looking at Lysithea, "Will that be okay, Lysithea?" 

 

"...My parents are okay. As far as I am aware, my father and Count Gloucester are old friends, so I'm sure he's treating them well. Do not expect me to wait forever though." 

 

"Of course, we shall move as soon as possible." 

 

"Yes, if my father truly is involved, then there will be evidence this time, I'm sure of it!" Ferdinand said, getting Edelgard to frown. 

 

"And what if there isn't?" she asked, catching him off guard. 

 

"Excuse me?" 

 

"What if there is no evidence? Are we going to sit idly by and do nothing?" 

 

"That is not what I mean, Lady Edelgard. However, if he is to stand trial, we must first obtain evidence of his wrongdoings." 

 

"Would that even help?" Byleth asked. "If he’s corrupt, then how many other people are corrupt? For all we know, the person meant to sentence him could be in his pocket." 

 

"That–I understand my father may be a criminal, but we cannot assume every noble is one as well." 

 

"Even if they aren't, most of them are self-serving," Lysithea muttered, "My family suffered because of the Empire before and no other house did anything, and even now they aren't acting." 

 

"I'm sure they're just biding their time as well-" Ferdinand started, before Edelgard slammed her hand on a desk. 

 

"Ferdinand, you should know as well as I do by now how corrupt the nobility can be. Six of the major houses in the empire turned against the emperor, and sat idly by as my family was experimented on. If you truly believe it is the duty of a noble to look after everyone else, then you should see how this system has laid the foundation for corruption!" Edelgard stated, frowning at Ferdinand. "Our ancestors might have 'earned' the right to be nobles, but how did the nobility of those who came after earned it? I am willing to admit there are those who may be deserving of being called noble, but a vast majority have the title simply because of their blood, and they make no attempt to prove themselves worthy!" 

 

“...I…cannot deny your words. But I still believe in nobility! Yes, it may be…less common than it should be for nobles to live up to the ideal they should hold, but that does not devalue those ideals!”

 

“I don’t have anything against those ideals, Ferdinand. What I take exception with is the people who use those ideals as an excuse to be corrupt! People who claim to be guiding and protecting the commonfolk under their power while actually abusing them benefit from the concept of the ideal nobility! As long as we place value in the system of nobility, it can be used as an excuse to do harm!”

 

“That’s not–...” Ferdinand took a breath. “I know there are problems, Edelgard. I…What do you propose we do then? If you’re so convinced we cannot have my father removed through legal means, what do you plan to do? Because I will not condone assassination.”

 

“Nor should you. And I do not intend to use illegal means to remove your father, merely nonstandard ones.” Edelgard straightened, facing Ferdinand directly. “Ferdinand von Aegir, would you support me if I chose to take the throne of Adrestia before the school year ends?”

 

"I… I already made it clear that I will support you when you become Emperor. Though, I would like to point out that you would have many duties that you would need to perform should you choose to become Emperor, many of which would require your attention far more than what the academy would let you." 

 

"I understand that. If need be, I am willing to withdraw from the academy," Edelgard stated, catching everyone off guard. 

 

"You are?" Ferdinand asked.

 

"...I suppose that's as good a sign as any how seriously you're taking this," Lysithea remarked, still frowning. 

 

Byleth, meanwhile, stayed silent, not sure what to say. Especially since she felt… tense. She had already known Edelgard was going to be Emperor, but for her to leave before the school year was over… 

 

"...very well. I must admit, it would be foolish of me to stand against you if you're being genuine. I, Ferdinand Von Aegir, swear to support your ascension to the throne." 

 

"Thank you." At that, Edelgard glanced at Byleth. "Professor, there are things I would need to prepare first, but would you be willing to accompany me when I head to the empire later this month?" 

 

"You want me to go with you?" 

 

"For one to ascend to the throne, one needs a representative from the church. I can think of no other I would prefer than you to be the representative," Edelgard stated. 

 

"...okay, I promise." 

 

"If I may, what exactly are you planning on doing once you ascend the throne?" Lysithea asked. At that, Edelgard took a deep breath. This was a big risk, but if she could convince Ferdinand, then she could surely convince everyone else. 

 

"I plan on abolishing the nobility system." 

 

"E-Edelgard–!?" Ferdinand started before she raised a hand to cut him off. 

 

"To be specific, my plan is to establish a system of merits, one where those who have the ability to, shall rise and be rewarded. Even if there are nobles who truly wish to protect those under them, they aren't allowing them to flourish. Think about Dorothea, because of the circumstances she had, she was able to join the academy despite being a commoner, but how many other commoners could be as skilled as her, if not more, if they were only given a chance to rise above their station? If we had more people like you, then this system would not be needed, but as is, if you truly wish to help the commonfolk, then you must see how damaging the nobility system is to them. If you truly wish to guide them as a noble, then do so, help them rise above their station so that those who can are able to earn the position they deserve!" 

 

"I… I understand what you are saying, but I have a hard time accepting it. I truly believe that the nobility should work to protect everyone," Ferdinand said, before sighing. "...How certain are you of your system working?" 

 

"It will take a great deal of work, and I don't expect it to be accomplished overnight, but I am completely certain that a new system is needed to fix what is wrong with Adrestia." 

 

"...I want you to write your manifesto. Let me read all your reforms. If I truly believe in what you are saying, I shall fully support you, but, if I find any faults, then I expect you to be willing to listen to my criticism." 

 

"I will be more than willing," Edelgard stated, meeting his eyes without flinching. 

 

After a moment, he nodded. "Very well. Then, as said, I, Ferdinand Von Aegir, shall support your ascension to the throne." 

 

At that, Edelgard couldn't help but feel a swell of joy. It worked, she had been able to convince him! 

 

"...Thank you Ferdinand," Edelgard said, hiding the elation she felt before she turned to Lysithea. "My apologies for getting off topic, Lysithea."

 

"It seemed necessary," Lysithea replied, turning away. "...For what it's worth, I had no intention of continuing House Ordelia. I am not opposed to your idea of doing away with the nobility." 

 

"Somehow, it feels like my statements lose some of their standing when another noble is okay with doing away with the nobility…" Ferdinand muttered. 

 

"Come now Ferdinand. If you end up crumbling so easily, I'm not sure how well any criticisms you have may stand," Edelgard teasingly chided. "Now, before we end this, I must ask that you keep what I told you a secret. I am planning on informing more people of my plans, but if word were to spread, then who knows what the nobility of Adrestria may do?" Or what the Church might do, but she wouldn’t say that.

 

"Hmph, I'm not one to spread gossip," Lysithea said. 

 

"I swear to keep this discussion a secret, though I do ask you to hurry with your manifesto," Ferdinand requested. 

 

"Of course. Oh, and Ferdinand, could you distract Hubert for a bit as you leave so I may discuss something with the professor?" 

 

"I shall do my best,” Ferdinand stated, before he and Lysithea left. The pair that remained behind heard Ferdinand say something about needing Hubert's help to practice dancing, before the doors closed again.

 

"...I must admit, being able to openly discuss my plans certainly removes a weight from my shoulders," Edelgard said with a smile. Byleth responded with a noncommittal noise, thinking that if things really had gone wrong with Ferdinand, she might have turned back time just to stop it. "I suppose I have you to thank in part for that, my teacher. If you hadn't made me tell Lysithea and Shez my reasoning I might have ended up keeping more secrets." 

 

"Well, I'm glad I could help," Byleth said, before frowning. "...are you actually going to leave the academy?" 

 

"...if need be, yes. I must say, this isn't quite exactly how I planned on becoming emperor, but such is how things go." 

 

"When are you leaving?" 

 

"...I would prefer to be here for the White Heron cup, to cheer Dorothea on,” she explained, which did make Byleth perk up a little, “Afterwards, I'll likely head back to take the throne, though I am not certain when exactly I will be withdrawing from the academy." 

 

"You should make sure to stay for the ball. Everyone is looking forward to it and it won't be the same with you gone." 

 

"If I can, I'll make sure to be here," Edelgard agreed, "At the very least, I would prefer we properly deal with Emily before I actually leave." 

 

"Hm…" Byleth couldn't help but frown. She knew they had to address the Emily issue. She was well aware, but…

 

"Being the emperor will help with that,” Edelgard continued, unaware of Byleth’s inner turmoil, “It will be easy to investigate the Korsch family to see if Emily has been replaced. I have to admit, I am already convinced she is one of the imposters, but it would be best if we could be sure.”

 

“Right…” That hadn’t been what Edelgard said before. She could change her mind, of course, that was fine. Right? “When do you think she was replaced?”

 

“If I were to guess, I imagine it had to be before the school year began.”

 

“So the Emily we’ve known was never the real Emily.” Byleth frowned, leaning back against one of the desks. “Which means the ‘Emily’ we know is an entirely different person from whoever Emily Korsch was. It also means the original is likely dead. It would be foolish to leave her alive if they had no further use for her.” She knew she was echoing Sothis’s words. Part of her felt like a hypocrite.

 

“That is very likely, yes.”

 

“...It’s strange. I shouldn’t feel conflicted, but I do. Emily can be unpleasant, but…she is one of my students. Or, she was.”

 

“Professor…you can’t feel that way about a spy.”

 

“I know. I just…I hope she really isn’t an enemy. I don’t want to hurt one of my students.”

 

“...That’s a very kind attitude for a mercenary, professor,” Edelgard noted, trying to sound a little teasing.

 

“I’m a teacher now, not a mercenary. My attitude needs to change to suit my profession. I think.” She shrugged. “...Maybe things would have been simpler if my father hadn’t left all those years ago and I became a knight instead…but, then, I wouldn’t have what I have now, so…Everything is very complicated.”

 

“Indeed. Life tends to be, professor. If it wasn't, I likely would have remained a spoiled princess, maybe only worrying about an arranged marriage or what sweets I would try to sneak at night," Edelgard said wistfully, "Though I suppose in that scenario, we likely would have met in the academy again. Just without the bandits coming after us." 

 

"Maybe? That's… nice to think about, still being able to meet you all," Byleth replied, a small smile on her face. 

 

"Yes, though, I am glad to be able to call you my teacher." 

 

"And I'm glad to be able to have you as my student." 

 

"...Professor, before I leave the academy, I have something important I wish to tell you," Edelgard said, keeping herself steady, "When that time comes, I hope you are able to understand." 

 

"Of course, whenever you're ready," Byleth replied, before she got up, "Now I'll leave you to your investigating. I should make sure everyone is actually dancing." 

 

"Knowing our classmates, they likely are," Edelgard remarked, chuckling to herself, even as she prepared herself for what she would confess.

 

Her teacher deserved to know her identity as the Flame Emperor.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Woo month for the ball! Surely nothing bad will happen this month? Ignore Acheron.

Red: Yeah that's probably not plot significant at all. More important, dancing! Ignore the Edelgard stuff too.

Indi: Just some cute stuff with everyone having fun!

Red: Absolutely nothing is going to go wrong! And anyways, thanks for reading!

Recruitment Drive

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

“Lady Edelgard, what the fuck?”

 

Edelgard blinked, then glanced up from her tea in visible confusion at her retainer. “...What did you just say, Hubert?”

 

“I said, Lady Edelgard, what do you think you’re doing?”

 

“...” She was fairly certain that wasn’t what he said, but also the first thing she heard sounded so completely out of character for him to say that she genuinely thought an auditory hallucination was more likely. Though his actual question still warranted a prodding response. “I am having tea, Hubert.”

 

He looked distinctly unamused by her wit.

 

"Why did you inform Ferdinand of all people of your plans?" Hubert said, glowering. "It is one thing to divulge your secrets to someone, but why him of all people? Just because he agrees his father must be punished doesn't mean he would have agreed with your goals." 

 

"And yet, he did. While he will likely have his criticisms of my reforms, the fact doesn't change that he is supporting me. Really, the fact that I told Ferdinand is for the best." 

 

"And why exactly is that?" 

 

"Simple, if I was able to convince him, think of how much easier it will be to convince everyone else." 

 

"What?" 

 

"It's what I'm planning on doing. Before I leave to ascend the throne, I'll make my case to my classmates. We are in need of allies, Hubert. It may be some time, years even, before we are capable of declaring war with the choices we’ve made so far, but changing the nobility system in Adrestia will require all the aid we can get. Especially if Those Who Slither in the Dark are active." 

 

"Lady Edelgard, I must insist you do not follow this plan." 

 

"Hubert, you're my most trusted ally, and my closest friend. I understand where your concern is coming from, but both of our ideas share the same level of risk. At least this way, we can plan around those who may or may not work with us, rather than letting things land as they may." 

 

"...I strongly advise against this course of action." 

 

"I'll make sure to keep that in mind. At the very least do take some comfort in knowing I won't tell Flayn." 

 

"I would hope you weren't foolish enough to inform her," Hubert muttered while Edelgard went back to her tea. Despite the confidence she seemed to hold, she was undoubtedly nervous about actually being honest with her classmates. For now though…. Best plan on who to talk to first.

"Dorothea, a word please." 

 

"Oh, sure Edie, what do you need?" Dorothea asked, glancing towards the princess while she helped Marianne practice her dancing with Hilda. It was almost funny seeing the Golden Deer so eagerly join in the next day of practicing after hearing what had happened to Ordelia. Apparently they wanted to distract themselves from the bad news, though Lysithea looked like she was about to blast someone in the face. That was probably because Shez was practically carrying her while they 'practiced' though.
