"Follow me if you would," Edelgard requested, leading the way to a corner at the far end of the courtyard. Raising an eyebrow, Dorothea followed behind, giving Hilda a thumbs up as she gave one in return. "I trust you heard what is happening in the Alliance?" 

 

"It was hard not to, Lysithea was being quite loud yesterday," Dorothea muttered with a frown. "Is everything okay?" 

 

"Not yet, but it will be. I'm having Hubert investigate at the moment and I'm already planning what to do to resolve things," Edelgard explained, "Before the end of the month, I am planning on taking the throne of Adrestia." 

 

"Really? Well, that's a surprise to hear… I had already known you'd be the Emperor, but to hear it happening so soon… well, it's a bit hard to imagine our little Edie like that." Dorothea teased, getting Edelgard to blush. 

 

"H-Hm. To that end, I wanted to know if you would support my ascension?" Now that actually caught her off guard.

 

"Huh? I mean, of course I do. Just, is it necessary to ask me? I mean, I'm not a noble." 

 

"You are still one of my closest friends. Not to mention that an Emperor doesn't just rule over the nobility. I also wished to ask if you truly support me in abolishing the nobility system," Edelgard stated, making her intentions clear. 

 

"...Of course I do, I have no love for the nobility, so if you were to do away with them, I certainly wouldn't complain," Dorothea said, before smiling. "Maybe I really should start writing that play about you? The young emperor seeking to change the empire, perhaps with a dashing mercenary by her side~?" 

 

"Hm. I would prefer the play remain as close to fact as it can if you write it. That being said, I will likely be away from the academy after this month." Edelgard did her best to adopt a teasing smile. "Perhaps you'll be able to take the time to grow closer to our professor while I'm gone." 

 

"Hm~ That is true, I can certainly make sure to sing your praises to her while you're gone~" Dorothea shot back, flustering Edelgard as she did. 

 

"...As odd as this sounds, I will miss being able to talk with you everyday like this once I take the throne, Dorothea," Edelgard said, after calming herself down. 

 

"Same for me Edie, but I look forward to meeting the emperor of Adrestia," Dorothea replied, giggling as they turned back to rejoin the class. 

 

Though as they did, they noticed Byleth speaking with Manuela, before the two glanced over at them. They then proceeded to give them both a thumbs up. 

 

"...Perhaps we should try to clear any misunderstandings first," Edelgard suggested. 

 

"Hm~ I dunno, is it a misunderstanding?" Dorothea asked with a teasing smile. "I mean, it is common for the Emperor to take on multiple consorts, no?" 

 

"...H-Huh?" Edelgard asked, her face burning up. But Dorothea didn’t reply, instead simply heading back to practice with that same teasing smile. “...H-Hmph…th-that’s not…”

 

Edelgard shook her head, trying to clear her head of the thoughts Dorothea’s teasing suggestion brought to mind. It was much more difficult than she thought it should be…

"Thank you for having tea with me, Petra," Edelgard said, smiling at her friend. 

 

"Of course, it is a pleasure to be here," Petra replied, smiling in return. 

 

"Now, while I would love to have small talk, I would rather cut to the chase." 

 

"Are we chasing something?"

 

"No, what I want to say is that I will likely be leaving the academy soon. I intend to become the emperor within the coming weeks." 

 

"Ah… that is certainly not small at all," Petra noted, "You are following your ambitions, yes?" 

 

"I am, though admittedly I didn't plan to go after them so soon. That being said, I do remember telling you I would hit as many pheasant as I needed to. As such, once you graduate, I plan on letting you return to Brigid and freeing your nation." 

 

"...You would?" Petra asked, a bit of disbelief in her voice. 

 

"Yes, I want Brigid to be an ally of the Empire, not a vassal. Once you become the queen of Brigid, I hope we will be able to shake hands as you once said," Edelgard stated, "Though, admittedly, it may be some time before that occurs. The reforms I will enact are guaranteed to cause unrest in the Empire, so I doubt we will be able to discuss becoming allies right away." 

 

"So… you would allow the people of Brigid to be free? No knots to the empire in any way?" Petra asked, "The people of my nation may not do nothing. They bear many grudges and may attempt something." 

 

"I wouldn't be surprised if they did. Even so, I want to put my trust in you, as my friend." 

 

"...You are being far more honest, Edelgard." 

 

"I suppose I am. We can thank our professor for that." 

 

"...The professor is a very kind person," Petra admitted, after a moment of silence. "At times, it is difficult to imagine her as a fighter." 

 

"It is, yet that kindness and strength has guided us and made us all the stronger." 

 

"It has," Petra agreed, before nodding, "I swear, once I am the queen of Brigid, I shall make our nations allies." 

 

"Thank you Petra. I am looking forward to it."

The clashing of axes could be heard in the training grounds, interspersed with the yelling of a young man as he swung his axe with all his might. Yet, even as he did, his opponent was able to block all his attacks with her own axe. Even without her shield, it was clear she was far more skilled with the heavy weapon than he was. Even so, he wouldn't give up, especially when he still had his secret weapon! 

 

With a loud yell, he swung his axe, a flame bursting over its head as he aimed to disarm his opponent! 

 

A loud clang was his answer, as well as a heat far stronger than he was used to as his opponent met his axe with hers, her weapon also coated in fire. 

 

"Aw, I was saving that up and you just have it too?" Caspar complained, pulling back as he began to pant. 

 

"You do remember we have the same professor, right Caspar? We also both share the same affinity," Edelgard asked with a raised eyebrow.

 

"Right, I uh… kinda did forget about that second part," Caspar admitted, a bit sheepishly. "But you know, that was pretty cool! I can already see it! You, the professor, and I, hunting down bandits in the night, only for our weapons to light up the darkness! It'll look so cool!" 

 

"I see you're the same as ever, Caspar." 

 

"Hey, that's not true! I'm way stronger now!" Caspar argued. 

 

"Well, that is true at least." 

 

"Glad you agree! So what's up? You have something important to talk about, right?" 

 

"That I do. I'm surprised you realized it." 

 

"Is it? I mean, it was pretty obvious something was up, you never really ask me to spar and the way you fought was different." Crossing his arms, Caspar thought for a moment. "It was like…like you were the professor! Yeah, like you were testing me or something!" 

 

"...I must admit, I didn't expect you to pick up on that." 

 

"Of course I would! If there's one thing I know, it's fighting!"

 

"That you do," Edelgard said with a smile. "Caspar, I will become Emperor at the end of the month. Once I ascend to the throne, I intend to rid Adrestia of its current system of nobility. As the second son of your family, and someone without a crest, you have very low prospects within our current system. I believe you are capable of doing great things, and in my new system, your talents will have the opportunity to flourish. Do I have your support?”

 

"Do you even need to ask? Of course I’ll back you up, we're friends!" Caspar declared with a smile. "I mean, as long as I get to beat bad guys, I don't think there'll be much change in my life anyways." 

 

"...I must say, you may be remarkably simple at times, but it is surprisingly refreshing." 

 

"Uh…you're welcome? I think?" Caspar said, getting Edelgard to laugh. 

“...Linhardt, how is it that whenever I track you down, you’re always sleeping?”

 

“That feels like it’s more your fault than mine,” Linhardt grumbled from beneath the book he’d laid over his face, his back flat against the grass beneath him as he relaxed in the shade of a tree. "Especially since you're waking me up." 

 

"...Can you please get up so I can discuss something with you?" Edelgard requested, not wanting to get into an argument. 

 

"If this is about you being the emperor and doing away with the nobility, sure, go ahead. I have no interest in taking on any noble duties." 

 

"...” She sighed. “Why do you already know what I'm about to ask you?" 

 

"Did you think Caspar would actually refrain from telling me?" he asked, moving the book on his face so he could give Edelgard a skeptical glance. 

 

"Well, I suppose that is my fault." 

 

"Quite. Anyways, onto more important stuff, I actually came to an astounding break-through in my research," Linhardt said, sitting up, "I think the professor’s crest might be artificial." 

 

"Linhardt, I don't have-... what did you say?" Once his words settled in, Edelgard felt her heart stop for a moment.

 

"Hm… perhaps artificial might not be the right word for it. It might be more accurate to say that I don't think she was born with it," Linhardt continued, muttering to himself. "I've been studying the samples she gave me and to describe it... Crests are inherently magical even if the people who might have one aren't skilled at it. Even so the magic weaves its way into their very being, but when I study the professor… it feels more accurate to say the magic is over her, rather than a part of her. You could say it's like cooking oil and water in a sense." 

 

"That… Linhardt, how certain are you about that?" 

 

"If I were to have another sample, I suppose I would be able to tell. As fascinating as the professor is, only having one subject to study means I can't compare her to anything else. Maybe if Lysithea actually let me study her, I might have an idea, but as it stands that's my limited hypothesis." 

 

"Lysithea?" 

 

"Hm? Oh, yes, it's quite fascinating, I had a hypothesis that she has two crests, and after some carefully worded phrases, she revealed to me that she did. That being said, she is being quite rude in not allowing me to study her." 

 

Edelgard sighed. “Linhardt, I know you tend to ignore social niceties, but even you should be able to understand why a young girl would be put off by your requests to ‘study’ her.”

 

“Hey, my interest is purely academic. All I want to know is how she came to have two crests. I probably wouldn’t need more than a blood sample to get started.”

 

“It should also be obvious that there are very few people who would willingly give their blood to someone upon request. Particularly when that someone is a fellow classmate and not a medical professional, and especially when that classmate has a history of hemophobia.”

 

“Fine, I see your point. Well, what about you then? Would you be willing to help with my research?”

 

Edelgard paused, then frowned at Linhardt. “...Is that meant to be a request to study my crest then?”

 

“Both of them, yes. I do recall that you had brown hair once upon a time, Edelgard. Add in how you and Lysithea seem to have bonded lately, and it’s not too hard to put things together. Loss of pigmentation in the hair, stunted growth, strength that exceeds what a minor crest holder should have, albeit magical for her and physical for you, I doubt I need to go on.” He propped his head up on a hand, an actual glimmer of interest in his eyes as he looked at her. “So, are you willing to aid in my research?”

 

“...Perhaps. My assistance depends on two conditions though.”

 

He sighed, but nodded, before gesturing for her to continue.

 

“First, I want you to report to me on whatever you discover about the professor. If our circumstances are similar…” She shook her head. “Never mind. Just make sure to share your findings with me.”

 

“That does sound annoying…but I guess I could just turn over my notes as reports…but then I actually have to write them so you can understand…” He sighed again. “Sounds like a pain, but sure. Please tell me the second condition isn’t anything too strenuous.”

 

“It may or may not be. What I want to ask is that you look into if it’s possible to remove a crest.”

 

That request made Linhardt sit up, the glimmer of interest turning into outright fascination. “Ah…I see, so a crest can be added then…and if that’s the case, why not removed too? Hm…Alright, Edelgard, you have a deal.”

Edelgard rapped her knuckles against Bernadetta’s door while leaning close, listening for the startled squeak the shy girl almost always let out when someone came to call on her.

 

“A-Ah!” And sure enough, there it was. “U-Uh…p-professor? O-Or is it Ingrid? P-Please don’t break my door again if it’s Ingrid!”

 

“...” Well that was concerning to hear. “No, it’s Edelgard.”

 

“E-Edelgard?! A-Ah, a-are y-you still upset about me following you around!? I-I’m sorry!”

 

“I’m not upset, Bernadetta, we already talked about…” She sighed. “May I come in? It feels awkward to speak to you through a door.”

 

"O-Okay…" A moment later, Edelgard heard the door unlock, and a small scurrying as Bernadetta backed away. Letting out a quiet sigh, she opened the door to find Bernadetta standing in the middle of the room. Well, she wasn't huddled in the corner of her room, so that was good at least. 

 

"Hello Bernadetta. What exactly was that about Ingrid breaking your door?" 

 

"O-Oh, it's n-nothing! Sh-She fixed it so it's a-all good! U-Unless she's angry she had to fix it, and sh-she sent you to deal with me!?" 

 

"She did no such thing, and I certainly wouldn't attack you because someone else broke your door," Edelgard stated, "I actually came by to talk about something important." 

 

"A-Ah, is this revenge for letting the professor get stabbed at the start of the year!? I knew that would come to haunt me!!" 

 

"Bernadetta please, calm down, nothing bad will happen to you I swear," Edelgard assured, trying to speak softly. "I will be claiming the throne of Adrestia soon, and I wish to have your support." 

 

"Y-You will?!" Bernadetta asked, completely surprised. "I-I mean, s-shouldn't you be asking m-my dad? H-He is the minister and a-all." 

 

"Bernadetta, I am aware of what kind of person your father is, he will have no position in the empire I will create. As soon as possible, I shall have him arrested." 

 

"...Y-You will?" Bernadetta asked, sounding very hopeful. 

 

"Yes, I intend to make sure no one like him will ever be able to rise to power again, and once I do away with the nobility, it shall be that much easier." 

 

"O-Oh…h-hm, well, th-that does sound nice, but why do you want my support?" 

 

"If I am being honest, if this had been at the start of the year, I might not have. Yet you proved my initial assumption of you quite wrong," Edelgard said with a smile, "Time and time again, you fought bravely in battle, despite your fear. Despite what you might think, you are a friend of mine, and I want you supporting me when I am Emperor." 

 

"H-Hm…O-Okay. A-Ah, but wait, if you arrest my father, is he g-going to be put under house arrest or something?" 

 

"Until he is properly charged for his crimes, most likely. Though if you would like, you are more than welcome to stay in Enbarr until he is sent away," Edelgard allowed, before smirking, "I'm sure Hubert will be more than happy to show you around the palace." 

 

To Edelgard’s satisfaction, Bernadetta actually did turn red instead of turning the teasing around on her like Dorothea would. 

 

“…d-do you think he would?” That response was a little unexpected though. "I-I mean, s-since he's so much scarier than everything else, he'll m-make sure nobody t-tries to mess with me, r-right?" 

 

“…heh. He most certainly would,” Edelgard agreed, feeling a smile come to her face at the thought of her intentionally intimidating retainer playing bodyguard to the shy Lady Varley. 

Entering Abyss was never a pleasant thing for Edelgard. Though it was far better lit and much more spacious than the dungeon she was once trapped in, the memories it trudged up were far from pleasant. Even so, she made the occasional journey down to read from the shadow library, or, in this situation, secure more allies. 

 

"Hello, Constance, Hapi," Edelgard greeted her housemates, the two lounging in the makeshift dormitories the Ashen wolves had made long ago. 

 

"Hey, Eddy," Hapi lazily greeted as she laid on her bed. 

 

"Oh, your highness, to what do we owe the pleasure of you visiting?" Constance said, immediately standing up. "Is this perhaps about restoring my house?" 

 

"...In a sense, it does involve your house," Edelgard started, getting Constance to perk up. "The main thing I want to speak about is that I shall soon be ascending the throne of Adrestria." 

 

"O-Oh, forgive my impertinence, your majesty!" Constance apologized, eyes widening. 

 

"I am not emperor yet Constance. It also wasn't the main thing I wished to speak about," Edelgard stated, locking eyes with her. "Perhaps in another time, your prowess would have surely returned your House to its status as nobility, but once I become Emperor, I intend to do away with the nobility system entirely." 

 

Blinking in surprise, Hapi sat up as Constance stiffened. 

 

"...What was that, Edelgard?" Constance asked, frowning. 

 

"I intend to set a system of merits, one in which anyone can achieve recognition and greatness for their ability. I came down here to see if you two would be willing to support me." 

 

"...Hm." Constance' mouth thinned while she seemed deep in thought. 

 

"...So, I feel like I need to point out, didn't the church help set up the nobility?" Hapi asked, getting Edelgard’s attention. "Won't that piss them off?" 

 

"Even if the goddess herself were to demand it of me, I would not change my mind." 

 

"Hm, well, I don't care for the church, so I'm all up for pissing them off," Hapi said, before glancing at Constance. "What about you, Coco?" 

 

"Hm, hm, hm, hm… I see. So you wish to establish a system in which ability is more important than blood. Well in that case, I have nothing to worry about!" Constance stated, laughing loudly. "My magic prowess is unmatched, so I shall easily thrive under your regime!" 

 

"Are you certain?" Edelgard asked. "You have been spending this entire time attempting to restore your house, have you not?" 

 

"And I shall! I imagine in your new system, you shall still have need of those to take care of territories, do you not? In that case, I shall prove to you that I am worthy of such a role! Be if through Nobility or Ability, my family name shall get the recognition it deserves!" Constance boasted. "Though I must admit, I would have preferred you told me beforehand so I was not making a fool of myself trying to restore my house to its former status of nobility." 

 

"I would not say that," Edelgard said, "...Though, I did have an interest in one of your spells. If I remember correctly, you have one that can change someone's hair color?" 

 

"Of course! And I have fully worked out all the kinks it once had!" 

 

"Would you… be able to change my hair color to brown, if just for a moment?" 

 

"That I can! Would you like to have a seat while I grab a mirror?" Constance asked, and Edelgard nodded as she sat down. 

 

Moments later, Edelgard stared at her reflection in the mirror. She saw…a normal looking girl looking back at her. One who didn't carry her burdens. 

 

"Gotta say, you look good Eddy," Hapi complimented. 

 

"Thank you," Edelgard said, softly smiling.

 

“...Hey Coco, would you mind if I borrowed Eddy for a sec?” That made her pause, glancing at Hapi, who looked oddly thoughtful.

 

“Hm? Whatever for?” Constance asked.

 

“Just a thing that popped into my head that I want to talk to her about. Promise it won’t take too long.”

 

“Hm…very well, though I will request that you inform me if there is anything that might concern–”

 

“Yeah yeah, I’ll tell you if it’s an important thing.”

 

Constance huffed at her girlfriend’s dismissal, but left the two alone as Edelgard raised an eyebrow at the redhead. “...What do you wish to discuss?”

 

“When you were a kid, did you ever get grabbed by a magic lady that ran experiments on you?”

 

Edelgard blinked. Of all things she could have expected her to say… “No…I was not experimented on by a ‘magic lady’. Did something like that happen to you?”

 

“Yup. Did you think me summoning monsters whenever I sighed was a natural thing?”

 

“...Ah. Hm.” Edelgard took a breath. For some reason…she found herself smiling. “I wish we had spoken earlier. It seems I keep finding people I have something in common with at this monastery…”

 

“Does that mean–No, wait, I think I get it. Little Thea’s also like us, huh?”

 

She blinked. “Little Thea?”

 

“Yup. You know, since Dororo’s Big Thea.”

 

“...” Edelgard tried not to giggle. Something about the blunt manner Hapi said that just tickled her sense of humor in a truly absurd way. “I…You shouldn’t let Lysithea hear you call her that, she would most certainly take it the wrong way.”

 

“Alright, good to know for the future. Hm…Mallow?" 

 

"Mallow?" 

 

"Yeah, you know, short for marshmallow. She kinda reminds me of one and she likes sweets, right?"  

 

“Your reasoning astounds me, Hapi.”

 

“So you agree then, nice.”

 

Edelgard didn't laugh, but she did let out an amused huff. "Why don't we get back to this magic lady you talked about? Can you tell me anything about her?" 

 

"Oh, right, well… she has like…peach-ish hair and huge tits." 

 

"..." Edelgard wasn't going to ask why that was what stuck out to her. "...Did you hear a name?" 

 

"Hm…Cleo-something." 

 

"...Cleobulus?" 

 

"Right, that was her name." 

 

"Hm…well, from what I know, I wasn't experimented on by her, but by one of her associates. While I am unsure who she disguised herself as, I can assure you, I will deal with her in time. Until then, I am actually planning on working in ways to rid our bodies of what these people have done to us. Your own affliction may be different from mine, but would you be okay with staying in Enbarr so you could potentially be cured?" 

 

“Yeah sure, I’m good with that,” Hapi agreed with a shrug, “I was planning to follow Coco anyway, so this just gives me another reason to head there. Gotta say, I didn't think I would have a chance to sigh freely again. I owe you one Eddy." 

 

"You really don't, especially since I can't guarantee I can fix this." 

 

"Still, if I don't pay you back, Coco will probably get all huffy…hm, I'd probably need to talk to Coco, Dororo, and ByBy first if I offered to kiss you." 

 

"H-Huh?" That certainly caught Edelgard off guard. "...L-Leaving aside Constance, why would you need to talk to Dorothea or the professor?" 

 

"Aren't you dating them?" 

 

“W-What gave you that idea? A-And why do you think I would be dating both of them?? I-I am not…p-promiscuous!”

 

“Okay? Not sure what that has to do with anything. I mean, the people back in my village were pretty open about stuff. Besides, don’t you emperor types usually have multiple wives?”

 

Edelgard’s face went scarlet before she let out an exasperated huff. Why did people keep bringing that up? “That doesn’t mean…I-I don’t have time to argue with you. If you want to talk about our mutual experiences later, then I will be fine with that, but if you just want to tease me then I think we better end this conversation here.”

 

“Sure, alright. See ya, Eddy. Say hi to Dororo and ByBy for me.”

 

Edelgard grimaced before walking off, trying to ignore the heat on her face. She really needed to find a way to handle teasing better…

Soon after walking into the stables, Edelgard quickly found who she was looking for as she spotted Marianne gently brushing her horse's mane. Clearing her throat, Edelgard tried to get her attention without spooking the girl. 

 

"O-Oh, Edelgard, hello," Marianne greeted, turning around to face her. "Did you come to check on the horses?" 

 

“I was actually looking for you, Marianne,” she replied, before holding up a hand, “Not for any nefarious reason. I am neither angry at you nor am I here on behalf of someone who most likely isn’t angry at you either.”

 

“...I…see?” Marianne gave her a confused look. “That is…good to know. U-Um, what did you want then?”

 

“I was hoping to speak with you about…Towards the end of this month, I intend to travel back to Enbarr and take the throne as the new Emperor. I have been speaking with my fellow classmates on this matter, and I felt you should be aware as well.”

 

“Oh, I-I see…um…w-why? W-Why tell me, I mean. I’m not an Adrestian noble, I do not see why you would want to tell me about it…”

 

“...Well, you are still my classmate, and I would like to let you know what is happening. That, and you are still the heir of House Edmund. As the heir to one of Leicester’s noble houses…Are you doing alright?” Edelgard asked as she noticed Marianne shrinking back.

 

“A-Ah, s-sorry…I, um…I-I d-don’t think…I-I a-am aware of my position, b-but I don’t think I can help you. I-I can’t promise any help from my father and…I-I w-wouldn’t be useful to you…”

 

"...Perhaps I misspoke, I am not seeking any aid from your father. I know not what man he is, but I do know who you are," Edelgard said, being careful with her words, "I also know that your crest has caused you many problems. Not simply because of the superstitions surrounding it, but also how people view crests." 

 

"...E-Edelgard?" Marianne asked, trembling a bit as she listened to Edelgard’s intense, determined voice.

 

"I intend to create a nation free of the crest system," she stated, immediately earning a gasp from Marianne. "Long have people suffered because of these 'blessings', whether they have them or not. So I do not want your father's support. I want the support of Marianne, someone who suffered under this system because of something out of her control." 

 

"Th-that… y-you… th-the church…" 

 

"Even if I have to become an enemy of the world, I shall fight until we are free from this tyranny," Edelgard stated, her gaze unwavering even as Marianne was unable to meet hers. "If you do not wish to support me, then I understand. Even so, I promise you that I shall make a world where you do not need to suffer." 

 

"...H-How are you so s-sure of yourself?" Marianne asked. 

 

"...A long time ago, I used to be quite pious myself, fully believing in the church and its ideals. Yet, despite my faith, neither the church nor the goddess protected my family or I. If the goddess does exist, then I am not favored by her. For the sake of my family, and for anyone else who has suffered, I had to remain strong." 

 

"..." Taking a deep breath, Marianne finally met her gaze. "I-I…I want to see the world you'll make. I-I can't promise my father will h-help, but if you can really d-do all that…" 

 

"I promise I will, even if history remembers me as a villain, I swear I will change this world," Edelgard said, before extending her hand. 

 

Staying quiet, Marianne hesitantly raised her hand, before grabbing onto hers, silently giving her support. 

That was all of them. She had convinced everyone. She was even able to get someone on her side when it came to going against the crest system!

 

…It was going to take time. She knew it would take time to realize her goals, to guarantee that her friends would not only support her fight against the nobility in Adrestia, but against the whole of Fodlan’s corrupt systems. She had to make sure to fully consolidate her power in the empire before she could declare war against the church, but when the time came, she hoped she would be able to convince them again. 

 

"Ferdinand, how many times do I have to say this? You have to make sure to match the pace of your partner!" Pausing in surprise, Edelgard turned her head to find Ferdinand and Flayn in the middle of dance practice in the gardens. 

 

"Ah, my apologies Flayn, I have never actually danced with someone whose stature is so different from mine," Ferdinand admitted, frowning as he looked down at his shorter classmate. "Especially someone who seems to prefer far more traditional dances." 

 

"H-Hmph, I was simply unaware that they performed different dances. It had been so long since I've been to the Empire, so most of my knowledge comes from books I have read." 

 

"No need to worry, that is why we are practicing!" Ferdinand stated before noticing Edelgard. "Oh, Lady Edelgard, hello!" 

 

"...Hello Ferdinand, Flayn. I was unaware you two were practicing on your own." 

 

"Oh, that was my idea! Since we were both the 'runner ups' in the voting, I thought it would be fun to practice together!" Flayn said with a smile. 

 

"Yes, though I might not have been chosen to be the representative, I fully intend to be dazzling at the ball! Why, I would not be surprised if my entire night is busy with one request after the other!" Ferdinand boasted, before pausing. "Oh, but I'm sure you have something important to talk about with Flayn. If you'll excuse me, I'll give you some time alone." 

 

"Ah, Ferdinand-" And he had already left. 

 

"Oh, what did you need to speak about, Lady Edelgard?" Flayn asked. 

 

Well…perhaps she should tell her something to keep up appearances. 

 

"I am planning on leaving the academy soon to be crowned the emperor of Adrestia. I have been letting my housemates know." 

 

"Oh… that is a surprise to hear," Flayn said, before frowning. "And a bit saddening if I am being honest." 

 

"Hm?" 

 

"I am sure you will be a wonderful emperor, but it is sad to know you'll be leaving soon. It has been… quite some time since I've had friends, so I was very glad at being able to join the Black Eagles. So to know you won't be here… well, I suppose it would be far too selfish to ask if you could stay." 

 

"..." That was… certainly not what she expected. "...I must admit, I wasn't sure what to make of you joining our class. Especially after the incident with your kidnapping. Though you have certainly surprised me, I certainly didn't expect you to get involved with Hubert's scheme during the Battle of Eagle and Lion." 

 

"Haha, yes, it was certainly quite fun! I've had so many new experiences since joining the class, and I'm glad I've been able to," Flayn said, smiling. "I'm glad that you were my house leader, I shall miss you when you're gone. I doubt I will be able to journey to the Empire any time soon, but I hope we can remain friends!" 

 

"...Yes, that sounds nice," Edelgard allowed, unsure of if she was lying or not. She knew what…type of person Flayn was, in regards to her being a Nabatean, though she couldn’t be sure how much of her persona was a facade. Though, considering that, she couldn’t help but think of how her initial impression of Shez as a complete idiot actually turned out to be right…

 

“Great! Then I will make sure to write!” Flayn declared, still smiling brightly. It was difficult to believe such a guileless girl could potentially be over a thousand years old, though she wasn’t that good at hiding it either.

 

"...Flayn, if I may ask, do you and your brother have some…distant relation to the archbishop?" Edelgard decided to ask. 

 

"E-Eh? Wh-what do you mean?" She asked, poorly hiding the truth. 

 

"I am simply thinking…the professor mentioned to me once that the archbishop saw her mother as a daughter. While I'm not sure if they were blood related or not, that would mean you and the professor are family, no?"

 

"..." A look of realization dawned on her. "...Am I related to the professor?" Flayn asked herself, completely blowing her cover. Not that she realized it. "Oh, that is wonderful news!" 

 

…Maybe she should follow instinct and think Flayn really was an innocent girl, even if she were a Nabatean.

Chapter End Notes

Red: Well would you look at this, an Edelgard-centric chapter.

Indi: Us? Making something Edelgard centric? Impossible.

Red: Completely impossible, we definitely haven't had Edelgard-centered scenes before. And I mean hey, we haven't made a full Edelgard-focused story yet.

Indi: Yet. Who knows what the future may hold.

Red: For now though, the future holds an oncoming revolution, and the plans are in motion.

Indi: That it does! Gonna be very interesting showing what's to come

Red: We hope you'll tune it to see it! For now, thanks for reading!

The White Heron Cup

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Jeralt let out a slow sigh as he leaned back in his seat. He never liked doing paperwork to begin with, especially with how his aches tended to act up after writing for a while, but now after everything that happened… he felt an ever-growing desire to just retire outright. He was old, he should get to just relax and spend what days he had left with his family…but, no, he had his obligations.

 

Important obligations too. At the moment, the paperwork stacked on his desk had to do with the Church’s investigations into what was being called the “Agarthan Order”, Rhea’s name for the supposed cult of dark mages that had infiltrated the monastery. Since Tomas had apparently been a different man entirely, that disturbed creep called Solon, there was a push to do some internal investigations into the church staff in addition to the knight’s external investigations into possible places these “cultists” might be hiding. The problem was, the church had a whole lot of staff and there was a big question of how they could even try to test for infiltrators.

 

One idea was to see if the clergy members could indeed cast faith-based spells properly, out of some assumption that any “heretics” would lack the ability to because they didn’t have faith in the goddess. It sounded like horseshit to Jeralt, but he didn’t have much to go off of himself…Well, he did have some ideas.

 

Realistically, the only person from that fight he could look into was the sole survivor, “Bias”. The one who hit Shez.

 

Working off the idea of looking into her specifically, he would want to look for a woman who had an affinity for fire magic. He had no idea of how old she was, what she might look like, or even if she had disguised as someone to begin with, but if he assumed she was someone who worked with Tomas/Solon and came to the church in the same timeframe as him…Hm…

 

Then his door opened, pulling him away from his thoughts. 

 

“Hey Jeralt, are you busy?” Catherine asked, the blonde knight entering pretty casually.

 

“Just with paperwork. Why, what’s up?”

 

“Lady Rhea wants to see you. I think it’s mainly about the security for the ball that’s coming up, since there’s some concern that something big might happen again.”

 

“Hm…Well, I can understand that concern. Just because it’s been quiet lately doesn’t mean it’s going to stay that way,” he agreed, before pushing himself up from the desk, “Alright, I’ll go chat with her.”

 

“Ah, before you go, mind if I ask you something?”

 

“Hm?” He raised an eyebrow at the younger knight, who seemed…kind of awkward, for some reason. “Sure, what is it?”

 

“Well it’s just…there’s this rumor that’s been going around, not that I take stock in those kinds of things, but, uh…And, ah, tell me if this is too much to ask, but your late wife, Sitri, right? Was she…Lady Rhea’s daughter?”

 

Jeralt paused, then frowned. “You know, that question raises a lot of questions. The first one being, why are there rumors about my wife?”

 

“Ah, that’s…kind of the thing. They’re not really about your wife, exactly, they’re about Professor Byleth.”

 

Alright, now he was confused and concerned. “And why are there rumors about Byleth?”

 

“There were rumors about her since she got here, captain, since there’s that whole thing about a random mercenary from out of nowhere getting made the new professor,” she explained, “As for the new rumors, they’re kind of an explanation for why that might be. Ah, that being that people are saying Byleth is Rhea’s granddaughter.”

 

“...” Jeralt pinched the bridge of his nose. “...Who’s saying that, and why?”

 

"Apparently it started with some of the students, before spreading to the staff. And well…. You know how Manuela is when she's drunk." 

 

"...I know Sitri and Rhea were close, but if they were related she never told me. As far as I'm aware she was just an orphan taken in by the monastery." And sure, Jeralt might not have kept the closest eye on Rhea, but he was sure he would have noticed if she had a kid…though, that was back when she’d gone by “Theia” and faked her death so “Rhea” could take over…Was the gap big enough for her to have a kid? 

 

Sitri did kind of resemble Rhea…There were definitely differences in how they looked, but…though, who would be the father then? He didn’t think she had anyone she was into like that, at least that he noticed, and she really wasn’t the type to have a one night stand...At least, he didn’t think she was?

 

“You’re thinking about it, huh?”

 

Jeralt paused, then frowned at Catherine. “So do you want to know because of your crush on her or what?”

 

"Just because I worship her doesn't mean I have a crush on her!" she denied as her face flushed. Jeralt couldn't help but sigh and feel sorry for Shamir. 

 

"Well, I'm not going to say yes. Mainly because I don't think it matters if she is or isn't," Jeralt said as he sighed. 

 

"Well…I’m just saying, it would explain why she puts so much focus on her." 

 

"Hm, I suppose." It still was difficult to think of Rhea as trustworthy, but… she hadn't attempted anything towards Byleth at all. She might have been pushy at the start, though that could easily be explained… 

 

"Alright, well, sorry to take your time," Catherine apologized, nodding to him before she left. Letting out a sigh, Jeralt made the quick journey to the Audience chamber. 

 

"Hello Jeralt, I hope you're doing well today,” Rhea greeted as Seteth gave a nod at his arrival. 

 

"As fine as I can be. Gotta say, it's been a while since I've had to do something fancy like protecting a ball," Jeralt responded. 

 

"Yes, it's a bit of a change up for us as well," Seteth stated.,"The Grand Ball is a reward of sorts for the students, so we tend not to have a heavy guard presence around to help keep their minds off of things." 

 

"Even so, we must make sure to keep them safe. While the building they'll be using for the ball itself will be monitored by the professors who are chaperoning, we need to make sure to have a patrol nearby at all times,” Rhea added, “I trust you've been able to properly plan things out?" 

 

"I have, though I hope neither of you two mind if I have my own men pick up some of the slack,” Jeralt replied, “With all those knights you're having going around, we're a bit low on men." 

 

"I shall make sure your men are properly paid for their assistance," Rhea said with a smile. "Though I apologize for not being able to provide enough knights, the threat of the Agarthans is not one we can ignore."

 

"Hopefully we hear back from the knights soon,” Seteth added, “As it stands, the continent of Fodlan is quite large, so it shall take some time for us to be able to find any clues to the Agarthan Order. Perhaps if we had a lead…" 

 

"Hm… I'm not sure how much it'll help, but they're after Shez, right? We found her in Alliance territory so maybe that's a start?" Jeralt suggested. "She said she lived in Ordelia territory with her mom."

 

"It would, if only things weren't tense in the alliance as it is… if only the Great Houses actually asked us for assistance rather than claim they can handle it themselves." Seteth sighed. "Regardless, we'll keep that in mind. Perhaps we should try investigating the territory bordering Phlegethon and Ordelia?" 

 

"It is as good a lead as any,” Rhea agreed before the door opened, getting their attention. 

 

"Oh, there you are, Captain Jeralt," Flayn greeted with a smile as she walked in. 

 

"Flayn? Did you need something?" Seteth asked, a bit surprised to see his sister. 

 

"I just came by to inform Captain Jeralt that the White Heron Cup is about to begin. Professor Byleth volunteered to dance with the students during the cup, so I wanted to come by and see if you wanted to watch!" 

 

"She did?" Now that definitely surprised him. "I didn't know she liked dancing." 

 

"She's been helping everyone practice for the ball and has been having fun, so I suppose it's not that much of a surprise!" Flayn said with a smile. "Supposedly she even went to get a special outfit for the cup!" 

 

"My, she certainly is giving it her all, isn't she?" Rhea asked with an amused smile. "I don't suppose it would be much trouble if I went along as well, would it?" 

 

"Oh, of course not Lady Rhea! What about you brother, do you want to watch as well?" 

 

"I suppose if I must." 

Despite many of the students' trepidations when it came to the White Heron Cup, it was still an event many loved to watch. As such, it was no surprise that all the students, as well as some staff and knights, were there to watch. 

 

"Hey dad, over here!" Shez called out, waving over to Jeralt as he entered the reception hall. 

 

“Hey Shez. Looks like you’re not dancing today.”

 

“Ha, nah, dancing isn't for me. I mean, I’d probably completely rule if I did go for it, but I figure I should give everyone else a chance to dance,” she replied with a grin. "And that includes Em here!" Reaching over, Shez pulled over the Adrestian. 

 

"H-Hey, don't pull me!" 

 

"Come on Em, just letting you meet my dad, don't think you two ever met." 

 

"No, I don't think we have. Nice to meet you." Jeralt said, greeting the noble, who craned her head up to look at him. For a brief moment, she squinted her eyes. 

 

"...Are you sure your sister is related to this guy? He's huge compared to her." 

 

"...She takes after my wife." 

 

"Oh, I guess that makes sense." Emily said, before scowling as Shez mussed her hair up. 

 

"Sorry about her dad, she can be kinda abrasive," Shez apologized as Emily tried to push her away. 

 

Though before Jeralt could say anything else, they heard Alois speak up, announcing the beginning of the White Heron cup, which he would also be judging alongside Manuela and Shamir. Jeralt let out a bit of a chuckle as he heard Catherine congratulate her partner on the position, getting the archer to scowl.

 

"Now, as for our representatives, we have, Dorothea from the Black Eagles, Yuri from the Blue Lions, and Emily from the Golden Deer!" Alois announced as the three students walked out to the middle of the reception hall, the former two looking quite confident, while the latter was unable to keep the frown off her face. Which only deepened as her class was the loudest when it came to cheering. "As for who our wonderful participants will be dancing with, we have Professor Byleth who has volunteered to be the student's partners as they perform!" 

 

"I'll do my best," Byleth stated with a nod, and a pump of her fist, though for most of the students they focused more on her attire. Specifically that of a dancer's attire, which meant she received a lot of staring, most of whom tried to look away. Aside from the Gautier kid who blatantly ogled. 

 

"Starting things off will be the Black Eagle House!" Alois announced with Dorothea smiling at Byleth as they both began to dance. Despite her words, it was clear Byleth was still inexperienced compared to Dorothea, since she did her best to lead but almost stumbled before Dorothea caught her. 

 

"Perhaps we should switch roles, professor? Not that I doubt you, but I'd rather you not end up falling as you try to lead," Dorothea suggested, quiet enough that no one else heard over the din of the music and talking. Nodding in return, Byleth steadied herself. 

 

With that the two changed roles, with Dorothea taking the lead, slowing her pace down to be in step with Byleth. Now moving much smoother, the pair danced together, perfectly in sync.

 

"There we go, professor. Much better, no?" 

 

"Yeah, your movements are easy to follow, thank you," Byleth praised with a small smile.

 

"No need to thank me~ Though, I would like to tell you that I'm planning on inviting Edelgard to the ball." 

 

"Oh, that's great. Glad I could help." Dorothea couldn't help but giggle at her earnest response. 

 

"Of course, though you should make sure to have a dance with her as well, I'm sure she'll love that." 

 

"Hm…well, I'm supposed to be a chaperone, but I guess one dance won't be bad," Byleth agreed as they slowed down, coming to a halt as the music ended.

 

"What a wonderful performance! One that will be hard to follow!" Alois praised with a grin. 

 

"For the sake of not being biased, I'll just say that was splendid~" Manuela followed up. 

 

"Good work on taking the lead there. You saw a problem and quickly fixed it," Shamir finished, giving the two a nod. 

 

Giving her student a thumbs up, Byleth smiled at her while Yuri walked up. She nodded at the Blue Lion, then the two clasped hands as they began to dance. Almost immediately, it became clear that while Yuri was indeed a skilled dancer, he didn't make much effort to keep pace with Byleth; the teacher plainly had a hard time keeping up as Yuri showed off. Where Dorothea was able to catch her before she stumbled, Yuri instead chose to catch her as she tripped over her feet, making it seem as if he was dipping her down. 

 

"And here I thought I'd be difficult to sweep you off your feet," Yuri teased, making Byleth huff in response. 

 

"Well that was quite the exhilarating performance!" Alois praised, still sounding impressed.

 

"That it was, seems our Blue Lion here is quite the leading man,” Manuela commented, before affecting a more critical gaze, “Though I must say, a dance is a duet, not a solo." 

 

"It was original, but had a lot of wasted movements," Shamir noted. 

 

Shrugging in response, Yuri rejoined the Blue Lions, who largely seemed grateful that it was over with. 

 

With that, it was time for the final student: Emily, who was notably tense as she walked up. And Jeralt knew his daughter well enough to see her tense up too, before trying to relax herself as they danced.

 

"I didn't know you could dance," Byleth said as she led the noble. 

 

"As if it's hard, it's just footwork, and like you said, I'm light on my feet," Emily grumbled, though she seemed to want to keep the dance simple compared to the other two. And it certainly was a far more simple dance with nothing of note occurring, aside from Emily rushing back to her class as soon as the dance was over. 

 

"That was a noteworthy performance!" 

 

"You did well out there, make sure to keep practicing and you'll shine in no time." 

 

"Good footwork." 

 

Emily scoffed at the praise, putting on a show of indifference, though it was pretty easy to see the slight flush on her cheeks from the praise, which turned outright red when a cheery Raphael gave her a pat on the head. Which also seemed to be a cue for the rest of the Deer to start praising her performance too, though Claude and Hilda seemed to be deliberately trying to fluster her while the rest were being more genuine, with Leonie also giving her a pat on the back and Shez outright hugging her, earning a yelp from the shorter girl.

 

“And there we have it, folks!” Alois declared once the dances were done, projecting his voice to be heard through the hall, “That was some excellent work from all our participants, and a good job from our professor! But unfortunately, we can only have one winner today, and I think me and my fellow judges already have our choice of winner here! Judges?”

 

“Well while I would hate to be accused of bias, I genuinely can’t vote for anyone other than the Black Eagle house’s very own Dorothea Arnault after seeing her stunning performance~!” Manuela praised, smiling brightly at her protege.

 

“Yeah, I have to give it to the Eagles too,” Shamir agreed.

 

“And there we have it! With her stunning start that stole all of our hearts, the winner of this year’s White Heron Cup is Dorothea!”

 

Jeralt clapped along with the rest of the crowd, though not nearly as wildly as some of the people in attendance. Even some of the quieter members of the Black Eagles began to cheer, aside from the Vestra kid, who still clapped. Dorothea herself seemed quite proud as she mentioned something about using this win to bolster her career. 

 

"Congrats kid, you did great out there," Jeralt said, approaching his kid and giving her a pat on the head. 

 

"It was mainly Dorothea," Byleth responded, watching while her student was surrounded by her classmates. 

 

"Right. Also, mind if I ask about the dress?" 

 

“Oh, the dancer outfit that's part of the prize looks like this. So I thought it'd be fun to wear it," Byleth explained, looking down at her dress. "Though apparently it's not what is usually worn during balls." 

 

"Pft, seriously By? Even I knew that," Shez teased as she walked up to her family, "It's gowns and stuff that usually get worn for fancy parties." 

 

"Hm, well, this technically is a ‘gown’, I think…Besides, Dorothea thought it looked good," Byleth replied, pouting a bit. 

 

"I'm sure she would," Shez said, chuckling, "Just make sure to actually wear your normal clothes during the ball. Er, or something more formal. Actually, something more formal would definitely be better." 

 

"I mean, I'm just a chaperone so I don't think I'll be dancing much."

 

“You sure? Because I’m pretty sure Dorothea’s bound to ask you. Unless Edelgard gets to you first?” Shez grinned. “Heck, I wouldn’t be surprised if you had a few more admirers willing to ask you after showing your stuff out there!”

 

"Oh, I'm glad they liked my dancing." Byleth said, not completely understanding what Shez meant. "Oh, I've been meaning to say, but I'll be leaving for a few days soon." 

 

"Is something wrong?" Jeralt asked. 

 

"No, I just need to accompany Edelgard to the Empire for something important. We'll be gone for less than a week."

 

"Do you guys need any help?" Shez asked. 

 

"No, it’s just something Edelgard needs some help with." 

 

"Hm, well, make sure to take care, kid," Jeralt said, "Must be important if it's something the princess has to do." 

 

"It is," Byleth responded, nodding. 

 

"Professor! Come on, we're going to go celebrate!" Dorothea said, grinning as she grabbed onto Byleth’s arm. "You too, Shez! Unless you want to mope about losing." 

 

"Hey, who said I was moping! Emily did great!" Shez boasted, chasing the two as Dorothea dragged Byleth away. 

 

Watching his kids talking with all the students, Jeralt couldn't help but let out a small sigh. It was different seeing them hang out with so many people their age but… it was a good different. 

 

"Hey, you're called the blade breaker, right?" 

 

Looking down, Jeralt found Emily standing by him. "Yeah? Did you need something?" 

 

"Just…wanted to ask if you would be up to training together. You're strong, right?" 

 

"I am the knight captain," Jeralt said, a bit amused. 

 

"Good, then we can train later," she stated as if it was a matter of fact. 

 

"Heh, sure sure. Now go on, you shouldn't be hanging around an old man like me, have fun with your friends." Jeralt gently pushed her forward, clearly flustering her a bit before she huffed and walked towards the rest of the students. 

 

"Well the children certainly seem like they're having fun," Rhea remarked, a smile on her face as she approached Jeralt. 

 

"Yeah. I didn't think Byleth would like dancing so much." 

 

“Yes, she did quite well. Heh, watching her, I could not help but think…” Rhea sighed, her smile turning a little sad, “...My mother loved to dance.”

 

Jeralt blinked. He’d never heard Rhea ever talk about her birth parents. Really, considering her secret, he was halfway convinced she’d been born directly from the Goddess. Though the fact that she was thinking of her own family when looking at Byleth… 

 

"...hey, Rhea, do you… think of Byleth as family?" Jeralt asked. 

 

Rhea paused at the question, not entirely ready for that…especially as she immediately thought of Seteth assuming she had a child of her own… 

 

"...I would not be opposed if she thought of me as family as well," Rhea said, being careful with her words. 

 

"Hm, I see…" Jeralt took in a deep breath as he tried to take in the possibility that Byleth was Rhea’s granddaughter…Hm. Did that mean she was his mother by marriage? 

 

"That aside, I was planning on having dinner soon if you wished to join me." 

 

"Oh, sure. I've only had some bread today, so I'm hungry." 

 

"Jeralt, you need to take proper care of yourself. I would think a captain of the Knight of Seiros would know better,” Rhea chided, making Jeralt pause at the…’motherlike’ tone she had there. 

 

…Maybe, if he ever retired, he wouldn't stick around Garreg Mach. He was way too old to be babied.

"I must say, seeing you dance was quite thrilling, though if it was up to me, I would have given the win to that young Yuri boy. Your dance together looked quite exhilarating!" Sothis said as Byleth entered her room, ready to retire for the night. 

 

"Traitor." 

 

"Just because I'm stuck with you doesn't mean I have allegiance to your house." Sothis huffed. "Regardless, you must ensure on the night of the ball that you must dance the night away! If I cannot dance, then you must at least dance for me!" 

 

"Sure sure," Byleth agreed, going over to her desk to write in her journal before going to sleep for the night. Though as she did, she accidentally knocked over the box for the pendant. Frowning, she got down to pick it up, before noticing something had slipped behind her desk. "Hm?" 

 

Reaching over, she grabbed it, finding it to be an envelope, one that was unmarked. 

 

"Oh? I wonder what this is," Sothis wondered as she floated closer. 

 

"Guess I'll see," Byleth replied, opening it to find a letter. 

 

Dear Professor Byleth, 

 

First off, I would like to apologize for entering your room without permission and leaving this in here. I found it a tad too embarrassing to talk to you about this in person. I promise I won't touch anything in your room…well, unless it looks interesting. 

 

I kid, of course. Now then, as for what this letter is actually about, I wanted to ask if you would meet me up on the goddess tower on the night of the ball. It's something rather important I want to discuss so I hope to see you up there. 

 

With love, 

 

"Huh, it's not signed," Sothis noted. 

 

"It’s Dorothea’s handwriting." Byleth said as she finished reading the letter. "I wonder what she wants to talk about…"

 

"Hmm…oh! Is there not that legend of two people meeting in the goddess tower to swear an oath together! Maybe this is a confession of love!" 

 

"No that's not it," Byleth said, shooting that idea down, "First off ,she's dating Edelgard, or will be. Secondly, Manuela said the legend was about a man and a woman, so it doesn't make sense for two women to make a vow up there." 

 

“...” Sothis sighed, before muttering something about a ‘ridiculous child’, which Byleth ignored. Rolling her eyes, Byleth tucked away the letter. She wasn't exactly sure what Dorothea would want to talk about, but whatever it was she would do her best to help. Maybe they were already planning to get married? 

 

…Huh. 

 

Byleth couldn't help but frown. She wasn't sure why, but she almost felt…disappointed for a moment there. 

 

…Well, whatever. So long as her students were happy, she would be happy. Though it did raise a question of why Dorothea wanted to meet her at the Goddess Tower. Maybe she had something important to tell her?

 

As Byleth mused to herself, Sothis watched her host with a mix of fond exasperation. How in the world did I end up with a girl who thinks only of others and never herself?

Chapter End Notes

Red: And so the White Heron Cup came and went. Important things be happening soon, and Dorothea winds up getting the dancer class! Which, I mean, I feel like she's kind of the default for the Black Eagles? But it works.

Indi: Really she's arguably the best unit in the game for it, if you discount making someone the dancer for funsies. Like say most of the Lions, who in game really don't want to take part in the white heron cup lol

Red: Faerghus is not a place for fun, nor dancing, apparently. Also just funny that it's great as a class for Marianne too considering its focus on swords and magic. Just put the poor shy girl out there to dance for everybody.

Indi: A genius move really, while everyone is distracted as they watch Marianne fumbling her dancing, you can take them out from behind!

Red: The real secret behind getting a second turn with a unit...

Indi: That it is. And we hope you all enjoyed that secret and this chapter!

An Emperor’s Ascension

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

The journey to Enbarr was a rather quiet one; two carriages traveled alongside one another through the countryside with Byleth and Edelgard in one, and Hubert in the other. When asked why he was in a different carriage, Edelgard simply responded that he was going to visit his father while they went to the imperial palace. Idly wondering what he was going to do, Byleth spent most of the trip gazing out the window. 

 

With everything that had happened during the year, she hadn't been able to enjoy traveling despite practically going all over Fodlan. The far from quiet marches of her mercenary life seemed like something from so long ago at this point.

 

"The empire, hm? I don't think we've traveled much there since I've awoken,” Sothis said, gazing out the window with Byleth, "It feels… ancient."

 

"Hm…" Moving her gaze away from the view outside, Byleth turned to look at Edelgard. "If I may ask, what’s your crowning going to be like?" 

 

"Well, officially we will not be proclaiming my ascension as emperor until next month," Edelgard answered, "The actual ceremony usually involves a large celebration that happens all over Adrestria, though that will likely be delayed. As is, all that will happen is my father will pass the crown to me, with a representative of the church being there to witness it." 

 

"Like how Seiros was the one who crowned the first emperor?" Byleth asked, getting Edelgard to nod, albeit with a frown. "Hm… are you sure it'll count with me?" 

 

"It is a bit of a loophole I will admit, as you work at the academy not so much the church, but since you were directly hired by Rhea and also wield a sacred relic, then I see no issue. Besides, I've never been one for traditions," Edelgard said with a smile. 

 

"Hm… you know, this will be my first time back in Enbarr since my first visit." 

 

"I'm not surprised, I doubt your father will have been in a hurry to head back. I suppose if there's time, I can show you around." 

 

"That sounds nice. The only place I actually visited was the opera house. And the inn we stayed at, I suppose," Byleth responded, "Though I'm sure you've been to the opera house plenty of times." 

 

"...That I have. My first time there was actually with my uncle, back before he'd been replaced." Edelgard sighed wistfully. "My memory of that performance isn't the clearest, but I do remember enjoying myself. The next time I went though… When I learned that the impostor died, I spent several days in disbelief, thinking that it must have been a lie, and he'd show up one day to drag me back to the dungeons… And when nothing came about I decided to go out, and enjoy the opera.

 

“Heh, that caused many rumors to go flying back then, about the 'disease riddled' child who couldn't even properly mourn her family's death," Edelgard said, chuckling bitterly. 

 

"...Did you enjoy the show?" Byleth asked, unsure of what else to say. 

 

"Quite, it was a marvelous production. Though I must say, it was quite a surprise to learn several years down the line the star of the production would be my housemate." 

 

"Something I'm sure you enjoyed," Byleth remarked, getting Edelgard to blush. 

 

"H-Hm… my teacher, may I ask you something?" Edelgard inquired, getting her to nod. "Say you were presented with two items: a beautiful ring, said to soothe your worries and a blood soaked axe, said to have fought constant battles, and you were only allowed to take one, which would it be?" 

 

"...Why can I only take one?" 

 

"It's what is expected of you," Edelgard responded, getting Byleth to frown. 

 

"Then I'll take both." 

 

Edelgard blinked. "I…professor, that’s not meant to be an option." 

 

"Sure, but I'm a mercenary. It’s only smart to be greedy when presented with potential treasures," Byleth explained, "The axe sounds reliable, and the ring sounds lovely, so it’s smart to take both." 

 

"...why are neither of you making this easy?" Edelgard muttered to herself. 

 

"Hm?" 

 

"Nothing. We're almost to the imperial palace, so make sure to be ready,” Edelgard deflected, trying to keep a blush off her face. 

 

Thankfully for her, Byleth didn't press the topic as they arrived at the castle to find a certain someone already waiting for them. 

 

"Lady Edelgard!" 

 

"Monica?" Surprise evident on her face, Edelgard did a double take as she spotted the redhead approaching them. "What are you doing here?"

 

"Is it really such a surprise I'm here? I mean, I can't really visit you that often when you're at the Academy, so why wouldn't I come to Enbarr when you mentioned you would be heading back to the empire?" Monica von Ochs answered as if it was the most obvious thing, before smiling at Byleth, “And hello again, professor! You’re looking well!”

 

“Hello Monica, it’s nice to see you again,” Byleth greeted with a small wave. "Still not going to join the academy again?" 

 

"Thank you for the offer, but no." 

 

"Aw." 

 

"...Did I miss something?" Edelgard asked as she glanced between the two. 

 

"I asked Monica if she wanted to rejoin the academy when she visited, but she said she was too busy helping you out." 

 

"That I am, ah, but we can catch up later! We should move quickly, your highness, I ensured that Duke Aegir would be distracted so we need to head to the throne room quickly!" 

 

"Thank you, Monica," Edelgard said, nodding to her before leading the three of them through the palace. She could hear all the servants they passed begin whispering in surprise at the sight of the princess, returned far earlier than expected. 

 

Sticking behind the pair, Monica hung back to let the two walk up the stairs of the throne room together. Awaiting them was a sickly old man, who looked a hair's breadth away from death. Yet even so, his eyes filled with life upon seeing Edelgard, both warmth and regret dancing in them. 

 

"Father, forgive me for making you do this. I understand how much pain you are in-" 

 

"There is nothing to apologize for Edelgard… I am content knowing you are free of that man…" Emperor Ionius IX said with a soft smile on his face, "That I would still be around to see you crowned emperor is more than I can ask for…" 

 

"...Thank you, Father," Edelgard said, trying to keep her tone even. "Now, with my teacher acting as representative of the church, please relinquish the crown to me." 

 

"Of course, Edelgard…" 

 

"For the sake of all of the Empire and all of Fodlan, I shall carry this responsibility on my shoulders," Edelgard stated, kneeling before her father. 

 

The Emperor slowly rose from his throne, his limbs struggling with the motion, before he seemed to gain a new life as he moved towards Edelgard and removed his crown, before placing it upon her head.

 

"By the covenant between the red blood and the white sword, and by the double-headed eagle upon your head, I hereby pronounce you, Edelgard von Hresvelg, the new emperor. Are you prepared to take those responsibilities as your own?"

 

"...I swear upon this throne, in accordance with the ancient covenant, I swear to use my power to lead Fodlan into a new dawn of peace," Edelgard swore, her voice wavering only for a moment before it hardened like steel with her resolve. With that, The Emperor arose as Ionius sat down. 

 

"My daughter… I wish I could have done more for you. That I could have kept you from being taken away to the kingdom, that I could have kept you safe from Aegir…" Ionius said, regret seeping into his voice. 

 

"...There is no need to say more, father. Your presence was my salvation. The care in your eyes comforted me, and the fury you felt fueled my own. The blood from your clenched fist told me I wasn't alone in bleeding," Edelgard replied, sorrow in her own voice. Silence fell upon the two before Ionius looked at Byleth. 

 

"You…are the Ashen Dragon, Byleth Eisner, correct?"

 

"Ah–" Stiffening at being addressed, Byleth bowed. "Yes, I am Emperor Edelgard’s teacher." 

 

"Thank you, for taking care of my daughter…" Ionius thanked, before he began to cough. He raised a hand, keeping Edelgard from going to him before his coughs subsided and he turned his gaze back towards Byleth. "An emperor will need many allies, and I am pleased to know you are hers." 

 

"...I’m glad to be Edelgard’s ally,” Byleth stated, “She has helped me many times, and I believe in her goal." 

 

"...You've helped me far more times, my teacher. Even long before we met." Before Byleth could ask what Edelgard meant, a loud voice sounded in the throne room. 

 

"Your majesty, what are you doing out of your bed chambers?" Duke Aegir practically demanded to know as he approached, before pausing. "Ah, your highness, what are-" 

 

"You misspeak, Aegir. You are to refer to me as your majesty," Edelgard stated, her voice cold and authoritative. 

 

And in an instant, the prime minister went from confused to shocked. "W-What!?" 

 

"It is true, she is now Emperor Edelgard, and an ordinance must be prepared to announce that fact," Ionius said.

 

"But before that, we must address another issue,” Edelgard stated, turning her glare towards the Prime Minister, “Ludwig von Aegir, for your crime of overstepping your authority, attempting to seize Alliance land, and potentially causing a war between Adrestia and Leicester, I hereby strip you of your title and place you under arrest!" 

 

"That–What are you saying!?" Aegir shouted, attempting to step toward Edelgard only for Byleth to draw her sword and place the tip against his throat.

 

"Take one step further and I will take that as a sign of aggression against the emperor." 

 

"Y-You! Do you know who I am!?" 

 

"The former prime minister," Edelgard stated, her gaze remaining steadfast. "Guards! Take this man away!" 

 

The imperial guard in the throne room approached the group, aiming their spears at Aegir, who could only shake in rage before he was taken away. He opened his mouth to complain, to rage, before he shut it with a frustrated growl, bowing his head and letting the guards pull him along.

 

"Heh. I've been wanting to do that for some time," Edelgard remarked, a smile coming to her face as she looked at Byleth, "Thank you, my teacher." 

 

"Hm… what exactly did you mean by me helping you before we met?" 

 

"Professor, do you remember what you told me about being in the Oghma mountains five years ago?" 

 

"Yes?" 

 

"My teacher, the man who replaced my uncle, died in the Oghma mountains five years ago. From a sudden rockslide." 

 

"Excuse me?" Ionius asked, unsure of what he just heard. 

 

"...oh."  Byleth slowly nodded as Edelgard’s words sunk in and she pieced together what she meant. “...Well, that’s one down then.”

 

“Pff-!” Edelgard stifled a giggle, covering her mouth for a moment before clearing her throat. “My teacher, please do not kill any of the other nobles involved in the Insurrection. I have my own plans to handle each of them, and a few are too useful to be removed.”

 

“Hm…I’m still going to keep a tally. I don’t have to kill them, we can count it if they’re handled in other ways.” She tilted her head, thinking. “Should I count Duke Aegir already or should we wait for his sentence?”

 

“I think waiting would be more appropriate,” Monica suggested, “That way if his sentence is death, you can be the one to swing the axe.”

 

“Oh, good point. Thank you, Monica.”

 

"...To be clear, I do not intend for you to become an executioner," Edelgard clarified. 

 

"Still something to keep in mind," Byleth commented, shrugging, "...Will Count Varley have his uses?" 

 

"...At the very least I believe it is appropriate for Bernadetta to be here to decide what to do with him." 

 

"Hm, fair." Byleth glanced at Ionius. "Ah, should I help your father back to his room?" 

 

"There is no need," Ionuis responded. "I'll have my guard do so when they return. Thank you for all you have done." 

 

"I'm just glad I could be there for her." 

 

"Well, with that settled, how about we have some tea, your majesty?” Monica offered, “I can have some prepared right away." 

 

"Thank you Monica, that sounds lovely," Edelgard said, smiling at her. "Farewell Father, I will see you as soon as I can." 

 

Giving her father a bow, Edelgard and Monica left, with Byleth following behind, before she paused and looked back at Ionius. 

 

"...Your daughter is incredibly strong, I'm honored to have met her." Bowing deeply, she walked off. 

 

Sitting upon the throne, Ionius could only smile, knowing his daughter was in good hands. 

The palace of Enbarr was far grander than Byleth had realized, practically dwarfing Garreg Mach with its size. She needed to make sure if Shez was ever here that someone would always be with her so she didn't get lost. Thankfully Edelgard and Monica knew their way around the palace quite easily, and they soon ended up on a balcony overlooking Enbarr while Monica brought out a portable tea set. 

 

"Will Bergamot be okay today, your majesty?" 

 

"Of course, thank you Monica. And there is no need to call me your majesty, you can still refer to me as Edelgard." 

 

"Oh no, I would never be so presumptuous," Monica replied as she prepared the tea. "Though I must say, I am honored to have been there upon your coronation, I shall make sure to transcribe the events perfectly!" 

 

"Transcribe?" Byleth asked.

 

"Monica has a perfect memory, and has taken it upon herself to be the historian who writes about me," Edelgard explained. 

 

"To ensure Emperor Edelgard is properly remembered for her grand deeds, I shall write down everything that occurs with her. It is a shame I wasn't there for her year at the academy. If only my father had allowed me to wait another year…" Monica said with a sigh. 

 

"It does seem like a shame, I'm sure it would have been nice teaching you," Byleth said with a smile, “And the offer is still open if you want to join–” 

 

"I think I’ll be fine, professor. Though, perhaps I will be able to learn a thing or two from you when you start working for her?" Monica suggested, trying to placate the earnest professor.

 

And succeeding, judging by her smile. "I would be happy to." 

 

"You must really like teaching, professor," Edelgard said with an amused smile.

 

"It feels nice,” Byleth admitted, “Maybe if I ever retire, I might settle down as a teacher somewhere. Though I'm not sure how many places are like the Officer’s Academy." 

 

"There is the sorcery academy in the kingdom, but aside from that, most nobles tend to have personal tutors when they are taught," Monica explained, "I'm sure you'd make quite a fortune as a personal combat instructor to nobles." 

 

"Hmph, it may not be what you're thinking about, but I would hope as my future advisor you weren't already planning on retiring before you ever started," Edelgard said with a pout, before pausing as she heard Monica gasp. 

 

"Is everything okay?" Byleth asked, concerned.

 

"Of course it is! This is the first time I've seen her majesty pout! Oh I shall make sure to keep that image forever ingrained in my mind!" 

 

…Edelgard could feel a headache starting to arrive. She shook it off though in favor of taking a sip of her tea. “Mm…very well done, Monica.”

 

“Oh, you flatter me, your majesty! Ah, I’ll have to remember this feeling of being praised…”

 

“It is very good,” Byleth commented too, prompting a smile from Monica.

 

“I’m glad to hear you enjoy it. I have been practicing my brewing in between the other tasks I’ve been carrying out for Lady Edelgard.”

 

“Other tasks?” Byleth paused. “Ah, is this stuff I’m allowed to know about, or is it confidential information?”

 

“Considering I intend to make you one of my confidants, I do not see an issue in sharing some of the work I have asked Monica to undertake,” Edelgard decided, “Monica, if you would?”

 

“Of course, your majesty! You see, while Lady Edelgard has been busy at Garreg Mach, I have been dutifully aiding her in a search for relics and other items of interest that may allow her reign to progress without issue,” Monica readily explained, in part because Edelgard had already let her know in advance what to say in such situations, “While we don’t expect too much resistance, there is the possibility of a rebellion, or even outside threats causing problems as her majesty attempts to enact her reforms.”

 

“Hm…Well, I might be able to help if the Church has a problem with the way you change things, Edelgard,” Byleth offered, and it took all of Edelgard’s self-control to keep herself from breaking out into a massive smile.

 

Fortunately for her, a distraction arrived in the form of Hubert. “Good day, your majesty. I see your ascension went well.”

 

"That it did, Hubert, thank you." 

 

"Such a shame for you to have missed it, perhaps if I have time later I can recount it for you," Monica offered, "Ah, but I shall be so busy helping her majesty. Unlike certain people.” 

 

"I'm sure Emperor Edelgard’s words will suffice. Unless you claim to speak for her?" 

 

"I resent that accusation." 

 

"So, Hubert," Edelgard cut it before they could continue, "How did your visit to your father go?" 

 

"Tragically, it seems that informing him of your intention to become Emperor was too much for his frail heart and my poor, unfortunate father had a heart attack. And fell down the stairs in the process," Hubert explained with a grim smile on his face. 

 

"Oh my, my condolences Hubert." 

 

"Truly a tragedy,” Monica commiserated, “Perhaps you would like to retire for the night?" 

 

"No, as the new Marquis Vestra I must be prepared to take on the mantle my father left me with his untimely and entirely accidental death." 

 

"You don't really believe that, do you?" Sothis asked as Byleth sipped her tea.

 

"...Well that's two down at least."

Chapter End Notes

Indi: And so we have Edelgard the emperor! A nice chapter that will set things in motion.

Red: That it shall! The wheels are turning and there's going to be a few feet run over by the time things are over.

Indi: Whose feet? Well I suppose that will be revealed later!

Red: And we hope to see y'all there to see it when it happens! For now though, thanks for reading!

Interlude - The Weathervane

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

“Hm…yes, I want that bust over there, where the light will catch it properly,” Acheron Lethe Phlegethon, the newly established conqueror of Ordelia, considered as he looked around his new lounge, “Ah, fix that painting right now! I will not have any portraits of myself be hanging crooked!”

 

His servants hurried to fulfill his commands to remove any trace of House Ordelia from their former castle in favor of images and decorations extolling his own esteemed self! All hints of Ordelia purple and white would soon be dragged away entirely in favor of glorious Acheron yellow!

 

“There you are, Lord Acheron.”

 

Acheron felt a frown come to his face at the interruption, though it soon turned to an ingratiating smile when he realized who was speaking to him. “Ah, Sir Myson! It’s so nice to see you! I wasn’t expecting you to come by! If I did, I would have prepared refreshments!”

 

He glared towards a pair of servants who didn’t look busy enough. “You two, prepare some tea for Sir Myson and his companion immediately!”

 

The servants set down the desk they were moving and immediately leapt to obey his orders, as they should.

 

“Haha, thank you for hospitality, Lord Acheron, but you need not put yourself out for our sake,” Myson demurred with a smile on his pale face, “My associate and I are merely here to ensure you are well supported in this time of transition.”

 

“Ah, I see!” Acheron let his smile fall for a moment when he noticed how the other warlock with Myson was gazing at his office with a faint frown on his pale face. “And is your guest going to introduce himself properly?”

 

“Oh, there’s no need to address Odesse. He is simply my assistant,” Myson explained, prompting a pause from the other warlock.

 

“Hm. Yes, hello Lord Acheron, I am here to assist,” the man muttered, not even bothering to hide the sneer on his face, which got Acheron to scowl.

 

“Now see here, I will not be glared at in my own castle!”

 

“Pray, forgive him, Lord Acheron,” Myson entreated with a small smirk, “He is used to wearing a mask.”

 

Acheron didn’t really understand what that had to do with anything, but he scoffed, choosing to ignore the second warlock in favor of focusing on the powerful mage sent by his benefactor. “Fine, never mind then. I presume you have a reason for coming here again? Does Duke Aegir require something?”

 

“No, his grace has no issues with how you are running things at the moment. We are simply here to confirm things are running smoothly. I see you are settling well in your new residence.”

 

“Hmph. As well as I can be with this incompetent ‘help’!” he snapped, glaring over at the servants, before turning back to the mages with a simpering smile, “Well you can tell Duke Aegir he has no need for any concern! I have Ordelia fully under my control! It's only a matter of time before those fools give me a seat on the roundtable, and if not, well clearly such a sizable gift to the Empire will grant me the title of count no?" 

 

"I'm sure Duke Aegir will ensure you are properly rewarded regardless," Myson responded, "Though things would have gone much smoother if you had actually captured the Ordelias." 

 

Acheron frowned. "Tell that to the men you provided! Strong though they may be, they're practically brain dead! They were too focused on just causing havoc instead of actually listening to my orders!" 

 

"I'll make sure to keep that in mind for when I train the next batch," Myson said, "Though at least they're still providing some use." 

 

"Hmph, that is true. Why, I think they would make a fine gift to Aegir as well! Even if I don't end up seceding, then it's only proper I establish good relations with my westward neighbors!" 

 

“You wish to gift our work to Aegir while claiming it as your own?” Odesse asked, offense audible in his voice, which gets Acheron to scowl at him.

 

“Those soldiers were given to me, were they not? It is my right to do with them as I wish!”

 

“Quite right, Lord Acheron,” Myson agreed, “You may use the pawns as you wish. And if that includes trading their services, why not do so?”

 

“Exactly! Ah, you have an excellent understanding of how things work, Sir Myson!” He sneered at the warlock’s companion. “You could stand to learn from him, wastrel.”

 

Odesse stared at him for a moment, then bowed his head. “My apologies, Lord Acheron, for my presumption.”
