“Hmph. You’re lucky I am feeling magnanimous enough to let your insults slide.” He pointed his finger at the upstart. “But do not think my patience is limitless!”

 

“Of course not, Lord Acheron.” Myson smiled. “Now then, I believe a part of our deal was that we be allowed a pick of subjects from the villages in your territory–”

 

“Yes, yes, of course, you’ll have your pick of the peasants, though I would prefer you stick to vagrants instead of anyone actually useful. I still need to fill my coffers, after all.”

 

“We’ll make sure to use discretion in our selections,” the mage agreed, continuing to smile. Acheron could see why Aegir sent him as a representative, the man knew how to properly interact with his better. He admittedly wasn’t sure what exactly these “experiments” the order of mages intended to carry out were, but he couldn’t care less if they had to take a few peasants to carry them out, just so long as it didn’t inconvenience him.

 

“As you will then. For now, I have important business to get back to, so if you would–” Acheron paused as the doors were suddenly shoved open, a sneer crossing his face as he glared at the servant that dared interrupt him. “You had better be one of those oafs I sent to get refreshments, or else I’ll–”

 

“Lord Myson, the Imperial Princess returned to the palace and has claimed the throne,” the messenger in black rapidly explained, ignoring Acheron completely, much to his aggravation.

 

“Now see here–”

 

“Ludwig von Aegir has been deposed and arrested as a result.” And that took the wind right out of his sails. “He is currently imprisoned and awaiting trial while Marquis Vestra was eliminated. I believe the newly crowned emperor intends to continue a purge of our assets while consolidating her own power.”

 

“So she really has turned against us,” Odesse griped, his eyes narrowed in irritation, “We should have moved to secure her obedience earlier. Wasn’t Bias still keeping an eye on her?”

 

“She was, though I doubt it was a close one,” Myson replied while disregarding the increasingly pale and sweaty Acheron, “At this point, I consider Bias’s judgement to be compromised. She took her twin’s death poorly, so I doubt she is taking Solon’s demise any better.”

 

“H-Hold on, one moment,” Acheron interrupted, “What was that about Duke Aegir being arrested?”

 

The messenger raised an eyebrow, before looking towards Myson, who nodded indulgently. “Go ahead, Keryx, share what you have to share.”

 

“Of course, Lord Myson. As stated previously, Ludwig von Aegir was deposed and arrested by the newly crowned Emperor Edelgard von Hresvelg.”

 

“...th-that–No, hold on, that can’t be right!” Acheron yelped, “W-What does that mean for me!? I-I mean, us! What does that mean for us?!”

 

“Well, presumably, the Emperor will declare that she does not support this action of yours, Lord Acheron,” Myson answered, before glancing at the messenger, “I assume she used Aegir’s support of Lord Acheron as the casus for removing the duke from his position.”

 

“Yes, Lord Myson, that appears to be the case.”

 

“Hmph. She’s grown into quite the cunning little schemer to move so quickly against us..”

 

Acheron swallowed, his dreams crumbling to dust in front of his eyes. Without the empire’s support, he couldn’t possibly stand up to the Alliance! They might even declare him a rebel lord if he stayed on his current course! And if the Empire wouldn’t take him while the lords of Leicester turned against him… “W-Well, Sir Myson, thank you for visiting today, but I really should get back to work! I, ah, have some letters to send to Count Gloucester, simply important correspondence, a matter between lords, that sort of thing–”

 

“You know, when I heard you were called ‘The Weathervane’, I thought it meant you had some sense of self-preservation, Acheron,” Myson commented, regarding the ambitious minor lord with far less amusement than he had up until that point, “Are you truly so stupid that you’d try to turn on us while we’re right in front of you?”

 

“Wh–How dare you! Do you have any idea who you’re talking to?!” Acheron demanded, his anger at being insulted overriding his concern, “I am Lord Acheron Lethe Phlegethon! This is my castle, and I will not be insulted inside of it! Guards! Remove these men from my presence immediately!”

 

…

 

“...Guard! GUARDS!” 

 

Acheron scowled, glaring around the room at the guards that should have been moving to aid him, but were instead just staring at him with…With contempt? And as he looked around, he started to notice the servants in the room with him had stopped working in favor of staring at him too, before one maid glanced at Myson. “Lord Myson, your orders?”

 

“Disperse. There is no need to keep up this charade any further, especially now that this beast has outlived its usefulness.”

 

“Of course, my lord.” Acheron’s own servant bowed, before a flash of dark magic caused the woman’s skin to turn a pale white as her clothes shifted into dark robes, a change that continued with every person present as Acheron slowly realized he was surrounded by dark mages and knights that had disguised themselves as his castle staff.

 

“W-What? W-What in the world is this!?”

 

“You did not honestly think we would trust a beast of your reputation so readily, did you?” Myson asked, some amusement showing at Acheron’s growing fear, “We already had to deal with Aegir pushing his boundaries with us, and I had no intention of allowing that to happen again, not when we’ve invested so much into this project here.

 

He smiled, and it was a cruel, sadistic thing that lent true malice to his pale visage. “I had planned to replace you eventually, but I didn’t expect the time to come so soon. Odesse, if you would?”

 

“Hm? Hold on, this is why you brought me?” Odesse grimaced. “I have to look like that…thing?”

 

“I need a man with a firmer spine to play his role,” Myson noted as Acheron tried to back away, sweat running down his face as it dawned on him just how much danger he was in, “I realize it is not as much time as you could have had to learn his mannerisms, but then we do not need an exact mimicry.”

 

“W-W-Wait, wait, h-hold on! Y-You can’t seriously be thinking of killing me!” Acheron insisted, because for all his faults, he could at least recognize a threat to his own life. “I-I–Y-You don’t understand, I’m useful! I-I’m incredibly useful! I am the lord of the rivers, I-I control the Great Bridge of Myrddin, I can be of great use to you! I-I have powerful friends!”

 

“Yes, I am well aware of that,” Myson replied as Odesse started to approach the craven lord, dark magic gathering at the younger warlock’s hands, “The fact that you have value is the whole reason we are doing this. Otherwise we would have simply disposed of you outright.”

 

“W-What!? N-No, no, stay back!” Acheron demanded, before yelping as his back collided with his desk. “A-Ah–n-no, no, you can’t do this, not to me! I-I am Acheron! I-I’m meant for so much more than this!”

 

“And I agree, Acheron.” Myson smirked. “The man called Acheron will indeed play a very important role in the coming days. Do not worry. I will make sure your name goes down in history.”

 

Acheron would have screamed, but then Odesse’s hand was on his face, and all he saw was darkness.

"So, how do you feel, 'Lord Archeron'?" Myson mockingly asked.

 

"Ugh, don't call me by that beast's name," ‘Acheron’ complained, glaring at Myson as he seemed to try to ease any aches in his flesh, "You really couldn't have found me a better body?" 

 

"Probably, but this was the best option, especially since just disposing of him would leave too many questions." 

 

"At least I don't have to act like him," Acheron muttered as he felt his face to make sure everything fit well. "I am definitely getting rid of this mustache." 

 

"Just don't make it too obvious that something has changed. The last thing we need is that Imperial brat to come down on us."

 

“Hmph. What if we fake some sort of traumatic event? Give my character a ‘reason’ to change so drastically, perhaps?”

 

Myson laughed. “You mean like having his body stolen from him? If you want to fake an assassination attempt, go ahead, though do try to get some further utility from it outside of simply getting rid of the mustache.”

 

“It doesn’t need to be an assassination, just something sufficiently traumatizing. Maybe we could let a demonic beast loose and have it as an excuse to collect materials? Or perhaps I’ll just change because of my changing fortunes, hm? I am meant to have grown a spine, so perhaps a change in looks would be conducive?”

 

“You’re meant to be stubbornly digging your heels in, not transforming into a warrior prince.”

 

“I wasn’t planning to go that far,” Odesse complained, before grimacing as he examined his new face in the reflection of a window, “Ugh…maybe I could start wearing a mask?”

 

“Do you plan to start calling yourself the Flame Emperor then?” Myson mocked, before pausing as a thought occurred. “Hm…now that might be a point of interest.”

 

“What? Using the Flame Emperor? I thought the rat had turned against us.”

 

“She has, but nothing says we cannot use that identity to our own ends. It would be useful if we could reveal her 'identity' after using it for our own ends. Show her the price for turning against us." 

 

"Hm… fair point. One problem though." Myson raised an eyebrow at Odessa. "I'm not as short as her." 

 

"...Clearly we would be getting someone else," Myson responded, calling him an idiot under his breath, "That Kronya girl would be a good choice.”

 

“Because she’s short?”

 

“Yes, but also because she’s a vicious and unsubtle sadist who is entirely loyal to our cause. She would never hold any sympathy for the beasts, nor allow personal attachments to make her loyalty waver in the same way Bias has.” He smirked. “She’ll be perfect.”

Chapter End Notes

Indi: If we ever do a modern thing with 3H, Odessa is gonna be a theater kid.

Red: Honestly, "Those Who Slither in the Dark" could work for a band name.

Indi: Kronya goes around trying to get people to buy their CD. Somehow Dimitri becomes a huge fan.

The Last Day Together

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Shez had to admit, it was kind of weird not having Byleth around. It wasn’t the first time the two of them had been apart for a while, especially when they had missions to do for the church, but that was part of what made it weird. Her sister hadn’t left in the middle of the month before, so it felt kind of weird, especially since she kept what she was actually doing over in Enbarr a secret.

 

“Perhaps she eloped?” Arval offered half-heartedly, which earned an immediate frown from Shez.

 

“Byleth wouldn’t do that. Besides, if she did, she’d invite me to the wedding.”

 

"I doubt you know what elopement means." 

 

"Hey, of course I do! Even if it was a secret marriage, By would tell me!" 

 

"I suppose that is fair…perhaps they are conspiring together?" 

 

“What would they be ‘conspiring’ about?”

 

“Who knows? Perhaps they aim to conquer the world?”

 

“Pff, By wouldn’t do that. And I don’t think Edelgard would either? She’s kind of intense but she’d probably stop at just conquering Fodlan.”

 

“...That…why is that your logic?”

 

“It makes sense, doesn’t it? I mean, if she wanted to conquer the world, she could have killed that Almyran prince and started a war with Almyra. That could have led to conquering them." 

 

"...Hm. There is something unnerving about you using logic." 

 

"Shut up. Anyways…hm, By’s supposed to be getting back today, I think…maybe I should try to go find her ahead of time?”

 

“You’ll get lost,” Arval bluntly stated.

 

“Wh–I won’t! Probably!”

 

“Shez?”

 

Shez blinked, then glanced over to the entrance of the classroom. “Oh, hey Dimitri. Why are you over here?”

 

“I heard you talking to yourself,” he replied, “Why are you hanging around in your classroom? Classes should be over already.”

 

“Well yeah, they are, but I don’t have anything better to do and I didn’t feel like training.” She crossed her arms over her chest. “I guess I could’ve hung out with someone, but everyone’s pretty busy getting ready for that ball dance thing. I guess I should too, since Hilda, Mercedes, and Dorothea are gonna be helping me with that, but also the way they smiled at me earlier filled me with dread for some reason…" 

 

"I can understand that. I've never been one for balls myself. Why, the only time I enjoyed dancing was with…an old friend of mine." 

 

"Oh?" 

 

"Yes, when I was young she taught me how to dance. It… was a long time ago, but I look upon that time fondly." 

 

"Heh, what, was she your first crush or something?" Shez had to admit, that was the first time she saw Dimitri recoil in visible disgust. 

 

"Please, don't suggest such a thing again." 

 

Shez blinked. “Eesh, did things end that badly between you two?”

 

“No, it’s…You are aware that I had a step-mother, right?”

 

“Yeah?”

 

“Well, my step-mother had a daughter, and while I do not know the full circumstances of what occurred, I consider her daughter more of a sister to me.”

 

“Ohhh. Oh! You’re like me and By! Well minus the step-mother part, since her mom’s dead too.” Shez paused for a moment, because she was pretty sure Dimitri’s step-mom was also dead, but she probably shouldn’t bring that up.

 

“Could it be? Have you actually learned tact? It’s a miracle!” Arval snarked, prompting a frown from Shez.

 

“Ugh, you shut up, I know what tact is.”

 

“...Er, Shez?” Dimitri said, frowning slightly, “I did not say anything.”

 

“...Oh. Uh, whoops, heh. Guess I just, uh…” Shez wracked her brain for a good excuse. “...I probably heard the voice of the goddess! Because…this is a monastery!”

 

The sound of Arval’s palm meeting their face went unheard by Dimitri, though it was extremely audible to Shez.

 

"...Shez, forgive me for bringing this up, but I believe you once mentioned having a voice in your head?" the prince mentioned, which made Shez stiffen.

 

“Uh…oh, right, I think I did…Yeah, back with the Almyran thing, huh.”

 

“It is truly a miracle you can keep any secrets,” Arval chided while Dimitri seemed…almost relieved?

 

“I see…Shez, I would like you to know that you’re not alone.”

 

“Well yeah, I know that–” Shez paused as his meaning registered. “Wait, do you have a weird ghost person that follows you around and tells you to kill people?”

 

Arval scoffed, offended. “I do not tell you to kill people! I offer prudent advice depending upon your circumstances!”

 

“Yes! Exactly–Well, not quite exactly that, it is less a single ghost and more…” Dimitri cleared his throat. “My apologies. I just…I’ve been haunted for such a long time and to know another shares my circumstances…”

 

Shez paused. She hadn’t really considered how weird and potentially distressing it would probably be for someone else to be haunted by a strange ghost person. Though Byleth didn’t seem too bothered by hers…then again, Byleth didn’t get bothered by much. “Hey, it’s okay! I get it, it’s weird and annoying having a ghost talking to you all the time–”

 

“How am I weird and annoying?” Arval complained.

 

“–but I’m sure you can get a handle on them! What’s your weird ghost like anyways?”

 

“...Ah, well…I hear the voices of my father, step-mother, and best friend telling me to avenge their deaths,” Dimitri explained.

 

“Oh, wow, that’s heavier than I expected. Though I guess Arval does try to get me to fight Byleth, so I can understand that part,” Shez said, earning a worried glance from Dimitri.

 

“The ghost haunting you tries to get you to kill your sister?”

 

“Ehhh…kind of? Kind of…It sounds worse when you say it out loud like that.”

 

“Er…sorry?” 

 

“No, no, it’s fine, I just try to ignore them when they get like that anyway. Uh, so! You’ve got a vengeance quest, that makes sense, I know about that whole Tragedy thing–Uh, not to downplay it, I just...So! Any guesses on who might’ve done it? Do you have an evil uncle? Oh, or some kind of sinister advisor?”

 

Dimitri blinked, before frowning. “Shez, my life is not a storybook.”

 

“Right, sorry, I know.”

 

“...I actually came to the academy hoping to find some clues on that subject, actually,” he admitted, “I’ve tried looking within Faerghus, but my own investigations have been fruitless. I…I don’t know what, precisely, I thought I might find here, but…”

 

“...Hey, Dimitri, just a quick question, but why did you think Garreg Mach would have the answer you’re looking for?”

 

“...” He sighed. “I…I don’t think I can answer that here. There’s a reason, but it’s a long story to explain it.”

 

“Well, hey, I have time.” Shez smiled up at him. “I’m just hanging around anyway.”

 

“...I appreciate the offer, but…some other time, alright?”

 

“Well well well, what do we have here?” Claude said with a smirk as he entered the classroom, catching Dimitri off guard and earning an amused look from Shez, “The Blue Lions House leader coming by to try to poach everyone’s favorite purple-haired merc back to his class? Or were you just looking to invite her to the dance, hm?”

 

Dimitri sighed. “Neither, Claude. We were just talking.” Then his eyes narrowed. “And I do hope you weren’t listening in on our conversation.”

 

“Me? Would I do that? No, that doesn’t sound like something I would do. I was just coming by to make sure you weren’t running off with Shez. It seems like there’s been a trend of royals eloping around here.”

 

Shez scoffed, audibly amused. “Why does everybody think By eloped? I know it’s obvious Edelgard has a crush on her, but Byleth’s not the type to just run off with someone.”

 

Dimitri blinked. “She does?”

 

"Yeah? I mean, it's pretty obvious to me." 

 

"Hm…she did have Hubert in a different carriage instead of having him ride with her and Teach," Claude noted, eager to get the rumors flowing. 

 

"That's completely inappropriate! What would Seteth or the Archbishop say!?" Dimitri suddenly snapped, earning confused looks from Claude and Shez. 

 

"Uh, Dimitri, it's not a big deal, we're just joking around." 

 

"Yeah, nothing’s wrong, no need to shout. Besides, By likes Dorothea, so-" 

 

"So she's leading her on!?" Dimitri questioned, his brow furrowed in anger.

 

“...” Shez and Claude glanced at each other before the former spoke, “No? I mean, By doesn’t tell me everything about her love life, probably since I pester her over it because it’s funny, but she wouldn’t lead anyone on, she’s not like that.”

 

“I’ve also gotta ask why you seem to care so much, Dimitri,” Claude said.

 

“Of course I care! I’m her br–Uh, I mean, it is…important for…Th-The academy has standards that should be upheld.”

 

Shez just looked all the more confused. “Wait, since when were you such a stickler for propriety?”

 

“Since always, obviously. I have always been like this, clearly.”

 

Claude, meanwhile, felt both his eyebrows raise before he managed to school his expression. “...Well hey, if you want to talk to the professor about propriety, you should probably head over now. She and Edelgard should be getting back any second now.”

 

“Wait, really?!” Shez pushed herself up from her desk. “She’s back?!”

 

“I said she’s coming back, not that she’s–and there she goes.” Claude watched as his friend practically vanished from sight, traveling as fast as she could go in a flash of violet light. “You know, I really should ask her more about those powers of hers one of these days. So, Dimitri, are you–And he’s gone too. Hm.”

 

His reaction might’ve implied his princeliness had a crush on Edelgard, but Claude had a feeling it was something else, in part because he really was eavesdropping and caught a good part of that conversation. 

 

Fodlaners really needed to learn to talk in private areas when they didn’t want people to overhear them.

"My teacher, before we arrive at the monastery, is it okay if I ask a favor of you?" Edelgard asked as the carriage arrived at the town outside Garreg Mach.

 

"Of course, what do you need?" Byleth answered without hesitation.

 

"I do believe I mentioned I had something I wished to inform you about, correct?" At Byleth’s nod, she continued. "If possible, would you be willing to meet me at the Goddess Tower on the night of the ball?" 

 

"Oh, why?" Huh, Dorothea also wanted to meet her there. Was it related?

 

"It is…a special place to my parents. You may take it as foolish, but I think being there will give me the strength for what I need to tell you." 

 

"...Okay," Byleth agreed, nodding as she saw the serious look on Edelgard's face, though she was internally trying to figure out why Dorothea and Edelgard wanted to meet her in the same place. She could also faintly hear an exasperated noise from Sothis, for some reason. "I'll make sure to-" Then both Byleth and Edelgard jolted as the door was suddenly yanked open.

 

"Hey there By!" Shez shouted, grinning at the two from the doorway. "Did everything go well?" 

 

"...Yes, it did. Why did you yank the door open?" 

 

"What am I not supposed to be excited to see you?" Shez asked, before turning to Edelgard. "Hey, quick question, you two didn't elope, right?" 

 

"...W-What!?" Edelgard asked, her face burning at the sudden question. 

 

"Shez, I'm not even dating anyone, why would I suddenly elope?" Byleth asked.

 

"That's what I thought! But, well, rumors started flying around and well-" 

 

"Professor! I must speak with you at once!" Blinking, Byleth looked out to see Dimitri rapidly approaching the carriage. 

 

"Sure?" Byleth said, not sure what was going on while Shez winced. 

 

"Dimitri, please don't-" 

 

"Professor, explain your promiscuity at once!" 

 

"...My what?" Byleth asked, completely confused. 

 

"Her what!?" Edelgard yelped. 

 

"Any relations you might seek to chase are your own business, but as the professor of this academy you must uphold standards!" Dimitri shouted as Shez tried to push him back, to little avail as Byleth remained confused about what was happening. 

 

Things only continued to get worse as thanks to this happening in a very public place, Byleth found herself getting dragged away by a very stern-faced Seteth who wanted some explanation for why Dimitri was yelling at her about her promiscuity. 

"Heh, it sure looks like you were dragged through the wringer," Jeralt said, chuckling when he saw an exhausted looking Byleth slumped on a table. 

 

"I don't know what I did…" Byleth complained as she looked up at her father, "Apparently people think I'm promiscuous?" 

 

That earned a pair of raised eyebrows. "Really?" 

 

"Yeah, so Seteth started lecturing me for several hours, but just when I thought I was free, Raphael walked by and congratulated me on the wedding for some reason. Which just set off Seteth again…" Byleth sighed. "Why are people thinking I eloped with Edelgard?" 

 

"Ah… well, you know how rumors are," Jeralt replied, not completely understanding it either. "So, aside from that, is everything good?" 

 

"Yeah, everything was handled well," 

 

"Hm, you sure? You seem down," Jeralt noted, sitting down across from her. 

 

"I do?" Byleth asked. 

 

"Well of course you do, you've been tense since learning that student of yours is leaving the academy," Sothis piped in. 

 

"Ah… hm… hey, Jeralt… how would you feel if I were to suddenly move away?" 

 

"Hm? Well, I probably wouldn't be happy about it, but you're an adult, and you can make your own decisions," Jeralt responded. "But we can always see each other again. Unless you want to run away from me specifically." 

 

"I wouldn't do that," Byleth immediately denied, frowning deeply, "Just…I've been feeling tense lately, and it's weird. It's not like anything else I've felt." 

 

"Well, it would help if you told me why you were feeling like this." 

 

"Ah…" Pausing for a moment, Byleth considered her words. "A student of mine is withdrawing from the academy." 

 

"Aaah. Well, it's obvious that you're gonna miss them. I mean, you've gotten pretty attached to your students, haven't you?" 

 

"I… think so," Byleth said, frowning. "...Hey, Jeralt, do you know if my contract with the academy will end when the academy year ends?" 

 

"Hm, you know, I'm not sure. I would imagine they'd make sure to find someone to take over your role, but I don't think they've been looking… honestly wouldn't be surprised if Rhea just assumes you're just going to be sticking around for the long haul." 

 

"Ah…" That was… different. She had just assumed her contract would end when the year ended, but if there wasn't an actual end until they found a replacement… 

 

"Come on kid, no need to look so down. That ball is happening tomorrow, right? So best get ready for it to make it a good night." 

 

"I… guess, yeah," Byleth agreed, frowning as she got up. She needed to have a talk with Rhea after the ball. As much as she liked teaching, she had plans for her future, and they didn’t involve staying at Garreg Mach for her entire life.

“I do apologize for the inconvenience my departure may cause the Academy, but I feel ascending to the throne of Adrestia is the only reasonable action I can take at this time,” Edelgard explained, before bowing her head to the archbishop, “I hope for your understanding in this time of transition, and I thank you for all you have done for me while I attended the Officer’s Academy.”

 

“I second her majesty’s words,” Hubert said, bowing his head too and barely hiding the smirk on his face, “Thank you for the many opportunities you have given us while we attended your esteemed institution.”

 

Rhea smiled, nodding to the two students in turn. “You are quite welcome, children. I am glad to see the positive impact the Academy has had on both of you, and I understand the circumstances you were faced with. I can only offer my praise in how you handled the avarice of the former Duke Aegir and my condolences that your school year was cut so short. If you wish to return for the graduation ceremony at the end of the year, I would be happy to host you once more.”

 

“Then I look forward to seeing you then, Lady Rhea,” Edelgard said as she straightened. A part of her considered the idea of bringing the Imperial Army with her to that reunion, before discarding it as far too mean. Though Hubert would probably be all for it…

 

“I have to say, this is highly irregular, though I suppose we should have expected something like this might happen given the royal heirs we were hosting this year,” Seteth commented, “I presume you have already decided who will take over for you as the Black Eagles House Leader?”

 

“Of course. I intend to pass it to Ferdinand. He is a good friend and I believe he will be a worthy leader.”

 

“A fine choice,” Rhea said, still smiling, “I imagine the young heir of Aegir would be happy for the opportunity to redeem himself following his father’s poor choices.”

 

Edelgard had to stop herself from pointing out that his Father's actions weren't his own. For now, she just nodded. 

 

"I suppose we'll make an official announcement during the ball?" Seteth suggested. 

 

"That would be as good a time as any," Edelgard responded. 

 

"If I may, I wish to thank you," Rhea spoke up, surprising Edelgard. "It may have been fate, but you and the other house leaders brought Jeralt and his family here. For that, I owe you greatly." 

 

"...I would agree, having the professor here has been quite the boon. I have learned many things from her," Edelgard replied, meeting Rhea’s gaze, "Perhaps with her help, we can help mend the relationship between the Empire and the Church. If at all possible, I was seeking to reestablish the Southern Church." 

 

"Oh?" That seemed to surprise Rhea. "That is a surprise to hear, though not an unwelcome one. I understand the Southern Church caused many issues in the past, so it pleases me to hear you're willing to work past that."

 

"Of course. I'll make sure to write once I have proper candidates for the position," Edelgard said, bowing to the Archbishop before she and Hubert turned around to leave. 

 

"Perhaps that second bow was a bit much, your majesty," Hubert noted once the doors closed behind them. 

 

"As long as it keeps up appearances," Edelgard responded, "But for now, let's just enjoy ourselves, the ball tomorrow will likely be the last peaceful day we'll have for some time." 

 

"Hmph. I have no idea how peaceful it will be, given how busy I will be fending off anyone who wishes to dance with you," Hubert muttered. 

 

"Come now Hubert, I'm sure even you have someone you wish to dance with." 

 

"None that I would be willing to forsake my duties." 

 

"There you are, Edie, Hubie!" Dorothea greeted, waving as the two before grabbed Edelgard’s arm. "Come on, I want to hear all about your trip~" 

 

"Need I remind you just who you're grabbing onto, Dorothea?" Hubert asked with a warning tone.

 

"Why, I'm just grabbing onto our dear Edie. Unless there's something you want to announce to everyone~" Dorothea teased. 

 

"It's all right, Hubert,” Edelgard assured, “And there's nothing to say, Dorothea." 

 

"Is that so~? Well, either way you and I need to get ready for the dance! Unless you have someone else you'd like to take as a date~?" 

 

"D-Dorothea?" Feeling her face grow flushed, Edelgard looked away. 

 

"Not hearing a no," Dorothea teased. 

 

"Ah, there you are, Lady Edelgard!" Ferdinand greeted, a smile on his face as he was followed by the Black Eagles. "I had heard you arrived, but I had yet to see you." 

 

"She probably just wanted to rest after her long trip," Lindhart muttered. 

 

"But she was in a carriage, why would she need to rest?" Caspar asked.

 

"Apparently Didi came marching up to her carriage yelling about something, so maybe that's it?" Hapi suggested.

 

"W-Was everything okay?" 

 

"There is nothing to worry about Marianne, Dimitri simply misunderstood something," Edelgard responded. 

 

"Well I hope the professor is okay,” Flayn said, “I heard that my brother gave her a very long and stern lecture, so I hope she is not too tired."

 

"The professor is very strong, a lecture will not defeat her!" Petra declared.

 

"H-Hm, Seteth isn't that bad, right?" Bernadetta asked. 

 

"Even if he has gotten victory over our professor, I have just the spell to make sure she can power through any lecture next time!" Constance added with full enthusiasm.

 

"That would have been helpful earlier,” Byleth remarked, walking up to the group. 

 

"Professor, there you are!" Ferdinand greeted with a smile. "Thank you for assisting Lady Edelgard on her trip!" 

 

"It's the least I can do. I'm just glad we could get back in time for the dance."

 

"Yes, tomorrow might be the last time I'll be able to be with all of you all at once," Edelgard noted, "As such, I have a proposition. In five years time, the millennium festival will occur, why don't we all make sure to meet here again?"

 

"Ooo, a class reunion, that sounds fun~" Dorothea commented.

 

"That it does! I shall likely be staying here at Garreg Mach with my brother, but I'll make sure to greet you all warmly when you visit!" Flayn said with a bright smile.

 

"That sounds great!” Caspar agreed, “We'll make it the biggest party around!" 

 

"...I-it does sound lovely." 

 

"B-Bernie isn't going to be left out!" Bernadetta declared.

 

"Even if I must swim the ocean, I shall return!" Petra agreed.

 

"Well, I suppose that I could pry myself away from however busy I will be to visit you all!" Constance decided, prompting a nod from Hapi.

 

"If Coco is in, I'm in too."  

 

"I would be remiss to miss such an event, and I swear my dance moves will outshine even you Dorothea!" Ferdinand boasted, getting Dorothea to let out an amused huff. 

 

"It sounds like a pain, but you guys will probably be more annoying if I try to skip out," Linhardt mumbled. 

 

"Heh, it seems that is everyone then," Hubert noted. 

 

"Not everyone yet." Turning her gaze towards Byleth, Edelgard smiled. "How about it, professor?" 

 

"...yeah, that sounds great. No matter what, I'll make sure to be here," Byleth agreed, returning the smile. It was a promise she intended to keep. 

Chapter End Notes

Red: Having a lot of characters in a scene really does get troublesome. Like, I realize we should have all the Eagles comment, but it really gets annoying keeping track of dialogue.

Indi: This is the real reason we're having Hubert and Edelgard leave.

Red: There's too many Eagles. We need less Eagles.

Indi: Now who to get rid of next...

The Night of the Ball

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

There were times when Byleth wondered how she would have done if she had joined the monastery as a student instead of a teacher. Usually those times related to her wearing an Academy uniform, either because her sister and students wanted to see how she would look in one, or in circumstances like these where she didn’t have that many formal clothes and so elected to wear a formal uniform instead of spending her money on something fancier.

 

She did add a black shoulder cape to her own version of the uniform, mostly to set herself apart from the students. Not that she really needed to, considering she knew who she was and she did still have her sword at her side. She did kind of prefer the silver version of the uniform her sister had got her though…it just felt like a nice personal touch. Though she could add some pink to it instead, that might be cute…

 

"I must say, it's certainly interesting how the most self-interest you show is when it comes to fashion," Sothis noted. 

 

"It feels nice being pretty." 

 

"Certainly. I shall not deny that wearing clothes you like is something everyone enjoys." 

 

"Hey there, By!" Shez greeted, making the two look over at her and pause, their eyes widening in surprise. Rather than her uniform or her normal clothes, Shez was wearing a full ball gown, one that was a mix of royal purple and silver that cinched at the waist with a violet sash and poofed out at the skirt. Her hair was also curled into ringlets, and she seemed to be wearing blush and eyeliner too. "What do you think?" 

 

"You look very pretty," Byleth said, smiling as she gave her sister a thumbs up. "Though I think I might have underdressed for this…" 

 

"Aw, no come on By, you look good!" Shez reassured, prompting a hum from Arval.

 

“You are far better dressed than she is."

 

"Arval, come on, you know I'm all for competitions, but this isn't one of them," Shez said, frowning at her friend.

 

"Hmph, this spirit your sister hosts certainly has quite the nerve if they're commenting on your sense of fashion," Sothis muttered, making a guess on what Arval had said. 

 

"Hm. Shez, if Arval is saying anything rude about my clothes, tell them to shut up," Byleth requested, catching everyone off guard. "Dorothea said I can dress how I want." 

 

"Pft- well, you heard her Arval." 

 

"I was not-..." Arval took a deep breath. They would choose their battles wisely and not get into an argument with children. "Shez, please tell your sister I am sorry for disparaging her clothes. She looks lovely." 

 

"Arval thinks you look cute,” Shez said, prompting an aggravated sound from the pale spirit.

 

"Aw, is the disparaging spirit just shy~?" Sothis teased, even if only Byleth could hear her. 

 

"Thank you, Arval," Byleth said, before focusing on Shez. "Now come on, we should get to the ball." 

 

"Oh, right, I am getting paid so gotta make sure I actually show up!" 

 

"Paid? Paid for what?" Byleth asked, though Shez moved ahead as quickly as she could in the dress before she got an answer. "...Hm." 

 

"If nothing else, your sister can take care of herself, so no need to worry," Sothis assured as Byleth followed behind her sister. 

 

“Mm…alright,” Byleth replied, before walking out into the crowd of students. She wasn’t the only one who wore the formal uniform, though she did notice a few students had chosen to dress up in even fancier clothes, so Shez wasn’t alone in her ball gown. 

 

Immediately, she could see Annette and Mercedes had dressed up, the former wearing a blue gown and chatting cheerfully at Felix, who seemed to be at least paying attention to her, while the latter wore a modest, light-brown gown and had her hair unbound from its usual side-tie as she danced with Dedue. Nice to see the Blue Lions were having some fun, though Byleth couldn’t help notice Sylvain striking out pretty badly in trying to ask another student to dance while Ingrid clearly decided she would prefer to stick by the buffet instead of bothering with a date.

 

As for Ashe, Byleth idly noted that he seemed to be hanging out with Yuri and Balthus…possibly not entirely by choice, if judging by his somewhat uncomfortable expression as Balthus regaled him with some tale of his adventures. Byleth was a little concerned, but Ashe gave her a small smile and a signal that he was okay when she looked worried, so she decided to just leave it for now. She did make a note that Yuri had decided to dress up though, wearing an ostentatious all-white suit, while Balthus had actually put on a shirt. Good to see he was getting into the formal spirit of things.

 

As for her own class, Byleth did feel a slight frown come to her face when she noticed Hubert and Linhardt were just wearing their normal uniforms, but, then again, did she really expect any better?

 

Dorothea looked good though, especially because she had decided to wear the dancer outfit she had won from the White Heron Cup. It looked good on her, and it seemed many people agreed judging by the amount of admirers she had. Not that Dorothea was paying attention to that; instead, she seemed to be encouraging Caspar and Petra to dance together, a happy smile on her face as she made sure they both knew what they were doing.

 

Byleth briefly considered that she should have worn her own dancer’s outfit to the ball, and probably would have if she knew it was an option, before discarding that thought in favor of continuing to check on her students. As one might expect, Ferdinand had dressed up for the occasion, wearing a crimson suit with white pants as he led Flayn through the steps of the dance, smiling encouragingly at her while she gave her best effort to follow his movement.

 

Also extremely expected and obvious was seeing Hapi and Constance together, though Byleth was a little surprised to see Hapi had dressed up for the occasion. Probably at Constance’s urging, considering their dresses seemed to match in style, though not color; green and black for Hapi, and pink and blue for Constance.

 

They weren’t the only girl-girl pairing at the dance either, as Byleth spotted Marianne with Hilda. The blue-haired Eagle was just wearing her formal uniform, but the pink-haired Deer had dressed up in a pink, red, and black dress of her own, her hair done up differently from her usual twintails and a faint blush on her face as she guided Marianne through their dance.

 

They looked like they were having a nice time, so Byleth just left them to it as she scanned the room, looking to spot the last of her eagles. Along the way, she did notice Raphael had joined Ingrid at the buffet and the two had gotten to some lively chatting while Ignatz seemed to have been dragged into the conversation with Balthus, Yuri, and Ashe. At least the latter seemed relieved to have someone else dealing with the Wolves. 

 

As for Leonie, Byleth felt a slight flash of surprise as she saw her father’s apprentice practically pulling Lorenz onto the dancefloor, the purple-haired and purple-suited noble seeming just as bewildered as Leonie insisted he owed her a dance. For what, Byleth wasn’t sure, but hey, it wasn’t her business. Unless the two started making out, then she was pretty sure she had a responsibility as a professor to stop that from happening.

 

Probably not something she needed to worry about though, at least from those two. Now, as for Bernadetta…

 

Byleth frowned to herself, before heading over to one of the tables and peeking under the tablecloth. She didn’t find Bernadetta under there, which was both kind of a surprise and kind of a relief, though now she felt a little concerned…up until she noticed the easily frightened Eagle fidgeting with the purple gloves of her gown, her usually messy hair actually brushed to the point it looked smooth. She was even wearing a few little black bows in it as she seemed to be working up her nerve to talk to Hubert, ever so slowly approaching him on her shaky legs.

 

Byleth smiled, internally wishing Bernadetta luck, though she did feel a little concerned as Bernie seemed to falter, muttering to herself anxiously…Something another student seemed to notice, judging by how Emily huffed in visible annoyance before walking up to Hubert and shoving him toward Bernadetta.

 

Hubert looked bewildered, then angered at the sudden shove, before he noticed Bernadetta hurry up to him, asking if he was okay. He responded in the affirmative, though he seemed a little distracted by the shorter Eagle’s change in clothing, and Byleth smiled in some satisfaction before she went up to Emily and gave her a little nudge.

 

“Gh–Who the f–Oh. Uh, hey, professor,” Emily greeted, which was actually kind of remarkable.

 

“Hello Emily. Are you enjoying the dance?”

 

“...Eh. It’s…different, I guess. Not really my thing.”

 

“Have you asked someone to dance yet?”

 

“...Maybe later.” She scratched her head, then gave Byleth a glance. “Do you want something?”

 

Byleth shook her head. “I just want my student to enjoy herself.”

 

And it was true. Even if she had her concerns about Emily being an imposter, some Agarthan assassin or similar…she wanted her students to be happy. And Emily was her student.

 

“I’m in a different class now, professor. You don’t have to worry about me. Besides, I…Well, whatever. I guess I might as well enjoy this while it lasts.”

 

With that, she walked off, not as agitated as she once was. It was nice to see.

 

“Hm…you really are too naive,” Sothis noted, catching Byleth by some surprise since she didn’t expect her to speak up at the dance, “If you are correct and that girl really is an Agarthan, she almost certainly murdered the original Emily Korsch to assume her form. A girl died so she could pretend to be her. That fact does not disappear just because she is relaxing in the absence of conflict.”

 

“...I know. But I want my students to be happy,” Byleth murmured back, earning a sigh from Sothis.

 

“Too naive and too kind for your own good,” she complained, though there was a faint fondness in her words.

“Hey Claude! There you are!” Shez called out upon seeing her house leader in the fancy formal uniform, from where he was standing with the other two house leaders. All three of them were in those formal uniforms, though they were also wearing sashes in their house colors. Probably a house leader thing. “Oh hey Dimitri, hi Edelgard!”

 

“Shez?” Dimitri exclaimed, looking caught off guard by her appearance, “You look…Well, ah, you look good. Very…radiant!”

 

“You could just tell her she looks nice,” Edelgard commented, before nodding to Shez, “I see you put a lot of work into your appearance. Well done.”

 

“...You look like Lorenz’s sister instead of Teach’s,” Claude stated, not at all hiding his amusement at her current state of dress, which earned a scandalized gasp from Dimitri.

 

“I do? Well I guess we both have purple hair,” Shez considered, tilting her head in thought as she crossed her arms over her chest, before she paused. "Hey, no trying to distract me with an image of Lorenz in a dress, you know what you owe me." 

 

"...Okay, not what I was planning, but interesting that's where your mind went," Claude muttered, as he pulled out a bag of gold coins to hand over. 

 

"Heh, thank you for your payment~!" Shez said, making sure to announce that quite loudly as she took the bag. Then she looked down at her dress. "...hm, shit I forgot this doesn't have pockets." She frowned, then seemed to study her own chest. “Hm…maybe I could do like Manuela…nah, the bag’s too big, I would look like I have three boobs.”

 

“...What?” Dimitri asked, his face reddening while Edelgard sighed and pinched the bridge of her nose.

 

“Claude, why don’t you tend to your date?” she requested, internally wondering how she ever thought Shez could possibly be a spy. She knew the girl wasn’t completely unintelligent, but it was impossible not to regard her as at least somewhat stupid.

 

“Aw, trying to get rid of me already?”

 

“Yes. Hopefully before Shez elects to shove her payment in her skirts.”

 

“...Would it fit between the ruffles?” Shez asked, glancing at her gown with some curiosity.

 

"Alright, come on before you flash everyone at the dance," Claude said, pulling her along, "We can talk later, your majesty, but for now, I might as well enjoy what my gold got me." 

 

"Oh, right, see you guys!"

 

"...I see Shez is the same as ever. I doubt she'll come by and talk with us later," Dimitri commented with a small frown as he watched the pair head onto the dancefloor, which earned a huff from Edelgard. 

 

“Isn’t that a good thing in our case? I noticed you wanted to say something while I explained what happened in Enbarr.” Edelgard turned, frowning up at the tall blond. “So go on, say what you wish to say.”

 

“...” Dimitri sighed, crossing his arms over his chest and frowning. “Are you really leaving the Officer’s Academy entirely?”

 

“Yes, I am. I have to. Duke Aegir’s overreach has shown that I cannot spend the rest of my year in leisure, even if I want to.”

 

Dimitri grimaced. “I would not call our year leisurely…”

 

“It could have been worse,” she replied, well aware that it could have been far, far worse than it had.

 

“It shouldn’t have been that bad to begin with! And that’s not even mentioning that the Church still hasn’t caught the last of those ‘cultists’, nor the Death Knight or the Flame Emperor!”

 

Edelgard frowned. “I know that, Dimitri, but that is the Church’s responsibility to deal with. My responsibility is to my people and my nation. I cannot let myself forget that responsibility, even if I would rather remain in these peaceful days at the Academy. And I do not need you to protect me.”

 

“...I am not trying to–”

 

“Then what was that spectacle yesterday?” she questioned with a deep frown, “You were accusing Professor Byleth of promiscuity.”

 

Dimitri stiffened, his face turning pink. “Ah, that…I admit, I may have overreacted–”

 

“Why was it your place to react at all? You and I are nothing more than classmates, Dimitri. Even then, we are not in the same house. I do not see why you should have any investment in me beyond the simple courtesy we pay each other as students who attend the same academy.”

 

“...” Dimitri worked his jaw, trying to decide what he should say. He could feel the chance for answers start to slip away from him. He should have talked to her before. He should have let her know what connection they had. He should have checked to see if she truly didn’t remember their days together at all. Because he could see, quite clearly now, that she didn’t. 

 

He really was nothing more than a stranger to her.

 

"...My apologies, but if I may, can I ask one question?" 

 

"I do hope you're not planning on asking me to dance after this." 

 

"No, I'd rather not make a fool of myself when dancing with someone as skilled as you," Dimitri said, a sad smile on his face. "I wanted to ask, that dagger you always have, its design seems to be of Faerghus, correct?" 

 

"...Yes, what about it?" 

 

"You know, in Faerghus blades are considered tools of destiny," Dimitri responded, "Something to be used to cut a better path forward to the future." 

 

Edelgard frowned, unsure of what he was meaning by this yet also… feeling something distinctly familiar about it. 

 

"Hmph, that is quite the belief. Why do you bring it up?" 

 

"..." Dimitri took in a deep breath as he remembered Byleth’s words about not understanding one another without talking. "...I'm glad you have cut your own path, El." 

 

He could see the look of confusion cross her face, along with the moment it turned towards realization as the truth dawned on her. “...Dee? You were…Ha…You were the boy in Faerghus.”

 

She laughed again, bewildered and disbelieving, but it was clear she understood. “…did you know? This whole time?”

 

“I did. I…Well, we were both young then. I can imagine the memories would fade in time.” He smiled ruefully. “I did not expect you to forget me completely though.”

 

“...I did not mean to. There were…extenuating circumstances.”

 

“...I heard there was a plague in Adrestia. Perhaps…passed from Faerghus?”

 

Edelgard startled, her eyes widening before she shook her head. “Dimitri, no, it wasn’t–Goddess, that would be horrific…there was no plague, Dimitri. It wasn’t…Did you think it was your fault?”

 

“...Maybe. Before you asked me just now, I doubt I would have realized it, but…I think there was some part of me that felt it had something to do with that. That perhaps you hated me for some fault of mine.” He shrugged. “It would hardly be the first friendship I ruined.”

 

“It wasn’t your fault, Dimitri. There wasn’t a plague. The…My siblings were murdered, Dimitri. And…” She took a breath and couldn’t keep her shoulders from shaking with some emotion she couldn’t describe. She almost felt like laughing at the absurdity of the situation. “...I wish I had more time to explain. I…This whole time…" 

 

Her mind went back to the night when they had first met Byleth. About how she had tried to get Claude and Dimitri killed. 

 

"Edelgard? Are you okay?" Dimitri asked, breaking her out of her thoughts. 

 

"...My apologies, this is just… a lot to take in." 

 

"I understand, would you like me to get you some water?" he asked, concern evident in his voice. 

 

"No, I just… need to sit down for a moment." 

 

"Okay… Edelgard, I know you are leaving, but I hope we can speak again before you leave," Dimitri requested. 

 

"...Of course," Edelgard agreed, before walking away. She needed to clear her head. Get some air to try and think this through- 

 

"And where do you think you're going?" Catherine asked as she clapped a hand down on her shoulder. "You really shouldn't be trying to leave your own farewell party." 

 

"I-I'm not trying to. I'm just trying to get some fresh air." 

 

"Sure you're not, and I'm sure it has nothing to do with the professor leaving already," Catherine said with a raised eyebrow. 

 

"Wait, she left?" Edelgard asked, her eyes looking around to see if Byleth had already gone to the Goddess Tower. 

 

"That she did, and while she can come and go, students really should stay at the ball," Catherine responded, smirking as she pulled Edelgard away from the door. "Come on, I'm sure there's plenty of people who want to dance with you." 

 

"There you are Edie!" Dorothea called out, getting their attention as she approached. "I was looking for you! I was starting to think you didn't want to dance with your date." 

 

"A-Ah, no, I just wanted to get some air." 

 

"You can get some air later! Come on, enjoy yourself," Catherine insisted, pushing Edelgard towards Dorothea, who smiled as she caught her. 

 

"Heh, come on Edie~." Dorothea grinned as she pulled her towards the dance floor. "Are you okay? You seem pale," Dorothea asked once they were in the middle of the dance floor, the music and everyone talking kept their conversation private as she spoke quietly. 

 

"...I just learned something very important," Edelgard said, unsure of what else to say. 

 

"Definitely seems like it," Dorothea replied, taking her hands as she began to lead the pair in a dance. "That's the second time I've seen you looking so pale. Though, no need to talk about it if you don't want to." 

 

"Thank you…" Edelgard murmured, before she looked around, watching the various students dancing and talking. It seems Yuri had been amused enough by Sylvain striking out so much that now he was leading him on the dance floor, while off in the distance she could see Cyril talking with Shamir, likely catching up with his mentor. Shez and Claude were certainly making quite the scene as they danced, neither of them that skilled but certainly eager. Behind her, Edelgard could hear Catherine giving Lysithea advice of some sort, one which Lysithea vehemently denied needing. 

 

"Coin for your thoughts?" Dorothea asked. 

 

"...I am simply realizing how much I'll miss this place," Edelgard answered. 

 

"Well, it's not like you won't be coming back, I mean, we did promise to have a class reunion here, and I'm sure despite how busy you'll be, you'll be able to find some time away from being the emperor." 

 

"Maybe, I suppose we'll have to see," Edelgard said. 

 

"Yup, and if you're feeling lonely, well the Mittlefrank Opera House is near the palace~." 

 

"...That does sound nice," Edelgard admitted, "It has been quite some time since I've been to the opera, but it has provided some comfort in the past." 

 

"Oh?" 

 

"Yes, I actually did see one of your performances before. It helped bring some… normalcy back to my life." 

 

"Well, I'm glad I could help then! And the emperor is always welcome to visit~," Dorothea teased, getting Edelgard to blush.

 

"H-Hm, right…" 

 

"Though I must say, it's a bit of a surprise to see that the professor left so early. I wonder if my letter had anything to do with it…" 

 

"Letter?" 

 

"Yes, I left one for her like I left for you. Did you not read it?" 

 

"Ah…" Edelgard frowned. "If you left an unmarked letter, Hubert likely threw it away while I was out." 

 

"...Goddess damn it, Hubie," Dorothea muttered, "Well, either way, we should make sure to get out as soon as we can so she's not alone out there for too long." 

 

"...Yes, that would be for the best," Edelgard muttered, before glancing up at Dorothea. "If I may ask, are you…actually being genuine when you talked about…you, the professor, and I?" 

 

"Why wouldn't I be~?" 

 

"Because…It's something I cannot fully understand myself. I can understand if you were attempting to do so if you did not want me to ignore my own feelings but there is no need to do this. I understand that it…might be tradition for emperors to do something like that, but you don't need to-"

 

"Edelgard," That caught the emperor off guard as she heard her friend call her by her name. "I'm doing this because I want to. You like the professor and me, I like you and the professor, and… well, Professor Byleth might have her difficulties with her emotions, but I'm sure she likes the two of us as well. And honestly…the tradition is just an excuse really. Even if we don't get married, isn't it enough for all of us to be with the ones we care about?" 

 

"...Even if it means a life of hardship?" 

 

"Heh, you know, Lorenz said something similar, about how a life of nobility is something most commoners aren't going to be ready for. I guess the life of royalty is even harder than that." 

 

"..." Edelgard moved her hand to hold onto Dorothea’s. "...There's something important I was planning on telling the professor. I think I want you to hear it as well." 

 

"Well I’d love to hear it, so we better sneak out when we can~" 

 

"Excuse me, my apologies for interrupting the festivities, but there is something to announce!" Seteth spoke up, catching everyone's attention. 

 

"I suppose I should get ready," Edelgard said, about to pull back, before feeling Dorothea gently squeeze her hand. 

 

"Make sure to take care of yourself, okay Edie?" 

 

"...Of course, thank you for everything, Dorothea." Edelgard smiled at her, before she bowed to the songstress. Turning around, Edelgard approached Seteth, and stood nearby as he continued talking. 

 

"Now, I understand much has happened this year. However, this is of great importance." He glanced over at Edelgard, before nodding to her. Taking center stage, she looked out over everyone. 

 

"Thank you for your attention," Edelgard began, taking in the sight of all the students she had spent so long with. Familiar faces, all looking up at her. "Recently, I temporarily left the academy to travel to Enbarr." Wait. "A matter of grave importance demanded my attention." Where is Emily? "As such, I would like to formally announce that I, Edelgard von Hresvelg am now the Emperor-" 

 

A loud explosion, one strong enough to shake the glass of the building they were in sounded out. Immediately, panicked screams were heard throughout the building, wondering what was going on. Dimly aware of Seteth trying to calm down the students, Edelgard rushed out of the building. 

 

Once she was out under the night sky, Edelgard felt her heart drop. Up, far above her in the air, the goddess tower was ablaze, crumbling from the hole the fire surrounded. For a moment, it was as if all sound had cut out, as she could only stare in horror at the sight. As she saw something fall from the tower, she couldn't help but scream. 

 

“PROFES-”

Letting out a small yawn, Edelgard sat up, her mind slightly bleary before she managed to shake the daze of sleep out of her head. She had a very important day to prepare for, after all. One that she couldn’t mess up. Depending on how things go, this could be her last peaceful day with everyone-

 

An incessant knocking at her door caught her attention, “Edelgard, can you open up?”

 

“Professor? What’s wrong?” Edelgard asked, worried about the slightly hurried tone in Byleth’s voice. Frowning, she quickly put on a robe to answer the door, only to stiffen as Byleth quickly pushed her way in and locked the door behind her. “P-Professor?”

 

“We need to talk. I know who the infiltrators are,” Byleth said, looking far too exhausted for someone who she was sure went to sleep early last night. “And…I know your secret.”

Chapter End Notes

Red: Man, it's tricky writing a big event when the main character can turn time back.

Indi: That it is! Ah well, hopefully we managed to make what's coming up work.

Red: Hopefully! It was tricky, but I like what we've got, and I hope you all like what we wrote! Thanks for reading!

Indi: See you next time!

A Meeting in the Goddess Tower

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

"Must you leave so early?" Sothis complained, frowning while she floated by Byleth. "The night is still young, there is more dancing to be had!" 

 

“I can dance later,” Byleth replied as she walked along the route to the Goddess Tower, “For now, I need to meet Edelgard and Dorothea.”

 

“Bah, are they even going to be up there yet? The last I saw, that house leader was still talking with that Dimitri boy and the songstress was helping others dance.”

 

“They’ll be there,” Byleth affirmed, “They might not be there yet, but I can wait for them.”

 

“Hmph. Fine, but I’m going to start annoying you if she doesn’t arrive quickly enough.”

 

Byleth could have replied “like you’re doing right now?” but she was more mature than that, so she let it slide in favor of heading up the Goddess Tower. She recalled the legend of the tower as she walked, and a part of her wondered if it would work if there were three people up there…hm well neither of the two she was meeting were that religious, so would they even believe in this legend? There had to be a reason why they both wanted to be up here with her. 

 

…Were they going to elope?

 

No wait, that didn't make sense. If they were going to do that, Edelgard wouldn't have made such a big deal of becoming the Emperor. The thought also made her feel weird, so she was just going to ignore it. 

 

Either way, it wasn’t long before she was inside the empty stone room at the top. It did have a nice view of the monastery from up there, she had to admit. The night sky looked beautiful…

 

The brief feeling of growing heat at the back of her neck was the only warning Byleth got before she ducked, drawing her sword and whirling around as a fireball went sailing over her head.

 

“Tch. I wonder, was that your power, Fell Star, or do you truly have that good of instincts?”

 

Byleth blinked, a frown coming to her face as she studied the blonde woman in front of her, who looked like an average priestess of the monastery. “...Fell Star?”

 

“You, abomination. That is the name of the false god that descended from the heavens and stole the land from its rightful rulers,” the woman explained with a small smirk, her tone calm and even, “I presume you know none of that truth then? You are a vessel, after all. Merely the echo of the False God.”

 

Byleth narrowed her eyes. “You’re one of those people then. The Agarthans.”

 

“Ah, excellent! You’re not a complete idiot!” The woman giggled, before placing a hand on her chest and bowing with a flourish. “Hello, Professor Byleth Eisner, daughter of Jeralt the Blade Breaker. For the past, oh, however many months, I have been known as Selene, a priestess of the Church of Seiros. My true name though…”

 

She giggled again, then straightened as darkness and flames erupted from her body. The guise of the priestess she wore burned away until Byleth was faced with a woman with pale white skin and pitch-black hair. Her robes transformed, twisting from white fabric into a black and scarlet shoulderless gown decorated with rubies, chains, and feathers. Her black-painted lips curled into a smile as her crimson eyes glittered with delighted malice. “Is Bias, Seeker of Vengeance.”

 

“...You want revenge against me then.” Byleth nodded while she considered the distance between herself and the mage. She could maybe strike her with the sword of the creator, there wasn’t that much space between them… “For Pittacus?" 

 

"Aha, so you do know what I want," Bias said, no amusement in her words despite her smile. 

 

"I heard from Shez that you want revenge for her. Though I don't know what that has to do with me." 

 

"Of course you don't. I would be surprised if you did, I mean, you didn't even know Thales was there, so how could you have known my sister was in the carriage with him! Hahahaha!" She began to laugh, unnerving Byleth. She sounded genuinely unhinged–And then the laughter cut off entirely. "But then that doesn’t really matter, no, not really. Because you still killed her, and I’ve been putting this off for so very long, trying to make sure I had everything lined up to make this work…It’s been maddening, you know? Knowing you were here with your happy little family. Your papa, and your sister." 

 

She laughed again, bitter and angry. “It seems some people really are favored over others, hm? Though you’re not really a person, are you? Just an empty shell with a god contained inside. I wonder, is the intelligence you have even your own, or are you just an amnesiac deity aping the actions of a human? You are heartless, after all, so the topic warrants speculation. Really, the scientist in me would love to see what the reality of ‘Byleth Eisner’ is, but I absolutely hate you and want you dead, so that curiosity can be damned for all I care.”

 

“...” Byleth took a breath, keeping her sword at the ready. She knew this woman’s motivations and that she was a threat to not only her, but likely her entire family. She wasn’t about to allow that. Even if her grip wavered as she stared at the mage, stricken with grief over her sister's death. 

 

“...a god…?” Sothis murmured, meanwhile, her brow furrowed in thought and concern. “I…could it be…?”

 

“Is that all you had to say?” Byleth asked, steady and ready to fight.

 

“Oh, no, thank you for reminding me.” Bias snapped her fingers with a grin and Byleth felt herself stiffen as she saw Emily appear in front of her, her arms bound tight and a gag in her mouth. “You know, I really should thank that Archbishop of yours. Or perhaps her chamberlain? Whichever one made all those faith magic books so readily available in their library. Ah, speaking of–”

 

She clenched her fist and there was a flash of red magic as Byleth felt a strange, tight sensation settle over her. The professor frowned deeper, then glanced at her hand as she tried to form a fireball. Nothing happened. She couldn’t call on her magic.

 

“And I believe that leaves one more thing,” Bias said, smirking once more as she placed a hand on Emily’s shoulder, earning a flinch from the restrained girl, whose eyes flicked towards the mad mage in obvious fear. A warranted fear, given Bias moved her other hand towards Emily’s face and set her palm alight with magical fire. “Toss your sword off the tower, or your student dies.”

 

“...Let Emily go afterward,” Byleth demanded.

 

“WHAT!?” Sothis screeched, snapped from her consideration as she stared at Byleth in shock. “You cannot be serious! That is your only weapon! You cannot just throw it away, and especially not for her! You know that girl is an imposter!”

 

“Throw the sword away first then,” Bias responded, her tone mocking, “If you care at all for this girl, it shouldn’t even be a choice–”

 

It wasn’t. Byleth tossed the Sword of the Creator out of the tower.

 

“...” The flames on Bias’s hand winked out as she laughed aloud, eyes wide with disbelief. “Hahaha! Are you serious?! You didn’t even hesitate! And for this trash!? Oh, or did you? Did you, perhaps, test things, hm? Maybe you struck out and saw that it wouldn’t work, so you turned back time to pretend you wouldn’t sacrifice your student’s life for your own sake?”

 

Byleth showed no reaction to the knowledge that Bias knew about her powers. She just held out her now empty hand. “I upheld my end of the bargain. Let my student go.”

 

“...You didn’t?” Bias blinked, her confusion obvious, before she scowled and shoved Emily forward. “Fine, take the trash. I’ll give you a moment to console her as a favor to your ‘kindness’ before I boil your brain inside your skull.”

 

Byleth caught her student and, despite the situation, she smiled at Emily. “It’s okay. I’ve got you–”

 

The sound of a knife piercing into flesh echoed through the tower. The barely tied ropes fell away from Emily’s body as she glared up at her wide-eyed professor. “...Just fall down and die.”

 

“...” Byleth just stared for a moment at her student, and at the blood dripping down from the black dagger in her hand, before she fell back to the ground with a faint thud, blood staining the front of her uniform.

 

“There, I did it,” Emily said, turning back toward Bias with a scowl, one hand clenched tight around the dagger in it.

 

“So you did! Hm, not quite as satisfying as I thought it would be.” Bias sighed. “I guess it just goes to show what they say about vengeance…ah, I don’t remember what they say about vengeance, it’s probably something pithy about it being bad. Ah well.”

 

“...Do I get to go now?” Emily asked, “I don’t…I just want to go home, Bias.”

 

“Hm? Home? Now where would that be again?”

 

“Would you stop screwing around? You said we could just warp out of here once I killed her, and I did. She’s dead, let’s go.”

 

“It’s a legitimate question, Kronya! After all, you’re the one cozying up to the beasts. Trying to find a new home for yourself, hm? It’s understandable, given no one wants you or would even care if you died. Really, our people would probably celebrate, given how you murdered Solon.”

 

“...” Kronya swallowed, trying to ignore the pit of despair growing in her belly at the sage’s outright gleeful lie. “You promised.”

 

“Ugh, you sound like a child when you whine like that. But then again, you were always a brat. At least you turned out to be useful at the end.” She grinned, raising a hand as fiery orange sigils began to light up all around the interior of the tower. “Now be a good little scapegoat and accept your sacrifice with dignity.”

 

Kronya flinched back, instinctively trying to get away as she looked for a route out–And then she felt a pair of strong arms wrap around her as Byleth put herself between Kronya and the explosion, the force of the blast sending them both right over the edge of the tower as the entire top erupted in a massive fireball.

 

Kronya’s eyes were wide with disbelief as she fell, the sheer impossibility of the situation keeping her from reacting for a second before her mind started working rapidly, trying to think of how she could survive the fall. Her guise burned away, her identity of Emily Korsch vanishing as she returned to her true flesh for the first time in almost a year. 

 

She had no time to enjoy the sensation though as her tails shot out, stabbing into the stone of the tower as she tried her damnedest to slow their descent. It was difficult, near impossible, and she could feel a pain in her spine at the sensation, but she held firm until they finally slowed to a stop on the ground.

 

“H-Haahhh…th-that bitch,” Kronya growled, tense and pained from the brutal descent, though her superior’s treachery stung almost as badly. She knew Bias had lost it, that she was a vicious bitch that couldn’t be trusted…but it still hurt.

 

She shook her head, then looked at the woman who tried to save her, who had burns all across her back and was breathing heavily in her grasp. “...why did you do that?”

 

Byleth tried to steady her breath, her back still stinging from the explosion, before giving the girl who wasn’t Emily as good of a smile as she could manage. “You’re my student, Emily. I protect my students.”

 

“...” Kronya swallowed. An Agarthan couldn’t cry, they had no need for tears. But the cold, black heart in her chest tightened painfully at her professor’s declaration. “...It's Kronya…" 

 

Reaching into her pocket, Byleth pulled out a red handkerchief, before grabbing Kronya's hand. With a gentle pull, she managed to get the Agarthan to open her tightly clenched fist, revealing the wound on her hand where Kronya had stabbed herself instead of stabbing Byleth, which she bandaged up with the handkerchief. 

 

"Sorry…my magic is still sealed…" Byleth apologized, her breathing getting heavier. 

 

"...You need to… get out of here," she continued, hearing more explosions erupting around the monastery as screams and roars rang out. "They're not…going to let you go…" 

 

“I know I won’t,” a cold voice said, before a spear of fire pierced through Kronya, making her scream in pain as she was consumed in flames–

“I upheld my end of the bargain. Let my student go,” Byleth repeated, trying to match the same cadence she spoke in earlier.

 

“...You didn’t?” Bias blinked, her confusion obvious, before she scowled and shoved Emily forward. “Fine, take the trash. I’ll give you a moment to console her as a favor to your ‘kindness’ before I boil your brain inside your skull.”

 

Bracing herself, Byleth caught the disguised Agarthan. “Don’t worry, I have this handled,” she said, before grabbing her hand before Kronya could stab her, moving to twist the knife out of her grip and toss it–

 

A blaze of fire cut her off. Bias did not hesitate for a moment when she saw Byleth making a move. This time, when the tower erupted in fire, they didn’t have a chance to get out, and Bias gladly burned with them.

Byleth ducked beneath the fireball that went over her head and swung out without hesitation, sending the Sword of the Creator straight at Bias and catching her–

Byleth stumbled at the bottom of the Goddess Tower, letting out a breath as she felt the phantom sensation of her own body burning. This Bias woman certainly didn't hesitate…taking in a small breath, she tried to figure out what to do. She still had two more charges, but she would rather not cut it close. Okay, Bias was planning on ambushing her on the tower, so she just had to make sure to face her somewhere else. Maybe she should find some back up? There were people on patrol so she could find help easily enough. 

 

Looking around, she tried to make it seem as if she remembered something, before walking away from the tower. 

 

“They’re behind us. That Bias woman can barely hide the scowl on her face,” Sothis said, staring behind Byleth. 

 

“Well that’s a start. I just need to find a good enough place to confront them,” Byleth murmured, getting on the bridge only for her eyes to widen as she ducked, barely dodging a fireball. 

 

“Don’t think you’ll be getting to safety that easily, Fell Star,” Bias called out, one arm outstretched while another wrapped around Emi–Kronya’s neck, holding her hostage. 

 

“...What do you want?” Byleth asked, playing along for now. 

 

“You dead and that sword gone,” Bias stated, not doing away with her disguise this time. “And if you don't, your precious student is going to pay the price. But you already knew that, didn’t you?”

 

“...How did you figure out how the divine pulse works?”

 

“Why would I ever tell you? You can talk to me all you want, but it doesn’t matter, does it? Nothing matters until you’re dead. What does reality matter when some abomination can just alter it at her own will, huh?”

 

Byleth grimaced. “That’s not how it works.” 

 

“Isn’t it? If the world doesn’t turn in the right way, you turn it back. That kind of power really is monstrous. Though, with it, I have to ask…why would you keep trying to save Kronya here?” she wondered, glancing at the younger Agarthan, “You should know she’s not one of you…and you should know that she, like all of our people, will strike you down the instant she gets the opportunity…” Her eyes drifted back up towards Byleth, a strange intensity growing in them. “Unless she didn’t. Unless this little bitch really is a traitor.”

 

Her hand lit aflame as her grip around Kronya’s throat tightened. “Gh–I-I-I wouldn’t! B-Bias, I’m–grk–I-I’m loyal–”

 

“Let her go,” Byleth ordered, her grip tightening on the Sword of the Creator.

 

“...No. I won’t.” Bias, wearing the face of the priestess Selene, smiled. It was a wide, unpleasant smile that showed her teeth. “You underestimate my resolve, Fell Star. I would gladly burn myself if it saw you dead in the attempt. Of course I would kill this degenerate failure if it meant ending you. In fact…I want to know something. Do you have a limit to your power?”

 

“...Why would you ask that? You won’t remember if I do turn things back.”

 

“Personal satisfaction…including the fact that it means, if I’m right…then this is guaranteed to make you waste a chance.” And in a sudden burst of flames, both Bias and Kronya were engulfed in a massive conflagration, the mad sage laughing loud while Byleth’s student screamed in pain–

 

The world went still, distorted, and Byleth couldn’t grit her teeth or clench her fists in the paused time she dwelled in before she could turn things backwards. Then she could, because she suddenly found herself in the Sothis’s throne room.

 

“Well this is aggravating,” Sothis complained with a frown, lounging on her throne with an aggravated frown, “To think, one of those foul sorcerers could figure out our powers, much less plan around them…though I suppose her willingness to destroy herself is certainly a contributing factor.”

 

“...Turning back to right before I go up isn’t working,” Byleth muttered, “I need to go further back, maybe see if I can get someone to help me.”

 

“Hm…she was waiting for you in the goddess tower. Perhaps if you were to bring someone with you? Or have someone sneak up on her while you confront her?”

 

“...How did she get a hold of Kronya?” Byleth wondered, frowning, “If I knew when she took her hostage…she was at the ball, right?”

 

“Yes, she likely grabbed her there. If Kronya didn’t go to her, that is. Bias might be planning to betray her, but Kronya is unaware of that. Much like how she isn’t aware of your ability to turn back time, it seems.” 

 

”So, we should go talk-” 

 

“No, there is no telling how she might react if you tell her that you’re aware of that plan, especially in a crowded location like the ball.” 

 

“...Right.” She knew Kronya was willing to let her live, but there was no saying how she might react if she was surprised like that. “...I should talk with Edelgard. She knows that Emily is likely the infiltrator, and if I dont go up to the tower, she and Dorothea might get caught in the trap instead.” 

 

“I see…hm. Well, I will say that Edelgard plainly favors you, so I believe you have a good chance of convincing her to aid you. The question is, when should you ask her for aid?”

 

“When? I…at the ball, right? I know where Kronya and Bias… should be, I think. If Edelgard could help me…Edelgard wanted to meet me to begin with. She’s who I need to talk to.”

 

“Are you certain of that? What of the knights? Or your father? Or perhaps Shez?”

 

Byleth paused. “I…damn it, I should have tried–”

 

“No, do not start thinking of what you should have done, think about what you will do . What happens if you inform the Knights of Seiros instead?”

 

“...They try to go after Bias, she probably kills them and blows up the tower, then comes after me and my family–She would try to kill Jeralt and Shez too. No, she hates me, she would go for them first if I tried to bring them along...You heard her earlier. She probably resents that I still have my sister and father…even though she killed her own father-figure…” Byleth felt her frown deepen. "And if I tell Shez…I don't know how she'd react to Emily being an infiltrator. She might get reckless and Bias could easily take advantage of that." 

 

"So your best bet is Edelgard. Do you think talking with her at the ball or before the ball would be best?" 

 

"...before. If I try during the ball we might not be able to sneak out easily," Byleth decided, doing her best to think things through, "It gives us some more time to plan too." 

 

"Very well then, you have a plan of attack. Go forth, and save your precious student," Sothis said, a smile on her face. 

Taking a deep breath as she stood in front of her mirror, Byleth didn’t change into the formal uniform this time and stuck to her usual outfit instead. Once she was ready, she left her room and made a beeline towards Edelgard’s. Once there, she carefully knocked on the door, trying to look as natural as possible in case Bias was watching her.

 

"Hm? Who is it?" 

 

"Edelgard, it's me. I had something I wanted to talk to you about. It might seem silly, but it's about the last test you had." 

 

"Excuse me?" A moment later the door opened and Edelgard stood there in a fancy, lordly outfit. 

 

"Do you mind if I could come in?" Byleth asked, stepping in once Edelgard moved to the right. And she immediately let out a breath once the door closed behind them. "Emily is the infiltrator, I confirmed it." 

 

“Wh–Ah…you did?”

 

“I did. Her name is Kronya, but more importantly, she’s working with a second…” Byleth trailed off. Of course she did. Because Edelgard couldn’t hide her reaction. There wasn’t the surprised confusion or bemusement that might come with hearing something unexpected. She recognized Kronya’s name, and there wasn’t a hint of surprise when she heard the word ‘second’. “...You knew." 

 

"Excuse me?" Edelgard asked, trying to school her features. 

 

"You knew Kronya was pretending to be Emily, and that Bias was the second," Byleth stated, noting the panic in Edelgard’s eyes. Almost instinctively, Byleth’s hand moved to her sword. "...are you one too?" 

 

“N-No! No, professor, please, I was never–” Edelgard stopped herself.
