She’d reached towards Byleth, trying to convince her, but she pulled her hand back and took a breath, closing her eyes for a moment. When she opened them again, there was a cold determination in her gaze. “Professor. I am not an Agarthan. Everything I have told you about my hatred for them was true. I never lied about that. I did, however, keep quiet when it came to other matters of importance. Such as the fact that, though I despise Those Who Slither in the Dark, I believed I could use them for my true goals of changing Fodlan.

 

“To that end…I became the Flame Emperor.”

 

"You…" Byleth felt dizzy. She had experienced dying today and somehow this was making her chest tense up more. 

 

"I wasn't working with them at first. The bandits that chased after us at the start of the year, and the incidents with Lord Lonato and the Mausoleum occurred because of me, but I had no hand in Flayn's kidnapping, or what they are attempting in Ordelia at the moment," Edelgard stated, attempting to keep her steel. "I also have reason to believe they had a hand in the Almyran invasion that happened recently." 

 

"I…" Byleth shook her head, trying to focus. "...you said Flayn’s kidnapping." 

 

"...I attempted to toss Bias off the trail, but…I believe I was the one who made her interested in Shez in the first place." 

 

"Have…This entire time I trusted you, and you were working with them. You kept telling me to leave Kronya alone, is this why? Were you mocking me behind my back?" 

 

"No, of course not! Professor you need to believe–"

 

"Shez died," Byleth said, her mind honing in on her sister's death at Lonato's hand. 

 

"What?" Edelgard’s eyes widened, shock evident in her eyes. "Professor, what are you–"

 

"Did you know about the divine pulse too? How much did Bias tell you?" Byleth demanded to know, her mind swirling with memories. Her chest clenched as she tried to focus, unable to hear Edelgard– 

 

She felt a hand touch her shoulder, and she couldn't stop her reaction. Grabbing her wrist, Byleth pinned Edelgard against the bed, placing her dagger against the princess' throat. 

 

Byleth felt tense, as neither of them made a sound. 

 

The heavy silence was only broken as Edelgard let out a small breath and closed her eyes. A small bead of blood swelled up from where the mercenary's dagger was placed. The memory of Edelgard and Kronya being cut down by the Death Knight flashed in her mind, and Byleth couldn't help her panic as she reared back, tossing her dagger into the floor. 

 

"...How much of it was real. Are…are we actually friends?" Byleth asked, feeling tears stinging her eyes. 

 

"I mean what I'm about to say. You are one of my most cherished friends, Byleth," Edelgard said, staring up at her professor. "I had intended on confessing to you at the goddess tower, yet it seems things have fallen out of my control."

 

"Yeah…" Byleth looked down at Edelgard, and felt her chest tense as she saw the trail of blood on her neck. Reaching down, she healed the princess. "S-Sorry." 

 

"It's okay. I was prepared for worse," Edelgard stated as Byleth moved off her. "...What did you mean Shez died? I just saw her getting dragged off to get ready for the ball." 

 

"..." She only had one charge left, she couldn't just rewind again. She had to take the risk. "...I have the ability to turn back time." 

 

“...” Edelgard took a slow breath, before frowning at Byleth. “My teacher…I understand you would not joke in this situation, but a part of me cannot help but feel that you are trying to ‘one-up’ my secret, as it were.”

 

“...pff-” Byleth snorted, unable to hide a giggle. “That–I swear, I’m not. I’m not Shez. Or Ferdinand.”

 

“He would absolutely…You can turn back time.”

 

Byleth nodded, getting serious again. “Yes, I can. I only really use it to avert disasters, and I have a limited amount of times I can use it in a day.”

 

"Disasters like…Shez dying?" Edelgard asked, before frowning as she remembered their first mission together. "Or…Ferdinand?"

 

"And others. I didn't need to with the invasion with how much you've all improved but…yes. The first time I had to use it was back when we first met, actually. I wasn't able to fully deflect that bandit's attack." 

 

"..." Edelgard let out a small breath, aware that if Byleth was telling the truth, then there was an alternate world where her choice to hire bandits led to her death. That was…darkly ironic. “So, what disaster prompted you to come back here? I can’t imagine you would come to me like this unless something terrible happened.”

 

Byleth frowned. “Why wouldn’t I come to you? I appreciate your help and your perspective.”

 

“...I meant it more in the sense…thank you for that.” She tried to ignore her face starting to redden. “I think you would normally be more circumspect and less harried if you had simply discovered the truth about Kronya and Bias, so clearly something went wrong. Add in the ability you just told me about, and I can’t imagine things went well tonight.”

 

“They were going well. Then…” Byleth sighed, then began to explain the events of the night.

 

"...I see, I must admit it is troubling to know that Bias knows about your ability as well, and that she's willing to kill herself and her hostage. Though I am just as surprised to hear that Kronya was trying to save you."

 

"Yeah…I guess she does care about us." 

 

"..." Edelgard bit down the instinct to say that it was a trick. "So…what is your plan?"

 

"...We need to keep track of Bias and Kronya. Heading to the goddess tower is a bad idea as well, we should try to lead them elsewhere," Byleth said, trying to keep a clear head, "Bias is extremely skilled with fire magic and won't hesitate to kill herself if it means succeeding in her goals." 

 

"So we need to make sure to catch her off guard…" 

 

"Yeah…hm. Hey, does Dorothea know about you?" 

 

"No? Why do you ask?" 

 

"Oh, well, you wanted to meet me up at the goddess tower and I got a letter from Dorothea saying she wanted to meet up there with you as well. So I thought maybe you had told her, with how close you two are." 

 

"...I was unaware that she wanted to meet us both up there," Edelgard said, idly wondering if Hubert had entered her room and tossed out an unmarked letter. 

 

"Oh…hm, so I guess you two aren't planning to elope," Byleth muttered, getting Edelgard to pause for a moment as she tried to register those words. 

 

“I…professor, no. I would not leave the monastery and abdicate my position just to elope.”

 

“Well I didn’t expect you to abdicate. I think it still counts as eloping if you leave the monastery to marry her in Adrestia,” Byleth pointed out.

 

“...I still have no intention of doing that.”

 

“Oh. Hm. Are you sure?”

 

“Professor, is this really a priority right now?”

 

"I just want to make sure everything is okay with you two" Byleth said with a small frown on her face. "I mean, you two won't be seeing each other for some time. And if nothing else, it's important that you two are happy." 

 

“Hm…well, I appreciate your concern, but we really should focus on what to do next, professor. If Bias is planning to make a move tonight, then we need to work to prevent it ahead of time.”

 

"That's true…well, the main thing to keep in mind is that she knows about the divine pulse. So we need to act as if nothing is out of the ordinary. If she gets any inkling that I turned back time then she'll strike," Byleth considered, trying to come up with a plan, "So we need to go about our day, which means getting ready for the ball. We also need to keep an eye on Kronya, since she's the important part to this. As long as we can keep her separate from Bias, then I can take Bias out easily. Hm…I could probably also wait a bit before heading to the tower so soon after the ball starts." 

 

"...Professor, exactly how early did you go to the tower?" 

 

"Oh…hm, about an hour after the ball started?" 

 

"Why did you go so early?" 

 

"Well you said you had something important to talk about, so I wanted to make sure I was ready." 

 

"That…professor I meant later in the night. You know, slipping away while the festivities were at a high point." 

 

"Oh…ah, well I guess I don't need to go that early then," Byleth allowed, looking mildly embarrassed. "Though I guess I already know what you wanted to talk about….hm, what do you think Dorothea wanted to talk about?" 

 

“...What indeed,” Edelgard murmured, her face warming a little as she considered what the songstress may have been intending. Presumably, she knew the legends about the tower too, so if she wanted both of them there… “Well, we can ask her later, when things are settled.”

 

"Hm, well hopefully it's not as big of a reveal as what you told me." 

 

"...do you wish to talk about me being the Flame Emperor?" 

 

"We can talk afterwards. I…I want to know what you're planning, but regardless of what happens you'll be important to me, okay Edelgard?" 

 

"...Of course, my teacher." 

 

"Now then, I should probably head back before anyone notices I've been in here for a while. I don't want any weird rumors to start about you cheating on Dorothea or anything," Byleth said, standing up as she got ready to leave. 

 

Edelgard didn't know how to respond to that so she chose not to. Instead, she just let out a sigh.

Things were going okay. The ball was still as lovely as the first time around and this time Byleth was able to stick around long enough to dance. It was admittedly a bit rough for her since she was still new to dancing, but when Flayn pulled her onto the dance floor, she was clearly looking for more fun instead of a perfect dancer. 

 

After that, it was one person after the other who wanted to dance with her, with the only break happening when Edelgard announced she would be leaving to be the emperor. Even Catherine wanted a turn, though said turn ended up being very short since Shez cut in, the mercenary spinning her sister around with surprising ease given the dress she was in. 

 

"You know, it's a shame you didn't get dressed up too," her sister said, grinning cheerfully in all her finery. 

 

"I suppose, though, who knows? Maybe next time we have a gala, I'll be in a similar dress," Byleth remarked, still amused by her sister's outfit. 

 

"Oh I'm sure everyone would have fun dressing you up. Though…hm, I doubt I can get Claude to pay for you. Maybe you can get Edelgard to pay for your dress and makeup?" 

 

"I'll ask." With a light chuckle, Byleth continued to dance with Shez, up until someone tapped Shez’s shoulder. 

 

"Mind if we cut in?" Dorothea asked with Edelgard standing by her side. 

 

“Hm? Oh, sure!” And Shez casually handed Byleth off to Dorothea with a cheeky grin. “Good luck you two! May the best dance partner win~”

 

Byleth blinked. “Shez, it’s not a competition–”

 

But her sister had already headed off to find the next person to dance with, leaving her with Edelgard and Dorothea, who grinned. "Heh, I'll try not to show off too much then~." 

 

"This really isn't a competition," Edelgard muttered, before pausing as Dorothea grabbed her and Byleth’s hand so the three could dance together. 

 

"Aw come on Edie, what's a bit of friendly competition?" Dorothea asked, a smile on her face. "Besides, I'm sure the professor here is enjoying being able to dance with her favorite students, isn't that right?" 

 

"A professor shouldn't play favorites," Byleth said, getting Dorothea to pout. "...Though it is nice being with you two." 

 

“It most certainly is~”

 

“H-Hm…ah, Dorothea, could I speak with the professor for a moment?” Edelgard requested, earning a big grin from the songstress.

 

“Ooo~? Looking for a little private conversation, are we~? Well I suppose I can leave you two be for a moment, though I expect to hear about any big decisions, alright?”

 

“Y-Yes, of course, I will make sure to inform you.”

 

That brought a smile to Dorothea’s face before she let go of the pair and moved over to join the rest of her friends, leaving Edelgard and Byleth to have a moment to themselves.

 

"Kronya is still in the gala. I've been having Hubert keep an eye on her, and it seems that she is likely waiting for you to leave before she goes to Bias," Edelgard said in a low voice as the two danced together. 

 

“Okay, that’s good…did anything else happen?

 

"Ah…well, I had an interesting conversation with Dimitri,” she murmured, before shaking her head, “More importantly, are you sure we shouldn't try to go after Bias yet? Or maybe try something else?" 

 

"No. I already know Bias trapped the tower with magic, somehow, and if she gets any indication that I know what she's planning, then she'll lash out. Our best bet is to attempt to leave soon and head to the courtyard. It's a wide open place and we can find cover easily should she attack us," Byleth decided, moving in sync with the emperor. 

 

"I see…well, in that case, we need to figure out a way for Dorothea to stay behind. I'd rather not drag her into this." 

 

"...yeah, if it's just the two of us, I have a better chance of making sure we make it out okay," Byleth responded, before glancing at the songstress who was smiling at the two. "We could ask her to wait here. I'm sure she'll be understanding." 

 

"Perhaps…though I will say, I must admit it is a shame we likely won't be able to climb the Goddess Tower tonight. It's an important place to my parents, and I was hoping to gain something similar by going there." 

 

"Hm? What happened there?" 

 

"It's where my father met my mother. From what he said, it was love at first sight," Edelgard said, a small blush on her face, "Perhaps if we have the time, we can meet there before I have to leave." 

 

“Maybe? That sounds like it would be nice,” Byleth replied, smiling, before a thought occurred. Oh, I wonder if Dorothea knows about that? Hm…Manuela said the whole legend about the tower referred to a man and a woman, but maybe Dorothea was going to try confessing there anyway? Heh, that would cute–

 

And in an instant, Byleth’s smile dropped, because she spotted a very familiar priestess walk into the room. In a second, it occurred to her that she didn’t actually have a guarantee that Bias would have stayed in one location just because that was what she did previously. Not when things had already changed…She should have made her move before the ball, she shouldn’t–

 

In the next second, Bias spotted her. And the moment she recognized the horrified look on Byleth’s face, a large, manic grin spread across her own.

 

“Professor? What’s wrong–” Edelgard began to ask before there was a burst of heat and both the sound of screams and the smell of burning flesh began to fill the room as Bias simply grabbed the nearest student by the throat and burned them alive.

 

“NO!” Byleth screamed, pushing Edelgard behind her as she drew her sword and swung at the manic Agarthan, who spread her arms wide as though happily accepting the blade about to carve through her chest. But before it did, she cast one more spell, and that entire half of the room exploded in fire. As she felt her flesh begin to burn amid the screams of her students, Byleth forced herself back, further than she'd ever gone before.

Sitting up in her bed, Byleth grit her teeth, before slamming her fist into the wall. Ignoring the stinging pain in her hand, the professor quickly got dressed and rushed out of her room. She couldn't hesitate, she needed to make sure Bias couldn't hurt anyone else. 

 

She knocked on Edelgard’s door, practically pounding her fist against the wood. “Edelgard, can you open up?”

 

She heard movement inside, and luckily, her student heard her too. “Professor? What’s wrong?” 

 

She didn’t answer, just waiting for a moment before she shoved her way in once the door was opened, ignoring Edelgard’s exclamation.

 

“We need to talk. I know who the infiltrators are,” Byleth said, panting from the running she had just done. “And…I know your secret.”

Chapter End Notes

Indi: I'm sure many of you have questions about what we're planning. Or maybe just want to scream at us.

Red: I would accept screaming. We did just end this chapter on the exact same cliffhanger as the previous one. Now with clarity!

Indi: If you want to aim the screaming correctly that was my idea!

Red: If you want to scream for other reasons, feel free too! We accept all sorts of screams to power our writing.

Indi: Feel free to scream at us in the comments or in the discord! https://discord.gg/T7E9sWEJsv

Red: For now though, thanks for reading!

Secrets Unveiled

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

"...you know my secret?" Edelgard asked, feeling herself tense on instinct.

 

"Yes, I know this is going to sound weird, but I have the ability to turn back time, and you confessed to me the last time around,” Byleth quickly explained.

 

Edelgard blinked, feeling the tension leave her body at the sheer absurdity of what her professor said. "Excuse me?"

 

"Agh, what did we say last time…oh, wait, you told me about the Goddess Tower and how your parents met there, how it was love at first sight and that you wanted something similar!" Byleth remembered, trying to focus all while she felt a strong adrenaline rush going through her body from the multiple times she had reset today. 

 

"...W-What?" Edelgard asked, feeling her face warm up as the words registered. 

 

“Yes, that was it–Look, it’s not important. You confessed to me and I know everything. I especially know about Kronya and Bias, and we need to stop Bias so she doesn’t kill Kronya or you or Ignatz.”

 

“Wait, please, professor, you’re–What happened to Ignatz?”

 

“She grabbed him and set him on fire, it was bad. Now, the important part is that we need to get to her before the ball. I thought I was being clever and she would stay at the Goddess Tower but she didn’t because I guess I didn’t fully understand how willing she is to divert from her plans. She’s also crazy, that’s important to know, and, ah…right, so, the main point here is that we need to get her before the gala ever happens. As long as we make sure to take her down before she can do anything, then that's what matters."

 

“...I…see. I…professor, while this sounds far too serious to be something you would joke about, I…you understand, it’s very hard to believe that you can travel through–”

 

“Like I said, I know everything. Your secret, that Emily is Kronya, that Selene is Bias, all that stuff.” Byleth grabbed Edelgard by the shoulders. “Listen, I know this might be hard to believe, but just…please, trust me.”

 

“...” Edelgard slowly nodded. “Of course. Ah…well, I know Bias is pretending to be the librarian, so...no, if she’s planning something tonight, she likely won’t be there today. If her plan is at the Goddess Tower, she might head there early on to ensure her trap is ready. How is Kronya involved?”

 

“Bias takes her hostage.”

 

Edelgard blinked at that information, but decided she could ask later. “Right, then if Kronya goes to the gala, then Bias needs to be there–”

 

“Right, damn it, she must have gone looking for her when she didn’t–But she didn’t leave until I left–No, never mind, I can’t think about that,” Byleth decided, interrupting herself, “If we get to Bias before the gala, it won’t matter. Knowing she’s the librarian is helpful, probably would’ve been helpful last time, though, I guess after I pushed you down, the detail might have slipped your mind." 

 

"...H-Huh?" 

 

"Ah, yeah, sorry I, um…after you confessed to me, I pushed you down onto your bed without thinking." Byleth admitted, looking away from Edelgard with a faint sense of shame, remembering how she almost stabbed her student.

 

Edelgard, on the other hand, felt her face flush at the thought of Byleth taking the initiative like that. 

 

After a moment, Byleth shook the thought off, focusing again. "Either way, we'll need to be careful. You need to make sure to keep an eye on Kronya, and I'll make sure Bias doesn't even get a chance to enact her plans.”

 

"...and what about you professor? You'd still be in danger." 

 

"Don't worry, I still have another charge left. I can still turn things back if I need to," Byleth lied, before reaching over and patting Edelgard on the head. "Just make sure everyone stays safe and has fun, okay?" 

 

"...Very well, professor." 

 

"Thanks. Oh, and make sure to tell Dorothea what you told me okay? It's only fair that she gets to hear it too.” She paused as a thought occurred. “Hm. Or would you prefer if I'm there with you when you confess?" 

 

Edelgard stared at her teacher. "You are…okay with her and…I…we?" 

 

"Why wouldn't I be?"

 

The complete lack of hesitation or guile in her professor’s question put Edelgard at a loss for words as she just stared at Byleth. “...” So, in lieu of a verbal response, she just nodded slowly as she tried her best to fight down the blush that tried to grow on her face. “V…Very well then.”

 

"Good. Now then…Bias mentioned being a ‘scientist’, do you think that might matter? Like where she might choose to hide?”

 

“...Hm. I…do not know. I don’t know where she hides out when she isn’t going around as Selene, but most of the clergy live within the monastery. If she were preparing something, she would likely want to do her work away from the monastery then…there are forests and ruins nearby. Perhaps she’s keeping a hideout out there?”

 

"That's as good a place as any to check," Byleth murmured as she got up. 

 

"Ah, wait, before you go." Standing up, Edelgard took a deep breath. "I understand that ‘I’ might have confessed already, however I feel as if it would be disingenuous if I didn't confess as well." 

 

“Oh, are you sure?” Byleth asked, a little concerned, “Things were…kind of tense last time, though…thinking about it, I guess that means it would be better to hear this time around? Hm.” She met Edelgard’s eyes, before nodding. “Alright, if it would make you feel better, I would be happy to hear your confession.”

 

Edelgard closed her eyes to steady herself before staring at Byleth. "My teacher, in this year that I've known you, you've become one of my closest confidants and assisted me in so many ways. I know that we come from far different ways of life and that our meeting was a coincidence but…I don't think I can ever imagine a life without you, or at least I don't want to. Thank you, for choosing the Black Eagles, for choosing me," Edelgard smiled as she took Byleth’s hands. "I love you." 

 

Byleth blinked. “Oh. That…thank you. I…did not expect to hear that. I think there was a misunderstanding. I was referring to you confessing to being the Flame Emperor.”

 

“...oh.” Edelgard’s face began to burn. "...Would it be possible for you to reverse time by a few minutes?" 

 

“Edelgard, that would be a grave misuse of my powers.” Also she didn’t have a charge, but she wasn’t going to say that. Also, Edelgard was still holding her hands and Byleth wasn’t sure if she should pull away, mostly because she didn’t really want to–And, of course, more importantly, her student just made an emotional confession and she should support her in this confusing time.

 

…my student just confessed to me. Or maybe she should leave, because now she was having confusing thoughts.

 

Neither of them were letting go of the other’s hands though…

 

She briefly tried to call upon Sothis for advice, only to be met with raucous laughter from her friend. 

 

"I think it might be best if we focus on the mission, for now," Edelgard decided as she gently pulled away from Byleth. 

 

"...Y-Yeah, we can talk more once everyone is safe," Byleth agreed before she cleared her throat. "Just, um…I'm sorry for not having a proper response right now. I don't really know much about matters of romance." 

 

"That's okay. Neither do I, really." Edelgard took a breath, trying to calm herself. "Talking later sounds like a good idea." 

 

"Yeah, I'll see you later," Byleth agreed, about to head out before pausing to look back at Edelgard, "Take care, Edelgard."

 

"You too, my teacher…are you sure I shouldn’t–"

 

“Don’t worry, I know what I’m doing,” Byleth assured her, “Just let me handle everything.”

 

“...Understood.” 

 

Once she had left Byleth made it as far as the stairs before stopping. Oh no, did I steal Edelgard away from Dorothea?

 

For some reason that made Sothis laugh harder. 

It had been some time since Byleth had to track a target, but the mercenary-turned-professor found herself slipping back into the rhythm of it easily enough as she sought out the Agarthan called Bias, who she was fairly certain still wore her “Selene” guise. At least, that was what she hoped.

 

It wasn’t easy trying to track down the disguised Agarthan. Byleth hadn’t looked into the clergy much previously, considering it hadn’t been a problem before now, but now she knew where they slept, so that was nice to know. It didn’t help her find Selene though, especially since no one had seen her all morning. Byleth wound up going around the entire monastery without finding her, largely because it was so busy and there were far more clergy members at the monastery than she realized. 

 

It didn’t help that she did get a little sidetracked helping out with setting up for the ball…

 

Ultimately, it wasn’t until after lunch, which she actually did have to eat because tracking a person while stressed and hungry was a bad idea, that she managed to catch sight of the blonde ‘nun’ walking into the cathedral.

 

Once she spotted her there, it was a matter of waiting while Byleth decided to take some time “doing chores” for the church. The saint statues were looking pretty nice, but she made sure to clean them up some more, and a bit of choir practice was nice. From what she could tell, Bias had headed into the Goddess Tower, which…no, confronting her there was a bad idea. She had way too many examples of how badly it could go if she confronted her in an enclosed space like that…

 

So on she waited, staying in the cathedral until the disguised Agarthan was about to leave. If Bias thought it odd that Byleth was in the Cathedral answering questions from the advice box, she didn't show it. Though Byleth did have to stay focused since she nearly let herself get distracted with coming up with good answers. 

 

Even if it was for cover, she wanted to make sure to offer proper advice! 

 

Song and dance live on in our memories, but there’s no real record of them. Even memories fade over time. Will anyone remember when I’m gone?

 

Byleth paused. She recognized the handwriting. She didn’t expect something that heavy from Dorothea, but as she thought about the songstress’s worries, she also couldn't help but think of how this was her last shot. If she wasn't able to take down Bias… 

 

I’m sure you’ll live on in someone’s heart.  

 

Returning the slip of paper to the box, Byleth took in a deep breath, before slapping her cheeks to focus as she left the cathedral. Moving ahead of Bias, she had Sothis keep an eye behind her on the Agarthan before pausing when the disguised mage took a turn, heading outside of the monastery in the direction of the ruins. 

 

Frowning, Byleth began to follow Bias, staying as quiet as she could while following the false librarian. She had one shot at this; if the Agarthan knew she was there, she'd rush off to kill as many people as she could. She was too far away for the Sword of the Creator to reliably hit, and a spell would take too long to hit her. At least once they got to the ruins they'd be away from the monastery…

 

As silly as it was, a part of her wished she'd get back in time for the ball. 

 

By the time they arrived at the ruins, the afternoon was turning towards evening. The aftermath of the fight against Aelfric was still evident with all the scarring littering the remains. Shaking her head of the thought of Jeralt’s former friend, she focused on the mage, before attempting to approach her. 

 

"Tell me, do you have eyes on the back of your head, or did you spend several attempts trying to figure out where I was going?" Bias called out, getting Byleth to stiffen. "I'm going to assume it's the former since you didn't know about the alarm you set off. In which case…well, I suppose I should have expected someone like you to have extra eyes." 

 

"..." 

 

"She doesn't know about me at least. That’s good, it means she doesn't know everything. I just wish we knew how she found out about the divine pulse,” Sothis muttered. Byleth tried to settle her nerves before she stepped out into the open. 

 

"So you are by yourself. Tell me, are you that afraid of me killing someone, or are you that arrogant?" Bias asked, eyeing the professor. 

 

"...The students deserve to enjoy their time at the ball," Byleth said, leveling her sword at the Agarthan, who blinked, before beginning to laugh. 

 

"Seriously? You come out here on your own for someone like that? My, you're either the most soft-hearted beast around, or the dumbest. Personally, I'm leaning towards the latter," Bias remarked, before taking a few steps back when Byleth tried stepping closer. "I quite think this distance is good enough between us." 

 

"...How did you find out about the divine pulse?" 

 

"Hm? Oh you never learned how I know? Well…I could tell you, or I could leave it to the next me. Presuming you have another charge. Tell me, I know you started with three, but surely you've increased that limit since awakening it. How many do you have left?" 

 

"...I have enough." 

 

"Ah, so this is your last one," Bias said, her grin threatening to break the face she wore. "In that case, I suppose I should tell you. Kronya isn't the only ‘infiltrator’~" 

 

Byleth felt her blood run cold. "What?" 

 

"Don't worry, I'll make sure to tell you before you die. Until then, feel free to rattle around that empty head of yours for an answer." 

 

"..." Byleth tried to focus. Who could have told her about the divine pulse? The only ones who knew besides Edelgard, who only just learned about it, were Jeralt, Shez, and Arval. None of them would have betrayed her…right? 

 

“Oh that’s a much better expression for you. That sense of betrayal…” Bias giggled. “Who do you think told me, hm? I mean, there can only be so many you ever told your greatest secret too…and only so many who would willingly tell me too.”

 

“...I can figure that out later,” Byleth decided, “First, I need to end you.”

 

“Heh. I suppose you’re hoping for a grand, final showdown then?” Bias looked around the ruins with a small smile. “It’s not the worst place to die…but, unfortunately for us both, if you’re here, it means I can’t have that finale. What a miserable outcome…”

 

“...Are you really so willing to die to achieve your vengeance?”

 

“You should know that already. I imagine I must’ve killed myself at least once to spite you. Either way, it doesn’t matter.” She raised a hand and snapped her fingers, smiling as a roar sounded out. “I packed about seven demonic beasts in a nice little chapel down that way. They were sealed in, getting hungrier and hungrier, and I just broke that seal, which means they’ll be running rampant if you don’t handle them. Consider it a parting gift.”

 

“...I can kill you, then handle the demonic beasts,” Byleth pointed out, her eyes narrowed, “I think you’re a bigger threat.”

 

“Aw. I’m flattered.” She didn’t sound like she was.

 

Neither said a word as they stared at one another, both waiting to see what move the other would make. The roar of a demonic beast pierced through the evening sky as the chapel they were locked in began to break and crumple. 

 

"Well, since you won't be going away, I suppose I'll take the honor of your first, and last, dance this lovely evening," Bias said as a glyph appeared before her. 

 

Not wasting a moment, Byleth rushed forward, her sword lashing out once she got in range, only to bounce off a protective barrier that had already been prepped.

 

"Please don't insult me by thinking you can kill me that easily," Bias chided while Byleth sprinted towards her, her sword snapping together as she prepared to slash through the barrier and glyph.

 

Then the glyph vanished, the spell dropping. It was the only warning Byleth had that something was wrong before a flash of pain went through her head. She flinched back, clutching at the wound in her face, blood trailing down her cheek.

 

She frowned, backing up as she watched Bias twirl a dagger in hand. "Ooo, don't tell me you didn't realize I had this on me before~ I may be a mage, but that doesn’t mean I can't defend myself with a knife." 

 

Not saying a word, Byleth did her best to heal the damage, even if it did little to fix the cut made by Agarthan weaponry. 

 

"You know, with you out of the way, there's nothing I really need to worry about. I can handle that little traitor quite easily, oh and the princess will certainly need to go. After all, that bitch lied to me and said you had no hand in Pittacus's death. Oh, I think dragging your corpse in front of her would be such a lovely gift, wouldn't it?" 

 

"..." Byleth felt her blood begin to boil, her grip tightening on her sword enough to hurt. 

 

The sight made Bias smile as she playfully tapped the dagger against her chin. "Though I wonder, should I start with your class or save them for last? I suppose it doesn't matter, as long as I make them regret ever becoming close to you. Ah, but don't worry, I'll make sure to leave your sister alive. She's far too valuable of a test subject." 

 

Unable to keep the scowl off her face, Byleth nearly rushed in. 

 

"Wait!" Sothis shouted, getting Byleth to stop. "You know she's trying to get you to lose your cool! As long as she can kill you, she doesn't care about living or dying!"

 

Byleth continued to glare at Bias, before letting out a breath she didn't realize she was holding as she tried to make a plan. One she wouldn't have much time to prepare since she heard the demonic beasts begin to free themselves. 

 

"Don't worry, Sothis. I promised not to die," Byleth murmured before rushing forward again. Bringing the sword up, she plainly telegraphed a slash down at Bias. 

 

"Ha, of course you want to use brute force you igno–" Bias felt her mind stutter for a moment, confusion hitting her as Byleth let go of the sword, the legendary relic weapon flying in the air which she couldn't help but track. 

 

It was only at the last moment that she glanced down to see a dagger coming straight at her. The air left her lungs as Byleth stabbed her straight in the chest, driving the blade in deep, though she reacted quickly and shoved her hand against the Fell Star’s face, right against the eye she’d already slashed.

 

Byleth bit back a scream at the heat that burned her face, but fought through the pain and pulled her dagger free, stabbing again and again–

 

And then something huge and heavy slammed against her side. She felt her feet leave the ground, her dagger flying free before she hit the dirt with a pained grunt, her face feeling like it was on fire as she saw a demonic beast in a stone mask roar towards the sky.

 

Half her vision was gone, but she looked around quickly, trying to spot the Sword of the Creator…and finding Bias first as the bleeding Agarthan pushed up to her feet, blood pouring down her front through a number of stab wounds. Bias met her gaze for a moment, fury in her eyes, before more roars caught their attention.

 

The Agarthan scowled…but she stumbled away, pressing a glowing hand to her own chest while Byleth managed to get to her feet and grab her sword from where it had landed, the weight of it feeling familiar in her hand as she turned to face at least half a dozen demonic beasts.

 

“...this is going to be difficult,” she murmured, letting out a slow breath. It was fine though. 

 

Everyone she cared about was going to be fine.

Kronya was anxious. She wasn't sure why, but she hated it. All she needed to do was take that dumb professor up to the goddess tower, and then she could go home. She didn't have to think, she could go back to enjoying mindless slaughter. Maybe even start with…bandits or something. 

 

Bandits? Seriously? Why did my mind default to that and not a church full of those dull-eyed beasts. In fact, why don't I just start on the people here? Kronya thought to herself before bumping into someone. "Hey, watch it!"

 

"Sorry, Emily," Dedue apologized, glancing down at the Agarthan. "I didn't see you there." 

 

"...geh, just make sure not to do it again," Kronya scoffed as she looked at who Dedue was with. "Oh, you're Mercedes, right?" 

 

"That I am, did you need something?" 

 

"No, just…" Kronya huffed, unsure of what to say. What am I even doing? Just stab her. "...the big guy is a good cook. Treat him nice, okay?" 

 

"..." Mercedes couldn't help but giggle. "Of course, thanks for checking on him." 

 

"Yeah yeah." Kronya huffed, walking away and ignoring the pair smiling. 

 

"Hey, Em!" Only to stiffen as Shez called out to her. "Where are you going?" 

 

"...out, I need fresh air." 

 

"Oh? Not going to dance?" she asked as she glanced down at her uniform. "I know you didn't get dressed up, but that doesn't mean you can't dance." 

 

"Well I'm sorry I don't look as ridiculous as you." 

 

"Pft, aw, but I thought I looked nice," Shez said, swishing her dress around with a laugh. 

 

"Of course you do… hey where is your sister?" 

 

"Oh I dunno. She’s been running around a lot today for some reason. I was just guessing she was busy, though it’s kinda a shame. I wanted her to see my dress.” She huffed, looking a little disappointed before shaking it off. “Did you need something from her?" 

 

"Yeah I…needed to ask her something," Kronya said, feeling uncharacteristically nervous. 

 

"...wait, don't tell me." Shez leaned forward with a frown on her face as Kronya felt a small bit of panic. "You have a crush on my sister, don't you?"

 

“...” Sometimes I forget she’s genuinely fucking stupid. “No, I don’t.”

 

“You sure? She’s objectively cute.”

 

“...wha…” How the fuck do I even respond to that? “Yeah, I’m sure I don’t have a crush on your sister because she’s not my type, dumbass.”

 

“Mm, if you say so,” Shez replied with a shrug, before glancing at her curiously, “What’s your type anyways?”

 

“Fuck if I know. I guess…someone taller than me?”

 

“Like Dedue?”

 

“No.”

 

“Hm…like Mercedes?”

 

“Also no.”

 

“Okay so not the tallest people…Hm, this is kinda tricky, since you’re so short.”

 

“...shut up.”

 

“Nah, I’m gonna keep chatting until I figure it out.” She paused, a thought occurring. “Hey, do you want to dance with me?”

 

Kronya stared at her for a moment…then shrugged. “Sure, why not?”

 

It wasn’t like Bias was calling on her, and…well, it might be nice.

 

And it actually was. Kronya wouldn’t call herself a good dancer, but it wasn’t like Shez was either. It was…nice. Everybody seemed to be having a good time too…well, aside from the princess, who was chatting with that blond prince and looked like someone just punched her in the gut.

 

Eventually though, Shez actually started frowning as she looked around.

 

“What’s up?” Kronya asked, glancing up at her.

 

“...It’s just…I’m not seeing Byleth around at all. I thought she might be busy, but it’s getting late, right? She should be here.”

 

For a moment, Kronya stilled, her thoughts going to Bias. Did she change her plan? “...Maybe we should look for her?”

 

“Ah…yeah, that’s actually a good idea. Let’s go see if we can find her.”

 

So Shez and Kronya left the ballroom, not really heading in a specific direction but just kind of looking around. And just her luck, Emily ran right into someone she didn't want to see. 

 

"Emily? Shez? Where are you two going?" Edelgard asked while Dorothea had a knowing smile behind her. 

 

“Ah…not really sure, I was just following Emily,” Shez admitted, shrugging, “We’re looking for By. Have you seen her around?”

 

"...no, we were actually looking for her," Edelgard said, glancing at Kronya. "I saw her earlier today, but she said she would be busy with something." 

 

"I will admit, I'm a bit sad she didn't show up at the ball, but she's probably fine. If she got my letter, then I certainly know one place where she might be," Dorothea said, winking at Edelgard. 

 

"I just want to make sure she's okay," Edelgard responded, even as her face turned pink. 

 

The scraping of a sword against stone caught their attention. Focusing, the group looked towards where the noise was coming from, ready for whatever came closer, only to stare in horror. 

 

Dragging the Sword of the Creator on the floor, her clothes tattered and blood soaked, Byleth approached the group with a slow, stumbling walk. Glancing up, Byleth smiled and raised a hand as the wind blew her hair to the side, revealing a bloody, burned wound where her right eye once was. 

 

"Hey there, sorry I'm late." Was all she said before she collapsed. 

Chapter End Notes

Red: I hope you all appreciate that we had two back to back cliffhangers for the sake of a dumb joke to start this chapter.

Indi: Man what a fucking chapter to release on my birthday, Byleth's been on a wild ride this mini arc

Red: That she has! A ride that she's finally able to get off of. Though not unscathed.

Indi: Kinda over, still have the aftermath to deal with. But don't worry there is some good stuff coming for Byleth soon-ish.

Red: Yup! Though she'll also have to deal with the consequences of running off on her own to solve problems. Not something you should ever do in a Fire Emblem. You can't solo a map! The game isn't built for that!

Indi: Not unless you make a really busted unit and even then you really should have at least two people.

Red: So yeah, remember folks, if you're chasing down a dangerous foe, make sure to bring friends! The true power of friendship is having extra people to help beat down your enemies!

Anger and Sorrow

Chapter by RK3996

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

“Stupid bitch stabbed me in the tit,” Bias complained to herself as she glared down at the mess of wounds her chest had become thanks to a certain professor, who happened to be surprisingly proficient with a dagger. Or maybe not that surprisingly, considering how proficient the Fell Star seemed to be with just about everything. “Fhhh…almost had her. Almost.”

 

But almost wasn’t good enough. Even if she’d gotten that last fireball off, it didn’t stop the Fell Star from stabbing her nearly a dozen times. She would’ve been dead if that demonic beast hadn’t barreled into the two of them right at that moment…Dead, and without killing the Fell Star to make it worth it. 

 

She didn’t believe for a second that the demonic beasts managed to kill her. Not after everything. No, she wouldn’t believe anything could kill that stubborn bitch until she did it herself, no matter what it took.

 

Bias growled in frustration, glaring down at scars littering her torso. Healing magic hadn’t worked fast enough, so a good portion she’d just burned closed to stop herself from bleeding out. 

 

Even now, she felt woozy, exhausted…but alive.

 

“...” Bias let her head fall against the tree trunk behind her as she stared up at the moon above, the dusk having faded to night in the hours she took dragging herself away from her ill-fated “final battle”. Not that there was anything really “final” about it. Not while she and the woman she hated the most in the world were still alive. “...heh. Should’ve brought Kronya with me. Even if she didn’t work as a hostage, I could’ve at least used the Spell of Zahras…wonder what she’ll do now, without me there? All alone…poor little puppy.”

 

She chuckled, before pushing herself up. The robes she’d worn as “Selene” were a bloodied mess, not worth wearing at this point, so she let the guise fall away, returning to a more “natural” appearance, as far as any Agarthan had a natural appearance. At the very least, the flesh she wore felt more like her now…and she had a nice dress on again, so that was a plus.

 

Even the wounds she took faded as her skin turned pale, though it wasn’t as though her body repaired itself. She could still feel that pain, the sense of being hurt. She still felt drained.

 

But her mind still worked. And it worked quickly, considering her next course of action.

 

She’d have to go to Ordelia. Myson’s plans clearly centered around that scrap of territory, and if she had other Agarthans to back her, she could still win. Even if it took everything she had, especially if it took everything they had, she would end that bitch. One way or another.

Jeralt didn’t know what it was about the Academy that made the most innocuous event turn into some major disaster. Seriously, the month of the ball should’ve been a time to take it easy, relax, and let his kids have fun. Not a time to have to deal with a pack of demonic beasts let loose by a mad mage who also just so happened to take one of his daughter’s eyes.

 

So yeah. He wasn’t happy.

 

"So remind me again what happened," he asked, staring down at the leader of the Black Eagles.

 

"...Dorothea had gone out looking for the professor, as we hadn't seen her at the ball. While searching we ran into Shez and Emily, before the professor appeared in the state she was in." Edelgard took a small breath, unable to meet his eyes. "She…The professor came by my room earlier, saying she might not be able to make it to the ball and that she had something important to do. If…If I had known this would have happened…" 

 

"..." Jeralt sighed. "I don't think anyone would have." 

 

"Captain Jeralt, I swear on my honor as the Emperor, that you will have the empire's full support in defeating the mage who harmed the professor," Edelgard said as she stood up, her hands balling up into fists. 

 

"...You're heading back to the Empire soon, right?" 

 

"Yes, noon tomorrow." 

 

"Well, hopefully she wakes up before then," Jeralt muttered. He sighed. “...hey, princess.”

 

“Yes?”

 

“Thanks for being there for my kid." 

 

Edelgard opened her mouth, stayed silent for a few moments, before she closed it, and simply bowed to him. 

 

Jeralt remained in his chair, staring up at the ceiling for a few minutes, before getting up and heading over to the nurse's office. It wasn't a long walk, but each step tired him, before he entered the room. The room was empty, safe for one person laying in a bed. 

 

The slow rise and fall of her chest let him know she was still alive but…he couldn't look away from her face, bandages covering the right side. He always knew his kids would be in danger when they became mercenaries. But…he should have stopped them from becoming mercenaries in the first place. Maybe then he wouldn't have to deal with seeing them almost die so many times… 

 

"...you're not allowed to die before me," Jeralt muttered, staring down at his daughter and wondering just why the goddess had it out for them…

Shez was furious, so much so that the word was practically an understatement. She didn't know who this Selene person was, but when she found her, she was going to gut her! 

 

And yet, for as angry as she was at the bitch that took her sister’s eye, she was just as angry at herself for spending the whole night dancing and playing around while Byleth was fighting for her life.

 

"You must remain calm, partner." 

 

"Don't tell me what to do!" Shez snapped, as she continued marching along, looking for the ruins. 

 

"If you keep walking in a random direction you're going to get lost. Do you even know where the old cathedral ruins are?" 

 

"I'll find them eventually. And then I'll find a clue on where the bitch went!" Shez shouted as she continued to move, using her sword to cut down brush as she walked. 

 

"..." Arval sighed, trying to think of how to play this. Bias may have failed, but it would be a waste to let his vessel kill her. If only he could simply eliminate the Fell Star himself…the problem was, the risk to his vessel was too great, particularly given the guard she was under. "...would it not be better to stay at the monastery, near your sister? After all, there's a chance that 'Selene' might return while you're gone." 

 

Jerking to a halt, Shez couldn't help but scowl before screaming as she slashed with her sword again, cutting a tree in two with ease. 

 

"...Fine," she muttered after a few moments, before warping back to the monastery. Arriving back in her room, Shez flopped down on her bed, feeling far too frustrated but unsure of how to channel it. 

 

She didn't know how long she was in her room, but it didn’t feel that long before she heard someone knock on her door. With a huff, she walked over and yanked it open. "What?" 

 

"...Hello, Shez," Edelgard greeted, noticeably stiff, "I…came to check on how you were doing." 

 

"Angry." 

 

"...That is understandable. What happened to the professor is horrible, and I–"

 

"I don't want to hear it! Well wishes aren't going to heal my sister!" Shez shouted.

 

"...Yes, condolences and the like can't fix the past," Edelgard muttered, looking down and sending a tinge of guilt through Shez’s heart. 

 

"Ah, shit. Sorry. I…I know you went through a lot too, it's just…" 

 

"It's alright Shez. Regardless of any similarities in our situations, only you can understand your own sadness. Any words I can give will only end up falling flat. Even so, I'll say this, even if it costs me my life, I'll make sure Those Who Slither can't hurt anyone else. And I promise you, that if you want to make them pay, then you'll have my help." 

 

“...ugh. Thanks for that. I…ugh…” Shez sighed, feeling emotionally exhausted and yet still angry. “...Do you know anything about this Selene lady?”

 

“I do, yes.”

 

Shez paused. She didn’t actually expect an answer to that question. “...what do you know?”

 

“I know her true name is Bias…She is a sage, which is apparently a position of importance in their society. And I…I knew who she was for some time.”

 

“...” Shez sat up. She stared straight at Edelgard, her eyes narrowed in a glare as her anger built up again. “...what the hell do you mean by that?”

 

"I've had dealings with her in the past. I used her as much as she used me." 

 

"That–Why didn't you say anything!?" Shez shouted, pushing herself up from the bed and approaching Edelgard. 

 

"Because I was afraid. Afraid that if I sold her out, she would sell me out as well. Afraid that I would be locked away in a dungeon for the rest of my life…Afraid of what the professor would think of me."

 

“...” Shez’s hands clenched into fists hard enough that her knuckles audibly popped. “...Is that why you didn’t want to go to Rhea about Lysithea’s problem? You didn’t want to screw yourself over? Cause you matter more than anyone else, huh, princess?”

 

Edelgard bit back her response, knowing fully well it would only make things worse. "...The church elevates those with crests. Even if we ignore the fact that they would have no idea about someone with dual crests, the possibility that they'd experiment on others isn't a risk I'm willing to take." 

 

“IT’S NOT YOUR RISK TO TAKE! THEY COULD’VE HELPED HER!” Shez shouted, completely furious, “I sided with you because Byleth thought you had a point, but you were just covering your ass! How long have you been using us, huh?! Do you even give a shit–”

 

“Of course I care. I want Lysithea to be cured of her condition, that is why I offered to host her in the Empire,” Edelgard stated, keeping her calm.

 

“Oh really? How can I believe that? You just admitted to being best friends with the bitch who took my sister’s eye, who’s to say you wouldn’t turn Lysithea over to your buddies for an extra favor?!”

 

“...Do not insinuate that the people who murdered every last one of my siblings are my friends.” Edelgard’s tone was deadly cold as she spoke. 

 

"Then why would you work with them!?” Shez’s voice, in contrast, was practically hot with rage. “What, did you work with Aelfric too and handed Byleth over to him!?" 

 

“Stop making wild accusations–”

 

“What am I supposed to believe, huh?! You just told me I can’t trust anything you tell me because you’ve been lying for, what, the entire year?!" 

 

"Even if you don't believe me, you need to understand that I would never do anything to harm the professor." 

 

"THEN WHY DID SHE ALMOST DIE!?" 

 

"Because she told me she could still rewind time!" Edelgard shouted back. "When she visited me…she said that it would be okay because she still had another chance to do things over."

 

That took the wind out of Shez’s sails. "...what? She…she told you she could do that?" 

 

“Yes. She did. She told me exactly what her powers were and how she has used them previously. And she assured me she still had one more chance to turn things back. So…so I suppose she must have considered this a better outcome.”

 

“...Or she lied to you,” Shez bluntly pointed out.

 

“...Yes, that is more likely. I suppose I prefer to think she wouldn’t do that.”

 

“Yeah, I imagine that’s because you don’t like it when you’re lied to. Like most people.”

 

“Hm.”

 

“...” Shez sighed. “That sounds like By though. Always trying to make everyone else happy and being stupid about it…”

 

"...I would not put it like that; but that's not inaccurate. Even so, she told me, even after I supposedly told her everything in a past timeline," Edelgard explained.

 

"..." Shez couldn't help but scowl. "It's because she's being stupid that I need to make sure she's okay. I don't care what you're planning on doing, but stay away from By. I don't want you near her." 

 

“I…Very well. I only ask that you not interfere if she wishes to seek me out.”

 

“Why would I do that for you?”

 

“I do not expect you to do so for my sake. I hope you would do so for Professor Byleth.”

 

“...How much of this have you told her?”

 

“Everything. I told her everything,” Edelgard stated without hesitation.

 

"..." Shez looked away. "Just get out of my room." 

 

Remaining silent, Edelgard inclined her head, before leaving. Alone in her room, Shez could do little else but scream as she slammed her fist into the door. 

Kronya stared down at the unconscious Byleth, watching the slow rise and fall of the injured professor’s chest as she slept. The bandages around her eye had been changed, so they weren’t as bloody. That was probably good.

 

The Agarthan assassin let out a slow sigh. She wondered what she was doing. Bias was gone and she was on her own at the monastery. What do I even do now…do I kill her? What would that actually get me…the sages would probably reward me for killing the Fell Star. Who knows, maybe they'd even make me a sage too. 

 

Sighing again, Kronya looked out the window to stare at the moon lighting the room. Or maybe they'd just kill me if Bias told them I'm a traitor. That would be simpler, I guess. I wouldn't have to deal with all these emotions, at least…

 

"Mnn…" Stiffening, she looked down and saw Byleth stir awake. Slowly opening her eyes, the professor looked around before noticing Kronya. And then, off all the reactions she could have, she smiled. "Kronya…you have no idea how happy I am to see that you're alive." 

 

“...why?” she murmured, feeling a strange stinging at her eyes. That’s the first time anyone has ever said that to me…

 

“Ah, are you okay?” Byleth asked, actually looking worried despite the fact that Kronya just considered killing her. There was just genuine concern in her voice, and it made the assassin’s throat feel tight. 

 

“...Why are you so worried about me?” she managed to say, trying to figure out what the professor wanted–

 

“I thought Bias might have hurt you. I’m glad to see that you’re okay.”

 

"So what if she hurt me? You know what I am." 

 

"I do. But you're still my student, even if you're in a different class now," Byleth said, smiling at her, “That’s all that matters.”

 

"..." Kronya let out a shuddering breath. "That…I would have killed you. If it meant I could be safe." 

 

"You didn't. You could have but you didn't." 

 

Kronya wasn't sure how she could sound so confident but…somehow she was. As if she fully trusted her completely. "...moron." 

 

"Hey now, I might not be your professor anymore, but I can still give you detention." 

 

“Not if I don’t stick around.” She meant her words to be a sharp retort, but they came out more like a mumble. She felt her face warm, but she huffed instead of acknowledging it, glancing away from the professor.

 

“...Mm. Yeah, that’s true. I can understand why you’re considering leaving. After everything that happened…” Byleth sighed. “...I would prefer it if you felt safe enough to stay, but I understand if you don’t.”

 

“…I don’t think I feel safe anywhere. It would be stupid of me to stay here, but…no one cares about me back home. Bias hammered that into my head well enough. Anyone I think might be on my side would probably just use me up and then kill me afterwards…” She trailed off, thinking of how just a few months ago, she would’ve killed someone for talking like that. And now she meant every word. “Is Bias still alive?”

 

“I’m not sure. I stabbed her several times in the chest, but then a demonic beast broke loose and got between us. If no one found her body, then either she’s still out there, or the demonic beast might have eaten her. She did set a lot of them loose all at once.”

 

“I’m pretty sure she’d more likely eat a demonic beast than get eaten,” Kronya commented, “…is it weird I feel sort of relieved? I kinda want to stab her myself…”

 

“Hm. I think that’s a reasonable feeling to have. I haven’t interacted with her all that much, but she seems very mean and unpleasant.”

 

“Yeah, she is. She’s always been a bitch.”

 

“Mm…even when her sister was around?”

 

Kronay blinked at the question, then actually thought about it. “...I mean, I didn’t interact with them all that much. She’s my superior, but I tended to do missions for Thales specifically–Ah, he was the Agastya.” At Byleth’s confused look, she huffed. “Our leader. The Sage of Light.”

 

“Oh. Ah, right, Bias mentioned him. She believes I killed him and her sister, though she’s more upset about her sister. Which…” Byleth lowered her gaze, a frown coming to her face. “...I think I can understand that.”

 

“...so I realize you’re having a moment, but what was that about you killing Thales?”

 

Byleth sighed. “I’m not sure. She said something about Pittacus being in a carriage with him, but I’m not sure what happened.”

 

“Yeah, that figures.” Kronya sighed too, frowning. “Bias had this whole idea that Thales was killed by foul play and I guess Pittacus was just a casualty along with him. All I know is that he died in some landslide. Other than that, I don’t know enough about it to make a guess myself.”

 

Something about that sounded familiar, but Byleth couldn’t remember why… “Hm…I’ll think about it later. Maybe…maybe there’s something I can do…”

 

“There’s not,” Kronya bluntly stated, “At this point, I don’t really care about Thales, but I know Bias still cares about Pittacus. Even if you didn’t kill her, I’ll bet Bias is latched onto that idea and won’t let it go until either of you are dead. She’s stubborn like that.”

 

“...mm. Are you going to be in danger from her?”

 

“Probably, but I’m bound to be in danger from any Agarthan. If I don’t get a Dolofonos sent after me, I’ll be surprised.”

 

“A what?”

 

“An assassin. I’m technically one of them. Built for murder, to the point that I’m pretty sure my brain is designed to feel pleasure when I kill people.”

 

Byleth blinked. “...your brain is designed?”

 

“Designed, built, and grown by the masterful power of Agarthan alchemy, yeah,” Kronya affirmed, before smirking, “In fact, I, much like the rest of my people, wasn’t born the same way as you bea–ah…you Fodlaners. Agarthans don’t do anything as inefficient as pregnancy to produce new people, no, we use huge glass cylinders filled with weird liquid as a sort of artificial womb. And even then, that’s just how we grow the flesh bodies we use. You want to know what I actually am, professor? I’m a small sphere, about the size of one of those crest stones, created with Agarthan sorcery, imbued with an Agarthan soul, and implanted into a body made by Agarthan alchemy, which, according to Agarthan logic, makes me a real human.”

 

Byleth opened her mouth, struggling to think of a response. She had to imagine she looked very confused right now.

 

"Shez is probably the same too, might have even been designed for the same caste, but with the powers she has…well, I don't know for certain, but they might have tried to design a new sage." Kronya felt a bit amused when Byleth looked even more confused. "Agarthans use a caste system: servants, warriors, scientists. And at the top of everyone are the sages, our oh so great leaders who know and decide everything. Thales was even the one to come up with the caste system after our people were almost wiped out, saying that some people are just naturally more servile while others are leaders.

 

"...hm, thinking about it, it's actually very fucked up that they say that when we're literally designed to be in certain castes. It’s not really natural if we’re made to be that way,” Kronya noted, starting to realize how horrible things were back in Shambhala. "Man, it fucking sucks realizing your entire life is a lie." 

 

"...Well, at least you have the chance to make your own life now," Byleth said, finally breaking through her stunned state. "I don't know when you're planning to leave, but you should leave a note." 

 

"You want me to leave a note to say I'm leaving?" 

 

"Shez will probably be sad if you just leave without saying anything." 

 

"...F-Fine. I'll say I'm… going on a vengeance quest for my…father?" 

 

"It's Emily's uncle that I stabbed, not her dad," Byleth reminded, before smiling. "Don't worry, I'll come up with a good excuse. You just focus on saying goodbye." 

 

"Yeah sure, whatever," Kronya replied, getting up and heading to Manuela's desk to grab some paper for herself–

 

"Oh, do you mind grabbing me a sheet as well?" 

 

…For herself and her professor. 

 

Sitting back down, the two began to write, with Kronya going through several sheets as she crumpled them to start over with a new one. Eventually she finally managed to write something she was satisfied with. 

 

"Here, give this to Shez," Kronya ordered, shoving the letter towards Byleth, before blinking as Byleth handed something to her. 

 

"Since you're not going to be here for graduation." 

 

Taking the paper, she unfolded it to see what was on it. 

 

'Certification of Graduation' 

 

'Awarded to Kronya for being the best that she can be' 

 

In the corner there was a crude drawing of Byleth giving her a thumbs up. 

 

“...” Kronya swallowed the lump in her throat, her eyes burning with suppressed emotion. “...this’s stupid…”

 

Byleth tilted her head, watching as the Agarthan plainly tried to hold back tears. “...do you want me to take it back?”

 

“No. It’s stupid…but it’s mine,” she murmured, and something in her finally broke, causing genuine tears to start rolling down her face. "Fuck, I'm not even supposed to be able to cry." 

 

"It's healthy to cry. Sometimes you need to let your emotions out," Byleth said while Kronya did her best to wipe away her tears. 

 

"S-Shut up," Kronya managed to get out, "I don't even know what I'm going to do when I leave…" 

 

"Well whatever you do, I'll make sure to find you," Byleth said, giving her best smile. "And if I don't, Shez will." 

 

"S-Stop trying to make me cry." 

 

"Heh, sorry," Byleth apologized, looking only slightly sorry. "If it's okay…do you mind if we talk some more before you leave?" 

 

"...got nothing better to do," Kronya mumbled as she looked away. The two settled in, talking the night away until Byleth began to drift off, exhaustion catching up to her and leaving Kronya on her own. 

 

No. Kronya thought to herself as she stood up. Even if I never see them again, I'm not alone. 

 

"Goodbye professor. Until we meet again." 

Chapter End Notes

Red: Lots of angry folks in this chapter. Understandably so, given what went down, and even then we haven't shown everyone's thoughts because, well, that would make for a much longer chapter.

Indi: Next chapter will show some more thoughts, and will have some big stuff happen, but we hope you enjoyed what we did here! I myself am quite proud of the kronya section there.

Red: Wild that she developed this much just from a choice to have her show up at the monastery earlier.

Indi: Yeah, it's definitely been fun writing her and I hope everyone's enjoyed what we've done with her!

Goodbyes, of a sort

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

The mood around the monastery felt strange after the ball. News of how Professor Byleth had gotten into a fight with an infiltrator that left her grievously wounded spread at a haphazard rate through the student body, in large part because the events of the ball had left everyone happy to have a nice night off so the sudden switch to “One of the professors was maimed” left everyone off balance. 

 

Then came the news that Emily Korsch, who most of the students had known as the aggressive girl from the Golden Deer, had vanished in the night without a trace. Well, without a deliberate trace, given that she had chosen to signal her departure by leaving a scrawled apology on the Golden Deer’s blackboard stating that she had to leave to “seek vengeance”. Which was…something.

 

With all that going on, Edelgard’s own departure from the monastery was nearly overshadowed.

 

"What a time to leave, huh Edie?" Dorothea asked as she leaned against a pillar by the courtyard. 

 

"If I could stay I would," Edelgard admitted, finding herself unable to offer a smile. "Yet an Emperor is beholden to her duties." 

 

"Sadly," Dorothea replied, before gazing up at the goddess tower in the distance. "Heh, any chance we can sneak up the tower with the professor before you go?" 

 

"I don't think we'll be able to," Edelgard responded, frowning as she remembered Shez’s words. "And…well, the professor needs the rest." 

 

"I know, it’s just…so much for trying to do something romantic." 

 

"I'm sure there will be other chances in the future," Edelgard said, trying to look forward. 

 

"Ooh? Are you finally agreeing to the three of us being together~?" 

 

"...I-If the professor is okay with it, then I won't say no."

 

"Heh, in that case you better make sure to visit her before you leave, okay?" 

 

"...I'll make sure to do so," Edelgard murmured, before blinking as she felt a pair of lips against her cheek. Her face warmed as she looked up at a smiling Dorothea.

 

“You deserve to be loved, Edie. And I’m gonna make sure you know that every chance I get~”

 

“...m-mm. Then…I will do my best to return that love, as much as I am able.” She considered kissing Dorothea in return, her heart beating rapidly at the thought, before she simply took the songstress’s hand and kissed the back of it. “I promise, I will be back for you.”

 

“I’ll be waiting~”

 

With that, Edelgard went to say the rest of her goodbyes.

 

Walking into the Black Eagles classroom, Edelgard silently regarded her classmates, nearly all of them in there despite classes being canceled for the day. 

 

"Ah, Edelgard." Noticing her first, Ferdinand stood up, getting everyone to turn towards her. "Are you…?" 

 

"...Thank you all for the memories we have developed throughout the year," Edelgard said, bowing to them. "It has been an honor to learn alongside you all." 

 

"I don't suppose there's any chance we can convince you to stay longer?" Flayn asked, trying to put on a smile. 

 

"Yeah come on, things are way too dour right now!" Caspar shouted as he shot up. 

 

"As much as I would agree with not doing anything, she is the emperor now," Lindhart pointed out. 

 

“She is the emperor, yes, but she is our friend as well,” Petra affirmed, before smiling at Edelgard, “It was good to be classmates with you, Edelgard.”

 

"...Make sure to take care, Eddy," Hapi murmured while Constance smiled at her, trying to remain bright despite the situation. 

 

"Twoud be unseemingly for the newly appointed Emperor to run herself ragged from pushing herself too hard." 

 

"I'll keep that in mind. Thank you again." There was more to say, more goodbyes to be had and more affirmations of friendship, but soon enough Edelgard bowed to her classmates and left the classroom. So that just left a few more…stopping by the dorms, Edelgard knocked on a door and heard an involuntary squeak from inside from Bernadetta, huddled in her room again. "Bernadetta…I just wanted to say goodbye. Thank you for everything." 

 

"...Y-You're really going?" 

 

"Yes. I don't have a choice," Edelgard admitted despite the frown on her face. "Make sure to take care, okay?" 

 

To her surprise, the door opened, with Bernadetta standing there for a moment, before hugging her. Stiffening in surprise, Edelgard stayed silent before hugging her back. After several moments, Bernadetta backed away. 

 

"S-Sorry." 

 

"There's no need to apologize, Bernadetta. I needed it. I look forward to seeing you again,” Edelgard said, smiling at her housemate, who gave a sad one in response before closing her door. With that she went to her last classmate. 

 

It was a small trek, but she found herself in the cathedral, where the more pious students were praying. Near the back of the pews, she spotted a familiar blue-haired girl, and Edelgard approached her. 

 

"...praying for the professor?" Edelgard asked, getting Marianne's attention.

 

"Yes, I…why does the professor have to suffer?"

 

"..." Edelgard didn't respond. How could she? The blame fell on her for not speaking up sooner. "I don't know, but she'll need everyone's help once Professor Manuela lets her get up." 

 

“...I wish you would be there to help. I-I…no. No, I know it’s selfish of me, but I still want you to be here instead of at Enbarr,” Marianne stated, looking at Edelgard with a surprising firmness in her gaze, “You’re…You’re someone I can believe in, Edelgard. I think we really are going to be lesser without you here.”

 

“...heh. I would ask that you not tell that to Ferdinand. It would likely break his heart.”

 

"Well…at least we'll all be here to help him," Marianne said, attempting to joke. 

 

"I'm sure he'll appreciate that," Edelgard replied, before bidding her farewell, and making her way to Manuela's office. At least, that was the plan before she ran into Shez. 

 

"I thought I told you to stay away from her," the purple-haired mercenary said, glaring at the emperor as she blocked the hall. 

 

"...I simply wanted to say goodbye." 

 

"I'll tell her for you," Shez stated, not moving an inch. 

 

"...you really won't let me see her?" 

 

"Just count yourself lucky I'm not gutting you right now–"

 

“Shez?” The younger Eisner sibling went stiff, a very awkward look crossing her face as she glanced back and saw her sister staring at the two of them. “...what were you saying to Edelgard?”

 

“Th-That, uh…wait, no, hang on, you should be in bed!” Shez quickly rallied, moving over to her sister with a worried look, though Byleth just frowned at her.

 

“Shez, why were you threatening Edelgard?”

 

“Because–Look, she’s not good for you–”

 

“She’s not good for me?” Byleth interrupted, giving her sister a remarkably skeptical look while Shez fumbled with her words.

 

Despite the earlier threat towards her, one Edelgard felt Shez probably would have made good on, the emperor stepped forward, catching Byleth’s attention. “Your sister was just feeling protective, professor. I think it was reasonable, given your recent injury.”

 

“Hm. Okay. You two are okay?” she asked, glancing between them.

 

Shez grimaced, but nodded. “Yeah, sure, we’re good.”

 

Her glare toward Edelgard said the opposite, but the emperor chose to ignore it in favor of smiling at her professor. “Well, I simply wished to say goodbye, professor. I’m glad I was able to be your student for so long, and I appreciate everything you’ve done for me.”

 

Her professor’s bright smile made everything worth it. “Thank you, Edelgard. I’m very glad to have had you as my student. And I look forward to working with you in the future.”

 

"I look forward to your service." Edelgard said, smiling back. Byleth seemed to want to say something else, opening her mouth and struggling to find the words before Shez spoke up.

 

“Alright, c’mon, we should get you back to bed,” Shez insisted, putting an arm around her sister’s shoulders and pulling her away from Edelgard, earning a pout from the professor.

 

“I don’t need to be in bed all the–Ah, goodbye Edelgard! I hope you have a pleasant journey home!”

 

Edelgard smiled at her professor’s well wishes, before turning to leave. She wished she could have had more of a…affectionate goodbye, perhaps a hug or something, but considering she could still feel Shez boring a hole into her back with her glare, she didn’t want to push her luck.

 

Arriving at where her carriage was waiting, she saw Hubert standing nearby, a cat in hands. "Are you ready, your majesty?" 

 

"About as ready as I can be." 

 

"Edelgard." Stopping as she was about to board the carriage, the emperor turned to look at Dimitri approaching her. “Were you intending to leave without speaking to me again?”

 

“...Honestly, Dimitri, I was distracted.” She stepped away from the carriage and let out a small sigh. With a slight nod to Hubert, her retainer bowed in return as he moved to finish preparing the carriage. “My farewell to Shez did not go well, though I was at least able to say goodbye to Professor Byleth.”

 

“Ah, that’s good. Well, not the Shez part, she’s been…well, she has been agitated after her sister’s injury…Regardless. Is…Is now a good time to talk, or…?"

 

"It's as good a time as any," Edelgard allowed.

 

"That's good, I was… really worried about you, Edelgard… to suddenly receive news that all your siblings had passed away, only to then hear your uncle did as well…" 

 

"...What happened, happened," Edelgard stated, "What matters now is that I move forward to ensure a better future." 

 

"...You mentioned that your siblings had been…killed? What happened?" 

 

"That…people like Solon were behind that tragedy. Behind many others as well. I wouldn't be surprised if they were the ones behind the Tragedy of Duscur, as well as fanning the flames between our nations." 

 

His eyes widened. "Are you serious? Then we have to do something about it!" 

 

"We can't do anything without knowing who exactly is behind those incidents," Edelgard said, frowning as she did, "As it stands, what I must do is deal with corruption in the Empire, and ensure war doesn't break out between it and the Alliance." 

 

"...This might sound odd to hear, but a part of me feels… relieved to know despite everything that has happened, you're still the same stubborn girl you used to be." 

 

"Hm. Is that how I look like to you?" Edelgard asked. "I'm not the same little girl from back then." 

 

"Even so, it's comforting," Dimitri said, doing his best to smile. "...I truly hope we can work together so our nations can prosper." 

 

"I suppose we shall see," Edelgard replied, before nodding to her long lost friend, "It was nice to see you again, Dimitri." 

 

"As it was to see you, Edelgard." 

 

With that, Edelgard boarded the carriage, noting that Hubert had chosen to sit up front, leaving her alone inside. She should make sure to thank him when given the chance…

 

Soon enough, she felt the familiar weight of her cat settle in her lap. Quietly petting him, Edelgard couldn't help but wonder how long it would be until she saw her professor again. 

Idly chewing on an apple, Byleth watched her sister with a raised eyebrow, waiting for Shez to figure out what it was she wanted to say. It seemed to be taking a while, considering her sister was pacing back and forth with a frown.

 

“Well it’s hardly a wonder she’s frustrated. You were injured quite severely on our…admittedly ill-planned mission,” Sothis commented, frowning at herself.

 

“Mm.” Byleth didn’t think it was that poorly planned. Sure, maybe she should have gotten some back-up, but that would’ve put people other than her in danger.

 

“I can tell what you’re thinking and no, it was stupid. And I was a fool for getting so caught up in your drive to defeat that sorceress that I didn’t even think to suggest another course of action!”

 

“It worked though,” she murmured, which got Shez to pause.

 

“Did you say something?”

 

“Yeah. I’m talking to Sothis. She thinks my plan was dumb.”

 

“...” Shez frowned. “Which plan is that? The one where you ran off on your own and almost got killed?”

 

“...ah, well…yes. That one.”

 

“Then yeah, she’s right, that was stupid.”

 

Byleth pouted at being ganged up on, huffing as she settled back in her bed. She reached for another apple slice, not noticing Shez’s frown deepening when she had to feel around a bit to grab one. “Everything worked out–”

 

“YOU’RE MISSING AN EYE, BYLETH!” Shez finally snapped, her shout echoing in the infirmary, “You almost died! You almost died and you only have one eye now, why are you so fucking calm!?”

 

Byleth blinked, a little stunned. “Ah–Shez, it’s okay. I’m fine, I just need to work on my depth perception–”

 

“That’s not the problem! Why would that be the problem!? You didn’t–Why didn’t you get me, huh!?”

 

“...I didn’t want to ruin your night.”

 

“...” Shez closed her eyes, balling up her fists as she tried to fight down the frustration she felt hearing that. “You can’t…Byleth, that’s fucking stupid. Who cares about some dance, huh?”

 

“I do. I care. I wanted the night to be perfect for everyone.”

 

“By, you can’t–You can’t do that! You can’t just–We’re supposed to be a team! You can’t go off on your own and almost die and–And I wouldn’t have even known! I would’ve been just, flouncing around in that stupid dress–”

 

“It wasn’t stupid, you looked nice–”

 

“YOU WEREN’T THERE! How could you even know, huh?!” Her hands clenched, her breath shaky as she tried to calm herself down, before she let out a little laugh. “Right, no, I’m being stupid, you turned back time, right? You…You just turned back the clock, and…did you try to take me with you? Did…Did something happen?”

 

“...” Byleth felt her mouth get dry. “I…ah…I…didn’t.”

 

“...you didn’t bring me with you?” 

 

The hurt in her voice made Byleth’s stomach twist in an uncomfortable way. “I wanted you to have fun–”

 

“Are you–Seriously?! I…I don’t care about that! I would’ve dropped everything to help you! Why wouldn’t you try to get help!?”

 

“I did! I did try, I went to Edelgard–”

 

“You went to her?!”

 

“I–Yes! What’s wrong with Edelgard?”

 

“What’s wrong with–You know she knew the whole time, right!? That that bitch Selene or Bias or whatever was here in disguise and she just…didn’t tell anyone! That the whole reason she didn’t want to go to the Church with info about the Agarthans was because she didn’t want to get caught!”

 

“I–Did Edelgard tell you–?”

 

“YOU COULD HAVE DIED, BY! Why isn’t this sinking in for you!?
