You could’ve died all on your own and I never would’ve known because she didn’t want to tell me!” Shez’s voice broke, tears starting to roll down her cheeks. “I can’t–I don’t care about a dance or a dress or any of that! I just…I could’ve helped. You know that…right?”

 

“I know. Of course I know,” Byleth reassured, trying to swallow the lump in her throat, “I wanted you to have a nice night. You looked so happy…how could I ruin that?”

 

“...why did you go to her? Why her and not me? I’m your family…”

 

“...She wanted to meet me at the Goddess Tower. I wanted to ask…I wanted to…” Byleth took a breath, trying to get her jumbled thoughts in order. “I thought I could get her help and everything would turn out okay. I…I was mad too, when I learned, but I…she told me she loves me.”

 

Shez stared at her sister. “...do you love her?”

 

“I…I don’t know. I was hoping I could figure that out.” She sighed. “Shez, I’m sorry. I’m sorry I didn’t go to you. I’m sorry I left you out. I didn’t…I wanted you to have a nice night and I’m sorry that I hurt you instead.”

 

“...” Shez rubbed her eyes with her arm, brushing away some tears, then let out a huff. “...I don’t…I don’t like her. Even if you do, she lied to us for the entire year and she never would’ve said anything to me if you didn’t get hurt. And that’s messed up. What’s the point of telling me after you get hurt, huh?”

 

“...It’s messy. I…I didn’t expect any of this to happen.”

 

“Yeah, well…me neither. So…I’m not giving my blessing or whatever. And I don’t know if I want you working for her either. She’s an asshole.”

 

Byleth frowned. “Shez.”

 

“I’m allowed to not like her! Her keeping secrets nearly got you killed!”

 

“...mm. I still want to go to the empire.”

 

“Yeah, well…I’m coming along with you if you are,” Shez stated, refusing any argument, “Someone’s gotta look out for you now that you can’t look out for yourself.”

 

“...” Byleth blinked with her single eye. “...too soon.”

 

“...” After a second, Shez’s lips twitched. “Pff-”

 

“Snrk–”

 

For a moment, both sisters just started giggling, the fading tension in the air breaking completely as they laughed together.

 

Byleth brushed a tear from her eye and nodded firmly. “Okay, so…you might not like her, but the plan is still on. We can figure things out with her later, I’m sure of it. Ah, maybe I should send a letter–Oh, right, did you get your letter from K–ah, Emily?”

 

Shez blinked. “My what?”

 

“Oh, did she…maybe she left it somewhere around here?” Byleth started patting herself down, frowning in thought as she tried to remember if Kronya had handed her the letter or if she’d left it somewhere close by.

 

Frowning, Shez glanced around before she noticed a slip of paper under the plate of apples. Reaching over, she pulled it out. 

 

Hey idiot, meet me at the mock battlefield. 

 

"...Short and to the point, I see." 

 

"Hm? Oh, you found it!" Byleth said, smiling as Shez pocketed the letter. 

 

"Yeah, guess I should go meet her before it gets dark," Shez said with a small huff. "Well, I should probably get something to eat before I do. You wanna go down with me?" 

 

“Ah…maybe not. I probably should get some rest.”

 

“Oh so now you want to stay in bed.” Shez huffed again. “I see how it is.”

 

“Well I do need my rest…maybe you could bring me something later?” Byleth asked leadingly, earning an eye roll from her sister.

 

“Fine, fine, I’ll bring you something sweet. But you’d better actually rest! If I get back here and I find out you went running around the monastery, I’m gonna tie you to that bed.”

 

“I solemnly swear that I shall remain in bed until your return,” Byleth promised.

 

“You better.” And with that, Shez headed out, still feeling agitated. She’d save that aggression for someone that deserved it though. Her sister didn’t deserve her anger.

“...Maybe I should’ve argued against her going with Edelgard,” Shez muttered as she trudged through the woods, a deep frown on her face.

 

“Why? Do you wish to upset your rival further?” Arval inquired, raising an eyebrow.

 

“No, that’s not it. I just…I’m not sure if I want Edelgard to have any actual power over Byleth. Not when I know she could just decide it’s worth it to screw her over to save herself.” She sighed, before giving her partner an annoyed glance. “And she’s my sister, not my rival. Would you quit it with that?”

 

“I am merely acknowledging the rivalry that you have chosen to allow to fall by the wayside–”

 

“She’s missing an eye, Arval. And I don’t care about some stupid kiddy rivalry at this point. She’s my sister, I’m not about to pull some competitive bullshit while she’s hurt.”

 

"Very well," Arval muttered, dropping the subject for now. He still kept in mind the obvious weak point the Fell Star now had. "Also you're starting to go the wrong direction, take a left here." 

 

"Thanks," Shez said, following the directions as she made her way to the battlefield. And soon enough, she found herself there, and spotted Emily! 

 

…Who was chowing down on a bag of sweet buns. 

 

"Um, Em?" 

 

She said something in response, sounding exasperated even as her mouth was stuffed full of food. 

 

“…uh, what was that?”

 

“Mmgf–“ Emily swallowed, glaring at Shez. “I said I’m eating, idiot.”

 

“Yeah, I noticed. Why do you have a bunch of sweet buns?”

 

“Because they taste good,” she stated in a tone that said she thought Shez was incredibly stupid.

 

“Oh. Well…yeah, I guess that’s a good reason.” Shez scratched her head. “So…what’s going on? Why’d you disappear all of a sudden?”

 

“The professor didn’t tell you?”

 

“Eh? What would Manuela tell me?”

 

“Not her, dumbass. Your sister.”

 

Shez blinked. “Uh…what would Byleth tell me?”

 

“That I’m an Agarthan.”

 

“…hang on, what?”

 

Emily huffed. “Right, guess I have to explain all of this…from the start, my real name is Kronya, I’m an Agarthan assassin that was sent to infiltrate the monastery and keep an eye on Edelgard, and none of those plans worked out at all so now I’m here.”

 

"...What??" 

 

"Ugh…" Standing up as she set her bag of buns down, Emily straightened up. A moment passed before a pulse of dark magic surrounded her, putting Shez on her guard. Said guard dropped as she watched the magic fade and where Emily once stood was the pale face of Kronya the Agarthan. "Believe me now?" 

 

"..." Shez had never been more confused in her life. Not only was her friend not the person she knew, but she was also an infiltrator. It really doesn't help that she looks really hot– Wait. Pulling out her sword, she took a step back. "...so you're working for Bias?"

 

“No. Not at this point anyway. She had some…big dumb plan to try to kill the professor at the Goddess Tower, but..I don’t know how she did it, but I guess Professor Byleth figured it out ahead of time and stopped her…” Kronya sighed, brushing hand through her hair. “...it’s the dumbest thing. Just…your sister said she was happy I was alive. So…yeah. I’ve been lying to you the whole time, I probably would’ve killed someone you cared about if things had gone differently, and…and yeah. I’m sorry. I liked spending time with you. Do you have any questions?”

 

"..." Shez had several questions, but one came to mind. "Is Edelgard working with Bias?" 

 

"If she was, she wouldn't have stonewalled me when I was in her class." 

 

“Hm. Well, I guess that’s one good thing about her…”

 

“Oh? What’s that mean?”

 

“Ah…nothing. I just learned she was lying to me and…and you were also lying to me, huh?”

 

“...Yeah. So…here I am. Coming clean.”

 

“...” Shez sighed, scratching her head. “...so. Kronya, huh? Guess I can’t call you ‘Em’ anymore. Hm…hey, what about Kro? Or Kron? Or…Nya?”

 

“Shez. Shut up.”

 

“Alright, alright, I’m just…I’m not sure how to take this. You’re Agarthan, you’re not Emily, you’re...you’re someone completely different. And I don’t know anything about you.” She sighed again, then a thought occurred. “Hey, do you know anything about my mom?" 

 

"Hm? That Periander lady?" Kronya asked, frowning in thought, "The name doesn't sound familiar, but…well, she was either a caretaker or a scientist if she took you when you were a baby. I…I wasn't…they only told me what I needed to know. Unless the sages decided to 'grace' us with their presence, I only ever interacted with the instructor. So I don't know anything."

 

“...How’s that work? The whole…everything, I guess,” Shez asked, trying to find the words, “...What are our people like?”

 

“Compared to the people up here? Terrible. I told some of this to the professor, but we have castes. Oratores, bellatores, laboratores. Basically nobles, knights, and commoners, now that I’m thinking about it, but…it’s still different. Oratores is supposed to be the caste of the scientists, alchemists, arcanists, whatever, and I’m a Bellator, so a warrior. Well, a Duellator if you want to be specific–Look it’s a lot of stupid classification stuff and technically I’d be a Dolofonos if I hadn’t killed my instructor.”

 

“...” Shez blinked. “Okay, I…didn’t get a lot of that, but what was that about killing your instructor?”

 

“Ugh…so, okay, you see this?” She gestured at herself.

 

“...Yes? I see you.”

 

“It’s me, but it isn’t me. It’s…the flesh I wear, essentially, and the moment I came into awareness, I didn’t look like this. I wasn’t…born the same way your sister was or the same way Fodlaners are. I was made. Constructed and then implanted into a body that would let me operate the way I need to. And from moment one, I was designed to be a killer. I didn’t get a mom, I got an instructor, and the instructors aren’t meant to take care of us. Caretakers are meant to educate Oratores, instructors are meant to break Bellatores. Either we get beaten into proper warriors or we get called defective and disposed of. And I didn’t want to break, so I carved the bastard open and got to be called an elite because of it.

 

“That’s why I have these,” she explained, gesturing to the tails behind her that she rose up to show Shez.

 

“...wait, what? I thought those were ribbons, what the…you have tails??”

 

“Yeah, I have tails. Like I said, I’m an elite. So…yeah, that’s my life story.”

 

“Wh–Wait, no, that was just the beginning part, you didn’t explain everything! And what about those lab guys, huh? What’s their thing?”

 

“They’re laborers. Servants. They’re not meant for anything besides doing the menial work.” Kronya looked away. "They're supposed to be lesser. Bugs among the 'humans'. It wouldn't even matter if we decided to stab one in the throat if they angered us. Ha, no wonder so many traitors came from them…" 

 

“Traitors?”

 

“People who left Shambhala. Our home city. It’s underground. Dark, cramped, and terrible,” Kronya explained, bitterness leaking into her voice, "They make us think it's so important yet one of the things they reward us is being able to go out and see the sun." 

 

"...man, our people suck, huh?" 

 

"Been figuring that out, yeah. Though you probably would have gotten lucky if you stayed. Pretty sure they were designing you to be a sage." 

 

"Wait, really?" 

 

"Yeah, all those weird powers you have are something special. Magic tied to a legendary figure for our people, the great sage Epimenides.”

 

“Oh. Oh, right, that’s the person that Solon guy was talking about…so…my powers are his powers?”

 

“I think so. Whatever you have, it's way more powerful and versatile than any elites I've seen. So who knows? If things had been different, you might have ended up being my boss." 

 

"...huh. Not sure if that would have been nice. Like, I like hanging around you, but everything else sounds like it sucks." 

 

"Yeah, it does, and that’s why I’m getting away from it. Now I just have to figure out what to do next." 

 

“...well, hey, maybe you could go to Leicester? Maybe become a mercenary?”

 

Kronya gave her a bewildered look. “That…wait, huh…that might not be a bad idea…that prick Myson is trying to cause problems in Adrestia and that bitch Cleobulus is in Faerghus, so Leicester might not be a bad place to hide out…”

 

“Yeah, see? And hey, once I’m out of here, I can meet up with you!” Shez decided, grinning, “You can join up with our mercenary company!”

 

“Ha, or maybe I’ll make my own group and be way better than yours, huh?”

 

Shez smirked. “Oh really? You’re gonna try to compete with us? Because I know I could kick your ass!”

 

“Yeah right, you’ve never fought me for real. I was always holding back!”

 

“Well so I was I! I’d kick your ass if I went all out!”

 

“Pff, prove it! Here and now!”

 

“Fine, I will!” Shez shouted, before the two charged at one another, fists flying as they fought. 

 

Arval, floating nearby, let out a sigh as the two girls faced off against one another. “I have a truly ridiculous vessel…Well, at least she has a friend to be stupid with,” Arval murmured, before settling in to watch the fight. Despite the annoyance he felt at the absurdity, watching the pair did feel…nostalgic.

 

Dwelling in memories was rarely comforting for him, but, for the moment, he sat back and watched, remembering sunny days long, long ago.

Sometime later, both Shez and Kronya laid out on the ground, bruised and panting heavily after their brawl. 

 

"You suck at punching." 

 

"I'm better at stabbing." Pushing herself up, Kronya wiped some of the blood trickling down her forehead. "Did you have to bite me?" 

 

"If the option is there, I'm going for it!" Shez said as she laughed. 

 

"Feh. Shut up," Kronya huffed, looking away from her. 

 

"Heh…so, you're leaving now?" 

 

"Yeah. It’s best that I don't stick around for long." 

 

"Right…then take care. I guess I'll just…stick around and figure out what to do for By." 

 

"You do that. And…make sure to let everyone know that knowing them wasn't…the worst," Kronya said, actually feeling embarrassed, "And tell Lysithea good luck with her family stuff." 

 

"Pft, aw you do care~!" 

 

"Shut up or I'll make you!" 

 

"I don't know if you can, pretty sure I won–" Was about as far as Shez got before Kronya grabbed her collar and pulled her in, cutting her off with a kiss. 

 

As her brain stopped working for a few moments, she almost fell to the ground when Kronya pushed her back. 

 

"Heh, I'd almost say you're cute now," Kronya commented before she took off, leaving Shez behind as her brain started back up. 

 

"...Bwuh???" 

 

Arval, meanwhile, decided to helpfully chime in. "You're a disaster, you know that right?" 

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Wonder how many people thought the meeting would end like that.

Red: Well we did have that relationship tag for a while there.

Indi: That we did! We really should get working on the rest of those relationships huh?

Red: Probably, probably...but what if 100 chapters of pining though?

Indi: What if...

Matters of the Heart

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

“Heeeeeeey, Byleth…I brought cake,” Shez began, peeking into the infirmary, “And, uh, I wanted to say I’m sorry about the Edelgard thing…I know I got really mad there and I feel bad about yelling, so…yeah. But hey, listen, if you want me to, I’m totally up to kidnap Edelgard so you can see her sooner.”

 

“Hold on, what happened with Edie?” Dorothea asked, peeking through the curtains around Byleth’s bed and earning a blink from Shez.

 

“Oh, uh…hey Dorothea? What’re you doing?”

 

“Helping Byleth get dressed.”

 

“...oh.”

 

“She’s helping me change my bandages,” Byleth called out, earning a pout from Dorothea.

 

“Aw, she would’ve bought it…now, what was that about Edie?”

 

“...” Shez grimaced, before moving over with the plate of cake in hand. “Well…uh…how much do you know about…everything, I guess?”

 

“That’s a big question, Shezzie. What does ‘everything’ mean in this context?”

 

“Uh…okay, it’s weird to actually explain this because there’s a lot going on and I guess I’m not as mad now? Because it kind of feels hypocritical to be mad since…ah, maybe I shouldn’t say? It might mess things up...” She frowned as she handed the cake over to Byleth. “Hm…basically, I don’t like Edelgard now.”

 

Dorothea raised an eyebrow. “That’s not really an explanation at all.”

 

“Ugh, I know. It’s like…” She glanced at Byleth, who wasn’t paying attention at all in favor of having some cake. So there would be no help there. “...Edelgard was keeping some secrets, but so was Emily, and those secrets are kind of related so now I don’t know if I should say anything in case it makes things weird and causes problems.”

 

“Hm, so Edie has a secret that has to do with Emily…I wonder if that was the thing she wanted to talk about at the Goddess Tower?" 

 

"...seriously? She was going to tell you too?" Shez paused, glancing at her sister. “...hang on, is there something going on between the three of you?”

 

Byleth paused in the middle of her dessert, glancing up at Dorothea, who gave Shez a little grin. “There might be~ Ah, professor, you wouldn’t mind if I talk to Shezzie, would you?”

 

The professor blinked, her mouth full of cake. “Er–”

 

“Great! Come on Shezzie.” And Shez found herself promptly pulled from the infirmary as Dorothea grinned at her. “So, I’m going to be blunt for a moment. I like both Edie and Byleth, more than I’ve ever liked anyone before, and I would like to be with both of them, if possible. And, well, I might be nudging a few things to make it possible, if you catch my meaning.”

 

“...” Shez stared at the songstress. “...um…alright, I…don’t want to talk about my sister’s love life.”

 

“Aw, why not?” She pouted. “We’re going to be in-laws, aren’t we?”

 

“...uh…okay, um…hm.  I…didn’t know that was going on. And now I feel weird that you’re trying to seduce my sister into a harem with Edelgard.”

 

“Hm. You make it sound dirty when you describe it like that.”

 

“I’m not trying to, I just…I’m confused? And…concerned, a little, because of the stuff with Edelgard that I’m still trying to figure out if I should say or if Byleth should say or…whatever. I…I do think you’d probably be good for By, and I gotta admit I like you better than Edelgard, but I didn’t realize you wanted a thing with both of them? Like, I knew you liked Byleth, and I knew Edelgard really liked Byleth, but now I feel weird about Edelgard, and…yeah.”

 

"Hm…Well, would it help if I admit it was only recently that I tried going for both of them? Prior to the mission at the Locket, I was pretty much willing to give up on both because I thought they'd be happier with each other."

 

“Oh, huh…hm.” She had a lot of thoughts right now and decided to default to her first idea. “So…do you want me to kidnap Edelgard?”

 

“Shez, I don’t want you to be banned from the entire country of Adrestia. That would make my wedding plans very awkward.”

 

“Right, sorry. Hm. I think I’m gonna need to think about stuff more, but…uh…I mean, as long as you’re good to Byleth, I think I’m okay with you." 

 

"Well I'm glad to hear that. I hope I can live up to your expectations,” she said with a smile.

 

"...heh. I’m sure you can. Just…make sure to take it easy with By okay? She's not doing great right now, especially since Edelgard apparently confessed her feelings before everything happened…" 

 

"She did?" Dorothea asked, actually sounding surprised. "Didn't think Edie would actually have it in her…" 

 

"Yeah she's definitely full of surprises," Shez muttered, before shaking her head. "Anyways, I'm going to figure out something else to do while you hang out with By. See you later." 

 

"See you," Dorothea said, waving her off, before turning back towards the nurse's room. With a quick breath, she adjusted her uniform slightly, before walking back in. "Sorry about that, professor~!" 

 

"Oh, did Shez leave?" 

 

"Yes, she had some things to figure out. How are you feeling, by the way?" 

 

"Ah…" Byleth set her fork down, glancing away from Dorothea as she actually felt a bit nervous. "Doing okay." 

 

"Glad to hear, professor. Oh, would you like me to bring some tea later?" 

 

"Maybe? It might be nice." 

 

"Will do. Though before then I think it would be best if we talked about something important." 

 

"...What exactly is that?" 

 

"You, Edie, and me of course~" Dorothea said with a grin. "I mean, I heard she confessed her feelings to you~" 

 

"...Sorry." 

 

"Hm? And what are you apologizing for?" 

 

"I…I wanted to help you two get together, and somehow I got Edelgard to fall for me." 

 

"Come now professor, I know you're not the most experienced, but it should be obvious Edelgard was crushing on you for far longer than you tried pushing us together." 

 

"...oh." Byleth felt her face get warm again. "I, um…didn't know that…since when?" 

 

"Around that time we all went out to town together. At least, that's when I noticed it anyway." 

 

"Oh…that…that's long ago." 

 

"It is. So I'm glad to hear some progress was actually made~" 

 

"H-Hm…if you say so. I…I don't know if I feel the same way. I don't really…understand romance. I've never felt like that to anyone before, so I don't know if I feel like that to Edelgard," Byleth said, as she took a breath to steady herself. "And…well, I never really thought of myself as pretty before, but now with this scar…" 

 

“Haven’t you heard, Byleth? It’s common knowledge that women love scars~” Dorothea teased, smiling at the professor in a way that made her face warm. She sat on the bed, her smile taking on a more understanding tinge. “I do understand why you’re worried though. For a diva, her beauty is her life. If you wind up scarred because some noble decides he doesn’t like how you spoke to him…well, you can’t exactly go on stage from then on, now can you? Though I think you could pull off quite the distinguished look with an eyepatch~.

 

“Teasing aside though…You’ve always been pretty, professor, and I know I don’t mind how you look now. And you can’t tell me Edie would have any aversion to someone with scars. We all have them, after all, even if they’re not immediately visible. Yours is just a little more noticeable." Dorothea reached down to the hem of her shirt, before pulling it up slightly, revealing the edge of a scar at her waist, faded but still slightly noticeable. "A drunk noble threw a broken bottle at me a few weeks before Manuela found me. I'm just lucky it didn't hit my face."

 

“...Hm. You didn’t deserve that.”

 

“People don’t deserve most things that happen to them. The world isn’t fair, but that much should be obvious to anyone that made it to adulthood. Anyone that thinks it is has something wrong with them…but, as I said, things could have been worse. It’s easy to conceal, with clothes or cosmetics, and I can still look perfect for the people that want me to pretend I am. You, on the other hand…I bet you could really pull off the fierce mercenary look if you wanted,” she remarked, brushing Byleth’s cheek beneath her wound, “And who knows? It could heal up nicely enough that with a glass eye, no one would even notice.”

 

“...I don’t know if I want to look like a fierce mercenary,” Byleth murmured, “I…Maybe I just want to be a cute professor…”

 

"Well in that case you're already doing great~" Dorothea teased, getting Byleth to blush. 

 

"Th-Thanks…I…I still don't know what romantic love feels like, so I don't even know if I can love Edelgard like that." 

 

"Aw come on professor, surely thinking about her makes your heart beat faster~" 

 

"My heart doesn't beat." 

 

"Doing that joke again professor?" Dorothea asked with a frown. 

 

"It's not a joke. My heart doesn't beat. It's never beaten," Byleth said, staring down at her lap. "I…I don't know what exactly happened, maybe a mix of my crest, and how I was stillborn but…that's just how I am." 

 

"..." Dorothea seemed lost for words, so Byleth continued. 

 

"I don't really read romance often but, whenever I do, there's always a focus in the heart. How it beats faster or goes out of control when someone is in love. And…well how am I supposed to feel that?" Byleth asked as her chest felt tight. 

 

"...Professor, is it okay if I call you Bylie?" 

 

"Huh? Oh, okay, sure," Byleth said, a bit confused by the non-sequitur, though she did like the nickname. 

 

"Well, Bylie, what do you think about Edie and I getting together, without you." 

 

Byleth felt her chest get tighter. "...H-Happy. You two would be happy, so I would be as well." 

 

"Really? So you wouldn't feel sad at all?" Dorothea asked. "Because if I was in that situation, I'd feel sad. Even if Edie loved me and only me, I'd feel sad knowing I left you out." 

 

"I don't…I wish I could feel emotions better so I could answer you. It's… it's uncomfortable not being able to feel things other people do. Shez has always teased me about who I like and such, but… I really don't know if I like anyone like that. I know dad loved mom, Shez is… attracted enough to people to flirt with them. Practically everyone I know is into someone else and I… I want to feel what they feel. I want to be able to experience every emotion everyone else does…" 

 

"Then, would you like my help?" Dorothea asked, smiling down at her. "Because I love you too, Byleth." 

 

"...Wh-What?" 

 

"I said what I said, Bylie. How was I not supposed to fall in love with how you’ve been this entire year? Really, I wouldn't be surprised if everyone had a small crush on you." 

 

"H-Huh? I, um…I just…I don't know…" Byleth frowned. "You don't need to include me. I don't know if I can love you two like you deserve."

 

"Heh, that's okay Bylie. I don't even know if Edelgard actually likes me or not, but I'm okay with that. I'm okay with just being a pretty face in the background of her life, so long as I can live a comfortable life." 

 

“...You should have someone you love,” Byleth said, still frowning, “You deserve to be happy, Dorothea.”

 

“And you don’t think Edie would make me happy? I could have sworn you were trying to push us together.”

 

Byleth’s frown turned a little awkward. “I thought…You two seemed to like each other. I thought you would be happy together.”

 

“That’s the thing, Bylie. I do like Edie, and I’m pretty sure she likes me too, I just don’t know if it’s in the same way as she likes you. Honestly speaking, I had resigned myself to marrying someone who just wanted a beautiful trophy for a wife if I couldn’t find anything better, so being the second wife to an emperor is far better than I ever thought I could get. And the funny thing is, I think Edie would do her very best to care for me and make me happy. She'd probably shower me with gifts to make me feel loved, even if she doesn't love me. Even if she does do away with the nobility, she'd likely make sure we'd want for nothing." She smiled sadly again. "Who knows, maybe one day she'll love me like you, or maybe she won't. Either way, I'll be okay with that." 

 

“...Will you?” Byleth asked, genuine concern leaking into her voice, “Dorothea, I want you to be happy. I care about you. Not just as my student, you’re my friend.”

 

“Heh…And what if I wanted to be more than friends?” Dorothea reached across the bed and put her hand on Byleth’s, smiling at her.

 

And Byleth felt her face warm up again. “...I-I…" Despite herself, she couldn't help but focus on how her hand felt…moving her hand, she gently grabbed Dorothea's. As their fingers intertwined, Byleth couldn't help but note how soft it felt, even with the calluses that were beginning to form. She wondered if this moment could last forever.

 

Her chest didn't feel tight anymore. "...Your hand feels nice." 

 

“So does yours,” she replied, before leaning closer, “Bylie, can I kiss you?”

 

Byleth’s eyes widened. For a moment, a strange moment, she thought she felt…something in her chest, before her mouth moved. “Yes.”

 

And then their lips were together and Byleth felt as if time had stopped. 

 

Feeling Dorothea pull away, Byleth could only stare up at her as the songstress smiled. "Heh, here's hoping Edie doesn't mind that I took the lead~" With a smile, Dorothea walked away, leaving Byleth alone as she now had several thoughts to deal with. 

 

A small thump sounded out in the room as Byleth fell back in her bed, staring up at the ceiling. 

 

"Hmph, did you finally realize some things?" Sothis asked as she floated above her. 

 

Byleth did. She realized many things. She also knew that…regardless of how things went moving forward, no matter what happened with Edelgard once she talked with her…she was in love with the two of them. 

 

Her chest felt tight, but it didn't feel bad this time. 

Rhea could remember few moments in her long, long life where she felt as genuinely enraged as she did after hearing what happened on the night of the ball. A second Agarthan had infiltrated the monastery, her sanctuary, while disguised as one of her faithful. A second infiltrator, right under her nose, who not only had the temerity to steal her way into the one place in the world that should have been safe, but the audacity to outright mutilate her mother’s vessel.

 

If she had that wretched creature in front of her, she would gouge the Agarthan’s eyes out with her bare hands.

 

As it was, however, the Archbishop should remain calm in times of crisis. So Rhea remained calm. Outwardly, at least.

 

"We've already begun to question the staff and clergy to see if any other infiltrators are among them. Captain Jeralt is being very thorough when it comes to questioning," Seteth stated as he read a report. "And based on what we've found at the old ruins, it seems the infiltrator only had plans to unleash demonic beasts, as there were no signs of anything else hidden there." 

 

"Have the knights double check. We have to be absolutely certain she didn't leave anything else behind," Rhea ordered, doing her best to keep her tone even. 

 

"Of course. As for what else there is to speak about, Professor Eisner is ready to deliver her report." 

 

"Manuela is letting her move about?" 

 

"Only to make her report at the professor's insistence," Seteth answered, lowering his report, "She is to return to bed afterwards." 

 

"...yes, that would be good, she needs it," Rhea muttered as Seteth moved to open the door, letting her mother in. 

 

"Hello there, Seteth, Lady Rhea, I'm sorry for worrying you," her mother said, bowing before the two. 

 

"There is no need to apologize. The fact that you are well and alive is far more important," Seteth said, nodding to her with a small smile. 

 

"Yes, now, I do believe you have a report for us?" Rhea asked, a little impatience leaking into her voice. 

 

"That I do. On the day of the ball, I had gone to the cathedral to check on the confession box, as I was worried that the students may be nervous for the upcoming ball. As I was there, I noticed that the librarian named Selene had exited the goddess tower,” Byleth started, recalling the events of that fateful day and lying through her teeth. "I was aware that normally people are not allowed up there, so I wanted to ask what she was doing, but then I noticed that she seemed to be moving suspiciously. For fear of losing track of her, I did not move to inform anyone and followed her.

 

“After following her, I discovered that she was attempting to unleash a hoard of demonic beasts upon the students. Sadly, she managed to discover me and unleashed them early," Mother explained before reaching up to her bandages, "I was injured in the process, but I was able to wound her as well. I believe she managed to escape, but those are not wounds she'll be able to ignore." 

 

It wasn't enough. She deserved to suffer far more for her crimes.  

 

"I see…did she say anything about her motives?" Seteth asked as Rhea remained silent. 

 

"She…she told me she wanted to hurt me because I apparently killed someone close to her. So she was going to harm the students to get to me." 

 

"That is troubling to hear…" 

 

"I don't know what exactly she's planning, but I doubt she'll give up easily." 

 

"She likely won't," Rhea agreed, letting out a small breath. "For now, it's best if you rest and recover. You can also tell your students they won't need to assist in any mission this month. With you injured, and the house leader leaving, I doubt it will be a good time for them to potentially get into combat." 

 

"Very well, Lady Rhea." 

 

"Now then, is there anything else you wish to say before you leave?" Seteth asked. 

 

"Ah, well…there is one more thing I wish to say. I wish to thank you for this opportunity that you've given me, but I think I shall retire from the position of professor at the end of the year." Rhea's eyes widened as she stared at her mother’s vessel. "Emperor Edelgard offered me a position as her advisor, and I think it might be a better fit for me, especially given my injury." 

 

"Oh, well, I suppose we cannot fault you for such a decision. This year has been rather…tumultuous." Sighing, Seteth shook his head. "I suppose we should be thankful that you gave us advance notice rather than simply quitting at the end of the year."

 

"I figured it would only be appropriate to mention it sooner rather than later–"

 

"W-Wait, are you sure you want to go?" Rhea called out, getting her mother to look at her in surprise, though it faded into a look of understanding.

 

"It's something I've been thinking about for some time but…yes, it's what I want." She smiled up at the archbishop. "I also want to thank you. I…I know I was curt at the beginning of the year but…I'm happy to have been a professor here. I got to meet so many people I care about now. I…I'm glad to have met you Lady Rhea, and I'm happy my mama knew you as well."  

 

Rhea paused, the words settling in her mind in a strange way as she stared at Byleth. It…felt nice to hear that, but it didn’t change things. Byleth was her mother’s vessel–She was her mother. She just…didn’t know it yet. 

 

In that sense, it was almost understandable.

 

At the same time, it wasn’t. The monastery should feel like home to her. Rhea had built Garreg Mach to be a new home, a new Zanado. Her mother should feel content here. Why would she ever want to go anywhere else?

 

For a brief moment, she felt a flash of anger towards the princess for daring to steal–But, no, that was foolish. She was being foolish, letting her emotions out of control like this. She had to think things through…

 

“I…I understand, professor. As Seteth said, thank you for giving us this notice ahead of time. Furthermore, due to the severity of your recent injury, I think it would be best if your class refrained from going on combat missions for the rest of the year. Perhaps, instead, some training exercises with the Knights of Seiros would be best?” And it would keep her here, at the monastery, where no one else could take her.

 

"That's very kind of you, Lady Rhea. I was hoping to start training soon so I can get accustomed to my change in depth perception," the child before her said, a smile on her face. 

 

"Of course, and if you wish, I can assist in your training,” Rhea offered, keeping her face even, “Though I may not appear as such, I am quite skilled with the blade and in hand-to-hand." 

 

"Really? Well, I suppose that makes sense. You are the leader of the church, it's to be expected that you can defend yourself," she agreed, as though it was completely expected that a major religious figure would be capable of brawling.

 

"Of course I can. Do you wish to begin your training right now?" Rhea asked, before Seteth cleared his throat. 

 

"Professor Eisner still needs to rest, Lady Rhea," Seteth said, before turning to the child. "Apologies for Lady Rhea’s forwardness. I believe she may simply wish to make most of your remaining time here. It is my understanding that your mother and her were close." 

 

"Ah, yes, she was the midwife for my birth actually. It's…odd to think, if mama had survived and we had stayed, I might have actually considered you an aunt, Lady Rhea." 

 

“...I…I would not mind, child, if you chose to consider me family,” she spoke carefully, trying to hide the welling of emotion that came with those words. The irony of Byleth’s kindly meant offer sat sourly in her heart and for a moment, Rhea wondered if she should simply order the child to be kept here, where she would be safe. She couldn’t let such a light in her life simply vanish, like so many others.

 

"Well…in that case, thank you Aunty Rhea," the child said, a large smile on her face. 

 

…She would give it time. Let her see that staying here was a far better option. And if she didn't…well, she was only one foolish child. Rhea could harden her heart to what needed to be done–

 

“Hm…your birthday is coming up soon.”

 

Rhea paused, then glanced at Seteth, who had spoken up once Byleth left the room. “I beg your pardon?”

 

“Your birthday, Lady Rhea. It should be on the eleventh along with Saint Seiros day, so perhaps it would be nice to do something to celebrate? Perhaps involving Professor Eisner and her family?”

 

“...Ah…such as?”

 

“Such as a dinner, perhaps? After all, while I could tell you felt some awkwardness there, it was clear you appreciated young Byleth’s interest in accepting you as family,” Seteth stated, looking oddly positive, “So I think it would be best for you to invite the Eisners to a birthday dinner with you. I can bring Flayn and we can let them know certain things about our familial connections.” He gave her a knowing look. “You cannot keep it a secret forever, Lady Rhea.”

 

“...” Oh goddess, he still thinks I am Byleth’s grandmother…No, wait, this is…good? Good. Familial ties are a good thing to emphasize. “Yes, perhaps that is a better idea…”

 

“Oh, you had an idea of your own?”

 

“No, I didn’t.”

 

“...ah…very well then, I’ll let them know as soon as possible.”

 

Rhea nodded, reconsidering matters. So maybe less hardening my heart, more opening my heart? To an extent, of course, opening it too much opens me up for heartache.

 

Yes, this was certainly a better plan.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Oh yeah we haven't said it yet, but happy pride everyone!

Red: Would you believe we didn't actually plan for the chapters featuring romance to be posted this month? This has all been one funny coincidence.

Indi: And yet what an amazing coincidence

Red: Yup yup. And with that coincidence comes Dorothea actually talking about her relationship expectations and how messy this kind of thing can be. Especially considering the hang-ups and trauma of all involved.

Indi: But hey I'm sure everything will be fine! Clearly no one is planning things.

Red: Yup! So please just ignore the mess of issues that is Rhea over there.

The Best Plan

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Ferdinand von Aegir was, in many ways, something of an oblivious young man. He had his ideas about how the world worked that he tended to stick to, but he was aware enough to realize how different things were now that Edelgard had left the Academy. The red shoulder cape now affixed to his uniform was proof enough of that.

 

Not only that, but Professor Byleth now bore an eyepatch where her right eye once was, a mark of the battle she had gone through while the rest of them remained entirely oblivious to the danger in their midst. He knew it must hurt her more than it could hurt any of them, but he couldn't help but feel it as a mark of shame for not being there for her! 

 

So he needed to think of something to do! 

 

"Well, perhaps it would be best if we acted as if nothing had changed?" Flayn suggested as the two had a brainstorming session. "I appreciated my brother's attempt to cheer me up after my kidnapping but...well, it was embarrassing having everyone get involved in a fishing tourney." 

 

“It was? Truly? I thought it was a nice event to bring everyone together.”

 

“It was still embarrassing,” Flayn insisted, pouting.

 

“Hm…but would Professor Byleth be embarrassed by such a thing? Perhaps we could put on a celebration of her accomplishments as a professor!"

 

"Well…maybe that would be a good idea. Especially given what my brother told me." 

 

"Hm? What did he say?" 

 

"Oh, well…don't tell anyone I said this but-" Pulling at his sleeve, Flayn had Ferdinand crouch down to whisper in his ear. 

 

"WHAT!?" he shouted as Flayn tried to immediately shush him. "You can't be serious about the professor quitting!" 

 

"All I know is what my brother mentioned. Apparently she has her reasons, but he didn't tell me." 

 

"...You don't think she's quitting out of shame, do you?" 

 

“Huh? Why would she be ashamed?”

 

"Think of it, she was gravely injured not only once but twice this year. Not to mention that not only were we unruly at the start of the year, a student who was a part of the Black Eagles fled the monastery entirely!" 

 

“Ah…I suppose that’s true…though I thought Emily left on a vengeance quest?”

 

“That is what her note claimed, yes, but it doesn’t not change the fact that she left without notice! Add in how both Edelgard and Hubert have left, she's probably feeling down on herself!" Ferdinand stood up, looking determined. "We need to rally everyone together to cheer her up!" 

 

"...Well," Flayn frowned, wondering if they might be jumping to conclusions before thinking…if Byleth was her family, then it was her duty to make sure she was okay as her elder! "You're right, we need to bolster her spirits!"

 

Yes, this was the best plan!

"Aren't you two overreacting?" Claude asked as he stared up at Ferdinand and Flayn from the tea table he was hanging out at. 

 

"Yeah, I mean, I haven't heard anything about this myself, as juicy as it sounds," Hilda muttered, as she picked up a macaroon to munch on. 

 

"I think we're reacting as appropriately as we can!” Ferdinand affirmed, “I understand that I may have only become house leader, but I would have hoped you'd take me seriously!" 

 

"I am," Claude lied as leaned back in his chair, "But you know how Teach is. She's quiet but she's not the type to just quit. I mean if she was, she probably would have done so much earlier." 

 

"But what if she's just bottling it down!" Flayn argued. 

 

Claude sighed as he looked away from them, before pausing, "Hey, Shez, come over here!" 

 

Blinking, Shez turned to the group, before walking over. "What's up?" 

 

"Can you tell these two to calm down and that Teach actually isn't sad?" 

 

"Wait, who told you she's sad?" Shez asked, sounding surprised. "Please don't tell me someone started gossiping, I really don't want By to cry again…" 

 

“Ah ha! You see!” Ferdinand exclaimed, pointing at Shez.

 

Flayn, meanwhile, actually listened to what Shez was saying. “Oh no! Oh, I’m so sorry to hear that she really has been upset!”

 

“Which is all the more reason why we need a celebration of her efforts to raise her spirits!” Ferdinand declared, his positivity undaunted.

 

"So, wait, is Teach actually planning on quitting?" Claude asked. 

 

"...okay, you guys have to actually tell me who's telling you this stuff," Shez replied in lieu of answering.

 

"Oh, wow, I didn't think she was doing that bad…" Hilda muttered. 

 

“Yeah, well, she lost an eye. You don’t exactly walk that off.”

 

“Yeah I can imagine the lack of depth perception would make that an issue,” Claude remarked, before pausing at the immediate glare Shez gave him, “Ah…sorry about that. Okay, so…as weird as it is to agree with the Empire’s loudest man and his new retainer, I gotta admit, it does sound like a good idea to cheer Teach up.”

 

“He’s definitely not the loudest,” Shez interrupted, “That’s Caspar.”

 

“He does tend to shout everything he says…” Flayn mused, before pausing. “Oh, am I Ferdinand’s retainer now? Oh I’ve never been a retainer before! Do I need to swear fealty now?”

 

“Probably. Anyways, so would the Empire’s noblest noble work?” Claude asked, turning his attention from Flayn to Shez, who tilted her head.

 

“I think Constance would try to argue that, but she’s also not a noble right now, so I think Ferdinand wins by default.”

 

“I would win such a title either way,” Ferdinand insisted, nodding, “Really, I would put myself in the running for the title of Fodlan’s noblest noble–”

 

“Yeah, but we’re not trying to start a fight with Lorenz, so we’re being specific,” Claude stated.

 

“Hm, I wonder who the Kingdom’s noblest noble would be then…” Flayn mused, looking thoughtful.

 

"Doesn’t Annette win that by default?” Hilda suggested, “When her competition includes Sylvain and Felix, she's definitely in the lead. Honestly, the only one who would be stiff competition is maybe Ingrid." 

 

"Well, yes, while I might have been wrong about my assumptions of the kingdom and its people, I will admit that their more…knightly values means they aren't a paragon of nobility like Lorenz or I," Ferdinand muttered before pausing, "Oh, I really should apologize to Dimitri for how I was." 

 

"Apologize for what?" Dimitri asked, as he and Dedue walked over having heard his name. "Is something going on?"

 

"Teach is depressed and wants to quit," Claude said, speaking up before anyone else could. 

 

"What!?" Dimitri exclaimed, taken aback by that revelation. "We need to do something!"

 

"Which is what we're trying to figure out," Hilda responded. 

 

"Right, to start we need to bring in everyone, but keep this a secret from the professor! It would be horrid if our plan was revealed before we could pull it off," Ferdinand said, starting the plan. 

 

"Hm…I could attempt to cook a meal with some of our classmates, if that is okay?" Dedue suggested. 

 

"Oh that sounds great, I want to help!" Flayn said, a large smile on her face. 

 

Those in the group who were familiar with Flayn’s cooking abilities blanched at the suggestion, though Ferdinand kept his composure as he spoke up quickly. “While I am sure the professor would appreciate your kind offer, Flayn, I am afraid I will need your aid in planning the event properly! You are to be my assistant, right?”

 

“Oh of course! I shall gladly aid you in whatever you might need!” she replied, successfully deflected, “What should we decide on first?”

 

“Hm…well the most sensible thing to begin with is likely–” Ferdinand began, heading over to a nearby table and pretty much ignoring the rest of the group in the process as he and Flayn began making plans.

 

“Hey, so where is the professor anyway?” Hilda spoke up, “She’s not still in bed, is she?”

 

“That’s…a good question,” Shez noted, frowning, “I know Professor Manuela said she’s okay to move around now, so I figure she’s gotta be doing something.”

 

“Then we’ll have to split up,” Dimitri decided, “Each of us can investigate a location Professor Byleth prefers to spend her time at. I believe she most commonly spends her leisure time at the fishing pond?”

 

“Yeah, usually. That or the greenhouse…or the mess hall?” Shez tilted her head and crossed her arms, thinking. “Those are all over the place though, huh? Might take a while for us to check all of them.”

 

“...aren’t they all in the same corner of the monastery?” Hilda asked, prompting a blink from Shez.

 

“Are they? No, the mess hall is by the dorms and the pond is by the town.”

 

“Those are right next to each other…”

 

“Where do you think the greenhouse is?” Claude asked, his eyebrow raised.

 

“...hm. That’s a good question. Well the greenhouse has plants, so…somewhere by the forest?”

 

“...Yeah, so, we need someone to go with Shez.”

 

“I’ll volunteer for that then,” Dimitri decided.

 

“Oh? You're still trying to steal our merc back, prince?” Claude asked with an amused grin, “You know, crawling back to a girl that’s already left you isn’t a great look.”

 

“You have to pay for dates, Claude,” Shez retorted, “You don’t have any room to talk.”

 

“...yeah, I’m not going to argue with that. Just make sure she’s home before dinner, alright Dimitri?”

 

"...we're not planning on leaving the monastery," Dimitri muttered, before he shook his head, "Regardless, Dedue, if you can please start on the meal that would be wonderful, I'll make sure to point Mercedes and Annette your way if I see them." 

 

"Of course, your highness," Dedue responded, bowing before he left. 

 

"Right, guess that means we should start looking. Make sure to tell everyone the plan, but keep it a secret, got it?" Claude said, before he and Hilda went off towards the mess hall. 

 

“Understood. We will keep the utmost secrecy–And he left already, hm.” Dimitri sighed at his fellow house leader’s lack of respect for his words, before glancing at Shez. “So, where would you like to look first?”

 

“Huh? Uh…well the mess hall would make sense, right?”

 

“...Claude and Hilda are going there right now. As is Dedue, I suppose, though I believe his intentions are to head for the kitchen–It doesn’t matter, we should just look somewhere else.”

 

“Oh, alright. Guess we should check out the greenhouse then?”

 

“...Why don’t we head in the other direction? Perhaps towards the cathedral?”

 

“Why would she be there? No, wait, she answers the advice box, she probably would be there.” Shez said, before nodding to herself. "Let's go!" 

 

"Let's," Dimitri agreed, as the two walked together. "Ah, do you mind if I ask how you're doing? I understand that what happened might have affected the professor more, but I want to make sure you're okay as well." 

 

"...Well, I'm mostly feeling awful. Like there I was having fun and she was almost dying." 

 

"I can understand where you're coming from. Though we were not as close as you and the professor, I can't deny how much sorrow I felt when I heard my stepsister and her siblings had been allegedly affected by a plague." 

 

"Ah, sorry to hear that…wait, you have a sister?" 

 

"Only through marriage and…well, I suppose since I finally reconnected with her, it's okay to talk about. Edelgard is actually my step-sister after her mother married my father."

 

Shez blinked. She looked up at Dimitri trying to parse those words for a moment before she pressed a hand against her face and groaned. “Great. So not only did I screw up with her, but now you’re gonna hate me too…”

 

“Hm? Why would I hate you?”

 

“Just…so the part about Byleth being sad and me not wanting to make her sad was because of a whole thing where I got mad at Edelgard and…ugh, this is hard to explain. I mean, I think I was crying more than Byleth–Whatever! The point is I was mean to Edelgard, and since you’re Edelgard’s brother, you’re basically obligated to be mad at me now.”

 

"...I'm sorry, I'm a bit confused. What exactly did Edelgard do?" 

 

"It's a long story and one I probably shouldn't tell since I'll mess it up. The important part is that Byleth is apparently okay with it, and may or may not be in love with Edelgard."

 

"What?"

 

"Yeah it's an entire thing. Edelgard confessed to her and now Byleth isn't sure if she feels the same way or not. I think. Maybe. I brought her cake, I think that means we’re good, but I've been giving her space since then." 

 

“Hm. Well, to begin, I don’t hate you, Shez. I actually wanted to check in with you. It’s why I volunteered to work with you in finding the professor.”

 

Shez blinked. “You want to check in on me? Why?”

 

“While you may be a Deer now, you were a Lion previously, and I consider it my duty as both your house leader and your friend to make sure you are feeling better after everything that happened.”

 

“...huh. I…I guess I kind of appreciate that. I, uh…it wasn’t all bad, being part of the Lions.”

 

“The fact that there were bad parts at all is more than enough reason to change classes,” Dimitri allowed, before giving her a slight smile, “I do wish, in hindsight, that you had decided to leave after the Battle of Eagle and Lion though. Perhaps we would have stood a better chance then.”

 

“Oh for sure, you definitely would’ve won with me on your side,” Shez stated, nodding, before she paused, “Huh. Sounds like someone’s training.”

 

“Hm?” Dimitri gave her a glance, before pausing for a different reason. “…how in the world did we arrive at the training grounds?”

 

Shez didn’t pay him any attention though, instead just heading into the training grounds and looking around curiously. Inside, the pair found Byleth and Rhea sparring, which came as a surprise for the two of them, especially when they saw the Archbishop, dressed in more practical yet still white garments instead of her usual gown, easily deflecting Byleth’s punches. 

 

"You might have trained to use more than your sight when it comes to sensing attacks, but you have to grow accustomed to this new change. Being unable to see is different then training to fight while blinded." 

 

“Hm. I understand. Being half-blind is actually more of a hindrance because my remaining sight keeps tricking me,” Byleth noted, frowning at her loss of depth perception.

 

“That is one way to think of it. It will be difficult to compensate for, but I am certain you can get back to your previous level of skill with practice,” Rhea assured, smiling at her.

 

“...Uh, hey!” Shez called out, catching Byleth and Rhea’s attention, “What’s going on over here? Are you two training?”

 

“No, I’m in a fight to the death for the right to become archbishop,” Byleth replied, entirely deadpan, which earned a huff from Shez and a little laugh from Rhea.

 

“Child, please, don’t joke about that sort of thing,” she requested while trying to stifle her giggles.

 

Byleth shrugged. “Okay. But yeah, we’re training. I’m trying to compensate for my eye going missing.”

 

“You say that like it wandered off on its own,” Dimitri commented, making Byleth pause.

 

“Oh, hi Dimitri. Didn’t see you there.”

 

“...” Dimitri wasn’t quite sure if that was intended as a joke or not. “Hello professor. Are you…feeling well?”

 

“About as well as I can be, yeah. Like I said, Rhea’s helping me get back into practice.”

 

“Yes, I noticed. I admit, I’m somewhat surprised to see you training with the professor, Lady Rhea.”

 

“Why wouldn’t I?” the archbishop asked, “Professor Byleth was injured while protecting the monastery from another infiltrator, one I cannot help but feel responsible for not catching before she could cause such pain. Therefore, I wish to aid her in her recovery as best I can.”

 

“Huh. That’s nice of you,” Shez commented, before glancing at her sister, “And you’re feeling alright, Byleth?”

 

“About as well as I can,” Byleth said, missing Dimitri’s grimace, “Though I was going to take a break since we’ve been training for some time. Oh, Shez, I was actually going to stop at the greenhouse, do you want to come with me?”

 

“Oh, sure,” Shez readily agreed.

 

“Ah, may I come along as well?”

 

“Actually, Prince Dimitri,” Rhea interrupted, “I wished to speak with you about the upcoming mission, and whether your class might be willing to provide aid.” 

 

“Oh…” Dimitri glanced at Byleth, concern evident before he schooled his features and nodded to the archbishop. “Of course, Lady Rhea.” 

 

“Thank you. It will be somewhat difficult to adjust to the changes with the Eagles, but I am certain we will be able to resolve this matter soon enough. You have all proven yourselves to be very capable,” Rhea praised as Shez and Byleth walked away. 

 

“So…what are you getting at the greenhouse?”

 

“I wanted to check on my garden, and…well, I wanted to get some flowers.” 

 

“Oh, were you going to bring them to your room?” 

 

“No, I just…wanted to get them for someone,” Byleth explained as they walked together. As they passed the dorms, Shez noticed Claude and Hilda by the pond, watching the two of them. Giving the two a sneaky thumbs up, she assured them everything was okay. 

 

Claude and Hilda, meanwhile, wondered what Shez was going to do to blow their cover.

"Wait, what's going on?" Dorothea asked, unsure of what she had just heard Ferdinand say. 

 

"The professor is leaving the academy out of shame, we have to work together to make sure she doesn't!" the noblest of nobles declared.

 

"...are you sure you aren't overreacting?" 

 

"Well, apparently Dimitri and Claude also think that. And there was something about Shez saying Byleth cried?" Caspar said, the rest of the Eagles having been gathered by the new house leader. 

 

"...What?"  Dorothea felt as if she had missed a great deal while going shopping. 

 

"She is probably leaving because of my grotesque countenance…" Constance muttered. 

 

"Of course not, Constance! You look great as always!" Flayn declared, before looking at the songstress. "We've already informed everyone! The Lions are helping in the kitchen, while the Deer are keeping an eye on the professor." 

 

“Wait, informed them of what?” Dorothea asked, trying to get at least some information here.

 

“The party, of course!” Ferdinand answered.

 

“...no one mentioned a party,” Hapi pointed out.

 

“We didn’t? No, I’m sure we did…though, did we inform you, specifically?”

 

“So you told everyone except your own classmates,” Linhardt noted.

 

"Ah…well we've been busy planning everything, so it slipped our minds," Ferdinand said, trying to excuse himself. "Regardless, we must ensure everything goes well!" 

 

“Sure. What’s the actual plan though?”

 

“Oh, that’s simple!” Flayn spoke up, “We are going to be hosting a party for Professor Byleth!”

 

“I got that part. What else?”

 

“Ah…” She trailed off, then looked at Ferdinand, wondering if there was actually anything else to the plan.

 

"Well we'd of course all speak about how much the professor means to us! I myself have already prepared a speech!" 

 

“W-W-We need to write speeches?!” Bernadetta squeaked, audibly terrified at the prospect.

 

“Ah, no, you do not necessarily–”

 

“Hell yeah! I’m gonna win this speech competition easy!” Caspar declared with a big grin. "I'm gonna speak the best!" 

 

“Not if I am speaking the greatest!” Petra countered, giving Caspar a competitive grin.

 

"..." Dorothea had a dawning realization that she had to be the responsible one now. "Okay, let's back up a minute, have any of you actually talked with the professor?" 

 

"Would that not ruin the surprise?" Petra asked in response. 

 

"But we can at least know if she’s leaving because she actually is sad or–" 

 

"But what if asking just makes her feel worse!?" Bernadetta squeaked out in a panic. 

 

Dorothea sighed, before pausing when Marianne raised a hand. “Um…it might be better just to ask…we should make sure she’s actually okay with having a party.”

 

“...Marianne, you’re the best,” Dorothea praised, happy to have someone else be responsible.

 

"O-Oh, um…thank you…" Marianne managed to mutter. 

 

"Hm…well, seeing if she is up for a party would probably be a good idea," Ferdinand agreed with a thoughtful look, getting Dorothea to roll her eyes. 

 

"Right, I'll go check that," Dorothea muttered, before walking past her classmates, looking for Byleth. Which, well, was easy enough since she found a large crowd of Golden Deer near the reception hall. 

 

"I'm telling you this is pointless," Lysithea grumbled. 

 

"You sure? Cause I want to make sure the professor is okay," Raphael said in response. 

 

"That's not what I meant!" 

 

"...So I’m guessing the professor is nearby?" Dorothea spoke up, catching their attention. 

 

“Oh, hey Dorothea!” Raphael greeted, smiling cheerfully, “Yeah, Professor Byleth and Shez are over there, talking to Seteth.”

 

Glancing past the Deer, Dorothea could see the sisters standing by one another talking with Seteth, with Byleth holding a bouquet of flowers. 

 

"Why is she holding flowers?" 

 

"I don't know, but it's a lovely bouquet," Ignatz said, before Lorenz sighed. 

 

"Clearly she is bringing them to the graveyard for her mother."

 

"That might be a big assumption but…well, that bunch of flowers does have the type that I see the captain take when he goes to the cemetery." Leonie muttered. 

 

"Right…well, good news is that all of you have been relieved of this duty, I need to talk with her so you guys can go," Dorothea said, before waving them off. 

 

"You sure? Cause I'm totally fine with sticking around," Claude asked as he raised his hand. 

 

"If you feel like letting Ferdinand prepare a massive speech, which means he will certainly expect you to prepare one too since you’re a house leader, go ahead." 

 

"..." Claude sighed, before gesturing for everyone to follow him. "Right. Come on guys, we got a speech to stop." 

 

"Wait, we can't just leave the professor!" Lorenz argued before being shooed away by Dorothea. 

 

"Yes you can now go," Dorothea said, sending the class off before heading into the hall and catching the end of the conversation. 

 

"–look forward to dinner together then," Seteth said before walking off. 

 

"Making plans?" Dorothea asked, getting the two mercenaries to look at her. 

 

"Kinda? Apparently it's Rhea's birthday soon, so Seteth wanted to invite us over for dinner." Shez answered, getting Dorothea to blink. 

 

"Oh, that's a surprise." 

 

"Mhm, I would have thought Rhea would have invited me when we were sparring," Byleth mused, before glancing at Shez. "Ah, Shez, do you mind giving us some privacy?" 

 

"You sure? I don't mind sticking around." 

 

"Yes, please." 

 

"Hm…well, make sure to call for me if you need anything!" Shez said, giving her best grin, before leaving the two alone. 

 

"So, Bylie, how are you doing?" 

 

"I'd say good. Everyone's been treating me nicely so that's a good thing at least." Byleth said, a small smile on her face, before pausing. "Oh, um…I wanted to give this to you." 

 

Extending her hands out, the mercenary handed her the bouquet of flowers. 

 

"Oh! Well, not that I dislike them, but what's the occasion?" Dorothea asked, looking at the beautiful flowers as she took them. White lilies, pink valerians, and red carnations all arranged together wonderfully. 

 

"No reason. I um…just thought you might like them," Byleth said, scratching the back of her head. "I know you like lilies and Edelgard likes carnations but…I thought they might look good with some valerians. They were, um, my mom's favorite, apparently." 

 

"Well that is very sweet of you, Bylie~" 

 

"I'm glad you like them," Byleth said, before clearing her throat. "I…I'm still new to this, but…I know I like being near you, and I want to keep being near you. So…when I go to Enbarr after I retire, I hope we can go see Edelgard together. So we can keep being…near each other…" Dorothea watched as Byleth began to blush slightly. "I'm really not good at this…" 

 

"Well I think you're doing fantastic~" Dorothea said, leaning forward and giving Byleth a kiss on the cheek. 

 

"H-Hm…thank you. Still, I want to be able to say this better…are there any poetry books you recommend?" 

 

“Poetry?” She paused. “Bylie, are you planning to seduce me through poetry?”

 

“Yes, that is exactly what I plan on doing. Do you have any recommendations?”

 

"...pft–hahaha!" Dorothea couldn't help herself from bursting into a fit of laughter. "Well, I'll admit I didn't expect you to be so blunt. Guess I'll do my best to find good poetry books for you." 

 

"Thank you, Dorothea," Byleth said, feeling her heart swell as the songstress smiled in return. 

 

"Heh, oh, quick question, are you up for a party?" 

 

"Hm? Does it have something to do with what the Deer were following me around for?" Byleth asked, getting Dorothea to blink. "I might have lost an eye, but I can still hear well enough. Not to mention they were being pretty loud." 

 

“Heh. Well, yes, they do tend to be loud, and yes, they do want to throw a party. Specifically, Ferdie and Flayn want to throw a party to help cheer you up since they think you’re quitting.”

 

"Oh, well, I am planning on going to work for Edelgard. I'm not going to be quitting right now though." 

 

"Yeah but you know how they overreact. Come on, let's go find a vase for these flowers, before we head over to the dining hall." 

 

"Yeah, let's," Byleth agreed, two walking off together. As they did, she felt fingers brush against her hand, before gently holding it. With a smile, she gently squeezed the hand in response. 

 

Though she only had a couple months left at the Academy, a part of her really did want these days to last forever.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Happy one year anniversary to Three Hopes!

Red: Crazy to think it's been a year already! (and still no DLC...)

Indi: And in just a month and a half it'll be our one year anniversary of Daughters!

Red: Crazy to think we've been at it for that long, but hey, it's been fun! And all because we thought it'd be fun to have Byleth and Shez be siblings...

Indi: And hopefully y'all will stick around to see this eventually come to an end! Whenever that happens.

Red: We are reaching the 100th chapter pretty soon. Let's see if something crazy happens then.

A Time for Family

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Saint Seiros Day, possibly the most important day of the year, especially for the faithful of Fodlan. It was the day dedicated to the founder of the Church, and prophet of the goddess. However, for a certain person, there was something more important. 

 

For Flayn, it was her Aunty Rhea’s birthday, and that meant she wanted to celebrate! And luckily for her, she and her brother wouldn't be the only ones to celebrate it! 

 

"So what kinda gifts do archbishops like?" Shez asked, glancing around the market with her sister and Flayn in tow. 

 

"Holy stuff?" Byleth responded, tilting her head as she looked at a drawing of a crest of Seiros. 

 

“Oh yeah, good point…though what if she likes the opposite? Like, since she’s surrounded by holy stuff all the time, maybe she’d like something that’s completely different!”

 

“Or she surrounds herself with holy stuff because she likes it.”

 

“Hm…what would the opposite be though…?”

 

“Are you listening to me?”

 

“I am, I’m just thinking about my own thing.”

 

“Mm.” Byleth decided to just leave Shez to that in favor of looking around the marketplace while considering what Rhea would probably like for a gift. There were those goddess statuettes, she would probably like those…or maybe a painting? A painting could be nice.

 

Shez, meanwhile, was thinking about what the opposite of church stuff would be. Maybe something exotic? Would Rhea like foreign stuff? Hm, maybe I should ask around Abyss then, see if they have anything neat…

 

"Hm…What do you think, Flayn?" Byleth asked, gesturing at a picture of a lake. "This looks like it would be nice to have in her office. A nice relaxing painting to look at when she's stressed." 

 

"Oh! That's a lovely idea!" the green-haired girl said, smiling as she looked away from the stylish hairclip she’d been checking out.

 

"Nice, I'll take this painting," Byleth said, looking at the merchant as she pulled out her coin pouch, before pausing as she saw a book of dessert recipes. "And this book, please." 

 

She hadn't gotten Edelgard a coronation gift yet, but maybe she'd like something handmade.

 

“Hm, maybe these?” Shez considered, picking up a bag of exotic spices.

 

“Oh, no, not those,” Flayn immediately interceded, “Lady Rhea can’t stand spicy foods.”

 

"Wait, really?" 

 

"Yes, she also can't handle hot drinks and often has to wait for them to cool down," Flayn explained, hoping to guide Shez away from other such gifts. 

 

"Huh…well, maybe she just hasn't had the right type of spicy food!" She should have known that would be a fool’s errand.

 

“Er…I don’t think…”

 

“Maybe we could find a book on foreign lands?” Byleth offered, trying to turn her sister’s interest elsewhere.

 

"Well…that would probably be a better option," Flayn admitted, nodding along. 

 

"If you guys think so, okay," Shez said, shrugging as she put down the bag of spices. "Hm…this is trickier than I thought." 

 

"If nothing else, I'm sure she'd appreciate the thought behind the gift," Byleth reassured, taking the painting from the merchant who had wrapped it up in some paper. 

 

“Sure, sure, but I want her to appreciate more than just the thought, I want her to like the gift!” Shez insisted, “I just gotta come up with something cool…maybe I should make something?”

 

“Hm…like what?”

 

“Well…I kind of know how to carve things, so…oh, wait, just had an idea! You two keep doing your shopping, I’m gonna find some wood!” Shez declared before hurrying off, grinning at the brilliant idea she just had.

 

“…should we be concerned?” Flayn asked, feeling strangely worried.

 

“Probably,” Byleth admitted, “I’ll get a back-up gift for her, just in case.”

Rhea had to admit, she hadn’t expected much for her birthday. Few even knew that Saint Seiros Day was the date of her birth. The most she ever really received were “anonymous” presents sent by her cardinals, who really were too secretive for their own good sometimes.

 

Regardless, receiving an invitation from young Flayn to have dinner with “her family” was an unexpected yet sweet gesture, if one that sent a pang of loss through her heart as she couldn’t help but remember the days long lost where Mother had once hosted grand feasts for all her kin.

 

…She would have those days back soon enough. She just needed to be patient.

 

Those were her thoughts as she made her way to the Star Terrace, where young Flayn claimed to have set up something special. Dining under the stars did feel like a nice suggestion, a good change from typically taking her meals in her office, though as she stepped out onto the terrace, she couldn’t help but feel her eyes widen.

 

“Happy birthday!” called out the three young women standing in front of the dining table set up on the terrace, with notably more enthusiasm from Shez and Flayn though Byleth still gave it her best. Staring at the three, Rhea slowly turned to look at Seteth and Jeralt. 

 

The former had a small smile on his face while the latter looked like he wanted to be barrel deep in mead. 

 

"You know, I gotta say, it's surprising to hear that you're Flayn’s aunt. Though this means that Seteth was lying to me when I asked if you two were related!" Shez stated, catching Rhea off guard again. 

 

"It is an honorary title, and now is not the time," Seteth groaned, his smile turning into a frown. 

 

"Normally I'd disagree, but I won't right now, especially since the much more important thing about Rhea being our granny!" 

 

Rhea suddenly felt like she wanted to be barrel deep as well. Still, she was the archbishop, and she was very practiced at polite smiles as a result. “Thank you, children. This is a very sweet gesture. Though, what was that about me being a…'granny', as you put it?" 

 

"You can blame me for that, if you wish." Rhea really did want to blame Seteth. "I know it might have been better if you told her yourself, but…well, I believed that with everything that occurred, it would be best just to take the plunge and divulge the truth of your relation to Byleth." 

 

Rhea would always regard Seteth as a stalwart ally and companion, one who had proven himself time again to be one of the few people in the world she could consider a true friend. She also found herself mentally cursing him because damn it all, this was such an awkward conversation to have now.

 

It wasn’t lost on her that she was the one who told him that stupid lie to begin with, but still. “Well, while I suppose it is not exactly how I would have wished to convey this information, I suppose I must thank you for taking that step for me, Seteth, given how reluctant I was to take it for myself.”

 

“And why were you that ‘reluctant’?” Jeralt spoke up, regarding her with an expression she wasn’t quite able to decipher. It seemed vaguely disgruntled though.

 

“Perhaps that was a poor choice of words. I merely meant to say that…if I must admit it, I wasn’t sure how to explain, given the inevitable changes to our relationships there would be once I elaborated on my relation to Sitri.” It wasn’t completely a lie, so she could pretend it wasn’t an issue.

 

"...I will admit that it would have been difficult at the start of the year, but I've gotten to know you, Lady Rhea," Byleth said, looking up at the archbishop, "My mama trusted you greatly, and, even if I didn't know her, it's because of you two that I'm here. Even if we weren't related, I would still think of you as family at this point." 

 

"..." Rhea didn't know what to say. There was a strange feeling inside of her, one that twisted within her as she stared at the scar the young woman had on her face and the patch covering where her eye once was. “...thank you for that.”

 

“And that means you’re family to me too!” Shez declared with a big grin, prompting a huff from her sister.

 

“Shez, we were having a moment.”

 

“A moment that I am now a part of!” Shez stated as she hugged Byleth with one arm. "After all, as your big sister, it's important to have my approval as well!" 

 

"While I don't wish to interrupt, I will point out that the food will grow cold if we do not hurry." Seteth pointed out. 

 

"Oh right! Come on, I helped cook!" Shez said, guiding Rhea to one of the chairs. 

 

"You did?" 

 

"Shez is actually a really good cook," Byleth said, sitting down at the table, "Don't worry, I made sure she didn't make everything spicy." 

 

Rhea grimaced on reflex, before smoothing out her expression. “Do you have a fondness for spicy foods, Shez?”

 

“Eh, not really? I can eat just about anything and be fine with it. I just thought it would be good for you to try some since I heard you don’t like it!”

 

“...I fail to understand your logic.”

 

“Really? Well, here’s what I was thinking: If you don’t like one type of spicy food, maybe you’ll find something that you do like if you try a different type, you know?”

 

“Hm. I see. Please do not cook spicy foods for me in the future, I truly do not like the taste at all,” Rhea very bluntly stated.

 

“Oh, uh…yeah, alright, I guess. Uh, what kind of foods do you like?”

 

“Fish!” Flayn immediately suggested, earning an amused noise from Rhea.

 

“I suppose I do enjoy fish. Some meat dishes can be quite good too, though truthfully I prefer colder foods,” she mused, considering what dishes she preferred, “Ah, there were some lovely fruits where I grew up that I still adore the taste of…ah, but never mind that. I would be happy to enjoy a meal with all of you.”

 

And she genuinely did feel happy to sit down with those she would consider family, listening to the children chat as they ate. She didn't join in, but she couldn't help but smile as they spoke about their shopping earlier. Rhea wondered when was the last time she could enjoy such simple pleasures as these. 

 

Perhaps she'd be able to enjoy something like this even more once everything was right. 

 

"You know, it's really weird to think how much things have changed since the start of the year." Shez said aloud. 

 

"Hm? What do you mean by that?" Rhea asked in return. 

 

"Well you know, By and I weren't exactly happy about joining up here but…things actually turned out pretty nice. We have a bunch of friends now, and our little family has gotten bigger." 

 

Rhea felt herself frown. Because while that thought was a pleasant one, the fact that they hadn’t enjoyed being at the monastery at first…no, some wariness was excusable, they had been in a new place. She put her smile back up, allowing herself to dwell on those positive feelings instead of feeling that offense. “I am pleased to hear you have found a home here, Shez. The doors of the monastery, of course, will always be open to you and your family.’

 

“Aw, thanks Granny!”

 

Rhea paused. “...Rhea would be fine, child.”

 

“Really? But that doesn’t feel as familiar. How about Gram-Gram? Or Grammy? Or… Grarchbishop!”

 

“No. Especially not that last one.”

 

Shez nodded. “Grarchbishop Grammy Gram.”

 

“...” Rhea took a breath, because she was a calm individual in complete control of her emotions.

 

“Hm…what about Grarchbishop Grhea?” Flayn suggested, and Rhea felt her eye twitch as Byleth visibly smothered a giggle.

 

“Ooo, good one!”

 

"Rhea is still the Archbishop, so you should refer to her with proper respect," Seteth reminded. 

 

"Yes, I would prefer you keep that in mind. Regardless of our… relation, you should make sure not to refer to me as such in public. As the archbishop, having…a child is something that isn't really allowed." 

 

"Oh…" Byleth frowned. "That's sad." 

 

"...Is that why Sitri was an 'orphan' at the monastery?" Jeralt asked, speaking up for the first time. 

 

"...Yes. Though I cared for her deeply, I had to consider my position as well," Rhea explained with a deep frown on her face. It wasn't that far from the truth; she did truly consider Sitri, and all her preceding ‘sisters’, as her daughters. If she could have, she would have openly raised her as one, but… 

 

"Thank you, for taking care of my mom, Rhea," Byleth said as she gave Rhea a small smile. 

 

“Yeah, Missus Sitri sounded like a great lady. And I guess if she was your kid, you must be pretty good too," Shez piped in, "I mean, you might have to be pretty stern cause of the archbishop stuff, but I guess under all that, you're still Rhea, huh?" 

 

"..." Rhea couldn't help but stare at Shez, someone who was Agarthan in nature if not nurture, being one of the first people to view her as simply Rhea. Strangely…it felt nice. "Thank you, Shez. That means a great deal to me." 

 

"So can I call you Gram Gram-" 

 

"No." She ignored how the girl pouted. Still, the dinner was enjoyable, though the topic of conversation eventually turned towards Byleth’s intention to leave the monastery at the end of the year, which still didn’t sit right with Rhea for many obvious reasons.

 

Still, Byleth had her reasons. "Honestly, even if I wasn't going to be working in the Empire, I would have likely tried to find new employment because I'm almost out of money." 

 

"Excuse me?" Rhea asked, genuinely confused.

 

"Yeah, I haven't been getting any pay raises, so I've been having to use my own money to help pay for everything," Byleth explained, "I actually had to take some quick contracts to get a bit more gold." 

 

"...Why have you not been getting a raise?" 

 

Byleth brought up her hand as she began to list things off on her fingers, "The mock battle ended up being a mess, bringing back a bandit head on the first mission, leaving the mission early in Magdred before the knights gave the clear, the church was occupied with everything that happened in the mausoleum, I technically didn't even have a mission during Verdant Rain Moon, the church was busy again with everything involving the kidnapping, and apparently letting my student set the central pavilion on fire was not good," Byleth elaborated, "I think the mission against the Almyrans was the first time I actually managed to get a raise." 

 

"..." With every example, Rhea slowly turned her head to Seteth. 

 

"...To be clear, while I do hand out pay, I myself am not in charge of deciding the value of the payments. That is the cardinals’ duties," Seteth explained, completely throwing them under the carriage. 

 

"Do you need money right now, kid?" Jeralt asked.

 

"I'm good right now," 

 

"I see." Rhea nodded. "Byleth, how would you like a hundred thousand gold?" 

 

"R-Rhea!?"
