"Come now Seteth, let me at least spoil my…granddaughter," Rhea said, trying to hide the slight unease she felt at saying that, "Actually, how about a million gold?" 

 

The room went silent, and Rhea ignored the wide-eyed stares she was receiving.

 

"..." Shez raised her hand. "Do I get an allowance too?"

 

“It is not an allowance, it is payment for services rendered,” Rhea stated, “If you wish to be paid by the monastery, you would need to join as a staff member.”

 

“Hm…can I get a hundred thousand gold as my starting salary?”

 

“You will have to negotiate that with Seteth.”

 

“...hmph. And here I was, thinking you were my favorite grandma…”

 

Rhea blinked at that, then felt…strangely hurt? Before she shook it off and decided to change the subject. “Child…how have things been for you?”

 

"Oh, uh…" Shez shrugged. "Still weird knowing I'm apparently related to those weird people, but I'm doing better, at least." 

 

"Ah…you were friends with Emily, right Shez?" Flayn asked with a frown. 

 

"...Yeah, still not sure what to think about her leaving," Shez muttered, not wanting to talk about her meeting with Kronya. "Ah, actually, I wanted to ask, has anything happened over in Ordelia territory?" 

 

"Oh, well, we have yet to receive any reports, but I imagine the Alliance will be able to handle matters now that Emperor Edelgard has dealt with the former Duke Aegir,” Rhea replied, “I imagine we will send your class over to aid the assembled forces there. It would be good to get some experience in seeing what a siege situation would be like.”

 

“So you’re sending my kid into another war then,” Jeralt noted, making Rhea pause and grimace.

 

“I…I understand your trepidation, Jeralt, but I assure you–”

 

“You can’t assure me of anything,” he bluntly countered, “Byleth lost an eye under your watch, in your monastery. I don’t believe for a second that you can keep either of my kids safe when it counts.”

 

"Ah, papa–" 

 

"Byleth, I'm putting my foot down. You've had too many near death experiences this year, and I don't want Shez to be in a situation like that again either." 

 

"Hey, I can take care of myself! Besides, it's not like I'm going to go off by myself!" Shez insisted, making Byleth wince and Rhea frown.

 

“Shez, that isn’t appropriate.”

 

“Huh? Oh, right–Sorry By, I didn’t–”

 

“It’s okay, I know I did something stupid,” Byleth muttered, before sighing, “Ah, why don’t we just get back to the food? Everything tastes really good, so good work there.”

 

“Aw, thanks! Heh, though it’s a little funny to hear you praise me considering you helped out.”

 

“I didn’t do much.”

 

“Nah, you helped! And I appreciate it!”

 

“Perhaps I could help next time?” Flayn offered, earning immediate winces from Seteth and Shez.

 

“Oh, yeah, maybe? Uh…actually, hey, By, do you think you’d ever want to teach a cooking class?”

 

Byleth blinked at the suggestion, then looked thoughtful, plainly considering the idea. “Hm…that might be a fun idea, sure. You tend to cook more than I do though, and I’m not exactly used to cooking with only one eye. Would you like to be my assistant?”

 

“Sure! I’m up for that!”

 

Rhea found herself smiling again as the children continued to chat, planning out an entire lesson for the students. It really was a nice idea, something calm and cheerful to let them be happy. And the happiness continued as Rhea was given her gifts, a lovely assortment of items and…as odd as it looked, she couldn't help but find the oddly shaped wooden carving that Shez gave her adorable. It didn't look anything like a dragon, but she enjoyed it nonetheless. 

 

Still…the problem in Ordelia did need to be dealt with. Treachery couldn’t be allowed, not when the Agarthans were active and she was so, so close to finally getting her mother back…

 

She didn’t think Jeralt could see her thoughts, but he likely had some idea of them, given how his gaze never softened for the rest of the evening. And once dinner was done, she wasn’t surprised to hear him request to speak with her in his office. Privately, so of course she sent Seteth off to spend the evening with his daughter while encouraging Flayn to spend time with their ‘extended family’ for an added distraction.

 

“Is there an issue, Jeralt?” she began, trying to keep her tone cordial.

 

“You know there is, Rhea. I don’t care if Shez needs to be exempt from the rest of her class. I don’t want you sending her to a war field.”

 

“...Jeralt, Byleth’s injury–”

 

“I don’t want to hear it!” he interrupted, anger overriding what remaining fear he had of Rhea. The year had softened him towards her somewhat, but it also meant he was even less willing to put up with her shit, “Whatever you want to say, it won’t change the fact that someone who wanted to hurt my daughters got away with hiding in your clergy for almost a year! She kidnapped Shez, she maimed Byleth, what next? I know I trained them as mercenaries, I know I’ve put them in danger too, but damn it, I don’t want this kind of life for them! I was an idiot then, and I’d be even dumber now if I didn’t learn my damn lesson.

 

“So make the mission a cooking class or whatever. I just…I need them to be safe, Rhea.”

 

“...Jeralt, the world is a dangerous place. If people like Acheron are not dealt with, the damage they cause can spread,” she replied, keeping her tone even. A part of her wanted to shout back, to show her anger at being questioned at every turn from a man who ran away…but, at his core, Jeralt wanted his children to be safe. And she didn’t want to drive him away again. “If you truly feel so strongly, you could go with them.”

 

“No. I’m not doing that,” he responded, frowning, “I’m not leaving Byleth unguarded either. I…look, I can stay.”

 

Rhea paused. “What do you mean?”

 

“I mean what I said. I can stay here. You should know already that Byleth wants to strike out into the world on her own, go work in the empire for the emperor, and odds are, Shez will follow right along with her. So I’ll stay here. I’ll keep being the captain of the knights, I’ll keep fighting for you, and I’ll give my kids a good reason to come visit.” Jeralt sighed. “I’m sure you have some big idea that Byleth can be someone important in the church or be your new Sitri or whatever it is you’re thinking, but she’s her own person. She’s going to want to spread her wings sooner instead of later. All I’m offering is that I help make this place somewhere she’ll want to land every so often.”

 

“...” Rhea wasn’t sure if the flight metaphors were meant to imply something, but…would it really be such an issue to indulge Jeralt’s concerns? A part of her did want to argue, yet she could tell if she made any attempts to do so he would likely leave and take his daughters with him. And while she could stop him, she truly didn’t want to hurt her old friend. "...Very well, Jeralt, I'll see what I can do. For the time being, the students won't be on any missions this month."

 

“Thank you, Rhea.” The gratitude in his voice was so genuine, Rhea felt her heart waver again. Though, why should it? It wasn’t as though Byleth would be harmed, she was merely getting her memories back. She would know the truth, that she was Sothis, and things would be fine.

 

Things had to be fine. Byleth, Jeralt, even Shez, they would all be fine. One day…they might even thank her for fixing things.

 

Despite everything, Rhea didn’t sleep well that night.

Chapter End Notes

Red: Honestly, Rhea's a very fun character to write. She's such a mess! It's great!

Indi: It's fun to take a character apart and see just why they're like that and how things can go with them.

Red: I think it's why she keeps getting focused on in our stories. She's this core part of the narrative that doesn't gets explored as much, so it's interesting to work with her.

Indi: And we certainly are going to be showing some stuff with her in the coming chapters. Until, then hope you enjoy!

Interlude - The Tyrants of Ordelia

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

“Well well well, would you look at what we have here?” Lord Acheron Lethe Phlegethon smirked at the wayward woman who wandered onto his doorstep. Or, well, into his audience chamber. “To think, the apprentice of Lord Solon would come to visit. To what do I owe the pleasure?”

 

“…Odesse, why do you have a mustache?” Bias asked, an eyebrow raised as she took in the altered shape of her fellow Agarthan.

 

“Because it is an aspect of the character I have taken, obviously,” Odesse replied, curling one end of his mustache around his finger, “That, and I found it has grown on me.”

 

“…Shut up. Where’s Myson?”

 

“Lord Myson is quite busy–“

 

“Then tell him I’m here, toady, and I have information he’ll want to hear.”

 

“Ah–Wait, Lady Bias–“ Odesse paused as she left, then let out an annoyed huff. “Being around the beasts certainly hasn’t improved her manners.”

 

Moments later, after Bias found an empty lounge with comfy enough chairs to wait around in, the Agarthan sage glanced up to see her colleague enter with a smile on his bearded face. “Took you long enough.”

 

“It’s lovely to see you too, Bias,” Myson replied, her annoyance not affecting his mood in the slightest as he moved over to sit in the chair across from hers, “Would you like a drink?”

 

“What? No, I don’t want–“

 

“Come now, you should try some tea,” he spoke over her, gesturing with a hand for Odesse to enter with an already-prepared tea set, “You’re up on the surface, indulge a little.”

 

Bias glared at her fellow sage, though Myson hardly seemed to care as he poured himself a cup and took a sip. “So you’re going native now?”

 

“Mmm…Bias, have you ever considered what will happen to our people once we achieve our vengeance?”

 

The sage blinked. “What? What the hell kind of question is that?”

 

“An important one. One I doubt Thales or Solon ever truly considered.”

 

“…I didn’t expect to hear that from you. I always thought you were Thales’s right hand.”

 

“Oh I was. But Thales isn’t around, now is he? He’s been dead for years, and I’ve realized he had his own shortcomings. His goal was always to have revenge against the Fell Star and her abominations, but what would happen afterward? Would we content ourselves with slaying our age-old enemies? Would we happily live among the beasts? Would we slaughter every last one of them and continue on with a grand genocide of the entire world?

 

“It’s a question we have to ask and answer. And I’ve found I enjoy the idea of actually using this land properly. Why shouldn’t we rule a new Agartha as its true masters? Especially when it has turned out the beasts have some surprising uses…but I digress. You wanted to report to me? I doubt you would have abandoned your mission at the monastery if you didn’t have anything to say.”

 

Bias laughed, bitterly. “Believe me, I have plenty to say.”

 

And once she recounted her story, with maybe one or two details omitted for convenience, Bias was annoyed to see Myson frowning at her.

 

“So you didn’t bring Kronya with you?”

 

She blinked. “That’s the part you focus on? What, did you have plans for that brat?”

 

“It’s not really relevant now…hm. Actually, do you think you could pass for a convincing Flame Emperor?”

 

“…what?”

 

“Hm…ah, I’ll fill you in on the details later. For now, do you think Kronya has been burned as well?”

 

“Probably. The puppy isn’t exactly subtle. Who knows, maybe she managed to slay one or two of the beasts before getting killed?”

 

“Ah, that’s annoying…no, it’s fine, we can still make things work. It’s good to know the great sage truly is active in that vessel, though it’s unfortunate you failed to kill the Fell Star. Not unforgivable, but certainly unfortunate.”

 

“Hmph. So what’s your plan here?”

 

“In Ordelia? Acquiring materials and testing projects, obviously. The original Acheron provided us with a convenient opportunity to overtake a territory and use its resources as we see fit. The number of test subjects we’ve acquired is enormous compared to my previous policy of abducting travelers.” Myson grinned. “In a way, we managed to implement your late mentor’s plans on a grand scale. Instead of one village to use as a test bed, we have an entire county.”

 

“For as long as it lasts,” Bias noted, “Solon’s plan would have caught attention sooner or later, and probably would have blown our covers anyway, which is what I was actually asking. How are you planning to hold all the gains you’ve acquired?”

 

Right at that moment, the two sages heard a warhorn blow. Bias frowned, glancing in the direction of the sound, before she paused when she noticed the smile on Myson’s face.

 

“Well isn’t that convenient? As for your question, Bias, I wouldn’t put too much value in what ultimately amounts to testing grounds.” He smirked. “After all, I have far bigger prizes in mind.”

“I have to say, this whole event is proving to be quite the Ordeal-ia,” Alois commented as he looked out over the fields leading towards Castle Ordelia. The castle itself was an impressive sight, nestled as it was atop a large hill that would be quite the climb to get up to. Not quite as bad as if it had been set up in the mountains that belonged to these lands, but then, the Ordelia family presumably still wanted people to visit their castletown. “I wonder if the other Alliance nobles ever realized Ache-er-ron would be such a pain?”

 

“...Anyways,” Catherine said, ignoring him entirely in favor of focusing on the war map in front of her and Count Erwin Gloucester, the leader of the Alliance forces looking to reclaim Ordelia territory from the treacherous upstart that took it. “It looks like we’ll be in for a long siege here. From what our scouts reported, Acheron’s been upping taxes to insane levels in the time he’s been in charge, apparently hoarding as much food and gold as he can.”

 

“Hmph. Leaving aside the Weathervane’s greedy nature, I have to imagine even he realized he would need supplies if he wanted to last through any siege,” Erwin noted, frowning thoughtfully, “Depending on how full his food stores are, he could last for moons without having to meet us in battle.”

 

“So the best move is to break him before he can get too cozy. Shamir’s already scouting out the area, and she should be back soon. Well, assuming she didn’t decide to just put an arrow in Acheron to begin with.”

 

“Ha, that would certainly save us some trouble,” the count joked, before looking serious again, “As for breaking the siege, Count Ordelia was quite helpful on the front. He provided me with a great deal of information regarding his castle’s layout and the placement of its defenses, which should make any assaults go far easier.”

 

“Seriously? Wow, the Count must really trust you if he’s willing to give away big family secrets like that.”

 

Erwin smiled, though it was a rueful one. “Yes, my friend certainly has put a great deal of faith in me. To the point that he confided his only real interest in reclaiming his territory is for the sake of his daughter and his people. Given his own poor health, I imagine he thinks reclaiming the land is worth extending his trust.”

 

“I could see that, yeah,” Catherine agreed, nodding with a frown, “It’s still crazy to think about though. I know nobles in Faerghus that would sooner smash themselves against their own castle than let anyone else know about their defenses, even their own allies.”

 

“Then I suppose it’s a good thing Count Ordelia is willing to extend that trust to us. Now then–”

 

“Lord Gloucester!” 

 

Erwin paused as one of his guards ran up, a frown coming to his face. “Yes? Did something happen?”

 

“The gates opened, my lord! It seems Acheron is fielding his army!” the soldier reported, prompting blinks from Erwin and Catherine.

 

“He is? Why in the world…”

 

“Huh. Either he’s dumber than we thought, or he’s got something up his sleeve,” Catherine noted, walking over towards Alois, “Do you see anything out there?”

 

“Hm? Well I can’t say I was paying much attention to the castle until that young man shouted about how the enemy’s approaching, but yes, I do see many things,” the older knight replied, earning an eye roll from Catherine.

 

“Like what, Alois?”

 

“Like the fact that it doesn’t look like he has much of an army at all,” Alois pointed out, gesturing towards the fields in the distance.

 

And yeah, Catherine had to admit she was surprised by what she was seeing too. “Hang on…are there only twenty of them?”

 

Her eyes didn’t deceive her. The group of armored knights striding out from the outer gates of Castle Ordelia clearly only numbered twenty in total. They stood in four rows of five, lined up perfectly, and even from a distance, it was clear the black-armored knights were taller than average. That didn’t change the fact that there were twenty on their side and over a thousand on Catherine’s.

 

“Hm. Do you think they’re looking to challenge us to single combat?” Alois suggested.

 

“You think they’re looking to settle things with one fight?” Catherine asked, glancing at the senior knight, “Why send out more than one then?”

 

“It could be an attempt at intimidation. A way of saying ‘oh, look at us, we have scary knights on our side too!’ Or something like that.”

 

"Well I wouldn't put it like that, but whatever knights he does have are certainly quite large." Erwin pointed out, frowning as he looked at the armored knights. "I imagine they're likely men that the former Duke Aegir provided." 

 

"Yeah and they're basically sitting ducks out there right now," Catherine said as she looked over the field. 

 

"Even so, we should try to parley with him, shouldn’t we? Even if his forces won't amount to much, it would be best that we prevent any fighting," Alois suggested. 

 

“Perhaps. I’ll send one of my men to see what they want,” Erwin decided, moving to his troops to call out for a messenger.

 

“Well, I guess we’ll have to wait for this parley party to get off the ground then!” Alois crossed his arms over his chest, tilting his head in thought. “Hm…a parlarty? No, that’s too wordy…”

 

Catherine would have rolled her eyes at Alois’s antics under most circumstances, yet for some reason, she found herself staring at the group of knights. They stood tall on the field and strangely still. She could mistake them for statues if they hadn’t been moving earlier.

 

Imperial knights tended to use black armor, but this group’s equipment looked different. Something about the shade of black, deep and dark in a material that she vaguely recognized, and the horned helmets they wore, modeled like a goat’s head…

 

Catherine had always prided herself on a certain talent of hers, that being the ability to tell at a glance if someone had a crest, and what crest it could be. And something about these men looked wrong.

 

“...hey, Alois, maybe–” One of them looked at her. Straight at her. And then he was in front of her and she leapt back as an axe smashed into the dirt where she just stood.

 

“Wha–How in the–” Alois exclaimed, only to have to leap out of the way as another appeared and nearly smashed him with a brutal warhammer.

 

Thunderbrand was in Catherine’s hands in a second as she slashed back at the knight, her eyes going wide when she saw her pronged blade catch on the knight’s black shield.

 

“How the hell–” The shield shoved forward and she felt herself go skidding back, the force nearly sending her off her feet. She stumbled, but then the axe was coming down towards her head and she had to defend as best she could. 

 

Fast, he’s way too fast for a big bastard, how is he moving like this– Out of the corner of her eye, she saw the other knight vanish in a purple light, reappearing to smash his hammer into the shield Alois just barely brought up to save his chest from getting caved in. He still went flying, crashing hard on the ground, and Catherine scowled at the sight.

 

“You bastards have no idea who you’re going up against!” she yelled, before deflecting a blow from the knight’s axe, getting around his unprotected side and swinging straight for his neck. 

 

Thunderbrand, gleaming with the power her crest poured into it, sliced straight through the knight’s neck, cleaving through black steel and mail to separate his head from his body. The helmeted head sailed through the air, though Catherine was already moving, leaping over the map to strike at the hammer-wielder. The second knight took the blow on his own shield before trying to crush her with his weapon, entirely unbothered by the surprise attack and his comrade’s sudden death.

 

If nothing else, these pricks are well-disciplined, Catherine allowed, continuing her onslaught of strikes and slices while the knight weathered the storm, using his shield to block as best he could while still taking cuts that rent through parts of his armor. Ultimately, in a battle of attrition, Catherine would likely win just from the sheer damage she could put out.

 

At least, that would be the case if she didn’t feel an axe slam straight into her back.

 

For a moment, Catherine’s mind went back to that day, many, many years ago, when Lady Rhea had saved her life. The wound she had taken then felt similar, though as she laid on the ground, trying desperately to figure out just how broken her body was, she felt herself thinking that this one was likely worse. And Lady Rhea wasn’t here this time.

 

She could move, that much she put together, and it felt like her armor had taken the brunt of the blow, enough that she could live, even if it was painful to move. 

 

She could see the knights moving away, leaving her for dead, and she saw, plain as day, that the man–the thing she decapitated–walked away. Then her mind swam, her muscles straining as she tried to get up–

 

“Catherine! Oh thank the goddess you’re still alive–Here, we need to get you up!”

 

Firm hands pulled her up, arms supporting her as she blinked at Alois. “Ah…ah, all…”

 

Why isn’t my mouth working? My jaw hurts. Or…my tongue?

 

“You took a nasty hit there, but don’t worry, I have you! Can you walk?”

 

She could stand. Or, she thought she could. Her legs seemed to be obeying her but it was difficult to keep her feet.

 

“Don’t worry, I can get you to a healer but we need to move fast! These knights are far more dangerous than we–“

 

Alois went stiff. Catherine understood why, because through the ringing in her ears, she heard it.

 

The roaring and screeching of demonic beasts.

“To make things simpler, I’ve decided to classify the saurian ‘demonic beast’ types according to their variants with names I found appropriate,” Myson explained as he gestured out over the walls of Castle Ordelia, towards the burning camp in the distance, “The land-based saurians shall henceforth be known as Ladons while the flying variants shall be Delphons. As for my new creations, our remarkably effective knights shall be known as Tyrants.” He smiled, looking at Bias. “Fitting names, wouldn’t you agree?”

 

“...Well, you’ve sure been busy,” Bias replied, watching the devastation with disinterest. 

 

"For a scientist, I'm surprised at how disinterested you are in my creations. Or perhaps you've chosen to forsake your path?" Myson asked, as he looked back over the battle. 

 

"I have something else I wish to focus on. And they aren't here right now." 

 

"Right, the Fell Star. I must admit I am curious about what sort of body it must have. If it has the Crest Stone within it, acting as a heart, it must be quite the fascinating sight. Do their organs even work like the rest of the beasts? You've seen the Fell Star bleed, so something must pump blood within it, but is it possible to remove its heart while leaving it alive…?" 

 

“Hmph. Catch the Fell Star yourself if you want to vivisect her,” Bias replied, annoyed, “I intend to kill the bitch the next time I see her though, so you’d better act fast.”

 

“Why do we need to make it a competition? She dies either way. My decision would simply make it a more productive death than simple incineration. You can derive a surprising amount of use from crest-afflicted bodies.”

 

“...” Despite her annoyance, Bias found herself getting curious. “Such as?”

 

“Such as my Tyrants. You might have noticed they are a good deal larger than the average beast.” Myson grinned. “The King of Liberation turned out to be a useful template to work with. Why have just one vicious barbarian on your side when you can have two dozen? Sure they might not be as intelligent as a fully resurrected beast, but they serve their purpose. That being said, I'm sure we can make even greater weapons if she was captured alive.

 

His smile widened. “Think about it: an army of Fell Stars. Taking all of Fodlan would be as easy as crushing an ant. And what's to stop us from expanding from there? If we play our cards right, we can take over the entire world," Myson said, reaching his hand out, as if to grasp the horizon. 

 

“Why?” Bias asked, an eyebrow raised.

 

“Because we can. Because it is our right to.” He turned to her, smirking. “And if that is not enough to assure your loyalty, then allow me to make another offer.” He held up a hand, fingers splayed. “Five years of service, and I will bring your sister back to life.”

 

There were few things at this point in her life that could shake Bias, not when she had allowed the fury inside of her to consume her every moment. Yet, for a moment, that fury flickered. “...what?”

 

“You heard me.” He continued to smirk, folding his arms behind his back.

 

“...how would…she’d been crushed. She had been completely buried, there wasn’t–”

 

“There were still remains. If even the barest scrap of flesh remained, then we have a chance, don’t we?”

 

“...th-that…”

 

“Think about it,” he said, turning his gaze back towards the devastation his creations were unleashing, “Oh, and before you ask, yes, I could do the same for Thales. I don’t have a reason to though. So if you want me to take an interest in this project…you would have to give me a reason.”

 

“...” Bias stared at her fellow sage, her hands starting to tremble at her sides. The thought of having Pittacus back…For so long, she just wanted vengeance. But if she could have her back…

 

A movement out of the corner of her eye caught her attention, and, in a sudden movement, Bias moved between Myson and the arrow that was about to pierce his back. It stabbed through her hand, making her grit her teeth, before she glared straight at the filthy rat that dared try to ruin her chance.

 

That Dagdan bitch caught her eyes for barely a second before the archer started moving, looking to escape while Bias snarled in fury and unleashed a flame that scorched a massive part of the ramparts, earning a small smile from Myson as he turned to watch.

 

Even if it had been bought, loyalty was a beautiful thing. 

 

As the screams and the roars of the battlefield continued, Myson enjoyed his victory. It would be the first of many. 

Chapter End Notes

Red: And so we see how things went in Ordelia. Not well, obviously.

Indi: Turns out things go bad without the protagonists there.

Red: Clearly Rhea was right and she absolutely should've sent Shez and Byleth to handle things.

Indi: Or maybe things would have been worse if they were there. checks our original draft.

Red: Shhhh, no telling.

A Dark Shadow over the Monastery

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Silently staring out over Garreg Mach, Shez took note of all the students wandering around. All of them, going about their days, trying to act as if nothing was wrong. As if their peaceful everyday lives would remain forever… if they knew what she knew… the knowledge she was cursed with- 

 

"Shez! What are you doing up there!?" Letting out a small yelp, Shez almost went tumbling off the building she was brooding on when she heard Dimitri yell up at her. "You're going to hurt yourself, get down!" 

 

"No! I'm up here for a reason!" 

 

"...Why are you wearing a cloak?" 

 

"Because I'm brooding!" 

 

"...I'm going to get Captain Jeralt!" 

 

"He can't do anything about this! And besides, I’m fine! I can warp if I fall! So ha!”

 

“Then I'll get Professor Byleth!”

 

“Don’t be a snitch!” Shez yelled back, only to pause as she heard the flap of pegasus wings.

 

"Excuse me, young lady, but students aren't allowed on rooftops. Please come with me, or I will have to take disciplinary actions." Frowning heavily, Shez refused to look at the pegasus knight as she got on the flying steed with her. Moments later, she was on the ground, with her cloak confiscated. 

 

"You better give that back!" 

 

"You'll get this back when we aren't dealing with crazed cultists," the knight responded before flying off. 

 

"...so, what exactly happened?" Dimitri cautiously asked. 

 

"Just… thinking about stuff," Shez responded, "Sorry for yelling at you." 

 

"It's okay, I just want to make sure you don't get hurt. Even if you are a part of the Golden Deer now, you were a member of the Blue Lions." 

 

"...Thanks. I might have just been… trying to deal with some stuff by acting like it was a story, you know?" 

 

"Not particularly. I've never been one for leisurely reading if I'm honest." 

 

"...You know, I'm not surprised," Shez responded, before actually thinking about what she said. "Was that rude?" 

 

"No, it's how it is in Faerghus. We don't look down upon reading, but there's a far bigger focus on training when we're younger. So, at the very least for me, most of my reading usually only involves schoolwork, or reports on what's happening in the kingdom." 

 

"...Huh." 

 

"So, do you want to talk about what brought you up there?" 

 

“Ah, well…you heard about what happened in Ordelia, right?”

 

"...Yes, the knights suffered heavy losses and were forced to retreat, weren't they?" Dimitri asked, frowning as he remembered the details he had heard. "To think a force nearly a thousand strong ended up losing." 

 

"Yeah. We don't even know who made it out or not since the knights got separated," Shez muttered, scratching the back of her head, "I don't like Catherine, but I don't want to hear she or Shamir ended up dying in some random battle, and dad would get pretty sad if Alois is dead." 

 

"Yes, it would be a devastating blow to lose any of them. I just hope the knights who retreated to Gloucester territory are able to return soon enough." 

 

Shez made a noise of agreement, before pausing when she saw Lysithea storming on by, a bag on her back. "Uh, excuse me Dimitri, I gotta check something." Jogging off before Dimitri could say anything, Shez moved in front of Lysithea before she could get to the monastery gates. "Woah, where are you going?" 

 

"To Ordelia territory!" the diminutive mage said, already a bit out of breath from the large bag she was carrying. "Now get out of my way!" 

 

"H-Hey now, you can't just go off to Ordelia by yourself!" Shez insisted, moving in front of the mage again. "We don't even know how many men Acheron has left!" 

 

“That doesn’t matter! I need to fix things!”

 

“How?? You’re one person and they beat a whole army!”

 

"That doesn't mean I shouldn't try!" 

 

"Yes it does, you could die!"

 

"So what?!" Lysithea shouted, trying to push past her again. "I was already prepared to!" 

 

Frowning, Shez grabbed her, before warping away and ending up in front of the noble’s room. "Alright, we need to talk." 

 

"What the hell is your problem!?" 

 

"What's my problem? You're the one going off into a death trap!" 

 

"That's because I want to make sure my parents are okay!" Lysithea shouted, frustrated tears starting to sting her eyes. "I was already prepared to die anyways!"

 

Shez winced, but put her hands back on Lysithea’s shoulders, holding her in place. “Your parents are okay. Count Gloucester has them at his house, right?”

 

“And he might be dead now! What do you think is going to happen to them if he isn’t around, huh?!”

 

“Probably nothing! If they’re still in his castle, nobody can get to them! That’s why castles have walls! And…and moats! Don’t they have a moat?”

 

"That doesn't keep people out forever," Lysithea grumbled, frowning as she glared at the floor. 

 

"Well yeah, but it'll keep them safe for now! I mean, your parents probably want you to be safe too, right? Especially since…" Shez frowned. She still felt a bad taste in her mouth at the thought of Edelgard, but she could shrug that off for the moment. "You'll be going to the Empire to get better, right?"

 

“...No. No, I’m not going to."

 

"What? Why not?" 

 

"Because I don't want to give them false hope. I don't even know if this will actually fix me, so if it doesn't work, I don't want to break their hearts. As far as they're aware, I'm just going to the Empire to study some more."

 

“...” Shez sighed. “Okay, Lysithea, this is awkward for me to say because I had a whole thing with Edelgard and I got mad and I still feel weird about it because of how I got angry–My point is! Even though I’m mad at Edelgard, I want you to get better. And I think going to the Empire is your best shot at getting better. They have the resources to help you and Edelgard has the same problem you have, so at least you know she’s on your side.”

 

"So I'm just supposed to stand by and not do anything for my parents?" 

 

"Look, you know what By has been through lately. Dad…he hasn't been taking it well. I don't even want to know how he'd react if she actually did die," Shez said, feeling her throat tighten up a bit, "Even if your parents think you're dying, they don't want you to die before them." 

 

"...Then what am I supposed to do?" 

 

“Ah…well, we can’t just go to Ordelia to fight Acheron. And school’s…kind of weird right now? We could try hanging out with everyone, but I feel like you actually want to do something instead of just hanging out…though we could make something sweet?” She tilted her head, thinking. “Hm…alright, for today, you and I are gonna hang out.”

 

“What? You just said–”

 

“Yeah, I know, but this is different! We’re gonna find stuff to do! Maybe we cook, maybe we read some tomes, maybe we explore the secrets of the monastery! Either way, it’s gonna be just you and me, doing stuff! Okay?”

 

"N-No? I'm not just going to–" Before Lysithea could finish arguing, Shez grabbed her hand, dragging her along to the dining hall, preparing for the day with some sweets at the dining hall. Specifically the Shez started to bake some, with Lysithea half-heartedly joining in. It was a start, if nothing else. 

 

"So, any idea on how graduation is supposed to go?" Shez asked, glancing down at her friend. 

 

"It's apparently a small ceremony before we get sent back home. Nothing that fancy, really," Lysithea muttered, stirring a bowl. 

 

"Huh…well that's lame. We've been doing this for an entire year and we don't even get a big party?" 

 

"It's still a monastery. As far as I'm aware, we're free to do whatever we want as we prepare to go home." 

 

"...so we could throw a party ourselves." 

 

"I am fairly certain you'll get in trouble if you do anything that gets out of hand." 

 

"Still something to consider." 

 

"No it isn't."

 

"Agree to disagree."

 

Lysithea let out an annoyed huff, before looking away, pausing as she saw Dorothea and Byleth chatting together in a corner of the dining hall. "Huh, the professor and Dorothea have been pretty close lately." 

 

"Oh right, uh…can you keep a secret?" Shez asked, getting Lysithea to cock an eyebrow. "Right." 

 

Leaning down, she whispered into her ear. "They're what!?" 

 

"N-Not so loud!" Shez said, trying to shush her, as she glanced over at the other pair. She stiffened for a moment when she saw them looking over for a few seconds, before going back to chatting. 

 

"Since when have they been…" Lysithea gestured with her hands, unsure of what to say. 

 

"A week or two? I think?" Shez said, shrugging her shoulders. "I'm not sure on the specifics. Like, yes, I like teasing my sister over her having a crush on someone, but now that she's actually dating someone it feels weird, you know?" 

 

“...not exactly.”

 

“Oh, right, you, uh…Yeah, I’m gonna stop talking,” Shez decided…though she decided against it a second later. “Seriously though, you get it, right? It feels weird having her be all lovey dovey.”

 

“Why would it be weird?” Lysithea asked, wondering how exactly her smiling a bit more than usual was lovey dovey. 

 

“I…don’t know? It’s like…I dunno. It’s a change, I guess.”

 

“...It sounds like you’re worried someone is going to take your sister away from you.”

 

“What? No, that’s not…That’d be weird.”

 

“Would it? She almost died–She was hurt badly recently,” Lysithea corrected herself after noticing Shez flinch, “It would make sense if you were feeling protective right now.”

 

“...maybe. Yeah, that might be it.” For some reason though, that didn’t feel right to her. And as Shez let her mind dwell on the issue, she couldn’t help but remember the hurt she felt when her sister told her she’d gone to Edelgard instead of her. “...so, uh, you got something else to talk about? Something different?”

 

"Well…have you been keeping up with your studies?" 

 

"Oh, totally! Things have been busy, but I've been making sure to read my tome before I go to sleep," Shez said, before laughing, "Though sometimes it just makes me go to sleep faster." 

 

"Of course.” Lysithea rolled her eyes. "It's a miracle you haven't somehow failed the year already." 

 

"Hey come on, I'm not that dumb. Besides, Balthus would probably fail before I did, and he already went to the academy!" Shez huffed in response, "Heck, I know I'm smarter than Kronya at least." 

 

"Who’s Kronya?" At the question, Shez stiffened. 

 

"Oh, well, you know she's…an old cat I had. Cause you know…Nya." 

 

"...So you're bragging about being smarter than a cat?" 

 

“...Yes.”

 

The look Lysithea gave Shez was one of confusion mixed with pity. “...If it’s any consolation, I would have said you were smarter than Emily.”

 

“Oh hey, that’s what–Wait, you said that weirdly. Why the emphasis on ‘would have’?”

 

“Well it was before I learned your bar for intelligence was a cat.” 

 

“Hey, cats are smart! I've seen them open doors." Despite her ironclad argument, Shez saw Lysithea stare at her with complete pity. “...hmph. Cats are definitely smart.”

 

“That’s not what I’m–Shez, your measure for intelligence is being smarter than a cat. Cats can be smart, sure, but I have seen more of them bump into doors than open doors.”

 

“...HEY BYLETH!” Shez shouted, catching her sister’s attention, “CATS ARE SMART, RIGHT?”

 

“THEY’RE NOT SMARTER THAN PEOPLE,” Byleth shouted back, before returning to her conversation with Dorothea.

 

“...feh. Let’s just bake stuff.”

 

Rolling her eyes again, Lysithea focused back on preparing the food, putting more effort into it now, which prompted a smile from Shez when she saw her friend no longer feeling so down. Sure, she might have humiliated herself there but it still worked! 

"So, what are we working on now?" Shez asked, glancing over the tomes she and Lysithea had. 

 

"I've actually been studying faith magic recently. Specifically I've been trying to get a handle on warp." 

 

"Huh? But I can just warp whenever, so why do you need to learn it?" 

 

"It's not like we're going to be by each other all the time. Besides, even if we are by each other, you might run out of energy to do that, right?" Lysithea said as she focused at the tome. 

 

“Uh…huh, I guess so, yeah.” Shez tilted her head, thinking. “Hm…hey do you think there’s a difference between my warp and the other warp? Like, mine is all shadowy but the other one is all lighty, so…yeah.”

 

“...are you just trying to make conversation right now?”

 

“Ah, mostly? But I also am kind of curious.”

 

Lysithea sighed before closing her book. "Well, from the outside your warp definitely has some advantages. You can use it on yourself and one other to travel great distances as long as you can visualize the location, correct?" At Shez’s nod, she continued. "You even seem to be able to warp short distances continuously, something warp isn't really used for. However, you can't send someone without sending yourself." 

 

"And? That doesn't seem like a downside." 

 

"It could be. Let's say you're covering an important location, but someone asks you to warp them elsewhere. What happens if, once you go with them, you realize you're out of long distance warps? Suddenly that place you were covering is missing a strong warrior." 

 

“Huh. That’s…a good point. Hm…I wonder if I can learn the other type of warp…”

 

“Why would you want–No, I can see how you came to that idea. I don’t think you should though, it might interfere with your usual magic. Come to think of it, don’t you have issues with faith magic?”

 

“Eh…I wouldn’t say I have issues with it, it just doesn’t come as easy to me as reason magic.” Shez shrugged with a frown. "It's like…it feels like it takes twice as much focus to cast a faith spell than it does a reason spell. As it stands I'm already a better swordsman than mage, so I haven't been putting as much effort in it as I do with reason." 

 

"Hm, I suppose I can understand your reasoning. It's better to focus on what you're skilled at than what you're not." 

 

"Yeah, exactly. I mean, I doubt you'd ever go around wearing heavy armor." 

 

Lysithea grimaced. “No, I don’t think I ever would. It would get in the way of my focus, and I doubt I'll be able to float with it on." 

 

"Wait what?" Shez asked, blinking in surprise. 

 

"Some mages, when they reach a high enough level, can use magic to move around in the air." 

 

"...You can fly?" Shez said, a mixture of awe and jealousy in her voice. 

 

“Not at the moment, no, but perhaps one day. And it’s not exactly like unassisted flight, I would still have to remain close enough to the ground or else I would plummet.”

 

“Still, that sounds really cool…”

 

“Can’t you fly already? You turn into that small ball of shadow.”

 

“Well that’s not…huh. Does that count? I don’t think that counts.” Shez pursed her lips in thought. "...Would I look cool with wings?" 

 

"Why is that your question?" 

 

"Because things with wings can fly, so I want to know if I could look cool with them." 

 

"I…suppose? I don't even know how that would work…" Lysithea said, before shaking her head. "Is there anything else you want to talk about, or can we focus on studying?" 

 

"Um…oh, it's your birthday at the end of the month, yeah?" 

 

"...Yes, what about it?" 

 

"Well, I was thinking we can do something big! I mean, it'll be the last party of the school year right?" Shez asked, before pausing. "Wait no, Ignatz's birthday is next month, but that's when everyone is leaving…maybe we try celebrating his early?" 

 

"So we don't need to do anything for my birthday." 

 

"What? No, we still are. I mean, even if it's just us two, we should still celebrate. In fact, what do you wanna do? It'll be my treat." 

 

"I would prefer to have a quiet day studying." 

 

“Are you sure? Actually, wait, what would you be studying for? We don’t have anything big at the end of the year…do we?”

 

“Shez, if I’m going to stay here instead of going to fight the people holding my family's territory, I need to at least spend that time studying what knowledge the monastery can provide for me. I don’t know if there’s anything that can help me with my condition here, but it won’t hurt to look, now will it?”

 

“Oh, okay, that makes sense…Oh, wait, I know what we can do!”

 

Lysithea sighed. “Shez, I’m not interested if it’s anything other than studying magic. At least, right now. We could maybe get more sweets later…”

 

“Then that’s great, because it totally is about studying magic! There’s a whole forbidden library down in Abyss!”

 

“...ah. Right. Abyss. The…dark, underground city filled with ghost knights…”

 

“What? No there's no ghosts….I think. They might have been magical but I'm pretty sure they weren't ghosts." 

 

“That’s not at all what I heard! There were ghost knights and golems and someone turned into a monster–”

 

“Okay, no, that last one definitely didn’t happen, I would remember that part. Some demonic beasts showed up, but pretty sure no one turned into one." Shez smiled at her. "Besides, even if ghosts showed up, I'll make sure to protect you!" 

 

"And how exactly are you going to fight a ghost?" Arval asked, which Shez didn't answer to avoid freaking out her friend. 

 

“H-Hm…well, I suppose you’re not the worst bodyguard to have,” Lysithea admitted, before sighing, “Fine, I guess we can try it. But I reserve the right to say I told you so if we have to deal with any angry ghosts!”

 

“Heh, don’t worry! Like I said, I’ll take care of everything!”

"Alright, here we go!" Shez stated, smiling as she and Lysithea walked around Abyss. 

 

"H-Hm…it's certainly much larger than I expected." 

 

"Yeah, and this is only where the people are living. There's plenty of tunnels and stuff hidden down here. Though we don't need to go down there, since we mainly wanted to see the town." 

 

"Right…well what exactly is down here?" 

 

"Well, there's the library like I said, and there's also a scrap pile where a bunch of old gear gets thrown. Leonie comes down here every now and then to see if she can find stuff I think. Oh, and there's also the wayseer." 

 

"A wayseer?" 

 

"Yeah, she can apparently tell how close people are," Shez said, before blinking as she remembered what she heard when she was down here the first time. "N-Not that it's accurate. I mean, how exactly can she tell that when she's down here?" 

 

“Probably through magic,” Lysithea pointed out, her voice deadpan.

 

“Well, yeah, but magic is things like throwing fire or ice, not seeing who people are in love with–Or, uh, not in love with, I think, just…close? With…emotions. And stuff.”

 

“...Shez, magic is capable of doing much more than just throwing around elements. Have you paid attention in class at all?” She paused. “Then again, the majority of magic taught in class is combat-related…”

 

"Yeah exactly! And besides, when I was a mercenary, it was all about combat magic. I overheard Constance doing something with tea being all rainbow-y but that's not really something I'll use." 

 

"Fine. So what else is there down here?" 

 

"Oh, there's like, a statue from Dagda? Apparently it's a goddess of fate or something?"

 

"What?"

 

“Yeah, right over there.” Shez pointed at the statue in question, which indeed portrayed a large, winged being, hooded and cloaked. “I think you can make offerings to her?”

 

“...Yes, I imagine you can make offerings to a statue of a goddess. Why would you want to though?”

 

“Uh…well, hey, why not? Maybe she’ll do something nice for us?”

 

Lysithea scoffed. “Our goddess never did…”

 

"Yeah, well, even more reason to give an offering to someone else, cause screw her." 

 

"Shez, I don't think you can say that." 

 

"Yeah? Well what's she going to do? She hasn't done anything nice for us," Shez said, smiling at Lysithea before dragging her off to the statue. 

 

“Ugh…what do you even plan to give her?" 

 

"Um…" Shez began to pat her pockets, before pausing and pulling out a small bag of cookies. "Ha! Still had some left over. Come on we both made them so we should both try praying." 

 

"You're the one– Oh fine, whatever," Lysithea huffed as Shez put the bag in front of the goddess of fate, before the two clasps their hand in a small prayer. 

 

I hope nothing changes, Shez thought to herself, before nodding after a few moments. 

 

"Alright, that should be good." 

 

"Can we go to the library now?" 

 

"Yeah, sure thing–" Shez blinked, hearing a small tink as her hair suddenly fell in front of her eye. Looking down, she saw her hairclip on the ground, having somehow snapped. "Aw dang it, can't believe it broke." 

 

"What exactly broke?" Lysithea asked as Shez crouched down. 

 

"A hairclip By gave me, it was actually the first gift she gave me," Shez huffed, looking at it in her hand, "I know I've had it for a long time, but I didn't think it'd just break like that." 

 

“...hm. I…hm.”

 

“Hm? What’s up?” she asked, glancing curiously at Lysithea, who was frowning.

 

“...You said this goddess is from Dagda, right?”

 

“Yeah? What about it?”

 

“...It’s probably nothing. I just…It’s a shame Shamir isn’t here right now.”

 

“Ah, yeah, it is. She’s always been cool. Not sure what she sees in Catherine, but…hey, they’re probably fine. I wouldn’t worry about them, they can handle themselves.”

 

Lysithea huffed. “I wasn’t worried.”

 

"In that case, why don't we go to the library?" Shez asked, putting away her hair clip. "Though, fair warning, not all of it is magic stuff." 

 

“Why would you mention that? I’m only interested in the magic books, I wouldn’t bother reading the rest of them.”

 

“Well sure, but there’s plenty of fun stuff in some of the banned books. A few of them are some pretty raunchy romance novels.”

 

“That–Why would I be interested in that?!”

 

“Well some of them are pretty good. You can skip over the pervy parts if you want to–”

 

“Shez, just…help me find books I’ll actually want to read, please. And no romance books!”

 

“Okay, okay,” Shez agreed, smiling a little as she followed her fuming friend.

 

And behind her, the altar to Dagda’s Goddess of Fate stayed as still as it always did, an unmoving statue far from home and uncared for by those above. None noticed when what had to be a trace of cave water dripped down its cheek, for a statue could not mourn the fate of those who gave it offerings.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: A normal day with Shez and Lysithea with absolutely nothing weird going on.

Red: Yup! Just two girls, hanging out! Just for fun!

Indi: Baking treats, reading books, making offering to pagan gods. As one does.

A New Day for Old Enemies

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

“Do try to keep up,” Myson, current Sage of Thunder and one of the remaining leaders of the Agarthan people, chided, not sparing a single glance back as his technical equal Bias followed him up a well-worn road crossing through the plains of Faerghus, “You’ve been out in the field for close to a year now, you should be used to physical activity.”

 

“Well forgive me for having trouble with these shitty roads,” Bias growled out, glaring at her annoyingly fit colleague. Her feet ached, but she kept up her pace anyway, unwilling to give him the satisfaction of falling behind. 

 

“I would believe you if you weren’t stumbling with every step,” the warlock taunted, his arms folded behind his back as he strode along the barren road.

 

“I wouldn’t be stumbling if we just warped to the meeting point.”

 

“But then I wouldn’t be able to listen to your struggles. Would you really deprive me of such a lovely sound?”

 

Bias grunted but kept quiet. There was no need to give the bastard any sense of satisfaction.

 

Still, she couldn’t help but comment when she actually saw where they were meeting. “Did that bitch really bring a tent out here?”

 

Calling it a tent felt like an understatement. It looked like some kind of royal war tent, big and boxy and all in Faerghus blue.

 

“Ha! Someone’s enjoying her position,” Myson commented, audibly amused as he walked towards the tent’s entrance, which was guarded by a pair of armored knights in azure plate wielding Agarthan spears. 

 

The pair nodded at Myson before one of them opened up the tent flap to let them in.

 

“Ah, Myson and Bias! My, what a reunion this is turning out to be~!” Cleobulus was wearing her guise, the skin of some overly impressive hedge mage that conned her way into court through curing a plague or some shit. Bias couldn’t care less, though she also couldn’t help but notice Cleo’s tits were massive now. She could have sworn the bitch had smaller honkers the last time she saw her… “All of the remaining sages, in one place.”

 

“Cleobulus, Chilon,” Myson greeted, nodding to her and him in turn, “It really is quite the reunion. To think our number was reduced so far…but alas, it seems to be how things go sometimes. Random chance took two of us, and the treachery of beasts took a third.” He clapped a hand to Bias’s shoulder in a parody of a consoling gesture. “And poor Bias nearly lost an eye preventing my own assassination. How fortunate I am to have her by my side.”

 

“Oh? You two seem close,” Cleobulus commented, smirking as Bias glowered at her and pushed Myson’s hand off her shoulder, “Heh. No need to be shy, dear. You can share your interests with us.”

 

“...can we get on with it?” Bias requested, earning a titter from Cleobulus.

 

“There’s no need to rush, Bias. Why not regale us with the tale? I am curious as to why your hand is bandaged.” Cleobulus smiled, no hint of concern in her voice, only sadistic interest.

 

“She took an arrow through it,” Myson explained, “A knight of the church decided to take a shot at me and Bias chased her off.”

 

“Chase her off? Why didn’t she kill the beast?” Chilon asked, his voice reverberating in his helmet. Bias sneered at the lummox, but if it bothered him, it didn’t show. Which was probably why the prick always wore heavy armor like that. He probably had the worst poker face otherwise…

 

“The bitch was faster than I thought,” Bias answered, “Does it matter? The beasts can’t do anything even if she overheard us. We didn’t talk about anything important.”

 

“I consider my projects quite important,” Myson commented.

 

“No one cares.”

 

“Heh, no need to be rude to hide your affections, Bias,” Cleobulus teased, her smile mocking, “And how have things gone for you lately, hm? I could have sworn you were supposed to still be at the monastery.”

 

“I was, but I saw a chance to kill the Fell Star and took it.”

 

“Ah, so the Fell Star does walk among us again…though I can’t imagine you succeeded.”

 

“I cost her an eye, at least.”

 

“Ooo, that is impressive. Probably doesn’t mean much in the long run, but I suppose allowances can be made for you abandoning your post since you wounded our greatest enemy in the process.”

 

“Hmph. I would not make such an allowance,” Chilon complained, plainly glaring Bias.

 

“Yes yes, your adherence to protocol is very inspiring, now let the adults talk,” Cleobulus dismissed, “So, the Fell Star returned and is maimed at our own flame sage’s hands. Excellent news, though it doesn’t mean we’re anywhere near done yet. So now the question becomes, what shall we, the wayward children of our lost land, do now?”

 

“Isn’t it obvious?” Chilon questioned, “We’ll slaughter those abominations and their ilk in the church and reclaim our homeland from the beasts that populate it.”

 

Myson sighed. “Yes, we all know that part. The question Cleobulus is asking is how we are going to go about it, right?”

 

“Correct,” Cleobulus purred, smirking, “I have a good thing going right now in Faerghus. A force of beasts under my authority, a ‘king’ that will follow his leash so long as it is in my hand, and a hapless populace I can abuse at my leisure~ Should I expect to use this all for the sake of Agartha as a whole, or are we going to have issues, Myson?”

 

The warlock simply smiled, before placing a hand on his chest and bowing deeply. “I do not foresee any issues between us, Agastya.”

 

Chilon stiffened while Cleobulus smiled. “Oh ho! I do like a man who knows his place, Myson~ I am surprised you’re so willing to give up your authority though.”

 

“As far as I am concerned, authority means little when it comes to the success of our people. Victory or defeat shall lie with you, our glorious leader, while I will content myself with my own projects.” His smile widened as he straightened. “So long as I am allowed to experiment as I wish, you have my full support.”

 

“Hmm…then, as thanks for that, perhaps I could offer some new stock for those experiments~? The people of Faerghus should have different constitutions, when compared to those of Adrestia and Leicester.”

 

“I would be very pleased with that, Agastya Cleobulus.”

 

“...That title is not official,” Chilon bit out, clearly aggravated and getting all the angrier when Bias scoffed.

 

“Seriously? The leaders of Agartha are all gathered in this one place. If we choose one of our number to be the new Agastya, then it’s as official as it gets,” she complained.

 

“Should I take that as a sign of your support?” Cleobulus inquired with another smirk.

 

“You might as well. I can’t say I give much of a shit. I have a deal with Myson anyway, so his interests are my interests, as long as he upholds his end.”

 

“And you have my oath that I will,” Myson stated with a smile.

 

“Good. So long as you keep up your deal, and I get to kill the Fell Star, we won’t have any issues.” Bias paused, then ignored an irritated noise from Chilon before she continued. “Speaking of our ‘age old enemy’, I should mention she has a sister.”

 

“What?!” Chilon exclaimed, “You mean there are two of them!?”

 

“No, idiot. She adopted a girl that was once one of our experiments," Bias explained, "Solon thought the brat was a failure, but it turns out he was wrong." 

 

“Ah, the source of the samples then,” Myson noted, amused.

 

“What samples?” Cleobulus asked, somewhat annoyed to be out of the loop. 

 

"Samples of a project that was meant to house the power of Epimenides, though it appears that isn’t quite what happened. Or, to be clear, it seems our wayward experiment gained more than merely his power.” Myson smirked. “She's the vessel of the great sage." 

 

The tent went silent, before Cleobulus laughed outright. “Haha! Good gods long dead, the fates really do have the most baffling senses of humor~!”

 

“This isn’t funny!” Chilon snapped, “Are you serious?! The great sage Epimenides is trapped in the body of some wayward failure?!”

 

“She’s clearly not a failure if she’s his vessel,” Myson pointed out.

 

“Not a failure at all if that’s the metric,” Bias added, “Though it doesn’t seem to be a complete reincarnation. The sage was possessing her when he spoke to me.”

 

“Oh? This is new information.”

 

“Don’t expect anything special. He taught me the spell of Zahras so I could deal with the Fell Star, nothing more.” Well, that and a few things she was keeping back in case they came in handy.

 

“So he’d be willing to help us?” Cleobulus asked, curious.

 

“You can’t be serious!” Chilon snapped, angered, “Even if the sage possesses that filth, the fact that it dared to call the Fell Star kin makes it a disgusting failure!” His voice lowered in a mix of disgust and contempt. “And failures are to be disposed of.”

 

“You really know how to bring down the mood,” Cleobulus complained, before glancing at Myson and Bias, “So? Can the little doll be recruited?”

 

“I doubt it,” Bias answered, “The mutt loves the Fell Star. She’ll hate me at the very least, though I doubt giving her my head will bring her to our side.”

 

“Please, as though we’d want that thing anyway,” Myson scoffed, “Even if the vessel is perfect, splattering it with paint will mar it all the same. Better I just make a clean version while we dispose of the wretch.”

 

“Would your ‘clean version’ also hold the mind of Epimenides?” Cleobulus questioned, audibly interested in the idea.

 

“I don’t see why it can’t. If it was done once, it can be done again.”

 

Cleobulus nodded before sitting back with a smirk. “Then so shall it be~. We kill the wayward child and make a better vessel! In fact…let’s see if we can use her corpse to help things along.”

 

“We’re going after her then?” Bias asked.

 

In response, she received a smirk. “Not just her, my adorably aggressive sage~ We’re going to put that entire monastery to the pyre! So I hope you can help with that, Sage of Fire~.”

 

“...Why did you rhyme that?”

 

“Because I wanted to. Speaking of sages, we’ve been missing a few positions lately, and it’s about time we fill them out.” She smiled, pretending to be sweet. “So, do we have any recommendations~?”

 

“Odesse has always been dutiful. We can make him the new Sage of Wind to fill out an empty spot,” Myson recommended, earning a glare from Bias at the prospect of her sister’s position being filled, “Oh don’t look like that. It wasn’t as though wind sage was even that fitting a title for her. I recall she was always better at light magic.”

 

“We really should change the names at some point,” Cleobulus noted, “Sage of Water doesn’t exactly fit me either, now does it?”

 

“Those titles are important positions that have existed for–”

 

“Chilon, shut up,” Bias demanded, before looking at the two that actually mattered, “So who gets Darkness and Light, huh?”

 

“Those positions can’t just be assigned –”

 

“I wouldn’t mind being called the Sage of Darkness in addition to being Agastya,” Cleobulus remarked, amused by Chilon’s outrage, “I’ve always been best with those types of spells to begin with~”

 

“Then that leaves Water and Light to be filled,” Myson noted, “Hm…We could always make Anaximandros the Sage of Light.”

 

“True, he does like to consider himself Thales’s apprentice.”

 

“I thought he hated him,” Bias remarked, earning a dismissive wave from Cleobulus.

 

“Yes, but no one really liked Thales to begin with. Authority breeds resentment. Who would we have for Water then?”

 

“Hm…Dolofonos?” Myson offered.

 

The noise Chilon made could only be described as outraged. “You would let a mere assassin be a sage?!”

 

“Then we can give it to Agnus or Kyrie.”

 

“Wh–Who!?”

 

“Members of my research team. I keep them around in case I need a new Odesse.”

 

“You cannot just hand off the rank of sage to whoever you want!” Chilon snapped, “These are important positions to our people! To be the Sage of Light is to be our great leader, to be the Sage of Darkness is to be our leading scientist, to be a sage is to be a guardian to our people–!”

 

“I second Myson’s suggestion,” Cleobulus chimed in, taking obvious pleasure in Chilon’s mounting frustration.

 

“I’ll third it,” Bias offered, which made Chilon outright growl.

 

“Motion passed then,” Myson decided with open amusement, “Anaximandros shall be our Sage of Light, though not Agastya, Odesse will be the Sage of Wind, and…ah, I suppose we didn’t decide specifically on who it should be…Oh well, Bias, be a dear and find Anaximandros and the first Dolofonos you see." 

 

"You're just–" Was all Bias heard Chilon say before leaving the tent, not wanting to hear anything else from him. She already had enough to deal with. 

 

Watching her breath mist out as she stared up at the sky, Bias wondered what life she would lead once she had her sister again. 

Rhea was running out of time. 

 

The end of the year drifted ever closer, the rivers of time flowing steadily and without pause. She wanted…She needed to bring her mother back into the world, and yet…Byleth showed no sign of her mother’s power. She thought there would be something, some indication that the goddess dwelled within her vessel, but there was nothing.

 

Her hair remained the same bluish shade, her body remained unaltered, and she hadn’t even regrown the eye she lost. She was still…just Byleth. And that…Rhea didn’t know how to deal with that.

 

To make matters worse, the Agarthans were plainly on the move again. It was the only explanation for the rumors of demonic beasts in Ordelia alongside knights with strange powers. And, speaking of knights…

 

She took a slow breath as she looked over the railing of the Star Terrace. She hadn’t heard anything yet from Catherine, Alois, or Shamir. Hopefully there would be something; she’d sent another three battalions to help support Leicester’s forces, under orders to reinforce Gloucester and rescue their lost comrades. Or retrieve them, if they were not…

 

She should try to remain optimistic.

 

If she wasn’t then she would break, and she needed to remain strong for Fodlan and her mother. Sighing, she shook her head, deciding she needed to go for a walk. Though as she did, she couldn’t help but notice how quiet it was at the monastery. Not only were a large number of her knights away, but several students and staff had left throughout the year. She only prayed that the ones who weren't traitors were doing well. 

 

Though as she shook herself out of her thoughts, she realized she was standing in front of the dorms. The dorm of one person in particular. Bringing her hand up, she knocked on the door.  

 

“Give me a moment,” Byleth called out, and Rhea only had to wait for a few seconds before the door opened. “Oh, Lady Rhea, is everything okay?” 

 

“I just wished to see how you were fairing, young one,” Rhea said, doing her best to smile. 

 

“About as well as I can be, I suppose,” Byleth replied as Rhea glanced into her room, and noticed what seemed to be a letter on her desk.

 

“Oh, my apologies, were you writing something?”

 

“Ah, yeah. A letter to her majesty,” Byleth explained, rubbing the back of her head. “I just wanted to let her know that everything is okay at the monastery.” 

 

“Sure, and that’s why you’re already on your tenth rewrite,” Sothis chimed in, while Byleth pointedly ignored her. 

 

“Ah, I see.” Rhea nodded, keeping her expression positive despite the reminder of why she felt so concerned for the future. “You truly do care a great deal for Emperor Edelgard.”

 

“Yes, I do,” she answered quite simply and earnestly. "I care for everyone here but as the former class leader, she's helped me as much as I've helped her." 

 

"Hm…oh, would you like to walk with me?" Rhea asked, not wanting to stand at the doorway. Nodding in response, Byleth walked alongside her, the pair aimlessly wandering around. "If I may, what exactly made you consider working for the Empire?"

 

"Hm…it was a few days before the Battle of Eagle and Lion. Edelgard and I talked about what she was going to do when she was Emperor. There's still things I don't understand, things I need to talk to her about, but…I want to be able to support her." 

 

"Is that so?" Rhea muttered in response before thinking. "You know, there was a young man I knew from the Empire. A nobleman. He also had grand ideals for what he wanted for Adrestia. He also supported me as much as I supported him." 

 

"...is he…?" 

 

Rhea had a moment's pause before getting her implication. "N-No, it wasn't meant to be. When it came down to it, I chose the church over him. Duty trumped over heart for me." Despite her falter there, Rhea did feel sorrow in her as she remembered Wilhelm. 

 

"...Do you regret it?" 

 

"There are many things I regret. Even so, I do not dwell on them." 

 

Byleth glanced up at her, remaining silent as she took in her words. Rhea wondered if her advice of duty over heart would be one Byleth agreed with. 

 

Byleth, meanwhile, couldn't help but wonder if Rhea knew she had feelings for Edelgard and was telling her not to choose duty over heart. She clearly regretted not going with her boyfriend and joining the church instead, so it would make sense.

 

"I'll make sure to keep your words in mind," Byleth said, completely misunderstanding the advice. 

 

“Good, I’m glad that you will.” Rhea continued her walk with Byleth, content to let things subside into silence for a moment as they simply walked around the paths of the monastery. “...how have things been going with your classes?”

 

“Well enough. It’s still weird going around with half my vision gone, but I’m managing. Ferdinand’s been doing well as the new house leader too. I think he’s trying to live up to Edelgard’s example.” She smiled. “It’s funny, Flayn actually decided she wanted to be his retainer, like how Hubert was Edelgard’s.”

 

“Oh? She hasn’t mentioned it.” 

 

“Well she’s been doing well in the position. Constance got annoyed that Ferdinand didn’t ask her, but considering she tried to start a coup against him, I think it was a good idea in hindsight.”

 

“...She did what?”

 

“Yeah, it was a whole thing. It’s probably a good thing it happened so late in the year, otherwise she might have seceded and then we’d have four classes. Then I would have had to deal with teaching two classes.”

 

“...what.”

 

Byleth suddenly paused, a thoughtful look coming to her face. “Hm. Hey, Rhea, who is my mother’s father? If it wasn’t the guy you mentioned.”

 

"Ah…I would prefer not to talk about him," Rhea said, internally panicking since she didn't think Byleth would outright ask…was it too late to say it was an immaculate birth? 

 

“Oh. Did something bad happen?”

 

“Ah…yes. He…died. Violently.” The instant she said it, Rhea felt like hiding her face in her hands.

 

“...Hey, Lady Rhea, you don’t need to tell me if you don’t want to,” Byleth said, concern now audible in her voice.

 

“...” Rhea sighed. “Truthfully, young one…I don’t remember your mother’s father,” she lied, trying to hide her discomfort as she did, “I had experienced a personal tragedy, so I sought comfort in drink. And…the arms of another.”

 

The best lies had grains of truth in them. When she was Seiros, rage and purpose had suffused her being, a drive to destroy all that Nemesis had built and return the world to the peace she had known as a child. Yet fury could not keep her going at all times. 

 

She never drowned her sorrows, though she might have wished to. And she never fully embraced Wilhelm, even if the urge was there.

 

“...It could have been Will. In another life, I might have married him. But I did not. And thus, here we are.”

 

"...I'm sorry for bringing up bad memories, Lady Rhea," Byleth apologized, her gaze drifting to the ground for a moment, "...For what it's worth, even if it was a mistake, I'm sure mom was happy. Even if she didn't get to see the world, she had you, papa, and even Aelfric." 

 

"...I could have done more for her." 

 

"Papa's like that as well sometimes. Take it from me, you did enough," Byleth said, smiling up at her. 

 

“...You are a kind child,” Rhea replied, returning the smile, “I wish…I wish a number of things had been different. Yet we cannot change the flow of time, try as we might." 

 

"...Lady Rhea, may I ask something?" At her nod, Byleth took in a breath. "My mama…did she ever dream of a little girl?" 

 

"Excuse me?" 

 

"Byleth, what are you doing?" Sothis asked, getting Byleth to glance at her for a moment. She decided to press on though, keeping her eyes on her grandmother.

 

"I sometimes have dreams of a young girl, with long green hair sleeping on a throne. Did mama mention anything like that?" 

 

Rhea froze. “A girl? A girl with green hair–You have dreams about a girl with green hair?”

 

“Yes, I do. I’ve had them since I was young.”

 

“...a girl. How…How old does she seem to be?”

 

Byleth frowned faintly, resisting the urge to glance at Sothis to check. “Ten, maybe twelve?”

 

“About half your age then?”

 

“I think so. Why?”

 

Rhea felt like sighing. She also felt like cheering or maybe even screaming. She was feeling a lot of things at the moment, and one of them was her mentally cursing herself for forgetting the extremely basic fact of her own species biology. Nabateans mature slower than humans, how in the world did I not realize– “I…That is…Has anything happened in these dreams? You said she was sleeping. Has she ever been awake?”

 

For some reason, Byleth felt a sense of dread at the question. "...N-No, she, um…sometimes seems like she's stirring?" 

 

“Of course. Of course, I should have realized…” Rhea murmured, frowning in thought as she looked away from Byleth, “This whole time…”

 

“Is something wrong?” Byleth asked, still feeling strangely nervous.

 

“No, not at all. Everything is perfect," Rhes said, smiling as she stared at Byleth. 

 

Byleth felt as if she wasn't smiling at her. “...I think I should get back to my room now. I still need to finish that letter. And I should get some rest.”

 

“Actually, professor, do you think you could come with me?” Rhea requested, still smiling at something only she could see, “It has to do with our family.”

 

“...what do you mean?”

 

“I mean as I say. I have something to show you that I believe will answer a number of questions you have about our family and our people.”

 

Byleth frowned. “Can’t you just tell me what you want to show me?”

 

“It would be easier to show you. A painting is worth more than mere words, and there are some secrets that need to be unveiled directly for them to be understood.” She smiled. “I promise, it will not take long. You can come back and write your letter right afterward." 

 

"Do not go with her," Sothis urged, and Byleth felt herself agreeing immediately.

 

"Maybe we can go tomorrow?" Byleth asked, as she took a step back. 

 

"There's no need to worry. I swear to you I only want what's best for you and our people." 

 

"Why do you keep saying ‘our people’?" Byleth asked, feeling uneasy.

 

“That is what I want to explain to you. The truth about everything . About me, about your mother, about you ,” Rhea said, gesturing towards Byleth with a genuine smile that just made the professor all the more unnerved, “I want to share it all with you. You’ll understand everything once your eyes are opened to the truth.”

 

“There you are, Rhea.” Both women paused in their tracks as a familiar voice cut through the tension, before they turned their gazes to Jeralt, who raised an eyebrow at the sight of Rhea and his daughter. “...Is something going on here?”

 

“Ah, Jeralt–”

 

“Hi Papa,” Byleth greeted, moving away from Rhea and promptly hugging Jeralt, earning a blink from the knight captain.

 

“...hey kid. Wasn’t expecting you to be so huggy,” he replied, wrapping his arms around his daughter with a small smile, before looking over at Rhea. “What were you two talking about?”

 

“...Nothing important. I was taking a walk with Byleth and asking her about her classes,” Rhea answered, frowning faintly as Byleth gave her a glance, her gaze questioning. Perhaps I shouldn’t have lied immediately. “Did you need something?”

 

Underneath that question was another one. Namely, did he interrupt them deliberately?

 

“Yeah, actually. A messenger from Faerghus showed up. Apparently the regent wants to visit.”

 

Rhea blinked, genuinely caught off guard by that answer. “He does? For what reason?”

 

“From what the messenger said, he has some information about the ‘cult’ we’ve been having trouble with. The one that he’s pretty sure has taken over Ordelia, and might be causing problems in the Kingdom.” He shrugged, keeping his hand on Byleth’s shoulder. “I figure the letter has more information about it, but he wanted that passed along as soon as possible. Along with one more request. He’d like the new emperor to be at the meeting too.”

 

“What?” To Jeralt’s surprised, it wasn’t Rhea that spoke, but Byleth. “Why would he want her here?”

 

“I’m not sure, kid. Could be a lot of reasons. Maybe it’s a power play, or maybe he’s serious about there being a big threat.” He glanced at the archbishop. “It’s up to you, Rhea. If we do go along with this, we’ll be hosting two royals at once, and not just princes and princesses. We’re talking about the current rulers of two nations being here while we have most of our forces trying to handle the Ordelia Crisis.”

 

"..." Rhea glanced at Byleth, before taking a small breath. She wanted nothing more than to have her mother back, but if the Agarthans truly were behind all this, she needed to make sure nothing could harm her. "Very well, have a missive sent to Emperor Edelgard."

 

She's waited for a millenia for her mother to return. She could wait a few more days for her dream to be achieved. 

Chapter End Notes

Red: Rhea, why are you like this?

Indi: A thousand years worth of built up trauma, presumably

Red: Yeah, probably. Speaking of trauma, would you look who's busy making evil plans.

Indi: I'm sure they're just morally ambiguous plans.

Red: You know Cornelia's morally gray because she shows off her cleavage. That's the rule.

Indi: Which clearly means Rhea isn't morally gray cause she shows no skin.

Red: Rhea isn't morally gray, but Seiros definitely is.

The End of Peace

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Edelgard von Hresvelg was a busy woman; as the newly instated Emperor she had far too many projects to start and plans to prepare for her reforms to take place. So when she received a letter from the archbishop asking for her presence at the monastery, she almost declined on the spot. After all, what kind of Emperor would she be if she came scurrying at Rhea’s beck and call? 

 

When she received Byleth’s letter asking for her to come back to the Academy, however, she immediately began preparations to go. 

 

Now she would of course say it was because the letter informed her that Rhea was planning something. What exactly she was planning was unknown, but her teacher made it clear that if need be, she would be leaving the monastery early with the Emperor. So clearly it made sense for her to go and help her. 

 

For Hubert and Monica, however, it was obvious she just wanted to see her professor again. 

 

Regardless, this was still an official diplomatic meeting, so Edelgard prepared herself. Dressed in the fine crimson of Adrestia, Edelgard looked like she was ready to fight a war instead of attending a political meeting. Though as well-crafted as her clothes were, she had to admit, she enjoyed the horned crown she wore on her head far more.

 

After all, who else could say they had a crown forged to resemble their enemies horns to symbolically make it her own? Of course, it wasn’t quite the full armored and padded war gown she wanted to have, but it was close in style. She still needed to get a cape, and it bared more of her shoulders and back than intended for the final design, but for now it would serve its function.

 

"I must admit, I've returned far sooner than I had imagined. I wasn't even sure if I would be back for the graduation ceremony." Edelgard mused, looking out the window as her carriage began to pull into Garreg Mach. 

 

"It's a shame we won't be able to stay for long," Monica noted, looking outside as well. 

 

"For the best, especially given the professor's apparent request," Hubert remarked as he closed a book he was reading. 

 

"Whatever it is that Rhea is planning, we must be careful. I trust you two can handle ensuring the professor gets out safely while I speak to Rhea?" Edelgard asked, glancing at her friends. 

 

"Of course." 

 

"Leave it to us!" 

 

Smiling at their prompt responses, Edelgard felt the carriage come to a stop. Getting up when Monica opened the door for her, she walked down, prepared for whatever happened. 

 

"Edie!" She didn't expect Dorothea to come running up, practically tackling her in a hug. Thankfully Edelgard was able to keep herself standing upright as she caught the taller woman. While also trying to ignore what was pressing up against her face right now. "Oh wow, you're certainly dressed for the occasion." 

 

"H-Hm, yes, it's only befitting my position," Edelgard responded, blushing as Dorothea backed away, plainly checking out her outfit. 

 

“I’ll say! You look gorgeous in that! And the horned crown looks really fierce on you~”

 

“Good, I was hoping to give that impression. Better to put a firm foot forward in whatever negotiations Rufus has planned.”
