"Right, I heard about that. Funny, you'd think the person asking for the meeting would show up early," Dorothea said, letting out a huff, "The Blue Lions don't even know when he's showing up." 

 

“They don’t?” She frowned. “Not even Dimitri?”

 

“Not from what I heard. I know he should be here, but–Oh, wait, here’s something more important,” Dorothea interrupted herself, grinning as she spotted a certain professor walking towards them. 

 

Edelgard, meanwhile, blinked because her professor appeared to have her arms full of at least five bouquets of flowers. “...hm. I see she’s happy I’m visiting.”

 

"Hello there, Emperor Edelgard," Byleth greeted, smiling at her. The two stared at one another, silent for the moment. Neither was quite sure what to say next. "...So, um, I got these for you. And one for Hubert and Monica as well." 

 

Saying this, she handed out three of the five bouquets. Edelgard had to admit, it was…interesting seeing how nervous her professor was right now. 

 

"And the other two?" Hubert asked, far too amused right now. 

 

"Oh…um…one for Dorothea too," Byleth said, handing it over to the songstress. "And...I guess I have one extra, so you can have it as well, Edelgard." 

 

“...Mm. Thank you, professor,” Edelgard responded with a smile, holding the two bouquets close to her chest, “...Ah, so, how have things been?”

 

“Well enough. Rhea scares me now.” Byleth’s blunt statement got Edelgard to stare at her in surprise. 

 

"Excuse me?" 

 

"I'll explain in a bit. We should go somewhere private," Byleth suggested, before turning around and walking away. 

 

“...I suppose I’ll be following Professor Byleth then,” Edelgard noted, before turning to her retainers, “Monica, please alert Seteth to our presence and let him know I will be right with the archbishop. Hubert, keep watch so no one eavesdrops or attempts to interrupt us.”

 

“At once, Lady Edelgard!”

 

“Of course, your majesty.”

 

With their responses given, she turned to Dorothea, only to pause when the songstress gave her a kiss on the cheek. “Have fun with Bylie~ Oh and be careful with Rhea. I don’t know what she wants exactly, but it’s enough to worry our professor.”

 

“I’ll be careful. Thank you for the concern,” she replied with a smile of her own, before giving Dorothea a kiss on the cheek in turn.

 

“Heh. Someone’s gotten bolder~”

 

“I’m an emperor. Remaining a blushing schoolgirl would be foolish of me.” With that said, on she went to follow her professor into a secluded part of the monastery. And to her surprise, another person happened to be waiting for them. Though perhaps she shouldn’t have been that surprised. “Oh, hello Shez.”

 

“Hey.” Shez, who was leaning against the wall in the store room with her arms crossed, possibly in some attempt to look intimidating or cool, raised a hand in greeting. “So…uh…alright, I’m going to just get this over with. I’m sorry.”

 

“...I must admit, I didn’t expect to hear that.” 

 

“Look, I still have problems with you, but I talked to Kronya, and well, I don't want to be a hypocrite.” 

 

“I see. Well, I want to apologize as well. My actions put you and the professor in danger, and I will forever regret doing that to you two.” 

 

“Yeah yeah, you can save the apologies. I’m still not happy with you taking Byleth from me.” 

 

“What?” Edelgard and Byleth said in unison. 

 

“What? Nothing. Shut up. I’m not upset.”

 

“...” Edelgard, despite the situation, felt a small smile creep up her face. “Didn’t you give me your blessing to marry Byleth before, Shez?”

 

Byleth blinked at that while Shez stiffened. “That–That was said before she almost died and now I feel weird about it, so shut up.”

 

“Ah–My apologies, I didn’t–”

 

“Look, just, Byleth has things to tell you about Rhea being weird, so…yeah. Listen to her. Not me. Well, aside from when I agree with her about how we need to get out of Garreg Mach and maybe smuggle her in your carriage. Speaking of, do you have secret compartments in there or do I need to carve one?”

 

“...The carriage has a secret compartment under one of the seats.” 

 

“Wait, really?” Byleth asked. 

 

“Yes, it was prepared if we ever needed to smuggle something. Though I doubt Hubert would have expected it to be a live human.”

 

“It can fit a fully grown human body,” Hubert commented from the doorway.

 

“Oh, can it fit two?” Shez asked.

 

“Not without effort. And perhaps a saw.”

 

“Ah, damn.”

 

“Couldn’t you just warp after us?” Byleth asked, giving her sister a confused look.

 

“Of course I can. I was thinking Dorothea would be in the compartment with you.”

 

“That sounds uncomfortable.”

 

“So you’re saying you don’t want to be up close and personal with Dorothea for a long stretch of time?”

 

“Not while we’re in an enclosed space and attempting to travel without being detected.”

 

“Dorothea is an Adrestian citizen,” Hubert pointed out, “We can have her ride in the carriage with just about any excuse.”

 

“Yeah, but that’s not as fun,” Shez complained.

 

“Before we continue any plans, can someone please tell me what Rhea is planning?”

 

“...That’s the thing, I'm not exactly sure. I was talking to her a few days ago and…do you remember that ability I mentioned having?” At her nod, Byleth continued. “I mentioned something along those lines to Rhea and…it was like she was no longer looking at me. As if I didn’t exist any more, and…she kept mentioning something about ‘our family’, as if it was some massive secret she held.”

 

“...” Edelgard glanced at Hubert for a moment. “I see…my teacher, for the sake of honesty, there is something I haven’t mentioned which I believe is what Rhea wished to tell you.”

 

“Of course you know.” Shez huffed. 

 

“Shez.” Byleth frowned at her sister.

 

“I’m not saying anything! Bleh, okay, so what’s the secret you know this time and never told anybody?”

 

“Shez…”

 

“Don’t you use a sad voice, you know I’m weak to that.”

 

“Rhea isn’t her true name,” Edelgard stated, deciding to cut through the byplay, “Her true name is Seiros. Or, perhaps more accurately, the Immaculate One.”

 

“...”

 

“...That’s a stupid name,” Shez commented, frowning, “Why is her being clean so important?”

 

“The Immaculate One is the name of the divine beast that allegedly aided the saints during the war against the King of Liberation,” Edelgard explained, ignoring that, “More accurately, it is the name of a dragon.”  

 

“...is that what she meant by ‘our people’?” Byleth murmured, frowning to herself.

 

“Wait, hang on, Byleth’s a dragon!?” Shez exclaimed, her eyes going wide, “How does that work?! She doesn’t have scales, I know that much!”

 

“She wouldn’t,” Edelgard commented, “From what I know of Rhea’s kind, they have two forms, human and dragon. Though the humanoid form is noted to have green hair, green eyes, and pointed ears.”

 

“Oh. But my hair is blue? And I don’t have pointed ears,” Byleth pointed out, brushing back her hair to show her lack of pointed ears.

 

“True. But you also have a human father,” Edelgard noted, getting Byleth to pause before her attention was caught by Shez letting out a sudden gasp.

 

“Oh shit, Seteth and Flayn are dragons.”

 

“...oh.”

 

“Yes, that is our assumption as well,” Edelgard agreed, nodding to Shez, “We also presume the two of them are likely Saints Cichol and Cethleann, given their status as father and daughter.”

 

“Wait, hang on, Flayn’s tiny! She’s young too! How is she–”

 

“Is she young? Or does she just look young?”

 

“...” Shez looked at Byleth, bewildered and worried.

 

And Byleth…Byleth was thinking about a lot of things at once. Like the question of how her mother’s body was intact after years of being dead. Or how Rhea directly stated her mother gave her heart to her. Which didn’t make sense…if she was human. But if she wasn’t…

 

She felt her chest. Her heart still didn’t beat. But what if it wasn’t a human heart? Did Rhea’s heart beat? Did Seteth’s? Flayn’s?

 

And…And then there was what Bias said. That she was the Fell Star, that she was a vessel, and Byleth felt dizzy as her mind started making connections because Seiros started the church, the Immaculate One was a servant of the goddess, Sothis was the name of the goddess – “That’s why. That’s what she wants. Rhea wants me to be the vessel of the goddess.”

 

“What?” Edelgard stared at her professor, her eyes wide. “What are you talking about?”

 

“Bias, she–She knew, how did she know? She knew–She called me empty, an empty vessel for–”

 

“H-Hey, By!” 

 

Byleth blinked, feeling Shez’s arms holding her up. “...I’m okay, I’m alright, I just…why didn’t I think about this earlier? The pieces were all there…” She looked up at Sothis, floating at her side as always. And yet, the spirit’s gaze was different from usual. Her usual immaturity wasn’t there; instead, there was a sort of resigned acceptance. “...did you know?”

 

“No, of course not,” Edelgard answered, thinking Byleth was talking to her while her own mind raced with the sudden information, “Professor, what did you mean? About Rhea wanting you to be–”

 

“Lady Edelgard?” Edelgard nearly cursed, turning to see Monica, who looked apologetic. “Ah, Rhea wants you up at her antechamber as soon as possible. She sent Gilbert to help escort you and I don’t know if I can distract him–”

 

“No, that’s fine. I’ll go with him,” she decided, before looking at the Eisner sisters, “Professor, are you going to be alright?”

 

“...I think. I think I need to think about…things.” Byleth sighed, putting a hand to her aching head.

 

“Hey, I’m sure you can just rest for a while, right?” Shez looked at the former Eagles. “We can meet up with you guys later. I’ll get Byleth back to her room, she can rest, and then I’ll figure out whatever we gotta do to get out of here, okay?”

 

“That sounds good to me,” Edelgard agreed, nodding to her, “We can discuss Rhea’s intentions once we have Professor Byleth in a safe place. I have to imagine I can make the excuse of wanting to meet up with our classmates if we need an excuse.”

 

“Right, yeah, that works. I mean, hey, they probably would’ve been over here already if Dorothea didn’t ask them to give her some private time with you,” Shez remarked.

 

"Well, I'll make sure to thank her later," Edelgard said, before glancing at Byleth, "I still don't understand what you mean about Rhea attempting to make you into a vessel, but I promise you I won't let her harm you, my teacher." 

 

"...Thank you, Edelgard," Byleth replied, though she still looked stressed. Nodding to her, Edelgard left, prepared for whatever was to come. 

 

"Alright come on, let's get you to a bed," Shez said, helping Byleth walk as they went to the dorms. "As fun as it would be to start smuggling you, it probably won't be comfy in a secret compartment." 

 

"Probably not," Byleth agreed, feeling exhausted as they left the store room. Glancing up as they walked, she couldn't help but note how foggy the sky had suddenly gotten. 

It was strange being back in the Archbishop’s audience chambers. Edelgard hadn’t thought she’d be back in this room anytime soon, and it did grate at her pride somewhat to be here at the archbishop’s command, as though the woman still had power over her.

 

Still, she’d pretended for long enough; she could keep up a farce for a little longer.

 

"Ah, there you are, Emperor Edelgard," the Archbishop greeted as she walked in. She wasn’t alone, as expected; a few Knights of Seiros stood nearby as guards for the meeting.

 

"Greetings, Lady Rhea. My apologies for my tardiness, I wished to catch up with my classmates and lost track of the time." Giving a slight bow, Edelgard couldn't help but notice how, beneath her usual calm, the archbishop seemed annoyed. Maybe impatient?

 

If she did intend for Professor Byleth to be used as a vessel of the goddess, perhaps she wanted to get whatever ritual she needed to perform over with sooner rather than later? The cynical part of her found it hard to believe, though not because she thought Rhea wouldn’t readily sacrifice the professor for her own ends; no, she was just surprised that Rhea was a genuine adherent of the false religion she had concocted.

 

"I see. I can understand wanting to see your friends again, but you really should at least inform me beforehand," Rhea responded, some of that annoyance showing.

 

"Of course." Edelgard made a show of glancing around. “Is Lord Rufus here as well, or…?

 

“Hm. He also appears to be tardy. And unlike you, I haven’t received word of his arrival at all yet, which is–”

 

She paused as the doors to the antechamber opened again and Gilbert walked in, alongside a man that certainly wasn’t the regent Archduke Rufus Thierry Blaiddyd. Instead, the man that came in didn’t look particularly noteworthy at all; he dressed like a priest, though in Kingdom Blue instead of Seiros White, and his features were decidedly average, with his hair being the most common shade of light brown found in Fodlan.

 

“And who might you be?” Rhea asked, frowning.

 

"My name is Miles, Lady Rhea, and I am the Kingdom’s representative at this meeting.” The man smiled, and for some reason, it seemed uncomfortably familiar to Edelgard. “I bring a missive from his majesty regarding some very important issues he would like to bring to your attention, Lady Rhea, and Emperor Edelgard.”

 

“Then why isn’t he here himself?” Rhea demanded, her irritation obvious, “Rufus asked for this meeting, he stated he would be here, so where is he?”

 

“His majesty is a busy man, Lady Rhea,” Miles answered, “He is ruling an entire nation, and cannot be drawn away by a mere meeting when a representative could suffice.”

 

“Miles, was it?” Gilbert spoke up, frowning at him, “You’re overstepping your boundaries here. Rufus is the regent of Faerghus, not its king, and he cannot ignore the summons of the archbishop.”

 

“Ah, of course, I am getting ahead of myself. And I must say, I am grateful to see Emperor Edelgard came to this meeting herself.” He smirked, turning his gaze to her. “If I may say so, you appear quite confident to leave your empire unattended. I do hope your ministers are able to handle the unrest without your presence.”

 

His tone was polite, but the words were targeted. Edelgard’s gaze was cool as she regarded the Kingdom’s messenger. “I assure you, my ministers will be able to handle things without issue. They are capable of working without a leader guiding their every move.”

 

“That is true, though you are a newly established leader. It is understandable to be concerned for your leadership when you haven’t truly proven yourself.”

 

Edelgard narrowed her eyes. “I have better things to do than trade barbs with a messenger. Tell us your missive or leave." 

 

"Very well." With a grin, the priest took out a scroll from his sleeve. "On behalf of King Rufus Thierry Blaiddyd, I bring a message to Archbishop Rhea." 

 

Edelgard’s eyes narrowed as he spoke. Rufus was meant to be the regent, not the king. Just what had occurred in the kingdom? 

 

"After much investigation, we of the Holy Kingdom of Faerghus have discovered that the true culprits behind the Tragedy of Duscur is the Empire. Specifically, the deceased Volkhard von Arundel, his sister Anselma von Arundel, otherwise known as the current emperor’s mother, and the former Prime Minister, Duke Ludwig von Aegir. As such, we demand that the students of the Black Eagle house be turned over to the Holy Kingdom of Faerghus as wards of his majesty and his appointed council. As well, due to her connection to the proven conspirators, we demand Emperor Edelgard step down and cede power to a regent appointed by the Holy Kingdom." 

 

"What!?" Miles paid Edelgard no attention as he continued. 

 

"Furthermore, because of the church’s gross negligence in management, such as allowing  several infiltrators to roam free within the monastery, executing loyal knights of Faerghus under false pretenses, and failing to ensure the safety of the students of the kingdom, or even your own staff, his majesty rightly believes you, Lady Rhea, are no longer suited to hold the position of archbishop." He gave Rhea a small smirk. “There is also, of course, the matter of you having a child out of wedlock. I believe your granddaughter, who you so eagerly gave the position of professor at the Academy, is proof enough of your indecency. It is his majesty’s belief that no true representative of the goddess could have such loose morals as to rut like a beast and bear a sickly bastard who only had the decency to die after bearing her own wretched spawn.”

 

In the past few seconds, Rhea had gone from shocked, to offended, to visibly outraged. By the end of his sentence, her face had darkened with rage and she was plainly holding herself back from ordering Miles killed on the spot by the bristling knights standing guard. Or killing him herself, if it came down to it.

 

“I see.” The anger was still there, but her tone turned cold as she addressed the messenger. “Miles, was it?”

 

“That is correct, Lady Rhea,” he replied.

 

“Miles, then. I understand you are a messenger. As such, I will refrain from ordering your execution for the heresy that has spilled from your lips. You are, however, excommunicated from the Church of Seiros. You are barred from all institutions of the church, and you have forfeited your rights to trial. If ever you are caught committing a crime by a Knight of Seiros, they have leave to execute you on the spot.

 

“ Furthermore ,” she echoed, “The same extends to Rufus Thierry Blaiddyd and the members of his ‘council’. I will also add that he is to be removed from the throne of Faerghus and exiled from the lands of Fodlan by the end of the week, or the nation of Faerghus shall be recognized as illegitimate and all lands and titles will be stripped from its nobility and returned to the Empire of Adrestia, which shall have the full support of the Central Church in retaking its stolen lands.”

 

Edelgard’s eyes were wide as she stared at the archbishop. A part of her was baffled that it could be that easy to just completely eliminate Faerghus as a legitimate nation, while another was considering just how to take advantage of the archbishop’s rage.

 

And yet…could she even pretend to be siding with Rhea when Byleth needed her to get out from under her thumb?

 

That decision could be left for later though as Rhea spoke again. “Emperor Edelgard will serve as witness of my orders and they will be shared among the Knights of Seiros once our conversation ceases. Am I understood?”

 

“Perfectly,” Miles replied with a surprising lack of concern. The man’s expression hadn’t changed at all. “You have chosen to ignore the lawful orders of King Rufus.” His smile widened. “And like that, the war begins.”

 

“Wha–War?! You dare threaten war when that usurper makes demands of those chosen by the goddess?!” Rhea snapped, letting her anger show.

 

“I do not threaten war, abomination. Our war has already begun.” Miles clapped his hands together, his grin threatening to split his cheeks. “It started over a thousand years ago, though I would say it’s only now that you have personally started a war with the festering sore called the Holy Kingdom. Oh, but where are my manners? I’ve been lying to you this whole time and here I am, forgetting to introduce myself properly.”

 

He placed a hand on his chest as dark magic burst up around him in a torrent, pushing Edelgard, Rhea, and all the knights back while his disguise burned away, leaving a pale-skinned warlock with a faint beard standing in the archbishop’s audience chambers. “I am Myson of Agartha, the Storm Sage of Shambhala, and I thank you for your hospitality, you filthy beasts.”

 

Then he turned his gaze towards Edelgard and she felt herself stiffen at the gleam of familiar yellow eyes in the shadows of his hat. “You’ve certainly grown from that time in the dungeons, little Edelgard.”

 

Edelgard went rigid, though she snapped out of it quickly when Rhea screamed in rage, “KILL HIM! DO NOT LET THAT MAN LEAVE HERE ALIVE!”

 

The knights leapt to obey the archbishop’s orders, drawing swords and charging as Myson smirked, before he vanished in a flash of magic right before the blades could slice his body. 

 

"I WANT ALL THE KNIGHTS AT THE MONASTERY TO BEGIN SEARCHING FOR HIM, AND SEND A MESSAGE TO THE KNIGHTS IN THE ALLIANCE TO RETURN AT ONCE!" Rhea demanded as the knights immediately moved, bursting out of the room and nearly knocking over Monica and Hubert.

 

"Your majesty, what happened?" Hubert asked once the pair of retainers entered the room. 

 

"Quickly, gather all the Black Eagles! The kingdom is demanding we hand them over, so we have to make sure none of them get taken!" Edelgard ordered her two retainers who immediately snapped to attention. "Lady Rhea, if they really have declared war, you need to ensure your knights are ready to mount a defense first and foremost!" 

 

“DO NOT–No, you’re right, we need to be ready.” Rhea nodded sharply. “Even if they have declared war, the Kingdom’s army will need time to–”

 

“LADY RHEA!” A knight shouted, pushing his way into the room in a genuine panic. “There’s an army outside the walls!”

 

What the hell is happening? Edelgard couldn’t help but think as Rhea’s eyes went wide.

“So…how long have you known?” Byleth asked within the void of her own mind, staring at Sothis as she reclined on her throne.

 

“It would not be exactly accurate to say from the moment Bias claimed that you were a vessel of a ‘False God’,” the Goddess of Fodlan answered, “But that is when things began to finally make sense for me. And over the past month…I would say it all began to slowly fall into place. Memories of a life I once lived, of powers I wielded, of children I had…” She sighed. “It has been…interesting.”

 

"So…what now?" Byleth asked, looking at Sothis. "Are you going to take my body?"

 

"No. I don't know what kind of person I was but…I was not the type of person to ask for someone to sacrifice themselves so I can walk the land," Sothis said, before sighing, "At least, I hope I wasn’t." 

 

"What do you remember?" 

 

"...I think Rhea was my youngest. I made several children, and I cared for them, yet she was the one who always stood by my side. She might blame herself for whatever happened to me."

 

“And…what happened?”

 

“I don’t know,” she stated quite simply, “I am more aware of who I once was, but I do not remember everything. Part of the problem is that I am…far longer lived than I realized.” She smiled wistfully, leaning back and looking at the “sky” of the void. “I traveled among the stars once. I settled here. I was welcomed. I think I was, at least. If Bias is any indication, there were those who did not appreciate my presence.”

 

“Hm. And…I’m descended from one of your children?”

 

“That does appear to be the case. Rhea, Seiros, the Immaculate One…whatever she chooses to call herself now, she is at least responsible for your mother’s existence. Though the fact that you have my heart, and by extension your mother must have had it as well, worries me.”

 

Byleth blinked. “I have your heart?”

 

“That’s the only explanation I can think of for why I am a part of you. And why my bones react to your presence.” Sothis crossed her arms, seemed amused at Byleth’s confused look. “That ‘Sword of the Creator’ of yours? It’s my spine.”

 

“...Oh.” Byleth wasn’t sure how to take that. “...It’s good I didn’t throw it off the Goddess tower then.”

 

"Yes, I would have been quite cross with you." 

 

"...Actually, how is it your spine? It's almost as tall as you." 

 

"Clearly this isn't my original form!" Sothis argued with a frown. "As I'm incomplete, I am stuck in this form."

 

"Right," Byleth said, refraining from pointing out the possibility that the sword was from her dragon form, and that she might have been a small dragon. Actually, that raised another question. “Did you have your children on your own?”

 

“...What exactly are you asking?” Sothis questioned, raising an eyebrow at Byleth.

 

“I want to know if there was a papa dragon involved. I’m asking because Rhea never actually said who my mama’s father was and I want to know if female dragons can just have kids on their own.”

 

“...” Sothis pinched the bridge of her nose. “I am capable of creating life on my own, yes, though I doubt Rhea is capable of doing the same, given that she clearly is not at the same level of power as I once was. I don’t know if a Nabatean could reach that level of power given how little I remember of my previous life, but, at best, she could probably make some sort of artificial life through alchemy.” She sighed. “That is likely the true origin of your mother. A homunculus, made with my heart in an attempt to resurrect me.”

 

“Oh. Hm. That does make sense. Thank you for explaining.”

 

“...why do you sound relieved?”

 

“I was starting to get worried I could get spontaneously pregnant, and I’m not ready for kids,” Byleth admitted, before tilting her head in thought, “I’m not sure if I want kids. I like teaching my students, so maybe? But I think there would be a lot more involved and I’m kind of worried I wouldn’t be good at any of it.” She paused. “Why are you covering your face?”

 

Sothis let out a deep sigh into the hands she had pressed to her face, her exasperation obvious. “I explain to you the likely origin of your mother and your first concern is if you are capable of immaculate conception.”

 

“I think it’s a valid worry. Rhea’s title is ‘Immaculate One’, isn’t it?”

 

“ That’s not why she’s named– Ugh, okay, I’m not going to get angry, it’s not your fault you don’t have any context for any of this. It is your fault that you’re this stupid though,” she grumbled, “...or maybe it’s Jeralt’s.”

 

“Hey, Papa was a good teacher.”

 

“No, he wasn’t. He was a decent parent, but I cannot say a man that hid basic realities of the world in which you live is a good teacher.”

 

“...He tried his best.”

 

"Given the situation he was dealt, yes, but that does not mean he didn't make mistakes." Sothis huffed. "But we can talk about that later. For now, you should probably awaken and see how exactly smuggling you out will go." 

 

"Right, and…regardless of who you are, I'm glad I met you, Sothis," Byleth said, smiling at her friend before closing her eyes to awaken. 

 

Only to end up jolting awake when a boulder came crashing through her door.

 

"...Sothis, how long have I been asleep?" 

 

"I don't know, half an hour???" the diminutive goddess exclaimed, staring in shock at the massive rock smashed into the doorway to Byleth’s room.

 

As for the professor herself, she had just one question: "What the fuck happened while I was sleeping?" 

Chapter End Notes

Red: So Byleth goes to sleep and wakes up to find a war has started. Where have I seen that before...

Indi: Man you guys thought she was gonna have a five year nap, turns out it wasn't even a five hour nap.

An Azure Day

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Jeralt had the worst headache of his life. And considering how often he woke up hungover, that was saying something.

 

Granted, alcohol could be blamed in part for the pain in his head, though most of it came from the simple fact that he was right all along and he never should have trusted Rhea. Which…yeah, it hurt to admit that. In his chest, not just his head.

 

He’d had a bad feeling when he saw just how nervous Byleth looked that night she talked with Rhea, so to find out she wanted to show Byleth something about 'her people' certainly left a bad taste in his mouth. He didn't know what exactly she was planning, but whatever it was likely had to do with what she had in mind back when Byleth was born. He didn’t know what she was up to exactly, but whatever it was, if she threatened his kids, he'd deal with the immortal archbishop himself. 

 

"...Should probably tell the kids how old the two of us actually are." He sighed, then splashed his face with some water before he left the washroom. He needed to have at least some of his mind working if he was going to get his kids and his company out of the monastery without Rhea causing problems.

 

He’d given his lieutenants the heads up the night before, letting them know they might be making a quick exit if things went wrong. His excuse to Rhea was going to be that he’d heard Alois had been sighted and he was going to take his troops to find his old apprentice. In the meantime, Byleth would be getting out of there with that princess she liked and Shez would join them a little later. Easy enough, hopefully.

 

A part of him felt bad for using Alois as an excuse when he still didn’t know if the man was even alive. It wasn’t going to stop him, but he did feel bad about it.

 

"Alright, just gotta work on guard duty till we can get everything ready," Jeralt muttered to himself, before pausing as he heard some screams. Frowning, he looked over to see people running in his direction. Though as he began to move in their direction, he stumbled for a moment as a large boulder slammed into the roof of the building next to him. "What the hell!?" 

 

"Captain!" a knight shouted as he ran up to him, "The kingdom is invading and is using siege equipment, we need to move!"

 

"What?" Jeralt heard another crash as another boulder hit a different part of the monastery. "What the hell–Ah, assemble the knights, we need to focus on getting everyone to safety first!" 

 

"Yes sir!" The knight responded, saluting him before running off. 

 

Frowning, Jeralt began to run for the gates, trying to get a good idea of what was going on. Whatever it was, getting out of here just got that much more difficult. Arriving at the gates, he saw a throng of people rushing into the monastery while several knights tried to keep things orderly. 

 

"Someone tell me what's going on!" 

 

"Captain Jeralt," Gilbert spoke up, getting the acting captain's attention, "The regent Rufus is currently invading the monastery with forces from the kingdom. Lady Rhea has also stated that the Kingdom will lose all legitimacy because of this invasion." 

 

"...What?" That was far more than Jeralt expected. 

 

"Captain!" Came the voices of his mercenaries, running up to him from the town. “What the hell is–”

 

“What’s going on is obvious,” Gertrude interrupted, speaking over Victor, “What’s important is what we need to do. Captain, your orders?”

 

Shaking his head, Jeralf focused; every second counted right now. "Alright, we can talk about the reasons why we’re being attacked later," Jeralt decided, before looking at the knights and mercenaries. "Gertrude, you and Victor set up a base for the injured to be taken care of! Ezra, I want you to find out what you can about the Kingdom’s forces! Candace, you and Gilbert focus on defending the gates and make sure no one gets past!" 

 

He was glad to see them immediately move to complete his orders. 

 

"And what are you going to do?" Aside from Gilbert. 

 

"I'm going to talk with Rhea," Jeralt said, frowning at the thought of having to talk with her again, "Also, I have to say, I'm surprised you seem okay with what's going to happen to the Kingdom." 

 

"...I would not say I'm fine with Lady Rhea’s decision. Once this is over, I shall be asking her for leniency, but now is not the time." 

 

“Smart man. Take it from me, Rhea has a temper. She might calm down once we handle things here. For now, just follow my orders and I’ll make sure we get through this,” he stated, thoughts already racing as he tried to figure out just how this was going to work.


Siege equipment means catapults, ballistas, probably fire orbs too. If they’re planning to stick things out, they’ll want a perimeter established and the Kingdom has enough pegasus knights to set up an air blockade, he thought as he raced through the monastery, looking for Rhea, We can probably hold out for a while, but if we don’t have supplies coming in and no one comes by to support us…this is going to be messy.

Edelgard was thankful that she had the foresight to bring her armor with her. She hadn't expected to get into a fight, but it always paid to be prepared. As such it wasn't long before she was fully armored and moving to her classmates. 

 

"Edelgard, what's going on?" Ferdinand called out to her as she arrived at the courtyard. 

 

"Yeah, what's this about the kingdom being bad guys??" Caspar asked as well, the young man looking confused but holding his axe ready to fight. 

 

"I don't know the full context, but it seems the regent Rufus is trying to establish himself as the king. The important thing right now is being prepared for whatever they throw at us," Edelgard stated while checking to make sure everyone was there, “The Kingdom has demanded we Eagles be turned over as political prisoners, so I’ll need all of you to stay vigilant."

 

"B-But why would they want us? W-We're just students!" Bernadetta shouted, hiding behind Hubert. 

 

"Mari and I aren't even from the Empire, so are they also going to want us?" Hapi asked, glancing at the former Deer. 

 

"I-I'm not just going to leave." 

 

"I doubt it'll matter to them anyways since they're invading the monastery," Monica pointed out. “They may just choose to capture whatever noble students they can get. And if they’re working for the same people that attacked your professor–”

 

“Those Who Slither in the Dark,” Hubert stated, earning an annoyed huff from Monica.

 

“Yes, I know, you came up with an amazing name for them, no one cares. The important thing is keeping everyone safe and finding a route out of here.”

 

“Woah, wait, aren’t we going to help fight these guys?” Caspar asked.

 

“We’ll likely have to, though we should prioritize getting everyone to safety,” Edelgard stated, “Where is Professor Byleth? She’s a skilled strategist and combatant, we’ll want her here with us.”

 

“Ah, I saw her earlier,” Flayn spoke up, “Shez was taking her to her room!”

 

“So the professor gets to nap while a disaster happens?” Linhardt asked, sounding faintly miffed.

 

"We should be waking her!" Petra suggested. 

 

"You all should go get her,” Constance added, “My unworthy existence shall go to the battlefield to buy you all time." 

 

"No battle plans until we find the professor!" Dorothea said, before heading off to the dorms, with the Black Eagles in tow. 

 

Walking a bit behind the group, Edelgard began to plan on the best ways to fight back against the invading force, where her classmates would be safest and what route they should use to escape–

 

"PROFESSOR!" Only for her mind to come to a halt at Dorothea's sudden yell. Rushing forward, Edelgard felt her heart sink as she saw a large boulder had smashed into Byleth’s dorm room. 

 

As the Black Eagles began to call out to the professor on the other side, they could hear someone's muffled yelling coming from inside. 

 

"Move," Edelgard demanded, her tone brokering no argument as the students who tried to move the boulder made way. Gritting her teeth, Edelgard grabbed onto the rock, her fingers practically digging into the hard stone as she called upon her crests. With a grunt of exertion, she lifted the rock above herself, freeing the former mercenary. 

 

“Holy shit.” She wasn’t sure who spoke, but they sounded impressed. Either way, Edelgard set the boulder down at her side, then immediately smiled when she saw her professor.

 

“Hello, my teacher.”

 

“...Hello, Edelgard,” Byleth greeted with a fond smile, before pausing, “And hello everyone else. If we have time, could someone explain what’s happening and if we’re under attack?”

 

Immediately all her students started talking, their voices drowning one another out. After a few moments, Byleth nodded. 

 

"Alright, we need to focus on defense then. We should move to the Cathedral, it's the most fortified building of the monastery, and it'll limit enemy forces thanks to the bridge. Constance, I need you to provide support in the air in case any pegasus squads come at us. Bernadetta, you keep her safe with cover in case anyone approaches her in the air," Byleth said, having understood everything, "Edelgard, we're going to need to meet up with the other teachers and house leaders to plan our defenses. Ferdinand, you can lead the Eagles in the meantime. I trust your judgement, just make sure everyone gets to a safe place as soon as possible.”

 

“Yes, of course professor!” Ferdinand agreed, nodding sharply at Byleth’s orders before quickly turning to the others. “Alright everyone, let’s be quick and careful!”

 

“Monica, Hubert, go with everyone else,” Edelgard instructed, holding up a hand to forestall any protests, “Professor Byleth can keep me safe well enough and every one of my classmates is a valuable target for our enemies. I will be with you as soon as possible.”

 

“Very well, Lady Edelgard,” Hubert said with a bow while Monica grimaced.

 

“Please be safe.”

 

“I will.” With that, Edelgard and Byleth promptly hurried towards the central building of the academy. “I have to say, it’s always nice to see you work,” she complimented on the way.

 

“Thank you. It’s nice having you back.” Byleth said, before glancing at Edelgard. "I kissed Dorothea." 

 

Edelgard stumbled a bit. "Excuse me?" 

 

"Well, technically she kissed me, but I just wanted to let you know that we're dating, and that I really like you as well, and I hope we can make this work." 

 

“...Professor, I feel like there were more appropriate times you could have told me this.”

 

“I was going to mention it earlier, but I didn’t get a chance,” Byleth said, feeling her face heat up a bit. "And I want to be able to say it as soon as I could. I still don't understand everything with my emotions, but I don't want to ignore them." 

 

“Hm. That’s a good thing to do, but I also feel like this may be…no, never mind. Thank you for informing me, professor. And…I hope to pursue things further after we handle things here.”

 

Despite the circumstances, Byleth found a smile making its way onto her face. She really did enjoy having her student back.

Dimitri had probably the deepest frown on his face that Shez had ever seen. It was kinda interesting, but also unfortunate given the circumstances. Though she could understand how he was feeling. She’d been around when he got the news, and the way his eyes went wide looked almost more horrified than surprised.

 

And now, he had to argue for his nation. “Lady Rhea, I beg you to reconsider! Punishing the whole of Faerghus for the actions of–” 

 

“Dimitri, your uncle has chosen to side with the worst heretics the land of Fodlan has ever faced,” Rhea stated plainly and simply, though it was obvious to everyone there that she was barely restraining some obvious rage, “He is a traitor to everything that the faith stands for and I will not hold back in ensuring everyone who chooses to side with him will be punished to the fullest extent.”

 

"Of course, I understand, but we need to find out who was forced to work with him!" 

 

"We can do that after we win, buddy," Claude noted, his usual smile being thinner than usual. This whole mess caught him just as off guard as everyone else, and that seemed to genuinely bother him.

 

"On that note, we should figure out what the prince needs to do," Jeralt said, his frown heavy, "If the kingdom is invading, then maybe he could get some of them to put down their weapons?" 

 

"My apologies Sir Jeralt, but I feel as if that would be far too dangerous for a student," Hanneman stated, glancing at the captain. "They have already made it clear they want to take the Adrestian students hostage, and I doubt they'll stop at just them." 

 

"Yes, if anything they'll take this as a chance to 'rescue' the kingdom kids," Manuela muttered. 

 

“I can’t just hang back and do nothing!” Dimitri argued, “These are my countrymen! I understand they are acting against the church, but they’re clearly being misled!”

 

"Regardless of who is leading them, they are attacking Garreg Mach. So we need to act now," Rhea stated, almost growling. Her glare only lessened slightly as the doors opened and Byleth and Edelgard rushed in. 

 

Dimitri though, his eyes narrowed, a frown coming to his face at the sight of Edelgard.

 

"Where are all the students?" Byleth asked upon entering and looking around to see who was there. Upon spotting Shez, she smiled and waved to her sister, who returned the wave with an awkward grin.

 

"Hanneman has his Lions by the knights barracks helping out there, and my Deer are by the entrance hall, helping guide noncombatants somewhere safe," Manuela answered.

 

“Good, I have the Eagles fortifying the chapel. We can evacuate noncombatants there, it’s a defensible position.” She paused, a thought occurring. “Would Abyss be a good evacuation point? Not many people know about it and there’s a lot of room down there.” 

 

"Abyss is supposed to be a secret of the monastery, not somewhere the townspeople should be going into," Rhea stated. 

 

"I don't really think something like that matters right now," Jeralt pointed out, annoyance filling his tone. 

 

"...Very well. We'll try to get as many people as we can to the cathedral, but for those we can't, they'll be guided to Abyss." 

 

"We should also make sure to take supplies to both locations, we don't know how long we will be fighting off the Kingdom’s forces," Edelgard suggested, getting Rhea to frown before nodding. 

 

"Very well. In that case, the Eagles can remain stationed at the Cathedral, and the Deer can help move people into Abyss. Dimitri, I will tell you now, even if you get your countrymen to lay down their arms, they will not evade punishment for their transgressions," Rhea stated, staring at the prince, who nodded. 

 

"Of course. Once they are aware they're being led astray, I'm sure they'll accept whatever punishment you give them," Dimitri said, doing his best to seem strong. 

 

“So maybe make that punishment something other than death,” Jeralt spoke up, frowning at Rhea, who returned the look, “Take from me, if people know they’re dead either way, you’re going to get a lot that refuse to surrender. If it’s between dying to the noose or dying to the sword, most men will take their chances with killing the guy who’s holding the sword.”

 

“...Fine. Leniency will be shown to those who lay down their arms." 

 

"So, what are our orders once we finish guiding people down?" Claude asked as he raised a hand. 

 

"You are to aid the Blue Lions. The same order applies to the Eagles once the Cathedral is secured." 

 

"Alright, let's get to it then!" Shez shouted, pumping her fists. While not as energetic, the rest of those in attendance got ready to move out. 

 

"Actually, Professor Byleth, I need a word with you." Up until Rhea spoke up, making Byleth stiffen. 

 

"Ah…what about?" 

 

"Yeah, Rhea, what do you need?" Jeralt asked, his frown deepening. 

 

Rhea stayed silent, considering her words. This was the best chance she had, and really, the best option for the monastery. If the goddess were to descend now, then the heretics would be smited without question. She just had to get her down there. "...Actually, I believe you and Shez should stay as well. You too, Emperor Edelgard." 

 

That got some looks of concern and confusion from the group there, but before long, those asked to stay were the only ones left. They were still in a siege, so everyone needed to get to work, which was why Byleth nodded to her father, confirming she would be fine.

 

Once he left, she looked at the archbishop. "What did you need, Lady Rhea?" 

 

"Recently, you told me of a dream you were having. I believe this to be a sign," Rhea said, choosing her words carefully as she spoke evenly, "Much like with Seiros before, I believe that you will receive a message from the goddess. To do so, I want to take you to a secret location within the monastery, with those closest to you by your side. Truth be told, it would be proper for your entire class to be there as well, much like how Seiros had her fellow Saints by her side, but given the situation, I think it would be best if they were to remain up here." 

 

“Mm. Okay. I haven’t heard that story before.”

 

Rhea paused. “Well, it may not be a common one, but it is a part of Fodlan’s history. I think it would be a method through which you could commune with the goddess directly.”

 

“Sure, alright. Is that what you think will happen?”

 

“Of course it is.” Rhea felt a small frown come to her face. “Is there an issue, child? I have given you my answer.”

 

“Yeah. I want to ask if you’re telling me the truth. Is that genuinely what you believe will happen?”

 

Rhea frowned. Shez and Edelgard were frowning too, the former crossing her arms over her chest while the latter seemed confused by the questioning, yet just as suspicious of the archbishop. “...Yes. I genuinely do believe you will receive a divine revelation from the goddess should you take a seat upon that throne.”

 

“Okay. You’re lying to me.” Byleth sighed. “Okay. I thought that would be the case, but…well, I lied too, so I guess that makes it even.”

 

“It’s not okay, By,” Shez murmured, frowning at her sister, who shook her head.

 

“No, you’re right, it’s not okay. I think it’s even though. Things being balanced doesn’t mean they’re okay, it just means…I lied about the girl on the throne being asleep, she’s been awake this whole time,” Byleth bluntly stated, staring into Rhea’s widened eyes. "She knows what you're trying to do, and wants no part in it." 

 

"...W-What?" Rhea asked, as she felt her heart stop. “No, that–That isn’t possible–”

 

“It is. You made it possible. You put her heart in my chest, didn’t you? You created my mother as a vessel for the goddess and you wanted to make me one too. That’s why I can see her, that’s why I can use the Sword of the Creator, and that’s why I’ve had dreams of your war against Nemesis for years now, Seiros. A lot of things make sense now. And I…I don’t know what else you want from me, but I don’t want to be a part of it." 

 

"That–No, you can't just–" 

 

“I will defend the monastery from those attempting to besiege it, and I swear to you, I will keep the people here safe. Afterwards, I’ll probably leave. Please don’t try to impede me, it could put people in danger.”

 

"I might not have sufficient context about what is occurring, but the Professor has the protection of the Empire,” Edelgard spoke up, moving to stand beside Byleth, “We will not declare war on the monastery, but I will not allow any harm to occur to her." 

 

“Also I can warp really easily,” Shez pointed out, “So if you try to push things, By and I can be gone in–”

 

“No, wait,” Byleth interrupted, looking at her sister, “Don’t do that, please. We still have people we need to protect here. I don’t want to see anyone be hurt.”

 

“Well yeah, that’s–By, I was going to come back, I’d just get you out first.”

 

“Oh, okay. Sorry, I misunderstood.” Apology given, she turned back to Rhea, meeting the archbishop's eyes. “I’m going to go help everyone now. I hope you’ll be willing to work with us, even if I don’t do what you want.”

 

“No. No, you cannot,” Rhea insisted, finally getting her bearings, “You do not understand, the world needs you to be the goddess! I don’t know what I did wrong, but I swear to you, this is your purpose! You are meant to be our world’s savior!”

 

"I would suggest leaving now," Sothis said, and Byleth found herself agreeing.

 

"I am not the goddess. My name is Byleth Eisner. That's all I am," Byleth stated, turning around to leave. 

 

"We're not done here!" Rhea shouted, reaching out to grab her. Yet Shez moved a second sooner than she could, her hand grasping air as the mercenary warped away with her sister and the Emperor. 

 

Rhea remained silent as she stared at the empty space before her, the monastery shaking around her. Clenching her fists, the archbishop let out a scream of pure rage. 

“So we’re gonna have to run the instant this invasion is over, huh?” Shez commented, glancing at her sister.

 

“Probably. Why did you bring us to the roof?” Byleth asked, returning the look with one of faint confusion.

 

“It’s the first place I thought of. Oh yeah, Edelgard, are you alright? No bits missing?”

 

“Yes, I am–...Is that a genuine concern?” Edelgard asked, furrowing her brow.

 

“Ehh…I don’t think so, but also I don’t usually travel with two people, so I’m kinda concerned, you know? Though don’t worry, Byleth knows how to heal, she can fix–” 

 

And Byleth promptly shoved both Shez and Edelgard down to avoid a spear thrown at them by a pegasus knight up in the air, before retaliating with a fire spell that blasted the woman off her mount. “We should probably be somewhere with more cover.”

 

"Right." Grabbing the two, Shez teleported again, taking them inside the greenhouse. 

 

"...Well it's some cover," Byleth muttered, "Okay, Edelgard, you need to get to the Cathedral, and get the Black Eagles ready to leave in case Rhea tries anything. We know she's after me, but she might try to capture any of you to get me to go with her." 

 

"Professor, if I tell them to get ready to run for your sake, they'll just immediately come charging to try and help you." Edelgard argued. 

 

“Then…Then tell them to be ready for when I get there. Or…mh, this is a bad time for Rhea to turn against us. If we can’t trust the church knights to be on our side…” She grimaced, some genuine frustration welling up in her. “…Just tell them to evacuate the townspeople, as planned, and to run the instant the enemy shows up.”

 

“Professor, that doesn’t solve–“

 

“I know it doesn’t. I can’t put you all in danger, you need to be safe–“

 

“Or you could ask them to actually help you,” Shez pointed out with a frown.

 

“This isn’t a situation they can help in. If Rhea is an enemy now, then we cannot trust our allies–“

 

“Then what’s the actual plan here? Because it sounds like I should just take you away from the monastery so you’ll be safe and then we can figure things out.”

 

“You can’t do that.”

 

“Why not? Genuinely, why not? I can get you out of here, then come back for dad, our friends, the mercenaries, everybody! Let the Kingdom guys take the monastery, it doesn’t matter as long as we get out of here!”

 

"People are in danger, Shez." 

 

"And I don't care about them. I care about you and my friends." 

 

"Then get them out of here if they want to get out of here. I'm going to fight until we either win or lose." 

 

"Byleth, will you just listen to me!?" 

 

"Shez, I think the professor–"

 

"You stay out of this!" Shez shouted, shoving Edelgard back. 

 

"Shez, you need to calm down," Byleth said with a frown, moving in between the two. 

 

"Why do you keep choosing her side!? You're my sister!" Shez shouted, glaring at her. 

 

"I'm not choosing sides. I'm just trying to do what I can." 

 

"And we should be trying to get out of here!" Shez countered, before suddenly trying to grab Byleth’s arm. The thought in her head was that if she just got Byleth out of there, everything would be fine. But instead Byleth smacked her hand away, hard enough for it to hurt.

 

“Shez, you need to stop. This is my fight–” She paused, her eyes widening when she saw the genuine frustration on Shez’s face.

 

“...Fine. Fine, whatever. Don’t expect me to help–Fh…” She grimaced, shaking her head. “That’s not…just…”

 

“...Shez, wait–” Byleth began to say before Shez flashed away on her own, off to another corner of the monastery.

 

Rubbing her eyes as tears began to prick them, she moved to find the Golden Deer. She wouldn’t abandon her friends, she wouldn’t just…she just couldn’t be around Byleth right now, not with her head aching like this.

 

"Fuck this school," Shez grumbled to herself, "Nothing has gone right because of this place." 

 

"It truly is a sham of a holy place, isn't it, partner?" Arval asked, floating behind her. Their voice was quiet and soothing, like a cool balm to the heat she felt building up in her skull. "But don't worry, I'll always be at your side." 

 

“...Thanks Arval. I’m glad I’ve got at least one person on my side,” she muttered bitterly, earning a small, pleased smile from her ever-present partner. 

 

It was almost time.

“What a beautiful day,” Myson remarked ironically, staring up at the foggy sky overhead where pegasi and wyverns clashed, a barely visible skirmish consisting of unseen ambushes and sudden strikes, all set off by one of the Kingdom’s pegasus knights getting knocked from the sky. One battle in the midst of a siege, ultimately inconsequential in the long run.

 

Well, unless one of those bodies managed to crush someone important. That might change things.

 

“Yes, quite…are you certain I should be here right now, Lord Myson?” Odesse asked, still in his Acheron guise as he stood beside his master, “I would think you would want me still managing Ordelia territory.”

 

“You’re a sage now, Odesse. That means you leave administrative issues to a lesser.”

 

“That is true, but also I’m the only one with the Acheron disguise.”

 

“True, but it’s not like we really need ‘legitimacy’ to maintain our holdings there. What are the beasts going to do anyway? Die in droves again?”

 

“Ha, probably. Perhaps they’re hoping enough of their corpses will land in the right place to make a hill over the walls?”

 

“If you two are done chuckling to yourselves, we have a war to win,” Chilon grumbled as he moved up to stand beside his fellow sages, his silver armor matching the cool fog being maintained through magic by Kyrie. All the better to hide the forces they’d snuck in under the archbishop’s nose.

 

“It’s a siege, Chilon. You’re meant to be a warrior, you should understand the concept of patience,” Myson chided, before giving the armored Agarthan a glance, “Though I can understand if you’re eager to try out your new equipment.”

 

“Hmph. Mock me all you wish. I will be the one to tear out that abomination’s heart on this day.” He flexed his hand, glancing down at the additions affixed to his gauntlet. Atop the steel of the armor covering his hand, lined with Kingdom blue, was what could initially be seen as a Hero’s relic. Its material resembled the bone of a standard relic, and it had a stone affixed to its center, though the “bone” was an ashen-black and the core lacked a crest. “How many of these ‘amplifiers’ have you made?”

 

“I’m surprised you’re even curious. And what you have isn’t so much an amplifier as it is a shield.” Myson smirked. “It would be a true shame to let all the work we put into Lady Edelgard’s relic go to waste, after all. Especially when I finally have the opportunity to acquire a proper crest stone to use in it, instead of having to reuse one from those wretched storm dragons.”

 

“Hm. Do you think we should try to acquire Blutgang after this?” Odesse inquired, looking thoughtful, “We may have managed to recreate it, but having the original is better than just having copies, right?”

 

“Perhaps…confiscating the remaining relics from the ‘noble’ beasts holding onto them could be a good choice,” Myson mused, “They’ve long outlasted whatever usefulness their ancestors had. Though perhaps what remaining blood of the abominations they have within them could be put to use? Of course, if they do simply bow down to us, then we can take things at a slower–”

 

“You think those wretches will bow to us?” Chilon questioned, his voice filled with derision, “These beasts are far too attached to their meaningless loyalties to ever bow their heads in truth. I have already had complaints from the beasts in this army of our choice in assaulting the monastery, concerns that the boulders we let loose could potentially kill that ‘prince’ of theirs.”

 

“The one we’re slandering as being involved in his own father’s murder?”

 

“Not everyone believes that. They think we are here for retribution against the Empire and the archbishop, and that ‘his highness’ is in need of rescue.”

 

“Really? That’s hilarious. I almost want to kill the prince just to see their reactions now…”

 

“We could always ensure his death as a way of boosting the beasts drive for vengeance,” Odesse suggested, “Perhaps if we entertain the idea of a peace talk between us and then murder him there?”

 

“Ah, an interesting proposition…” Myson rubbed his chin, thinking. “We would need to frame it as treachery on part of the Church if we wish to have it land properly though–“

 

“Why bother?” Chilon interrupted, irritated, “Let’s smash down the gates and put an end to this farce.”

 

“Weren’t you supposed to be a guard? You really have no sense for–“

 

“I have enough sense to know we shouldn’t be waiting for the abominations to attack!” He paused, seeming to think. “And I am the one commanding this army. So we will be attacking, right now.”

 

“…If you insist, commander. Do as you wish. Break down the gates, unleash your soldiers, and bring down the abominations. You have my blessing.”

 

“I don’t need it,” Chilon growled as he moved away from them, heading towards the amassed knights, mounts, and siege weapons that formed their army.

 

“Isn’t it reckless to attack now?” Odesse pointed out, “I thought Bias was still getting ready.”

 

"And who will we lose? Some kingdom beasts and maybe Chilon, nothing we cannot do without," Myson said, grabbing a bottle of wine to pour into two cups. "If it’s really any true trouble, we can just send Anaximandros after him to back the idiot up. For now, care to toast for impending victory?" 

 

"Of course, Lord Myson," Odesse replied, taking the cup and clinking it against Myson’s. With a grin, the two drank as they relaxed. 

 

"Hm, I must admit, the beasts do have some uses," Myson muttered, swirling his wine around, "Perhaps I'll keep some of them around." 

 

It would be his country soon enough, after all.

Chapter End Notes

Red: And here's the next one! In which conflict builds up and plots progress!

Indi: Gotta say, really glad seeing the response to the last chapter, was an important one after all.

Red: Yup! It's been very fun seeing all the reactions and the people guessing what will happen next.

Indi: Speaking of, we'd be glad to hear even more of them, especially over in our discord! https://discord.gg/gn2VtVPs8h

Red: But for now, thanks for reading! Big things are soon to come!

Crimson Rain

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Shez was not in the greatest of moods, and as such, once the opportunity to work out her stress came before her in the form of those Kingdom assholes breaking through the gates and invading the town, she happily indulged in it. 

 

Tossing her sword so it could shred through a group of mages, Shez flicked her hand to the side, forming Dark Spikes in time to pierce a paladin rushing her, though a moment later she felt a sudden flash of pain as a thoron from a surviving mage crashed into her. Gritting her teeth, she resummoned her sword and cut down the mage, before flashing over to a group of pikemen and separating their heads from their shoulders.

 

“You can’t do this alone,” Arval noted, his voice in her ear as she scowled.

 

“Shut up! I’ve got this!” Shez snapped back, ignoring the pain as she rushed forward once again, aiming for the most enemies she could see. "Come on assholes, the Violet Demon is ready to take on all of you!" 

 

Rather than answer with some banter, the Kingdom Knights only yelled in response as they charged at her. Ducking under a spear aimed at her head, Shez stabbed through the armored knight's chest before using him as a human shield as she charged the rest. 

 

“I know you do. All I’m saying is that you need to use the abilities you have at your disposal,” Arval replied, “Do you really want to put yourself at risk holding back the power you have?”

 

Shez grunted, shoving the knight off her blades and scanning the increasingly hectic battlefield. Looking around at the forces surrounding her, her eyes honed in on a knight with slightly fancier armor on a horse. 

 

Flashing away, she reappeared on the horse behind the knight and stabbed her sword into his neck. Grabbing onto the reins as the horse started to go wild, Shez pulled hard to make the horse trample over kingdom forces. 

 

“I got this, I know I–”

 

“I don’t doubt you. Just stop letting yourself be hurt.”

 

Shez paused for just a moment, long enough for an arrow to thud into her arm and make her grimace in genuine pain, before she ripped it free and let her awakened form loose. Her hair lightened, taking on a fiery shade while an orange halo formed around her head. In an instant, all the pain in her body vanished and she felt a genuine smile come to her marked face at the rush of pure power going through her.

 

With a roar, she charged at the group of archers, who had just a moment to panic before they were cut down by the mercenary. 

 

Shez felt more alive than she ever had before as she cut down swathes of knights. Even as weapons pierced her and spells battered her body she kept moving, letting her rage carry her. So when a knight she was about to stab was blasted with a Luna she didn't cast, she immediately pulled her horse back, glaring at whoever took her kill. 

 

"Shez, what are you doing!?" yelled a diminutive mage, staring up at the bloodsoaked mercenary. Shez stared back in confusion, her mind in a haze as several other students moved in to help. 

 

"Hey Shez, since when did you take horse riding lessons?" an archer atop a wyvern asked, a smirk on his face as he shot down some pegasus knights trying to swoop down. Which was a stupid question because she’d known how to ride horses for years, ever since Ezra taught–Or, wait, was it her dad that taught her? Or…both? 

 

She shook her head, trying to keep her thoughts from distracting her. Candace liked horses anyway, she was probably the one–

 

“Keep your wits about you!” shouted a guy on a horse. Purple-haired, like her, and there was another person on a horse–a girl, orange hair, using a bow like the other archer.

 

“Shez, you okay?” Orange girl asked, looking worried for some reason.

 

“I’m fine,” was Shez’s immediate retort, shaking off the weird confusion and nodding to–Leonie, right, she knew Leonie, they were friends, they met in that village.

 

She pulled the reins of her horse, focusing back on the battle. An archer with glasses was shooting down enemies and two big muscular guys were smashing any knight that was dumb enough to get close. They were her friends, she knew that, and none of the people in black and gold uniforms were enemies, she remembered that much.

 

There was a flash of pink hair out of the corner of her eye and Shez felt herself grin when she saw the girl with an axe bury it into the head of one of the bulky knights. Right, I need to get back to it. No more screwing around.

 

With that thought, Shez warped away from her steed and cut through another knight, sending the woman’s head flying before she leaped, swinging her swords in a whirlwind of death, carving another swathe through the Kingdom’s army. She wasn’t going to stop, she couldn’t stop, she was going to kill every last one of these bastards that were trying to hurt her family.

 

On the field of battle, Shez looked like a genuine demon. Blood soaked her swords, her clothes, her hair and skin. The markings on her face, the shining, spiked rings floating around her head and wrists, they all made her look like something otherworldly. And it felt like even more power was burning in her body, just waiting to be unleashed.

 

“You could destroy this entire army. None of them can stand up to you. You’ll be a true hero.”

 

Shez saw some of the soldiers scatter, routed, fleeing the brutal killer in their midst. Which…was a good thing. Getting the enemy to retreat was good–

 

“You should finish them. Letting the rats scurry away means they can come back to bite–”

 

“Miss Eisner!”

 

Shez paused, her attention drawn to a man on a wyvern, his hair a familiar shade of green. He was accompanied by a vaguely familiar boy on his own wyvern, the newer addition to their class–

 

“Good goddess, are you alright?” The man sounded worried, for some reason.

 

“Yeah. The blood isn’t mine.”

 

“That’s…I suppose that’s a better answer–Where is your sister?”

 

She paused, her grip tightening on her swords. “Why do you want her?”

 

“Lady Rhea wants her,” the boy spoke before the man could, his voice terse, “So you’d better tell us where she is.”

 

“Cyril, you don’t need to–”

 

“Go fuck yourselves,” Shez growled, agitation burning in her chest, “You try to take her and I’ll kill all of you.”

 

“Wh–Miss–no, Shez, I swear to you, I do not mean Professor Eisner any harm,” the man said, concern audible in his voice, “I just want–...what in the world is…?”

 

He trailed off, staring upwards with a look of growing horror. Shez turned her gaze in the same direction and felt her eyes widen in shock.

 

“...Oh that’s just not fair,” Shez muttered as she stared up, unable to do anything but watch as a mass of meteors fell from the sky, turning the fog overhead a bright red like the sky itself was on fire. Dimly, she half-remembered a lesson about the meteor spell and its effects. Effects that didn’t involve more than one enormous, flaming rock falling from the sky at once, yet reality was not conforming to what she knew and there were easily over two dozen up there.

 

She moved without thinking, turning and sprinting back to the monastery at a speed most humans couldn’t match. She needed to get back and protect–

 

"Shez!" Lysithea screamed, catching her attention through the haze of heat filling her mind. With a burst of speed, Shez jumped, tackling Lysithea into a building just as the meteors hit. 

Dimitri was not having a good day. Few people were really, yet Dimitri couldn't help but grimace as he stabbed another one of his countrymen who wouldn't surrender. He had to take down his countrymen before, when rebellion's needed to be stopped, but he had been able to prepare for those. 

 

It didn’t help that he was just…so confused right now. He knew he needed to speak to Edelgard to find out what she knew about Rufus’s claims. If his uncle was telling the truth, then Lord Arundel and Lady Patricia…they were brother and sister, if one had been involved than the other–He had to focus. 

 

He could ask Edelgard how much she knew later.

 

"Please, listen to me!” he called out, trying to get the soldiers to stop, “I don't know what Rufus has told you all, but he's lying!" 

 

“Lay down your weapons, your highness!” shouted one of the knights, his voice difficult to hear over the din of battle, “We only wish to clear up this misunder–”

 

“Fuck that! You killed your own father, didn’t you, boy?!” shouted another knight, the vitriol in his voice catching Dimitri off guard, “You see how easily he kills his own countrymen!”

 

Dimitri opened his mouth to defend himself, before the second knight charged at him, raising his sword to cut down the prince. Yet the blade never hit since Dedue blocked the strike, while Felix moved quickly, his sword stabbing into the opening of the knight's armor. 

 

"Keep your focus, boar!" Felix shouted as the knight gurgled on his blood. 

 

"Did you see that!? The Frauldarius heir has turned traitor as well!" 

 

"No, he was just defending his highness!" 

 

"It's all the fault of that dastard from Duscur!"

 

Dimitri watched on in horror as the knights turned at one another, their arguments quickly escalating before one stabbed the other with a spear. “NO! STOP, STOP!”

 

“They’re not going to listen to reason!” Felix snapped, scowling at the increasing bloodshed, “We need to–”

 

“I can stop them!” Dimitri insisted, staring at the carnage with wide, horrified eyes, “I am their prince, I have to–”

 

Dedue suddenly pushed him back and Dimitri nearly fell just from the surprise. A moment later, he saw why his friend had pushed him as a number of knights in white armor drove their horses into the melee, trampling Kingdom forces and piercing through them with their lances.

 

It didn’t matter whether they’d been arguing for or against Dimitri; the men died all the same, blue cloth and steel staining red under the church’s cavalry.

 

"Your highness, get back to the monastery!" Gilbert shouted, moving up to cover the students. "This is too dangerous for you!" 

 

"Gonna have to agree with him, Dimitri, I think this is a lost cause," Sylvain added, frowning heavily.

 

"Y-Yeah, the knights have it handled!" Annette agreed, her face pale as she stared at the bloodbath before her. Moving between the students, Mercedes did her best to heal any wounds she saw. 

 

"We can cover you as you move!" Ashe called, an arrow drawn as he kept an eye on anyone trying to approach Ingrid in the air. 

 

"Reinforcements coming around the corner!" Ingrid shouted, before ducking a volley of arrows aimed her way. 

 

Tearing his eyes away from the corpses, Dimitri saw a group of knights approaching. Clad in black armor, their leader wore a horned helm. They looked nothing like the forces the students had just faced, and the leader had a cruel smirk on his face as he looked at Dimitri. 

 

"So this is the wayward prince," he remarked, his horse coming to a halt. 

 

"Halt! If you have any honor as a knight of Faerghus, you will stand down now!" Gilbert shouted, moving in front of the students.

 

"As if I would be a knight like those beasts. Though I may be working with them, I am not bound by the ‘honor’ they cling to. I am Anaximandros, and I am above such petty concerns." 

 

Something ticked in Dimitri’s brain as he stared at the black-armored knight. Somewhere deep in his mind, he remembered a conversation he had with Edelgard. About the ones who were truly behind the Tragedy of Duscur, fanning the flames of war between their nations. And in a moment, he felt a sudden rush as he realized just how truly stupid he was being.

 

All of a sudden, laughter echoed through the battlefield, catching everyone there off guard as they looked around for the source, before realizing it was Dimitri laughing. 

 

Anaximandros seemed more amused than unnerved though. "To think, such a small amount of blood is all it took to break him."

 

"Boar, what are you doing–"

 

"You're part of them aren't you?" Dimitri asked, his hand clenching onto his spear. "The same group as Solon. The same group that caused the Tragedy." 

 

The students stared, their eyes wide and confused by what Dimitri was talking about. 

 

"...ahaha!" The horned knight laughed. "Ah, it seems you aren't as idiotic as your Uncle said." 

 

“What do you know?!” he snapped, pointing his spear directly at Anaximandros, “How much do you know about what happened that night!? Were you one of the people behind it!?”

 

“Behind it? That’s what you think?” The helm showed just enough of the pale man’s face to display the truly vile smirk he had. “I was there, boy. You didn’t think we’d leave everything up to a pack of wild beasts, did you?”

 

The knight suddenly felt his head jerk back, his helm getting blown off as Dimitri’s spear went shooting past him, barely being deflected. 

 

"KILL THEM ALL!" Dimitri ordered, charging forward as he grabbed a spear from a fallen knight. 

 

“Wh–Your highness!”

 

“Damn it Boar, this isn’t the time for–!” Felix tried to shout, only for Dedue to rush forward, bringing his shield up as the dark knights unleashed blasts of dark magic right at their group. 

 

Dedue grit his teeth, trying to keep steady as the magic impacted his shield and began to corrode the metal. He held firm, but Dimitri didn’t focus on that, instead rushing past his friend with his spear in hand and a vicious scowl on his face that morphed into a maddened grin as he rushed towards Anaximandros, the leader’s pale face and dark hair bared while his golden eyes narrowed in an angered glare.

 

“You vile beast!” he snarled, urging his steed forward and leveling his lance to pierce through the prince’s chest. Two blasts of magic made his lance move to the side just enough for Dimitri to slip past. With another scream of fury and leap to bring him level with the knight, Dimitri jammed his spear into the leader's chest, the armor almost breaking under the force of the prince's crest. Yet it held strong enough for Anaximandros, with a furious scowl, to slam his fist into Dimitri’s face, a crack sounding out as the prince fell backwards, his broken nose bleeding. 

 

"Got you!" Sylvain shouted, riding past to grab his prince.

 

"L-Let go!" Dimitri shouted, struggling while his friend took him away, “I need to kill him! I need to avenge–!”

 

"Get him back to the monastery!" Gilbert shouted as the students began to retreat, the knights covering their escape. Struggling in Sylvain's grasp, Dimitri nearly freed himself, before stopping when he saw clouds begin to part. The sounds of battle drained away as he watched a swarm of meteors begin to descend towards the monastery. 

"Emperor Edelgard, lay down your weapons-" Crushing the knight with her axe, Edelgard kept her guard up as she immediately twisted around to smash an assassin in the face with her shield. With the two down, she braced herself against her shield, enduring a cutting gale before charging forward into the mage's ranks, nearly breaking a wall when she smashed the mage against it. 

 

Hearing the screams of the mages next to her, she silently thanked Hubert and Monica for dealing with the threats while she took the moment to catch her breath. 

 

The Kingdom’s forces were many, but most of them were regular knights. They, however, weren't the problem, and she knew it was only a matter of time till the Agarthans unleashed their own soldiers. Sighing, Edelgard returned to her two retainers. 

 

"Lady Edelgard!" Running up to her, Monica handed her a concoction, the Emperor downing it in a moment to revitalize herself. 

 

"Your majesty, you may not like to hear this, but it might be time to consider our means of retreat,” Hubert brought up, “The knights can't hold off these forces forever, and I'm not certain how well we can last if we try to wait for Bergliez's forces." 

 

"We'll hold on as long as we can," Edelgard responded, "We can't allow the kingdom to take the monastery." 

 

"Even so, you need to consider your own safety." 

 

“In the short term, my safety is much more in question if the church’s forces are routed. In the long term, the monastery is a dangerous location for the kingdom’s forces to take. Its central position makes it an excellent staging ground for attacks all across Fodlan, and it will be difficult to retake if they manage to seize it and fortify themselves.” Edelgard turned back towards the encroaching army, taking note of how the church’s knights fared against the kingdom’s soldiers. At the moment, there seemed to be a clash of quality against quantity. “So, at the very least, we need to make this venture too costly for them to maintain a hold on the monastery.”

 

"Well, I can see the benefit of that." 

 

"Yeah, you shouldn't doubt her majesty, Hubert!" Monica said, even if she also wanted to get Edelgard out of there. Sighing in response, Hubert looked out over the battlefield. 

 

"Edelgard!" Glancing over, Edelgard saw the rest of the Eagles running up to them, haggard but uninjured. She felt a smile come onto her face as she saw her friends, especially when she saw Byleth covering them from behind. 

 

"I'm glad to see you're all okay," 

 

"Ferdie was able to do a surprisingly good job,'' Dorothea said, getting the young noble to preen for a moment. 

 

"Of course, though I wouldn't say it is much of a surprise–Ah, never mind that. What is the plan now?" Ferdinand asked, glancing between the Emperor and Professor. 

 

"We try to help out as much as we can, but we need to be ready to leave at any moment," Byleth said, a frown on her face. 

 

"What? So we're just running away!?" Caspar exclaimed. 

 

"A good hunter does know when it is prudent to end the hunt," Petra pointed out, “There is no shame to be retreating from a battle that is unable to be won.”

 

“Ah…yeah, I guess so. Still, we’re not gonna do anything to help take these guys down?”

 

“It’s more important to make sure all of you are safe,” Byleth stated, though she seemed worried, looking around the area with a faint frown, “...I’ll try to send Jeralt over here. He can help.”

 

"W-Wait, you're leaving??" Bernadetta asked, her nerves already shot. 

 

"Just to find Jeralt," 

 

"Hm, well, I can see the benefit of having such a skilled captain at our side," Constance muttered. 

 

"Don't suppose I'll be able to sneak in a nap while we wait…" Linhardt murmured, before jolting when Hapi outright smacked him upside the head.

 

“Not the time, Lin. Play the sleepy boy when we actually have time for it.”

 

“Mnh, fine, I’ll try to focus. But I really shouldn’t be on the frontlines anyway–”

 

“Then hang back and heal the injured if you truly cannot handle the fighting,” Edelgard suggested, frowning, “Where is Flayn?”

 

“Back at the cathedral,” Byleth answered, “She’s with the knights there, helping with the evacuations. Apparently there are secret tunnels, which will be our route out of here.”

 

“I see. Then allow me to go with you–”

 

“No. I know–I know Shez said I shouldn’t do everything by myself, but your priority should be making sure you and everyone else can get out of here. I can handle–”

 

“You’re missing an eye, professor.”

 

“I know I am, but I can’t–” Byleth abruptly stilled, a look of genuine horror crossing her face as she whirled around, staring at the sky. “ALL OF YOU, BACK TO THE CATHEDRAL, NOW!”

 

“Wh–Profess–” 

 

Edelgard didn’t hesitate. She grabbed Ferdinand and pulled him with her, satisfied to see Hubert and Monica quickly doing similar. The rest of the Eagles moved too, rapidly realizing their professor was completely serious about there being a very real danger, especially when she took steps to push anyone who wasn’t moving quickly enough to hurry back to the cathedral.

 

The danger made itself known to the students as they saw a swarm of meteors coming down from the heavens, crashing down onto the monastery. The boulders launched earlier felt like pebbles in comparison to the damage done by each meteor that landed, immense conflagrations erupting all around the monastery. 

 

As the students ran across the bridge, Byleth tried to get her students to move as quickly as they could, one final meteor coming down directly towards the bridge. Hearing a scream, she looked back to see Dorothea on the floor having tripped. Not wasting a moment, she ran back to grab her, helping her up just as the meteors hit the bridge. 

 

Gritting her teeth, Byleth moved as fast as she could, grabbing onto Dorothea with one hand and the Sword of the Creator with the other. As the bridge began to crumble, she swung her sword, the segmented blade extending as they fell. 

 

Clinging onto the mercenary, Dorothea couldn't help but scream, certain she was about to die. A sense of self-loathing hit her at the thought of having caused Byleth’s death as well. 

 

"Don't let go," Byleth said, her tone steady even while Dorothea couldn't feel any ground beneath her…and yet, she didn't feel like she was falling.
