Slowly opening her eyes, she looked around, and saw that she and Byleth were hanging in the air, the Sword of the Creator wrapped around one of the stone poles that hadn't gotten destroyed. "Try not to move too much either." 

 

“...r-right. Right.” Dorothea let out a shaky laugh, keeping her arms wrapped tight around Byleth. “I’ll do my best…”

 

“Good.” Byleth kept her own grip tight on her sword, her finger fixed firmly to its hilt. She wasn’t quite sure if her plan would work, but she didn’t have many other options, so she willed the blade to start retracting. But instead of the blade getting pulled back towards the hilt, the hilt began pulling her up towards the blade.

 

Okay good, it worked. She let out a small sigh, glad she was able to save on a charge for later. 

 

Up above them she could hear panicked screams, calling out to the two, before they changed into one's of relief as Byleth made it up to the edge, helping Dorothea up onto the bridge before climbing up herself. 

 

"Are you two okay?!" She heard her students calling, as the pair were helped up. Moving into the Cathedral, Byleth glanced behind herself at the monastery. 

 

"This is horrifying…" Marianne managed to sum up her thoughts simply enough as she stared out at the destruction before her. She couldn't see the entire monastery, but she could see fires spreading across the grounds and smoke billowed out into the air. 

 

Shaking her head, Byleth moved into the cathedral, looking for someone specifically, though she did pause for a brief moment when she noticed a horse was in the cathedral, before she spotted Flayn sitting against a wall. Running towards her, Byleth knelt down by her. "Flayn, are you okay?" 

 

"Professor? What happened?" the young girl asked, seemingly exhausted. She didn't look worn out from using her magic too much, she just seemed…tired. Byleth felt a bitter taste in her mouth as she was reminded that Flayn was probably in a battle like this, probably even one far more dangerous in the past. 

 

"Everyone's okay, we're going to focus on getting everyone out, okay?" 

 

"Is Seteth okay?" 

 

"Seteth is smart, he knows how to take care of himself. Don't worry, I'm sure we'll see him soon enough. I just need you to promise me something." Byleth said, reaching down to grab her hand. "Please keep everyone safe, okay? Please, from one Nabatean to another." 

 

That got Flayn to blink in surprise. "...Did Lady Rhea tell you?" 

 

"Something like that. And I have a lot of questions to ask when I get back, so make sure to stay safe, okay?"

 

"Wait, where are you going?" Flayn asked, trying to grab onto her hand before Byleth pulled away, already heading back to the broken bridge. 

 

“I’m going back to get my family. I promise, I’ll be back soon.” With that, she began running, ignoring the voices of her students for a moment in favor of sprinting towards the shattered bridge and swinging her sword out as she leapt, now using the blade to pull herself across the gap in a planned move instead of a moment of desperation.

 

Landing on the other side, Byleth let out a sigh, ready to fight. Up until an axe sank into the wall a few feet away from her. 

 

"YOUR MAJESTY, WHAT ARE YOU DOING!?" Blinking, Byleth turned around and felt her eyes widen as she saw Edelgard taking a running leap across the gap. Byleth felt that if her heart beat it would have stilled as she saw Edelgard practically fly over the gap, before she began to fall. Throwing herself forward, Byleth grabbed onto her outstretched hand before the Emperor could plummet. 

 

“Why would you–”

 

“Ask me after you pull me up, my teacher,” Edelgard requested, smiling despite the situation. With a small grunt, Byleth pulled her up. "Thank you, now I hope you forgive me." 

 

"For jump–" A smack sounded out as Edelgard slapped Byleth. 

 

"Professor, you need to listen to your sister more. You can't handle everything on your own." 

 

“...” Byleth blinked. She stared at Edelgard, then blinked again because she’d just felt the strangest thump in her chest when she was slapped and had no idea what to feel right now. "...Can you help me find Shez so I can apologize?" 

 

"Gladly, my teacher," Edelgard agreed, before offering her hand to Byleth. With a small smile, Byleth took it.

 

Across the broken bridge, Dorothea let out a sigh as she leaned against a wall, watching her classmates, and Monica, panic over what just happened while Ferdinand and Hubert tried to restore order. "I can't believe I'm in love with those two dummies. Though I guess that just means I'm the bigger idiot." 

Myson smiled as he took a slow breath in through his nose. “Do you smell that, Odesse?”

 

“Burning flesh, sir?”

 

“Yes, but not quite. It’s the reek of devastation. Of our long awaited triumph over the beasts that stole our lands. Today…we butcher every last one of those abominations and put an end to the false faith of the so-called goddess.”

 

Odesse nodded beneath his new mask, now wearing the armor of the Flame Emperor over his Acheron guise. Because what was a plan worth if it wasn’t used, even with the occasional inconvenience? “Indeed we shall, my lord! Though, what of the hegemon? She is present in the monastery, is she not?”

 

“She is, and if she dies, then so be it. It will be more convenient for us in the long run, really. Though if she survives, I have other plans. Dolofonos should be releasing Duke Aegir soon enough, and once Bergliez, Hevring, and Varley are dead, she’ll have lost her allies among the ministers.”

 

“...Er, sir, pardon my contradiction, but wasn’t Varley one of ours?”

 

“...Was he? Huh. Well, if he was, he clearly wasn’t important enough to keep alive if I forgot.”

 

“As you say, sir.”

 

Myson nodded to himself, watching the chaos unfolding as the fields around the town were crushed under flame and rock, before glancing over to the caster who unleashed such devastation, who was clutching her knees and panting with exertion as she tried to keep herself standing. “Oh Bias, you didn’t die. A successful trial then!”

 

“F-Fuck you too, Myson,” Bias grunted, sweat pouring down her head as the circlet she wore gleamed in the fire light. It wasn’t the only piece of jewelry on her; her hands and arms were covered in crest-stone embedded artificial bone. A similar choker encircled her throat, acting as a collar for the fettered sage. “Th-That…That took a lot from me…”

 

“Fascinating…preliminary trials did show a high cost associated with the high power used, though the fact you survived…well, I can’t help but wonder, are you able to continue?”

 

“...C-Can’t cast anything like that again…can’t even say it would kill me, I just physically can’t. The magic’s out of reach…”

 

“Truly fascinating. We should keep that in mind then. It’s not exactly a replacement for the orbital defense missiles, but it is something to keep in mind.” He took a mental note of how she appeared to be bleeding from her eyes. Then a small frown came to his face as he took note of the cracks in the gems set in her jewelry. One of which fractured entirely and crumpled free from her wrist. “Hm. It seems the amplifiers have a limit too. How unfortunate.”

 

“S-So no more than once with these, huh? Feh, you make some shoddy shit, Myson.”

 

He chuckled. “I’ll allow that for now, Bias. You did do excellent work with my ‘shoddy’ craftsmanship. Do you think you could finish the job though? Put the rest of the town to the torch with your natural magic, perhaps? I’m sure Chilon and Anaximandros would appreciate the help.”

 

“Why would I want to help those pricks?”

 

“Perhaps for a sense of satisfaction as you burn down everything the beasts built?”

 

“...doesn’t feel that satisfying, honestly,” she muttered, staring at the destruction with a dull gaze.

 

“Really? Shame. Ah well. Odesse, give the signal.”

 

“Oh, of course sir!” Odesse promptly raised a hand and launched a bolt of darkness upwards. It wasn’t nearly as impressive of a spell as Meteor, just a burst of darkness against the sky. It did, however, serve as a signal to the other Agarthan forces.

 

And with mighty howls of vicious rage, the demonic beasts were unleashed. The enormous monsters tore free of the cages they were brought in and charged the shattered gates, uncaring of any soldiers in their way as they barreled into the ruined, burning town.

 

They were joined soon enough by their flying counterparts, who began flying at whatever pegasi and wyverns they could get at, while a group of large knights in pitch-black armor stood as one and began to warp up to the walls, heeding their orders and cutting down everyone in their master’s way.

 

“What a beautiful day,” Myson remarked, smiling as smoke began to smother the sky and dye it a lovely crimson.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Man things escalated huh?

Red: To think, once this story was about cute shenanigans...ah well.

Indi: I'm sure we'll get shenanigans again. Once we get passed all the destruction. Maybe.

Red: Maybe! At some point! Eventually...possibly.

Silvered Sorrow

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

“Damn, this is getting bad,” Claude muttered under his breath, trying to keep an eye out for his friends among the smoke and fire. He spotted Ingrid flying off, which was a very bad sign, and a glance down showed a shock of red hair riding away too. “And the brave lions are turning tail…not a bad idea, honestly.”

 

First things first though, he should at least try to find his friends. He’d had a better chance of surviving with them, after all, and he’d probably used up most of his luck already managing to avoid all those meteors…that, and he actually liked his fellow deer enough to want them to make it out of there. So down he flew, trying to avoid the other fliers fighting in the sky, though he did have to shoot down a few blue pegasus knights on the way. While the door to the entrance hall was crumbled, the gaping hole from the meteor left Claude enough space for him to dive through the burning rubble.

 

"Anyone here!?" Claude shouted as he looked around. 

 

He heard some faint shouting under some rubble. Turning back towards the entrance, he moved towards it, grabbing onto the debris as he and his wyvern helped dig someone out. Underneath he found Shez huddled over an unconscious Lysithea. 

 

"H-Help…" Shez managed to get out, getting Claude to grimace as he saw the blood leaking from her head. Moving quickly, he helped them out, giving Shez a hand to get up. 

 

"Shit, this doesn't look good," he muttered, seeing Shez barely able to stand, while Lysithea seemed to have a broken arm. 

 

"Wh-Where's Manuela?" Shez asked, as Claude helped her walk. 

 

"Over by the barracks, come on, give me Lysithea," Claude said, taking the mage from Shez to lift her up on his wyvern. Though as he turned around, he saw Shez standing still, before suddenly straightening up. "Uh, you good Shez?" 

 

"Yeah. You go on ahead, I need to find the Ashen Dragon." 

 

“What?” He immediately frowned, his eyes narrowing. “Why would you call your sister–”

 

Shez didn’t reply, instead vanishing in a burst of strangely fiery shadows.

 

“...Damn it, this really isn’t the time for Shez to go crazy…” He sighed, before pausing as his wyvern nudged him, looking uncomfortable being inside the crumbling building. “Yeah, we should get Lysithea out of here. I doubt you like all this heat and dust either…then again, you guys live in deserts–”

 

The wyvern chuffed.

 

“Right, let’s get going.” Hopefully he could find Shez soon. 

Jeralt was in hell. He’d been on battlefields before, spent most of his life moving from one to another, but none of them hit the same level of hellishness as the burning landscape he now found himself in. The fact that it was the monastery, his home for centuries, just added to how shit everything felt.

 

Then again, that might be his own ancient body straining to keep itself together after all the exertion he’d already gone through. Being flat on his aching back wasn’t helping things either, especially with the ringing in his ears.

 

The fact that he didn't know where his kids were only added to it all. 

 

“Hey Captain, you alive around here?!” Well at least Victor survived. 

 

"Yeah, I'm here," he huffed, pushing himself up as he saw Victor approaching. "Where's everyone else?" 

 

"Keeping people safe. I was the only one brave enough to come and find you!" Victor said, laughing as he clapped the captain on his back. 

 

"Good to know everyone's okay. Have you seen Byleth or Shez?" 

 

"Uh, last I saw the deer kids were by the entrance hall? Shez is probably with them." 

 

“Right. We’re going there then. I’m finding my kids.”

 

“You got it, captain. We find the kids, get everyone else that’s alive together, and get out of here,” Victor agreed, nodding to Jeralt before handing him a lance, earning a small grin from the captain.

 

“Thanks. Come on, let’s see if everyone is alright.”

 

They weren’t, obviously. Meteors raining down on the monastery meant people were going to die, and he felt a grimace come to his face when he saw knights he recognized broken on the ground, blood staining their formerly white armor.

 

“Captain, Vic! There you are!” came a familiar voice, and Jeralt felt a slight increase in his mood when he saw Candace riding over, atop a familiar steed.

 

“Hey Candace. Thanks for bringing Argo,” Jeralt greeted, a small smile on his face as his horse moved over to him with a happy neigh.

 

“Yeah, of course! Not like I’m gonna leave the big boy behind, he’s practically part of the family!” she replied with a cheerful grin that didn’t really fit the situation. But hey, it was nice to see anyway. “Don’t worry, I made sure to get the other horses outta there too. Even helped that blue-haired girl get hers over to the cathedral!”

 

“...I’m glad you have your priorities in order, Candace," Jeralt muttered as she hopped off his horse. "Now come on, we have to find my kids before we leave."

 

"Got it!" With a salute, the trio got ready to move, before something appeared before them. Standing upright, a figure clad in black armor and soaked in blood turned its gaze towards them. Even missing an arm, the figure didn't seem any less imposing as it lifted its remaining arm, aiming its axe at them. 

 

"Move!" Jeralt shouted, bringing up his lance to catch the haft of the axe before it could sink into his head. Gritting her teeth, he pushed back against the monster as his lieutenants moved to flank it. With a roar, the two attacked, Candace shoving her spear into the opening where its arm once was, as Victor split its head in two. 

 

The creature seemed to shudder for a moment, before it let out a guttural strangled roar, flailing about and sending the mercenaries back. 

 

"Captain, what the hell is this thing!?" Candace asked, bringing her fists up since her spear was still in the monster.

 

"How am I supposed to know!?" Jeralt shouted back, keeping his eyes on the monster, as it charged back in. 

 

"Well if this thing kills me I expect a raise!" Running in as Jeralt did his best to defend, Victor aimed his axe to cleave off the creature's legs, only for it to vanish. Staring wide eyed, Jeralt noticed a shadow. Looking up, he saw the monster somehow above them, plunging down to drive its axe into him. 

 

Up until a scythe went spinning through the air, jamming into its back and sending the creature flying across the yard to smash into a bloodied pulp against a mound of rubble.

 

"TO THINK I WOULD HAVE SO MANY WORTHY OPPONENTS HERE!" And things took a turn for the worse as a familiar opponent appeared, astride an armored horse. "I MUST THANK MY MASTER FOR THIS OPPORTUNITY!" 

 

Scowling, Jeralt got ready to face off against the Death Knight, prepared for whatever he did. 

 

"WHAT ARE YOU DOING HERE!?" Up until the voice of the Emperor cut in, getting the Death Knight to stiffen. Turning their heads, everyone there saw Edelgard and Byleth rapidly approaching.

 

"MASTER? I AM FULFILLING OUR CONTRACT–"

 

"The contract is canceled! There is no third mission!" 

 

"...OH." The heavily armored knight seemed sheepish, almost fidgeting in his saddle as his horse shuffled anxiously in response to his awkwardness. “I…SEE.”

 

"...Kid, what's going on?" Jeralt asked, looking at Byleth. 

 

"I'll explain later. I'm glad to see you're okay, Papa," Byleth said, before stepping in close to hug him. 

 

"...Glad to see you're okay too," Jeralt replied, hugging her back. He glanced at Edelgard berating Jeritza. "...we're still going to talk about this later." 

 

"Good news captain, this thing is dead!" Candace said, ripping her spear out of the formerly undead creature. 

 

"Hm, lucky shot I guess," Victor muttered. 

 

"THERE IS NO LUCK. I FOUGHT ONE WHILE COMING HERE, THEY HAVE A WEAKNESS," the knight stated, moving over to the creature, and ripped his scythe out of it. At the end of the blade was a cracked orb, the weapon having pierced it. 

 

"What is that?" Edelgard muttered, looking at the orb, before the cracks spread and shattered. 

 

"Well, whatever it is, at least we know where to aim," Jeralt noted, frowning at the corpse, wary that it might move again. 

 

"Better than nothing I guess,” Victor huffed as they got ready to move. Letting go of Jeralt, Byleth moved to lead the group, ready to find the rest of the mercenaries and Shez, before she noticed someone shuffling towards them. 

 

Her eye widened when she saw Shez walking towards her, soaked in blood and shambling about as if in a daze. "SHEZ!" Running forward, she grabbed onto her sister, helping her stand as she began to heal her. Byleth could hear the others scrambling behind her, trying to get a good look at Shez, while the purple-haired mercenary mumbled something. "What? What happened?" 

 

A loud roar pierced through the monastery, getting everyone to stiffen and look at the unexpected sight of a white-scaled dragon emerging from the burning monastery, its wings spreading wide as it tore free of the rubble. Roaring again, it flew into the air with a number of black armored monsters clinging onto it, trying to stab or cut into its body. 

 

"Got you." 

 

"..." Byleth let out a cough, feeling something warm running down her chin while the same warm feeling covered her chest. Looking down, she saw her sister, smiling gleefully as she plunged her sword into her. 

 

Genuine confusion hit her before anything else. Because what she was seeing wasn’t possible. It just wasn’t–

 

“Turn back time, now!” Sothis yelled in her ear, and Byleth felt a tug on her body as her ability activated on instinct, pulling her back before she’d taken the blade to the chest. 

 

She was still close to her sister, she was still healing Shez, but this time her arms shot out, catching Shez’s wrist before the blade could form.

 

“Tch. Cheater.” 

 

Her sister’s voice sounded wrong. There was some distortion in it, like another person was speaking with her voice– “Arval?”

 

She spoke without thinking, the idea coming to her in a sudden rush. She knew Shez had a spirit following her, just like Sothis; she’d even had that spirit with her for much longer than Byleth had hers. So it was the only thought that made sense.

 

“Not quite.” It was still wrong though. The thing wearing her sister’s face smiled. It was a cruel smile, malice dripping from the expression. Then it dropped entirely, back to a cold focus. “I am Epimenides. And you, Fell Star, will meet your end today.”

 

And with that, the pair of them vanished, earning a panicked shout from Jeralt when they disappeared from his sight.

 

Byleth stumbled, not expecting the sudden rush of her sister’s ability to vanish at will. She found her footing and felt a flash of recognition as she realized they were at the training hall–Then she had to raise her sword, catching Shez’s blade before it could pierce her chest again.

 

Byleth had sparred with her sister before. She knew how Shez fought. And Epimenides knew how she fought too. 

 

Their strikes came lightning fast, each swing and stab moving fluidly from one to another in a rapid onslaught, intent on cutting Byleth down before she could react. The problem was, Byleth knew exactly how to react; every cut was blocked, each stab deflected, and when she saw an opening, she–

 

She didn’t take it. How could she? This was her sister.

 

“Shez, I know you’re in there!” she called out, her sword a moving wall as she blocked every single strike from her foe, “I know you can take back control–”

 

“Of course she’s in here,” Epimenides stated, stilling his onslaught for a moment to regard Byleth with another cold gaze. He placed a hand on his chest. “Shez is my partner. She is aware of what I am doing. And she approves.”

 

“Don’t lie to me.” There was no hesitation in Byleth’s voice. She didn’t believe that claim for a second. “Let her go. Now.”

 

Epimenides scoffed. “You arrogant abomination. Do you truly think you understand the depths of rage in my partner’s heart? You, who so readily abandoned her for the sake of others?”

 

“I think my sister loves me. I love her.” Byleth met the sage’s gaze, her eye narrowed. “And your hand is trembling.”

 

Epimenides paused, glanced at the hand clenched around his sword and scowled when he saw its grip faltering. “A foolish sentimentality. She will learn better.”

 

"What is your problem? What did Sothis even do to you!" Byleth demanded to know, getting Epimenides to glare at her. 

 

“She stole this world from us. My people once dwelled in glory. We would have burned as bright as the sun and you took it all! ” he suddenly shouted, appearing right in front of Byleth and swinging his sword at her head.

 

She caught the blade with the Sword of the Creator, then felt another rush as they suddenly warped, her feet catching on the tiles of the roof. The pair of them exchanged blows, Epimenides striking to kill while Byleth remained defensive and unwilling to harm her sister, before another roar caught their attention.

 

The white dragon screeched up in the sky as demonic beasts tried to swarm it, their teeth managing to catch on its flesh, though its retaliation was swift and brutal. Its claws rent through flesh while blasts of light scoured through the dark monsters, ripping them from the air, before its head reared back and light began to gather in its maw.

 

“Filthy beast…” Epimenides growled, his face a rictus of hatred at the sight of his ancient foe, before he turned back to Byleth. “Do you see!? Do you see what they are!? Nothing more than monsters, abominations cloaking themselves in human flesh! They dare take our shape when they are nothing more than arrogant animals!”

 

“You went to her birthday party,” Byleth retorted, sword at the ready.

 

“I was not speaking to you ,” Epimenides sneered, before charging at Byleth again as the beam of light lit up the sky, scouring the monsters that tried to swarm the Immaculate One.

 

Their blades clashed and when they warped again, Byleth had a moment to steady herself as she found herself on the couch of the knight's barracks, before being kicked back by Epimenides. 

 

"Woah!" Someone yelled as she crashed onto the ground, before flipping upright as Epimenides tried to stab her. Looking around, she could see several wounded in the barracks being tended to, with one class in particular inside. "Teach, Shez? What's going on?" 

 

"Shez is being controlled by magic, watch out!" Byleth managed to warn in time as Claude took a step forward, Lorenz grabbing him by his collar and pulling him back before he could get cut down by Epimenides. 

 

"Come to think of it, I might as well clear out the beasts trying to control this land," Epimenides decided, turning his gaze to the nobles of the Deer, who stiffened at the genuine malice in their friend’s eyes.

 

"Shez, I don't know what's going on, but we’re here for you. Whatever this is, I’m sure you can fight it!" Manuela stated, moving protectively in front of the students and making the sage scowl. Though before he could say anything, he was forced to swing his sword to cut apart a weak Seraphim launched at his vessel. 

 

"L-Leave my apprentice alone…" Lysithea managed to get out, breathing heavily from the cot she was laid out on. 

 

“Contemptible beast. You dare proclaim yourself the master of my–” A jolt went up the sage’s arm, making Epimenides scowl. “Stop fighting me! You know these beasts are worthless! Nothing more than filth, laying claim to lands they have no right to!”

 

“Hey, I don’t see your name on it!” Raphael called out, “Which the nobles actually do have! Right?”

 

“...well that is actually accurate,” Lorenz noted, nodding thoughtfully, “My surname is the name of my territory–”

 

“Is now really the time, guys?” Hilda asked, before stepping forward, “Look, whoever you are, leave Shez alone! I don’t know how you’re controlling her–”

 

“I am not controlling her. I am her partner, she is my vessel, and you filthy beasts have no claim to her!” Epimenides snapped, white markings spreading over more of Shez’s skin as his rage grew.

 

"Ha, if you were her actual partner she would have told us about you! Guess you aren't that important to her!" Balthus taunted, making Epimenides rage spike even further. 

 

"Yeah, as far as we can tell, you're just some obsessed weirdo!" Leonie further taunted. 

 

"Shez is our friend, and we aren't just going to let you take her." 

 

"Well you heard them," Claude said, following off of Ignatz, "I don't know what your problem is, but we'd like you to leave Shez out of it." 

 

Epimenides growled, about to attack, before he was suddenly grappled from behind by Byleth. "Let go of me, you abomination!" 

 

“I’m here. I’m here, Shez, I’m here for you,” Byleth murmured, her voice quiet and soothing as Epimenides felt his body still for a moment.

 

Then he snarled and pulled on the dark powers that were his to command, vanishing again with the Fell Star in tow.

 

Pushing her off as they landed in the town, Epimenides could still hear the sounds of battle raging out as he turned to face Byleth. "I'm going to enjoy killing all of you." 

 

"Shez?" a surprised voice said, getting the pair to look over and see Ashe standing nearby. 

 

"Don't get near her Ashe, it's dangerous!" Byleth said, moving in front of him. "Where's the rest of the Lions?" 

 

"W-We got separated, I was trying to catch up to them," Ashe explained, the young boy looking between the two in confusion. 

 

"Then you best just scurry away. That's all you beasts are good for. Though, where would you even run to? Your father is dead, after all. Murdered by the one trying to protect you now," Epimenides taunted, sneering with Shez’s face.

 

Ashe stiffened, his grip on his bow trembling–

 

“Stop that. Don’t mock him,” Byleth ordered, glaring at Epimenides.

 

The sage stared at her for a moment, before that cruel smile appeared on his face for just a second. He straightened, his visage cold and callous. “So again you defend everyone else. You said it yourself, Fell Star. That beast’s father murdered my partner, and yet you defend him? But then, you don’t care, do you? You’ve only made her life worse from that first moment you shot an arrow into her side.”

 

Byleth flinched, but moved when Epimenides vanished again, catching his blade on her own and bracing herself as they warped again, her feet landing on solid stone again.

 

“–just need to get to Abyss, Yuri’s organizing–wha-?”

 

“Shez?” Dimitri paused, ceasing his struggles for a moment when he recognized his former classmate. Dedue and Gilbert paused too, their grip on his limbs loosening as they saw Byleth and Shez exchanging blows, the sisters’ swords clashing again and again.

 

There were more exclamations of shock and surprise as Epimenides leapt away from Byleth and landed on a piece of rubble, regarding the Lions with interest. “Here we are. The first class my partner joined. The beasts that drew her into this vile place.”

 

“What are you talking about?” Byleth asked, moving in front of the students on instinct, ready to shield them in case Epimenides attacked.

 

“Professor? What the hell is going on?!” Felix exclaimed, staring between the two of them in confused shock.

 

“A good question, scion of Fraldarius,” Epimenides remarked, and the Lions present all stiffened at the unfamiliar voice speaking with Shez’s mouth, “You see, Fell Star, I thought it best to impart some truths. You already know what you are. The false goddess incarnated, the vessel of a monstrosity that invaded this world millennia ago. But do you know what they are? Do you have any idea why these beasts hold the power they do?

 

He looked almost bored. It was a deliberate affectation, an act of coldness and composure. Everyone there could see the fiery glow in their friend’s eyes, and the malice dripping from her blood-soaked body. “I gave it to them. These friends of yours? Their ancestors were my collaborators.”

 

“...what?” Byleth stared at him, confused, yet…feeling a strange sense of dread. “What are you talking about?”

 

“What does he mean…?” She heard Sothis say, the goddess’s voice echoing softly in Byleth’s ears.

 

“The great hero Nemesis, the King of Liberation. Do you know what that brute liberated the world from? Do you know who he and his heroes stood against?” He spread his arms, as though encompassing the world. “They stood against you, Fell Star, and your abominations. They stood against Sothis and her Nabateans. They drank of their blood and used their bodies as weapons. And do you know who they have to thank for that?" 

 

Byleth felt her body shiver as she took a step back, as if afraid of what he was about to say. 

 

"It was pure speculation at first. Despite how detestable they were, it couldn't be denied that the Nabateans were stronger than we humans. We wondered if we could make that power our own, so of course we had to test it out. Beast though he was, I must admit that he was a useful guinea pig. After all, he helped show how strong my masterpiece is." He smiled at Byleth. "It's truly a shame I wasn't able to kill you myself, but defiling you and your children's corpse more than made up for it." 

 

Byleth felt dizzy, as if she was about to collapse. Beside her she could see Sothis grabbing her head, clearly in some kind of pain. 

 

"Ah, but don't worry, you still have at least one child," Epimenides said, pointing up at the Immaculate One in the sky. "For now, that is. I wonder just what kind of weapon I could fashion from her…oh I know, I'll make a sword out of her spine! It will pair quite wonderfully with yours." 

 

Something snapped. Byleth wasn't sure what exactly, but the next thing she knew she was being yanked backwards. Shaking her head, she was able to focus and saw…herself. 

 

"I'LL KILL YOU!" The green-haired Byleth shouted, charging forward at Epimenides. 

 

With a grin that seemed almost manic, Epimenides clashed blades with Sothis. 

 

And all around them, the air burned with emerald flames and violet shadows.

The fields outside the walls of Garreg Mach were a place of chaos. Soldiers garbed in white and blue clashed across the burnt grass and bloodied dirt while knights in black armor slaughtered any who lacked the blood of Agartha. What was once a peaceful landscape had become a brutal battlefield, and in a flash of shadow, the battle became all the more chaotic.

 

Thunder boomed when the Great Sage Epimenides and the Goddess Sothis clashed blade against blade.

 

"I'll enjoy ending your life!" Epimenides shouted, flashing behind her. 

 

Turning on her heel, Sothis blocked his blade, glaring at the sage. "You'll beg for forgiveness by the time I'm done." 

 

Scowling, Epimenides flashed away, before a fully formed Luna appeared in his hands. With a yell, he launched it at Sothis, who met his spell with a Seraphim.

 

"Is that all your wrath is worth? Incessant taunting and screaming?" Sothis asked, walking forward, her eye alight with divine rage. "You carved up my body once, and you cannot do it again. How pitiful." 

 

"Be silent, you wretched monstrosity!" Epimenides shouted, launching a slew of Dark Spikes at her, each one prematurely exploding as a wall of light appeared before Sothis, the Abraxas fading away as she glared imperiously. 

 

“You celebrate your humanity as though it is something glorious, yet what about you is human?” Sothis questioned, swinging her blade out and carving a furrow in the dirt that erupted with flames, forcing Epimenides back and causing the battling soldiers to break off from their fights, their eyes widening in shock, “You are an arrogant wraith clinging to a life that is not yours to take! And I shall not allow you to hurt these children any longer.”

 

Epimenides scoffed. “What callous arrogance from a foul abomination! You came to our world, pretending at generosity, but all you wanted was subjects to worship your false divinity–!”

 

“Oh do be silent, you petulant creature,” Sothis ordered, the light in her eye glowing brighter as the soldiers on the field found themselves falling to their knees, suddenly aware of the divinity in their presence, “I demanded no worship. I gave without reservation and asked only for a home for my children in turn. One damned canyon was somehow too much for the great cities of Agartha to allow, and when you turned on one another and myself, you truly expected I would not retaliate in return?” 

 

The sneer of disgust looked out of place on Byleth’s face and Epimenides bristled to see it. “You–You had no right to our world! We made ourselves great! We needed no blessings from a monstrosity like you!”

 

Sothis rolled her eye. “Congratulations then, you won. You did kill me, as you so readily taunted. One thousand years past, you butchered my sleeping body and made weapons of my bones and blessings of my blood. And then you did…what, precisely? I do not see a revived Thinis. The names Malum and Septen do not ring through history. Oh, and what of Llium? Is there a nation still existent with that name? No? And yet, you had made your own king? You slayed the Fell Star? You destroyed the Nabateans, you retook Fodlan! And yet…no, how could it be? 

 

Her own tone turned mocking, derision in every word. “You wasted your chance at revival in order to continue squirming in the depths of the earth, intent on nothing more than wallowing in your own sense of superiority until my daughter killed you. Yet here you are, just as I am, lingering long past the point that we should have died. So allow me to be the one to send you off.”

 

“BE SILENT!” Epimenides roared, slamming his hand into the ground and causing it to erupt in massive pillars of jagged earth. 

 

Yet Sothis moved through them, time distorting around her as she stepped everywhere the stones weren’t. And when they threatened to smash into one of the knights, the armored soldier of the Kingdom found himself suddenly on clear dirt, some distance away.

 

Moments later, more soldiers joined him, shock and surprise echoing out as knights of both the Kingdom and Church found themselves out of the way, saved by a divine hand.

 

Then Sothis swung her sword and the erupting mountains were cleaved in half, dirt and rock spilling across the ground. 

 

Epimenides snarled, rage and fury burning in eyes that were not his own as the air twisted with darkness, rent asunder by his anger. Tyrants leapt at his call, the undead warriors following the order of the Great Sage’s blood, before falling to the ground in chunks, split apart by a blade that moved faster than eyes could follow. 

 

Epimenides stared, his eyes widening, before they narrowed again and he growled, the sound more bestial than man. In an instant, demonic beasts poured through the holes he made in the world, portals to bring the monstrosities charging at the goddess in human form. It took more than a single cut to put down the horrors made of humans, by Agarthan hands, but they still died all the same, slain by the approaching deity, whose gait had not once wavered.

 

Epimenides stumbled. For the first time in a very long time, he felt genuine dread enter his heart. “...f-filth. You–You monstrous–”

 

“You are a fool, o’ mortal man,” the goddess intoned, her blade burning with a holy light, “I would have gladly lived in peace, had you allowed it.” Sothis’s voice was little more than a whisper, yet it echoed across the field, bringing tears to the eyes of the soldiers there…and a snarl to the sage’s stolen face.

 

“YOU INVADED OUR LAND! I CARE NOT WHAT GIFTS YOU CLAIM TO HAVE GIVEN! WE ARE THE GUARDIANS OF THIS WORLD, AND YOU ARE NOTHING BUT FILTH LEECHING FROM OUR GLORY!” he screamed, arms thrown wide as he called upon every dark power in his grasp.

 

And in an instant, the goddess moved. Yet no sword swung.

 

Instead, Byleth wrapped her arms tightly around her sister, hugging her as hard as she could.

 

The shadows cut off. The fiery light in her eyes faded. And the halos that bound Shez’s body disappeared.

 

“...h-huh?”

 

“I love you, Shez,” Byleth said, keeping her arms tight around her, “I’m sorry if I ever made you feel like I didn’t. You’re my sister and my best friend. You’re the first person that made me feel happy, sad, frustrated…having you around made me feel like a person instead of something broken.” She took a breath, tears pricking at her eye. “I promise, no matter what happens, you will always be my family.”

 

“...” Shez let out a shaky breath, a sob slipping out. “I…I know…I just…’m stupid…”

 

“You’re not. You’re my brilliant little sister.”

 

Tears began rolling down her cheeks as she returned the hug, her eyes blurring with the emotions going through her…yet, despite the blur in her vision, she still noticed that Byleth had tossed aside the Sword of the Creator to hug her. And in an instant, Shez felt a surge of panic as all of Epimenides’s rage came roaring back. 

 

In one more flash, the two of them warped across the fields of Garreg Mach and wound up outside its main gate, startling the trio of Agarthans overlooking the devastation.

 

“What in the–?” Myson began, his eyes widening.

 

“The Fell Star?!” Bias exclaimed, her hand raising.

 

"She's unarmed!" Epimenides shouted, pushing Byleth back and launching a dark spike at her. Jerking back, Byleth dodged the spell, only to get blasted by a pair of miasmas from Myson and Odesse. 

 

Scowling, Bias tried to cast a spell, only for nothing to come, her magic still dry after her giant meteor swarm. 

 

"Shez, please," Byleth called out, ignoring the pain in her body as she backed up against a wall, "You can win, I know you can!" 

 

Epimenides grit his teeth, trying to fight his disobedient partner while she tried to take control of her body. 

 

"Well well, I must admit, I didn't think you'd bring the Fell Star herself into our laps," Myson said, a grin on his face, "I suppose we really do owe you one, Great Sage." 

 

"Just kill her already!" 

 

"No, I don't think I shall, she's far more–" Whatever Myson was about to say was cut off as a giant roar sounded out. Looking upwards, the group saw the Immaculate One descending upon them, racing to crash into them.

 

Moving quickly, the group managed to evade the dragon crashing into the wall, roaring with divine fury as it curled protectively around Byleth. Its eyes darted, taking in each of the Agarthans, before fixating on Epimenides and taking in the markings spread across Shez’s body. In an instant, the Immaculate One’s mouth opened wide, blue flames gathering before Byleth abruptly grabbed onto her.

 

“NO! No, you can’t–”

 

“Ha, sentimental fool,” Myson taunted, raising his hand as a Bohr gathered there.

 

“She’s really trying to keep her safe?” Bias murmured, staring at the Fell Star’s attempt at protection.

 

Odesse didn’t say anything. Instead, he choked, blood spilling from his mouth as the Great Sage Epimenides shoved his hand into the disguised Agarthan’s chest and crushed his heart.

 

The world shuddered as the void answered the sage’s call. Darkness erupted around the point Byleth and the Immaculate One stood, encircling the both of them in an instant.

 

And for a moment, Byleth felt a twist of fear in her…before she saw her sister. And where half of Shez’s face had been twisted in a rictus of triumphant hatred and fury, the other half was filled with heartbreak and sorrow.

 

“...It’s okay,” Byleth said, giving her sister a reassuring smile, “Stay safe–”

 

And then she was gone.

 

And despite his triumph, despite his victory, Epimenides felt his control slip away entirely as his vessel fell to her knees, her despair burying him deep as she let out a wail of pure anguish.

Chapter End Notes

Red: Happy Four Year Anniversary of Fire Emblem Three Houses, everybody! :D

Indi: It's been a fun four years of three houses, still one of my favorite FE games with some of my favorite characters, like Byleth!

Red: Yup! It's funny to think how fun a character who's emotionally blank for much of her story can be, but hey, it's made it a lot of fun to play around with her development. And hey, of course we gotta have everybody pop up in the anniversary chapter! Well, mostly everybody, but you get the point!

Indi: Well who knows, maybe next anniversary we'll have a chapter where everyone shows up. Not sure if it'll be daughters or a different story, but we'll see!

Red: For now though, thanks for ready, as always! It's great having y'all for our audience, and it's been a lot of fun writing this story!

Golden Dusk

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Tears stinging her eyes, Shez pushed herself up and went to where her sister once stood, trying to find any trace of her. Despite her desperate search, she found nothing at all, the area devoid of all life. 

 

"Hm, what a shame." She heard an Agarthan behind her say, "Not only did we fail to capture the Fell Star, but you also killed Odesse. So much for owing you one, Great Sage." 

 

Shez felt Epimenides try to take over again, before she bit her lip, forcing him back down. 

 

"I'm going to kill you," Shez stated, rage filling her body as she stood up, her sword forming in hand as she glared at the sage who spoke.

 

"Ah, it seems the vessel has taken over again. Today truly is such a mess." Myson sighed, bringing his hand up to form a barrier to block Shez’s attempt to cut him down. "Now how shall you make it up to me?" 

 

Scowling, Shez moved back, trying to fight through her exhaustion with her rage. 

 

"Oh, I know. We were going to capture the Fell Star and keep her alive for samples, but since we can't do that anymore, you'll just have to fill that role," Myson said, a smile on his face, "We'll need to amputate your limbs to make sure you can't escape, but don't worry, we'll keep you alive for as long as we can." 

 

“Fuck you…I’m not–Nh–” She gripped her head, before Epimenides straightened, letting out a sigh. “No need for that. My vessel is under my control–”

 

Then he ducked, feeling the muscles of his body burn as the crackling mix of electricity and darkness that was the Bohr spell went straight over his head. 

 

“I believe I already stated my intended course of action,” Myson remarked, already gathering up his magic for another blast, “A decrepit fossil is worth much more as material than another complication.”

 

“What–What are you talking about!? I am the–”

 

“You’re a relic from a bygone age. I have no need for another sage and I really would prefer keeping you as a test subject.” Myson shrugged. “That and you did kill Odesse, so I do want to mutilate you out of spite.”

 

"I am Epimenides, the Great Sage of Agartha–!" 

 

"Technically you're more akin to a facsimile of the Great Sage,” Myson interrupted, “Epimenides died a tragic death against the abomination's kin. So if you truly wish to make things better for Agartha, then you will offer me your body so we can have replenishable materials for as long as you can last." 

 

"You traitorous swine!" Epimenides shouted, before ducking another blast. 

 

"Sorry to say, but I'm loyal only to the Agastya of Agartha, and well." He stared at Epimenides' current form. "You're a bit…smaller than her." 

 

"Are you really talking about Cleobulus' tits right now?" Bias asked. 

 

“They are her most recognizable feature,” Myson remarked, laughing to himself, "Besides, she shows them off so readily, so it's not like she'd mind." 

 

“...Yeah, that’s fair.” Bias sighed, before glancing at Epimenides, who was glaring furiously at the pair of them. “What? Do you expect me to help? I couldn’t care less about some long dead sage. Especially when you decided to steal my vengeance.”

 

“You–You petty, spiteful–!” 

 

Bias scoffed, rolling her eyes at the furious sage. “We’re Agarthan, you idiot. Of course we’re petty and spiteful. If you don’t know that, you really are out of touch.”

 

Weighing his options, Epimenides looked between the two, well aware that Myson was the bigger threat right now. Though before he could move, more Agarthans arrived, being led by a horse riding knight with fresh scars on his face. "I see you two are having trouble here." 

 

"Only because we're trying to capture this one alive,” Myson replied, “I don't suppose you can help?" 

 

"I make no promises," Anaximandros said, aiming his spear at Epimenides. 

 

"...All of you will suffer by my hands," Epimenides stated, genuine rage in his eyes, before he suddenly disappeared. 

 

"Hm. What an annoying ability," Myson huffed, before glancing at Anaximandros, "Well, we can figure that out later. Care to report?" 

 

"A large number of the kingdom forces have switched sides, but the forces at the monastery have already begun to evacuate. We may have lost the Tyrants we brought, but Chilon is searching the monastery for anyone still remaining." 

 

"Hm. Well hopefully he ends up dying." 

 

"Someone's angry," Bias muttered. 

 

"Well excuse me for having a bit of hope for something nice after losing Odesse and a prime source for materials," Myson complained, frowning as he looked at his dead assistant, "Make sure to take him back to Shambala to be buried." 

 

“You’re not going to try reviving him?”

 

“The Spell of Zahras is not one that you can be brought back from. It demands a life be sacrificed to the void to cast one’s enemies into the darkness.” He sighed, shaking his head in disappointment, before he clapped his hands together. “Ah well. Agnus, attend.”

 

There was a flash of a warp spell and the dark mage that appeared immediately bowed his head to his superior. “You called upon me, Lord Myson?”

 

“You’re the new Odesse.”

 

The mage straightened, surprised. “Oh! You honor me, my lord! I will do my best to uphold the name!”

 

“I’m sure you will. Now then, let’s let Chilon wrap up his own venture, and then we can get to the important part. Looting!”

 

That prompted a cheer from the knights and some chatter among the mages, excited by the prospect of robbing the monastery of its wealth and secrets.

 

“You should hope he hurries,” Bias pointed out, “Most of this shithole is on fire already.”

 

"Eh, it's not like anything important is flammable." 

Edelgard could feel fire in her veins. Sweat beaded down her face, but her breath was still even. She kept a good grip of Labraunda in her grasp, its surface ablaze with her flames as she smashed it into and through the chest of a knight in full black armor, cleaving through flesh and bone and staining the ground red before she moved from his burning remains and split through another Agarthan mage. The entrance hall had been broken through, and there were few defenses between them and the cathedral. The rest of the monastery though…to call it ablaze was understating the conflagration it had become.

 

"Please tell me you have some idea on how to get out of here!" She heard Gertrude yell at Jeralt, the mercenary keeping close to her employer and launching bolts of light at anyone that got close.

 

"Not until we find my kids!" Jeralt shouted back, clashing against a knight, something Edelgard found herself agreeing with. Partially because she had somewhat hoped Shez would be able to warp them across the broken bridge, but mostly because she was worried about her professor. She had seen the look in Shez’s eyes before they disappeared and whatever was in there looked far too cruel to be the younger Eisner sister.

 

“We’re not gonna find them in all this smoke!” Victor called out, “We gotta be smart about this, Captain!”

 

“The hell is that supposed to mean!?”

 

“I’m not saying we just run, I’m saying–Princess, you got a place you and Byleth were supposed to meet or what?!”

 

“We were retreating to the cathedral before the bridge was destroyed!” she shouted in reply, “We’ll have to look for an alternate route!”

 

“I was hoping you had a better answer than that!” Victor complained, “What about you, Captain?! Do you know about any secret passages!?”

 

“How the hell are Byleth and Shez going to find us if we start crawling through secret passages!?” Jeralt snapped, though there was an undercurrent of desperation beneath the anger in his voice.

 

"They're smart, if they can't meet up with us, then they'll probably just head to the Empire themselves!" 

 

“Victor’s right, for once!” Ezra called out, his eyes scanning the courtyard for any sign of more enemies, “You know those two can take care of themselves!”

 

Jeralt grit his teeth, his grip tight on the spear in his grasp. Yet the desperate fear in his eyes was what prompted Edelgard to move up to him, placing a hand on his arm. “Captain Jeralt, Professor Byleth has been to the palace of Enbarr. She knows the route there, and you know she would protect Shez no matter what happens. I don’t know what occurred to cause Shez to warp away like that, but I’m sure we’ll see both of them soon.”

 

“...I can’t lose them,” he replied, his haunted gaze reminding her of her own father, “Not my kids. I can’t lose my kids.”

 

“You won’t. I promise.” At her words, Jeralt’s jaw clenched, before he slowly nodded. Nodding in return, she turned to Jeritza. "Jeritza, find a way to the Cathedral, tell everyone there to begin evacuating, and that we'll meet outside the monastery." 

 

"VERY WELL." The Death Knight agreed, before galloping off. 

 

"...You're going to need a good explanation for why he's working for you," Jeralt said, frowning at the Death Knight. 

 

"I swear, once we're safe, I'll–" Then she stiffened as a crawling sensation went down her back. There was something out there–Then she saw him. A man in the silver armor of a Great Knight, lined with blue, though his right hand appeared to be covered in a distorted relic, its bone-like material an ashen black and the core set in it appeared to be missing a crest while its surface was a muddy brown. 

 

More significant though was the full relic weapon in the man’s hand. It was an ugly thing that could loosely be called an axe, its “blade” resembling a curled wing with sharpened spikes on the inside, almost like the jaws of a beast.

 

“There you are, you rebellious brat,” the man growled. She could feel the glare through his helm as he strode forward, walking with heavy steps that seemed to shake the earth. “You’ve been allowed free rein for too long.”

 

"Well, looks like one of the bosses came out to deal with us personally. I'm flattered," Ezra muttered, ready to throw his knife. 

 

"As if I care about vermin like you." 

 

"And just who exactly are you?" Edelgard asked, readying herself for battle. 

 

“Hmph. And here I thought you might recognize me, you stupid brat,” the sage growled as he focused on Edelgard, "Though, I suppose you were always cowering in the corner of the dungeon, even as I dragged the bodies away." 

 

Edelgard’s eyes widened, as a memory flashed in her head of an armored knight in full black plate dragging away her younger sister's corpse. 

 

"...Captain Jeralt, I'm going to have to ask that you leave this to me," Edelgard requested, taking a step towards the Agarthan. 

 

"..." Jeralt almost argued, before noticing the look in her eyes. "...Make it quick." 

 

"Thank you. Now, if I may, what is your actual name?" Edelgard asked as she brought her shield up. 

 

"Chilon, Sage of the Earth and wielder of Aymr, the greatest relic crafted by Agarthan hands." As he boastfully introduced himself, Edelgard felt her mouth twitch. 

 

"Chilon…if memory serves me correctly, you were Thales' personal guard. Before he died, that is." 

 

Immediately, the sage growled. "Keep his name out of-" 

 

"Would you like to know how he died?" 

 

"...What?" Tightening his grip on his relic, he pointed the axe at Edelgard. "Don’t you dare lie to me, you little wretch. How could you possibly know that?" 

 

"I asked my professor." 

 

"What does the Fell Star have to do with this?" 

 

"Oh, she has a lot to do with it. It's a funny story really. You see, when she was around…oh, let's say, fourteen or fifteen years old, she was practicing her magic. At the prompting of her younger sister, she even showed off her prowess with Faith Magic. Now, despite her young age, she was quite skilled at Faith Magic. So much so that she caused a landslide in the Oghma Mountains." At that, she smirked. "Now, if I remember correctly, that irredeemable bastard had his head smashed in the Oghma Mountains, didn't he?" 

 

“You wretch!” Chilon spat, outraged, “How dare you insult your betters!? You wouldn’t be anything of worth were it not for our aid!”

 

“I would have had a whole family. I don’t care about what power you ‘granted’.” She hefted her axe and shield, ready to fight. “But if you insist I should repay your ‘generosity’, then I will gladly return every bit of agony you inflicted on my family.”

 

“Ha! I am the Sage of Earth, the greatest warrior of the Agarthan people!” he declared, bringing his axe into a ready position, his gaze completely focused on her, “Do you truly believe you can kill me on your own?!”

 

“Hm…that’s a fair point. Gertrude, would you mind?”

 

The sage paused, his eyes narrowing in confusion at the sudden, polite request, right before a bolt of light exploded right in his face. Chilon stumbled back with a scream of shock and pain as he was blinded, his free hand clutching at his face as he swung his axe wildly–

 

There was a flash of heat and pain as Chilon felt inexplicably lighter. His vision cleared and he swung again, realizing too late that his hand had been completely severed from his arm in one swift swing. The wound was already cauterized by Edelgard’s blazing axe, which swung straight into his chest in a vicious horizontal cut that smashed deep into his sternum and sent blood spraying from his mouth.

 

He tried to move, to raise his shield, and found himself bereft of his entire left arm before a foot smashed into his knee, cracking bone. Chilon howled, pain and fury pushing him forward, trying to call on the might of his people to end the wretched failure that wounded him!

 

A feat that was largely impossible given his lack of hands.

 

Then he was on his back and his helmet was torn off, his eyes meeting the cold gaze of the Emperor of Adrestia.

 

And yet, the sage remained defiant. "Do you expect me to beg!? I will never stoop so low as to cower before a failure like you! I swear, I will have my vengeance for this humiliation!" 

 

"Fine then. I'll give you a chance." She placed the blade of Labraunda on his throat. "Name one of my siblings, and I'll let you have a chance for revenge." 

 

"As if I would remember failures like them!" 

 

“Very well then.” And without a moment’s hesitation, Edelgard lifted the axe and swung it straight through the Sage of Earth’s neck, splitting his head from his body as his eyes still stared in disbelief at his own demise.

 

Staring down at him, Edelgard let out a small sigh of relief. She still had so much work before her, but…in this moment, it felt easier to breathe. She wondered if she managed to bring some peace to her family with this monster’s death... 

 

“...No wonder your daughter is into her,” Candance commented from behind the emperor, giving Jeralt a nudge with her elbow.

 

“Candace.”

 

“What? I’m just saying, if I was her age–”

 

“ Candace. ”

 

Edelgard huffed, faintly amused by the mercenaries’ antics. “We should probably get going now.”

 

“Yeah, you did just kill one of their bosses, so I’m pretty sure we’ll be in trouble if we stick around,” Ezra pointed out, “Well, with Gertrude’s assistance, of course–”

 

“You don’t need to praise me, dove,” Gertrude remarked, amused, before glancing at the corpse, “Ah, your highness? Or, wait, it would be majesty now…ah, either way, should we take that axe he had? It looks like one of those relic things.”

 

“Hm? I suppose,” Edelgard considered, glancing back at the discarded weapon. “Monica might be upset if I start using a new axe so soon after she found me one though.”

 

“Can I have it then?” Victor asked.

 

“You’d die, dumbass,” Ezra pointed out.

 

“I might not. Who knows? I could be–”

 

“I’ll hold onto it,” Jeralt decided, grabbing the axe and hoisting it over his shoulder with surprising ease, “Let’s just…get out of here for now. Though I’m coming back here if my kids don’t show up at that palace of yours, emperor.”

 

“Of course,” Edelgard readily agreed, nodding to her professor’s father. Who might become her father-in-law in the future. 

 

…Just something to consider.

Claude had to admit, retreating was far more bitter than he expected. Maybe it had to do with how injured his classmates were, or how they hadn't been able to find Shez, but nothing about fleeing the monastery felt good. 

 

"Come on, the sooner we get to my family's territory, the sooner we can figure out what to do," Lorenz said, leading the group on horseback, his usual pomp and flair gone. 

 

“What about Shez?” Lysithea murmured from her place on the back of Lorenz’s horse, her injuries as bandaged up as they could manage while she rested.

 

“Don’t worry, I’m sure she’ll be following us soon enough!” Hilda called out from her own place in the procession, before she glanced up at Claude, clearly wondering if their mercenary friend really would be okay.

 

"Yeah I'm sure she'll be fine, if she doesn't get lost anyways. Who knows, maybe next time we see her, she'll be crossing the border from Almyra," Claude joked, trying to lighten the mood. 

 

"She wouldn’t get that lost, right?" Raphael asked, looking back at the monastery. "Maybe we should leave a trail or something?" 

 

"We don't really have any supplies to do that, big guy. That and if we leave a trail, we might be leading anyone who attacked the monastery towards us…" Leonie muttered. 

 

"Then we'll just kick their ass!” Balthus declared, “Besides Shez is probably fine. Hell, she's probably hanging out in Abyss right now." 

 

“See? Keep optimistic, everybody,” Claude encouraged, grinning at his classmates.

 

“...um, but…shouldn’t we talk about how she seemed to be possessed?” Ignatz spoke up, frowning. “I mean, all of us could tell that she wasn’t acting like herself and there really did seem to be someone else in her body.”

 

“Right, yeah, that was weird,” Raphael agreed, “...do you think Shez has a secret evil twin?”

 

“...No, Raph. I don’t think any of us think that,” Leonie replied, giving her friend a confused look.

 

“Oh. Then I don’t know what that was.”

 

“Well…Shez always had weird powers. And Byleth said she was being controlled? And the…other Shez called Shez her partner, so…” Leonie sighed, scratching her head. “Honestly, that all happened really fast and I feel like most of us just kinda spoke without thinking." 

 

"In that case, we should figure out what to say to her when we see her again!" Claude suggested. "Such as, 'what the fuck was that about'?" 

 

"It would be more prudent to watch our language and ask if she's okay," Manuela chimed in, giving her students an amused look.

 

“Oh sure, but I feel like my suggestion is the better one to start things off. What do you guys think?" 

 

"We should ask if she's hungry,” Raphael suggested, “I mean, we only had breakfast today!" 

 

"Oh yeah that's true, we should get something to eat soon! Hey Lorenz, how far is your dad's place from here?" Balthus asked.

 

"If you're going to wait until we arrive at Gloucester Castle, then you'll have to pick up the pace if you want to eat today," Lorenz answered, getting the two to groan. 

 

"You know if you're inviting some food, I could just go on ahead and enjoy a nice meal myself." Claude said, winking as he patted his wyvern. 

 

"Hey Claude, have I ever said you were my best friend~?" Hilda asked with her own wink, only for Leonie to clap a hand on her shoulder. 

 

"If we're stuck on the ground, you are too." 

 

"Aw, but I'm so sweaty…" 

 

"It's not that bad, Hilda. Besides, I'm sure we can probably find a river or something to wash off." Leonie said, getting the noble girl to groan. 

 

"And if you guys are hungry, I could try hunting a bit. I'm no Petra, but I can probably find something." Ignatz offered, earning a grin from Leonie. 

 

“Now you’re speaking my language, Ignatz!”

 

“Ah, do recall that hunting in another nobles territory without their leave counts as poaching,” Lorenz pointed out, “We would not want to–”

 

“Hey, we’re not poaching, we’re just…uh…”

 

“Requisitioning supplies?” Claude suggested.

 

“Yeah, that!”

 

“...That is not at all what we would be doing,” Lorenz countered, unimpressed by their logic.

 

"I dunno, with how hectic things are being, who's gonna notice a rabbit or two going missing?" Claude asked. "I'm sure Shez would agree with me." 

 

"In that case, if we get in trouble, you'll shoulder all the blame?" Leonie asked.

 

"...Eh, maybe Shez agreeing with me means it's a bad idea." 

 

As the students laughed, Lorenz couldn't help but roll his eyes, far from amused, before glancing at Lysithea. "How are you doing?" 

 

"Tired…" 

 

"My apologies, I'll try to move as fast as we can without causing you discomfort. And once you get better we can make sure to get ready to give Shez a piece of our mind." 

 

"..." Lorenz heard her mumble something, though he couldn't make it out. 

 

"What was that?" 

 

"Nothing. Just talking about how stupid she is." 

 

"Heh, blunt but not incorrect. I must say, I'm sure Shez appreciates having a good friend like you." 

 

“...I hope so. She saved me…” she murmured softly, fighting to stay awake. She had so much she owed Shez for, and she was going to make sure to pay her back. 

A heavy silence fell upon the Blue Lions. Even with all the chatter from the residents of Abyss, both old and new, the students from Faerghus were unsure of what to say. 

 

“...So…do we…talk about what Shez said?” Annette asked, glancing among her friends with a faintly concerned look, “Because that was…a lot.”

 

"What do we even talk about?" Ingrid asked, letting out a sigh. "Are we even sure that it was Shez?" 

 

"I mean, I'm pretty sure that was the professor…before her hair turned green anyways," Sylvain said, rubbing the back of his head. "Still trying to wrap my head around the whole…goddess incarnate thing." 

 

"And what about the Heroes’ relics?" Annette asked, looking at the two lances Ingrid and Sylvain had. 

 

"Ah, my apologies, but we're a bit out of the loop," Hanneman said, gesturing to himself, Yuri, and Ashe. 

 

"Yes, care to enlighten us, friends?" Yuri requested, “Particularly about that part about Byleth being the ‘goddess incarnate’.”

 

“Ah, well, that part…hm.” Mercedes fidgeted with her hands, trying to think of how to explain. After a moment, she nodded to herself. “Professor Byleth is the divine vessel of the Goddess who has returned to the world for vengeance against those who murdered her children and mutilated their bodies, twisting their bones into weapons and we are the descendants of the apostates that imbibed their blood. Ah, the blood of her murdered children, specifically.”

 

"...What?" Ashe asked, completely taken aback. 

 

"It also seems like Shez might be the vessel for the one who led those who murdered her children, and was seemingly threatening her last remaining child. All this to say that all of us are likely forsaken by the goddess," Mercedes elaborated, her hands clasped together. 

 

"...This is certainly a lot to take in," Yuri commented, turning his gaze away from Mercedes. 

 

"Ah, the Alliance is likely forsaken as well, since many of them are descendants of the Elites as well." Yuri did his best to ignore what she was saying. 

 

"You know, this makes sense to me," Felix said, somehow saying that with a straight face. 

 

"How??" Ingrid asked, looking at him wide eyed. 

 

"The Crest weapons have always been unnerving and looked like bones. Clearly they must have been someone's bones." 

 

"The noble houses of the Empire are descendants of the Saints, who fought against Nemesis so they likely aren't forsaken as they did fight alongside the Immaculate One…" 

 

"So I knew they kinda looked like bones, but saying this makes sense is a stretch, Felix," Sylvain said, brushing past Mercedes's muttering. "...Should we bury the weapons?" 

 

"Wait, Sylvain no. I know this…is really bad, but these relics are very important, even more so now since we're at war," Ingrid pointed out. 

 

"The apostles likely aren't forsaken either," Mercedes mumbled, giving Yuri a glance that made him take a step away from the blonde. 

 

"Still it, uh, kinda seems like we should do something with them?" Annette suggested. "Maybe we could ask Professor Byleth what to do with them?" 

 

"That…would be most prudent if she is the goddess incarnate," Hanneman muttered. 

 

"Well, we should find where Professor Byleth is, right?" Ashe asked, worried about his friends. 

 

"I got it," Mercedes chimed in, speaking up as she clapped her hands together, "The Kingdom and the Alliance are both heretical lands and we all need to repent to the goddess for any chance of mercy." 

 

“...Should we be worried about her?” Sylvain asked, gesturing at Mercedes.

 

“I think we should all be very worried for our souls, yes,” the blonde replied. 

 

"...Technically I think Shez is only haunted by the spirit that killed the goddess’s children," Dimitri said, finally speaking up. 

 

"...Why is that the first thing you've said, Boar??" 

 

"Well…I've been thinking about what we heard, and I remember Shez told me she was haunted by a spirit that wanted to fight her sister." Dimitri shrugged, looking at Felix. “I feel like it’s the most reasonable explanation.”

 

“...What is wrong with you?”

 

“At the moment, less than usual, I think.” He sighed, scratching at his head. “I was…so absolutely filled with rage at encountering that knight who outright admitted to being one of the men that enacted the Tragedy, and yet now, I just feel…confused. I…I’m still upset, obviously, but…my own anger feels…smaller, almost, when compared to the rage of the goddess. The fact that she shares that same pain of her family being murdered…I feel…strange, yet also lighter, somehow?”

 

“Could the House of Blaiddyd be viewed as the worst of the heretics for turning against the goddess’s chosen while declaring themselves holy?” Mercedes asked, looking directly at Dimitri.

 

“...Well…the Church declared us holy." 

 

“Your kingdom is false and godless, born of blood and treachery.”

 

“Um…hey, Mercie?” Annette spoke up, looking worried for her friend, “Do you…want to maybe get a snack? It might help.”

 

“...I would like a cookie,” Mercedes murmured. Gently grabbing her friend, Annette helped Mercedes up, and walked her away to find something to eat. 

 

"...so, we're going to need to keep an eye on Mercedes," Ingrid said after they left. 

 

"Right…we'll also need to ensure that everyone here is safe before we begin scouting out. There are several entrances to Abyss, so making sure that our enemy doesn't find and use any of them is our top priority," Dimitri decided, standing up, still feeling confused but…he had something to focus on at least. 

 

"Oh, I just realized, Dorothea is dating a goddess," Sylvain commented, completely throwing everyone off. 

 

"...Sylvain, forgive my language, but what the hell are you talking about?" Dedue asked.

 

“You barely even cursed…” Felix muttered while Sylvain continued to explain his weird logic. 

 

"Oh, they were trying to keep it a secret, but it was obvious to me." 

 

"...Wait, what about Edelgard–No, I shouldn't ask. This doesn't involve me."

 

"Hm…does the goddess practice monogamy?" 

 

"Right, we are moving on from this conversation because this definitely feels like blasphemy," Dimitri decided.

 

“Then let’s bring up something else,” Yuri spoke up, catching their attention, “Namely, what are we going to do going forward?”

 

“What do you mean?” Dedue asked, frowning.

 

“I mean, what do we do here? The Church’s forces are scattered, right? So that means all of us are on our own. We might have each other, but we also have a lot of mouths to feed here, and a big question of where we go from here.”

 

“You’re talking about who we should side with,” Dimitri noted, earning a grin from the former Wolf.

 

“Exactly. Now, I might not have as direct an experience with everything that went on, but I like to be informed and asked around. From what I know, your uncle has declared war against the Church and the Empire. He’s usurped your throne and got your country declared illegitimate…but I guarantee he’d prefer having you under his thumb than killing you outright. You siding with Rufus gives him legitimacy. And more than that, it could keep Faerghus united. The Church is broken right now, so if you join up with Rufus, all the nobles there will likely be fine with flocking to your shared banner, and you have the Western Church to take over as the religious authority backing you up.”

 

“In exchange for throwing away my honor to side with a man who willingly works with those behind the Tragedy of Duscur,” Dimitri countered.

 

“That’s true. It’s also true that he’s leveled an accusation against the Empire that I have to imagine plenty of people will see as legitimate. That’s more than enough to justify a war. And you have to ask yourself…do you think he’s lying about Duke Aegir and Lord Arundel orchestrating that massacre?”

 

“...That is a truth I will have to look into myself,” he replied, ignoring the voices trying to push him in either direction. Killing Aegir, killing Rufus, declaring for the Kingdom, declaring for the Empire… “If I side with Edelgard, Faerghus is guaranteed to be considered illegitimate. I will be all but handing over the country to her.”

 

“Are you sure that isn’t what you should do?” Yuri questioned, “You heard Mercedes there. If the goddess herself is upset with you guys…well, it takes away the ‘Holy’ part to your kingdom.”

 

“Could we trust Edelgard?” Ingrid spoke up, “If we did side with her, would she even let us keep our lands? Or would we see Faerghus split up for Adrestian nobles to take?”

 

That earned a frown from Hanneman, though Yuri grinned. “An excellent question, Ingrid. Not only that, but if Adrestia does take Faerghus, what do we think it means for Leicester? We might see an ambitious Emperor decide all of Fodlan should be united. It doesn’t even have to be Edelgard. Any kid of hers would have that idea in mind.”

 

“Considering who she seems interested in, I don’t think Edelgard is having kids,” Sylvain pointed out.

 

“She can adopt,” Yuri retorted, “And that’s assuming Edelgard herself wouldn’t want to unite Fodlan herself. We don’t exactly know her motives, now do we?”

 

“We know she is in favor of a more equal society,” Hanneman remarked, crossing his arms over his chest, “One where crests are not upheld above the lives of people.”

 

“That’s kind of a dangerous sentiment up in Faerghus,” Sylvain noted, “I don’t disagree with it, but it’s not going to sit right with most of the nobles there.”

 

“I should point out, we aren’t certain of what Rufus wants either,” Dedue commented, frowning in thought, “What we do know is that Rufus has taken the throne and is willing to side with a man who directly participated in the massacre that took Lambert’s life.”

 

“Anaximandros,” Dimitri muttered, remembering the arrogant knight. “...what do you think would happen if we side with Leicester?”

 

“Do you trust Claude not to take advantage of Rhea’s declaration and take Faerghus for himself?” Yuri asked without pause, clearly having thought of it already, “If I remember my history right, House Riegan does have a loose claim to the throne of Faerghus. And if bowing to him can guarantee your nobles keep their seats…”

 

“What options do we have then?” Felix spoke up, audibly irritated, “All your doing is pointing out that every path in front of us is a terrible one.”

 

“That’s because they are,” Yuri replied, “We’re in a bad position. Not an impossible one, but one that means we need to think about what we’re doing. Prince Dimitri here does have power, but only as far as who he allies with. Trying to go this alone isn’t tenable. We need supplies, we need weapons, and we need a way to make sure we aren’t just rolled over by the first person who decides they can get a better deal by grabbing up a bunch of noble heirs.”

 

“Wait, why can’t we just try to get support from the nobles that will oppose Rufus?” Ashe asked, “I can’t imagine everyone is okay with what he’s doing.”

 

“Because even if Rufus himself is an idiot, whoever’s supporting him isn’t. They’re going to know people won’t agree with their decisions, so what do you think their first, best move is?”

 

“Killing everyone who would stand against them,” Dimitri realized with dawning horror.

 

Yuri held up a finger. “Not necessarily. They might just arrest the more valuable ones, probably under suspicion of being involved in the Tragedy. Noble hostages tend to keep people in line. Still, I wouldn’t recommend rushing to anyone’s rescue. We’re not exactly prepared for a fight like that.”

 

“...” Dimitri resisted the urge to ask ‘what do we do’. He was the prince. He should be making the decisions. “...There are houses that would remain loyal to me. Fraldarius, Ifan, Gautier, Galatea–”

 

“Yes, you have noble houses that are loyal to you. How quickly can we contact them without putting the people here in danger?”

 

“...” He took a breath. “...Charon is the closest major house. We should make contact with them first, then with the houses we know are loyal. We can stockpile supplies, if possible, and we’ll want to see if we can convert some of the land here into farmland… 

 

The prince sighed, feeling the weight of his responsibilities. “...We need to split up for now. Abyss can remain our primary refuge, but we cannot simply wait and avoid taking risks. One team needs to work quickly, a second needs to work carefully. Once we’re in a better position…then, perhaps, we can look into actual negotiations.”

 

“Leaving your options open then…not the worst decision,” Yuri remarked, seeming amused, “Just be aware, your highness, you’re going to have to get your hands pretty dirty if we’re taking this route.”

 

“I was willing to soak my hands in blood for the sake of avenging my family. I am certainly willing to claw my way through the dirt for the sake of my people,” Dimitri stated, meeting the Wolf’s eyes directly, and earning what seemed to be a genuine smile from him.

 

He ignored Felix’s scoff. His friend would come around. For now, he needed to focus on those here who needed his help. People who had lost their homes and those who never had any to begin with.

 

Vengeance could wait. He needed to help.

Seething as he stalked through bloodied fields, Epimenides cursed those who turned against him. After everything he did for his people, he couldn't believe their leadership would so eagerly repay his efforts with betrayal.

 

For now however, he had something he was looking for. He wasn't going to let those ingrates take his masterpiece. 

 

Arriving to where their last clash had taken place, he found his trophy. With a grin, he reached for the Sword of the Creator. 

 

Before he could grasp it however, he felt his vessel being wrestled from his control. Moments later, he was floating above his partner, who grabbed the sword and glared up at him. 

 

"Why do you fight against me, partner?" 

 

" Arval is my partner. You're just a monster!" Shez said, aiming the sword at him. "A monster who took my sister from me!" 

 

"She wasn't your sister. Just a vessel for an abomination–"

 

"Shut up! Will you just shut the fuck up!? I don't care what you have to say! Nothing you say or do will make me hate my sister!" Shez shouted, tears pricking her eyes. 

 

"...And nothing you do will get her back. She's gone forever." 

 

"..." Shez let out a breath, the sword shaking in her grip. For a moment, despair almost overwhelmed her before she forced it down through pure defiance. "I'll get her back. One day I will and we'll make you pay. Until then, I swear, if you try to take over me one more time, I'm going to make sure that there is nothing for you to possess." 

 

“You foolish child. You have no idea what that abomination took from our people–“

 

“OF COURSE I DON’T!” Shez shouted, glaring at the spirit, “I didn’t grow up in your shitty city because my mom knew it was crap and took me away from there! She knew it was awful and I know she made the right choice! Every Agarthan I’ve met, with one single exception, has been a piece of shit !”

 

“…you are an ignorant child,” Epimenides retorted, keeping his voice cold to bury his anger–

 

“And whose fault is that, huh? You know, I felt bad about getting mad at Edelgard because I realized she had a reason to hide what she did. I forgave Kronya because while she might’ve had shitty reasons, she cared about me. What about you, huh? How long have you been lying to me? Hiding that you’re this…whatever the hell you are!

 

“You could’ve told me. You could’ve told me–You could’ve just said you got your memory back, or…or whatever, something, I don’t know! I would’ve trusted you! A-And you could’ve told me about where I come from, and who my people are, and why you have this stupid grudge! And I would’ve listened! I might’ve thought you were wrong but I would’ve listened. And you didn’t give me a chance to because you do not give a shit about me. You just wanted to use me.”

 

She brushed away tears with her sleeve, angry and upset, before glaring up at the wraith that should’ve died ages ago. “…you could’ve been part of our family. I…I would’ve been happy with that. But that wasn't good enough was it?" 

 

"Would you have sided with me?" 

 

"Byleth is my family." 

 

"Then there's your answer." 

 

Shez tried not to cry as she slashed him, dispelling his form and leaving her alone. Taking in a deep breath, she turned around and looked at the ruined field before her. 

 

She didn't know where to go, so she just started walking. Maybe she could find someone. Claude, Dimitri, even Edelgard–
