“If you go to any of those filthy beasts, I will kill them,” Epimenides whispered in her ear, making her stiffen, “I have tolerated your foolishness for too long. If you will not accept your role, then I will ensure you live a life of nothing but suffering.”

 

“...” Shez let out a shaky breath. The sword was heavy in her grip, but still sharp as she laid it against her neck. “...try it, and I’ll kill both of us.”

 

Her grip spasmed as Epimenides fought her, his anger burning up inside her head. “You stupid child! You will not cast me back into that darkness–!”


“Don’t worry, partner . Wherever we’re going…we’re going together,” she muttered, before letting the shadows pull at her. She had no idea where she was going, but one way or another…Epimenides wasn’t going to hurt anyone she cared about.

Chapter End Notes

Red: And so we reach the aftermath of the monastery's invasion. Lasted longer than the invasion from Almyra, funny enough. At least in terms of chapters.

Indi: to be fair a lot of stuff happened. I mean this chapter alone has Mercedes having a crisis of faith, Edelgard getting some revenge and Shez not handling things well!

Red: True! Plus lots of other little reactions, interactions, and decisions being made among a very big cast of characters. And even then, we've still got more coming up.

Indi: Yup! We're not exactly at the timeskip just yet!

Red: That's right! Which is admittedly because I get a bit too detail oriented and it means timeskips bug me because it's like "well why hasn't everyone solved everything, huh? Why only when the protagonist is there??"

Indi: As for what exactly will happen next, we'll you'll see next time!

Interlude - Cindered Snow

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Dolofonos of Agartha waited patiently, cleaning his blades of the blood staining them. He had to take good care of his image now that he was a sage. Or, well, a sage candidate. Technically he still had competition, but he was certain he could achieve great things on his current mission, thereby securing his status as a sage!

 

“Hmph. Were your masters really incapable of sending someone to aid me sooner?” the subject of his current mission complained as he walked out of the room he had been changing in. 

 

Ludwig von Aegir would say he had seen better days, but his treatment as a prisoner of the empire was actually fairly generous when one took into account the crimes he was responsible for. Not that he really appreciated the nuance; being stuck in a well-furnished cell and fed three times a day was about equivalent to being stuck in a filthy, rat-infested dungeon with nothing but rags for bedding in his mind.

 

The irony was, of course, entirely lost on him.

 

“Yes, they were. The hegemon was occupying the palace, and her spymaster made infiltration difficult,” Dolofonos replied, his voice even and unconcerned despite the violence continuing throughout the palace. Not the loud, clanging of blades, but the sudden choked gasps of beasts finding their throats filled with steel. “Finding means by which we could get around his agents took a great deal of time and effort. We needed a perfect time at which the Emperor and her aides were absent, the security was low, and the staff was minimal. So, yes, this was the earliest time at which we could rescue you.”

 

Ludwig hadn’t interrupted, in large part because the assassin hadn’t paused in cleaning off his bloodied blades at all in the time he was speaking, though he soon found his voice again. “Fine, I see your point. I would have preferred if it could be done sooner, but I suppose it is fine as long as I am free. Now then, let’s make for whatever escape route you have set up and head to my territory. We’ll need to prepare for Edelgard’s retaliation–”

 

“That’s not what’s happening,” Dolofonos contradicted, “We’re taking this palace.”

 

“...What?”

 

“We’re taking the palace. You’re going to use your authority as a duke to take control.”

 

“...That…are you insane?! We don’t have the manpower to hold the palace, especially after Edelgard replaced everyone who would be loyal to–”

 

“Just tell them to follow you instead.”

 

Ludwig stared at Dolofonos, aghast. “I…that isn’t how anything works–”

 

“Just do it.”

 

And so, the palace of Enbarr was seized by Duke Ludwig von Aegir. For about five minutes.

 

“What in the world are you doing on that throne?” Myson asked, genuinely confused by the sight of the balding noble looking very uncomfortable as he sat on the throne of Enbarr.

 

“You tell me! Why am I supposed to hold the palace of Enbarr?!”

 

“You’re what?” Myson looked over at Dolofonos, who looked very pleased with himself. “...Why did you decide to take the palace of Enbarr?”

 

“It would be a boon for our forces, Lord Myson,” the assassin replied, nodding confidently to his superior, “To steal the hegemon’s seat of power will undermine her authority and erode confidence.”

 

“...Yes, those are all very good points, but we can’t keep it.”

 

Dolofonos paused. “We can’t?”

 

“No. Of course not. We don’t have nearly the resources in the Empire to maintain a hold on their capital. The plan was to go back to Aegir and use their forces to bolster our eastern holdings while using the Kingdom to take the west. Taking Enbar comes after we erode their power base and kill all of Edelgard’s supporters.”

 

“Oh. I was…under the impression that we had bolstered our forces.”

 

“Yes, we did. And then we lost a good portion of those forces taking the monastery. At this point, I’m just having Odesse ransack whatever we can get before abandoning the wretched place.” He paused. “Oh, also, Odesse died so I made Agnus the new Odesse.”

 

“Oh, I am sorry for your loss, my lord.”

 

“Yes, it’s tragic. Still, at least we filled out the ranks of the sages.”

 

Dolofonos blinked. “You did?”

 

“Yes, we did. Kyrie?”

 

A moment later, a female warlock warped in at Myson’s side, bowing her head respectfully. “Yes, my lord?”

 

“Nothing, I just wanted to show off that we now have a sage of water. Oh, though you should take Aegir back to his territory so we can actually enact our plan to trap Edelgard in a two-pronged war.”

 

“Of course, my lord.” She promptly walked over to Aegir. “Up.”

 

“...what? Are you trying to treat me like a dog?!”

 

“Hm.” Kyrie looked back at Myson.

 

“Be polite about it.”

 

“Of course.” She turned back to Aegir. “Please get up.”

 

“...” Ludwig’s eyes narrowed in suspicion, but he pushed himself up from the throne before frowning at Myson. “Is this truly the level of competence your people–”

 

“Kyrie, if you would,” the Agarthan requested, and the newly made sage promptly put a hand on Aegir’s shoulder before vanishing with him, warping away to the intended extraction point. “Finally, I thought I would have to keep listening to that grating voice of his…”

 

"Ah, Lord Myson," Dolofonos spoke up, getting the Warlock's attention.

 

"Hm? What did you need?" 

 

"Not to be rude but…I thought I was going to be the Sage of Water." 

 

"Well yes, but with how things went, I figured it was best to have a sage be one who doesn't work in such clandestine operations such as yourself. Unless you would prefer working out in the open more." 

 

"Ah, no of course not. I was…simply not expecting you to give it to someone else." 

 

Myson raised an eyebrow. “Is there an issue I am unaware of?”

 

“No, of course not, my lord.” He resisted the urge to start cleaning his blades again. They were already clean, he should be talking now. “...is this because I tried to take the palace?”

 

“You’re not being punished. I simply felt that Kyrie’s efforts should be rewarded,” Myson replied, mildly annoyed. 

 

“Yes, of course, my lord,” Dolofonos responded, trying to hide his disappointment.

 

“Would you like to be a sage as well?” 

 

Immediately, the assassin perked back up. “Ah…if you would grant me such an honor, my lord. Though, ah, didn’t you state that the ranks had been filled?”

 

“It’s fine, you can be the…secret eighth sage, the Sage of Blood.”

 

“Oh! I didn’t know there was a secret sage…”

 

“Yes, no one does. Congratulations.”

 

Dolofonos beamed proudly. “Thank you, my lord! I shall wear this honor with pride!”

 

“I’m sure you will. Right, that completely threw off my train of thought…Odesse!”

 

In an instant, Odesse appeared by Myson’s side. “Yes, my lord?”

 

“Report on how the clean-up of Garreg Mach is going.”

 

“Ah, not too well, my lord. Some pockets of resistance have cropped up that are giving us trouble. It seems the Fell Star’s appearance galvanized a number of Kingdom soldiers into turning against us and joining with the church forces. We have been able to loot some objects of interest, according to reports, but things have become more difficult than expected.” He paused. “Oh, and Chilon has died, my lord.”

 

“Oh really? Well that’s lucky–Ah, wait, no, now I have to find a new Sage of Earth…” Myson paused, then looked at Dolofonos. “Dolofonos, you’re the new Earth Sage.”

 

“Huh? Oh, ah…hm.”

 

Myson raised an eyebrow. “Well? I thought you would be happy.”

 

“O-Oh, yes, it is an honor, my lord, but…am I no longer the secret eighth sage then?”

 

“...” Myson sighed. “Odesse, make a note. Dolofonos is now the secret eighth sage of Agartha, the Sage of Blood.”

 

“Oh, I was not aware that there was a secret–” At Myson’s annoyed glance, Odesse immediately changed the subject. “Of course, my lord! And, ah…the Sage of Earth title?”

 

“Ugh, I’ll find someone for it later. For now…hm…” He glanced at the throne of Enbarr, before casually raising a hand and launching a Bohr at it, blowing the throne to pieces. “There, that’s better. Dolofonos, set some fires. We’re going now.”

 

“At once, my lord!” Dolofonos saluted, before getting right back to work with a sense of joy at his new position.

 

It just went to show, hard work always paid off.

One week after the events at Garreg Mach, Rufus Thierry Blaiddyd, the Grand Duke of Itha and Regent of Faerghus, held court at Castle Fhirdiad. Representatives from every major house were called to attend, and Margrave Matthias Raoul Gautier found himself in a truly chaotic throne room.

 

Voices fought to be heard over the din as questions were raised by every count and courtier present. Word had spread quickly of an invasion of Garreg Mach, an attack directed at the Church of Seiros itself, something that galvanized the lords of the Holy Kingdom in a righteous anger against whatever fool would attack the heart of Fodlan. And then that anger was roughly undercut when the news spread that the army that struck at the church marched under the banner of Faerghus.

 

So here they were, lords and representatives, waiting to hear from the regent that so severely overstepped his boundaries.

 

Matthias spotted him first. The blond head of hair that looked so similar to Lambert’s was unmistakable, even if his locks were paler. 

 

Rufus never had the presence his brother did. Lambert could draw people in with his voice, convince men to follow him into a bloody battle with only a few words while Rufus followed in his shadow. The way they dressed conveyed it further, as the pale teal of Itha never matched up to the vivid blue of Blaiddyd.

 

And yet, here was Rufus, wearing that vivid blue in the form of a surcoat, clasped with silver. A silver crown lined with sapphires encircled his brow, and a furred cape of blue and white trailed from his shoulders as he walked up to the throne and sat upon it, facing the crowd with an admittedly regal posture.

 

And following him was another familiar face: Cornelia Arnim, the new bishop of the Western Church, wore a pleased smile as she followed her obvious patron. The former court mage wore a white gown that looked closer to what a proper holy woman should wear, though the blue and indigo lining, coupled with blue feathers lining her vestments and a silver girdle cinching her waist, nearly made Matthias scowled at the sheer ostentatious wealth she was putting on display.

 

The sapphire necklace resting on her openly displayed chest didn’t help that impression at all. 

 

Then she spoke, in a voice that carried through the throne room. “Presenting his majesty, King Rufus Thierry Blaiddyd.”

 

The hall went dead silent. Matthias felt his eyes go wide, the shock of that proclamation stealing his voice, before an immense anger built up inside of him.

 

“How dare you!” he snapped, pushing his way to the front with a fierce scowl, “You have no right to that throne, Rufus! You are the regent, nothing more!”

 

More voices spoke up, echoing the sentiment or just fighting to be heard, but Rufus seemed unbothered. He simply met Matthias’s eyes, and the head of House Gautier felt himself pause for just a moment.

 

Had Rufus’s eyes always been that blue?

 

“I see there are objections to Lady Cornelia’s declaration.” His voice was calmer than Matthias expected, his tone even. “That is fine. I didn’t expect it to be immediately accepted. What I do expect is for all of you to listen as I lay out the horrific, criminal conspiracy I have discovered was enacted against Faerghus. By that, of course, I refer to the Tragedy of Duscur.”

 

More murmurs sprung up throughout the hall, though they quieted the instant the regent began his explanation. 

 

Matthias crossed his arms over his chest, listening with an irritated frown that slowly grew more horrified the longer he listened to the regent’s tale of a monstrous conspiracy enacted by the nobility of Adrestia. Not because of the contents of the regent’s speech, but because of the implications he was putting forward.

 

“Years ago, Anselma von Arundel, a woman of noble birth from a minor Adrestian house, seduced the emperor of Adrestia and bore him a daughter. Years later, while her rival consorts and their children were butchered in Enbarr, she came to Faerghus, took the name Patricia, and married my brother. Your king.

 

“She never grew close to my brother. She always kept her distance, though not out of guilt. No, she chose to avoid getting close to Lambert because she, a liar and a bigamist, intended to have him killed from the moment she met him. Thus she worked with traitors within the Kingdom, savages within Duscur, and murderers within the Empire to butcher my brother and all of his attending knights! 

 

There was a cold glint in Rufus’s eyes as his false fury subsided. ”And yet, how was it that my nephew survived? That he alone was spared? Was this mere fortune? No, not at all. Dimitri was spared as part of the plot. The plot that the chosen heir of Adrestia and the prince of Faerghus would be wed to steal our land out from under us!”

 

The noises of outrage made Matthias scowl. The idiots around him were getting pulled in by their already present hatred of Adrestia and Duscur, willing to believe the worst of those they considered their enemies. “And what proof do you have for your claims?”

 

He knew he made a mistake the instant Rufus smirked. “Thank you for asking, Margrave Gautier, for I do have proof of my claims.”

 

And on cue, a number of individuals wearing the clothes of Western Church clergy entered, carrying boxes of books and documents, which they set down.

 

“These are the records of the Western Church’s investigation as a neutral third party.” The fact that he could say that with a straight face while Cornelia smiled at him in approval made Matthias’s stomach turn. “Included are documents penned by Anselma von Arundel regarding her conspiracy and those she brought in under her sway. In addition, I have testimony from a witness.”

 

Matthias stiffened as he saw Rodrigue marched out by a pair of those damnable ‘Tempest Knights’, so-called protectors that were little better than tax collectors for all the payment they demanded for their ‘protection’. 

 

“Duke Fraldarius, thank you for joining us,” Rufus said, smiling at the duke, “It is my understanding that you looked into the matter of ‘Patricia Blaiddyd’ and her involvement in the Tragedy of Duscur. Am I correct?”

 

“...that is correct.” Rodrigue seemed pained as he spoke. Reluctant, maybe, though Matthias found himself looking for hints of bruising.

 

“And you had your suspicions of her involvement, didn’t you?”

 

“...I did.”

 

“And what did you find?”

 

“...” He took a breath. “I discovered that her carriage was undamaged and empty.”

 

The gasps that rang out had to be planned. Matthias couldn’t believe anyone was being taken in by this farce.

 

“Thank you for your testimony, Duke Fraldarius. We will be discussing your own failures to properly protect the crown from undue influence soon, but before that, I think it best to assuage any issues my people may have.” He stood from the throne. “For I can understand your concerns, my people! I myself harbored concerns! Is my nephew merely a victim in this conspiracy? Is the princess Edelgard a mere pawn of a greater evil? I sought answers! That is why those who support me chose to speak with the archbishop, to bring back our noble children and ensure the threat of the Empire is ended! And what did we find instead?! A declaration that we are false, that we are nothing! That our sovereignty is rendered worthless by the mere word of a corrupt institution!

 

“Do you think I did not feel trepidation? Do you think I did not worry, making these hard choices? Of course I did! And so I turned to the goddess herself, to pray for her guidance! And she showed me the truth, that the archbishop has turned away from her light! That she is no servant of the goddess, but a heretic of the highest order! And if you ask for proof, then I shall gladly give proof of her favor!”

 

He extended a hand, and Matthias went rigid when he saw a crest of Blaiddyd glowing above the usurper’s palm, bathing the room in a blue light. A major crest of Blaiddyd.

 

“...goddess above…” It was impossible to tell who spoke. The shock that spread through the room at the impossible sight stunned all present.

 

“Hail!” Then a sudden shout cut through it. Viscount Mateus stepped forward, kneeling to Rufus. “Hail Rufus, King of Faerghus!”

 

“Hail Rufus, King of Faerghus!” echoed another viscount, Gideon.

 

“Hail Rufus, King of Faerghus!” came a third, Elidure, and that brought more voices to the fore, echoing the sentiment as the usurper found his legitimacy in just one gesture.

 

It was madness. An impossibility that sat poorly in Gautier’s gut. The idea of the crestless gaining a crest…it opened up too much. If Rufus could give crests, if he had that power, then any noble would flock to his side. They didn’t even have to be faithful; the cynical among them would gladly give over loyalty for the sake of gaining a powerful crest.

 

And his own position just became a great deal more tenuous. The house of Gautier held its power because they could wield the Lance of Ruin. Yet if Rufus could hand their ancestral crest over to a sycophant…

 

Maybe he should just escape, bring Rodrigue with him. The duke looked like he was about to be sick, the implications clearly sinking in for him as well. And if he believed Rufus could give a crest, then why wouldn’t the rest of these nobles believe it?

 

Perhaps he was being paranoid. Perhaps he was merely making assumptions…but then Rufus glanced at him. And the usurper smirked.

 

…he had to get out of Fhirdiad. 

“We can’t just do nothing!” Catherine shouted, glaring angrily into the calm face of the Eastern Church’s bishop. The knight probably would have looked more intimidating, were it not for the fact that she was still in a white infirmary gown. 

 

“I am not asking you to do nothing, Lady Catherine. I am asking you to wait and recover until we have a better understanding of the situation,” the Eastern Bishop stated, frowning up at the taller knight.

 

“I understand that the monastery was attacked! That means I need to be out there, protecting–”

 

“You are not going anywhere with that injury of yours.”

 

“Watch me!”

 

“Ah, now hold Catherine, I think Lady Juliet has a point,” Alois interrupted, glancing between the two ladies, “Believe me, I’m as worried about everyone as you are, and I know for a fact you’re certainly not spineless.”

 

Catherine blinked. “What? What would…Why would you bring up the idea of being ‘spineless’ right now?”

 

“I’m saying I know you have a spine, Catherine, because I saw it when your back was cleaved open. Seriously, I would believe the bishop when she says you should rest, that was downright gruesome.”

 

“That’s–How can you be so calm about this?! The monastery might have been burned to the ground and everyone there put the sword!” Catherine snapped.

 

“I know that’s possible, but it’s not guaranteed ,” Alois emphasized, “We don’t know anything yet. I know Captain Jeralt was there, and I trust him with my life. If anyone can keep the monastery safe, he can. And until Shamir gets back to tell us what she found out, we’re going to keep calm and you’re going to rest–”

 

“I’ve been resting! How the hell am I not better already!?” she questioned, glaring at the bishop, who met her gaze with a calm frown.

 

“Because whatever weapon you were wounded with resists healing magic. It doesn’t completely negate it, which is the only reason you’re still alive, but not only did you take a blow that would have killed most people were you not both incredibly hardy and incredibly lucky , you were feverish with a severe infection for weeks. The fact that you’re standing now is impressive, but I guarantee it will be even longer before you’re ready to fight again.” The bishop sighed, shaking her head. “I understand your fears. I share them. But we cannot allow ourselves to give into fear, or we’ll lose before we can act.”

 

Catherine scowled, but Alois nodded along to the bishop’s words. “Yes, exactly! We cannot allow ourselves to give into fear, no matter what! There is nothing to be afeared of!” He paused. “Hold on, that one might be an actual word…”

 

“You have been off your game lately,” Shamir noted as she entered the infirmary, “Half of your puns are just bad wordplay.”

 

“Only half?” Catherine asked, her frown fading to a slight smile when she spotted her friend.

 

“Shamir!” Alois was more exuberant in his greeting, a wide smile coming to his mustachioed face. “You look well! What news do you have of the outside world?”

 

“Nothing good, unfortunately. No one knows where Rhea is and from the rumblings going around, Rufus declared himself king and appointed Cornelia Arnim as the new archbishop.”

 

“What?! He can’t do that!” Catherine snarled, openly furious, but Shamir just gave her a resigned sigh.

 

“Unfortunately, most of Faerghus wouldn’t agree with you. Duke Fraldarius was already arrested, supposedly for his failures in protecting Lambert, and the lesser nobles are gladly signing on with him for some reason. Some people are saying he has the blessing of the goddess, but nobody in Alliance territory believes that, so we shouldn’t have to worry about zealots coming this way. At least not without resistance.”

 

“And what of Captain Jeralt?” Alois asked, obviously worried.

 

“From what I’ve heard, he’s in the Empire. Odds are, his kids are with him, though I don’t know for sure.”

 

“Oh, good. Byleth and Shez wouldn’t leave their father alone in this difficult time, so I’m sure they’re with him.” Alois settled back, looking relieved, though Shamir grimaced.

 

“Don’t be too happy. The Empire is having its own trouble, from the sound of it.”

 

“We can discuss that later. What about Garreg Mach?” Catherine questioned, frowning.

 

“Destroyed.” She chose to ignore Alois’s flinch as she continued her report. “Supposedly the invaders let loose a lot of meteor spells at once and then had demonic beasts set loose to smash everything that wasn’t burning. A lot of the knights are missing too, though apparently so is a good portion of the Kingdom’s army. The ones that survived, at least. Nobody is really sure what happened there, but it sounds like those mages that were in Ordelia joined up with Rufus’s forces.”

 

“The dastards that created those monstrous knights?” Alois furrowed his brow. “That…How in the world could a group of mages that needed the support of Lord Acheron of all people be such a massive threat?”

 

“I doubt they were working for Acheron. Odds are, it was the other way around.”

 

“So what does that make them then? Adrestians? Foreigners?” Catherine asked, frowning.

 

“Hm…oh! What if they’re from Morfis?” Alois suggested, “That land is said to be one of skilled mages, isn’t it? So perhaps they sailed across the seas to trouble us!”

 

“We should probably look into more likely results before making big assumptions,” Shamir noted, “All we really know is that they’re mages, they don’t like us, and their leader knows how to make monsters.”

 

“And claims he knows how to resurrect the dead,” Catherine commented, remembering part of Shamir’s previous report.

 

“ Claims, ” Alois emphasized, looking pretty disturbed by the suggestion.

 

"Regardless of what they can or can't do, it's obvious that they're dangerous. Even if they lost a sizable amount of kingdom forces in the battle, they're bolstering it with their weaponry and odd magic,” Shamir noted, “As it stands, our best bet would be to wait for things to settle and talk with the Alliance houses to get some aid." 

 

Catherine frowned. "And how long is that going to take?"

 

"Well, the Alliance is known to take a long time to come into agreement about anything, but surely they must understand how important it is to act immediately!" Alois said.

 

"...So what's our second best bet?" Catherine asked, looking away from him.

 

"Going to one of the other nations and trying to get allies there. The kingdom is closer, but it's also the most dangerous as we don't know whose siding with who. The Empire on the other hand is having trouble with Aegir, who’s apparently leading a rebellion against the Emperor. I don't know who sided with him, but if we try to go into Adrestia we'd have to go through Hrym territory, which he controls,” Shamir explained, “And that’s not mentioning how we’d have to deal with whatever forces Acheron has blocking the major bridges.”

 

“So what, we’re stuck?”

 

“We could go with the original option,” Alois commented, “Yes, the Alliance might take time to act, but this is a crisis–”

 

Catherine scoffed. “Yeah, sure. Look, Alois, I’m pretty sure we’d have better luck getting help from Almyra than getting the Alliance to act in a timely fashion.”

 

“I wouldn’t recommend that. We might move slowly here, but you’d be lucky if the Almyran court just laughed you out of their halls.”

 

“I know that, it wasn’t a real suggest–” Catherine blinked, then looked over at the unexpected new voice standing by the door to the infirmary. “Claude?!”

 

“Hey there,” the young noble greeted, grinning at the trio of knights that were staring at him in visible surprise, “I heard this is where I should go if I wanted to know what the Knights of Seiros were up to and I have to say, I didn’t think this was all I would find.”

 

“Oh, well, we do have more members present, but most of them are either recovering or assisting the Eastern Church–”

 

“What the hell are you doing here?” Catherine asked, talking over Alois, “And when did you get here? Because this is some suspicious timing.”

 

“Oh I got here before Shamir did,” Claude replied, amused, “I just hung out until you three met up again, since I figured it would be better to talk to you all at once.”

 

“So what do you want from us?” Shamir asked, regarding the former student with a small frown, “We don’t exactly have much to offer.”

 

“Yes you do,” Claude countered, “The three of you have something very important to offer me here: information.”

 

“What, do you want us to spill the secrets of the church?” Catherine asked, unamused.

 

“If you’re willing, sure,” he replied, shrugging, before he gave them a more serious look, “Here’s the thing: I don’t know what’s going on right now. All of Fodlan is in chaos and nobody seems to really know who’s responsible or why. And I can imagine you all understand why that’s a problem, right? There’s some kind of organization working in the shadows here, people who can somehow start conflicts all across Fodlan through a mix of subtle manipulations and brazen acts of defiance and violence that keep catching everyone off guard. 

 

“I don’t know what their deal is, but I know they hate the church with a burning passion and Rhea was angry enough with them to decide the Kingdom should be dissolved just for working with them.”

 

“Hang on, what!?” Catherine exclaimed, her eyes wide.

 

“Yeah, it’s a whole thing that happened, and I’m not surprised you didn’t know, considering where you are right now. But you do know some things,” Claude noted, his gaze intent, “We’re all out of the loop right now, but not completely. I’m on one side of it, you’re all on the other. So what I’m suggesting right now is that we pool that information. I tell you what I know, you tell me what you know, simple as that.”

 

“...” Catherine shared a look with Shamir, a frown on her face. The archer met her gaze, then shrugged, not really minding the idea. As far as she was concerned, it was like strategizing with a new client. “Hm…what do you know about what happened to Lady Rhea?”

 

“Not much, unfortunately. I know no one took credit for capturing or rescuing her, and she disappeared pretty early into the invasion. I didn’t see her die though, so I have a feeling she’s still kicking.”

 

“Hm…that’s not very reassuring…but thanks.”

 

“Ah, if I may,” Alois spoke up, looking concerned, “I…well, I don’t doubt that Jeralt would have evacuated everyone from the town and saved as many civilians as he could, but…do you know what happened to the townspeople?”

 

“I do, and your family’s safe, Alois.” The knight visibly relaxed, almost sinking as the tension left his body. “The civilians were evacuated to Abyss or the cathedral before the fighting really got going. I don't know the specifics on where they all ended up, but most of the ones at the Cathedral ended up going to the Empire from what I've heard." 

 

“Then they could be in Abyss, or with Jeralt? Well, I suppose I know where I need to look first then!”

 

“And while you find your family, I can talk with our friends here,” Claude said, grinning at Catherine and Shamir, the former of whom let out a huff.

 

“I wouldn’t call us friends, kid.”

 

“Yet. You wouldn’t call us friends, yet .” Claude smirked at the pair of knights. “I’m sure we can fix that though. I’ve been told I’m pretty charming.”

Seteth woke up with a pounding headache inside a cave. He hadn’t done that for well over a thousand years by this point, so he was understandably confused for a moment. He even had a brief moment of wondering if the past years had simply been a dream and he never truly left the canyons of Zanado before everything coalesced in his mind and he remembered the fire and pain that had preceded his unconsciousness.

 

“Huh. Hey, Seteth’s awake.” He blinked at the voice that spoke up, then looked over to spot a familiar boy.

 

“Cyril? What is…what are you doing here?”

 

The Almyran boy looked at him, a small frown on his face. “I brought you here. You were knocked out by one of those meteors exploding and I made sure you didn’t hit the ground." 

 

"I…Well, thank you, Cyril, but I meant what are we doing in Zanados." 

 

The young boy shrugged. "He said to go here," Cyril explained, pointing to the side, getting Seteth to look over at a cloaked figure standing nearby. 

 

“Hello Seteth. It is good to–”

 

“Aren’t you the gardener?” he interrupted, genuinely confused as he stared at the cloaked man with a familiar voice.

 

“...I’m a gardener, yes. Not the head gardener, actually, though I suppose since he was killed in the meteor strikes–Ah, I suppose that arguably makes me the head gardener now, if just because everyone else either died or evacuated…though the greenhouse is undoubtedly destroyed too, so–”

 

“My condolences for your loss, but that doesn’t explain anything,” Seteth interrupted, frowning.

 

“Oh there’s no need to apologize, he was racist so it’s not really a loss–”

 

“Could you please focus, Mister…?”

 

“Hm? Oh, Gajus. And right, yes, I should explain things. Starting with something that should hopefully explain things,” he said, before he reached into the top of his robe and pulled out a necklace made of a silver chain attached to a fragmented stone…

 

Seteth’s eyes widened. “...is that a crest stone?”

 

“It was once part of one, yes." He placed the chain back under the robe. "Cyril, I hope you don't mind fetching some water for Seteth here." 

 

"Yeah, okay,” the young boy agreed, nodding before he left. 

 

"...Do you mind explaining to me why you have a fragment of a crest stone on a necklace?" Seteth asked, trying not to shout. 

 

"Lady Rhea gifted this to me long ago, when I became one of her cardinals," Gajus replied, his hand still holding onto the fragment under his robe. "It was a sign of her trust in me, and other cardinals who received a stone." 

 

"...What?" 

 

"Forgive me for not coming to you sooner Saint Cichol, but Lady Rhea thought it prudent to keep the identity of her Cardinals secret unless otherwise necessary," Gajus explained, before kneeling to Seteth, "However, with her missing, we felt it necessary to reveal ourselves to you once you had awoken. Without the archbishop we have no leader, and we see no other better suited to the position than you." 

 

“...” Seteth had a thousand thoughts running through his head. He knew the cardinals existed, but the idea that they would want him as archbishop…and more than that, “What happened to Rhea?”

 

“We do not know, unfortunately. The Immaculate One unleashed her power upon the invaders, but she vanished amidst the chaos. And, well…” He frowned, looking a little conflicted.

 

“...what is it?”

 

“Well…there are claims that the goddess returned.”

 

Seteth’s eyes went wide, before he fixed the Cardinal with as serious a look as he could muster. “Tell me exactly what happened.”

 

And so, the cardinal explained as much as he knew, as unbelievable as it all sounded. 

 

“...So, to summarize, a good portion of the remaining Knights of Seiros, along with a number of the Knights of Faerghus who defected to our side, now believe Byleth Eisner is the goddess, her sister Shez is some type of dark god counterpart to her, and they’ve returned to the heavens together.”

 

“That does seem to be the doctrine they are establishing, yes.”

 

“I see.” Seteth considered that information. He processed it. Then he decided to focus on something else because that was insane. “And Flayn is fine?”

 

“We believe so, yes. From what we know, she retreated with the Black Eagle class to the Imperial capital and she is likely residing in the palace of Enbarr at the moment.” Gajus stated. "From my understanding Enbarr is experiencing a refugee problem, and a civil war in the Empire thanks to the former Duke Aegir, but the violence has yet to reach Enbarr." 

 

"I see…" Seteth let out a sigh, pinching the brow of his nose. "I'll need to gain my bearings first before I can decide anything." 

 

“Of course. Please, make yourself ready and then follow me, if you would.”

 

It did take a moment for Seteth to ‘ready himself’, as it were. He dressed easily enough, in simpler linen clothes than he had gotten used to wearing, though he made a note to find a comb as soon as he could. He looked downright shaggy at the moment…

 

Zanado looked livelier than it had been in ages. The once barren canyon was teaming with soldiers in white and gray. Some were still wearing the blues of the Kingdom, though it seemed they had painted over the sigils of Faerghus in favor of Seiros’s symbol. 

 

“Is there a reason why you chose to go to Zanado?”

 

“A mix of reasons, really,” Gajus admitted, “It is a better place to hide than the monastery’s ruins, particularly given the beasts the apostates and heretics unleashed. In addition, a number of the, ah…’enlightened’ seem to view staying in a sacred place as a way to get closer to the ‘reawakened goddess’. Being here seems to bring a measure of peace to their tormented souls. Many of them were consumed by guilt before we gave them work to do.”

 

“Hm…I suppose I can see why–Is that a golem?”

 

“Hm?” Gajus glanced over at Seteth’s surprised question, then nodded. “Ah, yes, it is. Unfortunately, it was too late to have them assist with the battle, but Iris and Bernhard made sure to bring as many as we could get along to help assist here. They contribute a great deal to our defenses, and some of our labor efforts.”

 

“...Should you really be using golem for–”

 

“Most of the staff is gone, your holiness. We take what we can get.”

 

“Right,” Seteth allowed, feeling strangely chastened, before pausing as Cyril returned.

 

“Oh, you’re up. Here, water.” And he promptly handed Seteth the pitcher he’d brought.

 

“...thank you, I suppose,” Seteth replied, deciding to just hold the pitcher for the moment as he looked to Gajus, “I can’t say I expected any of this when I woke up, but…if you require my assistance in leading these people, then I’ll do my best to be worthy of your trust.”

 

The cardinal smiled. “Thank you, Archbishop Seteth.”

 

“What? Why’s he the archbishop?” It seemed Cyril wasn’t happy with that decision.

 

“It’s just a temporary arrangement until we can find Lady Rhea,” Seteth assured, nodding to the young boy.

 

“...hmph. I’m going to hold you to that.”

 

“Of course.” Seteth turned his gaze towards the canyon again, taking in the knights, the clergy, the golems, and thinking of a time long ago when Zanado had teamed with life just like this. When humans and Nabateans had lived together, openly.

 

He wondered what Flayn would think of this sight. What his brothers might think. What Rhea would think. Then he sighed and shook his head, focusing on the here and now instead of what might be, someday.

 

There was work to do.

Chapter End Notes

Red: And so we put off the timeskip by another chapter. It felt pretty important to show what everybody else what up to, leading up to everything that happens next.

Indi: You can technically consider this a mid timeskip chapter as these scenes aren't happening at the same time.

Red: True, there's some time progression going on. Like at least a week passes between each section.

Indi: Also true. Also also, thank you all for all the views kudos and comments you've given us! It's almost our one year anniversary of daughter's and we already passed 100k views and 1.3k kudos and comments!

Red: Yup! That's wild! Thank you very much for all the support!

Indi: We hope to see you for the next chapter which will come out for our anniversary and we also hope to see you in our discord! https://discord.gg/gn2VtVPs8h

Zahras

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

“...It’s okay,” Byleth said, giving her sister a reassuring smile, “Stay safe–" 

 

Before she could finish, the darkness consumed her. Pitch-black surrounded her on all sides before the void enveloping her stretched out into the distance, until the only thing she could see was the stone beneath her and a strange sky above. 

 

"...Stay safe, Shez. I love you," Byleth continued, finishing her words. Though before she could let what happened sink in, a roar made her jolt. 

 

Unleashing a swathe of flames into darkness above them, the Immaculate One roared, as if trying to reach the heavens. She roared and raged, beams of light illuminating the dark, before her body began to shift. Slowly growing smaller, Rhea turned her fury towards Byleth. 

 

"YOU IMPUDENT CHILD! Why would you stop me from attacking them!?!” 

 

"...She's my sister," Byleth retorted, trying to ignore the pain in her side as she stood up straight. 

 

"She's an Agarthan! You saw how she was! All of it, her false friendliness, was nothing but a trick!”

 

"No,” she immediately denied, “That wasn't Shez. She was under control of someone else. She was fighting back." 

 

"And look where her 'fighting back’ got us," Rhea growled, her glare boring a hole into Byleth. "I should have executed her when I discovered her true nature." 

 

Byleth’s eyes widened, and before she could stop herself, her fist crashed against the archbishop’s cheek. 

 

"..." The disbelief in Rhea’s face lasted a moment, before it was replaced with divine fury. "You…To think, you would not only be a failure, but you would also dare to strike me…No matter. I'll just have to try again once I manage to escape from here." 

 

Stiffening, Byleth took a step back, before trying to call upon the divine pulse. Though, as she did, her head throbbed, almost making her double over in pain. Before she could figure out what happened, she felt Rhea tackle her, the archbishop’s hand becoming claw-like. 

 

"W-Wait!" 

 

"Don't worry mother, I'll succeed next time," Rhea stated, before plunging her hand down.

 

"And how many times have you attempted this already?" a divine voice questioned, her hand lightly holding Rhea’s wrist, yet keeping the Immaculate One's hand in place. 

 

"W-What?" 

 

"I raised you better than this, Immaculate One. Take your weight off of me.” There was no kindness in the goddess’s voice. No hint of warmth or affection, merely cold authority as the progenitor god glared into Rhea’s eyes.

 

And like a chastened child, the Immaculate One hastened to obey. She stood, nearly stumbled, but righted herself, trying to keep steady despite the swell of joy in her chest. “M-Mother? C-Could I have truly–”

 

“Be silent.” Her tone brooked no argument nor disobedience. The goddess stood, shorter than Rhea yet feeling enormous to the younger dragon. And while Rhea herself had lived for millennia…in the moment, she felt like a child, faced with the eternity her mother embodied. “Sit.”

 

Rhea stiffened. “What? Mother, I–”

 

“Sit.”

 

Rhea sat, her legs folded beneath her under her mother’s glare.

 

“How many times, Immaculate One?”

 

“...” Rhea didn’t try to pretend. She knew what question her mother was asking. “...counting your current vessel…it would be thirteen times, mother.”

 

“Hm. And Sitri was the twelfth then? You sacrificed twelve lives in vain attempts to break the single taboo I laid down upon our people and resurrect me.”

 

“It was not in vain,” she replied, trying not to argue yet unable to hide the complicated emotions going through her at the moment. To have her mother back…it should be a happy occasion, but–No, everything would be fine. “I succeeded. You are here.”

 

“That is all you care about. You destroyed twelve lives you brought into the world, and you care nothing for them.” Sothis’s voice was cold to the point of sending a genuine shiver of Rhea’s spine. “Byleth called you grandmother. An honor you did not deserve.”

 

“...” This wasn’t how it was supposed to happen. Her mother’s return should have been a joyous occasion. The goddess should have brought light back to Fodlan. But there was nothing but cold darkness in this empty void, and there was no hint of affection in her mother’s gaze. “...I did…I-I did love them, mother, I just–”

 

“You wanted your mother back. You brought children into the world to die for my sake. I was not present. I cannot comment on your treatment of your crafted children. I can look at how you treated Byleth. Because as she said, I was awake the entire time. I saw how you choose to send children out to fight and kill on your behalf. I saw how you ran your church, how you treated those in your power, and how you reacted to those you thought were your foes. I have seen your charity and your cruelty, Archbishop Rhea of the Church of Seiros, founded in your name to enact your will.”

 

Her hands raised and cupped Rhea’s cheeks, holding her with a gentle tenderness that made whatever protest the archbishop could conceive die in her throat. The goddess’s eyes gleamed in the darkness, a light ever present even in the depths of the void. 

 

“I have seen your work, my child,” she intoned, her divine word reverberating in the darkness. “And it makes me puke.”

 

Rhea had a brief moment for her mother’s words to register before Sothis reared back and slammed her forehead straight into the archbishop’s with a loud THWACK.

 

“AUGH!” Rhea exclaimed, grabbing at her throbbing head as she blinked tears from her eyes. “Ow ow ow–OW?! Why would you do that?!”

 

“BECAUSE YOU’RE A DAMNED IDIOT!” Sothis snapped, dropping the heavenly goddess act in an instant as she glared down at her daughter. “AND I’M AN IDIOT FOR NOT DOING THAT SOONER!”

 

“H-Huh? W-Wait, Mother–”

 

“NO! DO NOT GIVE ME THAT WHINY ‘AWWWW, MOTHEEEER’ CRAP! Do you even realize how insane it is to hear my own child founded a religion based around me?! I went to sleep for what I thought would barely be a nap and woke up to find out the majority of my children are dead, and the sole remaining one apparently started a continent-wide cult! What kind of nonsense is that?!” the goddess ranted, half-enraged and half-baffled, “And you, you just–Gah, there’s too much I want to say and yet–No, no, damn it, I am The Beginning, I can just make more time if I need to!”

 

Rhea blinked through her teary eyes, confusion reigning supreme over her mixed emotions. “U-Um…Mother? What are you saying–”

 

“Did I say you could talk?”

 

She stiffened, immediately shutting her mouth in the face of maternal disapproval. Which she had to admit, she wasn’t sure how to deal with. Mother never got angry at me…

 

"Now then, shall we talk about how your mistake is the one that got us into this situation?" Sothis asked, finally calming herself down, "Because I believe that if a certain someone had just given up on trying to revive me using the baby of one of her 'children' then Jeralt would never have taken her away and you would have had a loving family with you here all along. 

 

"Or perhaps if you had just accepted Byleth as her own person, you wouldn't have scared her when she tried to show a bit of honesty about me being awake. You could have shown her a modicum of the same honesty when she asked you the truth of what you were planning. If you did she might not have ran away from you, while still trying to keep people in the monastery safe." 

 

Rhea remained silent, whatever she was about to say wilting as Sothis glared at her. 

 

"Did you even try to get to know Byleth, or was it all just a pretext for my 'resurrection'? How fixated were you on the idea of me, that you failed to see the bright young girl who would openly cry when visiting her mother's grave, who went into a panic when her sister was kidnapped, who is stumbling her way through a relationship so poorly she asks her lover if she can recommend poetry books to seduce her–” She paused, her lips quirking upwards in a moment of amusement. “And who apparently gets quite embarrassed when I point out her moments of emotion.”

 

Sothis sighed fondly, shaking her head. “We really should talk about our recent streak of arrogance as well. Yes, I said ‘our’, because I was foolish to assume that because our thoughts aligned, they must be correct. It is easy to allow divine power to make one complacent, as evidenced by my own demise and our current situation. In many ways…Shez was correct.”

 

“Wh–Mother, what are you saying–” Rhea began to protest, only to flinch when Sothis leveled another glare at her.

 

“Did I say Epimenides? I said Shez , did I not? Honestly, it’s like you don’t even listen!” she complained, before shaking her head, “As I was saying, Shez wanted us away from the battle and, as foolish as it might seem to leave your students and family to fight on their own, her plan of simply evacuating everyone was better than what we came up with. So you will need to apologize when we escape. Yes, I know you were planning on doing so, yet you must do so even more. On hands and knees at the very least.

 

Her joking smile faded. "We must also prepare for my departure." 

 

Rhea stiffened. "W-Wait, Mother, what are you saying?" 

 

"I said what I said. You broke the one taboo I had, and it is not one that I wish to continue. I don't plan on leaving just yet, as I can't trust you with Byleth, but it's only a matter of time," Sothis explained, sighing as she placed a hand on Rhea’s shoulder. "If there is one thing I must apologize for, it is coddling you far too much. Perhaps it was because you were my youngest, but I kept you far too close, and didn't let you spread your wings to have a life of your own." 

 

"...No, mother, I was happy. Being with you was all I ever needed, you have nothing to apologize for," Rhea said, tears starting to spill from her eyes, "Please, don't leave me." 

 

"My sweet foolish child, I already have. Even now, I wouldn't call myself the Sothis you once knew. So, please, cherish what you have, and not what you lost." 

 

“I-I can’t, I…It was all for you, everything I made, it was just–”

 

“You made a resting place for our people and a sanctuary for the survivors. It pains me to hear you could not open your heart further to allow those who would love you to be by your side…but I do not think you a monster, Immaculate One. Foolish, yes. Blinded by grief and fear, certainly. But I will not spend what little time we have left lambasting you for past failures. You already know what fault I find in your actions.

 

She pressed a kiss to Rhea’s forehead, gentle and tender, before she straightened, standing to her full height once more. "I'll be watching over you two, so please, ensure that I can pass with no regrets." 

 

Sothis buckled for a moment, as if about to fall over, before catching herself. Rhea wondered what her mother was going to say, until Byleth suddenly grabbed her forehead. 

 

"OWWW! Why is your forehead so strong??" the former mercenary asked, tears pricking her eyes as she crouched down, trying to soothe the ache in her head. 

 

"A-Ah?" 

 

"I know I hurt myself a bit punching you, but I didn't expect for your forehead to hurt that much. Are all dragons like this?" Byleth asked as she healed her forehead, "You know what, I don't care. Rhea, I'm quitting." 

 

"Wha–" 

 

"I know it's probably just because I'm irritated because of how much my head hurts, but I'm feeling really emotional right now, so I'm going to need you to shut up," Byleth ordered while continuing to rub her forehead. "I'm not going to apologize because you just tried to rip my heart out. And for that matter, you're also not invited to the wedding." 

 

"...You're getting married?" 

 

"Yes. Well, I assume so. I didn't actually propose before getting trapped here, but I'm planning on doing so when we escape." She took a breath and stood back up, before rubbing the pained tears from her eyes. “Hah…right, how do I…uh…”

 

Byleth trailed off, a look of concern coming to her face. “Uh…Sothis? I can’t, um…”

 

A divine light returned to the young woman’s eyes, before her brow furrowed. “...hm. Hm. It appears I may have made a mistake.”

 

“...er…mother?” Rhea spoke up, a little worried, “What do you mean?”

 

“...” Never in her life did she ever expect her mother to look so awkward and embarrassed. “...Well, this is not an insurmountable problem. Presumably.”

 

“Mother, what happened?” she insisted, her concern growing.

 

“To be clear, the decisions that I made were perfectly sensible–She threw away the Sword of the Creator,” Byleth answered, interrupting Sothis, before the goddess abruptly gasped in offense, “How dare you! Don’t put the blame on me, you ungrateful brat! I tossed away my own bones so you could hug your sister! Yes, that was very nice, and I really appreciate it, but we really should just say it. Just because we should doesn't mean we should be so blunt!" 

 

Rhea couldn't help but stare in confusion at the conversation happening before her. "You…threw away the Sword of the Creator?" 

 

Sothis whirled towards her, scowling. "Only temporarily! I didn't expect for Epimenides to somehow lock us in a place that exists outside of time…I bet they didn't even make this void. They probably just found it, like how I gave them everything," the progenitor god groused, pouting.

 

“...I do not understand, mother. Why is this an issue?”

 

“Because I needed a focus through which I could channel my power. Or, more accurately, Byleth could, since my intent is to pass my powers to her as my successor.”

 

“Wh–You can’t–!”

 

“I can, and I am going to. The issue is…well, I don’t imagine you happen to be carrying a fragment of my original body around with you?”

 

"...Why would I?" 

 

"Right…hm. That is…troubling." 

 

“And…why is it troubling?”

 

“Because that means we’re stuck here.”

 

“...oh.”

 

“Yes, ‘oh’.”

 

The pair, technically three, of them lapsed into silence. Then Sothis decided to sit down.

 

“...ah, mother?”

 

“Do you have anything to actually say to me, or are you wondering what I am doing?”

 

“...the latter.”

 

“I am thinking.”

 

“I see…Is there anything–”

 

“Rhea, we are trapped in an endless void of darkness and, apparently, rocks. If you are truly desperate to be useful, look around to see if there is actually anything of use here.”

 

“Ah, yes, of course!” She promptly stood and began walking, carefully exploring their surrounding area.

 

“...don’t go too far!” Sothis called out after a moment, frowning. A moment later, Byleth spoke up, the glow in her eyes fading. “You’re worried about her.”

 

“Of course I’m worried about her, we’ve already established she’s not exactly sensible under pressure.”

 

“Mm. I don’t think I like her at this point.”

 

“That is understandable. Your decisions are your own, do not allow me to influence you.”

 

“Okay. We’ll think of some way out of here.”

 

“Of course we will. If there’s a way in, there’s a way out. We’ll find a way.

"..." 

 

"..." 

 

"..." 

 

Byleth had no idea how long the three of them had sat in silence after Rhea’s return, but it felt like an eternity. The fact that she hadn't slept just yet, however, meant it was probably just a few hours. Maybe. Unless the void worked differently than the regular world.

 

"So…you have a lover?" Rhea eventually asked.

 

"Ah. Yes…well, technically two? Um, Edelgard and I never made it official, especially since we need to talk with Dorothea, but…" Byleth shrugged, feeling very awkward. She hadn’t really expected this line of questioning, so…yeah.

 

"I see…is that influencing why you wish to work for her?" 

 

"What? No. Well, maybe? I…I wanted to work for her, before I realized I liked her like this." 

 

"And what exactly made you want to work with her?" 

 

"Edelgard…we talked about what she wants for Fodlan, to make it a better place for everyone, not just nobles. There's still so much I don't know about this nation, so seeing her be so strong despite everything that happened to her…it was inspiring." Byleth let out a small laugh. "She even imprisoned one of the men who led the insurrection instead of having him be executed on the spot. Meanwhile, I really wanted to kill Catherine for what happened in Gaspard, so I evaded her until Edelgard pushed me to confront her. She’s good at that, pushing people into doing what they think they can’t do." 

 

"And Dorothea?" 

 

"I…She was one of the first friends I made here. Things might have gotten off to a rough start, but we worked past the misunderstanding. Her dream might not be as grand as Edelgard’s, but she's still going for it with the same determination. Even if she is willing to drop it to help a friend." Byleth scratched her head a bit sheepishly. "She told me recently that she actually canceled some dates so she could keep checking up on me after I got injured against the Death Knight."

 

“Hm. And that attracts your interest?”

 

“...Well, yes. Is that strange?” 

 

"No, I am simply curious. There's…much I don't know about you, because I haven't tried to get to know you," Rhea admitted with a sigh, "Speaking of, what exactly is it that Edelgard wishes to do for Fodlan?" 

 

"Um…" Byleth glanced at the archbishop, before scooting back a bit. "Promise you won't get mad?" 

 

“...No.”

 

“Then I’m not going to tell you.”

 

“You cannot ask me to keep my temper when you know what you plan to say will enrage me.”

 

“Which means I won’t tell you,” Byleth reiterated, “I’ll only tell you if you promise not to get angry. And if you lie, Sothis is going to know.”

 

"...Very well, I promise not to get mad," Rhea said, after taking a deep breath. 

 

"Well…She didn't tell me everything, but I believe she wants to make a land that doesn't rely on the crest system, where anyone, be they noble or common born, is rewarded and punished by merit and not by their blood." Byleth took in a deep breath. "She knew she would face opposition, especially from the church given how they're the ones that help push it. To that end…she became the Flame Emperor." 

 

“She…Then that–So that is why–” Rhea’s gaze hardened, a fierce scowl coming to her face. “And she turned you against–Gah!”

 

And she promptly reeled back when her mother flicked her forehead. “No. Bad Immaculate. Do not break your promises.”

 

“Nhhh…” Rhea rubbed her forehead, still frowning. “I am allowed to be angry when–”

 

“You promised you wouldn’t get angry from what Byleth told you, so no, you are absolutely not allowed to get angry in this situation,” Sothis retorted, unimpressed. “Have you always been so dishonest?" 

 

"She just said Edelgard is working with the people who murdered our kind!" 

 

"There were extenuating circumstances." 

 

"What kind of circumstances could those be?!" 

 

"They, um…murdered Edelgard’s siblings," Byleth said, cutting in and making Rhea pause. 

 

"What?" 

 

"The insurrection. It gave them access to Edelgard and her family. They experimented on her and several others, until she was the only one still alive. Presumably to make her into a weapon against you," Byleth explained, a frown on her face as she looked down at the floor. "It wasn't just her family, there were other experiments. Countless people probably died. All to give Edelgard the Crest of Flames."

 

“...oh…no, that can’t be right. I would have…” She paused, a memory coming to her mind. Of the Agarthan, Myson, and his taunt towards Edelgard. His mention of ‘dungeons’. “...why wouldn’t she tell me?”

 

“Why would she?” Byleth asked, before Sothis sighed.

 

“To her, you are the one responsible for the world that would allow such a crime, my child. Would you have told the Elites the truth of Nemesis’s massacre in hopes they would join you?” the goddess questioned.

 

Rhea had no answer for that. "...It seems I have much to think about." 

 

"Yeah, you do," Byleth said, getting Rhea to pause again. The Archbishop felt like this wasn't going to be an easy time here…Then Byleth stood up, clapping her hands together. “Alright, empty your pockets.”

 

“...excuse me?”

 

“Empty your pockets. If we’re going to be stuck here, we should take stock of what we have and what we can maybe use to help us. Like if you have some sort of magic sword in your robes that could work as a substitute for the Sword of the Creator.”

 

“...I do not. I was going to retrieve my sword, but then the meteors hit and I had to become the Immaculate One to survive.”

 

“So you don’t have a sword then.”

 

Rhea frowned at the lack of sympathy. “No. I do not.”

 

“Hm. What do you have?”

 

"Nothing, really. My robes do not have anywhere to hold items." 

 

"Oh. That sucks," Byleth remarked, frowning. "Hm…you should sew pockets onto your gowns. They're handy." 

 

"If you say so. I've never really needed to hold onto something directly on my person." 

 

"Because your sycophants would get everything or hold it for you?" 

 

"...I would not call them sycophants–"

 

"Rhea, I'm pretty sure Catherine would cut down an entire village of people just because you told her to." 

 

“...I wouldn’t tell her to do that.”

 

“You sure? What about if the village denounced you for some reason? Like the villagers that were following Lonato.”

 

“I will defend myself if attacked, but I will not raze a village of innocents.”

 

“Right, but what defines an ‘innocent’ in your–”

 

“Actually, thinking about it, I might still have a sachet of calming herbs somewhere on me,” Rhea muttered, starting to check herself while very obviously changing the subject.

 

"Oh, nice, that sounds handy. Hm, can they work as a tea or should I just bite down on them?" 

 

"I believe it's safer to not ingest them directly, especially given their strong taste. I've heard of those who use them as incense, while others add them to their meals."

 

“Neat. Hm…well, it shouldn’t be too hard to start a fire,” Byleth noted, “And we could probably carve out a rock to use as a bowl or something…Ah, more importantly than that, we need to prioritize. The major necessities you should always have are food, water, and shelter. Everything else can come afterward.

 

Byleth looked around the void, frowning thoughtfully. “Hm…this place seems pretty empty, so we probably won’t be able to find food. Water is more important though, since thirst kills faster than hunger. We might not need immediate shelter, since this place seems empty, but that’s not a guarantee…”

 

“Hm. I don’t suppose you brought any items to help with our survival?”

 

“Of course I did, I always carry extra stuff with me,” Byleth replied while taking off her coat, before beginning to root around in its pockets. Moments later, she laid out everything she had on her: two healing concoctions, a key, some bandages, a small pack of jerky, and a whistle. "Okay, so we both get a concoction to ration as a drink, and we can split the jerky equally." 

 

“You can keep the jerky.”

 

Byleth frowned. “Rhea, you can’t starve yourself just because you don’t like the food that’s available–”

 

“I am not starving myself, child. I am a Nabatean.”

 

“...so you don’t need to eat?”

 

“In a sense.”

 

“What sense is that? Everything needs to eat.”

 

Rhea sighed. “To put things simply, child, I can survive without eating for a great deal of time. In fact, simply resting will allow me to survive without issue because we heal in our sleep.”

 

“She could also eat rocks,” Sothis pointed out as she floated by Byleth, making the professor blink.

 

“You can eat rocks?”

 

“...hm. I…yes. I presume Mother told you?”

 

“Of course I did,” Sothis answered through Byleth, giving her daughter an annoyed look, “Don’t be pretentious, Immaculate. It’s not embarrassing to share how you plan to survive however long it takes to get out of here.”

 

“Do rocks have nutritional value?” Byleth abruptly asked, earning a huff from Sothis.

 

“Not especially, but some of the minerals in them can be useful and they’re generally good for digestion. Try to find salty ones, if you can.”

 

“Why? Are those better for her?”

 

“No, they just taste better.” Sothis paused. “Hm. You might be able to eat rocks now too, Byleth.”

 

“...I don’t know if I want to test that. That feels like something Shez would do.”

 

"And you do remember me saying she was correct, right?" 

 

"..." Byleth frowned, before looking around and spotting a loose rock nearby. Reaching over, she grabbed it, and held it close. 

 

"Um…child, what are you doing?" 

 

With a deep breath, Byleth lifted the rock up and bit down on it. 

 

A sharp crack could be heard within the void followed by a scream of pain. 

 

“Hm. So you can’t do that yet,” Sothis noted, “...I’m sure your next set of teeth will be stronger–”

 

Byleth could not punch ghosts. She could try though.

“Okay, we’ll save trying to eat rocks for later,” Byleth decided, ignoring the faint sting she could still feel in her teeth. Healing magic was helpful, but it didn’t take all the pain away. “Water is the more important thing to figure out anyway, which brings me to my first thought. Namely, can either of us use ice magic?”

 

"...I am not especially skilled at ice magic,” Rhea admitted, “In terms of Reason Magic, my expertise lies more with fire.

 

"Damn. Well, I can't really blame you, I'm not that good at it either. I've tried to have Shez teach me, but, well…we both have different ways of learning," Byleth decided to say, before sitting down, bringing a hand up as she focused. "Okay, just focus on the cold, make it solid…" 

 

After a moment, a sigil appeared before Byleth as she attempted to cast Blizzard, before a few cubes of ice flew out, clattering on the floor a few feet away. 

 

“Oh, that’s actually a lot better than usual,” she noted, a little impressed with herself.

 

“You haven’t been able to do that before?”

 

“No, not really. The most I’ve ever managed is mist. And even then, I think it was more like smoke.”

 

“That is because your soul is naturally attuned to fire,” Sothis noted, “Fire, light, and thunder are what you’re best with, so elements that contrast them are harder to grasp.”

 

“Oh. So why can I do ice now?”

 

“Ah, you’re talking to mother,” Rhea noticed, deciding to keep quiet while Sothis huffed.

 

“Obviously because my power is aiding yours. After all, I am the progenitor, the source of all magic and the power that gives it strength.”

 

“Huh. Is that why magic circles look the same?”

 

“Indeed it is! Their power is derived from my own!” Sothis declared, looking quite proud of herself.

 

“So why does dark magic look different?”

 

And that got her pride to drop into annoyance. “...because it is derived from a different source and structure. One that is most definitely worse than what my children created, hmph.”

 

“...okay. So, uh…can you help with making water then?”

 

“Of course I can! Move over,” she demanded, and Byleth ‘moved over’ so Sothis could take hold of her body again, “Hm, now then…it has been some time since I’ve done this, but it shouldn’t be beyond my means at all to create a source of water for you both. In fact, I could probably create an entire lake! And a forest! And even animals to hunt!”

 

“...” Rhea wasn’t sure why, but she had a strangely familiar feeling of dread welling up inside of her. It was oddly nostalgic…

 

What she didn't expect was for a loud bang and smoke to come from her mother’s outstretched hands, as if a well of magic suddenly exploded rather than bursting forth. Waving her hand as she coughed, Rhea did her best to clear the smoke. 

 

"Mother? Young one? What happened?" 

 

As the smoke dissipated, Rhea found Byleth sitting on the ground, her face covered in soot, before she let out a cough. "...so I guess water is a no go." 

 

“Er…are you okay?” Rhea paused. “Is mother okay?”

 

“Ah…” Byleth sat up, trying to think for a moment. She could still feel Sothis’s presence, but… “I think she knocked herself out.”

 

“That…hm.”

 

“...well this doesn’t solve our water problem,” Byleth noted, frowning.

 

Rhea sighed, before pausing as a thought occurred. “Hm. All we really need is ice to then melt into water, correct?”

 

“Yeah? If we have ice, I can just use fire magic to melt it. Why–Oh, you’re walking away.”

 

Byleth watched for a moment, initially feeling confused, before it turned to a faint annoyance when she was pushed back by the sudden appearance of a bulky dragon in her personal space. Then with a simple opening of her jaws, the Immaculate One breathed a blue flame that bathed the surrounding rock in a cold ice.

 

“Oh. So you do know ice magic.”

 

Rhea huffed at Byleth’s comment. “This is not the same as the magic humans use. Hoarfrost is a magic utilized by dragons, more powerful than any cold humans can harness.”

 

“Huh. Well, that’s interesting and possibly good to know for future reference…” Byleth pushed herself up, looking curiously at the mound of ice that had been formed amid the stone. “Hm…okay, we can reuse the concoction bottles for water, and if we dig a big enough ditch, we could probably have a bath or two…could you make a few more of these? I’m going to start digging.”

 

Rhea raised an eyeridge at Byleth, then very easily pressed a claw into the rock beneath them and simply tore through it, forming a very large hole quite quickly.

 

“Oh, that’s useful. Okay, keep doing that, please. If possible. make sure it's smooth so we don't have to deal with sharp edges while bathing," Byleth requested, and she had a feeling that Rhea rolled her eyes at her before the dragon continued expanding the hole, making sure it was deep enough to hold a sufficient body of water. 

 

"There, that should be good," Rhea said, turning back into her human form after digging two ditches, "One to bathe in and one to drink from." 

 

"Good work Rhea," Byleth said, smiling at the archbishop, before working on melting the ice into the holes. The archbishop watched for a moment, then moved over and lit her own hand aflame to begin melting another ice mound until they had two proper pools of water.

 

“Hm. Are you sure we should be getting comfortable here?” she asked, glancing at Byleth, “We should focus our efforts on escaping as soon as possible.”

 

“That’s a bad way to think about it. We aren’t making it harder to escape by making sure we’re going to be comfortable while we’re here,” Byleth replied, “Sothis might be able to figure something out, or we could discover a way out if we travel far enough. We don’t know for sure yet, but it doesn’t hurt us at all to set up a camp so we’ll have somewhere to return to.”

 

“...hmph. Very well. Let me know if my mother awakens. I am going to look around again,” Rhea decided, moving away from the pool and shifting into the Immaculate One again as she flew off into the void.

 

“Okay.” Byleth watched her leave, then glanced over at Sothis, who was floating beside her again with a small frown. “Should I mention you’re awake right now?”

 

“...no, let her fly for the moment. She always enjoyed clearing her head in the sky," Sothis answered, watching the white dragon grow small in the distance. "It's almost comedic. It took her breaking the one taboo for me to realize my mistakes." 

 

"What do you mean?" 

 

"I coddled her too much, I didn't let her fly as free as she should have. The monastery might have been a self imposed cage she built for protection, but that was only because Zanado was a cage of its own. One she's never been able to leave." 

 

“Hm. It sounds like she was happy though.”

 

“Does it matter if I give my child a happy childhood when she is never happy in her adulthood? She never moved past my death, and I…I can understand it. She was the youngest and she lost everyone she ever loved. I just wish she had managed to find something new and not lost herself in her own grief.”

 

“I don’t know if she could have. Some people, when they lose those they care about, don’t ever get over it.”

 

“…I wish things had been better for her. I dislike the choices she made, but I don’t want her to be miserable.” She glanced at Byleth. “And I can’t stay with you forever.”

 

Byleth paused. “You can’t?”

 

“No. I will be with you, always, because you bear my heart. My existence is not one that can be summed up in simple terms like ‘living’ or ‘dead’, so I will always linger in some form. Yet, as I said to that fool of man that possessed your sister, I should not be haunting this world as I do. My time has passed, and I should pass on as well.” Sothis looked into Byleth’s eyes, a small smile on the spirit’s face. “Do not weep overmuch for my passing, though I do expect at least some mourning and wailing.”

 

“Mm. I’ll make sure to forget about you immediately.”

 

“Ah–You little brat! I gift you with divine power and this is how you repay me!?” the goddess fumed, before her scowl broke into another smile as she pretended to be angry, “Well now you need to do something special for me! Compose a poem–No, a song! A song in my honor!”

 

“I’ll get right on that.” Byleth stared at her long-time companion, then brushed at her eye, trying to clear a faint sting there. “Mm…so, what does this involve? Am I going to turn into a dragon?”

 

“Of course not–...well, actually, hm…ah, the thing here is that I shall become one with you, and you will gain…well, I’m not entirely sure. I don’t think you’ll get the power of creation, not unless you live to be over a thousand…”

 

“...is that something I can do?”

 

“Possibly, though don’t assume anything. I’m not sure how this might change you, but…well, you can never be sure how life changes you.”

 

“Please don’t turn the possible physical changes I might go through into a proverb.”

 

“Stop taking everything I say so seriously then!”

 

“I refuse.” She crossed her arms over her chest, trying to remain firm…before she let her arms fall at her sides. “...should I call Rhea back here?”

 

“That would probably be best, yes.”

 

“...I don’t want to say goodbye to you.”

 

“I will still be with you. I promise you that.”

 

"..." Byleth reached up, her hand passing through Sothis. "...I wish I could at least hug you." 

 

“...damn it, don’t make me cry. I’m the one who’s supposed to be keeping things together,” the goddess grumbled.

 

The two chatted for a bit longer, just enjoying the feeling of being in one another’s company, before Byleth turned her gaze towards the sky overhead as Rhea flew back towards them. She took a slow breath, then let herself step back, in a sense, relinquishing control of her body to Sothis as the goddess smiled sadly at her daughter.

 

“I didn’t have any luck this time either. This place might be genuinely endless…” Rhea trailed off, noticing the glow in Byleth’s eyes, and shifted back to her human form as she frowned at her mother. “...what is it?”

 

“It’s time, Immaculate One.”

 

“...no. N-No, please, it can’t–I just got you back–” Rhea stiffened, her protest choked off when Sothis gave her a hug, wrapping her arms tightly around her child.

 

“Mm…I cannot believe you had the audacity to grow taller than me,” she murmured, feeling how stiff and tense Rhea was. “It is okay. I am sorry I wasn’t there when you needed me.”

 

“...” Rhea swallowed her sorrow, trying to fight back tears. “They took you in your sleep. I never even had the chance to say goodbye to you." 

 

“I know. I am sorry.” She sighed, softly, then moved back and reached up, taking her daughter’s face in her hands and meeting her eyes. “Immaculate One, for all I disapprove of your actions, I know you spent a very, very long time alone. I wish you could have moved on from me, but I am not unhappy to be here, with you and with Byleth. You may have caused pain…but you also brought this child into the world.

 

Sothis smiled with genuine warmth despite the sadness in her eyes. “My heart is her heart now. My life is hers, but her life is not mine. Let her be her own person, and I swear, you will be happier for it.”

 

Tears spilled down Rhea’s cheeks, her composure cracking completely as she crumpled to her knees, only held up by her mother’s gentle grasp. “I-I…I thought…I thought everything would be better…”

 

“I know you did. You tried your best. I could never hate you for that.” Sothis pressed a kiss to Rhea’s forehead. “I love you, my child. Be safe. Be happy. Find those that will fill your heart with love and wonder and I swear to you, this pain will fade.”

 

“It hasn’t. It’s been so long and it still hasn’t…”

 

“I promise, it will.” She rested her forehead against Rhea’s, then began to hum a song the Immaculate One knew by heart. A lullaby, sung to her as she drifted to sleep millennia ago…

 

For the first time in a long time, the tension left her body, and Rhea began to relax.

 

" In time's flow," The two began to sing together in their native tongue, " See the glow of flames burning bright," A light began to envelope Sothis as Rhea’s grip tightened, " On the swift river's drift," Sothis’s voice began to fade, " Broken memories alight…" Singing alone, Rhea wept, holding onto the young girl who cried in return. 

 

United by the loss of a loved one, the two held onto one another, letting their tears fall unabated. 

Byleth blinked awake, slowly and with a faint frown. She wasn’t sure how long she’d been sleeping, given the eternally dark sky overhead, but after Sothis…passed, she’d been sleeping a lot more. 

 

Part of that might have been a form of depression or mourning, but she was pretty sure it was mostly just emotional exhaustion. Or maybe a side effect from fusing with Sothis. Which was still something she was adjusting to.

 

“...” She debated going back to sleep. She’d done that a few times, woken up just to sleep again, but she felt like moving now. Curiously, she wasn’t even that stiff, despite sleeping on stone with her coat as a pillow. “Hm…maybe I should take a bath…”

 

Rhea wasn’t around at the moment, so she’d presumably have privacy. She couldn’t really say she was bothered by the idea of her being around though. Rhea was…she was family, even if things were complicated and messy, and she’d had baths with Shez before. So with that line of logic figured out, she made her way to the bathing pool and began to undress, starting with taking off her eyepatch because it was feeling annoyingly tight for some reason.

 

Then she blinked. With two eyes.

 

“...what.”

 

Moving to the pool of water, she stared at herself, and saw two eyes stare back at her. There was still some scarring but her eye was back. In a rush she began to remove the rest of her clothes, trying to see if the rest of her scars had healed as well. 

 

She wasn't sure whether she should be relieved or not to see the scars on her body, both old and new, including the one the Death Knight had left on her chest. 

 

“Okay. Okay, that’s…good? Good. Yes, having an eye back is good, I have two eyes again. Oh this feels weird now…” She blinked at her reflection, then paused and brushed her hair back, trying to see if her ears were pointed now.

 

She twitched slightly upon feeling the tips of her now pointed ears. Taking in a breath, she tried to calm herself down, letting go of her ears before splashing water on her face. This…was a lot to take in at once, and she decided to instead focus on relaxing. 

 

Stepping into the water, she formed a basic fire spell to warm it up, getting it just right for her to relax. Letting out a sigh, Byleth laid back in the water, staring up into the void…or was she staring down? 

 

She didn't really have any idea if up was still up in the void. It would have been okay if there was…any form of landmark here to help focus on, but there really wasn't anything. A part of her wished she had brought a book, but she probably would have read it ten times over by this point. 

 

"...I need a new hobby," she muttered to herself, before glancing around. Gardening and fishing weren't really options here, so she had to make do with what she had. Not that she had much, aside from rocks, all she had was what she had brought with her. 

 

It was a shame they ran out of calming herbs already, those helped a bit after Sothis left. 

 

Regardless, there had to be something to do…hm. Reaching for her clothes, Byleth grabbed her dagger, along with a stray rock nearby. It was a decent sized one, bigger than her hand, so it would make good practice… 

 

With a nod, she began to carve a face into it, starting with the imperious looking eyes–

 

"Byleth, are you awake?"
