"I'm not doing anything!" Byleth shouted, sinking her hands into the waters to hide the rock. 

 

“...” Rhea, who had decided to discard her archbishop raiments a while ago in favor of just wearing her white gown, stared in obvious confusion at Byleth, before her cheeks turned a little pink and she averted her gaze. “Right, ah…I apologize, I did not realize you were…of course, it is perfectly normal for a woman your age to want some…stress relief, and, ah…I will leave you to that.”

 

Byleth blinked, before abruptly realizing what Rhea thought was going on and immediately going completely red. “Th-That’s not–...m-mmh…”

 

Sinking into the water, she hoped that the surprise of her eye returning would be enough to get Rhea to forget about this misunderstanding.

“To begin, Nabatean biology is quite different from human biology,” Rhea began, attempting to act dignified and calm after Byleth asked her to explain her body’s changes. In return, Byleth chose to ignore how the archbishop had literally squealed with excitement when she first explained her changes. “As you already know, our people may resemble humans, but we have a number of significant differences that make us entirely distinct from them.”

 

“Right, we can eat rocks,” Byleth agreed, nodding.

 

“...that…there are other differences, of course.”

 

“Right. What do rocks taste like anyway?”

 

“I think there are other things we can focus on–” Rhea paused as Byleth put a pebble into her mouth.

 

“...hm. I don’t know why, but my first thought is ‘tastes like chicken’.”

 

“Yes, everyone says that. The rocks at Zanado tasted more like pheasant though. There’s a subtle difference,” Rhea replied, her exasperation fading as she discussed the topic, “Honestly, the stones here taste more of duck to me than poultry. More…fatty, somehow.”

 

“Duck is a type of poultry.”

 

She paused. “What? No it isn’t. Poultry doesn’t refer to all birds.”

 

“Yeah, but duck is a type of poultry. Chickens, ducks, and geese are all types of poultry. I think it counts as long as it’s domesticated and nobles will domesticate anything if they think it’s pretty.”

 

“...well, yes, that is true, but you wouldn’t call a falcon poultry .”

 

“Mm…I think I would. A bird is a bird.” Byleth tilted her head, thinking. “Have you ever eaten a falcon?”

 

“...I believe we should discuss something else now.”

 

“I have. It wasn’t that good. Sort of gamey.”

 

"Why did you eat a falcon?" 

 

"Well I was hunting for food, and it's the only thing I saw,” she explained, “When you're traveling, you kinda eat whatever you can get your hands on if you're low on supplies." 

 

"I thought your family were all famous mercenaries? Surely you must have had food more often." 

 

"More than other mercenary groups, sure, but that didn't mean we didn't have dry spells. Heck, the entire reason I met Shez is because we didn't have any jobs for a few months so we needed to go hunting." Byleth shrugged. "It's why I always try to save up on money. Though I ended up blowing all my savings while I was here." 

 

Rhea winced. “Ah, yes, I recall you saying so…you were supposed to get raises–”

 

“I know. I didn’t. So, yeah.” She paused. “Is it weird that I’m more mad about that than you trying to kill me?”

 

“...the offer for a million gold is still open.”

 

Byleth raised an eyebrow. “Where am I going to spend it? In the infinite darkness?”

 

“...Don’t sass me.”

 

“You’re not my boss anymore so you can’t give me orders,” she bluntly stated.

 

"...Your resignation hasn't been officially filed." 

 

“You can’t pay me, so that isn’t valid.”

 

“Yes it is.”

 

“Then I’ll just leave anyway. I’m a traveling mercenary, and as Jeralt says, if a job is terrible, just leave.” She paused. “To be clear, I really enjoyed teaching. I don’t enjoy working for you. You’re a bad employer and I will be informing other mercenary groups of such.”

 

Rhea frowned, before moving over to her discarded raiments and picking up her headdress. “Would this suffice for payment?”

 

“It’ll do for severance pay,” Byleth stated, taking the gold headdress without hesitation. She looked at it for a moment, before putting it on. "Does this mean I'm the Archbishop now?" 

 

“...No.”

 

“Would I be if I took the rest of your clothes?”

 

“No. The clothes don’t make the archbishop.”

 

“Hm.” Byleth obviously didn’t believe her.

 

"Do you even want to be the archbishop?" 

 

"Probably not, but it would make it easier to dissolve the church so things are easier for Edelgard." 

 

Rhea sighed. “Can we get back to the changes you’ve gone through? Such as how much you’ve been sleeping, for instance.”

 

Byleth blinked. “That’s a Nabatean thing?”

 

“It is! It is perfectly normal for Nabateans to sleep for long periods of time due to illness or injury so our bodies can regenerate, as you can clearly see.” Byleth raised an eyebrow, but Rhea didn’t seem to notice her own wordplay. “I remember some members of my kind would sleep for an entire week because they were stressed." 

 

"Oh…hm. But I could get so much done in a week…" Byleth murmured, frowning.

 

"Ah, I can understand your apprehension. Flayn is also not fond of sleeping for long periods of time after…a rather extended period of recovery." 

 

"Hm…so as long as I make sure to stay healthy and unstressed, I should be okay?" Byleth asked before thinking. "...Might be a good idea to stock up on calming herbs when we get out of here."

 

“They do tend to help, yes. Though I will note that you should probably take some on your own to get more used to it.”

 

Byleth paused. “...why? Did I say something weird?”

 

“A few things, yes. You were quite emphatic about wanting to cuddle with your girlfriends, you declared your intent to pull ‘Shez’s ghost’ out of her body and then beat him to death, and you suggested crests were the root of all evil and the solution to the world’s woes was to make everyone into dragons.”

 

“...all I remember is being hungry and eating the rest of the jerky.”

 

“Yes, that will happen sometimes. You get used to it. Admittedly some of the fault lies on me for giving you the calming herbs I use for myself. I tend to require a stronger version." 

 

“...huh.” Byleth slowly nodded. “We were having a biology lesson.”

 

“Ah, right, where was I…well, do you have any questions?”

 

“I guess so. I do want to know if this is something that, ah…well, if I can ever go back to being human. I’m not…I’m definitely not unhappy to have my eye back. It just feels strange and I want to know if I can fix it.”

 

Rhea blinked. “Fix it? Child, this…isn’t something you fix, it’s part of who you are.”

 

“No, it’s…I only became like this because I fused with Sothis. I’m not…like this naturally.”

 

“I know that. I know you were mostly human previously, but now you are a Nabatean in truth. That is reality.” She tried to smile. “You could look at it as a natural progression, if you want. In a sense, it is your heritage awakening. Though Sitri was a homunculus, you are still partially Nabatean, and now you are Nabatean in full. Isn’t that natural?”

 

“...Nothing about me is natural,” Byleth muttered, feeling a strange surge of sadness, “My heart doesn’t beat.”

 

“Mine doesn’t either, child. Our hearts are stones. They do not beat like human hearts." 

 

"..." Byleth looked up at Rhea and saw nothing but honesty in the older woman’s gaze. She stared for a moment, then took in a deep breath, trying to absorb that information. That she wasn't alone in how her heart worked was…certainly something she didn't expect. "...What about Shez? Or Edelgard and Dorothea? All of my other friends and students…they're just human. Am I supposed to outlive them now?" 

 

"You can offer them your blood, see if they wish to extend their life. But…I cannot guarantee they'll accept." Rhea managed to smile then, but it was a sad one. “It is the reality of being who we are. It is inevitable you will outlive at least some of those you care for. But then, that is true for many, isn’t it? Living means you will inevitably outlive someone you love.”

 

“...Hm.” Byleth laid down and stared up into the darkness. She could see with both her eyes now, though there wasn’t anything to see. “...that’s scary.”

 

“It is.” Rhea moved over and sat beside her. “...I’ll be there for you. I promise.”

 

Byleth remained silent for a moment, before leaning against Rhea, seeking the only comfort she could. 

“The Diligent One and the Patient One were my eldest siblings,” Rhea recalled, using her vestments as a pillow while she lay beside Byleth, the two of them staring up into the void, “I remember them being so…impossibly vast compared to me. It hurts, thinking they were reduced to nothing more than ‘relics’ for humanity to kill each other with.”

 

“Mm. I can understand that. I don’t think I’d forgive anyone if they killed Shez,” Byleth commented. Despite her effort to be cordial, she could hear a bit of accusation leak into her words.

 

Rhea just sighed though. “Yes, you made your point. I feel as though the hypothetical harm I could have caused is outweighed by the very real harm that happened to my people.”

 

“And I feel like it’s not a competition.” She paused. “...would it be rude to ask which relics they are? I’m sorry if it is, I just don’t have a lot of context outside of them.”

 

“...Those who bear the Crest of Goneril have the blood of Diligent, while those who bear the Crest of Lamine have the blood of Patient. They were the Kalpa Dragon and the Aegis Dragon.” Rhea let out a wistful sigh. "The Patient One would likely be very amused that the Steadfast’s remains are called Aegis. She was always quite doting." 

 

“Mm…Kind of like Mercedes?”

 

“I suppose.”

 

“Neat. Hey, what are Seteth and Flayn’s Nabatean names?”

 

“Hammer of Judgement and the Benevolent One,” Rhea readily answered, faintly amused by Byleth’s curiosity, “They are an earth dragon and a light dragon, respectively.”

 

“Huh. Hey, how come Seteth and Flayn have different crests?”

 

“It likely has to do with young Flayn’s mother. Mixing with a human can have interesting results at times. Light arising from Earth is not impossible, for we all came from the same source. The progenitor formed us all through her will and her magic, and then we spread out. There were those like Seteth, Indech, and Macuil, who were born of basic elements, then there were the direct children of the Goddess herself. In that sense, there were six crests that were sacred: Aegis, Kalpa, Star, Grim, Storm, and Sky, with the last belonging to myself. It was only later that humans tied our crests to human ‘heroes’ and declared them unique.

 

"Huh…so, were you always a leader?" 

 

"No. I was never meant to lead, I was simply a warrior. Even when we went to war against Nemesis, Wilhelm was the one actually leading our armies." She sighed. “I can give orders in the field, but I have always been better directed by another, working with commanders who have greater tactical acumen than I.”

 

“Hm. So why did you become the archbishop?”

 

“...because it was the only way I felt safe. I had to have control over…everything. It was why I pushed Wilhelm away. I couldn’t handle the idea of letting him have power over me. It's why I recognized the Kingdom and the Alliance too. I felt as if it would let me remain in control while stopping the wars their existence caused." Rhea let out a sigh. "And I decided to completely throw that away because one Agarthan got under my skin." 

 

“Hm? How so?”

 

“...ah, I suppose it was rather hectic at that point…I declared that the Kingdom is no longer a legitimate nation in a moment of blind fury.”

 

“...” Byleth sat up, giving Rhea an incredulous look. “What? You can do that?”

 

“Technically, yes, given the Kingdom derives its authority from the Church.”

 

“...but doesn’t that completely remove their authority over their lands?”

 

“It…would. If it is upheld, though given my…absence, I cannot imagine things going well.” She paused. “...I may have given both the Empire and Alliance justification to invade the Kingdom. Hm.”

 

“Yes. That’s exactly what you did. What did this guy even say to upset you so much?”

 

Rhea sighed, before repeating what Myson said, word for word.

 

“...” A vein pulsed in Byleth’s forehead. “...I’m going to skin him.”

 

Rhea smiled. “I can help.”

 

Byleth laughed in response, before laying back down, staring up into the darkness. “...I hope we get out of here soon.”

 

“As do I, child. As do I.”

Chapter End Notes

Red: Happy Anniversary everybody! Specifically, the anniversary of this story!

Indi: Yup yup, it's been one year since we started uploading Daughters!

Red: And wow is that wild to think. But hey, thanks to everyone who's stuck with this initially little and now very, very big story of ours!

Indi: Thanks a lot! And we hoped you enjoyed this bit of Rhea and Byleth in the void before we officially hit the timeskip!

Red: Yeah we're still not at that yet. Next chapter! We promise!

Indi: Until then, see you next time! And feel free to join our discord! https://discord.gg/gn2VtVPs8h

A Changed World

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

The Fall of Garreg Mach Monastery was an event that would echo throughout the history of Fodlan. As the Year 1180 of the Imperial Calendar came to an end, so too did the balance of power between the continent’s three major nations.

 

The most changed of the three was the Holy Kingdom of Faerghus, which now emphasized the “Holy” aspect of its name to an unsettling degree as the Western Church, once damaged by its members’ ill-fated attempt to take on the Central Church, assumed a new, greater power with its reformation as the Great Church of Faerghus. Under the authority of its recently established archbishop, Cornelia Arnim, the Northern Church, as it would come to be known, officially crowned the former regent of the kingdom, Rufus Thierry Blaiddyd, as its rightful king following his nephew’s disinheritance from the line of succession for the crime of murdering the knights of the Kingdom’s army.

 

Following his ascension, King Rufus enacted several reforms aimed to expand the power of the nobility he favored while curtailing his political rivals. Most significantly, Duke Rodrigue Achille Fraldarius was imprisoned for conspiracy against the crown, while other major nobles, such as Margrave Gautier, Count Charon, and Count Galatea faced censure and fines for their ties to the supposed conspiracy. 

 

House Galatea, whose holdings were known for their frequent famines, capitulated first of the three, surrendering to the king’s judgment and consenting to have their lands instead managed by a regent of Rufus’s choice in exchange for keeping their titles. House Charon, meanwhile, attempted to hold out against the royalist army, but was ultimately forced to flee their lands for Alliance territory following a disastrous siege wherein the Count of Charon fought to his last breath. Finally, House Gautier held strong as a true fortress of the north, though it was not long before the besieged house began to feel a hungry sting due to the lack of trade from their southern neighbors, particularly as winter approached once more and the raids from Sreng began in earnest.

 

Bereft of support from the strongest among them, it was not long before the houses that were not already allied with King Rufus conceded to his authority. As for those who readily supported him, Houses Kleiman, Mateus, Elidure, and Gideon found their fortunes vastly increased by an influx of weapons from the king’s stores and resources from the pillaged Great Houses. 

 

Count Rowe, of course, eagerly joined with the king, proclaiming he was always on his side.

 

Of course, it was impossible not to mention, in the midst of this new order forming, the tales of how King Rufus was chosen to bear the Crest of Blaiddyd by the goddess herself. Such tales found a disturbing purchase quickly within the nobility of Faerghus, particularly when the newly named Duke Mateus took regency of House Fraldarius’s lands, now bearing that house’s famous crest.

 

Yet despite his successes, Rufus’s hold on Faerghus was not a complete one, and whispers spread of the young prince who still resisted his uncle’s rule…

 

With a roar, Dimitri Alexander Blaiddyd swept a group of soldiers with his spear, knocking them onto their backs as he continued charging forward, moving from opponent to opponent without wasting a single second. 

 

"Watch your back!" Felix shouted, deflecting an arrow aimed for Dimitri’s neck, covering the prince who smiled in response. 

 

"But you're already doing that for me." 

 

"Hey come on you two, no time to flirt!" Sylvain joked, trampling over an armored knight as he joined his friends. 

 

"Shut up!" 

 

"Enough chatter, enemy Tyrant coming directly at us!" Ingrid shouted, staying in the air to provide support as she spotted a black clad brute charging them. 

 

"An abomination such as him has no right in the goddess’s world," Mercedes intoned from atop her white steed, a blaze of fire hitting the monster in the form of a Ragnarok, getting the creature to scream but kept moving. 

 

Luckily, an Excalibur cast a second later by Annette put down the undead monster, the massive gale tearing apart the burning corpse and scattering its limbs. “Augh, I hate how they scream now! Why would they even make them do that?! It’s so creepy!”

 

"I don't think the people who made them really care if they're creepy or not…" Ashe muttered, firing arrows off at some mages before they could blindside the melee combatants. 

 

Remaining silent amongst his chattering classmates, Dedue charged forward, slamming his shield into a demonic beast. With a grunt of exertion, he pushed hard enough to launch the beast on its side. Quickly moving back, he let Yuri rush in, slicing open the soft underside of the beast with ease. 

 

"Heh, you know, I can't help but wish we had someone as reliable as you with the Wolves back in the day." He grinned up at the large man from Duscur. “Would’ve been nice having a solid wall of muscle on my side.”

 

“Hm, I suppose I can accept that praise,” Dedue joked, smiling faintly as he took stock of what else they needed to do to finish the skirmish, “Though, didn’t you have a man filling the role of a ‘solid wall’ on your side back then?”

 

“You mean Balthus? Oh sure, but he’s more of a brawler than a defender, and I definitely wouldn’t call him reliable.”

 

Elsewhere, Balthus felt an odd sense of offense, before he shrugged it off and punched out his foe in the underground fighting ring he was taking part in.

 

“I see. Well, I thank you for the praise anyway,” Dedue replied, before quickly raising his shield to block an arrow from an archer on horseback.

 

The bow knight scowled as his shot was deflected, before quickly pulling at the reins of his horse and turning to try to flee, only for an arrow from Ashe to pierce into his back and send him falling from the saddle to crash into the ground.

 

"Alright that should be the last of them," Sylvain said, grinning as the battle came to an end. 

 

"Thank the goddess, hopefully they have some supplies we can take," Annette muttered, as she let out a sigh. 

 

"As if the goddess would grant us such mercy..." 

 

“...Is it me, or does Mercedes seem a lot more like Marianne these days?” Sylvain commented, looking a little concerned.

 

“I mean…Marianne was always more down on herself,” Ashe pointed out, “Mercedes is kind of…upset with everything. Well, except for Annette and Dedue.” He paused. “I guess Yuri too? Because of that whole ‘Apostle’ thing.”

 

"Well as long as we can direct it at the people we're fighting, it should all be okay," Ingrid said, landing beside them. 

 

"Come on Mercy, I'm sure the goddess will give us something nice for dealing with people actively going against her," Annette said, gently guiding her friend off the battlefield. 

 

"Well if nothing else, little miss short and sweet definitely knows how to handle her," Yuri remarked, very amused. 

 

“True…though does anyone else find it kinda concerning she’s started wearing white armor and riding a white horse?” Sylvain asked, earning some weird looks, “Hey, I’m just saying, considering who her brother is, I’m starting to wonder if we’ll see her put on a skull helmet and call herself ‘The Life Knight’.”

 

“That’s a terrible idea, Sylvain,” Yuri retorted, mock-frowning up at him, “Obviously she’d be ‘The Sacred Knight’.”

 

“...Yeah, sure, that’s the issue there.”

 

Off to the side, Felix, Dimitri, and Dedue looked over the battlefield. "Most of the men here seem to be Gideon's forces. They must be stretching thin if they're down here in Charon territory." 

 

"Then that just means we're making headway," Felix pointed out. 

 

"Yes, but…I can't help but wonder just how many people will be left once the war is over at this rate." Dimitri sighed. “I knew my uncle had sided with those monsters, but I thought even he wouldn’t want to rule over a kingdom of the dead.”

 

“Considering those monsters he’s working with can raise the dead, I don’t think he cares about the living,” Felix remarked.

 

“Faerghus is a large country,” Dedue pointed out, “We may be surrounded with death at the moment, but I can’t imagine every part of the kingdom looks this bad.”

 

“So we should just ignore the rumors that Rufus is burning villages that don’t, or can’t, pay his raised taxes?”

 

"No, but we mustn't lose ourselves. The people of Faerghus are strong, you know this as well as I." 

 

Dimitri let out a sigh, turning his attention away from them as he let his mind wander. It was hard to imagine three years had passed since that fateful day at the monastery. Losing Count Charon had been a bad blow to their burgeoning resistance, but they’d still managed to hold strong…so far, at least. 

 

It turned his stomach to think that he and his friends had basically become bandits, raiding the Kingdom for supplies and striking at the knights that were meant to protect the people. But then he remembered those refugees they brought to Abyss, whose faces lit up with open joy when they returned after these raids, and some of that conflict subsided.

 

One day, he would make things right in Faerghus. For now though, his mind drifted to his former schoolmates as he felt himself wondering just what was happening in the other countries of Fodlan.

Of the three nations, the Alliance was the least directly affected by the fall of Garreg Mach, yet that did not mean it remained untouched. Much like always, the Alliance stood divided. 

 

After the death of 'Acheron’ at Garreg Mach, the forces of Count Gloucester, and those remaining of Count Ordelia, refocused their efforts into taking back the stolen land. With no heir to take over with the lord’s demise, House Phlegethon should have dissolved, yet his forces somehow held firm, claiming to be under the authority of “Lady Cocytus”, who declared the land a part of the “The Principality of Hrym” started by the rebelling Duke Ludwig von Aegir, formerly of Adrestia.

 

With the rebel state’s support, Phlegethon maintained its grip on Ordelia territory and effectively cut the Alliance off from the Empire entirely, heavily disrupting trade and causing a great deal of trouble for those Alliance houses that wished to ally with Adrestia.

 

Sadly, aid would not come easily to Gloucester and Ordelia. 

 

House Riegan was forced to focus on defending their own land from Kingdom invasions, which, while not as many, were no less fierce than those attacking the Empire, particularly as they pushed into Daphnel territory, all while threatening to subsume the smaller houses of Siward, Albany, and Burgundy. House Goneril, in contrast, found themselves facing unexpected raids from the East as Almyra saw the chaos engulfing Fodlan and found an opportunity to damage their longstanding foes.

 

House Edmund, largely safe from the invasions by land, surprisingly wanted to establish contact with the Emperor. This decision appeared to be in part due to the sudden “disappearance” of the House’s heiress, Marianne von Edmund, who had wound up on the other side of the country after following her classmates in the Black Eagles. Otherwise though, Edmund made few moves towards aiding their fellow Alliance members.

 

With their attention divided, the Alliance made no move towards quelling the current chaotic state of Fodlan. Yet the wheels of politics never stopped turning…

 

“Alright, so here goes our first meeting of the new year,” Claude began, clapping his hands together to catch everyone at the Roundtable’s attention, “And, uh…well three out of five isn’t bad.”

 

“So Margrave Edmund isn’t planning to attend at all?” Lorenz inquired, frowning, “He’s not even sending a representative?”

 

“Yeah, turns out he’s pretty focused on trying to link up with the Empire. Well, the half of the Empire that’s still loyal to the Emperor. Or I guess the third that’s still loyal and isn’t currently invaded by the Kingdom? Speaking of which, Judith! Nice to have you attending one of these.”

 

“Thanks Claude.” The current head of House Daphnel stood up from her place at the table, nodding to the far younger representatives present. “As you all likely know already, Count Ordelia has chosen to have his house step down as one of the Great Houses of the Alliance, and chose House Daphnel as their interim representative. I imagine we’ll have to actually talk about who’s going to be the real fifth Great House when we get a chance, but this announcement is just to make things official.”

 

“So what’s that mean for Lysithea?” Hilda asked.

 

“As far as I know? She’s renounced her noble title and the Ordelia line is going to die out. They don’t exactly have cousins to take things over.” Judith glanced over at Lorenz. “Isn’t your father taking care of things there?”

 

“That does seem to be the plan, yes. House Gloucester will be taking the lands of Ordelia and Phlegethon and distributing them to branches of our household.” He grimaced. “Once it is properly seized, at least.”

 

“That’s a lot of land you’re taking there,” Claude noted.

 

“Well we would be willing to distribute the land to those assisting in the reclamation of Ordelia territory…if anyone would actually bother to help.”

 

“Hey, come on, we’re busy helping with the Almyran thing!” Hilda complained, frowning, “You know, the thing that we’re not getting support for?”

 

“I was under the impression that House Albrecht was aiding–”

 

“Yeah, Baltie helping us out doesn’t count as House Albrecht helping. He’s not part of them, and they’re not helping us, even though they’re trying to say they should get to be one of the Great Houses.” She huffed, crossing her arms over her chest, before giving Lorenz a look. “Also, isn’t Baron Muller helping out you guys?”

 

“Well…true, she is, but–”

 

“So that’s not no one.”

 

“...I would simply prefer that we have more support. After all, there are other houses in Leicester capable of helping–”

 

“Who? I mean obviously there’s Albrecht, but we’ve already established Lady Albrecht is a bitch who isn’t helping, and then there’s the trio of Albany, Siward, and Burgundy, who are dealing with, what, Lady Judith?”

 

“Frequent invasions from the Kingdom,” Judith answered.

 

“There we go! Frequent invasions. So that leaves, who? Claude, who’s also dealing with everything going on and did actually send troops your way, or…oh, maybe House Nilsson? Are they having any issues from the invading Almyrans? No? Really? Oh, no, wait, they are! And they’re also taking care of the church people who survived because, right, the Central Church is gone. So…yeah. Are you still complaining?”

 

"I am not complaining. I am merely stating what the situation is," Lorenz said with a sigh. "And for the record, Baron Muller isn't asking for any of the land. She is instead asking for Shamir to be handed to her for her assistance." 

 

That prompted pauses from everyone present. 

 

“...Like…Shamir Nevrand?” Claude asked, “The Dagdan knight of Seiros?”

 

“Yes. I…do not know many people with the name Shamir. And she was quite specific.”

 

“...” Hilda, in a display of uncharacteristic seriousness, folded her hands and gave Lorenz a very unimpressed look. “Lorenz. Did you promise to give over a human being to a baron in exchange for her assistance?”

 

“What? No, of course not! I have already stated as much to her, yet she seems to be obsessed with her! I don't even know what for! As far as I'm aware Shamir doesn't owe her any outstanding debts." 

 

“...Yeah, makes no sense at all why she would want to grab her without a reason,” Hilda murmured, rolling her eyes.

 

"So, the criminality of some of our houses aside, we’re dealing with a lot right now. So far, we’ve been able to hold everything back, but we’re facing invasions on three sides because of Hrym, Faerghus, and Almyra. I know the Knights have been chipping in as much as they can, but even they’re getting stretched thin,” Claude noted, frowning down at the map spread across the table.

 

“Catherine has been a big help trying to hold back Faerghus,” Judith remarked, “And as cynical as it might sound, hosting the remnants of House Charon is probably a big reason why she’s so willing to help instead of trying to search for the archbishop like the other knights.”

 

“Shamir has been helping out a lot on our end too,” Hilda pointed out, “Those arrows of hers are really good for taking out Almyran wyvern knights. Or, well, wyvern whatever-they-call-them.”

 

“Cataphracts,” Claude commented off-handedly, still frowning at the map, “...if we could focus all our attention on one problem at a time, we might be able to just deal with one and be done with it.”

 

“Yes, and if our enemies would conveniently decide to lay down their arms and armor, we would win just as easily,” Lorenz retorted, annoyed, “We need solutions here. Obviously the so-called Principality is our largest threat at the moment given they have actually seized our land and have the opportunity to push in further!”

 

“I don’t know about that,” Judith remarked, “Faerghus has hit our trio of minor houses again and again and I’m pretty sure they’re starting to waver. Burgundy had a pretty bad harvest last year because of all the farms being burned and Siward doesn’t exactly have the strongest backbone.”

 

“I’ll admit, I’m kinda surprised Albany didn't jump just to be contradictory,” Claude commented, before glancing at Hilda, “So, let me guess, things are bad enough in Goneril that you can’t afford sending troops?”

 

“Honestly, we might be able to,” Hilda admitted, “The problem is…okay, you know how a little while after the monastery fell, that Shahid guy tried invading again?”

 

Claude grimaced. “Yeah, I know, and I think I know what you’re about to say. Someone else is running things over there now, huh?”

 

“That’s my guess. Either that or Shahid got a lot smarter after losing again, because now we keep having to deal with sudden, staggered attacks, over and over again. There’s just enough of a lull for us to start getting comfortable before they suddenly hit us again, somewhere we weren’t looking, and it’s making a lot of trouble for us. We’re nowhere close to cracking, sure, but it means that we can’t send troops away from the front or else we might actually see them break through.” She sighed. “With the church guys helping out, we have just enough people to garrison all the forts. Maybe we can start pulling things away, but we'd probably only be able to send a squad at most.

 

She sighed again, pouting. “That’s not to mention how I actually have to put in all this effort now…”

 

“Yeah, that’s the real travesty here,” Claude agreed, grinning, “Alright, well, while I try to figure out how I’m going to handle this next year of running around, putting out fires, let’s just check in real quick. I know Ignatz is with your guys, Lorenz, and last I heard Raphael’s helping out at the Locket, so my big question is where’s our wayward mage and mercenary?”

 

“I presume you refer to Lysithea and Leonie, given, well…” Lorenz trailed off, the mood visibly lowering as everyone thought of Shez, before he shook it off. “Well, while she might have renounced her title, Lysithea is still upholding her noble prestige by assisting those towns that need aid along the borders of Ordelia. She’s contributed a bit to our efforts at retaking the land, but primarily, she and Leonie have been dealing with issues like bandits attempting to prey on those displaced by the conflict.”

 

"Well, hopefully they have fun with that," Hilda muttered. 

 

"Oh I'm sure they will," Lorenz said, quite amused, "Don't tell Lysithea I mentioned this, but she has quite the obvious crush on Leonie." 

 

"..." Both Hilda and Claude stared at the purple-haired noble incredulously. 

 

“...I have to say, these meetings have been getting a lot better since you kids took charge,” Judith commented, openly amused.

The Empire of Adrestia, under its recently crowned Emperor Edelgard von Hresvelg, soon found itself in its own unfortunate circumstances directly following the Fall of Garreg Mach as the empowered Kingdom quickly began striking at its southern neighbor. Bolstered by its empowered knights, Faerghus waged bloody war, seeking to conquer the lands to its southwest in a war of retribution against those it claimed to have started the Tragedy of Duscur. 

 

Though the armies of Faerghus failed to hold Garreg Mach itself, finding themselves instead driven off by an unexpected cadre of ‘Reformed Knights’ that struck at their forces, the Kingdom still quickly pushed its armies into rapidly overtaking Houses Barnabas, Martyn, and Gillingr, before claiming the former territory of Arundel as a staging ground from which it continued assaults into the empire’s western half.

 

While Adrestia would normally be able to strike back against such an assault with its superior numbers and resources, a treacherous attack from the east caught them off guard. The newly freed Duke Aegir was quick to take advantage of the attack on the monastery and moved with the aid of his Agarthan allies to strike before the Emperor could properly return, escaping from custody and forming his own nation known as the “Principality of Hrym” in honor of its base of operations (and a slight attempt on Aegir’s part to hedge his bets by not attaching his own name directly to the new faction).

 

Though the newly established Archduke Aegir and his Agarthan allies did not manage to take the capital, the damage they caused to the palace and the imperial city as they made their escape heavily disrupted Emperor Edelgard’s early attempts to maintain order in the capital. This, along with the surge of refugees of the monastery, meant the Emperor was forced to focus inward while she attempted to wrest control of Adrestia away from those seeking to ruin it.

 

Unfortunately, her efforts would be further stymied when the Agarthans struck all at once in a trio of brutal assassination attempts against the Ministers of Domestic, Military, and Religious Affairs. Ultimately, Count Leopold von Bergliez managed to survive the attempt on his life and even slew the entire team of assassins sent to murder him, though not without sustaining heavy wounds and a near-crippling injury. In addition, his firstborn son was killed during the assassination attempt, leaving House Bergliez without a crest-bearing heir.

 

Similarly, Count Waldemar von Hevring was saved from his own potential demise by the timely intervention of Ladislava, a member of the Emperor’s personal guard who had been delivering a message to the count at the time and managed to save him from being sliced open by the assassins, though not without both of them sustaining injuries. Luckily, such injuries were not lethal, but they still put the count out of commission when he would have been needed.

 

Finally and tragically, Count Varley, who had been under house arrest during these events, was successfully assassinated by a group of Agarthan assassins, who quite brutally stabbed the former minister to death despite his protests that he was on their side. Reportedly, his daughter passed out from the news, though witnesses of the event remarked that the young woman had a strangely relieved expression on her face.

 

Even with these losses, the Emperor fought back with all the force she could. Bolstered by the aid of the remaining loyalist nobles and the famed mercenary, Jeralt Eisner, Edelgard von Hresvelg held firm against enemies on all sides, though striking back against her foes had been difficult for the young emperor, particularly as the forces of the Principality managed to seize a great deal of Bergliez and Varley territory during the opening years of the war.

 

And yet, life for the former Eagles did achieve a sort of normalcy in the midst of the chaos that surrounded them…

 

Dorothea still wasn’t used to waking up in such a luxurious bed. Even during her time at the Opera Company while the beds might have been nice, there wasn't much privacy given they tended to be three or four divas in a single room. And while there were the 'private' rooms, there was little comfort to be had there for her. 

 

Regardless, she would have been okay in the large bed if she had company, yet she was unfortunately used to waking up alone. 

 

Dorothea let out an annoyed sigh as she sat up in bed and brushed a hand through her long, messy hair. She’d need to properly brush it–Though, no, she had maids that did that…Goddess, that was still strange. It wasn’t like she hadn’t had people help her with her hair before, it was pretty common back at the opera company to help each other out like that, but none of them had worn cute maid outfits while doing it. Well, except for that one time Adrienne was playing a maid…

 

Still, it's not like she could exactly blame Edelgard; the former songstress only went to sleep long after midnight. 

 

Really all the Eagles were running themselves ragged after the battle at Garreg Mach, but they still made sure to sleep. Sighing as she got up, Dorothea began to brush her hair, doing her best to make herself presentable before tossing a robe over her nightwear. Putting on her slippers since it would be silly to walk around barefoot, the Diva went out to Edelgard’s office. 

 

Walking down the halls, Dorothea greeted those who she saw along the way. She didn't think she'd ever get used to people bowing to her, but that was the least of her worries. Soon enough she found herself in front of the Emperor's office. Slapping her cheeks, Dorothea did her best to get rid of any remaining sleepiness, before slightly loosening her robe. Nodding to herself, Dorothea put on her best smile and opened the door. 

 

And sure enough, there was her Edie, perfectly dressed in her silver armor and scarlet skirts, her hair tied back in that new braided style of hers…All around, she looked as adorable as always, even if she didn't get to wear that armored dress she wanted to. Shame that she couldn't get it finished yet; apparently it would take another few months at the very least. It was an even bigger shame that she seemed so determined to work herself to death.

 

“Hello Edie~! Hard at work as always?”

 

“Ah, Dorothea. Yes, we’ve had another push on the western front, a consequence of the Kingdom’s generals taking some surprisingly risky moves, though they appear to be bolstered by more of those mechanical monstrosities, the Titanuses…” Edelgard murmured, looking through the reports and making notes in between signing orders, “Hubert’s people successfully raided an Agarthan laboratory, so we have notes on their current projects. It seems their leadership is splitting their forces, with Titanuses being used in the Kingdom while demonic beasts, which they refer to as ‘Ladons’ and ‘Delphons’, are being used by their Imperial allies, which means they’re appearing in both Empire and Alliance territory, which raises questions–”

 

“You’re saying ‘which’ a lot,” Dorothea noted, amused.

 

“I am? Oh, I suppose I am…It is a concern though. I would have thought they would abandon Ordelia territory with the death of ‘Acheron’, but they managed to keep it as a sort of buffer for years at this point. Maybe they’re more invested in Ordelia than I thought? Perhaps…" She sighed, shaking her head before finally looking up, "Regardless we–..." 

 

Dorothea couldn't help but smirk as Edelgard looked away, her face a bit pink. Though in her defense Dorothea had loosened the robe even more while she had been talking. "Heh, seems even a big, strong emperor can get all blushy." 

 

“M-Mm. You don’t…I do not need ‘comforting’ right now–”

 

“Then why don’t we have some fun because I want to, hm?” Dorothea asked, walking closer. "I mean, we're both aware how sturdy your desk is." 

 

“...I feel…that might not be…appropriate–”

 

“Did anyone complain?”

 

“...” Edelgard glanced to the side, her face warm. "I-It's early isn't it?" 

 

"True. In that case," With a grin, she tapped Edelgard on the nose, "How about some breakfast?" 

 

“...Ah. You were teasing me.” She huffed. “...Breakfast would be good.”

 

"That it would. So come on, let's go get some food." 

 

"Are you not going to get dressed first?" 

 

"Aw, but this robe is so comfy. But fine, I'll go get dressed, while you go save us a seat," Dorothea said, grinning as she tied her robe close. 

 

"I will, I just need to read one more report–" 

 

"So what I'm hearing is I should toss everything off your desk so we can have fun?" 

 

"..." Edelgard tried to fight the temptation, well aware that it would set her back if all her papers were tossed about. “...I’ll head to the dining room.”

 

“Hmm…or you could help me change. Just so I know you’re not sneaking off to work when you shouldn’t.”

 

Edelgard sighed, before getting up to follow the songstress. 

 

Soon enough, the songstress was dressed in a modest yet tasteful dress, though she did have her hair tied in a loose ponytail with a purple ribbon. "There we go, now I'm ready for the day." 

 

"You do look lovely." Edelgard complimented, smiling at her. Dorothea smiled back, before noticing something. 

 

"Hey, Whiskers, off the vanity," Dorothea pouted as she gently shooed the cat away from the bowl where Snappy was resting. Cute cat or not, she didn't want Byleth’s pet to go missing one day because of him. "I'll make sure to get you some treats later, but Snappy is off limits." 

 

"I still can't believe you saved Snappy," Edelgard said with an amused huff, then grabbed Whiskerton to lower him onto the floor. 

 

"To be fair, all I did was ask Sir Jeralt to grab him when he went to search the monastery. Besides, I didn't want Bylie to get sad when we find her," Dorothea replied, before she let out a small sigh. 

 

“Yes, that is a concern…I believe Jeralt is investigating the monastery again. He’s been framing it as supporting the western front, but…well, Bergliez has raised concerns about one of our generals heading off on his own for random searches.”

 

“Hmph. Well Count Bergliez could just take the suggestion to have a task force searching for Bylie at all times instead of having it be ended after a year–”

 

“Trust me, if it was up to me I would be having our forces scouring the monastery everyday,” Edelgard said, frowning as she remembered the missive she received from the minister about not wasting resources on the dead. 

 

“I know, I know, you miss her too…I just…I wish I knew what happened. I know she has to be okay, she’s…she’s Bylie, there’s no way she wouldn’t be fine. But…” Dorothea sighed. “I just want to know why she didn’t come back…”

 

"I'm sure she has her reasons. Who knows, maybe she and Shez were on their way here and just got lost. Maybe by the time we find them, they'll have taken over Almyra," Edelgard joked, trying to lighten the mood. 

 

"...Not to be rude, but I really don't think Shezzie should be in charge of a nation," Dorothea replied, biting back a chuckle. "I mean, I think she was trying to argue with Bylie over whether cats are smarter than humans one time." 

 

"Hm…well, I don't know, but I would say Whiskerton is smarter than Bergliez, wouldn't you say?" 

 

"Ah but our cat is the smartest in the land. Perhaps we should make him Emperor?" 

 

"Who do you think I have named as my successor?" 

 

Dorothea immediately burst into giggles, before trying to stifle them. “E-Edie, please–”

 

“You have to admit, he would be much better at the job than the majority of the nobles in the Empire. And I'm sure we can retire in peace with him in charge," Edelgard said, trying not to laugh as Dorothea giggled. 

 

"Tr-Truly this will be the greatest reign of the Empire, second only to yours of course." 

 

"Hm…no, I think he would do a much better job," Edelgard decided, before laughing when Dorothea burst out giggling again. She wrapped her arms around her as the songstress leaned in close. Even as the Diva stopped giggling and continued to shake, Edelgard held her up. Silently rubbing her back, Edelgard stayed strong. 

 

It was what she needed.

Yet for as grand the motivations of those leading Fodlan were, there were those far beneath them that continued to make their own moves. Be it peace or at war, bandits will be around, and someone will need to clean them up. 

 

"Are you sure you want to be coming along, Miss Lysithea?" Leonie asked, grinning at her ivory-haired friend. 

 

"You don't need to call me Miss, Leonie," the mage grumbled. 

 

"Well you are technically my boss, so…" 

 

"And as your boss, I'm telling you to stop. Besides, this is better than staying cooped up home all day," Lysithea said, guiding her horse along the trail. 

 

"Fair enough, I guess," Leonie said with a shrug. "So what do we know about this bandit again?" 

 

"Well she seemingly works alone, and has a tear shaped mark on her face. While she hasn't harmed any villager, she has extorted them for 'protection' money after clearing out any other nearby bandits." Lysithea grimaced. “Supposedly, she has some ‘inventive’ ways of dealing with bandits that try to operate wherever she sets up her ‘territory’.”

 

"Eesh, sounds like we're dealing with some wacko. You sure you're up for this?" 

 

"I am. I could probably handle this on my own if my parents weren't insistent I take a bodyguard." 

 

“Hey, I’m not going to argue with you. I’m just curious how you think we’re going to find this ‘Teardrop Bandit’. She tends to move around, right?”

 

“True, but she has certain villages that she frequents, and there were sightings reported recently in this area. So if we check these forests–” 

 

That was when a human body dressed in mercenary gear smashed through a nearby bush and landed on the path in front of them.

 

“...hm.”

 

“Well that’s either a good sign, or a bad one,” Leonie remarked, before glancing at the mercenary, “Hm…hey, you alive?”

 

“Hhhhhh…”

 

“Yeah, he’s alive. So probably a better sign than a bad one?”

 

“Hm.” Lysithea decided not to respond to that in favor of veering off the path and instead following the trajectory the mercenary had taken. And sure enough, she and Leonie found themselves in a clearing surrounded by broken trees and groaning mercenaries, with the apparent leader of the bunch being held up by the front of her armor by a cloaked woman holding a pitch-black sword.

 

“Alright, ‘Captain Berling’, you’ve got one chance to tell me who hired you to go after me before I start checking how many fingers you can lose without crying,” the woman stated, her sadistic smile showing clearly in the shadows of her cloak.

 

“G-Gh…y-you’re a monster…” the mercenary choked out, earning a laugh from the woman.

 

“Oh, you think I’m a monster?” The woman’s cloak shifted before a trio of bladed tails rose out from it, their points aimed at Berling’s eyes and throat. “Then why don’t I show you how monstrous I can–Eh?”

 

The woman paused, then turned her gaze towards Lysithea and Leonie. The mage stiffened as she caught sight of a pale face and crimson eyes, before she glared straight at the Agarthan–

 

“Hang on…is that you, pipsqueak?” The Agarthan stared at Lysithea, her confusion turning to elation as she recognized her. “It is! How's it been– Woah!" 

 

Ducking, the Agarthan dodge a Dark Spike aimed at her, tossing the mercenary captain to the side as Leonie charged forward with her spear. 

 

"We'll give you one chance to surrender, Agarthan, or else we'll settle this with force!" Lysithea commanded, being careful not to use too much magic with all the injured nearby. 

 

"What the hell?! I know I left without saying anything, but you guys are being way too rude!" Kronya complained, bringing her sword up to deflect Leonie’s spear. 

 

Lysithea’s eyes narrowed. “You left? What are you talking about?”

 

“The academy, duh! You know–Wait, hang on.” The Agarthan held up a hand and sheathed her sword, before fiddling with her cloak’s clasp and tossing away the garment, showing the…interesting outfit she was wearing, along with her bright orange hair. “Okay, see? It’s me!”

 

“…” Lysithea glanced at Leonie. “Is she a relative of yours?”

 

“Wh–Not everyone with orange hair is related,” Leonie complained, frowning at her friend, “You sound like Shez.”

 

“Oh, right, I only ever revealed my identity to Shez…” The Agarthan sighed, looking put out. “Can’t believe I forgot that…then again, I haven’t interacted with any of you in…three years?” She tilted her head, thinking, before shrugging. “Well whatever. So, hi, I’m Kronya, but you guys knew me as Emily because I was in disguise to keep an eye on Edelgard, but then all that stuff happened and I joined the Golden Deer, and then later I defected from Agartha because of Shez and Professor Byleth.”

 

“…what.”

 

Kronya blinked, staring at her baffled former classmates. “Okay, what part did I lose you at? I thought I explained things pretty concisely.”

 

"...Everything you just said is confusing." 

 

"Seriously? And here I thought you were the smart one…wait, where's Shez? She can clear this up," Kronya said, looking around, "Or the professor, I talked with her before I left." 

 

"..." Leonie and Lysithea shared a glance, before the mercenary stepped forward. "Okay, look, Kronya was it? Do you have any proof about what you're talking about?" 

 

"Hm? Oh yeah totally, I keep it on me all the time." Kronya said, before reaching up under her top. Blushing, Lysithea looked away as the Agarthan pulled out a folded piece of paper. "Here we go! Professor Byleth gave this to me!" 

 

Unfolding it, she showed the two what was on it. 

 

"...A certificate of graduation?" 

 

"That does look like the professor's handwriting…"

 

"That's because it is! Now do you believe me?" 

 

"I'll at least extend you the benefit of the doubt," Lysithea muttered. "We still need to talk about what you're doing." 

 

"What I'm doing? These guys are the ones who attacked me!" 

 

"That's because people think you're a bandit," Leonie pointed out, getting Kronya to stare at her. 

 

"What? No I'm not, I'm a mercenary." 

 

"..." Lysithea felt a headache coming on as she sighed. "Look, we can talk about this later. Let's just make sure everyone here is okay, and check on the villages and towns to make sure none of them were hurt." 

 

"Of course they haven't been hurt, I've been protecting them!" 

 

Yeah, there was the headache. 

Chapter End Notes

Red: And here we go, the timeskip! Three years, rather than five! So kind of between Hopes and Houses.

Indi: That it is! So Byleth and Rhea probably won't be stuck in the void for five years. Maybe. We'll see.

Red: We shall! For now though, thanks for reading and hope y'all enjoyed!

Life Goes On

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

“Huh. So I need to set up a contract with a village ahead of time…or else I’m just extorting money from them,” Kronya repeated, nodding slowly as she absorbed Lysithea and Leonie’s explanation of why she was being regarded as a bandit.

 

“Yep. There’s a thin line between being a merc and being a bandit, and whether or not people agreed to pay you is that line,” Leonie helpfully explained.

 

“You could also avoid doing things like leaving severed heads out on spike ‘warnings’,” Lysithea pointed out, “Or, perhaps, not use people as furniture.”

 

“Hey, this bitch tried to kill me, I’m allowed to use her as a seat if I want,” Kronya countered while sitting on top of Captain Berling’s back, the mercenary currently struggling to remain on all fours instead of just collapsing to the ground, “And those were warnings for bandits! To keep them away from the villages I was protecting!”

 

"It doesn't really help if you leave them close enough to the villages that the villagers think you're threatening them," Leonie contradicted, recalling what some of the villagers had said. 

 

"For that matter, you really need to stop delivering bandit chief heads to the village elders' houses." 

 

"Then how are they supposed to know I dealt with the bandits?" Kronya asked, frowning. "Hey, Berling, that's what you do, right?" 

 

"...I mean, our clients do ask for proof, but–"

 

"See? She agrees with me." 

 

“I wasn’t–”

 

“Shut up, Berling,” Kronya ordered, before looking back at her former classmates, “So, what, am I in trouble for doing my job?”

 

"Well since you were being more of a bandit, yes." 

 

"Ugh. Where's Shez or the professor? They would agree with me," Kronya complained, getting the two former Deer to stiffen. 

 

"Shez? The Violet Demon?" Berling spoke up. 

 

"Yeah, you know her?" 

 

"Every merc worth their salt in the Alliance knows about her and her sister!" Berling exclaimed, before letting out a sigh. "I actually wanted to go against Jeralt’s mercenaries to prove how tough my group was, but well, after the demon and dragon went missing, it wouldn't be the same." 

 

“They’d probably kill you.”

 

“...I could beat them–”

 

“You couldn’t beat me,” Kronya stated quite bluntly.

 

“Yeah, well…it would be different.”

 

“Yeah, because they’d kill you.”

 

“You’re more likely to kill people than Professor Byleth is,” Lysithea pointed out.

 

“Well, actually…” Leonie scratched her head. “Byleth is pretty direct when it comes to people threatening her sister. And by that I mean the first time I met her, she cut off a guy’s head. Though she supposedly lets threats against her slide." 

 

"Yeah, Shez mentioned that–Wait, what's this about her and the professor missing?" Kronya frowned, looking down at Berling. “Did you have something to do with this?”

 

“What? No! I have no idea what happened!”

 

“...I have my eye on you.”

 

“You also have your ass on her,” Leonie pointed out.

 

"Yeah, it makes sure she doesn't move." 

 

"Moving on," Lysithea cut in, "Yes, Shez and the Professor are missing. They disappeared three years ago after the battle of Garreg Mach. No one is sure what happened." 

 

"And because of everything going on with Fodlan as a whole, we don't even know what's going on in the Empire or the Kingdom aside from both being caught in a civil war," Leonie further explained. 

 

"...Hm." Nodding, Kronya got up, grabbing Berling to pick her up. "Alright come on, we're going looking for Shez." 

 

"W-Wait, why am I going with you?" 

 

"Not just you, all your goons as well. You lost to me so that means you have to work for me now!" Kronya said, as if that explained everything. "So come on, let's go!" 

 

“Emily–Ah, Kronya, that’s kidnapping,” Leonie pointed out.

 

“So?”

 

“That’s also a crime.”

 

“...” Kronya narrowed her eyes. “...I’m allowed to loot them though, right?”

 

“You mean rob them?”

 

“They tried to kill me, I beat them, their stuff is my stuff.”

 

“Uh–”

 

“If I say yes, can we get going?” Lysithea asked, frowning in open annoyance.

 

“Yes, absolutely,” Kronya agreed without hesitation.

 

“Then yes, you can ‘loot’ them. Just be quick about it.”

 

Kronya grinned. “Oh don’t worry, I always am.”

“I don’t think you needed to strip them naked,” Leonie noted as she followed behind Kronya, who was riding on her ‘newly acquired’ horse, the saddlebags practically bursting with clothes and weapons.

 

“Course I did. Loot is loot. Besides, I can’t wear the same thing all the time,” the Agarthan replied, her cloak back on and her hood up as she led the way through the forest.

 

"You say that, but you didn't even change." 

 

"Well yeah. I'm not going to change out in the open, I'm not a perv." 

 

Lysithea felt like she needed to ignore half of everything she said. Letting out a sigh, she chose to study the Agarthan. It was hidden now thanks to her cloak, but the messy orange hair she had was long, reaching below her shoulders. And while she was still pale, she didn't look like a corpse, like the rest of her people. And, well, it was difficult to tell on horseback, but Lysithea was pretty sure she was the same height as Kronya now. 

 

“Sure, sure. So where’s this hideout of yours anyway?” Leonie asked, “And I think I should mention that having hideouts is also a bandit thing to do.”

 

“Oh really? You’ve never heard of a mercenary hideout?” Kronya retorted.

 

“No, because I don’t think those exist.”

 

“Well they do, so shut up. Anyway, it’s not far, just in these caves I found. Had to run some bears out, but I made it pretty homey afterward.”

 

“...Where’d the bears go afterward?”

 

“How should I know? Wherever bears go.”

 

Lysithea tried not to sigh, but Kronya made it very, very difficult. Especially given the fact that her hideout genuinely did look like a bandit’s lair, complete with trophies hanging on the walls, furs being used for bedding, and boxes and barrels filled with supplies placed haphazardly wherever Kronya found room to store them.

 

"...So this is where you live?" 

 

"Yeah, it's not much but I made it my home," Kronya said, quite proud of herself as she began to dump her new loot further in the cave. 

 

Lysithea remained silent, looking around the cave, before pausing as she saw a Garreg Mach uniform hanging against a wall as well. "...I'm surprised you kept that." 

 

"Hm? Well it's clothes, so I might as well,” the Agarthan replied while picking out a tunic from her gathered clothes and pulling it on over her leotard. People tended to stare when she went around with just it on. “Got no reason to throw it out." 

 

“So you’re not keeping it for sentimental reasons?” Leonie asked.

 

“The hell are those?”

 

“...yeah, alright, I should’ve expected that answer.”

 

"So…you've just been living here since you left Garreg Mach?" Lysithea asked. 

 

"Not entirely. It was a few months afterwards, I think. Had a few places before this, but this is a nice spot. Keeps me covered and keeps any rain and shit out." Kronya said, as she began to dig around in a box. "You guys want any fruit? Snagged some a few days ago while I was out." 

 

"I'm good." With a frown, Lysithea looked at the Agarthan. "So…was there ever an Emily?" 

 

Pausing before she could take a bite out of an apple, Kronya let out an annoyed sigh. "Yeah. She was grabbed a bit before the school year started. I didn't even know her name was Emily until I got to the academy." 

 

"...So you did kill her?" 

 

"Yeah. She was loud and annoying. Kept screaming at me every day until she died." Kronya frowned as she placed the apple back in the box. "But…there's probably someone that's sad she's gone now." 

 

“So you murdered a girl and took her place,” Lysithea reiterated, her arms crossed over her chest. Her hand clutched at her sleeve as she tried to keep her expression even. “Do you feel at all guilty?”

 

“...that’s a good question.” Kronya scratched her head, turning and sitting down on a barrel. “...I don’t think I can feel guilt. She wasn’t the first person I killed, and she wasn’t the last either. I’m…meant to kill. I was made for that purpose. And the people I killed on behalf of Shambhala…no matter who they were, my superiors didn’t want them dead for any good reason. I wasn’t a knight hunting down evildoers, I was an assassin sent to kill traitors and obstacles to us. And I enjoyed it. I still enjoy it. Getting to kill people. I can’t stop myself from enjoying it.

 

“...I want to, though. I…I wish I wasn’t like this anymore. I want to be able to do things because it's what I want, not just because of how they made me." 

 

“Hmph. I’m not a priest and redemption isn’t something I considered myself qualified to speak on,” Lysithea stated, meeting Kronya’s eyes, “As long as you’re on our side, I will consider you an ally.”

 

“Yeah, that works.” Kronya paused. “Are you gonna pay me?”

 

"Would you prefer looking for Shez and the professor on your own?" 

 

Kronya blinked, before a calculating look entered her eyes. “Ah, I get it. So just like all nobles, you expect me to work for free with just the honor of serving you to fill my belly. For shame, Lysithea, for shame.” She looked at her ‘fellow mercenary’. “You’re with me on this, right Leonie?”

 

“...Well, I am getting paid…" 

 

"...Of course you have favorites," Kronya grumbled as she frowned at Lysithea. 

 

“Ah, well, I’m not getting paid by her–”

 

“Don’t talk to me, scab.”

 

"How do you even know what that word means?" 

 

"I can read." Kronya huffed, reaching into a different box and pulling out a few books. "Unlike you guys, I continued my education." 

 

"...Goddess, how are you even more annoying?" Lysithea asked.

 

“Like I said, I continued my education. Unlike you.”

 

"Well, I mean, we are at war,” Leonie pointed out.

 

"Yeah, so what? I still had time to read, scab." 

 

"Stop calling me a scab!" 

 

"Stop being one!"

 

“Would you two knock it off?!” Lysithea demanded, “Kronya, are you willing to help us or not?”

 

“Of course I am! That should be obvious! I just want to be paid for any non-Shez related activities.”

 

“How would you even quantify that?” 

 

“If Shez isn’t involved, I’ll nag you until you pay me.”

 

“And what about when we find Shez?”

 

“Then I’ll be content. We can talk about any further jobs afterwards."

 

"Right, that sounds good enough," Lysithea said. "For now, we need to just continue checking on villages, then we can head back to Castle Gloucester.”

 

“Oh? Isn’t that Lorenz’s place?”

 

“Yup, he’s been supporting us in checking things out,” Leonie explained, “Since Ordelia’s still under the control of House Phlegethon–”

 

“Who?”

 

“Acheron’s house,” Lysithea explained, earning a blink from Kronya.

 

“He’s still alive?”

 

“No, he died at Garreg Mach, apparently. The current head claims to be his cousin or sister or something stupid, considering she’s never been seen before.”

 

“Huh. Weird. And they’re the people that took over your territory, right?”

 

“They are, yes,” Lysithea answered, plainly getting annoyed, and even Kronya wasn’t that oblivious.

 

“Hm…so do you have any plans to take back your castle?” She wasn’t oblivious, but she was still pretty thoughtless.

 

“Hmph. Count Gloucester and my family’s forces are handling that. I’m willing to aid if they ask for me, but maintaining order and protecting the people comes first.”

 

“Alright, that makes sense. And hey, there probably isn’t anyone left in the castle that isn't on Phlegie’s side. Anyone else would’ve been killed ages ago.”

 

“...” Lysithea sighed. “You didn’t need to mention that.”

 

“Yeah yeah, so what’s next? Are we going after any real bandits?”

 

“I just said what we’re–Ugh, never mind.”

 

Leonie chuckled. “Gotta say, it’s nice having you back, Emily. And wow does it feel weird saying that.”

 

“Hey, it’s been nice seeing you too…ah…”

 

“...Leonie.”

 

“I knew that."

The world had changed, and nothing would make it change back. Yet the war that consumed Fodlan hadn’t touched every part of the continent. For one lone village, hidden in the mountains, things remained largely at peace…aside from the presence of a lone girl who had returned to her first home.

 

Letting out a sigh as she pulled her arrow out of a deer she had just shot, Shez lifted up her kill onto her shoulder, the weight settling easily in her grasp. It wasn't much, but it would hopefully last her the month. Things had changed, but at least meat was still the same. 

 

She had changed especially. Her hair was different; cut shorter, though still messy, with her awakened form’s coloration permanently in shading her locks the color of a sunset. Well, she was pretty sure it was permanent since it wasn’t going away. She’d taken to wearing longer sleeves and pants too, to hide the white markings that decorated her body, and a red-orange scarf kept her safe from the cold…even if it did mean she was kind of hot after getting a workout.

 

Wiping the sweat off her forehead, the girl walked back up the trail to her home. She had to admit, she didn't think she would end up back here of all places when she first started wandering, but in another way, it made sense. This was the place she first ended up alone; it was fitting it was where she ended up when she was alone again. 

 

Her mother’s house hadn’t been maintained while she was gone. She didn’t think it would be, not when she was gone for years, but it was still sad coming back and seeing it falling apart. A good chunk of her time these past few months was spent fixing it all up, in between her big project. She wasn't really a carpenter, but she could at least patch up holes. 

 

A decent amount of that time was also spent yelling at the village head who kept trying to get her to leave, so that was fun at least. Still, she was able to get the place decent enough. The fireplace kept things warm, the roof kept the rain out, and she’d got a good amount of jerky stocked up–

 

“This is pathetic.”

 

And the only problem was the stupid piece of shit still in her head. “You’re pathetic, you vile bastard.”

 

“As you have stated previously, yet you are the one–”

 

“Shut the fuck up,” she responded. There wasn’t really any vehemence in her voice at this point, the response was basically automatic now.

 

“Would you listen–”

 

“We’ve gone over this, asshole. Leave me alone, I won’t berate you until you start crying.”

 

“I never–Ugh.” The sage let out a frustrated noise. "So you’re truly committed to this insane course of action!?”

 

“Yup. And you’re an idiot if you haven’t figured that out yet.” Walking away from the frustrated spirit, Shez got back to her house and started her work on preparing and cleaning the deer. It was an easy routine at this point, and soon enough she had a good store of venison to put away in her cold storage. And once she was done, she headed out again, to a quiet place nearby.

 

A mound of dirt that had flowers laid on top rested a few minutes away from her home. It had been a shallow hole, but she was happy it hadn't been disturbed while she was gone. Sitting down by it, she stayed silent for a few minutes. 

 

"...Hey, mom, how's it going? Sorry I haven't been visiting often. I’ve been busy down south, trying to figure things out. Patrol routes are a pain to map and those assholes keep way too many beasts around–Ah, sorry for cursing. I do that too much nowadays…I get frustrated easily.” She sighed. “...I think I’m almost there. I…I have to hope I am. I can’t…go back yet, not until…I’m going to get her back. I’m going to get my sister back. Even if…Even if I’m not sure if I deserve to call her my sister anymore.”

 

Shez brushed at her eyes, letting out a shaky breath. 

 

"You'd probably like her. She'd probably be a great daughter. Better than me, at least." 

 

She didn't hear anything back as she sat there in silence. She didn't know how long she sat there, but she eventually got up and went back home.

 

"I love you, mom," she murmured, before heading back inside. Her eyes drifted towards the swords she’d collected, hung up on the wall. Her Killing Edge was still good, but maybe she should bring along a couple extras…the Venin could be useful and she liked the Brave… Sometimes she wished she had four arms so she could use more than just two swords.

 

…maybe that was something she could practice? Not growing arms, but using four swords…three swords were certainly possible if she held one in her mouth. She’d need to practice anyways if she wanted to pull off this big, dumb plan of hers. 

 

But hey, it was the only plan she had.

 

So she went over to the chest she was keeping some of her stuff in, dug out her notes and the maps she’d acquired, and laid them all out on the table. 

 

“Alright…really wish I was better at reading maps…” Shez sighed, then smacked her cheeks and focused.

 

After all, she needed to put in a lot of work if she wanted to take Castle Ordelia.

Chapter End Notes

Red: Hey would you look at that? Shez is around now.

Indi: Woo Shez! Clearly everything will go okay now.

Red: Yup! The hero returns! And she's...mostly hanging out at home right now, but she's got plans!

Indi: Important plans! Which will be shown off next time we see her.

Red: Yup yup. We've gotta see how Shez wound up where she is, after all.

Indi: That we do, and we hope to see y'all next time to show that off!

The Wandering Asura

Chapter Notes

CW: So there's a brief attempt at self-harm and some suicidal thoughts in this chapter, specifically in its third section. Just a little heads up there for those who might not be comfortable with it.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Three Years Ago

Long, long ago, the Agarthan people worshipped the sun.

 

Shez grimaced, covering her eyes in an attempt to block out the bright, shining sun overhead. The treetops above her didn’t do much to cover it, the light shining through the leaves, and that just put her in a bad mood.

 

Granted, she was in one already because of…well, for a lot of reasons, really. Not being able to see her friends and family was a very good reason to be upset. Being stuck with the bastard who was the whole reason why she couldn’t see her friends or family was another good reason.

 

“What is your plan, exactly?”

 

Her lips twitched almost automatically into a snarl at the sound of that bastard ghost’s voice. She glared up at Epimenides, who floated above her, the prick.

 

“Why do you give a shit?”

 

“Because you are my vessel–“

 

“Fuck off! I don’t belong to you!” she snapped, her anger echoing through the forest.

 

“You were made for me.” His retort was blunt, his own annoyance obvious, “You were meant to be mine entirely. Just as your monstrous sister was meant to be a vessel for the abomination.”

 

“...” Shez took a slow, careful breath. “...you know, I never actually spoke to Sothis. All these months of her following my sister around and I didn’t even hear her voice until she came out to kick your ass.” She glanced up at Epimenides again, glaring at the wraith. “It’s gotta piss you off that she’s still better than you, huh?”

 

“You would not mock me if you knew what that creature had done,” he growled, glaring down at her, “It burned the entire world!”

 

“Oh, really.” Shez stood up, then made a show of looking around the forest. “Huh. Huuuuh. See, I’m not saying you’re a lying piece of shit, but the world doesn’t look burned to me.”

 

“You would think that…this, what you see around you?” He gestured to the forest, a sneer on his lips. “It is nothing. A false world crafted by that monstrosity-“

 

Shez smacked her hand against a tree. “Sure as fuck feels real to me, you lying sack of garbage.”

 

“I am not lying! I–“

 

“Hey, Epi? Do me a favor and die. I’m gonna figure out where I am.” And with that, Shez began moving through the forest, ignoring the seething spirit. She knew she wasn’t the best with directions, but if she just kept moving, she was bound to find something, right?

 

Eventually she did, as she stepped out of a forest and found a watchtower, which usually meant there was a town or something nearby. Feeling her stomach growl, she looked around to see if she could find any sign of life. Mostly to get some food. 

 

Her heart stopped as she saw a familiar village in the distance, a place she hadn’t seen since everything in her life changed. “Ah.”

 

That was Remire Village. It looked the same as it did at the beginning of the year…and that put into a strange perspective just how long it had been since Shez and her family were just a band of traveling mercenaries.

 

“...huh. That’s a strange sense of nostalgia…” Shez took a slow breath, staring at the town. She could feel tears prick at her eyes before she wiped them away with her arm, trying to keep steady. “Gotta say, I’m glad they’re doing okay…”

 

Epimenides glowered behind her, still irritated. Perhaps that was why his first instinct was to scoff. “Ah yes, bask in the glory that is some backwoods settlement scraping by. This place could burn to the ground and the world would never notice.”

 

Shez paused mid-step, staring at the village for a second before glaring back at Epimenides. “Don’t fucking touch them!”

 

“...and why not? I told you before what my intent was if you chose to galavant with beasts.”

 

Shez’s eyes went wide, then narrowed in a furious glare. “You piece of shit–Fine. Guess I’m not getting breakfast then. Hope you feel every damn hunger pang…”

 

“You petulant child–”

 

“You piece of shit,” Shez retorted, glaring straight at the wraith. Then she shook her head and moved back to where she’d first wound up, looking around for– “Ah, there we go.”

 

Epimenides watched his vessel with a frown as she crouched down and pulled a familiar sword from the dirt. “The Fell Star’s spine…and what do you plan to do with that?”

 

“Hide it. It’s pretty heavy, so I don’t think it’s a great idea to lug it around with me. That, and I don't want assholes like you to get a hold of it.” She ignored Epi’s angry response in favor of hoisting the sword into her arms with a small huff. “Eesh, Sothis must’ve been a big girl…well, at least her relic doesn’t turn people into monsters. Now let’s see, where should you go…”

 

It took some traveling before Shez found what she considered an appropriate spot.

 

“Did you really need to scale a mountain?” Epi complained.

 

“First off, fuck off. Second off, you make it sound like I climbed all the way instead of warping. Third off, it’s not exactly easy to get up here, now is it?” Shez pointed out, gesturing to the landscape far below her, “Oh and fourth off, fuck you.”

 

With her point made, Shez turned back to the mountain’s peak and pulled the Sword of the Creator up. Her muscles strained for a moment at how heavy it was, before she jammed it into the rock, shoving it forcefully into the mountaintop. It pierced through the stone, and when she let go, it stood straight and tall at the top of the world.

 

“There. There…” Shez stared at the sword for a moment, then took a small, shaky breath to steady herself. “…I’m sorry, Byleth. I’m so sorry.”

 

There was no response. Just a cold breeze.

There were other gods, of wind and water, of storms and land, and yet the Sun was held sacred above all else, for it gave life to the world.

 

Shez watched the crackling campfire dance in front of her. It’d been a long time since she was this alone. But what else was she supposed to do? Epimenides made it clear what would happen if she tried heading for any village or town, so how was she supposed–

 

“Hello there!”

 

She stiffened, her eyes widening at the voice that rang out through the woods. She’d stuck to the deeper parts of the forest for the past weeks, away from the main roads, so why was there some random guy out here? “Uh…hi?”

 

The guy, a partially bearded man with thick sideburns and a bowl cut, seemed friendly enough as he walked over, smiling. “What’s a young lady like you doing out in the woods so late at night?”

 

“...sitting. Eating.” Shez resisted the urge to glance around. She didn’t want to somehow bring out Epimenides by looking for him. “I, uh…I’m traveling at the moment.”

 

“All alone? You should be more careful, there’s a war on these days,” he said while walking over, before pausing, “Oh, where are my manners? I’m Pallardo, a merchant traveling with my caravan.”

 

“A merchant?” Yeah, she could kinda see that, he did look merchant-y… “Oh, wait, I know you! You were at Garreg Mach, right?”

 

“Oh, yes, I was! Ah, you were a student there, weren’t you? I remember seeing you around.”

 

“Yep, I was. Name’s Shez.”

 

He blinked, a look of surprise crossing his face. “You’re Captain Jeralt’s daughter! Ah, of course, that makes sense. You must be out here on a mission then.”

 

“Ah…no, not really. We kinda got separated after the whole…monastery attack.”

 

“Ah, that’s a shame. I’m sure your father must be worried about you.”

 

“...yeah, he…probably is,” she admitted, feeling a pang in her heart at the thought of her dad. But she couldn’t go find him. Aside from the Epimenides problem, it was because of her that Byleth…vanished.

 

“Then he’d probably pay a great deal to get you back.”

 

“Yeah, I guess–...ah. Shit,” Shez muttered, immediately becoming aware of the group of guys surrounding her camp. She sighed, setting down the half eaten fish she had caught. "Don't do this." 

 

"Sorry to say, but no can do. I have my men to feed, and I'm never one to turn down such a tidy profit," Pallardo said, before smirking. "Especially since I've heard a certain captain is now a general in the Empire. So good news for you, I'm sure daddy dearest will be able to pay your ransom easily enough." 

 

“I thought you said you’re a merchant?”

 

“Oh I am. I just need to look for other forms of income these days. This war is hard on everyone.”

 

“...hm. I’m pretty sure the war has only been going on for a few weeks.”

 

“Ha. You’ve been out here for a while, huh? It’s been more like two months since the whole continent decided everyone should start fighting each other.”

 

“Oh. That’s…” Shez sighed, before starting to push herself up, which got a number of spears and arrows pointed at her.

 

“Why don’t you stay right there?” Pallardo suggested, “We’ll let you up once you toss aside your weapons–”

 

Then Shez was right behind him, her sword at his throat. “No, I don’t think so. None of you guys move, or I’ll–”

 

Then her head felt hot. Everything felt hot. Then it was dark and she…she had to…

 

No, this isn’t right. The thought echoed in her mind, a rush that went through her body and she pushed back to awareness, forcing her consciousness back–

 

And she stumbled, gasping, panting, trying to breathe. She nearly retched, her body trembling from the sudden rush of having to get control of herself…and she was covered in blood.

 

“...a-ah…aaAAAH!” 

 

Her scream echoed through the woods, blood dripping from her hands, her arms–She buried her head in her hands, trying to calm down, trying to–

 

“This is what you want? To cavort with self-centered beasts like these vermin?” Epimenides spoke directly into her ear, his voice low. 

 

"Sh-Shut up," Shez ordered, trying to calm herself down, as she refused to look up. She didn't care about the bandits but…gagging as she felt some bile rise up, Shez did her best to choke it down. 

 

"Hmph, is a little blood all it takes now? I seem to remember someone reveling in killing more than the Fell Star," Epimenides remarked, getting Shez to stiffen, “Do you truly–”
