“I’m sick because YOU STOLE MY FUCKING BODY!” she snapped, glaring straight at Epimenides, “You piece of shit. You–I’m going to end you! ”

 

“Hmph. An empty–”

 

“SHUT UP! SHUT YOUR FUCKING MOUTH! I’m going to kill you! I don’t care how I do it, I don’t care how long it takes, I AM GOING TO GOUGE YOUR EYES OUT AND TEAR YOUR HEAD OFF WITH MY BARE HANDS!”

 

“...your threats are empty. You cannot harm me in any way that matters.”

 

“Tell yourself that. I’m gonna find a way to hurt you. And I’m not gonna stop until you die.”

 

Epimenides scowled down at his blood-soaked vessel, ignoring the strange chill that went down his spine at the sheer hatred his former partner regarded him with.

Yet one day, a new god appeared. A goddess of alabaster flames and emerald light descended from the heavens, garbed in the clothes of royalty. And with her, came blessings inconceivable.

 

Scowling, Shez flashed forward, her blade carving into a demonic beast’s hide, making it screech in pain. It was difficult, getting used to only wielding one sword at a time again, but she didn't have much of a choice. Not only was she staying away from towns, any bandits she fought against had horribly kept iron swords that would likely snap after a battle or two. 

 

Jumping up to dodge a tail swipe, Shez raised her free hand up, sending a volley of Dark Spikes into the monster's wound, making it scream again, before it collapsed to the ground 

 

Breathing heavily, Shez wiped the sweat on her forehead as she tried to catch her breath. Glancing down at her Killing Edge, she grimaced when she saw it had begun to chip. “Damn it…”

 

“My, would you look at that? Your sword is beginning to break. If only you had one that would never–”

 

“Fuck off, Epi,” Shez muttered, before glancing at the beast’s corpse. “...right, I know these things can have those weird metals in them…or on them. I don’t actually know where Byleth got those bits and I don’t know what to do with them anyway so I have no idea what I’m even trying to do here…fuck.

 

She let out a frustrated sigh. “...maybe I should just grab those crappy iron swords and stock up on them? Just toss them away when they break…”

 

“You are a true fool–”

 

“I’m not using your sword, asshole. Not when I’m pretty damn sure you’d use it against me.”

 

“I have no reason to kill you, vessel. I require your body to exist in this world, remember?”

 

“Yeah, I know, and it makes me think bad thoughts about myself, so kindly shut the hell up already!” She sighed again, trying to think of something. “...maybe I can go after those Kingdom assholes? Or maybe find some Agarthans…or just better equipped bandits.”

 

Shez crossed her arms over her chest, her brow furrowed as she tried to think…before she paused as a shout rang out.

 

“Damn it all, the beast is down!”

 

“Oh, great.” Shez sighed, turning towards the sound and watching as a group of soldiers came down from the nearby hill. Most of them were wearing black armor and…orange tabards. Which, huh. Black armor usually means Empire, but they wear red, not orange…weird. “Uh, hi?”

 

The soldiers paused, looking amongst each other, before one of them stepped forward. A brown-haired guy with weird pauldrons, which probably meant he was the boss of these guys. “You there! What do you think you’re doing with a beast of the principality, huh?”

 

“...uh…well I killed it.” Something about this guy’s voice sounded familiar.

 

“You expect me to believe that one woman managed to slay a demonic beast? Ha! You don’t look like anything special to me!”

 

“...sure.” That voice sounded really familiar. “So who are you guys supposed to be? A mercenary band?”

 

“Ha ha ha! So not only are you stupid enough to lie to us, but you’re ignorant too! You’re addressing an officer of the Principality of Hrym, the new nation that has risen from the ashes of Adrestia!” The man smirked, his expression callous and filled with malice as his men cheered his proclamation. “Now then, considering you’re claiming to have destroyed principalian property, that means you owe us a debt, and I can think of–”

 

Shez snapped her fingers. “You’re that fucker that kidnapped Byleth! During the Aelfric thing!”

 

Metodey paused. Then he took a second look at the purple-haired woman who claimed to have killed a demonic beast single-handedly. Then he really looked, staring straight at her while sweat began to bead down his forehead.

 

“...uh, Sir Metodey?” one of the Hrym knights spoke up, “Are you feeling–”

 

And Metodey promptly bolted in the other direction.

 

“...” The knights watched their leader scrambling to get away, then turned to look at Shez, who was grinning. 

 

“You know, I was just thinking I needed to get some new equipment. Any of you got a Killing Edge?”

 

The knights glanced at one another, before raising their weapons as they got ready to fight. 

 

Approximately ten minutes later Shez was standing over Metodey, twisting his arm as the former mercenary screamed. "You know, I'm surprised your arm still works after how badly it got broken. Or well, worked anyways." 

 

“AHHHH, STOP, STOP, I’M SORRY!”

 

“Hmm…so how many people have you killed since joining up with this princely thing?”

 

“Gh–I-I’m just following–GYAH!”

 

“Oh, dang, that actually tore there. Wow. I actually kinda feel bad about that, uh…” She let his arm drop and gave him a pat on his dislocated shoulder. “Sorry. Oh, though, real quick, what’s that princely thing anyway? Also, you said ‘principalian’ earlier? Is that the actual word, or what? I know if a duke runs something, it’s ‘ducal’, so is it ‘principal’? Or is it ‘princal’? Or does princely work?”

 

Metodey made a faint keening noise.

 

“Hey, come on, you’re the first real person I’ve talked to since…I mean, do I want to count bandits? I’ve said things to bandits a few times but we’re not really talking so much as I’m saying things while destroying them.” Shez paused, then poked him. “You good down there?”

 

“No…” Metodey weakly murmured.

 

“Hm, right. Well, I’m going to take your stuff. You actually have some pretty nice swords and that’s good for me because it means I don’t have to use my fancy sword that just so happens to belong to a piece of shit who is so completely shit and worthless that I don’t want anything that’s associated with him.”

 

“So you say.” Shez stiffened at the cold tone of Epimenides’s voice. “Yet you rely on my power all the same. You travel through the shadows I wield. It is my magic that ensures your survival. Yet you would cast that aside? I do not believe that for a moment, ingrate.”

 

“…” She took a breath, then got up from Metodey’s back, trying to–

 

“You would leave vermin like him alive? You truly have–“

 

She warped away, trying to ignore his voice, his mocking tone–

 

“Pointless. You cannot hold to your decisions for even a moment–“

 

“Fuck off. They’re my powers, not yours–“

 

“They are mine. You would have nothing if not for me–“

 

“I HAVE NOTHING BECAUSE OF YOU!” Shez screamed, her rage a near physical thing as darkness emanated from her body.

 

“You are nothing without me. You would have been thrown away ages ago were it not for my power.”

 

“I know that’s not true!”

 

“You know it is. The Fell Star would have outpaced you without my aid. You would have been left behind, the little sister clinging to her coat, desperate to catch up but never making it.” His tone was cold, stoic, as though everything he said was fact. “You reveled in the power I gave you. Finally, you were special. You were better than her. You were stronger, more powerful, you were the one that protected her.

 

“You think I do not know? You think I cannot feel your thoughts, your emotions? I know your triumph and your resentment. I know you could not stand that she saw you as a child to be protected, that she would put herself in danger to keep you safe. You were useless again, unworthy of her love and crushed under her condescension.” His gaze pressed down on her, gleaming with light. “Lie to yourself all you like, for you cannot lie to me. You hated her.”

 

“...” Shez stared up at him, tears running down her face. Then her sword formed in her hand, and in one swift motion, she twisted it around and rammed the white blade straight into–

 

It stopped, inches from her neck, as her arm locked in place, though not without twitching and straining. 

 

“Do you think I would allow you to–”

 

“I think you’re a piece of shit. I think you’re a lying bastard. I think I might’ve been upset, yeah, because I’m stupid. I love my sister. I hate you. And I figured something out.” She bared her teeth, tears staining a maddened smile. “You need me alive. Not that hard to figure out, we’ve talked about it before, but like I said, I’m stupid. It just didn’t click for me that you need me to live. And I sure as hell don’t feel like living right now.

 

“So here’s how it’s going to go. You can try to fill my head with all kinds of bullshit. You can say I hated my sister or my dad or my mom or whoever else I know for a fact I love with all my heart, and I’ll tell you I fucking hate you.” She giggled, her grin a rictus. “Yeah, see, I remember what that fucker back at the monastery said. If I know one thing, it’s that we Agarthans are spiteful pieces of shit, and you’re the worst of them all because you’re dumb enough to think it means the rest of those assholes would like you.

 

“Yeah, you remember that, right?! The moment they heard you were back, THEY TRIED TO KILL YOU! Because you can go on and on about my stupid thoughts and feelings that I had when I was being a dumbass, but we both know no one in this world loves you. No one wants you around. And I’m going to remind you of that every single day. You don’t want me to have peace? You don’t want me to have friends or family? THEN I’LL DO THE SAME THING TO YOU, YOU PIECE OF SHIT!”

 

Shez laughed, a cruel, maddened sound as she glared straight at the parasite hooked into her soul. “You might be tied to me, but I’m tied to you too, asshole. And I’m going to make every moment you’re with me hurt .”

Bolstered by the new god, the civilizations of Agartha grew to untold heights. Yet they felt no gratitude. The Fell Star was not the Sun.

 

The new paradigm did not suit Epimenides. His vessel, once happy to call him partner, loathed him with all her heart. He had thought that acceptable, a sacrifice made for the good of the world. 

 

One day, she would understand.

 

He thought to wear her down. To make it clear her purpose, her role. He would sever those foolish bonds she clung to and make her his true vessel. A perfect existence through which they would fix a warped world.

 

Yet she hated him all the more.

 

He thought to mock her reliance on his power. He thought to make it clear she needed him. And then she began to use his sword. She began to use his magic. She began to Awaken.

 

She used his power.

 

In the recesses of his mind, he could admit to being impressed by his vessel’s change in demeanor. The cold focus with which she began to work. If only she did not respond to his every comment, his every suggestion, his every criticism with vehement vitriol.

 

At one point she stopped screaming obscenities and simply yelled at the top of her lungs anytime he spoke up. 

 

So, he decided to look upon her in silence as she acted, fighting a group of kingdom soldiers who she had stumbled upon. She cut through them with an efficiency he had never seen of her before, not wasting any of her movements as she cut down anyone before her. 

 

A scowl appeared on his face as a knight managed to gut her with a spear, only for his head to go flying as he pulled back. Even as her body healed with his magic, he knew she could have dodged that. Yet she didn't, because she knew Epimenides needed her more than she needed him. 

 

It was infuriating. The gall she had to claim he was useless to her while wielding his power, while wearing his marks upon her body, while shining like a rising Sun…

 

She didn’t need him. She needed his power. And he could feel how she pulled on it. How her fury and hate drew in the darkness and wreathed her body in light. She was taking from him.

 

Her power was inherited. It was his by right. He had worked to rival a god and she took it from him with every furious breath.

 

Something had to be done.

The Agarthan people sang songs of war and told legends of great battles. Their drive in battle was to prove their superiority. It was only natural the city-states of Agartha would one day turn their blades away from their rival humans, and instead towards the god in their midst.

 

Despite her efficiency in dealing with threats, there was no purpose Epimenides could see behind Shez’s actions. She struck at bandits, knights of the Kingdom, and soldiers of the Principality specifically, so her slaughter was not indiscriminate. 

 

In fact, she was often very particular and focused, keeping watch on a specific group for some days or even weeks, scouting their strengths, weaknesses, and purpose, before moving in to destroy them utterly and raiding what supplies they had. She showed no mercy to those she had chosen to target, and more than once he had watched as she pierced a fleeing soldier through the back. Otherwise, she spent her time keeping on the move, sticking to the wilds of Fodlan and avoiding any settlements.

 

Sometimes, she would simply warp away, vanishing through the dark and arriving in a random place, seemingly just to test her limits. She wouldn’t answer any questions he had, though once, when she traveled to the mountains called Fodlan’s Throat, she stared out into the distance, towards the lands called Almyra.

 

“...” She sat down and stared for a stretch of time, taking in the distant prairies and desert. “...their castles look different.”

 

“Of c–”

 

“Shut the fuck up.” She continued to stare, then let out a slow sigh. “...Someday, I’m gonna go over there. Not sure what I’ll find when I do, but I’m gonna.”

 

“You would abandon–”

 

“Fuck off.” Then she pushed herself up, and started to travel again, returning back through the Kingdom and slaughtering a squad of Tempest Knights along the way. 

 

There was no delight in her actions, just a cold rage. She wasted no time, every strike was meant to kill or cripple, and the latter was only so she could finish them as quickly as possible before she returned to her travels.

 

He wondered what she was looking for, but he knew better than to ask. He wondered if she even knew what she wanted. 

 

One day, he saw the first moment of vulnerability he had seen in months. Traveling though the Kingdom, Shez had bundled herself up, keeping quiet as she did her best to ignore the cold. She was low on supplies, so she didn't want to risk a fire which might attack unwanted attention. 

 

So when the voices drifted close, she couldn't help but stiffen at who spoke. 

 

"...on Dimitri, you have…isn't that right?" She heard Sylvain, his tone still jovial despite it all. 

 

"Shut up!" Ingrid retorted, chiding her friend. “...can’t just suggest–”

 

“...just teasing…”

 

“...” Shez took a slow, shaky breath. Epimenides watched as she plainly considered going over to her former classmates. It would be her first positive human contact in a long time.

 

That was why Epimenides floated closer, speaking softly. “I will not impede you.”

 

“…”

 

“You wish to go to your friends, do you not? I swear, I shall stay out of your way. I shall not harm them.” It was a necessary kindness if he wanted his vessel to finally stop resisting him.

 

Then she warped away, and Epimenides paused at realizing they were now in a field far from the forest Shez had hidden in. “What–Why would you do that?! You had a chance to reunite–“

 

“Why would you want me to reunite with my friends?” she asked, glaring up at him.

 

“I wasn’t–I swore to you that I wouldn’t–“

 

“I. Don’t. Trust. You.” Each word was blunt and forceful, genuine anger on her face. “You lied to me for months at least ! You are not my friend, you’re just the piece of shit I need to tolerate until I can get rid of it. Because I am telling the truth when I say I’m going to fucking kill you.”

 

“Do you truly wish to test me? Because I can–” 

 

In a moment, Shez shifted to her awakened form and glared up at the spirit, her arms spread wide. “Then do it.” 

 

“...What do you think you are doing?”

 

“I’m testing your bullshit. Control me. Do it.”

 

The sage’s eyes narrowed. “Do not test me, vessel. The instant I seize control, I shall go back and slaughter those friends of–”

 

“Do it. Do it, you piece of shit. Take control of me again. Rob me of my body, ruin my life…do whatever the fuck you can think of.” Her violet eyes burned orange as they locked with his. “You’ve had two years. You can’t tell me you didn’t have anything you wanted to do.”

 

“...Hmph. My greatest foe is slain. I have no reason–”

 

“Then why are you still here? Why? You got what you wanted, right? Except, not really. There aren’t any parades for Epimenides. You went right in front of ‘our’ people and they wanted to kill us. They didn’t give a shit. And none of them came looking for us.” She let her arms drop. “None of them care about you. They only wanted the power you had.”

 

“As though you care. You intend to see my name lost–”

 

“Your name was already lost. Nobody nowadays knows who ‘Epimenides the sage’ is. And why would they? You’re just some guy that died ages ago. You never did anything important, and the world doesn’t know who you are.”

 

“I am responsible for–!”

 

“Yeah yeah, you invented magic and mutilated corpses, wow, so special.” She rolled her eyes, making him scowl. “Nobody knows what you did. Other people took credit for the stuff you did and it doesn’t matter that you ‘won’. Nobody even knew Byleth had the goddess in her. All you did was hurt my sister. And I’m never going to forgive you for that.”

 

“...I do not want your forgiveness,” the sage muttered, his voice bitter as he looked away from his vessel.

 

“Then get on with it. Possess me.”

 

Epimenides scowled, turning back to his vessel. “Why do you desire such a thing from me? You claim I robbed you of your body–”

 

“Don’t say that,” Shez ordered, anger audible in her voice, “Don’t say ‘claimed’ when you know what you did. You want to talk about how bad you have it? You stole my fucking body and used me to hurt the people I care about!”

 

“I did not!” Epimenides retorted, “I stayed my hand! I did not strike down any of your friends! All I did was state the truth to them–”

 

“FUCK YOU! You just said whatever would hurt and confuse people the most!”

 

“I told the truth! That they live in a world based on lies is no fault of mine–”

 

“Bullshit! You can’t say you made the relics and then act like you’re not responsible for how things turned out! You don’t get to say that!”

 

He grimaced. “You said it yourself, my name is lost to history. Others took credit for my achievements. Therefore, by your rationale, I am absolved.”

 

“...ha. You’re a fucking monster.”

 

He’d heard it from her before. Yet this time…he let the pain fade. The word meant nothing to him. “I am an ordinary man who took a stand against the beast that destroyed the world. Nothing more.”

 

And Shez laughed. “You really wish that was true, huh? You really want to be a hero. The regular guy with a fancy sword in hand that took a stand against an evil dragon and saved the day. But you’re not. The world went on without you." 

 

"...I was a doctor." 

 

Shez raised an eyebrow. She didn’t say a thing to him.

 

"The lands of Agartha were wealthy, and prosperous," Epimenides continued, "Even if the Fell Star gave us the tools to do so, we were the ones who made ourselves great. Everything we achieved was because of our own hands." 

 

No response. Just more staring.

 

"There were those who wanted more. Rallied under Thales and those like him, they rose up against her, wanting to take what they thought they deserved. I had nothing to do with that conflict. I was simply a doctor, tending to those in need far from the war. At the time, I prayed that everyone would remain safe. The Fell Star did not care. Even though we had nothing to do with the conflict, we were punished." 

 

“...You’re so full of shit.”

 

Epimenides stiffened, then glared at her. “I am not–”

 

“I don’t know if you noticed, but I have dreams about your life, asshole. All I’ve ever seen is you being a smug piece of shit as you try to kill Seiros and her saints. I don’t see ‘Epimenides the doctor’ or whatever the fuck you think you can say that’ll make me sympathize with you.”

 

“Why would I lie?!”

 

She scoffed. “Don’t give me that. You’d lie to make yourself look better and Sothis worse. The only reason you’re telling me anything now is because you want to convince me you were right all along. For all I know, you led the charge and Thales was the poor, simple doctor who didn’t want anything to do with what happened.”

 

Epimenides grimaced. “If nothing else, Shez, I implore you to believe that Thales was not a mere civilian caught up in a fight he did not want. The man was a, ugh, senator .”

 

“...Yeah, I don’t know what that is.”

 

“Think of a noble but with the pretense of being chosen by the people.”

 

“Uh…so like a mayor?”

 

“Infinitely worse than that, but it is an adequate comparison for your point of reference.”

 

“Hm…Yeah, well…what about all that stuff you said in the fight? About how you’re the ‘guardian of the world’?”

 

“The Agarthan people are the guardians of this world. We maintained the cycle of…” He sighed, his usual haughty loftiness fading. “...yet the world continued without us. The world did not wait for my return, the land had changed. And here I am, stuck to a fool who thinks eating toxic mushrooms will make her stronger." 

 

“Go fuck yourself.”

 

Epimenides paused, not expecting the sheer venom in his vessel’s voice. “...I intended that as a joke–”

 

“Yeah? And what the hell gives you the right to joke with me?” she asked, the anger in her voice returning, “We’re not friends. You’re the asshole who pretended to be my friend. You want to make things right? Go away. Give back Arval then do everyone else a favor and die, for real this time.”

 

"I am Arval–" 

 

"No, you're not. Arval was a dick sometimes, but they were still my friend! They cared about me and Byleth! They're the one who pushed me to talk to Byleth after she almost died against Catherine!!" She glared straight at Epimenides. “So I don’t care who you are, Epi . To me, you’re just the prick that pretended to be my friend. That’s all you’re ever going to be.”

 

“...One day, you will under–”

 

“I won’t. You could tell me every detail of your life and I’m not going to understand why you decided to lie to me in the first place. I’m not going to understand you, I’m not going to like you, and I’m not going to forgive you. That should be obvious at this point.”

 

Epimenides stared back at her, before looking away first. Words failed him as he wilted under her glare, a throbbing in the back of his head. 

 

"I'm sorry, partner," a voice not unlike his own said, one far softer than the Agarthan man ever spoke with. 

 

“What?” Shez stared up at the spirit, her eyes going wide while Epimendies went rigid. “What was that?”

 

"Nothing! It was nothing!" Epimenides shouted, trying to ignore the odd sensation in his body. 

 

"...Haha, Arval really is still alive in you, huh?" Shez murmured, her voice low, rubbing away the tears in her eyes. "Guess that's just someone else I have to save from you."

 

“...You…You are a fool. And I will stop you from ruining…” He closed his eyes and shook his head. “Speaking to you is pointless.”

 

“Right back at you, Epi.” Shez pushed herself up, brushing some dirt from her clothes. “Just know, I’m waiting for the next time you try to take my body from me. I know I can push you out. And when I do…you’re going to know you can’t ever do that to me again.”

 

Epimenides didn’t have a response to that. All he could do was watch, quietly, as his vessel began a new trek towards the distant horizon. Not once did she spare a look back at him.

It was by mortal hands that the world burned, scorched and sundered by the monstrous weapons of war they brought to bear. And it was by divine hands that their flames were smothered, the pillars of light that consumed their nations washed away beneath a deluge of divine recompense.

 

Yet the antediluvian Agarthans felt naught but contempt for the victor in their war. Spite drove them beneath the earth, determined to live away from the light brought by the divine star. 

 

And so, they abandoned their Sun…and gladly dwelt in Darkness.

 

Shez shined like sunlight. Even when she didn’t call on the power within her, the top of her hair burned a mix of red and orange that bled into trails of pink and purple, akin to a twilight sky. Her eyes would oscillate between orange and purple, often shifting with her mood, and she wielded the blade of Epimenides without reservation as she continued her bloody work.

 

Thus a Demon became an Asura, her blades now stained with the blood of over a thousand souls.

 

It almost made the wraith that followed her proud.

 

“…hey, Epi.”

 

Epimenides paused, almost going stiff on reflex, before he looked down at his vessel, who was reading a journal claimed from one of her recent victims. She sat near the fort’s fireplace, reading by lantern light while the bloodied bodies of the soldiers that once occupied it cooled on the floor around her, the commander still impaled on their dining table by Shez’s Killing Edge, its blade stained a permanent crimson with the amount of lives it had taken. “…yes? What is it?”

 

“What’s our home city called again? The place I was born in.”

 

He blinked, genuinely surprised by the question. “…Shambhala. Our home is called Shambhala. It is where the majority of our people fled to survive the Fell Star’s retribution.”

 

“Sure, okay. It’s in Hrym, isn’t it?”

 

“…what?”

 

“It’s in Hrym. The old territory, not the new nation. It’s gotta be.” There was a glint in her eye. Some sort of malicious drive. “It’s the only place that makes sense. It’s why they’re so invested in it, why they went after Ordelia…why I grew up in Ordelia. It was the closest place my mom could hide without risking everything.

 

She chuckled. “That’s gotta be it…”

 

“…and what do you intend to do with that information?” Epimenides asked, frowning.

 

“You don’t get to know that.” She sighed. “…it’s my best bet. I go there first, then…the new Archbishop, that Cornelia lady, she’s one of us too, huh? And I bet there’s another one pressing things in Almyra, putting them on the attack…alright. Alright. I know what I’m doing.

 

Shez stood, nodding to herself. “First thing’s first, I get Byleth back.”

 

“Do you truly think the Fell Star still lives?” Epimenides questioned, his mind starting to race. If she was aiming to figure out where the Agarthan people were located and intending to enter Zahras…she had seen him cast the spell. Could she be–

 

“Course I do. I know she’s alive. She has to be.” Shez took a breath, then grinned. “Hell, she has Rhea with her, doesn’t she? So odds are, those two are probably surviving together and getting along just fine!”

The screech of the Immaculate One echoed out through the void, before a roar of blue flame bathed a massive swathe of the rock floating in the darkness, illuminating the emptiness around them for a scant moment. Then Byleth punched the dragon in the face, snapping her jaw shut with a vicious uppercut.

 

The Immaculate One snarled, lunging for the smaller woman, whose eyes glowed in the darkness. Her jaws snapped shut around empty air, the shadows in the void twisting and shifting with an emerald sheen as Byleth bent time in a space where it did not exist.

 

The dragon paused, eyes searching the void as a low growl emanated from her throat–Then she felt a weight on her head and had about a second to react before Byleth punched her in the eye.

 

“GYAAAH!” Her scream echoed loudly through the darkness, her heavy body stumbling as she shook her head, trying to buck off the young woman gripping onto her horns. She roared in pain and fury before flapping her wings, taking off into the black sky overhead.

 

Byleth tightened her grip on the Immaculate One’s horns, clinging on for dear life as the dragon soared through the void, flying fast through everlasting darkness. She tried to retaliate, to start punching at the top of Rhea’s far too hard head, but her blows did nothing but annoy the enormous dragon, who promptly twisted in the air, spinning in an attempt to dislodge the pest grasping onto–

 

And then she slammed straight into a rock she didn’t see floating in the void. Dust and stone flew out from the point of impact, before Rhea began to fall, prompting a triumphant shout from Byleth…right before she realized the dragon’s current position meant that she was actually going to land on top of Byleth when she crashed.

 

“Ah–No no no no–”

 

Alas, the void was not willing to bend to Byleth’s attempt to turn back time, and thus she and Rhea smashed heavily into the stone below, sending up a plume of dust into the uncaring darkness.

 

A time later, both Nabateans managed to regain consciousness, whereupon a now much more human-looking Rhea immediately whirled on her younger counterpart.

 

“YOU PUNCHED ME IN THE EYE!”

 

“YOU TRIED TO BITE ME!”

 

“THAT WAS INSTINCTUAL! YOU WERE THE ONE WHO HIT ME IN THE FACE IN THE FIRST PLACE!”

 

“YOUR TORE MY LEGGINGS!”

 

“IT WAS AN ACCIDENT!”

 

“I CARE A LOT ABOUT THOSE LEGGINGS! I BOUGHT THEM MYSELF!”

 

“THAT–Wait, really? How? Those look remarkably fancy for something you purchased on a mercenary salary.”

 

“I made more money working as a mercenary than I did working for you!” Byleth snapped, "And Candace helped me talk Anna down to a cheaper price." 

 

"Oh…really? That's actually rather impressive. I haven't had any personal dealing with any Anna for generations, but I understand how her family is." 

 

"Wait, you do?" 

 

"Well yes, her ancestor Ernest was a Nabatean." 

 

“...” Byleth’s eyes narrowed, skepticism radiating from her gaze. “What.”

 

“What?”

 

“There was a Nabatean…named Ernest. Really?”

 

“Well that was his human name, not his Nabatean name. His Nabatean name was the Avaricious One.”

 

“...” Byleth opened her mouth. She thought for a few seconds. She sighed. “That makes more sense than I want it to.”

 

"Good. Now, will you be apologizing?" 

 

"..." Byleth took in a deep breath, before tackling Rhea.

 “And I don’t want to hear any shit to the contrary!” Shez stated, pointing straight at Epimenides, “I’m going to get my sister back, I’m going to fix Fodlan, and I’m going to kill every single asshole that gets in my way, you included!”

 

“...You’ve lost your mind.”

 

Shez laughed. There wasn’t much humor in it. “If I have, you know whose fault it is. Now if you’ll excuse me, I’m going home.”

 

“You’re going to do what–”

 

And in an instant, Shez vanished back into the dark, ready to put her plan into action.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Shez has not has a good three years.

Red: It was honestly funny seeing people reacting to the last chapter with "huh, I guess Shez didn't go insane". Yeah, no, things have been bad for her.

Indi: Yeaaaaah. She hasn't completely lost it. But also she has.

Red: Shez just got really focused and very goals oriented, has no time for sadistic madness because that gets in the way of killing more people/gathering information.

Indi: That it does! Now what exactly is her plan? Well, you'll find out soon enough.

Red: It will likely involve more murder.

Indi: Shez deserves to murder some assholes. As a treat.

Interlude - Secrets of the Nabatean

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

In her time away from the monastery, Flayn had come to learn much of the world. Things weren't as simple as she had thought, though she should have realized that. She had been asleep for a millennia, so it was probably too much to expect things to stay the same.

 

It was almost funny how the only thing that stayed the same was how the Agarthans were still around…

 

Sighing, she pushed herself up and away from her small patch of flowers she was growing in the garden. The Palace of Enbarr had a lovely garden and Edelgard had been kind enough to allow her a space to attempt growing her own plants, so she did.

 

…She didn’t have a lot to do otherwise. She was a Black Eagle, but classes had ended long ago and it was obvious Edelgard wasn’t sure what position Flayn should have in whatever plans she was making.

 

She didn’t think Edelgard disliked her, but it was hard to say the emperor fully trusted her. Even after the years outside the Academy where Edelgard opened up to everyone else from her original class, she seemed to keep Flayn at a…possibly unintended distance, in part because she plainly had issues with the crest system and church as a whole. It was impossible not to notice, especially since she was open about her distaste for both with everyone else.

 

It made her wonder just how everything was going to turn out. It’d been almost three years since she last saw her father and news about what happened to the people of the church was as sparse as it was contradictory. If even half the rumors were true, Seteth had apparently become the leader of the remaining Central Church forces resisting the Kingdom’s authority while also eloping to Almyra with either Catherine or Alois, all of which Flayn found quite unlikely. Alois was married, after all, and Catherine had a very obvious crush on Lady Rhea–

 

“Hm? Hello Flayn, you’re looking thoughtful.”

 

Flayn paused, then glanced up, a smile coming to her face as she spotted Linhardt. “Good morning, Linhardt! And, ah…yes, I suppose I do have a few thoughts on my mind.”

 

“I would hope so. If you let your mind have no thoughts, you’ll wind up like Caspar.”

 

She giggled at the comment, then stood and brushed down her pants. Being away from the monastery granted her an opportunity to try out some new clothes and she found she quite enjoyed fashion suited for commonfolk. The poofy blue pants she wore were very easy to move around in and suited her linen shirt quite nicely. Add in a bandana to protect her hair and gloves for her hands, and she matched the image of a common gardener very well! Though she still needed to keep her ears covered; people might ask questions if they noticed they were pointed.

 

Funnily enough, her choice to dress as a common gardener did cause some nobles to assume she was a common gardener, which was amusing until one noblewoman had been very rude to her as a result. Some nobility could be very unpleasant…

 

She shook off that thought and glanced at Linhardt. “So are you planning to spend some time in the garden?”

 

“Of course, it’s pleasant out here. Besides, I should be able to hide from Edelgard and my father here.”

 

“Huh? Why would you be hiding from your father?”

 

“Oh, he just has that air like he wants to make me do something. Honestly, you'd think his injuries would have gotten him to loosen up, but if anything he's still as stringent. Either way, I’d prefer not to get involved until Edelgard forces me, so I’m going to nap out here.”

 

“Ah, I see…Hm.” Flayn frowned to herself. If Edelgard was planning something big, shouldn’t she be involved? She was part of the Eagles too, Edelgard was her friend, and the Adrestians had always been good to her…She nodded, resolved. “Thank you, Linhardt! I am going to speak to Edelgard now!”

 

“Hm? Uh…what did I do?”

 

But Linhardt wouldn’t get an answer as Flayn hurried off to find the emperor. It was a bit tricky to find her, of course, the Palace of Enbarr was by far one of the largest buildings in all of Fodlan, and if she wasn't in her office then who knows where–

 

“Oh, careful,” Marianne warned, steadying Flayn when the young Nabatean nearly ran into her, “Flayn? What are you doing running around the castle?”

 

"Ah, hello Marianne, I was just looking for Lady Edelgard," Flayn said, smiling at the noble. She had to admit, it felt nice seeing the girl looking much healthier these days compared to her days at the monastery. Though as she looked up at Marianne, she noticed a letter in the noble’s hands. "Oh, my apologies, did I interrupt you reading something important?" 

 

"...Something like that. I, um…received a letter from my adoptive father." 

 

"Oh. Oh that's wonderful!" Flayn said, ignoring the pang she felt as she thought of her own father. "How is he?" 

 

"He didn't say. He…just wants me to return to the Alliance. I didn't know he had been searching for me all this time." 

 

“Oh! Oh, I see, that is…” She gave Marianne a curious look. “Good?”

 

"I'm…not sure. I don't have a close relationship with my adoptive father. He only adopted me because of my crest and… I don't know what exactly he plans for me if I return." 

 

"So…you don't plan on doing so?" 

 

"Not right away, at least. I don't want to leave everyone here when they're still dealing with the war. And…we're still searching for the professor." 

 

"...That is true," Flayn said, refraining from saying the professor wasn't the only one she was hoping to see. Her father was still missing as well, and…well, even if there were issues with Lady Rhea, she wanted to find her too. “Ah, have you heard anything?”

 

“Unfortunately I haven’t. Sorry. General Jeralt went out on another search mission recently though, so perhaps he’ll be able to bring back good news,” Marianne suggested, which earned a smile from Flayn. While the news wasn’t exactly good, at least the usually morose girl was more positive these days.

 

"Well hopefully he returns soon," Flayn said, nodding before remembering where she was going. "My apologies, but I need to go talk with Lady Edelgard." 

 

"Take care." With a wave, Flayn took off, searching for her former house leader again. Though it was still quite confusing trying to navigate the castle. If only they put up signs to show where everything was… 

 

Before she could figure out where she was however, a door next to her suddenly blasted open, getting completely broken off its hinges. 

 

"Fascinating!" She heard Constance shout out, followed by a groan from someone else. 

 

"Hey, Coco, I think Momo might need a nap." Came Hapi's voice as something slumped over. Feeling very curious, Flayn peaked her head in to see the aforementioned two, alongside Monica, who was slumped over a desk, and Hubert who was reading over a stack of papers, despite the room looking very disheveled from the sudden explosion. 

 

"So they've made artificial relics to act as amplifiers. Though it seems the drawbacks can be far more sudden than regular relic weapons. Perhaps there are ways to compensate for it,” Hubert mused, his eye twitching for a moment at the damages, before looking back down at the documents. “We know from Lady Edelgard’s report that using one of these allowed an Agarthan general to use Aymr with no apparent issues…though we might wish to wait when it comes to testing that. Particularly if a regular amplifier is so volatile.”

 

"D-Do you think this is what helped cause the meteor swarm?" Monica asked, pushing herself up slightly, letting Flayn see the pseudo relic on her hand. She couldn't help but stiffen at the sight. Relic weapons were already an atrocity to her, but to see these black, bone-like mimics…she couldn't help but shiver slightly. 

 

"Perhaps? Though they must have used a much stronger version, or perhaps multiple of these to make something devastating…though in either case, they likely weren't able to use it multiple times since they only launched the one attack," Constance muttered. 

 

"Or maybe the person who casted it just died if we're lucky," Hapi said with a shrug, before noticing Flayn. “Oh, hey Flay. What’s up?”

 

“Oh, I was just looking for Edelgard, but then the door exploded,” she explained, gesturing to the wrecked door in question.

 

“Lady Edelgard should be referred to with proper honorifics,” Hubert chided, giving her an annoyed look, “She is the emperor, if you would recall.”

 

“Yes, I recall,” Flayn replied, resisting the urge to roll her eyes. Hubert could be as nagging as her father sometimes…and that thought made her sad so she wasn’t going to focus on that. “So what are you doing?

 

"Merely testing something we acquired from our shadowy enemies." He smirked. “They may not have parted with it willingly, but we’ve put their failures to good use.”

 

”Hm. Are you sure it should be used? Relic weapons are…very volatile, even under the best circumstances,” she pointed out, more than a little disturbed by the artificial bones of the false relic.

 

"Yeah, it does seem like it can be very dangerous. Still, at least we know just how dangerous it is," Hapi commented.

 

“Exactly! In fact, we should take steps to see just how dangerous these artifacts can be!” Constance declared, “Multiple experiments are needed with multiple subjects–”

 

“We need them to volunteer, Coco. And let’s try to keep things ethical, alright?”

 

“I am certain we can acquire some bandits and a few soldiers that are more criminal than dutiful,” Hubert mentioned, which earned a frown from Hapi.

 

“...Yeah, let’s not get into the human experimenting business. Not a fan of that.”

 

"Ah, right, of course, my apologies." Surprisingly, Constance actually sounded apologetic. 

 

"I-I can still help…" Monica said, still looking exhausted. 

 

“No, that’s quite alright. I think we had better put an end to the experimentation for now,” Hubert decided, “We’ve established what these artificial relics are likely meant for and how they are used, which is a good starting point.”

 

“Of course, though a starting point is merely the beginning!” Constance declared.

 

“Yes, that is what ‘starting point’ means.”

 

"Right, well, I'll leave you all to it," Flayn said, giving them a smile before she left. Better she leave the magical research to people who were experienced with it. Now if only they could build a magic tool so she wouldn't get lost… 

 

Regardless, she continued to walk, only to get nearly trampled over as a trio rushed past a corner. "Woah!" 

 

"Oh, sorry Flayn, didn't see you there! Just in a bit of a rush!" Caspar apologized, the once short boy having had quite the growth spurt as he glanced down at her. 

 

"Y-Yeah, sorry! We just wanted to make sure we greeted Petra when she arrived!" Bernadetta explained, the archer also having a growth spurt of her own, even if she wasn't as bulky as Caspar in his armor. 

 

"Oh, is Petra back already?" 

 

"Not yet!" Ferdinand spoke up. "But we need to prepare a welcoming party for her, and you are more than welcome to join if you are not busy." 

 

"Oh, I would love to! I can get some of the flowers from my garden to help spruce up the venue!" She paused. “Oh, wait, I was going to visit Edelgard, actually. Um, right, let me do that first, then I can–Oh right, do you know where Edelgard is at the moment?”

 

"Ah, I believe she went to the training ground earlier, she wanted to see how the soldiers were doing before Captain Jeralt returned,” Ferdinand explained, before smiling. "Would you like me to guide you?" 

 

"Oh, yes, please," Flayn replied, smiling up at the nobleman. 

 

"Then guide I shall! Bernadetta, Caspar, my apologies but I'll be joining you two later!" Ferdinand declared, waving their friends off before the two walked off together. "How have you been, Flayn?" 

 

"Excellent, I think. I'm hopeful that Captain Jeralt will have some good news for us once he returns."

 

"Hopefully. If nothing else, I hope he was able to figure out who the mysterious soldier that's been attacking the principality is," Ferdinand muttered. 

 

“...do you think it could be…”

 

“Professor Byleth? Or Shez? It could be, though I am uncertain. It might be related to those ‘Reclaimer Knights’ that have been causing trouble for the principality.”

 

“Hm. Has Edelgard decided what to do about them yet?” Flayn asked with a small frown. She didn’t know what to make of the knights that declared themselves to be fighting on behalf of the goddess. She knew they were apparently made up of former Knights of Seiros and defecting Knights of Faerghus, but they’d been staying out of much of the conflict, to the point that it wasn’t clear where their loyalties were meant to lie. Add in the rumors that her father was involved with them that she wasn’t sure she believed…

 

She wanted to think that if her father was in charge of the remaining church forces, he would have come to support her in the Empire. If he hadn’t…it just didn’t match her idea of her frankly overprotective father, and that worried her. 

 

“Officially, no, though they have been a topic of conversation,” Ferdinand explained, frowning thoughtfully, “I know Hubert has been looking into them for some time now, but they’re a reclusive group. The fact that they don’t follow standard church doctrine is cause for concern, especially since the Northern Church has been using their ‘Reformation’ to proclaim themselves the true faith…”

 

“Mm. Um…has Edelgard given my proposal any thought?” Flayn asked, the current conversation reminding her of an idea she’d had before.

 

“She has, you don’t need to worry about that. Honestly, I think restarting the Southern Church is an excellent idea! Without the Central Church to keep balance, the faithful of the Empire need somewhere to turn!”

 

“Yes, exactly! Even if it's not on the same level as the Central Church, it can still help the people greatly!" Flayn said, a smile on her face. 

 

As the two talked, they soon arrived in the training grounds of the castle, where a group of soldiers were going through some sparring practice. They seemed to be handling themselves well, though it was hard to tell if the Emperor watching over them was pleased or not. 

 

Flayn had to admit, despite only being slightly taller than her, Edelgard always seemed to tower over those around her and she couldn't help but envy that confidence. 

 

"Ah, Edelgard there you are!" Ferdinand called out, getting the Emperor's attention. 

 

"Ferdinand? Did you need something?" 

 

"Not me, Flayn wished to speak with you, if you're not busy." 

 

“Hm. Ladislava, handle the drills for now,” Edelgard commanded, earning an immediate salute from the bodyguard-turned-general. 

 

“Of course, your majesty.” 

 

“Oh, allow me to assist!” Ferdinand immediately offered, going right along with her with his usual enthusiasm and aplomb.

 

And with that settled, Edelgard turned towards Flayn. “What did you require?”

 

The young Nabatean paused, trying to collect her thoughts. “Ah…well, I had an initial request, which was to know what your new plans were, but, ah, then I was reminded of my other proposal, which was to reestablish the Southern Church, and, ah…my apologies, I am rambling…”

 

“I did give your proposal a good deal of thought, Flayn, and I think it is a good idea.”

 

It took a moment for Edelgard’s words to register, then Flayn immediately smiled. “O-Oh! I am glad to hear that! Er, so, is the Southern Church going to be reestablished?”

 

“Indeed, I plan to have it built back up soon, though there are a few issues to take care of before we can fully make the project work. For instance, we’ll need a bishop.” 

 

"Oh, of course. I…am aware there was a count in charge of religious affairs who passed away, so I imagine you'll need to find someone suited for the role." 

 

"Yes, and on that matter, who would you nominate for the role?" 

 

"W-Wait, you want me to choose?" 

 

"At the very least I want to hear who you think would be well suited for the position. This is your proposal, is it not?" Edelgard asked, staring at Flayn with a calculating eye. 

 

"Oh, uh…" Flayn paused, trying to think of who would be good for the position. "...Someone like Professor Byleth?" 

 

“…hm. I doubt there are many people like Professor Byleth.” Edelgard gave her a curious look. “I would have thought you’d suggest someone more like Rhea.”

 

“Huh? Oh, yeah…ah, well, while Lady Rhea was the Archbishop for a very long time, I, er…” She looked around for a moment, hoping no one was listening in, before leaning towards Edelgard and speaking in a low voice. “I’m not sure she was very good at it…”

 

Edelgard’s lips twitched. “I must admit, I am surprised you would say that. Aren’t you one of Rhea’s supporters?”

 

“Huh? Um…I guess? I mean, don’t get me wrong, I support Lady Rhea! I just…there were a lot of problems at the monastery? And I…um…I guess it was kind of…disillusioning?”

 

“Hm. How long were you at the monastery?”

 

“Oh, um…well, I actually joined the same year you and the others did. Before that, I lived away from the monastery.” She huffed. “I actually had to beg my father to let me go there…um, so, yes, I hadn’t actually seen what Lady Rhea was like as the archbishop before then and…well I know she tried her best! I just think, maybe, we need somebody, um…less distant? Maybe? I’m not sure if I’m articulating this well…”

 

"Well, I understand what you mean if nothing else," Edelgard stated, as she thought about what to say. "And what about someone like your father?" 

 

"Ah…" Flayn frowned. "Don't get me wrong, I love my father but…well, while he might be more personable, he also tends to keep out of others’ business as well. I didn't even know about all the troubles Fodlan was facing because he never told me…and I didn't even bother to learn. I spent so long trying to figure out how to socialize with everyone, I didn't bother to learn what they were going through." 

 

“Hm. And now?”

 

“Now…Now I want to try to make things better. And I think starting up the Southern Church could do that…maybe…no, not maybe, I know it will help!”

 

That earned a small smile from Edelgard. “I see you have your convictions. Well, we will have to discuss the matter of the bishop further, along with some other issues. After seeing what became of the Western and Central churches, I would prefer it if the Southern Church remained more of a spiritual organization without a focus on governance or military.”

 

“Oh, so more like the Eastern Church then? I think that works perfectly then! The church should be there to support people, not fight them!” Flayn stated, surprising Edelgard at the support. 

 

"...If I am being honest, part of the reason I'm so open to the idea of reopening the Southern Church is because I had plans for that in the past. However, I had all but abandoned them after everything that occurred," Edelgard admitted. 

 

"Oh…well, I can understand why. I mean, without someone to grant it legitimacy, some might take offense to it. Even so, I'm sure you'll make it work!" 

 

"...Hm. If I were to admit something else, there are other secrets that I am keeping, much like I'm sure you are." 

 

“Eh? A-Ah, I-I mean, uh, w-what do you mean? I-I have no secrets to keep at all, ahahaha…” Flayn said, weakly defending herself under Edelgard’s stare. "...Maybe we should go to your office if we're going to discuss such things." 

 

“Would you be willing to discuss such things?”

 

“...I would, yes. I…want to be honest with my friends, so yes, I am willing to tell you the truth.”

 

“Very well, then we can go to my office,” Edelgard said, saying the last bit loud enough for Ladislava to hear, who nodded in return as the Emperor walked away. Despite how nervous she felt, Flayn followed along. Preparing herself for what’s to come. Soon enough the two were in the imperial office. In the moment, Flayn mostly felt thankful that Edelgard was so used to the halls of the palace. 

 

“So…um, how is Dorothea? I, uh, haven’t seen her today,” Flayn asked, sitting across from Edelgard, unsure of how to start. 

 

“She is well. She seems to be helping some of the others prepare for Petra’s arrival,” Edelgard said, keeping her tone even. 

 

“That’s good to hear…” Flayn took a breath, trying to settle her nerves. “...I would like to be honest with you, Emperor Edelgard. I…believe you may know a number of things already about my situation, though I am unsure of how much. In all honesty, you might even know more than me.”

 

Edelgard simply raised an eyebrow, her hands folded in front of her. “And what would you like to be honest with me about?”

 

“To begin with, Flayn is not my original name.” She untied her bandana and brushed her hair aside, showing a pointed ear. “I was once known as Cethleann, though that is only one of my names. Seteth is not my brother, he is my father, though that was never a very well hidden secret, and we were both once known as ‘saints’, though I do not really know if our actions warranted that title. I am a Nabatean, and my name is the Benevolent One.”

 

The entire time she spoke, she watched Edelgard. And she had to admit, she was impressed; not once had the emperor reacted as though anything Flayn was saying was new information to her. Perhaps none of it was. 

 

Either way, if it was or wasn’t, the emperor maintained that same calm, focused look to her, listening intently and showing nothing in turn. “You claim to be Saint Cethleann then.”

 

“Yes, I do, because I am. I was born over a thousand years ago to the Hammer of Judgment, whose name among humankind was Cichol, and Carmun, who was my mother. We lived apart from the city of Zanados, which was why we survived when the forces of Nemesis and his Eleven Elites massacred the Nabateans.” She kept her gaze steady and her voice even, though it wavered slightly when she mentioned her mother’s name. Even with how long it had been, the wound of her passing was still there. “...I realize I am…what I am saying may sound like nonsense without context, but I am trying to start from as far back as I can. I…Is there anything in particular you wish to ask me? I can give proof, if you want, like the location of my mother’s grave or stories from back then.”

 

"...The Benevolent One and Hammer of Judgement sound more like titles than names." 

 

"In a sense, they're both. When we are born, Nabateans are simply called 'hatchlings' and it isn't until we reach a certain point of maturity that we 'earn' our names. I myself earned my name because I kept wanting to help all the humans I met." 

 

"...and the Immaculate One?" 

 

"She…Aunty Rhea was the youngest of the children of Sothis, she always stuck by her side, and in return Sothis favored her greatly. Though I suppose that led to her getting quite spoiled." Edelgard tried not to laugh at the thought of Rhea being a spoiled child. 

 

"So, just to be certain, you claim Rhea to be your aunt?" 

 

"That is also in a sense. I would say the title is more honorary. Rhea is…a direct child of the goddess, while my father and I are descended from her children, yet we all fought on the same battlefields and she cared for us as family. I like calling her Aunty Rhea more than Lady Rhea, because it makes us feel more like family, though it wasn’t unusual among the Nabateans to refer to those you are close to by familial terms. I might call you Sister Edelgard, for example.” She paused. “I-If that would be allowed, of course.”

 

“...” Edelgard tried to ignore the odd feeling that went through her. “I see…at the moment, I would prefer being called Edelgard, if that is okay with you.”

 

“O-Of course!”

 

"For the sake of honesty, I fear I must apologize to you Flayn. I understand I have kept you at a distance but that is not from distaste. It comes more from a sense of…not knowing what to do." Edelgard paused as she considered her words. "At the start of the year, I never considered someone like you joining my class, and when you did I thought it would only be a matter of time for that bond to end, as it would be temporary at best. I am still uncertain where you stand, since as you say, you are one of the four saints." 

 

"...I can understand that. Truth be told, until recently, the church was all I knew. When I awoke from my slumber, it was just my father and I, but then he left to join the church. So I was alone again until I was allowed to join. So I was happy to join the church, it meant I could be with people again, I could have friends! Yes, my father told me things were dangerous, but it was always in terms of my blood or to stay away from people who were very forward…

 

She frowned, letting some of her frustration show. “Truth be told, I am angry. At both my father and myself. He never told me about what happened to Fodlan and…I chose to live in ignorance. I never bothered to learn about the history of Fodlan, only the trends and such that the youths liked. The Insurrection, the Tragedy of Duscur, the Almyran invasions…There are so many tragedies in this land and I lived in ignorance."

 

"We all live in ignorance until our eyes are forced open," Edelgard noted, her tone surprisingly sympathetic.

 

“That is true…I still find it difficult to comprehend though. I went to sleep one day and when I awoke, the entire world was so very different and my past persona was lauded as a saint, of all things. Even though I’m pretty sure at least half of what they ascribe to me were actually actions my mother took,” Flayn muttered, allowing herself a small moment of bitterness at how history had forgotten someone she adored.

 

“Hm. History has a tendency to forget those who do not shake the world with their actions, tragic as it might be.” She sighed. “My own siblings are likely to be a footnote in my history, whenever and however it is written…it truly does not feel fair that those who impact our own lives so significantly are disregarded so completely.”

 

“...hm…could I…know their names?” Flayn asked, wondering if she had gone too far with the question yet forging on anyway, “I do not know how long I will live, but I will make sure to carry those names with me…i-if it is alright with you.”

 

“...” Edelgard smiled. “I would be happy to tell you about them, though I fear my own memories won’t match up to the life they once had. In exchange…could you tell me about your mother?”

 

Flayn returned her smile, brightly and openly. “I would love to.”

Jeralt was feeling his age. He’d been feeling his age for the past three years. Some days, it felt like he’d just collapse under the weight of all the years he’d lived, all of it pushing down on him at once until he was crushed beneath it all.

 

The loss of his kids settled deep in his bones. It wasn’t quite despair, not yet; he’d never exactly hit that point. He’d seen other people hit in, breaking under the sheer weight of their sorrow. He couldn’t do that though. He didn’t know where they were…but he was positive his kids were out there. He’d find them, some day.

 

If he didn’t…or if he did, and they were…That’s when he would stop. Just…stop.

 

But that wasn’t something he let himself dwell on. Not while there was still a chance. Not while there was still work to do.

 

The little emperor, Edelgard, had an intensity to her that reminded him of Rhea. The difference was, Rhea put that intensity towards keeping things the same. Edelgard wanted the world to change, and she’d bend things as far as they could go to make it happen. Maybe even break it, so it could be fixed up better.

 

Byleth liked her, so that’s why he was willing to work for her instead of just running around all of Fodlan until he dropped, looking for any hint of where his kids went. And it’s what brought him out towards Garreg Mach. Not to the monastery itself though, but towards some of the lower valleys in the central Fodlan stretch of the Oghma Mountains. Specifically, towards the Red Canyon.

 

“So hey, Captain, do you think it counts as heresy if we enter the canyon?” Victor asked, giving Jeralt a glance as the pair of them crouched by an outcropping, waiting for Candace to return from her scouting, “I mean, we don’t exactly have permission from the archbishop–”

 

“Doesn’t really matter if no one’s around to enforce the rule, right?” Jeralt pointed out, “I doubt any knights are going to be bothered. Aside from the ones invading the canyon in the first place.”

 

“Right, that makes sense…speaking of, are we supposed to go after them? Because we kinda left the rest of the battalion waiting back thataway.”

 

“We’re just checking things out. If they cause problems, we’ll try to deal with it. If they seem like they can be reasoned with, we’ll talk to them. For now, we wait until Candace gets–”

 

“Hey Captain! Guess who I found!” 

 

The goddess really does have a funny sense of timing, Jeralt mused to himself, before he sighed and stood up from his cover to spot his lancer returning with…some kid he didn’t recognize. “Hey Candace. Who’s that?”

 

“Eh? You don’t remember Cyril, captain?” Candace asked, looking confused, “You know, the little Almyran kid! Well, not so little now, but you know what I mean!”

 

“So did you blow our cover or wh–Oh huh, that’s that Cyril kid,” Victor recognized as he peeked up to spot Candace and her companion, who apparently everyone but Jeralt remembered.

 

"Right, hi there kid. What exactly are you doing here?" 

 

"I'm on guard duty." Cyril said, yanking his arm free from Candace. "What are you doing here?" 

 

"Recon." Jeralt gruffly responded as he eyed the kid. He looked a bit worse for wear, but didn't seem to be malnourished, at least. Wasn't letting go of his bow either, his free hand staying close to his quiver. Had an axe at his side too, probably as a back-up weapon. That or he was planning to be a woodcutter if this guard thing didn’t work out. “So, are you part of the group squatting in the canyon or what?”

 

Cyril’s eyes narrowed. “What’s it to you?”

 

“Well I was sent by Emperor Edelgard to check out what’s going on with a group of knights that took over one of Fodlan’s holy sites, so that’s what I’m doing. I’d prefer it if this doesn’t turn into a fight, kid, especially since you’re the one at a disadvantage here.”

 

Cyril scowled. “I can still–”

 

“Hey, c’mon cap, you need to be nicer when you’re talking to kids!” Candace chided, before giving Cyril a pat on the head, which he moved away from, “Alright buddy, mind showing my friends to your group? We’re looking to negotiate, not fight.” She paused, then glanced at Jeralt. “Right?”

 

The question wasn’t rhetorical, she’d clearly forgotten. “Yeah, we can negotiate. We’re not going to start a fight.”

 

He’d sure as hell finish one if it came to that though.

 

“...hm…yeah, alright,” Cyril decided, nodding, “I’ll take you there. Not like you could do much anyway.”

 

Jeralt decided not to point out that there was plenty he could do right now to make Cyril’s day unpleasant. Aside from that being a bad move in general, the kid was still a kid. He didn’t want that kind of blood on his hands if he could help it. 

 

And once he actually got a view of the canyon, he quickly realized that Cyril was absolutely right.

 

“Holy shit,” Victor muttered, staring out at the golems standing guard around at the canyon. The massive stone constructs were completely still, almost like statues; Jeralt would’ve assumed they were if it weren’t for the fact that one of them turned its head towards them the instant they caught its attention.

 

“Woah…that’s a lotta guys,” Candace remarked, her own attention on what was basically an army filling up the canyon. And it wasn’t as though they just had a camp down there; it looked like the “Knights of Reclamation” had built their own settlement, complete with fortified buildings, defenses, and wells for water. “How many are down there?”

 

“At least a couple thousand,” Cyril stated, looking smug, “Think you three can measure up?”

 

“Eh? Uh…well, we can’t really divide it up by a thousand if there’s just two thousand there, cause if we try to divide that with three of us, then we get a really weird number–”

 

“It was rhetorical, Candace,” Jeralt pointed out, before letting out a sigh, “Alright, you made your point, kid. Can we speak to your boss now?”

 

“Yeah, alright. Seteth will probably be happy to see you guys.”

 

Honestly, Seteth looked more stressed than happy when he spotted Jeralt walking up to him, particularly since the former chamberlain seemed to be in the middle of arguing with a guy who looked a whole lot like the fishkeeper at Garreg Mach. 

 

“–genuinely don’t have enough supplies to work for a sustained campaign–Jeralt?” Seteth blinked, genuinely caught off guard when he noticed the former captain of the Knights of Seiros. Then Seteth immediately went over to him and clasped his hands to the former captain’s shoulders. “Thank the goddess you’re here, you have to help me with these people!”

 

“...alright.” That’s not a good sign.

 

“Hey Bernhard,” Candace, meanwhile, greeted, waving at the fishkeeper, because apparently she just knew everyone.

 

"Oh, hello," the fishkeeper greeted in return. 

 

"So, what exactly is going on?" Jeralt asked, deciding to keep on track, something Seteth appreciated. 

 

"You've likely heard of them, but this is the camp of the Knights of Reclamation," Seteth stated, confirming who they were. "And it was decided that I would be the leader, given my previous qualifications.”

 

“We named him the archbishop,” the fishkeeper, of all people, explained.

 

“The interim archbishop, who is not the official–Look, never mind. I am the leader of these people for various reasons, all right? Now, the only problem with this position is that the knights here are apparently fully dedicated to starting an almost suicidal campaign." 

 

“Uh…what–”

 

“Jeralt, I need you to understand, I have spent three years surrounded by religious zealots who want to invade everyone ,” Seteth stated, trying to keep a calm tone and very obviously failing, “They are utterly convinced that the goddess returned when Garreg Mach was invaded and declared…apparently a number of things. The point is, everyone who isn’t here, right now, is potentially a heretic and I think it might be my fault for holding them back so long but I couldn’t just let them die, now could I? They want to invade the Kingdom in retaliation and then the Hrym secession happened and they became the next target, then somehow it turned into a whole thing that the Alliance was also the problem because they broke away from the Empire, but also the Empire needs to be invaded because they turned away from the goddess’s light and I have no idea how they even get half the ideas they’ve come up with.”

 

“...what.”

 

“Hey captain, they got a statue of your daughter over there for some reason,” Victor pointed out, catching Jeralt’s attention. And…yeah, that was pretty clearly a statue of Byleth, striking a triumphant pose with the Sword of the Creator pointed towards the sky and her foot on a demonic beast.

 

“Huh. They made her boobs huge,” Candace noted while Jeralt turned his gaze towards Seteth.

 

“... What .”

 

“Honestly, it’s one of their better attempts,” the fishkeeper commented, “We probably have a few still scattered around, along with those murals Luca helped paint–”

 

“You, shut up,” Jeralt ordered, pointing at the fishkeeper, before turning his glare back towards Seteth. “What the hell is this about Byleth being worshipped by these lunatics?”

 

Seteth winced at the insult, particularly when a few of the knights nearby paused and frowned at Jeralt. “...Essentially, the Knights of Reclamation have convinced themselves that your eldest is the goddess incarnate, because of the abilities she displayed that were beyond mortal means." 

 

“Well, she was openly speaking as the goddess,” the fishkeeper pointed out, “And her being was radiating divinity–”

 

“Didn’t I tell you to shut up?” Jeralt sighed irritably. “Right, what the hell is this?”

 

“Well from the look of it, a bunch of Kingdom deserters and Church remnants decided to make a cult based around calling your daughter the new goddess,” Victor commented, before frowning in thought, “Or the reborn goddess?”

 

“The latter,” the fishkeeper–

 

“Why are you still talking?” Jeralt complained, “And I already got that part, Victor.”

 

“So wait, if Byleth is their goddess, is Shez anything?” Candace asked.

 

“Basically the opposite,” Cyril spoke up, “Something about the two of them fighting each other and talking about ancient peoples. Most people here are saying she’s a demon or a fallen goddess.”

 

“I personally like ‘The Adversary’ as an epithet.”

 

Jeralt glared at the fishkeeper. “...I’m going to punch you the next time you speak up.”

 

Seteth gave Bernhard a look, making the fishkeeper back down before he could say anything. "Essentially, the Knights are remnants of the Knights of Seiros and Kingdom Soldiers who were at the monastery. I've managed to keep them in check for now, but I feel like it's only a matter of time before they go charging off at the first thing to set them off." 

 

"...Right. Well, if it makes you feel better, Flayn is doing alright," Jeralt said, unsure of what else to say. 

 

"...It does, yes. I was aware she was in Enbarr, and that the war hasn't hit it yet at least, so I assumed she was safe. Even so, knowing is better than assuming." 

 

"I can understand that," Jeralt muttered as he looked over the knights there. They seemed to be doing their best with maintaining their settlement, but there was definitely tension in the air. Lots of people with weapons and not much to do. Sighing, he rubbed the back of his head. "I can't promise anything, but if you come with me, I can get you a meeting with the Emperor." 

 

"And hey, the little Emperor is Byleth’s student, so when you think about it, if anything she's like super holy for you reclamation people!" Candace helpfully chimed in. 

 

“Huh, maybe we could use that–”

 

Jeralt warned him. So while Bernhard slept the forced sleep of an idiot who wouldn’t shut up, Jeralt turned back to Seteth. “So what resources do you people even have? I’m not seeing any pegasi or wyverns.”

 

“...” Seteth decided to ignore the knocked out fishkeeper. “Yes, that…well, we’ve had a few issues with retaining mounts over the years. Demonic beasts certainly thinned the mounts we once had and many of them escaped into the wild without the stables to keep them in. Our trained flyers also suffered the most casualties of our forces back in the monastery invasion, so we haven’t been able to train people up again…” He sighed. 

 

"Then it definitely seems like you people need help," Victor pointed out. 

 

"We do. However, I don't think it would be wise to march these knights straight into the heart of the Empire. They’re not completely undisciplined, but with the chaos going on right now, I feel like they’re bound to get into a conflict with either the Imperial soldiers or the Principality’s forces…” He sighed again, frowning. “Those traitors are the main reason we’ve been stuck here for so long with how much of the Empire’s north eastern territory they’ve taken. Still, if I were to go alone, then who knows what these knights will get up to." 

 

"Then I can leave some of my men here," Jeralt offered, "We were only supposed to do some recon, so we don't have a surplus of supplies, but they can share some stuff and keep an eye on them while you and I go back." 

 

“Oh yeah, for sure!” Candace agreed, “I can definitely hang out with these weirdos! Byleth and Shez were like little sisters to me, so I can share all kinds of stories!” She paused, then glanced at Jeralt. “You’re not like a father to me, captain.”

 

“...I don’t know why you felt the need to say that.”

 

“I wanted to make things clear between us.”

 

“...Sure.” He decided to just ignore that. “So, you good to–”

 

“Archbishop Seteth, I would like to report that–...why is Bernhard unconscious on the ground?” Some robed guy asked, looking concerned.

 

“He fell asleep,” Jeralt stated.

 

“...what? How in the world did–Wait, aren’t you the father of the goddess?”

 

“And now I’m leaving. Come on, Seteth.”

 

“Ah, wait, right now? Shouldn’t I hear the report–”

 

“No. Come on.” 

 

“But–”

 

“You want to see your daughter, right?”

 

“...” He turned to the robed man. “Luca, you’re in charge.” Then he promptly followed after Jeralt.

 

“...” After a moment, Victor glanced at the new guy. “So what were you reporting on anyway?”

 

“Oh, just that Pallardo’s back at the monastery again.”

 

“...the merchant guy?”

 

“He turned to banditry a while ago. Honestly, I’m not sure how he keeps showing up since he’s been reported killed at least five times.”

 

“Huh. Sounds immortal,” Candace remarked, “Maybe you could add him to your religion?”

 

“What? We can’t just add people–...actually, hm…”

 

“...Hey, wait up, I’m going with you guys!” Cyril called out, promptly hurrying after the two older men. Because honestly? Screw sticking around these weirdos.

 

Why couldn’t they just worship Lady Rhea like normal people?

Chapter End Notes

Indi: You know it's very fun to actually have it end up with Flayn still with the Eagles post time skip.

Red: That it is! It's a fun thing to do, considering Flayn usually sticks to being part of the church faction.

Indi: And we even gave her a new design as well, for fun!

Red: Yup! Because hey, wearing the same uniform over the course of three years would be weird.

Indi: Yeah, it's odd she never got a new outfit. Do you think Seteth just never gave her the money for it something?

Red: The church faction in general just doesn't have post-timeskip designs. Rhea kinda drops the fancier parts of her archbishop clothes, just keeping the gown and flowers (or putting on the Seiros outfit to fight directly), and Cyril does have a different design, but Catherine, Shamir, and Alois all keep the same outfits, same as the professors.

Indi: Everyone deserves a post time skip design. Especially Byleth! I wonder if she'll get one here...

Red: Perhaps, perhaps. At the very least, she's going to need to get new tights after the last ones ripped.

Indi: The ultimate design change. New tights.

The Arrival of Dawn

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

If there was one thing Shez had gotten better at over the years, it was keeping track of directions. On occasion she still might forget a thing or two, but when it came down to getting from her village to Castle Ordelia, she knew it better than the back of her hand. She’d repeated the path enough times that she’d practically created a new trail where her feet fell.

 

Well, not really, since the castle was a ways away from the mountains she grew up in, but her own means of travel made it easy to get to a nice vantage point to check out the patrols. As usual, the place had some of those masked demonic beasts walking around outside, on patrol for any threats. There were flying beasts too up on the ramparts, the monstrous sentries overlooking the surrounding area like birds on the lookout for prey.

 

Twelve walkers, eight flyers, Shez noted to herself, keeping a careful watch of her own, That’s two more from last time…Guess they’ve been making more again.

 

She wasn’t sure where “House Phlegethon” was getting more people to make into monsters, but she knew for a fact there were even more inside the castle. The demonic beasts were the Phlegethon's main way of keeping the Alliance’s forces back so it made sense they’d keep more in reserve. Those beasts were bound to be her biggest obstacle to getting inside…

 

She could fight them, but it would take too long, meaning it would alert everyone inside. And if she warped inside, then she'd be surrounded by a bunch of demonic beasts. It was a two part problem and one she was having trouble solving, especially since the castle was fully locked down. She hadn’t seen them even bring in supplies, which probably meant they had some way of getting it in without being spotted. Some kind of underground passages were most likely, but she hadn’t managed to find any of them despite her scouting.

 

Sighing, she considered her options, before looking at the beasts, trying to find an opening to flash past them. 

 

“You’re not going to make it in, you know,” Epimenides murmured, which Shez ignored because he could go fuck himself. “You have no idea what you’re getting in–”

 

And Shez flashed straight up to the ramparts, letting herself land for a moment as two of the flyers looked the wrong way, before she went right into a shadow step, moving into the courtyard and letting herself drop down. Once her feet touched the ground again, she immediately moved, going straight for the castle proper while taking note of every beast lounging around. There were demonic beasts filling the courtyard, three walkers to be specific, so she kept moving, going to the first door she spotted. The hall she entered didn’t seem well kept, but it seemed more out of misuse than being trashed, so there probably wasn’t anyone nearby. 

 

Even if there was, she had to be careful on who she grabbed; if she didn’t grab an Agarthan, then her plan wouldn’t work. Which made it all the more annoying that she could only be sure who was who based on how pale they were. 

 

Do Agarthans have different blood? That might make it easier to tell… She let out a little sigh, before starting to explore. 

 

The further in she went, the cleaner the place started looking. Not even Agarthans like living in filth, I guess. The problem was, she didn’t know what the interior structure of this place was like. She’d seen it from the outside plenty, but she didn’t know what the inside looked like and she had no idea what the Agarthans were doing with the place…aside from knocking down some walls, apparently.

 

She blinked, staring at the hole in what had clearly been a wall previously, before she noticed the wood supports set up to keep everything in place. Renovations, maybe? Why are they opening up–

 

“It’s fucking bullshit is what it is,” grumbled a weirdly familiar voice further in, sounding irritated and strangely raspy, “This place is a drain on our resources. We should focus on fortifying or destroying those damn bridges and leave this place to rot.”

 

“We still have on-going projects here, Lady Bias,” another voice replied, her tone more stoic, “Lord Myson wishes to continue investing in the exploration of empowered Ladons. Project Khione could very well–”

 

“Giving those monsters ice breath isn’t going to win us the war. It’s just another stupid idea that idiot is insisting we try out because he thinks if he has enough projects set up, one of them is bound to work,” the first one said, grumbling all the while. "Oh sure, let's just try to empower these demonic beasts even more, it's not like they could ever go wild and cause a rampage in the middle of our base." 

 

"We do have security measures in place–" 

 

"As if I care about that!" Bias shouted, a slam ringing out as she seemingly hit something. "Sages, why did I agree to do this?" 

 

"Please, Lady Bias. I'm sure Lady Pittacus will appreciate all you did for her." 

 

"Don't speak as if you knew her." 

 

"I'm not. I have simply been instructed to say such things by Lord Myson." 

 

“...fucking idiot.” A sigh sounded out, still with a strange rasp to it. “Not you, that moron we call a leader.”

 

“I appreciate the lack of insults directed towards me. I will have to report your–”
