“If you say anything about reporting my ‘insubordination’, I’m going to kill you regardless of the consequences.”

 

“...I understand these parameters. Still, I should note–” 

 

“Just stop talking. I need some air.”

 

Well, Shez probably wasn’t going to get a better chance than this. And besides, she owed Bias for smacking her that one time anyway. So the instant the gremory got close, Shez darted out from her hiding place and–

 

Immediately dodged straight back, her eyes going wide at the wall of flames that erupted between her and Bias. “Fucking rats got in again–...hang on. I know you.”

 

“Yeah, I know you t–” Shez was about to retort before she stiffened, staring at the Agarthan sage, who the years plainly hadn’t been kind too.

 

“What? You looked surprised, brat.” Bias grinned, showing off how half her face and a good amount of her upper body was covered in burn scars. The rest of her body was hidden beneath a black gown lined with fiery patterns, but Shez could see metal bracers on her arms with red stones implanted in them. Same with a choker around her neck and a diadem around her forehead, her dark hair bound back and looking redder than before. “Did you expect me to still be pretty?”

 

“Not really. Looks more like your outside is starting to match your inside,” Shez replied, drawing her swords.

 

“Arrogant little shit.”

 

"Sadistic hag," Shez shot back, before dodging to the side as a fireball was launched at her. Landing on her feet, Shez dashed forward, bracing herself as she went through a wall of fire Bias cast, before attempting to slash through her. 

 

"What is it with you two freaks being so suicidal?" Bias snarled as Shez’s blade clashed against a magic barrier, causing it to crack. 

 

"I'm not the one who's going to die tonight," Shez responded, jumping back as she heard footsteps rapidly approaching. A glance to the side showed guys in black armor. Possibly more Agarthans, so she debated grabbing one–Then one extended some kind of fancy spear and it launched a lightning bolt at her, so that wasn’t great.

 

She still dodged it, though then she had to avoid another fireball–then a lot of fireballs, launching from Bias’s hand–Or, more accurately, from a larger ball of fire she was conjuring in front of her and then launching pieces of at Shez–And then there was a bolt of ice launched from the blonde lady in a brown noblewoman’s gown–

 

Then her eyes went wide when the fire orb Bias conjured abruptly expanded, before bursting apart and fully bathing the entire hall in–

 

Then Shez took a slow breath, feeling her heart racing rapidly in her chest as she stood in the cold night air again, the heat on her body leaving her unpleasantly warm despite the chill. She let herself sit down for a moment, her body trembling slightly from the adrenaline coursing through her.

 

“...been a while since I’ve had to take on someone actually dangerous,” she murmured to herself, recapping the details of the fight in her mind as she tried to figure out just how dangerous Bias was going to be. The fact that she noticed me so quickly was what screwed me over. Maybe I should just go for the kill on her and then grab one of the shittier ones…

 

“You truly are insane.” And she immediately felt her mood plummet when the asshole spoke up. “What was that stunt meant to accomplish? Now your foes are aware–”

 

“Oh so now they’re ‘foes’. What happened to being a big happy Agarthan community?” she complained, frowning up at the prick.

 

Epimenides glared back. “You know as well as I that the current crop of sages are threats to us–”

 

“Yeah, whatever, shut up. Though I’d gotten good enough to take those pieces of shit on…though, then again, that bitch clearly wasn’t resting on her laurels…fuck, this is going to be a pain…”

 

“Then abandon this foolhardy plan of yours and–”

 

“Shut the fuck up. I’m not abandoning anything. The next Agarthan I see? I’m going to rip their fucking heart out,” Shez stated, before stating to travel back to her house. It took a bit of travel, but it didn’t matter. Her home was far enough away that Bias and whatever pricks she worked with wouldn’t be able to follow her, and once she got there, she could put the new info she got to work in her notes. Besides, now that they know I’m there, they’re going to step up security. That means they’re bound to bring in even more Agarthans, and then I can grab one of those assholes to experiment with. Might not even have to fight that Bias bitch…

 

She did want to kill her. If she had the opportunity, she’d go for it, but killing Bias wasn’t a priority. Getting Byleth back was, and for that to happen, she just needed an Agarthan heart. From there…well, she knew how Epimenides cast it. She’d been right in there with him when he did, and she sure as hell remembered that moment with perfect clarity.

 

She let out a small breath once she arrived at her home, her boots touching down on the wood as she just warped inside. She might need to clean up the dirt later, but for now, she needed to note down everything she–

 

Then a knock at the door caught her attention and she let out a frustrated sigh. “Seriously? Right now? It’s the middle of the night, can’t it fucking wait…”

 

She lit some lanterns first, letting the light illuminate her home so she could see better–Though, honestly, her night vision was weirdly good these days; not perfect, but she was definitely better at seeing in the dark–and went over to the door with one in hand so she could talk to the dickhead elder that kept trying to kick her out.

 

“I told you already, this is my mom’s house and I’m not–”

 

“Shez??”

 

“...” Shez stared at Kronya. The Agarthan stared back, looking alarmed and bewildered, her eyes wide. …oh, her hair got longer.

 

"What are you doing here!?" Shez’s eyes glanced to the side, finding Lysithea standing next to Kronya. She's taller now…  

 

Shez felt her mouth dry, unable to say anything as she saw two of her closest friends standing before her. She didn't know what to say. What could she say? 

 

Jerking back when she saw one of them move towards her, she slammed the door, before immediately warping away when she heard the pair pound on the door, yelling at her to open up. Stumbling on her feet, Shez tried to calm herself as she fell back against a tree. 

 

She thought she was ready for anything. Ready to do whatever it took to see her sister again. Yet all it took to make her panic was seeing her old friends…

 

“So you run away ag–” 

 

The sheer panic that flooded her mind the instant Epimenides spoke up felt like a bursting dam, a scream ripping its way out of her mouth as dark magic erupted from her body, rotting the trees and blackening the dirt around her. 

 

Shez trembled, her limbs shivering as she held her head, trying to fight down the mental distress that came with the sudden, overwhelming thought that Epimenides was going to murder her friends, that he would take control again and use her own body to hurt them–Then she noticed, out of the corner of her eye, the wraith in question.

 

And he was strangely limp. His eyes were blank, staring at nothing, and his mouth hung open as he floated there, as though he’d been knocked out. 

 

Shez blinked, then stared at him. He genuinely did look like he’d been knocked out. And as she watched, he just…faded, disappearing from view. “...uh…Ep? Epi? You…are you dead? I’m gonna be kinda disappointed if you’re dead because I really wanted to kill you myself and maybe get Arval back in the attempt? I was figuring it out, but, uh…hello? You there?”

 

The tension hadn’t completely disappeared from her body. She still felt rigid enough that it was starting to hurt, and her breathing wasn’t steady at all, but…but…but what? She…was she free?

 

She glanced down at herself, seeing the markings still on her. Which probably meant that he was still alive, or that he had lied when he said this was his power. Shez was really hoping it was the latter. He was a liar, so honestly, it being stolen power would make sense.

 

“...right. Right. Do I…talk to my friends? Because…what if he comes back? But also, they’re right there, I could just…fffh, damn it, this–Why are they here anyway?? I don’t…nnhhh…”

 

Right, she needed to figure something out. Even if they couldn't find her after she flashed away, she couldn't just–

 

"–surge of magic from over here!" And she couldn't help but stiffen, pushing back against the crumbling tree as she saw Lysithea and Kronya soon come into view. 

 

“Shez! There you are! Why are you running away from us?!” Lysithea called out, her brow furrowed in anger, “Where have you been anyway!? Were you really just here this whole–”

 

Then she paused when Kronya put a hand on her shoulder, the Agarthan stepping forward with a small frown.

 

And Shez…Shez had no idea what she wanted to say.

 

“...so, hey. I had no idea you were missing, but apparently you were,” Kronya began, her frown turning to a little smile as she seemed to relax, “And, uh…I guess you’re under arrest?”

 

“...what?”

 

Kronya glanced at Lysithea, who just gave her a genuinely baffled look in response. And Kronya apparently took that as agreement because she nodded. “Yup, you’re under arrest. Apparently you've been squatting without paying taxes for a few months, so…yeah." 

 

Shez frowned. "Why would I pay? It's my house.”

 

"Really? That shitty looking place is yours?" 

 

"Yes. It's where my mom raised me," Shez stated, annoyance cutting through her anxiety. 

 

"...ah. Well. Clearly we need to talk with the old guy. Right pipsqueak?" Kronya asked, looking at the mage to bail her out. 

 

"..." Lysithea let out a sigh, before walking up to Shez. She stayed silent as she stared at the purple-haired girl, then silently reached out. "Come on, I have some tea and food in my supplies." 

 

Shez stared at her hand. For a moment, a thought flashed through her brain of Epimenides suddenly seizing control right as she took Lysithea’s hand and ramming his sword through her chest. “...Alright. I could use some tea.”

 

She made no move to touch Lysithea. She just…shook her head, and Lysithea lowered her hand after a moment, frowning. The tense feeling didn't leave the air as the trio walked together back to Shez’s house. Though it almost left when Shez spotted her broken door, which had been knocked off its hinges. 

 

"Why?" 

 

"...You slammed the door on us and weren't answering," Kronya said, looking sheepish. 

 

"..." Shez let out a sigh, stepping inside, and picking up the door to try and put it back into place after Lysithea and Kronya entered. 

 

A few minutes later, the group was sitting at the table, having been joined by Leonie who had apparently been speaking with the village elder. The village elder was not invited in, particularly since Shez bluntly stated that she’d burn his house down the next time he tried to send people after her.

 

“Isn’t that kind of an overreaction?” Leonie had asked, “I mean, you are hiding out in a house that doesn’t–”

 

“He’s the one who threw me out of the village after my mom died,” Shez had replied.

 

“...Never mind then.” And now they were just kind of sitting around in awkward silence, waiting for the tea to heat up. “...so…what have you been doing these past few years?”

 

“Traveling. Killing people.” Shez paused. “From the Kingdom and the Principality, mainly. Plus bandits. And Almyrans, a couple times. Invading ones.”

 

“...okay then. And, uh…did you visit Captain Jeralt at all in that time?”

 

“No.” Shez’s response was blunt, clearly wanting the subject to be dropped, but her tone just made Leonie frown.

 

“Why not? You’re his daughter–”

 

“I nearly killed my sister and sent her to the fucking void. Don’t ask me to go back to him until I get her back.” 

 

“That’s heavy as hell. Leonie, stop talking to her,” Kronya ordered. Thankfully, the orange-haired mercenary seemed too taken aback by Shez’s answer to hear what Kronya said. 

 

"...So, you're that wandering soldier people have been talking about?" Lysithea asked. 

 

Shez shrugged. "I don't know what people are talking about, so I wouldn't know." 

 

"...Shez, have you kept contact with…anyone, at all, since the monastery?" 

 

"No. I…" Shez looked up at her friends, before grimacing at the image of Epimenides taking over and killing them. "I…I can't." 

 

“...jeez, you really feel guilty for what happened, huh?” Leonie commented, her frown more sympathetic now, “Shez, you don’t have to punish yourself–”

 

“Leonie, shush, you’re making it worse,” Kronya stated, before turning to look directly at Shez, “So, what happened?”

 

“Wh–Kronya, you can’t just ask her to relive what happened–”

 

“Shhh, I know what I’m doing,” Kronya said, holding up a hand to ward off Leonie while staring at Shez, “Well? I’ll share if you do.”

 

“...I got possessed by a shitty ghost and he made me try to kill Byleth,” Shez explained, trying to keep her voice steady, though her tone just sounded dead as a result, “Then he forced me to use a spell that sent her to some sort of void. I don’t know the specifics, but she and Rhea were sent there so hopefully those two have each other." 

 

"So the professor is still alive?" Lysithea asked.

 

"She has to be. There's no way she's dead." Shez stated, almost sounding desperate there. She took a breath, calming herself down. “I have a way to get to her. I just…I have a plan.”

 

“Cool, what is it?” Kronya promptly asked, looking very curious.

 

“…I…I need an Agarthan heart.”

 

“Oh. Not mine, right?”

 

“N-No?! No, never!”

 

“Good. I like Professor Byleth but I’m not going to die for her.”

 

"Wait, why do you need a heart?" 

 

"Cause our hearts are basically a chunk of magic, duh," Kronya said in response to Leonie. 

 

"So you'll use a heart for some type of ritual and save the professor?" Lysithea asked, trying to keep things on track. 

 

"As long as things work out. I haven't really been able to test it. I, uh, almost managed to, but things got too dangerous at the castle," Shez stated. 

 

"Right…" Lysithea sighed, before standing up. "Okay, we should shelve this conversation for tomorrow. It's late and you clearly need some rest." 

 

"That's what I was planning on getting," Shez mumbled, only to stiffen as Lysithea glared at her. 

 

"Leonie, Kronya, come on, we shouldn’t impose on Shez, we can sleep elsewhere tonight." 

 

"What? Hey, why do I have to go too??" 

 

"You're still technically a bandit, so listen to me or I really will arrest you! Now come on!" Lysithea ordered, grabbing onto Kronya and pulling her along. Not that she had any success in doing so until Leonie helped her out. 

 

Staying quiet, Shez watched the three of them leave, before letting out a sigh as she stared at her tea cup. Getting up, she walked upstairs, only to pause when she passed her mom's room. She placed a hand on the door, before continuing on into her room. Once inside, she slumped down against a wall, exhaustion hitting her as she found herself unwilling to get in her bed. 

 

It was quiet. 

 

For the first time in years, she didn't have to deal with some annoying voice in her head, and now the world was finally quiet… 

 

She felt tears prick her eyes, before rubbing them away, unwilling to break. She couldn't. Not yet. 

 

So focused was she on keeping her grip, she nearly missed the door to her room opening. Stiffening, she looked up to see Lysithea standing at her doorway. 

 

"...I talked with the village elder, he's not going to try and kick you out of here anymore," Lysithea stated, her eyes briefly glancing around the room. 

 

"Oh…thanks. That's really nice," Shez said, unsure of what else to say. The silence sat upon the two for a time, before Lysithea walked over, sitting down next to Shez, but leaving some distance between the two. 

 

"Have you been keeping up with your magic studies?" 

 

Blinking at the sudden question, Shez glanced at Lysithea. "Ah…yeah. I'm, uh…still not the best mage around, but I think I'm almost as good as you were back at the academy." 

 

"Someone thinks highly of herself, I see." 

 

"Eh…well, maybe not that great…s-so…how's your arm?" 

 

"Better. Took a few months to fully heal, but I can use it as easily as before," Lysithea said, raising the arm that had been broken in their last meeting. 

 

"That's good." She searched for something else to say. “...how are things going?”

 

“Well enough. I gave up my noble title.”

 

“You did?” Shez paused. “Uh, congratulations? That’s…something you wanted?”

 

“It is, yes. After everything that happened, my noble title was just a burden. It honestly feels much more freeing to be rid of it. Still, a part of me is bothered that House Phlegethon controls Castle Ordelia. It was my home, at one point, and it feels unpleasant knowing they’re using it to their own ends.”

 

“...well, uh…I was kind of planning to try going at them again, so…”

 

Lysithea paused, then furrowed her brow. “Shez. Did you just say you want to take Castle Ordelia single handedly?”

 

“...uh…I mean…I have, uh…done pretty okay with doing stuff like that before?”

 

“You’ve taken castles before.”

 

“...not exactly. I’ve taken forts though. By, uh, killing everyone inside. Honestly, I killed so many people that it permanently stained my sword red.”

 

Lysithea sighed. “Shez, that’s not something that can–”

 

Shez showed her the sword.

 

“...hm. That’s disturbing.”

 

“Yeah, I think I might’ve cursed it. Not sure how, exactly…also kind feels like I should name it something other than ‘Killing Edge’ because of it? LIke…Murder Edge.”

 

"...That's stupid." 

 

"What? No it's not. Murder is like, above killing right? So it makes sense." 

 

“Shez. That is stupid.”

 

“...” Shez crossed her arms over her chest, pouting. “I think it’s a great name…”

 

"Of course you do," Lysithea muttered, "Look, the point is I'm not letting you storm a castle on your own." 

 

"I can handle it," 

 

"It doesn't matter if you can." 

 

"Look I don't even need to take the entire thing I just need–" Shez stiffened as Lysithea grabbed her face, forcing the older girl to look at her. 

 

"We're helping you, got it?" 

 

"..." Shez felt a tightness in her chest as her body began to shake. She didn't even realize she had started to cry until Lysithea pulled away. 

 

"Shez? What's wrong?" 

 

"..." Shez shook her head, as she rubbed her eyes. "S-Sorry, just…that's the first time someone touched me in years. I…I'm good, I just–" 

 

She felt Lysithea wrap her arms around her, hugging her as tightly as the mage could. 

 

In that moment, feeling the first physical comfort she had felt in years, Shez couldn't help but cry. Unable to hold herself back any longer. 

 

She wasn't sure how long the two sat there, but by the end, Shez was exhausted, her eyes stinging from her tears. 

 

"Come on, you should get some rest," Lysithea encouraged, helping Shez stand up and guiding her to the bed. 

 

"...Thanks," Shez mumbled, practically collapsing on the bed. 

 

"Do not thank me. Just promise me you won't go off on your own," she requested.

 

“...I’ll try. I…I don’t want to be alone anymore…” Shez murmured in reply, exhaustion dragging her down into unconsciousness, where she dreamt of destroyed cities and people that died ages ago, their names lost to time and their faces long forgotten. All she knew was, as she awoke, that she was holding her Agarthan sword in her hand.

 

The fear that went through her in that moment saw her practically spring out of bed and rush out of the room, all exhaustion forgotten–Until she saw Lysithea, sleeping on her couch. Completely unharmed.

 

“...fhhhh…fuck…okay. Okay…” The blade was clean. She…wasn’t sure what that meant. She wasn’t sure why the sword was even out. Had she called it? Why? “...Epimenides? Are you there?”

 

No answer, aside from Lysithea stirring in her sleep and muttering a complaint about someone stealing her cake, before she settled back down.

 

“...huh. Alright. Okay.” She still wasn’t sure what any of this meant. All she knew was that she felt a strange sense, in the back of her mind, that this sword…belonged to her. And she knew its name. “...Rudra. Hm.”

 

For some reason, she found her gaze turning toward her mom’s room. She hadn’t gone in there in…she hadn’t gone in there at all, not since she got back. Other than just a cursory check to make sure nothing had broken, she hadn’t ever gone inside…And she felt herself walking over, opening up the door, and stepping inside.

 

She wasn’t sure why she thought there would be something crazy in here; her mom’s bedroom looked the same, untouched from all the years she’d been away…and kind of dusty. It felt sort of nostalgic though. She remembered her mom letting her sleep in here when she was little or if she felt sick or scared…

 

Shez took a little breath and brushed away the tears before they could really gather in her eyes. She really had been ignoring this place for far too long.

 

"..." Walking over to the bookshelf in the room, she grabbed a book and began to see what she could find. 

 

It was illuminating, in a sense. She didn't read deeply into the books she was reading, but she found various types. Books on how to care for the young, cookbooks filled with healthy recipes, and various other books that seemed more in line with someone trying to raise a child, rather than a mysterious mage who was on the run from the Agarthans. It made sense, in a way. Her mom had always been great, so knowing she just put her all into raising her…

 

Shez hugged a book to her chest. “I wish you were here…there’s so much I want to ask you…”

 

Setting the book down, she continued to search, making sure to be careful and not damage any of them. As she did, she couldn't help but pause as she pulled a book near the bottom out. Though she didn't focus on the book, but on something behind it. Frowning, she reached out, her fingers pressing against the wood, as she felt a slight give. It wasn't completely moving, but she could feel something was there… 

 

Taking a deep breath, she focused her magic in hand, before hearing a click, the wooden panel suddenly giving way as she found a small alcove hidden behind it. Inside was a single book, and a letter with a wax seal on it. 

 

Her fingers trembling, Shez reached out, grabbing the letter, and pulling it out. 

 

The seal was nondescript, nothing to signal who it could be from but…Shez knew who left it there. Taking a deep breath, she opened the letter, making sure to take care not to break it. 

 

"Hello, my darling daughter, 

 

I hope this letter finds you well. I'm not sure when you'll find it, if at all. As it stands, I am writing this while you are asleep so you will not even know it exists until you find it. 

 

Regardless, I felt it only appropriate to write this. I know not when it will be my time, but my illness is only getting worse, and I do not know how long it will be before I perish. It is almost silly to think about. Here I am, dying to a Fodlan disease, yet I cannot muster any hatred for them. All I feel is sorrow knowing I will not be here to see you grow. 

 

I do not know when you will find this letter. I hope it is not too long. I hope you will be well. I hope I get an opportunity to speak with you before my end but I am uncertain if I will be able to. I hope for a great many things, but most of all, I hope you will find happiness in this world we live in.

 

We are not from Fodlan. If I did not get a chance to tell you this, allow me to inform you of this fact now. You and I are from a nation that predates all others on this continent. We are from Shambhala. Our people are called Agarthan.

 

There is so much more I want to tell you. I wish I could have told you when you were an adult, as I planned. I intend to leave this letter with my notes. There will be things in there that may disturb you. I love you. I want you to know that I love you more than anything in this world. No matter what we were intended for, I love you. You are my sunlight. I wish I had more time with you.”

 

It had long since dried, but Shez could see stains on the letter, smudging the words near the end. She tried her best to keep her own tears from staining it, holding the letter close. She was careful with it; gentle, really.

 

Then she set it down in a faint sigh, then began to look through the book of her mother’s notes. It wasn’t a proper book; there was a cover and there were pages inside, but she quickly found that it wasn’t really written like a straightforward journal or narrative. The entries in it were a mix of notes, sketches, experiments, projects…it was surprisingly eclectic for what she knew of her mother, almost like she’d just taken everything she had and bound it together in one place.

 

There was some rhythm, as she seemed to put the older notes first. They seemed so different compared to the first letter she had received, notes on experiments written with no personal inflection. 

 

That all changed when she got to her notes on the vessel. 

 

Shez wasn't the first one. And she certainly wasn't the first one Periander worked on. Yet she was the first seemingly successful one. Periander noted how she had survived past her first year, which meant things were finally turning positive. 

 

And suddenly, there was an entry that was just a single line. 

 

The child smiled at me. 

 

Shez almost expected to see a follow up entry saying how Periander’s view had changed and she had to get the child out of there, or some kind of declaration of her intent to defect…but it just continued on for a while. There were more observations, more notes about how Shez was progressing. There were important things recorded, like when she started crawling and when she spoke her first word, but they were more like secondary observations. There was a mention of how she’d taken over the “vessel’s development” while the other researchers moved on to other projects. 

 

There was a timeline written out of what would be expected from Shez as she grew. How she’d be trained in combat and magic, how she’d be educated. There was a note that she would be expected to fight in a live combat exercise and would only be considered a success if she lived.

 

The words there were a little darker. Like Periander had been pressing down more firmly with whatever she was using to write.

 

The next entry Periander wrote was about starting her new life in a town she had stumbled upon. From then on her entries seemed to be more on her day to day life, speaking about how Shez had grown up, how even if it was just the two of them, it was the most fulfilled she had felt in her entire life. Shez tried not to cry at that, before she kept on reading.

 

On and on it went. Even when Periander noted her illness and how it grew worse, she would always make sure to write about Shez first and foremost. And eventually it came to an end, the last entry being about how she and Shez celebrated together, in honor of the day they arrived at the village. 

 

There was still more afterwards. Spells that Periander had put in great detail for Shez to train and study with. Locations of Agarthan bases were, so that Shez would know where to avoid. But the one thing that made Shez’s heart stop was the final page of the journal. 

 

The forbidden spell, Zahras. 

 

It came with a warning that Shez should only use it as a last resort. Utilizing the power of the void was dangerous, and the potential to be lost in it herself was way too high. Which actually meant it was perfect for Shez’s purposes…

 

She couldn't help but grin at the mention that the only one with the power to control the darkness was the Great Sage, Epimenides. 

 

“Shez? What are you doing in there?” Then Lysithea’s voice caught her attention, drawing Shez’s gaze over to the former noble in the doorway. 

 

"Figuring out how to save the day," Shez said, before moving over and hugging Lysithea tightly, "Thanks, Lys." 

 

“...ah…you’re welcome?” She wasn’t quite sure why she was being thanked or hugged, but…Shez gave nice hugs, so she leaned into it. It probably wasn't the right time to focus on how firm Shez felt, yet she also couldn't help but focus on that. 

 

Then she heard a scandalized gasp behind her and turned to see Kronya staring at the two of them. “You harlot! Is Leonie not enough for you!?”

 

“WHAT!?”

 

“Oh, you and Leonie are a thing?” Shez asked, looking at Lysithea with a mild curiosity, “Huh, guess that explains–”

 

“We’re not! Why–That’s not–We aren’t dating! At all!” Lysithea insisted, prompting a scoff from Kronya.

 

“Yeah, right, and you definitely don’t have a thing for strong, firm mercenary girls either, huh?”

 

"Sh-Shut up!" 

 

"Hey Lys, it's alright if you have a crush on Leonie. Though I think she has a thing for Lorenz, so you better hurry up." 

 

"I don't have a crush on her!" Lysithea almost shouted. 

 

"Sure you don't," Kronya said, clearly not believing her. 

 

"I'll prove it!" 

 

"And how are you going to do that?" Kronya asked, raising an eyebrow in a clear challenge. 

 

"Geh…" Lysithea glanced at Shez, before nodding, and grabbing her by the collar. Shez had a moment to widen her eyes, before she was pulled into a kiss. Lysithea wasn't exactly sure how long she was supposed to keep the kiss going, because she certainly wasn't going to make it just a peck and get mocked for it afterwards. 

 

It seemed Kronya decided it was long enough with how she yanked Lysithea away. The Agarthan glowered at the mage for a moment, before promptly pulling a stunned Shez into a deep, forceful kiss…which soon transitioned to her pushing Shez to the floor, their lips still locked together as Kronya pressed up indecently close to her crush.

 

“Ah, hey Lysithea. Is Shez up y–...” Leonie blinked, staring at the two girls tongue-wrestling on the floor, before looking at her friend, whose face was quite red at the moment. “...well, uh…sorry Lysithea, I guess you missed your shot?”

 

“Wh–No I didn’t, I kissed her first,” Lysithea insisted, frowning–

 

And Kronya immediately pushed herself up from her current make-out session, glaring at the white-haired girl, “The hell you did! I kissed her first!”

 

“No you did not–”

 

“Yes, I did! Three years ago, when I left! I kissed her first! Right Shez?”

 

Shez didn’t respond. “Bwuh.” No, wait, she did. She just didn’t respond intelligibly.

 

Lysithea rolled her eyes. "Oh sure, of course you did. Shez never said anything about that after you left!" 

 

"What? Why didn't you??" Kronya asked, turning in Shez who seemed to be staring off into the distance with a dazed look. 

 

"...I think you might’ve broken her,” Leonie pointed out, earning a frustrated noise from Kronya.

 

“Hey, Shez! Stop being broken! I need you to confirm that I claimed you first!” Kronya said, shaking Shez. 

 

"E-Even if you did kiss her, it's childish to think that means you claimed her!" Lysithea shouted. 

 

"Shut up, pipsqueak!" 

 

"Gh–Stop calling me that! I'm taller than you now!" 

 

"..." Leonie let out a sigh, before backing out of the room, and quietly closing the door behind her. She already had a long day waiting for her, she could feel it. 

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Finally good things are happening to Shez! Sure we might have made Shez cry a lot this chapter, but it was mostly cathartic!

Red: It's good to get those emotions out! Shez needed a bit to get herself together, otherwise, well...yeah, this probably would've gone to a bad place.

Indi: That it would have, but with the temporary reprieve she has, she might as well do the most she can.

Red: Yup yup. And we'll get see what else she can do with this reprieve, along with how temporary it might be, very soon.

Indi: That we will, but until then, hope you enjoyed!

A Rangale Reunion

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Shez was still feeling weird, for a lot of reasons. 

 

For one thing, Epimenides was still silent. She had no idea why he hadn’t come back yet, and she was positive he wouldn’t be gone forever, but for now, his absence was…surprisingly refreshing. She’d gotten used to his constant unpleasantness. Now that it wasn’t there…it was like a weight had been lifted.

 

For a second thing, she had her friends again. And two of them had crushes on her.

 

…She was going to focus on the part where they were around for the moment because she still wasn’t sure how to take that. She should probably talk to Lysithea and Kronya about…everything at some point, but at the moment, she was just processing a lot of emotions at once.

 

And traveling. She was also traveling at the moment, because apparently it would be a bad thing to stay in her house all the time. Which, well, she could always warp back, so traveling wasn’t that big of a commitment. Though, considering she was traveling towards Gloucester territory to talk to Count Gloucester, Lorenz, and the other people trying to retake Castle Ordelia, it was still kind of a commitment…

 

But those were complicated thoughts and she didn’t really want to think those at the moment, so she was distracting herself.

 

“Slaughter Edge,” she suggested.

 

“The Bloody Blade,” Kronya countered.

 

“Hm…Blood Edge?”

 

“Don’t rip me off. What about ‘The Crimson Carver?’”

 

“Oh, that’s neat. Hm…maybe ‘The Red Reaper’?”

 

“The Scarlet Slicer?”

 

“The Carnelian Cleaver…”

 

“The Vermillion Violator!”

 

“Eugh. That sounds wrong.”

 

“Why do I like her…” Lysithea muttered to herself, staring at the purple-haired idiot walking ahead of her.

 

"Well it could be worse," Leonie said, trying to comfort her. 

 

"How?" 

 

"You could have a crush on Kronya." 

 

"..." Lysithea let out a loud sigh. Hopefully this journey won't take too long…

 

Meanwhile, up ahead of them, Shez and Kronya were still debating potential sword names.

 

“Maybe I’m thinking about this the wrong way,” the purple-haired mercenary mused, “It’s a special cursed sword, so it needs something special to call it, like how the sacred weapons and relic weapons all have fancy names.”

 

“Oh yeah, those things…” Kronya shrugged. “I just call my dagger Athame.”

 

“Oh? What’s that mean?”

 

“Knife.”

 

“...seriously?”

 

“Well I guess it’s more like ‘ceremonial knife’ or ‘black knife’,” the redheaded Agarthan allowed, shrugging again, “Also, don’t the relic weapons have a bunch of different names? I know there’s that one lance thing that’s just ‘the lance of whatever’ and then there some type of hammer that’s just ‘the crusher’–”

 

“So I could call it something like ‘the carver’?”

 

“Sure, but why not add the ‘crimson’ part at that point? You might as well, right?”

 

“I guess…I just feel like it should be something special. You know, something that feels as unique as ‘The Sword of the Creator’.”

 

“Like that, huh? So what about ‘The Sword of the Destroyer’?”

 

“…maybe not that unique,” Shez muttered, before pausing when she noticed a flag in the distance, “Huh. Hey Lysithea, which crest is that?”

 

Lysithea paused, raising an eyebrow. “What in the world are you talking about–Huh?” Then her eyes widened and she quickly pushed past Shez and Kronya to stare at the lavender flag flying the Crest of Gloucester right above a banner of the Alliance. “What the–Is that the Gloucester camp!?”

 

“Is it?” Kronya asked, squinting at the distant flags.

 

“What? That can’t be right, we should be at least a couple days away from…” Leonie trailed off, spotting the flags too, and the fact that they were clearly flying above a fortified war camp, judging by the barricades and wooden walls set up around the area. “...what the hell…”

 

“Huh. Guess we took a shortcut,” Shez commented, shrugging while Lysithea and Leonie stared at her in open bafflement, genuinely wondering if their friend’s tendency to get lost had somehow translated into them somehow getting to the military camp way ahead of schedule. “Well whatever. Let’s go say hi!”

 

And so, off she went. And while the guards at the gate were understandably wary of unexpected travelers, Lysithea had a way with words that barreled through any objections and got them into camp pretty easily. The fact that she was the former heir of Ordelia and had the crest to prove it certainly made things easy.

 

And once inside, another familiar face looked quite happy to see them.

 

“Lysithea, Leonie! I cannot say I was expecting to see you two so soon! And–“ Lorenz froze when he spotted Shez, before a small, genuine smile came to the nobleman’s face. “My word…I…you look well, Shez.”

 

“…ah, screw it,” Shez decided, before heading over to the skinny noble and pulling him into a tight hug, “I missed you, buddy.”

 

“O-Oh, well, I–“ Lorenz didn’t seem to know what to do with his hands for the moment, and actually seemed relieved when Shez released him. “I must say, I didn’t expect such a display of affection.”

 

“Eh, it’s more like appreciation. I mean hell, Lysithea kissed me, so I figure a hug is fine.”

 

“She did?”

 

“She did, huh?” Leonie echoed, giving the blushing girl an amused glance, “You know, that doesn’t feel very fair to me. I didn’t even get a hug yet.”

 

“Oh, good point,” Shez allowed, before heading over to the redhead and fully picking her up in a hug, earning a startled laugh from her.

 

Lorenz, meanwhile, paused when he noticed the frowning fourth member of Lysithea’s group. “Oh, hello. May I ask who you might be, Miss?”

 

“It’s Kronya, we met, I was going by Emily then,” Kronya bluntly explained, before pausing, “Huh. You filled out.”

 

Lorenz blinked, trying to process all of that. “Pardon me?”

 

“You put on muscle. I remember you being lankier, like a tall stick.” 

 

He blinked again, his mind finally catching up enough to feel outraged. “A stick?! How did I look like a stick?!”

 

“Like I said, you were really lanky. You are good at tea parties though and it’s been a while since I’ve had some, so I’d be pretty happy if you invited me to one,” Kronya said, shrugging her shoulders. "Turns out I actually started enjoying the taste of the stuff, go figure." 

 

“...”

 

“...oh hey, it’s the glasses guy,” she noticed, walking past him and over to Ignatz, who blinked in confusion at seeing a strange cloaked woman approaching him.

 

"...Can someone please explain to me what's going on?" Lorenz asked, ignoring Kronya talking with Ignatz, who seemed confused and embarrassed at how she was complimenting him over no longer being a 'little geek'. 

 

"It's a long story, one we can get into once we finish planning things out," Shez said, as she grinned, "Congrats Lorenz, you're gonna help us take back Lysithea’s old home." 

 

It was a dramatic declaration, one befitting the Violet Demon’s return to the field.

 

“Er, yes? That’s why we moved our camp here.” And then Lorenz ruined it by giving her a confused look. “In fact, you would be helping us, if you were to consider how we were here first.”

 

“Oh so you did move the camp!” Leonie realized, looking relieved, “Man, I thought Shez managed to somehow shrink the distance between her village and the main camp.”

 

“How in the world would she do that?”

 

“I have no idea, I was just–”

 

“Can we just discuss how we are taking the castle back now?” Lysithea requested, prompting a pause from the pair of former Deer.

 

“Oh, yes, of course! Please, follow me!” And so, Lorenz led the way!

 

“...I was trying to do something there,” Shez muttered, before sighing and following after her pompous friend. Though she did make sure to at least wave at her other former classmate. “Ah, hey Ignatz.”

 

“Huh–Oh, hello Shez,” he greeted in reply, then looked back at Kronya again, “Er, now what was that about you being Em–...wait, hold on–”

“Wow, this all looks really fancy,” Shez commented, genuinely impressed as she looked around Lorenz’s big war tent, prompting a proud smile from the nobleman.

 

“Why thank you! I like to make sure my war tent is capable of accommodating anyone as needed, particularly–”

 

“Oh hey, grapes,” Kronya noticed, not paying attention to Lorenz at all while she went over to grab herself a snack.

 

“…it seems your manners have deserted you almost entirely after leaving the academy, Emily,” Lorenz noted, frowning at the Agarthan.

 

“Well yeah, I didn’t have to use them,” she replied without shame, “Also, call me Kronya, it’s my actual name. I mentioned that part, right?”

 

“You did introduce yourself as such, though you didn’t truly explain yourself.”

 

“Ah, it’s a whole thing. Should I tell everybody now or should I wait until the rest of the Deer show up?”

 

“I’m afraid most of our former classmates will not be attending this meeting,” Lorenz replied, before pausing, “Though, come to think of it, I suppose given there are six of us here, we actually do have most of the class present.”

 

“…so do I tell everyone now, or…?”

 

“Would it help with the upcoming battle if you told us now?” Lysithea asked.

 

“Probably not,” Kronya replied, shrugging.

 

“Then save it for later. We need to focus on what’s immediately relevant right now.”

 

“Speaking of, what’s the plan, Lorenz?” Leonie asked, catching the noble’s attention.

 

“Ah, I’m glad you asked! You see, my father and I are coordinating a two pronged attack on Castle Ordelia so that we might finally retake it–”

 

“I got that part,” she interrupted, “What’s the actual plan though?”

 

“Ah, right. You see, Castle Ordelia has been difficult to take due to a number of–”

 

“It’s full of demonic beasts and the Agarthans holding it are completely fine with letting them loose if anyone gets close,” Shez commented, earning a small frown from Lorenz that she didn’t notice as she thought about her recent infiltration attempt, “I didn’t get an exact count of all their beasts, but they have at least a dozen of the big walker types patrolling the outside of the castle and around eight flyers up on the ramparts, along with more inside. I’d say…you’d probably have to deal with twenty of the big walker types altogether. And considering they probably have a few more in reserve, I’d say you should assume there are at least ten flyers around the castle at any given time.”

 

“...” Lorenz looked over at Ignatz. “Could you write that down?”

 

“Huh? O-Oh, yes, of course!”

 

While his knight quickly got to work, Lorenz focused back on Shez, looking very intently at her. “How far did you manage to get into Castle Ordelia?”

 

“Ah…not that far into the main building, I think. I did manage to catch one of their bosses, at least. Do you know about Bias?”

 

“Oh of course that bitch is around here,” Kronya complained, earning a curious glance from Lorenz.

 

“I believe I might need some more context before I make any assumptions of who ‘Bias’ is meant to be. I would also like to know what your relation is to these ‘Agarthans’.”

 

“Ugh, right, let me explain real quick–” Shez paused when the flap to the tent was abruptly pushed open by a knight in Alliance yellow.

 

“Lord Lorenz, we have wyvern riders approaching from the west.”

 

“From the west? Hm…well, it seems we might have another guest arriving soon.” He sighed while his fellow former Deer just looked confused. Though that confusion quickly turned to exasperation for Lysithea when she spotted a certain white wyvern approaching.

 

“Of course it had to be Claude…”

 

“Hey there, everybody!” Claude called out, a wide grin on his face as he landed and promptly hopped off his wyvern, who chuffed when Claude gave it a pat on the head, “I hope I’m not interrupting the heartfelt reunion here.”

 

“You are not–Wait, how did you know there was even a reunion going on!?” Lorenz questioned, openly baffled.

 

“Well I couldn’t help but notice our Lady Lysithea’s distinct white hair, and once that was there, it was pretty easy to spot Leonie’s fiery hair,” he replied, grinning at the former noble and current mercenary, before he visibly stiffened…and a lazy smirk came to his face as he raised a hand in greeting. “Hey there, Shez. Good to see you.”

 

“...Jeez, nothing fazes you, huh?” Shez responded, feeling a small grin come to her face at her friend’s antics.

 

“What can I say? I like to take things as they come.” Then he glanced at Kronya. “Hey Emily, how are you doing?”

 

“Pretty good. Had some grapes.”

 

“Oh that’s bullshit!” Shez exclaimed, half-surprised and half-amused, “How in the world did you guess that she’s Em?”

 

Claude shrugged. “She’s the same height as before.” That, and it was the luckiest guess of his life, but he wasn’t about to say that. “So, are we holding a class reunion? Because it might take a bit to get Hilda, Raphael, and Balthus over here if it is. That and I still don't know where Cyril is." 

 

"Well, to be specific, we're preparing our assault on Castle Ordelia. We were also about to be informed by Shez on what exactly these Agarthans are." 

 

"Buncha underground assholes who hate you all," Kronya helpfully chimed in. 

 

"...Well, she's not wrong. I don't really know the specifics, mostly because the only guy I know who knows anything is a completely untrustworthy asshole, but apparently they're a group of people who fought against the goddess. After losing, they apparently hid underground throughout Fodlan," Shez explained. 

 

"Hm…well, that's both good and bad news. Good in that we finally know for sure what we're up against, but bad in that we don't know where they are," Claude muttered. 

 

"Well, I actually do," Shez responded, before taking a notebook out of her pack, "My mom left me this apparently. It's got a bunch of info, including where the Agarthan’s bases are!" 

 

"..." Claude couldn't help but stare at the notebook, and he was sure everyone else was as well. "...Do you mind if I borrow that?" 

 

"Yes. I'll point out on a map where the bases apparently are." 

 

"Aw, come on Shez, not gonna let your dear old friend check it?" Claude asked, giving her a wink, "If you don't I might just have to sneak it off you later." 

 

"..." Shez took a deep breath in, before laughing as she put the book away, "Goddess, I can't believe I missed how much of an asshole you are." 

 

“So should I take that–”

 

“Don’t push it. I can and will beat up anyone who takes this without my permission.”

 

“I’ll stab them,” Kronya added, offering her support and smirking smugly at Lysithea, who bristled.

 

“Can we get back to the topic at hand?” the former noble requested, frowning.

 

“Ah, right, let’s do that,” Shez agreed, nodding, “Okay, so, starting from the top…”

 

And so, the next few minutes were spent getting everyone caught up on the basics of the Agarthan people, their apparent cultural grudge against the goddess herself and the church as a whole, and who the leaders were. Which did answer a lot of questions for Claude, considering he still hadn’t known for sure who these “cultists” that hated the church were, and certainly explained some things about Shez and Emily/Kronya.

 

“Ah, I see, so then this Bias woman is the Red Mage!” Lorenz remarked after Shez explained the whole deal with the Agarthan’s “sage of fire” and how she’d infiltrated, then later invaded, the monastery.

 

That made Shez blink. “The Red Mage?”

 

“Yes, I know, it’s not a very impressive name, but while I put forth ‘The Crimson Sorceress’, Hilda insisted it was too ‘wordy’–”

 

“It is kinda wordy,” Leonie commented in good humor, “Though to answer the question, she’s one of the more dangerous people who have been causing problems in the Alliance. A really powerful fire mage whose burned entire battalions, if the rumors are true.”

 

“No, they are accurate,” Lorenz noted, frowning, “She’s remarkably dangerous and we’ve had her as a priority target for a while now, alongside The Black Knight and The Flame Emperor.”

 

Shez blinked, genuinely surprised by that last one. She’d never actually encountered the guy that gave her sister trouble, and the last she saw, the guy in question, assuming the weirdo in armor at the monastery invasion had been the Flame Emperor, wound up getting killed by Epi. So, odds were, someone else could have taken up the mantle–

 

“You mean Edelgard?” Kronya asked, an eyebrow raised.

 

The silence in the tent was deafening, though it was also short-lived, broken before its time by Shez face-palming. “Of course she is…”

 

“What?” Lorenz asked after a moment, looking genuinely confused, “No, the…right, I realize where there might be some confusion, but the Flame Emperor is a mercenary, or at least we presume he is a mercenary, working for the Principality. He may be an Agarthan, now that we are more aware of that faction, but I assure you, he isn’t the actual emperor. Plenty of bandits like to use royal titles for themselves and that doesn’t mean they are actual royalty.”

 

“Right, I know that. I also know the Flame Emperor is Edelgard,” Kronya replied, “It’s the identity she wore when she was helping us infiltrate the monastery.”

 

"Wait, seriously?" Leonie blinked, before trying to connect the dots. "Edelgard… I know she's the Emperor now, and she can use fire magic but…no, that can't be it, that's too stupid, right?" 

 

“...I called it,” Claude said, nodding to himself.

 

“You did not,” Lysithea retorted, giving him an annoyed glare.

 

“Nah, I absolutely knew it.”

 

"Wait, you knew that the entire time and didn't say anything??" Shez asked, bewildered.

 

“Well, not the entire time, but I figured it out at some point.”

 

“Was that point two seconds ago when Kronya said it?” Lysithea questioned, openly annoyed.

 

“I’m pretty sure it was longer than two seconds ago that she spoke up. Still, I guess I should assume from your reaction, Shez, that you just realized it now?” he asked, grinning over at her, “You seemed pretty exasperated there.”

 

“Ah…well, yeah, I do feel kind of dumb now. Edelgard confessed to me that she had to help the Agarthans for reasons, it was a whole thing–”

 

“She did!? Then shouldn’t we–” Lorenz began before Shez held up a hand.

 

“They killed her entire family except for her dad, so I decided to give her a pass. She also fought them at the monastery, which probably means they’re not allies. Which raises some big questions about what she’s doing working for them again.”

 

“Uh, I don’t think that makes sense,” Leonie noted, frowning, “I’m not sure how to take the whole ‘she was working with those people’ thing–”

 

“What do you mean ‘those people’?” Kronya complained, frowning at her, which she ignored.

 

“–but she’s been in Adrestia for the past few years fighting a war on two fronts against the Kingdom and the Principality. I don’t think she could be doing that and popping up in random places across the Alliance for the past few months.”

 

“Oh, so it’s a recent thing?” Shez asked, frowning.

 

“Indeed, it is,” Lorenz spoke up, still frowning thoughtfully, though he shook his head, “The Flame Emperor has only been sighted in the past six months though his preceding reputation for infiltrating the monastery has bolstered the threat he presents. Or, well, she presents?”

 

“We don’t actually know who this new Flame Emperor is, or if they even are Edelgard,” Claude noted, “Though having testimony that she actually helped the Agarthans infiltrate the Church is an interesting tidbit…”

 

Shez frowned at her friend’s calculating tone, before pausing when she noticed Lysithea being strangely quiet. She moved over to the mage, leaning in and speaking in a low tone. “Hey, you okay?”

 

“...I believe I am.”

 

“...Did you know about, uh…?”

 

“I did not, no. I am…considering how I feel.”

 

“Right, yeah.” Shez held out her hand, then smiled slightly when Lysithea took it. She led the shorter girl out of the tent and found a place by some boxes to sit down. “So, ah…do you want to talk about things?”

 

Lysithea raised an eyebrow. “‘Things’?”

 

“Yeah, things in general. I don’t know if you want to talk about the Agarthan stuff, so I figure we can leave it open for anything you might want to talk about.”

 

“…You truly are ridiculous, Shez. And I missed having you around.”

 

"I missed being around you too," Shez responded, a sad smile on her face, "I'm sorry I was away for so long, but I swear, if it wasn't for Epimenides, I would have come to find you. After all, a student needs her teacher, right?" 

 

“Hmph. Well…if you intend to still learn from me, I suppose I could teach you some of what I’ve learned over these past few years. Though I imagine you must have improved as well.”

 

“Eh…well, I’ve definitely gotten better at killing people…oh, hey, actually–” Shez pulled out her mother’s journal, a smile coming to her face as she moved close to Lysithea. “Here, my mom put a lot of spell stuff at the end of her notes here. Do you think you could help me figure it out?”

 

“...you would trust me with your mother’s work?”

 

“Well yeah, of course. I trust you.”

 

Lysithea stared at Shez for a moment, before abruptly hugging the taller girl, earning a surprised noise from her.

 

“O-Oh, uh…well, I guess we can start by hugging,” she murmured, before smiling slightly as she returned Lysithea’s hug. “...I really have missed you.”

 

“I know that.”

 

“Well, I gotta make sure you know.”

 

“Mmf. You truly are a ridiculous woman,” Lysithea mumbled into Shez’s chest, continuing to hold her tightly. “You are very lucky I like you.”

 

That brought a small smile to Shez’s face. “Yeah. I know I am.”

Chapter End Notes

Red: Hello everybody! Your word of the day is: Rangale.

Indi: Feel free to study while Shez catches up.

It's Hard to Break a Heart

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

“You know, when you said Ignatz made some pictures of our enemies to help with, uh…what was the word?” Shez asked, though she didn’t avert her gaze from the ‘pictures’ in question.

 

“Visualization,” Lysithea answered, also staring at Ignatz’s work.

 

“Right, visualization. So yeah, when you said that, I thought you meant they’d be sketches or ink prints, sort of like what you’d see on a wanted poster. Not full of paintings.”

 

Because those were indeed full paintings in front of their group, one for each of the “top three”. One displayed a knight in black plate armor with curled ram horns on his helm, wielding a three-pronged lance wreathed in darkness; the second showed a mage with a crimson bird’s mask over her face and robes that were a perfect match for Bias’s, her hands gathering flames at her palms; and the last was of a very familiar armored individual, the white mask-like faceplate standing out to everyone who had seen it before.

 

A scarlet axe was held in one hand and a shield in the other, and Shez felt a faint shiver as she stared into its empty eyes. “Alright, that’s seriously impressive, but also really creepy, Ignatz.”

 

“O-Oh, um, sorry?” the nearby knight apologized.

 

“No, it’s good. Just…it’s not creepy that you can do this, I’m still impressed, I’m just saying the face here looks really creepy. Does it really look like that? I didn’t see it for that long at the monastery.”

 

“Yep, it looks exactly like that,” Leonie confirmed, “And I have to say, it makes a weird amount of sense that it apparently started as Edelgard’s disguise. Sort of like how Jeritza turning out to be the Death Knight just made sense.”

 

"Oh yeah, speaking of, who exactly knows about her being the Flame Emperor?" Claude asked from his place over by the war map, "Aside from Hubert anyways." 

 

"Well, if she hasn't told the Black Eagles, then the only one who probably knew was Byleth." 

 

"Professor Byleth knew?" Lorenz inquired, also standing by the war map.

 

"Yeah, apparently Edelgard told her back before the ball at Garreg Mach. So if nothing else, if Byleth is willing to trust her I'll give her the benefit of the doubt. Especially since Rhea is a bigger threat to her." 

 

"Hm? Wait, why would Lady Rhea be a threat?" Ignatz asked, sounding very curious. 

 

"Because she wants to sacrifice Byleth to bring back the goddess." 

 

“...Oh. I see.” Ignatz blinked. “I’ll admit, I didn’t expect that answer.”

 

“Yeah, it’s kinda crazy.”

 

“Hm. So, hey, quick question,” Claude spoke up, “Does that whole ‘sacrifice Professor Byleth to bring back the goddess’ thing have anything to do with the group of crazed knights squatting in the Red Canyon that claims they saw the goddess descend three years ago?”

 

“...there’s a bunch of what?” Shez asked, before pausing when Lorenz made an annoyed noise.

 

“Ah, of course, the ‘Knights of Reclamation’. A group of true lunatics who were already disavowed by the remnants of the Knights of Seiros, particularly given they’ve taken to raiding supply lines.”

 

“They’ve been raiding you guys?? Wait, doesn’t that make them bandits?”

 

“In a sense,” Claude agreed, shrugging, “The thing is, they’re well-armed and armored, and they fight against the principality’s forces, so we’ve been tolerating them.”

 

“Even though they’re raiding supply lines?”

 

Lorenz grimaced. “Well, I suppose it’s less ‘raiding’ and more just ‘stealing from’, but even if they make sure not to harm anyone, they are still robbing necessary supplies from us to support themselves instead of properly joining with the remaining Knights of Seiros.”

 

“Oh, yeah, that’s also a thing,” Shez noted, “What do you mean the Knights of Seiros are still around?”

 

"Well, it's mainly the remnants of the knights who tried to take back Castle Ordelia back before everything went bad, but they're still calling themselves that." 

 

"Wait, so Alois and Shamir are okay?" 

 

"And Catherine." 

 

"...Well I'm glad Alois and Shamir are doing fine. Where are they anyways?" 

 

“Shamir should be with my father right now,” Lorenz answered, “She has been invaluable in facing off against the demonic beasts that make up Phlegethon’s forces. As for Alois, he has essentially stepped up as the captain of the true Knights of Seiros while Jeralt is busy in Adrestia. Speaking of, we have attempted to make contact with your father, but there have been some difficulties due to the Principality intercepting our messengers, so I apologize if it may take some time to get in touch with him.”

 

“Oh, yeah, uh, that’s fine, I get it, things are tricky these days,” Shez responded, trying not to sound too awkward.

 

“So back to the main point, it sounds like we’re going to have to deal with the Red Mage, also known as Bias, if we want a shot at taking Castle Ordelia,” Leonie brought up, drawing everyone’s attention back to the matter at hand.

 

“Ah, yes, she might be a problem,” Lorenz agreed, nodding thoughtfully, “If fortune favors us, she may be drawn towards my father’s forces. He and Shamir are intending to take the majority of our army into combat against the demonic beasts while my battalions instead aim to take this fortress here–“ He pointed to a small figure of a fort set on the map. “–which, thanks to Shez, we have confirmed is indeed an Agarthan outpost.”

 

“It was my mom’s work, not mine,” Shez demurred.

 

“Either way, it is very helpful. As you all likely know already, Castle Ordelia has been fortified heavily these past few years. In its early days, when the Principality was established and the traitors of Leicester and Adrestia joined forces, there was a steady stream of supplies sent to the castle House Phlegethon now occupies. However, thanks to my and my father’s efforts–”

 

“Plus all the soldiers under your command,” Leonie commented.

 

“Ah, yes, of course, we cannot forget their valiant efforts either! It was thanks to all of us that we gradually struck down their supply lines and successfully drove them into the corner that they now find themselves in. However, despite our efforts to essentially starve them out, House Phlegethon hasn’t broken yet, which is what led us to believe they may have ways of getting supplies into the castle without detection.”

 

“So you think this fort has a secret tunnel in it then,” Claude noted, prompting a small frown from Lorenz.

 

“Well…yes, essentially.”

 

“Wouldn’t it make more sense for their supply line to be coming from the south?” Lysithea pointed out, an eyebrow raised, “If their supplies are coming from what used to be Empire territory, it wouldn’t make sense for a more northward fort to be where they smuggle it in from.”

 

“Unless they’re not using it to smuggle food,” Shez noted, frowning thoughtfully, “They need people to make demonic beasts. It wouldn’t be impossible for this to be where they’re sending them.”

 

“...well that’s a morbid thought,” Leonie muttered.

 

“Not an inaccurate one though,” Lysithea remarked.

 

“Still, it doesn’t sound like a bad idea to at least check it out,” Shez continued, “Either there is a tunnel or isn’t, but either way, we’ll have taken one of their outposts and we can use it as a staging point to invade the fuckers.”

 

“That isn’t quite how I would put it, but you grasp the spirit perfectly!” Lorenz said with a grin, “Now, shall we begin planning our attack? I would prefer to be ready as soon as possible so we can schedule the attack to line up with my father’s offense.”

 

Shez raised her hand. “Could we do it today?”

 

“What? Ah…well, I wanted to plan ahead–“

 

“ Could we do it today?” Claude echoed, raising an eyebrow at the noble, who immediately straightened at the challenge in his rival’s voice.

 

“We can and we will!” Lorenz declared, before promptly pushing his way out of the tent, “MAKE YOURSELVES READY, SOLDIERS! TODAY IS THE DAY WE SHALL SEIZE THAT FORT!”

 

“Wow. He gets loud when he’s being commanding,” Kronya noted, before glancing at Leonie, “Lucky you.”

 

“…Yeah, I don’t know what that’s supposed to mean.”

 

“It means what it means.”

 

"Alright guys, I hope you're ready to fight. And remember, try to capture at least one of these guys alive, if possible," Shez said before Leonie could respond. "If all goes well, then we'll have some amazing back up for when we take the actual castle!" 

 

“We will? Who?”

 

Shez beamed. “The absolute best back-up we could ever ask for.”

The fort wasn’t important enough to have a fancy name. It was just an outpost in a strategically important place for Ordelia territory, nothing that special, which was what made it very noticeable that it had a lot more personnel than a fort of its size should.

 

And while it was a decent fort that would probably hold strong against most invading enemies, at least long enough for it to send out messengers for reinforcements, it wasn’t prepared for someone who could warp with a thought like Shez.

 

“So why do they have a fort this far north anyways?” Kronya asked while slitting the throat of one of the guards on the wall, glancing over at Shez, “Wouldn’t they want their defenses pointed at the empire?”

 

“Sure, but you never know who could get around them,” Shez replied, weaving around the defenders and cutting or stabbing straight through them once she saw any openings, “And besides, Leicester’s full of backbiting nobles. Putting a fort pointed towards their neighbors is just smart.”

 

“Huh. Good to know.” With that, she stabbed another guy in the eye, before flipping over him and stabbing her tails through the set of guards trying to cut down Shez, ending the fight with three bloody impalements.

 

"There we go." Leaning out over the wall, Shez waved over to where the rest of the group was, before tossing the rope ladder she was given so they could climb up. 

 

"So, I saw that you hugged Lysithea," Kronya commented.

 

"...uh, yeah. Is now the time to talk about that?" Shez asked, glancing over towards the group approaching. 

 

"Well, I figure while we have some privacy. Look, I'm not going to say some stupid shit like it's me or her, I just want to know if you like me like you like her." 

 

"Ah…well, I dunno. Honestly, I didn't think I'd ever get to meet up with any of you guys again, let alone anyone else, so…I just never really thought about that stuff," Shez looked away, a bit embarrassed, "But…I do want to spend more time with you." 

 

"...Hm," Kronya frowned for a moment, before nodding, "Fine, you belong to me, and she belongs to you." 

 

Shez blinked. “Uh…hang on, what?”

 

“It works perfectly, like a natural hierarchy. I am on the top, you are beneath me, and she is beneath you. I don’t have to touch her, and yet it stays stable.”

 

“...that’s not how relationships work. Also why would you be on the top?”

 

“Because I have more kills than you,” Kronya stated with a teasing tone as she promptly stabbed her tails through the faces of three guards who’d gotten into her range. 

 

"Wha– Hey that's not fair!" 

 

"Heh, not my fault you're so slow," Kronya teased as Leonie exited the gatehouse.

 

“Alright you two, stop flirting. I’ve got the gate open, everybody else should be pushing in now.”

 

“We’re not–Wait, shit, right!” Shez quickly broke off from Kronya, earning a small pout from the Agarthan, and leapt from the wall to join with the main force assaulting the fort. 

 

Plenty of black-clad soldiers stood in their way, but with Lorenz’s cavalry and Claude’s support from the air, the enemy soon found their defenses breaking down in a bloody slaughter. Not that the Deer actually wanted it to be a full slaughter; the problem was, none of the enemy Agarthans were willing to surrender.

 

"Glory to Agartha!" A mage yelled, attempting to cast a miasma on Shez while her back was turned only to receive an arrow to the arm. Screaming out in pain, he lifted his other arm to try and cast again, only for his arm to get lopped off as Shez spun around. 

 

“Yeah yeah, glory to whatever,” Shez complained, irritated, “Now how about you–“

 

At that exact moment, darkness burst out from the mage, a pair of glowing “eyes” marking a Death Γ that the Agarthan cast on himself. As one might expect, he immediately dropped down dead, earning a grimace from Shez.

 

“Well shit, that’s…inconvenient,” she muttered, before shaking it off and trying to get back into the fight. She just needed to take one alive so she could rip their heart out and… Eesh, that’s a gruesome thought. Could I really tear out someone’s–No, stop, don’t think about that! Think of it as getting Byleth back! You’ve killed hundreds, getting squeamish now is stupid! Just focus!

 

And she promptly did exactly that, getting fully focused on the task at hand and cutting down everyone in the way between her and her friends taking the outpost! It’s just that she only wound up realizing that she’d already killed every Agarthan present after they’d taken the base. Herself and Kronya excepted, of course.

 

“....ah, dammit.”

 

Huffing, she wiped some blood off her face before she marched back to her friends, who didn't seem to have much luck either. 

 

"Jeez, these guys seem to care more about what's going on than that Bias bitch," Shez muttered while Kronya pulled her dagger out of a corpse on the floor.

 

"Well in that case, I guess you'll be using Bias to save the professor." 

 

"Assuming she doesn't fight to the death to spite you," Lysithea pointed out. 

 

“Ugh, she would…I’m not sure why these guys are so set on dying for their cause anyway. You’d think some of them would have self-preservation,” Shez remarked.

 

“You weren’t raised in Shambhala,” Kronya pointed out, “I wouldn’t be surprised if Myson or Cleobulus have been telling them to die before allowing themselves to be captured.”

 

“Hm. It sounds like the lower ranks are more zealous about their ‘cause’ than their leaders,” Lysithea noted, which got Kronya to immediately shake her head.

 

“No, the leaders are just as zealous. Everyone in Shambhala is raised to hate the Fell Star and see the people of Fodlan as beasts and vermin. You could probably make the servants surrender, if just because they weren’t built for fighting, but the minions will fight ‘til they die, and the leaders will just run away while ordering everyone else to die for them." 

 

"Well, as long as we can get one of them, I don't care who we get," Shez huffed, before turning to Lysithea, "So, any idea on how this fort connects to the castle?" 

 

"I've never been down here, but…" Lysithea frowned, as she remembered unpleasant memories, "...There's probably something in the dungeons, if it's anything like the castle." 

 

"Oh?” Claude glanced over, "Did our young mage spend a lot of time playing down there?" 

 

"...Yeah, playing, sure." She shook off whatever thoughts were going through her head, focusing again. “Let’s go investigate. We need to hurry.”

 

"Hey Claude, bit of advice," Shez said, slinging an arm around his shoulder as Lysithea began to lead the forces to the dungeon, "Don't tease her about this stuff, got it?" 

 

“Hm…sounds like there’s a story there,” he commented, which earned a frown from Shez.

 

“Don’t poke at her either. If she wants to tell you, she’ll tell you.”

 

“Knowing her, that means I’ll never get to hear what her story is.”

 

“Then just deal with that. You don’t need to know everything,” Shez said, before glancing up as Lorenz called out from ahead of them.

 

“We’ve found a hidden passageway!" Waving them over, Lorenz stood by a wall that had shifted open, stretching out into the darkness. 

 

"Alright, so who's going in first?" Leonie asked. 

 

"Huh? Why don't we all go?" Kronya asked in return. 

 

"Because we need to ensure this does connect to the castle. As such a vanguard will go in and see where it leads, before returning for the rest of us so we can synchronize our attack with my father's forces,” Lorenz explained.

 

"Which is why I am going,” Lysithea spoke up, “I'm the one that's most aware of Castle Ordelia’s layout, so I will be able to tell if we do end up there."

 

"In that case, I'm going too! We might end up catching an Agarthan or two off guard enough that I can actually grab one," Shez said, volunteering after Lysithea.

 

"Then I'm going too, since I'm the top," Kronya stated. 

 

“The what?” Leonie asked while Ignatz noticeably stiffened beside her.

 

“A-Ah, I don’t think that’s an entirely appropriate topic right now, Emily–Ah, Kronya-“

 

“So what are you even on top of?” Leonie questioned, ignoring him.

 

“The hierarchy, duh. I’m on top, Shez is in the middle, Lysithea is below her.”

 

“That’s inane,” Lysithea remarked, exasperated.

 

“Indeed,” Lorenz agreed, nodding, “Of the three of you, Lysithea is from a major noble household–“

 

"I already renounced my title." 

 

"Yes, I am simply saying even a former noble has a higher standing than those who never were. No offense intended, of course." 

 

"Right, this is getting–" 

 

"Then make me a noble," 

 

"Excuse me?" Lorenz asked, a bit surprised by Kronya's demand. 

 

"You can do that right? Ennobling me, that's the word right?" Kronya asked, before thinking. "Actually, since Lysithea isn't keeping her castle, I can have it right?"

 

“What?!” Lysithea practically screeched, “You–Are you seriously trying to take my home right after we get it back?!”

 

“Uh…yeah? You don’t want it, right?”

 

“I–Y-You still can’t just take it!”

 

“Give it to me then.” 

 

"I'm not doing that!" 

 

"See Shez? This is why I'm clearly the better option, she doesn't even want to give us her castle." 

 

Shez blinked. "Wait, why am I getting involved?" 

 

“Good question. Here’s a better one,” Claude said as he poked his head out from the passageway, “Why are you chatting when we should be investigating?”

 

“...Good point.”

 

With that, a squad of Deer promptly entered the tunnel presumably leading towards Castle Ordelia, with Shez taking the lead. Lysithea came with her, of course, which meant Leonie and Kronya had to come with, the former because Lysithea was still her employer while the latter was insistent on getting her castle, and Lorenz insisted on leading the squad, so Ignatz came along too. And of course, Claude was already in the passageway to begin with so…

 

…Hang on…didn’t we just wind up bringing everyone? Shez wondered to herself while holding up a torch to light the way. As she questioned this, Shez kept looking forward, her eyes and the marks on her skin glowing in the darkness of the tunnel. 

 

"Based on the direction, it seems we truly are going towards the castle. We'll likely end up needing to time our assault with the outside forces to catch those inside off guard completely," Lysithea said as she walked beside Shez, her voice carrying through the tunnel.

 

"Is that so?" came a voice up ahead of them, making the group stiffen while Shez summoned her sword in her free hand, getting ready to fight. 

 

Her grip on her sword tightened once she registered the familiar sight of a bird-masked mage dressed in red. "What are you doing down here?" 

 

"Please, once I got a report that the fort was getting assaulted, it was more than obvious what you were planning," Bias taunted, flanked by two guards in black armor.

 

"And you came down with only two guys? Seems kinda dumb to me," Claude pointed out, bow at the ready and an arrow in hand.

 

"Oh yes, because bringing a large group into an enclosed space is such a good idea. Especially in a tunnel that could collapse from a single explosion," Bias retorted, a ball of flame forming in her hand.

 

“That would kill you too!” Leonie shouted, though it just earned a chuckle from the Agarthan mage.

 

“Then I’ll just have to be careful, now won’t I?”

 

“Hmph. Then we shall simply have to–” Lorenz began, before pausing when Kronya darted past him, “Wha–Wait–!”

 

But the Agarthan assassin didn’t listen, instead using her tails to spring forward so she could plunge her dagger straight into Bias’s chest. Unfortunately for her though, one of the knights stepped in the way, catching her blade on his shield and shoving her back, though she landed on her feet.

 

“Well would you look at that…” Bias murmured, pushing past the knight that just saved her.

 

“Ah–Lady Bias, you shouldn’t–”

 

“Shut up. So you’re still alive, puppy. I thought for sure you would have gone down trying to kill your way out of the monastery.” The sage removed her mask, letting Kronya see her smile and the other Deer see her burns. “I have to say…I’m glad I was wrong.”

 

“Why's that? Did you want to kill me yourself?” Kronya questioned, glaring at her former superior.

 

“That’s a cruel thing to ask. Though…if it came down to it, I really might have. That professor of yours, the Fell Star…I was planning to use you as a hostage against her. But then, I planned a lot of things.” Bias tilted her head. “And now you’ve joined up with the broken vessel. So I have to ask…what exactly are you two planning?”

 

"Why would I tell you?" 

 

"Think of it as catching up. After all, we did work together for some months. If I'm being sentimental I will admit I enjoyed your company more than I do those at the castle." 

 

"If you're feeling that kind, then you better surrender. It would make taking you alive a lot easier," Shez said, not lowering her guard as her eyes stayed on Bias. 

 

"Hm? You need me alive?" Bias seemed to think for a moment. "Fishing for information are you? Or do you think taking me hostage would make Myson falter?" 

 

"As if we need that! Besides, your two lackeys here will work just as well!" Kronya shouted, ready to strike. 

 

"They would?" Bias seemed to pause, the gears in her head turning, "...You want to perform the forbidden spell." 

 

“Ah–“ Kronya glanced at Shez, unintentionally confirming things for Bias.

 

“So that’s it then…are you hoping you can get the Fell Star back? You know it’s a one way trip, don’t you? No one ever escapes the void of Zahras.”

 

"Not even the one who created it?" Shez asked, glaring at Bias. 

 

"..." Bias's lips twitched, "So you've accepted his power? Or perhaps you tore it out of his hands? Do you truly think you can do what the Fell Star or her spawn can't?" 

 

"Only one way to find out." 

 

"..." 

 

Silence fell upon those in the tunnel. No one said a word as Shez and Bias locked eyes, instead just waiting for what signal would set off the building sense of impending violence. 

 

Seeing her lips twitch again, Shez prepared herself for whatever condemnation Bias was about to say. How she was being idiotic, that she might as well die to save herself the time. 

 

What she didn't expect was for Bias to begin cackling. 

 

Her laughter echoed out all around them, bouncing off the walls of the tunnel, manic and loud. Nobody made a move. They just stared at the cackling sage who had just completely dropped her thin veneer of sanity.

 

Then the laughter finally petered off, and Shez felt herself tense when Bias grinned at her. “That…I like that. That’s a good attitude to have.

 

She straightened, her grin still wide. “I’ll see you at the castle. You’d better give me a good show.”

 

“Wait, Lady Bias, shouldn’t we–“ one of the knights began to say, before Bias quite casually put a hand on his chest and caused him to burst into flames.

 

The sudden blaze made everyone stumble back, caught off guard by the bright flames and sharp smell of boiling metal. The knight didn’t even have a chance to scream before smoke filled the tunnel, obscuring their sight.

 

“Try not to suffocate!” Bias called back to them, her voice taunting, “And enjoy your practice dummy!”

 

A thud caught Shez’s attention, making her glance down to see the second knight unconscious. 

 

"And make sure to give your sister my regards~!" 

 

“Shez, what in the world is she talking–”

 

“No time!” Claude interrupted, speaking over Lorenz and sounding uncharacteristically serious, “We need to get out of here before that smoke chokes us!”

 

“Ah, yes, good point–Everyone, retreat! We need to let the tunnels clear before we–Kh-”

 

“Stop talking in the smoke!” Leonie ordered, before grabbing Lorenz by the back of his armor and pulling him back with the rest of the retreating Deer, all while Shez found herself staring at the armored Agarthan on the ground in front of her.

 

“...right. Figure it out afterward,” she muttered to herself, before grabbing the knight and hoisting them up.

 

It wasn’t that difficult to carry the Agarthan, so Shez wasn’t sure where this strange, heavy feeling was coming from…

“So, getting Teach back involves ripping out this guy’s heart, huh?” Claude asked, summing up Shez’s past few minutes of attempting to explain just why she needed to take an Agarthan prisoner.

 

"Pretty much. I don't know if this plan will work, but it's my best shot at saving Byleth," Shez responded, staring into the cell they had tossed the unconscious prisoner in, "And the sooner, the better." 

 

“I see. And the guy needs to be alive for it?”

 

“...yeah.” Shez shrugged. “It’s not like I haven’t killed people before.”

 

"So, when are we going?" 

 

"We? Who said you're going too?" 

 

"Well the last time you disappeared, you were gone for three years, and it wouldn't hurt to have Teach owe me one," Claude said, a smirk on his face. 

 

"And the people here are going to need every person they have to take the castle back, since I doubt Bias is just gonna twiddle her thumbs after what happened."
