“Isn’t that a better argument for why you should put off going to grab Teach until after we take the castle?” Claude raised his hands when Shez immediately glared at him. “I’m just saying, it might be good to handle the big threat first. Teach can wait a little longer for rescue, can’t she?”

 

"..." Shez sighed. "I get that. I just…I need to make sure she's okay. She's been stuck in that place for so long that I don't even…" 

 

“Well, it’s up to you. You’re the only one that can cast this spell, right?”

 

“Yeah. I have to use it on myself. I, ah…I don’t know how well this is going to work. I’ve got my mom’s notes and I’ve got the memories of what that asshole did to make it work.” She took a breath, before nodding. “So no more waiting. I just have to go right ahead and, ah…crush this guy’s heart. In my hand. After tearing it out of his chest…”

 

“...Are you sure you have to rip it out with your bare hand?”

 

“Uh…I mean, technically I just have to be holding the heart, I guess I could just…plunge my hand into his chest.”

 

“Right. Well, I guess it’s good he’s still unconscious.”

 

“...Honestly, that kind of makes it worse. At least if he was awake, he could fight–No, no, that’s actually worse, that…ugh, why am I getting weird about this? I just need to punch into a guy’s chest, it’s not that difficult.”

 

Claude raised an eyebrow. “It’s not?”

 

“It shouldn’t be! I might not have done it before, but–Wait, should I have practiced this? Would it be weird if I practiced?”

 

"...on who?" 

 

“...good question. Okay, uh…” Shez took a breath, staring at the unconscious Agarthan man. “I guess I’m doing this. Do you think you could grab Lysithea and Kronya real quick? I know they’re helping with the whole ‘on fire tunnel’ thing, but they should probably be here for this.”

 

“Sure, if you want. Just don’t use this as an excuse to go there on your own.”

 

Shez frowned. “I’m not gonna do that. No running off on my own, I know that much.”

 

“Okay, I’m holding you to that. I might actually make you pay a fine if you do go off on your own.”

 

“You can do that?”

 

“I’m a duke now, I can absolutely do that.”

 

“Huh.”

 

With that, Claude headed off, leaving Shez alone for a moment as she glanced over at their Agarthan prisoner. Which she still felt pretty weird about. Like, sure, the guy was working for Bias, and considering how most Agarthans were, he was probably the type to consider everyone around him horrible beasts.

 

But then…Kronya had been like that, hadn’t she?

 

Why does this bother me? I can kill tons of people without hesitating, I have a lot of blood on my hands, but now that I have a chance to save my sister, I start getting squeamish? What the hell is that? she mentally berated herself, starting to scowl, I just need to get this over with. No more hesitating, no more waiting. Just…don’t think about it.

 

She stepped forward, flexing her hand. The Agartha’s outer armor had been removed, so there was only a tunic in between her and his chest. If she just used some dark magic to make it easier to push through…

 

“...damn it,” she muttered, turning away, “I…I’ll just wait for the oth–”

 

“This is why you need me.”

 

Shez stiffened. The sound of that far too familiar voice sent a cold sweat down her back, her eyes darting around the cell to try to spot–And then she went fully rigid, though not because of the tension she felt.

 

It was because someone else was in her body.

 

“You need me to do what needs to be done. I see that now. And you will too, once we are finally rid of that wretched creature that consumes your thoughts,” Epimenides stated with her voice, before he turned and plunged their hand straight into the chest of the captive Agarthan without hesitation.

 

Then all was darkness.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Well, things are popping off. Again.

Red: Does it count as popping off at this point if we keep having pop offs?

Indi: Close enough.

Red: Fair. But yeah, plan accomplished! For the most part.

Indi: And that means we'll soon be seeing everyone's other favorite mercenary soon enough!

Red: That we shall! Hopefully it's a nice reunion without anything going wrong at all!

Indi: I'm sure it'll be fine.

A Verdant Void

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Byleth wasn’t sure how or why, exactly, but the void that surrounded her at all times of the day seemed to have…changed. Not immediately, it was a process so gradual she barely noticed, but it seemed to have gone from an endless expanse of darkness to more like a night sky. There were stars and strange stretches of color across the sky that Rhea called “nebulae” when Byleth asked what they were, which didn’t make sense at all.

 

Not the “nebula” things, she could understand what those were since they were basically just void clouds, but the stars. She didn’t understand how those could be here since they weren’t anywhere there should be stars. Right?

 

“It’s just weird,” Byleth commented while laying back and staring up at the distant lights, “This place is supposed to be empty. Why would there be stars?”

 

“Hm…presumably, Zahras is merely a part of the greater void that forms our night sky,” Rhea considered, also watching the distant stars, “That, or…perhaps they are false stars, gathered in this place for one reason or another.”

 

“...could you touch them?”

 

“Hm?”

 

“Stars are lights in the sky, aren’t they? So couldn’t you fly up and touch them?”

 

“Stars are far greater than that, Byleth. Each one in a sun in their own right, merely distant from us.”

 

Byleth blinked, then sat up, giving Rhea a skeptical look. “Really?”

 

“Yes, truly. My mother came from one of those distant stars, in fact. Though…this night sky does not match our own, so I cannot point it out to you." Rhea reached a hand up into the sky. "Sometimes I wonder what the world mother came from was like, what could have made her leave hers and journey all alone." 

 

"...If Sothis never said anything, then she was happier here, at least," Byleth said, laying back down, "And we have to make sure her home stays safe." 

 

"...Yes, we do," Rhea responded, finding herself smiling for some reason, "Though I'm sure whatever you do, she'd be proud of you."

 

"Hm…I'm sure she'd be proud of you too, even if she would have had her complaints." 

 

"There is no need to comfort me but…thank you, Byleth." 

 

With that the two sat in a comfortable silence.

"Child, might I ask a favor?" 

 

"Hm? What about?" Byleth asked, glancing over from where she was soaking in the bath.

 

"Can you please stop leaving your…dolls near the bath?” Rhea requested, also in the middle of bathing, though she was keeping her knees close to her chest in an attempt at modesty, “It is awkward having them stare at me." 

 

"I like bathing with them though." 

 

“...You understand how I might find that concerning, right?”

 

“No, not in the slightest,” Byleth replied, “You can just turn them around if you don’t like them watching you.”

 

“Child, that…” Rhea paused. “Do you like it when they watch you?”

 

“When it’s Edelgard and Dorothea, yeah. I’m not keeping the rest of them near the bath, that would be weird.” She tilted her head in thought. “I guess I could include Shez, we’ve bathed together before. Saves on time and water.”

 

"That's not…Child, is there a specific reason why you keep Edelgard and Dorothea so close?" 

 

"Hm? Well, it feels nice." 

 

"...Hm. Byleth, did…did Jeralt not tell you about the pegasi and the wyvern?" 

 

"What?" Byleth stared up at her, blinking, before her eyes widened in shock. "Rhea, no it's not a sex thing!" 

 

"Oh! Yes, it's not, that's a good thing. Just…I understand if you need some time alone–" 

 

"I'm not talking about this with you,” she stated, getting up and walking away without bothering to dry herself off or dress, aside from grabbing her coat, “And I get plenty of time alone! Don’t make it weird!”

 

“...Wait, did you mean that in the euphemistic sense–And she’s gone. Hm.” Rhea glanced at the pair of dolls perched on the side of the ‘bath’, their bodies little more than spheres perched atop cones with some small carvings to give them ‘hair’ and ‘clothes’. Still, their staring eyes, one imperious, the other mirthful, seemed fixed on her. “...this is your fault.”

 

She didn't receive a response, so instead she reached over, trying to push them away, only for the Edelgard one to tip over. Rhea couldn't help but stiffen as a crack sounded out as the doll broke. 

 

"Rhea, what did you break!?" 

 

“I didn’t! It just–I moved and it tipped–”

 

Byleth gasped as she spotted the decapitated Edelgard doll. “Assassination…”

“Byleth! BYLETH! Come on now, child, it’s been a month according to the tally chart! Stop hiding in these…admittedly eerie ruins!” Rhea called out, feeling a faint shiver as she took in the lines of strange light that crossed through the metallic floors. They reminded her of an age she really didn’t want to recall…

 

"So it seems even the great Archbishop feels fear," a…strangely sing-songy yet still monotone voice called out, "I wonder if she knows Edie also felt this when she was assassinated." 

 

"...Byleth, I know that's you. You're horrible at mimicking voices." 

 

"..." 

 

Rhea wondered if Byleth would say something, only to feel a rock hit her head. "...Did you just throw a rock at me???" 

 

"That's what you get for not playing along!"

 

“Why would I play a–...” Rhea let out a slow, aggravated sigh when she noticed the number of small, stone ‘knights’ arranged in an army at about shin height. “...did you individually carve all of these?”

 

“Obviously. I only have one knife and you’re not helpful.”

 

“...That is impressive, but also I feel as though the isolation is getting to you, Byleth–” She promptly ducked another rock. “STOP DOING THAT!”

 

“The Empire of Bylethia shall not bow to draconic tyranny!” 

 

Rhea stared, somewhat stunned, as Byleth began to let out low cheers and yells, as if trying to mimic an army roaring before a battle. “...You understand this is absurd, correct?”

 

“And you understand that a large, stationary target is easily struck by catapults.”

 

“Is that what the rocks are supposed to–” She caught the next rock and promptly pitched it back.

 

“Ha! Missed!”

 

“...tch.” Rhea narrowed her eyes, before grabbing one of the stone soldiers and pitching it in the direction of Byleth’s voice.

 

She heard a faint yelp, followed by a laugh. “Ah, so you begin your assault! I knew you treacherous hounds of Seirosia would attack us!”

 

“Seirosia? No, never mind.” Rhea sighed, rubbing her temples. “Byleth, this is absurd. Not only are you waging a war with stone toys, you were the one who attacked first.”

 

“And yet you were the one to counter-attack! Making you the true aggressor!”

 

“...What am I doing?” Rhea murmured, before simply walking through the stone knights, who couldn’t really do anything to stop her on account of being dolls made out of rocks.

 

“So I see the tyrant of Seirosia has chosen to take to the field herself! Fight valiantly men! Strike down your foe! Win glory for your people! Do your best! Earn your pay!” Byleth continued to call out, in between adding her own sound effects to the ‘battle’.

 

Rhea sighed to herself, continuing to walk as she tried to find Byleth, all while knocking over dolls in her way. The sounds of 'battle' continued, now adding the cries of those who 'died' in battle. 

 

Soon enough however, the sounds began to peter out, until only the sound of falling dolls remained. 

 

Turning a corner, Rhea found Byleth, the young Nabatean hugging her knees to her chest. "...Byleth?" 

 

"Oh, hey, Rhea. I guess you won," Byleth muttered, continuing to stare ahead. 

 

"..." Moving closer, Rhea sat next to her. "I'm guessing this isn't because I wasn't playing along?" 

 

"...I've never been alone since Shez showed up. Jeralt would do his best, but even he couldn't be around me all the time, and I only started to get close to the other mercenaries thanks to Shez," Byleth murmured, hugging her knees closer to herself. "I know you're here Rhea, but…" 

 

"...There's still some distance and wariness, I imagine." 

 

“Yeah. You scared me, back at the monastery. I thought we were getting close and you would be like family too, but then you weren’t. You just wanted your mother back, and you were using me to get her.” She glanced up at Rhea. “Was any of it real? Did you care about me at all besides as a vessel for Sothis?”

 

"...It would be dishonest for me to say yes. When you were stillborn, I couldn't help but wonder if the life that was given to you was that of my mother, and you simply were unaware," Rhea admitted, unable to meet her gaze. "At best, I thought that you simply couldn't remember. At worst, I thought of you as a vessel that would disappear when mother returned. Now it just seems that my treatment of you will be another thing I shall regret for the rest of my time." 

 

“Hm. Do you know how you could make up for it?”

 

Rhea paused, then glanced curiously at the younger woman. “How?”

 

“Play along with my nonsense for a bit.”

 

“...So you admit it’s nonsense.”

 

“Well yeah, obviously. It’s fun though.”

 

“...” Rhea sighed, though a small smile came to her face. “Very well then, I suppose the nation of Seirosia must respond to this intense aggression from the Empire of Bylethia.”

 

The smile she received from Byleth made it worth it. “Ah, but you fail to realize, tyrant of Seirosia, that we of Bylethia have a secret weapon!” she declared, before gesturing towards…

 

“...Is that meant to be a dragon?” Rhea asked, staring at the vaguely winged rock that looked like a cross between a snake and a bear.

 

“...yeah. You found me before I could finish it,” Byleth muttered, her cheeks turning a little pink.

 

“I see. Well, your…dragon-bear-snake appears very fearsome.”

 

“...it’s just a fat dragon, it’s not part bear.”

 

“No, the neck would be wider if she was just fat. Also, given that the nation of Seirosia is one of draconic tyranny, clearly this marvelous creature should be on my side,” Rhea decided, getting up and picking up the stone hybrid without issue.

 

Byleth gasped. “Treachery! To think you would recruit one of my loyal soldiers out from under me! This deception shall not go unavenged!"

 

"Ah, but your army could not face off against me before, how will they stand up against the combined might of my and my Stalwart general, the Unfaltering Blade of Devotion?”

 

"Though you may have a dragon, my army will not fall to you! We shall rise against your tyranny!" Byleth stated, before moving to grab her soldiers. 

 

Smiling, Rhea began to play with Byleth, the two acting out some inane story that made no sense to her. Even so…it was the first time in so long that she was able to laugh so freely. 

 

She would never be able to make up her past actions to Byleth, this she knew, but if she could make her happy, then she would. 

"Hey, Rhea, what was Wilhelm like?" Byleth asked seemingly out of nowhere as she finished remaking an Edelgard doll. 

 

"Oh, why do you ask?" 

 

"Because I want to know your type,” the younger woman bluntly stated. 

 

"...Ah, may I ask why?" the archbishop inquired, unsure of what else to say. 

 

"Well I was just thinking that both Edelgard and Dorothea are kinda different, so I was wondering what my 'type' is, and I figured if I knew what someone else's was, I can help figure out my own." 

 

“That is an odd line of logic, Byleth,” Rhea replied in the midst of shaping her own armored knight astride a horse. A mix of fire magic and her own natural strength made it a bit easier to mold the stone, though some of the more intricate details required using her nails. “I would think you would have an idea of who you find attractive.”

 

“See, that’s the issue. I think everyone’s attractive.”

 

“...truly?”

 

“Yeah, everyone I’ve met has qualities that make them interesting and in terms of physical appearance, I’m pretty sure I like just about everything. My family members obviously aren’t, because that would be gross, and people like the mercenaries I grew up with and Alois are also just not appealing in a romantic sense, I guess because I consider them family, but everyone else is pretty attractive to me.” She paused. “...not Gilbert though. He’s not my type, I know that.”

 

“Well he is married, so I would hope not.”

 

“Him being a bad dad is a bigger turn off, really.”

 

“...’turn off’?”

 

“Slang meaning that I don’t find him attractive. I think specifically it means I don’t find him sexually appealing, but I just don’t think he’d be a good partner since he abandoned his family to join the church without telling them and then refused to interact with his daughter when she came to find him.” She glanced over at Rhea, who looked alarmed. “Shez complained about it to me.”

 

"...I see. I was unaware of such an issue. I must admit if I had learned about this before, I likely wouldn't have said anything other than it being honorable to choose the church in such a circumstance. Nowadays…" 

 

"Yeah. So as I was saying, he's a no," Byleth continued before pausing, "...I guess anyone of Ashe's age or younger is a no as well. Age difference and all." 

 

"Then I'm afraid I can't comment at all. I am over a thousand years old, after all." 

 

“...” Byleth put down her doll and walked over to Rhea to give her a hug.

 

“...um, Byleth, while I appreciate the hug, I am not sure why you’re hugging me.”

 

“Because no one else is over a thousand years old and I think it’s sad that you’re going to be alone forever.”

 

“...” Rhea sighed. “That…I will be honest, child, that genuinely hurt to hear.”

 

“Oh. Sorry. Okay, we can change the standard for you since that limits your dating pool way too much.” She tilted her head in thought. “...what about Hanneman? He’s old.”

 

“Please stop making assumptions of who I should date based on age.”

 

“Okay, then what about Hanneman on the basis that he’s a well-educated nobleman from Adrestia? He’s also interested in crests and history, so you have stuff in common.”

 

"...Byleth, why are you focusing so much on Hanneman?" 

 

"Because I feel if I don't do something, he and Manuela are going to keep bickering for the rest of their lives…actually, are you interested in Manuela?" 

 

“I haven’t considered her a romantic prospect, no." 

 

"Are you sure? She's hot." 

 

“I understand she is physically attractive. The issue, Byleth, is that I have become aware I have a number of blindspots in regards to the people of Garreg Mach due to the distance I keep from them. In spite of that, I am already well aware of her reputation as a lascivious drunk who keeps a remarkably messy room. Honestly, it's a miracle her protégé didn't end up like her.” 

 

"..." The younger Nabatean's face went pink.

 

"...Byleth?" 

 

"I wasn't thinking of Dorothea being like Manuela, shut up." 

 

“...Byleth–”

 

“She answered the door naked one time, I can’t let myself think about Dorothea doing that.” Her face went from pink to red. “...oh no, I did that to Edelgard.”

 

“What.”

 

“Shut up. I need to…not be here.” Byleth stood and immediately walked away, her face crimson.

 

"..." Rhea let out a sigh, wondering how much longer she'd have to deal with...well, everything, really.

"So, hypothetically speaking–"

 

"Byleth, if this is another awkwardly personal question, then I'll have to ask you to stop." 

 

"It wasn't. I wanted to know what you would have done if Sothis did come back and was okay with what you were planning." 

 

"Oh…well, there wasn't much beyond that. Once the goddess had descended, then she would make her rightful claim of the land of Fodlan, and guide us forevermore." 

 

"...” Byleth gave Rhea a flat look. “Rhea, that's stupid." 

 

"What? No it's not!" 

 

"Yes it is. Ignoring everything with the Agarthans, there's still the issues with the western church thinking you're a heretic, and I don't know if people will accept a little girl being the goddess, especially if she looks nothing like the murals you have around the place." 

 

"...Okay, admittedly I hadn't expected her to be a young girl, but once she shows off her divine miracles, people would know she's the goddess." 

 

“Like what? No one notices when I reverse time.”

 

“...you can reverse time?”

 

“Yeah, obviously. Did I not tell you?" 

 

"You certainly did not. Unless you did so before reversing time." 

 

"Can't in the void. It's outside of time or something," Byleth said, uncaring of Rhea’s incredulous stare, "I figured out how to sorta stop time in here, but I can't reverse it." 

 

“...I see. Well, the goddess is perfectly capable of other miracles, such as creating life. At the height of her power, mother could form worlds with a mere thought.”

 

“Huh. Neat.”

 

“...You don’t believe me.”

 

Byleth shrugged. “Sothis is maybe ten at most in my brain and I find it hard to believe she could make a world. I know she made you, but making everything seems pretty impossible.”

 

"...Hmph, well, it's not my fault you didn't see her at the height of her power. And besides, she wouldn’t have looked like a child, she would have been you. Or, well…taken your body, which I do still apologize for–”

 

“It’s fine. I still find it hard to believe people could worship me as a goddess though. I’m not that impressive.” With a shrug, Byleth grabbed a rock to nibble on, "I mean I know my clothes are cute, but I don't know if they'd make me worshipable." 

 

"That…your sense of fashion aside, you would have been provided new vestments for your position." 

 

"Oh, really? What do they look like?" 

 

"Ah…give me some time." Rhea requested, before she began to cut out a stone slab from the floor. Nodding, Byleth sat back, before waiting approximately one tally mark as Rhea worked on carving something on the rock. 

 

"Here we are!" Rhea said, showing off the stone slab that depicted Byleth in some form of holy vestments. "Alongside this, I would have granted you the title of Enlightened One." 

 

"...why is the collar so big?" 

 

"High collars are fashionable." 

 

"..." Byleth squinted a bit, wondering about Rhea’s sense of fashion. "And what about the cape? It looks like it would drag on the floor."

 

"...Okay, admittedly, the vestments were originally designed with the first of my attempts in mind. Baal was surprisingly tall, compared to the rest of you." Rhea frowned a little sadly, remembering her first ‘daughter’, before she shook off the memory. “Regardless, it could be fitted to your body better–”

 

“Do I get to keep my usual outfit?”

 

“I would prefer it if you dressed with more…care for your station.”

 

“I’m not dressing like a priest. I’m not even part of the church.”

 

"...I suppose you aren't, but regardless, are you saying you'll wear two outfits at once?" 

 

"What? No, I'll just take the coat. Look, give me a bit," Byleth requested, before trying to cut out a stone slab as well. 

 

Approximately three tallies and several destroyed slabs later… 

 

"Here we go!" 

 

"..." Rhea wasn't sure what she was looking at. Was it a demonic beast? It looked vaguely humanoid, but… “Byleth, I will be perfectly honest with you, I have no idea what I am looking at.”

 

“What? It’s me. Obviously.”

 

“...hm.” Rhea tried to study the image, hoping somehow she would be able to parse the meaning hidden in the poorly carved picture. “...why do you have horns?”

 

"...Rhea, they're not horns, it's the collar of the cape," Byleth explained, as if it was the most obvious thing in the world. "Do you need glasses?" 

 

“Apparently,” Rhea muttered, her eyes narrowing as she tried to piece together… “Why is there a gap in the middle?”

 

“Because my top doesn’t cover my midriff.”

 

“What? Then…oh, that is meant to be your belly button then.”

 

“Yes, obviously. What did you think it was?”

 

“An eye.” Well, at least it became easier to decipher the image with an indication of what she was supposed to be looking at. “So these are meant to be your leggings on your legs then?”

 

“Yes, the leggings you tore up.”

 

Rhea sighed. “I apologized for that.”

 

“It doesn’t stop my legs from being cold.”

 

“It’s not even cold here, the air is just…mild. I imagine a lack of heat would make this place feel colder, but somehow it’s lacking cold as well–Never mind. Byleth, I don’t think you’re particularly good at carving images into stone.”

 

“Hm. Hurtful.”

 

"I'm sorry, but it's true. Still, you're good at other things. You're a fantastic teacher, for example!" 

 

"Hmph." With a pout, Byleth turned away from her. 

 

"Byleth, please, we all have things we're not good at." 

 

"Name something you're bad at then." 

 

"Well, being the archbishop for one, apparently." 

 

“True,” Byleth readily agreed, before she paused. “Hm. Do you think you want to try a different job when we get out of here? You were bad at being archbishop, but you seem really good at stone carving.”

 

“...you think I should become a stone carver?”

 

“Yes, but call yourself an ‘artisan’. It sounds more impressive and you’re more likely to get noble clients that way.”

 

“...hm. I suppose I will keep that in mind. I never truly considered what I would do if I ever stepped down from being archbishop…do you have any other ideas for potential professions I could take up?”

 

“Well you have the hips to be a barmaid.”

 

“Byleth.”

 

Byleth shrugged, unrepentant. “You asked.”

 

"...Do all barmaids need to have a certain type of hip?" 

 

"It helps. Generally speaking tavern owners and such will want someone pretty serving drinks and the like to help bring in customers. With how strong you are, they might not even have to pay to have someone guard the place in case anyone gets too drunk." 

 

“...I don’t want to spend my retirement being pawed at by drunks.”

 

“It’s a suggestion, you don’t have to commit to it. Besides, the higher class places have rules about that, I think.” 

 

“Regardless, I do not think the profession of ‘barmaid’ is for me. Particularly since your only reasoning appears to be based on my figure.”

 

“And your strength. You have to be on your feet for a long while, serving drinks and bringing food, and like I said, you could basically be their tavern guard too. Who knows, it might be fun. You could maybe meet someone nice too.”

 

“I see the subject has turned back to my romantic life again…Byleth, I don't have any interest in pursuing anyone romantically. If that changes, I'll let you know, but as it stands, it's not for me." 

 

"Oh…okay…can I still talk about romance with you?" 

 

"As long as you don't try to set me up with someone." 

 

“I didn’t have any plans to do that.”

 

“...I did not accuse you of having plans, Byleth.” She frowned. “Did you have plans?”

 

“...I’m going to go practice my stone carving,” Byleth decided, getting up and walking away as Rhea let out an exasperated sigh.

 

“Who were you even thinking of–No, don’t engage with her, she’ll wind up convinced you’re attracted to Dimitri again…”

“Fire. Thunder. Wind–Damn it. Fire, thunder, wind–Damn it. Fire, thunder, wi–nh…” 

 

Byleth frowned at her hand, which was stubbornly refusing to cast a wind spell on command. She could get Fire fine, she could get Thunder fine, but she couldn’t get Wind. There was some kind of…block in place, one that she just couldn’t figure out.

 

“Practicing again?” Rhea asked while draping her freshly washed gown over the drying pole they’d set up in their sort-of-home in the void. The fact that they only had rocks around meant the pair had to get creative when it came to crafting furniture and tools, but Rhea really was surprisingly good at stone crafting.

 

Thanks to her, they had actual furniture. Albeit very hard, rocky furniture, and most of their chairs looked more like thrones. Which, thinking about it… “Do Nabateans have a thing for thrones?”

 

“I asked you a question first, Byleth.”

 

“Huh? Oh, yeah, I am. I want to figure out how to do wind spells. I feel like it’s there, I just…can’t figure it out,” she admitted, frowning, “I know the formulas for it, but it just doesn’t come to me.”

 

"Well, I would help you, but in terms of reason magic, my expertise lies with fire magic," Rhea said, moving over to sit in one of the stone thrones. "Generally speaking, having someone who knows a specific type of magic you wish to learn helps, so you would be best suited to find someone who knows wind magic when we escape." 

 

"Really? Because when Shez-...hm." 

 

"Is something wrong?" 

 

"No, I'm just remembering I asked Shez for help with ice magic once, but…she didn't explain it well, so that wouldn't really contradict what you said. As nice as she is, I wouldn't say Shez is a good teacher." 

 

"I'll take your word for it," Rhea said, before stifling a chuckle, "Remember when she thought I was offering her the position of being a professor?" 

 

“Considering how the year went afterwards, I almost think you should have.” Byleth paused, a small grin crossing her face. “Actually, you absolutely should have. She would have been hilarious as a professor.”

 

"She probably would have charged the other two teams on her own during the mock battle." 

 

"Ah, but then the other students wouldn't have rushed the field thinking someone was cheating." Byleth said, before snickering slightly. "Of course, she probably wouldn't have a team in the first place, since I imagine her training would have involved just beating them with a sword in a 'spar' against her."

 

“Heh. Well, she wouldn’t be the worst professor we ever had. That would be the fool that ran off due to the bandit attack.”

 

“That’s a pretty low bar.”

 

“Well you’re not exactly inspiring confidence in Shez’s teaching abilities.”

 

“That’s true. I…hm.” Byleth frowned to herself. “...hm. Have I been…You know, thinking about it, while she might have had a rough time of it at the start, I bet she would have risen to the occasion. She’s not an idiot. She’s just…she acts dumb sometimes and she has a bad sense of direction, and sometimes I need to help, but she’s strong and capable, and…” 

 

“...Byleth?” Rhea gave her a concerned look. “Is everything all right?”

 

“...no. No, it’s not. I haven’t seen my sister in…in way too long. And I wasn’t…I was treating her like she was stupid and weak, and I didn’t think she could handle anything–”

 

“I don’t believe that’s what you were doing–”

 

“It was. I didn’t believe in her and she’s going to think that. She’s going to think I thought she was useless but she’s not–” Byleth took a breath, feeling a lump in her throat. “...what if I hurt her?”

 

“...she knows you love her,” Rhea pointed out, frowning faintly.

 

“I didn’t get to say it though. It just…we were put in here before I could.” Byleth rubbed her eyes. "Despite everything that happened, that's the thing I want to change the most. To let her know how great she is." 

 

"..." Rhea moved in close, gently wrapping her arms around her, holding Byleth close. The young girl took in a shuddering breath, before she began to cry, letting her tears flow free. Rhea remained silent, gently rubbing her back, letting Byleth take as long as she needed. 

 

Eventually, Rhea pulled away, as Byleth took a deep breath, trying to calm herself. 

 

"...Thank you, Rhea." 

 

"It's the least I can do." 

 

Byleth put on her best smile as she rubbed her eyes. "You know Rhea, I'm glad we got to know one another." 

 

"...I am too. I know I can never make up for what I did, but…I hope we can be a part of each other's life from now on." 

 

"No promises, but…I'm looking forward to it," Byleth said, smiling back at her. "Grandma." 

 

"You really don't need to call me that–" 

 

A sudden crack sounded out within the void, as if space itself had been ripped open. 

 

Pressing up against each other's backs, Rhea and Byleth scanned the area around them, trying to find the source of the noise. "...What was that?" 

 

"Whatever it is, we need to be careful," Rhea stated, quickly moving to get dressed. 

 

"Sure," Byleth agreed, keeping one hand on her dagger before beginning to walk with Rhea towards the source of the sound.

 

"You don't think this is another Agarthan trick, do you?" 

 

"Why wait so long then?" 

 

Rhea remained silent, unsure of the reason. Though before they went much farther, they heard a noise. 

 

"Ngh…" 

 

Byleth felt her eyes widened, her now-pointed ears twitching at the strangely familiar groan. Before Rhea could stop her, she took off sprinting, her chest tightening as she ran.

Groaning, Shez pushed herself up, her head throbbing in pain.

 

"F-Fucking asshole…" she muttered, rubbing the back of her head. She grit her teeth, feeling her anger begin to boil up over how that piece of shit stole her body again.

 

Her freedom had been short-lived, and she was going to get it back one way or another. 

 

"Shez?" 

 

Blinking, the mercenary looked over and found her sister staring back at her. She had green hair and she wasn’t wearing her coat or her stockings, but it was her. After all this time, it was her. 

 

"...Byleth?" 

 

Shez could feel her eyes stinging as her vision began to blur. Pushing herself up, she walked towards Byleth, before stopping right in front of her. She wanted to say something, anything. But what could she say? It was her fault that Byleth was stuck here. Did she even want to see– 

 

Stepping in, Byleth hugged her, holding her tightly. "I'm so sorry. I'm so sorry for how I treated you. I love you so much." 

 

"...Y-You don't need to apologize. I-I'm the one who got you stuck here." 

 

"Only because I pushed you away! You're a better sister than I deserve, and I’m so glad you’re here–” She paused, a thought occurring as she immediately started checking Shez over with a worried frown. “How did you get here? Did someone send you? Are you okay??”

 

“...pfffff–” Shez covered her mouth, trying to stifle her laughter at her sister’s sudden worry. “S-Seriously? It’s been years and you still get this worried about me?”

 

“Of course I do,” Byleth immediately responded, before clarifying, “Not because you’re incapable, I think you’re very capable, I just…you’re my sister. And my best friend. And I…I know I should have listened to you. You were just trying to keep me safe and it wasn’t fair of me to assume I knew best. I was wrong, I am sorry, and I am so glad you’re here.”

 

Shez blinked rapidly, tears gathering at her eyes as her giggling turned to a choked sob, before she wrapped her arms around Byleth and hugged her as tightly as she could, completely overwhelmed with emotion.

 

"I'm not going to let anything happen to you again."

 

The two continued to hole one another, only pulling away as they heard someone running up to them. 

 

"Byleth, what happened–"

 

"YOU! Get away from my sister!" Shez shouted as she flashed towards Rhea.

 

"Wait, Shez!" Byleth called out, a moment too late as Shez buried her fist into Rhea’s face. She winced as Rhea stumbled back, almost falling before she righted herself.

 

“...” The archbishop pressed a hand to her bruised cheek and let out a slow sigh, before looking at Shez, who was glaring straight at her. “...I suppose I deserved that.”

 

“Yeah, you did,” Shez spat, still glaring. Though she paused after Rhea’s words fully registered. “...” Then she glanced back at Byleth, taking in her sister’s somewhat awkward expression. “...ah. You two made up.”

 

“Essentially,” Byleth agreed, nodding, “Though I’m sure Rhea understands why your first instinct was to punch her and won’t hold it against you. Right?”

 

Rhea frowned at Byleth’s very pointed question. “...Yes, of course. I can accept that your sister just acted in a moment of protectiveness and won’t punch me again, please.”

 

"Hm. As long as you don't do anything weird,” Shez agreed, matching Rhea’s frown, “Jeralt’s probably going to want to hit you if you see him though." 

 

"...I'll keep that in mind." 

 

"Wait, Shez, how is papa? And everyone else?" Byleth asked.

 

Shez paused, a complicated expression crossing her face. "Ah…I, uh…I haven't seen Jeralt in a few years, but he's apparently in the Empire." 

 

Byleth’s brow furrowed in worry. “You haven’t? Did something happen?”

 

"Some stuff, yeah. I'll tell you everything when we get out. I just need to deal with an asshole first." 

 

“You truly are such an ungrateful child.”

 

Shez stiffened, before immediately drawing her sword and glaring at the figure floating above them. “And you’re still a piece of shit.”

 

Epimenides scoffed, his gaze contemptuous as he looked down upon his corrupted vessel and the foul creatures that invaded his world. “Mock me all you wish, partner , for this is the day I reclaim you as my vessel. The modicum of freedom I have allowed you was far too much, and it was foolish of me to allow you to live in anything other than a despair so crushing that you could not resist me. So now I shall rectify my past errors. No more half-measures like this foolish exile. Now, I shall put to right what I should have long ago.

 

His eyes burned bright in the void, fiery and contemptuous as darkness gathered at his hands. “Today is the day the Fell Star dies!”

Chapter End Notes

Indi: And here we go, a proper reunion!

Red: Finally reunited after a whole lot of tragedy and shenanigans!

Indi: Now hopefully everything goes well after this.

Red: Yup! No need to worry about the crazed sage that wants to kill everybody here.

Indi: Eh, they've been through worse.

The Great Sage

Chapter by RK3996

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Byleth couldn't help but frown, well aware that she was only armed with a dagger right now while she faced off against a mage that wanted her dead. It didn't help that she had left her coat behind in her hurry. "So, this is Epimenides, huh?" 

 

She wasn’t quite sure how she expected him to look, but he seemed a lot younger than she would have thought. Almost like Sothis, in that sense, though where the goddess had been colorful and almost soft in appearance–even if she would’ve been really annoyed to hear Byleth describe her like that–Epimenides was stark white aside from his gleaming, fiery crown, halo, and wings, and every bit of him seemed sharp and angular. 

 

That, and there was no hint of the kindness Sothis could carry in her gaze. The only thing showing in the sage’s eyes was a cold contempt.

 

“Yeah, that’s him. He’s a prick,” Shez noted, glowering at the wraith that possessed her, while Rhea’s eyes widened in recognition.

 

“That mage…the same one from the war against Nemesis? But how?! I slew him myself!”

 

Epimenides scoffed, the sound echoing through Zahras. “You arrogant abomination. Do you truly think your monstrous powers could put an end to my existence?" 

 

"How about your powers ending you?" Shez asked, glaring at him. 

 

"Tch. You would side with the spawn of that abomination?" 

 

"That really shouldn't surprise you." 

 

"Shez, I'm going to need a full explanation later, but for now I think we have someone we need to deal with," Rhea muttered, cracking her knuckles. 

 

“You read my mind. Gotta say, I like you a lot better when you want to kill the same person I want to kill.”

 

“It is a surprisingly efficient way of bonding people together,” Byleth remarked.

 

“You speak of bonds, filth?” Epimenides scoffed, “Then let us see how much these ‘bonds’ of yours matter to you.”

 

With that, he spread his arms and let loose a massive torrent of darkness that consumed their surroundings. Bracing themselves, the trio felt the darkness wash over them, before they found themselves elsewhere within the void. 

 

"Okay, be ready for whatever shit he has planned. The sooner we take him out, the better." 

 

"Don't suppose you have a spare sword I can use?" Byleth asked. 

 

"Sure, just don't break it." Shez said, tossing her red blade at Byleth. 

 

"Thanks. Rhea, do you want my dagger?" Byleth offered, glancing at the older woman. 

 

"No, I think I would prefer to use my hands for this." 

 

"Remind me not to get on your bad side," Shez muttered, as the three of them looked around. "Hm, don't tell me he ran away." 

 

"What, like you did?" 

 

Shez opened her mouth, ready to retort, only to stop as she saw who spoke. "Lysithea?! What are you doing here!?" 

 

“What do you think? I’m getting dragged into another mess because of you!” Lysithea snapped, glaring straight at Shez with a lot more venom than she’d ever seen on the former noble’s face, “You always do this! You rush off and get everyone hurt because of it!”

 

“Wh–No I don’t!”

 

“Yes, you do! Who can forget how you abandoned all of us for three years, huh!?”

 

Shez flinched, genuinely hurt. “You know I didn’t–It wasn’t my fault!”

 

“Of course it was! It always–”

 

Then Byleth stepped in front of Shez, a frown on her face. “Stop it, Lysithea. Shez isn’t at fault here. She was brought into the void by Epimenides.”

 

"Is that why you left?" 

 

Byleth felt her throat tighten. She turned her head, her eyes widening as she saw a familiar brown haired girl, dressed in a dancer’s outfit. "D-Dorothea?" 

 

"You left without saying a word, we had no idea what happened to you," the songstress said, taking a step towards Byleth. "All this time…you were stuck here because of Shez." 

 

"What? N-No, it wasn't her fault," Byleth denied, moving towards the songstress. 

 

"H-Hey, Byleth wait–" 

 

"Don't think you're off the hook!" Lysithea shouted, getting Shez to flinch. 

 

“I-I’m not saying that, I just–This doesn’t make sense, how are you here? And why’s Dorothea dressed like that??”

 

"H-How are you even here? Where is Edelgard?" Byleth asked, looking around, though her words earned a frown from Dorothea.

 

"Of course you ask about her, rather than focus on me." 

 

"Dorothea? What are you talking about?" 

 

"Byleth, Shez, something clearly isn't right, this is a ploy–" 

 

"Much like your ploy to resurrect the goddess?" Seteth asked, standing behind Rhea. 

 

"...Excuse me?" 

 

"Don't try to hide it, Immaculate One. I am well aware of your plots. Even now you still plan to do so, do you not?" He regarded her with open contempt. “You have always–“

 

Both Shez and Byleth jolted at the sound of a fist smashing through a head. 

 

“Wha–Rhea, what the fu–?!” Shez exclaimed, before blinking as ‘Seteth’ dissolved into darkness.

 

“He called me ‘Immaculate One’,” Rhea remarked, glaring over at ‘Lysithea’ and ‘Dorothea’. “We do not refer to each other by our Nabatean names.”

 

“Th-That’s insane! You can’t believe her!” Dorothea protested, “She just murdered him on a whim!”

 

“She’s a monster!” Lysithea insisted, gathering magic in her hands, “You know she’s a monster, and she needs to die right now!”

 

“Hang on, that’s bullshit!” Shez snapped, “I know Lysithea isn't blind enough to miss that fake Seteth literally just melted!”

 

“You really should learn to shut up already, Shez!” Lysithea snapped, raising a hand and raining orbs of mire on the battlefield, “No one wants to hear the stupid drivel that pours out of your empty head!”

 

"Okay you're just being a giant asshole, Epimenides!" Shez shouted as she flashed away to dodge the mire orbs. Byleth, meanwhile, did her best to block a sudden stab from Dorothea as the songstress formed a Levin sword in her hand.

 

“Oh Bylie, why did you have to leave us like that?” she asked, her voice sad enough to send a pang through Byleth’s heart, “You really hurt everyone. Do you really think you deserve to live after shattering our hearts?”

 

"..." Her mouth set into a frown, Byleth tried to keep her focus up as she stared the songstress down. "...Dorothea, what did we do that time we all went to town together?" 

 

"Are you really trying to appeal to the old days?” she questioned, glaring at Byleth, "Talking about haircuts and sweets won't win me over!" 

 

"...I'm really glad i never told Shez everything that happened there." Taking in a deep breath, Byleth steadied herself. "I'll make sure to apologize to you when I see you again." 

 

Then in one swift motion, she batted away a swing from Dorothea and cut straight through the false version of her student, splitting her head from her neck. The sight still made her grimace uncomfortably, but she did feel a slight sense of relief as the songstress burst into shadowy magic.

 

In the meantime, Shez actually had a pretty easy time just flashing straight over to Fauxsithea and cutting her down, deliberately striking fast and hard so the fake would “die” quickly and she wouldn’t have to watch whatever show the sage would’ve put on otherwise.

 

“To think you would so willingly murder your closest allies. You truly are nothing more than beasts!" Epimenides taunted, his voice echoing out around them as the area around them distorted again.

 

“Great, more rocks,” Shez complained, a little annoyed.

 

“How do you think I felt?” Byleth muttered, before pausing as she looked around, “Hm…I feel like I actually spent some time here. That pillar looks familiar.”

 

“Is it a pillar if it’s made out of rock?”

 

“...Shez.”

 

“Yeah, I realized how stupid that sounded the second I said it. I meant if it’s naturally formed, not–”

 

“Pay attention, both of you,” Rhea ordered, glowering out at the darkness, “Be ready for anything. He’s bound to create more facsimiles of those we care for in an attempt to make us waver.

 

“Understood,” Byleth murmured as she brought Shez’s sword up, ready for whatever came next. 

 

Meanwhile, Shez herself glared up at the void, "I'm getting real sick of your shit Epimenides!"

 

"Don't think it's over yet, partner,” his called out, echoing in the darkness around them, before shadows surged forth once more as faceless soldiers began to form. 

 

"Does he mean to wear us down now that his trick has been discovered?" Rhea asked, swiftly moving through her opponents, knocking their heads off with full force. 

 

"I doubt it, he's probably just biding his time!" Shez answered, making quick work of the shadowy soldiers. 

 

"Just try to keep an eye out for him. The sooner we find him, the better," Byleth instructed, sending an Aura through a group of soldiers, before turning in her heel to slice someone behind her. 

 

"Professor!?" 

 

Only to hesitate for a moment as she saw Edelgard staring back at her, though the surprise on the Emperor's face suddenly changed into a smirk right before she rammed into Byleth with her shield. 

 

Byleth grimaced at the sudden impact, stumbling backward for a moment, though she quickly found her feet in time to avoid an arrow that nearly went through her head.

 

“Stay still, Teach!” Claude called out, another arrow drawn back on his bow as his white wyvern flew above the chaos, “Things will go easier for everyone if you just lay down and die!”

 

Byleth didn’t actually register his words though, instead staring in some confusion as she casually deflected another arrow with her sword. “Claude has a wyvern?”

 

“Yeah, it’s a new thing!” Shez yelled, cutting through some shades before leaping to land by Byleth, “Gotta say though, I’m kinda confused by Edelgard showing up in her school uniform.”

 

“Hm. These shades are made by Epimenides, aren’t they? So he has to go by what he already knows. He can’t make a shade that reflects someone he hasn’t encountered before and he can’t adjust to changes he doesn’t know about.”

 

"Huh, guess that's why Dorothea was in that dancer outfit, it would be too obvious if she was in a uniform,” Shez muttered. 

 

"Hm." Frowning, Byleth dodged a shield charge from Edelgard, before blocking an axe swing. "If Claude and Edelgard are here, that leaves…"

 

Grabbing Byleth, Shez warped away as a spear went flying through where they had stood, burying itself into a wall. “Yeah, I was wondering when he’d show up too.”

 

“Running away again, Shez?” Dimitri growled, glaring at them both as another spear formed in his hand, “You abandoned all of us, and then you were too much of a coward to show your face!”

 

“I know it’s you, Epi,” Shez said with a frown, “If you’re trying to guilt me for not saying hi to the Lions in that forest, I’m gonna have to remind you that you said you’d murder all of my friends the moment I tried to contact them.”

 

“Liar!” Dimitri snapped, snarling, “You betrayed all of us! You abandoned your friends just because things would be too difficult for you!”

 

“...is this about me transferring classes??” she asked, baffled, “Alright, that’s just stupid! I left because…well, a lot of reasons, but it’s not like I didn’t want to stay friends! It’s just…things happened!”

 

“You abandoned all of us when we needed you. When you could have–”

 

“Ignore him,” Byleth ordered, keeping her eyes on Edelgard, who regarded her professor with a cold glare, “He’ll say anything to hurt you. Arguing it just gives him more ammunition.”

 

“Always so clever, aren’t you, professor?” Edelgard remarked, beginning to circle Byleth and Shez. Across from her, Dimitri began to do the same, the two royals keeping their eyes on the sisters. “That cleverness so often gets you into trouble though. Shez may have abandoned her friends, but if you had your way, you would have eagerly left her behind.”

 

“I wouldn’t. She’s my sister and I love her. I was being protective and stupid.”

 

“What was that about not arguing?” Shez asked, though a part of her felt warm at Byleth’s affirmation, “Don’t put yourself down either. I know you’re smart.”

 

“Thanks.” Byleth took a breath, watching Edelgard, before she lightly nudged Shez with her elbow. Shez nodded, slowly and near imperceptibly, in response, her own eyes focused on Dimitri.

 

Then the two sisters promptly turned and charged at the opposite house leader, with Byleth dodging a stab from Dimitri and ramming her sword straight through his chest while Shez fully leapt over Edelgard, a quick slice cutting the princess’s head off before she could even react. 

 

Both shades fell and dissolved into shadow as Byleth and Shez turned to give each other a quick high five, before facing off against Claude, who still circled far above them. Finally, his wyvern began to swoop down, flames filling its mouth while Claude drew back an arrow–Then he and the wyvern promptly exploded when a very large fireball collided with him.

 

“Oh, right, Rhea,” Byleth noted, turning to the archbishop in question and giving her a wave.

 

“...I didn’t think the shades bled that much,” Shez murmured, staring at the purple blood staining Rhea’s fists while a number of shadowy bodies lay crumpled on the ground around her.

 

“I find most things bleed heavily if you hit them hard enough,” Rhea noted, idly cleaning her hands off with a scrap of her dress.

 

“...I gotta remember you’re Byleth’s grandma.”

 

Rhea blinked. “Er…what?”  

 

“I mean, I guess that means you’re mine by extension, which does make it weird,” Shez mused, tilting her head in thought, though she paused when the void around them shifted again, “Oh damn it all, are you really trying this trick a third time!?”

 

“Of course he is. He doesn’t seem very imaginative,” Byleth commented, keeping her sword at the ready as she stayed close to Shez.

 

“If you demand imagination, then far be it from me to deny you,” the voice of the sage echoed out through the dark, before the two sisters found themselves in another new location.

 

“Hey, wait, where’s Rhea?” Shez asked, immediately noticing the archbishop wasn’t there with them…right before she noticed what Epimenides had done. “...oh you piece of shit.”

 

“...Ah. That’s…That’s really cruel,” Byleth murmured, staring at the figure of her father, Jeralt, who looked at his daughters with a disapproving glare.

 

Shez, meanwhile, let out an irritated huff as she saw Rhea standing there, all dressed up in her saint gear and wielding an all too familiar sword and shield. “Is this because I called her hot? Because that’s a dick move if so.”

 

“...You called her what?” Byleth asked, raising an eyebrow as Shez stiffened.

 

“I, uh…L-Look, I say stupid stuff sometimes, you already knew–” Then Shez jerked back, dodging the thrust of her father’s spear. “Gh–Gonna fucking kill that asshole–!”

 

Byleth, meanwhile, took a breath as she faced off against Rhea, who readied her sword. “...Well, at least I’ll get to work through some things.”

 

“What a selfish child you are,” the fake intoned, beginning to circle Byleth as she did the same, “You killed your own mother to enter this world and stole mine to maintain your wretched, empty life. You were broken from the very moment I first laid eyes on you, you disgusting creature.”

 

“It was a mistake to take you in,” Jeralt growled, stabbing forward as he stalked towards his adoptive daughter, “Everything went wrong the moment I let a parasite like you into my camp. How many times did you nearly kill Byleth? You were a worthless screw-up from the start, worming your way in as though you belonged.”

 

“Yeah? Well I belong there more than you do, Epi,” Shez taunted, deflecting each stab and glaring into the eyes of the thing that wore her dad’s face, “What are you even supposed to be, huh? The ghost of some long dead fuck-up who couldn’t cut it a thousand years ago? Everything that you fought for is gone , the world doesn’t want you around!”

 

Byleth struck, deliberate yet forceful, watching Rhea’s every movement as the archbishop clashed blades with her.

 

“You have no right to the power you’ve stolen!” the saint sneered, using her shield to catch the professor’s strikes, “My mother is dead because of you! The world would be at peace if you just surrendered this empty existence you call a life! But no, instead you are an abomination worse than any other!”

 

“...You Agarthans really like that word, abomination,” Byleth noted, before raising her free hand and causing a sudden flash of light that made Rhea stumble back with a yelp of pain as she was blinded. A yelp that cut off with a sudden choke when Byleth stabbed straight through her chest. “...For what it’s worth, I don’t think I’m really angry at the real you. Even with everything…I don’t know. I guess…you still feel like family.”

 

“You’re no family of mine,” Jeralt snarled, swinging the spear in a wide arc, keeping Shez at a distance, “You’re just a leech, feeding off of everyone you get attached to! How many people are dead because you insisted on getting close to them!? Even your own mother died because of you!”

 

“You really don’t know shit, do you?” Shez muttered, before vanishing from view.

 

Jeralt whirled, swinging behind himself, before pausing when he realized Shez wasn’t–And then a white sword drove straight into his head as Shez leapt from the top of the pillar she’d warped to.

 

The constructs melted into shadow again and the sisters smiled at each other from their place on the field…only to pause as they realized they weren’t alone as the field shifted again.

 

Shez stared at Byleth, who stared at Shez. Or at least, the Shez next to her, just as there was another Byleth beside Byleth.

 

“...Oh this is going to make my head hurt,” Shez muttered, before pausing, “Wait, I don’t have to fight the other Byleth, I just have to fight my–”

 

And she promptly raised her sword to block her doppelganger’s strike, the copy apparently having the exact same idea that she had.

 

Byleth, meanwhile, launched a ball of light that collided with the fireball her copy cast, before the pair clashed swords as well. 

 

“She was right, you know,” the false Byleth murmured, staring dully into her counterpart’s eyes, “You are an empty shell. You knew it from the beginning. Even these emotions you think you feel now are just your way of aping those around you. You pretend to be happy, angry, sad, just so you can fit in. None of it is real. You’ll never feel anything. You can’t love anyone.”

 

“...” Byleth didn’t have a moment to take a breath, not in a fight to the death. She’d always been good at thinking in the middle of a battle though. “Do I really look like this?”

 

“Yes, you really look–...Look?”

 

“It’s just…my hair looks terrible and my clothes look really bad too,” she commented, examining the ‘mirror’ that her doppelganger presented with a frown. “Oh, there’s a tear right on my chest. Was that there the whole time? You didn’t add that, right?”

 

“...What? Why would I–”

 

And Byleth punched her confused copy straight in the face because the idiot wasn’t paying attention to her free hand. She then proceeded to cut the fake’s head off while it was still dazed, and nodded to herself. “Right, I need a haircut…Hm. I shouldn’t let Shez do it.”

 

Speaking of Shez, she turned towards her sister, who seemed to be having a bit more trouble with her own copy, given that the two of them were both in their awakened forms at the moment and were matching each other strike for strike.

 

“...Hm.” Which led to a slight problem for Byleth. Namely that she wasn’t actually sure which one was her sister since they looked completely identical. “Ah, Shez?”

 

“Yeah?”” the pair asked in unison, both looking over at her.

 

“...Hm. Do you want my help with this?”

 

“Nah, I got this–” “Yes, please, help me–”

 

And Byleth immediately flung a fireball at the one that actually asked for help.

 

Shez watched as her doppelganger exploded in flames, then looked over at Byleth. “...That was all you needed to figure it out?”

 

“Yes.”

 

“...I feel like I should be mad for some reason, but that’s fair.”

 

“You two are truly absurd,” Epimenides said, his voice echoing through the void before the sisters found themselves standing in a strange new area, where the caves and rocks appeared to mix with carved stone and strange teal lights across the ground. The sage himself stood above them, atop a higher platform with stairs leading up to it. “To think, you would work so readily together despite your natures…a true aberration in this world’s natural order.”

 

"Yeah whatever, are you going to come down here and fight us, or are we gonna have to drag you down?" Shez asked, glaring up at him. 

 

Before he could answer, the space next to Shez and Byleth shattered, as Rhea came crashing through it. Jerking back a bit in surprise, the sisters watched Rhea ram her fist again and again into the face of a barrel-chested and gray-haired man, rhythmically punching into the bloodied ruin.

 

The mimic of a man seemed to twitch as Rhea continued to beat him, before he finally faded away. 

 

"...Uh, was that guy important?" Shez asked, staring at Rhea, who was breathing in deeply. 

 

"He was no one." 

 

“Okay then.”

 

Byleth furrowed her brow. “Huh. I think I had dreams about exactly this moment. Though with more stabbing instead of punching.”

 

Epimenides, meanwhile, scowled from his place atop the dais. “So it seems all three of my foes have gathered in one place. The incarnation of that hateful monstrosity, the abomination that enslaved this continent, and my fractured vessel, too foolish to realize the true depths of her betrayal. You all–“

 

“You’ve got a lot of nerve, talking about betrayals,” Shez interrupted, glaring straight at the sage, “But it doesn’t matter, does it? I’m done arguing with you, Epi. I don’t care what you have to say. You’re here, in front of me, and that means I’m going to kill you.”

 

"If that is all you have to say, then let us begin," Epimenides said, before forming two cylindrical objects, which charged for a moment before sending twin beams of magic straight at the two nabateans. 

 

As Byleth and Rhea dodged to the side, Shez charged forward, aiming directly at their captor to finish this, flashing behind him as he tried to make her stumble with a screeching Banshee spell. Slashing with all her force, she scowled as her blade clashed against a magical barrier. 

 

"Foolish child, do you think you could harm me in my realm?" he mocked, glancing back at her with a cold glare–Then he flinched when a ball of light exploded against his barrier. 

 

Epimenides immediately looked towards the source, his eyes wide at the sight of Byleth’s extended hand, before a series of Agnea’s Arrows began smashing against his barrier, the bolts of magic stabbing into its surface. “Gh–You loathsome beasts! You think you can break through the power of–”

 

Then Shez rammed the point of her sword into the barrier and started stabbing into it, aiming to pierce through to get to the Agarthan sage.

 

Scowling, he warped away, making Shez stumble forward as he appeared behind Rhea. Raising his hand, a swarm rushed towards the Nabatean, which crashed against a bolganone as Rhea whipped around. 

 

Smoke covered the area, before abruptly parting as Dark Spikes pierced through them. None of them hit, and Epimenides narrowed his eyes as he searched for his foes.

 

Then Rhea’s fist smashed into his barrier hard enough to leave a crack. It quickly sealed back up, but the evidence of damage was enough to drive Rhea into smashing her fists against the barrier again and again, aiming to break through the magic shield while Epimenides glared in open fury, incensed by the damage done.

 

“You vicious, unthinking brute! You think you can just overwhelm me with force?!”

 

“Not alone,” she remarked, her own glare cold and intent as Epimenides felt a faint chill down his spine, right before two swords nearly pierced it. 

 

“GAH!” He yelled in pain from the sudden sharp points driving into his back as a pair of blades wielded by a pair of sisters pierced through his barrier. “YOU WRETCHED–!”

 

He saw Shez’s glare. The sheer fury in her eyes made a small, forgotten part of himself suddenly surge up, causing Epimenides’s barrier to falter for only a moment, though a moment was all Rhea needed.

 

The fist that smashed into the sage’s face was a falling star impacting the earth. It hit him with a force he could only compare to the blast that killed him, breaking parts of his skull as the pair of blades tore through him, plunging all the way through and out of his chest. Had he lungs, they would have been impaled. 

 

As it was, the sage did not bleed red blood; he was not alive in that sense. Instead, the darkness that made up his being began to leak, flowing upwards into the air as he felt himself choke.

 

“Grk–Nh, hah, w-what…w-what is this? Am I…Am I dying?” He asked the question to the void itself, staring up at it as particles flowed from the wound in his chest. “...no. Why? I shouldn’t. I defeated death. I returned. I…why is it so dark? I…It was dark then…and then that hellish light…”

 

Rhea stared at him, silent and coldly satisfied. Byleth stared at her sister, concerned for her. Shez bowed her head, trying not to look at the being that was once her friend as he died.

 

“I…I cannot die. I cannot. I cannot. I can not. I am Epimenides. I am eternal. I am the protector of this world…” His gaze drifted down to the twin swords piercing through his chest. “No. No, not like this. Not ever. I cannot–I will not tolerate this humiliation.”

 

Shez stumbled, catching herself before she tripped from the sudden disappearance of the weight on the end of her swords. She looked around, then grimaced when she saw Epimenides stumbling, trying to keep himself steady after warping away from them. There were holes in his white robes, darkness starting to drench the cloth like leaking blood. “...Come on, Epi. Can’t you just…just, please, give up already.”

 

“...” He stared at her, a dull look in his orange eyes. “Give up? Give up…what? My life? My world? My pride?! ” He stumbled, that dullness morphing into a burning, vicious hate. “You know nothing of our greatness! You scramble in the dirt, unknowing of the depths to which you’ve sunk! These monsters stole everything from us, and you want me to give it up!? You want me to bow to my killers!?”

 

“YOU WOULD SIDE WITH THEM OVER ME?! ” His voice echoed out, harsh and furious and all too pathetic as he tried to hold himself together, unwilling to cede for even a second. The void twisted around him, darkness reacting to his fury, before it began to pull towards him. His hand extended, and a book formed above his palm, the sight of its glowing surface making Rhea audibly growl.

 

“You hid a relic here.”

 

“Hrotti…my book. I crafted its pages from the flesh of your kind and built its cover with the bones of a black-scaled beast…” He tapped a finger against the crest stone there. “Her heart still beats here. Though…no, your kind has no beating hearts. You have nothing but stones. You are not alive. All you are…is material, for making something greater than you could ever be.”

 

His eyes turned towards Shez, ignoring the fury in Rhea’s eyes. “You abandon humanity for falsely ‘living’ objects crafted by the worst abomination to ever come to this world. You side with these…things? Then allow me to show you what monsters you would bow your head to.”

 

The void twisted again, darkness pouring into Epimenides’s wounds and burning bright with the same red-orange light that engulfed the tome called Hrotti. That light built up, shining brighter and brighter before twin roars echoed out in the dark as Shez came face to face with two massive creatures. One, an enormous horned turtle; the other, a gigantic, beaked and feathered dragon.

 

The pair of dragons roared loudly, the sound echoing through the void as Rhea audibly snarled. “You would pervert even my closest allies!?”

 

“This is what you fight for, Shez.” Epimenides ignored her, his eyes locked on his vessel. Fiery light filled his wounds, sealing them even as it burned at his robes. “Monsters, all of them. They are beasts. It is only right we treat them as beasts. What crime was there in hunting such creatures?”

 

“...” Shez just stared at him, up until she felt Byleth’s hand on her shoulder. She sighed softly at the comforting gesture, before nodding to her sister and turning towards their companion. “Hey Rhea, it might be kinda messed up to ask this, but could you handle the big guys?”

 

“I would have argued if you asked otherwise,” Rhea stated, before immediately charging towards the dark copies of her fellow Nabateans, her body shifting as she went until a white dragon smashed straight into the false copy of the Immovable, immediately bowling the water dragon over onto his shelled back before she leapt for the Wind-Caller, sending the wind dragon to the ground in a screeching tangle of limbs.

 

“...I could handle this,” Byleth noted, giving her sister a concerned look.

 

“Yeah, you could. I think I oughta do it though.”

 

“Okay.” Byleth passed her sword over, nodding to Shez as Epimenides scoffed.

 

“Spare me this ridiculous act,” he demanded as he tried to stand tall, every inch of his being pushed to the limits of keeping himself alive, his eyes focused straight on the hateful Fell Star that ruined everything. “You are nothing but a heartless beast, incapable of even the slightest–”

 

Then the great sage of Agartha choked as a pair of blades pierced straight through his chest and out his back. 

 

A pair of violet eyes filled his vision. It took him a moment to realize he was looking into the eyes of his vessel, before light spilled from his mouth and leaked down his chest, closer to blood than the darkness that began to flake away from his body. “...y-you…?”

 

“Yeah. No hesitating this time,” Shez stated, meeting his gaze, “No sneak attacks either. Though it doesn’t seem like you saw me coming.”

 

“...Y-You…Y-You foolish…ch-child…” He glared back at her, dark magic gathering as his halo and crown glowed. “Y-You would…Y-You…H-How could you?”

 

“Pretty easily, Epi. You’re a monster.” She stated it plainly and simply, the truth of her statement resonating in the air. “All I want from you is one answer. Can I get Arval back?”

 

“...h-ha. W-What use would I have for a construct that served its purpose?” His glare deepened, fiery light and deep darkness flickering around his body. “You think I can ever truly die? You may think me defeated, but for as long as my power resides within your body, I still linger! You will never be rid of me! And I will make you pay for this betrayal!”

 

“It’s my power too, Epi,” Shez retorted, her grip tightening on her summoned sword…before a thought occurred to her, and her eyes locked on the crown Epimenides wore. “And you just put an interesting thought in my brain.”

 

“Wh–What are you–” And Epimenides went rigid as Shez grabbed his crown. “NO! NO, DON’T YOU DARE–”

 

She ignored him, gripping tighter and starting to pull as red lightning crackled between him, a shriek of pain and outrage sounding out from the sage while Shez pulled on his power, her own markings glowing brighter in the dark with each forceful tug. She could feel him try to pull back, magic surging in piercing darkness and fiery light, before it suddenly surged, trying to push into her brain in some attempt at overwhelming her mind.

 

“IGNORANT CHILD! YOU HAVE NO CONCEPT OF WHAT FORCES YOU ARE–!”

 

“I DON’T CARE! STOP TRYING TO HURT MY FAMILY AND GIVE ME BACK MY FRIEND!” Shez shouted over him, before tightening her grip and tearing the crown from Epimenides’s head.

 

The sage shrieked, then stumbled away from her as his body was wreathed in fiery light. The pair of swords pushed themselves from his chest as his wings sparked and his halo fractured, before there was an eruption of light and sound as the power that was Epimenides destabilized entirely.

 

Power surged throughout the void, illuminating it as though a sun was born in its darkness. Every construct the fell sage had brought forth burned away in the light, before it finally subsided and a white figure stumbled out from the light, blinking their orange eyes in bleary confusion.

 

“...p-partner?” they managed to say, before collapsing forward into Shez’s arms.

 

"H-Hey Arval," Shez said, holding her friend close, "Glad to have you back." 

Chapter End Notes

Red: So ends Epimenides! Man, it's been quite the journey to reach this point.

Indi: Been a long time coming, and it finally happened, albeit with a tough fight. Including one where Rhea went sicko mode offscreen.

Red: We had to move her over there for a bit because she just kept killing the moral quandaries when they showed up. She has no patience for that sort of thing.

Indi: Such is what happens when you finally get to vent your frustrations

Red: Rhea has a lot of repressed rage. This situation...didn't really help that, but y'know. Small steps at a time.

Indi: At least she has a new hobby to pursue once they escape.

Red: That she does! But for now, thanks for reading!

The Return of the Eisner Sisters

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

"So, you're Arval," Byleth said, staring at the spirit, who had woken up again and was now floating beside her sister.

 

"Yes…I must admit, it is certainly refreshing being able to speak to someone other than Shez. No offense, partner," Arval replied, before glancing at Rhea, who was keeping her distance, “Though I suppose not everyone is ready to talk?” 

 

"Give her a moment, she’ll warm up. You're nicer than the other guy." 

 

"Of course they are! No way I would have been friends with Arval if they acted like Epi!" Shez declared, before slapping the spirit on the back. "And boy do I have so much to tell you!" 

 

"No need. I may not have been aware during my possession, but I seemed to have retained Epimenides’s memories." Arval smirked at their partner. "Really now, partner, I didn't think you'd end up with two girls." 

 

Byleth blinked as Shez stiffened. "Wait, what happened?" 

 

"I-I'll explain later! For now we should try getting out of here!" 

 

"You actually have a method to escape?" Rhea asked. 

 

"Yes! …Maybe. As long as it works, anyways," Shez said, getting Rhea and Byleth to stare at her blankly. "H-Hey, Epimenides is the one who made this place, right? So as long as Arval and I work together, we should be able to escape!" 

 

"In theory, that should work,” Arval agreed, “As this is his realm, his power should allow you to open it once more. Although…to be specific, you do not need me, you merely need his power." 

 

"Eh, semantics." 

 

"I don't think I made myself clear. You don't need me, partner." 

 

Shez paused, then gave Arval a concerned look. “What do you mean? I just got you back.”

 

“I know that, and I appreciate all you have done to help me, partner. Though I could have done without being stabbed through the torso twice,” they remarked, patting their mostly healed chest. Their smile faded after a moment as Shez continued frowning. “...I am sorry, partner. I…I would like to continue on as we were before, but we cannot ignore the years that passed between the last time you and I interacted without his presence.”

 

“...what does that mean?”

 

“It means that your body should be your own, Shez, just as it means that a part of me will always worry that Epimenides could return if I remained connected to you. I know it is unlikely, but so was the event that caused him to awaken in the first place, and I refuse to let you suffer the pain of sharing a body with someone who would rip it away from you if he ever had the full opportunity.”

 

“...” Shez swallowed, feeling her eyes start to burn with gathering tears. “That’s not fair, Arval…”

 

“I know. I’m sorry. If I could, I would happily be your companion again. But if I did, then I would remain as an unheard specter, only able to interact with the world through using you…” They took a breath of their own, trying hard to keep their composure. “I…You should be free of this burden, partner. Free to live your life as you choose, without the legacy of a long dead fool hanging over you.”

 

"B-But…but…I-I was able to beat him before, and I can beat him again!" 

 

"And are you willing to risk everyone you know for me?" Arval asked, getting Shez to stiffen. They smiled, leaning up and giving their partner a hug. “Thank you for caring so much about me, partner. You risked everything to try to bring me back, and I will always be thankful for that. Just as I am thankful that I finally get to hold you like this.”

 

It took Shez a moment, but she eventually returned the hug, holding her friend as tightly as she could.

 

“Ngh-A-Ah, c-careful, I am not as hardy as you–”

 

“Oh, right, sorry!” She hugged them less tightly, before finally letting go. “...You know I would fight him for you, right? I’m going to keep fighting if I need to. He won’t stop me, even if he does come back.”

 

“...you truly are the best partner I could ask for,” Arval praised, smiling at her, before they let out a sigh, “Though, if I have to admit it, I am also absolutely exhausted after everything. Fighting you is a tiring affair, partner, and I think I need some time to rest regardless.”

 

“Oh, so all of that was just an excuse not to tell me you needed a nap, huh?” Shez questioned, raising an eyebrow at Arval…then letting out a small sigh of her own. “You really want to stay here?”

 

“...I want to stay close to you. I need to stay here.”

 

“Got it…I’m going to miss you.”

 

“I’ll still be here, partner. Who knows? Maybe I’ll find a safe way to visit at some point…or perhaps you could visit me, once you figure out how to do so safely.”

 

“Yeah, maybe if I find a way to get here without killing someone every time.” Shez sighed again, before glancing back at Byleth and Rhea. “Well, I’m pretty sure I know how to get out of here now, mostly because of the whole…absorbing Epi’s powers thing. So whenever you want to go, I’m up to go.”

 

"...Thank you for being Shez’s friend, Arval," Byleth said, smiling at the spirit. 

 

"And thank you for taking her in, all those years ago." 

 

"I think that was more papa than me." 

 

"Even so, thank you. Given how absent-minded she can be, I shudder to think what would have happened to her before I had awakened." 

 

"Fuck you too, Arval," Shez muttered, the venom missing from her voice. 

 

"Don't worry, she'll be okay." Glancing at Shez, Byleth put a hand on her shoulder,."She's stronger than both of us realize." 

 

Shez huffed, her face reddening a little at the praise, which earned a sly smile from Arval. “Indeed, she truly is the most wonderful partner I could have asked for. Strong, brave, and far smarter than she gives herself credit for.”

 

“Eesh, you’re really laying it on thick there,” Shez grumbled, actually getting kind of embarrassed.

 

“Why partner, whatever might be wrong, hm? I thought you adored being praised for your strength and skill?”

 

"Yeah yeah," Shez huffed, looking away, "Just…take care, okay?" 

 

"If you get bored, Rhea and I made a bunch of stone dolls you can play with," Byleth offered, getting Shez to blink. Even more so when Rhea seemed to speak up for a moment, as if to take the offer away, before deciding not to. 

 

“I appreciate that. Thank you, Byleth. I am glad to have finally met you properly, and I’m sorry for trying to provoke Shez into conflict with you. I suppose I can blame it on the influence of Epimenides, but I still want to apologize regardless. I made some trouble for you, even if my partner loves you too much to ever truly hurt you.”

 

“Hmph. It’s like you’re trying to embarrass me at this point,” Shez grumbled, which earned a small smile from Byleth.

 

“No need to be embarrassed. I love you too, little sister.”

 

“...this is the only time I’m letting you call me ‘little’ anything, especially since you’re still shorter than me.”

 

“So, are we able to leave at any time now?” Rhea spoke up, trying to keep her face neutral despite the mix of emotions she felt at the moment. Mostly good, though a part of her did feel weird looking at Arval.

 

“Oh, yeah! I think I can get us out of here right now!” Shez said with a grin, “Unless there’s anything left for you guys here?”

 

“No, anything of note can be left here for, ah, Arval to…amuse themself with, I suppose.”

 

“I appreciate that,” Arval said, smiling at Rhea, who looked distinctly uncomfortable.

 

Shez, meanwhile, got up and drew her swords. She could feel a thrum of power through her, something that linked up with the void itself, and she could feel it pulsing through her white sword…actually, she could feel it in both her swords now. Which had some implications that she was going to think about later. 

 

For now, she just glanced over at Arval again. "I'm gonna miss you, buddy." 

 

“I will too. And remember, I will always be happy to host you if you get the opportunity to visit.”

 

Shez remembered what exactly it took to travel into Zahras. "...I'll think about it." 

 

"You're nice Arval, but I don't think I'll come back here anytime soon,” Byleth said apologetically.

 

Rhea didn’t even bother to reply. 

 

"Ah, yes, the ‘sacrificing a life’ part…well, we can work something out, I think. For now, please make sure to take care of her, okay, Byleth?" Arval requested.

 

"I will…thank you for saving Shez all those years ago, Arval. I don't think I could ever pay you back for that."

 

"You'll have to be more specific, I lost count of all the times I had to save her." 

 

“Yeah yeah, laugh it up,” Shez grumbled, which did earn some small laughs from Byleth and Arval before she stabbed her swords forward into the open air, somehow piercing into the void itself.
