With a slow drag downwards, she split the void apart, bringing light into the darkness for a sudden, impossible moment.

 

And then they were gone.

Once she landed back in the dungeon, Shez took a deep breath, trying to ease herself as she heard Byleth and Rhea land behind her. Behind them, the rift quickly closed–

 

"Wait, we forgot my headdress," Rhea realized, getting Shez to pause before she glanced at the archbishop.

 

“Uh…I’m not sure I can do a return trip right now?” She wiggled her sword, trying to see if she could find another easy way to cut across realms.

 

"Technically it was mine, also, since I took it as severance pay,” Byleth commented, before pausing, “Though…hm, I just realized I left my coat behind…Well, it should be fine. I still have a spare at the monastery…right?" 

 

“Oh, right, you guys are really out of the loop,” Shez realized, “Okay, uh…so, bad news, the monastery kind of fell a while ago. All the demonic beasts and invaders, plus Rhea suddenly disappearing, meant we all had to abandon the place and scatter, and nobody has taken it back yet. Well, I think no one has? I’m not completely sure. I’ve been kinda wandering around while the war is going on–Oh right, there’s been a war going on for the past three years.”

 

“...oh. That’s not good.”

 

Rhea looked even less pleased with that news. “How could this–No, never mind. Between whom?”

 

“Huh? Oh, uh…everybody?” Shez attempted to answer, “I mean, the Empire split in half–Well, maybe more like…two thirds, one third? Uh, Duke Aegir–No, Archduke Aegir now, he seceded from the Empire and made this whole Princy thing that’s invading the Alliance–Oh shit, right, the raid!”

 

Shez immediately moved to the entrance to the dungeon, looking around worriedly. “HEY! IS ANYBODY STILL HERE?!”

 

The lack of a prompt response immediately made her worried. She had no idea if time worked the same way between the void and the regular world and that struck her with a sudden sense of terror that she might have spent years and years inside fighting Epimenides without even realizing–

 

"There you are!" And she suddenly found herself pushed against a wall, Kronya scowling at her as she grabbed her collar. "Where the fuck did you go!?" 

 

“Oh! Oh, great, I didn’t go missing for a century!” Shez let out a little relieved laugh, before smiling happily and giving Kronya a hug. “Mm, it’s good to see you!”

 

“...” Kronya, meanwhile, found her anger and worry rapidly fading as Shez embraced her, her face actually warming a bit as she was pulled close to her chest. “...uh…yeah. Okay. I’m good with this.”

 

“Oh, hi Kronya,” Byleth greeted as she peeked out of the cell, smiling when she spotted the Agarthan. Before she noticed Kronya’s current position and the fact that Shez was hugging her very tightly. “Huh.”

 

“Mm–Eh? O-Oh, uh, hey professor! I was just–Wait, what the…” It took Kronya a second to register what she was seeing, before an immediate, big smile came to her face. “Professor! Holy shit, Shez actually got you back!”

 

“Yep, she did. It’s nice to see you again, you’re looking well.” And a little bit squished, but then Shez was being very enthusiastic with her hugging.

 

“Ah, right, you already know about her!” Shez remembered, grinning, “Heh, well, guess that means I don’t have to introduce you!”

 

“I wouldn’t mind if you did. I think you’re supposed to introduce someone as your girlfriend if you’ve started dating her, right?”

 

“I am? Huh, I guess–Ah, wait, u-uh, Kronya and me? No, we’re not, er… exactly dating, I think.”

 

Kronya saw an opportunity and immediately took it, keeping one arm around Shez as she pulled out of her embrace and grinning at Byleth. “Oh yeah, we haven’t been dating for a while, we’re way more official than that. Hell, I think we’ve been married for three years now, right Shez~?”

 

Shez blinked. She…wasn’t quite sure what to say in response there, though Byleth just nodded. “That makes sense. I am upset you didn’t invite me to the wedding though.”

 

Shez’s eyes narrowed at her sister’s deliberately blank expression. “We’re not married. I…you kissing me in the forest doesn’t count as marriage, Kronya.”

 

“It doesn’t? Hm, that’s a shame. I guess you’ll just have to marry me properly then~”

 

“...I-I, uh…w-where’s everybody else?” Shez asked, deliberately changing the subject.

 

“Oh, right, that. They got a letter from Lorenz’s dad that said the attack was going on right now, so they had to go. You weren’t around though, so I said I’m staying.” She smirked. “So jokes on them, I made the right choice here.”

 

“There’s an attack?” Byleth asked, frowning.

 

“Ah, crap, I didn’t think it would happen this soon,” Shez muttered, before turning to her sister, “Remember how Castle Ordelia got taken by that Acheron guy? Agarthans decided to keep the place after he died, so we were going to go through a tunnel here and try to take it back from them.”

 

“It’s going to be my castle when we take it back,” Kronya added, looking smug.

 

“That wasn’t decided yet–Right, okay, we should go help them. As much as I hate her, Bias is still a dangerous opponent and I don’t want everyone to go up against her without us.." 

 

"Bias is here?" Byleth asked, a frown on her face. 

 

"Yes, but you better not go rushing off to fight her on your own," Shez warned, frowning at her sister.

 

“I won’t. I’ve learned from my mistakes. So, shall we take her on together?” She extended her hand to Shez, smiling.

 

“...Hell yeah, let’s do it!” Shez declared, grabbing her sister’s hand firmly.

 

“So should I address the presence of an Agarthan here, or…?” Rhea asked, raising an eyebrow as the sisters remembered she was standing in the cell the whole time.

 

“Oh, yeah, uh, this is Kronya,” Shez introduced, gesturing towards her.

 

“Hey,” Kronya greeted, giving her a small wave.

 

“...” Rhea raised an eyebrow. “And who is she, exactly?”

 

“I’m Shez’s future wife.”

 

“...u-uh, well, aside from, um, that…possibility, Kronya’s my friend and, ah, you might’ve known her as Emily,” Shez explained.

 

Rhea’s eyebrow remained raised. “Who?”

 

“...Emily Korsch?”

 

“...?”

 

“She was a student at the academy. She left after Bias attacked?”

 

Rhea frowned. “She was one of the Agarthans that infiltrated the monastery?”

 

"Look, trust me, Kronya can be trusted," Byleth said, vouching for her former student. 

 

"...Did you know she was–" 

 

"Rhea, we can deal with this later. Come on." 

 

Rhea frowned, then sighed, acquiescing. “Very well. Do you have a sword I can use?”

 

“Oh yeah, we should get both of you swords,” Shez realized, “Well that should be fine, there’s bound to be a bunch around here.”

 

"Oh right, Shez, do you have the Sword of the Creator?" Byleth asked.

 

"Oh, no, I actually hid it, since it was too heavy for me to carry around. Don't worry, we can get it after this!" 

 

"Good, I'd prefer to make sure Sothis' spine is okay." 

 

"Yeah, of course–...what?" 

Castle Ordelia had seen better days. That’d already been true when it had been overrun by demonic beasts, but it certainly didn’t look any better now that it was being fully besieged by an invading army.

 

Even then, the castle likely would have held out against its invaders…were it not for the infiltrators that made their way inside through a secret tunnel, past all the defenses that were meant to keep intruders out.

 

“Oh wow, Claude and the crew did some good work here,” Shez noted as she exited the tunnel alongside her sister and companions, taking in the black-armored corpses strewn about the ground. “Oh, I bet Lysithea got that one! Guy looks like a pincushion, she definitely spiked him.”

 

"I could have done better," Kronya commented, before she ran forward towards the sound of combat. 

 

"This isn't a competition. I'm sure you've kept up your training, but you need to remain careful," Byleth said, keeping a steady grip on the steel sword she’d been given. 

 

“Oh I’ll be careful! Careful not to show you up too much, professor!” Kronya called back, before using her tails to propel herself forwards and stab straight into the neck of a knight distracted by Alliance forces.

 

“Well, I suppose it’s a good thing to have an Agarthan’s bloodthirsty nature on our side for once,” Rhea muttered as she hurried after the younger women, her white gown changed out for some proper, if basic, armor to fight in.

 

Byleth and Shez, meanwhile, quickly fell into rhythm as they joined the fight. Shez sped in, cutting down foes with ease while Byleth supported her with magic and her own blade, taking out any stragglers and finishing the wounded as the two sisters, working together in near perfect sync despite all their years apart, took control of the entire battlefield.

 

The Alliance troops, initially surprised by the sudden reinforcements, quickly rallied and began to push against the forces of House Phlegethon, who soon found themselves routed. Though Byleth and Shez didn’t focus much on that, instead heading further into the castle in search of their friends while the Alliance troops found themselves suddenly under the command of the archbishop, of all people, as Rhea took charge.

 

As for the Eisner sisters, they soon made their way to the great hall of Castle Ordelia, where, sure enough, they found their friends, their foes, and a modified demonic beast.

 

“Woah, that’s a big guy,” Shez remarked, taking in the quadrupedal monstrosity, its head covered in a metallic mask. Unlike an “altered demonic beast” though, the modified beast had a blue cloth hanging over its mouth instead of the standard red one and the metal covering its body was spikier and silvery instead of golden. “Ah, that’s probably the ice-breath type they were talking about.”

 

“You didn’t mention that earlier,” Byleth noted, quickly taking in the battlefield and all the forces present as the Deer tried to deal with the monster.

 

“Eh, I had other things on the mind. I don’t think there’s much difference between them, but be careful anyway.”

 

“Understood.” The wide spacing in the great hall meant that the Deer had a good amount of room to maneuver, as evidenced by Claude using his wyvern to stay out of harm’s way, though the battle seemed like it wasn’t going completely in their favor considering the Agarthans had multiple armored knights backing up the beast. “Hm…LEONIE! IGNATZ! FOCUS YOUR ARROWS ON THE BEAST! KEEP ITS ATTENTION AWAY FROM LORENZ AND WHITTLE DOWN ITS ARMOR SO HE CAN GUT IT!”

 

The Deer in question paused for just a second at the sudden, surprising voice calling out orders, but with a renewed vigor, the former students leapt into action as Byleth and Shez joined the fray. 

 

"CLAUDE, COVER THE ARCHERS! LYSITHEA, SCATTER THE KNIGHTS!" Byleth shouted, causing the two in question to go into action, a flurry of magic and arrows kept everyone safe. 

 

Letting out a roar as Lorenz dragged his spear through its gut, the Demonic Beast released a spray of frozen magic, only for it to clash against an Aura. As an icy mist exploded across the battlefield, the demonic beast had a moment to look around only to roar in pain, as Byleth and Shez jumped through the mist, their swords piercing through the metallic mask and into its eyes. 

 

The beast shrieked in agony, stumbling and wrenching its head to try to throw them off, though its limbs soon began to weaken before it finally collapsed, crashing to the ground.

 

“Oh, my. That is not optimal.”

 

Byleth and Shez pulled their swords free from the dead beast and stepped forward together, looking and glaring at the two women up on top of the dais.

 

“Heh. So you did get her back…” Bias murmured, then smirked beneath her mask and waved to the two sisters, “Hello, Fell Star and Failed Vessel.”

 

“You know, it feels unfair that you got to say hi first,” Claude complained as he landed his wyvern beside Byleth, before glancing at the older Eisner sister, “Hey Teach. Long time, no see.”

 

“Hey Claude,” Byleth replied, keeping her eyes on Bias.

 

“We’re going to have to talk later,” Lysithea stated, moving to stand beside Shez as magic gathered at her hands.

 

“Ah, yeah, we definitely do,” Shez agreed, thinking about…well, a lot of things at the moment, “For now, we better focus on the fight.”

 

“Excellent thinking, Shez. I will congratulate you on your success later,” Lorenz stated, bringing his horse up alongside Lysithea, his own eyes locked on the second woman up on the dais, “For now, Lady Cocytus Phlegethon, if that is your real name, on behalf of House Gloucester and the Alliance, I demand your surrender!”

 

“I will have to refuse,” the blonde in the brown dress replied, her hair curled into drills, “Surrender is not an option.”

 

“You sure?” Shez called out, “Because we don’t have to kill you. You could just call it quits here and let us take you prisoner.”

 

“You would have value as a hostage,” Claude pointed out, “Sure, you might’ve committed a few crimes here and there, but if you’re willing to give us information–”

 

“That is a remarkably insulting insinuation, you filthy beast,” Lady Cocytus responded, her tone cold and even, “To claim I would betray my kind for the sake of a beast’s mercy…I believe I will have to kill you personally for that.”

 

“...well, can’t blame a guy for trying.” Claude’s eyes narrowed even as he kept up his smirk. “Any chance you’ll tell me who you really are before you kill me?”

 

Lady Cocytus, otherwise known as Kyrie of Agarthan, the Sage of Water, regarded Claude with a cold disinterest. “I have no reason to give my name to a dead man.”

 

As the false noblewoman stood poised to face off against the Deer, Bias stared down at Byleth, her gaze unwavering. 

 

She felt her hands twitch the longer she stared, as her pulse began to rush. Even with the mask covering the Agarthan’s face, Byleth could tell Bias was smiling as a light within the sage's heart began to kindle once more. 

 

"Bias, before we start, I only have one thing to say," the Fell Star started, "I'm sorry for what happened to your sister," 

 

Bias felt her smile become a scowl, "What, don't tell me you're going to do a sappy–" 

 

"But, regardless of what happened, I want you to know that I'm going to kill you here and now. Because I hate you far more than I could ever pity you." 

 

"...Oh you have no idea how long I have waited to hear those words." Then she raised her hands and the room erupted in flame.

Chapter End Notes

Red: Hi Arval! Bye Arval!

Indi: They're still alive at least, but well, doesn't want to risk Shez

Red: Yup! Perhaps we'll see them later, but for now, fight time!

Indi: And boy is it going to be one heck of a fight.

Fimbulvetr and Ragnarok

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

The Great Hall of Castle Ordelia burned as the Agarthan Sage of Fire let loose with years of pent up hatred. The torrent of fire she let loose melted the stone floor, searing it down to the earth beneath it, which began to bake under the intense heat.

 

“Mm. Not good,” Byleth remarked, having already used up a charge just to move everyone out of the way of that blast, which prompted startled noises from Lorenz and Lysithea when they realized they were suddenly several feet to the right of where they’d been standing previously.

 

“W-What in the–”

 

“It’s magic, don’t worry about it,” Shez interrupted, before quickly warping over to Bias, though she had to warp back when another burst of flame nearly took her head off. Said flames did also set the ceiling on fire, which wasn’t great. “Oh, this is going to be bad–”

 

Then, all of a sudden, the heat in the room abruptly cut out as Lady Cocytus let out a slow breath, mist emanating from her mouth as she spoke: “Niflheim.”

 

In an instant, the melting stone went solid, cooled back to solid stone as the temperature dropped. A small stone, placed as a jewel on Lady Cocytus’s chest, glowed a vivid blue as the disguised Agarthan called on a rush of ice magic far beyond anything the assembled Deer had seen before.

 

Frozen constructs, knights made out of ice, began to form in front of the Deer, their spindly forms clutching frozen spears that quickly jabbed out towards the closest targets. All while Kyrie breathed out a cold mist that began to fill the room.

 

“A successful attempt,” the Agarthan noted, before glancing at her fellow sage, “May I expect your assistance?”

 

“You can expect me to kill the Fell Star,” Bias responded, her eyes fully on Byleth as flames gathered at her hands, spinning like wheels in her grasp, “Anything else, you should be able to handle.”

 

“Hm…I can understand these parameters,” Kyrie accepted, before raising her hand again, “Tundra.”

 

Ice and snow launched from her hand, bathing the ground in frost and scattering the Deer with a relentless barrage of hail.

 

“What the hell do we do against that!?” Leonie yelped, dodging a stab from one of the spear-wielding ice-knights before retaliating by impaling the construct with her own spear and using it as a shield from the snow, “How can they even cast spells that strong?!”

 

“It’s the stone at her chest!” Ignatz called out, taking cover from the snowstorm behind the dead demonic beast, “It started glowing when she cast her spells!”

 

“Good eye!” Claude praised, trying to keep his wyvern low to avoid getting the poor, shivering mount stabbed by icicles, “So we have a weak point to aim for!”

 

“And how the hell do we hit it!?” Lysithea snapped, before sending a blast of darkness to shatter some of the constructs.

 

Byleth and Shez, meanwhile, had a slightly different problem on their hands in the form of Bias launching herself off the dais and smashing right into the ground between them. A plume of fire erupted around her body as the sisters dodged back, but Bias didn’t even take a moment to pause before letting loose with a fireball at Byleth.

 

Byleth easily cut the fireball in half, dispersing the magic, but that just brought Bias in closer as she launched flame after flame at the object of her hatred. 

 

“You have no idea how long I’ve wanted another chance at killing you!” the Agarthan shouted, the eagerness in her voice obvious to anyone listening.

 

"I think I have a good idea," Byleth responded, dodging a stream of fire as Bias continued to unleash her flames. 

 

"Oh please, everything I've done to you pales in comparison to what you've done to me." 

 

"You burned my eye out!" 

 

"And it grew back! Not to mention you stabbed me in the tit!" Bias shouted back, before a pillar of fire burst up behind her, cutting off Shez’s attack. "You can tell the brat to leave." 

 

"As if I'd let Byleth fight you alone!" 

 

"I already know how dangerous you are,” Byleth stated, “I'm not risking letting you escape, especially since you'd just go after someone I care about." 

 

"In the past, perhaps. But right now?" Bias faced Byleth, and the former mercenary could tell she was smiling. "I don't care about hurting you, I want nothing more than to kill you. To see the life drain from your eyes as I tear open your chest and burn you alive from the inside out~”

 

Byleth blinked. “...hm. Shez, you’re better with obvious emotions, did what she said sound weird to you?”

 

“It sounded kinda flirty, yeah.”

 

“Hm. Hm. I…hm…Please don't tell Dorothea or Edelgard about this,” Byleth requested, before dodging another giant ball of flames that filled the air with even more steam. Which, hm. “Shez, could you come over here? I would like to use your power to warp around.”

 

“Are you really calling out your plans right in front of me?” Bias questioned, a mix of amusement and indignation audible in her voice as Shez immediately warped over to her sister and put a hand on her shoulder. Then the pair vanished again, right before another torrent of fire bathed the place where they stood in flames. “Tch. You can’t run from me, Fell Star! I’m not going to–

 

The instant she felt heat at her back, Bias whirled, catching the fireball Byleth threw. She held it in her head, scoffing. “Are you seriously trying to fight me with my own element?! Are you really that stupid!?”

 

“No, I’m just better at it than you are,” Byleth stated quite plainly, which earned an audible growl from the sage as she immediately caused the fireball to triple in size, before throwing it back at Byleth. Though, of course, Shez immediately warped with her again.

 

“Yeah, she really is bad at this,” Shez commented, keeping an arm around her sister’s shoulders, “She’s just going wild, not actually aiming.”

 

“Is that what you think?” Bias’s tone turned low and angry, the flames she held focusing to a point before shooting forward as a beam of fire. And then it missed. Again.

 

If she wasn’t wearing a mask, the Eisner sisters would’ve plainly seen a vein twitching in Bias’s forehead. “STAY STILL, YOU SHIT!”

 

“Huh.” Meanwhile, Claude was watching the flames while trying to keep low and avoid the continually launching icicles and spawning ice-knights. “Hey Lysithea, how attached are you to this place?”

 

“...” The mage, who was crouching beside his wyvern, frowned at him. “...why?”

 

“Because your crush and her sister are trying to piss off that fire mage enough that she does something stupid. Problem is, all this heat and cold probably isn’t going to be good for the stone around here.”

 

“...hm. A castle can be rebuilt. It doesn’t matter as much as us surviving.”

 

Claude grinned. “Good answer.”

 

And then he promptly stood up, aimed, and loosed an arrow straight at Kyrie. The Agarthan ice mage didn’t even move, instead raising a hand and forming a shield of ice in front of her that the arrow pierced into. “What a thoughtless action. Do you beasts have any sense of–”

 

Then she blinked when she saw Byleth and Shez suddenly appear in front of her, the latter grinning and giving her a cheeky wave while the former made a rude gesture towards Bias on the other end of the room. And Bias, in a moment of pure anger, immediately launched a massive, focus beam of fire straight across the room.

 

Sure enough, Byleth and Shez vanished before it could hit them, but Kyrie couldn’t copy that ability to warp and instead felt her eyes go wide as she saw an inferno about to impact her. “Oh dear.”

 

Heat met cold in an enormous plume of steam and mist, the shield shattering immediately and blasting Kyrie into the far wall with a brutal impact.

 

"Ah, shit, she was one of the few I could tolerate," Bias grumbled as she saw her companion slump onto the floor, "Sorry, Kyrie!" 

 

"I-If you wish to make it up to me…" the ice mage said, reaching up to grab the jewel on her chest, "Then do make sure to take notes." 

 

The combatants stared in confusion as she pulled the stone from the pendant, before their eyes widened in shock when she put it in her mouth and swallowed it. The mage seemed to gag for a moment, before a sudden chill hit everyone there. 

 

The air seemed to pulse with a sudden pressure, before the temperature dropped rapidly, the walls fully freezing as Kyrie’s body trembled. Her guise as Lady Phlegethon melted away, the magic that formed it burning up in a burst of icy blue magic that rushed through the Agarthan’s body, her hair bleaching white in a way that looked far too familiar to a certain mage among the Deer.

 

The cerulean scales that began to spread across her skin were different though. As was the sickening crack of her bones as her body began to shift and morph. Everyone could only look on in horror as her limbs began to elongate and grow thicker. As her partly burnt clothes fell away to expose pale-blue muscle, hardened like stone and stretched taut across her distorted body, Kyrie stood at her full height on clawed feet, a long, scaled tail extending down from the base of her spine. Now towering over everyone there, the once human-looking Agarthan stared down at her gathered foes with eyes like glowing blue orbs in black pits, before her mouth opened to bare sharp teeth in a fierce roar.

 

"...Myson, you mad man." Byleth heard Bias mutter, before the remaining sage jerked back when a spear of ice jutted up from the ground, almost gutting her. "Ha, fine, if this is the end you want, then take it. As for you…”

 

She glanced at Byleth, smirking. "I'll let you go for now, but know this, next time we meet, I'll have you on your knees begging for mercy~" 

 

“Please stop speaking like that,” Byleth requested.

 

“The fact that it bothers you means that I’m going to keep doing it.” With her piece said, Bias warped away, leaving everyone behind to deal with the sudden monstrosity in their midst.

 

"...Hm." Deciding not to think about that, Byleth turned back to the transformed Agarthan, just in time to block a clawed hand swiping at her. 

 

"F-FELL STAR!!!!" Kyrie shouted, her hand clenching the sword, and forming ice over the blade. Eyes widening, Byleth let go of the sword and jerked back as the sword froze over an instant later. Crushing the sword, Kyrie tried to swipe at Byleth again, only for the green-haired mercenary to warp away thanks to Shez grabbing onto her. "ABOMINATION!" 

 

"FOCUS YOUR ATTACKS!" Byleth commanded as she and Shez appeared on the other side of the field. "SHE'S AFTER ME, SO I'LL KEEP HER ATTENTION!" 

 

"Seriously? Wouldn't it just be smarter to, I dunno, freeze time and attack her?" Shez asked, her breath heavier from all the warping she had been doing. 

 

"Not that easy," Byleth admitted as Kyrie looked around in a jerking manner, her head twitching and twisting before her gaze focused on Byleth, "Moving while time is stopped takes more out of me, so I can't use it as much or as long. And I'd rather not get close to her right now." 

 

Bringing up her hand, Byleth cast Bolganone on the charging Agarthan as a slew of arrows and magic hit her as well, alongside a javelin thanks to Lorenz, only for the monstrosity to shrug it all off. Continuing her charge, the beast left a wake of ice as she moved, before leaping towards Byleth. 

 

A screech of frustration echoed out as Kyrie’s claws tore and froze the ground where Byleth once stood, the professor easily escaping thanks to her sister’s powers. Kyrie rapidly looked around before she jerked when a volley of Dark Spikes hit her from two directions, making her scream as they exploded. Yet before the smoke could even settle, she was attacking once again, this time rampaging at whoever was closest. 

 

“Shit!” Shez yelped, immediately letting go of Byleth and warping over to Lysithea so she could grab the mage and vanish before Kyrie’s claws could slam down on her. 

 

“Ah! Sh-Shez??” Lysithea yelped, startled by the mercenary’s sudden appearance. Her face warmed slightly as she felt Shez’s arms around her, before her embarrassment faded into worry when she saw how heavily Shez was breathing. “What’s happening to you?”

 

“H-Huh? Ah, nothing, I think? I mean, I guess I was moving a lot, really just…doing all that.” She paused. “Shit, this is still the same day I finished off Epi. That’s wild.”

 

"What??" 

 

"I'll explain later," Shez responded, looking back towards the fight as Kyrie tried to leap towards Claude, his wyvern screeching as it pulled back a now frozen wound on its gut. 

 

Before she could leap again, Kyrie's head was slammed to the side thanks to Byleth grabbing a hammer from a fallen knight. Kyrie turned to look at Byleth, before letting out a roar that caused an explosion of ice to bloom from the ground. Gritting her teeth as she felt a sharp pain in her abdomen, Byleth froze time, pulling back as she swung the hammer again and again into the Agarthan, before moving away as time started again. 

 

Kyrie jerked, cracks sounding out as she was impacted several times all at once, but her hide was too hard to get through and with another screech of rage and anger, the temperature dropped even further.

 

Doing her best to channel fire magic through herself, Byleth felt her body shiver from the spreading cold. She cursed the fact that she had forgotten her coat. Her allies didn't seem to be faring much better as their breath misted over, specks of ice beginning to cover their clothes. 

 

The walls had almost entirely ice over by this point and thick icicles were forming on the ceiling as the Agarthan monstrosity twisted around, searching for anyone she could vent her fury upon. She bristled at the sight of weapons leveled in her direction, the glow of magic stinging her eyes, before she sighted what was to her mind an easy target: Ignatz, who stood away from the group, trying to nock an arrow with trembling fingers.

 

The archer froze as the beast suddenly raced towards him, her massive size belying a frightening speed as his friends reacted just seconds too late–Then a brutal crack sounded out through the room, and everyone froze.

 

Ignatz shivered, staring up with wide eyes through frosted glasses as he saw Kyrie collapse to the ground, a shriek of pain sounding out from the monster as she clutched the stump at her shoulder. 

 

Her right arm had snapped off completely.

 

“It’s too cold, even for her,” Lysithea realized, staring at the creature as she howled in pain, “Whatever she did, her body is not built to handle this kind of magic. She’s been freezing herself from the inside this whole time…”

 

"Everyone, keep moving! If we can't beat her, then we have to outlast her!" Claude shouted, getting Kyrie’s attention. With a pained roar, she attempted to attack the noble, only to stumble thanks to her loss in balance. 

 

Before she could push herself up, a mire spell landed on her back, the sludge weighing her down. Yet it only held for a few seconds before freezing, shattering to pieces as Kyrie pushed herself up.

 

Growling, she began to lash around wildly, attacking whoever she saw with reckless abandon as more cracks started to form across her body. 

 

"Aim for her legs! If we can destroy one, she won't be able to move!" Lorenz shouted, before ducking as Kyrie clawed into the ground, sending frozen chunks at the purple-haired noble. 

 

Before the monstrosity could continue to attack, a salvo of arrows and magic struck her distorted body, causing more cracks to form across her limbs, before a loud shatter rang out as her leg snapped and she fell. With a roar, she made one last desperate attack, dragging herself with her free hand towards Byleth before attempting to leap with her remaining leg. 

 

Gritting her teeth, Byleth swung the hammer with all the force she could muster. As metal met scale, there was a brief moment of resistance, before the metal broke through, shattering Kyrie’s head and driving the Agarthan into the ground. 

 

Panting heavily, Byleth let the hammer go, exhaustion rapidly hitting her. Placing a hand on her abdomen, she used the last of her magic to heal herself, closing the wound as best she could. All while the beast before her twitched on the ground, black blood leaking from a shattered skull.

 

“What the hell was that?” Leonie muttered, staring down at the ruined monster. Before she paused and glanced over at Byleth. “Also, uh…hi?”

 

“Hello,” Byleth replied, turning to her friend and smiling, “It’s nice to see you, Leonie.”

 

Then she promptly flopped forward, narrowly getting caught by Shez and Leonie before she could hit the floor. 

 

"Please tell me you guys brought a healer," Shez asked, glancing around her former classmates, "Because Byleth and I really need one." 

 

With that, she flopped forward as well, getting Leonie to yelp as she held onto both sisters so they wouldn't fall over. 

 

"W-We should get them out of the cold!" Ignatz immediately said, moving to help Leonie carry the two. 

 

"Right, we should all get out of the cold before we start feeling the effects," Claude stated, "Lorenz, make sure none of Count Gloucester's men mess with the body before we can properly check it out." 

 

"Hmph, you are lucky that we have more pressing matters to focus on rather than you attempting to order me around," Lorenz huffed as everyone began to leave. 

 

"What happened here?" Though before they could, they were stopped as they found the former archbishop standing before them. One who looked both worried and angered as she stared at the unconscious Byleth. 

 

And before anyone could answer, another interruption appeared in the form of Kronya, making her way past Rhea and standing proudly. "Alright, everyone is dead, this is my castle now!" 

 

“...” Rhea stared at the absurd Agarthan for a few seconds, before turning to look at Claude and Lorenz with a baffled expression. “You agreed to give her this castle?”

 

Lorenz scoffed. “We made no such agreement–”

 

“They absolutely did,” Kronya interrupted, nodding firmly, “Castle’s mine.”

 

“It is not–”

 

“Well we do need a new Count to hold this territory,” Claude mused, trying to hide a smile, “I guess if Lorenz and Lysithea already agreed to it, I’ll give the go ahead too.”

 

"I did not–" 

 

"Alrighty then, the first order of business is to get me a fancy room," Kronya said, grinning to herself. Lysithea couldn't help but scowl at the assassin, yet was unable to offer a retort thanks to Leonie speaking up. 

 

"Guys can we argue later? Shez and Byleth kinda need to see a healer."

 

“Ah, yes, of course. Please, allow me to aid them,” Rhea offered, quickly heading over to help lift Byleth up–Though she immediately dropped her when she spotted the remains of Kyrie, earning a small yelp from the exhausted professor. “What in the Goddess’s name is–Oh no, my apologies child! I didn’t mean to–Here, let me help you up.”

 

“That’s a good question, actually,” Kronya commented while Rhea fussed over Byleth, “What the hell is that thing?”

 

"One of the people working with the Red Mage. I don't know what exactly happened, but she swallowed a small stone-like object," Lorenz explained as Rhea healed Byleth’s now broken nose, "Whatever it was amplified her power, but also turned her into this." 

 

Rhea stiffened. “Was it a crest stone?”

 

“Not sure,” Claude admitted, “It might’ve been, but we can’t exactly check now, can we?” He paused. “Well, maybe if we cut her open.”

 

“Claude! That is a revolting suggestion!” Lorenz reprimanded, looking disgusted, “Even if she became a monster, you should know better than to suggest dissecting a human being! Especially in front of the archbishop! It goes against every teaching of the church!”

 

Claude raised an eyebrow, well aware that Lorenz wasn’t as faithful as this show he was putting on suggested. Then again, they were in front of the archbishop herself…who actually looked a little irritated that her own rules were coming to bite her like this.

 

"Thank you, Lorenz," Rhea said, a bit of annoyance in her voice, "For now, let's just try to make sure no one touches the remains." 

 

"Of course, Lady Rhea," Lorenz responded, bowing slightly to her as Claude rolled his eyes. 

 

"In that case, after making sure Teach and Shez are okay, we should find some place to discuss what we should do going forward." 

 

"I vote we head to the Empire," Byleth said, raising a limp hand to vote. 

 

“You would,” Shez grumbled, though she sounded amused.

 

“Oh, maybe we should go find Captain Jeralt first?” Leonie suggested, immediately making Shez blanch.

 

“Ah…maybe that Empire visit is a good idea after all.”

 

“Great! Captain Jeralt should still be down there, I think.”

 

“...h-hm. So that’s where he is…” Letting out a sigh, Shez felt a bit of dread, realizing she couldn't run away from her dad forever. Maybe he wouldn’t be too mad…?

Humming to herself, Bias watched on from the frozen rafters above as the Fodlaners left the room, leaving Kyrie’s body alone. That purple one was having some of his knights head in to guard the body, which made things slightly inconvenient, but Bias was nothing if not good at dealing with inconveniences.

 

…no, that was a lie, she was bad at getting rid of those that inconvenienced her. She let out a sigh at that thought, feeling annoyed with herself for letting the Fell Star get away again. She’d let her temper get away from her, but she just felt so…elated in that moment, that she was finally getting a chance to kill the object of her obsession. The fact that the Fell Star came back to her, that she existed in the world again, it brought Bias out of what had been a depression stretching on for years.

 

At least with the Fell Star back, Miss Byleth Eisner, Bias could put her mind to something constructive instead of dwelling on her murdered sister and how that bastard Myson was holding her resurrection over her head. Of course tormenting the bitch clearly had no effect, considering she had been stuck within Zahras for years and yet remained as strong-willed as ever. Sure, it might be fun to kill her loved ones before her, but that wouldn't break her. 

 

No, Bias needed to get far more personal, to have her scream in pain and agony as she begged for the sweet release of death. Then and only then, would Bias be satisfied. 

 

"Well, Miss Byleth Eisner, I can't wait for the two of us to get well acquainted with one another~." 

 

With a grin, Bias hopped down, launching a plume of fire all around her and getting the guards to scatter. It would only buy her a few moments, but it was enough. Having gotten well acquainted with the false relic stones, Bias could tell where in Kyrie’s body the stone remained. 

 

Before anyone could react, she plunged her hand into Kyrie's stomach, her hand wreathed in flames to protect her from the cold. Then she tore the stone straight out in one swift motion.

 

For a moment, Bias stared down at her now dead companion. A part of her couldn’t help but marvel at the monstrosity she became…before she launched herself up again with a burst of flame, escaping as quickly as she could before any of the guards could grab her. 

 

The stone pulsed in her hand, its surface warped after its time in Kyrie’s belly. The part of Bias that still retained her scientific curiosity observed the distortions in the stone, noting where it had likely connected to her flesh based on the shifts in its surface. Instead of a perfect sphere, the stone resembled more of a spiked prism…octagonal, maybe?

 

Bias continued studying the stone as she used her flames to propel herself up to the castle walls, noting its increase in size and the patterns spread across it. 

 

Patterns that resemble an Agarthan core, she noted, her curiosity rising, Did you eat up some parts of Kyrie, little stone? And if you did…how could I use this information?

 

Bias smiled as she vaulted over the ramparts. All in all, she had to say, today was a good day~.

Chapter End Notes

Red: I was kinda surprised some folks thought this would be the end for Bias. Like, I wouldn't say she's final villain material, we have plans for that, but she's been a big enough antagonist that she's gonna stick around until a fitting point. Like a Hubert instead of an Edelgard.

Indi: That and we can do more fun things with her, such as her being flirty with Byleth to make her uncomfortable.

Red: Murderously flirty. More taunting than actually affectionate and all that.

Indi: Yup yup, as for what else she'll do, well you'll find out eventually!

Red: That you shall! For now, hope you all enjoyed this boss fight!

Rest and Recuperation

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

“This sucks,” Shez grumbled from the bed she was laying in, prompting a glance from Byleth in the next bed over.

 

“We need to rest, Shez. We went from fighting Epimenides to fighting through a castle and taking on Bias and Kyrie, all in one day.”

 

“I know that. Still sucks. I went to sleep already, I should be able to get up now.”

 

“Can you get up?”

 

“...” Shez attempted to move her very sore limbs, then let out a little hiss of pain. “Nh…yeah, no, that’s not working…"

 

"See? Besides, the beds are comfy. Much better than rocks." 

 

“Rocks? Wait, how barren was that place you were stuck in?”

 

“Extremely. I slept on rocks, I trained with rocks, I even ate rocks. Apparently that’s just something I can do now.”

 

“Huh. Oh yeah, uh…I guess we should talk about why your hair’s green now?”

 

“I fused with Sothis and she turned me into a Nabatean. Why’s your hair orange?”

 

“Uh…I think it’s because I was leeching power from Epi? So now I’m, like…’fully awakened’, I think.”

 

“Huh. So you were only semi-awakened before now?”

 

“I guess? Unless going fully awakened would mean my hair turns fully orange. Oh, or white, like Arval’s…ah, I really don’t want my hair to turn white, that would suck.”

 

“Well that’s rude, partner,” Arval complained as they floated beside Shez, “I find a way to visit and the first thing I hear is you complaining about my hair." 

 

"Arval!?" Shez shouted, getting Byleth to flinch slightly from the sudden shout. "What are you doing here!?" 

 

"Checking in on you, obviously. I mean, it hasn't even been a day since we separated, and here you are, infirmed already." 

 

“Hey, I fought a huge battle after we left! It was tough! And also, how are you talking to me!? We had a whole big goodbye over the fact that you couldn’t come back with me! What happened to that!?”

 

Arval shrugged. “I took a nap and felt better, so I thought I would say hi and it turns out I can.”

 

"..." Shez narrowed her eyes. "Give me back my tears." 

 

"Heh, well, to be specific, I still have a connection with you, but it's more strenuous. I won't be able to talk to you all the time, but we'll be able to discuss things on occasion. Just be aware that the connection isn’t perfect, so we may–” And Arval abruptly vanished.

 

“...hm.” Shez laid back down. “...I think I’m gonna take a nap now.”

 

Byleth raised an eyebrow, having been there for half of that entire conversation. “Should I ask about what happened?”

 

“Arval can talk to me from the void, apparently.”

 

“...didn’t they say that would be a bad thing because Epimenides could take control of them again?”

 

“I think it’s fine? It’s like…they, as a separate person, are using magic to talk to me from the void. We’re not in the same body anymore and there’s no chance Epi could take me over if he ever did come back.” 

 

“Oh, that’s good then. Make sure to tell them hi for me."

 

"Sure," Shez agreed with a sigh, settling back in her bed. 

 

"Hm…hey, do you know when we'll get to eat? I kinda want to eat something that isn't a rock." 

 

"Just ask when someone comes by." Shez huffed, before turning over and going to sleep. 

 

"...hm." Sighing, Byleth laid back, staring up at the ceiling and waiting for someone to come by. “...I’m bored.”

"Gotta say, didn't think you'd still be such a big eater after all this time, Teach," Claude commented, watching the green-haired mercenary as she scarfed down her third plate of food. 

 

Byleth let out a muffled reply, before swallowing, "You try living off of rocks for three years." 

 

"...Right. Speaking of, I wanted to ask just where exactly you've been. I was going to ask Shez as well, but…" He glanced over at the snoring mercenary, "Well, I can do that later." 

 

“Gmnh–Mm-”

 

“You can swallow your food first.”

 

Byleth did so, then took a moment to drink some water and wash it down. “Mm. Thank you for being patient. I really was hungry…and still somewhat am…”

 

“So I’m guessing you really didn’t get a lot of food where you wound up?”

 

“I mentioned the ‘living off rocks’ part earlier.”

 

Claude paused. “That was literal?”

 

“It was, yes. I was stuck in a void of eternal darkness. It wasn’t very good for keeping myself well-fed.”

 

“...hm. So, do you mind explaining that part? How did you wind up in a ‘void’? And how in the world did you manage to survive off of eating rocks?”

 

“Oh, that last part is easy to explain. I actually–” Byleth paused as the door to her room was shoved open, before smiling slightly when she saw Kronya was the one barging inside. "Hello there, Kronya." 

 

"Hm? Oh, hey there professor! Was coming to visit Shez, but I see she's still out," the Agarthan said, glancing at the sleeping Shez, who snored in response, "Oh hey, you got food. Can I have some?”

 

“No.”

 

Kronya blinked at the blunt refusal, then shrugged. “Alright, I guess. So, what’s up? Is Claude bothering you?”

 

“You’re the one who shoved her way in,” Claude remarked, amused. 

 

"I'm not bothered, it's nice being able to talk to people. Aside from Rhea I only had my dolls to talk to," Byleth said, before munching on a piece of fish, "It's a good thing Rhea was there, or I might have started acting like the dolls were real people."

 

"...Uh, you good, Teach?" 

 

"As good as anyone who was locked in the void for three years can be with the only company around being Rhea." 

 

“You have my condolences,” Kronya said, very sincerely, “You’re lucky I’m here to make things better." 

 

"That I am. Though I'm sure Shez will be luckier when you two do get married." 

 

"Of course she will! I'm just glad we managed to find someone for Shez to use that spell. Sorry to say, professor, but I wasn't going to volunteer." 

 

Byleth drank some water, before smiling. "I'm glad you didn't have to." 

 

"...W-Well yeah, I just said I wouldn't," Kronya huffed, looking away. 

 

“...” Claude, perhaps inadvisably, decided to cause problems. “Literal heart-rending sacrifices aside, aren’t you getting ahead of yourself, Kronya? You still have Lysithea for competition, remember?”

 

"Pff, as if! She might not be a complete pipsqueak, but I could take her in a fight." 

 

“Lysithea is interested in Shez too?” Byleth asked, before pausing in thought, “Hm…it’s been three years, I forgot if I knew that already.”

 

"Even if she is interested, I already staked my claim. And as the stronger of the two of us, I win." 

 

"You should probably talk with Shez about that, to see how she feels," Byleth advised as she tilted her head, "I mean, who knows, it could end up like Dorothea, Edelgard, and me." 

 

"Woah what?" Claude asked, blinking in surprise. 

 

"Well, I guess we never made it official, since everything that happened at the monastery happened before we could, but I was dating Dorothea, both of us are interested in Edelgard, and I'm pretty sure she's interested in the two of us." Byleth paused before frowning, "Hm. I need to check if they're okay." 

 

“Hm…well, I get why you might want to, but there’s a few things in the way of that,” Claude stated, his gaze calculating as he considered all of the information he’d just received, “There’s an entire new nation between us and the Empire, in case you didn’t know already.”

 

Byleth’s frown deepened. “I didn’t. Shez mentioned that Duke Aegir escaped and seceded from the empire.”

 

“Yeah, he did, and he made his own nation out of Hrym called the Principality. Officially, Phlegethon here, formerly known as Ordelia territory, belonged to Hrym since that icy lady declared Archduke Ludwig as her liege. Of course, we of the Alliance didn’t exactly recognize that claim, but there wasn’t much we could do about it until now.”

 

“And now that this castle is mine, I get to decide who I side with!” Kronya declared, grinning proudly.

 

“And by that you mean you’re siding with us, right?” Claude asked with an eyebrow raised.

 

“Yeah, obviously. You just gotta make it worth my while.”

 

“…such as by, say, giving you a castle?”

 

“Not at all. That was my payment for fighting for you guys in this last battle. I’m a mercenary, you have to keep paying me if you want me to work for you.”

 

"...Mind helping me, Teach?" 

 

"No, she's right. If she's a mercenary now then you need to discuss a proper contract, and payments,” Byleth agreed, nodding. "Though, Shez would be disappointed if you sided against her." 

 

“Hey, I never said I was siding against Shez!” Kronya responded, “I’m automatically on her side, since she’s my fiance.”

 

“Ah, congratulations.”

 

“Did she even agree to that?” Claude asked.

 

“She will! Anyways, it’s not like I’m going to ask for anything crazy here,” Kronya assured, “I just want to be one of you Great House people.”

 

“...that is an amazing idea and I fully support your claim.”

 

"Oh sweet! Glad we got that settled," Kronya said, grinning, before heading over to sit by Shez. 

 

"Is it that simple to be a great house noble?" Byleth asked in a whisper to Claude. 

 

"No, she'd need all the other great houses to approve, but if it means she'll help us, I can say that much, at least," Claude quietly responded, "But that aside, we really should figure out what to do next." 

 

"Well, we should try to meet up with the Empire, right? Even if there is a Principality between us, we should send a small messaging party." 

 

"That might sound like a good idea, but it's not that simple. We just took back Ordelia and Phlegethon territory so we need to shore up defenses there before the Principality attacks. If we try to cross their borders too early and get caught, we might incite a response from them before we’re prepared to handle it. And sadly, we don't have the troops to make any big moves since we're also dealing with attacks from the Kingdom and Almyra." 

 

"What exactly is happening with Almyra? I thought I dealt with Shahid." 

 

"Yes, but he decided to rear his ugly head again thanks to the rest of Fodlan being at war." Claude let out an annoyed huff. "It's not just him either. From the reports I've gotten, there's at least two other princes and a princess who are also launching attacks of their own. Thankfully, they're too busy bickering amongst themselves to launch a conjoined assault." 

 

"Hm. Do we know why they're all attacking if they're not working together?" 

 

"Nope," Claude lied as he leaned back in his chair, "My best bet is that they're doing this to prove themselves worthy of the throne." 

 

"Hm…could we establish contact with one of them?" 

 

"Now why would you want to do that, Teach?" 

 

"Well, if they're trying to prove themselves, then defeating their siblings in combat would be a good start right?" Byleth asked, tilting her head in thought. "Not to mention if they agree to work with us, they'd have the backing of the Alliance and presumably the rest of the nations once we deal with all our problems." 

 

"...That he would, wouldn't he?" 

 

"Or she. You said one of them was a princess right?" 

 

"Eh, she's probably a lost cause. Trust me, Teach, I've heard nothing but awful things about her." 

 

"If you say so…wait, I got it. I know who we should back," With a smile, Byleth nodded, "We get Shahid. I beat him up once I can do it again to make him agree to work for us." 

 

"...Right. I'll make sure to pin in that idea, Teach," Claude said, standing up, "For now, I have something to think about." 

 

With that Claude left the infirmary in a hurry. 

 

"...huh, he left before I could answer his question from earlier…eh, it's not that important." She glanced over at Kronya, who was currently leaning on Shez’s bed, waiting for her to wake up. For a brief moment she felt a tinge of jealousy with how Shez had both girls interested in her nearby. "...I hope we get to go to the Empire soon." 

Byleth stared into the mirror and fluffed her overly long hair with a small frown. “Hm…I definitely need a haircut.”

 

“Oh, do you want me to–”

 

“No,” Byleth immediately refused, not even bothering to look at Shez, who pouted. "The last time I let you cut my hair, I wore a helmet for a month." 

 

"Hey, that's only because Arval distracted me!" 

 

"Can you promise they won't distract you this time?" 

 

“Ah…probably? Look, I’m older, I’m wiser, I can definitely fix your hair. How short do you want it?”

 

“...maybe I should just try braiding it like Rhea?” she considered, rubbing her chin in thought as Shez huffed. "I could just keep it in a ponytail…" 

 

She brushed her hair back, taking a moment to stare at herself. Her time in Zahras really hadn't been kind to her. For one thing, she was paler than she once was and she still had scars around her right eye from when Bias had burned her face, so it seemed her healing factor wasn't perfect either. She’d probably be bearing the scars of this experience for a while…

 

Sighing, she moved to lay back down on the bed. 

 

"I hope we get to go soon." 

 

"Since when have you been this restless?" 

 

"It's…aggravating having to wait for everyone to come to a decision. I know there's important things we need to figure out, but…I want to make sure everyone is okay first. I know Edelgard and Papa are keeping them safe, but I want to see my class again." 

 

“I guess I get that. It still feels weird seeing you be the one complaining about being in bed,” Shez commented, laying back and propping her hand up with her hand, “Then again, you don’t have cute girls feeding you grapes when you request it.”

 

“...I am not jealous of you and Kronya,” Byleth said, jealously.

 

“Suuuuure. Seriously though, what gives? I thought you’d be looking on the bright side since you’re out of the void.”

 

“Mm…I guess it’s because I’m out of the void. I’m here, back in Fodlan, but I’m still not with everyone I care about. I’m happy to be back together with you, it’s just…I want to be back with my students. With Edelgard and Dorothea…and I want to make sure Papa is okay.”

 

"...Yeah, I guess I can understand that…if you want, I can try telling Claude that you should go to the Empire while I stay and help with the Almyrans." 

 

“No, I’m not leaving you alone again.” Byleth pushed herself back up, a determined glint entering her eyes. “Alright, I’m going to talk to everyone.”

 

“Huh? Wait, what’s up?”

 

“I need to know everything about the war with Almyra. Then we’re going to win it so I can get back to my students.” 

 

“...Heh, well, guess there’s no point in arguing huh?” Shez asked, standing up alongside Byleth. With the determined look in her eye, Byleth led the way out of the room. Though she immediately had to stop as she almost bumped into Lysithea…who had a bowl of grapes for some reason. 

 

“O-Oh, hello professor,” 

 

“...Hi, Lysithea. Did you need something?”

 

“N-No, I, uh…just heard from Kronya that Shez was awake so…” Lysithea glanced down, before blushing, and hiding the bowl of grapes behind her back. 

 

“...Hm.” Byleth decided to ignore that and just keep walking to the castle’s meeting room. She had more important things to focus on than being jealous of Shez. Not that she was. 

 

Soon enough, she was in the meeting room, interrupting the discussion going on. 

 

"As such, I believe it would be best–Byleth?" Rhea exclaimed, surprised to see her walking around. 

 

"Hello, I need someone to bring me up to date on the Almyran situation." 

 

“The Almyran–ah, Byleth, we were actually just discussing the next course of action,” Rhea stated, gesturing to Lorenz, Claude, and a man who was clearly Lorenz’s father, “I believe our best move is to take Garreg Mach back and unite the forces of the Alliance and the Knights of Seiros so we can better deal with the issues across Fodlan.”

 

“Mm. We need to deal with Almyra first. It’s a bigger priority than gaining a position we can take at any time. Even though we took back Ordelia, we still have enemies on three different sides, so if we try to take Garreg Mach, we'll be stretching ourselves thin. Instead of trying to establish a new base, we should deal with one of the threats. From my understanding, the Almyrans invading us are actually four separate armies, none of whom are working with one another. So despite their size, they'll likely be the easier threat to deal with." Byleth took a breath as she considered her next words. "I mentioned this to Claude, but I believe that if we can convince one of the Almyran Royals to side with us, we could use their assistance to deal with the others, and potentially stop the invasions all together." 

 

"...You would have us aid those who have been invading us?" Count Gloucester asked. 

 

"Only one. From my understanding they're doing this to prove themselves as worthy as being ruler of Almyra. If we can back one of them, we could use that as leverage to ensure the invasions get called off, if they do take the throne." She paused, then glanced at Count Gloucester. “Also, hello, I’m Byleth Eisner, formerly a professor at Garreg Mach. It’s nice to meet you, sir.”

 

“...” Lorenz’s father appraised the professor for a moment, before showing a small smile. “Count Erwin Fritz Gloucester. Likewise. So, you believe we can suborn one of the Almyran princes invading? How exactly would we go about that?”

 

“To begin with, we need information. Who the members of the royal families are, what their relationships are to each other, and who has the best chance of actually being useful to us. It will probably take some time to get all that together, but hopefully House Goneril has some ideas we can use.”

 

"Actually, I have some information, so we don't need to go all the way there just yet," Claude spoke up, getting everyone's attention, "Thanks to the close ties between House Goneril and Riegan, I've been keeping up with who exactly we're facing. To be specific, the four Royals currently attacking us are named Farah, Aziz, Aref, and Shahid. Now, we've already met Shahid, so I'll be brief. He seems to be the oldest of the siblings, so he has the biggest backing behind him, but he's also the most incompetent in terms of leading an army. Everyone who fought at the Almyran invasion during the Academy can tell you easily enough that Shahid has no head for tactics and his only real move is to just get as many soldiers as he possibly can before charging for the forts. The only thing that makes him dangerous is if he has competent commanders backing him up.

 

“Aziz and Aref, meanwhile, are actually working together. Supposedly they have the same mother, which is why they’re helping each other out. The thing is, they're also liable to turn on one another once it comes down to who's gonna be king. Blood only goes so far when it comes to court politics. And well, if they turn on each other, one of them will turn on us," Claude explained as he went down the list of siblings, "Then of course, we have Farah, the only princess of the group. As a younger, female sibling, she has the smallest backing from the traditionalist nobles of Almyra, which also makes her the one who wants to prove herself the most. Despite how small her army is, she's actually surprisingly competent and has been using plenty of hit and run tactics when attacking the Locket.

 

Claude spread his hands out, grinning at the group. “So there you have it. We’ve got the arrogant oldest, the package deal that’s bound to spoil, and the headstrong princess who wants to look her best. Not exactly our best options for allies.”

 

“We don’t need a permanent ally,” Byleth noted, “For the purpose of ending the invasion, we need a temporary ally who’s willing to back down at the end. It would be better if we could get a genuine ally who will work for a long-term peace, but if it comes down to it, facing one exhausted enemy is better than going after four ready ones.”

 

“Hm. I cannot say I am comfortable with that idea, professor,” Lorenz spoke up, frowning.

 

“Oh? Not a fan of allying with Almyrans?” Claude asked, keeping his tone light.

 

“It’s not that. I understand that rationale and I can accept that a new ally is better than another enemy, regardless of their nation of origin. The issue I have is with planning for a temporary ally. It would be dishonorable to plan on betraying our ally from the beginning. We should only side with someone we have the confidence will treat us as we intend to treat them.”

 

"Hm, that's certainly an idealistic hope." 

 

"I will agree with my son,” Count Gloucester spoke up, “Even if we were able to deal with an ally turned enemy, we have no way to ensure no one else will retaliate afterwards. Surely the king would see us defeating four of his children as an excuse to lead the armies himself?" 

 

"Well, the king leading a campaign himself probably isn’t going to happen unless we go out of our way to kill the royals,” Claude explained, “Almyran society values strength, but there’s still just as much backbiting and politicking among their nobles as there are over here. Maybe more so, since I’ve noticed poisoning people is considered pretty reprehensible in Fodlan.”

 

Rhea grimaced, displeased by the reminder of what happened at the Battle of Eagle and Lion. “Yes, I am sure you are well aware of that, Claude.”

 

“Oh sure, it was a good lesson learned from my days at the Academy. If you want to poison someone, do it with a venin weapon.”

 

Count Gloucester actually cracked a smirk at that. “A valuable lesson to learn indeed. So, as long as we avoid killing any of them, that will serve to our benefit?" 

 

"For now. However, even if the king won't retaliate, he also won't reign any of them in." Claude grinned wryly. “The throne of Almyra doesn’t necessarily go to the eldest. The king decides who his heir is, and there’s a lot of politics that go into who gets picked. Even if he dislikes one of them, they'll probably be appointed if they prove themselves. At the same time, you could be his favorite, but if you rest on your laurels, you won't get anywhere." 

 

“Hm…” Byleth tilted her head in thought. “Do you have any ideas on who his favorite might be?”

 

Claude shrugged. “Beats me. I’d say he doesn’t have a favorite, if just so he can avoid the politics that would come with it. Back to the important part, if we really need to side with an Almyran to push things forward…there might be one more option. You see, there's supposedly another prince, one who isn't fighting at the border."

 

"And how does that help us?" 

 

"Well, this prince supposedly has some connections to several high ranking men in the opposing forces, such as Nader the Undefeated. Allegedly, the reason this prince isn't taking arms up himself is because he wanted to gain merit in his own way, and decided to travel the lands of not only Almyra, but of Fodlan as well," Claude said, preparing himself for his big reveal. 

 

"Oh, it's you, isn't it?" Only to have Byleth point at him. 

 

"...Huh?" 

 

"It makes sense. When we fought at the Locket, Nader specifically talked to you, as if you two were already acquainted. You're also quite skilled with wyvern riding, something more common in the Empire and Almyra rather than the Alliance. It would also explain how you seemingly came out of nowhere if you were born in a different nation and raised there.”

 

“...wow. You’re just gonna steal my thunder completely, huh, Teach?”

 

"Oh, sorry, go ahead," Byleth said, gesturing for him to continue. 

 

"...Right. Well, as Teach so eloquently put it, I am indeed a prince of Almyra, and my actual name is Khalid," Claude said, a bit deflated at being unable to do his whole reveal. 

 

An awkward silence fell over the room, as what was supposed to be a dramatic reveal now felt like a casual mention. 

 

Rhea, meanwhile, had her face in her hands. “...Did anyone attending the academy actually tell the truth of who they are?”

 

“...” Lorenz began to–

 

“Put your hand down, Lorenz.”

 

Lorenz quietly lowered his hand. 

Chapter End Notes

Red: And so, decisions are made! After a bit of bed rest and some complaining about said bed rest.

Indi: And some complaining about totally not being jealous

Red: Totally not. Oh and there was some big reveal somewhere in there.

Indi: Maybe

An Astonishing Almyran Altercation

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

"So, to clarify, you are the remaining Almyran prince?" Erwin asked, his arms crossed over his chest as he regarded Claude with a new eye. 

 

"Well if you want to be specific, I’m the only half-Fodlaner Almyran prince,” Claude answered, “The rest of the royals, you already know about, or they’re just too young to be leading any armies.”

 

“So you’ve been lying to us this entire time?” Lorenz questioned, looking much more annoyed than his father.

 

“Essentially? Yep, I’ve been lying about my origins. I didn’t lie about being on your side though, especially since I could’ve sabotaged our efforts for years if I really wanted to side with any of my siblings, who have zero reason to support my claim to the throne. And, if it helps, I’ve been having Nader keep me informed about what’s going on over on the Almyran side of things and I’ve passed his info onto our forces to keep the Locket defended. Ask Hilda, she can confirm it. Oh, and that’s not to mention that Nader can ruin Shahid’s entire offense if we want to push things right now.”

 

“What? How?”

 

Claude grinned. “Turns out, most people prefer working for a commander they know will do his best to keep them alive instead of a prince that’ll throw their lives away while leaving them to starve from a lack of supplies.”

 

"Before we continue, I would ask that we see what Lady Rhea has to say,” Erwin interrupted,  “The tenants of the Church of Seiros speak against foreign relations, so I must ask if we have your blessing on continuing down this path, Lady Rhea.”

 

“...” Rhea stayed quiet for a moment, thinking. Saying yes would mean overturning centuries of careful work to keep the countries that surrounded Fodlan from interfering in their affairs. It could very well put them directly on the path to Almyra influencing–Then Byleth kicked her shin below the table and the archbishop had to hide a wince. “Hm. I can see the potential issues there could be from taking this course of action, but allying ourselves with Claude, or perhaps ‘Khalid’, may indeed be for the best.”

 

“Plus he’s been fighting on Leicester’s side for years now,” Byleth pointed out, “Choosing not to trust him at this point is just stupid.”

 

Erwin’s lips twitched in amusement. “Quite. Very well, I acquiesce to the wisdom of the archbishop.”

 

“If I may, Lady Rhea, I do have something I wish to say,” Lorenz spoke up, frowning at Claude, who tried to smile in return.

 

“Hey Lorenz, what’s up? Something the matter?”

 

“Obviously there is. For the past three years, you have been lying to us, Claude. That is a significant hurdle for anyone to overcome in trusting another person,” he stated, before sighing, “Yet you are not the only one. Kronya has openly admitted to lying to us with ill-intentions, and yet we have accepted her as one of our own all the same. It would be hypocritical of me to refuse your aid at this point. I would even consider it outright foolish, given how you have proven yourself to be a competent leader through times of great upheaval.”

 

"So there's no problem?" 

 

"The problem comes from the simple fact that not only are you a leader of the Alliance, you are also the prince of a foreign land. Regardless of your intentions, there is a clear conflict of interest if we are to aid you in becoming the King of Almyra." 

 

“I mean, I am still the rightful heir of House Riegan.”

 

“Claude.”

 

Claude sighed. “Yeah, I figured that wouldn’t work. I never really thought I’d be the King of Almyra and a noble in Fodlan at the same time, so I won’t try arguing it. You’re probably going to have a tricky time figuring out who should be the new heir of House Riegan though…which is why I’d like to ask to be able to name that heir myself.”

 

Lorenz frowned, but Erwin raised a hand to stave off his son’s response. “Oh? I suppose that could be allowed, though I would implore you to name someone who actually is of Fodlan. No trying to be tricky.”

 

“Hey, don’t worry, my pick is someone who has a distinguished bloodline, going all the way back to the very first people of Fodlan.” Claude grinned, a mischievous glint in his eyes. “As such, I’d like to formally adopt Kronya of Shambhala as my heir.”

 

“What.” Lorenz flatly asked.

 

“What.” Rhea echoed.

 

“Her? Really?” Erwin genuinely asked, raising an eyebrow.

 

“Claude, I like Kronya, but that’s a terrible idea,” Byleth stated.

 

“And I graciously accept it!” Kronya declared as she pushed her way through the door to the meeting room with a huge grin on her face.

 

“Wh–How did you get here?!” Rhea questioned, obviously baffled by the Agarthan’s appearance.

 

“I was outside the door for a while!”

 

“So you were eavesdropping,” Erwin noted.

 

“...Yes, and I sincerely apologize, your majesty!”

 

“...” Erwin’s lips twitched in faint amusement. “It would be ‘your lordship’, if you’re trying to be formal, though ‘Lord Erwin’ or ‘Count Erwin’ would be more appropriate.”

 

"Of course, Count Lord Erwin!" Kronya said, much to Erwin's further amusement. 

 

"Wait, wait, we can't just have someone with no experience in nobility as the leader of House Riegan, much less as the leader of the Alliance!" Lorenz spoke up. 

 

"Also it's weird for Claude to adopt Kronya since I'm pretty sure she's older than him," Byleth pointed out. 

 

“Age isn’t a factor in adoption, just who happens to be the head of the family. Which is me,” Claude pointed out, obviously amused, "And while Kronya might not have any experience, I'm sure I can help teach her about noble etiquette until I retire. And hey, so can you, right Lorenz?" 

 

“I–Wait, that–”

 

“Oh, so like at the Academy,” Kronya noted, nodding, “Yeah, that works for me.”

 

“I think that is a perfectly reasonable suggestion,” Erwin spoke up, seeming curiously pleased, “I am certain my son would gladly mentor the future Duke of House Riegan. I am certain she will be a very capable head of the house, in time, though I imagine she will be unable to take the lead as sovereign of the Alliance. So it would be only natural for House Gloucester to claim such a position instead.”

 

"Once I officially step down from my position as the head of House Riegan, that is,” Claude replied.

 

“Of course. I imagine you’ll be more than satisfied being the King of Almyra by that point.”

 

"I suppose we'll see, won't we?" Claude asked, winking at him. 

 

“...noble politics are weird,” Byleth commented, earning an exasperated, and commiserating, sigh from Rhea.

 

"...So do I get a fancy crown?" Kronya asked. 

 

“Absolutely,” Claude decided, nodding.

 

“Sweet.”

For the past three years, Hilda Valentine Goneril had been called upon to do what she least enjoyed doing in the entire world: actually working. 

 

Not only was she expected to act as her family’s representative at Roundtable meetings despite her protests that she really didn’t have the head for that kind of thing, but she’d actually been forced to fight on the frontlines against the invading Almyrans! Well, forced wasn’t exactly the right word, considering Holst probably would have been happy to keep her occupied far from the Locket if he had the option. The problem was, they genuinely didn’t have the option.

 

“Fodlan’s Locket was built to beat back any Almyran army that came at it, and it’d done its job admirably for centuries. Four armies though, making repeated raids on campaigns that had lasted years by this point…well, it was said that even the wind can wear down a mountain if given enough time. Or maybe that was waves…though waves wouldn’t be by mountains, they would be cliffs at that point–”

 

“Baltie, stop mangling that saying,” Hilda requested, giving her ‘bodyguard’ an annoyed look.

 

“Huh? Ah, damn, I thought that was internal,” Balthus muttered, before shrugging as he looked out over the ramparts of the Locket’s major fort. Well, one of its major forts. Top three, at least. Maybe top five.

 

“Why are you monologuing anyway? Are you planning to join a troupe or something?” she asked, standing beside him. 

 

“Nah, I’m just planning my memoir. Gonna hire a guy to write this tell-all story about the awesome deeds I got up to. Then I’ll rake in the dough once it gets popular!” He laughed. “Goodbye gambling debts!”

 

“...don’t you need money to hire a writer in the first place?”

 

“Hm? Well yeah, but I’ve got money. You and Holst pay me, remember?”

 

“And you don’t use any of that money to pay off your debts because…?”

 

“Because I gotta save up to hire a writer! Besides, I already have to budget some coin for my drinks and entertainment, so I’m barely scraping by as it is!”

 

“Sure, whatever.” Hilda rolled her eyes at her brother’s friend, before turning her gaze back towards the distance. “...it’s also weird that you’re picking now to monologue to yourself. We’re not even facing Almyra right now.”

 

“Well not right now, but we are still at war-”

 

“I mean we’re literally faced towards Leicester because we’re waiting for the reinforcements that are supposed to arrive today.”

 

“Right, those guys. Well that’s probably them there. Either that or we’re about to be attacked by wyvern-riding bandits,” Balthus pointed out, gesturing towards the cluster of wyverns headed in their direction. “Ah, hey, looks like Claude’s coming along…huh. Since when did he have two white wyverns?”

 

“...Baltie, I don’t think that’s a wyvern,” Hilda replied, staring at the enormous white dragon flying towards their fort.

 

“...yeah. Yeah, I’m seeing it now. Alright, guess I have to ask how Claude managed to tame a dragon now.”

 

“That’s probably a bad idea,” Shez commented, “Rhea would definitely take it the wrong way.”

 

“She would? Why would she–” Hilda stopped. She turned, staring at Shez, who was now beside her, on the opposite side from Balthus. “...how.”

 

“Hm? Oh, I warped over, thought I’d say hi. And, uh, also, sorry for being missing for these past few years, I was sort of held hostage by a crazy guy, it’s a long story, I’m fine now.”

 

“...” 

 

“...” Balthus glanced down at Hilda, noticed her truly baffled stare, and did what any reasonable guy would do and casually pushed her towards Shez.

 

Hilda stumbled a little at the sudden push…before just deciding to go with it and giving Shez a very, very tight hug. “I’m glad you’re okay.”

 

"Same here," Shez said, hugging her back, before feeling something pop in her back as Hilda started hugging a bit too hard there. “Ack–T-Too tight, too tight!”

 

Luckily for her, a bit of healing magic cleared that right up, and then came the fun of dealing with all the sudden guests to Hilda’s fort. Or, well, the fort she was currently in charge of.

 

Still, the guests were mostly her friends, so at least she wasn’t expected to act all proper. “Oh wow. You know, I’m actually more surprised to see Leonie and Lysithea here than the professor. I get that that’s weird, but seeing Shez makes it just feel right that Professor Byleth would be here too.”

 

"I'm glad to see you as well, Hilda," Byleth said, rubbing her back after her own spine-popping hug. 

 

"So, mind telling me what the sudden visit is for? Not that I'm complaining, but well, I am technically in charge here," Hilda said, glancing at her friends. 

 

"I think I can explain that, but first, there's something I need to admit to you, Hilda," Claude spoke up, facing his retainer with an uncharacteristic seriousness, "Something I've been keeping a secret from you for a long time." 

 

"Uh, not to interrupt, but if you're going to propose you better check in with Holst first," Balthus said, deciding to butt in. 

 

"Baltie!" 

 

"What? I'm just saying, if he doesn't, Holst will kill him. Well, he'll probably still kill him, but at least it'll be an easier death!" 

 

"I'm not proposing!" Claude cut in before sighing, "Right, I'm just gonna say it before Teach or someone else says it before me. My real name is Khalid, and I'm an Almyran prince." 

 

Hilda blinked. "Oh…Well, you heard him Baltie, you owe me gold." 

 

"Damn it!" 

 

"...what?" Claude asked, before shaking his head. "No, wait, what? What bet are you talking about?" 

 

"Oh, well Baltie bet you weren't Almyran and I bet that you were," Hilda said, as if it was obvious, "I mean, whenever you visit, you always stare wistfully over to Almyra, and sometimes when we're fighting against them, I hear an Almyran soldier say something about someone named Khalid, which sounded similar to your name. Then when I mentioned this to Baltie, he said there was no way you were Almyran, and decided to bet me on it. 

 

She paused. "Oh, but the prince thing is a surprise." 

 

Claude just sighed. “Right…also Rhea’s a dragon.”

 

“She’s a what?!”

 

“There we go! That’s a better reaction!”

 

Lysithea pinched the bridge of her nose. “Can we please get on with the actual important matters at hand?”

 

“Are you saying the archbishop isn’t important?”

 

“I’m saying you’re not as funny as you think you are and we have a job to do here!" 

 

"That we do! Mainly, dealing with the Almyrans that are invading," Claude declared, a smile on his face, "I hope you're ready to no longer be on the frontlines against the Almyrans, Hilda." 

 

"Oh you have no idea. I for one can't wait to be able to sleep in all day." 

 

"Well we just got to do a bit more work, starting with our old friend Shahid's army, and his many, many, less than loyal soldiers." 

 

“Just how many people do you expect are going to turn traitor?” Leonie asked, raising an eyebrow.

 

“Enough to make things easy.”

 

Lysithea huffed. “You should know by now not to say things like that, Claude.”

 

“What? Do you really think I’m going to jinx–”

 

“Ah bup bup!” Shez interrupted, “None of that! In fact–”

 

The mercenary planted her sword into the ground, turning to her friends with a suitably dramatic grin. “I bet this will be the most fierce fight of our lives!”

 

“Pfft, not even I’m going to bet on this fight being easy,” Balthus stated, and everyone there felt a strange sense of relief the instant he said that.

Byleth had to admit, it felt weird wearing Alliance armor. Not that it was bad per se, she just didn't think yellow was a good color for her. Once she had time, she'd ask if she could find someone to dye the cloth on her new armor. 

 

As it stood, the padded armor and chainmail would have to do. And it worked rather well as Byleth got used to fighting in such a large scale battle. Well, for the most part. 

 

"Hm, starting to remember why I don't wear so much armor," Byleth stated, deflecting an arrow, before slashing down on a charging spearman. 

 

"Aside from the fact that it leaves you all sweaty?" Hilda asked, as she slammed her axe hard enough to break through a soldier's heavy armor. 

 

"Yeah. It's too tight on my chest." 

 

"Oh, yeah I totally get that. You have no idea how many complaints I've heard about how I dress for combat, but come on, I need to let the girls breathe!" 

 

"...You refer to your chest as girls?" 

 

"Well yeah, who doesn't?" 

 

"Huh…well, you learn something new everyday." 

 

“What do you call them then?”

 

“My breasts. I don’t see what else I would–“ She ducked a glaive swung for her head and retaliated with a Thoron that scorched through the warrior’s chest. “–call them.”

 

"I feel like I shouldn't be around for this conversation," Claude commented, before sniping an archer trying to sneak on them. 

 

“Don’t eavesdrop then.”

 

“Yeah Claude, have some dignity,” Hilda teased, before she raced forward and rammed her axe into and through the neck of a wyvern, decapitating the mount in one stroke and sending its rider crashing to the ground with enough force to break bones. “Speaking of no dignity, where’s that older brother of yours?”
