"We should be seeing him soon, since he tends to stick to the back of the army," Claude replied as the trio made their way through the valley as quickly as they could, cutting through the flank of the enemy's army as the main Alliance forces kept the enemy’s focus on them. Not that it was difficult to do that, considering the main Alliance force had a dragon backing them up.

 

"Let's just hope this Nader guy doesn't decide to double cross you instead," Hilda remarked, swinging her axe through a barricade to crack it open before pushing through. 

 

"What–How did you get here!?" shouted Prince Shahid, trying his best to hide a surprised flinch at the sight of Leicester forces breaking into his outpost.

 

"Well, we did leave our flanks open since you sent the army in full response to theirs," Nader the Undefeated commented, an amused smile on his face as he took in the sight of his wayward charge alongside a pair of familiar faces. 

 

"Well don't just stand there! Deal with this trash!" Shahid shouted at his guard. 

 

"Woah now, don't you want to hear what we have to say?" Claude asked. 

 

"As if some Fodlan coward has anything worthwhile to say to me, much less someone who looks like my half-breed brother!" Shahid responded, drawing an arrow as his wyvern roared, reading to pounce on the intruders!

 

"Oh hey, aren't you that wyvern that tried to follow me before?" 

 

Only for the wyvern to immediately get on its haunches at Byleth’s words, causing the prince to fall off with a startled yelp. The wyvern paid no intention to that, instead letting out a chirp as it folded its wings, before laying down in a show of submission.

 

“You absurd beast!” Shahid shouted, pushing himself up with an enraged glare at his mount, “What do you think you’re doing!? You’re supposed to carry me to victory, not dump me on the filthy ground!”

 

The wyvern glanced at its rider, before focusing its attention back on Byleth and chirping again, making a vein pulse in Shahid’s head.

 

“You know, I haven’t heard wyverns chirp that much before,” Hilda commented, letting her axe rest on her shoulder while taking note of how none of Shahid’s guards were actually moving to assist their prince.

 

“You’ll hear it every so often if you spend enough time around them,” Claude replied, openly amused at his brother’s misfortune, “Usually if they’re trying to pretend they’re cute, harmless, and didn’t just set fire to their stable thanks to an ill-timed sneeze.”

 

Back at the fort, a certain albino wyvern twitched and cocked its head, feeling like it had just heard its master’s voice for a moment before it shrugged it off and turned back to the leather ball it had been given to play with and chew on while its master was out doing sneaky things.

 

Byleth, meanwhile, casually walked up to Shahid in the middle of his angry tirade and put her sword to his throat. “I would recommend surrendering now, your highness.”

 

“–worthless, just like your entire line of so-called pure breed–” Even then, it took her pushing the blade close enough for him to actually notice. 

 

“Huh?” Shahid blinked, before going stiff. “Gh–N-Nader! What are you doing!? Protect me!”

 

“Hm?” The Undefeated, who’d been idly cleaning his ear with a finger, paused and glanced down at the fallen prince. “No, I don’t think I’m going to.”

 

“Wh–Are you insane!? This is treason!”

 

“No it’s not. I don’t have an obligation to fight for you. I’m here as an observer this time, on your father’s orders. I can’t fight for you directly because otherwise I might wind up fighting your siblings.” He grinned. “You did listen when I reported in, right?”

 

Shahid hadn’t. He’d actually fully assumed Nader was there to support his conquest and hadn’t checked at all during the campaign. “Gh–Guards! Seize the Fodlaners and kill Nader for his treasonous actions!”

 

“I just said why I’m not committing treason. Also, you have a sword to your throat–”

 

“Shut up! Guards! What do you think you’re doing!?”

 

“Committing treason,” one of the guards stated quite bluntly.

 

“Treason against you, specifically, your highness,” another guard added, before nodding to Claude, “We hope you’ll accept our defection, Prince Khalid.”

 

“Oh sure, come on over,” Claude replied, ignoring Shahid’s gobsmacked expression, even if a part of him did want to laugh, “I know we’re planning a pretty big victory feast after we take down the other royals, so feel free to join in.”

 

“Thank you, your highness!” the gathered guards called out, earning an amused chuckle from Nader.

 

“Careful men, we don’t want to give Prince Khalid too much of a swelled head–”

 

“What is going on here?!” Shahid finally snapped, sheer indignation breaking through his confusion.

 

"Why dear brother, that's simple. I'm making my own claim," Claude said, before drawing an arrow and aiming it at Shahid, "As Prince Khalid of Almyra, I order you to stand down, Prince Shahid." 

 

"...You,” Shahid growled, his hands clenching to the ground beneath him, "All this time, you've been hiding here of all places!?" 

 

"I'd prefer to say ‘biding my time’. Not that it matters. What does matter is you either bow out of your own volition or we deal with you, right now." 

 

"As if I'd–!" Shahid shouted, only to get cut off as Byleth grabbed his collar, yanking him to the side as an arrow grazed his cheek. Blood began to leak down the wound as Shahid stared, shocked and stunned. “Y-You…”

 

“Hm. Did you need to do that, Teach?” Claude asked, his attention on Byleth, “I don’t think anyone here would’ve minded if I put an end to his ambitions permanently.”

 

“Would you have been okay with it?” Byleth questioned in turn, earning a huff from Claude.

 

“Believe me, Shahid’s not exactly worth keeping alive after everything he’s done. This ass has been stubbornly charging at the same wall over and over again for years now. He doesn’t have value as a hostage and he’ll cause more problems if we let him go. It’s better to end things here.”

 

“Are you okay with that?” she repeated.

 

“...I’d been working up the nerve on the way here. Feels like a waste if I don’t go through with it.”

 

“What do Almyrans think of fratricide?” She glanced back at Nader. “Fodlaners don’t really like it, but I’ve seen nobles be ordered to kill their siblings before.”

 

Hilda paused. “You have? When–Oh, the thing with Sylvain’s brother?”

 

“Mm hm.”

 

Nader, meanwhile, shrugged. “Prince Shahid made his choice when he came to the battlefield. If Khalid wants to off him himself, that’s up to him. If he were just a Fodlander then the king would have to respond, but if this is a battle between siblings…well, there'll certainly be fallout, but nothing you have to worry about." 

 

"..." Letting out a breath, Byleth let go of Shahid, and took a step away as Claude drew another arrow. 

 

"W-Wait, you can't be serious!" Shahid shouted as he tried to back away, stumbling and failing to get to his feet.

 

"It’s up to you, Shahid,” Claude stated, coldly and calmly, “Give up and accept you’re not going to be king. That’s your only way out of this.”

 

"...They'll never accept you. Even if you win here, nothing will change about you being a worthless half-breed!" 

 

"Then I suppose you'll just have to see me succeed from hell." 

 

An arrow flew, whistling through the air before ending with sharp squelch, then a thud as a body fell. 

 

“...” Hilda put a hand on Claude’s back. 

 

He let out a slow sigh as he lowered his bow. “Let’s hope my other siblings aren’t as stubborn.”

 

“Hopefully,” Byleth murmured. A part of her wondered if she could have done something more to prevent what happened, but…the most she could think of was just killing Shahid herself. And she wasn’t sure if Claude would take that any better. 

 

Though that thought made her wonder just how Shez and everyone else was doing on their part of the mission. She’d like to check in on them, but she couldn’t travel as rapidly as Shez could. Not without some kind of steed or…

 

She looked over at the bowed wyvern. The wyvern immediately lowered its gaze to avoid provoking her.

 

“…hm. Hey, Claude, I’m taking this wyvern.”

 

"Huh?" Was all Claude could before Byleth hopped on the wyvern, grabbing its reins and taking to the skies in a sudden burst of speed. “...hm. Is it just me, or does Teach seem more emotional than usual?”

 

“Pretty sure she’s feeling weird,” Hilda replied, shrugging, “It happens.”

 

“Hm. How much do you want to bet she’s running off to check on Shez?”

 

Hilda huffed. “I’m not Baltie, Claude. I don’t take obviously bad bets.”

 

"Sure you don't," Claude said, before looking at Shahid's corpse, "...For now, I guess I have to get ready for whatever happens."

Flying was an interesting sensation for Byleth. The air flowing past her hair felt…almost right, though she chose to ignore that as she guided Bitey towards where a familiar purple flash flicked around the battlefield. 

 

Shez seemed to be handling herself well, pushing the princess Farah back while clearly not going for the killing blow. Byleth took a moment to observe the princess, who did resemble her brothers in terms of hair and skin color, with a lean figure decorated by a scale mail hauberk, violet cloth, and gold gauntlets and boots. Her long hair was braided with gold thread and she was riding a wyvern while wielding an axe, which briefly reminded Byleth of Edelgard…and she wasn’t going to think about that right now because she needed to commit to the plan.

 

A part of her wanted to leap into battle, to join her sister in taking down the princess, but she wasn’t going to be overprotective again. Shez could handle herself.

 

And she did, taking advantage of the princess’s wyvern overextending itself and warping up into the saddle to kick Farah off, sending her crashing into the dirt right before Shez jumped off and landed straight on her. Her feet impacted the princess’s chest, driving the air from her lungs, before Shez stabbed her swords into the ground on either side of Farah’s head and gave her a cheeky grin.

 

“And that’s that, your highness! Looks like you lose!”

 

"Geh…what are you waiting for then? Finish what you started," Farah demanded, glaring up at her. 

 

"No can do! I'm supposed to take you out, but killing is a no go," Shez replied, before pausing when she heard the flapping of wings. With a quick glance, she saw Byleth approaching, "Oh, Byleth, you got things settled already?" 

 

"Claude did, at least," 

 

"...That’s Shahid's wyvern. So he has been struck down," Farah muttered, before staring up at Shez, "You have already struck down an Almyran prince, so it won't be long until Father retaliates, and I hold no use as a hostage–”

 

“Yeah, shut up,” Shez ordered, “You’re not here as a hostage–Wait, is she a hostage? I think it’s more like a prisoner than a hostage.”

 

“I think it’s more like a catch and release thing,” Byleth replied, shrugging, “Claude is going to talk to them and get this sorted out so he can be king.”

 

Farah, who had already been quite offended to be ordered to ‘shut up’ by some random, albeit skilled, Fodlan soldier, blinked at that. “You–What?! A savage from Fodlan can’t become the king of Almyra!”

 

“Claude can,” Shez responded, “He’s Khalid.”

 

“...what?”

 

“Claude is Khalid. Oh, right, I guess you don’t have context for that. So you know who Khalid is, right?”

 

“Of course I do! He’s my craven brother who ran away from home!”

 

“Yeah, no, he was actually over here fighting wars and stuff. I think he put it as ‘winning in my mother’s homeland so I can claim my father’s’ or something like that.” Shez shrugged, standing and sheathing her swords. “He’ll explain it better.”

 

“...I…you…what?” Farah managed to ask, openly baffled.

 

“Come on, up you go,” Shez insisted, holding her hand out to the bewildered princess to help her up. “The sooner we finish up this battle, the sooner we get a victory feast. Which, hey, I’m pretty sure you’re invited if you need some extra incentive.”

 

“...” After a moment’s hesitation, Farah slowly took Shez’s hand and allowed herself to be pulled up. And then she took a second to consider how strong the Fodlan warrior clearly was, as evidenced by her firm grip, and made a few quick mental calculations. “...are you a noble of Fodlan?”

 

“Huh? Uh, not really? My dad is captain of the Knights of Seiros though–Wait, hang on…Hey, Byleth? Rhea’s our grandma, right? If she’s still the archbishop, does that make us nobles?”

 

Byleth considered that question, then shrugged. “Probably not.”

 

“Yeah, probably not.”

 

Farah just stared for a moment. “...the granddaughter of Fodlan’s ruler would be sufficient.”

 

“Huh? Oh, Rhea’s not the ruler, she’s like…wait, what do you mean ‘sufficient’?”

 

“You are of sufficient rank to be a viable consort.”

 

“...what.”

 

“She already has a fiance,” Byleth chimed in.

 

“Ah, a pity.” Farah glanced over at Byleth, ignoring Shez’s blatant confusion. “What about you?”

 

“I have two fiances.”

 

“Damn,” Farah muttered, before looking over at Byleth for a moment. "...They would not be willing to travel and live in Almyra?" 

 

"One of them is the Emperor, so that's not really an option." 

 

"Hm. How annoying,” she grumbled, before pausing. “Fodlan has an emperor? I thought you were led by a series of independent lords that bow to your religious leader, the ‘archbishop’.”

 

“Uh, no? You guys do know Fodlan is three different nations, right?” Shez asked.

 

“...It seems my education has some gaps in it.”

 

Byleth immediately perked up, her eyes practically gleaming. “I can answer any questions you might have.”

 

“...By, you can’t recruit her for the Black Eagles,” Shez pointed out.

 

“The Deer have two Almyrans in their class, I can recruit one if she is willing to join.”

 

Farah raised an eyebrow. “...is this a cult?”

 

“Better. It’s a student house at the Garreg Mach Officer’s Academy,” Byleth readily explained, moving to Farah’s side to help support her, “You see, the academy has its attending students divide into three houses–”

 

Shez, meanwhile, just sighed. Somehow, she felt like this was going to reawaken some kind of old rivalry, though whether it was going to be between the Eagles and the Deer or between Claude and his sister, she wasn’t sure. Might be both, now that she considered it…

 

Well, at least Byleth seemed happy.

Chapter End Notes

Red: I feel like we always end the Almyran conflicts in one chapter. Which, while it might be game accurate, is kinda funny considering they're such a big nation. It just works out that way though.

Indi: That it does, though they're not completely out of the picture, even if Shahid is.

Red: True true. Alas, there wasn't really a way for things to end well with Shahid. He's too proud to back down and too thoughtless to realize he should.

Indi: Yeah, but at least we have the other siblings to play around with for a bit

Red: That we do! Oh yeah, and Kronya continues her path to becoming the ruler of United Fodlan, the true endgame for this story.

Indi: The true golden ending

Well that was Easy

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

“Gotta admit, I thought it’d be harder to take down four Almyran royals,” Shez commented as she helped dice some vegetables in the main fort’s kitchen.

 

“Oh yeah? Why’s that?” Raphael asked, trying his best to keep his eyes on Shez and not on all the food being prepared. His distractedness was understandable though; the big guy had worked up an appetite after spending his initial reunion with his friends beating the crap out of a bunch of Almyran soldiers in between his group and the pair of remaining Almyran princes.

 

“Well, they’re from a major nation outside of Fodlan’s borders, right? One with a whole ‘warrior culture’ thing going on,” Shez elaborated, “I figured that would mean they’re all a bunch of badasses that would take, I dunno, about a few months of effort to corner and defeat. Not a day.”

 

“Ohh, now I get what you mean. Yeah, I guess I can understand why you’d be confused. Or are you disappointed?”

 

“Uh…I don’t know, maybe? I think I was expecting some kind of…epic clash, the kind that sagas are written about, and instead I hear Shahid got killed without me doing anything, the twins were taken down by your team, and Farah is just flirting with my sister because apparently she likes shorter women?”

 

“Huh. Shorter women are easier to pick up,” Raphael noted, looking thoughtful.

 

“Well yeah, I know that. Lysithea is really easy to carry. Same for Kronya, though she gets all squirmy. That’s not really my point though.”

 

“Hm…oh, I just thought of something.”

 

“Yeah?”

 

“Aref and Aziz aren’t twins. Aref is three years older.”

 

“...that’s not exactly…huh, really? They look so similar though…” Shez considered this new information, then just shrugged. “Eh, I’ll keep calling them twins because it’s easier. They can correct me if it’s a problem.”

 

"You can always ask them if it's a problem when we take food over to them. Hm, do you think they'd tell me about Almyran food?" 

 

"You could always ask Claude." 

 

"Oh yeah that's true," Raphael said, a smile on his face as he continued to watch the food. “...so hey, do you want me to help out?”

 

“Can you cook anything other than salted meat?”

 

“Huh? What else would I need to make?”

 

Shez chuckled, ignoring one of the fort’s actual cooks as the guy huffed in annoyance. “I think our friends and guests would probably want something more than that, yeah. Hm…maybe I could show you how to cook other stuff sometime? If you’re up for it.”

 

“Oh sure, that sounds great! Though I think you’re underestimating the tastiness of pure meat.”

 

“Raph, buddy, I can absolutely show you how to cook even tastier meat than just salted jerky. Here, how about we move over? We can let these guys cook while we start practicing,” she suggested.

 

And while one Eisner sister began teaching her friend how to cook, the other was busy “guarding” a trio of Almyran royals. Though anyone who happened to look in on her makeshift classroom would probably say she was doing more lecturing than guarding.

 

“–so of the official Fodlan nations, the Leicester Alliance, marked here in yellow, is technically the ‘youngest’, though the nobility that makes up its leadership can trace their lineage back to the Ten Elites,” Byleth explained, gesturing to the map of Fodlan she’d marked, “This is part of what gives the Great Houses, most recently made up of the noble houses Riegan, Gloucester, Goneril, Edmund, and Ordelia, their justification to make decisions for the rest of Leicester. 

 

“However, it should be noted that House Edmund was actually raised to a Great House based on merit and wealth, and they do not have their own crest named after them. Similarly, House Ordelia also lacks a specific named crest, and instead traditionally bears the crest of House Charon, a Faerghus noble house. The reason for that actually goes back several hundred years, but before we get into anything like that, I would like to ask if you have any questions.”

 

Immediately, hands raised.

 

“Isn’t Consort Tiana from House Riegan?” Aziz asked.

 

“To my knowledge, yes, she is.”

 

“House Goneril is the one that maniac Holst is from, correct?” Aref questioned.

 

“I wouldn’t call him a maniac, but yes.”

 

“Are you certain you’re not available for marriage?” Farah inquired.

 

“I’m not. Sorry.” Byleth responded, biting back a sigh, "My apologies, Farah but aside from already being with someone else, I don't really know you that well." 

 

"So if you were to get to know me, perhaps on a date, marriage would be on the table?" 

 

"I did not say that," 

 

"Yet as an instructor, is it not your duty to aid your students as best you can, and to do that you must get to know them, correct?" 

 

“Don’t harass this instructor too, Farah,” Aref chided. 

 

“This is why you can’t retain any of your staff,” Aziz commented, earning a huff from Farah.

 

“You make it sound like I’m some dirty old man.”

 

The brothers shared a glance. “In spirit, if not body.” “You do have certain tendencies.”

 

“Your words are lies and slander, and I will absolutely have vengeance for this.”

 

"Please refrain from arguing or you'll get detention," Byleth stated. 

 

"Don't think you can give hostages detention," Claude noted, walking into the makeshift classroom, "Also pretty sure said hostages shouldn't have their arms unbound." 

 

"Don't worry, I can handle them if they try anything. Aref can attest to that." 

 

The prince in question nodded, choosing not to draw attention to the purple bruise around his eye. “I would also point out, younger brother, that you have a dragon that razed half our forces, and a maniac that slaughtered the other half alongside his band of shockingly muscular Fodlaners.”

 

Raphael did get along with Holst and Balthus surprisingly well. Byleth wouldn’t be surprised if the trio of muscular Leicester men just bonded through flexing. She was pretty sure that was how male friendships worked anyway.

 

"That doesn't mean I'll be dropping my guard around you three." 

 

"You would be wise not to. Even if you have defeated me, that does not mean I accept you as the future King of Almyra," Farah noted, staring at Claude, "You may have won this time, little brother, yet you should not expect all those who follow you to remain loyal, lest you have a close ally turn traitor." 

 

"Oh don't worry about me, I can handle myself, especially with someone like Teach by my side. Right, Teach?" 

 

"Hm? Oh, well, sure. While I'm around anyways. Not sure how long I'll be staying though," Byleth admitted, shrugging.

 

“...you really had to undercut my point, huh Teach?”

 

“Well I’m not your professor. You’re part of the Deer, remember?” She tilted her head, thinking. “Maybe you should ask Manuela? I don’t think she’ll say yes, but maybe she’ll be interested in seeing what Almyra is like.”

 

Claude just sighed. “How about we stop talking about my plans for the future? Let’s focus on what the rest of you are going to do going forward, and why it’s going to involve staying out of my way and letting me take the throne.”

 

“Hmph. Do you really think our own nobility will gladly hand over the throne to you, Khalid?” Farah questioned, glaring at her brother, “You do realize it is not merely a matter of foreign blood that causes them to question your capabilities, don’t you? You have no connections to the great lords of Almyra and no ties that bind you to our kingdom. No betrothal, no sponsorship, and no true prospects amid a court that already thinks poorly of you.”

 

“Oh please, I knew all of that already,” Claude countered, his usual smirk back in place, “Farah, I’ve been planning how I’m going to take Almyra’s throne from the first moment I saw our father sitting on it. Trust me or don’t, but dealing with Fodlan was the tricky part. Bringing Almyra to heel? Give me a year and I’ll have everyone from Odaenathus to Zabdas bowing their heads to their new king.”

 

“Are those regions in Almyra?” Byleth asked, interrupting Farah before she could reply, “Actually…hm. Claude, do you have any books on Almyra? The library at the monastery didn’t have many books on foreign countries and they were sparse on details.”

 

“Teach, I am completely willing to hook you up with books the church doesn’t want you to read later, but I was sort of having a staredown with my sister here.”

 

“Oh, sorry.” Byleth glanced at Farah. “I’m invested in making Claude king of Almyra because it will make things easier for all of us. Please don’t get in the way of that.”

 

Farah narrowed her eyes. “...Marry me-”

 

“No.”

 

“Damn…very well, if , and only if, that option is entirely off the table…do you know anyone similar to you who may be interested in marrying a foreign princess?”

 

Byleth tilted her head in thought. “...Manuela is single.”

 

“You mentioned her earlier. She is another professor?”

 

“Yup.” Byleth paused, thinking of what qualities Farah might like. “Hm…her boobs are also bigger than mine-”

 

“Alright, we’re ending that conversation now,” Claude decided.

 

“I don’t mind continuing it.”

 

“I do mind, so we’re stopping it.”

 

“Are all Fodlaners perverts?” Aref murmured, leaning towards Aziz while Claude tried to direct the conversation in a direction that didn’t involve setting up his former professor with his sister.

 

His brother shrugged. “They do seem more immodest. That Goneril girl was practically baring her chest, and some of the outfits they wear are…well, they have a different culture. Sure, it might be worse than ours, but we should respect that while they hold us under the threat of death.”

 

“Hm. Wise words of wisdom indeed.”

The remaining clean-up of the Almyran forces went quickly once the news of Prince Khalid’s appearance and the four royals’ defeats began to spread, and soon enough, the forces of the Alliance, and the Knights of Seiros, to a lesser extent, gathered together for a grand feast to celebrate their victory!

 

"Gotta say, it feels nice being able to have a big celebration again," Shez said, lifting a mug of ale in the air, knocking it against Byleth’s as she raised hers in return. 

 

"Feels nice being able to drink again, at least," Byleth replied before she drank hers, "Mm. Speaking of, how long have you been drinking alcohol? Last I remember, Papa didn't let you." 

 

"That was three years ago, I can drink if I want," Shez retorted, letting out a huff as she took a big swig of hers. 

 

"Fair enough. Either way, I'm looking forward to finishing up here and going to the Empire." 

 

"Eh? I thought we were going to take Garreg Mach first?" 

 

“...” Byleth sighed, looking genuinely despondent. “Right…maybe Rhea and the knights could handle that on their own…”

 

“Hey, no need to mope. I could do it myself–”

 

“I’m not letting you out of my sight for at least a year.”

 

“...that’s going to make some stuff awkward.”

 

“You know what I mean.” Byleth huffed. "I just want to be able to see all of the Eagles again." 

 

"Come on Byleth, it's not that bad." 

 

"You're just saying that cause you have your girlfriends." 

 

"Wh–No I'm not–" 

 

"They fed you grapes, whatever you say is invalid," Byleth cut off, before downing her mug of ale in one go. 

 

“...so you’re jealous, huh?”

 

Byleth gave her amused sister the most annoyed look she could manage. “Shut up.”

 

“I’m just saying,” Shez said, not even bothering to hide her grin, “You have been complaining a lot–”

 

“Shut. Up.”

 

“And I seem to recall you saying they were both your fiancees? Right? Which is kinda weird, because I’m not sure when you would have ever asked them to marry you–”

 

“I’m getting more ale.” Byleth got up from the bench, ignoring her smug sister and her stupid giggles in favor of trying to find the nearest barrel of alcohol. Which was more difficult than expected because the fort’s dining hall was full of people, to the point of the celebration spilling out of the fort and into the surrounding mountaintop. 

 

The addition of the Almyrans alongside the Alliance forces was probably at fault for that, though it was nice seeing everyone alongside one another, eating, drinking, and making merry. There might have been some tension in the air at some point, but Holst and Nader, who were currently in the midst of another arm wrestling match in front of a cheering crowd of burly men, did a lot to make that tension disappear into a festive atmosphere. 

 

Eventually though, she managed to find a barrel of ale that hadn't been emptied, mainly thanks to Rhea seemingly keeping it for herself. 

 

"Do you mind if I have some?" Byleth asked as the archbishop downed a mug. 

 

"Oh, Byleth," Rhea said, her cheeks slightly pinked as she looked over, "Go ahead. Just don't take it all." 

 

"No promises," Byleth muttered, filling her mug up again before drinking. “Mm…so, the plan is to go to Garreg Mach next?”

 

“Of course. I need the monastery back if I am to begin repairing the damage Fodlan has suffered,” she stated, “I owe it to Mother–...I owe it to the people of Fodlan to right the wrongs I have allowed to linger for far too long.”

 

Byleth stared at her for a moment, then shrugged and took another drink. “Mm. Just make sure you don’t try to do everything yourself. It’s fine to rely on other people and trying to solve your problems on your own makes you vulnerable to missing the important stuff. I made that mistake and got trapped in the void.”

 

“...I know, Byleth. I was with you.”

 

“Yes, you were, so make sure to remember that lesson.”

 

Rhea just sighed. “I have to admit, I am surprised you are so against returning to the monastery with how obviously you enjoy the idea of teaching again. Were you not aiming to recruit that Almyran princess to your class earlier?”

 

Byleth shook her head. “I already mentioned my relationships with Edelgard and Dorothea to you. I need to make sure they’re fine before I consider my future plans.”

 

“And those plans include recruiting foreign royalty to your class?”

 

“Potentially. I’m not sure if I’ll still be teaching at the monastery after we’re done with everything or if I’ll accept that offer from Edelgard to become her advisor…assuming that offer is still open. I don’t think she would rescind it, but either way, I’m figuring things out as I go and I think I’ll be able to make better plans once I know all of my loved ones are safe.” She took another drink, before nodding to herself. “This conversation is getting too heavy for a celebration. Pick a different topic.”

 

“Huh? Oh, er…I…do you have anything in mind?”

 

“Hm…what do you call your breasts?”

 

“...what.”

 

“One moment.” Byleth stood up and searched the crowd for a hint of pink hair. “Hm…ah, there. HILDA, COME OVER HERE! I NEED YOU TO PROVIDE CONTEXT!”

 

A moment later, a very confused Hilda Goneril walked over. “Uh, what’s up, Byleth? Why’d you shout across the party like that?”

 

“Tell Rhea what you call your breasts.”

 

“Oh, so that’s what this is about…uh, professor, I think you had too much to drink–”

 

“I have a high tolerance for alcohol. I think.” She glanced at Rhea. “Do Nabateans have a high alcohol tolerance?”

 

“Ah…yes, of course,” Rhea lied, “All of us have a naturally high tolerance for alcohol.” Then Byleth’s words registered. “Wait, don’t…don’t say that.”

 

“Say what?”

 

“The naba-word! You cannot–We are supposed to keep it a secret!”

 

“Rhea, you turned into a dragon in front of everyone,” Byleth reminded.

 

“...” Rhea glanced at Hilda, who was honestly just confused by this conversation and kind of hoping she could find an excuse to leave. “Hm. You still shouldn’t…oh, never mind. What were we even talking about?”

 

Byleth wracked her brain. “...breasts?”

 

“Hmm…breasts are nice, I suppose. I do find them appealing,” she admitted with a shrug before pouring herself another drink.

 

“Really? Hm…so do you have anyone you like romantically? Because I might have tried to set up Manuela with that Almyran princess, so I’m not sure if she’s still an option.”

 

“...why would you do that?”

 

“Manuela has made it obvious that she wants to marry somebody so I’m trying to come up with good options for her. Part of me kind of wants to match up everyone I know so they’re all paired together. I’m not sure why, but it makes my brain feel good.”

 

“You’re trying to be a matchmaker?”

 

“Maybe? It would be nice if everyone had someone to love.”

 

“Hm. You do not need another person in your life to be fulfilled, Byleth.”

 

“...you say that, but you spent a thousand years trying to resurrect one specific person so you could feel fulfilled.”

 

“Yes, and that was a bad idea, so now I have chosen to simply work on fixing things. After everything is said and done, perhaps I will explore self-improvement as well and try to find ways in which I can become a richer person on my own, without a dependence on my mother’s validation.”

 

“Mm. Mm…okay. I can respect that. I might forget about this conversation and try pushing someone at you if I think they’re good though, so consider this a warning in advance.”

 

Rhea sighed. “I suppose that is the best I can hope for…hm, right, Hilda, I apologize for ignoring–” The archbishop blinked, finally noticing the noblewoman had left a while ago. “Ah. I suppose that’s…hm.”

 

Meanwhile, across the party, Shez huffed in amusement at the sight of Rhea’s bewildered expression. “Oh come on, I’m sure it’s fine if we let those two keep drinking. They might be fumbling a little, but they’re not hurting anyone.”

 

“Well they might hurt their reputations if they keep loudly talking about tits like that,” Leonie commented, equally amused.

 

Lysithea let out an exasperated sigh, something she found she was doing more and more often these days. “I would prefer it if you stop them before they do anything worse than chat about breasts in a public place.”

 

“Like what?” Shez asked, still more amused than concerned, “C’mon, it’s Byleth and Rhea. They’re not exactly party animals.”

 

“I don’t think I ever heard of Rhea even going near a party,” Leonie remarked, still watching the pair for a moment before turning her attention to her friends, “More importantly, how are things going to play out with Claude now? Sure, he’s apparently stepping down from being Duke so he can throw his hat in the ring for being the King of Almyra, but what’s that mean for everyone else? Is he going to help us with taking on the rest of our enemies or are we on our own?”

 

“That’s...yeah, those are good questions. I know Claude is trying to do something clever by making Kronya the new duke, though I’m not sure how he’s going to pull that off. Heck, I’m pretty sure he’s trying to get Count Gloucester to handle things for him, though I’m not sure how that works either.”

 

“Count Erwin wants to become the new head of the Alliance and Claude is essentially handing that position to him,” Lysithea explained, frowning, “He has chosen Kronya to be his ‘heir’ because he knows she is not prepared to run anything and he is letting Count Erwin, or more likely Lorenz, instruct her in the ways of the nobility because it lets House Gloucester hold power over House Riegan.”

 

Shez narrowed her eyes. “So he’s making Kronya his patsy?”

 

“That is one way to describe it, I suppose. I can’t guess exactly what Claude wants, but I wouldn’t put it past him to play to Count Erwin’s ambitions to the point of letting his own house fall in standing, just so he can get an advantage somewhere down the line.” She tilts her head thoughtfully. “In fact, placing a weak leader in House Riegan during a time of crisis, right after House Ordelia has officially dissolved means the Alliance might go through some very rough changes in the future…”

 

“...well shit,” Leonie responded, summing up the situation quite concisely. “...does this mean we need to kill Claude to stop his evil plan?”

 

“It’s too late at this point for his death to change anything,” Lysithea pointed out, “I’m not saying no though.”

 

“I am,” Shez spoke up, “We’re not killing our friends, guys. And I’m pretty sure you’re the ones who should stop drinking if you’re seriously considering it.”

 

“It was a joke, Shez. Mostly.”

 

“We could always just beat him up,” Leonie offered, obviously amused.

 

Shez did consider that offer slightly more seriously though, before shaking her head. “No, that would still be a dick move. It would probably cause more problems than it would solve if we beat him up too badly. As is, we should just get ready to move out towards Garreg Mach.” 

 

“Right, that's a pretty important place to take. Haven't heard much about it other than those weird knights who started living near it.” 

 

“Yeah, they're probably going to be a problem, but hey, won't be the first time we've dealt with a problem. And besides, I've dealt with worse knights,” 

 

“Really? Who?” 

 

The banging of a door cut off Shez as the trio looked over to see a familiar knight rushing in. “Lady Rhea, I'm so glad to see you're okay!” 

 

“...Her,” Shez grumbled, frowning as she watched Catherine approach Rhea. 

 

“Really? You have an issue with Catherine? I know she can be a bit much but I didn't think she was that bad,” Leonie asked, glancing at Catherine, who seemed to be fussing over the inebriated Rhea. 

 

“It's a long story, and one I'm not in the mood to get into. What matters is that even if Byleth forgave her, I haven't.” Shez huffed, as she finished off her mug. “Ugh, maybe it would be worth it to go to the Empire instead…” 

 

Surely it couldn't be any worse than dealing with Catherine. 

Edelgard von Hresvelg was frankly having one of the worst battles of her life. 

 

It was supposed to be simple. While the Knights of Reclamation didn't seem to be the most reliable force around, they would provide the necessary back-up her forces needed to take back the Eastern portion of Adrestia seized by Aegir and the armies of Hrym. She would have preferred if the entire Reclamation force helped, but she couldn't quite complain about the back-up they received in their clash at Fort Merceus.

 

She wasn't sure how to feel about Ludwig von Aegir being a tough opponent, but it wasn’t as though the arrogant “archduke” could take the full credit for his army’s success. No, the real pain in her ass had to be the enormous, bulky foes resembling suits of armor with a large shield on their left arms and sharp blades on their rights who could send a squad of knights flying with a single swing, as well as a magical armament perched atop the fort’s walls that seemed to be able to rain down lightning across the entire battlefield. 

 

“Edie!” At Dorothea’s shout, the Emperor moved to the side, evading a thoron that crashed into one of the living suits of armor, causing it to jerk for a moment, and giving Edelgard the chance she needed to smash her axe into it. The sacred blade of Labraunda smashed into the Agarthan symbol on its chest and split open the stone there, causing blue sparks to spray from the twitching titan before it crashed to the ground.

 

A cheer sounded up from her troops and their allies at the sight of one of their foes crashing into the dirt, but Edelgard couldn’t share their enthusiasm. One enemy felled didn’t make a battle won and the principality’s forces were far more entrenched and fortified than she preferred. 

 

Fort Merceus was always going to be a difficult target to take. It was meant to be the Empire’s last line of defense against invaders from the north, and having it turned on her certainly rankled an admittedly proud part of Edelgard. She’d been looking for a way in ever since it was first taken by the Agarthans and if Hubert had any luck at all, the gates should be opening enough for them to make a proper push in any moment now.

 

Then they didn’t, and Edelgard felt a scowl come to her face once the allotted time for Hubert’s plan ran out. She buried down the tinge of worry she felt for her close confidant and head of her household, steeling herself as she raised her voice. “FALL BACK! WE NEED TO RETREAT AND REGROUP!”

 

The order spread quickly and she was gratified to see Ferdinand using his cavalry to rapidly relay it to their forces. There was a shift in the battlefield as her army moved into defensive formations, blocking the enemy’s spells and arrows while they hurried back into cover.

 

“Hubie didn’t come through?” Dorothea asked, a frown on her face as she looked worriedly at the walls.

 

“It’s possible the entrances were discovered. We’ll have to rethink things.” It would be a setback, but not an impossible one. Hubert was skilled at getting out of difficult situations so she was confident she would see her spymaster soon enough; once she made sure everyone was fine, they could look for another way at striking at the fort.

 

Ferdinand returned to them soon enough, a frown on his face as he took in their retreating forces. It wasn’t a rout by any means, and if they maneuvered properly, they could draw some of the enemy into another counterattack, so at least the assault wouldn’t be wasted. “A sudden retreat like this might be bad for morale, Edelgard.”

 

“I’m aware. It would be worse to waste our forces on a direct assault we have no chance of succeeding at.”

 

“I know. The problem is, there are more people on our side that will take this badly–”

 

“Emperor Edelgard!” Ladislava called out from atop her wyvern, bringing it close, “The Knights of Reclamation are still trying to push the attack, they aren’t obeying the order to retreat.”

 

Edelgard grimaced. “Of course they aren’t. Stubborn fools…Ferdinand, speak to their commander, get him to see reason.”

 

“Understood, your majesty! I’ll have them following us before the enemy has a chance to realize there was a problem to begin with!” he replied with all his usual pomp and chivalry, earning an amused huff from Dorothea.

 

“You know, I was wondering why you decided he should stick around here instead of heading the second team with Monnie, but I’m starting to get it.”

 

“He would be a decent commander,” Edelgard admitted, “But right now, I need him close by. He’s better at talking with the former church knights than Monica would be.” It helped that he and Flayn were close. The young Nabatean was already helping out a great deal in her role as the Southern Bishop, even if her new position had annoyed the cardinal leading the Reclamation forces. 

 

Something about “overstepping her bounds”, as though a holy man of a defunct church had any authority to speak of.

 

“He does balance out Hubie better too,” Dorothea noted, before giving her emperor a glance, “Do you think Monnie’s group has a good chance of taking Varley county back?”

 

“They’ll have a better chance if we can keep Ludwig and his allies focused on us, and taking Fort Merceus will guarantee the archduke can’t look anywhere else. Which means we’ll just have to do our best to seize it.”

 

A siege wasn’t broken by just one loss, even if it was grating to see the ‘Stubborn Old General’ standing strong. She really would have preferred to take the damn fort in a single battle, the way her professor would have if she’d been here.

 

Edelgard sighed. It was times like this that she really missed Byleth.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Hey there everyone, and happy Holidays! Sorry about not uploading lately!

Red: Yeah, a mix of writer's block and life stuff made writing difficult, but hey, we're getting back into it! And hopefully y'all like this new chapter!

Indi: We even have another chapter almost ready, though don't expect it right away, turns out our old habit of a chapter every 3 or 4 days wasn't good in the long run lol.

Red: Alas. Ah well, hopefully we can get back into a semi-regular schedule at some point.

Indi: Hopefully! For now though, hope you enjoyed the chapter!

Red: As always, thanks for reading!

Churchward Bound

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Byleth had to admit, she thought the day she returned to Garreg Mach would be a happier occasion. 

 

It’d been three years since she last set foot on the stones of the monastery, and the last time she had been there had been…rough, to say the least. So a part of her couldn’t help but think that her eventual return to the academy would be a pleasant experience. Perhaps bittersweet, at most, but still overall triumphant.

 

Of course, she wasn’t actually at Garreg Mach at the moment. Really, she could only barely be considered to be beginning her journey towards Garreg Mach, on account of the fact that there were still tons of things to do in the Alliance. So instead of an immediate journey to reclaim the monastery, she woke up that morning with a pounding headache and a dry mouth due to overindulging with drinking the night before, and then had to sit through a meeting about how they would actually be taking Garreg Mach back.

 

And by this point, she’d heard the name “Garreg Mach” so many times that she was pretty sure it stopped being a word.

 

“Hey, Eisner, pay attention!” Catherine called out, scowling at her from across the room and not helping things in the slightest. But then the blonde had never been a particularly helpful person in Byleth’s life. 

 

“I’m paying attention,” Byleth responded, trying her best not to glare at the loud blonde. It didn’t help that Rhea was sitting at the head of the table, looking completely serene despite the fact that Byleth knew she drank more than her. She was pretty sure the archbishop had cheated with healing magic or something…which raised the question in Byleth’s head of why she herself hadn’t used healing magic to fix her problem. And now she was feeling stupid–

 

“Then what did I just say?” Oh, she’s still talking.

 

Byleth glanced at the board, then extrapolated what the knight was probably talking about. “We’re going to Garreg Mach to take it back from the people that took it. That’s our first priority so it’s where we’ll put the majority of our focus. Alois and Shamir are already heading here so we’ll meet with them first, then probably take Rhea and some wyverns to get there quickly, whereupon we will bring down the wrath of the goddess or something like that.

 

“After that, we can talk to the Knights of Reclamation at Zanado. Going to them first will overcomplicate things and cause a delay, and ideally we’ll get this all done today so we don’t have to worry about it further,” she finished, turning her gaze back to Catherine, “Correct?”

 

“...that…well, we were planning to scout the area first before committing to an attack,” she replied, looking a little put out.

 

“...no you weren’t. You prefer going right for the attack. I guess you could have changed over the past few years, or my understanding of your personality isn’t as full as I thought, but my impression of you is that you’re just as impatient to take back the monastery as Rhea is because you view it as a personal insult that it was taken under your watch in the first place.”

 

Catherine’s eyes narrowed, before she huffed in annoyance. “Smartass…alright, professor , what’s your plan for dealing with the demonic beasts and bandits that have taken over the monastery?”

 

“Target the beasts first and use the elites in our group to eliminate all of them, preferably in small squads of four to compensate for weaknesses, before displaying the beasts’ corpses as a method of demoralizing the bandits into surrendering.” She paused, a thought occurring. “Are we intending to take the bandits alive? Because that could be to our benefit if it means we won’t have to fight to kill them all.”

 

“If they are occupying the monastery, I would prefer if no quarter was given to them,” Rhea remarked, looking understandably displeased at the thought of invaders taking over her home.

 

“Right, but people who think they have a chance to live will surrender if the option is offered. Otherwise we might be looking at a much bloodier battle.”

 

“Do we really want to take them alive though?” Hilda spoke up, sounding as annoyed as Byleth felt. Potentially more so because the main reason she was even in this meeting was that Claude and Holst were busy. “They’d probably get executed for banditry anyway, right? That and it’d be a waste of time to put them in any cells because, again, they’re probably going to die anyway.”

 

“Since when are you so bloodthirsty?” Leonie asked, raising an eyebrow at her friend. As a random mercenary she probably wouldn’t have been invited to a meeting like this, but Hilda used the excuse that Leonie was her bodyguard. That and there was no way Leonie was going to be left out of a meeting about going to find Jeralt.

 

“I’m not, I just find it dumb to worry about bandits when there are way more important things to be thinking about.”

 

Like finding Marianne , Byleth thought but didn’t say. She could empathize with the noble’s feelings; she really wanted to see her students again. Particularly the two that managed to capture her unbeating heart…

 

“We’re just trying to clear out the monastery as quickly as possible. If that means taking prisoners or even letting some of the bandits escape, then we should allow for those options,” Byleth reiterated, “The important part is securing the monastery. How we do that doesn’t matter as much as getting it done.”

 

“I’d say the way we take the monastery back does matter as much as taking it back,” Catherine retorted, earning a blank stare from Byleth.

 

“…if you’re arguing with me just for the sake of it, I’m going to punch you.”

 

“What, you can’t handle someone having a dissenting opinion?”

 

“…” Byleth narrowed her eyes. “Nothing you do or say will change the fact that Rhea likes me more than you.”

 

“…”

 

Hilda whistled, impressed. “Wow, I didn’t think the professor had a catty side.”

 

“You’d be surprised,” Leonie remarked, trying to hide the fact that she was just as surprised.

 

“Byleth, Catherine, now is not the time to argue,” Rhea spoke up, trying to be a voice of reason between the two glaring women, “Obviously I do have a greater affection for Byleth because she is family to me, but–“

 

Byleth did wind up punching Catherine in the face, but only because the blonde punched her first.

“Gotta say, I didn’t expect to achieve my goals like this,” Claude remarked, looking out over the grounds of the fort, where Alymyran soldiers milled about Leicester troops, chatting and working with one another in preparation for their return home. And, of course, for the next battles ahead.

 

“What do you mean?” Shez asked, glancing at him from her own place on the wall.

 

“I mean as I say.” He sighed, letting his tone get wistful. “I grew up with a sword hanging over my head. Everyone around me knew that I was some half-breed brat with the lowest chance of ever sitting on the throne, and they made sure I knew it.

 

“Then in just one battle, all of my biggest rivals were taken down and I went from no chance at all to a practical guarantee that the throne is going to be mine. That’s all it took. One battle, and I have everything I ever dreamed of.”

 

Shez nodded, looking thoughtful at her friend’s honesty. “And now that you have everything you want, you’re not sure if you’re okay with it being so easy?” 

 

“Oh not at all, I love that it was this easy,” Claude denied, letting a big grin spread across his face, “Just thinking about how things might have gone if I had been a bit more honest when we were at the academy.” 

 

“Well, you probably wouldn't have gotten this back then, since we weren't at war and all. For all we know things could have gone better or gone way worse,” Shez said, before she let out a sigh, “But…I guess I would have appreciated being trusted like that.” 

 

“It’s hard to trust when everything you’ve been told and every sign you’ve seen points to the idea that you’ll be ruined or killed if your identity gets out. I had some pretty reasonable doubts that I would be treated kindly if people knew I was a half-Almyran prince sneaking his way into the country. Even if I did go in completely openly, I bet you there would’ve been an uproar just from people looking to tear down House Riegan.”

 

“That’s really cynical and pessimistic…and probably more realistic than them accepting you with open arms.”

 

Claude chuckled. “Yeah, you get what I mean. Of course, being the surprise heir of House Riegan still put eyes on me, and with those eyes came plenty of expectations. It actually used to annoy me whenever people said I had privilege because I was a noble. What kind of privilege does a half-breed that everyone hates have? But, looking back on it, I can’t deny that I had a lot of advantages that put me up here.

 

He smirked. “So now I know how to exploit those advantages for everything I can get.”

 

“Like having all your rivals taken out in one go?”

 

“Exactly. ”

 

Shez huffed in amusement, before deciding to bring up a concern she had. “Hey, so why did you put Kronya up as your ‘successor’ anyway? I know there’s no way you’ll be able to hold onto the whole ‘Duke of House Riegan’ position if you’re going to be king, but why her?”

 

“Oh that’s easy. Count Gloucester really wants to put his house as the new sovereigns of the Alliance and I just handed him an heir of House Riegan that needs his help to understand noble etiquette. Kronya, meanwhile, wants power, approval, and a cozy position, right?”

 

“Eh…well, that’s not exactly wrong,” Shez admitted, a bit glad to have his reasons confirmed, “I’m not sure if she’d say she wants a cozy position, but essentially owning the capital of the Alliance is probably going to make her happy.”

 

“Then my assumptions were still mostly right. I figured it was the easiest way to get a lot of allies on my side that are happy with me specifically. Of course, Gloucester could try to turn on me in the long run, but that’ll put him on the bad side of too many people for the risk to be worth it. Better he takes what’s right in front of him and starts planning for a more cooperative future.” He grinned over at her. “Hell, if he had the chance, I bet he would try marrying Kronya and Lorenz together to secure everything. Such a shame for him that you seduced her already.”

 

“...Okay I know you're trying to get me flustered but you put the image of Kronya and Lorenz getting married in my head and now I have to hit my head against the nearest wall.” 

 

Claude paused, then smirked. “Thinking about it, isn’t he about a foot taller than her? They’d make for quite the pair, side by side. Long man Lorenz and his tiny, stabby wife.”

 

“...” Shez turned her gaze to Claude. “Or I could hit my head against yours.”

 

“Hey now, my brain is more valuable than yours, you shouldn’t threaten it like that.”

 

“Eh, Byleth can handle things for us.” That got Claude to laugh, up until he realized Shez was actually walking towards him. 

 

“Uh, wait, you aren't serious, right?” he asked, backing away. 

 

“C’mon Claude, let me introduce you to the wonderful world of being a dumbass!” Shez offered with a malicious grin. Turning on his heel, Claude began to run as Shez chased after him, intent on hunting him down. 

 

Elsewhere, Byleth looked out towards the south, an aching in her chest as she let out a sigh. 

 

“Hey there Professor, are you doing okay?” Hilda asked, walking up to the green-haired woman, “Don't tell me Catherine actually scrambled something in there.”

 

“No, she hits hard, but I was healed properly,” Byleth replied, even though her jaw still ached. “I still hit her harder.” 

 

“Ha. Remind me not to get on your bad side.” 

 

“Don't worry, you probably won't,” Byleth replied, before tilting her head, “Well, as long as you don't make Marianne cry, I suppose.” 

 

“I would never!” Hilda exclaimed, offended at the thought. 

 

“Then you have nothing to worry about,” 

 

“Hmph. You know, even if she was happy, I'm still annoyed that Marianne left the Deer to join the Eagles.” 

 

“Hm…Apologizing might be meaningless, but I am still sorry. If she had stayed with the Deer, then she'd probably be here with you.” 

 

“Yeah, but she's probably safer with your students. I might not be that close to Edelgard, but even I know not many can take her in a fight.” Sighing, Hilda leaned against the rampart next to Byleth. “Gotta admit, a part of me’s been wanting to try and sneak into the Empire for years now.” 

 

“I can understand that. The main reason I haven't raced off is that I know it'd be bad to go by myself, and that I need to think logically.” 

 

“And I definitely don't want to deal with all the extra work. Claude would probably figure out if I tried to sneak off and he'd give me tons of work to do down south," Hilda said with a laugh. 

 

“He probably would. Though I think you'd be good at whatever work that'd be.” 

 

“Ugh, don't let anyone hear you. I already want to retire.” 

 

“It'd be nice to retire while young, though I don't think I'll be able to with how much I have to work on,” Byleth remarked, before pausing when she heard yelling. 

 

“Stop chasing me!” Claude shouted, running past them as a purple blur soon followed. 

 

“NEVER!” Shez yelled, leaving the two to stare in silence, before Byleth turned to Hilda. 

 

“See what I mean?” 

Shez’s shenanigans aside, things progressed pretty smoothly once their plans were made. Claude, in an unsurprising but somewhat disappointing outcome, had to head back to Almyra with his remaining siblings to get things settled on that end. Holst would be going with him as Leicester’s official ambassador, a first for the Alliance. The fact that he had the backing of the archbishop to give the trip legitimacy probably helped.

 

And so, after many tearful goodbyes, some more than others, they were on their way.

 

“You know, I feel kind of bad for Farah,” Shez admitted, sitting with her sister on Byleth’s new wyvern, “She seemed like she really wanted to come along.”

 

“I have my suspicions that her intentions were not entirely innocent,” Byleth responded, keeping her eyes forward, “Besides, if she truly wants to join my class, she can apply to join the Officer’s Academy next year.”

 

“Oh please, you were just as upset that you’re not getting a new ‘Eagle’,” Shez teased, earning a huff from her sister. “...so, after this, you’re gonna go back to teaching at the monastery?”

 

Byleth paused. “Hm. I guess I haven’t fully thought about my future plans. I know it’s an option. I just…”

 

Shez watched her sister trail off, then made a show of shrugging as she let out a sigh. “Yeah, future plans are a pain. I have no idea what I’m doing. Aside from maybe being Kronya’s trophy wife?”

 

“‘Trophy wife’?”

 

“Well I know I can kick ass and all but I have no idea how noble stuff works. So odds are I’m just gonna be standing around, looking hot to raise her prestige. I mean, if I do marry her anyway, because, well, I guess there’s still stuff with Lysithea and…hm. Um…anyway! Let’s figure that out later!”

 

Byleth smiled at her sister’s antics. “Yes, let’s focus on retaking the monastery first. Everything after that…we’ll see.”

 

With that, their journey to reclaim Garreg Mach continued, though Byleth’s thoughts did keep drifting. It didn’t help that it was a rather long journey, since they had to stop at Gloucester territory to resupply. They had planned to pick up Kronya too, but apparently she was busy with the Count. Something about fortifying the Bridge of Myrddin against a potential retaliation from Hyrm.

 

That was slightly concerning, but Rhea was adamant about reclaiming the monastery before helping the Alliance further, so onward they went until they arrived to set up camp further down the mountain from the monastery and began scouting. To the army’s surprise though, the mountains were bizarrely clear of demonic beasts for the first time in years, which was concerning to an understandably on edge Byleth.

 

“Hey, Byleth, are you doing okay?” Shez asked, marching next to her sister on the way up towards the monastery.

 

“I think so. Everything just feels…tense,” Byleth admitted, unsure of what else to say. 

 

“Because of the battle, or because of something else?”

 

“Something else.”

 

“Mm…more future thoughts?”

 

Byleth considered the question, then shook her head. “No. It’s…something about being here, in this area, is making me feel tense.”

 

Her answer made sense the moment she said it. Something about being near Garreg Mach…she’d enjoyed being at the monastery in the time she was there, but, equally, it was a place that put her family and newfound friends in danger, again and again. And her last memories here–fire, blood, being attacked by a monster that possessed her sister–they weren’t pleasant ones.

 

When the gates of Garreg Mach grew closer in sight, she felt her chest clench as a flood of memories rushed through her head, including the phantom pain of Shez’s sword in her chest. 

 

“Byleth? You okay–” Feeling a hand on her shoulder, Byleth felt herself flinching as she pulled away from Shez. “Ah.”

 

“S-Sorry. Sorry, I…” Byleth took a breath, then abruptly gave her sister a hug. Shez couldn't help but stiffen a bit, her arms awkwardly at her sides as Byleth hugged her tightly. After a moment, she hugged her back, feeling Byleth give her one more squeeze before breaking the hug. “I think I'm not comfortable here.” 

 

“Ah…do you want to stay back?” 

 

“No. I want to help here, and…even if I am afraid, I don't just want to run away.” 

 

Shez’s lips turned up into a grin. “Hell yeah, we’re gonna face those fears and then we’re gonna kick their asses!”

 

In the face of her sister’s enthusiasm, Byleth couldn’t help but return that smile. “Yes, we will. Onward!”

 

“Onward!” Shez echoed before they continued their journey up towards Garreg Mach, moving towards the front of the procession as they made their way to the front gates.

 

There was still a sense of tension in the journey, though it came more from an awareness that they were moving into enemy territory than any previous anxieties. That and most of those who had been there before couldn't help but feel uneasy as they looked upon the destruction wrought upon the town. Luckily, or perhaps ominously, they still didn’t run into any threats on the way, even though there had supposedly been demonic beasts practically ruling the mountains for years. Once they reached the gate though, Byleth found herself pausing at the sight of black banners threaded with red flame patterns hanging from the wall.

 

“I don't remember hearing anything about this,” she heard Catherine mutter, the knight already pulling out her sword. 

 

“They must have moved in recently,” Shamir noted, a hand moving to grab an arrow. 

 

“Regardless of when they moved here, their occupation shall not continue,” Rhea stated, marching forward, ahead of everyone else. She didn't get far before she caught an arrow that had been launched at her, crushing the shaft as she did. She openly snarled, glaring up at the archers on the wall as a surprisingly familiar individual stepped forward.

 

“FOOLS! YOU ENTER THE TERRITORY OF THE FLAME EMPEROR!” declared someone who was definitely wearing the Flame Emperor’s armor, “LAY DOWN YOUR ARMS AND ARMOR, AND PERHAPS I SHALL SPARE YOUR PITIFUL LIVES!”

 

“…” Byleth glanced at Shez. “Yeah, that’s not Edelgard.”

 

“You still thought it was?”

 

“Not really, but it’s good to confirm it.”

 

“This bastard would dare call my home his territory,” Rhea growled, a murderous glint in her eyes, “I’ll rend him limb from–!”

 

“Hang on,” Shez interrupted, a frown coming to her face as she looked up at the bandits on the wall, “I think I know that guy.”

 

“The Flame Emperor?” Shamir asked, an eyebrow raised while Rhea glowered at being interrupted.

 

“No, the other guy, next to him,” Shez explained, pointing up towards a scruffy man with a bowl cut, “Hey, aren’t you Pallardo!?”

 

The man called Pallardo immediately stiffened while the ‘Flame Emperor’ felt a cold sweat start to go down his back. “Ah…yes, I’m Pallardo! Why are you asking?”

 

“Didn’t I kill you??”

 

“…no?” 

 

“Why was that a question??”

 

“Uh…well, I’m alive, so–wait, hold on…” His eyes narrowed in suspicion, before he abruptly recognized the orange-and-purple-haired young woman. “You’re the girl that killed Pallardo!”

 

“Yeah, I just said–Hang on, who are you then? His twin brother?”

 

“Ah, no, we’re not related, I’m just his body double.” He paused, his brain catching up with his words. “Also, uh, I’m Pallardo. Forget what I just said.”

 

“Does it even matter who he is?” Catherine asked, bewildered by the exchange while Shez’s eyes narrowed in suspicion at the increasingly sweaty Flame Emperor.

 

“It might. Hey, Metodey! How’s the arm?”

 

The so-called Flame Emperor, who had been staring straight at the Eisner sisters while unconsciously clutching his previously dislocated arm, stiffened…then promptly bolted in the opposite direction, sprinting away from those devil sisters as quickly as he could.

 

Everyone couldn't help but stare in confusion, before a blast of dark magic hit the stunned enemies, sending bandits flying. 

 

“Don't let him get away!” Lysithea shouted, getting everyone to move, rushing the bandits who scrambled to defend themselves. 

 

Drawing his bow, a bandit archer aimed at Shez, ready to fire before suddenly feeling his face crumbling under the force of Rhea’s fist as the archbishop raged against those who attempted to take her home. 

 

“Shit!” ‘Pallardo’ shouted, before turning around to run after the ‘Flame Emperor’. 

 

Byleth and Shez glanced at one another, before nodding as they immediately took off, chasing down the two who ran. Byleth had to admit, it was almost impressive how quickly the bandit was able to run wearing all that armor. 

 

“Gotta say, I’m almost impressed that dick is still alive,” Shez remarked, feeling a lot more casual now that she knew the Flame Emperor was just an asshole instead of someone important, “Kinda surprised he was scary enough to be one of the big three threats the Alliance was worried about though.”

 

“Anyone can be dangerous under the right circumstances,” Byleth reminded.

 

“Oh sure, but it felt like the big bad Flame Emperor would be somebody more important, you know? Like…oh, like my evil twin!”

 

“...” Byleth frowned. “Didn’t you suggest that before? Back when Bias abducted you?”

 

“Did I? Uh…oh yeah, I thought he might be my evil brother! And I’m absolutely not wrong that it would’ve been cool if he was!”

 

“It would have been awkward. I don't think Fodlan could handle two of you.” 

 

“Ha! We could probably win the war on our own.” Shez laughed, turning the corner as they continued their chase, entering the Monastery proper as the pair of bandits kept fleeing further.

 

“Partner, where are you?” Though she did stumble for a moment as Arval suddenly appeared next to her. 

 

“Woah, give a warning next time will you?” 

 

“I'm giving a warning now! Something feels wrong here,” Arval warned as the sisters burst into the dining hall, right in time to see ‘Pallardo’ and the ‘Flame Emperor’ practically collapse at the feet of a cloaked man. An Agarthan, based on the black clothes and bird mask. 

 

“B-Boss! Please, help me! Those devil sisters are here!” Metodey frantically begged.

 

“This was supposed to be an easy job!” ‘Pallardo’ complained, “Weren’t we just supposed to be your doubles!? I was told nothing about having to deal with Pallardo's killer!” 

 

“...Yeah, this looks completely dangerous, buddy,” Shez muttered, glancing at the Agarthan, who seemed busy reading a journal of some kind. 

 

“Hm? Seriously, we haven't even been here for a week and you already let someone break through? Jeez, I know you're hired help, but I thought you'd at least be more useful than this,” the masculine-sounding Agarthan complained, his voice audibly annoyed. 

 

“That's on you for hiring those two of all people,” Shez remarked, forming her sword and leveling at him as the pair of bandits scrambled to hide behind their apparent leader.

 

“I would suggest cutting him down now,” Arval suggested, their hackles clearly raised.

 

“Hm? Now now, no need to be all violent, I was actually hoping to get to talk to you. After all it's not everyday you meet the legendary Ashen Dragon and Violet Demon,” the Agarthan remarked, before raising the journal, getting Byleth to stiffen, “Thanks for leaving your journal behind, by the way! It was fun reading about–” 

 

Feeling the flow of time come to a halt at her command, Byleth rushed forward, her hand outstretched to grab her journal–

 

Feeling her hand grab air, she had a moment to blink, before a foot was driven into her side. Grunting as she was tossed back, time started again while the Agarthan let out an amused whistle. 

 

“Woah, I was told about the time reversal, but not that.” Standing up, the Agarthan set the journal down. “Gotta say, that was more exciting than I thought it'd be.” 

 

“...Who are you?” Byleth questioned, leveling her sword at him, as Shez gave her sister a concerned glance. Nobody should’ve been able to counter Byleth when she was using her time powers.

 

“Me? Well, I don't have a proper name, but you could call me by my project title: The New Liberator,” he said, before pulling down his hood and taking off his mask, making the sisters stiffen. 

 

A familiar smile greeted the two, along with a shock of messy purple hair covering one eye. The young man beneath the hood regarded the pair with casual amusement, before turning his visible eye towards Shez, its iris a divine shade of pale green. 

 

“Though, you could always call me Shez, sister.” 

Chapter End Notes

Indi: I wonder if anyone guessed we would actually do evil Shez twin when Shez joked about it.

Red: On the one hand, we have been making twin jokes for a while with Shez. On the other, I fully expect this to baffle at least a few of our readers.

Indi: Probably, but hopefully y'all enjoyed this surprise!

Red: We certainly had fun coming up with it!

Indi: That we did! And hope yall will stick with us to see what else we come up with!

Red: As always, thank you for reading!

A Surprising Reunion

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Byleth and Shez could only stare in shocked silence at the man standing before them, claiming to be Shez’s brother. The man in question smiled back at them, before his face slowly turned red. 

 

“Wait, no, don't call me that, that's embarrassing,” he said, cutting through the tension as he covered his face, looking away from the two. “Ah, give me a second, please, I need to come up with something better…”

 

Byleth stared at the embarrassed Agarthan for a moment, then looked at her sister with open bafflement. “You really do have an evil twin…”

 

“...why’d you say that after he made himself look like a complete dork?” Shez questioned, staring at Byleth, who casually averted her eyes. “Don’t look away.”

 

Byleth ignored her though, focusing on Evil-Shez. “Who are you, really?”

 

“Huh?” He turned back to her, his eyebrow raised. “I just said who I am. I mean, obviously I can’t also go by Shez, that would just get confusing, but I didn’t really think of my own name before now. Papa Myson usually just called me subject…uh…subject…I know it was a number, but maybe it was a name? Like…Sigma? Though that feels kinda lame for a name, right?

 

He held his chin with his hand, thinking. “...maybe Shax? What do you think about Shax?”

 

“So you’re just a knock-off me then,” Shez commented, frowning, “I guess that works then.”

 

“...well now I don’t want to call myself that, jerk.”

 

Byleth stared. “Two of them…”

 

“Can you two please stop joking and deal with him!” Arval shouted. 

 

“Aw, come on Arval, as a fellow Agarthan shouldn't you be on my side?” Shax complained, making the spirit stiffen.

 

“You can hear me?!”

 

“He can hear you??” Shez echoed.

 

“Am I the only one who can’t hear Arval?” Byleth asked, feeling oddly left out.

 

“Aw, no need to be sad, little sister,” Shax mockingly consoled, “You’re not missing anything worthwhile.”

 

“…when were you born?”

 

“Physically? I suppose my creation process only really started three years ago, but I did have an accelerated growth cycle.”

 

“Wait, what? So you’re like a baby?!” Shez exclaimed, earning an abrupt laugh from Shax.

 

“Ha! Nah, nope, no I am most definitely not. Full maturity here, sis, just on an accelerated timetable. And besides, if we factor in the other half of my creation, then I’ve got a good thousand years on both of you.”

 

“…uh…what? You’re an old man?”

 

“All little kids think they’re more mature than they are,” Byleth remarked, earning a side-eye from Shez.

 

“That felt pointed.”

 

“Not towards you.”

 

Shax chuckled. “Ah, so this is what having siblings is like. Fun, but also kind of annoying…but going back to your stupid question, while I might’ve been made not that long ago, the half of me that shares blood with Byleth there was born, lived, and died before this shitty church was even a thing.” 

 

“...Do you mean Nemesis?” 

 

“That I do! It seems mixing the blood is why I look like this, rather than a full clone of Shez here.” With a grin, he opened his cloak, before pulling out a sword he had at his side. 

 

Byleth felt her breath stop when she saw the black blade he pulled free, its familiar design sending a shudder through her body. The sword in his hands was not the Sword of the Creator, she knew that much, but it still made her take a step back. 

 

The “bone” it was made of was too dark, nearly fully black, and while the general shape was the same, the two crest stones set in the center of the false sword bore the crests of Timotheos and Noa. It felt…wrong. Disturbingly wrong.

 

“It's also why I can use this! Shame you seem to be missing yours,” Shax remarked, before swinging his sword, the blade extending just like the original to reach the sisters. Bringing their own swords up, the pair blocked the whip-like attack. Or at least tried to.

 

Moving back, Byleth felt a frown on her face at the sight of her sword split in half. “Should have gotten a silver sword.” 

 

“Here!” Shez called out, tossing Byleth her red sword before warping behind Shax, who ducked her swing and kicked Shez in the abdomen, sending her flying back.

 

“Nice trick! Let’s see if I can copy it!” the clone taunted, before flashing over to Byleth and bringing down the dark sword in a heavy overhand swing, nearly sending Byleth to her knees when she blocked it.

 

Placing her palm against the flat side of her sword, Byleth pushed to the side, getting Shax off of her. Shifting the blade, Byleth stabbed at his side, hitting air when he flashed away.

 

“Ha! Good luck hitting–” Letting out a yelp as he ducked, Shax lost a few hairs off the top of his head after Byleth flung her sword at him. Appearing behind him, Shez caught the tossed blade, before bringing both her swords down on him. Falling to his knee as he blocked the strike, Shax smirked up at her. 

 

“Had a feeling this wouldn't be easy. Oh well!” Shax abruptly grabbed Shez’s wrist, giving her only a moment to blink as Dark Spikes formed around them, about to crash down–

 

Shax paused as he found himself suddenly returned to his previous position, right before he felt an abrupt heat at his side. He braced himself, but the fireball’s explosion still sent him flying across the room before he managed to arrest his flight by stabbing his sword into the floor.

 

Immediately, his eyes went to Byleth as a smirk crept up his face. “Wow, Miss Bias was right, that time reversal isn't fair at all! Couldn't you have waited a few more seconds, huh?” 

 

“I’m not taking requests from you.” 

 

“Well, if you're going to be rude.” Standing up, an orange glow surrounded him as familiar markings appeared on his face. “Guess I don't need to hold back.” 

 

“Seriously, do you not have anything original??” Shez complained, glowering at her copy.

 

“Aw, you’re hurting my feelings here, sister! I can’t help it if I’m similar to my twin!” He grinned, his eyes flicking between the two of them before he paused and tilted his head. “Ah…hm, I might need to cut this short. As fun as it would be to try testing myself with the rest of your forces, I can’t say I’m willing to fight a battle I know I’m going to lose. And I can’t see myself taking out that alabaster abomination if I’m having trouble with you two.”

 

“You mean Rhea?” Byleth questioned, keeping an eye on the Agarthan and taking some mental notes of his appearance. His ‘awakened form’ looked similar to Shez’s, but there were slight differences in the markings and his eyes were more red than orange.

 

“That’s the bitch!” Shax agreed, still grinning, “She feels like somebody I’ll have to work my way up to, not the first beast on kill list. Though, if I get the chance…ah, I’ll figure that out later. For now though…” 

 

Looking around, Shax spotted the two cowering bandits hiding behind the kitchen counter. With a flash, he appeared next to the two with a bright smile. 

 

“T-Time to go, Boss?” ‘Pallardo’ asked, looking hopefully up at his employer. 

 

“That it is.” 

 

“Oh thank the goddess, finally my luck turns around! Now let's get–” Whatever the ‘Flame Emperor’ was about to say was cut off as Shax grabbed the pair by their faces, the Flame Emperor's mask cracking from the force of his grip. His smile remained fixed in place as a surge of magic went through his arms and burst his sleeves apart, pure darkness flowing through his body and pushing right into his unfortunate victims.

 

“Make sure to buy me some time,” Shax requested as the two began to let out muffled screams. 

 

Byleth and Shez watched on in horror as they heard bones begin to shift and snap, a black mass covering the two bandits before they began to grow, their clothes tearing under the stress of their sudden growth. A crash was heard as the two demonic beasts destroyed the kitchen they were once standing in, before the pair of monstrosities roared, their enormous maws opening to show sharpened teeth. 

 

“...What did you just do?” Byleth wondered, staring at the forced transformation with a sense of creeping dread.

 

“How the hell…?” Shez murmured, torn between staring at the monsters and her distorted double.

 

“Just a bit of insurance we gave them beforehand. Consider it a severance package for their lackluster performance,” Shax explained, before giving them a quick two finger salute, the veins of his arms pulsing black, “See you two later!” 

 

With that, he vanished in a burst of darkness, leaving the sisters to deal with the pair of black and crimson demonic beasts that were tearing their way out of the dining hall’s ruins.

 

“...Guess we're not having a victory feast,” Byleth muttered, before casting an Aura on one of the demonic beasts, the holy rings trapping it as it screamed in pain. 

 

Not saying anything, Shez rushed out, chasing after the other demonic beast to cut it down before it could get away. She really hoped they wouldn't get blamed for all the destruction it was causing as it scrambled away, crashing into the fishing hut next to the pond. At least most of the monastery had already been destroyed before they showed up.

 

“Alright, enough of that,” Shez huffed, flashing above it, and using her awakened form to give her a boost to cut through its neck. Grunting as her sword got jammed, she put her weight behind it, pushing through its neck as it screamed. “Egh…” 

 

“Shez?! Where did the demonic beast come from?!” came a sudden exclamation that drew Shez’s attention towards Lysithea’s rapid approach, along with a number of knights following her.

 

“Ah, long story, real quick, mind helping?” Shez requested. She might’ve gotten better at killing monsters over the course of her years alone, but demonic beasts were pretty durable and even this new creature was–And then she actually pierced through something important and the whole thing abruptly dropped, crashing to the ground as its tongue lolled out of its mouth. “Oh. Huh, guess they aren’t as durable…”
