She hopped down from the slain beast, then took a second to make sure Byleth was handling her own monster well enough. Her magic seemed to be holding it in place well enough, and soon Catherine and Shamir joined in to slice it up and fill it full of arrows, respectively.

 

“Alright, now that that’s handled, uh…” Shez glanced back at Lysithea, trying to think of how to phrase things, “I guess, um…to make a long story short, I have an evil twin.” 

 

Lysithea blinked. She glanced over at the ruined dining hall, where Byleth was explaining what happened to an irate Catherine, then frowned at Shez. “Shez, I realize you have a rivalry with Byleth, but calling her evil is uncalled for.”

 

“What? No, not her! Obviously not Byleth, we’re not even twins–Oh, wait, I guess I did say that for a while…well, anyway, she wouldn’t be the evil one even if we were, obviously that would be me.”

 

That earned a small frown. “Shez–”

 

“ Anyway , that's not important right now! I have an actual evil twin! Who’s a guy for some reason!” 

 

“...What?” 

 

“I have an evil twin who’s a guy for some reason,” Shez repeated, “I’m not sure how else to explain it. Well, I guess there is the thing where he’s apparently related to Byleth too because his blood was mixed with Nemesis’s, which I really don’t understand how that could’ve happened considering–”

 

Lysithea held up a hand. “Shez, slow down. You’re starting to ramble. Why don’t you take a moment to collect your thoughts, and then we can report what happened to Lady Rhea and–“

 

“WHAT HAPPENED TO THE DINING HALL?!” the Archbishop in question shrieked, looking understandably upset with the complete destruction of a part of the monastery. Granted, most of the monastery was fairly ruined from the attack three years prior, but at least most of the buildings were actually intact. Or, well, they had been.

 

“…or she’ll just wander over on her own,” Lysithea mumbled, a little put out..

 

Meanwhile, Byleth decided she should be the one to answer Rhea’s enraged question. “Shez has an evil twin who is male for some reason and he turned the fake Flame Emperor and his second-in-command into demonic beasts.”

 

Rhea paused, her anger turning to confusion as she turned to Byleth, then looked at Shez, before looking back at Byleth in obvious bafflement. “What.”

 

The sisters glanced at each other. “Do you want to explain or should I?”

 

“Eh, I got this,” Shez assured her sister, before turning to Rhea, “Okay, so, it turns out the Flame Emperor here was actually this guy who I thought I killed called Metodey–“

Byleth felt a small frown come to her face as she gazed upon the ruins of her bedroom. She’d always thought her bedroom at the monastery would be temporary, considering her plans to leave Garreg Mach at the end of the year, but it still felt bad seeing it smashed apart and crumbling. Bias’s meteor shower really had destroyed a lot of the monastery, and years of neglect hadn’t helped things.

 

She let out a small sigh, before heading towards Shez’s room. Luckily for her sister, Shez’s bedroom had managed to avoid the rocks and flames that ruined most of the other dorms. In fact, it was probably the most intact place Byleth had seen so far.

 

“Wow, I completely forgot I borrowed this book from the library,” Shez said as she skimmed through the book in her hands, glancing over at Byleth as she entered, “Hey By, do you think that Bias bitch will try to go after me for having an overdue book? She was the librarian and all.”

 

“Yeah, probably,” Byleth replied, shrugging, “I have to imagine it’s the whole reason she hates us to begin with.”

 

Lysithea rolled her eyes, giving Byleth an unimpressed look from where she was sitting on the bed. “Could you two please not joke about the mad sorceress with a vendetta against you?”

 

“Okay, sure. We can talk about how Shez decided to bring you to her bedroom instead.”

 

“Wh–I was just–I-I’m helping her search her room!”

 

Shez snorted, grinning. “Yeah you’re being really helpful Lys. Doing the proper noble thing of supervising while I do the work, huh?”

 

Lysithea’s face reddened, before she pushed herself up. “You were the one who said I could sit!”

 

“Pff–I know, I know, I’m just teasing! Heh, sorry about that,” Shez said, stifling her laughter, before she paused, “Wait, I need to check something.” 

 

Getting on her knees, Shez reached under her bed, searching for something. 

 

“What exactly are you doing?” Lysithea asked

 

“Searching for my box,” Shez replied, tossing bits of rubble and clothing out from under the bed, before she smiled, “Aha!” 

 

Pulling her arm out, Shez held a box that seemed pretty dusty, but otherwise undamaged. Wiping the dust off as she stood up, Shez placed the box on her bed. 

 

“...Why exactly were you hiding this under your bed?”

 

“Eh, no reason. Just felt like putting the junk there.” With that, Shez opened the box, displaying several random objects that were stuffed inside. 

 

Byleth peered at the box’s content curiously, wondering when her sister had turned into such a hoarder, before she paused when Lysithea made a surprised noise. 

 

“W-Where did you get that doll?!” the former noble squeaked, surprised and embarrassed to see a very familiar princess doll amidst Shez’s bizarre collection.

 

“Hm? Oh, I found it. Uh…I think it was in the reception hall or something?” Shez shrugged. “Why, you like it?”

 

“That–No–Well, yes, I do–Th-That’s not the issue here! The issue is that it’s my doll!”

 

“You own dolls?” Shez asked, getting Lysithea to blush. 

 

“Shut up!” 

 

“It's a nice looking doll,” Byleth said, trying to help. 

 

“Th-That's not the issue here!” Lysithea responded, looking back at the box, before grabbing a small book about sweets. “Wait, this is mine as well!” 

 

“...” Byleth peered into the box as well, “...Shez, why do you have things belonging to my students as well? Actually, I think there are things belonging to everyone from the academy here. Students and faculty.” 

 

“Really? Huh.” Shez shrugged. “Well they’re mine now.”

 

“...Shez, how did you get these?”

 

“Found them,” Shez answered, before thinking about it, “I think it started with a hairclip I found. It looked nice, and I didn't know who it belonged to, so I kept it. Afterwards, I just started keeping whatever I found.” 

 

“And you kept them in a box under your bed instead of looking for their owners.”

 

“Well yeah. Finders keepers.”

 

Byleth gave her sister a blank stare. “Shez, we’re returning these.”

 

“Aw, what? Why?”

 

“Aside from the fact that these don’t belong to you, you’re not even using them for anything. You’re just collecting things for no reason.”

 

“That's not true, I use some of the stuff!” Reaching into the box, she pulled out a foldable razor, “Like this!” 

 

“That's Hubert’s.” Only to immediately drop it when Byleth guessed who it belonged to. 

 

“...I'm not cursed because I used that, right?” 

 

“You probably are.” 

 

“Don’t tell her that,” Lysithea chided.

 

“She has to learn,” Byleth replied, before starting to look through the box’s contents again, “Hm…well, at least you kept everything in one convenient place. It will make it easier to return everything to their real owners.”

 

“...Can I keep anything that doesn't belong to anyone or they don't want?” Shez asked as Byleth began to move things around in the box, trying to make it neat. 

 

“Sure,” Byleth responded, “It's a good thing most of the Golden Deer are here, it'll make it quick to return some of these things.” 

 

Shez couldn't help but pout as Byleth picked the box up, and walked out of the room, handing something to Lysithea as she did. “Oh, is that perfume yours?” 

 

“A-And what if it is, is that a problem?” 

 

“Oh no, of course not. I used it a bit myself and liked it, so you have good taste.” 

 

“H-Hmph, of course I do!” Lysithea retorted as she turned away from Shez, her cheeks turning pink as she tried to subtly spray herself with the perfume. 

 

And so the Eisner sisters, plus Lysithea, began returning every lost item Shez had collected to their owners. A task that earned some grumbling from Shez, but also one that Byleth seemed to take to with a surprising degree of enthusiasm.

 

Though maybe not that surprising, now that Shez really thought about it. Byleth was always pretty task-oriented and liked making people happy, so a simple job like giving Raphael his sack of rocks back would be the kind of thing she liked.

 

“Why would you even bother keeping a burlap sack filled with rocks?” Lysithea questioned, raising an eyebrow at Shez while the mercenary watched her sister give away her stuff.

 

“Eh…I probably had a reason when I found it,” Shez replied, tilting her head in thought, “…maybe I thought it was for decoration?”

 

“…you think a burlap sack filled with rocks is a decoration?”

 

“Hey, I don’t know what nobles are into. Or most commoners, apparently, since it was Raphael’s.” Shez paused. “Oh, maybe I thought it would be good ammo? Maybe for throwing at people?”

 

“It would be better to buy a sling to use for the rocks than throw the rocks by hand,” Byleth pointed out as she returned to them, “Also you’ve never trained with a sling before, so you would probably–Hm. Wyvern.”

 

Shez blinked, then followed her sister’s gaze up towards the sky where there was indeed a wyvern flying in. “...is that one of ours?”

 

“I don’t think…no, hold on. It has yellow on its reins and saddle.”

 

“An Alliance wyvern?” Lysithea wondered, furrowing her brows in thought as the wyvern approached…before she let out an annoyed sigh when she spotted the shock of orange hair the woman on the wyvern’s back had. “Of course it’s Kronya…”

 

“Eh? It is?” It took Shez a second to make the same connection, but the instant she did she smiled brightly and started heading right over, “Hey, Kronya! Ha, so now you show up! You completely missed the battle!”

 

“Ah, Shez, my beloved! I have arrived for thee!” Kronya responded in a remarkably similar sounding tone of voice to a certain purple-haired noble. The Agarthan also happened to look a lot more “noble” than she did before, now wearing black and gold armor that looked similar to Claude’s, if modified to fit her better, and apparently having actually combed her hair for once in her life. 

 

She hopped off the wyvern without any issue and strode over to Shez with a bright grin. “So hey, how was that? Did I sound like one of those fancy nobles or what?”

 

“Uh, I guess? I don’t think nobles say ‘thee’ though,” Shez replied, glancing at Lysithea for confirmation.

 

“No, we don’t use ‘thee’ in common conversation,” Lysithea explained with a sigh, “That’s an archaic vernacular.”

 

“I’m Agarthan, I’m better at ‘archaic vernacula’ than you’ll ever be,” Kronya retorted, before turning her attention back to Shez, “Also, it’s not my fault I missed the battle, I needed to get my fancy outfit ready! Apparently that’s a very important part of being a noble!”

 

“It really isn't,” Lysithea grumbled. 

 

“Well how would you know?” 

 

“Because I was a noble as well!” 

 

“Former noble. I'm the noble now,” Kronya pointed, smirking at Lysithea. 

 

“...” Lysithea’s eye began to twitch as magic began to condense in her hand. 

 

“Woah, woah! Come on now, no need to fight!” Shez said, getting in between the two. “Come on Kronya, we have to fill you in on what you missed.” 

 

“Is it really that important?” 

 

“Shez has an evil twin,” Byleth said. “Specifically a brother.”

 

“...Huh…is he hot?” 

 

“Why is that your first question?!” Lysithea asked, practically shouting. 

 

“Because it's important, duh,” Kronya responded, making Lysithea’s eye twitch again. 

 

Deciding it would be best not to get caught in the crossfire, Byleth walked away, looking for a place to store the box since she had finished returning everything to the Deer scattered around the monastery. She could always put it in her room, but a part of her felt like Shez might wind up “collecting” it again if she didn’t do something to hide–

 

Then she paused when the sound of movement caught her attention. It was distant, but her now pointed ears were slightly more sensitive than they had been before, and she already had good hearing back then, so the sound of footsteps against stone immediately drew her attention towards a large pile of rubble along one wall.

 

Her eyes narrowed as she inclined her head, focusing on the sound. From the noise…there were likely two people, one with heavier steps than the other. Neither were making an effort to disguise their footsteps, so it was possible they weren’t dangerous…but it was equally possible that they just didn’t know they should be quiet.

 

“...don’t know why you want to head up here now,” one of the voices muttered as they reached the entrance the rubble was covering, “I thought you said there were too many bandits up here to deal with?”

 

“Yes, there were ,” the other voice countered. Something about his amused tone sounded strangely familiar… “Remember that friend of mine I had planted near the oh so threatening ‘Flame Emperor’?”

 

“Yes, the one you insist isn’t actually the real Flame Emperor. What point are you trying to make?”

 

“Well he scrambled back down here, saying they’d just been cleared out by an unexpected army coming up the mountain. One that I think we should introduce ourselves too.” 

 

“Hold on, who exactly–” Before the strangely familiar voice could finish his sentence, a hand pushed one rock out of the pile of rubble, causing the rest of the rocks to collapse down and fully expose the entrance.

 

Byleth tensed, her hand beginning to gather magic before her eyes went wide in genuine surprise. “Dimitri? Yuri?”

 

The prince of Faerghus gaped, staring back at the professor with equally wide eyes. “...Professor Byleth?! You’re alive??”

 

“Seems so,” Yuri remarked, openly amused as the pair stared at one another, “Hello again, friend. Long time, no see.”

 

“...oh.” Byleth reached into the box she held and picked out a training logbook, before holding it out to Dimitri. “I think this is yours.”

 

“Ah…thank you, professor.” Dimitri took the logbook. “...professor, why do you have this?”

 

“Shez found it years ago and never gave it back.”

 

“Oh. I see. Is…there a reason why she did that?”

 

“She just keeps things that she finds, apparently. I also found these leather gloves that I think might be yours, and Yuri, I believe this makeup brush and these weighted dice are yours.”

 

“Why would she keep my gloves…” Dimitri murmured while Yuri let out an amused huff.

 

“Is there a reason why you think these are mine, professor?”

 

“Yes. They’re obviously yours,” Byleth bluntly replied.

 

“...well, I guess I can’t argue with that. But more importantly, Dimitri, don’t you think you should talk to the professor about our needs?”

 

“Hm? Oh! Right, yes, professor! We of the Kingdom need your help–”

 

Byleth held up a hand, forestalling Dimitri’s request. “I’m going to the Empire next. I can help the Kingdom afterwards.”

 

“Uh…excuse me?” 

 

“As it stands, taking back the Empire is the next logical step for our forces. Aside from being plentiful in resources to help supply the army, the Empire has a larger standing military force that will be able to better aid us in taking back the Kingdom. Not to mention that, since we have taken back Myrddyn Bridge and Garreg Mach, we're in a tactical position to close in on the former Duke Aegir’s position,” Byleth said, being straight and concise in her explanation that she had practiced. 

 

“I…see,” Dimitri replied, frowning for a moment when he thought of something, “...Professor, does this have anything to do with Edelgard in specific?” 

 

“...Obviously, I can still lend your forces anyone willing to help you out,” Byleth continued, fully ignoring that question, “Maybe some of the Alliance soldiers would be willing to help? The Church might help too, but I don’t know what Rhea’s current plans are.”

 

“Then maybe we should ask her first?” Yuri suggested, “And we could also explain what we actually need help with so we don’t get told ‘no’ immediately.”

 

“...right. It would be good to know what you actually need help with.” She nodded to that, before turning around and heading off, the chest of lost items still in her hands.

 

“...” Dimitri glanced at Yuri. “Do you know where she’s going?”

 

“Why in the world would I know that?”

 

“...should we follow her?”

 

“You’re the king, remember?”

 

“You know I’m not officially crowned yet.”

 

“We could get Rhea to do that.”

 

“...We should follow her.”

 

And so they did.

Chapter End Notes

Red: I always like to read the comments we get, and it was fun to see some people last time around asking questions like "Hey, why are you introducing another antagonist now? Don't we already have enough villains?" And the answer to that is, put simply, I like villains and I cannot be stopped.

Indi: Also while we do have villains, let's be real, do any of them seem like final boss material? Myson is fun and all, but he doesn't even have a character portrait

Red: You need a character portrait to be a proper major villain, it's the rules. And Male!Shez has a character portrait!

Indi: That he does! As for what he'll do, well you'll have to stick around and see!

Red: That you will! Oh also Dimitri's here again. Weird.

Indi: That he is! Wonder how that will effect things. Ah well, for now I hope you all enjoyed, and make sure to keep an eye out on valentine's day, we might have something special dropping then!

Revelation, Reinterpretation, Reclamation

Chapter by RK3996

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

“So, hang on, the Lions have been living under Garreg Mach in the Abyss this whole time?” Shez questioned, staring in some understandable confusion as Dimitri and Yuri talked with Rhea and Catherine, the two sides bringing each other up to speed on everything that happened.

 

“Apparently? I don’t know why you’re asking me like you think I’ll have an answer,” Lysithea replied, just as baffled.

 

“Huh. You’d think they’d be busy trying to kill Dimitri’s evil uncle.”

 

“They can always plot to commit murder and seize vengeance while living underground,” Kronya pointed out, “It’s a proud tradition in Agartha.”

 

“I don’t think a tradition like that could be called ‘proud’,” Lysithea remarked while Shez tilted her head in thought.

 

“Huh…I think I might need to check mom’s notes again. Faerghus has a couple Shambhalas in it, right?”

 

“As far as I know, there’s only one Shambhala,” Kronya replied, “If you mean that there are other Agarthan outposts in Faerghus, then yes, there should be.”

 

“Good to know,” Shez murmured, waiting for a good point in the current conversation to butt in. And once she was pretty sure she spotted one, she promptly interrupted. “So hey, Dimitri, long time, no see! Quick question before we start catching up on what we’ve been up to, were you or the other Lions wandering around Faerghus for some reason a year or so back?”

 

“Seriously?” Catherine asked, giving Shez an annoyed look, “He was just talking about–”

 

“No, it’s fine, Catherine, I don’t mind explaining,” Dimitri said before he turned to Shez with a weary smile, “We haven’t been ‘wandering’, exactly, though we have been trying our best to resist my uncle’s tyranny. While Abyss has become something of a headquarters for our resistance, we have been trying our best to save people from those so-called Tempest Knights whenever we are able. As it is, making the Abyss our base had some unseen advantages as the series of tunnels beneath the monastery stretched out far beyond what we expected.”

 

“While we can't say for sure how far or how many there are, we've found several that seem to open out in different territories in the Kingdom, as well as some into Alliance and Imperial territory. Though we try to use them sparingly so they don't get discovered,” Yuri added in. 

 

“Yes, I recall there being information about such tunnels in the church’s archives,” Rhea spoke up, looking thoughtful, “If necessary, I believe there is even one leading directly to the Imperial capital, though unfortunately there isn’t one that leads to Fhirdiad.”

 

“Oh, that makes sense. The first emperor was your boyfriend, right Rhea?” Shez asked, not noticing the alarmed look she received, “Meanwhile that Blaiddyd guy was just a random noble before Loog turned traitor and crowned himself king, so it’s not like you’d put a tunnel to his house.”

 

“I wouldn’t say Loog ‘turned traitor’,” Dimitri argued, frowning.

 

“...that’s the part you paid attention to, huh?” Yuri remarked, getting the prince to pause.

 

“I never know what information you’ll suddenly be aware of,” Lysithea commented, giving Shez an exasperated look.

 

“Hey, I retain plenty of the things I learn,” Shez countered, “I just don’t have a use for them most of the time.”

 

“Rhea likes men?” Kronya, meanwhile, clearly had focused on the most important part of that conversation. “I thought she and the blonde there had a thing going on.”

 

“She can like both,” Shez assured, “Also, Catherine wishes they did.” 

 

“Would you shut up?!” Catherine demanded, glaring at Shez, who stuck her tongue out at her, “Gh–Oh that’s real mature!”

 

“More mature than you.”

 

“You’re really not,” Lysithea muttered.

 

“Can we please return to the subject at hand?” Rhea requested, feeling a headache coming along, “Dimitri, where exactly is the rest of your class?” 

 

“They should be arriving soon enough, I just came ahead with Yuri to get an idea of what was occurring up here,” Dimitri said, before pausing, “Ah, Shez…you might want to inform the professor that she should avoid Mercedes.” 

 

“What, did she fall in love with her too?” Shez asked, an eyebrow raised.

 

“...not exactly? It’s more…she believes your sister is a vessel of the goddess.”

 

“Uh…what’s the problem with that?”

 

“...She believes your sister is a vessel of the goddess.”

 

“Yeah, I got that part. I don’t get why that’s a bad thing since she's completely right about that. I mean, Byleth isn’t just a vessel, like how I’m not just a vessel for Epi, but that doesn’t really change the fact that Rhea made her one.”

 

The sound of Rhea’s hands meeting her own face echoed loudly in the ensuing silence.

 

After a second, Shez seemed to realize something. “Oh, wait, do you guys not know that part? Man, it’s getting tricky trying to keep track of who knows what…”

 

“Shez, please just assume no one knows the very secret things you continue to mention without thinking,” Rhea requested through gritted teeth, her voice muffled by her hands.

 

“But a lot of people do know though? Lysithea, none of this is new info for you, right?”

 

“...Shez, all of that information is new to me,” Lysithea replied, staring at Shez in complete confusion.

 

“Wait, really? I could’ve sworn…” Shez frowned to herself, thinking back to her previous conversations with the former noble. “...huh. Hm. Yeah I might’ve just screwed up.”

 

“I already knew all of that,” Kronya lied, her arms crossed over her chest as she regarded her lessers with a superior smirk.

 

“Ignore her,” Shez requested, “Actually, ignore everything I said for the past minute. Just forget I said anything.” She glanced around, trying to think of a distraction, especially since Rhea was still glaring at her. “So, hey, where’d Byleth go?”

 

“Down to Abyss,” Yuri answered, partially distracted by the implications of the new information he’d just received, “She wanted to check on the other Lions when they arrived.”

 

“Huh. And Mercedes is with the Lions, right?” 

 

“...Forgive me, Lady Rhea but I think we may need to take a small break,” Dimitri said, quickly moving to leave the office. 

 

“Hey, wait, Dimitri! Come back here! Don’t just run off!” Catherine shouted, following after the prince. 

 

“It can't be that bad, right?” Shez asked, deciding to follow along, “I mean, Byleth can probably handle it.” 

Byleth had often heard rather gruff mercenaries and the occasional crude knight say something along the lines of wanting a woman on their knees in front of them. She had wondered what they meant and why they seemed to be positively inclined to the idea. 

 

She honestly had no idea how it was supposed to be pleasant at all because seeing Mercedes drop down to her knees and begin praying towards her actually made her feel very uncomfortable. 

 

“...” She looked over at Annette, who had let out a small, exasperated sigh at the sight of her friend abruptly kneeling. “Is this…normal?”

 

“No–Well…yes? Now it is, I guess, but it’s been a while since she just stopped to pray out of nowhere–” She paused, abruptly registering Byleth’s presence. “Oh. Um. Huh. Hi, professor?”

 

“Hello.”

 

“Right, yeah, hi. Again. Uh.” Annette stared at Byleth, her usually quick mind working much slower than usual as she stared at the green-haired professor, who used to have blue hair, and who had been missing for years now– “PROFESSOR BYLETH!? Wha–How–Why–N-No, no how! How are you here!??”

 

“The Goddess Incarnate is capable of many miracles, Annie,” Mercedes stated, not moving from her praying position.

 

“Woah, what’s with all the shouting–” Sylvain asked as he walked over, the small frown on his face dropping along with his jaw once he caught sight of Byleth. “Holy…”

 

“Yes, very holy,” Mercedes agreed.

 

“Sylvain? Did something hap–...” Ingrid arrived about a second later and went about as still as her childhood friend, her eyes wide as she–

 

“Oh, Ingrid, I think this is yours,” Byleth spoke up, handing her a curry comb from her box of stuff, “There’s also a jousting almanac and some horseshoes that I think are meant to be used for pegasi in here. One moment.”

 

“...u-uh…thank you…professor?” 

 

“You’re welcome. Could any of you explain why Mercedes is praying to me? I find it uncomfortable.”

 

Sylvain couldn’t help himself. “What, you don’t like seeing a cute girl on her knees in front of you? I know I’d enjoy a sight like that.”

 

“Hm. Sylvain, this lipstick and this crumpled love letter are yours. I think this book about Sreng might also be yours, though I would like to borrow it, if I could. I like history books,” Byleth explained quite calmly, “Also, my respect for you has dropped immensely. Do better.”

 

“Huh…gonna be honest I'm surprised you had any respect for me at all.” 

 

“Sylvain!” Ingrid shouted, knocked out of her stupor, before realizing who was there, “Wait, Professor, you're alive!?”

 

“Yes? Well, unless this is some weird afterlife anyways.” 

 

“Then where have you been?! You've been missing for three years!” 

 

“The void.” 

 

“...The void?” Sylvain asked. 

 

“A dark, desolate place in which nothing is alive and I found myself close to the brink of insanity several times,” Byleth casually explained. 

 

“Ah…oh, um…” Sylvain glanced at Ingrid and Annette, neither of whom were sure what to say to that, “...How are you alive?” 

 

“Hm. I don't want to get into the details. Long story short, the goddess gave me her powers.” 

 

That actually got Mercedes to stop praying, catching Byleth’s attention. She glanced down at the pious girl, who was staring at her fellow Lions with what looked like an uncharacteristically smug look on her face. “Isn’t that very interesting, everyone? The professor truly is an incarnation of the goddess. Oh, if only someone had mentioned such a thing all those years ago…”

 

“...is it weird that I find this side of her attractive?” Sylvain muttered, before tensing on reflex. When Ingrid didn’t elbow him, he gave her a concerned look. “Uh, Ingrid–”

 

Ingrid didn’t respond, instead promptly kneeling to Byleth. “P-Please forgive our families' trespasses, oh holy goddess! I swear, we had no idea we were wielding the bones of your children!”

 

“Sothis’s children,” Byleth corrected, “I haven’t given birth to anybody. I think I would have noticed if I did.” 

 

“S-Still, it is my duty to atone for my families’ sins!” Ingrid said, before glancing at Annette and Sylvain, grabbing their sleeves and yanking them down to kneel. 

 

“You really don’t need to do that–”

 

“Why are all of you kneeling on the floor?” Felix wondered as he turned the corner, staring at his friends and already looking like he wished he hadn’t asked that question. “Did the boar do something–Oh. Hey Professor. I thought you were dead.”

 

“Hey Felix,” Byleth greeted, unfazed. “No, I was just in the void.”

 

“...What?” 

 

“The professor has come to grace us once again, to not only pass her holy judgment upon us but to also save Fodlan from what it's become,” Mercedes stated, as if it was obvious. 

 

“Great, she's in one of these moods again,” Felix sighed, looking exhausted. 

 

“Hm.” Byleth glanced at the Lions, taking in how they all changed over the years, before setting her box down, and offering a hand to Mercedes. “There's no need to kneel to me.” 

 

“There is no need to show me mercy, Professor. I shall accept your judgment.” 

 

Grabbing Mercedes’s hand, Byleth pulled her up. “There is nothing for me to judge. You and your friends should not be judged for the sins of your ancestors. When this war is over, I believe Sothis would be happy to have the remains of her children buried, but if you truly wish to atone, all I ask is that you work alongside us until it is over.” 

 

“...Y-Yes. Yes, of course, professor,” Mercedes readily agreed, nodding her head as happy tears began to gather at her eyes. So it was only natural that Byleth gave her a hug, earning a slightly startled noise from the taller blonde. “O-Oh, um…thank you, professor.”

 

She returned the hug, smiling genuinely in her goddess’s embrace.

 

“...so are we allowed to stand up now?” Annette murmured, glancing at Ingrid and Sylvain.

 

“Uh…” Sylvain glanced at Byleth, who gave them a quick thumbs up before continuing to hug Mercedes. “Seems so.” 

 

“What is even going on…” Felix muttered, feeling his exhaustion rise. 

 

“Hm, you're really soft, Mercedes,” Byleth couldn't help but note once they finished hugging. 

 

“Oh, thank you, professor. Annie tends to say the same thing, actually.”

 

“Makes sense. I've seen you practice with a bow at times, but you've mainly kept to magic right?” 

 

“That I have. Magic does come easier to me than standard weaponry.” 

 

“I see. If you don't mind, would we be able to practice together later? I'm a bit rusty on my magic skills, so I would like to refine them.” 

 

“Of course!” Mercedes agreed, looking very eager to help. 

 

“...Don't tell me you're going to try and seduce Mercedes, Professor,” Sylvain said, trying to crack a joke. 

 

“Oh no, I don't mean to be rude, but I would hate to intrude upon you, Dorothea, and Edelgard, professor. Ah, speaking of, are they here as well?” Mercedes asked. 

 

“Unfortunately, no. I’m planning to meet up with them soon though. I want to head to the Empire next to fix things over there.”

 

“W-Wait, you’re not going to help us take back the Kingdom?” Annette asked, a worried frown coming to her face.

 

“Not yet. Empire first, then Kingdom. I already fixed the Alliance and the Church, so now we do the Empire.”

 

“Hm…I guess that makes sense, tactically,” Ingrid commented, also frowning but looking thoughtful, “Our enemies in the Kingdom are organized under Rufus and fortified in Fhirdiad, whereas Edelgard’s forces are dealing with a rebellion. If Aegir’s dealt with, that frees the Empire up to help us…though, I’m not sure we really want to put ourselves in Adrestia’s debt.”

 

Sylvain was looking thoughtful for a very different reason. “You just want to get together with your girlfriends, huh?”

 

“I would like to be cuddled, yes,” Byleth replied.

 

“Mercedes could provide that if you work for us,” Felix brought up, earning a scandalized noise from Annette.

 

“Felix! Don’t offer Mercie as payment!”

 

“Oh, I would gladly tend to your needs, professor,” Mercedes offered, turning Annette’s scandalized gaze towards her.

 

“M-Mercie! Don’t offer yourself as payment!”

 

“I’m sorry, but I’ll have to decline,” Byleth stated, “While the offer is tempting, I am no longer a mercenary and I don’t think it would be sufficient payment even if I was. Also, Mercedes, I’m fairly certain your brother is in the Empire right now.”

 

“Oh. Well, everyone, it seems I am going with Professor Byleth to the Empire–”

 

“MERCEDES!” Annette practically wailed, earning a small pout from Mercedes.

 

“It won’t be that long…and besides, you could come with me.” She paused, a thought occurring. “Oh, and Constance would likely be there too, that is an added incentive to visit.”

 

“I–You–Uh…hm.” Despite her instinctive reaction to refuse the idea of abandoning the Kingdom, even if it was just temporarily, Annette had to admit that she was tempted. “...maybe we should talk to Dimitri first?”

 

“You probably should,” Byleth agreed, “He should be talking with Rhea right now if you want to see him.”

 

“Lady Rhea is here too?!” Ingrid exclaimed.

 

“She’s still alive?” Felix asked, earning an immediate frown from Ingrid.

 

“Huh. Where was she these past few years?” Sylvain wondered.

 

“In the void with me,” Byleth readily answered, “She contributed to keeping me sane when she wasn’t driving me insane.”

 

“Wait, did she also receive the goddess’s power?” Sylvain asked. 

 

“Something similar. You should ask her if you want any details, though don’t expect much. Rhea likes to keep things secret.”

 

“Yeah, I did notice that…you know she tried to keep the Lance of Ruin way back when we took it from Miklan?”

 

“That does sound like her.”

 

“W-Well still, this power you got is really amazing, professor,” Annette said, speaking up, “I mean, you look almost exactly the same as when we last saw you.” 

 

“...Ah, right. That's part of the power,” Byleth said, nodding while feeling strangely grateful that her hair covered her now pointy ears. That would have been awkward to explain.

 

“What are you talking about?” Felix asked, an eyebrow raised, “She has two eyes again.”

 

“...I-I know that,” Annette mumbled, having actually forgotten that would be unusual.

 

“Oh yeah, that is weird,” Sylvain noted, “How’d that happen?”

 

“Clearly it is a divine miracle of the goddess,” Mercedes stated primly.

 

“Yeah, that,” Byleth agreed. She wasn’t even lying, it had absolutely been a miracle that her eye came back. Though she should probably keep the Nabatean thing more of a secret than she did back in Leicester.

 

“Oh hey, here’s where you ran off to!”

 

Byleth paused, then glanced over at her sister as Shez approached with a big grin on her face. “Hello Shez.”

 

“Heh, hey yourself! So hey, did Mercedes start worshiping you the moment she saw–Oh, hey, Mercedes! And everybody else!” Shez beamed at her former classmates while the Lions all just kind of stared at the exuberant mercenary. “Long time no see–Oh, hang on, where’s Dedue and Ashe?”

 

“They’re out on a mission at the moment bringing supplies to one of the villages we’re protecting,” Felix explained, his arms crossed and his eyes narrowed, “Are you still possessed?”

 

“Nope, I killed the ghost possessing me and it’s all good now.”

 

“You were possessed by a ghost?” Annette asked.

 

“You weren’t under the control of a dark god?” Mercedes also asked, earning a bewildered blink from her friend.

 

“Uh, nope, not a dark god. Just a really dickish dark mage who thought he was more important than he was,” Shez explained, summing it up pretty concisely, in her opinion.

 

“We can explain more later,” Byleth offered, before turning to her sister, “Is Rhea going to let us go to the Empire?”

 

“Huh? Oh, uh…probably, but it might take a while–Hey, c’mon, don’t pout.”

 

To the gathered Lions’ surprise, Byleth actually was visibly pouting instead of just looking neutrally displeased. “We should go sooner instead of later.”

 

“Yeah, I know you’re eager, but you’re the tactician here, right? Does it make tactical sense to go running off towards Adrestia without back-up?”

 

“...No.”

 

“Exactly! Besides, weren’t we going to go find those Knights of Reclamation guys at Zanado? You were the one that made that plan in the first place,” Shez pointed out, much to Byleth’s chagrin.

 

“Okay, I understand. We’ll make preparations first. I still want to get to the Empire by the end of the month though.”

 

“Sure, sounds like a plan to me. And hey, don’t worry too much. It’s not like we need to hurry or anything,” she assured, patting her sister on the back, “It’s not like anyone’s going anywhere.”

If asked, Victor would say he’d lived a decent life. Not in terms of morals, he’d gladly talk up how corrupt he’d been as a guard before becoming a mercenary, but in terms of contentment. 

 

Sure, the merc life was rough, but he’d made friends, gotten a decent amount of money over the years, and lived about as comfortably as he cared to live. He knew in his heart that he was a man of violent means, not suited for living in a decent way, but happy with the life he’d had. It could’ve been better, but it could’ve been worse too.

 

Such were his thoughts amidst the roars and screeches of what had to be dozens of demonic beasts tearing through Zanado. And with more pouring into the canyon by the minute, he was pretty sure that number would go up to over a hundred.

 

The day started off fine enough. He couldn’t say he really liked hanging around with the zealous weirdos that made up the Knights of Reclamation, but a job was a job and Captain Jeralt told him and Candace to keep an eye on them until he got back, so that’s what Victor did. 

 

All told, it wasn’t too different from living in a merc camp, just with higher standards for polished weapons and armor, and way too much praying. Candace seemed to enjoy herself though, telling stories about the captain’s kids to a captivated audience who seemed to take every childhood story as a possible gospel.

 

She was right in the middle of telling a tale about Byleth’s first time riding a horse when they first heard the sound of a flute playing on the breeze, followed by a demonic screech. The flap of heavy, featherless wings echoed throughout the canyon before a sudden wave of monsters struck the Reclamation camps. Then it was chaos.

 

“Hey Vic, did you know these demonic beasts traveled in herds?” 

 

Victor blinked, stirred from his thoughts as he glanced over at Candace, a bloodied spear in her hand and a genuinely curious look on her face, like she hadn’t just asked a stupid question. Though, come to think of it… “I don’t think it’s a herd if they’re predators, right? Herds are for cattle and sheep, it’d be like a pack of wolves or bears.”

 

“Do bears travel in packs?”

 

“Uh…” He didn’t know the answer to that. “Is that really the kind of question you should be asking right now?”

 

“I guess not? I’m just not super sure what to talk about while we’re hiding.”

 

“We’re not hiding, we’re taking cover,” Victor corrected, before peeking over the stack of crates they were hiding behind just in time to see two beasts manage to bring down one of the guardian golems. “Damn, there goes another one…we might need to make a tactical retreat here.”

 

“Oh, we’re running?”

 

“ Tactically ! It ain’t craven if it’s tactical.”

 

“Yeah alright, sounds good to me.” She moved up beside him, scanning the bloodied canyon as knights screamed their defiance against the brutal beasts. “You think we could take some folks with us? Don’t feel right to just leave ‘em to die.”

 

“If they wanna retreat, they can go for it. What we’re doing is being tactical. The captain needs to know things went wrong, right? So we should be smart about it. Maybe grab some horses so we’ll be faster.”

 

“Oh, maybe we can get a pegasus–“ The pair of mercenaries paused as an audible crunch sounded out, followed by a scream of terror that ended abruptly as a pegasus knight hit the ground. They glanced upwards, saw the swarm of flying beasts going after everything in the sky, and came to a better decision. “Horses are fine.”

 

“Horses are great,” Victor agreed, “Hell, pegasi are pretentious anyway, with their fancy wings and stupid high flying ways.”

 

“What’s pretentious mean?”

 

“It means like nobles.”

 

“Ohh…aren’t you just mad because pegasi won’t let you get on them?”

 

“I’m not mad, and they’re pretentious anyway. Now c’mon, let’s find a way outta here.”

 

It was easier said than done, but the pair of mercenaries were at least able to maneuver through the chaotic canyon without being immediately crushed or eaten by the hulking monstrosities that were ripping their way through everything.

 

“RALLY TO ME, KNIGHTS OF RECLAMATION!” declared one of those cardinal guys, waving a staff as a way of gathering up the scattered knights. Victor, of course, immediately decided to avoid that area, though it wasn’t long before they bumped into another one of the robed cardinals.

 

“You two! Captain Jeralt’s subordinates! Fantastic, you’re still alive,” the man said, sounding genuinely pleased to see them. 

 

Victor couldn’t really say the same. “Ah, yeah, hey, uh…Cardinal! What’s up, what’s your plan? Candace and I were thinking–”

 

“No time for that! We need to hurry. We cannot allow these monstrosities to defile the sacred land of Zanado no matter what happens! We all must lay down our lives if necessary to keep it safe!” There was a familiar, zealous look in the cardinal’s weirdly bright green eyes that Victor definitely didn’t like.

 

“Right, uh, well, me and Candace were actually about–”

 

“Why’re your eyes green, Bernhard?” Candace spoke up, a frown on her face, “Thought they were blue.”

 

“What?” The cardinal blinked, confusion entering those strange eyes of his. Which, now that Victor looked, seemed to be glowing. “I…h-hold now, what is that…why do I feel…?” 

 

A full body shudder went through him as his skin started to pale. Though, no, it wasn’t paling. There were white scales growing across the cardinal’s face.

 

Victor shoved him back, knocking the cardinal to the ground before he grabbed Candace and just started moving, getting away from whatever the hell that was.

 

“Ah, hang on, shouldn’t we–”

 

“Nope, we’re not helping, we’re not staying, and we sure as hell ain’t fighting whatever that was!” Victor declared, before going right for the closest horse he spotted.

 

The steed sure as hell wasn’t happy with all the blood, noise, and monsters around it, practically wailing with fear in a horsey way, but Candace was always good with the big animals so Victor let her calm it down while he kept an eye out for more trouble. And there definitely was more trouble coming considered there were now giant white beasts in the mix, shrieking and biting at the other monsters.

 

“Why are there white ones now?!”

 

“Some animals are albino,” Candace pointed out while petting the trembling horse’s snout, “There there, that’s a good girl…ah, albino means they’re white for some reason.”

 

“I know what albino means! It’s like the little princess or Shez’s noble friend!”

 

“Oh yeah, those two…aw, I miss Shez.”

 

“Yeah, I do too, but is now really the time–“

 

“Aw, it’s sweet to hear even random soldiers like my sister,” came a voice from nearby. One that sent an immediate shiver down Victor’s spine, an instinctive sense of danger making him very wary as he turned to look at a cloaked man perching on a nearby crate, looking a lot like the bird his mask resembles. “Though, you two don’t seem like the rest of these peons. You’re still generic-looking trash, but you’re not wearing white or blue like these zealots…”

 

The stranger cocked his head, studying them. “So now I’m curious. Just how do you know my twin?”

 

“…last I checked, Captain Jeralt doesn’t have a son,” Victor replied, moving in front of Candance.

 

“Do I need to be his son to be Shez’s brother? She did have a mother at one point.”

 

“She would’ve mentioned you.” He tightened his grip on his axe’s handle.

 

“Not if she didn’t know about me.” He tilted his head the other way, the light of the flames nearby glinting in the lenses of his mask. “You didn’t answer my question. Or, hm, maybe you did. You did say ‘Captain Jeralt’. So you’re one of his.” He turned his head, looking curiously at the destruction around them. “Is he around? Because I have some thoughts–“

 

Most mercenaries weren’t particularly loyal individuals. It was a rough type of career that tended to reward callous disregard for those around them, particularly since yesterday’s ally might be tomorrow’s enemy. Yet when a person spends years and years fighting alongside someone, it was almost unthinkable that there wouldn’t be a sort of trust formed between them.

 

Victor wasn’t sure when he decided he wasn’t getting out of this situation alive, but he didn’t even need to look at Candace for a sudden sense of understanding to hit the blonde merc. And so, in a swift, almost synchronized motion, Victor lunged for the man in the mask as Candace hopped on the horse and immediately urged the beast into a full gallop away from them.

 

“Oh?” The masked man stared curiously at the axe he’d caught on his sword, the blade inches from his skull. “I coulda sworn I was being cordial. Did I mess up somewhere?”

 

“Nah,” Victor replied, his muscles straining as he tried to drive the axe in, “I just don’t like your attitude, brat.”

 

“Huh. Well that’s a shame, I guess I’ll have to work on that.”

 

Then he vanished and Victor stumbled, his eyes going wide right before he let out a choked grunt. He looked down at the black blade protruding from his chest, only briefly registering the sight before it suddenly went upwards.

 

“Man, this sucks. I really thought I could get something useful here…ah well. It’s not like anybody will miss some random wretch.”

 

Victor blinked, a bit surprised to see a blue sky overhead. He would’ve thought the smoke would cover it.

 

Well, it wasn’t the worst sight to die seeing. Such were his thoughts right before his head hit the ground.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Man, when we made Victor way back when, I didn't think he'd go out like this.

Red: Yeah, it's a funny thing killing off a character. Sure, he's an OC, but it was fun having him around when he did get time to pop up.

Indi: As for how things will be going forward, well, it's gonna be rough for Byleth and Shez at least.

Red: And Rhea, considering this is the second time there was a gruesome massacre in the Red Canyon. Man, people need to stop living in Zanado, the place is definitely cursed.

Indi: Ah well, I'm sure they'll figure something out.

Grand Teacher Shez (April Fools)

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Ensure the elder Eisner sister is given the position as professor. 

 

Rhea’s instructions had been simple, so simple that not even her most foolish of knights would be able to mess it up. The elder Eisner sister, Byleth Eisner, would be made a professor, all to ensure that her mother's vessel stayed at the academy. Rhea would have preferred offering her the position herself, yet as the archbishop she still had business to attend to, namely punishing the former professor who had abandoned his students. It had been quite a while since circumstances allowed her to bring out the pliers again, and she wanted to savor the moment, perhaps to the detriment of her schedule.

 

Regardless, she'd be able to greet the vessel of the goddess the next morning once she chose which class to join. 

 

“I want to teach the Lions!” Shez stated, a large smile on her face. 

 

“...Huh?” 

 

“I'd prefer to join the Black Eagles,” Byleth stated, getting Shez to frown. 

 

“Hey, why aren't you joining my class?” 

 

“Would you join my class if I was the professor?” 

 

“...okay, yeah, I guess that’s fine then.”

 

“...” Rhea looked at Shez, then Byleth, then Shez again, before blinking at Jeralt. “What?”

 

“Shez wants the lion class, and Byleth wants to join the Eagles. I thought that was obvious,” the mercenary captain stated, “Not sure why you wanted Shez as a teacher, but your toady made it clear refusing wasn’t an option.”

 

Rhea glanced at Seteth, who nodded to her unasked question. He had no idea why the archbishop wanted Shez Eisner as a teacher either, but he obeyed the instructions as given.

 

“...I see. Hm.” Rhea, meanwhile, was reminded that everyone around her was an idiot and this was why she was in charge because none of these morons could find their own backside with two hands and a map. Well, at least she’ll still be staying at the academy either way. Still, this does ruin some plans… “Very well then. I believe you will be needing a uniform then, Byleth, and Shez…ah…why don’t you speak to Hanneman and Manuela? Perhaps they can aid you in putting together a lesson plan.”

 

“Oh I don’t need that, I’ve already got loads of plans already.”

 

For some reason, the young woman’s confidence did not reassure Rhea.

“Hm. So this is what it’s like wearing a skirt,” Byleth noted to herself, now dressed in the academy uniform. She’d decided to go for the silver version instead of the standard color, mostly because it just looked better to her, and she had to admit, she enjoyed how swishy her new outfit felt. “Swish swish…”

 

She should probably make sure not to kick too high while wearing it though. It probably wouldn’t be too much of an issue, but she heard something about some students being ‘skirt-chasers’ and now that she was wearing a skirt, she might be a target of those hostile students.

 

“I may not know why they dislike skirts, but I shall be ready for them.”

 

“That’s not…never mind,” Sothis muttered as Byleth headed out of her room, ready to greet the day.

 

Shez, meanwhile, was not ready to greet the day. In fact, she was still in bed, not dressed in the slightest, and was currently being semi-metaphorically poked by her own ghostly companion.

 

Metaphorically because Arval couldn’t actually touch her face to poke her properly. “Partner. Partner. Wake up, partner.”

 

“Mffhgl…”

 

“Partner, you’re a teacher now, you need to attend your class.”

 

“Grng…” 

 

“...Your sister is about to eat your snacks,” Arval muttered with a blank expression, causing her to snap up. 

 

“She wouldn't!” 

 

“Oh good, you’ve awakened. You have a class to teach.”

 

“Huh? Oh, right, shit, I’m a professor now! Uh–No, wait, why would I even be worried? I can just warp to the class–”

 

“Get dressed first,” Arval interrupted, well aware of how things would go if they didn’t. They knew their partner could be foolish, but showing up to her first class in her undergarments would send a very wrong message to her students.

 

“Oh, right, clothes. Ugh, damn it, I let my guard down because the bed was comfy…” Shez grumbled as she picked out an outfit for the day–

 

“Are you really going to wear your regular mercenary clothes to class?”

 

“Hm? Uh…should I not? I think it looks pretty good and it wasn’t like the other professors had uniforms.”

 

“Fine, you're going to be late enough as is,” Arval huffed as Shez got dressed before heading out to her class. Soon enough, she was standing in front of the Blue Lions class, a wide smile on her face before she pushed it open. 

 

“Hey there, sorry if I'm late, still getting used to this!” Shez stated as the Lions turned to the door. 

 

“Ah, Professor, we were starting to get worried something had happened to you.” Dimitri said, greeting the mercenary as the Lions crowded around her. 

 

“Nah don't worry about it, I just went to sleep late by accident. Still, since we're late, I figure we can go straight to it.” 

 

“Oh, what do you have planned, Professor?” 

 

“Well, since we have the mock battle in a few weeks, I figured the best thing to do is simple,” Shez gave everyone a large smile, “A spar, all of you against me!”

 

“Huh? Uh, professor–”

 

“Sounds good to me,” Felix immediately agreed, looking far more interested already, “Right here, or at the training yard?”

 

“Felix, you can’t fight in the class–”

 

“We have a training yard?” Shez asked, before pausing, “Actually, yeah, that makes way more sense! Come on everybody, let’s go to the training yard!”

 

The Lions glanced at one another for a moment, before Felix abruptly began to follow her, signaling to the rest to move as well. Hopefully it wouldn't be that bad, the students thought, unaware of how intense the sparring would be. Though hey, at least only three of them wound up puking from exhaustion. That was pretty good for a first day, in Shez’s professional and inaccurate opinion.

 

Meanwhile, Byleth was having a relatively simple lesson, listening attentively as Manuela laid out her plans for the mock battle. Even if it wasn't necessary for Byleth to listen, since she had been informed she wouldn't be allowed to participate. Still, she wanted to leave a good first impression. 

 

“So, how'd your first day of class go?” her classmate Dorothea asked, smiling down at the mercenary. 

 

“Well enough, I suppose. I am somewhat lacking in magic skills, so once Manuela begins to teach more on that, I'll be content.” 

 

“Well you're in luck, Manuela only taught me for a short while back when she was at the Opera House, but I can assure you that she's an excellent teacher,” Dorothea said, walking alongside Byleth as they left class, “Ah, but enough about that, I was hoping to learn more about you.” 

 

“Hm? How so?” 

 

“Well I figured a beautiful mercenary like you must have been quite popular while traveling around. Any romantic tales you want to share~?” Dorothea asked, hoping to hear about any worthwhile nobles who could be a potential option down the line. 

 

“Hm, my apologies, I don't have much experience with that. I don't attract much attention in terms of romantic matters.” 

 

“Really, no experience at all?” Dorothea asked, a bit surprised. 

 

“None,” Byleth replied, before pausing as she glanced at the songstress, her eyes lingering on her fellow student’s figure. It was just an errant thought, but, well…they both were students, so it should be okay, “Unless you wish to help me, that is.” 

 

Dorothea paused, then immediately smiled in a far more flirtatious way as she leaned towards the mercenary, angling her posture to give Byleth a very good look down the front of her shirt. “Of course, I’d love to help you learn all about romance~ Why don’t we find somewhere private so I can tutor you, hm~?”

 

Byleth, who had been staring straight at the enticing sight offered to her by the flirtatious songstress, needed a second to actually respond. “...sure. That sounds good to me.”

 

“Great, let’s get going then~” And with that, Dorothea quite eagerly led her new friend off, happy to teach her all about “romance”. Sure, she’d probably still be looking for a rich noble afterwards, considering life as a mercenary definitely didn’t appeal to her, but she could at least help a cute girl get some experience.

“So how have classes been?” Byleth asked Shez, as they sat down for a meal together. 

 

“Oh going great! Well, for the most part. The class still can't stack up against me in a fight, but they've been improving!” Shez answered with a smile on her face, “Dimitri even managed to land a hit on me yesterday. It was a glancing one, but still.” 

 

“Hm, either you're taking it easy on them, or they're more talented than I expected.” 

 

“Eh, a bit of both. I haven't used my awakened form, but they're fast learners,” Shez responded, taking a bite out of her chicken, “Anyways, how are things with you?” 

 

“Going well, I have a girlfriend now.” Byleth stated getting Shez to gag on poultry. 

 

“W-What!? Since when!?” 

 

“First day, I suppose. She wants to keep things casual, so we haven't gone around telling anyone, but it's been nice,” Byleth explained, thinking about all the ‘tutoring’ Dorothea gave her. 

 

“And why didn't you tell me!?” 

 

“I am now,” Byleth said as Shez frowned.

 

“Then tell me who it is.” 

 

“It's–”

 

“Ah there you are, Byleth, I hope I'm not interrupting something important.” Pausing, Byleth glanced over to see Edelgard standing nearby. 

 

“Oh, hello, did you need something?” 

 

“Yes, I was hoping we would be able to squeeze in one more sparring match before the mock battle tomorrow.” 

 

“I don't mind, it's nice spending time with you, Edelgard,” Byleth said, before pausing when she heard a gasp from beside her.

 

“So this is who it is!” Shez ‘realized’, pointing at Edelgard, “You’re dating the princess!?”

 

Edelgard blinked, caught off guard. “Er, what?”

 

“Don’t think you can hide it from me!” Shez reiterated, before pausing, “Hm, is this why you kept your relationship a secret? You didn’t want anyone to realize the princess seduced you?”

 

“Edelgard didn’t seduce me,” Byleth responded, nonplussed.

 

“Eh? Well I know you didn’t seduce her, you’re not that good with relationships.”

 

“...I’m better than you are.”

 

“Yeah right. I don't want to call you a liar, By, but I doubt you know how to flirt.” Shez huffed, getting Byleth to frown. 

 

“Hm.” Standing up, Byleth turned to face Edelgard, who took a step back as the mercenary stepped forward. “My Lady, I apologize for my sister. If you would do me the honor of joining me, I'd be happy to spend time alone with you.” 

 

“Huh?” A bit caught off guard, Edelgard glanced down at Byleth’s offered hand. 

 

“Nothing would make me happier than you accepting my offer.” 

 

“...” Still fairly bewildered and bemused, Edelgard decided to accept her classmate’s hand. She wasn’t expecting Byleth to bring her hand to her lips and kiss it, though she had enough decorum not to blush at the gesture. She did feel flustered though. “T-Then we should go, Byleth.” 

 

“Gladly.” Offering the princess her arm, the two were soon off, leaving Shez alone as she watched them walk off. 

 

“...When the hell did she learn how to do that?” Letting out a huff, she leaned back, hoping her sister wouldn't become a flirt. She didn’t want to see her turn into Sylvain.

It turned out, Shez didn’t need to worry about Byleth turning into Sylvain. Mostly because Sylvain wished he could be as successful as Byleth.

 

“Excuse me, Professor.” Pausing in the middle of grading papers, Shez glanced up to see Mercedes standing by her desk. “I hope I'm not bothering you.”

 

“Oh hey, Mercedes, don't worry about it! This was boring anyways,” Shez responded, setting her quill down, “What's up?”

 

“Well, I wanted to inform you I was planning on transferring to the Black Eagles.” 

 

“Huh? Wait, why? Don't tell me this is because of the mock battle.” 

 

“Don't worry Professor, I wouldn't hold a grudge over something so silly, especially since it was a month ago. This is more due to…personal reasons,” Mercedes explained, glancing away from her. 

 

“Really? If there's something wrong, you can tell me,” Shez offered, racking her brains as she tried to figure out what could be the problem, before remembering something from last night. Specifically, she remembered seeing Mercedes having a tea party with Byleth. “...This is because of Byleth, isn't it?” 

 

The older girl blushed, her face turning a light shade of pink as she averted her gaze. “Er…well, I just…think it may be better for my current studies if I join Byleth’s class. I mean no offense, professor, I just think I would be better suited in the Eagles classroom.”

 

What, are you going to raise your Faith by ‘praying’ to Byleth? Shez thought but didn’t say. Instead, she just sighed. “Yeah, alright, if that’s what you want…hm…no, you know what, fuck that.”

 

Mercedes blinked, a little alarmed. “Professor?”

 

“Mercedes, you can join Byleth’s class, sure, but I guarantee to you that I’m gonna grab you back before the end of the year! In fact, I’m gonna snatch up all the other students so my class will win everything, all the time, forever!”

 

“A-Ah…good luck with that, Professor?” Mercedes said, though it seemed Shez didn't hear her as she began to form a plot to snatch all the students. Though it seemed her devious plot wouldn't go unnoticed when Byleth marched up to her later while she was practicing her swordplay at the training yard.

 

“You're not allowed to steal my girlfriends. Get your own,” Byleth demanded, earning a scoff from her sister.

 

“Oh please, you can’t tell me what to do. I outrank you in the school hierarchy!” Shez declared with a big grin, radiating smugness, “And besides, I’m not stealing your girlfriends, I’m stealing your classmates. There’s a difference.”

 

“Not really.”

 

“...the hell’s that mean?” Shez asked, only to see Byleth pout. 

 

“I don't want them to leave.” 

 

“Wh–Seriously? Are you that attached to Emily?”

 

“If they’re not dating me, I still want them to be my friends,” Byleth insisted, still pouting.

 

“...well, fine, I guess I won’t steal your classmates specifically, but no more stealing my students!”

 

“Mm…that should be fine, I don’t think you have anyone else I would like kissing.”

 

“That–So you admit it’s for horny reasons!”

 

Byleth shrugged. “I like kissing.” She tilted her head. “You should try getting a girlfriend. Or boyfriend. Or both.”

 

“And whom am I supposed to date, huh? I can't date any students, and the only staff who aren’t that older than me are Catherine and Shamir. Which I'm definitely not doing since that feels like a giant headache.” Shez huffed, before pausing, “...I guess the librarian is cute.” 

 

“...Tomas?” 

 

“No! I meant the assistant Librarian. I think her name is Selene?” Shez said, considering the question, “She seems nice enough.” 

 

“Okay. Good luck Shez. I can give you some tips if you need them.” 

 

“I am not taking flirting advice from you.” Rolling her eyes, Shez began to walk away, before turning around. “Also I call dibs on the Deer students first!” 

 

“Hm, fair enough,” Byleth replied, waving Shez off, before heading off herself, not wanting to be late for her date. Besides what was the worst that could happen? Shez gets rejected? 

Byleth wasn't sure how exactly the library caught on fire, but she was going to at least keep quiet about the possibility that it was Shez’s fault. Thankfully, the knights managed to save the books before the flames spread too far, and there was mainly just some damage to some furniture. Still classes were canceled for the day as the staff tried to get everything sorted out and made sure no one was injured. 

 

Granted, part of that “sorting out” was apparently trying to track down Selene and Tomas since they turned out to be weirdly pale infiltrators.

 

Byleth was just happy she was in town when that happened, though it did mean her date was interrupted. 

 

“...So it wasn't a no at least,” Shez started as the two sat in the courtyard. 

 

“But it wasn't a yes.” 

 

“Shut up. It could’ve been a yes if that old guy didn’t interrupt,” Shez complained, before letting out a huff and laying down, “I bet if I was a student, I'd have tons of people to kiss.” 

 

“That's what you get for stealing that bandit boss kill.” 

 

“...Are you seriously miffed about that?” Shez asked, a bit surprised. 

 

“Not really, but also thinking back on it, it would have been nice showing off to Edelgard more.” 

 

“Didn't you already save her life?” 

 

“Hence why I said more.” 

 

Shez huffed again. “Still don't know how you’re dating so many people.” 

 

“I'm just that loveable. That and Dorothea says I'm a natural–” 

 

“No details, I don't need to hear that,” Shez requested with a grimace, “I'm really lucky you aren't dating Sylvain, that would have been horrible.” 

 

“I did think about it. But Dorothea wasn't into the idea, and I was dating her first, so yeah.” Byleth paused, thinking. “I think she actually said ‘not Sylvain, never Sylvain’ specifically.”

 

“Hm. Hm. So, seriously, when did you become such a flirt?”

 

“I discovered a natural talent for seduction. And also I find a lot of people here attractive.”

 

“Feh…”

 

Byleth glanced at Shez. “You could always just quit being a professor. Maybe Papa would take over for you?”

 

“Screw that, I’m not giving up! I never give up!” Shez insisted, giving her sister a determined glare, “I’m going to be the best damn teacher this school has ever seen! I’ll win at being a teacher! And I’ll seduce someone hot too!”

 

“...” Byleth looked back at the still smoking library. “Hm…maybe try again away from the monastery next time.”

 

“Ah–...yeah, that might be a good idea…”

Rhea took a deep, exasperated breath. “Professor Eisner…how did you start a war with the Kingdom?”

 

“Okay, look, technically it was only supposed to be a war with the Western Church,” Shez began, “And even then I’d say it was less a war and more an ass–No, wait, shouldn’t say it was an assassination…uh…” She visibly tried to think of an excuse. “...it was peacekeeping.”

 

“You killed the Bishop of the West, Count Rowe, and, somehow, Miklan Gautier, while also burning Arianrhod to the ground.”

 

“Ah, hang on, that last part was Dimitri’s fault.”

 

“I take full responsibility for my actions…” the house leader stated, his head bowed in obvious shame.

 

“But, hey, good news! I did complete the mission to assassinate Lord Lonato–”

 

“It wasn’t an assassination, stop saying that,” Rhea insisted, before sighing again, pinching the bridge of her nose, “Why do you keep using that word anyway?”

 

“Oh, because of the letter we found that said people were trying to assassinate you. That’s why I did the Western Church thing, and then things kind of…spiraled?”

 

“How do things ‘spiral’ into you burning down the Kingdom’s second largest city?” Seteth asked, openly baffled.

 

“Arianrhod is a city? I thought it was a fort?”

 

“It’s both, professor,” Dimitri pointed out, his head still bowed.

 

“Oh, weird. Well…I’m pretty sure it had something to do with the Tragedy of Duscur. Probably.”

 

Rhea blinked. “What?” 

 

“Uh, Dimitri, mind explaining?” 

 

“When we were searching for evidence of who was attempting to assassinate you, we were led to the Western Church, which in turn unearthed evidence that led to potential perpetrators behind the Tragedy of Duscur,” Dimitri stated, his hands clenched into fists at his sides, “The Western Church might not have been behind it, but they were working with someone who potentially did, which led us to Arianhod.” 

 

“And while we were there, Dimitri tried to question Rowe,” Shez continued, picking up where he left off, “And, well…one thing led to another and we had to fight off his men while trying to escape.” 

 

“And how does that involve burning the city to the ground?” 

 

“That…I'm not sure?” Shez said, glancing at Dimitri. 

 

“While we were there, I discovered the Court Mage Cornelia there, who believed I had discovered her secret before escaping. Soon afterwards, as we were attempting to escape as well, several demonic beasts seemed to appear from nowhere to lay waste to the city.” 

 

“Yeah, it's like they were summoned,” Shez said, frowning, “After that, well, Dimitri realized that if Cornelia was at least a bit behind the tragedy, there's one obvious person who was assisting her. So I sent a letter of formal declaration of war to Rufus.” 

 

“...Please tell me you're joking,” Seteth requested incredulously. 

 

“No, she is not,” Dimitri stated, “When she sent the letter, I requested we return here so we may request aid to tear those monsters to shreds.” 

 

Rhea realized the young man wasn't bowing his head in shame, but in barely constrained rage. 

 

“And where exactly does Miklan come into play?” Seteth asked, choosing not to broach Dimitri’s request at the moment.

 

“Uh…whose Miklan again?” Shez asked.

 

“The bandit with the scar on his face,” Dimitri explained, “He was Sylvain's brother.” 

 

“Oh! Oh no, I should apologize to him…” 

 

“I don't think you need to. He's not fond of him.” 

 

“Oh, well, that one is on me. Just kinda got lost and bumped into him when we were going to Arianhod,” Shez said, before shrugging, “Dude was a creep so I killed him.” 

 

“Well this explains why you've been gone for over a month…” Rhea muttered, feeling exhausted. 

 

“Oh, right, speaking of, how's Byleth? Didn't get to talk to her on my way up, so I wanted to know if anything happened to her.” 

 

“Ah, I believe she is spending time with Edelgard,” Rhea answered. 

 

“I still find it inappropriate that she's seeing multiple people,” Seteth huffed. 

 

“...Wait, at the same time?” Rhea asked, a bit surprised, “Is it serious?”

 

“Maybe? Last I knew, she was dating Dorothea, Edelgard, and Mercedes. Don't know if it's gotten serious, but they seemed to be doing well,” Shez explained, before pausing as the door suddenly opened. Turning around, she smiled at who walked in, “Oh, hey By, we were just talking about you!” 

 

“Hm? What about?” 

 

“You and your girlfriends. Rhea wanted to know if it had gotten serious for some reason.” 

 

“Oh, well, I'm not sure? Things are starting to get serious with Edelgard, but Mercedes seems to be dealing with something with her dad?” 

 

“Huh, did you offer to beat him up?” 

 

“Of course,” Byleth said with a nod, “As for Dorothea, it's still casual. As far as I'm aware she's still looking for a rich noble.” 

 

“Wait, does she think you aren't good enough?” Rhea asked, suddenly serious. 

 

“Lady Rhea, is this really appro–” Seteth began, before pausing when Rhea held up a hand and shushed him.

 

“Byleth, please continue.”

 

“Hm? Well, from what Dorothea’s told me, she’s fine helping me ‘learn the ropes’, and she has told me that I’m sweet and soft like a teddy bear, but she needs to marry someone with money to live a comfortable life and being a traveling mercenary doesn’t seem like it would work well with her life plans.”

 

“Huh. Are teddy bears sweet?” Shez asked.

 

“I don’t think so. The ‘sweet’ part was a separate compliment.” 

 

“You should not be with someone who doesn't value you if you don't have money,” Rhea advised. 

 

Byleth shrugged. “I think it’s fine. Like Dorothea said, at least we can’t get pregnant.”

 

“Miss Byleth, that is deeply inappropriate to speak of in the archbishop’s chambers,” Seteth reprimanded.

 

“Yeah By, I'm gonna have to give you detention for that,” Shez said with a grin.

 

“...you’re not my professor,” Byleth pointed out.

 

“Yeah but I still have that power. Right Seteth?”

 

“You do, yes. And even if you didn't, she would still get punished for saying such things,” Seteth said, before shaking his head, “Regardless, is there a reason why you're here, Miss Byleth?” 

 

“Oh, right. Apparently some disaster is happening in the Empire so while Edelgard is getting everyone ready, I came up to see if we could get help.” 

 

“What??” 

 

“I requested aid first,” Dimitri said, speaking up and reminding everyone he was there.

 

“Hey, yeah, we were here first!” Shez pointed out, “What’s going on in the Empire that’s so important? It’s not like we don’t have a war going on too.”

 

Byleth shrugged. “I don’t really know, but apparently it involves a gigantic demonic beast abducting the prime minister and climbing to the top of Enbarr’s palace.”

 

Rhea blinked. “What.”

 

“A gigantic demonic–How in the world did that happen!?” Seteth demanded.

 

Meanwhile, all the way down in the capital of the Empire, a certain man named Myson sat on a hill outside the city limits, watching as his intended masterpiece screeched in rage at the wyvern and pegasus knights trying to rescue a screaming Duke Aegir from its clutches, one enormous hand clutching onto the top spire of Enbarr Palace.

 

“...Odesse?”

 

“Yes, Lord Myson?” responded his bird-masked attendant.

 

“Let’s blame Chilon for this.”

 

“Of course, Lord Myson.”

 

Back at the monastery, Byleth shrugged again. “Not sure. So yeah, can we have help with that?”

 

“Again, I asked first,” Dimitri stated irritably.

 

“Yeah, but I’m pretty sure your thing is just a you problem. My thing is a me problem, so it matters more.”

 

“Pff-” Shez tried to cover her snort, clearing her throat and attempting to look professional. “C’mon Byleth, you’re being kinda rude there.”

 

“No, she has a point,” Rhea commented, earning a baffled look from Seteth, “This really is a ‘you’ problem, Dimitri, and the church does not get involved with ‘you’ problems. So, what was it you wanted us to do to support you, Byleth?”

 

“Hm…can I borrow Shez?”

 

“Of course, she can be your new professor.”

 

“Wait, what?” Shez blinked. “Hang on, what about the war thing? Also, wait, I can’t be Byleth’s professor! I need to beat her class at school stuff!”

 

“Professor Shez, clearly there is a set of priorities here,” Rhea began, “You can always have your competition with your sister at a later date. As for the ‘war’ with Faerghus, I will simply send a message to the regent telling him the previous letter was a mistake and clearly we were just declaring war on Mach again.”

 

“Mach? What’s Mach? Is that like a secret fourth nation of Fodlan?”

 

“No,” Rhea lied, “Now then, let’s focus on the immediately relevant, pressing disaster in the Empire and hope we don’t have anything else happen in the next few–”

 

“Lady Rhea, the Almyrans are invading!” Alois shouted as he ran into the audience chamber, “The Locket has fallen and half the mountains are on fire!”

 

“Why would they set fire to the mountains?” Seteth asked, bewildered, “ How would they set fire to the mountains?”

 

“...okay, that is a concern,” Rhea noted, “Perhaps we should prioritize–”

 

“LADY RHEA!” Catherine shouted as she burst into the room, “Sreng’s invading from the north and just took Fhirdiad!” 

 

“They did? How?”

 

“Apparently Lady Cornelia just opened the gates for them!”

 

“That witch…” Dimitri grumbled, prompting Shez to pat him on the head.

 

“There there, we’ll kill her later.”

 

“Hm.” Rhea was starting to see a pattern. And that pattern seemed to come to fruition when Shamir entered the room too. “Let me guess. Dagda is invading?”

 

“Nope,” the archer replied, unruffled as ever.

 

“Oh. Why are you here then?”

 

“Some kind of umbral beast is crawling on the monastery and I wanted to see if you noticed.”

 

Rhea blinked, then glanced behind her, out of the window of her audience chamber, where a massive, monstrous, skull-headed creature was peeking through the glass.

 

“...Sitri?”  

 

“...” Rhea turned back to the group. “...Professor Shez, I’m not sure how, but I’m fairly certain this is your fault.”

 

“Wha–I was gone for a month! How could this all be my fault!?”

 

“Oh, wait.” Byleth raised a hand. “I think the umbral thing might be my fault. Sorry.”

 

“Of course it isn’t your fault,” Rhea reassured, before Seteth spoke up with audible annoyance in his voice.

 

“How is it your fault, Byleth?”

 

“Friend of my mom’s asked me for a chalice, I got it for him, then was kind of busy taking Edelgard on a double date with these two cuties I met down there. Apparently the redheaded one, Hapi, can make demonic beasts show up when she sighs, and she did sigh on the date. Not sure why there was a delay though.”

 

“Wait, she can do what?” 

 

“Her sighs summon demonic beasts. Though well, I suppose it wasn't a sigh, more so a m–” Whatever Byleth was about to say was cut off as the demonic beast smashed its forearm through the window, grabbing onto her and pulling her out. 

 

“Wha–Hey get back here!” Shez shouted, leaping out the window to grab onto the beast as it crawled away. 

 

“...” Rhea couldn't help but let out a sigh, hoping things didn't get more out of hand. 

Somehow Sitri was alive. Rhea wasn’t quite sure how that happened.

 

Well, no, she did have something of an idea, considering she was there for the whole “Umbral Beast Incident”, wherein apparently Aelfric, of all people, decided to use the Chalice of Beginnings to resurrect his childhood friend, who he was apparently a lot more obsessed with than Rhea realized. It was probably a good thing he was dead now, otherwise things would’ve been even more awkward…

 

“So. To sum up this whole…series of events,” Jeralt began, looking very unimpressed, “Instead of burying Sitri after her death like a normal person, you, Rhea, decided to just put her body down in Abyss.”

 

“I feel like I should be given more benefit of the doubt than that,” Rhea murmured, only to pause when Jeralt glared at her. “...hmph.”

 

“Some time later, Aelfric found her, went crazy, and decided to do a ritual to bring her back to life involving an artifact that ‘Saint Seiros’–” He gave Rhea another pointed look. “–made to bring the goddess back to life. This ritual involved sacrificing the lives of four kids with the crests of the Apostles, but because two of them were apparently ‘busy’–” He deliberately did not look at his daughter at that moment. “–he tried using substitutes, which apparently included a number of mercenaries, some bones he found in Abyss, and Zanado fruits, for some reason.”

 

“To be fair to the psycho, didn’t it wind up working?” Shez pointed out, gesturing towards Sitri, who was sitting on a couch Rhea had brought up to her office so she could lay down. Which she wasn’t actually doing, having instead decided to let Byleth rest her head in her lap while she hummed a familiar lullaby.

 

“Kid, turning himself and a bunch of other people into a gigantic demonic beast–”

 

“Umbral beast,” Sitri corrected, before going back to stroking Byleth’s hair.

 

“Right, that. Either way, I don’t think he would’ve counted it as a success,” Jeralt muttered. 

 

“Eh, the dude was weird enough to try all this just for her, he probably thinks it was a success,” Shez pointed out, before shrugging, “It's just a good thing Byleth only got knocked out.” 

 

“Yes, I'm happy I didn't hurt her too badly,” Sitri said with a sigh, before glancing at Shez, “Thank you again, for rescuing me.” 

 

“Hey, no need to thank me. I don't even know what I did,” Shez said, remembering how her powers interacted oddly with the umbral beast, “Besides, if I didn't I'm sure everyone else who showed up would have figured something out.” 

 

“Yes, I, uh…certainly didn't expect Byleth to have so many…close friends who showed up to save her,” Sitri muttered, feeling her face heat up, remembering how she came to awareness with nothing but black blood covering her otherwise bare body. Which would have been uncomfortable enough, but the fact that the majority of her rescuers were clearly enamored with her daughter made things that much more awkward. 

 

Fortunately, the other components of the umbral beast waking up seemed to have distracted everyone, particularly that one admittedly well-built young man who declared himself the “Naked King of Grappling!”. He certainly was attention grabbing, for more than one reason.

 

It's a shame he got knocked out by Jeralt for trying to flirt with her, but she had to admit, being swept up in her husband’s arms and carried away by him with his cape for cover was quite nice.

 

“Oh, they’re not just her friends, they’re her girlfriends,” Shez shamelessly stated, earning a sigh from Jeralt.

 

“Shez, don’t tattle on your sister.” 

 

“How is that tattling?” 

 

“Well, I already had an inkling that was the case, but I didn't want to assume,” Sitri said, before glancing at Jeralt, “You have made sure to talk with them, correct?” 

 

“About what?” The captain asked, raising an eyebrow.
