“About making sure none of them break her heart, and to be careful,” Sitri responded with a frown. 

 

“Sitri, she can take care of herself,”

 

“She's just a baby!” 

 

“...She's twenty.” 

 

“That–...no, she is not. My daughter is not the same age as me.”

 

“...so, hey, does this mean I’m officially the older sister?” Shez asked.

 

Rhea paused. “What do you mean ‘officially’?”

 

“Hm? Oh, it’s a whole thing I do with Byleth,” Shez explained, “Basically, since nobody’s sure how old I actually am–”

 

“We’re pretty sure she’s at least two years younger,” Jeralt stated, though Shez ignored him.

 

“–me and Byleth decided to do a thing where I can be the older sister if I beat her in these competitions we have, like taking out the leader of a bandit band or doing more push-ups.”

 

“...so you are not, actually, the older Eisner sister,” Rhea noted, feeling a headache coming on.

 

“Well, no, I guess–Look, clearly I am because Miss Sitri said I am. Right, Miss Sitri?” she asked, turning towards Byleth’s mom, before pausing when she noticed Sitri was staring at her quite intently. “Uh…Miss Sitri?”

 

“Hm…” Sitri stared at her for a few more seconds, before coming to some kind of conclusion and patting the cushion next to her. “Sit here, please.”

 

Shez blinked, then, after a bewildered look towards a nonplussed Jeralt, walked over and sat beside Sitri, who promptly began patting her on the head. “...um–”

 

“You can lay down too if you want.”

 

“Uh, I think I'm good,” Shez said, feeling awkward even if it felt nice. 

 

“Hm, well, I just want you to know, though we have just met, I can tell you care deeply for Byleth. As such, I would like to think of you as my daughter as well, if you are okay with that.” 

 

“Ah…well, just…I'm not going to call you mom, but I guess that isn't bad,” Shez said, looking away with a faintly flustered look.

 

“I'm happy to hear that,” Sitri said, with a smile, before glancing at Rhea, “Well Lady Rhea, I suppose you now officially have two grandchildren.” 

 

Jeralt blinked. “What.” 

 

“Hm? Oh, did I never mention Lady Rhea is my creator?” Sitri asked, looking curiously at her husband, “My apologies, I suppose it never came up.”

 

“…Yeah. I guess it didn’t,” Jeralt echoed, staring pointedly at Rhea.

 

“Wait, why did you say ‘creator’ and not mom?” Shez asked, getting Sitri to stiffen. 

 

“Right, I believe we have a war we need to focus on. Well, several really, and an incident with an entirely different demonic beast. Those are all much more important than focusing too much on the accidental use of one word instead of another,” Rhea said, clapping her hands together in an attempt to move the conversation along. Now hopefully this would be settled quickly and she wouldn’t have to deal with any more nonsense.

Rhea sat on a hill, her legs against her chest as she stared at the merrily burning flames that had engulfed Garreg Mach. It was beautiful, in a strange way, how the flames flickered and danced above the ruin of her life’s work.

 

“...okay, this wasn’t my fault,” Shez stated, also sitting on the hill a little ways away, “I want to make that very clear. You can blame me for the Kingdom exploding, but not for this.”

 

“Doesn't that technically fall on you and Lysithea?” Byleth asked, sitting beside her sister.

 

“Well yeah, but as the Professor I take full blame for it. And even then it's not like we could have known that black water was super flammable.” 

 

Of course they couldn’t, because Rhea had hidden the information on the foul black water and everything related to it. Did that technically make the Kingdom’s destruction her fault?

 

…no. No, the Agarthans are to blame, she mentally decided, before sighing. “I don’t blame you for the monastery burning, Professor Shez. I mostly blame Seteth.”

 

“...yeah, it was kinda his fault,” Shez agreed.

 

“Mostly his,” Byleth echoed, “...Good news though, Edelgard is willing to host us at Enbarr once they get the palace fixed.”

 

“Oh, that’s very kind of–”

 

“You’re only invited if you step down from being archbishop, Rhea.”

 

“...” The problem was, that actually sounded fair at this point. “...is this about the Almyrans?”

 

“It’s not not about them. I think it’s all the other stuff though, like the legion of dragons you kept in the basement.”

 

“They were crest stones when I put them down there–Never mind.” Rhea sighed again, ignoring the distant sounds of screeching and the roar of flames.

 

“Alright sweet, I'll tell my students we're going on a trip to Enbarr.” 

 

“Hm, should we invite Claude? I feel kind of bad for him being the only Golden Deer left.” 

 

Shez shrugged. “Should’ve joined my class when I asked then.”

 

“...he’s the house leader?”

 

“Should’ve joined anyway. Then we could’ve been the Golden Lions. With antlers.”

 

“...why would the lions have antlers?”

 

“To keep the deer part, duh.”

 

“Hm…I'm going to ask Edelgard how big her room is,” Byleth said, getting ready to walk away. 

 

“Still can't believe you became a skirt chaser,” Shez huffed. 

 

“Hm? But I don't hate skirts. They're swishy.” 

 

As the pair of sisters left, Rhea let out a slow sigh. She sat there for a few moments, before pulling out a small bag she kept on her, glad she had gotten her calming herbs when leaving the burning monastery. 

 

Easily lighting the herbs, she sat back, doing her best to enjoy her forced retirement as calmly as she could. 

 

…She still thought this was all Shez’s fault.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Byleth has become an incorrigible flirt, truly the most dangerous timeline of all.

Red: Truly, truly dangerous. At the very least, very dangerous to the virtues of basically the entire student body. It's a wonder Shez was able to even recruit any of them.

Indi: But she did! Sure it might have cost the a good chunk of the Kingdom and Alliance, but she succeeded.

Red: It's fine, if they were important they would've survived.

Indi: And hey, the students survived at least! Granted they might need to stay in Enbarr for awhile till there homes get rebuilt but it's fine.

Red: It's fine, it's fine, it's all good. Also Gilbert died, that's canon.

Indi: And so did Mercedes's dad, so really, no one important.

Red: Really, more people came back to life than died, if we count all the new Nabateans destroying the monastery (and possibly the surrounding region).

Indi: So really, there's no downside. Maybe.

Everything Will Be Okay

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

“Before we begin preparations to leave, I wanted to ask a favor, Byleth,” Rhea asked, approaching the young woman while she sat by the pond. 

 

Byleth sighed, glancing back at the archbishop. “Please don't tell me you want to take Fhirdiad back first.” 

 

“No. I just wanted to visit somewhere with you. We'll be able to return before the day ends,” Rhea explained while Byleth frowned, “There might not be any benefit to seeing how it's faring, but I want to see what is happening at Zanado, and what these ‘Knights of Reclamation’ are planning.” 

 

“Your not the first person that’s brought that up. Shez reminded me that I wanted to go there anyway the other day,” she replied, staring out into the water where the ruined remains of the dock still floated. “We can afford to take a detour. It would probably be better to have more soldiers too, which we can get if we recruit those knights.”

 

“Hm. You think they will join us that readily?”

 

“I don’t see why they wouldn’t. Apparently they revere me, and most of them were Knights of Seiros before, right?”

 

“And the rest of them are turncoats from the army that invaded Garreg Mach,” Rhea pointed out, “While I would like to believe that they would be stalwart allies and that whatever forces of mine joined them are still loyal, I hope you can understand why I have some concerns.”

 

“I guess. You are kind of a pessimist when it comes to people.”

 

“I've had enough experience with people to default to pessimism.” 

 

“Hm. So, do you want to go now? If we take my wyvern we could return before dinner.” 

 

“The sooner the better. We should probably inform Catherine and Dimitri before we leave though, lest a panic be caused by our disappearance.” 

 

“Hopefully they're on the way to the stables,” Byleth muttered, getting up and leading the way to where the mounts were kept. Though as they passed by the main gate where the market once stood, they heard a commotion, a guard shouting something she couldn't quite make out. “Hm. One moment.”

 

“Byleth? What is it?”

 

Byleth ignored her, her brow furrowed as she headed towards the gates. Something in the air was raising her hackles, and before long she felt a shiver go up her spine at the smell of blood.

 

“–brought her up here as quickly as possible, now go get a healer and quickly!” Alois ordered the gate guard, who rushed to obey his command, before he paused at the sight of Byleth’s approach. “Professor, quickly, you know healing magic, right?” 

 

“Who's hurt?” Byleth asked, quickly moving over, before coming to a halt as she saw who was being carried. 

 

In a different situation, she would have been happy to see someone from her mercenary group. However, she could feel nothing but dread when she saw Candace, blood soaked and unconscious. Arrows littered her body, and where her right arm once was, there was now a bandaged stump. 

 

She was over at her side in an instant, pressing her hands against Candace as white light glowed from her palms and flowed into the blonde’s wounds. 

 

“Take the arrows out as I heal her, we can’t let the wounds heal over them,” she instructed, and Alois got to work without hesitation or complaint. Candace made some faint, pained noises while Byleth worked, prompting a small grimace from the professor. “I know, I’m sorry for hurting you. I promise it will feel better soon. You’ll be okay.”

 

The words were more to reassure herself than Candace, who was too out of it to even register the meaning if she could even hear them. Byleth could feel a sense of worry gnawing a pit in her stomach, familiar enough that she could recognize it immediately. If Candace, one of her father’s lieutenants, was this wounded, what did it mean for Jeralt? Were they in some kind of battle? Was he okay? If he was, why wasn’t he here? If he wasn’t…

 

“Everything will be okay,” Byleth murmured. She wasn’t sure if she believed it.

The Academy’s infirmary had been one of the casualties of the invasion years ago, smashed to pieces by one of the falling meteors, so the church’s forces had set up a tent for any wounded out in the courtyard. That was where Shez hurried the instant she heard about Candace being brought in.

 

She couldn't get close, since Candace was still resting, but she could see the wounded mercenary laying in bed. 

 

“...What happened?” 

 

“I don't know. We were on patrol, and we saw her riding up. I don't even think she was aware of where she was or where she was going with how much blood she lost,” Alois explained, frowning deeply. 

 

“Whoever she was facing, they were using the same weapons as the Death Knight who attacked the professor way back when,” Manuela informed, hearing their conversation as she continued looking over Candace, “Which certainly didn't help with healing her.” 

 

“Wait, so an Agarthan went after her?” Shez asked, frowning too, “Was she attacked? Did she get into a fight with them or what?”

 

“We don’t know yet,” Alois replied, rubbing his chin with furrowed brows, “If I had to guess, from where the arrows hit her, she was fleeing a group of attackers, perhaps seeking aid from her allies?”

 

“So…wait, was she already close? Because if she wound up here, then she had to be in riding distance or she would’ve died from her wounds, right?”

 

“That seems likely…given where we met her on our patrol, it's likely she was coming from somewhere north of the monastery, so perhaps she was fighting someone in the kingdom?” 

 

“Why would she be in the Kingdom? Last I heard, Jeralt was in the Empire.” 

 

“We can figure that out later. What matters is making sure she's okay,” Manuela said as she let out a huff, “Speaking of, where is the professor?” 

 

“Rhea took her somewhere, said it would help take her mind off things,” Shez replied as she huffed as well, her arms crossed over her chest, “It's probably for the best that she is keeping busy.” Then a thought occurred. “Actually, hang on…where’d she actually take her?”

 

“Er…wouldn’t you know that?”

 

“She didn’t mention…shit, wait, I think they were going north.” 

 

“Oh, I wonder if they went to Zanado?” Alois commented.

 

Shez stared at him, then promptly warped away, traveling northward as quickly as possible while muttering as many curses as she could think of towards the stupid archbishop who seemed to absolutely refuse to leave well enough alone. Then those curses got a great deal louder when she heard roaring in the distance.

 

The Red Canyon of Zanado was named as such for the tale of a slaughter that took place within it over a millennia ago, where blood flowed so heavily that the very stones turned red. Now, the Red Canyon was dyed crimson once more as humans and beasts alike bled in ruby rivers.

 

“He was here,” Arval muttered in Shez’s mind, making her stiffen as she stood at the cliff edge overlooking the canyon, “Your so-called twin…and there, there’s your sister.”

 

Shez looked where he pointed and scowled at the sight of some massive monsters trying to eat her sister. Trying and failing, luckily, as Byleth moved quickly and carved deep wounds in their dark flesh, all while using light magic to hold off any that tried to take advantage while she was fighting. She was still very outnumbered though, so of course it was up to Shez to even the odds by warping up above one of the bigger beasts and letting gravity add some momentum as she swung straight down with both her swords.

 

Demonic beasts had tough hides at the best of times, to the point that Shez was pretty sure they had some kind of magic barrier that needed to be broken before they could actually be hurt. Luckily for her though, these weren’t fresh beasts set up to guard a castle; most of them were already bloodied and torn up by the knights they’d been trying to kill, to the point that she could see spears and arrows impaling those thick scales of theirs. 

 

All that to say, when she swung, she cut deep into the beast’s neck, splitting through muscle, sinew, and even bone as its pained roars cut off without another sound.

 

“That’s one for me,” she said, sparing a grin at Byleth before she let the magic of her awakened form flow through her body and sprinted into the fray.

 

She didn’t see it, but she would be very amused to know her sister gave her an annoyed frown and a quiet “Hmph.” before running in to join her.

 

Though Shez was actually way more focused on fighting off the monsters than playing along with the silly competition she started, especially since there still seemed to be people in the canyon that needed help judging by the sounds of fighting up ahead. And one of those people happened to be Rhea, who was currently attempting to ward off a winged, white beast with a spear. 

 

“There you are! What were you thinking bringing Byleth here!?” Shez shouted as she slashed at the strangely colored beast. Letting out a pained roar, the creature tried to slam its hind claws down on her, but she easily flashed back out of range. 

 

“Don't hurt them!” Rhea shouted, looking over more panicked than she did a moment ago. 

 

“What?? Why wouldn't I!?”

 

“I'll explain as soon as we subdue them!” Rhea shouted back, before dodging a tail strike from the beast. 

 

“Wh–And how the hell are we gonna do that!?” Shez yelled, warping away as the white beast tried to blast her with a beam of light from its mouth, “We can’t exactly pin down the regular demonic beasts, how are we supposed to deal with this thing?!”

 

“I don’t know, but we can’t kill them! Please, child!”

 

Shez blinked at the actual desperation in Rhea’s voice, then sighed and glanced at Arval. “You got anything?”

 

“Hm…subduing an enemy combatant–No, subduing a monster…” they murmured, thinking, before Shez felt a sudden rush of symbols in her brain. “Something like that?”

 

“Woah…we’re gonna need to figure out how many things I actually know how to do now,” Shez decided, because between her mom’s notes and Epimenides’s lingering knowledge, it felt like she was in genuine danger of becoming some kind of super intelligent mage person, and it would be way too weird for her to suddenly switch up her entire style like that. Though maybe Lysithea would like it? She’d probably be into all sorts of magic stuff–

 

“Focus,” Arval spoke up.

 

“Right, focusing.” Shez took a breath, then promptly warped on top of the white beast’s head, in between its huge horns. She felt it buck beneath her, the monster immediately detecting the weight on its head and trying to fight her off, only for her to press her hand against its head, directly on the strange flesh of its body. 

 

Where regular demonic beasts had thick, leathery hides that reminded Shez of tightly bound bandages up close, the white beast looked like its body was made up of vines, thickly corded into a vaguely wyvern-ish shape. The comparison continued with how these big things had wings instead of forelegs, which would make the next part trickier, but Shez was nothing if not willing to adapt to tricky circumstances.

 

So with one hand pressed to the beast’s head, she spoke one simple word. “Tartarus.”

 

And in an instant, the monster’s body went rigid, its limbs locking up as it suddenly crashed to the ground. The beast twitched and its wings flared, the momentary robbery of its limb control fading in an instant as the divine magic coursing through it pushed out the darkness that sought to bring it low, only for Rhea to suddenly place her own hand against the beast’s head.

 

“I am not your foe,” she stated, her eyes sad as the beast beneath her stilled, its empty eyes unfocused. The beast seemed to no longer struggle, letting Shez drop the spell she was holding. With its new freedom, the beast looked around, as if unaware of where it was. “It's okay. You will be okay once more.” 

 

“When everything here gets settled, you better tell us everything. You're not getting out of this, got it?” Shez stated, staring at Rhea. 

 

“...Of course,” Rhea replied, sounding far too tired. Shaking her head to clear some of that exhaustion, she looked around. “Where is Byleth? We were separated.” 

 

“Ah, she’s somewhere around here, probably saving people and healing the wounded,” Shez replied, before pausing as a demonic beast’s head abruptly landed on the ground nearby, its tongue hanging out of its bloodied mouth. “...or she’s carving through all the monsters around. Oh, actually, one sec!”

 

Shez warped away from Rhea, glancing around the battlefield for a moment before she spotted her sister leaping up and splitting a flying beast straight in half. She whistled, impressed, before cupping her hands around her mouth to project her voice. “HEY BY! RHEA SAYS NOT TO KILL THE WHITE ONES! SHE HAS SOME KIND OF THING WITH THEM!”

 

“UNDERSTOOD!” her sister shouted back, immediately turning to strike at the next nearest beast, “HOW MANY ARE THERE?”

 

“Oh, good question. Rhea, how many are there?”

 

“Ah…potentially five to seven, though there may be more if the mutation has a different factor to it than I presume.”

 

“Right, that might make this tricky…any chance you know of a handy way to help take them down easily?”

 

Rhea sighed. “Shez, it isn’t going to be that convenient–”

 

“Agarthan sorcery detected.” Then both of them paused as a large, golden golem with a lion on its chest poked its head up from where it had been lying, seemingly broken, on the ground and turned its gaze straight towards Shez. “Priority One: Extermination of demons set to Priority Two. New Priority One Established: Elimination of Agarthan Sorcerer–”

 

“Hey, wait a sec, I know you!” Shez interrupted, her brief confusion turning to elation once she recognized the ‘giant lion lady’, “Marcelle! Hey, how’s it been?”

 

The golem actually paused in the middle of pushing itself up. “...Priority One set to Primary Directive: Eliminate Agarthan–”

 

“No, no, do not set that as your directive!” Rhea interrupted, putting a hand on Shez’s shoulder and moving her out of the way. Or, to be more exact, shoving her off her feet. “Marcelle, Shez is not an enemy, she’s on our side!”

 

“Could’ve told her that without shoving me,” Shez grumbled as she got up from the ground.

 

“Mark her as an ally and do not take any steps to harm her! Understood?”

 

“Authority Recognized. Response Formulated: Greetings, Saint Seiros. Directive Requested.”

 

Rhea sighed in some relief, before fixing the golden golem with a serious gaze. “Relay the following instructions to all the other golems present within Zanado. The chief priority for our forces is to keep the remaining humans within the canyon safe. The entities called demonic beasts should be eliminated with all due haste, but it is a secondary priority to keeping the people here, humans and nabateans, safe from these monsters. And along with that, I want all of you to avoid engaging with the white, wyvern-like beasts. They need to be subdued nonlethally.”

 

“Instructions received, new directives established, new objectives established. Parameters set.” The golem immediately turned around, steam releasing from its body in large plumes before it launched a beam of light that blasted one of the flying beasts out of the sky.

 

“Oh wow. How the hell did these guys lose with these ladies helping them out?” Shez wondered, glancing at Rhea.

 

“They might be strong, but they can still be overwhelmed,” Rhea stated, taking a moment to catch her breath, “That and they tend to have one track minds. They wouldn’t have dealt well with a sudden ambush, which is what this disaster seems to have been.“ 

 

“Yeah, I guess that makes sense. These guys wouldn’t have known how to deal with…” Shez trailed off.

 

“Hm? What is it?”

 

“I…h-hang on.” Shez mumbled, before heading over towards a body on the ground. Something about the rough, dull leather of his clothes caught her attention amidst all the bloodied whites and blues, and she felt a lump form in her throat when she recognized the bald head and bearded face, marred by what looked like a blade cleaving straight through it. “...ah.”

 

She took a small breath, then crouched beside Victor’s body. It’d been years since she’d seen the rowdy mercenary with a bald head and big belly, his rough features almost always graced by a grin for one dumb reason or another. Usually because of some argument he thought he won with Ezra.

 

Judging by the dried blood and the flies buzzing around, he’d been killed maybe a day ago. Maybe less. Too late to help him.

 

“...is he someone you knew?” Rhea asked, her voice somber as she looked over Shez’s shoulder.

 

“Yeah. He’s the guy who taught me how to play cards. Uncle Victor.” She took another breath, shakier this time. “I thought…I knew things could’ve gone bad, but I thought…”

 

“You never believed the next time you would see him, he would be dead.”

 

“Yeah. Yeah…hm. This was done by a blade, not a beast. The arrows in Candace would make sense if they had archers at a distance, but someone getting up this close while a bunch of demonic beasts were rampaging has to be a ballsy bastard…” Shaking her head, she looked off towards where Byleth was finishing off another beast. “...Can you keep an eye on him for a moment? I…I need to make sure Byleth is prepared for this.” 

 

“Of course, child.” Rhea nodded to Shez and watched while she left, before letting out a sigh as she turned back towards the bloodied canyon. Not for the first time, she began to wonder if her former homeland had become a cursed place, rather than a blessed one. To see it become the site of another massacre…it hurt. It truly, truly did.

 

The white beast that had once been one of her loyal cardinals let out a soft, mournful noise as it lowered its snout to her, reacting to her sorrow. She returned its sympathy with a sad sigh of her own, before petting the beast as best she could, its thorny surface making it difficult to get close without injury.

 

She could accept some injury though, if it meant providing comfort to one of the few who had stood by her for so very long.

 

“I swear, I will avenge you,” Rhea stated, ignoring the way the thorns pricked and cut at her hand, “You and all others who died in this place. I will find whoever did this…and I will end them.”

The Principality of Hrym. A name that carried with it a sting of betrayal and grudges harkening back decades, centuries, and millennia. A bloodied land of mountains and wetlands, its place between the Airmid River and Pearl Sea made it at once both valuable to hold onto, yet almost impossible to cultivate properly.

 

Centuries had been spent attempting to make something of worth in these sodden lands that had once traded hands between several different houses. Once upon a time, it had even belonged to the vaunted House Ordelia, though the formation of the Alliance ensured it would never belong to them again. 

 

The Empire could not stand to have traitors within its borders, after all, and so the land became Hrym, named for the viscomital house that took ownership of it.

 

Of course, House Hrym never knew the true reason for why every venture to make something of their land failed miserably. Forts sinking into the marshes as they were built, mines collapsing before anything of worth could be found, miseries and tragedies alike, all chalked up to the seeming reality that the environment was simply unsuitable for any true ambitions, and not to sabotage.

 

No one ever truly considered that there would be those lurking deep in the dark that saw this land as theirs, and were ruthless in ruining any who came close to taking it.

 

Now though, those who once slithered deep below stood tall and arrogant, displaying for one and all the proud cruelty of the Agarthan people.

 

“Dear goddess, what is that monstrosity?!” questioned Archduke Ludwig von Aegir, the nominal leader of the principality, as he stared down from the balcony overlooking Castle Hrym’s courtyard.

 

“Isn’t it obvious? It’s our new weapon,” answered his nominal advisor, the sage called Myson, whose bearded face held a truly vile smile as he rested his hands on the balcony’s railing, “Meet the Typhon, your grace. Or as you may prefer to call it, a giant demonic beast.”

 

Ludwig gripped the railing, squeezing down on the stone in an attempt to steady his nerves. The monster down in the courtyard truly was gigantic, far larger than any of the beasts his “advisor” had crafted before. Its body was a mix of fat and bulky, its black, bandage-patterned flesh bulging beneath the chains that held it down while figures in black clothes and bird masks examined its hulking physique. “...are those eyes on its throat?”

 

“Oh my, you have some truly impressive eyes of your own to notice that detail, Ludwig,” Myson praised, sounding surprisingly genuine, “Yes, it seems to be a way for the Typhon to compensate for its otherwise limited field of vision. Unlike the quadrupedal Ladon, the Typhon is bipedal, so the eyes will allow it to notice anything that might get too close beneath it. Clever, don’t you think?”

 

“...that thing can walk on two legs?”

 

“Of course. You can, after all.” Ludwig gave him an incredulous look there, but Myson paid no attention, his shadowed eyes still on the beast. “The important part is getting it outfitted properly. A proper helm and some gauntlets will make it all the more formidable, and to a far greater degree than its cousins. Doesn’t it just make you want to test it out?”

 

Honestly, Ludwig would prefer to never have to see a beast like this one ever again, but he felt like that would be the wrong answer here. Especially since Myson actually turned to him.

 

“Do you know of any close villages that aren’t necessary for our cause? I would prefer we do not destroy anything vital during the testing phase.”

 

Ludwig couldn’t immediately come up with an answer for that question, in large part because any unnecessary villages had already been used up for the Agarthan’s testing over the past few years. And while he wasn’t one of those bleeding hearts that would argue for the nonexistent value of peasant lives, even he could piece together that they were really cutting into Hrym’s labor force with all of these experiments.

 

Thankfully for him, he was saved from having to bring that up thanks to the arrival of an Agarthan warlock. “Lord Myson, the Liberator, Lord Dolofonos, and Lady Bias have arrived to give their reports.”

 

“Oh, excellent, I was wondering how things were going. Come along, Ludwig. You may as well hear how the war is going.”

 

Ludwig grimaced at the Agarthan’s irreverence. He was the archduke of the principality, and yet this lunatic treated him more like a pet than an ally! It was Ludwig von Aegir that gave this endeavor even the slightest hint of legitimacy, and yet everyone here looked down on him! It was infuriating!

 

He still followed after Myson though, trailing only slightly behind him as the mad mage led the way to the castle’s war room. It wouldn’t do to be uninformed about his so-called allies' insane schemes. He might not be able to control the Agarthans like he once did, but Ludwig could hopefully curb their worst instincts so he’d actually have a nation to rule by the time this war was over.

 

The treasonous duke felt himself tense once he entered the lounge, his shoulders bunching up at the sight of the worst of the Agarthans he was forced to interact with. Fortunately for him, Bias didn’t bother looking at him, instead keeping her eyes on some type of warped crest stone in her hand. It was for the best; he could still smell the burning flesh from the last time the witch had “assisted” his forces.

 

Unfortunately for him, another one of the worst did notice him.

 

“Greetings, Lord Myson and Duke Ludwig,” Dolofonos greeted, standing and bowing to his superior before nodding to Ludwig. For some reason, the deranged assassin thought the two of them were friends after he’d set Ludwig free from his cell those years ago and Ludwig…well, he wasn’t about to correct the man in case it somehow constituted an offense warranting execution. 

 

He’d seen what the “Blood Sage” could do with those knives when he was in a foul mood.

 

“Archduke, remember?” Myson corrected as he moved over to sit in the chair at the “head” of the lounge table, “Our beloved ally is independent from the Hegemon and we need to keep that in mind.”

 

“Of course. I intended no offense, Archduke Ludwig.”

 

It took Ludwig a moment to notice the lunatic’s gaze was expectant. “...ah, yes, no offense taken, Sir Dolofonos.” Then, to be polite, he continued. “How did your…mission go?”

 

“Well, thank you for asking.” He reached into a pouch at his side and drew a black flute that made Ludwig’s skin crawl to look at it. “The ‘Demon’s Lure’ proved effective at corralling the ladons and delphons, though it seems to have a deleterious effect on them overall. They appeared to be even more berserk than usual and they failed to follow any further commands after being unleashed into the enemy encampment.”

 

“Interesting,” Myson mused, stroking his beard thoughtfully, “Not a complete success then…to be clear, those church remnants were still wiped out, correct?”

 

“Of course, Lord Myson. Though our younger operative nearly let one get away,” Dolofonos stated with a small frown towards the masked Agarthan seated beside him, who chuckled at the chiding.

 

“Aw, sorry about that. It wasn’t that bad though, right? I got the beast’s arm, and you had those archers head after her, so odds are, she’s dead anyway,” the young man said with a careless amusement that Ludwig was surprised to see. Most Agarthans, while arrogant and dismissive in general, were very deferential to their superiors, from what he’d seen.

 

Now if only they considered Ludwig a proper superior, as they should, and not just some pet of their masters…

 

“The escapee is likely dead, yes, but she shouldn’t have come close to escaping to begin with,” Dolofonos chided, before looking back at Myson, “Not only that, but the operative failed in his mission to secure the monastery.”

 

“Hey now, don’t say it like that,” the young man complained, “I had the monastery plenty secure! It's not my fault the beasts I were given were incompetent.” 

 

“Yes, my apologies for that, I'm afraid we've had our hands quite full here,” Myson responded, as he examined his creation, “I must say, you don't seem to put off about it.” 

 

“Well, I did have quite an interesting fight. Though before I talk about that,” He glanced over to Bias with a pout, “Why didn't you tell me she could also stop time?” 

 

“Excuse me?” The Agarthan responded, looking up from the warped crest stone. 

 

“You know, the Fell Star. You told me about her time reversal, not her time stop.” 

 

“...I was unaware she could do such a thing,” Bias stated, a frown evident through her veil. 

 

“Hm? I must say, it's quite interesting that you don't sound surprised to hear she's alive, Bias,” Myson remarked, regarding his subordinate with an inscrutable expression, “Is there any reason why you didn’t report the Fell Star’s survival immediately to our forces?”

 

“I was busy.”

 

“Hm. With what?”

 

“Figuring out some things that relate to my personal project. You remember the enhancements you gave Kyrie, right?”

 

“Ah, so that’s her heart then,” Myson noted, ignoring the way Ludwig grimaced at that piece of information, “I was wondering. May I have a look?”

 

Bias tossed the stone–the heart–to him with a disturbing casualness. “Careful there. You wouldn’t want to break the poor thing.”

 

“Yes, I’ll be careful…you should have reported the Fell Star’s return.”

 

“No need to chide me. You know now, so is it really a problem?”

 

“Hm. I must admit, Bias. I am beginning to doubt your commitment to our cause. Letting Kyrie die, failing to report the Fell Star’s return…there’s not much incentive for me to uphold my end of our deal if you aren’t upholding yours.”

 

“You wanted my service, I’m serving you properly,” Bias bit out, her anger growing. Ludwig winced to see the upholstery beginning to smolder beneath her hand.

 

“Are you really? Why is the Fell Star causing us problems then?”

 

“Because her bitch of a sister is hanging around too! In case you didn’t notice, it’s hard enough dealing with one of them, but both at once is bullshit.”

 

“Hey now, there’s no need to be mean, Lady Bias,” the young man complained, “That’s my sister you’re talking about too.”

 

“Oh don’t give me that!” she snapped, pointing at the masked man, “You can’t tell me your ‘papa’ really managed to make a functional, adult clone in less than a fucking year! Either he’s taking credit for something that already existed, or there’s more to you than you’re saying, you damn mutant.”

 

The boy just laughed at that. “Ah, you’re always so harsh, Lady Bias. But I like that about you.” He chuckled, before looking at Myson. “Hey, Papa Myson, you mind letting her off this time? I got a nice test of my own abilities out of those two showing up, and who really cares if they took the monastery?”

 

“Wait, what?” Ludwig interrupted, a look of alarm crossing his face, “You let the enemy retake the monastery!? Do you realize how dangerous that is?! Now they have a rallying point right in the center of Fodlan!”

 

“...” The boy tilted his head, the action disturbingly birdlike given his mask. “...who’re you?”

 

“Wh–How do you not know who I am?!”

 

“I introduced Duke Ludwig earlier,” Dolofonos stated, giving his younger comrade an unimpressed look.

 

“Archduke,” Myson reminded as though it were an afterthought.

 

“Oh, he's one of those beasts you're keeping around? Hm, he doesn't like he'd be useful for much though…” 

 

“Now, now, there's no need to be rude to him. He is still our ally, isn't that right, Archduke?”

 

Ludwig grimaced, but nodded. It rankled at his pride to be so obedient to these…creatures, but he hadn’t gotten where he was in life by being a fool. One way or another, he was going to survive the Agarthans’ machinations and Edelgard’s fury, and find a way to come out on top!

 

“Excellent. Sit by Bias, if you would.”

 

…eh? “Er, what was that?”

 

Myson glanced at him. “There’s an open spot next to her. It would be awkward if you were standing this entire time, wouldn’t it? So go ahead, sit.”

 

“...ah, well, there's no need to worry about my comfort! I am perfectly capable of standing for this meeting.”

 

“I insist.”

 

And so, he sat, trying his best to ignore the uncomfortable amounts of heat he could feel coming off the seething woman beside him.

 

“Now then, why don’t we discuss our next steps?” Myson decided, turning back to the group while rolling the stone around in his hand, “Bias, you seem to need some positive feedback to actually do your job properly, so I’ll thank you for bringing this stone back and use the information it grants me to progress with your reward. In exchange…Ludwig, name a city we would want burned.”

 

Ludwig paused. “...an entire city?”

 

“I did say that, didn’t I?”

 

“You did, Papa Myson!” agreed the strange boy, prompting a nod from Myson.

 

“As I thought. You see, the issue in front of us, Ludwig, is that we’ve enjoyed our stalemate with the hegemon for some years now. She attempts to make progress, we push her back, so on, so forth. But if she has the Fell Star and the Failed Vessel to tip the scales in her favor, then we need to make appropriate steps to ensure she can’t break this deadlock of ours. And while my predecessor may have had more options for causing mass destruction, I have found that Bias makes for a decent enough substitute.” He grinned. “Thales never managed to burn the monastery, after all.”

 

“I…see,” Ludwig responded, his mind racing, “Couldn’t we direct Lady Bias towards the monastery then? That is where our enemies are gathering.”

 

“No, I would prefer not to risk her on something like that. There’s too high a chance she would let her grudge get the better of her and die stupidly to the Fell Star.”

 

“I’m right here,” Bias groused.

 

“I know, and I’m not wrong. You know that.”

 

She grunted, but said nothing more.

 

“Just think about it, Ludwig. I’ll be back to you in a moment,” Myson stated, before looking at his subordinates. “Dolofonos, we’ll want to deal with the hegemon sooner rather than later now. Going after her directly is going to be a risk and while I am loath to waste all those years of work, removing her from play is a better move than letting her continue to lead the enemy.”

 

“I understand, Lord Myson,” Dolofonos said, bowing his head, “She’ll be dealt with immediately.”

 

“Aw, that really does feel like a waste,” the masked man complained, sinking back in his seat with his arms crossed over his chest, “Are you sure we can’t find some way to use her better than just killing her off? Maybe brainwash her or something?”

 

“Thales had some ideas on that subject,” Myson noted, “They were all remarkably stupid though. Very poorly thought out.” He tilted his head, thinking. “Hm…the best idea that could work would ultimately reduce her to a rampaging beast, but by that point, she’d be more useful dead anyway. Our best case scenario would be retrieving her corpse for further use.”

 

“Fine, fine, I get it.” The boy leaned forward with sudden, obvious eagerness. “So do I get to go along for this, Papa Myson?”

 

“Hm…why not? You do need more field experience, and I would like to see how you measure up to our previous project. You have my permission to kill her, Sigma.”

 

“Ah, that reminds me. I decided on a new name.” The boy lifted his mask, showing off a grinning face. “Call me Shax.”

 

“That’s an awful name,” Bias bluntly stated.

 

“Aw, come on Lady Bias! I thought it was good!”

 

“Because you’re a stupid brat.” She glanced at Myson. “Why not just send me with these two? Burning down the Imperial Army would be just as good as destroying some random city.”

 

“No, it wouldn’t be. I want this attack to be two-pronged, Bias. What is it worth to me if you kill a thousand soldiers who have already lost the head leading them? No, I want to make the remaining beasts submit. I want to remind them that they live and die at our leisure.” His grin grew into a bloodthirsty smile, and Ludwig felt himself shiver at the sight of the mad cruelty in the warlock’s yellow eyes. “So then, Ludwig, my dear friend…I hope you have an appropriate target in mind.”

 

The archduke shifted in his seat and tugged at his collar, trying to cool himself down. He could feel sweat starting to soak into his clothes and he wasn’t sure if it was just because of the heat. “I, ah…w-well, I, er, imagine…”

 

“What about the capital?” Dolofonos proposed when Ludwig trailed off, “Our territory here is essentially the capital of the Principality, and we do not need two capitals.”

 

“Not a bad idea, but one that runs the risk of running into trouble,” Myson pointed out, “Edelgard will be by the capital, after all, and if we try to have her killed while also having Enbarr burned, the two missions may conflict with one another. No, I would prefer a target that holds value, but will be… softer. Easier to ruin.”

 

“Not a necessary target then,” Bias remarked, raising an eyebrow.

 

“No, it might actually be better if the strategic importance was minimal. We’re looking for an act of cruelty, not pragmatism. And besides, we’re already going to be destroying the Bridge of Myrddin.”

 

“H-Hold on a moment, what was that?” Ludwig asked, paling despite the heat. “You–The Bridge of Myrddin is one of our most important routes to the Alliance–”

 

“And with Ordelia territory taken from us, all it presents is an avenue for attack from the north,” Myson countered, “I don’t need trade partners, Ludwig. Any asset we can’t use is a liability. You would do well to understand that. Now name a city, or we’ll have to see if Boramas will suffice as a new testing ground.”

 

Ludwig flinched at the suggestion. The idea of burning his own home city–or worse, leaving it to this madman’s machinations–made him recoil. He already knew Myson wouldn’t accept an argument, the man clearly wanted to destroy a city purely for the sake of it.

 

So, with a heavier heart than he expected, he took a breath, and in one word condemned thousands to a painful death. It’s your own fault, Hevring. You should have stayed loyal, you damned fool. “Mozghuz.”

 

Myson chuckled. “Mozghuz then.” He turned his gaze towards Bias. “You heard him, Bias.

 

“Burn it to the ground.”

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Plans are being made!

Red: Evil plans! Good plans! Plans of vengeance!

Indi: Man we really need to start going easy on our protags huh? Maybe soon.

Red: Maybe! Gotta build up the bad guys before they start to lose.

Indi: As for when that starts happening, well you'll hopefully see soon enough!

Time to Get Moving

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Byleth was quiet on the way back to the monastery. It kind of reminded Shez of those early years when she first joined up with Jeralt’s Mercenaries, when her future sister barely talked or emoted at all.

 

Though, that wasn’t quite accurate. This time, Byleth’s eyes were red from tears, and she sniffled when Shez gave her a hug.

 

“You gonna be okay?” Shez asked, checking her over.

 

“Yeah…I will be. I didn’t think…I thought everyone would be okay.” She took a shaky breath. “...m-maybe if I go back–”

 

“We don’t know when he died, By. It looked like it’d been more than a day and you know that’s your limit.”

 

“Mm. Still, maybe if we went together, we could make it in time?”

 

It hurt to hear her sound hopeful. She’d probably come up with a dozen arguments for how they could have done something to help if Shez let her, so instead Shez just gave her sister a hug. “It’s not your fault.”

 

“...” Byleth returned the hug, squeezing her tightly.

 

After a moment, once she felt Byleth start to pull away, Shez pulled back. “Alright, you visit Candace, I’ll handle all the planning stuff. You leave it to your big sister, okay?”

 

“...you’re younger than me,” Byleth pointed out, unimpressed.

 

“But I’m still taller,” Shez retorted, grinning.

 

“Fine, you're the baby big sister.” 

 

“...I’m willing to accept that because it means I win. Also, never call me that in front of any of our friends.”

 

“I disrespectfully decline because I know you’ll call me the tiny older sister the first chance you get.”

 

“...hm. Well I probably wouldn’t have because I didn’t think of that until you said it, oh tiny elderly one.”

 

Byleth squinted at her sister. Shez returned the “glare” with a fierce one of her own, though she couldn’t stop herself from grinning, at least a little bit. Then the somber mood hit them again and they both slumped with a small sense of guilt at feeling cheerful after a tragedy. 

 

“Just…tell Candace I say hi if she wakes up while you’re there,” Shez requested, earning a nod and then another hug from Byleth, before the elder of the Eisners peeled away from her younger sister and headed over to the infirmary tent while Shez went over to Rhea’s impromptu war room, which was currently set up in the courtyard in between the classrooms.

 

It was mostly just a fancy table with a map and some chairs, plus an overhang to keep the weather from messing anything up. Not that fancy, but it was the best they had while the monastery was being cleared out and fixed up.

 

“Shez,” Dimitri greeted at her approach, nodding solemnly to her, “You have my condolences for your uncle’s death. I did not realize Captain Jeralt had a brother among his forces, but I am sure you were close–”

 

“He’s not my dad’s brother,” Shez replied.

 

“Oh. I see, I didn’t realize your mother–”

 

“Honorary uncle, Dimitri.”

 

“Ah, of course. I imagine Lady Rhea would have mentioned it if she had a son.”

 

“...yeah, probably,” she responded, trying to follow the prince’s logic. Does he think Missus Sitri is my mom, or does he think my mom is Rhea’s daughter? Either way, I think he forgot Byleth and I aren’t blood related…eh, whatever. “So, what’s everyone over here thinking about? Still arguing about whether you’re gonna go north or south?”

 

“We need to figure out our next course of action,” Catherine stated, frowning, “The attack on the knights in the canyon is proof we can’t just keep waiting around. Our enemy isn’t about to just sit back and let us do whatever we want without responding.”

 

“Yeah, okay, I get that. So we should go to the Empire first since there’s active fighting going on down there.”

 

That earned frowns from all the Faerghans around the table, aside from Yuri who let out an amused noise. “You would think, but his highness disagrees.”

 

“Look, I get that, but we just found someone close to us dead and another near death,” Shez pointed out, “Even if you guys end up agreeing to head to the Kingdom, there's no way Byleth is risking staying away from our dad and her class any longer.” 

 

“And I understand that, but we must take the greater scope into consideration,” Dimitri argued, “As it stands, the Empire hasn't fallen to the rebelling forces while the Kingdom is in much more dire straits.” 

 

Shez sighed, pinching the bridge of her nose. “...alright, fuck it, how about this? Me, Byleth, and whoever else wants to go are going to the Empire to fix the problems there, and you guys can keep doing what you were doing before, just with more back up. You’ve managed to last three years like this, you can wait a couple months for us to clean up the Empire.”

 

“I doubt it will take only a few months–”

 

“Yeah and how long is it going to take to beat your asshole uncle, huh? We’re not going to the kingdom while our dad is in danger, that’s it. The rest of this shit, you guys can figure it out, but Byleth and me are going to meet up with our dad and then we’re going to fix the Empire. End of discussion.”

 

“Well we could try to discuss it further,” Yuri offered, a small smile playing on his face as he raised his hands in surrender at Shez’s immediate glare, “Alright, alright, no need to get testy with us. You have your priorities and we have ours. I just think you should carefully consider what will do the most good for the most people. Don’t you?”

 

Shez frowned, then actually considered the suggestion. “The most good…oh shit, you’re right!”

 

“Oh goodie. Care to tell me what I’m right about?”

 

“The Sword of the Creator! That’ll be the best weapon to have for taking down all our enemies! I gotta go grab that thing!”

 

“Wait, what–” Dimitri began right before Shez warped away without another word, the mercenary already completely set on her completely sensible new plan.

Byleth pushed her way into the infirmary tent with a small frown, one that deepened when she saw Candace still sleeping steadily in bed. The blonde mercenary looked peaceful while she rested, but the bandages covering her body were more than enough evidence of how close she’d come to dying. How close she’d also come to dying.

 

“Oh, hello Byleth,” Manuela greeted with a smile by Candace’s bedside, though it faltered once she saw her fellow professor’s expression, “What’s wrong? Do we have someone else that needs medical attention, or…?”

 

“No. Sorry. It’s too late for that.”

 

“Oh. Oh, I’m sorry.”

 

“Mm. Thank you. It’s…I feel like I should do something more. That maybe, if I just went back–”

 

“You shouldn’t think like that,” Manuela chided, frowning, “We can’t change the past.”

 

I can, Byleth thought but didn’t say. Shez wasn’t wrong though, the chances that she could go back and get there in time to save Victor were nonexistent at this point. It felt…wrong not to try though. She’d already used the divine pulse a few times, mostly in that fight with Shax, but if she pushed things–

 

“Hey, don’t get lost in your own head over there,” Manuela said, drawing Byleth’s attention back to her, “Hm…why don’t you sit? I’m sure your friend would appreciate the company.”

 

“...okay.” And with that, Byleth sat by Candace’s bedside. She wasn’t sure what she was supposed to do in this situation. Maybe just wait? But waiting led to her eyes lingering on Candace’s injuries, and she couldn’t help but stare at the stump where the blonde’s arm once was.

 

“Sorry to say it, but I think my career as a musician is over before it began…” came a raspy voice that made Byleth immediately straighten, her eyes going wide as she looked right at Candace. The blonde smiled over at her captain’s kid, her eyes half open and heavy with exhaustion. “Mornin’ Byleth…you look like somebody died.”

 

“...that’s a terrible joke, Candace.”

 

“Mm, yeah, I figured.” She sighed, laying back on her pillows and staring up at the ceiling. “Victor didn’t make it then.”

 

“No. I’m sorry.”

 

“Ah, it happens. It’s a shame though, I liked the big lug. Spent a lotta years together.” She glanced at Byleth. “How’re you holdin’ up?”

 

“...I…feel bad about it. I feel like I could do…something and I could fix it.”

 

“Nah, you probably couldn’t. There were a lot of beasts there, and then that weird guy that said he was Shez’s brother–”

 

Byleth went still. “What? You saw Shax?”

 

“That’s his name? That’s weird. Sounds a lot like Shez but if it was written wrong. Or…said wrong?” Candace shrugged. “One or the other. Victor tried to hold him back. Betcha anything that the son of a bitch was the one who killed Vic.”

 

“...” Byleth felt her hands clench into fists, her knuckles popping as her anger rose. “Shax killed Victor. He…Did he say anything? Anything at all?”

 

“He was asking about the captain.” Candace scowled. “I bet anything the prick thinks he can take Jeralt on. Little shit is gonna have another thing com–” Then she abruptly sat up, her eyes going wide.

 

Byleth stiffened. “Candace? C-Candace, are you okay?”

 

The dirty-blonde lancer turned to her, her eyes still wide with alarm. “Holy hell, Byleth, when did you get here?!”

 

“...huh?”

 

Candace reached out, grabbing the younger mercenary by the shoulder and staring into her eyes as a startled laugh slipped out of her mouth. “Saints and Seiros, you’re here! You’re here, you’re alive, you’re actually–” Then she was suddenly hugging Byleth, her one arm wrapping tightly around her. “Goddess, I thought–I don’t know what I thought, I just…I’m so glad you’re okay, kid.”

 

Byleth blinked, bewildered at first, before a small laugh slipped out, half incredulous and half overwhelmed, filled with more emotion than she knew what to do with. “C-Candace…did you only just now realize who I am?”

 

“Heh, sorry, my thoughts were all over the place there. I really just…it made perfect sense you were here, and I felt so bad about Victor, but then…then you’re actually here. You’re actually here and alive and fine–” She pulled back, immediately starting to check over the younger woman. “You are fine, right? No wounds? No diseases? No surprise pregnancy?”

 

“How in the world would that last one be something I need to worry about?”

 

“You never know! That’s why it’d be a surprise!” 

 

Byleth couldn’t help but giggle. She put her hands on Candace’s shoulders, lightly pushing the older woman back. “I’m fine, Candace. I promise. You’re the one I should be worried about. You’re missing an arm.”

 

“Oh, right, that.” Candace glanced down at the stump where her arm once was. “Huh. That’s gonna make mercenary work harder.”

 

“...Candace, I think that's the least of your worries right now.” 

 

“No, I don't think so. I mean, how else am I supposed to get paid?” She paused again. “Hang on, you have green hair.”

 

“I also have green eyes,” Byleth agreed, nodding. “And don’t worry, I’ll make sure you have more than enough money to live comfortably after the war ends.” She rubbed her chin thoughtfully. “Hm…maybe you could be the new stable master?”

 

“Huh…yeah, that would be nice! I wouldn’t mind taking care of horses after all this is over. Or now, I guess, since I don’t think I’m gonna be fighting anymore…shit. I don’t think I can fight anymore. I…well, maybe? You kinda need two arms to use a lance, but maybe…”

 

“Don’t think about that right now,” Byleth requested, trying to get the blonde to focus on her again, “You need to focus on recovering. Everything else can come after that. You’re family, so of course we’re going to take care of you.”

 

“Aw…that’s really sweet, kid.” Candace smiled, before pressing her head against Byleth’s. “I’m glad you’re okay.”

 

“Mm. I’m really happy you’re alive.”

 

“Then I’ll make sure to stay that way.” She sighed, smiling. “It’s so strange talkin’ to you now. You’re smilin’, you’re chattin’, you’re just…you’re so different from that little quiet kid that toddled after the captain. I still see her in you sometimes, but you’ve really grown up.” Tears started to prick at her eyes as she laughed. “Ah, listen to me, soundin’ like an old lady…I’m so sorry Vic didn’t get to see you like this.”

 

“...I’m sorry I wasn’t here–”

 

“Ah, nope, no apologies from you,” Candace insisted, ruffling Byleth’s hair, “You might be an adult now, but you’re still a kid to me and Vic, and that means we gotta help you, not the other way around. And I’d be more than happy if you outlived me more than a dozen times over.”

 

“...” Byleth gave her another hug, squeezing her tightly. “...thank you for buying me clothes. I ripped my tights. Sorry.”

 

Candace blinked. “You did? Dang, those were nice tights…hm, shit, gonna need to see if Anna’s around, maybe get a new pair–Hang on, were your ears always pointy?”

 

Byleth paused, not expecting the older woman to notice her other new change. “...not exactly. I fused with Sothis and now I think I might be a dragon person of some type.”

 

“Huh. I have no idea what that means. You got wings?”

 

“I…don’t think so? At least, I haven’t managed to turn into a dragon like Rhea can, so I’m not sure.”

 

“Rhea can turn into a dragon?”

 

“Mm hm. It’s an interesting ability, but it lets her cheat in fights.”

 

“Huh. Does she cheat a lot?”

 

Byleth nodded. “Constantly.”

 

“Huh, would’ve figured an archbishop would play more fair…eh, I can respect it. So, tell me, what else have you been up to? Do you know how Shez is doing? And how’d you get your eye back?”

 

Byleth smiled, then settled in to begin answering all of the blonde’s questions. She still had her worries, especially about her father now that she knew Shax might be after him, but in the moment, she was content to just talk.

 

Once she was sure Candace really would be fine though, she wasn’t about to let anything stop her from getting to Edelgard’s side as quickly as possible.

 

She was going to make sure everyone she loved would be safe. 

Sometime later, Byleth joined back up with Rhea and Dimitri in the war tent, though she wasn’t discussing future plans so much as directing an incredulous gaze towards the latter. “Shez went where ?”

 

“To find the Sword of the Creator, professor,” the prince explained, “Apparently she hid it somewhere–”

 

“On top of a mountain, yes, she told me. And you let her go?”

 

Dimitri frowned. “I couldn’t exactly stop her, professor.”

 

“Hm. Still. You know she’s bad with directions, I don’t want her to get lost–”

 

“Hey By!” Shez greeted as she abruptly appeared right beside her sister, a very familiar hollow sword in her hands that she promptly handed to Byleth, “Here you go, got your spine sword back!”

 

“...oh. Thank you, Shez,” Byleth accepted, ignoring Dimitri’s baffled look and Rhea’s exasperated sigh, “You shouldn’t run off like that though.”

 

“Yeah, I know, I warped away before I really thought about it. It’s a shame too, I had this thought in my brain about bringing you up there and having you pull the sword out all dramatically, with lightning flashing in the distance and all that.”

 

“That sounds dangerous. Lightning tends to strike metal, especially in high vantage points.”

 

“...eh, we’d live.”

 

“Hold on, Shez, since when can you warp all the way from the monastery to the…which mountains did you go to?” Dimitri asked.

 

“Uh…Oghma Mountains, I think?” Shez considered, frowning, “No, wait, are we in the Oghma Mountains…it was definitely an Oghma mountain, I know that much.”

 

“That’s still a remarkable distance to be able to warp. The spell normally has much greater limitations and while I know you have your own special version, I could have sworn you couldn’t go that far with it,” he pointed out.

 

“Oh, yeah, I guess? I kinda warped all over the place while I was wandering around Fodlan all those years, so I guess I just got better at it,” Shez said with a shrug, before turning to Rhea, “So, hey, are we still sticking to the ‘going to the Empire’ plan, or do you wanna drag Byleth on another trip?”

 

“No, I do not intend to ‘drag’ the professor anywhere at this point,” Rhea stated with a small frown on her face, “However, I may not be able to accompany you as planned. While I do agree that we should make haste to the Empire, the fact that my cardinals have been transformed into…draconic beings means that I cannot leave the monastery just yet. Not while they need me.”

 

“It's for the best that you stay here,” Byleth agreed, “While Dimitri needs help in the Kingdom as well, it's important we keep a central base secured. Though you'll be able to use most of our forces from the Alliance to aid you, Dimitri.” 

 

The prince looked a little bit more relieved to hear that. “Thank you, professor. It’s been difficult maintaining the few victories we do win in the Kingdom. We just didn’t have the manpower to secure the territories we managed to take, so with an influx of troops we might actually be able to reclaim Charon before the end of the month.”

 

“Mm. Good. Just be careful, okay? Having back-up doesn’t mean you have the advantage.”

 

“Believe me, professor, these past few years have done a great deal to make me more aware of my own limitations,” Dimitri assured.

 

“Hm…” Byleth glanced at her sister. “You just said you’ve overcome your previous limitations on your warping, right?”

 

“Hm? Yeah, that’s basically what I said,” Shez agreed.

 

“Does that mean you could warp us to the Empire?”

 

“Oh yeah, probably! We’ve been to plenty of places in the Empire, so I’m sure we could get out there easily!”

 

“Then that’s our plan. We’ll shadow warp over to make things easy.”

 

“Sounds good to me!” Shez said with a grin as she put a hand on her sister’s shoulder.

 

Rhea’s eyes widened. “Wait, Shez, don’t–!”

 

But alas, her words did not reach the young Eisner sister, who promptly warped away with her older sister in tow.

 

“Wait, did she just…?” Dimitri asked, looking at Rhea as the archbishop let out a deep, exasperated sigh.

 

“For the love of–Of course she did…why am I surrounded by reckless children?”

 

“Who are you calling a child?” Lysithea asked as she pushed her way into the tent, raising an eyebrow at Rhea.

 

“Not you, Lysithea, just…Shez.”

 

“Oh, that is much more reasonable. Though, now that you mention her, where is Shez? I should think we ought to make our plans to visit the Empire sooner rather than later.”

 

Rhea stared at the young albino woman for a moment, then just waved her off. “Dimitri, you handle this. I’m going to see to my cardinals and the possible survivors in the canyon, and then I’m going to chase down those reckless idiots before they manage to set fire to Enbarr.”

 

“Wh–Wait, Lady Rhea–” But alas, his words did not reach the archbishop, who promptly left the tent without another word to him. “...why do people keep ignoring me…”

 

“Dimitri.” He paused, then turned to Lysithea, who was frowning up at him with a distinctly unimpressed expression. “Where is Shez?”

 

“...ah…well…er, would you believe me if I said I do not know?”

 

Alas, she did not.

Meanwhile, far, far south of Garreg Mach, a certain pair of sisters abruptly found themselves in the middle of a vaguely familiar street that was almost immediately filled with the sounds of screaming.

 

“Woah, what?” Shez looked around, blinking in confusion as she saw people all around them, suddenly running away from the pair of sisters while screaming things like “IT’S ANOTHER INVASION!” and “TYRANTS! TYRANTS IN THE CITY!!”

 

Byleth, meanwhile, pressed a hand to her face and let out a deep sigh. “Shez. Where are we?”

 

“Huh? Oh, uh…the Empire, I think?”

 

“You think?”

 

“Uh…yeah, yeah, it’s definitely the Empire! See, I remembered how we went to Enbarr when we were kids and figured I could just head over here! And it worked!” Shez stated, before stumbling a bit, suddenly looking dizzy, “W-Woah, guess I went too far.” 

 

Byleth frowned, a little worried. “Are you okay, Shez?”

 

“Yeah, yeah, just…guess I do actually have a limit to how far I can warp…or how much I can warp? One of those…” She took a breath, rubbing at her head. “Ah, definitely feeling weirdly tingly right now…”

 

“Hm, we should find a place to sit down–” 

 

“DON’T MOVE!” Pausing, Byleth looked up to see that they were surrounded by soldiers dressed in imperial garb, all pointing spears at them. 

 

“...hm.” 

 

“Invaders, drop your weapons!” another shouted as the soldiers inched closer. 

 

“H-Hey, no, we're not invading!” Shez responded, standing on shaky legs, “We're here to see Edelgard!” 

 

“THEY’RE AFTER THE EMPEROR!” So it seemed that wasn’t the best response Shez could have given.

 

“H-Hey, seriously, guys, we’re not a threat–” Shez tried to explain, before blinking when she heard a sword clatter to the ground beside her.

 

“We surrender,” Byleth stated, raising her empty hands over her head.

 

“...eh? W-Wait, By–”

 

“She also surrenders.”

 

“No I don’t!”

 

“Yes you do.”

 

“No, hang on, there’s no way I’m going to surrender to a bunch of–”

 

Minutes later, Byleth sat calmly on the bed across from her sister, who was shackled to the wall of their cell. “So. What did we learn?”

 

“That apparently you’ll give up the second we’re in trouble,” Shez grumbled, pouting at her sister.

 

“If they had attempted to hurt you, I would have rewound time and actually fought them. They didn’t, so I didn’t.”

 

“Yeah, well–Wait, hang on, you can rewind time!”

 

“Yes. You know that.”

 

“So rewind time! Make it so I didn’t mess up!”

 

“No.”

 

“What do you mean ‘no’?!”

 

“I mean no. This is a learning experience.”

 

“...feh…why am I shackled though?”

 

“You tried to bite a guard.”

 

“Well I couldn’t stab him, you made me drop my sword!”

 

“One of the guards called me a ‘polite young lady’,” Byleth said, giving her sister a small, amused smile, “I think that means I won at being arrested.”

 

“You can't win at being arrested!” 

 

“And yet, I have.”

 

“Just you wait till my head stops hurting, then I'll be breaking out of here without you,” Shez pouted as she leaned back against the wall.

 

“Don't worry, I'll make sure to rewind if things go badly or if we spend too long here. For now though, keep this in mind to fight your impulse control.” 

 

“Fuck you, I have great control.” 

 

“You warped all the way to wherever you left the Sword of the Creator because the idea came to you. Then you warped both of us to Enbarr for the exact same reason,” Byleth pointed out, “You can be impulsive. It’s just something we’ll have to work on–” She paused, glancing past the cell bars. “Someone’s coming.”

 

Shez blinked, then immediately quieted down, tilting her head and listening. After a moment, she heard the same thing her sister had. Three sets of footsteps, two slightly louder. Leather boots in front, slightly off pace–a limp perhaps–and armored boots following. A noble and two guards?

 

Byleth leaned against the wall, keeping a careful eye on where the group would be approaching from. While she doubted the guards would do anything stupid, she wasn’t risking Shez’s safety if there were any idiots who wanted to start trouble. 

 

Luckily, the person approaching wasn’t an idiot at all, and Byleth felt a smile come to her face as she was finally reunited with one of her students. “Hello Hubert.”

 

“...” Hubert von Vestra, right hand man to the Emperor of Adrestia and Minister of the Imperial House, stared at his long lost professor for a moment, then let out a deep, exasperated sigh. “Hello Professor. How is it that the first time I’ve seen you in three years, you’ve managed to get yourself locked in a jail cell?” He held up a hand before Byleth could speak. “No, don’t answer. It was Shez’s fault.”

 

“Hey! You don’t know that for sure!” Shez complained.

 

“It was,” Byleth confirmed, earning an annoyed grumble from her sister.

 

Hubert let out a deep sigh again, “Am I correct in assuming the ‘Tyrant’ that appeared, was just her warping into the middle of the city?” 

 

“Yes. It was handy, but it did mean we left Dimitri and Rhea mid-conversation." 

 

Hubert frowned. “Hm. So the archbishop has returned…Though I must say professor, I'm surprised to hear you met up with Prince Dimitri before her majesty.” 

 

“Don't remind me,” Byleth said with a pout, “I wanted to come here sooner, but everyone kept dragging me along with their stuff first. Speaking of, is Edelgard here?” 

 

“No, she's currently on the Eastern Front.” 

 

“Huh? Then why are you here? I thought it was your job to be a ghost around her?” Shez asked. 

 

“I received an injury during an attempt to take Fort Merceus, so Lady Edelgard ordered me to return to Enbarr to recover and ensure nothing went awry while she's gone,” Hubert explained, before giving Shez a wry look, “Such as someone warping into the middle of the city in an attempt to invade.”

 

“Oh. Well, good thing we’re not here to invade then.”

 

“A very good thing indeed,” he agreed, his voice dripping with sarcasm. 

 

“Hm. Is everyone there with Edelgard?” Byleth asked.

 

“A majority of our classmates are assisting her, yes, though Bernadetta accompanied me when I was sent back.” 

 

“Oh that's good, I'll be happy to see her.” 

 

“So are you two dating or are you still overly devoted to Edelgard?” Shez asked, before pausing in thought, “Though, huh, I guess you could be both? I think even Bernie might get jealous if her man was fully devoted to someone else though.”

 

“Bernadetta understands my devotion to Lady Edelgard and her cause,” Hubert bluntly stated before opening up the cell door, “Come along, Professor. We should hear what you’ve been up to these past three years.”

 

“Alright. Thank you, Hubert,” Byleth said as she got up from the bed, earning a blink from Shez.

 

“Uh…hang on, guys? Shouldn't you unshackle me so I can come along?”

 

“I don’t recall you being a part of our class, Shez,” Hubert remarked, “So it wouldn’t be right for you to attend a class reunion. You understand, of course.”

 

“Hey come on, at least unshackle me so I can lay on the bed!” Shez shouted as Hubert closed the door, “If you walk away I'm going to rattle these chains so loudly!”

 

“Could you have one of the guards let her free once we leave?” Byleth requested in a low voice while she walked away with Hubert, pretending to ignore Shez’s angry chain rattling.

 

“Can you guarantee she won’t try to take advantage of that generosity and make an escape attempt?”

 

“Hm…I’ll take full responsibility if she does anything dumb.”

 

“Then I’ll ensure she’s released at an appropriate time,” Hubert stated, getting Byleth to smile, before she glanced down at his limp. 

 

“...How is everyone?” 

 

“Well enough for those that have been at war for three years. Some thrive amidst the combat, others are weary of it, but for the most part, everyone is healthy and are carrying out their duties as they should be,” he explained, “I imagine your return will be very good for their morale.”

 

Byleth imagined that was Hubert’s way of saying everyone would be happy to see her again, which was a nice thought to keep with herself as she followed him up from the dungeons.

 

“In fact, we can confirm that theory right now,” Hubert stated before pushing open a door leading into a lounge, where a familiar girl whose messy hair was tied up in a topknot was waiting, a book in hand, “Greetings, Bernadetta.” 

 

“Hello, Bernie.” 

 

“Oh, hey there Hubert, Professor, was everything okay?” Bernadetta asked, setting her book down as she stood up, before pausing. “P-PROFESSOR!?” 

 

“It's nice to see you again, Bernie,” Byleth said, a small smile on her face, before she suddenly had to grab onto the skittish archer when she practically tackled her. 

 

“Y-You're back! When did you get back!?” Bernadetta asked, looking…down at Byleth. 

 

“...Huh, you're taller than me now,” Byleth couldn't help but note, bringing her hand up to check the difference in height between the two. 

 

“H-Huh? Ah–I-I’m sorry! I-I didn’t mean to!”

 

“I’m not upset, I just find it interesting. Hm…is this what it feels like to be a proud mama?”

 

Bernadetta blinked. “Um…I-I don’t think you’re that much older than me, professor.”

 

“Isn’t that something parents are supposed to say? ‘You got so big’?” Byleth paused to think before turning to face Hubert. “You better treat her right, or else.” 

 

“...your mind is an enigma as always, professor.” Hubert sighed. “Would you like me to make some tea?”

 

“Oh, please. Though…hm, don’t you prefer coffee? Maybe that would be better.”

 

“I can stomach tea as necessary, professor–”

 

“Well now we have to have coffee. As your mother-in-law, I’m not letting you have a drink you don’t like just for propriety’s sake.”

 

Hubert sighed again while Bernadetta looked oddly touched. “Professor, you are not my mother-in-law.”

 

“Not yet. I don’t see a ring on Bernadetta’s finger. You need to fix that.”

 

“...you wouldn’t be my mother-in-law regardless. Bernadetta isn’t your daughter.”

 

“She could be. And besides, I would still be your lady-in-law once I work things out with Edelgard.” She paused, frowning in thought. “That isn’t too presumptuous, is it?”

 

“It is, and you wouldn’t be my ‘lady-in-law’ either way since that isn’t a real term,” Hubert stated, starting to remember why he found it so exhausting to interact with the professor.

 

“Hm. Fine. Oh, and it should be obvious I’m not an Agarthan infiltrator, so don’t try to poison me to make sure. I’ll know and I’ll make it very awkward for both of us.”

 

“...It's surprising how much more…vocal you've become, Professor.” 

 

“The void did things to me.” 

 

“Hm. I suppose I shall go fetch the coffee.” Hubert said, walking away wishing to be done with the conversation. 

 

“Thank you,” Byleth said, before smiling at Bernadetta again, “I'm glad to see you're okay.” 

 

“A-All of us are. Edelgard did her best to make sure everyone stuck together, regardless of how tough things got…” Bernadetta said, her eyes starting to grow teary eyed, “W-We never gave up on looking for you!” 

 

What else could Byleth do but hug her? “Thank you. I’m so glad to see you again, and I’m sorry I couldn’t be here sooner. I’m so proud of you.”

 

To very little surprise, that brought even more tears to Bernadetta’s eyes as she tightly hugged Byleth back, letting her emotions loose in her professor’s comforting embrace. By the time Hubert returned, Bernadetta had started full on sobbing, which was somewhat awkward to come back to. Particularly since she was still sniffling as they sat down for tea.

 

Still, it wasn’t the most awkward thing to happen at their reunion. No, that would be how Byleth paused right before taking a sip of her coffee, gave Hubert a distinctly unimpressed look, and poured the cup into a nearby plant.

 

“I said no poisons.”

 

“...it was a sedative–”

 

“Poison is poison, Hubert, and I can taste the difference.”

 

“Really? I was under the impression it was a tasteless poison.”

 

“You just admitted it was poison. Also, my taste buds are different now.”

 

“Does that have to do with your change in hair color, and the fact that you have two eyes again?” Hubert questioned, before pausing when Bernadetta tugged on his sleeve. He turned, then actually had to hold back a wince when he saw she was glaring at him.

 

“D-Don’t poison the professor!” Bernadetta ordered, her voice only slightly wavering, which earned a very proud smile and a pat on the head from Byleth.

 

“...very well. Now then, I believe you were about to discuss the ‘void’ you claim to have been trapped in?” Hubert deflected, trying to ignore Bernadetta’s continued pout.

 

“Hm, right, that part…okay, we should probably let Shez out of her cell to share her side of things. This is going to be a long story.”

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Reunions! Well, some of them at least, Byleth will be meeting the rest of her Eagles soon enough!

Red: Very soon! Fast travel is a really convenient power and Shez has been unintentionally leaving markers around ever since she was a kid. Granted, she couldn't actually warp that distance without having the power of Epimenides and she still can't really spam traveling across the entire continent, but it's still pretty handy.

Indi: That it can be! Up until her friends show up annoyed at her for leaving so suddenly.

Red: Yeah she's gonna be in trouble for that. Ah well, live and learn.

You Jinxed It!

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

“Why do you look like an onion?” were the first words Shez said to Bernadetta in three years.

 

Suffice to say, the lady of House Varley was fairly bewildered by that question. “U-Um…I do?”

 

“Yeah, your hair does. The way you tie it up makes you look like an onion.” Shez paused, noticing Byleth’s frown. “That’s not a bad thing though! You look cute! Like…an onion!”

 

“...a-are onion’s cute?”

 

“They are when they look like you,” Shez said, nodding as though her words made perfect sense.

 

“U-Uh…thank you, I guess? I just have it like this to keep it out of my eyes,” Bernadetta explained as Hubert took a sip of coffee, choosing not to mention the new style was mainly thanks to a botched attempt on the archer’s part to cut her own hair. 

 

“Oh huh. Why not tie it back then?”

 

“...i-it just works better like this,” Bernadetta mumbled, a little embarrassed.

 

“I guess? Hmm…hey, maybe I could cut it for you–”

 

“Don’t let Shez near your head with a knife,” Byleth advised, earning a pout from her sister.

 

“It was one time…”

 

Bernadetta, meanwhile, had taken that advice in a very different way than Byleth had intended and was now watching Shez very warily, her mind filled with images of gruesome violence enacted at the hands of the purple-haired mercenary. “P-Please don’t stab Bernie’s brain out!”

 

Shez blinked. “What?”

 

“Leaving aside Bernadetta’s paranoid fantasies and Shez’s ineptitude,” Hubert interrupted, earning an offended gasp from Shez and a small whimper from Bernie, “Professor, I believe you were going to tell us about your extended absence.”

 

“Right, well, that starts with back in the monastery when Shez got taken over,” Byleth explained, glancing at her sister, who frowned at the thought of Epimenides.

 

“Yeah, I had a guy in my head who really didn't like Byleth and wanted her gone.” 

 

“Hm…does this have anything to do with your origins?” Hubert asked.

 

“Pretty much. I got rid of him though, so you don't have to worry about that,” Shez said, giving him a thumbs up. 

 

“...” Hubert made a mental note to question Byleth about that later. “I see…and you ended up in a…’void’ as you said?” 

 

“Rhea and me, yeah,” Byleth explained, “We were both stuck in there and didn't have a way out until Shez figured out how to get in on her own.” 

 

“Then pray tell, how exactly did you survive in this ‘void’ for three years?” 

 

“I had someone in my head as well, though she was nicer. When it came down to it, she gave me her powers so that I could survive, even if it meant she would fade away,” Byleth elaborated, letting out a small sigh before she sipped some tea, “Mm…Her name was Sothis, and she was the goddess.” 

 

“...” Hubert took a deep breath, before folding his hands and leaning forward, staring intently at Byleth and ignoring how Bernadetta had started choking on her drink. “I think you’ll need to explain a great deal more, professor.”

“You know, I'm surprised you aren't clamoring to go straight to Edelgard,” Shez pointed out, staring at Byleth as they lounged around the tea room. Hubert and Bernadetta had left a little bit ago, the former apparently intent on making notes and writing messages while the latter just seemed to be following him for lack of anything better to do, all while mumbling something about “failing the goddess’s class”, which was silly considering Byleth knew Bernadetta passed her tests just fine. 

 

“I love all of my students equally, and I'm not going to push my reunion to the side to see one in particular,” Byleth explained, “That and I push too much, Hubert will probably think I'm planning something devious.” 

 

“I feel like the most ‘devious’ thing you could think of is stealing some food.” 

 

“Just because I get big portions doesn't mean I'd steal food.”
