“What about the times you took food from my plate, huh?”

 

“Shez, you would put whatever food you didn’t like onto my plate. Mostly vegetables,” Byleth pointed out, “You were a picky eater as a kid.”

 

“...yeah, well…I can’t think of an argument to that.” Shez huffed, crossing her arms over her chest and sinking in her seat. “...when do you think Hubert’s going to be back? I want to ask him how dad’s doing.”

 

“Hm. We can go look for him if he doesn’t–” And right on cue, Hubert entered the tea room again, an attempt at a pleasant smile on his face.

 

“Hello again, Professor, Shez,” he greeted while Bernadetta scurried in behind him, “I apologize for the wait, but I felt I should send a message to Emperor Edelgard as soon as possible to let her know of your return. I imagine your father would be with her, so he should be well-aware of your arrival as well.”

 

“Oh, thank you Hubert,” Byleth said with a smile.

 

Shez, meanwhile, gave him a very suspicious look. “Were you listening in on our conversation?”

 

“Why Shez, it’s as though you do not trust me.”

 

“You didn’t answer the question.”

 

“Did you really need my answer? Regardless, preparations will be made so we can return to her majesty's side. Though before that, I believe we need to get the two of you properly groomed.” 

 

“Huh? Why's that?” 

 

“Need I remind you that you are meeting with the Emperor of Adrestia?” Hubert asked, a frown on his face, “That and while I understand the professor and the former archbishop have grown closer, I don't think Lady Edelgard will be happy seeing her in church garb.” 

 

“Oh, right. Hopefully we can get something that fits me properly,” Byleth considered thoughtfully, before looking at Bernadetta, “Would you mind helping us, Bernadetta? I don’t know much about Adrestian fashion.”

 

“H-H-Huh? W-Wait, w-why are you asking Bernie?? Sh-She’s not a fashionista, she doesn’t know anything!” she immediately protested.

 

“Well you know how to dress yourself, so that’s good enough for me,” Shez decided, walking over to Bernie and pulling her to her feet, earning a startled squeak from the anxious noble. “Come on, let’s get moving or else I’ll carry you again.”

 

“A-Ah, n-no! W-Why do people think they can carry me like a sack of potatoes?!?”

 

“I’ll carry you like a princess if it’ll make you feel better, just get moving.”

 

Alas, despite her years of progress, Bernadetta was still very weak to anybody being even slightly forceful with her, and Hubert was zero help at all as the Eisner sisters essentially abducted the heir of House Varley to go pick out new clothes. Luckily for her, neither sister was especially adventurous when it came to fashion so things progressed fairly smoothly, with Byleth in particular being very happy afterwards thanks to her finding a new pair of leggings to replace her ruined ones.

 

“And now my legs will always be warm,” she said with a smile, idly admiring the floral patterns in the mirror. Her current outfit largely resembled her old one, thanks to her finding some nice shorts to go with it, though the black, short-sleeved tunic she’d found actually showed off less of her chest than she was used to. A part of her was actually tempted to make a strategically placed tear in the fabric, before shrugging off the thought and returning to the gloves and armor pieces she intended to add to her selection.

 

Shez, meanwhile, had gone for something quite a bit fancier. 

 

“Ta-dah!” the younger Eisner sister said with a grin, showing off the armor she’d appropriated from the Empire’s stock, “I call it the ‘Armor of Asura’! How’s it look?”

 

“Huh. Do you need that many scarves?” Byleth asked, tilting her head curiously at her sister’s new appearance.

 

“They’re not scarves, they’re…tassels? Or, no, it’s more like, uh…a four-pronged cape!”

 

“Interesting. Why ‘Asura’?”

 

“Dunno, it just kinda came to me. Fits me pretty well though, right?”

 

Byleth stared at Shez for a moment, fully taking in the changes in her appearance, the orange gleam of dawn’s light that never truly left her hair or eyes, how tall she had grown, and just how happy and confident she looked now that things were finally turning around. So, of course, she smiled. “It fits you perfectly.”

 

“Heh, thanks! You know, it actually is kinda crazy how well it does fit me,” Shez commented, putting her hands on her hips as she checked herself out in a nearby mirror, “It almost feels like it was made for me, which is pretty weird to think…hey Bernadetta, do you know anything about this armor?”

 

“H-Huh?” Bernadetta glanced up from where she’d been sitting while thinking about all the ways she could potentially screw up her professor's reunion with her classmates, “U-Uh, s-sorry, I don’t–W-What was the question?”

 

“Just wondering if you know anything about this armor.”

 

“U-Um…I-I think E-Emperor E-Edelgard had it commissioned for you?”

 

“...huh?”

 

“Eep! I-I’m sorry, I-I don’t know anything else, I s-swear!”

 

“I’m not mad, Bernie, I just…why’d she do that for me?” Shez asked, before glancing down at herself, “And how the hell did she get the proportions so right?”

 

“Did she make anything for me?” Byleth asked, curious.

 

“E-E-Eh? U-Uh, m-m-maybe? I-I don’t, um…” Bernadetta trailed off, fidgeting with anxiety, before she let out a breath of relief as the door to the room the Eisners commandeered opened up and Hubert stepped in, followed by a face that made both sisters stiffen in surprise.

 

“Right this way, Lieutenant,” Hubert said with a smile, before stepping to the side to let a very annoyed mercenary enter the room.

 

“Kid, you’re really trying my patience here. Why don’t you tell me what this surprise is supposed to be so I can get outta here already–” 

 

“Ezra?” 

 

Byleth wasn’t sure if it was her or Shez who spoke first, but either way, the lanky, scruffy mercenary cut himself off with a sudden start, his eyes going wide. “Byleth? Shez?”

 

Shez hugged him first, but Byleth wasn’t far behind, earning a startled laugh from the veteran mercenary before he returned the hug.

 

“Saints, I haven’t seen you two in years! Where were–wait, did both of you dye your hair?” he asked, happy and baffled in equal measure.

 

“Uh, not exactly?” Shez began, pulling back and trying to think of how to explain everything that happened to her and Byleth over the past three years. Byleth, meanwhile, was not releasing the hug. “Okay, so, I guess it all started when I got possessed–“

 

“What.”

 

Meanwhile, off to the side, Bernadetta sidled up to Hubert, who was watching the proceedings with a small smirk. “…I-It was really nice of you to do this.”

 

“Hm? Whatever do you mean?”

 

“Reuniting them like this. It’s nice.”

 

“It was practical,” Hubert retorted, “Now the Eisner sisters will both feel indebted to me and, by extension, Emperor Edelgard. It would have been better if I could have brought their father, but I suppose an honorary uncle will suffice.” 

 

“Hm.” Bernadetta glanced over to the trio, a smile spreading on her face. “You're a lot nicer than you're willing to admit.” 

 

“Take it as you will,” Hubert muttered, rolling his eyes as he moved to sit down, letting the mercenaries reunite. 

 

Of course, not every part of their reunion was positive.

 

“Victor’s dead?” Ezra asked, genuinely surprised, “I thought that prick would live forever…”

 

“Yeah…it wasn’t great finding that out,” Shez replied, ignoring the insult. She knew how the two lieutenants could be.

 

“Mm. I wish we’d gone there earlier…” Byleth murmured.

 

“Hey, nobody can know how things might play out,” Ezra pointed out, “Fodlan’s a big place and we’re in a dangerous line of work. Victor knew the risks, and the only reason he’d be upset going out the way he did is that he didn’t get to see you two before he went.

 

He smiled at the two of them and ruffled their hair, earning a smile from Byleth and a playfully dramatic huff from Shez, before his expression turned serious. “We can hold a funeral later. Right now, the most important thing is that I get the two of you to your father.”

 

“Right. Where is he?” Byleth asked, not noticing how Shez winced at the mention of their dad.

 

Ezra did notice, but he didn’t say anything. “Right now, he’s on the Eastern Front with the emperor and her strike force, along with the rest of those church knights, trying to reclaim Fort Merceus.”

 

“Fort what now?” Shez asked.

 

“Fort Merceus, also called ‘The Stubborn Old General’, is one of the Empire’s major cities,” Byleth readily explained, the information she taught in class quickly coming back to her, “It’s a fortress city that serves as the capital of Bergliez County and is famous for being impregnable.” A frown came to her face. “If the Agarthans captured it…no wonder the war has been in a stalemate.”

 

“Indeed,” Hubert spoke up, “Losing Fort Merceus was one of the most costly events of the war for her majesty. Not only did its seizure stymie our attempts to retake the lands Hrym had stolen, but it has opened Enbarr up to attack and strained her majesty’s relationship with Count Bergliez.”

 

“Why isn’t he the one trying to take it back then?” Shez asked.

 

“Unfortunately, the reality of having enemies on all sides means Count Bergliez and a majority of the Imperial Army have been stretched thin trying to stave off the Kingdom’s invasions. The simple reality that we are faced with is that the Empire is at an unprecedented disadvantage, and the only way to regain that advantage is to ensure Fort Merceus is reclaimed.”

 

“Which is what you need us for,” Shez finished, crossing her arms over her chest.

 

“Then that’s what we’re doing,” Byleth decided, nodding to Hubert, “Do you have a way of getting us there quickly?”

 

“Do recall who you are speaking to, professor.” Hubert smirked, raising a hand and allowing dark magic to flow upwards from his palm. “I am entirely capable of taking you there myself–”

 

Then Bernadetta poked his side and his magic fizzled out entirely with a pained hiss. He glared at the archer, but, for once, she didn’t falter in frowning back at him. “You’re still injured…”

 

“...I can simply take some concoctions–”

 

“He was injured with the black weapons, the ones that don’t heal easily,” Bernadetta explained, turning to her professor and earning a scowl from Hubert.

 

“Do not act as though I am an invalid!” he argued, before pausing when Bernadetta turned her worried frown towards him again.

 

“Do you really think you can take them there without hurting yourself?”

 

“...” Hubert considered saying something very cruel in that moment, something that would assuredly undercut the archer’s confidence and make her back down. “...” Instead of doing that though, he turned his gaze back towards Byleth and Shez. “I can provide steeds that should get you there before the day ends.”

 

He ignored the happy smile Bernadetta gave him, instead watching as the professor nodded. “Okay, then let’s get moving. I don’t want anyone else to get hurt before I can get to them.”

 

“What are the chances of someone going after Edelgard today of all days?” Shez questioned with a raised eyebrow, before pausing when Byleth and Ezra both sighed. “...aw, damn it. Did I just jinx us?”

 

“You did,” Bernadetta affirmed, initially calm but with an obvious panic growing in her eyes, “You absolutely, definitely, completely did, and now Edelgard is going to be assassinated and cities will burn and oh goddess, what if the sky just explodes?!?”

 

“...Okay, I’m pretty sure at least one of those isn’t going to happen.”

“I gotta say, I can’t see how our people could take being underground for all these centuries,” Shax commented as he gazed up at the evening sky, watching as the sun began its slow descent beneath the horizon, “These kinds of views feel too beautiful to just miss out on.”

 

“Our ancestors had far greater concerns than pretty skies, fool,” Dolofonos reprimanded, his own eyes instead focused past the fields surrounding Fort Merceus and towards the distant Imperial encampment, where his targets lay unsuspecting of the incoming threat, “The abominations and their ilk needed extermination, and our people have been dedicated to that cause for well over a thousand years! Do you truly think such immaterial phenomena warranted their attention?”

 

“Mm hm, yeah, I would say so.”

 

“...then you truly are a fool.”

 

“If you say so.” Shax lowered his gaze from the distant sky and looked towards the camp instead, all while ignoring the old man’s urge to grab the disrespectful Dolofonos by the neck and squeeze until it snapped. The idea appealed, sure, but then he’d get in trouble with Papa Myson, and that just wouldn’t be practical.

 

Instead, he focused on the camp where he’d soon spill an emperor’s blood. Time and the threat of attack had turned a war camp into something of a fort itself, scarlet banners bearing black eagles flying over the high walls and watchtowers. 

 

It was funny. The Emperor put so much emphasis on her school days that she took the black eagle as a personal symbol instead of the standard Imperial gold. Remarkably sentimental for a monarch.

 

Shax had to admit, in the privacy of his own mind, he was curious about her. In the eyes of his superiors, she was a failed experiment who needed to be wiped out. Yet for a ‘failure’ to not only escape the grasp of the Agarthan sages but also be in open war against them and holding her own? Shax was confident enough in his abilities to know he would defeat her, yet he couldn't help but respect her too. 

 

Even the old man couldn't help but acknowledge the strong opponent Shax would have to face. 

 

A part of him couldn't help but wonder that if she had not broken free, would they have become allies? Perhaps it could have been the two of them against his wayward sister and the Fell Star.

 

He had to admit, the thought was strangely appealing. His ally here, Dolofonos…he wasn’t exactly impressive, for all he claimed to be some kind of special sage. And with Lady Bias going off on her own mission, he felt…dispirited. A bad thing to feel before a battle.

 

So he did the logical thing: Clapped his hands together and grinned. “Alright, I’ll be right back. Don’t try starting things early, else I might not make it back in time to help.”

 

“What? Where do you think you’re going–?”

 

Shax thought he was going to visit one of the people he actually liked in this world, so he did exactly that, vanishing from the ramparts and reappearing in a carriage traveling towards a city destined to be burned.

 

“Oh, it’s you. Myson’s little project.” Bias sighed, eyeing the sudden intruder in her carriage with a raised eyebrow. “What would have happened to you if I decided to leave something on that seat you’re perched on?”

 

“Hm? Nothing, probably. It’s not as though I can teleport into a solid object. I probably would just be sitting on top of whatever thing you put here,” Shax explained, before pausing and grinning as a thought occurred. “Does the fact that you didn’t block my seat mean you thought I would visit?”

 

“It doesn’t. It just means I didn’t have anything I wanted to put there.”

 

“Oh. Hm…well were you hoping I would visit?”

 

Bias sighed again. “What do you want, Shax?”

 

The boy in question brightened at the use of his chosen name. “I just wanted to check in with you, Lady Bias. You are going to be leading an attack soon and I’m going to be participating in one too, so I thought it would be good to chat ahead of time.”

 

“So you abandoned your post because you felt like chatting?”

 

“I wouldn’t say I abandoned it, I can go back at any time. I know where Dolofonos is, so I can just head back to where he is.”

 

“Hm. Is that how your version of the ‘shadow warp’ works?”

 

“Sort of? I think so, at least. It’s easier than trying to visualize a place. As long as I have a specific person I can travel to, I can travel to where they are, and I have connections to our people so it’s even easier to travel to them.”

 

“Hm…so you can go to places you’ve never been before as long as you have an ally present there. A limit, but also a benefit,” Bias mused, a thoughtful look crossing the sage’s scarred face. 

 

Shax’s gaze lingered on those scars, partially hidden beneath the veil she wore, each one telling a fascinating story of pain and injury. “What’s it like, burning a city?”

 

“Painful. My body burns with the same heat that the beasts burn in. Myson talks about making these things more stable, but I can tell he only cares about making them more powerful,” Bias said, flicking the necklace around her neck. 

 

“...Huh, gonna be honest, didn't expect that answer. Would have thought you enjoyed it more.” 

 

“I don't feel anything slaughtering these beasts. Them and Myson are just stepping stones for what I want.”

 

Shax nodded. “The Fell Star’s death.”

 

Curiously, Bias paused there. She glanced at the carriage’s door, a curtain drawn over the window to hide the countryside. “...My sister died in a carriage just like this one.”

 

“She did? What happened?”

 

“A truly stupid turn of events. She was riding with Thales and an ill-timed spell caused a landslide. The carriage was damaged and she likely died on impact.” Bias took a breath. “Likely. Thales though, he crawled free. There was dark magic in the area, as my mentor described it, so it’s likely, likely , that he buried the carriage himself and then died like a fool when it brought the rest of the mountain down on his head.”

 

“...huh. I haven’t heard all that much about Thales,” Shax admitted, “Nobody seems to talk about him anymore.”

 

“Our people prefer to forget the dead while remembering the grudge. If you want to take any sort of lesson from his example, I’d say…learn to recognize when you’re still in danger. Arrogance tends to be our greatest killer.”

 

“Ha! In that case I'm already leagues ahead of him. I might have been willing to take on the Fell Star and my sister, but I knew well enough to not take on an army on my own.” 

 

“And that’s how you die,” Bias retorted, unimpressed, “You’re at least smart enough to know when to run, I’ll give you that, but it’s when you think you don’t need to run that they’ll get you.”

 

Shax paused, raising an eyebrow. “Huh…how do you know when to run then? Because if you don’t know you should run, then how will you know when to…wait, does that sentence make sense?”

 

“I’m saying you shouldn’t waste time on dramatic speeches or posturing. Just get the job done and go. And if the job isn’t worth it, go before it kills you.”

 

“Is that what you do?”

 

“Mostly, but also I’m a massive hypocrite so you shouldn’t listen to my advice.”

 

Shax blinked, then laughed. “Then how do you know if the job is worth it then?” 

 

“That depends on you. Do you only care about Myson's approval, or do you wish for something more?” 

 

“Hm…” He could picture what the old man would want. Killing anyone he wanted, ruling over whatever land he claimed, drinking and indulging in whatever pleasures he desired. Shax could see the appeal in that kind of lifestyle, but he didn’t really feel like the kingly type. “What about your approval?”

 

Bias rolled her eyes. “Try to come up with something better than that by the next time we talk.”

 

Shax huffed in annoyance at the dismissal, before grinning. “Fine, I’ll come up with something amazing for a life goal by the next time I see you. So that means you’re not allowed to be arrogant before then, got it?”

 

“I should be saying that to you, boy.” She drummed her fingers on her knee, staring at the strange creation Myson brought into this world. “One of these days, you’ll have to tell me what Myson did to make you turn out so stable. Otherwise I’ll have to dissect you for the answer.”

 

“Oh, there’s no need to do that, I’m fine with explaining. To put it simply, Papa Myson didn’t exactly grow a new clone of my sister in the traditional way. It’s more like…he repurposed some materials that already existed.” He grinned, his emerald eyes flashing crimson for a moment. “Obviously he had to alter some things, but hey, it wasn’t like we were really using those corpses except as some kind of last ditch failsafe.”

 

“...You don’t exactly have the same build as Nemesis,” Bias noted, earning a laugh from Shax.

 

“Oh sure, but he wasn’t the base used. Papa Myson is a smart guy, the type to use things other people disregard, and the project to remake the Great Sage had plenty of failures before my sister was born. There wasn’t much left of those past mistakes, but he used what he could along with the blood you retrieved from my sister, plus plenty of samples from the previous King of Liberation to make me turn out the way I did.”

 

“Huh.” A gleam of curiosity entered Bias’s eyes as she leaned forward with a newfound interest. “And how would you turn out if you added more than that?”

 

“Hm? What do you mean?”

 

“Why stop with just the King? Why not all of the so-called Elites?”

 

“...because I didn’t think of that before now. Huh.” Shax tilted his head thoughtfully, considering the suggestion. “Hmm…thanks for the talk, Lady Bias. You’ve given me a lot to think about.” He grinned. “See ya~!”

 

Then he vanished, returning back to the fort just in time to startle Dolofonos.

 

“Gh–W-Where did you just go? We were about to launch the operation–”

 

“No, you weren’t. I told you not to until I got back,” Shax bluntly stated, before smirking, “No need to worry though, my head’s clear now.

 

“Let’s go kill an Emperor.”

Chapter End Notes

Red: I wonder if anyone noticed before now that the characters would be in their Hopes timeskip designs and not their Houses timeskip designs?

Indi: I'm sure some people picked up on it.

Red: I'm still curious! Anyways yeah, mostly set-up this time. Next chapter is where the sky gets set on fire.

Indi: Well, probably not the sky. But something will be on fire!

Fire in the Night

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Edelgard von Hresvelg, the young emperor of Adrestia, let out a tired sigh as she tried to rub the urge to sleep from her eyes. Rest was something she could ill-afford at the moment, not when her scouts were reporting new movements from Fort Merceus, and certainly not when she had even more reports to read through before making strategic decisions that would impact the lives of everyone under her command.

 

She let out a sigh and rubbed her furrowed brow, trying to ease away some of the stress of her position. The news lately had been…mixed. On a positive note, apparently the Alliance was intending to join the war in earnest now that the Almyrans had been repelled and Ordelia’s territory reclaimed. Then, on a negative note, there were already rumors circulating that some type of disaster had befallen the monastery and the Knights of Reclamation living in the Red Canyon. The news was vague, information could only travel so fast, but it was possible that fool posing as “the Flame Emperor” had done something drastic.

 

If they had, it was likely the Knights of Reclamation that were meant to be helping her would go scurrying back to the canyon, either out of a misplaced sense of duty or a more reasonable desire to help their imperiled comrades. She couldn’t fault the church remnants for wanting to rescue their main force from whatever may have happened, she just had a difficult time extending them any charity after their recent showings. Having an extra army trying to seize Fort Merceus should have been a boon, but the knights often clashed with her soldiers and Seteth seemed to believe he had more authority in the camp than he did. 

 

Edelgard distinctly remembered having to stop Hubert from outright attacking the former chamberlain when he tried to give her orders under the guise of “offering advice”. Even then, things wound up devolving into particularly vicious insults before Jeralt interceded. She was lucky to have the former mercenary turned general here to keep the peace, though the thought of him once again brought to mind her missing professor–

 

“Lady Edelgard?”

 

A voice brought her out of her thoughts, bringing her attention towards the tent’s entrance. “Oh, Flayn. Did you need something?”

 

“Yes, I was hoping to speak with you,” the young bishop replied. She’d certainly been surprised when Edelgard offered her that position, but she took well to it. Better than most, though Seteth hadn’t been pleased when he heard. Edelgard was fairly certain he still bore a grudge for that revelation ruining his reunion with his wayward daughter. “I hope this isn’t a bad time.”

 

“No, not especially.” Edelgard smoothed her papers out and got up from her seat to directly face her former classmate. “Is the matter urgent?”

 

“Um…yes, it is. Well, in the sense that I think you should know about it urgently, though I am unsure if we can act on the information right now…ah, to explain, my father and Captain Jeralt received word from a surviving member of the knights that were at Zanado.”

 

Edelgard felt her brow furrow. “So something did happen. By ‘surviving member’, I assume some sort of attack took place directed at the Knights of Reclamation?”

 

“Yes, though it sounds less like an army attacked and more like a large group of demonic beasts swarmed into the canyon. They may have been directed by magic, though I’m not completely sure,” Flayn explained with a worried frown, “My father and Cardinal Luca are obviously upset and I’m worried they might be about to go back to the canyon.”

 

“Do you think they’ll desert?”

 

“I think the entire group might. The reclaimers might be on our side, but you and I know it is because they think we support their ideas. If they decide that reclaiming Zanado matters more than trying to take back Fort Merceus…”

 

Edelgard sighed, rubbing her temple to try to stave off a building sense of irritation. It wasn’t like the “Reclaimers” had even been that useful, particularly with their insistence on being independent from Imperial command, but it would still be a blow to the forces they had gathered here. To say nothing of how it would affect morale to have such a large force abandon them… 

 

“I see I'll need to speak with them,” Edelgard muttered, as she began to head out of the tent, “Do you know where they are?” 

 

“I last saw them by the canteen, but maybe you should save this for tomorrow? You look exhausted.” 

 

“The sooner I deal with this, the sooner I have one less problem to deal with later,” Edelgard responded, before pausing. She began to look around, searching the crowds of soldiers all around her as they attended to what duties they had or simply spent time with friends. It was still early in the evening so the camp was still active. So why did she feel like there was something out of place?

 

“Is something wrong, Edelgard?” 

 

“...No, I suppose the night air was brisker than I realized,” Edelgard said, her exhaustion momentarily forgotten as tension built in her shoulders.

 

Flayn frowned. “Perhaps we should return to your tent for–”

 

The Nabatean stilled, some age-old instinct recently reawakened by the pressures of war  warning her of danger right as a completely ordinary soldier passed by her. Something about the way he moved, the purpose in his step, made her look at him, her ear twitching at the sound of cloth against metal–Her hand shot forward, grabbing him by the wrist, and she could feel a knife up his sleeve.

 

“Flayn? What are you–”

 

“Tch.” The assassin clicked his tongue, ignoring the emperor for the moment as he suddenly twisted and Flayn saw a flash of steel going right towards her–

 

Edelgard’s fist crashed into the assassin’s side with an audible crunch as several of his ribs broke at once. He had a moment to choke, spittle mixed with blood flying from his mouth, before Flayn used a technique her professor had shown her back at the monastery to pull him fully over her shoulder and slam him against the ground, using the man’s weight against him.

 

The man only had a moment to gasp out in pain, before Edelgard kicked him in the head, knocking him out completely as the soldiers around them began to react. Shouts of panic began to ring out, soldiers clamoring that there had been an assassination attempt on Edelgard, while some rushed to her aid–

 

Edelgard only had a moment to react, jerking backwards as one of those approaching soldiers attempted to slice her throat open. She found her footing without stumbling and deflected the second attempt to stab her, right before she noticed Flayn raise a hand out of the corner of her eye.

 

She shut her eyes tight, but there was still enough brightness to the flash of light to see it through her eyelids. It still kept her from being blinded while the second assassin screamed in pain, clutching at his eyes after the bright light seared them. Fortunately for him, he didn’t have to linger with that pain for long when Edelgard smashed her fist into his jaw, sending him to the ground in a single blow.

 

“ASSASSINS IN THE CAMP!” rang out loud as Flayn moved to Edelgard’s side, her eyes wide with alarm.

 

“Edelgard, you’re bleeding!”

 

The emperor paused, then glanced at her arm, where a thin cut had gone through her sleeve. “It’s nothing, I can–”

 

Her head swam before a sudden comfort spread through her body, cool and soothing as Flayn pressed a glowing hand to the wound. “Venin blades–We can’t let them cut you again!”

 

“I wasn’t planning to allow them to,” Edelgard stated, her attention turning to the camp as more shouts and cries went up, along with sudden bursts of fire and lightning. Of course they would aim to burn the camp. They’ll be targeting my fellow Eagles. “Flayn, grab Labraunda from my tent then stay with me! We need to regroup!”

 

“Understood!” Flayn moved quickly, immediately acting as ordered and soon enough, Edelgard felt the familiar weight of her sacred axe in her hand. It was time to clear out these fools that thought they could take her head.

“You really did jinx us,” Byleth remarked at the sight of half the Imperial camp ablaze, a deep frown on her face as she urged her new wyvern onward.

 

“I didn’t mean to!” Shez retorted, scowling at the flames below from her own pegasus, “How was I supposed to know–You know what, never mind, let’s just figure out where your students are and get this over with!” She glanced back at Bernadetta, who was riding with her and had her arms wrapped tightly around her waist. “Do you see any of them, Bernie?”

 

“W-What?? H-How am I supposed to see them from up here?!” the archer squeaked, tightening her grip as thunder boomed down below.

 

“You’re an archer, you should have good eyesight!”

 

“Th-That’s not how it works! I can’t see when it’s nighttime and there’s smoke and fires ruining my night vision–” Bernadetta paused as a flash of light caught her attention. “W-Wait, that’s–Ah! That’s Edelgard, down there! That’s her axe!”

 

“Ha, you see? I was right!”

 

“Right, then that’s where we’re going,” Byleth decided, before she stood up in her saddle.

 

“Yeah, that–Wait, what are you doing–” Shez began to ask before Byleth leapt from her wyvern. “WHA–YOU DUMBASS!” She immediately passed the reins of the pegasus to Bernadetta, who blinked in surprise. “Hold this!”

 

“W-W-Wait, Shez, are you–” Bernadetta tried to ask before the mercenary abruptly vanished from the saddle, leaving the archer to try to steady the steed as she was suddenly abandoned in the middle of the sky. “Ah–Oh I knew I shouldn't have come along! Why do you do this to yourself, Bernie!?”

 

Meanwhile, a certain plummeting professor searched the burning camp below for signs of her students. The world moved in slow motion around her as she assessed the situation, her powers over time bringing everything to a crawl while she took note of who she could spot.

 

There was Ferdinand, calling out commands and leading the efforts in quelling the flames. No assassins around him.

 

There was Linhardt, teeth grit as he tried to heal a wounded soldier without getting too close to the blood leaking from her wounded chest. Caspar was with him, his fist crushing the skull of the assassin that swung the blade. Blood hung, suspended in the air as it became clear the assassin wouldn’t survive Caspar’s blow. Not an immediate threat then.

 

There was Marianne, atop a familiar steed as she called down a rain of ice over burning fortifications. She hadn’t seen the assassin poised to leap. Byleth had.

 

In a sudden jolt, time resumed and Byleth repositioned herself, feet now pointed towards the ground. By all rights, a fall like this would injure her, were she still fully human.

 

Dirt and dust exploded outward as she landed, but she’d already moved, leaping and swinging her sword to cleave straight through the foe that would have hurt her student. He fell in two halves while she rolled to her feet, eyes scanning for more danger.

 

“...professor?”

 

She paused, glancing up at the utter awe in her student’s voice, and nodded. “Hi Marianne. I would love to talk soon, but I need to make sure everyone is safe. You’re doing great.”

 

“Th-Thank you…th-thank you!” Marianne called out, surprised but smiling as a sudden joy swelled in her heart. 

 

With a small smile in return, Byleth rushed off, searching for anyone else in danger. It was hard to tell who was an enemy right away now that she was in the thick of it, but as time slowed to a halt again, she could see Shez cutting down an assassin who had been clashing blades with Petra. 

 

Nearby, Constance and Hapi were covering Dorothea while the songstress helped an injured soldier to cover. The former mercenary nearly dropped her control of time at the sight of her, but she kept her focus. They could talk once everyone was safe. 

 

Soon enough, Byleth found Edelgard standing by Flayn while the pair scanned their surroundings. In that moment, her chest clenched as she saw a familiar smiling face behind the two. 

 

Noticing her, Shax waved, before his sword moved in the stopped time, aiming for the Emperor’s neck. 

 

There was no time to think. The Sword of the Creator swung out, racing across the distance and clashing with Shax’s false version. The chains intertwined, before Byleth felt herself suddenly get pulled off her feet as Shax yanked his sword back while cocking his fist. So Byleth did what came naturally and slammed her fist into his.

 

Time resumed in a boom of sound, elemental light and darkness bursting outwards with a rush of emerald and amethyst flames.

 

Byleth glared into Shax’s eyes, his gaze burning a bright crimson in a distorted mirror of her sister. Shax grinned back, filled with glee at the prospect of fighting his fated foe.

 

And nearby, Edelgard’s eyes went wide at the sight of her professor. “Byleth?”

 

There was a sharp, painful noise as the mirrored swords pulled free from one another, their chains grinding before they settled back into proper blades. The noise didn’t matter though. What mattered was the impossible sight in front of the young emperor’s eyes.

 

“Hi Edelgard,” Byleth greeted, her gaze flicking towards her student for a moment before returning towards her grinning foe, “I’m sorry it took me so long to get back. I would really like to catch up soon, but it’ll have to be after this. Also, hi Flayn.”

 

Flayn didn’t respond, mostly because her jaw had dropped at her professor’s unexpected return. “...h-hi?? Hello?? Um…” She looked at Edelgard, hoping she had a better grasp of the situation.

 

Edelgard simply nodded though, before moving to face Shax. “Shall I assume this is the enemy’s commander, professor?”

 

“Probably. His name’s Shax, he’s apparently Shez’s brother, and he has weird powers because of Agarthan experiments,” Byleth summed up, “He can’t reverse time, but he can tell when I do it and he’s able to still move when I stop time.”

 

“You can stop time?”

 

“Yeah, it’s a new thing. Goddess powers. I might be a dragon now.”

 

Edelgard processed that information, then just nodded. “Understood.”

 

“Are you two done catching up with each other?” Shax asked, crouched low and tensed as he prepared to lunge for the pair, “I don’t mind if you want to chat, but I was really looking forward to this.”

 

“I see. Then could you leave and let us talk instead of fighting?” Byleth requested, making Shax blink.

 

“I…no? Obviously no.”

 

“Mm. Then, before we start, did you kill a bald, heavyset man in the Red Canyon? He would have been with a blonde woman.”

 

The clone cocked his head. “Huh. You knew that guy?”

 

“Should I take that as a yes?”

 

“You should, because I did. Mind if I ask why you care?”

 

Byleth shook her head. “I don’t mind. I wanted to make sure you were the one who killed Victor and took Candace’s arm. I owe you for both of them.”

 

“Oh really? If I knew offing some random mercenaries was all it took to get you raring to fight, I would’ve hunted the blonde too.” Shax smirked. “Actually, is your papa somewhere around here? Maybe I should take his head–”

 

As he taunted her, Shax kept an eye on Byleth’s sword, ready for her to swing. The moment she extended it, he'd strike. Yet instead of doing what he thought the logical thing was, Byleth instead launched a fireball at his face, the explosion nearly engulfing him as he jumped back. 

 

“Jeez, can't take a joke huh?” Shax asked, smirking while the smoke began to dissipate. Bringing his sword up, he blocked the Sword of the Creator as it whipped through the smoke, its chain wrapping around his own blade. He felt himself get pulled forward for a moment, before pulling back, making the blade go taut as Shax stared down the former mercenary. “I know you’re strong and all, but you didn't think you'd be able to sweep me off my feet like that, did you?” 

 

“No, I'm just holding you in place.” 

 

At her response, Shax blinked, before seeing a shadow move over him. Looking up, he stared mouth agape as he saw the Emperor rushing down towards him, having leapt up into the air to smash him down. Shit.

 

In an instant, Shax vanished out from under the emperor’s earth-shattering swing, warping a few feet away with an amused grin. “Alright, you can be clever, I–”

 

Then a ball of light hit him straight in the face, making the clone yelp as he clutched at his eyes with his free hand. Shit! The small one, I forgot about the damn shortie–

 

On a desperate instinct, he brought his sword up in an attempt at guarding himself, just in time to feel the emperor’s axe slam into his blade. And while the Sword of the Liberator was sturdy enough to meet the sacred axeblade without breaking, Shax was pretty sure he felt the bones in his arm rattle as he was sent skidding back, his feet digging into the dirt. He reoriented his sword and stabbed it into the ground, stopping his momentum and letting him keep his footing. 

 

Shax blinked the spots from his eyes just in time to see the Sword of the Creator swing straight for his head. So of course he warped again, his heart pounding in his chest as he felt a grin come to his face. His last fight with the Fell Star hadn’t been nearly this close–

 

He had to deflect another fireball, then duck a cutting gale from the short lady, who was really starting to concern him. He hadn’t been expecting to deal with a support mage along with the Fell Star and the Emperor, and she was helping keep him more on the backfoot than he liked, so he did the logical thing of warping behind her and stabbing–Then he blinked as she deflected his attack with a staff of all things. That shouldn’t have been possible, but then he noticed the glow of sacred light on the stupid thing right before he realized her hand was raised right at his chest, green wind gathering at her palm.

 

“Shit–!” On instinct, he warped, but even then he’d felt the blades of wind cut into him in the half-second before the girl’s spell went off. Grimacing as he felt blood leak down his chest, Shax stared at his three opponents, reassessing his odds. 

 

“Okay time out, who the hell is she?” he asked, leveling his sword at Flayn. 

 

“My student,” Byleth answered, taking the pause to assess the bloodied Agarthan in turn.

 

“Yeah no shit! I meant, what's her deal!? The only one of those beasts I was told to worry about was that Archbishop of yours!” 

 

“I am Flayn,” the Nabatean in question calmly stated, “And I believe you owe at least an arm to my professor.”

 

“At least,” Byleth agreed, “I suppose I could be satisfied with your arm and the head of your boss, as long as you surrender.”

 

“Heh, no chance of that,” Shax replied, his eyes flicking from threat to threat. He knew the Emperor was strong, but he had no idea she had one of the abominations as a bodyguard! And from what he could hear of the old man’s muttering, the bandit actually recognized her, which meant she had to be a dangerous one. “Have to say, I didn’t expect the Flame Emperor to have a secret weapon like this just wandering around her camp! I thought you understood how the abominations–”

 

“I’m not speaking to you,” Edelgard bluntly stated, “Surrender or die.”

 

“Harsh! I’m trying to establish a rapport here!”

 

“No, you’re trying to decide if this is a fight you can win,” Byleth noted, “Just like last time. And just like last time, the longer you take to fight us, the more likely it is that reinforcements will appear. Do you think you can win if that happens?”

 

“Hey now, I haven’t even gone all out yet, remember?” He grinned, markings beginning to spread across his skin as an orange glow surrounded his body. “So you really shouldn’t–”

 

“You don’t have a halo.”

 

Shax blinked, then raised an eyebrow at Byleth. “Excuse you?”

 

“You don’t have a halo. Shez has one when she does that,” Byleth explained, a hint of curiosity entering her eyes, “You don’t have the same powers, do you? At least, you don’t have the entire thing that she does.”

 

“...what the hell is that supposed to–” A sudden twinge in his head made Shax whirl, his sword colliding with the twin blades wielded by his counterpart as Shez glared straight into his eyes.

 

“Hey, asshole. You owe me your life for taking Victor’s.”

 

“Seriously, who the hell was that guy to you two!?” Shax questioned, before warping away right before Byleth’s extended sword could take his head off. He landed on his feet, but had to block another strike as Shez appeared right in front of him, fully able to keep up with him thanks to her own warp. “Gh–Damn it, you won’t get me like this!”

 

He warped again, this time behind Edelgard, and stabbed straight through absolutely nothing as she suddenly vanished.

 

“WHAT!? SHE CAN DO THAT TOO!?” he yelped, baffled, before a flash caught his attention and he had to block two swords at once. He stumbled, trying to deflect each stab and strike, before Shez suddenly vanished. “Wh–Ah.”

 

For a moment, Shax wished he had the ability to stop time too because all of a sudden a number of things made sense at once. First, Edelgard couldn’t warp, but Flayn could use Rescue to bring her out of danger. Second, his foes were much better at coordinating than he expected because Shez had just vanished right as Flayn cast what a small part of his mind recognized as Excalibur. Third, wind magic hurt. A lot.

 

Byleth watched as the sudden cyclone ripped into Shax, cutting into his armor and sending him flying up into the air to crash painfully into the dirt nearby and go limp, either dead or unconscious. She was glad the plan worked, especially since she’d had to keep the cues for it nonverbal, but she still glanced at Edelgard to see if she was okay. 

 

The emperor looked exhausted and it was likely only a determination to see the fight to its end that was keeping her on her feet. She would need rest after this, which might be difficult to convince her of considering how bad the camp looked at the moment. And that wasn’t even addressing how much Byleth had to explain about these past few years.

 

Still, they could fix things up and then have a proper reunion–

 

Byleth paused, her brow furrowing as she heard…a flute? Strange music filled the air, the sound carrying despite the voices shouting and the roar of flames around the camp. And something about it…she could feel a strange sensation in her chest. Like a growing heat.

 

“The hell is that?” Shez muttered as she walked up beside her sister, swords still in hand while she frowned at the sound.

 

“I’m not sure,” Byleth responded, listening to the strange tune with a deep frown.

 

“A-Ah…”

 

“Flayn? What’s wrong?” Edelgard asked, drawing Byleth’s attention towards the emperor as she worriedly checked over her fellow Eagle, who was clutching her head.

 

“I-I do not…I do not know, something about that sound…” A faint glow formed around her body, green light beginning to emanate from her skin.

 

“What in the world…?”

 

“Ah, Flayn!” Byleth hurried over to her students, but before she could do anything, the light faded as the music stopped and a voice sounded out.

 

“So you proved to be useless after all. I should have expected as much,” stated a man dressed as an Imperial soldier. He held his side as he gazed down at Shax, then snorted contemptuously and kicked the fallen clone straight in the chest.

 

“GAH! F-Ffhah, w-what the hell?!” Shax choked out, glaring up at the soldier, “You prick! Why kick me!?”

 

“What else should be done with a lazy fool?” the man questioned rhetorically, before turning his gaze towards the four women warily watching him.“The Fell Star and the Failed Vessel. Interfering again, I see. Bias should have burnt you both to ashes when she had the opportunity.”

 

“Oh great, another one,” Shez muttered, annoyed, “How many of you assholes are there?”

 

“Hmph. You really are a foolish vessel. I am no mere ‘asshole’, I am Dolofonos! The Agarthan Sage of Blood!” he declared as his guise melted away, revealing a thin, lean man in black assassin’s garb, “And I am here to end you, so-called Emperor!”

 

Byleth frowned and immediately moved in front of her students to protect them, though Edelgard didn’t respond at first. She stared at the declared assassin, her tired mind trying to think of why this particular Agarthan seemed familiar… “Oh. You’re the one Flayn threw into the dirt earlier.”

 

“You threw him into the dirt?” Byleth asked, glancing at Flayn.

 

“Hm? Oh, um…oh, yes, I did! Yes, that was earlier, he tried to stab Edelgard so I threw him over my shoulder, like you taught me, and Edelgard kicked him in the head,” Flayn readily explained, perking up a bit.

 

“...” Shax glanced up at his superior. “So I’m the useless one, huh?”

 

“You may have thwarted my first attempt on your life, traitor,” Dolofonos began, ignoring Shax, “But you have no idea the type of hell I’ve unleashed on your encampment!”

 

“Does it have to do with the flute you have?” Shez asked, pointing with her sword to the flute in the assassin’s hand. The one that wasn’t holding his ribs.

 

“Indeed, with this, ‘The Demon’s Lure’, I have summoned a horde of demonic beasts to destroy this entire camp!”

 

“Oh. So like Hapi’s curse?” Byleth asked.

 

Dolofonos paused. “Who?”

 

“Hapi. When she sighs, she summons demonic beasts.”

 

“That…no, of course not! The Lure does not merely ‘summon’ demonic beasts, it calls upon an entire horde!”

 

“Okay. Where are they?” Byleth inquired.

 

“...they will be arriving soon! They merely take time to get here.”

 

“You know demonic beasts show up immediately whenever Hapi sighs, right?” Shez pointed out, “I think you made a worse version.”

 

“No, we didn’t, because the Lure summons a horde .”

 

“From where? Do they just show up or do you need to have a bunch of them already prepared?”

 

“Stop questioning the Lure! You do not need to know the details!”

 

“Oh damn it all,” Edelgard muttered, feeling a headache coming on, “Don’t you idiots have a number of beasts in Fort Merceus?”

 

They did, in fact. And, at the moment, every single one of those demonic beasts were going berserk and attempting rip their way free of Fort Merceus so they could charge the Imperial encampment, much to the panic of the Agarthans still at the fortress who suddenly had to deal with their rampage.

 

“...that isn’t important!” Dolofonos insisted, “What is important is that you die tonight, traitor!”

 

“I am not going to argue the semantics of my loyalty with a delusional assassin,” Edelgard stated, stepping forward with her axe in hand, “I don’t know how many of your comrades you brought. I doubt any of them are still alive. You’ve lost already.”

 

“I’ve lost nothing! You’re the one who lost! As we speak, my comrades are burning that damned city of Moss! Even if my mission fails, you’re already finished!”

 

“Ah–Why would you tell her about that!?” Shax questioned, baffled by his superior’s inability to keep his mouth shut.

 

Edelgard, meanwhile, furrowed her brow. “Moss? Moss…Moz–Mozghuz?” Her eyes widened in alarm. “You’re burning Mozghuz?!”

 

“That’s right! And you have no way of–!”

 

“Shez, can you warp to Mozghuz?” Byleth asked, turning to her sister.

 

“Uh, not sure, but maybe? I don’t know where that is exactly–“

 

“It’s a coastal city in Hevring territory,” Edelgard stated, immediately focused on Shez, “If I show it to you on a map, can you get there?”

 

“Uh, maybe? I’m not great at reading maps–Oh, maybe if someone sends me in the area, I could just head for the first flaming city I see?”

 

Dolofonos, meanwhile, was starting to think he said too much. So he defaulted to his first instinct and pulled a knife. “You’ll never get the chance–“

 

Then he had to dodge as a sacred axe nearly split his head in twain. “Ha! Foolish traitor, I cannot be felled by–!”

 

Then he had to dodge, again, as the Sword of the Creator swung out and nearly took his head off. “Geh–Foolish Fell Star! I shall not be slain by–!”

 

Finally, a cutting gale caught him in the chest and sliced him in half, a choked noise sounding out before the Agarthan Sage of Blood collapsed in a spray of his title’s namesake.

 

“Woah. Nice aim there, Flayn,” Shez praised, glancing at the frowning healer.

 

“Hm? Oh, thank you! It’s better to aim for center mass with ranged attacks, right professor?”

 

“Mm hm.”

 

“Still, was that your first time killing someone?” Shez asked, “Because I know that can be hard for you healer types–”

 

“It wasn’t,” Flayn replied.

 

“Oh. Really?”

 

“I have fought in two wars, Shez. It would be surprising if I hadn’t.”

 

“...huh. Wait, was there another war before this one? Or is this the second–No, wait, hang on, I think I’m forgetting something…”

 

“She’s Saint Cethleann,” Byleth explained.

 

“Right! Yeah, okay, and Seteth’s Cichol, I remember now. Oh yeah, is he around here?”

 

“We can find him later, we still need to deal with your apparent brother,” Edelgard said. 

 

“He already left,” Byleth pointed out, pointing towards the spot  on the ground where Shax had been, “He warped away when that assassin revealed their other plan.” 

 

“Hm, right, then we need to move. If we're lucky, they haven't begun to burn Mozghuz yet, but we shouldn't delay our response,” Edelgard stated, letting out a sigh. Though her eyes softened as she glanced at Byleth. “...We can talk afterwards.” 

 

“I would be happy to,” Byleth replied with a smile.

 

“Uh, not to interrupt the happy reunion, but don’t we have to deal with the demonic beasts thing?” Shez asked, earning another sigh from Edelgard.

 

“Right. Problems never seem to cease…we’ll have to send scouts to see if there are actually any demonic beasts approaching, then perhaps send a team to cull them as needed. If we could divide our forces properly, with perhaps one half dealing with the threat while the other heads to Mozghuz to–”

 

“FLAYN! WHERE ARE YOU!? ARE YOU SAFE?!”

 

“Or someone else could interrupt me,” she muttered while Flayn grimaced, turning towards the sound of Seteth’s voice.

 

“I’m here, father! Please stop shouting! Edelgard already has a headache!” she called back, trying to pitch her tone to carry without making Edelgard’s headache worse.

 

“FLAYN!” Seteth had no such considerations, and him landing his wyvern nearby didn’t help matters, “Thank the goddess, I was so worried! Are you alright? You aren’t hurt, are you?”

 

Flayn tried not to grimace at her father’s fussing. “I’m perfectly fine, father. I was at Edelgard’s side the entire time. I was completely safe.”

 

“Yeah, she even killed the enemy commander!” Shez spoke up in support, though her words earned a sigh from Flayn and an alarmed look from Seteth.

 

“She did?! Flayn, are you–“

 

“Father, I am a war veteran, please stop coddling me!”

 

“Eesh, you’re still at it, Seteth?” an unexpected voice spoke up, making both Byleth and Shez pause, “I know you’re worried about your kid, but the rest of us are still trying to put out fires–…”

 

Jeralt Eisner blinked.

 

The noise of the camp seemed to fade away, the yelling of soldiers and crackling of flames melting into meaningless noise. Byleth felt her throat tighten up as she stared at her father, who looked exactly like she remembered. Rushing forward, she pulled the man into a tight hug. 

 

“Hello Papa,” she murmured, pressing her face into his chest. She had too many thoughts in her head right now, worries and concerns, and she tried her best to focus on what was important. “I want to talk soon, but I have to make sure Mozghuz doesn't get burned down.”

 

“...I…uh…what?” Jeralt responded, baffled. He still hugged her back, of course, obviously. His mind was just taking a moment to catch up with the fact that his daughter was in his arms again. 

 

“Mm…I missed you,” Byleth replied. She attempted to pull back, but Jeralt just hugged her tighter, keeping her in place.

 

“...I missed you too, kid,” he said, tears beginning to prick at his eyes. He was feeling too many emotions at once, though one rose above the rest as he started to look around. “Is Shez with you? Where…”

 

A ways away, Shez stiffened when her father noticed her. She felt awkward, knowing it was her fault that Jeralt had been left alone this whole time–

 

“Oh thank the goddess, you’re both okay.”

 

Then her father’s words registered, and she couldn’t stop herself from rushing right over and wrapping her arms around her family.

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Family Reunion!

Red: The Eisner family is whole once more! And wow, it's been a while since they've seen each other.

Indi: It has! Hopefully things go better now. Well, at least once the war is done anyways.

Red: Speaking of, that's another sage down! Kinda. Dolofonos was more an honorary sage than anything super important.

Indi: He shall be missed. If they bother to remember him.

Melee at Mozghuz

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Cities on the surface were remarkably dark at night. Unlike the constantly lit interior of Shambhala, there were only a few scattered lights visible in Mozghuz, a natural result of the city “going to sleep”. Its denizens would nestle safely in their beds, many unwilling to waste the candles needed to keep awake, while the few lantern-bearing travelers in the dark were primarily guards on patrol to ensure those denizens would have restful nights.

 

None of them were aware of the oncoming destruction in human form. For that reason, Bias pitied them.

 

Not enough to let them live though.

 

She turned her gaze towards the other Agarthans assembled by the hillside. They were more eager, the mages gathered with tomes and staves meant to aid in the upcoming arson while the warriors stayed near the Ladons, keeping watch on the demonic beasts. They chatted about their intended slaughter with a casualness that Bias felt almost envious of.

 

Intellectually, she knew the Fodlaners were beasts. False humans that followed the will of the Fell Star and obeyed the abominations that stole the world from the only true people that existed in this corrupted land. Killing them was something to take satisfaction in.

 

She hadn’t felt satisfaction in a long time. And it brought thoughts to her mind that she wasn’t meant to think.

 

“Lady Bias!” Then a familiar voice pulled her from those thoughts, drawing her attention towards Myson’s mutant.

 

“Shax. I thought you were supposed to be with Dolofonos,” she remarked, regarding the hybrid with a raised eyebrow, noting the wounds on him that were slowly healing on their own. 

 

“Sorry to say but I didn't feel like dying with him, especially after he spilled secrets.” 

 

“What secrets were those?” she asked, idly glancing over the wounds she could see. Nothing beyond superficial damage, from the looks of it, but that was just at the surface.

 

“Well aside from rambling on about how that flute of his was supposed to work, he spilled the fact that you’re supposed to burn this city to the emperor and the Fell Star.”

 

Bias paused in her examination, looking Shax directly in his eyes. “She’s in the empire already? You fought her?”

 

“Yeah, I did, and it didn’t go great. The emperor had one of the abominations as a bodyguard and they caught me off guard.”

 

“Really? No, never mind, you can explain in a moment. To be clear, the Fell Star knows our plans and is coming here?”

 

“Yeah, probably. I can’t imagine they’re going to let us burn one of their cities without…uh, Lady Bias?”

 

“Hm? What is it?”

 

“You’re smiling.”

 

Huh. So she was. Though to call the disturbing leer spread across her face could hardly be called a pleasant smile. “Why wouldn’t I be? You brought me good news.

 

Bias shook off the sense of ennui that had been weighing her down, turning her full attention to Shax. “We’re putting off the attack. Killing the Fell Star takes priority.”

 

“Huh? Wait, but Papa Myson ordered–“

 

“That prick doesn’t outrank me. Besides, burning a city doesn’t do anything for our cause while killing our people’s greatest enemy does,” she explained in a lighthearted, if raspy, tone. 

 

“But our orders–“ 

 

Shax paused as Bias patted him on the head, a genuine grin on the sage’s scarred face. “Don’t worry, you’ll learn to prioritize when you’re older. Just try to live that long, alright?”

 

“…yeah, okay,” he mumbled, his face slightly red, “Uh, so, what do you need me to do?”

 

“Stick around. You can tell when the Fell Star uses her powers, right? So you’re going to be my canary and sing for me whenever that happens. I’ll adjust the plan accordingly as needed. Understand?”

 

He nodded, hiding a slight wince as his aches protested the movement. “Understood.”

 

“Hm. How injured are you?”

 

“Don't worry about me, I can still provide some back up!” Shax said, trying to put on a big smile even as his body ached. 

 

Bias just rolled her eyes and waved a hand, a soft glow settling over Shax’s body as he blinked in surprise. “You’ll be better at doing that if you don’t have broken ribs.”

 

“Ah…yeah, I guess that’s true. I didn’t expect you to heal me though.”

 

“Hmph. I know I’m not as good at it as Pittacus is, but I still know how to cast healing magic,” Bias grumbled, waving off the boy’s words, “Just stay close. You can tell when the Fell Star uses her powers, right? That’ll help me deal with her.”

 

“Oh, alright! Sure, I can be your bodyguard, Lady Bias!”

 

Bias rolled her eyes, but decided not to correct the brat. She had better things to focus on.

 

It hadn’t been too long since they last clashed, but the sadistic sage was already looking forward to her next reunion with Byleth Eisner.

Reunions were a funny thing. Byleth was certainly happy to see her father and all her friends and students again after years apart, but also they were currently in the middle of a potential disaster and she was pretty sure all the hugs she was getting were delaying their response.

 

It was nice at first, being able to hug her dad, and then as they were moving to the war tent, she was brought into a sweeping hug by Ferdinand. Thankfully it wasn't a long hug since he realized it was a serious situation, but after she was put down Petra came in with a quick hug, as did Marianne. 

 

Once again she didn't mind it, but a small part of her did mind getting tackled by Caspar since it sent the two of them sprawling to the ground from the force of the hug. 

 

As she was getting up, she couldn't help but notice Dorothea, the songstress standing at the back of the group. The songstress smiled and raised a hand in greeting, something that Byleth returned, though Dorothea didn’t approach her just yet, for understandable reasons given that Constance had just launched into an excited declaration of just how wonderful it was to see her professor once more. Again, very nice to hear, but perhaps not the right time for it. Still, she soon managed to break away and go up to Dorothea–

 

Who promptly swept her up into an embrace, dipped her, and kissed her straight on the lips, making the former professor’s eyes go wide as her face went fully crimson for the first time in years.

 

“Somebody’s popular,” Shez commented from nearby, amused by her sister’s plight.

 

“Sure is,” Jeralt agreed with a small smile, before glancing at his younger daughter, “How are you feeling?”

 

“Hm? Oh, don’t worry, I’m not jealous. I already met up with most of my classmates from both classes, so I can handle Byleth getting fawned over.”

 

“Heh. That’s not exactly what I meant, kid. It’s been a while since I’ve seen you, and, well…you, both of you, look so different.”

 

“Ah…yeah, I guess that’s true.” Shez ran a hand over her altered hair, her warmer, orange-pink locks standing out amidst the purple. “Yeah, I…sort of got possessed back there, those years ago. I had this…evil ghost in me, and I…” She took a small breath. “...I…I’m sorry.”

 

“You have nothing to be sorry for,” Jeralt stated without hesitation, though his words earned a frown from Shez.

 

“I do though. I…I know it was Epimenides who did it, but he used my body to send Byleth to that void. I was the whole reason she was gone all this time, and then…ugh, it’s a lot to explain, but I…I could’ve tried to find you earlier, but I didn’t. Because…I don’t know…”

 

“You were worried you’d hurt me.”

 

Shez blinked, then looked up at Jeralt, who met her gaze with a sad look of his own. “...yeah. I…I mean, like I said, I–It was my body, and he could just…he could take me over, and…a-and it was my fault–”

 

He put a hand on her shoulder, cutting off the recrimination before it could start. “It wasn’t. Of course it wasn’t. You said this Epimenides guy took control of your body. I believe you. I know, no matter what happens, you would never really try to hurt Byleth. You kids have had your ups and downs, but that’s just what being family is like. There's plenty of things I could have done better, but as long as we have each other, it'll be okay.” 

 

Shez didn't say anything, before holding onto him again, pulling her dad into a hug. 

 

Jeralt didn't say a word, simply wrapping one arm around her, comforting his daughter as she cried. 

 

“...er, should we say something?” Ferdinand inquired, giving the embracing Eisners an awkward glance before Byleth, now covered in kiss marks and still slightly flushed, shook her head.

 

“No, let them have a moment. We need to talk about our plans going forward anyways,” she stated while wiping her face clean, ignoring Dorothea’s smug smile while she drew the assembled Eagles’ attention back to the map at the center of the war tent, “To start off, hi everyone, it’s great to see you, I would be very happy to talk to all of you at length later. Right now, we have two very important things to deal with because it turns out the enemy commander was an idiot.

 

“First, here at Fort Merceus, we have whatever remaining enemy forces their are. I don’t know the complete command structure, so I would like to be filled in as soon as possible so we know if killing Dolofonos disrupted their chain of command, or if we need to eliminate another enemy commander. Either way, we have reason to believe that Dolofonos has caused the demonic beasts at the fortress to go berserk. They may attempt to attack the camp, or they may just rampage. We should shore up our defenses either way, but we might have an opportunity to seize Fort Merceus if luck is on our side.

 

“However, I do not believe that should be our priority at the moment. The second issue we face tonight is that the enemy is aiming to burn the city of Mozghuz.”

 

“What?” Linhardt, surprisingly, looked alarmed. “Why would–I realize Mozghuz is a major city, but it’s hardly of strategic importance compared to Merceus or Enbarr. Or even Boramas.”

 

“What do you mean ‘even’ Boramas?” Ferdinand asked, frowning, earning a sigh from Dorothea.

 

“Ferdie, it’s really not the time,” she chided, before turning to Byleth, “So, what’s the plan, Professor?”

 

“I can answer that,” Edelgard spoke up, somewhat amused that her classmates were deferring to Byleth again already, “I believe the most prudent choice right now is to divide our forces, with myself and the rest of us Eagles forming a strike force to deal with the enemy at Mozghuz before they manage to burn the city. Meanwhile, General Jeralt…ah…”

 

“It’s alright, I get it,” Jeralt said, looking over to the emperor, “You need me here to handle whatever happens with Fort Merceus. Don’t worry, I’ll handle it.”

 

“Thank you, General.” Edelgard nodded to him. “I understand it may be difficult separating this soon–”

 

“Believe me, if I didn’t trust you’d bring them back, we wouldn’t be having this conversation.” He could admit, internally, that he wasn’t really that okay with leaving his kids to fight some pyromaniacs right after reuniting with them, but at least he knew they were fine.

 

“Okay, so, where am I going then?” Shez spoke up, drawing attention her way, “I know Byleth is going with you guys, there’s no way she wouldn’t, but do you want me coming along or would it be better if I stick here in case some bullshit happens?”

 

“Hm, my teacher, what do you advise at this moment? You have a better understanding of Shez’s skills and abilities, so I'll trust your words.” 

 

“...” Byleth glanced over at her sister for a moment, before regarding Edelgard, “I believe she'd be best suited here. Aside from the camp needing everyone they can have in case an attack is launched, she'd be able to get a message out quickly if need be. Not to mention that if our forces from the monastery arrived, she'd be able to fill them in properly.” 

 

“Understood, professor.” Edelgard paused. “Hm, I might need to think of a new title for you, now that you’re no longer working for the academy.”

 

“Professor is fine,” Byleth replied, “I still like the title. Now then, everyone who knows how to ride wyverns or pegasi, please raise your hands. We’ll need to travel quickly, so anyone who doesn’t, I’ll make sure to teach you later, but for now, please pair up with those of us that do. Edelgard, you’re with me, I want you to nap on the way over.”

 

Edelgard blinked. “...er, what do you mean, professor?”

 

“You’re clearly exhausted, so you’re going to be sleeping while I fly our wyvern towards Mozghuz. Would you prefer to sit behind me or in front of me? Front might be safer since I can keep my arms around you.”

 

“I… professor, I don't think that would be the best course of action,” Edelgard protested, her face heating up. 

 

“Hm,” Byleth looked at her, before glancing at Dorothea for a moment, “If you would be more comfortable with Dorothea instead, that can work as well. I'll just need to ride alongside the two to guide my wyvern if you two aren't skilled at flying.” 

 

“Do you think the three of us could sit on the same wyvern?” Dorothea spoke up, starting to grin as Edelgard blushed, “Then we could sit Edie between both of us~”

 

“Maybe? I suppose that's something we can practice for if the case arises in the future,” 

 

“Oh I certainly wouldn't mind ‘practicing’ with you two~” 

 

“Perhaps we can move on to discussing something else,” Edelgard said, her face completely red. 

 

“...Oh, that was flirting,” Byleth realized. 

 

“Maybe I should just go myself and leave her here,” Shez mumbled, earning an amused huff from Jeralt.

 

“It’s good to have you two back.”

 

“Heh. Glad to be back, dad.”

Soon enough, with preparations settled, the Eagles were on their way to Mozghuz. Well, most of them. Unfortunately, Flayn had to remain behind because Seteth was getting very loud about her being in a fight with a dangerous assassin and Marianne offered to remain behind to keep her company. That, and she didn’t really want to leave Dorte behind, and unfortunately her beloved horse happened to be wingless. A shame, but at least most of the class was together for the mission.

 

Due to the safety issues of having three people on one mount, Byleth rode a pegasus alongside her wyvern while Edelgard and Dorothea sat atop it. She had offered Bernadetta a seat on the pegasus with her, but the archer didn't seem to want to be near a pegasus at the moment with how panicked she’d been after the sisters had left her alone on one. A shame, but at least she’d consented to riding with Petra on her wyvern.

 

Regardless, Byleth was happy to have some time with the two, even if Edelgard had quickly fallen asleep thanks to Dorothea’s gentle singing. 

 

“I have to say, it almost feels like we're back at the academy. Just going on one of our usual missions with our professor guiding us,” Dorothea noted as she held onto the sleeping Emperor. 

 

“It does feel nice to be back, even if things have changed,” Byleth replied. 

 

“Speaking of, do you mind explaining why your hair changed colors? I’m not against it, but I am curious.” 

 

“I'll go more into detail when Edelgard is awake, but long story short, I was stuck in the void and I might be a dragon now.” 

 

“...” Dorothea blinked as she stared at Byleth, before letting out a laugh, “You certainly lead an interesting life, Bylie. I can already see the countless operas made in your honor.” 

 

“Hm. Never thought of that, but I suppose it would be interesting,” Byleth muttered, before she glanced at Dorothea, who smiled back at her, “...I'm sorry.” 

 

“Hm? For what?” 

 

“Your smile. It's not as bright,” Byleth said as she looked down at the reins of the pegasus she was on, “I didn't have the option, but…I wasn't here for any of you for three years.” 

 

“You’re right, you didn’t have the option,” Dorothea replied, giving her professor a wry smile, “I’m not going to blame you for being gone, Bylie. I’m just happy you’re back.”

 

“Thank you. I do find it strange everyone keeps saying that though. I thought at least one person would be upset with me for disappearing.”

 

“You’re difficult to be upset with, Bylie, and besides, I don’t think anyone here is cruel enough to blame you for what happened. Sure, we were upset, but not with you. Not after everything you did to make sure all of us were safe.”

 

Byleth smiled. “I’m glad you’re all okay. If you’d been hurt before I could get here…I don’t know what I would’ve done.”

 

“Bylie, that’s sweet to hear, but please stop talking about us being injured for a little bit, okay? I don’t know if you remember, but I’m not exactly proficient at riding any sort of steed and I think if you make me nervous, our scaly friend here is going to sense weakness.”

 

“You don’t need to worry about that. Blade will be a good wyvern and not cause any problems. Right, Blade?”

 

Dorothea wasn’t sure, but it sounded like the wyvern chirped in response. Though her mind couldn’t help but focus on something else Byleth said. “‘Blade’?”

 

“Mm hm. I named him for a fat dragon Rhea stole from me. The ‘Unfaltering Blade of Devotion’.” Byleth glanced over at Dorothea. “Hubert loaned him to me so that’s why I thought of it.”

 

“...hm. Hm.” Dorothea nodded and decided to just leave things there for now.

 

“Oh, I need to name the wyvern I got from Claude.” Byleth, meanwhile, was still focused on the previous topic. “Hm…well if this one is Blade…Bow, maybe?”

 

“You certainly have a very direct naming sense. Oh, speaking of, you'll be happy to hear we have Snappy back at Edelgard’s palace, safe and sound,” Dorothea said, pausing as she heard Byleth let out a happy gasp. 

 

“Oh, if I knew you had him, I would have visited the castle. I’ll need to say hi after–”

 

“INCOMING!” Caspar suddenly shouted. Understandably so, given there was a giant fireball flying directly towards their formation.

 

“EVASIVE MANEUVERS EVERYONE!” Ferdinand added, and the Eagles promptly scattered to avoid the unexpected attack.

 

“Geh–Ah, E-Edie, it’s time to wake–”

 

“I’m awake,” Edelgard interrupted, taking the reins from Dorothea and promptly urging the wyvern downward, “EVERYONE, TO THE GROUND! WE’LL MAKE THE REST OF THE JOURNEY ON FOOT!”

 

“WATCH THE TREES, THERE MIGHT BE AN AMBUSH!” Byleth shouted as well, as she dove down, scanning the area in search for attackers. She couldn't help but frown at the lack of visibility the night gave her, but it did make her question something. 

 

They had been traveling for some time, and they still hadn't spotted a burning city yet. Furthermore, how had the enemy been able to set up an ambush? It implied they knew ahead of time–

 

Shax warped away before we could finish him off, she realized, a frown coming to her face, He must have gone to Bias to let her know we were coming. Did she call off her mission to hunt us instead?

 

It would fit with what Byleth knew of the vengeful sorceress. Which meant her students were absolutely in danger right now. There was a sharp difference between taking on an enemy that didn’t know they were coming and strolling straight into an ambush. One as sharp as the arrow that just plunged into her steed’s throat.

 

“Damn–!” Byleth cursed as the arrow managed to catch the pegasus right in a lethal spot, the poor beast immediately dropping out of the sky before she managed to wind back time and keep the wound from even happening. 

 

Instead, she urged her steed lower than before and leapt off of it when they were close to the ground. The moment her feet touched the dirt, she rushed off into the woods, searching for any hint of her foes. She heard a slight rustling coming from the direction the arrow had come from, and with a flick of her wrist, her sword extended out, stabbing into a bush right as another arrow flew out, grazing her cheek. 

 

Retracting her blade, she flicked the blood off it before pressing up against a tree, taking over while searching for more foes. She could hear more arrows loosed on the breeze and glanced skyward, checking to make sure none of her students were hit. No sudden impacts, but she felt a small frown come up when she noticed there were wyvern riders in black flying to intercept those students that were still in the air.

 

Her mind raced, deciding on if she should focus on keeping her students safe or moving towards the objective when she heard a rustle of movement in the brush. A glance to the side showed knights in black armor on the prowl, their pitch-black plate ironically making them stand out even in the darkness. They held halberds in hand, the points aimed outwards as they swept the forest for Byleth and her students.

 

So of course Byleth swung her blade into the first one that got close, slashing the knight’s head clean from their shoulders before rushing in to take advantage of the close quarters. Normally a lone swordswoman against a squad of knights with polearms would be at a disadvantage, but the Sword of the Creator gave a lot more reach and Byleth was perfectly fine with employing Thunder spells where applicable. And she wasn’t the only one.

 

Lightning split the sky over the woods and Byleth turned her gaze towards the second source of thunder, briefly wondering which of her students was letting loose with the electrifying spells, before a sudden light caught her attention. A bright, orange light, which was rapidly approaching in the form of a truly massive conflagration.

 

Byleth dove to the side, rolling to her feet and running the instant the woods were set alight. The flames spread rapidly behind her, the dark forest turning to a raging inferno within seconds as several points in the woods suddenly erupted into flames. Briefly, she felt a surge of concern for her students, but she buried that fear for their safety under the immediate need for self-preservation as she sprinted her way towards the source of the fireball. After all, she already knew Bias was involved here, so any huge flames lighting up the night had to be coming from her. 

 

Sure enough, the instant Byleth broke through the treeline and her foot touched the grass of the surrounding plains, her eyes immediately locked on the familiar sight of the Agarthan Sage of Fire. The ruby-colored artificial crest stones affixed to her jewelry gleamed in the night, illuminating Bias’s scarred, smirking face.

 

“Byleth Eisner. There you are.” Her smile widened, scarred skin stretching. “I was wondering when I’d get to see you again.”

 

“Call off your men,” Byleth ordered, unamused and unwilling to play along. 

 

“Oh please, as if they'd listen to me at this point." Bias sighed, pretending to be put out. “Those bloodthirsty fools had been raring to go slaughter the beasts in that city for hours by the time I told them we had a change of plans. You should’ve seen how much they were pouting over having to turn away, and it was only by promising them that they could butcher whatever battalion you brought along with you that I kept them from going rushing off on a murder spree. 

 

“Really, you should be thanking me for redirecting their attention. Now they’ll focus on beasts that can actually fight back.” Bias paused as a roar sounded out and the woods lit up with even more flames. “Speaking of beasts, which do you think have better chances here? My monsters, or whatever wretches you managed to scrape together?”

 

“I know my students are better than your troops. I have faith in them.” Byleth stepped forward, her sword in hand as she frowned at the scarred sage. 

 

“Oh please, faith has nothing to do with reality. Both of us know even if my forces were to win, you'd just rewind time to fix your wretches’ mistakes. Who knows, maybe you've already seen them get torn to bits a few times already?” 

 

“I haven’t,” Byleth bluntly stated.

 

That brought a frown to the sage’s face. “You’re serious, huh? That’s annoying. I thought these peons could at least kill off a few of them…well, whatever. At least this way I’ll get the satisfaction of burning you all to the bone by myself.”

 

Byleth frowned as fire began to collect in Bias’ hands, well aware that she'd need to keep her focus on the Agarthan. Even if she wanted to make sure her students were safe, Bias knew her well enough to be able to catch even a slight moment of distraction. 

 

With a flick of her wrist, Bias sent a fire spell towards Byleth, which was easily blocked. Before she could begin to question the weak spell, the former mercenary quickly had to move as a barrage of fire came her way, as the Agarthan seemed to try and overwhelm her with quantity. 

 

“I must admit, before I had to deal with you, I wasn't much for tactics.
