Why bother myself with trying to come up with some ingenious plan when I can just set my enemies alight?” Bias mused, as she continued to launch spells that Byleth deflected or dodged. “Of course, it's not that simple when your opponent can control time, meaning I had to get a bit tricky. I suppose you only have yourself to thank for this.” 

 

Byleth blinked as a fireball shot right past her, going straight into the bushes and colliding with a barrel she hadn’t seen– 

 

A searing heat crashed into her back for a brief moment as the sound of an explosion rang out. 

 

In the next moment, Byleth had returned to just a few seconds prior, blocking the fireball meant for the explosive, before quickly rolling away. 

 

“It truly is a shame that I can't experience the memories of the time you erased. There are so many excruciating moments I wish I could revel in.” Bias sighed fondly with a genuine smile. “Ah well. At least I can enjoy knowing you did suffer. That, and I might as well go all in now that you know.”

 

Byleth’s eyes widened in alarm as wheels of flames gathered at Bias’s hands. She quickly sprinted towards the sage, extending her sword and swinging it in an arc meant to catch her across the neck, only for the swing to suddenly jerk to a stop when it met it’s dark counterpart.

 

“Heh, sorry Fell Star, but I’m not letting you kill Miss Bias too,” Shax stated with a smug grin, making Byleth frown in annoyance, “It wouldn’t look good for me if I let two superiors die in one night, you know?”

 

Byleth didn’t reply. Instead, she rushed forward, intent on locking blades with Shez’s distorted reflection–

 

“Back.” The order came suddenly, unexpectedly, and Byleth’s eyes widened as Shax abruptly vanished into shadow, leaving her with barely a second to freeze time in an attempt to escape the plume of flame before it washed over her.

 

The second the world went gray, Byleth leapt out of the way and rolled to her feet–Only to have to block Shax’s blade before it could cut into her.

 

“Don’t forget, I can’t do the same tricks as you, but I sure as hell can counter them,” he taunted, before looking back right as time resumed, “OVER HERE!”

 

In the next second, he vanished again and Byleth dropped to the ground, narrowly avoiding the flames erupting above her back. She grimaced at the sheer heat, keeping as low as she could to avoid her clothing catching aflame. Fighting these two on her own was going to be difficult…

 

Fortunately for the professor, she wasn’t alone.

 

The only warning Bias received was the slightest glint of light in the middle of the night, caused by the glow of her firestorm reflecting off the axe blade that nearly took her arm off. The flames cut out entirely when she pulled her hand back, though it was still plenty bright enough to see the blue-haired man swinging straight for her head.

 

His blow bounced off a hastily erected barrier that was stabbed through seconds later as the scion of House Aegir joined his comrade from Bergliez in a flurry of strikes that would have broken through the sage’s defenses, were it not for Shax leaping to her aid. 

 

“Caspar, next time do not leap from your wyvern to join the battle!” Ferdinand reprimanded in between stabbing at gaps in the Agarthan swordsman’s defenses.

 

“Hey, you jumped off yours too! How else did you get down here so fast?!” Caspar retorted, using his axe to deflect any return attacks whenever Ferdinand overextended.

 

“Huh, so I did!” Ferdinand admitted with a laugh, “It seems I moved so quickly, I scarcely even thought my actions through!”

 

“I really need to stop those two from pairing up,” Linhardt murmured as he extended a hand towards Byleth, who felt a rush of cool light magic soothing her burns.

 

“They actually cover for each other pretty well,” Byleth noted, before glancing at Lin, “How is everyone else doing?”

 

“Last I saw, our trio of witches were trying to broil a demonic beast.”

 

“…witches?”

 

“Dorothea, Constance, and Hapi. I suppose you could count Hubert as witch-adjacent, but he isn't here right now.” 

 

“Huh. What about Marianne and Flayn?”

 

“You can’t seriously tell me you would count those two as ‘witches’.”

 

“Hm. Yeah, that’s fair….what about Edelgard?”

 

“I feel like being the Emperor puts her above a regular witch.”

 

“Hm. A witchperor…wait, did you see her and the others back in the woods? Are they doing okay?”

 

Linhardt paused as the head of a demonic beast abruptly sailed over the treeline and crashed into the ground nearby. “...I think they’re doing fine, professor.”

 

Byleth nodded, before pushing herself up to rush towards Shax. The purple-haired man couldn't help but scowl as he locked blades with Byleth, his eyes flicking towards Bias.

 

“This isn't going to end well if you don't back down now,” Byleth said, keeping her eyes on the Agarthan. 

 

“As if it would end well even if we surrender,” Shax responded, a half-hearted grin on his face, “The least I can do is make sure you lose out as well.” 

 

“What–?” Byleth found herself stumbling forward as Shax suddenly moved backwards. The next moment she took to right herself quickly turned into one of horror as he saw him twist around, throwing his sword at Ferdinand, the noble’s back turned to them. 

 

Byleth reversed time right as the Sword pierced through the noble. 

 

“Ferdinand, dodge!” Byleth shouted, the noble moving to the side without question as the sword flew past him. 

 

Shax vanished a moment later, grabbing the sword and turning with a swing at Ferdinand’s head, only for Caspar to copy the Agarthan and throw his axe straight at him, forcing Shax to block. Bias attempted to take advantage of the confusion, aiming a Ragnarok at Caspar, only to hiss in pain as an arrow pierced into her palm. She whirled, shooting a furious glare at Bernadetta, who, very admirably, did her best not to cry in fear while nocking another arrow.

 

Shax scowled furiously at the sight of Bias’s wound, but had to focus on dodging another stab from Ferdinand. He swung, breaking through the noble’s spear, only for Ferdinand to immediately draw the sword at his side and keep on swinging.

 

“You’ve got to be kidding–!” Shax snarled, right before Caspar buried his fist into his side. The Agarthan choked, flying across the field and crashing on the ground, before rolling to his feet. Blood leaked from his lips as his eyes flared red, an orange glow burning around his body. “THAT’S IT! I’M GOING TO RIP ALL OF YOU LIMB FROM–”

 

He didn’t get to finish his threat, in large part because Petra, unbeknownst to him, had been moving through the grass right behind him, and in one swift motion grabbed the Agarthan’s head and slashed his throat. Blood sprayed through the air as Shax’s eyes widened and he audibly choked, before warping while clutching his neck. He flashed across the field multiple times, stumbling and choking, then abruptly fell beside Bias, wheezing and struggling.

 

And Bias, surrounded on all sides by enemies, with the object of her hatred right in front of her with a sword in hand, ripped the arrow free from her palm and burned the wound closed. Her eyes flicked towards Byleth, meeting her gaze. The air seemed to still, quiet aside from the crackle of flames and the pained choking of the dying boy at her side, orange light flaring around his body with the effort of keeping himself alive.

 

She should have gone all out from the start. Just burned him to ash along with the Fell Star and her filthy pets. It would have been the smart decision. Now she had the beasts baying for blood all around her.

 

She weighed her options, thinking quickly, then paused when she saw the Emperor stride out from the burning forest. Black blood steamed off her shining axe, its blade burning with her own blazing flames.

 

Edelgard looked more like a goddess than the Fell Star did. Vicious, wrathful, and vengeful towards any slight. The type of god the Agarthan people once worshipped. 

 

The sight brought a small smile to Bias’s face. “Damn. It’s a shame we never got to really work together, majesty. It could've been great.”

 

“Lay down your arms and surrender, Bias,” Edelgard ordered, glaring straight at the sage of flame, “You have nowhere to go and no chance of completing your mission. You will not harm any citizen of Adrestia tonight.”

 

“I could still kill all of you,” Bias pointed out, simply shrugging her shoulders, “As for surrendering…You know I can’t.”

 

“Why not?” Byleth asked, stepping forward with a frown, “You don’t need to throw your life away.”

 

“You’re asking me that? You…” Whatever fury that might have built up inside of Bias sputtered out abruptly, her usual rage failing her. “...I have more reasons to hate you than any other Agarthan. They all hate you in the abstract. You though…you took my sister from me.” She laughed then, bitter and tired as she looked from one god to another. “You understand. Right?”

 

“I do,” Edelgard agreed, “Regardless, I will not allow you to harm Byleth in your misguided quest for vengeance.”

 

“Misguided, huh? Easy for you to say. You killed Chilon, didn’t you?”

 

“Indeed. I offered to let him go, however, if he could remember a single one of my sibling’s names.”

 

“Really? You did that? Huh.” She tilted her head. “You’re telling the truth too…Well, how about it, Byleth Eisner?” She turned her gaze towards the Fell Star. “What is my sister’s name?”

 

“Pittacus,” Byleth answered without hesitation, her guard still up. Though it faltered slightly when she saw Bias blink, genuinely surprised.

 

“...well, I’ll be damned.” The sage let out a sigh, then glanced down. Shax was weakening beside her feet, his regenerative properties unable to keep up with the mortal wound he was barely able to breathe through. He’d likely die in the next minute, at most. “...” 

 

Bias closed her eyes, then looked up at Byleth, who paused at the look of exhaustion in the Agarthan’s gaze.

 

“I can’t stop now,” she simply stated, before magic began to gather at her hands.

 

Byleth and Edelgard rushed forward, followed by Ferdinand, Caspar, and Petra while Bernie let her arrow fly and even Linhardt let loose a Cutting Gale. They didn’t get there in time though as Bias extended her hand and cast Recover on Shax.

 

The young Agarthan gasped as his throat closed back up, his wound mended in seconds, before he looked up to meet the sage’s gaze. She gave him a small smile, then turned as every jewel on her body gleamed with a crimson light, calling upon the strongest flame magic she could possibly manifest: a Meteor Swarm, same as the one that devastated Garreg Mach all those years ago.

 

Yet she didn’t get a chance to cast it. In one swift motion, Edelgard von Hresvelg swung her axe to smash through the barrier the sage had conjured, just in time for her professor to swing her sword in a swift, vertical arc, splitting through the circlet on Bias’s head. The Sword of the Creator cleaved through the artificial crest stone, and in an instant, everyone present was blasted back by the force that erupted from the sage’s forehead.

 

Byleth flew back, though she suddenly skidded to a stop thanks to Edelgard, who kept her arms tight around her professor as she arrested her movement. She glanced back at her student for a moment, grateful for the save, before immediately looking back towards Bias, who still stood.

 

The sage stared upwards into the night, blood leaking from the fragments of stone embedded in her head and flowing from her eyes in a disturbing mockery of tears. Yet the expression on Bias’s face was not one of sorrow, but of pained relief.

 

“NO!” Shax felt no such relief though, his expression twisted in a moment of shock and horror before he stumbled towards Bias, trying and failing to find his feet. Desperate, he warped closer and wrapped his arms tightly around her, barely able to stand under his own power. Even still, he managed to shoot a truly hateful glare towards Byleth before abruptly vanishing with Bias, the pair disappearing from the field entirely.

 

“...uh…did we just win?” Caspar asked, turning towards Byleth with a confused look.

 

“I think so,” Byleth replied, getting back up and helping Edelgard to her feet, “Is everyone okay?”

 

“Nothing that Marianne and Lindhart can't handle, professor!” Ferdinand said, a smile on his face as Dorothea walked over and healed a cut on his head. 

 

“You do remember they're not the only healers, right?” Dorothea asked, letting out an amused huff as Hapi and Constance followed her out from the woods. 

 

“Well, I suppose we should consider ourselves lucky that Bias’ grudge made her forget her mission,” Edelgard stated, before stumbling slightly. 

 

“Are you okay?” Byleth asked, holding onto the emperor. 

 

“Yes, I'm just starting to realize that I might actually need to sleep,” Edelgard said, plainly struggling to stay awake now that the adrenaline was leaving her body. “Hm. Byleth, don’t tell Hubert about this, please.”

 

And then she promptly slumps in Byleth’s arms with a sleepy mumble.

 

“Wow, congrats Bylie, it took me sometime for her to feel comfortable enough to sleep in my arms, yet here you are only a day back and she's already sleeping in yours,” Dorothea teased, having walked over after checking on Ferdinand. 

 

“Hm. Do you want to sleep in my arms as well?” 

 

“Come now Bylie, at least wait till we have some privacy. Though I certainly am willing to take you up on that offer~.” 

 

“Okay, good. I’ve been wanting to cuddle for three years now and I would really love to just get to that,” Byleth replied, unashamed, though she paused after a moment. “Hm. Hopefully things are going okay with Shez…”

Chapter End Notes

Red: Reunions certainly moved fast this time around, but alas, impending disasters have a way of making people hurry.

Indi: They'll have some downtime later, hopefully. Alas that's how wars go.

Red: To compare it to the games, we're in the mission portion of the chapter, not the downtime portion.

Indi: And well, it was certainly a big mission.

Fracas at Fort Merceus

Chapter by RK3996

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Fort Merceus, otherwise known as the Stubborn Old General, was easily Adrestia’s most famous fortress city. It was the capital of Bergliez territory and arguably one of the cornerstones of the entire nation, serving as Enbarr’s greatest bulwark against potential invasions, a role that kept it regarded as the Empire’s most stalwart defender. It would also have been one of two famous forts if the Rowes hadn’t stolen Arianrhod, but that was ancient history that nobody reasonably would still be angry at and thus was irrelevant to the current situation.

 

As for what that situation was, the simplest way to describe it was a fracas. A clash, a skirmish, or even a tussle could also be appropriate words, all owing to the fact that a poorly thought out plan on the part of the upjumped Agarthan Dolofonos, who really hadn’t warranted the sage title he held, led to the entire fort being overrun by demonic beasts.

 

As for how that happened, the simplest explanation was that the Agarthans weren’t as smart as they thought they were. The idea behind the Demon Lure, otherwise known as the magic flute they made, was to replicate the ability of a former test subject to summon demonic beasts in order to swarm their enemies with overwhelming force. 

 

Unfortunately for the Agarthans, they failed to understand a core aspect of the test subject’s ability: When Hapi sighs, her crest quite literally summons the nearest demonic beast, in some cases outright warping a beast to be closer in order to respond properly to what they interpret as a call for aid from one of their own kind. The flute lacked that aspect, and instead only worked by calling the nearest demonic beasts. And while that was very effective at Zanado, where the beasts that had populated the lands surrounding Garreg Mach eagerly heeded its call, it was less effective at Fort Merceus, where the beasts were being kept inside specific stables.

 

Said stables were now shattered, and the beasts were gladly ripping through the garrison that once held them. Including the mechanical Titanii, which were doing their best to hold firm against an onslaught of demonic claws and teeth.

 

Alas, their efforts would prove futile as the nearby forces of the Empire and the Reclaimers besieged the gates and broke straight through in the midst of the chaos. Agarthan commanders soon found their heads leaving their shoulders as a certain shadow flashed through the fort, swinging her swords with practiced precision to cause even more chaos while her father led a charge of armored knights to pierce into the hides of the enemy beasts.

 

Screeches and cries filled the air as wyverns swooped from the night sky and drove their claws into the scaley hides while their riders drove axes and spears into vulnerable necks. Seteth led from the front there, calling for no quarter to be given to the traitors and sorcerers that held the city.

 

Elsewhere in the fort, Jeralt grit his teeth irritably as the order passed around, his lance buried deep in the sparking innards of a Titanus. He pulled it free as the machine collapsed, bleeding lightning, and called instead for the garrison’s remaining troops to surrender.

 

Unfortunately, the first order had already spread, and the desperate garrison fought to their last, convinced only death awaited them at their enemy’s hands. A fear that became a premonition as the remainder of the night was spent on an exhausting slaughter, until finally some desperate soldiers of the principality laid down their arms for a chance at survival.

 

One Jeral granted, though he had to actively stop the Reclaimers from butchering the surrendering soldiers. Suffice to say, even after the fort was fully reclaimed by the allied armies, tempers were high in the war room.

 

“You cannot give my soldiers orders, Captain Jeralt!” Seteth complained, frowning at the Imperial Army’s leader, “You left the knights, they are not under your command!”

 

“It’s general, Seteth,” Jeralt replied, deeply unimpressed, “And I’ll give orders when I need to. Like when your troops are about to execute unarmed prisoners.”

 

“They’re traitors and Agarthans, General . We cannot afford to take prisoners, not when they stand against everything the church was built to protect!”

 

“Even war has rules. If there’s a chance to end the fight early and avoid the slog of killing everyone on the enemy’s side, we should take it. Otherwise, we have to spend hours hunting troops that have hunkered down and won’t give up because it means certain death, just like we did tonight because of your orders.”

 

Seteth scowled. “Agarthans don’t surrender, Jeralt. Their own soldiers would sooner kill a commander that gave that order than give themselves up to be captured.”

 

“Yeah, well one did, and it saved us a hell of a lot more fighting when she got her troops to stand down. So we’re going to treat her the way we’d treat any captured commander and keep her as a prisoner of the Empire. And if you and your knights try to execute her or anyone else we captured, we’re going to have problems.”

 

The two men glared at one another, the air thick with tension while, nearby, Shez and Flayn watched from atop a set of boxes they were using for seats. 

 

“Man, your dad gets aggressive when it comes to war,” Shez remarked, idly cleaning her swords while watching the argument.

 

“I think the years may have worn him down,” Flayn replied, frowning sadly, “He has had to fight without anyone at his side for so long…”

 

“What about Cyril? Or those cardinal guys?”

 

Flayn paused, her cheeks turning slightly pink. “Oh. I forgot about Cyril…”

 

“Isn’t he like your dad’s squire or something?”

 

“I-I haven’t seen either of them in ages! It wasn’t as though I deliberately forgot…” she mumbled with a pout, earning a chuckle from Shez.

 

“Don’t worry about it, I’m sure he won’t mind–Oh hey, speak of Cyril and he appears,” Shez remarked as the door opened and Cyril walked in along with Marianne.

 

The tanned teen raised an eyebrow at Shez, but ignored her in favor of heading over to Seteth. “I spread the news, everyone should be ready to go in another hour.”

 

“Go?” Jeralt asked before Seteth could respond, “What do you mean? You’re planning on leaving?”

 

Seteth grimaced as Jeralt gave him a skeptical look, but nodded. “The Empire has more than enough troops to hold Fort Merceus. The Knights of Reclamation, however, have a duty to return to the church and aid Lady Rhea in this time of crisis, now that we know she’s returned. I am sorry to leave so suddenly, but we can hardly stay here when the Church of Seiros needs us.”

 

“Seriously?” Shez spoke up, frowning, “You’re leaving just like that? You know Rhea’s probably going to want to help the Empire anyway, right?”

 

“I would prefer to make sure of that myself, Shez. Besides, it would be safer for Flayn to return to the monastery–“

 

“I’m not going,” Flayn promptly stated, frowning.

 

Seteth sighed. “Flayn, I know you have friends in the Empire, but–“

 

“Father, no, I–“

 

“Flayn, you misspoke. You meant ‘brother’–“

 

“I meant Father , because everyone already knows I am your daughter, not your sister, and I cannot go with you because I have responsibilities here!” Flayn argued, “I am the bishop of the Southern Church, I cannot abandon my duties just because it is not safe in wartime!”

 

“That–Flayn, you can’t–“

 

“And how is the monastery safer anyway?! The war started with it being invaded and burned! I know I am not a grown woman by your standards, Father, but I have duties and responsibilities of my own that I cannot overlook purely because you are worried for me. If you leave, I am not going with you.”

 

“…” Seteth just stared silently, his mouth agape as he tried to think of something to say. “…but…you’re not safe here.”

 

Flayn let out a loud, exasperated sigh there, earning a chuckle from Shez, who hopped off her perch and grinned at the shorter girl, “Nice work speaking your mind there, Flayn. How about we take a walk before your dad says anything too stupid?”

 

“Hmph…I would quite prefer that. Marianne, are you coming with us?”

 

“Oh, sorry, I was actually just here to report to General Jeralt,” Marianne explained, nodding to Shez’s father, “I have a tally of the battle’s casualties from Miss Gertrude, sir, including injuries and fatalities.”

 

“Ah, thanks for that,” Jeralt replied, “Though you could probably save that for later. I think Seteth and I need to have a…let’s call it a fatherly chat, parent to parent.”

 

“Gross,” Shez said, “Anyway, sounds like you’re free, Mari, so c’mon.”

 

“Oh, alright.” 

 

Cyril watched the three ladies head out, then turned his gaze back to Seteth, who still seemed at a loss for words, and Jeralt, who was giving the chamberlain a much more sympathetic look. “Hm. I still vote that we go to Lady Rhea as soon as possible.”

 

Meanwhile, as the pair of dads began to commiserate over the difficulty in keeping their children safe, Shez glanced at Flayn as they walked along the largely intact ramparts of the fort. 

 

“So, you really aren’t an adult by Seteth’s standards?” she asked, a little curious.

 

“Hmph. I doubt my father would see me as an adult even if I grew taller than him,” Flayn huffed, pouting.

 

“Fathers can certainly be protective in their own way,” Marianne noted. 

 

“Oh, right, how are things going with your dad, Marianne? I mean, I know he's over in the Alliance, but have you stayed in contact?” Shez asked. 

 

“Only recently. I know he wishes for me to return to the Alliance, but I don't have any intention of doing so. Not until the war is over at least,” Marianne responded, before letting out a breath, “It's interesting. This time away from him has actually made me think of my adoptive father in a new light. At the very least, we're certainly in for a long talk once everything has been settled.” 

 

“Yeah, I can get that. I know I definitely want to talk with By and Dad more once things get settled…hey actually, Flayn, you mind if I ask you some…well, personal questions?” 

 

“Hm? Oh, er…what type of personal questions?” Flayn asked, giving Shez a questioning look.

 

“You know, the type that relates to, uh…your and By’s side of the family.”

 

Marianne blinked. “Byleth is related to you, Flayn?”

 

“O-Oh, well, ah…sort of? Not exactly, it, um…we’re cousins!” Flayn decided to say, “And being cousins, we have family things in common so yes, we should probably talk about those things in a more private area! Um, thank you for walking with us Marianne but you can go now, bye!”

 

With that, Flayn promptly took Shez by the hand and pulled her away, earning a blink from Marianne. “Oh. Um…alright then…” She turned and began to walk away, frowning to herself. “Why did they ask me on a walk if they were just going to run off…?”

 

Meanwhile, Shez let herself get dragged along as Flayn scurried away, a little surprised at how strong the short girl’s grip actually was. Still, she pretty easily pulled Flayn to a stop once they got up to the fort’s ramparts, making the Nabatean squeak as she was abruptly halted in her tracks by the much stronger mercenary. “Okay, I think this is private enough. We can’t exactly go much further unless you want to perch on a roof or something.”

 

Flayn blinked. “Um…Shez, I don’t perch on things.”

 

“Yeah, I know, that’s something I do.”

 

“Oh. Huh, I suppose I do recall you having a tendency to ‘perch’ on things…ah, wait, never mind that! Shez, you need to be more subtle! Not everyone knows about the, er…you know!”

 

“The fact that you and every other person with green hair is apparently a dragon person?”

 

“Yes! That! Though also, no, not exactly! Linhardt isn’t, I checked!”

 

Shez raised an eyebrow. “How?”

 

“No pointed ears! That is a consistent quality we Nabateans have–Ah, wait, I said it outloud…”

 

“So I’m guessing that means you haven’t told anyone about being a Naba-thingy?”

 

“Ah, I did tell Edelgard, actually. She even knows about, um…w-well, she knows everything.”

 

“Like you being one of the saints,” Shez noted, nodding.

 

“Oh, so you know that part too…well, yes. So…ah, right, you wished to ask me a personal question, correct?” 

 

“Yeah, well, not anything specific. More so just…well, what exactly does being a Nabatean mean? You can change forms, right?” 

 

“Ah…not exactly. I could, but I lost that ability long ago. Maybe one day I'll be able to regain it, but until then, I'm stuck like this, much like my father,” Flayn explained. 

 

“And that happened because of that war a thousand years ago, right? Against what’s-his-face?” 

 

“Nemesis, and yes. Though I suppose it could be worse. If I had been stuck in my other form, then I would never have been able to befriend all of you.” 

 

Shez shared a smile with Flayn there, before crossing her arms over her chest. “That’s a shame though. It’s good you didn’t get stuck as a dragon, but it would be pretty convenient to have another one around right now.”

 

“Oh, well…I might, maybe, have an idea for how to, um…fix my condition?” Flayn said a little hesitantly, fidgeting slightly with her sleeves. When Shez gave her a confused look, she smiled awkwardly. “Um, so, do you remember that man that tried to kill Edelgard?”

 

“Shax? Or the weirdo with the flute?”

 

“Ah, the second one. And that flute is actually what I wanted to bring up,” Flayn explained as she fished around her robes, before pulling the flute in question out from her sleeve where she’d been hiding it.

 

“Hang on, you took it?”

 

“W-Well it’s not like Dolofonos is going to use it now…it’s just, when he did use it, I could feel this strange energy in my body, so, um…”

 

“She wants to use the flute to regain her draconic form,” Arval explained for Shez, looking curiously at the flute in question as they floated beside their partner, “It does seem to carry some transformative properties for individuals with Nabatean blood…though I would advise against trying to use it outside of a controlled environment.”

 

“Hm, yeah, that would probably be bad,” Shez remarked, before pausing at Flayn’s confused look, “I mean blowing the flute without preparing ahead of time would probably be a bad idea. It’s made to call demonic beasts, right? So we’d have to make sure the area’s clear first, and we don’t know the range it has either.”

 

“M-Mm…I realize there are concerns, but…it could benefit us a great deal, couldn’t it?”

 

“Maybe? I'm not exactly sure about how that'd work…oh hey, quick question, why would Seteth think you're still a kid if you had kids yourself?” 

 

“W-What? Shez, I don't have any children!” 

 

“Then how are there a bunch of people with your crest running around?” 

 

“That's because I granted them my blood! It's the same with my father and Lady Rhea!” 

 

“Wait, really?” 

 

“Yes, how else do you think your father has a crest of Seiros? Lady Rhea likely granted him some of her blood,” Flayn said, letting out a huff as she calmed down, “Nabateans can grant someone a crest by offering them their blood, and it's usually only done to those they are very close to. It essentially bonds the two together.” 

 

“...so like a marriage–”

 

“Not like a marriage! Like an adoption! Those are two very different things!”

 

“...so you do have kids?”

“No! Not–You can adopt a person as family without them necessarily being your child, okay? Do you understand?” Flayn asked, getting a bit frustrated.

 

“No, not really–”

 

“Your sister adopted you as her sister,” Arval spoke up, making Shez pause.

 

“Ohh, like that…yeah, okay, I get it. So you have siblings then?”

 

“...” Flayn started to rub her temples. “...I am being messed with. You are messing with me, right?”

 

“Maybe a little bit,” Shez replied, admitting nothing.

 

“Okay, well if the Professor gave Dorothea her crest, would you call them sisters?” 

 

“...so it is a marriage thing–”

 

“Shut up, please,” Flayn requested.

 

“Heh, alright, shutting up–Oh, huh.”

 

Flayn sighed, looking up at the taller girl as she stared off into the distance. “What is it now?”

 

“Hm…not sure if I should say, you did just ask me to shut up–”

 

“Shez, you are my friend and I care for you, but you are being as annoying as my father right now.”

 

“Okay, okay, I’ll cut it out.” She raised a hand and pointed out into the distant horizon. “We’ve got a dragon coming this way.”

 

“...” Rather than say anything further, Flayn just turned around to look in the direction indicated. “...huh. Huh. That’s Lady–Uh, I mean, it’s the Immaculate One! The holy dragon sent by the goddess–”

 

“Yeah I already know it’s Rhea.”

 

“Oh…please don’t tell anyone else.”

 

“She’s not keeping it a secret. I’m pretty sure all the Deer know already at this point, maybe the Lions too, and I’m sure Edelgard knows already.”

 

“Well, yes, she does, but–Wait, why is Lady Rhea coming here?” Flayn asked, abruptly realizing that it was very weird indeed for the archbishop to not only leave the monastery, but to do so in dragon form.

 

“If I had to guess, she’s probably pissed off that I warped away to Enbarr in the middle of a conversation with her.”

 

“…” Flayn turned to stare at Shez. “…why would you do that?”

 

“Sometimes I just do stuff without thinking about it. It’s a problem,” she admitted with a shrug, “Anyways, we should probably tell your dad that Rhea’s visiting. And probably let the rest of the fort know so they don’t think we’re being invaded by some sort of fancy demonic beast.”

 

Flayn was about to say she didn’t think anyone would mistake Rhea for a demonic beast, before she considered how scary the Immaculate One could look to humans and how the soldiers in the fort had already been fighting demonic beasts all night. “Hm…yes, let’s do that.”

Luckily, there wasn’t a panic when an enormous dragon landed within the courtyard of Fort Merceus, though there were a whole lot of shocked gasps when the gathered troops saw that dragon turn into the archbishop.

 

“Yes, yes, I was blessed by the goddess, it’s very impressive,” Rhea said, waving off the stunned looks while a number of wyvern and pegasi landed nearby, carrying with them some very familiar faces, “Now where is Byleth?”

 

“She’s on a date with Edelgard and Dorothea at some city called Mozghuz,” Shez quite helpfully answered from beside Rhea, earning a startled noise from Catherine at her sudden appearance and an exasperated sigh from the archbishop.

 

“Shez, what is she actually–Oh, hello Flayn.”

 

“Hello Lady Rhea!” Flayn greeted with a smile and a curtsy, prompting a smile in turn from Rhea.

 

“It’s good to see you are well. Perhaps you could be more helpful than Shez?”

 

“Hey, I’m plenty helpful!” Shez complained while Flayn paused. 

 

“Um…the thing is, Lady Rhea, Shez wasn’t entirely inaccurate? Byleth really did go to Mozghuz with Edelgard and Dorothea.”

 

“Oh. Hm. Why in the world would she go to–?”

 

“LADY RHEA!” 

 

Rhea tried not to sigh at the shouts, instead turning to greet an alarmed Seteth and some very flustered Knights of Reclamation alongside an equally exasperated Jeralt. Meanwhile, Shez glanced over at the archbishop’s retinue, noting who decided to come along on her trip.

 

“Oh, hey Mercedes, hey Alois,” she greeted, smiling at the blonde and her honorary uncle.

 

“Greetings Shez! I hope our sudden arrival isn't a drag-on the resources!” Alois greeted with a large smile. 

 

“Hello there Shez, you may want to move,” Mercedes greeted, getting Shez to blink. 

 

“Wait, what–” Shez received an answer before she could finish asking, thanks to the sudden kick she felt slamming into her side.

 

“Why the hell did you just leave without saying a word!?” Kronya yelled, glaring down at Shez while she tried to recover. 

 

“K-Kronya?! Okay, look, I know–” And once again Shez was cut off, this time by a book as Lysithea smacked her over the head with a hefty tome. 

 

“IDIOT! What in the world made you think it was okay to rush off into a war front on your own!?”

 

“Ah–W-Wait, I wasn’t on my own, I brought Byleth with me!” Shez tried to explain, but neither glaring girl seemed to appreciate her excuse.

 

“You damned moron!” Kronya growled, her tails bristling, before she paused when she noticed Flayn staring at her with wide eyes. “Oh, hey, Lys, the other shorty is here.”

 

“I AM NOT THAT SHORT–Wait, who do you mean–Oh, Flayn. Hello.” Lysithea nodded to Flayn, who stammered out a baffled “hello?” before she turned back to Shez. “Honestly, did you even think of how worried you made us?”

 

“Ah, uh…n-no? Not really?” Shez winced at the immediate glares she received for that answer. “S-Sorry! I just didn’t think at all! I know it was dumb, but it just made sense to warp in the moment and I didn’t think…sorry.”

 

“...” Lysithea sighed at Shez’s contrite expression before crouching down to look her in the eyes. “I suppose I can forgive you…but you have to promise me you won’t run off without telling us again.”

 

“Ah, okay, sure, you got it. I promise I won’t run off again,” Shez says, sitting up with a sigh and rubbing her head. “I really am sorry I worried you.”

 

“Hmph…I didn’t hit you too hard, did I? I didn’t want to actually hurt you.”

 

“I did,” Kronya said with a huff, “Couldn’t even bring me along for the fight, huh?”

 

“I didn’t know there’d be a fight!” Shez protested as she stood up, “Besides, if I did bring you, you’d probably wind up as the prime minister somehow.”

 

“Hey, I–...wait, could I do that?”

 

Lysithea immediately frowned. “Kronya. No.” 

 

“Hold on pipsqueak, I just had an idea,” Kronya said, before taking a lock of her hair and holding it up, “Does this look like it’s the same shade as Ferdinand’s hair?”

 

Now Lysithea looked alarmed. “Kronya, what in the world are you thinking?”

 

“Look, it’s simple. I pretend I’m Duke Aegir’s bastard daughter–“

 

“Kronya–“

 

“–and I get Ferd to abdicate so I’m the only valid candidate–“

 

“Kronya, no–“

 

“–and then I use my marriage with Shez as leverage to get Edelgard to make me emperor!”

 

“ How is that even supposed to work?!”

 

“IS THAT AN AGARTHAN?!” Seteth yelped before Kronya could elaborate on her brilliant plan, earning a deep sigh from Rhea.

 

“Yes, that’s Kronya, she’s the Duke of Riegan and Shez’s fiancé. Now can we please stay on topic?”

 

“She’s Shez’s what now?” Jeralt asked, visibly alarmed, which elicited an even deeper sigh from Rhea.

 

“Please, just, talk to her about it. Now does anyone else have any pressing questions to ask?”

 

“I would like to know where you’ve been for the past three years, archbishop,” Hubert stated, “It would be good to corroborate the professor’s story.”

 

“...” Rhea slowly turned towards the blackclad man that had abruptly appeared out of nowhere, ignoring the startled yelps from the nearby knights. “...how did you–When did you get here??”

 

“Moments ago. Shez isn’t the only one who knows how to warp.”

 

“Wait, I’m not?” Shez asked, before pausing, “Oh, wait, regular warp magic, right. Almost forgot that’s a thing…”

 

“Like how you forgot to mention you have a fiance now?” Jeralt asked, raising an eyebrow at his daughter.

 

“...uh…I, well, we didn’t…it’s not exactly…she hasn’t asked me directly–”

 

“Then allow me to do that right now!” Kronya declared with a dramatic swish of her golden cape, before she got down on one knee, “Shez Eisner, would you do me the honor of becoming my betrothed?”

 

Shez blinked. She stared down at Kronya, who smiled brightly up at her, before she registered that the redheaded Agarthan actually had a ring in her hand. One made of black metal with an orange jewel embedded into it. “...o-oh. I…o-okay, yeah. Sure.”

 

Then Kronya was kissing her on the lips and her bewildered response somehow felt just perfect.

 

“Remarkably romantic,” Hubert drawled while Flayn let out a noise like a fully heated tea kettle. A sound that was echoed by a brightly smiling Mercedes and an even more excited Alois, who somehow managed a higher-pitch than either of the young women. At least one window broke.

 

Lysithea, meanwhile, stiffened at the sight, before letting out an irritated huff. She crossed her arms over her chest, watching the display with open indignation.

 

Of course, the most visibly excited, by her standards, was Byleth, who was full on applauding alongside a deeply bewildered Edelgard.

 

“Whoa, what?” Shez exclaimed, breaking the kiss as she noticed her sister, “When the hell did you get here??”

 

“I had to burn three pulses to get the timing right,” Byleth explained, “I wasn’t going to miss this moment.”

 

“...you said there was an emergency,” Edelgard remarked, frowning up at her professor.

 

“It was absolutely an emergency. I would have brought Dorothea, but it took too long and I needed you so the guards wouldn’t ask questions. I’ll make it up to her later.”

 

“...” Shez wasn’t sure what to make of anything right now. So she defaulted to pretending to be a lot more confident than she actually felt and leaning on her competitive side, wrapping an arm around Kronya’s waist, which earned a surprised yet pleased noise from the shorter Agarthan, and smirking at Byleth. “Well, I’m glad you got to see me beat you at romance! After all, I got proposed to first!”

 

That snapped Jeralt out of his own stunned state, a sigh slipping out as his surprise at some woman he didn’t even recognize proposing to his daughter turned to a familiar exasperation. “Kid, seriously? Don’t make this a competition now.”

 

“No, it’s fine Papa, I’ll allow Shez this victory,” Byleth said quite magnanimously, “After all, I am ahead of her in other ways.”

 

Shez paused. “What? What’s that mean?”

 

“Simply that last night, I experienced a bliss that you have not, little sister.” Byleth allowed some smugness to show. “I am sure you’ll catch up soon enough. I still got there first though, thanks to Edelgard and Dorothea.”

 

The stunned silence that followed was broken by Edelgard rolling her eyes. “Do you really have to talk about it like that? You’ll give people the wrong idea.”

 

“Hm? What do you mean? I was with you and Dorothea last night and it was very nice.”

 

“I don’t need to hear this,” Rhea decided, already feeling tired. Mentally, if not physically. “Shez, congratulations on your engagement. Emperor Edelgard, I believe you and I have matters to discuss that do not pertain to my granddaughter’s romantic dalliances.”

 

Seteth stiffened, alarmed. “Wait, Lady Rhea, are you certain you should say that–“

 

“Seteth, I flew here in dragon form. At this point I can hardly keep track of who knows what and which secrets are still secret, so I am hardly going to care if people know Byleth and I are family.” She paused. “Shez, you are also family, by extension, so please do invite me to the wedding. I like attending them and it’s been a while since I’ve gone to one.”

 

“Oh, uh, sure?” Shez agreed, “I mean, I guess everyone here is invited? You’re all either friends or family, so yeah.”

 

“Wait, even me?” Catherine asked.

 

“…” Shez had honestly forgotten the blonde knight was even here. “Uh…you can come along if Rhea or Shamir want to bring you.”

 

“Huh. Well that’s better than I thought I’d get…”

 

“Don’t worry Catherine, I’ll invite you to my wedding,” Byleth reassured, doing her best to smile at the knight when Edelgard immediately went pink beside her.

 

“Ahem. Maybe we should save such a discussion for a different time?” Edelgard suggested after clearing her throat. 

 

“Oh, right, it should probably be after the proposal–”

 

“Now then, I believe we should move somewhere else to discuss important matters, Rhea,” Edelgard said, trying to move past the topic. 

 

“Yes, let's,” Rhea agreed, taking the excuse to leave. 

 

“...So both of them at the same time, huh, professor?” Kronya commented, glancing over Byleth. “Impressive.” 

 

“Kronya, please don't.” Shez pleaded, not wanting to hear about her sister’s “romantic dalliances”.

 

“I don't see what the big issue is, Shez,” Byleth said, tilting her head slightly, “Kronya and Lysithea are here so you can do it later.” 

 

“W-What!?” Lysithea squeaked, feeling her face heat up while Shez raised an eyebrow at her sister. 

 

“Jeez, By, I know it's been three years but I didn't think you'd end up becoming a perv.” 

 

“Huh? What's perverted about cuddling?” Byleth asked.

 

“...” Shez sighed. “Never change, Byleth. Never change.”

Chapter End Notes

Red: Happy Anniversary to Fire Emblem: Three Houses! Here, have this nonsense.

Indi: Hope you all enjoyed this! It's been a fun five years of enjoying three houses.

Red: It has! It's wild that we managed to write such a long fic out of this game, but hey, there's a lot to it and it's still lots of fun working with these characters. Also Kronya wins the Shezbowl with the surprise proposal, mark that on your bingo cards if you have them.

Indi: If not, then we apologize but you are not eligible for any prizes.

Red: Oh also, we put up one-shot for today as well, feel free to check that out. It's a silly, fluffy one and I blame Indi for all of it.

Indi: Yes yes, so make sure to check it out to see what I'm to blame for! It's called Riddle for the Ages!

Relationships are Tricky

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

The dungeons of Fort Merceus were rarely used to hold actual invaders. While the fortress city was one of the major capitals of the Empire, most of the people who lived in it were either members of the Imperial Army or those related to them, so the dungeon was usually reserved for those troops who needed to cool off after being drunk and disorderly. Certainly, the cells had held invaders, spies, and even deserters in the past, but it was rare for them to be this full.

 

They also weren’t usually so nicely furnished, but then Emperor Edelgard was well known for being surprisingly magnanimous with prisoners, particularly those who surrendered. Of course, her own past of being held in some particularly dark and foul dungeons did contribute to her aversion to poorly treating her own prisoners. And it was that same past that saw her frown at the sight of the sole surviving officer of the enemy garrison, sitting across from her on the other side of an interrogation table.

 

The young woman, assuming she was as young as she looked, had black hair and the same shade of corpse-white skin most Agarthans had. The two lines tattooed under her right eye seemed to mark her as someone important, though the emperor didn’t have a complete understanding of just what Agarthan iconography actually meant. Perhaps she could learn now that she knew Shez had somehow seduced Kronya?

 

Those questions could come later though. “Captain Kore of Agartha. It is my understanding that you are the only remaining leader of the Hrym Army forces stationed at Fort Merceus. Is that correct?”

 

The woman nodded. “It is.”

 

“It is also my understanding that you wish to speak on behalf of the soldiers under your command in order to ensure their fair and equitable treatment as prisoners of war. Is that also correct?”

 

Another nod. “It is.”

 

“Very well then.” The emperor folded her hands and stared at the Agarthan captain, meeting the woman’s violet eyes with an even gaze. “My first question is ‘why?’ In my experience, your people do not tend to care for your subordinates.”

 

“I was assigned to be the overseer of my battalion by my superiors,” Kore stated, her tone calm and professional, “The duties of a ‘captain’ is to utilize their subordinates to their fullest extent. This includes ensuring their health and well-being for the sake of cohesion and the effectiveness of the unit. I have found that the standard treatment engaged by other overseers, wherein ill-performing subordinates are tortured or executed, to be ineffective at maintaining unit efficacy. It is impractical.”

 

“I see. That is a strange point of view for an Agarthan,” Edelgard noted, studying the stoic woman for any reactions, “In my experience, your people tend to prioritize sadism over practicality.”

 

Kore stared at her. “...Is there a question in your statement?”

 

“What made you decide to prioritize preserving the lives of your subordinates instead of taking a final stand and attempting to kill as many people as possible?”

 

“I believe I answered this question. My duty is to preserve the lives of my subordinates–”

 

“Is that really true?” Edelgard interrupted, “If you asked one of your sages, would they have told you to keep your soldiers alive?”

 

Kore shook her head. “The priorities of the sages are irrelevant. Lord Dolofonos is dead, his orders have no bearing on my decisions.”

 

“Why is that? What made you want to keep your soldiers alive?”

 

“...that…it is my duty to preserve–”

 

“That doesn’t answer the question. Why is it a priority for you?” Edelgard looked her directly in the eyes and saw the Agarthan’s gaze waver. “I want to understand your reasoning, Kore. If I am satisfied by your explanation, it could ensure better treatment for yourself and your soldiers going forward.”

 

That caught her attention. “I…I believe I understand. Though…” She mulled over the question, a small frown coming to her face. “...I was assigned to this fort soon after it was taken, approximately two years ago. It was believed that having some Agarthan superiors placed in a position of authority would ensure this strategic point would be kept secure from attempts to reclaim it.

 

“I was placed in charge of a battalion of the Principality’s soldiers. It is my understanding that a majority of our forces are made up of those who benefited from Archduke Aegir’s policies and those who were disenfranchised by Imperial rule. I believe you would refer to them as ‘corrupt soldiers’ and ‘bandits’. I found their quality to be lacking and attempted an experiment in raising their effectiveness. The less educated members of the pack began referring to me as ‘Lady Boss’ as a result.”

 

Edelgard raised an eyebrow. “The ‘pack’?”

 

“...it is common parlance to refer to the individuals known as ‘Fodlans’ as ‘beasts’. I have found most of the Fodlans do not like being referred to as such and have endeavored to change my language appropriately. However, some members of my battalion seemed to take pride in the designation and began referring to themselves as ‘hounds’ for reasons I do not understand. They seemed to appreciate my efforts to ensure their effectiveness, however. My refusal to use torture as a punishment was viewed as benevolent, rather than practical. Bleeding soldiers do not make for effective soldiers.”

 

“Hm. And no other Agarthans took issue with your mindset?”

 

“A majority did not care. One did react negatively to my efforts to ensure efficiency and murdered one of my subordinates on a whim. Murder is not tolerated in an effective encampment, and I executed him for the crime. My fellow captains understood from that point on that the members of my battalion were part of an experiment I was running, and any attempt to disrupt the experiment would result in their immediate, lethal removal as a factor. My superiors did not care either way as long as manpower was not wasted.”

 

“I see. Well, while I cannot confirm the status of all your men, those we have captured had their wounds treated. I presume you'll wish to negotiate for yours and their treatment going forward?” 

 

“...If possible, I wish to speak with my battalion. Some of them may act in ways that risk the others, so I wish to let them know I have things handled.” 

 

Edelgard nodded. “You will be permitted to speak with them, though you will be kept under watch while you do so. I hope I don’t need to directly state that any attempts to escape would not go well.”

 

“I understand. I will endeavor to ensure my soldiers will not give you cause to rescind the mercy you have shown them.”

 

Edelgard gave her another nod, then stood and walked out of the room without another word. Then she simply waited outside the door, listening to hear if Kore let anything slip now that she was supposedly alone.

 

And sure enough, the Agarthan let out a relieved sigh as she slumped in her seat. “Scary…no one said the hegemon was that scary…stupid Dolofonos, stupid Myson, why do I have to be in charge now? I wanna go home…”

 

“…” Edelgard made a mental note to make sure Bernadetta “unintentionally” encountered Kore. Judging by Kronya, the easiest way to get an Agarthan to fully defect was to introduce them to someone similar to them.

 

She would probably have to keep Hubert away from her though. He’d either scare her off or, considering how Bernadetta acted around him, somehow earn the Agarthan’s attraction, and she did not need more relationship drama in her camp.

“It truly is strange,” Lysithea muttered as she poked at the slice of strawberry cake set on the table in front of her. Not something one would normally have at a war camp, but there was a celebration going on. “Anyone, myself included, would think I would be much angrier about having the girl I have affections for abruptly stolen out from under me. Yet at most I feel…maybe annoyed, but more so at Kronya in general for making a spectacle than at her for romancing Shez.”

 

“Hm…do you think you care for her as well?” Marianne asked, the former Deer taking a moment to refill both of their teacups, “Sort of how Professor Byleth cares for both Lady Edelgard and Dorothea?”

 

“…I feel like if I start liking Kronya, I’ll have to have my head checked. Falling in love with an idiot is one thing, but falling for two of them?”

 

“Is she really that bad?”

 

“She’s Emily, Marianne.”

 

Marianne paused, thinking back to what she knew of the odd noble from back at the academy. Which, to be fair, wasn’t much since they essentially swapped classes, so she just made a non-commital noise and shrugged. “Maybe you’re happy for them?”

 

“Hm…I do not think that is it either. I…I think I am jealous? I cannot say I like the idea of Shez spending her life away from me…No, in fact, I think I hate that idea! I want to be with her, to spend time together, whatever time we do have, and the idea that Kronya of all people is stealing that from me is infuriating!” she snapped, before sitting back down with a huff. “…alright, maybe I am angrier about this than I thought.”

 

Marianne nodded, choosing not to mention the cracks in the table where Lysithea had put her hands. “I think I understand. Things have been happening very quickly lately, so it’s difficult to process your feelings until you have a moment to sit with them.”

 

“Mmf.” Lysithea slumped on the table, glaring at her slice of cake. “…it likely is something like that. I know I am irritated. I think a part of me believed we would remain in our current equilibrium for longer, where neither myself nor Kronya actually made the push towards marriage. I should have known that impulsive fool would throw caution to the wind and I’m just as annoyed at myself for not realizing it.”

 

Marianne took a sip of her tea as she collected her thoughts. She didn’t really feel qualified to give relationship advice, especially with her own lack of one… “What do you want to do going forward?”

 

“Hmph…well, I can either give up on Shez or try to force my way into their relationship…”

 

Marianne furrowed her brow. “Are you sure those are the only options?”

 

“I don’t want to be a jealous fool pining after someone I cannot have. If this were a contest, then Kronya has won already with a decisive strike.”

 

“But…it isn’t a contest,” Marianne pointed out, “And…well, the professor seems happy to be with Dorothea and Edelgard. Very happy, actually. So…are you sure there isn’t a way you can be happy here too?”

 

Lysithea paused. She turned her gaze towards Marianne, a bit surprised. “I have to say, I didn’t expect that from you, Marianne.”

 

The noblewoman blushed slightly, before smiling. “Being in the Empire has been good for me.”

 

“…yes, it has. Alright, I know what I’m doing!” Lysithea pushed herself up from the table and strode her way right over to where Kronya and Shez were sitting together, currently being regaled by Alois with the tale of his own proposal to his wife.

 

“Oh, you should have seen it, we danced and danced all night!” Alois said, practically shouting as he leaned against Shez, the purple-haired girl looking both amused and exhausted at his antics. Kronya, on the other hand, looked like she was ready to stab someone if it wasn't for Shez holding onto her. “It's the most memorable night of my life, even more so than when I became a knight!” 

 

“Alois, sorry to interrupt, but the professor was asking for you,” Lysithea cut in, getting his attention. 

 

“Oh, what does she need?” Alois asked, glancing at the white-haired girl. 

 

“Uh…” Lysithea glanced over at Byleth, the green-haired merc currently chowing down on her meal, in between chatting with Mercedes and Flayn. “She wants to ask you for advice on how to propose.” 

 

It was like she spoke the magic words. “Oh! Well of course, I would be happy to share a proposal for proposing! No, wait, let me do that again, I’m sure I can think of a better–”

 

“You should hurry, I think she might go to Seteth if you’re not available.”

 

“Oh goddess, no! I can’t let him take my spot as honorary uncle!” 

 

Shez watched her self-appointed honorary uncle sprint away, before glancing at Lysithea skeptically. “Byleth didn’t really ask for him, did she?”

 

“No, I just needed him to leave so I could speak to you. To both of you,” she stated, looking at Kronya, who raised an eyebrow.

 

“Well if you wanted him gone, I could think of a much easier way to do that.”

 

“Kronya, you’re not stabbing Alois,” Shez reprimanded, earning a smirk from her fiance.

 

“I never said–”

 

“I know what you were implying. Anyways, Lysithea, what did you want to talk about?”

 

Lysithea put her hands on the table, deciding to be blunt. “What place do I have in your life going forward?”

 

Shez paused. “Uh…okay, wow, that’s a heavy question.”

 

“I know, but it is one I need to have answered,” Lysithea said, before sighing, “You already accepted Kronya’s proposal, and it seems like you genuinely do wish to be with her. However, I am attracted to you as well and…well, I have reasons to find you infuriating, Kronya, but I do consider you a friend instead of an enemy.”

 

Kronya blinked at her. “Oh. I…have to admit, that feels good to hear, pip–Uh, Lysithea. I think of you as a friend too.” Her tails fidgeted, plainly showing her discomfort with being emotionally open. “Uh, Shez, you talk now.”

 

“Oh, uh, sure, right.” Shez took a breath, collecting her thoughts. “Right…okay. I guess…I never really thought about…no, I did think about romance stuff, sure. I’ve thought about it a lot, actually. And…I do like both of you. I like you, Lysithea. But I also like Kronya. And…I think I love both of you. You’re my best friends and it makes me happy when you’re around. Whatever happens with all this war stuff going forward, I want to make sure both of you are happy.” 

 

“...That's good to hear,” Lysithea said, feeling her face turn pink, “We don't need to talk about all the details here and now, but going forward…you and me, and you and Kronya, right?”

 

“I don't mind. Besides, I'm the one who's going to be in charge so it doesn't matter,” Kronya stated, smirking at Lysithea's confused expression. “What? Don't forget that I'm gonna be in charge of a noble house who is in charge of the Alliance.” 

 

“House Riegan isn't in charge of the Alliance just because they're the Duke!” 

 

“Hm, you're right. Shez help me figure out how to become the Queen of the Alliance.” 

 

“Uh…would it still be called The Alliance if there was a queen?” Shez helpfully asked. 

 

“That's true…well we can't make it a kingdom, that'll make it seem like we're ripping off Faerghus,” Kronya said, frowning in thought. 

 

“Ugh, you're impossible. Come on Shez, you've spent enough time around her today,” Lysithea said, grabbing onto Shez to drag her away. Or at least, she would have, if it weren't for the fact that she wasn't physically strong and Kronya grabbed onto Shez in response. 

 

“And who said you could take her?” 

 

“I deserve to spend some alone time with her!” 

 

“Hey I wasn't spending any time alone with her either with Alois spouting off about his wife!” 

 

“What!? it's not like it's my fault you couldn't figure out how to drive him away like I did!” 

 

“Shut it pipsqueak!”

 

“I'm taller than you!” 

 

Shez couldn't help but sigh as she was pulled from both sides by the two girls, both of whom seemed much more invested in arguing than actually coming to a decision. Ah well, this is what she signed up for, so she really had no right to complain.

 

Besides, it felt kind of nice being fought over.

Rhea felt a vein pulse in her head as she listened to Seteth and Hubert continue their “argument”. It was difficult to see it as one, given the pair had devolved from actually arguing about logistics to poorly sniping at one another like the pettiest of children. She was sure if it went on long enough they would both devolve into crying tantrums. 

 

Though before she could interrupt she felt a hand on her shoulder. Glancing over, she saw Jeralt staring at her, before gesturing to a door for the two to head out through. Deciding a tactical retreat was better than dealing with the two bickering children, Rhea left with him, and soon the two of them stood on the ramparts of the fort. 

 

“Thank you for that rescue, General Jeralt,” Rhea began, respectfully using her old friend’s new title, “It seems you still have the heart of a knight, no matter how much time passes.”

 

“No need for the thanks. I could tell things would escalate if you got involved,” was the man's gruff response. It wasn't much, but at least he didn't sneak out on his own. 

 

“Yes, I had forgotten how irritating war meetings could be. Though even though it has been so long since I've been in a war council, the squabbling remains the same.” 

 

“And when would that have been? Back when you were Seiros, or someone else?” 

 

“...When I was Seiros. I was never one for tactics, but as I was the ‘Chosen of the Goddess’ it was expected of me to join in each meeting. If it weren't for Wilhelm, I likely would have knocked out many officers during those meetings.” 

 

“...for three hundred years, we knew each other. I thought I knew so much about you, but you never told me about this, huh?” He huffed. “But I guess I shouldn’t be surprised you’d keep secrets from me.”

 

Rhea grimaced. “I suppose there could be countless excuses I could come up with. Yet nothing I say would be able to make up for what I did to your child.” 

 

“It wouldn't, no. The only reason I'm willing to talk to you at all is because Byleth seems to have made up with you at some point in the last few years.” 

 

“That is one way to put it. We certainly had plenty of time to talk and fight.” She sighed. “I could provide excuses, but we both know they would be empty. I made a number of stupid, selfish decisions and deeply hurt those I care for. I can only offer my sincere apologies, and hope that I haven’t destroyed our friendship completely.”

 

“...” Jeralt turned his gaze fully towards her. “I want you to be completely honest. What happened with Sitri?” 

 

“...Sitri was never the healthiest, you know this. The fault there can be laid upon me. Mother could create life upon a whim, but my powers were a pale imitation of hers. Try as I might, none of my daughters could be called a full-blooded Nabatean, and they didn't have the hardiness of a normal human constitution. So when it came time for Byleth’s birth, though I tried everything I could, I knew I wouldn't be able to save them both. So Sitri asked me to do the only thing that would have ensured Byleth’s safety. To give Byleth her heart, the crest stone that was her source of life.” Rhea closed her eyes, vividly remembering that exact moment. The tears in Sitri’s eyes, yet also a fiery determination that the archbishop had never seen before. “More than anything, Sitri wanted Byleth to live. And…I wish I could say that was my only thought as well. I wish I was as good as she thought I was. I…”

 

“...did you kill her, Rhea? Did you kill Sitri?”

 

“I did. I could give my reasons, both justifiable and monstrous, but it was my hand that removed her heart and placed it within your daughter’s chest. I am a mother who murdered her child.”

 

“...” Jeralt took a slow breath, his hands clenching at his sides. His knuckles popped from the tension. “...she really asked you to?”

 

“She did. I don’t know if that should change anything though. My motives were suspect, regardless of her choices in the matter, and I understand if you bear hatred towards me for them.”

 

“Hatred would be putting it lightly. It'd be one thing if it was just that, but you were going to use Byleth too, weren't you?” 

 

“I can't deny that, no. I convinced myself that she had truly died that day and the one who was reborn was the goddess in disguise. Which is what led to my change in demeanor, as you are aware.” 

 

“...I always wondered for the longest time whether I had made the right choice to leave with Byleth,” Jeralt admitted, “I did the best I could, but it wasn't a life she should have lived. Even so, it was better than whatever you had planned for her.” 

 

“It was, that can't be denied. Whatever safety she might have been guaranteed would simply be a cage that would have tightened around her, particularly if I had any reason to believe the goddess truly did dwell inside her.” She sighed again, staring out into the distant fields. If she knew the land correctly, Garreg Mach laid in the direction they were looking, though far beyond the horizon. “Perhaps I could have loved Byleth for herself, but unless mother spoke to me directly to just tell me I was a forlorn fool refusing to let go of the past, as she did within that void, I would have ruined whatever relationship we had one way or another. It’s in my nature to do so.”

 

“Alright, now you’re just being unfair to yourself,” Jeralt grumbled, before fixing Rhea with a direct stare, “Look, I don’t like what happened. I don’t think I’ll ever feel fine with knowing how Sitri died or what you had planned for Byleth. But you stayed with my kid for three years and made sure to take care of her.”

 

“Ah, to be clear, I did attempt to harm her in a rage initially before my mother intervened,” Rhea interrupted. She winced at the flat stare Jeralt gave her. “I thought I should be honest.”

 

“…Rhea, there are a lot of reasons I shouldn’t punch you. The reasons I should are feeling a lot more compelling right now, and you keep adding to them.”

 

“Er, my apologies. Though, perhaps you should? If it would help.”

 

“Rhea. You’re still the Archbishop. And there are a good hundred people around here that would try to gut me if they saw me punch you in the face. So let’s avoid that.”

 

“…I’m not.”

 

Jeralt raised an eyebrow. “You’re not what?”

 

“I am no longer the Archbishop. At least…I plan to dissolve the position as soon as I can. My leadership has been lacking for far too long, and it is high time the church steps back from trying to rule, particularly through manipulation and falsehoods. I understand that Emperor Edelgard has plans for the future that Byleth wishes to aid, so I wish to learn more about what she plans.” 

 

“Well for starters, she's not a fan of you,” Jeralt stated getting Rhea to frown, “In fact, I’m pretty sure she was planning on starting a war with you if the Kingdom hadn't kicked things off first.” 

 

Rhea stared at her old comrade who had just calmly informed her that Edelgard wanted to wage war against her as though it was just small talk. Though, given what Rhea knew about her already… “Is this related to her being the Flame Emperor?”

 

“Oh, you know about that part?”

 

“I think the more significant thing is that you know about it.”

 

Jeralt shrugged. “She told me not long after we got away from the monastery. I was upset, sure, but Byleth likes her, so I gave the emperor a chance and I can’t say I regret it.”

 

“Even though you know she wanted my head?”

 

“I’m not sure if it’s past tense.”

 

Rhea sighed, frowning at her friend’s morbid joke. “Hm. Well, I suppose that means the Alliance is the only nation that doesn’t have a leader that wants me dead. Perhaps I should try retiring there?”

 

“I don’t know about that. There might be some arrogant noble that thinks they’re smarter than they are aiming at you for their own reasons.”

 

Somewhere in Almyra, Claude abruptly sneezed.

 

Rhea, meanwhile, grimaced. “It’s Gloucester, isn’t it? I never liked that family…the young man at the academy prayed often, but I could tell it was just for show.” 

 

“Rhea, I'm pretty sure most nobles are just religious for show.” 

 

“...hmph. You’re just cynical, Jeralt. I’m certain a majority of the nobility at the academy were perfectly faithful young people. Besides, I encountered the young lord Gloucester recently, so I am confident in my assessment of his character. He is clearly the deceptive schemer of the group, much like the Vestra boy is for Edelgard’s Eagles.” She paused. “Come to think of it, it might be his fault she was led so far astray…”

 

“Rhea.”

 

“What?”

 

“Don’t say ‘what’. You know what I’m talking about.”

 

“Jeralt, I don’t know–“ 

 

“You’re trying to find reasons that it isn’t Edelgard’s fault that she doesn’t like you because you want to like her.”

 

“…that isn’t something I do,” Rhea grumbled, averting her gaze from her old friend. Because she was annoyed with him, obviously, and not because he has any sort of point. “…maybe if she made friends with a nice, pious girl, she could rediscover her love for the goddess. Someone like Mercedes, perhaps?”

 

Jeralt sighed beside her and even muttered “Seriously, Rhea?” but she didn’t know why he was acting so exasperated. Clearly this was the perfect plan. What could possibly go wrong?

Jeritza von Hrym was a man with darkness in his heart. He knew that truth quite intimately, for it haunted his every waking moment.

 

No matter where he was, no matter what he was doing, the Death Knight was within him, and the years of brutal bloodshed he had committed against the northern invaders made that monster’s voice so much louder. It did not speak to him, not with words, but with impulses and dangerous thoughts. More than once, his ruined mind would consider striking against his own allies, of slicing the War Minister’s head from his shoulders in the middle of a meeting or riding down his own men in the midst of a charge.

 

Bergliez had noticed. Understandable, given how blatant his monstrous urges must be. Yet, for some reason, that led to the War Minister making Jeritza his adjutant? A baffling decision by all measures, especially since Jeritza deliberately wore the Death Knight’s armor to make people interact with him less. And yet, for another bizarre reason, Bergliez appeared to find his murderous curse amusing instead of concerning.

 

It almost came as a relief when he received a letter from Lord Hubert recalling him from the western front. Apparently, Byleth Eisner had returned from wherever she went and Hubert believed her return represented an opportunity to change the direction of the war. So while Bergliez assured Jeritza he would be missed, for some reason, he would have to leave the war against Faerghus to return to his master’s side.

 

One of his subordinates gave him a basket of muffins for the journey. It was an odd gesture, particularly since Jeritza and the Death Horse would be warping most of the way, but they were nice to snack on so he supposed it was acceptable.

 

Once he made it to the emperor’s war camp, however, he was surprised to learn her majesty had apparently seized Fort Merceus already and had been residing there for nearly a week, repairing and reinforcing the fortress while also conducting diplomatic talks with the Church of Seiros. Jeritza had been under the impression that the Church was defunct, given most of it had burned down, so he was somewhat surprised to hear there were even talks necessary.

 

In fact, hadn’t Edelgard put the small green girl in charge of the church? 

 

…questions for later. For now, he intended to see just what happened at the fort in his absence.

 

“–and the false god spoke his most hateful truth, that the very relics wielded by the unrighteous nobility born of the Elites were made from the bones and hearts of our goddess’s very own children!” 

 

He wasn’t expecting a sermon. A sermon might get the very last thing he would have ever expected to hear in the Emperor’s camp, given her antipathy towards the church. Yet there was a woman, clad in radiant white armor, speaking to a large crowd of soldiers in both church white and Imperial crimson.

 

“Yet we are not lost, my friends! For despite the betrayals conducted in her name, the goddess forgives!” the woman declared, her strangely familiar voice reverberating in a hooded helm crafted to resemble a serene woman’s face, “She fought for us against the false god and his face-stealing servants, and even freed Her sister from his fell clutches! Not even dragging Her into his own domain could stop our goddess from striking him down! And though it took many years of fighting, She has returned to us once more! The Goddess walks among us! And with Her righteous fury, we shall deliver justice upon those who have escaped it for far too long!”

 

There were cheers from the crowd, though Jeritza wasn’t quite sure what he was feeling. Something about the woman’s voice…it made him feel strangely warm. Almost…nostalgic.

 

Then the woman caught sight of him, and he could hear her gasp. He was used to that reaction though, so it didn’t bother–

 

“Ah, my apologies, friends, but the goddess has sent me a wonderful sign! Lady Flayn, would you mind taking over?”

 

Oh, so the small green girl was here. The armored woman passed over the book she had held while speaking and hurried from the stage. Jeritza briefly wondered where she was going, before he noticed she was headed right for him.

 

The Death Horse whinnied at his side as Jeritza felt himself tense, his hand twitching for–

 

“EMILE!” Then he heard that name and went completely still, right before the woman, his sister, crashed right into his chest and wrapped her arms tightly around him. Jeritza couldn't help but stiffen, about to push her away as he felt the Death Knight begin to rise– “Oh Emile! It’s so good to finally see you! Where were you?! Do you know how worried I've been?!” 

 

“...Mercedes?” The moment he fully realized who was holding onto him, he grabbed onto her shoulders, pushing her away. 

 

Reaching up, Mercedes took off her helmet, the young woman breathing heavily as she wiped her brow. “Hah, my apologies, I acted hastily there. I suppose it must be quite a sight to see me dressed like this.” She laughed a little awkwardly, then shook her head. “Mm, my apologies, again. I’m not used to wearing such heavy armor, but Lady Rhea and Cardinal Luca thought it would suit me. Well, the Cardinal did. Lady Rhea’s sense of fashion…ah, never mind that! How are you? Are you well?”

 

Jeritza could be forgiven for not responding immediately. The first thing he could even think to say was– “You cut your hair.”

 

“Hm? Oh, yes, I did.” Mercedes giggled, adjusting the short bob her hair had become. “It felt more practical to change it. But more importantly, how are you Emile?”

 

Hearing his name again, Jertiza couldn't help but jerk back. “My name is Jeritza, knight in service to Emperor Edelgard.”

 

“Emile, I know we haven't truly spoken since we were children, but surely you remember me. We met again at the academy, remember? Oh, how have you been doing? Have you been eating well? You haven’t just been eating sweets, have you?” 

 

Jeritza thought back to the basket of muffins he had eaten on the way, then quickly buried down whatever feelings his sister’s concern had stirred within him. “This ‘Emile’ you speak of is long gone. There is no reason to speak to me.” 

 

“...I see, I understand,” Mercedes said, nodding her head, which made Jeritza let out a sigh of relief that his sister understood– “You must be attempting to birth yourself anew under the grace of the goddess to cleanse yourself of your past sins! Worry not my dear brother, for I shall aid you!” 

 

Jeritza blinked, before suddenly he suddenly found himself being tugged away from his horse by  his very insistent and surprisingly strong sister. 

 

“Here, I should introduce you to everyone–Oh, though, no, you would know everyone already, wouldn’t you? You have been working with Edelgard for the past few years, and I know you were at the church three years ago,” his sister mused while continuing to pull him along, mostly because he had almost immediately fallen back into instinctively following her lead. Vague childhood memories resurfaced as she led him through the camp. She had been taller than him, once, and it felt strange looking down at her– “Oh, I know! I should bring you to Constance! Oh it’s been so long since she’s seen you!”

 

Oh no.

 

He looked around, in hopes of finding a form of salvation. It would be simple enough to pull himself free, but he didn't wish to hurt his sister, even as the Death Knight began to rise at the thought. Maybe he could say he had orders that he needed to attend to first? He had been told to arrive here so really he needed to speak with the Emperor. 

 

“I need to–”

 

“There you are, Constance!” Mercedes called out, getting the blonde who was currently resting in the shade with Hapi to look over at her.

 

“Oh, did you require my aid, Mercedes?” Constance asked, smiling as she got up, while Hapi lazily waved at her. 

 

“No, I just came over to introduce you to Emile! I know you two have been serving under Emperor Edelgard, but I wanted to make sure you two did know each other.” 

 

“Emile? Oh how wonderful it is to–...Wait, the Death Knight is Emile!? Is this why you've been avoiding me whenever you were at the palace!?” Constance asked, completely flabbergasted as Jeritza stood there awkwardly, unsure of how to escape. 

 

“So as the only one out of the loop, what's going on?” Hapi asked, feeling curious about the situation. 

 

“Right, Hapi, as I've told you before, this is my childhood friend, Mercedes. And Jeritza here is apparently her little brother Emile,” Constance explained, gesturing at them. 

 

“...Little?” Hapi muttered, staring up at Jeritza. “Jerry seems pretty big to me.” 

 

“He was much smaller when he was young. I have no idea how he managed to shoot up so significantly.” Constance huffed, before thinking about something, “Perhaps I could make a spell to make people shorter or taller…something to consider.” 

 

“Enough of this. I have to report to the Emperor,” Jeritza stated, finally pulling himself free of Mercedes’ grasp. “I am not this Emile you speak of, I am the Death Knight, and I–”

 

“Emile.” Only to stop at Mercedes’s voice, her tone brooking no argument, “I understand that you've been through much, and I won't force you to do anything, but you're my brother. That fact will always be true. No matter what trials you go through, I'll be there to help you, even if you don't want my help. And once you're done, then we can go visit Mother together, okay?” 

 

Jeritza glanced back at her for a moment, “...I shall remember your words.” 

 

Then he walked, very calmly, to meet with his emperor. No, he was not running away. That would be comical.

 

“Dang. Your big little brother can move fast, Merce,” Hapi commented, watching the fully armored knight practically power walking away from their group.

 

“He always was a good runner,” Mercedes said with open pride, smiling happily. Truly, the Goddess had blessed her on this day to be able to see Emile again. She really should make sure to spread Her word to him soon. Maybe he could join her in her sermons?

 

For some reason, Jeritza felt an urge to start running. The worrying part was that, as far as he could tell, the urge was coming from the Death Knight…

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Jeritza starting to realize maybe his family isn't the most sane.

Red: Mental illness can run in families. If you or a loved one suddenly develop a more violent alternate personality that's either hyper murderous or zealously devoted to a brand new messiah, please talk to your doctor.

Indi: Or let it rock if the new messiah is cool enough.

Red: True! Embrace the Will of Byleth everybody, she's a benevolent deity who will give you good grades and headpats.

Indi: And gold stars! But only if you're a good student.

Red: So join the church of Byleth today!

Interlude - Agarthan Aggravation

Chapter by RK3996

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Lord Myson of Shambhala, Sage of Thunder and duly appointed protector of the Agarthan people, had a lot on his mind at the moment. For the first time in a while, the creator of monstrosities fouler than any other felt…perturbed. Though that might not be the right word.

 

He wasn’t exactly troubled, per se, nor truly unsettled, but perhaps…annoyed?
