There certainly was some annoyance in the mix of feelings percolating in his skull as he stared down at the map in his castle’s war room. Well, Ludwig’s castle, though anyone reasonable could tell who was holding the leash between the man and the beast he declared “Archduke”.

 

Regardless, Myson wasn’t happy. Yes, that was the right way to explain it; for all the emotions roiling within him, not one of them was positive. And why would they be? The stack of reports strewn across the floor had nothing but bad news within them.

 

Failure after failure stained the ink on those pages, all pointing to one truth that he found increasingly difficult to ignore–

 

“MYSON!”

 

The doors slammed open and the thunder sage raised his gaze towards the fat, bald beast that decided to invade his domain. “Ludwig. I was just thinking about you–”

 

“Don’t give me that!” the archduke snapped, “I can’t afford to be afraid of you right now, not when I had to hear from some random soldier on patrol that we lost Fort Merceus!”

 

Myson grimaced. “Which soldier was that?”

 

“Don’t change the subject! That idiot wasn’t the only person I spoke with! I know we’ve completely lost Merceus, just the same as I know Dolofonos is dead and Mozghuz is still standing! What in the world happened out there!? I thought you were supposed to have a dozen secret projects in place to stop Edelgard from making any progress!”

 

“I do have more projects, Ludwig. I simply need time to implement them.” It rankled to have to explain himself to a beast. The wretch in front of him was far more palatable when it was cowering.

 

Yet Aegir didn’t seem to understand that fact. “We don’t have time! Holding Merceus was the only thing that kept Edelgard from pushing her way into our territories! How long do we have before she takes Varley or Boramas!?”

 

“We have forces in her way, Ludwig–”

 

“And she just joined together with the Church’s army! I thought they were supposed to be eradicated?! You told me–”

 

“They were eradicated,” Myson retorted, his irritation growing, “The fact is, the church’s forces were scattered after the battle at Garreg Mach. We destroyed the largest force. That there are still some feeble remnants clinging to life is not–”

 

“Feeble remnants?! Myson, they have a damned dragon sent by the goddess! Or did you not receive that report?!”

 

Myson did receive that report. He received a great many reports, but it was Shax’s report of what, precisely, happened at Mozghuz that contributed to his current mix of negative emotions. A simple attempt to cow the damned imperials and that rebellious brat they called an emperor had turned into a complete loss. An entire battalion of oratores and bellatores had been wiped out, and his moronic weapon of mass destruction had gotten herself killed.

 

He pointed Bias towards a softer target specifically so she wouldn’t let her damn grudge override her sense, and yet, somehow, she went right into battle against the Fell Star anyway! And then she had the temerity to lose!

 

It had been a poor decision in hindsight, a thought to simply cull the beasts and remind them of their places, yet now he was down two sages, lost a major fortress, and the abominations were apparently allying with the imperials. He didn’t want a repeat of the Second Great War, damn it!

 

“Myson! MYSON!” And then there was the beast chattering at him!

 

“What is it, Ludwig?” Myson asked, affecting an appearance of calm even as he buried down his urge to rip the beast’s tongue from its mouth.

 

“What are we going to do?! We can’t sit here and wait for Edelgard to make her next move! Not when we’re already on the backfoot!”

 

“I am aware of that. However, plans will need to be adjusted. We are on the defensive now, so if we act too hastily–” A knock at the door made Myson grit his teeth. “Enter.”

 

A masked Agarthan dressed in the standard robes of his station entered and bowed. “Lord Myson, I bring ill-tidings from the northern front. Our attempt to destroy the Bridge of Myrddin has failed at the hands of the enemy called ‘Gloucester’. While some damage was done, the structure remains intact, and we have received a direct declaration of war from the Leicester Alliance as a result.”

 

“...we weren’t already at war with them?” Myson had to ask.

 

“Gloucester seems to believe it needs to be made official through paperwork, Lord Myson.”

 

“...” Myson made a mental note to hunt down the current lord of Gloucester once this debacle was over with. “I see. Change of plans, Ludwig. You’re going to Boramas.”

 

Aegir blinked. “What? Hold on, what are you–”

 

“You wanted this, didn’t you? Go to Boramas, defend your city. I’ll send Shax with you along with a sufficient number of regiments and demonic beasts to act as a supporting force for your task. If needed, I will fully support you in a longstanding siege against the empire.”

 

“...hm. Well, it’s good you see reason,” Aegir said, nodding to him, “I’ll get ready to go at once.” He paused for a moment, his face twisting as though what he was about to say pained him. “Thank you.”

 

“There’s no need.” Especially since Myson’s true reason for sending the bald beast to Boramas was so he’d delay whatever forces the Empire and the Church brought to bear. “Do be quick. As you said, time is of the essence.”

 

Aegir nodded and hurried away, proving yet again how obedient of a tool he was. If only the rest of his subordinates were as groveling…maybe it was something he could work on? Shax might have had a substandard performance lately, but his creation was devoted to the point of retrieving Bias’s corpse even while under threat from the Fell Star.

 

Perhaps there was something he could use there? He had been meaning to go back to Shambhala for some time now, so with a flick of his wrist, the sage warped away. He could have someone else deal with cleaning up the reports.

The void beyond death was redder than Bias thought it would be. She knew, once upon a time, that her people believed in a vast afterlife of plains and rivers, ruled over by a god that wept tears of iron for the lost.

 

Then the Agarthans discovered Zahras, and the truth of the nothingness that lay beyond became clear to them all.

 

So imagine her disappointment when instead of blissful cessation, she felt only a pulsing, painful heat. She wanted to move, to do something, but she felt stuck, trapped, as though restrained by straps and buckles. 

 

A surge of hate went through her body. If this was what death was, if she had to be trapped in her own aching body and aware of herself, then couldn’t she at least see her sister? Wasn’t that allowed?

 

For a brief moment, she was genuinely tempted to pray to the Fell Star for some release from this hell.

 

Then she opened her eyes.

 

She still felt that heat, that pain, the ache in her body, but it dulled to the familiar levels she normally felt. The biggest difference was the strangely heavy sensation at her head, but she ignored that in favor of assessing her situation.

 

“Oh, you’re awake. Good timing. Lord Myson is visiting for an inspection.”

 

Bias blinked, slowly, then turned her gaze towards the mage standing at her side. “…Odesse?”

 

“Indeed, Lady Bias,” the robed man agreed, bobbing his head in a nod that made him resemble the bird he was masked as.

 

“Aren’t you dead?” If so, she was going to be very annoyed with whoever was running this shitty afterlife.

 

“No, Lady Bias. I think I would know if I was. Or would I?” He tilted his head, considering the question, then shrugged. “Regardless, I believe you are referring to my predecessor, Odesse the First, as I have chosen to designate him. Lord Myson decided I should be the new Odesse after his demise at the hands of Epimenides.”

 

“Right. I knew that, I was there.” She let out a sigh, laying back on the surgery table she was strapped to. The lights overhead, gleaming blue lines in black steel, showed she was back in Shambhala. “So I’m alive?”

 

Odesse didn’t seem to mind the disappointment in her voice. “Indeed, you are. Your core was salvageable and I am familiar enough with your model at this point to make repairs to your redundant gray matter without requiring a full transfer to new flesh. I could still perform the transfer at your request, however.”

 

“Remove my restraints, then we can talk.”

 

“Of course, Lady Bias.” With a simple press of a button, the restraints slid open, allowing Bias to sit up and take stock of her damaged body.

 

Admittedly, there was less damage than she expected, considering the last thing she saw was Byleth Eisner’s relic sword swinging for her head. She didn’t even have much damage beneath the neck, aside from the scars that were already present from her past injuries.

 

“Hm…is there anything I should know?” she asked, glancing at her healer, “I had one of Myson’s enhancement stones explode on my forehead. I figure that should have done some damage.”

 

“Oh, an enormous amount, yes. I did have to replace a great deal of your skull plating, graft some skin, and add in stitches and bolting to keep everything together, but it was still much better than I would have expected. Under most circumstances, the physical impact of the explosion would have caused your brain to smash against the interior of your skull, presuming the skull itself did not shatter from the concussive force. Fortunately for you, you were built to be a superior being!” Odesse stated with plenty of Agarthan pride.

 

“...sure. Are you saying I lived because I’m built better?”

 

“I presume so! Your physical body is surprisingly hardy for a member of the oratores caste. While physique is important, of course, most of our caste is built to emphasize mental processing power over physical strength and durability.” He tilted his head, thinking. “I suppose if I had to make an alternative hypothesis, it is possible that your attunement to the enhancement stone granted you a measure of protection against its effects. Most mages are shielded from the effects of their own magic, otherwise every fireball would burn the skin from the hand of their casters.”

 

“Hm. And what if the enhancement stone changed me physically?”

 

“...I suppose that is an alternative hypothesis, Lady Bias,” Odesse replied, though he didn’t sound too happy with the idea. Either because he truly believed in Agarthan supremacy, or because he just didn't like being told he was wrong.

 

Either way, Bias had more important things to focus on. “What about shrapnel? The stone exploded, so the pieces of it had to go somewhere.”

 

“Oh, yes, there was shrapnel. I had to dig out most of it while performing your surgery.”

 

“‘Most’?” Bias grimaced. “Odesse, do I have rocks in my head?”

 

“It is unlikely, though not impossible, that I missed some small fragments. I meant more that there were shards in your clothing, Lady Bias. Luckily the explosion was localized to your forehead, so I mainly had to remove the fragments from the front half of your upper body. You should be entirely clean of them though.”

 

“...If you’re wrong about that, I’m going to smack you.”

 

“If I am incorrect, Lady Bias, then my life is forfeit for the sake of restoring–”

 

“No, it isn’t,” she interrupted, “I outlined what the punishment is if you’re wrong. I’m not going to kill you for saving my life. If you screwed up, I will smack you, once, in a location of my choosing. Probably your face, but it might be the shoulder if I’m not feeling particularly vindictive.” She paused, a frown coming to her face. “Hey, ah…were there any other survivors with me?”

 

“Of course, Lady Bias. Project Deva, who has chosen the designation ‘Shax’, is responsible for returning you to us. His own restoration was simple.” For some reason, Bias had the impression Odesse was smiling under his mask. “Your mending was invaluable in ensuring his continued survival, Lady Bias. It was very impressive.”

 

“...sure.” Bias decided to ignore whatever weird feelings his praise gave her, instead looking around the surgery suite. “So is he here, or…?”

 

“He is, yes.” Odesse turned and tapped at the walls, sending out a signal through the facility. “I have just alerted him to your awakening–”

 

Immediately, there was a flash of violet and Shax appeared. “LADY BIAS! YOU’RE OKAY!”

 

Bias winced at the noise, her head throbbing. “Tone it down, your voice is stabbing into my brain.”

 

“Huh? Oh, sorry! I’ll keep quiet, I promise!” the weird little mutant swore, still smiling brightly at her, before he paused for some reason. “Oh, huh. Lady Bias, you don’t have clothes on.”

 

“...yeah? And? I just had surgery, why would I have clothes on?” she asked, staring at his confused expression.

 

“Uhhh…I guess that’s a good question? Why would you…What? Wait, what does ‘take a chance’ mean?” Shax tilted his head, then shook off whatever strange thoughts he was having. “Ah, whatever. I’m glad to see you’re okay! I knew you’d be! You’re a sage, you’re too amazing to die to any beast!”

 

Bias refrained from pointing out how many of their sages had already died to the ‘beasts’. Still, she couldn’t let him live with any delusions. “You were the one that kept me alive, Shax.” Even if she wasn’t sure how to feel about that fact. “The only reason I’m here is because of you, not any inherent quality on my part.”

 

“Well that’s not necessarily–” Odesse began before silencing himself when Bias glared at him.

 

“...thank you for saying that,” Shax said, a genuine smile on his face. It was a nice sight.

 

“...alright, enough emotions for now. Odesse, give me a robe.”

 

“Of course, Lady Bias.”

 

Bias rolled her eyes at the deference, then winced slightly at the headache the motion gave her, but still got dressed in a simple robe once it was offered to her. Nothing fancy yet, but she could always get dressed properly soon enough. For now, she had questions.

 

“So, you’re running things here?” Bias asked, glancing at Odesse again as she tied the robe closed at her waist.

 

“Indeed, Lady Bias! I was assigned as the steward of Shambhala by Lord Myson while he focused his attention on the war effort!”

 

“Really? And how’s that going?”

 

“Quite well! The majority of the more acerbic members of our leadership are busy on the battlefield, so I have been able to get a great deal of work done on our projects without any questioning or sabotage from those who wish to vie for the power of my position.”

 

Bias briefly wondered if she counted as one of those ‘acerbic members’ sent to the battlefield before a frown came to her face. “What projects are those?”

 

“Oh, I thought you knew already. Well, given Lord Myson is focused on the production of ‘demonic beasts’ at his outpost and Lady Cleobulus has requisitioned a majority of our weapon production capabilities, I have focused my efforts primarily on Project Pittacus.”

 

“…oh. Uh…that’s…good,” Bias murmured. A part of her never quite believed that Myson was actually working on bringing her sister back. Hearing differently…it was definitely something. “Can I see your results?”

 

“Of course! Right this way!”

 

Bias followed behind Odesse as he led the way through the facility, her mind still racing with the potential implications of her sister’s potential resurrection. She noticed Shax following behind them, and almost cracked a smile at how dutiful the boy was being. Still trying to be my bodyguard, huh?

 

She brushed off the stray thought as they arrived at a room filled with incubation vats. The large, glass tubes seemed to be modified though, the fluid inside more of a greenish shade than the typical watery liquid that would normally fill the birthplaces of the modern Agarthans. Part of her mind turned towards considering the chemical composition and what effects this new liquid might have, but most of her thoughts were focused on the figures within the vats.

 

Each one contained a single Agarthan, and every one of those Agarthans was identical to Bias.

 

“Woah…so many Lady Biases…” Bias could hear Shax’s amazed curiosity from behind her, his fascination obvious, but her attention was fully on her replicas. 

 

“...What is this?” 

 

“Project Pittacus!” Odesse proudly declared, “More specifically, subjects thirty-seven to fifty-eight. Subjects one to thirty-six were deemed complete failures and disposed of.” 

 

Her hand twitched. “What do you mean ‘disposed’ of?” 

 

“Well simply put it's surprisingly difficult to recreate someone with limited materials that were in far from pristine conditions, especially since I myself did not know Lady Pittacus very well, so I've been going off of Lord Myson’s specifications,” Odesse readily explained, “Originally, we had the idea of attempting to accelerate her growth much like Project Deva, but the problem came from not being able to stabilize her aging. As such, subjects one to twelve all passed away from age-related complications and physical stress. Afterwards, we pivoted to attempting to create her as an adult from the start, but attempting to replicate her personality has been a challenge. 

 

“Thirteen to thirty-six were all deemed failures as well for one reason or another, be it from an unstable body or brain death, but we have been making progress! In fact, if you wish Lady Bias, you could take one of these and have them act as your sister! It would greatly help my research.” 

 

“...” Bias had thoughts. She had a lot of thoughts. She had to actively force down her instinctive outrage at the idea that Odesse had murdered copies of her sister, but the rest of her thoughts were surprisingly less negative and more fascinated. “To be clear, are these clones of me, or clones of Pittacus?”

 

“Both, essentially. We did utilize samples from you, Lady Bias, but most of these were made with the remains we secured from the site of Lord Thales’s death.” Odesse sighed in disappointment. “It’s a shame the buzzards got to his own remains before we could properly secure them. Still, we did retain some samples for potential use, though that is off topic so I digress.”

 

Bias made a small mental note of that, before refocusing. “Hm. I’m guessing her body wasn't intact enough to work with?”

 

“Unfortunately. Our predecessors in the Nemesis Project were quite fortunate to retrieve only slightly mutilated bodies, and even then they had several centuries to work on revitalizing them.” Odesse sighed. “It’s almost a shame Lord Myson and Lady Cleobulus decided the subjects would be better used as materials than their intended purpose as elite soldiers. We didn’t even get a chance to see them active.

 

He glanced at Shax, who was still looking curiously around the lab. “Though I suppose this result is still valid. How has Project Deva performed so far?”

 

“…well enough,” Bias muttered, her eyes still on the closest clone floating in its tube, “He brought me back, so I might be biased.”

 

“I see–Wait, was that wordplay?”

 

Bias ignored the question. She stepped closer, looking directly into a face that was identical to her own. It almost looked like she was just sleeping in there…

 

The hiss of the door opening wasn’t enough to distract her. Then Shax excitedly exclaimed “Papa Myson!” and she felt herself tense.

 

“Hello Shax–Huh. This is unexpected,” Myson remarked as Bias turned to face him, “I thought you were dead, Bias.”

 

“So did I,” she replied.

 

Myson smiled. “And you’re well enough to joke too. You must be feeling quite good.”

 

“I’ve felt better.” Such as before he showed up. “What do you want?”

 

“There’s no need to be rude, Bias. Can’t I come by to check on your recovery?”

 

“You just said you thought I was dead.”

 

“So I did. Anyway, this is certainly an interesting place to find you,” he remarked while glancing over the sealed clones, “How long have you had this little project running?

 

Bias raised an eyebrow. “Odesse is the one running it. He said it was on your orders. He was even using your ‘specifications’.”

 

Myson blinked at her. “…of course he was. After all, returning your twin to you is a major priority.” He cleared his throat and turned his gaze fully towards the closest clone. “So these are all viable recreations of Pittacus?”

 

“That’s what I was trying to find out,” Bias stated, growing increasingly unimpressed with her supposed leader, “Odesse was just saying how it’s been tricky recreating her personality.”

 

“Indeed!” Odesse chimed in, “While I am confident that we have successfully recreated the original body of Pittacus, right down to a programmed affinity for wind magic, there haven’t been any signs of true personality within the subjects we tested. Regrettably, it seems while they are sentient, they are not sapient.”

 

“What’s the difference?” Shax spoke up, sounding curious while Bias’s brow furrowed in thought.

 

“Sentience denotes an ability to perceive and feel. There is evidence that the subjects are capable of reacting to stimuli and even following basic orders. However, they show no signs of initiative or ability to respond rather than simply react. In essence, it is the difference between your leg jerking when tapped on the knee and you making the decision to kick someone.”

 

“You used the bare minimum of programming for their cores then,” Bias noted, earning a nod from Odesse.

 

“Of course. We don’t want a secondary mind to grow within the core before Pittacus can properly revive within the body. It is a difficult thing, finding the right balance.”

 

“It might help if Myson didn’t sabotage you,” Bias remarked, giving the sage in question an unimpressed look, “Pitt’s specialty was light magic, not wind magic.”

 

“It is? But…she was the sage of wind.”

 

“Right, and Thales was the sage of light despite focusing on darkness and that Quake spell of his. In a world that made sense and didn’t have stupid political implications, Pittacus would’ve been the sage of light and Thales the sage of earth. But that’s now how it wound up working.”

 

“Huh. Well, that actually does ruin this entire batch.” Odesse turned towards the suspended clones, plainly frowning. “What a waste…”

 

“Not necessarily,” Myson spoke up, looking thoughtful, “We could always repurpose them into troops for our–”

 

“No, we’re not doing that,” Bias interrupted, “Odesse, Myson is right on one thing, they can be reused. So use them as lab assistants. If they are anything like Pittacus or me, they’ll be much more useful in that type of setting.”

 

“Hm…well, I suppose they were made for you in the first place,” Odesse noted, looking thoughtful, “It’s only right you decide what they should be used for. And it would be useful to have assistants around…do you truly believe they would be better suited in this role? We do need combatants and you yourself are a very skilled mage.”

 

“I needed time to develop into what I am now. They should get time too.”

 

“Time we don’t have,” Myson pointed out, earning a glare from Bias.

 

“Time I’ll give them then. Like I said, Odesse, it’s what Solon did with me, and you can see how I turned out.”

 

“You killed Solon, remember?” Myson drawled. 

 

Bias paused, because no, she didn’t remember that. She knew her mentor was dead, sure, but there was a disconnect…She shook the thought off. It wasn’t relevant. “My point still stands.”

 

“True, you are very effective…and being compared to Lord Solon, well…” Odesse seemed to smile there, before nodding. “Very well then. I would prefer having assistants to soldiers anyway.”

 

“That doesn’t change our problem though,” Myson pointed out, “Thanks to your loss at Mozghuz and Dolofonos’s failure to kill that brat they call an emperor, the deadlock we were in has broken in the Adrestians’ favor. So what are we going to do to counter them?”

 

Bias glowered at her fellow sage, then paused when Shax suddenly spoke up. “Ah, Papa Myson, I actually do have an idea. Well, it’s Lady Bias’s idea, but I think it’s a good one!”

 

“Oh?” Myson raised an eyebrow, though his gaze was on Bias instead of Shax. “And what idea was that?”

 

“Well, it’s pretty simple,” Shax continued, oblivious to his creator’s ire, “What if I got more crests?”

 

That drew Myson’s attention. “…excuse you?”

 

“Yeah, you know, since I already have that crest of flames thing, what if we put more crests in me? We have the blood of the ten elites, right?”

 

Bias winced. “Uh, Shax, that’s not–“

 

“That’s an interesting idea, Shax,” Myson interrupted, a small smile coming to his face, “Do you think you could handle it? As we’ve seen with the beasts, adding more than one crest to a creature tends to have unpleasant effects.”

 

“Yeah, but I’m Agarthan! I’m better than that!” he said brightly and carelessly.

 

“I suppose you are…very well then. I’ll see if a project is viable, given the resources we have. Cleobulus has most of the materials we need if we really do want to use all of the elites, but…perhaps there are other ways to enhance you, Shax.”

 

The boy beamed. “Awesome! You hear that, Lady Bias? I’m going to be even better!”

 

“…that’s great, Shax,” Bias replied, though she couldn’t quite muster up a smile for him, “Could you give me a second though? I need to talk to Myson about our plans going forward.”

 

“Oh, uh, sure! You do that! I’ll just…talk with Odesse, I guess?”

 

“Oh, good, I was hoping I could have someone to bounce ideas off of,” Odesse stated, grabbing onto Shax’s shoulder and steering him away, “Now then, what do you think about possible biological enhancements for these subjects now that–“

 

“Come on,” Bias requested, inclining her head.

 

Myson smirked, then followed her out of the lab and into the well-lit hallway. “I’m surprised you wanted to discuss ‘our’ plans. It was my understanding that you were content to follow orders.”

 

“The circumstances changed. What are you planning to do with Shax?”

 

“Are you attached to the deva?” he asked, sounding amused, “Is this a platonic attachment? Perhaps a sort of…maternal instinct has awakened? Or is it–“

 

“Answer my question.”

 

Myson chuckled. “Why are you so aggravated? You’re the one that proposed the deva should be further enhanced. Truthfully, I should have considered the idea sooner. His current form might be useful, but imagine if he had the physique of his source.”

 

Bias grimaced. “You were the one that decided Nemesis would be more useful as materials than as a weapon.”

 

“I can admit mistakes. Though I wouldn’t say this was one. A being with the loyalty of a perfect Agarthan soldier, mixed with the magic of the Great Sage and the malice of the Fell Star, all embodied within a hulking behemoth of a warrior…” His grin was sharp. “Doesn’t that sound just perfect?”

 

“Would he even keep his mind?”

 

“Of course he will, that’s the point. It’s not as though the mind of Nemesis is active within him.” His smile turned thoughtful. “Though I do have a mission planned for him already…it should be fine. I’ll send him out with Aegir and in the meantime I can prepare for his metamorphosis.”

 

Bias’s frown deepened. “His body is already grown. You’d be altering his entire skeletal structure and muscular systems, not to mention how his organs would have to–“

 

“And?” Myson interrupted, an eyebrow raised. “He’s a fast-grown vatborn. How long do you think he’ll last without modification? It’s better we get enough use out of him now than wait for him to age into uselessness.”

 

“I thought he was stable –“

 

“Now, certainly. In the future…well, I don’t exactly need him to last longer than the length of this war.” He waved a hand dismissively. “It barely matters anyway. The blood of the Fell Star will either keep him stable or lead to his degradation. Better we use him while we have him.”

 

Bias narrowed her eyes. “He calls you ‘papa’.”

 

His eyebrow raised again. “You say that as though it should mean something.”

 

“…I’ll go along with him,” Bias decided, “You need him for this project, so I can–“

 

“No, I have a different plan in mind,” Myson interrupted, “Shax’s suggestion reminded me that we have allies to call upon. Ones who really should be willing to give it their all to defend our ancestral homeland.”

 

“What? Who are you…oh. You want me to speak with Cleobulus.”

 

“Good, your mind is still working well enough to make obvious inferences.”

 

“Fuck off. You want to beg her for help because we’re screwed otherwise.”

 

“Language. You don’t want to influence Shax to be as crass as you, now do you?”

 

Bias clenched her fist, the pop of her knuckles keeping her centered in the moment even as she buried her urge to press a hand to Myson’s smug face and start cooking . “Alright. I’ll run and get Cleo so you can hide beneath her skirts. But let’s make something very clear, Lord Myson.

 

She stepped closer, smoke beginning to leak from her clenched fist. “I’ll play along with whatever bullshit you want to put forward, because you’re right. I do care about Shax now. Just like I care about Pittacus. In fact, I’d put the two on a close enough level that I would be very, very unhappy if you hurt either of them. So let’s make things clear: The second you make a threat towards Pittacus, even if it’s just her copies, or toward Shax, I will burn you. I will burn you right down to the bone until I hear your marrow boil. Are we understood?”

 

Myson’s smile dropped. His eyes narrowed and he scowled, for once showing the aggravation he felt. “So those are your limits then? Fine. Then I’ll make something very clear to you , Bias. Your only value to me was as a weapon and a test subject, and the moment you failed, you should have been left in the dirt. The only reason you are alive is because that boy you are attached to is too stupid to realize you’re worthless. That, and the fool I left in charge here. The original Odess would have known to let you die on that operating table.

 

“But since you are here, let me be clear once more: Do as I say, or I’ll rip your heart from your chest with my bare hand.”

 

“...” It was funny. Normally, insults like that would have set her off. She would have burnt the scowl straight off of Myson’s face without a second thought. And yet, for some reason she couldn’t explain, Bias smirked. “Then we understand each other. Be good to our people while I’m gone, my lord .”

 

Bias gave a mock bow then turned and left, ignoring Myson’s glare as it bore into her back. She had better things to do than play along with his bullshit.

Chapter End Notes

Red: Oh hey, look who's back. Yeah, this is a chapter I feel like people might not like, which is probably why it's taken so long to upload it. But alas, plans were made, and it feels like we need to get this out here so the story can continue properly. So yeah, Bias lives.

Indi: For now, who knows how things will progress. Either way she's very fucked up.

Red: Feels fitting for spooky month to set up painful resurrection and body horror. Though we haven't gone full Frankenstein just yet.

Indi: Yet.

Victory at Varley

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

No battle could satiate the Death Knight. Not once during the years of war he had fought had the monster born of blood thirst felt a rush comparable to the battle against the Ashen Dragon and the Blade Breaker, the moment he had nearly perished in brutal combat. He still remembered the Blade Breaker’s spear piercing through his body, and he yearned to once again feel that pain.

 

The so-called “Tyrants” he faced on the fields of Varley were nothing more than mindless beasts made from rotted corpses. There was no joy to be had in killing an opponent who had died long ago, no matter how viciously the creatures battled.

 

Even so, he continued to battle in the bloodied fields outside Varley’s capital. It wasn't enough to quench his thirst, but it served its purpose. Blood soaked the ground, feeding the worms within. His scythe still gleamed, eager for more. He felt that hunger, that thirst, deep in his belly. A craving for split flesh and rent gore.

 

The Jeritza part of his mind briefly considered taking up poetry before the Death Knight rallied in a brutal swing that cleaved the head of a dead man from its shoulders. Immediately, his gaze turned to the rest of the ruined field, seeking out a new foe, though…had he truly massacred all of the foes set against him? It was a shame if so. He wanted to continue feeling blood splash against his armor…

 

Yet in the absence of prey, the Death Knight subsided and Jeritza took a slow breath through his helm. He would need to clean his equipment again. The Death Knight truly was a terrible entity; not only did he embody the hideous bloodlust the lurked within Jeritza’s heart, but he truly had no concept of how inconvenient it was to maintain equipment properly. 

 

Dried blood was such a pain to get off of metal! It clumped and flaked! It was like the Death Knight wanted their equipment to rust…

 

He shook the thought off before urging the Death Horse forward. He had more work ahead of him if the battle was not yet won, though he wouldn’t be surprised if the horns of victory had already blown and the Death Knight noticed not in the throes of slaughter.

 

Castle Varley stood in the distance, still flying the false flags of Aegir’s faction. The Death Knight stirred for a moment, his attention garnered by the idea of their master allowing him to put the traitor to death. Jeritza ignored that idea though; more than likely, the young Aegir would be prompted to do the deed to affirm his loyalty. It would be cruel, but the reality of politics often were.

 

The army had split again, their forces dividing between the mountains and the coast. He, along with Emperor Edelgard and the Ashen Dragon, who the Death Knight only avoided lunging for because his master had glared at him, had taken a portion of their forces to seize Varley alongside the Reclaimers, those knights of the church whose white armor looked disgustingly pure on what should be a field of blood and ruin. Their goal was to unite with the forces at Garreg Mach, such that the church could be properly utilized against their treacherous foes.

 

Meanwhile, the Violet Demon and the loyal Aegir would seize Boramas, and the lands of Hrym would be caught between the jaws of the Imperial Army, to be ripped apart at her imperial majesty’s leisure. It was a brutal plan, one befitting the emperor that would change the world–

 

“MAY THE GODDESS GRANT YOU A PEACEFUL REST!”

 

…now if only those plans didn’t involve allowing his older sister to fight on the battlefield.

 

Mercedes, meanwhile, was having a perfectly pleasant time on the battlefield as she delivered the goddess’s judgement unto the monsters Her foes chose to bring forth into the world. The sacred weapon within her grasp shone with a holy light as she launched arrow after arrow through the bodies of the undead creatures named for their tyranny, the Tathlum Bow practically singing as its string strummed like a harp’s. It was made to slay monsters, and the fulfillment of its purpose brought forth a joy that Mercedes could practically feel.

 

If one were to ask the elder of the Bartels siblings if she had a second personality within herself, a sort of “Death Knight” of her own, she would likely be confused by the question. Certainly, she could feel more…invigorated while within battle than she would have been, once upon a time, but that had been true ever since she received the goddess’s divine revelation, all those years ago at the academy. 

 

It wasn’t as though she had a voice speaking within her head, merely that she had a better sense of how the enactment of violence upon a vile enemy was as much a way of embracing the goddess’s will as healing her friends was. She still had a kind heart and cared deeply for the lives of those around her. That care was the very reason why it was so necessary that she put an arrow through the head of a Hrymian soldier; it ended the poor man’s suffering as he fought for a false cause, and that was just as much a kindness as giving him a cookie would have been.

 

Wasn’t it better to send him into the goddess’s embrace than to leave him to the cruel fate of being denied Her warmth? It was a kindness.

 

Besides, if Mercedes did happen to have a more zealous personality that pushed forth during moments of battle or preaching, then she wouldn’t be called a “Death Knight”, now would she? Sylvain joked once that she would be a “Life Knight” when he thought she didn’t hear him, but that title was absolutely not a correct description.

 

After all, she hadn’t been formally knighted.

 

Mercedes paused in her ruminations as she heard the sound of hoofbeats on the pavement. Her gaze flicked towards the potential danger, before her gaze softened the moment she saw her brother in his eerie armor. “Oh, Emile, there you are! I didn’t realize we were both on this side of the battlefield.”

 

“...I did not expect to cross paths with you either, Mercedes.” While his horse remained steady and stalwart, her brother shifted in his saddle, as though nervous. “You should not be on the battlefield. It is a dangerous place.”

 

“Of course I need to be here, Emile. I can’t just let my friends fight without me,” Mercedes replied, before she continued with a slight increase in fervor, “Besides, it is the will of the goddess that we bring a righteous judgement down upon those who would betray her followers and bring these foul perversions of life and death into the world.”

 

“You sound like the church knights when you speak like that, Mercedes…”

 

“Oh, I’m sorry, do you dislike it?” she asked with a genuine concern, “I hope I haven’t been making you uncomfortable. It’s just…we need to fight to save the people of our homeland. I know it’s been a long time since I lived in the empire, but it feels…right, being back here and fighting to save it.”

 

Jeritza wasn’t good with words. He didn’t know how, exactly, to explain that it wasn’t his sister’s words that were concerning him, but her actions. He didn’t like seeing her kill people, as hypocritical as that thought was, and he really didn’t like seeing her put herself in danger, even if she was surprisingly deadly with that bow.

 

“...You should focus on healing our wounded,” he said, defaulting to the first thing he could think of, “It would help more. Especially if you were back at camp.”

 

“Oh, don’t worry, I’ve made sure to heal everyone I see get injured,” Mercedes readily replied, “It’s actually better for me to be on the battlefield as a healer, since it means I can get to them more quickly. Daisy is very helpful for moving quickly across the field.” She patted her steed’s armored head for emphasis, earning a proud snort from the bulky war horse.

 

Jeritza would have said more, but both he and Mercedes went still as they heard war horns blow thrice in the distance. A signal from the Imperial Army, declaring enemy reinforcements were approaching.

 

In an instant, the Death Knight rose once more. “THE HORNS OF WAR CALL FOR ME. THIS TALK IS POINTLESS. STAY OUT OF MY WAY OR MEET MY BLADE.”

 

He began to turn before the barest giggle made him still. “Do not worry, I will not impede you. The Goddess’s work must be done, little brother.”

 

With that, his sister urged her own horse forward, riding ahead of him with arrows already nocked to her bow. The Death Knight huffed under his breath, then followed in the zealot’s wake, keen to spill the blood of those foolish enough to face his blade.

 

Hopefully his sister wouldn’t kill the interesting opponents before he could get to them…

Byleth had to admit, she never actually expected to come back to Castle Varley. She remembered coming through the main gates and walking the exact same path of well-cared for hedges with her father and sister. It was the first castle she had ever been inside, but the most she remembered from that day, all those years ago, was how Count Varley stood above them and literally looked his nose down at her family.

 

She didn’t really understand emotions back then, not in the same way she could express them now. If she had to sum up her experience, she would have called it…annoying. Though even then, it was less because Count Varley had cheated them on payment and made them walk all that way for nothing, and more that he’d been rude to her father.

 

It didn’t matter now though. Count Varley was long dead according to Edelgard, all thanks to a group of Agarthan assassins being given the wrong noble to target. In a way, it was a sort of justice that his life would come to an end at the uncaring hands of those he betrayed the empire to support.

 

Which made it very weird that a man calling himself Count Varley was kneeling right in front of them with his hands bound.

 

To be clear, the kneeling and bound hands weren’t the weird part. Byleth had broken into the castle’s inner sanctum alongside Edelgard and captured the apparent commander of the enemy forces, so it made perfect sense that said commander would be restrained for capture. 

 

It was just really weird that he looked exactly like Count Varley.

 

“Why?” Thankfully, Edelgard was just as confused as her former professor, and asked the question that was on both of their minds. “Why in the world would you choose to pose as Gregoire von Varley? You do realize he’s been dead for years now?”

 

“...” The imposter didn’t respond, instead keeping very calm and very still.

 

“We are going to interrogate you, Agarthan. The only reason I am choosing to begin with this question instead of anything more actionable is that I am genuinely bewildered. That, and your choice of visage made Bernadetta faint.”

 

That was also something Byleth was concerned about. Bernadetta had already been anxious from being back in her childhood home, so it was understandable that seeing her father’s ‘ghost’ would make her react badly. 

 

Dorothea was taking care of her at the moment, which left Byleth and Edelgard to handle the interrogation. Speaking of, Byleth should contribute.

 

“Tell us,” she bluntly demanded, which made the man flinch for some reason. Maybe it was the blood on her armor?

 

“...It was Lord Myson’s order that I impersonate the flesh I wear,” the Agarthan muttered.

 

Edelgard frowned. “What do you mean Myson ordered it? Why would he do that?”

 

The Agarthan closed his eyes and muttered a prayer to gods long dead. “He…felt annoyed that he…that his subordinates made a mistake in their choice of targets. As such, he declared that I should be Varley in his place, despite it already being well known that Count Varley had been assassinated, publicly at that.” 

 

Byleth could have sworn that the fake Varley almost sounded...annoyed there. 

 

“...He had you replace Varley because he was annoyed?” 

 

“Lord Myson tends to prefer keeping the same people around, even if only by name.” 

 

“What’s your real name?” Byleth asked, earning a blink from the Agarthan.

 

“...why do you want to know, Fell Star?”

 

“It doesn’t sound like you enjoy being Varley, and I want to know what your real name is,” she explained, before crouching to better look him in the eyes, “My name is Byleth.”

 

“...I am Anacharsis.”

 

She gave him a smile. “Thank you for telling me.”

 

“You’re…welcome?”

 

Beside her, Edelgard cleared her throat. “Now then, Anacharsis, are you willing to answer our questions?”

 

“No. I have failed to hold a key territory for my superiors. My life is already forfeit.” His eyes narrowed. “I have no intention of betraying my people. My one request is that my death be quick.”

 

Edelgard nodded. “That is about what I expected to hear. At least you didn’t try cursing us in some stupid act of defiance like the last three Agarthan commanders…Hapi, please see to it that Anacharsis is transported to the cells at Fort Merceus.”

 

“Sure thing, Eddy,” the redhead replied, standing up from the chair she’d been relaxing on, “Before I do though, can we get him to take the Varley face off? Otherwise he’ll scare Bernie-Bee again, and she gets really loud when she shrieks.”

 

Edelgard tried not to sigh as she glanced at the man, who in turn did sigh, before the familiar swirl of Agarthan magic surrounded him, revealing the man beneath. Edelgard had to admit, she could somewhat understand why this man was chosen in Varley’s place given his rather thin and gaunt appearance, though he lacked the same facial hair. 

 

“You truly intend to take me prisoner?” Anacharsis asked, raising an eyebrow. “I was under the impression capture meant execution.”

 

“Nope. Eddy’s official policy is that you pale guys get the same rights that other enemy leaders would get when captured,” Hapi casually explained, before gesturing at the Agarthan, “Up.”

 

Anacharsis frowned at her, then did his best to stand up with his hands still bound. “Why? We are not like you beasts. The Agarthan people–“

 

“Are a bunch of really pale people who think they’re better than everyone else,” Hapi finished, unimpressed, “As far as I’m concerned, the only difference between you guys and the knights of Faerghus is that you’re slightly whiter. Now stop complaining about getting to sit out the war and come on.”

 

Anacharsis grumbled some unflattering things under his breath, but still followed Hapi readily enough, leaving Edelgard and Byleth behind in the office.

 

The moment they were alone, Edelgard let out a sigh and leaned against what had been Count Varley’s desk. “One step closer to victory…now if only the rest of the Agarthan leadership would be as reasonable about surrendering.”

 

“Would you be okay with accepting their surrender if they did?” Byleth asked as she moved beside the young emperor and sat on the desk with her, “They’ve done terrible things to you.”

 

“They have. They've done a great deal of harm to a number of people, our friends included.” Her brow furrowed, a frown coming to her face. “We will be dealing with genuine monsters from this point onward. Not inexperienced youths forced into leadership or reluctant commanders made to wear false faces…though, we’ll have to investigate Anacharsis. If it turns out he’s been experimenting on the populace or allowing people to be stolen away by his superiors…

 

Edelgard let out a frustrated sigh. “It would be easier if I could see them as all monsters, but Hapi was correct. There are more differences than skin tone, but at their core, the worst Agarthan is the same type of person as the worst Adrestian. Cruel, self-centered, and obsessed with their claims of superiority. So how can I justify treating them differently?”

 

“Hm. I don't think I'm an expert in this, but I don't think anyone would blame you for treating them differently because of your experiences with them. Sure they might be the same type of person as the worst Adrestian, but they’ve done worse things, right? They had the opportunity to do better like Kronya and chose to do worse instead.” 

 

“To be fair, I doubt many had their guard lowered because of your sister,” Edelgard noted as she pushed off the desk, “Even so, if I'm to make a better future, I can't just execute prisoners of war. Which means I’ll need to figure out what to actually do with them after the fighting ends.” 

 

“I'm sure you'll make the right choice when it comes down to it. You don't like Rhea, but you're willing to work with her.” 

 

“I doubt Rhea would appreciate a family member of hers equating her with the Agarthans,” Edelgard dryly noted.

 

“It’s fine. I’m her favorite so she’ll let me get away with it,” Byleth stated quite primly, earning an amused noise from Edelgard. Though before the pair could continue their conversation, their attention was drawn towards the room’s door as it opened up to let in a familiar blonde.

 

“Lady Edelgard–Oh, excellent, you’re here too, professor,” Constance greeted, her expression more serious than usual, “I have important news that needs to be brought to your attention as soon as possible!”

 

“...” Edelgard glanced at Byleth, then looked back at her former classmate. “And that information would be…?”

 

“Our scouts have spotted the Kingdom’s forces approaching from the north!”

 

That made Edelgard immediately go stiff. “What? How did they get here so quickly!? Garreg Mach should have been in the way–I thought Dimitri and his allies were holding the monastery!?”

 

“Er, yes? I meant Dimitri’s forces.” Constance frowned, tapping her chin with her fan. “Hm. I can see where I caused some confusion there. It doesn’t help that both sides of the Kingdom conflict are using blue for their heraldry…”

 

“That probably makes things confusing on the battlefield,” Byleth noted as Edelgard sighed. 

 

“Constance, I ask that the next time you report something that you make sure to be specific.” 

 

“Well, I'll certainly be sure to keep that in mind, but would it truly matter in any other situation?” 

 

“What about if Aegir showed up trying to ambush us?” Byleth suggested, “In that case, saying ‘Imperial forces are arriving’ would slow down our response.” 

 

“Hm, I can see your point. Thank you professor! I suppose there are still things I have to learn from you!” Constance stated, before letting out a haughty laugh. 

 

Edelgard wanted to sigh again, but she had more important things to deal with right now than expressing her annoyance. “Fine. We’ll send a messenger to make sure these really are Dimitri’s forces and to set up a meeting on our terms. It would be inconvenient to say the least if we have to work around the Kingdom and the Church–…oh damn it all…”

 

“Edelgard?” Byleth frowned, concerned by the emperor’s sudden frustration. “What’s wrong?”

 

“Byleth, where are Rhea and Seteth?“

 

“They should be leading the church’s forces in battle towards the northern point of–Oh. I see the problem.”

 

Edelgard let herself groan, fully feeling the weight of her crown. “I swear, if either of those two try to re-establish ties with the Kingdom to form a coalition against me, I am going to…” She took a breath. “Think very carefully about what I will do because they are still your relatives, my teacher.”

 

“Oh, that’s fine, we can beat them up,” Byleth allowed, “I’ve punched Rhea in the jaw before. It might be fun to do it again.”

Rhea paused as a strange phantom pain began to make her jaw ache, before she took a sip of her tea to soothe it. Chamomile was a personal favorite of hers, so it was nice getting to have some while Seteth chattered with Dimitri and his entourage.

 

“–of course, we will need to reestablish our footing at Garreg Mach before we commit to your campaign,” Seteth stated, nodding to Dimitri and those friends of his. Rhea recognized Yuri, of course, and the large boy with the dark complexion was the one from Duscur. The rest of them though…well, it had been three years and she already had so many names to keep track of in her head, so she could be forgiven for a lapse.

 

“That isn’t an issue. Garreg Mach is the church’s domain, it is only natural that we return it to you,” Dimitri readily agreed, “We only hope that you're willing to allow us to use it as a base until we establish a forward camp in the kingdom.” 

 

Thankfully the blue-haired swordsman and the blonde knight had left the tent earlier, so Rhea didn't have to worry about their names. Especially since Seteth seemed far more eager to take a hold of this conversation. 

 

“Garreg Mach will always welcome those who mean it no harm,” Rhea stated, setting her cup down. 

 

“Thank you, Lady Rhea,” Dimitri said, smiling at her. 

 

“Now then, while the Church cannot commit yet to any specific course of action, we would like to discuss what will happen to the Kingdom once the usurper Rufus is dealt with,” Seteth stated, frowning deeply, “Not to mention how many nobles sided with him. Even those who bent the knee in an attempt to protect their land shouldn't be let off easy.” 

 

“I understand. I believe the most important thing to do is to restore and support the major houses so we can avoid creating too much instability–” Dimitri paused as the tent flap was pushed up by one of the guards outside.

 

“Your majesty, uh…” The knight went stiff, visibly uncomfortable once he realized he’d interrupted his king. Still, he rallied valiantly enough to actually get his words out. “The Adrestian emperor is here to see you.”

 

“Edelgard? Why does she want to speak with me?” the young king asked, visibly confused.

 

“Because you’re holding a meeting with my so-called ally within Imperial territory,” Edelgard bluntly stated as she brushed past the knight.

 

“Ah, wait, you can’t–” And said knight very quickly found his wrist caught before he could try to stop Edelgard from entering.

 

“No touching,” Byleth stated, before releasing the knight’s wrist and nudging him out of the way and back into irrelevance. “Hi Dimitri, hi Yuri, hi Dedue.”

 

“...hello Professor,” Dimitri greeted, his advisors echoing him with varying levels of amusement and bemusement, “Edelgard, is there an issue here?”

 

“That depends entirely on you and Rhea,” Edelgard bluntly stated, crossing her arms over her chest as the former archbishop in question blinked at the unexpected hostility, “What are you discussing?”

 

“All we are discussing is how we’ll take Faerghus back from the usurper sitting on its throne,” Dimitri explained with a placating gesture, “Seteth and I simply want to ensure things return to normal as quickly as possible.”

 

That made the young emperor’s eyes narrow. “‘Normal’. Should I take that to mean you intend to restore Faerghus and the Church of Seiros to their previous status?”

 

Dimitri frowned, a dark look crossing his gaze. “Not completely. The nobles that have chosen to follow my uncle will need to be dealt with. I fully intend on executing those involved in my uncle’s treason, and even the ones who have chosen to support him out of fear will need to pay reparations for their cowardice.”

 

“But that comes later,” Yuri spoke up with an easy smile, “Right now, we were talking about how to get the throne. We weren’t planning some kind of secret pact against the empire.”

 

Dimitri blinked, darkness replaced by bewilderment. “Wait, is that–Edelgard, I swear to you, I have no intention of striking at the Empire! Why would you even think that?”

 

“Certain individuals here have disagreed with my choices in the past. It made me wonder if they might be seeking a more…compliant partner,” she responded, her eyes turning towards Seteth in a full glare. Her gaze was so intense, it almost felt like she was glaring at Rhea too. But that was silly.

 

Obviously I haven’t done anything wrong here, so she can’t be mad at me, the ancient Nabatean idly thought as she sipped her tea again.

 

Edelgard’s frown deepened while Seteth let out a sigh. “Emperor Edelgard, I understand that you and I have had…disagreements on how this war should be conducted, but I am only thinking of the security of Fodlan as a whole. We need to restore the Church of Seiros as a rallying point for all those who would seek solace from the horrors the Agarthans would unleash upon us. Garreg Mach is already being used as a place for refugees, correct? Then it is the church’s responsibility to return to prominence so those people may be protected.”

 

“I disagree,” the emperor retorted, “I have no intention of supporting the Central Church in any return to prominence.”

 

“What?” Dimitri blinked. “Wait, El–No, I mean, Edelgard. What do you mean you don’t support the return of the church? You’re working with the church’s remnants, just as we are.”

 

“No, I am not. I was operating under the assumption that the ‘reclaimers’, as they call themselves, were our allies in the fight against Hrym, and yet here they are, attempting to undercut our entire alliance by forming a pact with you!”

 

“We had no intention of undercutting you, your imperial majesty,” Yuri interceded in a very polite tone, “There’s no reason we can’t all be friends here.”

 

“Exactly,” Dimitri agreed, “We’re all working towards the same goal, right?”

 

“I am not putting her back into power!” Edelgard retorted, which was strange given the only women in this discussion were her, Byleth, and…wait.

 

“One moment,” Rhea spoke up, frowning, “Who said I was being put back into power?”

 

Dimitri paused. “Hold on, Lady Rhea, weren’t we just discussing–”

 

“Pardon me, your majesty,” Seteth interrupted, before turning his gaze to the woman he swore his loyalty to all those centuries ago, “Lady Rhea, I understand you have some reservations about the current state of the church and your position in it, but you have to understand, you are an important part of the church’s structure. Having you return to your position as archbishop is key to stabilizing Fodlan–”

 

“But I don’t want to,” Rhea bluntly responded, still frowning.

 

“L-Lady Rhea?!” Dimitri looked like he had been hit by the full force of her blunt response and was reeling from the impact.

 

“For countless years I've been leading Fodlan, and made mistake after mistake in a paltry attempt to keep the peace and keep myself safe. The time spent trapped might have been agonizing, yet they were also the most liberating years of my life, no longer needing to worry about lords attempting to rebel or nations splintering off over petty disagreements.” 

 

Seteth winced, glancing at the Faerghans. “Ah, Lady Rhea, maybe you shouldn’t–”

 

But Rhea wasn’t having that. “No, I’m not about to keep my mouth shut about this anymore! Faerghus has been a pain in my ass for centuries by this point! I didn’t want the Empire to split up! I don’t like war! But that blond prick of a count thought he should be king and threw a damn fit that ruined everything I built up! And I’m not going back to being archbishop just so the land of rebels can feel better about being traitors to every oath they swore!”

 

“That’s not–Lady Rhea–”

 

“Would you stop calling me ‘Lady’ already!? I am no longer the archbishop, I do not want to be the archbishop–In fact, the archbishop position is now officially dissolved! If you demand I wield my authority then fine , here I am, wielding it properly! No one may ever hold the title ‘archbishop’ again without being a direct heretic of the church’s teachings! As far as I am concerned, the only authorities left in the churches are the bishops of the Eastern and Southern churches, and they can figure out what that authority means on their own. ”

 

She sat back down with an irritated huff, ignoring the stunned stares directed her way. Even Edelgard looked caught off guard by the sudden tirade, sharing a glance with Byleth.

 

“Did you know about this?” she asked, raising an eyebrow at her former professor.

 

“Yup. I guess you two haven’t had a chance to talk about it yet.”

 

“Hm…I suppose I should have taken the time to.”

 

“You did have a lot of other stuff to handle,” Byleth commiserated, before glancing over at Dimitri and Yuri, who seemed to be very busy discussing things in hushed voices. Something about ‘legitimacy’ and ‘losing claims’.

 

It didn’t seem immediately relevant to Byleth, so she turned her attention to the remaining Lion in the tent. “How have things been with you, Dedue? I didn’t see you when Shez and I visited the monastery.”

 

“Ah, yes, I was out aiding the villagers under our protection at the time,” Dedue replied, trying to ignore the immense awkwardness in the air as he kept a hand on Dimitri’s shoulder in an attempt to steady him, “My apologies for not greeting you sooner. To tell the truth, I was unaware that you had even returned, professor.”

 

“Really? Dimitri didn’t tell you?”

 

“I believe his majesty was distracted with other matters at the time.”

 

“Nobody else mentioned it?”

 

“I thought the king here would, so I didn’t,” Yuri commented casually, turning his attention away from his flustered king, “Sorry about that, big guy.”

 

“It’s no trouble. And, if I may, Lady Rhea?” The former archbishop glanced up at the ridiculously tall man, a frown still on her face. “I know it may not be my place to say so, but…the Kingdom has its faults, yet good people still live within it. You shouldn’t abandon them because you are weary of our position.”

 

“Did I say I was abandoning anyone?” Rhea retorted, allowing more of her annoyance to show, “I dislike war, but I will still fight against the Agarthan scourge plaguing these lands.”

 

“Then…what will become of the kingdom?” Dimitri asked, focusing back on the former archbishop.

 

“...” Rhea stared at Dimitri for a moment, before letting out a sigh, “Now is not the time to discuss such matters, but I'll say this to you, Edelgard: attempting to take back all the land of the Kingdom will only lead to more war from the Faerghan nobles attempting to maintain their independence. Whether or not the Empire is willing to keep the war going isn't up to me.” 

 

“I seem to recall you were the one who declared Faerghus is no longer a legitimate nation,” Edelgard pointed out.

 

“I did do that, yes, and you may take it as justification to conquer their lands as Wilhelm once did against the forces of Nemesis.” Rhea folded her hands in her lap, focusing all her attention on the young woman. “There is a reason why Seiros spared the children of the elites, however. Violence breeds violence, and choosing to continue that war would have risked destroying every gain we secured. It was better to make heroes out of monsters than to bleed the entire continent until nothing remained. Mercy can destroy an enemy by making them an ally.”

 

Dimitri winced, not happy to hear his ancestor be called a monster, but Edelgard still frowned. “Being ruthless is a type of mercy too. It spares you and those who follow after from the harm your ‘allies’ cause when they become enemies again.”

 

“Perhaps. If Seiros had gone on to wipe out the bloodline of the elites, then Fodlan as we know it would look very different. I doubt there would be an intact empire though. One cannot slaughter a people without consequences, and there will always be those who remain after, missed by the purge and harboring hate in their hearts. A hate I could not deny as being righteous, for there is no pain greater than to be the last of your family.” She noticed Dedue’s face tightening at her words, the same as Edelgard and Dimitri.

 

Rhea took a slow breath, closing her eyes. How many families have died because of this land I built? She opened them again when she felt a hand on her shoulder.

 

“Should we talk about this later?” Byleth asked, keeping that steady hand on her.

 

Rhea smiled. “No, I’ll be fine.” Then she turned her gaze back to Edelgard, whose expression was inscrutable. “I prefer peace. I know you have grand designs for how Fodlan should change, going forward. I will not interfere in whatever you choose to do. I think you are kinder than you give yourself credit for though. Seiros still slew the elites themselves. No prisoners were taken there.”

 

“Er, really?” Dimitri spoke up, drawing attention back his way.

 

“Well yes, obviously,” Rhea stated, frowning again, “I wasn’t about to let any of those butchers live peacefully after slaughtering my entire–“

 

“Maybe we shouldn’t be discussing the deaths of Dimitri’s ancestors in front of him,” Byleth interrupted, giving both Rhea and Edelgard a reproachful look, “I think talking about the hypothetical destruction of his entire bloodline is also rude.”

 

Edelgard winced. “Ah, right…my apologies, Dimitri, I was…getting carried away.”

 

Dimitri seemed like he had a few things to say on that subject, but then Yuri whispered in his ear and he let out a breath before laughing awkwardly. “There’s no need to apologize. I understand these were all hypothetical and you don’t actually believe my entire family history is evil and we deserve to have been wiped out, ha ha…”

 

“That’s not–Dimitri, I’m sorry, I didn’t intend to imply that.”

 

“To be fair, the Blaiddyds always have been troublemakers,” Rhea commented, frowning at the memories, “I swear, the whole family was obsessed with dark magic for centuries before Loog made the effort to repair their reputation, and even then he was probably the largest thorn in my backside because of his rebellion.” A thought occurred and she had to school her features to hide her mischievous smile. “In fact, did you know Loog only had one hand?”

 

Dimitri blinked. “Wait, really? But he was one of the greatest knights of his age, how could he fight with a missing hand?”

 

“There are workarounds to such a disability, but it doesn’t really matter since Loog only lost that hand after he became king. The lech smacked my rear when I visited his newly founded kingdom and I cut the offending hand off right then and there.” She tried not to laugh at the young king’s horrified expression. “It did leave quite a mess on the dining table–“

 

“Rhea!” Seteth interrupted, cutting in on her fun as always, “Don’t lie to people about their own ancestors! Especially such an important historical figure!”

 

She debated trying to keep the joke up, before choosing to pout instead. “It could have happened. You weren’t there.”

 

“I know it didn’t because you have the exact same expression whenever you think you’re being funny! It’s been ages and yet you get that exact same ridiculous look as when you pushed Macuil off a cliff and insisted the wind tried to steal him!”

 

“He shouldn’t have stolen my cookies,” Rhea stated primly, before cracking a smile at Edelgard’s disapproving frown, “Now now, don’t get upset on your friend’s behalf now. Else I might have to start telling entirely true stories about Seiros and Wilhelm.”

 

To her credit, the emperor didn’t flinch. “You’re bluffing.”

 

Rhea smirked. “He was utterly fascinated by my ears, you know? Always nibbling at them whenever we–“

 

“Let’s stop talking about this,” Byleth requested, and Rhea smirked at the show of weakness.

 

“I don’t know why you’re embarrassed, granddaughter, these are the types of things you should be hearing, especially if you plan to have children. Wilhelm and I were unfortunately incompatible, but things should work fine with you and Edelgard.”

 

“…they should?” Her confusion was adorable.

 

“Of course. After all, male Nabateans carry the eggs, so you should be able to–“

 

“WE DO NOT!” Seteth snapped, and Rhea couldn’t stop herself from laughing at his completely red face, “S-STOP LAUGHING! Rhea, you can’t just–Don’t just lie –“

 

“Wait…” Dimitri’s brow was furrowed. “Does that imply–“

 

“It doesn’t imply anything because Rhea is lying!” Seteth insisted, before scowling at his cackling comrade, “Were you always this immature?!”

 

“…” Edelgard watched the woman she once thought would be her greatest obstacle continue to laugh over her own stupid joke, then let out a sigh and turned to her old friend. “My apologies for acting so hastily and harshly, Dimitri. I made some rash assumptions.”

 

“…Edelgard…El,” Dimitri began, his brow furrowed, “I don’t want to, but I have to ask. Do you intend to conquer Faerghus?”

 

“I intend to change Fodlan. The old system of crest-based inheritance and nobility have failed the people of this land for too long. This war presents an opportunity for us to change the systems that govern us for the better.” She met his gaze evenly. “I don’t want to fight you. I do still regard you as a friend. However, I will do what I must to achieve my goals.

 

She glanced at Rhea again, who was starting to contain her horrible sense of humor. “…I am open to negotiations. Perhaps we can discover a solution we both find palatable.”

 

“How about we have those discussions later?” Yuri proposed while Dimitri thought things over, “It’ll let tensions cool and you and his majesty here can both fill in your respective retainers in on what’s going on.”

 

“I can accept that,” Edelgard readily acquiesced, “Dimitri?”

 

“…yes, I think that would be best,” he agreed, “And, ah, despite the circumstances, it is good to see you again, El.”

 

“It’s good to see you as well, Dee,” she replied with a small smile.

 

“…” Rhea, meanwhile, was frowning again. “Edelgard, I can accept your dalliance with that Dorothea girl given Byleth’s affection for her, but I will be very cross with you if you cheat on her with this one.”

 

“Excuse me?” Edelgard asked, raising an eyebrow at Rhea. 

 

“I-I would do no such thing! Edelgard is like a sister to me!” Dimitri said, looking far more flustered over the idea. 

 

“I understand we were friends when we were young Dimitri, but saying that you see me as a sister is a bit much, no?” Glancing over at Dimitri, Edelgard raised an eyebrow.

 

“I don't think that's what you should be focusing on!” Dimitri insisted, getting her to chuckle. 

 

“What can I say? Seeing you like this reminds me of how fun it was to tease you when we were young. I remember how embarrassed you got when I thought you were a girl on our first meeting.” 

 

“Geh–I-I need to go now, there’s, ah…Felix. Doing things. Bye.”

 

Edelgard had to smother her giggles as Dimitri hurried straight out of the tent, his ears turning pink. Dedue sighed, trying his best not to smile as well as he followed after his liege, while Yuri actually stuck around. 

 

“So, any chance I can get some elaboration on that ‘Nabatean males lay eggs’ thing?” he asked, earning an immediate glare from Seteth while Rhea burst out laughing again.

 

She should go to these types of meetings more often. They were surprisingly fun.

Chapter End Notes

Red: Happy Halloween everybody! In the spirit of the season, we bring you all bloodshed, disguises, and silly tricks!

Indi: Hope you're all having a nice day! Managed to finish this chapter quickly so we figured we might as well treat you all!

Red: And for an extra treat, if you're looking for something quite spooky, we put up another story over here: (https://archiveofourown.org/works/60220291/chapters/153670084). Fair warning though, this is legit spooks, some proper gory horror over here.

Indi: Fair warning that it will get worse in terms of horror.

Red: Yup! So we'll keep the silly bits over here and hope you all have fun with whichever you choose to read.

Indi: Regardless we hope you enjoy the chapters!

A Prelude to Bigger Things

Chapter by RK3996

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Castle Varley had settled into a type of peace now that the red flags of House Hresvelg flew above its walls. The dust had settled, the enemy defeated, and a certain group of Blue Lions now relaxed within the walls instead of waiting in a tent outside, set up in a proper lounge for them to meet in. Though “relaxed” probably wasn’t the right word to describe them.

 

“Hold on, Loog wasn’t even a duke?” Felix asked, “He was a count?”

 

“Is that really the most important thing to focus on here?” Ingrid complained, frowning at her friend, who had the audacity to roll his eyes at her.

 

“I think it’s relevant to ask if my ancestor Kyphon helped somebody rise above him. Making someone he outranked his new king seems like a stupid move.”

 

“That’s not–Do we even know for sure if House Fraldarius even was a ducal house at the time? Maybe he rose in status too!”

 

“I know because my family history has it recorded that we were dukes from the earliest days of the Empire and every official record agrees with that.” He frowned as a thought occurred. “Hold on, did you Blaiddyds steal our ancestral land?”

 

“No, of course not,” Dimitri replied, though his voice was more weary than argumentative, “Our lands were our own…but we did take a significant amount from House Lamine, who tried to stay loyal to the Empire and was routed and exiled for it.” He sighed. “Lady Rhea was willing to clarify, this time without any jokes…well, hopefully.”

 

“There was a House Lamine?” Ingrid asked, before wincing, “Um…should we mention that to Mercedes?”

 

“...I am debating that question with myself. It would probably be worse if she found out on her own, but…you’ve noticed she is spending a good deal of time around her brother lately.”

 

Ingrid frowned. “Why is that a problem? It makes sense she would want to spend time with her long lost brother.”

 

“Her brother’s the Death Knight,” Felix snarked, earning another glare.

 

“I know that! It’s just…Mercedes is a sweet girl, we shouldn’t assume bad things about her just because of who her brother is. And just because she’s been…enthusiastic about killing our enemies. And that is a point to remember, she hasn’t attacked anyone that wasn’t trying to kill us first.”

 

“She'd also probably get angry at us if she thinks we were intentionally keeping this a secret from her,” Sylvain pointed out. “And if she doesn’t, Annette would on her behalf.”

 

“Why do you sound more scared of Annette?” Ingrid wondered.

 

“Because between the two of them, I know Mercedes would be gentle if she killed me.”

 

“Annette is very effective with a war hammer,” Felix added.

 

Ingrid raised an eyebrow. “Why do you sound proud of that?”

 

“Perhaps we should get back to the topic at hand,” Dedue spoke up, standing by Dimitri’s side as always, “Do you believe Edelgard would attempt to conquer Faerghus after defeating her enemies in the Empire?”

 

“I think it would be a smart move if she went for it,” Sylvain answered, his expression turning more serious, “She has the most justification she’s ever going to get. Rufus attacked first, he’s a usurper, and Rhea’s last big act as archbishop was declaring Faerghus as a whole a rebelling territory. If she wants to make Faerghus part of Adrestia again, now’s the right time to do it.”

 

“It might not matter if she wants to conquer us,” Felix pointed out, “Adrestians have been clamoring to take Faerghus ‘back’ from the moment Loog declared independence. Now that they have a chance to, they’ll pressure her to attack even if she doesn’t want to.”

 

“Imperial nobles aren’t known for their loyalty,” Ingrid grumbled, frowning, “If any of them do invade Faerghus, they’d probably keep whatever land they seize just because they can.”

 

“…I thought Yuri was supposed to be the cynical one,” Dimitri muttered, “None of you think Edelgard and the Empire would be content with returning our territories to us as friends and allies?”

 

“Edelgard might, but we can't forget that the Ministers launched a coup against her dad, and one of them is actively rebelling right now. It’s safe to assume they won’t stay loyal if they think they’d get a better deal,” Sylvain said, before grinning, “If I could, I'd work my charms on her, but I think Dorothea might stab me before I get the chance.” 

 

“She is better with a sword than you might expect,” Felix commented, earning a sigh from Ingrid.

 

“Do you two always have to be so single-minded? We need to make some real plans for what we’re doing here!”

 

“Well unless you’re willing to try seducing the emperor, I’m out of ideas,” Sylvain replied, “We don’t exactly have much to offer them. The Empire had more weapons, more food, and more manpower than the Kingdom did when things were normal. Right now, we’re a struggling army who already annoyed the Empire by trying to poach their allies. So what do we have that they could ever want?”

 

“...we have relics,” Felix noted with a serious expression.

 

“What!?” Ingrid practically yelped, “Felix, you can’t be serious!”

 

“It’s the only thing we have that they could want.”

 

“You’re not wrong,” Sylvain remarked, frowning, “It’s not a great idea though. We’d be giving up our only advantage if things do turn bad between us.”

 

“You asked what we have that they could want. I answered. We don’t have many options when it comes to keeping things peaceful between us and the Empire. So unless Yuri manages to strike a deal with whatever he’s doing right now or anybody else thinks of something, trading the relics is our best bet for guaranteeing we have allies.”

 

Nobody looked happy with that thought. Least of all Dimitri, who openly sighed. “I suppose it’s too much to hope that my past friendship with Edelgard will move her heart?”

 

“About that, how much time did you two spend with each other?” Sylvain asked.

 

“Ah, well…we didn’t meet up every day, exactly, but I believe I first met her…ten, maybe eleven years ago?”

 

Sylvain nodded. “Right, we’re doomed.”

 

“Wha–Why would we be ‘doomed’??”

 

“We’re betting on a friendship you had with a girl from over a decade ago. We’re doomed.”

 

“C-Come now, it's not like she forgot about it! She still kept the knife I gifted her!” 

 

“Wait, she's the one you gave a dagger to?!” Sylvain stared at his friend for a good few seconds, then nodded solemnly. “Alright, new plan. Dimitri, you have to seduce–”

 

“We’ll give them Gautier territory.”

 

“Ah–...I mean, my dad’s not going to like that.”

 

“We’ll deal with that when we come to it,” Dimitri decided, before leaning back in his seat with a sigh, “To think, our best chance of taking back our Kingdom might require giving parts of it away…”

 

He wondered if Edelgard had to deal with these types of problems.

Edelgard had to admit, after almost having an aneurysm over the possibility of Rhea and Dimitri making a behind the scenes deal she felt strangely relaxed. Granted that was probably thanks to Dorothea giving a shoulder massage. 

 

“Wow, you feel tense,” Dorothea remarked, working her fingers as best she could into the emperor’s stiff shoulders, “Did things really go that badly with the Lions showing up?”

 

“No, actually. Things went better than I expected,” Edelgard replied, letting out a slow breath while she felt the tension leaving her body, “Seteth overstepped, but Rhea really isn’t interested in taking power again, as unbelievable as that sounds. As for Dimitri…well, it’s nice to see he’s doing well.”

 

“Oh? Didn’t you say you were worried about facing him again?”

 

“Yes, well…I was prepared to have to fight him if he proved to be a danger to my goals. I didn’t want to, but I was prepared to. Now though, I feel…optimistic. Dimitri has shown himself to be open to negotiation and while I do still intend to change the system of governance across Fodlan, such that crests no longer hold sway over the lives of our people, it would be better if he remained in charge of Faerghus as an allied leader.” 

 

“Well you won't hear any complaints from me if that's the case.” 

 

“No, but I'm sure I'll hear plenty from nobles on both sides as we try to discuss a peace treaty…If nothing else I'll have to ask for Arianrhod to appease the Ministers.” She frowned. “I’ll have to see who can actually govern the city under that circumstance. Giving it to Bergliez gives him more territory than I’m comfortable with.”

 

“Poldie does seem like the type to get a swelled head if he gets to have two castles,” Dorothea concurred, “And Waldie already has his own city too…hm. A part of me thinks it’s gauche to even be talking about bartering a city filled with people for political reasons, but another part of me can’t help but think Connie would love to have it…”

 

“Do we really want to put Constance in charge of a major city?”

 

“We could always ask Monnie to keep an eye on her. Or just put Monica in charge in general.”

 

Edelgard sighed. “Maybe…the problem is, I don’t want to just hand over leadership to a friend just because I like them. That defeats the whole point of ridding ourselves of the nobility in the first place.” Her brow furrowed.”Maybe I could require a test for the position of Arianrhod’s governor?
