I was already planning to require exams for the ministerial positions, so it could be a good way to find an appropriate leader…”

 

“If you’re looking for a commanding officer for our next adventure, I can assure you I would be a more than worthy candidate!” Constance declared as she entered the room, fan in hand and a haughty smile at her lips.

 

“No, we weren’t talking about that,” Edelgard plainly stated, slightly deflating her noble friend.

 

“Oh. Well, regardless, I heard discussions of leadership, and as the heiress of House Nuvelle, I would like to present myself for your consideration!”

 

“Is that the only reason you’re here, Constance?”

 

“Not at all! I also bring news once more of approaching envoys! From the Alliance this time!”

 

“Really? Why would they be getting involved?” Dorothea asked.

 

“I can think of a few reasons,” Edelgard grumbled as she pushed herself up, “We’ll have to spend some more time together later, Dorothea. Duty calls.”

 

“As it always does.” Dorothea sighed, then kissed her love on the cheek. “Try not to take on even more responsibilities this time, okay Edie?”

 

“I’ll try not to. I already feel like a glutton with how much is being piled on my plate…Constance, walk with me. Where is everyone else?”

 

“Hapi and Bernadetta are with Yuri at the moment,” Constance readily reports, falling in step behind the emperor as she heads out, “He’s apparently in a reminiscing mood, talking on about our past friendships and how we should try to reunite the Wolves once more, never mind the fact that Bernadetta never was one.”

 

“He might consider her an honorary one, given what I’ve heard of their past.” A past he seemed to be using to try to bind Bernadetta closer to his side, Edelgard mentally noted, Even if Dimitri does turn out to be a reliable ally, I’ll have to keep an eye out for Yuri. “What about Jeritza?”

 

“He’s with Mercedes and Professor Byleth, sweeping the rest of the castle for potential problems. Things do seem to be progressing fine on that front, though I swear Emile is avoiding me.”

 

“I noticed he tends to wander off when you’re around. If I didn’t know better, I would say Jeritza gets nervous around women.”

 

“That does sound exactly like him,” Constance remarked, “Emile never seemed comfortable around anyone besides his sister in the first place…but still! He’s known me for years! He should know better than to cower in the presence of the illustrious Constance von Nuvelle!”

 

Edelgard did her best not to roll her eyes. It was probably for the better that Ferdinand was leading the second army; he and Constance tended to encourage one another’s antics whenever they were in the same room, and if she remembered Lorenz’s attitude correctly, then she really didn’t want all three of them in the same room at the same time…

If one were to ask a common person in Fodlan what the greatest city in Adrestia was, they would tell the asker, without hesitation, that it was Enbarr, the Imperial capital. And if that person asked the follow-up question “what is the second greatest city in the Empire”, the common person would most likely answer “the Empire has more than one city?”

 

Commoners are rarely educated beyond the basics.

 

But if one were to ask a slightly more worldly commoner, like a merchant or some such, they would more than likely answer “Fort Merceus”, which is one of many reasons why House Aegir has historically had something of a rivalry with House Bergliez.

 

Suffice to say, Boramas wasn’t exactly the most famous city in the Empire compared to its contemporaries, but it was a very important one. A key port city alongside its far less famous sister city, Rusalka, which was mostly known for being on the common map of Fodlan and not much else, Boramas was a center of commerce and industry for the Empire’s eastern coast, which made its capture paramount to the Imperial loyalists.

 

Ferdinand von Aegir, recently appointed general of the Empire’s secondary army, took a slow breath as he took in the walls of his home city from the encampment his troops had set up out of range of the city’s defenses. It had been some time since he returned to his birthplace, and seeing it now, with the orange banners of Hrym flying in the wind above it all, put a pit in his stomach deeper than any other.

 

“You doing okay, kid?”

 

He started for a moment, then let out another breath as he glanced at the much older man standing at his side in the lookout tower. He put on his best smile, willing his nerves to settle. “Of course, General Jeralt! I, Ferdinand von Aegir, am doing perfectly fine! I am merely mentally preparing myself for the battle ahead!”

 

Jeralt regarded him with an unimpressed stare. “Ferdinand, I have two kids. I can tell when I’m being lied to.”

 

“That–It is not a lie! I am indeed preparing myself–”

 

“It’s fine if that’s what you’re doing. Hell, it’s a good thing. Sieges are rough work, and it’s good to get your head on straight before you make any big moves,” Jeralt stated, “I don’t think that’s what you’re doing though. There’s a difference between getting ready and getting lost in your own thoughts.”

 

“...” Ferdinand turned his gaze back to the walls. “...It is very likely I will kill my father today, General Jeralt.”

 

“Yeah. It’s a real possibility,” Jeralt muttered, before letting out a sigh, “I don't recall ever doing business with him. What kind of man is he?” 

 

“I think if you were to ask anyone else, they would give a far from flattering idea of who he is, and sadly they wouldn't be wrong,” Ferdinand said, his hands tightening into fists, “But if there's any part of the man that I once admired still within him, then I can say for certain that if we meet on the battlefield, he won't surrender.”

 

“Hm. I guess there’s something to respect there. Even a corrupt man can stand by his convictions.”

 

“I’m not sure I can even give him that respect. My father…he is cruel, he is a coward, and he has, more than once, run away from justice to protect his own life. To say he is standing by his convictions is affording him more honor than he deserves.” He heard something pop in his knuckles. “He could have stayed in the dungeons. He could have turned on the monsters he supported at any time! But he didn’t, and now…”

 

“You don’t have to be the one to kill him.”

 

“I should. It should be me that puts an end to the misery he’s caused.” Ferdinand tried for a smile. “Doing so should finally assure Hubert of my complete loyalty to her majesty. Perhaps he’ll be less crabby then.”

 

“You’ve been fighting a war with him for three years, Ferdinand. I doubt Vestra thinks you’re about to turn traitor out of nowhere.”

 

“General Jeralt, not to be rude, but Hubert thinks that about everyone. I wouldn't doubt if he has a contingency plan for everyone and anyone in case any of us turn traitor,” Ferdinand said before letting out a huff, “I can see it now. We've recently started getting along over tea and coffee so he could just as easily poison any tea leaves he prepares for me and I'd be none the wiser.” 

 

“...Didn't take you for a pessimist.” 

 

“Take it as you will, but I know Hubert.” Ferdinand shook his head with a grin. “Just as well as I know that as long as I never turn traitor, I'll have nothing to fear from him, and I have no intention of doing so.” 

 

Jeralt stared at the much younger man for a few more seconds, then let out a deep sigh. “Is it just your generation that’s this dramatic? I swear, people weren’t so…intense back in my day.”

 

“General Jeralt, I mean no offense, but from what I’ve heard from Shez, your day was back when people still used bronze weapons.”

 

“I’m not that old,” the old general complained, giving Ferdinand an annoyed look. One made worse by the simple fact that he couldn’t tell if the brat was joking.

 

“Well, to answer your question, General Jeralt, you have met General Bergliez. So I don’t think it’s just my generation that has a flair for the dramatic.”

 

Jeralt couldn't help but grumble, not wanting to argue over how Bergliez was far closer to Ferdinand’s generations than his. “Fine, then it’s an Adrestian thing to be overly flowery and dramatic.”

 

“I feel I should take some offense, but the Empire is typically held as a center of the arts in Fodlan and Enbarr is quite famous for its opera companies…come to think of it, where are you originally from, General Jeralt? I don’t think you’ve ever said.”

 

Jeralt glanced at Ferdinand, then did his best to keep his face neutral as a thought came to mind. It was probably stupid, but…well, even Rhea was being honest these days. “Hm…well, we’re about to go into battle together, so I guess I can tell you, Ferdinand. Just try not to let this slip, alright? It’s something I haven’t even told my kids.”

 

Ferdinand furrowed his brow. “You haven’t? Then…is it alright for you to share this secret with me?”

 

“It’s fine, kid. I know you won’t tell anyone. See, Shez might’ve joked about my age to you before, but I am a hell of a lot older than you’d think. In fact, back when I was born, there were actually four nations in Fodlan, not three.”

 

Ferdinand blinked. “What?”

 

“Yeah, it’s not something the church would tell you, but back in the day, Faerghus split into three. One of those thirds, the eastern part, would eventually seize independence again and become Leicester, but the western third was conquered again by Faerghus. For a time though, it was it’s own country, the nation of Mach, and ever since it was reabsorbed, the people there have resented Faerghus for stealing their freedom from them. Why do you think the Western Lords over there hate the royal family so much? It was Faerghus that stole their nation from them, so they’ve hated the royals ever since.”

 

“W-What, General Jeralt, you understand what you're saying is too much to believe. How do you even know this?” 

 

“Because I was part of the army who took back Mach for the Kingdom,” Jeralt explained, before shaking his head, “Granted, back then I was just a squire, so I didn't help out much, but I still fought.”

 

“That…I knew about the Crescent Moon war against the Alliance, but I wasn't aware that a second war had occurred as well.” 

 

“Civil wars tend not to get as much attention, especially when the winners can just claim it was a failed rebellion. Trust me kid, I’ve been around long enough to know how much the Kingdom has had to stamp down on to keep its appearance of the Holy Nation,” Jeralt explained, letting out a sigh as he did, “I was never the patriotic type, but I did what I thought was right. Regardless of how I might feel about it, Faerghus was my homeland, so to see how much it's changed…it makes me wonder how things might have turned out if it went just slightly differently.” 

 

“...I must admit, General Jeralt, I didn't know you were burdened with something like this.” Ferdinand said, frowning for a moment as he seemed to go deep into thought. “...May I ask why you told me this?” 

 

“To get it off my chest? Or maybe I'm just trying to show you the respect you deserve for what you're going through.” He shrugged. “I was where you were at one point, fighting people I used to know and care about. It’s not the last time it happened either, but there’s not much you can do about those feelings besides just keep going. A wound will eventually heal into a scar, and even if it aches every so often, those scars will fade in time too. As long as you’re alive, you can keep going.

 

“...Goddess, I really am getting old,” Jeralt grumbled after a moment, scratching at his head, “I’m usually a few drinks in before I get this preachy or morbid. Alright Ferdinand, we should check in on–...oh no.”

 

Jeralt had seen that look in Ferdinand’s eyes before. That same starry, awestruck gaze Alois and Leonie would give him. “...damn it, I did it again…ah, hey, kid–”

 

“Ah, yes General Jeralt? Oh, my apologies, you were saying something about–Oh, checking in on the troops, of course, I should have realized sooner! Yes, let’s check in on everyone and make sure we’re all ready for battle!” And then he was off, heading down the ladder before Jeralt could say anything else.

 

“...I should stop giving speeches.”

Chapter End Notes

Red: First chapter of the new year! And wow was this one a pain for me. This chapter is mostly set up for later stuff, and it felt necessary to have it, but I just don't have a lot of enthusiasm for it. Alas.

Indi: Sometimes you just have to get the set up out of the way.

Red: True, true. Welp, I'll just have to throw in some genuine absurdity in the next one to get the mojo flowing again. Which we'll hopefully get finished up and posted sometime this month instead of having delays.

Indi: Hopefully, if nothing else I can confirm there's definitely some absurdity next chapter.

Red: It will also involve at least one of our actual main characters (Shez and Byleth). Sorry Edelgard, Dimitri, you are technically secondary characters in this story even if you have political talks going on.

Indi: Tis important to remember Byleth and Shez are our protags, even if Byleth was stuck in the void for three years.

The Battle of Boramas

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Ludwig von Aegir was not a good man. To be specific, he wasn’t the type of man who would content himself with being called “good”.

 

To a man like Ludwig, being “good” was the same as being mediocre. It was the same as being known as “nice”; a middling description that said nothing about the person in question beyond their ability to adhere to basic courtesies. So no, Ludwig von Aegir was not a good man.

 

Good men were not great men. And Ludwig von Aegir wanted to be a great man.

 

He wanted to be the type of man stories were told of. He wanted to be the type of man people praised as a leader, a visionary, a hero ; when he had been younger, he dreamed of glory like other young men dreamed of wealth or women. He craved recognition and lusted for power with the deep-seated hunger that made men into emperors.

 

And yet, reality disappointed him. For though he desired glory, his youth was bereft of it. 

 

The position of Prime Minister was guaranteed to him by birthright. His talents only ever matched what was expected of him. There were no great wars to win glory in, and those conflicts that did occur were handled by others.

 

Bergliez fought the Empire’s wars. Hevring wrote the Empire’s laws. Gerth pacified the Empire’s neighbors. Even Varley, the wretch, commanded the Empire’s faith.

 

Ludwig von Aegir looked at the world he grew up in and found himself faced with an uncomfortable truth: He was not an exceptional man.

 

And he found, in that truth, a deep, vicious hatred.

 

Wounded pride had a way of festering, and Ludwig von Aegir came to the simplest conclusion that a man in his position could come to: If the world would not give him what he wanted, he would take it.

 

It was a reasonable choice. It was Ionius’s fault, really. Centralizing power under the emperor was a stupid provocation, and all for what? One wife among many that had been chased away by her betters?

 

Hrym had been a necessary sacrifice, just like the Imperial children.

 

Ludwig von Aegir knew he would never be the Emperor. That destiny wasn’t meant for him. But his son…his boy, his pride and joy, Ferdinand von Aegir…he would.

 

Edelgard had been perfect. The same age, born with a crest of Seiros, and already favored by the Emperor…Ludwig knew there were other factors at play, but he always believed that it was his choice that made Edelgard into the perfect emperor that she would become.

 

He could content himself with being the power behind the throne. Edelgard would conquer all of Fodlan with Ferdinand at her side and he, Ludwig von Aegir, would be known as the man that made it all happen. The savior of Adrestia.

 

So what went wrong? 

 

The first thought that came to mind was the death of that idiot Arundel or Thales or whatever his name had actually been. A chance rockslide that killed the man who had supported Ludwig’s ambitions had seemed like a boon in disguise at first. The Agarthans had pulled back, startled by their master’s demise, and Ludwig did the natural thing of taking advantage of that weakness.

 

It was smart to do. It left him in full control of Enbarr without any interference from those bird-masked buffoons that scurried in the shadows and he had enjoyed that freedom quite readily.

 

But then Edelgard turned on him, and Ludwig still didn’t understand why. Didn’t she comprehend the sacrifices he made for her sake? He would have made her a perfect emperor, ruling a united Fodlan with the church reduced to an impotent wreckage incapable of wielding any influence against her. And yet, even with the church destroyed, that dream was so far out of reach, he could nearly weep.

 

To think the Kingdom would have the audacity to attack first. To think they would even prove to be a threat! Yet that foolish girl focused her efforts on rooting out her greatest supporter instead of slaughtering the northern traitors that would dare to threaten the greatest empire that the world had ever known!

 

Ludwig would have gone to her side in an instant if Edelgard could simply put aside her foolish pride and understand that she needed him! That the Empire needed his guidance, his wisdom, his ambition!

 

But no. And now the crimson banners of Adrestia were streaming through his open gates.

 

“It was sabotage, my lord!” declared one of his commanders, his voice frantic beneath the savant’s helm he wore. “Infiltrators managed to get into the western gatehouses and open nearly all of them!”

 

“My lord, the northern walls have been breached!” another officer called out, “Weaknesses in the structures were taken advantage of and we’re taking heavy losses across that entire flank!”

 

“What about the seas?” Ludwig asked, his voice strangely calm.

 

“Blockaded, my lord! Ships bearing the Adrestian flag have cut us off completely!” answered his admiral, panic obvious on her face.

 

“Lady Fenja has gone to reinforce the troops on the western front, my lord, but we may need to consider our options–”

 

“Oh? What options are those?”

 

The officers in the war room stiffened, before turning their gazes to the young man sitting atop a nearby table, his legs crossed beneath him. His tone had been curious, but these officers of Hrym, veteran commanders with plenty of experience with their supposed “allies”, were rightfully wary of saying anything that might provoke the Agarthan in their midst.

 

Ludwig, meanwhile, just glowered at the annoying brat. “Presumably, my commander is suggesting we surrender, retreat, or reinforce our barricades to prepare for a final stand.”

 

“Oh, huh.” Shax tilted his head. “Well you’re not doing the first one. Papa Myson made it pretty clear to me that I’m supposed to kill anybody on our side that tries to surrender since he doesn’t trust any of you to keep quiet about all the plans Hrym has going on.”

 

Ludwig could practically see the morale in the war room drop at those words. “Hmph. I suppose it is good to know where I stand with that dastard…though your father has nothing to fear from my soldiers. Execution is all that awaits us if we surrender at this point. Even if Edelgard wasn’t being unreasonable, we’ve reached the point of no return now.

 

He let a humorless smile spread across his face just as he spread his arms outward. “I am the Empire’s greatest traitor, next to that wretched barbarian Loog. Leaving me alive in the event of her victory is unconscionable.” His lips turned downward. “In fact, the very idea is offensive to the dignity of Adrestia.”

 

“Huh.” Shax stared at him, assessing the older man. “That’s…an interesting way to think of things. Hm…well, anyways, I guess you could run away if you really, really wanted, but I have orders to bring you directly to Papa Myson if that happens–”

 

“That won’t be necessary.” If surrendering into Edelgard’s custody offended Ludwig, the very concept of leaving himself to Myson’s “mercy” horrified him. “No, today is the last stand of Ludwig von Aegir. Today…I will have victory or I will have death.”

 

His commanders shared a look, before one in heavy armor nodded his head to his liege. “We will follow at your command, my lord.”

 

Their loyalty nearly made him smile. This was how it should be. Prompt obedience, loyalty unto death…if only the rest of this forsaken world could understand the concept. “Prepare for battle. We’ll sortie from the castle and strike with everything we have.”

 

“At once, my lord!”

 

As his remaining commanders readied themselves for what could easily be their final battle, Ludwig found his eyes returning to Shax, who seemed, at most, mildly curious at the activity in the war room. “Boy.”

 

“Hm?” His eyes flicked toward Ludwig, shifting from green to red and then back again. “What’s up?”

 

“You’re younger than my son, aren’t you?”

 

“You have a son?” Shax paused. “Did I know that? I think I knew that…oh, right, the one with the lance. Wow, he has a lot more hair than you do.”

 

A light glinted off of Ludwig’s bald dome as he glowered. “You should learn to respect your betters–”

 

Then he flinched when Shax’s expression went completely cold. “I do. You’re not better than me.”

 

“...bah, I don’t know why I ever bothered!” Ludwig snarled, “You’re just like that arrogant father of yours!”

 

“I am?” Shax suddenly smiled. “Heh, that’s nice of you to say! No one’s ever compared us before!”

 

“...” So it seemed an easy way to earn the eerie boy’s approval was to compare him to his dastard of a father. Well, Ludwig supposed that made sense. Any son would enjoy being compared favorably to his father. Ferdinand had, once. “...hm. You want to make him proud, don’t you?”

 

“Oh, uh…yeah. I do.” Shax nodded, seeming confused by the shift in topic.

 

“Good. That’s natural. A young man should strive to make his family proud. As long as you work towards that goal, you’ll live a life you can be satisfied with.”

 

“...huh. Isn’t your son fighting against us?”

 

“He is. That son of mine…he’s too softhearted for his own good. He should have known better than to follow that girl’s orders. He was meant to be an emperor himself, but now…” Ludwig sighed, then shook his head. “It doesn’t matter. At least I know House Aegir will still be secure in the future with him as its head.”

 

Shax stared at him with a small frown. “It sounds like you’re expecting him to win.”

 

“Bah, I’m no fatalist. I am a realist! Your father doesn’t intend for me to survive this battle, boy, and I know this day will likely be my last. I’m not happy with the idea and I certainly do not intend to go quietly on my way to the goddess!” He clenched his fists, then released the tension in his body with a sigh. “But if today is going to be my end…then I would like to make one request, Shax.”

 

“...what is it?”

 

“Do not harm Ferdinand. If I lose this battle, allow him to be the one to end my life.”

 

“...why would you want that?”

 

Ludwig scoffed. “Isn’t it natural for a father to choose his own death over his child’s? If Myson is half the man he should be, he would agree with me.” He turned away then, grabbing his axe and shield from where they were waiting. “Now then, that’s enough life lessons. I thank you for allowing me to impart some wisdom before I meet my fate.”

 

“You’re welcome, I guess,” Shax replied, still frowning faintly. 

 

It was strange. The things Ludwig said made sense to the young man, his mind going over each word as he followed the corpulent noble out of the war room and towards the sounds of battle. But at the same time, they didn’t quite sound right.

 

After all, Myson would never throw his life away for Shax. He was too valuable for something so pointless. But…the idea of an adult sacrificing themselves for someone younger still made sense. That was what Lady Bias had done.

 

So…what kind of man did that make Myson?

 

It was a curious thought that percolated in the young Agarthan’s head as he followed Archduke Aegir out to war. Sure, there was more shouting orders and armoring up and something about trying to use commoners as human shields, which frankly sounded impractical since you couldn’t really tie a person to a shield and use it effectively since they’d be too heavy, but the main objective at the moment was hanging back and watching Ludwig raise his axe in front of a crowd of armored knights.

“FOR THE TRUE EMPIRE!” Ludwig declared, proud and bald, the sunlight gleaming off of his fancy axe, before he took one step and his chest erupted in a spray of blood.

 

“...huh.” Shax blinked, staring at the duke’s bleeding body as it walked a few more steps before toppling over, his feet apparently failing to realize the rest of the body was mortally wounded. “...wait, shit–”

 

“LORD LUDWI–Gerk–!” one of the generals started to shout right before a pointed tail went straight through his throat. Two more tails stabbed outwards, extending from a very pretty orange-haired lady that had just killed three heavily armored knights in less than a second and was currently stabbing a very sharp dagger into the kidneys of a fourth.

 

Then Shax noticed the likely reason why the guy he was supposed to protect just started bleeding everywhere, the purplish flash of shadow giving him a quick heads up to bring his sword up to block a blade going for his eyes.

 

“Hey prick, heard you tried to kill my sister again,” Shez greeted, glaring into her clone’s eyes as her twin blades locked against Shax’s greatsword, “You mind staying still so I can cut your balls off?”

 

“Uh…no, I don’t think I’m going to do that,” Shax replied, before pausing when he noticed the tailed lady shiver.

 

“Gods, you have never sounded sexier than you do right now,” the redhead said, grinning at Shez as she pushed a knight’s helmet up and shoved her tails through his chin.

 

“Not right now, Kronya! Flirt after!” Shez ordered, before she vanished in a flash of violet. 

 

Shax promptly ducked, eyes scanning for where the attack would come from, then warped away before a sword could skewer his head from above. “Gh–How do you do that?!”

 

“What, you can’t warp above people?” Shez asked, smirking, “Then why the hell would I help you out by explaining how it works?”

 

“I can figure it out myself then!” Shax snapped, his thoughts racing. Ludwig was dead already, beasts couldn’t survive losing all their blood, but what did that mean for Shax? Should he flee the fight or try to kill some of the enemy in return?

 

Weakling, the old man’s voice rumbled in his head, louder and clearer than it normally was, Too frail to fight, too feeble to kill…run away, coward. Lest you die and waste my blood in your veins.

 

“Shut it!” he snapped, smacking his fist against his head to shut up the ancient failure. He glared at Shez, who had paused in confusion at his sudden outburst. “You…You and your damn sister, you just keep ruining everything!”

 

“Yeah, and? You assholes started this,” Shez countered, “Your boss started this war in the first place, his boss killed Edelgard’s family and tortured her, and don’t think I forgot about you killing Victor! So don’t give me any of that whiny crap about us making things suck for you!”

 

“Gh–But you just killed Ludwig! That makes things even!” he whined, “It’s fine if I killed your bald guy because you just killed mine!”

 

“That’s not how anything works! And, wait, what do you mean I killed Ludwig?” Shez asked, her anger faltering, “Like…Ludwig von Aegir? Ferdinand’s dad?”

 

“Yes! You cut his chest open!” Shax pointed out, literally pointing with his sword to the bloodied body of Hrym’s so-called “Archduke”.

 

“...ohhh nooo, oh shit. Ohhhhh, shit.” Shez winced, looking from the bleeding baldy back to Shax. “That’s him? Really? I thought that was just a commander–A-And besides, he doesn’t look anything like Ferdinand!”

 

“He said his kid’s name was Ferdinand, that means logically he’s your Ferdinand’s dad,” Shax retorted.

 

“Aw shit, that’s…maybe if I blame it on Shax…?” Shez muttered to herself, making her clone stiffen.

 

“What!? No! Don’t you dare blame your screw-up on me! I was keeping watch on Ludwig, you were the one that killed him!”

 

“What’s the problem?” Kronya spoke up, pulling her tail free of another impaled knight while she casually cut the throat of a mage struggling in her grasp, “We were trying to kill that guy in the first place, right?”

 

Shez winced. “Well, yeah, but…you know! He was Ferdinand’s dad! I’m pretty sure he had this whole thing about having to fight him and I just ruined that!”

 

“...so, wait, it’s a bad thing that you killed Ferdinand’s father for him? Did he want to kill his dad?”

 

“Ah–Maybe? I mean…I think it was kind of a noble honor thing?” Shez shrugged, still looking sheepish, “Do you think he’ll be mad?”

 

“Does it matter? Just lie and say he was killed by that one,” Kronya suggested, pointing at Shax, who let out an offended gasp.

 

“Seriously?! Both of you are the worst! You–you liars! Traitors! Beast-lovers!”

 

“…” Shez just stared at her clone with a blank expression, then nodded to herself. “Alright, yeah, let’s just beat up Shax and blame the death of Ferd’s dad on him. Good plan, Kronya.”

 

“Thank you, beloved~!” Kronya crooned as Shax grimaced, readying his blade.

 

His eyes quickly scanned the field, his thoughts racing as he tried to figure out a way out of this. It wasn’t like the Hrymians could help, most of them were dead already, and Ludwig was too busy bleeding on the ground to help, a trail of blood following the archduke as he crawled– Wait, hang on, what?

 

Shax stared at the still-alive noble, then promptly flashed over to him and hoisted him up, fully ignoring Shez’s surprised yell as he warped away with Ludwig.

 

“Gh–B-Be more c-careful, boy,” the archduke grunted, his face pale as the two stumbled onto the wall surrounding the palace. “Y-You had better not kill me with a poor landing!”

 

“Why does everyone keep saying I’m the one that’s gonna kill you?” Shax asked, genuinely getting frustrated, “My whole job is to protect you!”

 

“Hmph…y-you're doing a poor job of it then…”

 

Shax winced, the old man’s voice echoing failure in his head. “I know that! But, look, I can get you to Papa Myson, I–“

 

“No!” Ludwig grabbed his arm, clutching tight to him, “N-Not him! Not that…that butcher!” His eyes were wide, frantic, before they steeled into something more solid. “Not him…don’t take me to him. Take me to my boy. To Ferdinand.”

 

“…you still want him to kill you?” Shax asked, his brow furrowed.

 

“I want…I-I want to see him…i-if you can give me anything, give me that.” The bleeding hadn’t stopped. It was strange that a man like Ludwig could still be alive after such a grievous wound.

 

Shax stared at him, then looked out over the city. Wyverns and pegasi clashed in the sky above while fire and thunder roared down below. Less buildings were on fire then he would have expected, but that made a weird sort of sense. The Imperials would want the city intact after purging it of all traitors.

 

Still, the chaos of battle made it difficult to tell where anyone important was hanging out. Shax narrowed his eyes, looking for anyone that seemed significant among the rabble, before he spotted a hint of orange in the distance and grinned.

 

“There we go. C’mon Ludwig, let’s go get you killed by your son!”

 

“Th-That’s not–“ Ludwig tried to protest, though Shax ignored him completely in favor of grabbing the bald archduke and warping into the thick of the fighting.

Jeralt Eisner had seen a lot of war. It was only natural when someone lived as long as him. People had a tendency to pick fights, and the powerful would either gain the loyalty of those willing to fight for them, or they’d just hire somebody to fight in their stead.

 

So yeah, Jeralt knew a lot about war; in particular, he was well aware of the fact that besieging a city was always a pain in the ass. The gates had to be broken or opened, the walls had to be scaled, and once a soldier was inside, he had to fight through unfamiliar streets teeming with people that wanted him dead.

 

If Jeralt had his way, he wouldn’t even come close to cities. Living in the countryside was feeling more appealing day by day.

 

The worst part was, somehow he got put in charge of the most rambunctious brats on the field.

 

“COME ON, IS THAT ALL YOU'VE GOT?!” Caspar shouted, blood drenching those fancy sacred gauntlets of his as he smashed his way through the enemy forces. 

 

Apparently there was a story behind why Caspar had the sacred weapon of his house now, one involving having to beat his one-legged dad in a fight that still left craters in the landscape outside Fort Merceus. Jeralt didn’t feel like asking.

 

Instead, he stayed back and kept a close eye on the reckless kid as broken bodies went flying in his wake. Though, calling the kid reckless wasn’t quite right. He was brash and liked to charge in, sure, but Caspar at least knew how to keep his friends close. Having the crown princess of Brigid as his partner in bloodshed seemed to cover for the kid’s weaknesses; whenever someone tried to strike from Caspar blindspots, there Petra was, cutting through throats and stabbing into the gaps of armor before moving straight along to the next target. And where she couldn’t be, the pair of mages added to their shared battalions picked up the slack.

 

For a kid with a fear of blood, Linhardt was handling himself pretty well out here, healing and warping people as needed in between throwing out his own bits of wind and fire. He clearly preferred playing support, but Jeralt’s kid had trained him, and that meant the lazy brat did know how to handle himself.

 

As for Lysithea, Jeralt was convinced he could have thrown her out into the city on her own and she would have taken it in a couple hours. Sure, the city wouldn’t be intact after that, but he was still sure she could do that damage. 

 

So yeah, Jeralt’s side of the battlefield was being handled decently enough. He would have said it was a clean sweep, if it weren’t for the sudden flash of purple light that deposited a heavily bleeding bald man at his horse’s hooves.

 

“There, I got–Wait, no–“ The kid staring up at him, mouth open in obvious shock, looked like Shez. Too much like Shez. He could have been her twin for how similar they looked. “Shit. Shit!”

 

He even had that same look she’d get when she thought she screwed something up.

 

“No no no, where is he?!” the kid demanded, looking around the bloodied street as the battle moved away from them, Casper’s battalion leading the charge despite the fact they were infantry and not cavalry. “He should be here! Where is Ferdinand?!”

 

“Wrong side of the city, kid,” Jeralt stated as he hopped down from Argo, the old warhorse entirely unfazed by the bleeding body at his feet, “Last report I got, he was fighting that Fenja woman in some dramatic duel to the death.”

 

“What?! But that’s–No, he’s supposed to be over here so he can fight his dad in a dramatic duel to the death!”

 

Jeralt raised an eyebrow, then looked down at the bleeding man. “This is Ludwig von Aegir?”

 

“Yeah, he is!”

 

“The enemy commander?”

 

“What? No, he’s not the enemy, he’s–” Shax paused. Then he took the time to actually look at Jeralt. “Uh…that depends. Which side are you on?”

 

“The Emperor’s. I’m Jeralt.”

 

“...oh. Ohhhhhh nooooo…” The kid winced. “Uh…can I have him back?”

 

“No.”

 

“But he’ll die!”

 

“Gotta be honest, I’m surprised you care, kid,” Jeralt said as he crouched down beside Hrym’s so-called Archduke. The arrogant prick actually had the balls to glare at him. Still, Jeralt could see the value in taking him alive, so he popped the cork on a potion and forced it into Aegir’s mouth.

 

“Wh–H-Hey! What are you doing!?”

 

“Healing him.”

 

“You look like you’re drowning him!”

 

“I can do both,” Jeralt stated, making sure the prick downed every last drop. The flow of blood stopped, his wounds sealing up as the concoction worked its magic. Ludwig’s breathing evened out, his face slowly regaining some color, so Jeralt grabbed his head and casually slammed it against the cobblestone, knocking the man out cold.

 

“Ah–That wasn’t healing!” Shax complained, prompting Jeralt to turn his unimpressed gaze towards him.

 

“Kid, you just handed me the enemy commander. Until I can secure him properly, it’s better for him to stay unconscious.” He stood back up, brushing off his pants. “So, is this your way of asking to defect?”

 

“What? No, of course not! I’m not a traitor! I just–He was dying and he asked me to bring him to his son, so I did that!”

 

“Then I guess it’s too much to hope that you’re willing to surrender.”

 

The kid’s eyes narrowed in a glare. His irises were red instead of Shez’s purple, so that was one difference. Though Shez’s eyes did tend to have that orange glow these days, so it might be something similar. “I’m not surrendering either. Now give back Ludwig, or…why am I even talking to you? I should kill you.”

 

“I’d prefer it if you didn’t. I might be older than I have any right to be, but I still want to live long enough to see my kids get married.” Jeralt shrugged, making no move to unstrap the lance from his back. “I don’t really want to fight you either. You look like my kid.”

 

“…what? That’s…that’s all it takes?”

 

Jeralt nodded. “The way I see it, you’ve got four options here, kid. You can try to go for me, and probably catch the attention of everyone on my side doing so. I’m sure you can handle yourself, but I’m also sure the white-haired girl over there can kill a grown man with a flick of her wrist, so you ought to think about the risk here.”

 

Shax frowned, then glanced over towards the battling battalions, only to flinch. “Gh…”

 

“Yeah, that’s a fair reaction.”

 

“I’m not reacting to her, I…the other one, with the purple, uh, wait, magenta? The reddish-purple hair and tan skin, she cut my throat.”

 

“Ah, Petra. Yeah, she does that. Which brings me to your other options. Surrender, defect, or retreat.”

 

Shax snapped his gaze towards Jeralt, scowling. “I told you, I’m not a traitor! Why do you keep saying I should defect?!”

 

“Honestly? You look like my kid.” Jeralt shrugged. “Practically, if you’re even half as good as Shez, you’d be good to have on our side. The kids might complain, and I doubt Vestra will be happy until he has something on you to keep you from turning coat again, but it would still be a decent win for us.”

 

“…you’re crazy. Shouldn’t you hate me too for killing that Victor guy?”

 

“Kid, Victor was a mercenary. He knew the score. He’d probably curse me if I didn’t take the opportunity to try recruiting you. But if you really don’t want that, I can accept your surrender. Edelgard is fine with taking prisoners. Even Agarthans.”

 

“That…That’s stupid. I’m not–No Agarthan would surrender,” Shax retorted, his voice wavering.

 

“Some have. They’re being treated fine. You could meet them, if you want.”

 

Shax stared at him, then shook his head. “N-No. No, I can’t–You’re lying. Agarthans–It is our duty, our–It’s impossible for us to…to…” He screwed his eyes shut, then punched the side of his head. “Shut up! Let me think!”

 

Jeralt frowned, but stayed quiet, watching the kid mutter to himself.

 

“...n-no. No. I can’t.” The kid looked up at him, those red eyes wavering. “I have to…I have to fight. For Lady Bias and Papa Myson.”

 

“Alright, if that’s your choice.” Jeralt still didn’t move to grab his weapon. “But it doesn’t have to be today, kid. Do us both a favor and go home.”

 

“…” The kid stared at him. He glanced to the side, taking note of how far ahead the Bergliez battalion was, then sized up Jeralt, obviously thinking about if he could take him in a fight. His eyes narrowed and Jeralt tensed at the bloodlust in the kid’s eyes…then Shax slumped, the fight going out of him. “What would be the point? I still can’t win…”

 

“…hey, kid–“ Jeralt began to reach out, but Shax vanished, warping away in a familiar flash of purple shadows. “…hm. Not feeling great about how that went.”

 

Argo whinnied, drawing his attention back to the old warhorse. Jeralt’s steed tapped his hoof on Aegir, earning a pained groan from the unconscious traitor.

 

“I’m sure Ferdinand would prefer it if we bring his dad back alive, Argo,” Jeralt pointed out, “So don't crush him.”

 

Argo chuffed, displeased, but settled down so Jeralt could hoist the unconscious archduke on his horse’s back.

 

“I really am getting too old for this,” Jeralt muttered as he secured Aegir in place, “If that kid had gone for me…I don’t think I could’ve fought back.”

 

Argo made another displeased noise, trying to move closer to Jeralt. Either to comfort him, or to complain about the extra weight on his back.

 

“…I have a feeling this is going to be my last war, Argo. One way or another.”

Chapter End Notes

Indi: Fun fact, in an earlier draft, Shez ended up killing Ludwig outright there at the start.

Red: Yup! Would've cut his head off completely. But then it turned out that things worked out just a bit better if he still lived.

Indi: And hey, it led to Shax meeting Jeralt for the first time.

Red: An important moment for any Shez-adjacent individual. Though alas, no adoptions this time.

Indi: Maybe next time. Or maybe not. We'll see. Also important thing to note that wasn't shown off in this chapter, everyone thinking Jeralt was cool for somehow capturing Ludwig while their backs were turned.

Red: Maybe that'll be in the next chapter? Still gotta clean up around here a bit, figure things out, and there's always more room for Jeralt being the coolest guy ever who absolutely is surviving this war.

Indi: Nothing bad ever happens to Jeralt, after all.

Afterword
